Title: The Mereology of Depression-Networks of Depressive Symptoms during the Course of Psychotherapy
Authors: Holler, I.; Schreiber, D.; Bos, F.; Forkmann, T.; Teismann, T.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: 1 background research ha shown that it is important to examine depressive symptom in the light of the mereology the ratio between one symptom and the whole disorder the goal of this study wa to examine change in the symptom interrelation of patient undergoing cognitive behavioral therapy treatment cbt via network analysis 2 method outpatient with depressive symptom n 401 were assessed with the beck depression inventory three time pretreatment after 12 session and post treatment during cbt gaussian graphical model were used to estimate the relationship among symptom 3 result the severity of depressive symptom significantly decreased over the course of therapy but connectivity in the network significantly increased community of symptom changed during treatment the most central and predictable symptom wa worthlessness at baseline and after 12 session and loss of energy and self dislike at post treatment 4 conclusion the result indicate that the severity of depressive symptom decreased during cognitive behavior therapy while network connectivity increased furthermore the association among symptom and their centrality changed during the course of therapy future study may investigate individual difference and their impact on the planning of psychotherapeutic treatment
Journal: Int J Environ Res Public Health

Title: Experience Versus Report: Where Are Changes Seen After Exposure-Based Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy? A Randomized Controlled Group Treatment of Childhood Social Anxiety Disorder
Authors: Asbrand, J.; Heinrichs, N.; Schmidtendorf, S.; Nitschke, K.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.
Abstract: a considerable number of child and adolescent with social anxiety disorder sad do not benefit from treatment a much a expected however treatment success should not be measured with social anxiety report alone the cognitive behavioral and physiological component of social stress should also be assessed the author examined an exposure based sad specific group cognitive behavioral therapy cbt in a randomized controlled trial n 67 age 9 13 year blind randomized allocation to treatment cbt n 31 and waitlist control wlc n 36 group success wa operationalized a a clinically significant reduction of symptom measured with sad specific questionnaire structured interview and change in response to the trier social stress test tsst in the cbt group there wa a trend toward a significant increase in positive cognition in the tsst after treatment d 0 37 whereas these positive cognition decreased in the wlc group d 0 40 no significant result involving group appeared for negative cognition behavior and physiology child in the cbt group but not parent further reported le social anxiety in one questionnaire from pre to post treatment d 0 89 a structured interview confirmed a decrease in severity of sad in the cbt group while the gold standard of a blind interview showed efficacy of treatment not all trait and state measure demonstrated similar success pattern trial registration eligibility criterion and some of the dependent variable cognition physiology for treatment success were registered with the german research foundation tu 78 5 2 he 3342 4 2 prior to recruitment clinical assessment of diagnosis and behavioral data were not a priori planned a outcome measure for this trial and therefore analyzed in a post hoc approach

Title: Emotion recognition in girls with conduct problems
Authors: Schwenck, C.; Gensthaler, A.; Romanos, M.; Freitag, C. M.; Schneider, W.; Taurines, R.
Abstract: a deficit in emotion recognition ha been suggested to underlie conduct problem although several study have been conducted on this topic so far most concentrated on male participant the aim of the current study wa to compare recognition of morphed emotional face in girl with conduct problem cp with elevated or low callous unemotional cu v cu trait and a matched healthy developing control group cg sixteen girl with cp cu 16 girl with cp cu and 32 control mean age 13 23 year sd 2 33 year were included video clip with morphed face were presented in two run to a emotion recognition multivariate analysis of variance with the factor group and run wa performed girl with cp cu needed more time than the cg to encode sad fearful and happy face and they correctly identified sadness le often girl with cp cu outperformed the other group in the identification of fear learning effect throughout run were the same for all group except that girl with cp cu correctly identified fear le often in the second run compared to the first run result need to be replicated with comparable task which might result in subgroup specific therapeutic recommendation

Title: Body image related negative interpretation bias in anorexia nervosa
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Anderle, A.; Schmidt, H.; Febry, S.; Wunsch-Leiteritz, W.; Leiteritz, A.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: a distorted body image and pronounced body dissatisfaction are hallmark of anorexia nervosa an that typically result in dietary restraint and compensatory behaviour cognitive bias such a negative interpretation bias are considered key maintaining factor of these maladaptive cognition and behaviour however little attention ha been paid to empirical test whether negative interpretation bias exists in an and to what degree it is associated with symptom severity participant in the present study were 40 woman with an and 40 healthy woman with no history of an eating disorder body related negative interpretation bias i e a tendency to interpret ambiguous information about the own body in a negative way wa measured by a scrambled sentence task patient with an showed a stronger body related negative interpretation bias than healthy control within both group negative interpretation bias correlated strongly and positively with an symptom severity and these effect were not moderated by level of depressive symptom the finding support the idea that biased interpretation of body related information is associated with the specific psychopathology of an targeted computerised intervention e g interpretation bias modification may help to alter these dysfunctional cognitive schema that lie at the heart of an

Title: Effects of approach-avoidance training on implicit and explicit evaluations of neutral, angry, and smiling face stimuli
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Becker, E. S.; Lange, W. G.; Rinck, M.
Abstract: a growing body of evidence show that the prolonged execution of approach movement towards stimulus and avoidance movement away from them affect their evaluation however there ha been no systematic investigation of such training effect therefore the present study compared approach avoidance training effect on various valenced representation of one neutral experiment 1 n 85 angry experiment 2 n 87 or smiling facial expression experiment 3 n 89 the face stimulus were shown on a computer screen and by mean of a joystick participant pulled half of the face closer positive approach movement and pushed the other half away negative avoidance movement only implicit evaluation of neutral expression were affected by the training procedure the boundary condition of such approach avoidance training effect are discussed

Title: Olfactory Perception in Relation to the Physicochemical Odor Space
Authors: Bierling, A. L.; Croy, I.; Hummel, T.; Cuniberti, G.; Croy, A.
Abstract: a growing body of research aim at solving what is often referred to a the stimulus percept problem in olfactory perception although computational effort have made it possible to predict perceptual impression from the physicochemical space of odor study with large psychophysical datasets from non expert remain scarce following previous approach we developed a physicochemical odor space using 4094 molecular descriptor of 1389 odor molecule for 20 of these odor we examined association with perceived pleasantness intensity odor quality and detection threshold obtained from a dataset of 2000 naive participant our result show significant difference in perceptual rating and we were able to replicate previous finding on the association between perceptual rating and the first dimension of the physicochemical odor space however the present analysis also revealed striking interindividual variation in perceived pleasantness and intensity additionally interaction between pleasantness intensity and olfactory and trigeminal qualitative dimension were found to conclude our result support previous finding on the relation between structure and perception on the group level in our sample of non expert raters in the challenging task to relate olfactory stimulus and percept the physicochemical odor space can serve a a reliable and helpful tool to structure the high dimensional space of olfactory stimulus nevertheless human olfactory perception in the individual is not an analytic process of molecule detection alone but is part of a holistic integration of multisensory input context and experience

Title: Theory of Mind in Pre-school Aged Children: Influence of Maternal Depression and Infants' Self-Comforting Behavior
Authors: Nonnenmacher, N.; Muller, M.; Taczkowski, J.; Zietlow, A. L.; Sodian, B.; Reck, C.
Abstract: a milestone of child development is theory of mind tom the ability to attribute mental state especially belief and desire to other person and to understand that their behavior is guided by mental state the learning process about the mental world also take place in social communication and interaction beginning in infancy infancy is assumed to be a sensitive period for the development of social skill through interaction due to limited self regulatory skill infant depend on sensitive behavior of their caregiver to regulate affective state and physiological arousal and in turn mutually regulated affect allow the infant to gradually acquire the capability to self regulate negative affective state effective and adequate affect regulation is an important prerequisite for environmental interaction and thus for the development of socio emotional skill the present study investigated the relation of self regulatory ability in infancy and later tom in pre school aged child of clinically depressed mother and healthy control the sample comprised of n 55 mother child dyad n 22 diagnosed with postpartum or lifetime depression according to dsm iv and n 33 healthy control mother infant interaction wa videotaped during the face to face still face paradigm at 3 and 42 month postpartum mother were interviewed with the structured clinical interview for dsm iv axis i disorder scid i to evaluate maternal psychopathological status according to dsm iv at the age of m 4 0 year child s tom ability were assessed using content false belief and location false belief task the result of this study show that contrary to our hypothesis maternal depression did not impair the development of child s tom ability per se rather an interaction effect highlight the role of infant s self comforting behavior during mother infant interaction in infancy 3 month postpartum for tom development at pre school age assessed with the maxi task this association wa distinct for female in comparison to male child the result of this longitudinal study shed light on the discussion how maternal depression influence child development and point in the direction that self comforting behavior in infancy can also be seen a a resource

Title: Personality types revisited-a literature-informed and data-driven approach to an integration of prototypical and dimensional constructs of personality description
Authors: Kerber, A.; Roth, M.; Herzberg, P. Y.
Abstract: a new algorithmic approach to personality prototyping based on big five trait wa applied to a large representative and longitudinal german dataset n 22 820 including behavior personality and health correlate we applied three different clustering technique latent profile analysis the k mean method and spectral clustering algorithm the resulting cluster center i e the personality prototype were evaluated using a large number of internal and external validity criterion including health locus of control self esteem impulsivity risk taking and wellbeing the best fitting prototypical personality profile were labeled according to their euclidean distance to averaged personality type profile identified in a review of previous study on personality type this procedure yielded a five cluster solution resilient overcontroller undercontroller reserved and vulnerable resilient reliability and construct validity could be confirmed we discus wether personality type could comprise a bridge between personality and clinical psychology a well a between developmental psychology and resilience research

Title: Oxytocin differentially modulates eye gaze to naturalistic social signals of happiness and anger
Authors: Domes, G.; Steiner, A.; Porges, S. W.; Heinrichs, M.
Abstract: a number of previous study ha shown that oxytocin ot promotes facial emotion recognition and enhances eye gaze to facial stimulus in human other study report valence specific effect of ot supporting the proposed prosocial role of ot in social interaction in the present study we tested the hypothesis whether ot might selectively enhance eye gaze to positive approach related but not to negative threat related social cue in a placebo controlled double blind between subject design we assessed the effect of intranasal ot administration 24 iu in 62 healthy male volunteer on eye gaze toward the eye of neutral positive happy and negative angry facial expression compared with placebo in order to capture the dynamic of facial expression we used video sequence showing neutral face gradually displaying a specific emotion in line with previous study ot increased eye gaze toward neutral facial expression moreover under ot treatment eye gaze remained increased when the face showed a happy facial expression but in contrast decreased when the face displayed an angry expression these result support the notion that ot differentially modulates visual attention toward social signal of positive approach and threat and thereby contributes to the modulation of non verbal interpersonal communication

Title: Use of machine learning to classify adult ADHD and other conditions based on the Conners' Adult ADHD Rating Scales
Authors: Christiansen, H.; Chavanon, M. L.; Hirsch, O.; Schmidt, M. H.; Meyer, C.; Muller, A.; Rumpf, H. J.; Grigorev, I.; Hoffmann, A.
Abstract: a reliable diagnosis of adult attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd is challenging a many of the symptom of adhd resemble symptom of other disorder adhd is associated with gambling disorder and obesity showing overlap of about 20 with each diagnosis it is important for clinical practice to differentiate between condition displaying similar symptom via established diagnostic instrument applying the lightgbm algorithm in machine learning we were able to differentiate subject with adhd obesity problematic gambling and a control group using all 26 item of the conners adult adhd rating scale caars s s with a global accuracy of 80 precision positive predictive value ranged between 78 gambling and 92 obesity recall sensitivity between 58 for obesity and 87 for adhd model with the best 5 and best 10 item resulted in le satisfactory fit the caars s seems to be a promising instrument to be applied in clinical practice also for multiclassifying disorder displaying symptom resembling adhd

Title: Expectation of exercise in trained athletes results in a reduction of central processing to nociceptive stimulation
Authors: Geisler, M.; Eichelkraut, L.; Miltner, W. H. R.; Weiss, T.
Abstract: a single endurance exercise session wa shown to lead to a reduction of pain perception and an elevation of mood we hypothesized that athlete who regularly practice endurance might also induce change in mood and pain processing in expectation of an endurance session we compared the expectation effect of a 2 h run on mood and pain processing to a run free control day rfc fifteen trained runner were assessed with repeated painful and nonpainful pinprick stimulation in a functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri scanner prior to a 2 h run and at rfc pain rating pressure pain stimulus response function and euphoria rating were also assessed there were no mean expectation effect on any of the behavioral measure however highly trained athlete needed more pressure to evoke a pain rating of 46 pre run v rfc but were le euphoric pre run v rfc furthermore analysis of brain activity to painful stimulus applied immediately before the 2 h run compared to rfc revealed increased activation in the medial prefrontal cortex mpfc and reduced activation in posterior insula additionally le trained athlete had reduced activation in posterior insula to painful stimulation pre run v rfc compared to highly trained athlete the result suggest reduced central pain processing in expectation of an endurance run and an association between the amount of the expectation effect and training frequency which differs depending on the stimulus applied

Title: Generalization of appetitive conditioned responses
Authors: Andreatta, M.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: a stimulus conditioned stimulus c associated with an appetitive unconditioned stimulus u acquires positive property and elicits appetitive conditioned response cr such associative learning ha been examined extensively in animal with food a the u and result are used to explain psychopathology e g substance related disorder or obesity human study on appetitive conditioning exist too but we still know little about generalization process understanding these process may explain why stimulus not associated with a drug for instance can elicit craving forty seven hungry participant underwent an appetitive conditioning protocol during which one of two circle with different diameter c became associated with an appetitive u chocolate or salty pretzel according to participant preference but never the other circle c during generalization u were delivered twice and the two c were presented again plus four circle generalization stimulus g with gradually increasing diameter from c to c we found successful appetitive conditioning a reflected in appetitive subjective rating positive valence higher contingency and physiological response startle attenuation and larger skin conductance response to c versus c and importantly both measure confirmed generalization a indicated by generalization gradient small change in c u contingency during generalization may have weakened generalization process on the physiological level considering that appetitive conditioned response can be generalized to non u associated stimulus a next important step would be to investigate risk factor that mediate overgeneralization

Title: From decision to action: Suicidal history and time between decision to die and actual suicide attempt
Authors: Paashaus, L.; Forkmann, T.; Glaesmer, H.; Juckel, G.; Rath, D.; Schonfelder, A.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: a substantial proportion of suicide attempt seem to be realized in a sudden manner however it is unclear how suicide attempter showing a rapid transition from the decision to die to acting differ from suicide attempter showing a slower transition regarding their suicidal history the main aim of this study wa to determine the proportion of suicide attempter who reported a rapid transition 5 10 180 min between their decision to die and their actual attempt furthermore attempter group v 5 v 10 and v 180 min were compared regarding suicidal history ideation plan and number of lifetime a well a 12 month suicide attempt a well a depression hopelessness and trait impulsivity in total 118 inpatient 62 7 female age m 38 71 sd 14 71 hospitalized due to a recent suicide attempt were assessed using structured clinical interview measure assessing suicidal history and self report instrument thirty six percent reported a time period of 5 min 44 a time period of 10 min and 73 a time period of 180 min between their decision to die and their attempt participant with a rapid transition 5 10 180 min did not differ from participant with a slower transition 5 10 180 min regarding suicidal history depression hopelessness and trait impulsivity taken together a rapid transition seems common but nevertheless rapidly realized suicide attempt cannot necessarily be characterized a impulsive

Title: Imminent danger? Probabilistic classification learning of threat-related information in obsessive-compulsive disorder
Authors: Exner, C.; Zetsche, U.; Lincoln, T. M.; Rief, W.
Abstract: a tendency to overestimate threat ha been shown in individual with ocd we tested the hypothesis that this bias in judgment is related to difficulty in learning probabilistic association between event thirty participant with ocd and 30 matched healthy control completed a learning experiment involving 2 variant of a probabilistic classification learning task in the neutral weather prediction task rainy and sunny weather had to be predicted in the emotional task danger of an epidemic from virus infection had to be predicted epidemic prediction task participant with ocd were a able a control to improve their prediction of neutral event across learning trial but scored significantly below healthy control on the epidemic prediction task lower performance on the emotional task variant wa significantly related to a heightened tendency to overestimate threat biased information processing in ocd might thus hamper corrective experience regarding the probability of threatening event

Title: Nucleus accumbens activation is linked to salience in social decision making
Authors: Schmidt, S. N. L.; Fenske, S. C.; Kirsch, P.; Mier, D.
Abstract: aberrant salience may explain hasty decision making and psychotic symptom in schizophrenia in healthy individual final decision in probabilistic reasoning task are related to nucleus accumbens nacc activation however research investigating the nacc in social decision making is missing our study aimed at investigating the role of the nacc for social decision making and it link to aberrant salience attribution 47 healthy individual completed a novel social jumping to conclusion jtc fmri paradigm showing morphed face simultaneously expressing fear and happiness participant decided on the current emotion after each picture and on the general emotion of series of face nacc activation wa stronger during final decision than in previous trial without a decision particularly in fear rather than happiness series a jtc bias wa associated with higher nacc activation for last fearful but not last happy face apparently mechanism underlying probabilistic reasoning are also relevant for social decision making the pattern of nacc activation suggests salience not reward drive the final decision based on these finding we hypothesize that aberrant salience might also explain social cognitive deficit in schizophrenia

Title: Heart-related anxieties in relation to general anxiety and severity of illness in cardiology patients
Authors: Muschalla, B.; Glatz, J.; Linden, M.
Abstract: absence of an adequate reason for anxiety is a criterion for pathological anxiety however the presence of danger or fear provoking stimulus may even be a risk factor for anxiety and doe not exclude that there is additionally pathological anxiety too the question is to what degree can heart related anxiety be explained by the severity of illness or trait anxiety two hundred and nine patient 37 8 woman from a cardiology inpatient unit completed the heart anxiety questionnaire progression anxiety questionnaire job anxiety scale and the state trait anxiety inventory the severity of cardiac illness wa rated by the treating cardiologist using the multidimensional severity of morbidity rating time absent from work due to sickness wa assessed a an indicator for illness related impairment heart anxiety wa significantly related to progression anxiety and to a lesser extent trait anxiety and indicator of subjective symptom of somatic illness no association wa found with medical rating for prognosis multimorbidity or reduction in life expectancy heart related anxiety is a symptom of an anxiety disorder although partially dependent on subjective suffering it cannot be explained by the severity of medical illness treatment of health related anxiety should focus on how to cope with subjective symptom of illness

Title: Doctoral researchers' mental health and PhD training satisfaction during the German COVID-19 lockdown: results from an international research sample
Authors: Naumann, S.; Matyjek, M.; Bogl, K.; Dziobek, I.
Abstract: academia ha been facing a mental health crisis particularly affecting early career researcher ecrs moreover the covid 19 pandemic posed an unprecedented burden on the mental health of many individual therefore we cross sectionally investigated how doctoral researcher n 222 evaluate their mental health status and satisfaction with their phd training before and during the pandemic a compared to self reported retrospective evaluation about the pre pandemic state we found decreased satisfaction with phd training and overall well being the whole sample exhibited high level of personal and work related burnout a fifth indicated clinically meaningful level of depressive symptom and almost 25 experienced severe loneliness when exploring predictor of depression anxiety and burnout we identified low satisfaction with phd training a the most prominent predictor for poor mental health suggesting a link between the doctoral work and their mental health status female v male and doctoral researcher in individual doctorate v structured phd program reported higher symptom of burnout our study replicates previous finding of poor mental health in doctoral researcher and indicates further decrease of mental wellbeing under the influence of the pandemic systematic adjustment in academia are required to improve the mental health of ecrs

Title: Acceptance-Based Emotion Regulation Reduces Subjective and Physiological Pain Responses
Authors: Haspert, V.; Wieser, M. J.; Pauli, P.; Reicherts, P.
Abstract: acceptance based regulation of pain which focus on the allowing of pain and pain related thought and emotion wa found to modulate pain however result so far are inconsistent regarding different pain modality and index moreover study so far often lack a suitable control condition focus on behavioral pain measure rather than physiological correlate and often use between subject design which potentially impede the evaluation of the effectiveness of the strategy therefore we investigated whether acceptance based strategy can reduce subjective and physiological marker of acute pain in comparison to a control condition in a within subject design to this end participant n 30 completed 24 trial comprising 10 s of heat pain stimulation each trial started with a cue instructing participant to welcome and experience pain acceptance trial or to react to the pain a it is without employing any regulation strategy control trial in addition to pain intensity and unpleasantness rating heart rate hr and skin conductance sc were recorded result showed significantly decreased pain intensity and unpleasantness rating for acceptance compared to control trial additionally hr wa significantly lower during acceptance compared to control trial whereas sc revealed no significant difference these result demonstrate the effectiveness of acceptance based strategy in reducing subjective and physiological pain response relative to a control condition even after short training therefore the systematic investigation of acceptance in different pain modality in healthy and chronic pain patient is warranted

Title: Temporal stability and effect dynamics between executive functions, perceived chronic stress, and hair cortisol concentrations
Authors: Weckesser, L. J.; Schmidt, K.; Moschl, M.; Kirschbaum, C.; Enge, S.; Miller, R.
Abstract: accident caused by human error illustrate the fragility of cognitive processing and it coordination by executive function against stress to better understand how core executive function change over time influence each other and are affected by chronic stress exposure a prospective cohort study wa conducted from 2016 to 2019 five hundred sixteen german adult aged 25 55 year mean age education age 38 0 11 3 year 67 female 94 occupied 20 smoker completed at least one internet based biannual assessment of response inhibition updating and set shifting using a go nogo spatial 2 back and number letter task respectively chronic stress exposure wa indicated by self report on the perceived stress scale p and hair cortisol concentration hcc statistical analysis were performed by multivariate stochastic differential equation modeling all indicator of executive function task specific rts in target trial or their contrast to nontarget trial and chronic stress showed intraindividual stability over time 12 to 63 of their variance wa attributable to trait influence with respect to lagged mutual association faster go nogo target rts predicted faster number letter target rts later in time while faster number letter target rts predicted higher hcc later in time both with maximum effect size of d approximately 0 1 standard deviation however p wa not predictive of later hcc and vice versa none of the chronic stress indicator significantly predicted indicator of executive function at subsequent time point these finding suggest that set shifting is capable of modulating the body s physiological response to chronic stress exposure whereas executive function appear comparably robust against chronic stress exposure psycinfo database record c 2021 apa all right reserved

Title: Anger and aggressiveness in obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and the mediating role of responsibility, non-acceptance of emotions, and social desirability
Authors: Cludius, B.; Mannsfeld, A. K.; Schmidt, A. F.; Jelinek, L.
Abstract: according to psychodynamic and cognitive model of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd anger and aggression play an important role in the development and maintenance of the disorder sub clinical sample with ocd have reported higher anger and anger suppression patient with checking related symptom of ocd showed a le aggressive self concept a assessed by an implicit association test iat this study assessed anger and aggressiveness self concept in ocd a well a possible mediator of the link between ocd and aggressiveness a total of 48 patient with ocd and 45 healthy control were included measure included the state trait anger expression inventory ii and an aggressiveness self concept iat agg iat an inflated sense of responsibility non acceptance of emotion and social desirability were tested a mediator a expected patient with ocd reported higher trait anger and anger suppression compared to healthy control contrary to hypothesis the aggressiveness self concept agg iat did not differ between group the inflated sense of responsibility mediated the relationship between group and anger suppression non acceptance of negative emotion mediated the relationship between group and trait anger a well a anger suppression however comorbidities and medication may account for some effect in anger suppression elevated trait anger and anger suppression in ocd patient could be explained by dysfunctional belief or maladaptive emotion regulation strategy emotion regulation therapy might help to enhance awareness and acceptance of emotion and possibly improve treatment outcome

Title: Direct and indirect assessment of perfectionism in patients with depression and obsessive-compulsive disorder
Authors: Cludius, B.; Landmann, S.; Kulz, A. K.; Takano, K.; Moritz, S.; Jelinek, L.
Abstract: according to the transdiagnostic perspective psychological disorder share common cognitive process involved in their pathogenesis one dysfunctional belief that ha been found to be associated with several psychological disorder including major depressive disorder mdd and obsessive compulsive disorder ocd is perfectionism perfectionism comprises two factor namely perfectionistic striving and perfectionistic concern this study aim to replicate and extend previous research in several way we aimed to a similarity between the two disorder using bayesian statistic furthermore a dysfunctional belief are assumed to not be fully accessible by introspection we included an indirect measure perfectionism single category implicit association task sc iat the sc iat and a self report measure of perfectionism fmps wa used in patient with mdd n 55 ocd n 55 and in healthy control n 64 in replication of previous finding patient with mdd and ocd differed from healthy control regarding self reported perfectionism score furthermore bayesian statistic showed that the two patient group did not differ regarding perfectionistic striving and only showed difference on perfectionistic concern when the doubt about action subscale which is also closely related to symptom of ocd wa included contrary to our expectation the sc iat did not discriminate group in conclusion these result give further evidence that self reported perfectionism may serve a a relevant transdiagnostic process more study are needed to a implicit facet of perfectionism

Title: Assessment of Tobacco-Related Approach and Attentional Biases in Smokers, Cravers, Ex-Smokers, and Non-Smokers
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Maas, J.; Wiers, R. W.; Becker, E. S.; Rinck, M.
Abstract: according to theory of addictive behavior approach and attentional bias toward smoking related cue play a crucial role in tobacco dependence several study have investigated these bias by using various paradigm in different sample type however this heterogeneity make it difficult to compare and evaluate the result the present study aimed to address this problem via i a structural comparison of different measure of approach avoidance and a measure of smoking related attentional bias and ii using within one study different representative sample in the context of tobacco dependence three measure of approach avoidance were employed an approach avoidance task aat a stimulus response compatibility task src and a single target implicit association test st iat to a attentional bias a modified stroop task including smoking related word wa administered the study included four group n 58 smoker n 57 non smoker n 52 cravers and n 54 ex smoker we expected to find strong tobacco related approach bias and attentional bias in smoker and cravers however the general pattern of result did not confirm these expectation approach response assessed during the aat and src did not differ between group moreover the stroop did not show the expected interference effect for the st iat cravers had stronger approach association toward smoking related cue whereas non smoker showed stronger avoidance association however no such difference in approach avoidance association were found in smoker and ex smoker to conclude these data do not provide evidence for a strong role of implicit approach and attentional bias toward smoking related cue in tobacco dependency

Title: A brief cognitive-behavioural social skills training for stabilised outpatients with schizophrenia: a preliminary study
Authors: Rus-Calafell, M.; Gutierrez-Maldonado, J.; Ortega-Bravo, M.; Ribas-Sabate, J.; Caqueo-Urizar, A.
Abstract: achieving social functioning and achieving social competence are two main objective of psychosocial intervention for people suffering from schizophrenia the present preliminary study present a novel approach of social skill training sst based on the proposal of kopelowicz et al kopelowicz a liberman r p and zarate r 2006 schizophr bull 32 1 s12 23 that link the treatment to seven specific target behaviour social perception social information processing responding and sending skill affiliative skill interactional skill and behaviour governed by social norm thirty one stabilised outpatient were randomly assigned to one of two group sst n 13 or treatment a usual n 18 tau case management medication adherence psychotherapy leisure engagement and family support and were assessed at baseline in cognitive performance clinical symptomatology social cognition and psychosocial functioning these outcome were evaluated across post treatment and at the 6 month follow up appointment sst subject showed improvement in psychopathology social discomfort social cognition self regulation statement during interaction social withdrawal interpersonal communication and quality of life compared with the tau group at the 6 month follow up result were maintained for negative symptom social discomfort and some functioning outcome neuropsychological variable were also examined a mediator of benefit from skill training result support the efficacy of the brief sst for outpatient with schizophrenia and show the need to implement empirically supported intervention in mental health service to enhance patient social functioning and quality of life

Title: Fear generalization of implicit conditioned facial features - Behavioral and magnetoencephalographic correlates
Authors: Roesmann, K.; Wiens, N.; Winker, C.; Rehbein, M. A.; Wessing, I.; Junghoefer, M.
Abstract: acquired fear response often generalize from conditioned stimulus c towards perceptually similar but harmless generalization stimulus g knowledge on similarity between c and g may be explicit or implicit employing behavioral measure and whole head magnetoencephalography we here investigated the neurocognitive mechanism underpinning implicit fear generalization twenty nine participant underwent a classical conditioning procedure in which 32 different face were either paired with an aversive scream 16 c or remained unpaired 16 c c and c face systematically differed from each other regarding their ratio of eye distance and mouth width high versus low value on this threat related feature tf implicitly predicted the presence or absence of the aversive scream in pre and post conditioning phase all c and 32 novel g face were presented 16 g face shared the tf of the 16 c face while 16 g face shared the tf of the 16 c face behavioral test confirmed that participant were fully unaware of tf u contingency c compared to c face revealed higher unpleasantness arousal and u expectancy rating a generalization of these behavioral fear response to g compared to g face wa observed by trend only source estimation of event related field showed stronger neural response to both c and g compared to c and g in anterior temporal 100 m and temporo occipital 150 m 553 587 m ventral brain region reverse effect were found in dorsal frontal area 100 m 173 203 m 257 290 m neural data also revealed selectively enhanced response to c but not g stimulus in occipital region 110 167 m 330 413 m indicating perceptual discrimination our data suggest that the prioritized perceptual analysis of threat associated conditioned face in ventral network rapidly generalizes to novel face sharing threat related feature this generalization process occurs in absence of contingency awareness and may thus contribute to implicit attentional bias the coexisting perceptual discrimination suggests that fear generalization is not a mere consequence of insufficient stimulus discrimination but rather an active integrative process

Title: The Error-Related Negativity Predicts Self-Control Failures in Daily Life
Authors: Overmeyer, R.; Berghauser, J.; Dieterich, R.; Wolff, M.; Goschke, T.; Endrass, T.
Abstract: adaptive behavior critically depends on performance monitoring pm the ability to monitor action outcome and the need to adapt behavior pm related brain activity ha been linked to guiding decision about whether action adaptation is warranted the present study examined whether pm related brain activity in a flanker task a measured by electroencephalography eeg wa associated with adaptive behavior in daily life specifically we were interested in the employment of self control operationalized a self control failure scfs and measured using ecological momentary assessment analysis were conducted using an adaptive elastic net regression to predict scfs from eeg in a sample of 131 participant the model wa fit using within subject averaged response locked eeg activity at each electrode and time point within an epoch surrounding the response we found that higher amplitude of the error related negativity ern were related to fewer scfs this suggests that lower error related activity may relate to lower recruitment of interventive self control in daily life altered cognitive control process like pm have been proposed a underlying mechanism for various mental disorder understanding how alteration in pm relate to regulatory control might therefore aid in delineating how these alteration contribute to different psychopathology

Title: Centralized gaze as an adaptive component of defensive states in humans
Authors: Merscher, A. S.; Tovote, P.; Pauli, P.; Gamer, M.
Abstract: adequate defensive responding is crucial for mental health but scientifically not well understood specifically it seems difficult to dissociate defense and approach state based on autonomic response pattern we thus explored the robustness and threat specificity of recently described oculomotor dynamic upon threat in anticipation of either threatening or rewarding stimulus in human while visually exploring naturalistic image participant 50 per experiment expected an inevitable no or avoidable shock experiment 1 or a guaranteed no or achievable reward experiment 2 that could be averted or gained by a quick behavioural response we observed reduced heart rate bradycardia increased skin conductance pupil dilation and globally centralized gaze when shock were inevitable but more pronouncedly when they were avoidable reward trial were not associated with globally narrowed visual exploration but autonomic response resembled characteristic of the threat condition while bradycardia and concomitant sympathetic activation reflect not only threat related but also action preparatory state independent of valence global centralization of gaze seems a robust phenomenon during the anticipation of avoidable threat thus instead of relying on single readout translational research in animal and human should consider the multi dimensionality of state in aversive and rewarding context especially when investigating ambivalent conflicting situation

Title: The Limbic System in Youth Depression: Brain Structural and Functional Alterations in Adolescent In-patients with Severe Depression
Authors: Redlich, R.; Opel, N.; Burger, C.; Dohm, K.; Grotegerd, D.; Forster, K.; Zaremba, D.; Meinert, S.; Repple, J.; Enneking, V.; Leehr, E.; Bohnlein, J.; Winters, L.; Frobose, N.; Thrun, S.; Emtmann, J.; Heindel, W.; Kugel, H.; Arolt, V.; Romer, G.; Postert, C.; Dannlowski, U.
Abstract: adolescent onset major depressive disorder mdd is associated with an increased risk of recurrent depressive episode suicidal behavior and psychiatric morbidity throughout the lifespan the objective of the present study wa to investigate brain structural and functional change in adolescent patient with mdd furthermore we aimed to clarify the influence of early life stress on brain function and structure the study investigated adolescent patient with severe mdd n 20 mean age 16 0 range 15 18 year and a control sample of matched healthy adolescent n 21 mean age 16 6 range 15 18 year functional mri data were obtained using a face matching paradigm to investigate emotion processing structural mri data were analyzed using voxel based morphometry vbm in line with previous study on adult mdd adolescent patient showed elevated amygdala activity to negative and reduced amygdala activity to positive emotional stimulus furthermore mdd patient showed smaller hippocampal volume compared to healthy adolescent higher level of childhood maltreatment were associated with smaller hippocampal volume in both depressed patient and healthy control whereby no association between amygdala reactivity and childhood maltreatment were found our result suggest that hippocampal alteration in youth mdd patient may at least partly be traced back to higher occurrence of early life adverse experience regarding the strong morphometric impact of childhood maltreatment and it distinctly elevated prevalence in mdd population this study provides an alternative explanation for frequently observed limbic structural abnormality in depressed patient

Title: Facial emotion recognition in adolescents with nonsuicidal self-injury
Authors: In-Albon, T.; Ruf, C.; Schmid, M.
Abstract: adolescent with nonsuicidal self injury nssi have been described a having considerable impairment in social interaction and social difficulty are often a trigger for nssi however little is known about how adolescent with nssi disorder process facial expression of emotion we investigated the recognition of facial expression of emotion in 47 adolescent with nssi disorder 28 clinical control without nssi and 51 nonclinical control following a neutral or a sad mood induction participant were presented with a dynamic facial expression that slowly changed from neutral to full intensity happiness sadness anger disgust fear or neutral closed open mouth recognition of facial expression wa measured by the intensity of the expression at which participant could accurately identify the facial expression no group difference in the recognition of facial expression were found all group required comparable stage of emotional expressivity to correctly recognize emotion and there were no significant difference in accuracy result indicate no mood effect on recognition or accuracy valence and arousal rating of stimulus indicated that compared to the nonclinical control group but not to clinical control the adolescent with nssi disorder rated the stimulus a significantly more unpleasant and arousing

Title: Age dependent changes of distractibility and reorienting of attention revisited: an event-related potential study
Authors: Berti, S.; Grunwald, M.; Schroger, E.
Abstract: adult of three age group 18 27 39 45 and 59 66 year performed an auditory duration discrimination task with short 200 m or long 400 m sinusoidal tone performance wa highly accurate and reaction time were on the same level in all group indicating no difference in auditory duration processing task irrelevant rare change of the frequency of the stimulus were introduced to check whether the subject firstly were distracted by change in the environment while focusing on the task relevant information indicated by prolonged response and secondly could re focus on the relevant task after distraction the result show that a distraction effect is present in all group importantly the 59 66 year group showed a behavioral distraction effect nearly twice a high a the other group the event related brain potential erps show mismatch negativity mmn p3a and reorienting negativity ron elicited by deviant which are present in all group aging effect on these erp component were observable in all three component but a revealed a weak significant effect for the mmn only taken together the behavioral and erp result suggest that the function of balancing the processing of task irrelevant change in the stimulation while focusing on task relevant information is effective during adulthood until the 7th decade of life

Title: Dispositional cognitive reappraisal modulates the neural correlates of fear acquisition and extinction
Authors: Hermann, A.; Keck, T.; Stark, R.
Abstract: adverse learning experience play a significant role in the etiology of anxiety disorder however not all individual experiencing negative event develop heightened anxiety this is possibly due to individual difference in the regulation of negative emotion associated with these negative event cognitive reappraisal is defined a reinterpreting an emotion eliciting situation in a way that change it emotional impact a more frequent use of cognitive reappraisal in daily life ha been shown to be more adaptive however no study to date examined the association of dispositional cognitive reappraisal with emotional learning in order to elucidate individual difference in negative emotional response towards aversive event the goal of this functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri study wa to investigate the association of dispositional cognitive reappraisal with subjective electrodermal and neural correlate of fear acquisition and extinction data of 41 healthy individual who participated in a socially relevant differential conditioning paradigm acquisition and extinction learning day 1 extinction recall day 2 were acquired dispositional cognitive reappraisal wa negatively associated with right insula and hippocampus activation during acquisition furthermore the reduction of self reported conditioned fear during extinction learning a well a reduced insula and enhanced rostral anterior cingulate cortex activation during extinction learning wa related to cognitive reappraisal in addition reduced recovery of conditioned arousal reduced anterior cingulate and dorsomedial prefrontal cortex activation and enhanced ventromedial prefrontal cortex activation during extinction recall wa observed in individual with higher cognitive reappraisal score the result indicate that dispositional cognitive reappraisal modulates subjective and neural correlate of fear conditioning probably leading to reduced acquisition and stronger extinction learning and recall these result point to the important role of dispositional cognitive reappraisal in the development and modification of conditioned emotional response and might further improve our understanding of anxiety disorder

Title: Affective Styles in Panic Disorder and Specific Phobia: Changes Through Cognitive Behavior Therapy and Prediction of Remission
Authors: Totzeck, C.; Teismann, T.; Hofmann, S. G.; von Brachel, R.; Zhang, X. C.; Wannemuller, A.; Pflug, V.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: affective style appear to be relevant to the development of psychopathology especially anxiety disorder the aim of the current study wa to investigate change in affective style in patient with panic disorder and specific phobia a a result of undergoing cognitive behavioral therapy and to identify a possible link between certain affective style and remission the sample consisted of outpatient n 101 suffering from panic disorder specific phobia or agoraphobia who completed the affective style questionnaire asq before and after therapy a well a at a 6 month follow up assessment multivariate analysis of variance were conducted to test for change due to therapy logistic regression analysis were calculated to test for the impact of affective style on remission from anxiety disorder and hierarchical regression analysis were calculated to examine the association between change in affective style and symptom reduction result indicated significant increase on the asq subscales adjusting and tolerating after therapy concealing did not decrease significantly after therapy in addition higher score on adjusting significantly predicted remission from anxiety disorder finally we found a significant association between increase on the adjusting scale and the reduction of anxiety symptom

Title: Can placebos reduce intrusive memories?
Authors: Kube, T.; Kirsch, I.; Glombiewski, J. A.; Herzog, P.
Abstract: after traumatic experience intrusive memory can flash back and evoke significant distress here we investigated whether the frequency and severity of intrusion can be reduced by the provision of placebo after the online exposure to the trauma film paradigm healthy participant n 112 received deceptive placebo dp open label placebo olp or no treatment in the dp group participant were led to believe to receive a dopamine modulating drug which wa supposed to disrupt the consolidation of traumatic memory although they in fact received the same placebo tablet a the olp group for one week the result show that the group did not differ in the frequency of intrusive memory after one week however participant receiving olp reported a significantly reduced intensity of intrusion a compared to dp across group negative expectation about the intensity and controllability of intrusion were associated with a higher frequency of intrusion higher distress higher burden and more negative appraisal the result suggest that expectation play an important role in the emergence of intrusive memory and that some of the disabling aspect of intrusive memory can be reduced by placebo this may carry clinical potential because placebo are an accessible cost effective intervention to reduce the risk of intrusive memory

Title: Don't Make Me Angry: Frustration-Induced Anger and Its Link to Aggression in Women With Borderline Personality Disorder
Authors: Bertsch, K.; Back, S.; Flechsenhar, A.; Neukel, C.; Krauch, M.; Spiess, K.; Panizza, A.; Herpertz, S. C.
Abstract: aggression is a prominent interpersonal dysfunction of individual with borderline personality disorder bpd in bpd aggression is predominantly reactive in nature often triggered by frustration provocation or social threat and is associated with intense anger and an inability to regulate this strong negative emotion building on previous research we were interested in investigating negative emotionality in general and anger in particular in woman with bpd before and after frustration induction to achieve this 60 medication free woman with bpd and 32 healthy woman rated the intensity of negative emotion angry frustrated upset embarrassed nervous before and after performing a titrated mirror tracing task which reliably induces frustration and distress a expected woman with bpd reported significantly greater intensity of negative emotion before and after frustration than healthy woman specifically they showed a significantly stronger frustration induced increase in anger while other negative emotion remained unaffected by frustration induction this anger increase wa significantly related to aggressive behavior reported in the 2 week prior to the experiment a well a to the level of frustration experienced in the experiment itself but not with emotion dysregulation the current data confirm the important role of frustration induced anger independent of emotion dysregulation in bpd in particular with regard to aggression a prominent interpersonal dysfunction of this disorder these finding underline the importance of intervention with particular focus on anger

Title: Ambivalent heroism? - Psychological burden and suicidal ideation among nurses during the Covid-19 pandemic
Authors: Holler, I.; Forkmann, T.
Abstract: aim during the covid 19 pandemic the risk for nurse mental health ha rapidly increased the two main goal of this study were the examination of 1 the psychological burden and 2 of suicidal ideation and it associated risk factor one year after the covid 19 pandemic begun design this wa a cross sectional online survey method n 1311 nurse 96 9 female aged 18 63 year m 30 96 sd 8 48 were assessed for various symptom of psychological burden suicidal ideation and behaviour and it risk factor result almost half of participant 41 5 reported heightened level of depressive symptom 691 52 7 reported a medium to high risk for burnout one fifth of participant 21 7 reported suicidal ideation in the past 4 week the direct contact to people with covid 19 wa not related to the extent of the psychological burden depression agitation perceived burdensomeness and previous suicide attempt were associated with suicidal ideation

Title: Central nervous system processing of emotions in children with nocturnal enuresis and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder
Authors: Equit, M.; Becker, A.; El Khatib, D.; Rubly, M.; Becker, N.; von Gontard, A.
Abstract: aim nocturnal enuresis ne and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd are common in childhood we analysed the central processing of emotion in child with ne adhd ne adhd and control method we examined 13 child with ne 13 with adhd 14 with ne adhd and 14 control acoustic evoked potential were recorded using standardised methodology for the event related potential positive negative and neutral picture were presented and time interval of 250 450 450 650 and 650 850 msec evaluated hypothesis were tested with repeated measure analysis of variance result in the frontal region child with ne showed more intense response to positive and negative picture than control measured with event related potential viewing positive picture child with ne adhd differed from child with adhd in the central and parietal and for all type of stimulus in the parietal region child with ne adhd elicited the strongest response child with adhd did not differ from control there wa an unspecific interaction effect of the acoustic evoked potential in child with ne compared to the control conclusion child with ne processed emotion differently from child with adhd and control child with ne adhd processed emotion the most intense displaying interaction effect of the central nervous system that cannot be explained by each disorder alone

Title: Regional differences in health-related quality of life in elderly heart failure patients: results from the CIBIS-ELD trial
Authors: Chavanon, M. L.; Inkrot, S.; Zelenak, C.; Tahirovic, E.; Stanojevic, D.; Apostolovic, S.; Sljivic, A.; Ristic, A. D.; Matic, D.; Loncar, G.; Veskovic, J.; Zdravkovic, M.; Lainscak, M.; Pieske, B.; Herrmann-Lingen, C.; Dungen, H. D.
Abstract: aim patient reported outcome such a health related quality of life hrqol are main treatment goal for heart failure hf and therefore endpoint in multinational therapy trial however little is known about country specific difference in hrqol and in treatment associated hrqol improvement the present work sought to examine those question method and result we analysed data from the cardiac insufficiency bisoprolol study in elderly cibis eld trial in which patient from central and south eastern europe completed the hrqol questionnaire sf 36 at baseline and the end of a 12 week beta blocker up titration follow up 416 patient from serbia mean age 72 21 year 69 nyha class i ii 27 4 woman and 114 from germany mean age 73 64 year 78 9 nyha class i ii 47 4 woman were included controlling for clinical variable the change in mental hrqol from baseline to follow up wa modulated by country serbian patient m baseline 37 85 v m follow up 40 99 t 526 5 34 p 001 reported a stronger increase than german m baseline 37 66 v m follow up 38 23 t 526 0 68 n for physical hrqol we observed a main effect of country m serbia 39 28 v m germany 35 29 t 526 4 24 p 001 conclusion we observed significant difference in hf patient from germany and serbia and country specific difference between serbian and german patient in mean physical hrqol change in mental hrqol were modulated by country those result may reflect psychological sociocultural aetiological difference or regional difference in phenotype prevalence more importantly they suggest that future multinational trial should consider such aspect when designing a trial in order to avoid uncertainty aligned to data interpretation and to improve subsequent treatment optimisation

Title: Process-symptom-bridges in psychotherapy: An idiographic network approach
Authors: Kaiser, T.; Laireiter, A. R.
Abstract: aim real time monitoring of psychotherapeutic process wa recently described a a promising new way of tracking period of change in ongoing treatment this approach generates complex multivariate datasets that have to be presented in an intuitive way for clinician to aid their clinical decision making using network modeling and new approach in centrality analysis we examine bridge node between symptom stress and aspect of the psychotherapeutic process between therapy session intersession process isp method we recorded intersession process a well a depressive and anxiety symptom using daily questionnaire in ten case regularized thresholded intraindividual dynamic network were estimated we applied bridge centrality analysis to identify individual bridge between psychotherapeutic process and symptom in the resulting model case wise interpretation of bridge centrality value are offered result bridge centrality analysis revealed individual bridge node between intersession process and symptom severity strength and direction of bridge varied substantially across individual conclusion given current methodological challenge idiographic network study are feasible and offer important insight for psychotherapy process research in this case we demonstrated how patient deal with period of increased symptom stress in this case we have described how patient deal with their therapy under increased symptom load bridge between psychotherapeutic process and symptom stress are a promising target for monitoring system based on isp future study should examine the clinical utility of network based monitoring and feedback in ongoing therapy in the near future process feedback system based on idiographic model could serve clinician to improve treatment

Title: Physical activity, mental and physical health during the Covid-19 outbreak: longitudinal predictors of suicide ideation in Germany
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Truskauskaite-Kuneviciene, I.; Kazlauskas, E.; Gelezelyte, O.; Teismann, T.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: aim suicide ideation ha increased since the outbreak of covid 19 in many country the present longitudinal study investigated potential predictor of suicide ideation subject and method data of 406 participant from germany age m 27 69 sd 6 88 were assessed via online survey in spring 2020 baseline bl and in spring 2021 follow up fu result the current result reveal a significant increase in symptom of depression anxiety and stress between 2020 and 2021 positive mental health pmh sense of control and physical health significantly decreased depression symptom bl pmh bl and consciously enhanced physical activity since the pandemic outbreak fu significantly predicted 12 month suicide ideation fu in a moderated mediation analysis the positive relationship between depression and suicide ideation wa significantly mediated by pmh consciously enhanced physical activity significantly moderated the negative association between pmh and suicide ideation conclusion the context of covid 19 could negatively impact mental health and physical health this might increase the risk for suicide ideation however pmh and physical activity might serve a protective factor the protective effect of physical activity could be especially important in people with high depression symptom and low pmh such a clinical patient potential way of how pmh and physical activity could be enhanced in the covid 19 context to prevent suicide ideation are discussed

Title: Experimental longitudinal evidence for causal role of social media use and physical activity in COVID-19 burden and mental health
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Swarlik, V. J.; Grethe, G. A.; Schillack, H.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: aim the covid 19 outbreak ha severely impacted people s mental health the present experimental study investigated how to reduce this negative effect by a combination of two intervention subject and method participant n total 642 were user of social medium in germany for two week the social medium group n 162 reduced it social medium use smu by 30 minute daily the physical activity group n 161 increased it physical activity by 30 minute daily the combination group n 159 followed both instruction and the control group n 160 did not get specific instruction online survey assessed variable of smu physical activity mental health covid 19 burden and lifestyle at six measurement time point up to six month after the intervention result in the experimental group addictive smu depression symptom and covid 19 burden decreased while physical activity life satisfaction and subjective happiness increased all effect were stronger and more stable in the combination group in the longer term smoking behavior decreased in the social medium group only conclusion thus the conscious combination of le smu and more physical activity lead causally to more psychological resilience against negative pandemic impact and to higher level of mental health over six month prevention program could improve their effectiveness by integrating the time and cost efficient intervention separately or in combination supplementary information the online version contains supplementary material available at 10 1007 s10389 022 01751 x

Title: Eating problems in young children -- a population-based study
Authors: Equit, M.; Palmke, M.; Becker, N.; Moritz, A. M.; Becker, S.; von Gontard, A.
Abstract: aim to analyse the prevalence of atypical eating problem and their association with anxious or oppositional behaviour in young child method one thousand and ninety child examined in the school enrolment test in a defined geographical region were included 544 boy the parent completed a 25 item questionnaire regarding their child s eating behaviour and anxious or oppositional behaviour result half of the parent reported that their child avoids certain food 53 twenty three percent showed selective eating 26 showed an aversion against new food child with underweight avoided more type of food and ate smaller amount than child with normal or overweight three group could be differentiated sixty one percent of the child were normal eater with avoidance of certain food normal weight status and low anxious or oppositional behaviour thirty four percent showed selective and or restrictive eating and 5 worried about their weight child with selective eating and with weight concern were more often affected by anxious and oppositional behaviour conclusion atypical eating problem are common in young child without accompanying weight loss behavioural or emotional problem selective eating should be seen a a normal feature in young eating behaviour parent of young child with selective restrictive eating or with weight worrying and psychological problem should be offered advice treatment

Title: Assessing Diabetes Self-Management with the Diabetes Self-Management Questionnaire (DSMQ) Can Help Analyse Behavioural Problems Related to Reduced Glycaemic Control
Authors: Schmitt, A.; Reimer, A.; Hermanns, N.; Huber, J.; Ehrmann, D.; Schall, S.; Kulzer, B.
Abstract: aim to appraise the diabetes self management questionnaire dsmq s measurement of diabetes self management a a statistical predictor of glycaemic control relative to the widely used sdsca method 248 patient with type 1 diabetes and 182 patient with type 2 diabetes were cross sectionally assessed using the two self report measure of diabetes self management dsmq and sdsca the scale were used a competing predictor of hba1c we developed a structural equation model of self management a measured by the dsmq and analysed the amount of variation explained in hba1c an analogue model wa developed for the sdsca result the structural equation model of self management and glycaemic control showed very good fit to the data the dsmq s measurement of self management showed association with hba1c of 0 53 for type 1 and 0 46 for type 2 diabetes both p 0 001 explaining 21 and 28 of variation in glycaemic control respectively the sdsca s measurement showed association with hba1c of 0 14 p 0 030 for type 1 and 0 31 p 0 003 for type 2 diabetes explaining 2 and 10 of glycaemic variation predictive power for glycaemic control wa significantly higher for the dsmq p 0 001 conclusion this study support the dsmq a the preferred tool when analysing self reported behavioural problem related to reduced glycaemic control the scale may be useful for clinical assessment of patient with suboptimal diabetes outcome or research on factor affecting association between self management behaviour and glycaemic control

Title: Mental Strain and Chronic Stress among University Students with Symptoms of Irritable Bowel Syndrome
Authors: Gulewitsch, M. D.; Enck, P.; Schwille-Kiuntke, J.; Weimer, K.; Schlarb, A. A.
Abstract: aim to investigate the degree of mental strain and chronic stress in a german community sample of student with ibs like symptom method and material following an internet based survey about stress this study recruited 176 german university student 23 45 2 48 year 48 3 male with ibs like symptom according to rome iii and 181 student without ibs 23 55 2 82 year 50 3 male and compared them regarding current mental strain scl 90 r and the extend of chronic stress beyond this ibs subtypes ibs severity and health care utilization were assessed result student fulfilling ibs criterion showed significantly elevated value of mental strain and chronic stress nearly 40 of the ibs group versus 20 of the control reached a clinically relevant value on the scl 90 r global severity scale ibs subtypes did not differ in term of mental distress or chronic stress somatization anxiety and the chronic stressor work overload social tension and dissatisfaction with job were most closely connected to ibs symptom severity regarding health care utilization our result show that consulting a physician frequently wa not associated significantly with elevated mental strain or chronic stress but with ibs symptom severity conclusion our data contribute additional evidence to the distinct association between psychological stress and ibs in community sample

Title: Working memory for pitch, timbre, and words
Authors: Schulze, K.; Tillmann, B.
Abstract: aiming to further our understanding of fundamental mechanism of auditory working memory wm the present study compared performance for three auditory material word tone timbre in a forward recognition task experiment 1 participant indicated whether the order of the item in the second sequence wa the same a in the first sequence in a backward recognition task experiment 2 participant indicated whether the item of the second sequence were played in the correct backward order in experiment 3 participant performed an articulatory suppression task during the retention delay of the backward task to investigate potential length effect the number of item per sequence wa manipulated overall finding underline the benefit of a cross material experimental approach and suggest that human auditory wm is not a unitary system whereas wm process for timbre differed from those for tone and word similarity and difference were observed for word and tone both type of stimulus appear to rely on rehearsal mechanism but might differ in the involved sensorimotor code

Title: Is it a Case of "Work-Anxiety" When Patients Report Bad Workplace Characteristics and Low Work Ability?
Authors: Muschalla, B.
Abstract: aim work anxiety may produce overly negative view of the workplace that impair provider effort to a work ability from patient self report this study explores the empirical relationship between patient reported workplace characteristic work anxiety and subjective and objective work ability measure method 125 patient in medical rehabilitation before vocational reintegration were interviewed concerning their vocational situation and filled in a questionnaire on work anxiety subjective mental work ability and perceived workplace characteristic treating physician gave independent socio medical judgment concerning the patient work ability and impairment and need for supportive mean for vocational reintegration result patient with high work anxiety reported more negative workplace characteristic low judgment of work ability were correlated with problematic workplace characteristic when controlled for work anxiety subjective work ability remained related only with social workplace characteristic and with work achievement demand but independent from situational or task characteristic sick leave duration and physician judgment of work ability were not significantly related to patient reported workplace characteristic conclusion in socio medical work ability assessment patient with high work anxiety may over report negative workplace characteristic that can confound provider estimate of work ability assessing work anxiety may be important to a readiness for returning to work and initiating work directed treatment

Title: Elimination disorders in persons with Prader-Willi and Fragile-X syndromes
Authors: Equit, M.; Piro-Hussong, A.; Niemczyk, J.; Curfs, L.; von Gontard, A.
Abstract: aim elimination disorder are common in typically developing child only few study have addressed elimination disorder in person with intellectual disability id and even fewer study in those with specific syndrome the aim of the study wa to investigate the rate of elimination disorder and behavioral symptom in person with prader willi pws and fragile x syndrome fxs in a large sample method three hundred fifty seven person with pws or fxs were recruited through parent self help group a questionnaire regarding elimination symptom a well a the child behavior checklist cbcl young adult behavior checklist yabcl were filled out by parent or caregiver result the sample included 191 person with pws 54 5 male with a mean age of 20 0 year and 166 person with fxs 92 2 male with a mean age of 15 4 year person with fxs were significantly more often affected by elimination disorder 29 3 of person with pws and 48 8 of person with fxs had at least one elimination disorder person with fxs also had more often duo 29 5 v 12 0 and fi 28 9 v 12 6 rate of ne were similar in both group 22 0 in pws v 28 9 in fxs young adult with pws had more behavioral symptom in the clinical range 70 8 v 48 3 incontinence and behavioral symptom were significantly associated in person with fxs conclusion ne duo and fi are very common in person with fxs and pws and are associated with other behavioral symptom in person with fxs they persist into adulthood early assessment and treatment are recommended

Title: Reduction of depressive symptoms predicts improved glycaemic control: Secondary results from the DIAMOS study
Authors: Schmitt, A.; Reimer, A.; Ehrmann, D.; Kulzer, B.; Haak, T.; Hermanns, N.
Abstract: aim evidence from randomised trial analysing effect of depression treatment on glycaemic control in group comparison is inconsistent the aim of this study wa to test if the reduction of depressive symptom would explain improved glycaemic control irrespective of treatment group method the diamos study tested effect of cognitive behavioural therapy cbt versus usual care on depressive symptom in a 12 month prospective trial hba 1c wa a secondary outcome since the result suggested superiority of cbt for improving depressive symptom but not hba 1c we conducted this secondary analysis to test if reduction of depressive symptom could explain improved glycaemic control when assessed irrespective of treatment group affiliation reduction of depressive symptom wa assessed using baseline to follow up change in the center for epidemiologic study depression scale ce d we used multiple regression analysis adjusting for baseline hba 1c and depression group affiliation and covariates to a association between reduction of depressive symptom and follow up hba 1c result 181 participant provided eligible data depressive symptom decreased between baseline and follow up by averagely 5 1 11 8 ce d point greater reduction of depressive symptom predicted greater improvement of hba 1c at follow up while adjusting for baseline hba 1c and covariates beta 0 24 p 0 004 additionally patient with greater reduction of depressive symptom were more likely to reach in target hba 1c 7 5 at follow up adjusted or 1 04 95 ci 1 01 1 08 p 0 023 conclusion the finding suggest that reduction of depressive symptom can explain improved glycaemic control behavioural treatment might aim to improve both affective and glycaemic outcome

Title: Levels of personality functioning and not depression predict decline of plasma glucose concentration in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus
Authors: Ehrenthal, J. C.; Dux, A.; Baie, L.; Burgmer, M.
Abstract: aim psychosocial variable influence chronic disease such a type 2 diabetes mellitus while there is evidence for a negative impact of depression much le is known about stable personality oriented factor aim of the study wa to a the impact of depression and personality functioning on glucose regulation in patient with type 2 diabetes method seventy five adult individual with a first diagnosis of type 2 diabetes were consecutively recruited in an outpatient medical practice plasma glucose hba1c wa measured at initial contact and after three and six month of a standardized disease management program depression wa assessed by self report patient health questionnaire phq d level of personality functioning with the screening version of the operationalized psychodynamic diagnosis structure questionnaire opd sqs result using mixed regression model opd sqs score were associated with lower baseline level of hba1c but a le steep decline over time phq d score were neither associated with intercept nor with slope of hba1c conclusion in type 2 diabetes level of personality functioning but not depression predicted decline in plasma glucose during the first six month of a standardized disease management program personality functioning may be especially important in chronic disease that demand a high level of compliance and lifestyle change

Title: Impact of an acceptance facilitating intervention on diabetes patients' acceptance of Internet-based interventions for depression: a randomized controlled trial
Authors: Baumeister, H.; Nowoczin, L.; Lin, J.; Seifferth, H.; Seufert, J.; Laubner, K.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: aim to 1 determine diabetes patient acceptance of internet based intervention ibis for depression to 2 examine the effectiveness of an acceptance facilitating intervention afi and to 3 explore subgroup specific effect method 141 diabetes patient from two inpatient rehabilitation unit and one outpatient clinic in germany were randomly allocated to an intervention ig and a no intervention control group cg the ig received an afi consisting of a personal information session before filling out a questionnaire on patient acceptance of ibis predictor of acceptance performance expectancy effort expectancy social influence facilitating condition and internet anxiety a well a sociodemographic depression related and diabetes related variable the cg filled out the questionnaire immediately patient acceptance of ibis wa measured with a four item scale sum score ranging from 4 to 20 result the cg showed a low 50 7 to medium 40 8 acceptance with only 8 5 of all diabetes patient reporting a high acceptance of ibis for depression the afi had no significant effect on acceptance ig m 10 55 sd 4 69 n 70 kg m 9 65 sd 4 27 n 71 d 0 20 95 ci 0 13 0 53 and the predictor of acceptance yet subgroup analysis yielded a trend for depressed diabetes related distressed female and younger 59 participant and for those who do not frequently use the internet to profit from the afi conclusion diabetes patient show a rather low acceptance toward ibis for depression finding indicate that the afi is likely to be effective in the subgroup of depressed diabetes related distressed female or younger diabetes patient but not in the whole target population hence afis might need to be tailored to the specific need of subpopulation

Title: Reducing problematic alcohol use in employees: economic evaluation of guided and unguided web-based interventions alongside a three-arm randomized controlled trial
