Authors: Buntrock, C.; Freund, J.; Smit, F.; Riper, H.; Lehr, D.; Boss, L.; Berking, M.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: aim to perform an economic evaluation of guided and unguided internet based intervention to reduce problematic alcohol consumption in employee compared with a waiting list control condition wlc with unrestricted access to treatment a usual design a cost effectiveness analysis cea and cost utility analysis cua from a societal and a cost benefit analysis from the employer s perspective with a 6 month time horizon setting open recruitment in the german working population participant employee 178 male 256 female mean age 47 year consuming at least 14 woman or 21 men standard unit of alcohol suas per week and scoring 8 men or 6 woman on the alcohol use disorder identification test measurement on line questionnaire administered to a suas and a quality of life aqol 8d and resource use outcome measure wa responder 14 21 suas for the cea and quality adjusted life year qalys for the cua net benefit regression wa used to estimate cost effectiveness for each study arm bootstrapping and sensitivity analysis were performed to account for uncertainty intervention five weekly module including personalized normative feedback motivational interviewing goal setting problem solving and emotion regulation provided with adherence focused guidance n 142 responder n 73 51 4 qalys 0 364 standard error se 0 006 or without guidance n 146 n 66 45 2 0 359 0 007 control were on a waiting list n 144 n 38 26 4 0 342 0 007 finding from a societal perspective the guided intervention had a probability of 55 54 of being the most efficient strategy at a willingness to pay wtp of euro0 per responder qaly gained compared with the unguided intervention and the control condition at a wtp of euro20 000 per qaly gained the probability wa 78 from an employer s perspective the guided intervention had a higher probability of a positive return on investment 81 compared with the unguided intervention 58 conclusion a guided internet based intervention to reduce problematic alcohol consumption in employee appears to be both cost beneficial and cost effective

Title: The impact of negative treatment experiences on persistent refusal of antipsychotics
Authors: Lincoln, T. M.; Jung, E.; Wiesjahn, M.; Wendt, H.; Bock, T.; Schlier, B.
Abstract: aim we investigate reason for persistent medication refusal in schizophrenia spectrum disorder and test whether factor that speak for a rational decision such a negative experience with medication or low symptom distress predict medication refusal even after taking difference in insight into account method we included 45 participant with schizophrenia spectrum disorder of which 20 had refused antipsychotic medication for at least three month and assessed reason for taking or not taking medication labeling condition a mental disorder insight experience with the previous treatment symptom and symptom distress positive and negative consequence and experience of psychosis causal belief therapeutic relationship with previous clinician and attitude towards medication result group did not differ in symptom severity but medication refusers reported significantly le insight le satisfaction with their most recent psychiatrist and with previous medication and more negative belief about harmful effect of medication they also felt le informed about medication after controlling for insight the perceived helpfulness of the previous treating psychiatrist or 0 30 z 5 58 p 0 018 and of previous medication or 0 27 z 6 87 p 0 009 and feeling insufficiently informed about medication or 0 53 z 3 85 p 0 050 significantly predicted medication discontinuation conclusion building rapport with patient with a different view of the nature of their condition and encouraging informed decision on medication are likely to improve medication adherence however the finding also suggest that refusing medication after a phase of initial adherence is also the consequence of negative experience with medication and could result from weighing the pro against the con

Title: Alexithymia increases effects of ego-depletion
Authors: Schnabel, K.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: alexithymia is associated with deficiency to identify describe and express emotion paucity of fantasy and an externally oriented cognitive style the current study provide evidence that alexithymia is also related to self regulation process and exacerbates effect of ego depletion a state where self regulation resource are reduced due to previous act of self regulation in study 1 ego depletion effect of a handgrip task on pain tolerance were increased by alexithymia in study 2 an emotion suppression task showed stronger effect of ego depletion on a stroop task in participant high rather than low in alexithymia but only after suppression of emotion induced by negative and not positive picture the result imply that alexithymia increase susceptibility to ego depletion effect that consumption of self regulatory resource ha stronger consequence for people high in alexithymia and that they should experience special support in way to replenish self regulation resource

Title: Polygenic risk for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) predicts brain response during working memory task in OCD, unaffected relatives, and healthy controls
Authors: Heinzel, S.; Kaufmann, C.; Grutzmann, R.; Klawohn, J.; Riesel, A.; Bey, K.; Heilmann-Heimbach, S.; Weinhold, L.; Ramirez, A.; Wagner, M.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: alteration in frontal and parietal neural activation during working memory task performance have been suggested a a candidate endophenotype of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd in study involving first degree relative however the direct link between genetic risk for ocd and neuro functional alteration during working memory performance ha not been investigated to date thus the aim of the current functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri study wa to test the direct association between polygenic risk for ocd and neural activity during the performance of a numeric n back task with four working memory load condition in 128 participant including patient with ocd unaffected first degree relative of ocd patient and healthy control behavioral result show a significant performance deficit at high working memory load in both patient with ocd and first degree relative p 0 05 a whole brain analysis of the fmri data indicated decreased neural activity in bilateral inferior parietal lobule and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in both patient and relative most importantly ocd polygenic risk score predicted neural activity in orbitofrontal cortex result indicate that genetic risk for ocd can partly explain alteration in brain response during working memory performance supporting the notion of a neuro functional endophenotype for ocd

Title: Differentiating aversive conditioning in bistable perception: Avoidance of a percept vs. salience of a stimulus
Authors: Wilbertz, G.; Sterzer, P.
Abstract: alternating conscious visual perception of bistable stimulus is influenced by several factor in order to understand the effect of negative valence we tested the effect of two type of aversive conditioning on dominance duration in binocular rivalry participant received either aversive classical conditioning of the stimulus shown alone between rivalry block or aversive percept conditioning of one of the two possible perceptual choice during rivalry both group showed successful aversive conditioning according to skin conductance response and affective valence rating however while classical conditioning led to an immediate but short lived increase in dominance duration of the conditioned stimulus percept conditioning yielded no significant immediate effect but tended to decrease duration of the conditioned percept during extinction these result show dissociable effect of value learning on perceptual inference in situation of perceptual conflict depending on whether learning relates to the decision between conflicting perceptual choice or the sensory stimulus per se

Title: Increased salivation to mirror exposure in women with binge eating disorder
Authors: Naumann, E.; Trentowska, M.; Svaldi, J.
Abstract: although body image disturbance are not a diagnostic criterion of the binge eating disorder bed intervention study yield evidence of it importance in the maintenance of the disorder therefore the aim of the present study wa to experimentally test the influence of body related schema in the occurrence of appetite in individual with bed after collecting baseline saliva woman with bed and weight matched control cg were either given a food exposure fe or mirror exposure me while participant salivary reaction wa assessed once more in addition participant repeatedly rated their actual desire to binge dtb and emotion main result reveal a significant salivation and dtb increase in the fe compared to the baseline condition in both group however only in bed participant salivation and dtb increase were significantly higher in the me compared to the baseline condition the result support the importance of body image for the maintenance of bed

Title: Neural correlates of body image processing in binge eating disorder
Authors: Press, S. A.; Biehl, S. C.; Vatheuer, C. C.; Domes, G.; Svaldi, J.
Abstract: although body image disturbance play a central role in the development maintenance and relapse of binge eating disorder bed study investigating the neural basis underlying body processing in bed are still missing to address this gap we conducted a preregistered german clinical trial register deutsches register klinischer studien drks registration drks00008107 combined functional magnetic resonance fmri eye tracking study in which 38 woman with bed and 22 healthy control weight matched for overall equivalence processed image of their own body an unfamiliar weight matched body and visually matched nonbody control stimulus while performing a one back task woman with bed responded with higher left fusiform body area fba activity than control during body image processing despite higher level of self reported body dissatisfaction woman with bed did not show overactivation in emotion processing area in response to their own body the eye tracking result indicated that visual attention toward the presented stimulus wa associated with increased activity in the extrastriate body area eba and fba across group our result thus provide evidence for an aberrant neural processing of body image in bed and highlight the importance of controlling for visual attention in future study assessing neuronal body processing psycinfo database record c 2022 apa all right reserved

Title: Differences in perceptual memory determine generalization patterns
Authors: Zenses, A. K.; Lee, J. C.; Plaisance, V.; Zaman, J.
Abstract: although memory of past experience is crucial for the ability to transfer knowledge to new situation surprisingly little research ha directly investigated the relationship between memory and generalization the present study sought to investigate how the perceptual memory of a trained stimulus influence generalization to similar stimulus forty participant underwent a fear conditioning procedure on day 1 and separate memory recall and generalization test on day 2 we focused on two aspect of perceptual memory namely memory bias i e over or underestimation of stimulus magnitude and uncertainty we found that memory bias predicted the pattern of generalized self reported expectancy rating and psychophysiological response fear potentiated startle response memory uncertainty wa measured in two way self reported uncertainty rating and variability in stimulus recall we found that higher level of self reported memory uncertainty corresponded with a broader generalization gradient on u expectancy while greater variability in memory recall wa associated with a broader generalization gradient on fear potentiated startle response taken together our finding suggest that memory is an important determinant of generalized behavior and illustrate the need to account for these interindividual difference in perceptual memory when examining the generalization of learned response

Title: Towards a mechanistic understanding of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) using an RCT neuroimaging approach: Effects on regulating own stress in social and non-social situations
Authors: Guendelman, S.; Bayer, M.; Prehn, K.; Dziobek, I.
Abstract: although much research ha shown that mindfulness based intervention mbis can reduce psychological stress it is le clear if effect generalize to everyday social situation which range among the largest stress trigger furthermore mechanism of mbis have not been fully established emotion regulation er ha been suggested a one key mechanism yet the role of cognitive reappraisal and acceptance strategy is still under debate to address these question a neuroimaging based randomized controlled trial rct wa performed n 68 comparing mindfulness based stress reduction mbsr with a reading listening intervention read using a novel dyadic paradigm for self and other emotion regulation under stress a primary outcome on behavior and brain level and established empathy measure clinicatrials gov nct03035669 compared to read mbsr led to self reported stress reduction through both cognitive reappraisal and acceptance only when regulating self and not when regulating others distress in addition mbsr led to increased brain activation over time for regulating own parietal cortex and others precuneus tpj emotion through cognitive reappraisal and acceptance albeit this effect wa also seen for the reading intervention for regulating own stress via reappraisal brain change did not scale with subjective stress reduction and amount of meditation practice more distant generalization effect of mbsr on socio emotional functioning cognitive empathy and compassion could also not be shown this study identified both cognitive reappraisal and acceptance a two er mechanism of mbsr but indicates that effect do not extend to social setting

Title: Body-oriented gaze behaviors in men with muscle dysmorphia diagnoses
Authors: Waldorf, M.; Vocks, S.; Dusing, R.; Bauer, A.; Cordes, M.
Abstract: although muscle dysmorphia md ha been added a a specifier for body dysmorphic disorder in the 5th edition of the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder experimental research on psychopathological mechanism is lacking because model of eating disorder ed suggest parallel between md and ed body oriented attentional bias which are prominent in ed model have been identified a potentially important maintaining factor specifically we predicted the existence of bias toward subjectively negative area of one s own body and positive area of a bodybuilder in md we tracked gaze behavior of 24 men with md diagnosis 24 weight training control and 24 non weight training control during exposure to picture of their own body an average male body a lean muscular body and a hypermuscular body moreover state body image and affect were assessed at baseline and after each stimulus partially supporting our hypothesis men with md diagnosis and non weight training control but not weight training control displayed significant bias toward subjectively negative area of their own body only men with md diagnosis displayed bias toward positive area of the hypermuscular body and reacted with a large significant deterioration in state body image and affect attentional bias possibly contribute to the negative effect of critical examination of one s body and of upward comparison there seems to be a specific positive bias toward subjectively ideal hypermuscular body in md in conjunction with a negative bias toward oneself insofar a this pattern might maintain the severe muscularity dissatisfaction it should be explicitly targeted by cognitive behavioral intervention psycinfo database record c 2019 apa all right reserved

Title: Positive Emotion Dysregulation in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder
Authors: Wolkenstein, L.; Sommerhoff, A.; Voss, M.
Abstract: although ptsd is associated with both emotion regulation er difficulty and persistent difficulty experiencing positive emotion research concerning positive er in ptsd is still scarce we aimed to clarify whether ptsd patient show dysfunctional response to positive emotion and whether positive er is associated with ptsd symptom severity ptsd patient n 59 were compared to healthy control hc n 58 with respect to their self reported regulation of positive and negative emotion we used the response to positive affect questionnaire to a positive er and the difficulty in emotion regulation scale and response style questionnaire to a negative er ptsd patient showed deficient negative a well a deficient positive er a compared to hc both dampening of positive emotion a well a positive rumination were associated with self reported symptom severity furthermore dampening contributed to the prediction of ptsd symptom severity beyond depressive symptom and negative rumination this study support and expands previous finding of dysfunctional positive er in ptsd further research is needed to clarify whether deficit in positive er contribute to the onset and maintenance of ptsd if so therapeutic approach should aim to help ptsd patient build up adequate skill to handle positive emotion in ptsd

Title: Startle eye-blink modulation by facial self-resemblance and current mood
Authors: Finke, J. B.; Larra, M. F.; Schilling, T. M.; Lass-Hennemann, J.; Blumenthal, T. D.; Schachinger, H.
Abstract: although salient stimulus are known to modulate startle eye blink response and one s own face is considered of particular salience effect of facial self resemblance on startle responsiveness have not been systematically investigated for the present study picture from the face database rated a neutral were digitally morphed to resemble the participant n 37 face to varying degree 25 50 75 perceptually matched geometrical shape served a a control condition at soas of either 300ms or 3000ms after picture onset startle response were elicited by white noise 50ms 105db and recorded at the orbicularis oculus via emg prior to the experiment self reported mood wa assessed by mean of the panas relative to non face stimulus the presentation of face reduced startle magnitude at short but not long lead interval furthermore for probe presented at a soa of 300ms a linear decrease in startle magnitude with higher level of self resemblance wa observed presumably reflecting higher salience of the self face the startle modulating effect of self resembling face during longer lead interval wa moderated by the participant current mood negative affect predicted stronger pattern of attenuation which might be interpreted a an increase in self focus resulting from more negative mood

Title: The motive to drink due to social anxiety and its relation to hazardous alcohol use
Authors: Cludius, B.; Stevens, S.; Bantin, T.; Gerlach, A. L.; Hermann, C.
Abstract: although study on social anxiety and alcohol related problem are numerous the exact nature of the relationship remains unclear in the present study we investigate how the motive to drink due to social anxiety is associated with hazardous alcohol use over and above habitual alcohol use social anxiety and alcohol outcome expectancy we also examine which factor define the motive to drink due to social anxiety and clarify the impact of the type of social situation drinking due to social anxiety habitual alcohol use and gender but not social anxiety were associated with hazardous alcohol use social anxiety increased the motive to drink due to social anxiety but fear of cognitive performance deficit after drinking reduced it alcohol wa used to reduce anxiety more frequently in situation where intake of alcohol is deemed socially acceptable these finding suggest that the motive drinking due to social anxiety not social anxiety per se is related to hazardous alcohol use the motive is weakened by the expectation of alcohol induced cognitive deficit a well a by the type of social situation in which alcohol is to be used

Title: Neural signature of delayed fear generalization under stress
Authors: Kausche, F. M.; Zerbes, G.; Kampermann, L.; Buchel, C.; Schwabe, L.
Abstract: although the generalization of fear to stimulus resembling a threatening stimulus is an adaptive mechanism fear overgeneralization is maladaptive and thought to play a key role in anxiety related disorder since there is typically a delay between an initial fear experience and a situation in which fear over generalization may occur we assessed delayed fear generalization and it neural signature moreover a stress is known to affect fear learning we further tested whether acute stress modulates fear generalization therefore we conducted a two day fear generalization study with initial fear acquisition on day 1 and a fear generalization test after a 24 hr delay in the mri scanner prior to fear generalization testing participant were exposed to a stressor or a control manipulation our behavioral data showed the expected generalization of fear at a neural level fear generalization wa accompanied by increased fear signaling for stimulus that resembled the conditioned stimulus in the bilateral insula and frontal operculum whereas activity declined in frontal hippocampal and temporal region including the ventromedial prefrontal cortex a stimulus became more similar to the conditioned stimulus importantly stress did not modulate fear generalization neither on a behavioral nor on a neural level interestingly in an explorative comparison to two other study that used the same paradigm but tested generalization immediately after acquisition we observed increased fear generalization in the delayed relative to the immediate generalization test in sum our result suggest that stress leaf fear generalization and it neural signature unaffected but that a temporal delay might increase the extent to which fear response are generalized to stimulus resembling the threatening stimulus

Title: Hair androgen concentrations and depressive disorders in adolescents from the general population
Authors: Kische, H.; Voss, C.; Haring, R.; Ollmann, T. M.; Pieper, L.; Kirschbaum, C.; Beesdo-Baum, K.
Abstract: although the link between androgen and depression is well established in adult the effect of cofactor on this association are le clearly understood particularly in youth epidemiological cohort study of adolescent in dresden germany analysis comprised data of 985 individual assessed at baseline and of 512 individual at 1 year follow up we investigated multivariable regression model for cross sectional and longitudinal association of hair testosterone dehydroepiandrosterone dhea and their cortisol ratio with 12 month diagnosis of major depressive disorder mdd and mdd without any anxiety disorder assessed with standardized diagnostic interview dia x 5 and with dimensional depression score phq 9 promis separately for male and female the potential moderating effect of social support wa determined cross sectional analysis yielded inverse association of testosterone and dhea with mdd and mdd without any anxiety disorder in male in cross sectional and longitudinal analysis baseline ratio cortisol dhea wa significantly inversely associated to promis depression in male only cross sectional association for ratio cortisol dhea and promis depression remained significant after bonferroni holm correction no robust association were observed in female participant social support exerted no consistent moderating effect on the investigated association the present observational cohort study showed no consistent association of hair androgen concentration with depressive disorder in adolescent however finding provide some support for the association between the cortisol dhea ratio and depression in male longitudinal research design in large sample are needed to understand the interplay between androgen depression and developmental and social factor in youth

Title: Polygenic Heterogeneity Across Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder Subgroups Defined by a Comorbid Diagnosis
Authors: Strom, N. I.; Grove, J.; Meier, S. M.; Baekvad-Hansen, M.; Becker Nissen, J.; Damm Als, T.; Halvorsen, M.; Nordentoft, M.; Mortensen, P. B.; Hougaard, D. M.; Werge, T.; Mors, O.; Borglum, A. D.; Crowley, J. J.; Bybjerg-Grauholm, J.; Mattheisen, M.
Abstract: among patient with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd 65 85 manifest another psychiatric disorder concomitantly or at some other time point during their life ocd is highly heritable a are many of it comorbidities a possible genetic heterogeneity of ocd in relation to it comorbid condition however ha not yet been exhaustively explored we used a framework of different approach to study the genetic relationship of ocd with three commonly observed comorbidities namely major depressive disorder mdd attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd and autism spectrum disorder asd first using publicly available summary statistic from large scale genome wide association study we compared genetic correlation pattern for ocd mdd adhd and asd with 861 somatic and mental health phenotype secondly we examined how polygenic risk score pr of eight trait that showed heterogeneous correlation pattern with ocd mdd adhd and asd partitioned across comorbid subgroup in ocd using independent unpublished data from the lundbeck foundation initiative for integrative psychiatric research ipsych the comorbid subgroup comprised of patient with only ocd n 366 ocd and mdd n 1 052 ocd and adhd n 443 ocd and asd n 388 and ocd with more than 1 comorbidity n 429 we found that pr of all trait but bmi were significantly associated with ocd across all subgroup neuroticism p 1 19 x 10 32 bipolar disorder p 7 51 x 10 8 anorexia nervosa p 3 52 x 10 20 age at first birth p 9 38 x 10 5 educational attainment p 1 56 x 10 4 ocd p 1 87 x 10 6 insomnia p 2 61 x 10 5 bmi p 0 15 for age at first birth educational attainment and insomnia pr estimate significantly differed across comorbid subgroup p 2 29 x 10 4 p 1 63 x 10 4 and p 0 045 respectively especially for anorexia nervosa age at first birth educational attainment insomnia and neuroticism the correlation pattern that emerged from genetic correlation analysis of ocd mdd adhd and asd were mirrored in the pr association with the respective comorbid ocd group dissecting the polygenic architecture we found both quantitative and qualitative polygenic heterogeneity across ocd comorbid subgroup

Title: Preventing maltreatment in institutional care: A cluster-randomized controlled trial in East Africa
Authors: Hecker, T.; Mkinga, G.; Kirika, A.; Nkuba, M.; Preston, J.; Hermenau, K.
Abstract: an increasing number of orphan in low and middle income country are living in institutional care facility where they experience poor quality of care and ongoing maltreatment to prevent maltreatment we tested the effectiveness and feasibility of the intervention interaction competency with child for caregiver icc c in a two arm cluster randomized controlled trial 203 caregiver 65 5 female m age 36 63 year sd age 12 26 and 356 child 46 1 female m age 9 43 year sd age 1 93 from 24 orphanage in dar e salaam tanzania participated from august to october 2018 baseline and march to april 2019 follow up orphanage were assigned to the intervention or waitlist group caregiver in the intervention group received the icc c intervention to prevent maltreatment through focusing on non violent caregiving strategy the primary outcome wa the change in self reported maltreatment by caregiver conflict tactic scale trial registration clinicaltrials gov nct03594617 20 july 2018 participation in the intervention resulted in a significant reduction in reported maltreatment f 2 0 153 a decrease of positive attitude toward violent discipline f 2 0 248 and an increased level of childcare knowledge f 2 0 220 in the caregiver sample each indicating a moderate effect caregiver training participation did not predict reduced maltreatment reported by child aspect of feasibility including motivation to participate acceptability and integration of the new strategy were evaluated positively the study promise initial effectiveness and feasibility of effort to improve the situation of child in institutional care setting in resource poor country by offering training to care provider

Title: Gender differences in episodic memory and visual working memory including the effects of age
Authors: Pauls, F.; Petermann, F.; Lepach, A. C.
Abstract: analysing the relationship between gender and memory and examining the effect of age on the overall memory related functioning are the ongoing goal of psychological research the present study examined gender and age group difference in episodic memory with respect to the type of task in addition these subgroup difference were also analysed in visual working memory a sample of 366 woman and 330 men aged between 16 and 69 year of age participated in the current study result indicate that woman outperformed men on auditory memory task whereas male adolescent and older male adult showed higher level performance on visual episodic and visual working memory measure however the size of gender linked effect varied somewhat across age group furthermore result partly support a declining performance on episodic memory and visual working memory measure with increasing age although age related loss in episodic memory could not be explained by a decreasing verbal and visuospatial ability with age woman s advantage in auditory episodic memory could be explained by their advantage in verbal ability men s higher level visual episodic memory performance wa found to result from their advantage in visuospatial ability finally possible methodological biological and cognitive explanation for the current finding are discussed

Title: Effects of context preexposure and delay until anxiety retrieval on generalization of contextual anxiety
Authors: Andreatta, M.; Neueder, D.; Glotzbach-Schoon, E.; Muhlberger, A.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: animal study suggest that time delay between acquisition and retrieval of contextual anxiety increase generalization moreover such generalization is prevented by preexposure to the context ctx presumably due to an improved representation of such context we investigated whether preexposure and time passing modulate generalization of contextual anxiety in human on day 1 42 participant preexposure group explored two virtual office while 41 participant no preexposure group explored a virtual stadium on day 2 24 h later all participant learned to associate one office ctx with unpredictable unconditioned stimulus u and another office ctx with safety on day 3 either 24 h recent test or 2 wk remote test later participant revisited ctx and ctx without u a well a a generalization context g ctx result revealed successfully conditioned anxiety and anxiety generalization for rating g ctx wa a aversive a ctx wa while safety generalization wa found for startle response g ctx elicited startle attenuation a ctx did time between learning and testing enhanced generalization a reflected by comparable startle response to all three office in the remote test contextual preexposure facilitated extinction of explicit conditioned anxiety assessed with rating these result suggest that memory trace of a context degrades with passage of time in human like in animal and consequently anxiety generalization enhances after context preexposure high cognitive process seem to be crucially involved in facilitating extinction or safety learning

Title: Therapy Dogs as a Crisis Intervention After Traumatic Events? - An Experimental Study
Authors: Lass-Hennemann, J.; Schafer, S. K.; Romer, S.; Holz, E.; Streb, M.; Michael, T.
Abstract: animal assisted therapy ha been proposed a a treatment adjunct for traumatized patient in animal assisted crisis response dog are used directly after a traumatic event to reduce stress and anxiety however to date there are few controlled study investigating the effect of therapy dog on ptsd symptom and to our knowledge there is no study investigating the effect of a therapy dog intervention directly after a traumatic event in this study 60 healthy female participant were randomly assigned to one of three group after exposure to a traumatic film clip trauma film paradigm one group of participant interacted with a friendly dog for 15 min another group of participant watched a film clip showing a person interacting with a friendly dog and the last group wa instructed to relax participant who had interacted with the dog after the film reported lower anxiety level le negative affect and more positive affect after the intervention a compared to the other two group however the participant who interacted with the dog showed a smaller decrease in physiological arousal after the traumatic film clip compared to both other group there were no difference in intrusion symptom between the three group our result show that dog are able to lessen subjectively experienced stress and anxiety after a traumatic stress situation

Title: Transcranial direct current stimulation improves clinical symptoms in adolescents with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
Authors: Soff, C.; Sotnikova, A.; Christiansen, H.; Becker, K.; Siniatchkin, M.
Abstract: anodal transcranial direct current stimulation tdcs of the prefrontal cortex ha repeatedly been shown to improve working memory a patient with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd are characterized by both underactivation of the prefrontal cortex and deficit in working memory that correlate with clinical symptom it is hypothesized that the modulation of prefrontal activity with tdcs in patient with adhd increase performance in working memory and reduces symptom of adhd to test this hypothesis fifteen adolescent with adhd 12 16 year old three girl and 12 boy were treated according to the randomized double blinded sham controlled crossover design with either 1 ma anodal tdcs over the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex or with the sham protocol 5 day each with a 2 week pause between these condition anodal tdcs caused a significant reduction in clinical symptom of inattention and impulsivity in adolescent with adhd compared to sham stimulation the clinical effect were supported by a significant reduction in inattention and hyperactivity in a standardized working memory test qbtest the described effect were more pronounced 7 day after the end of stimulation a fact which emphasizes the long lasting clinical and neuropsychological change after tdcs this study provides the first evidence that tdcs may reduce symptom of adhd and improve neuropsychological functioning in adolescent and point on the potential of tdcs a a form of treatment for adhd

Title: "I just don't look forward to anything". How anticipatory pleasure and negative beliefs contribute to goal-directed activity in patients with negative symptoms of psychosis
Authors: Pillny, M.; Schlier, B.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: anticipatory pleasure refers to a state of positive affect in anticipation of future event that ha been found to motivate goal directed behavior previous research ha indicated that patient with negative symptom of psychosis show reduced goal directed behavior because demotivating belief impede anticipatory pleasure this study aim to link demotivating belief and anticipatory pleasure to patient motivation in everyday life using the experience sampling method we examined the motivational process of goal directed activity in the daily life of 35 patient with negative symptom and 36 healthy control we tested whether the mechanism underlying goal directed behavior differs between patient and healthy control and whether demotivating belief interfere with goal directed behavior by impeding anticipatory pleasure multilevel analysis revealed that anticipatory pleasure mediated the association between goal intention and goal directed activity in both group indirect effect 24 30 in the patient group however the association between social goal intention and anticipatory pleasure wa weaker b 0 09 se 0 05 p 01 0 17 0 04 than in the control but this wa not found for goal intention related self care or recreational activites also demotivating belief were more pronounced in the patient sample f 1 70 72 11 p 001 and moderated the effect of goal intention on anticipatory pleasure for social activity in the whole sample b 0 12 se 0 05 p 01 0 20 0 08 our result support the assumption that a set of demotivating belief prevents patient with negative symptom from looking forward to social activity and thus provide a possible psychological explanation for the social withdrawal of patient with negative symptom

Title: Brain activity associated with illusory correlations in animal phobia
Authors: Wiemer, J.; Schulz, S. M.; Reicherts, P.; Glotzbach-Schoon, E.; Andreatta, M.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: anxiety disorder patient were repeatedly found to overestimate the association between disorder relevant stimulus and aversive outcome despite random contingency such an illusory correlation ic might play an important role in the return of fear after extinction learning yet little is known about how this cognitive bias emerges in the brain in a functional magnetic resonance imaging study 18 female patient with spider phobia and 18 healthy control were exposed to picture of spider mushroom and puppy followed randomly by either a painful electrical shock or nothing in advance both patient and healthy control expected more shock after spider picture importantly only patient with spider phobia continued to overestimate this association after the experiment the strength of this ic wa predicted by increased outcome aversiveness rating and primary sensory motor cortex activity in response to the shock after spider picture moreover increased activation of the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc to spider picture predicted the ic these result support the theory that phobia relevant stimulus amplify unpleasantness and sensory motor representation of aversive stimulus which in turn may promote their overestimation hyper activity in dlpfc possibly reflects a pre occupation of executive resource with phobia relevant stimulus thus complicating the accurate monitoring of objective contingency and the unlearning of fear

Title: Recognition memory, primacy vs. recency effects, and time perception in the online version of the fear of scream paradigm
Authors: Zlomuzica, A.; Kullmann, F.; Hesse, J.; Plank, L.; Dere, E.
Abstract: anxiety disorder are characterized by cognitive dysfunction which contribute to the patient s profound disability the threat of shock paradigm represents a validated psychopathological model of anxiety to measure the impact of anxiety on cognitive process we have developed an online version of the threat of scream paradigm tosp to investigate the impact of experimental anxiety on recognition memory two animated passive walkthrough video either under threat of scream or safety condition were shown to healthy participant recognition memory primacy v recency effect and subjective estimation of the length of encoding session were assessed subjective anxiety stress and emotional arousal rating indicated that experimental anxiety could successfully be induced safe threat or reversed threat safe between the two passive walkthrough session participant exposed to distress scream showed impaired retrieval of complex information that ha been presented in an animated environment in the threat condition participant failed to recognize detail related to the person encountered their spatial location a well a information about the temporal order and sequence of encounter participant group which received a threat announcement prior to the first walkthrough session threat threat v safety safety and threat safety v safety threat showed poorer recognition memory a compared to the group that received a safety announcement p 0 0468 and p 0 0426 respectively mann whitney u test cohen s d 0 5071 effect size r 0 2458 in conclusion experimental anxiety induced by the online version of the tosp lead to compromised recognition memory for complex multi dimensional information our result indicate that cognitive function of vulnerable population with limited mobility can be evaluated online by mean of the tosp

Title: Amygdala hyperactivation during symptom provocation in obsessive-compulsive disorder and its modulation by distraction
Authors: Simon, D.; Adler, N.; Kaufmann, C.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: anxiety disorder have been linked to a hyperactivated cortico amygdalar circuitry recent finding highlight the amygdala s role in mediating elevated anxiety in obsessive compulsive disorder ocd however modulation of amygdala hyperactivation by attentional distraction an effective emotion regulation strategy in healthy individual ha not yet been examined while undergoing functional magnetic resonance imaging twenty one unmedicated ocd patient and 21 control performed an evaluation and a distraction task during symptom provocation with individually tailored ocd relevant picture to test the specificity of response additional aversive and neutral stimulus were included significant group by picture type interaction were observed within fronto striato limbic circuit including the amygdala in these region patient showed increased bold response during processing of ocd trigger relative to healthy control amygdala hyperactivation wa present across ocd symptom dimension indicating that it represents a common neural correlate during distraction we observed dampening of patient amygdala hyperactivity to ocd relevant stimulus augmented amygdala involvement in patient during symptom provocation present across ocd symptom dimension might constitute a correlate of fear expression in ocd linking it to other anxiety disorder attentional distraction seemed to dampen emotional processing of disorder relevant stimulus via amygdala downregulation the clinical impact of this strategy to manage anxiety in ocd should be further elucidated

Title: Investigating sustained attention in contextual threat using steady-state VEPs evoked by flickering video stimuli
Authors: Stegmann, Y.; Andreatta, M.; Pauli, P.; Keil, A.; Wieser, M. J.
Abstract: anxiety is characterized by anxious anticipation and heightened vigilance to uncertain threat however if threat is not reliably indicated by a specific cue the context in which threat wa previously experienced becomes it best predictor leading to anxiety a suitable mean to induce anxiety experimentally is context conditioning in one context ctx an unpredictable aversive stimulus u is repeatedly presented in contrast to a second context ctx in which no u is ever presented in this eeg study we investigated attentional mechanism during acquisition and extinction learning in 38 participant who underwent a context conditioning protocol flickering video stimulus 32 s clip depicting virtual office representing ctx were used to evoke steady state visual evoked potential ssveps a an index of visuocortical engagement with the context analysis of the electrocortical response suggest a successful induction of the ssvep signal by video presentation in flicker mode furthermore we found clear index of context conditioning and extinction learning on a subjective level while cortical processing of the ctx wa unexpectedly reduced during video presentation the difference between ctx and ctx diminished during extinction learning together these result indicate that the dynamic sensory input of the video presentation lead to disruption in the ssvep signal which is greater for motivationally significant threatening context

Title: Illusory correlations between neutral and aversive stimuli can be induced by outcome aversiveness
Authors: Wiemer, J.; Muhlberger, A.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: anxiety is often characterised by an overestimation of the contingency between concern relevant and aversive stimulus and an amplified aversiveness of such aversive stimulus here we tested whether outcome aversiveness causally enhances contingency estimate twenty four participant were exposed to neutral visual cue which were followed by startle sound the loudness and hence the aversiveness of the cue wa determined by the cue colour while the likelihood of the startle sound always remained constant 50 result indicated an illusory correlation specifically for the cue followed by the most aversive startle sound a reflected in enhanced on line and a posteriori covariation estimate this bias wa positively correlated with state and trait anxiety physiological arousal measured by pupil diameter wa enhanced in response to the most aversive startle sound confirming it distinct processing in conclusion these result suggest that aversive outcome may induce illusory correlation most likely in anxious person and explain previous finding of illusory correlation in anxiety disorder

Title: Generalization of Conditioned Contextual Anxiety and the Modulatory Effects of Anxiety Sensitivity
Authors: Andreatta, M.; Neueder, D.; Herzog, K.; Genheimer, H.; Schiele, M. A.; Deckert, J.; Domschke, K.; Reif, A.; Wieser, M. J.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: anxiety patient overgeneralize fear response possibly because they cannot distinguish between cue never been associated with a threat i e safe and threat associated cue however a context and not cue are discussed a the relevant trigger for prolonged anxiety response characterizing many anxiety disorder we speculated that it is rather overgeneralization of contextual anxiety which constitutes a risk factor for anxiety disorder to this end we investigated generalization of conditioned contextual anxiety and explored modulatory effect of anxiety sensitivity a risk factor for anxiety disorder fifty five participant underwent context conditioning in a virtual reality paradigm on day 1 acquisition participant received unpredictable mildly painful electric stimulus unconditioned stimulus u in one virtual office anxiety context ctx but never in a second office safety context ctx successful acquisition of conditioned anxiety wa indicated by aversive rating and defensive physiological response i e scr to ctx v ctx on day 2 generalization participant re visited both the anxiety and the safety context plus three generalization context g ctx which were gradually dissimilar to ctx from 75 to 25 generalization of conditioned anxiety wa evident for rating but le clear for physiological response the observed dissociation between generalization of verbal and physiological response suggests that these response depend on two distinct context representation likely elemental and contextual representation importantly anxiety sensitivity wa positively correlated with the generalization of reported contextual anxiety thus this study demonstrates generalization gradient for conditioned contextual anxiety and that anxiety sensitivity facilitates such generalization process suggesting the importance of generalization of contextual anxiety for the development of anxiety disorder

Title: [Efficacy of the >>Tuebinger-Intensiv-Programm fur Eltern<< in Treating Childhood Anxieties - A Pilot Study]
Authors: Schlarb, A. A.; Jager, S.
Abstract: anxiety problem among young child are highly prevalent and related to family factor such a parenting behavior or parental psychological health the current pilot study examined the effectiveness of the non specific short term behavioral hypnotherapeutic parent training tipe in treating abnormal childhood anxiety childhood anxiety parenting behavior parenting sense of competence and psychological stress of the parent were measured at three point in time pretest posttest 3 month follow up obtained data wa compared to a waiting list control condition after participating parent of the treatment condition reported le dysfunctional parenting behavior le psychological stress and higher parenting sense of competence their child were significantly le anxious these effect were stable after three month family of the waiting list control condition however showed no significant change we conclude that a general behavioral hypnotherapeutic parent training positively affect the course of childhood anxiety problem

Title: Diverging patterns of EEG alpha asymmetry in anxious apprehension and anxious arousal
Authors: Harpfer, K.; Spychalski, D.; Kathmann, N.; Riesel, A.
Abstract: anxious apprehension and anxious arousal are central transdiagnostic anxiety dimension and have been linked to divergent pattern of frontal and parietal alpha asymmetry the present study examined the relationship between alpha asymmetry and anxiety dimension in 130 individual whose electroencephalogram eeg wa recorded at rest we applied a 2 anxious apprehension low v high x 2 anxious arousal low v high design to contrast brain lateralization in four group result revealed that anxious apprehension wa associated with more left than right frontal brain activity in the lower alpha band an effect driven by decreased right frontal activity exploratory analysis showed more left than right brain activity at central site associated with anxious apprehension parietal activity wa not lateralized a a function of anxiety dimension taken together the current result support that anxious apprehension is associated with more left than right frontal and central activity and suggest a broader distribution of alpha asymmetry associated with anxious apprehension than previously thought

Title: Appearance Teasing and Mental Health: Gender Differences and Mediation Effects of Appearance-Based Rejection Sensitivity and Dysmorphic Concerns
Authors: Schmidt, J.; Martin, A.
Abstract: appearance teasing is a common phenomenon in social interaction especially in adolescence several study have shown it negative impact on mental health a well a on body image while these finding prove stable in various context le evidence is available for possible gender difference in these relationship in particular the role of two important body image variable appearance based rejection sensitivity ar and dysmorphic concern and their contribution to mental health impairment ha not been assessed in gender specific process model in a cross sectional survey study n 501 407 f 94 m we retrospectively assessed early appearance teasing experience a well a current ar dysmorphic concern depression anxiety and self esteem we analyzed gender difference in these variable and their interrelation we then examined the mediating role of ar and dysmorphic concern in explaining mental health variable in adulthood due to early appearance teasing in gender specific serial mediation model the result show high ratio of early teasing experience but no significant gender difference regarding the frequency of early appearance teasing while teasing experience were significantly related to body image variable in adulthood in both gender r 0 32 p 0 010 we observed significant relation with mental health outcome in woman r 0 30 p 0 001 but not in men r 0 20 p 0 250 serial mediation model show that ar and dysmorphic concern mediate the effect of appearance teasing on mental health in all outcome in woman deltar 2 0 17 but not in men deltar 2 0 03 finding remained stable when controlling for body mass index age and relationship status the finding show similar frequency of appearance teasing and associated negative effect on body image in men and woman specifically in woman the effect of teasing on mental health were stronger and mediated by ar and dysmorphic concern overall the result point to the relevance of ar for etiological model of body image disorder and female mental health however men did not show the same relationship of teasing and mental health differential resilience factor regarding the negative effect of early appearance teasing could be an important target for future research

Title: Impact of COMT Val158Met-polymorphism on appetitive conditioning and amygdala/prefrontal effective connectivity
Authors: Klucken, T.; Kruse, O.; Wehrum-Osinsky, S.; Hennig, J.; Schweckendiek, J.; Stark, R.
Abstract: appetitive conditioning is an important mechanism for the development maintenance and treatment of psychiatric disorder like substance abuse therefore it is important to identify genetic variation which impact appetitive conditioning it ha been suggested that the val 158 met polymorphism in the catechol o methyl transferase comt is associated with the alteration of neural process of appetitive conditioning due to the central role of the dopaminergic system in reward processing however no study ha so far investigated the relationship between variation in the comt val 158 met polymorphism and appetitive conditioning in this fmri study an appetitive conditioning paradigm wa applied in which one neutral stimulus c predicted appetitive stimulus ucs while a second neutral stimulus c wa never paired with the ucs a a main result we observed a significant association between the comt val 158 met genotype and appetitive conditioning skin conductance response scrs revealed a significant difference between c and c in val val allele carrier but not in the other genotype group val val allele carrier showed increased hemodynamic response in the amygdala compared with the met met allele group in the contrast c c in addition psychophysiological interaction analysis revealed increased effective amygdala ventromedial prefrontal cortex connectivity in met met allele carrier the increased amygdala activity point to facilitated appetitive conditioning in val val allele carrier while the amygdala prefrontal connectivity result could be regarded a a marker for altered emotion regulation during conditioning which potentially impact appetitive learning sensitivity the scrs finding indicates a stronger conditioned response in the val val allele group and dovetail with the neural difference between the group these finding contribute to the current research on comt in emotional processing

Title: The relationship between neuroticism and appetitive conditioning
Authors: Klucken, T.; Kruse, O.; Klein, S.; Kampa, M.; Tapia Leon, I.; Stark, R.
Abstract: appetitive conditioning is considered a central mechanism for the vulnerability to psychiatric disorder however the investigation of individual difference that are related to altered appetitive learning ha been almost neglected so far the aim of this study wa to investigate the link between neuroticism and appetitive conditioning process 79 subject participated in a differential conditioning procedure in which a conditioned stimulus c wa paired with a reward money after a fast behavioral response while a second conditioned stimulus c wa never followed by a reward irrespective of the behavioral response a a main result neuroticism correlated negatively with the underlying neural process of appetitive conditioning in female but not in male in detail higher level of neuroticism were associated with decreased neural response in the left p 001 and right amygdala p 011 left p 063 and right p 019 nucleus accumbens and left p 002 and right p 021 orbitofrontal cortex all result are family wise error corrected the present result support previous finding which also showed an inverse sex specific effect in the context of neuroticism and emotional processing in female in addition the finding suggest that neuroticism is not solely linked to increased amygdala sensitivity during the processing of negative stimulus but also to decreased neural response when processing rewarding stimulus possible explanation for the sex difference and implication are discussed

Title: Four-year follow-up of a randomized controlled trial of triple p group for parent and child outcomes
Authors: Heinrichs, N.; Kliem, S.; Hahlweg, K.
Abstract: approximately 15 20 of child experience behavioral and or emotional difficulty evidence based treatment will likely not be sufficient to reduce the prevalence of these difficulty in child and adolescent effective prevention program are therefore also needed to enable family access to support at multiple point across the lifecourse the aim of the current investigation wa to evaluate the 4 year efficacy of the group based triple p positive parenting program a a prevention program administered universally seventeen preschool were randomly assigned to triple p n 11 preschool 186 family or a no parenting intervention control group n 6 preschool 94 family long term efficacy wa analyzed with hierarchical linear model using maternal and paternal self report measure mother and father from the intervention preschool group reported significant reduction in dysfunctional parenting behavior d 0 24 and 0 19 respectively mother also reported a le steep decline from pre to post intervention in positive parenting behavior which wa maintained 4 year later d 0 38 father from intervention preschool reported a delayed le steep decline in positive parenting during the follow up d 0 33 in addition mother from intervention preschool reported immediate improvement in child behavior problem during the program while mother from control preschool did not report this immediate change however with mother from intervention preschool reporting more child behavior problem at baseline the effect disappeared by the fourth year d 0 19 the result support the long term efficacy of the triple p group program a a universal prevention intervention for changing parenting behavior while there wa little evidence for maintenance of change in behavior problem

Title: Feasibility, Acceptance, and Safety of Metacognitive Training for Problem and Pathological Gamblers (Gambling-MCT): A Pilot Study
Authors: Gehlenborg, J.; Bucker, L.; Berthold, M.; Miegel, F.; Moritz, S.
Abstract: approximately 90 of problem and pathological gambler remain untreated this treatment gap may be diminished by the implementation of low threshold treatment program a cognitive distortion play a crucial role in the development and maintenance of gambling problem intervention targeting gambling related bias may be particularly effective the aim of the present study wa to examine the feasibility acceptance and safety of a novel metacognitive training for individual with gambling problem gambling mct twenty five participant were included in an uncontrolled pilot trial with two assessment point intervention the intervention comprised eight training module targeting gambling specific cognitive distortion at baseline and post assessment symptom severity a measured with the pg ybocs and gambling related cognitive distortion a measured with the gab were assessed in addition interim assessment measuring session specific change were conducted subjective appraisal wa examined after each module and also post treatment on average participant took part in 4 16 sd 2 84 training session both intent to treat and per protocol analysis showed significant improvement on the pg ybocs and the gab d z 0 37 1 37 after bonferroni correction for multiple testing linear mixed model for the analysis of session specific change showed no deterioration in participant mental state after any of the module subjective appraisal of gambling mct wa good the present pilot study provides first evidence for the feasibility acceptance and safety of gambling mct recruitment of participant remains challenging emphasizing the importance of overcoming patient related treatment barrier future study need to investigate the efficacy of gambling mct in randomized controlled trial

Title: The effects of an unexpected spider stimulus on skin conductance responses and eye movements: an inattentional blindness study
Authors: Wiemer, J.; Gerdes, A. B.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: are spider evolutionarily relevant threat cue that capture attention automatically and preattentively also in non fearful person previous study concerning this question did not examine response to unexpected spider stimulus although this is an ecologically valid situation therefore we conducted an inattentional blindness ib experiment while unselected participant n 120 were focusing their attention on a visual discrimination task suddenly a spider or a flower image appeared the rate of reported detection were not enhanced for spider image and fear of spider had no moderating influence on ib rate however spider picture in general elicited greater skin conductance response than flower picture and this difference wa also observed for picture that were not reported afterward moreover eye movement data revealed that the spider stimulus wa initially fixated more often than the flower stimulus in sum our finding imply that enhanced reaction to unexpected spider image are independent of fear level and include early engagement process awareness of a spider picture doe not seem to be a prerequisite for elevated arousal

Title: A randomized-controlled trial of heart rate variability biofeedback for psychotic symptoms
Authors: Clamor, A.; Koenig, J.; Thayer, J. F.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: arousal and the way it is coped with are relevant to the emergence of psychotic symptom heart rate variability hrv stem from autonomic response to environmental demand such a stress and is an index of physiological arousal adaptability and homeostatic reflex forming autonomic balance a randomized controlled between subject trial that compared hrv biofeedback bf to an active relaxation and to a waiting control condition wa conducted in a sample with attenuated subclinical psychotic symptom n 84 a 20 min intervention wa preceded and followed by repeated assessment of stress response change score of the post stress period were analyzed using anova for hrv subjective stress perceived control and state paranoia a expected bf participant showed greater improvement in perceived control than waiting control p 0 006 however no group difference occurred in hrv paranoid symptom or subjective stress in exploratory analysis in a subset of participant who were breathing per protocol the expected effect were found for total hrv and state paranoia thus this trial of hrv bf for people with attenuated psychotic symptom indicates that the intervention may hold potential if conducted per protocol to reach this longer training might be inevitable future study are needed to further elucidate efficacy and applicability of hrv bf in clinical sample

Title: Does perpetrating violence damage mental health? Differences between forcibly recruited and voluntary combatants in DR Congo
Authors: Hecker, T.; Hermenau, K.; Maedl, A.; Hinkel, H.; Schauer, M.; Elbert, T.
Abstract: a a consequence of the ongoing conflict in the democratic republic of the congo drc combatant are constantly involved in various form of violence finding concerning the impact of perpetrating violence on mental health are contradictory ranging from increasing to buffering the risk for mental ill health the present study investigated the impact of perpetrating violence on mental health in total 204 forcibly recruited and voluntary male combatant mean age 24 61 year from different armed group in the eastern drc took part in the study in a semistructured interview respondent were questioned about appetitive aggression and posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd a well a self experienced violence and self perpetrated violent offending a multivariate analysis of variance eta 2 23 revealed that voluntary combatant perpetrated more violent act eta 2 06 and showed higher appetitive aggression eta 2 03 a moderated multiple regression analysis r 2 20 showed that perpetrating violence wa positively related to ptsd in forcibly recruited combatant but not in voluntary combatant thus perpetrating violence may not necessarily qualify a a traumatic stressor further study might consider assessing the combatant s perception of committing violent act

Title: Neural correlates of training and transfer effects in working memory in older adults
Authors: Heinzel, S.; Lorenz, R. C.; Pelz, P.; Heinz, A.; Walter, H.; Kathmann, N.; Rapp, M. A.; Stelzel, C.
Abstract: a indicated by previous research aging is associated with a decline in working memory wm functioning related to alteration in fronto parietal neural activation at the same time previous study showed that wm training in older adult may improve the performance in the trained task training effect and more importantly also in untrained wm task transfer effect however neural correlate of these transfer effect that would improve understanding of it underlying mechanism have not been shown in older participant a yet in this study we investigated blood oxygen level dependent bold signal change during n back performance and an untrained delayed recognition sternberg task following 12sessions 45min each of adaptive n back training in older adult the sternberg task used in this study allowed to test for neural training effect independent of specific task affordances of the trained task and to separate maintenance from updating process thirty two healthy older participant 60 75years were assigned either to an n back training or a no contact control group before t1 and after t2 training waiting period both the n back task and the sternberg task were conducted while bold signal wa measured using functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri in all participant in addition neuropsychological test were performed outside the scanner wm performance improved with training and behavioral transfer to test measuring executive function processing speed and fluid intelligence wa found in the training group bold signal in the right lateral middle frontal gyrus caudal superior frontal sulcus brodmann area ba 6 8 decreased in both the trained n back and the updating condition of the untrained sternberg task at t2 compared to the control group fmri finding indicate a training related increase in processing efficiency of wm network potentially related to the process of wm updating performance gain in untrained task suggest that transfer to other cognitive task remains possible in aging

Title: Linking psychophysiological adaptation, emotion regulation, and subjective stress to the occurrence of paranoia in daily life
Authors: Bahlinger, K.; Lincoln, T. M.; Krkovic, K.; Clamor, A.
Abstract: a stress is relevant to the formation of paranoia maladaptive behavioral and physiological stress regulation is discussed a a crucial indicator of vulnerability this is supported by research linking psychosis to the tendency to make le use of functional and more use of dysfunctional emotion regulation strategy er and with a lower vagally mediated heart rate variability hrv however it remains unclear whether er serf a a mediator between resting state hrv on the one hand and subjective stress level and paranoia on the other and whether this is specific to paranoia a compared to depression we used an experience sampling method during seven day to repeatedly a the experience of stress usage of er strategy paranoia und depression 9 day in a sample with subclinical positive symptom n 32 resting state hrv wa measured during a 5min interval in the laboratory data wa analyzed by multi level model higher resting state hrv wa predictive of lower stress level and of using more functional er strategy reappraisal acceptance in daily life but did not predict the use of dysfunctional strategy rumination suppression or paranoia the association between resting state hrv and stress wa mediated by the usage of functional er le functional and more dysfunctional er were linked to higher level of stress paranoia and depression our study highlight that deficit in er represent a link between psychophysiological and phenomenological aspect of paranoia but also of depression this encourages to further investigate transdiagnostic prevention and therapy program aiming to improve er and to increase hrv

Title: Affective states contribute to trait reports of affective well-being
Authors: Brose, A.; Lindenberger, U.; Schmiedek, F.
Abstract: asking people to provide global judgment or trait report of their affective experience is a standard method for assessing trait affective well being with countless application in the social science trait report reflect numerous influence that generally go unnoticed although state affect is a highly plausible candidate for such influence this source of unwanted variance doe not receive much attention and is usually not controlled for in empirical study using 100 day data from the cogito study we provide direct and strong evidence that trait report of affect depend on how people feel at the time they provide the evaluation i e their affective state for example participant experiencing more positive affect on a specific day relative to their individual mean also provide more positive rating of their global affective experience furthermore we found that current affect influence trait rating in a surprisingly differentiated way those particular facet of affect that are more le prevalent at a certain moment are believed to occur more le often in general we stress the need for repeated observation within individual to estimate state contribution to standard assessment of trait affect to distinguish between state and trait in psychological assessment and to achieve good indicator of affective experience in the social and medical science

Title: Episodic memory and executive functioning in currently depressed patients compared to healthy controls
Authors: Pauls, F.; Petermann, F.; Lepach, A. C.
Abstract: at present little is still known about the link between depression memory and executive functioning this study examined whether there are memory related impairment in depressed patient and whether the size of such deficit depends on the age group and on specific type of cognitive measure memory performance of 215 clinically depressed patient were compared to the data of a matched control sample regression analysis were performed to determine the extent to which executive dysfunction contributed to episodic memory impairment when compared with healthy control significantly lower episodic memory and executive functioning performance were found for depressed patient of all age group effect size appeared to vary across different memory and executive functioning measure the extent to which executive dysfunction could explain episodic memory impairment varied depending on the type of measure examined these finding emphasise the need to consider memory related functioning of depressed patient in the context of therapeutic treatment

Title: Make up your mind about food: A healthy mindset attenuates attention for high-calorie food in restrained eaters
Authors: Werthmann, J.; Jansen, A.; Roefs, A.
Abstract: attention bias for food could be a cognitive pathway to overeating in obesity and restrained eating yet empirical evidence for individual difference e g in restrained eating and body mass index in attention bias for food is mixed we tested experimentally if temporarily induced health versus palatability mindset influenced attention bias for food and whether restrained eating moderated this relation after manipulating mindset health v palatability experimentally food related attention bias wa measured by eye movement em and response latency rl during a visual probe task depicting high calorie food and non food restrained eating wa assessed afterwards a significant interaction of mindset and restrained eating on rl bias emerged beta 0 36 t 58 2 05 p 0 045 a health mindset a compared to a palatability mindset attenuated attention bias for high caloric food only in participant with higher eating restraint no effect were observed on em bias the current result demonstrate that state difference in health versus palatability mindset can cause attenuated attention bias for high calorie food cue in participant with higher eating restraint our finding add to emerging evidence that state difference in mindset can bias attention for food above the influence of trait difference

Title: Probabilistic reward learning in adults with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder--an electrophysiological study
Authors: Thoma, P.; Edel, M. A.; Suchan, B.; Bellebaum, C.
Abstract: attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd is hypothesized to be characterized by altered reinforcement sensitivity the main aim of the present study wa to a alteration in the electrophysiological correlate of monetary reward processing in adult patient with adhd of the combined subtype fourteen adult with adhd of the combined subtype and 14 healthy control participant performed an active and an observational probabilistic reward based learning task while an electroencephalogramm eeg wa recorded regardless of feedback valence there wa a general feedback related negativity frn enhancement in combination with reduced learning performance during both active and observational reward learning in patient with adhd relative to healthy control other feedback locked potential such a the p200 and p300 and response locked potential were unaltered in the patient there were no significant correlation between learning performance frn amplitude and clinical symptom neither in the overall group involving all participant nor in patient or control considered separately this pattern of finding might reflect generally impaired reward prediction in adult with adhd of the combined subtype we demonstrated for the first time that patient with adhd of the combined subtype show not only deficient active reward learning but are also impaired when learning by observing other people s outcome

Title: Impaired attention toward the eyes in psychopathic offenders: Evidence from an eye tracking study
Authors: Gehrer, N. A.; Scheeff, J.; Jusyte, A.; Schonenberg, M.
Abstract: attention orienting to socially salient cue such a the eye of interaction partner is assumed to be crucial for the development of intact social cognition dysfunction in such basic process that guide the perception of social cue have been suggested to play a role in the development of psychopathy the present study investigated gaze pattern in two group of incarcerated psychopathic and non psychopathic offender while recording their eye movement participant were asked to categorize either gender task 1 or emotional expression task 2 of facial image psychopath exhibited significantly reduced attention orienting toward the eye a indicated by absolute dwell time a well a frequency of the initial fixation on the eye region this pattern wa evident across all emotional expression and independent of the task the present result suggest a pervasive impairment to attention orienting toward the eye in psychopath compared to non psychopathic offender this impairment appears to affect not only general attention but also early attention shift thus our finding provide evidence that these dysfunction might particularly contribute to the development of psychopathy instead of antisocial behavior per se future study should further examine the origin emergence and consequence of these impairment in order to develop targeted intervention

Title: Visual attention and sexual arousal in women with and without sexual dysfunction
Authors: Velten, J.; Milani, S.; Margraf, J.; Brotto, L. A.
Abstract: attention to sexual stimulus is a prerequisite to process such stimulus a sexually meaningful and is an important mean to facilitate sexual arousal attending to sexual cue is crucial for healthy sexual functioning study suggest that sexual dysfunction is associated with le attention towards sexual stimulus the goal of this study wa to use an eye tracking based free viewing paradigm to investigate whether woman with sexual dysfunction visually attend to the genital area in dynamic sexual stimulus i e erotic video differently than woman with subclinical sexual function or those with typical sexual functioning a total of 69 woman m age 27 77 sd 8 00 with clinical n 30 subclinical n 23 and typical n 16 level of sexual functioning watched four 1 min video clip depicting heterosexual couple engaging in vaginal intercourse or cunnilingus while the total fixation duration on the genital area a well a their subjective and genital sexual arousal were recorded a hypothesized the clinical group fixated on the genital area le than woman with typical sexual functioning a longer total fixation duration on the genital area wa followed by increase in subjective arousal and genital arousal the relationship between attention and arousal wa not moderated by sexual functioning group this study provides first evidence of the role of sustained visual attention for facilitating sexual arousal in woman with and without sexual dysfunction

Title: Attention orienting to the eyes in violent female and male offenders: An eye-tracking study
Authors: Gehrer, N. A.; Zajenkowska, A.; Bodecka, M.; Schonenberg, M.
Abstract: attention to the eye and eye contact form an important basis for the development of empathy and social competence including prosocial behavior thus impairment in attention to the eye of an interaction partner might play a role in the etiology of antisocial behavior and violence for the first time the present study extends investigation of eye gaze to a large sample n 173 including not only male but also female violent offender and a control group we assessed viewing pattern during the categorization of emotional face via eye tracking our result indicate a reduced frequency of initial attention shift to the eye in female and male offender compared to control while there were no general group difference in overall attention to the eye region i e relative dwell time thus we conclude that violent offender might be able to compensate for deficit in spontaneous attention orienting during later stage of information processing

Title: ADHD symptoms are associated with the modular structure of intrinsic brain networks in a representative sample of healthy adults
Authors: Hilger, K.; Fiebach, C. J.
Abstract: attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd is one of the most common neurodevelopmental disorder with significant and often lifelong effect on social emotional and cognitive functioning influential neurocognitive model of adhd link behavioral symptom to altered connection between and within functional brain network here we investigate whether network based theory of adhd can be generalized to understanding variation in adhd related behavior within the normal i e clinically unaffected adult population in a large and representative sample self rated presence of adhd symptom varied widely only 8 out of 291 participant scored in the clinical range subject specific brain network graph were modeled from functional mri resting state data and revealed significant association between nonclinical adhd symptom and region specific profile of between module and within module connectivity effect were located in brain region associated with multiple neuronal system including the default mode network the salience network and the central executive system our result are consistent with network perspective of adhd and provide further evidence for the relevance of an appropriate information transfer between task negative default mode and task positive brain region more generally our finding support a dimensional conceptualization of adhd and contribute to a growing understanding of cognition a an emerging property of functional brain network

Title: The Orienting Response in Healthy Aging: Novelty P3 Indicates No General Decline but Reduced Efficacy for Fast Stimulation Rates
Authors: Berti, S.; Vossel, G.; Gamer, M.
