Abstract: automatic orienting to unexpected change in the environment is a pre requisite for adaptive behavior one prominent mechanism of automatic attentional control is the orienting response or despite the fundamental significance of the or in everyday life only little is known about how the or is affected by healthy aging we tested this question in two age group 19 38 and 55 72 year and measured skin conductance response scrs and event related brain potential erps to novel i e short environmental sound presented only once in the experiment 10 of the trial compared to standard sound 600 hz sinusoidal tone with 200 m duration 90 of the trial novel and standard stimulus were presented in four condition differing in the inter stimulus interval isi with a mean isi of either 10 3 1 or 0 5 s blocked presentation in both age group pronounced scrs were elicited by novel in the 10 s isi condition suggesting the elicitation of stable or these effect were accompanied by pronounced n1 and frontal p3 amplitude in the erp suggesting that automatic novelty processing and orientation of attention are effective in both age group furthermore the scr and erp effect declined with decreasing isi length in addition difference between the two group were observable with the fastest presentation rate i e 1 and 0 5 s isi length the most prominent difference wa a shift of the peak of the frontal positivity from around 300 to 200 m in the 19 38 year group while in the 55 72 year group the amplitude of the frontal p3 decreased linearly with decreasing isi length taken together this pattern of result doe not suggest a general decline in processing efficacy with healthy aging at least with very rare change here the novel in the 10 s isi condition the or is a effective in healthy older adult a in younger adult with faster presentation rate however the efficacy of the or decrease this seems to result in a switch from novelty to deviant processing in younger adult but le so in the group of older adult

Title: Early hypervigilance and later avoidance: Event-related potentials track the processing of threatening stimuli in anxiety
Authors: Kausche, F. M.; Harpfer, K.; Carsten, H. P.; Kathmann, N.; Riesel, A.
Abstract: avoidance behavior is a core symptom of anxiety disorder that may hinder adaptation anxiety disorder are heterogeneous and previous research suggests to decompose anxiety into two dimension anxious apprehension and anxious arousal how these two dimension are associated with avoidance of and exposure to threatening stimulus a well a their accompanying neural process is barely understood we examined threat processing using event related potential n1 lpp from 134 individual considering the influence of anxiety dimension during a two phase picture viewing task the participant watched neutral and threatening picture which they were instructed to either avoid or attend to during repeated presentation result showed that threatening compared to neutral picture were associated with increased attention allocation n1 and in depth processing lpp modulated by task instruction lower during avoidance further increased anxious apprehension wa associated with heightened automatic attention increased n1 followed by reduced lpp amplitude for threatening picture suggesting reduced in depth processing during re exposure threatening picture were associated with increased in depth processing with no difference between previously avoided and maintained picture together these result illustrate that avoidance and high anxious apprehension seem to lead to similar neural change in the processing of aversive image that may conflict with long term adaptation

Title: Costly habitual avoidance is reduced by concurrent goal-directed approach in a modified devaluation paradigm
Authors: Gluck, V. M.; Zwosta, K.; Wolfensteller, U.; Ruge, H.; Pittig, A.
Abstract: avoidance habit potentially contribute to maintaining maladaptive costly avoidance behavior that persist in the absence of threat however experimental evidence about costly habitual avoidance is scarce in two experiment we tested whether extensively trained avoidance impairs the subsequent goal directed approach of reward healthy participant were extensively trained to avoid an aversive outcome by performing simple response to distinct full screen color stimulus after the subsequent devaluation of the aversive outcome participant received monetary reward for correct response to neutral object picture which were presented on top of the same full screen color these approach response were either compatible or incompatible with habitual avoidance response notably the full screen color were not relevant to inform approach response in experiment 1 participant were not instructed about post devaluation stimulus response reward contingency accuracy wa lower in habit incompatible than in habit compatible trial indicating costly avoidance whereas reaction time did not differ in experiment 2 contingency were explicitly instructed accuracy difference disappeared but reaction time were slower in habit incompatible than in habit compatible trial indicating low cost habitual avoidance tendency these finding suggest a small but consistent impact of habitual avoidance tendency on subsequent goal directed approach costly habitual responding could however be inhibited when competing goal directed approach wa easily realizable

Title: Incentive-based, instructed, and social observational extinction of avoidance: Fear-opposite actions and their influence on fear extinction
Authors: Pittig, A.; Wong, A. H. K.
Abstract: avoidance is a transdiagnostic symptom of clinical anxiety and it reduction a major focus of cognitive behavioral treatment this study examined the instrumental extinction of goal directed avoidance by mean of incentive verbal instruction and social observation and their influence on fear extinction participant acquired conditioned fear and instrumental avoidance response n 160 in four randomized group the reduction of avoidance by incentive for non avoidance instruction to refrain from avoidance and social observation of non avoidance wa compared to no intervention before removing the aversive outcome conditioned fear when avoidance became unavailable subsequently wa tested incentive instruction and observation all reduced avoidance better than no intervention however with different degree and influence on conditioned fear incentive and instruction strongly reduced avoidance despite high level of fear i e fear opposite action this initiated fear extinction thereby reducing conditioned fear when avoidance became unavailable social observation directly reduced conditioned fear presumably because it conveyed additional information about the absence of the aversive outcome however observation only moderately reduced avoidance and resulted in higher fear when avoidance became unavailable the effect of social observation may depend on the nuance of the demonstrator s behavior the clear effect of incentive and instruction provide support for clinical intervention to reduce avoidance during exposure therapy and can serve a experimental model for their controlled investigation

Title: Implicit approach and avoidance in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder
Authors: Cludius, B.; Kulz, A. K.; Landmann, S.; Moritz, S.; Wittekind, C. E.
Abstract: avoidance is regarded a an important feature for the development and maintenance of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd and is usually assessed using explicit measure such a self report scale however some behavioral schema are unavailable to introspection making them partially inaccessible by explicit measure we used an approach avoidance task aat a an implicit measure to examine behavioral tendency in patient with ocd including patient with checking and contamination related symptom n 63 compared with a healthy control group n 30 participant were asked to respond to the color of a stimulus or stimulus frame by pulling a joystick toward themselves or by pushing it away the stimulus were comprised of checking related contamination related and neutral picture and word patient with contamination related symptom were slower when responding to ocd related stimulus independent of approach or avoidance unexpectedly patient with checking related symptom were faster at pulling approaching and slower at pushing avoiding checking related material compared with neutral stimulus the slower pushing avoiding of checking related compared with neutral material correlated positively with explicit rating of avoidance these result suggest a biased approach avoidance tendency in patient with checking related symptom of ocd but not in those with contamination related symptom of ocd future study are necessary to a whether the aat might be useful in the assessment of treatment gain a well a whether it might be a training tool to enhance psychotherapeutic change in ocd psycinfo database record

Title: Investigation of automatic avoidance in displaced individuals with chronic Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
Authors: Wittekind, C. E.; Behmer, F.; Muhtz, C.; Fritzsche, A.; Moritz, S.; Jelinek, L.
Abstract: avoidance of trauma related stimulus is a key feature of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd however avoidance ha almost exclusively been investigated with explicit measure targeting more strategic aspect of behavior the aim of the present study wa to examine automatic avoidance in older individual displaced a child at the end of world war ii with n 22 and without ptsd n 26 and in non traumatized control participant n 23 with an approach avoidance task aat participant were instructed to respond to the color gray brown of trauma related neutral and control picture by pushing or pulling a joystick group did not differ significantly a to their behavioral tendency towards trauma related picture thus there wa no evidence for automatic avoidance in individual with ptsd however high vigilance wa associated with stronger implicit avoidance towards trauma related picture in the ptsd group several explanation for the non significant result a well a implication and limitation of the present finding are discussed

Title: Relationships between addictive Facebook use, depressiveness, insomnia, and positive mental health in an inpatient sample: A German longitudinal study
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Rohmann, E.; Bierhoff, H. W.; Margraf, J.; Kollner, V.
Abstract: background and aim individual with high level of negative mental health often tend to use the social platform facebook to escape from daily stress they are at risk to develop an emotional bond to facebook linked to a need to stay permanently online the current work investigated addictive use of facebook and it conceptual framework in clinical context method in a longitudinal study design duration of daily use of facebook addictive facebook use depressiveness insomnia and positive mental health pmh were assessed in a sample of 349 inpatient m age sd age 50 13 9 41 of a psychosomatic rehabilitation clinic in germany over a period of on average 6 week result regression analysis revealed that duration of daily facebook use at the first measurement time point t1 served a significant positive predictor of addictive facebook use at the second measurement time point t2 addictive facebook use t1 significantly positively predicted depressiveness and insomnia t2 it prediction of pmh t2 wa significantly negative mediation analysis showed that pmh t1 partially mediated the association between addictive facebook use t1 and depressiveness t2 and fully mediated the relationship between addictive facebook use t1 and insomnia t2 discussion and conclusion current longitudinal result indicate that addictive facebook use might negatively impact the recovery process of inpatient thus it might be relevant to a and consider addictive facebook use in the clinical context therapeutic intervention are suggested to focus on the enhancement of inpatient pmh level which may buffer the negative effect of problematic facebook use

Title: The role of inhibitory control and decision-making in the course of Internet gaming disorder
Authors: Kraplin, A.; Scherbaum, S.; Kraft, E. M.; Rehbein, F.; Buhringer, G.; Goschke, T.; Mossle, T.
Abstract: background and aim internet gaming disorder igd is associated with impaired inhibitory control and more impulsive decision making however it remains unclear whether these association are cross sectional or predictive we aimed to test the hypothesis that lower inhibitory control and more impulsive decision making correlate with are predicted by and predict more time spent on gaming and higher igd severity method a stratified convenience sample of 70 male participant 18 21 year wa recruited to achieve broad data variability for hour spent on gaming and igd severity in three annual assessment t1 t2 t3 we measured gaming behaviour and igd severity using the video game dependency scale csas ii both gaming related measure were correlate t1 predictor t2 or outcome t3 of inhibitory control and decision making which were assessed at t2 using a go no go task and an intertemporal choice task respectively result higher igd severity at t1 predicted more impulsive decision making at t2 beta 0 45 95 ci 0 14 0 76 lower inhibitory control at t2 predicted more hour spent on gaming at t3 beta 0 13 95 ci 0 25 to 0 02 we found weak or no evidence for the other association discussion and conclusion lower inhibitory control predicts more time spent gaming possibly due to insufficient top down regulation of the behaviour impulsive decision making is rather a consequence of igd than a predictor which may be due to altered reward learning one dimensional etiological assumption about the relationship between neurocognitive impairment and igd seem not to be appropriate for the complexity of the disorder

Title: Individual cortisol response to acute stress influences neural processing of sexual cues
Authors: Stark, R.; Markert, C.; Kruse, O.; Walter, B.; Strahler, J.; Klein, S.
Abstract: background and aim problematic pornography use can be conceptualized a an impulse control disorder or alternatively a a behavioral addiction stress is an important trigger in addiction but le is known about the neural effect of stress in problematic pornography use therefore we aimed at investigating the effect of stress during the anticipation and viewing of sexually explicit material while considering person characteristic related to potentially being at risk for developing problematic pornography use method in an fmri study n 157 men age mean 25 46 sd 4 11 we used a sexual incentive delay task a social stress test wa used to induce stress in half of the participant salivary cortisol wa repeatedly measured and person characteristic were considered moderating the effect of cortisol response result we found no group difference in the neural response during the anticipation phase but a higher reactivity to sexual stimulus in the dacc in the stress group acute stress activated a pronounced cortisol response which positively correlated with neural activation in the reward system nacc dacc to sexual cue further the individual time spent on pornography use moderated the effect of cortisol in some region of the reward system dacc mofc discussion and conclusion our result suggest that acute stress related increase in cortisol can enhance the incentive value of cue announcing sexual stimulus this might explain why acute stress is considered a trigger of pornography use and relapse and why individual stress response might be a risk factor for developing a problematic pornography use

Title: Are Drinking Motives Universal? Characteristics of Motive Types in Alcohol-Dependent Men from Two Diverse Populations
Authors: Ertl, V.; Preusse, M.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: background and aim since alcohol use disorder are among the most prevalent and destructive mental disorder it is critical to address factor contributing to their development and maintenance drinking motif are relevant driving factor for consumption identifying group of drinker with similar motivation may help to specialize intervention component and make treatment more effective and efficient we aimed to identify and describe distinct motive type of drinker in dependent male from two diverse culture uganda and germany and to explore potential difference and similarity in addiction related measure moreover we investigated specific link between motive type and childhood maltreatment traumatic experience and symptom of comorbid psychopathology method to determine distinct drinking motive type we conducted latent class analysis concerning drinking motif drinking motive scale in sample of treatment seeking alcohol dependent men n 75 subsequently we compared the identified motive type concerning their alcohol consumption and alcohol related symptom alcohol use disorder identification test history of childhood maltreatment childhood trauma questionnaire trauma exposure violence war and abduction exposure scale psychopathology posttraumatic stress diagnostic scale depression section of the hopkins symptom checklist and brief symptom inventory and deficit in emotion regulation difficulty in emotion regulation scale result we found two congruent drinking motive type in both context reward oriented drinking motif like the generation of positive feeling and enhancing performance were endorsed almost equally by both motive type whereas high relief motive endorsement characterized one group but not the other the relief motive type drank to overcome aversive feeling withdrawal and daily hassle and wa characterized by higher adversity in general emotional maltreatment in childhood and psychopathological symptom were reported to a significantly greater extent by relief drinker effect size of comparison ranging from r 0 25 to r 0 48 however the motive type did not differ significantly on alcohol consumption or alcohol related symptom and traumatic experience apart from childhood maltreatment conclusion the chronology of addiction development and pattern of drinking motivation seem to be similar across culture i e that motive targeting intervention might be applicable cross culturally addressing comorbid symptomatology should be a key treatment component for relief drinker whereas finding alternative for the creation of positive feeling and way to counteract boredom and inactivity should be a general treatment element

Title: Sexual incentive delay in the scanner: Sexual cue and reward processing, and links to problematic porn consumption and sexual motivation
Authors: Markert, C.; Klein, S.; Strahler, J.; Kruse, O.; Stark, R.
Abstract: background and aim the use of pornography while unproblematic for the majority can grow into addiction like behavior which in it extreme form is labeled a compulsive sexual behavioral disorder in the icd 11 who 2018 the aim of this study wa to investigate the addiction specific reactivity to cue in order to better understand underlying mechanism in the development of this disorder method we have used an optimized sexual incentive delay task to study brain activity in reward associated brain area during an anticipation phase with cue predicting pornographic video control video or no video and a corresponding delivery phase in healthy men correlation to indicator of problematic pornography use the time spent on pornography use and trait sexual motivation were analyzed result the result of 74 men showed that reward related brain area amygdala dorsal cingulate cortex orbitofrontal cortex nucleus accumbens thalamus putamen caudate nucleus and insula were significantly more activated by both the pornographic video and the pornographic cue than by control video and control cue respectively however we found no relationship between these activation and indicator of problematic pornography use time spent on pornography use or with trait sexual motivation discussion and conclusion the activity in reward related brain area to both visual sexual stimulus a well a cue indicates that optimization of the sexual incentive delay task wa successful presumably association between reward related brain activity and indicator for problematic or pathological pornography use might only occur in sample with increased level and not in a rather healthy sample used in the present study

Title: Recovery After Stress-Autonomic and Subjective Arousal in Individuals With Psychosis Compared to Healthy Controls
Authors: Bahlinger, K.; Lincoln, T. M.; Clamor, A.
Abstract: background and hypothesis heightened stress level in individual with psychosis psy are associated with psychotic symptom occurrence and may be partially attributed to well established deficit in resting state heart rate variability hrv and emotion regulation in healthy participant resting state hrv and self reported emotion regulation skill have been linked to recovery after a stressor however it is unclear whether stress recovery is altered in psy thus we compared the autonomic and subjective recovery of psy to healthy control hc and investigated the predictive value of resting state hrv and emotion regulation skill study design we assessed resting state hrv and self reported emotion regulation one week prior to a combined physical and cognitive stress induction after the stress exposure we assessed the autonomic decrease in heart rate hr increase in hrv and subjective decrease in subjective stress and negative affect recovery in psy n 50 and hc n 50 over 60 min study result repeated measure anova revealed the expected interaction of time x group for subjective stress but not negative affect or autonomic stress resting state hrv predicted recovery of hr and emotion regulation skill predicted recovery of hrv but not of the other parameter conclusion although subjective stress recovery wa delayed in psy the absence of autonomic recovery deficit suggests that a prolonged stress response may not contribute to heightened stress level to the expected extent improving resting state hrv and emotion regulation may support autonomic recovery but further investigation is required to test the impact of such improvement on psychotic symptom

Title: Responses to stress in patients with psychotic disorders compared to persons with varying levels of vulnerability to psychosis, persons with depression and healthy controls
Authors: Lincoln, T. M.; Kother, U.; Hartmann, M.; Kempkensteffen, J.; Moritz, S.
Abstract: background and objective an experimental design wa used to test whether self reported psychophysiological and symptomatic stress response increase a a function of the underlying vulnerability to psychosis a proposed by vulnerability stress model method stress response of participant with psychotic disorder psy n 35 were compared to those of participant with attenuated positive symptom a n 29 first degree relative of person with psychotic disorder rel n 26 healthy control hc n 28 and control with depression dep n 30 using a repeated measure design participant were assigned to a noise stressor a social stressor and a no stress condition in random order stress response were assessed via self report salivary cortisol level heart rate and skin conductance level state paranoia and depression were assessed with clinical scale result psy reported to be significantly more stressed than hc a and rel across all condition which went along with increased heart rate and decreased overall cortisol release in contrast a showed elevated level of cortisol psy showed a stronger response of self reported stress to the noise condition compared to the no stress condition than hc but no stronger response than the other sample furthermore the stressor did not trigger stronger psychophysiological response or symptom increase in psy limitation the social stressor wa brief and not individualized and did not have an effect on cortisol conclusion the finding support the notion that subjective stress responsiveness increase with vulnerability but not the assumption that symptom arise directly a a function of stress and vulnerability also the generally high level of arousal seem to be more relevant to psychosis than the responsiveness to specific stressor

Title: Avoidance of all feedback? Attention allocation during and after public speech in social anxiety
Authors: Lin, M.; Qian, M.; He, D.; Wen, X.; Li, X.
Abstract: background and objective attention avoidance of feedback related stimulus is proposed to be associated with and maintain social anxiety however previous research ha mainly focused on comparing the attention bias between two type of stimulus while little is known about attention distribution pattern among positive neutral and negative feedback and non feedback stimulus in individual with high trait social anxiety hsa or low trait social anxiety lsa method the current study assessed eye movement pattern of participant with hsa or lsa during a speech task high anxiety condition or while solely watching audience feedback of the speech low anxiety condition a pre recorded audience who displayed approving neutral or disapproving gesture wa presented a feedback stimulus while neutral facial photo were used a non feedback stimulus result only in the high anxiety condition participant with hsa exhibited longer total fixation on non feedback stimulus compared to those with lsa whereas in the low anxiety condition both group paid more attention to emotional feedback stimulus limitation the final sample size wa modest due to a high suspicion rate of the reality of the audience conclusion these finding suggest that only in highly anxious social situation socially anxious individual lack the attentional preference toward positive feedback that individual with low anxious have

Title: Performance in a blocked versus randomized emotional Stroop task in an aged, early traumatized group with and without posttraumatic stress symptoms
Authors: Wittekind, C. E.; Muhtz, C.; Moritz, S.; Jelinek, L.
Abstract: background and objective attentional bias ab for trauma related stimulus have been examined in many study assessing different trauma sample in emotional stroop task est blocked and single trial format are used almost interchangeably in clinical research there is reason to believe that different design yield different result and a different process which however ha been hardly examined in study furthermore there is a dearth of information about ab in older trauma survivor with posttraumatic stress symptom method older adult with n 20 and without ptsd symptom n 26 a well a non traumatized control n 21 completed an est in which word were presented both blocked and randomized result analysis revealed that individual with ptsd symptom showed ab for trauma and depression related word however mode of administration did not significantly influence reaction time limitation the emotional stroop task cannot disentangle the underlying cognitive mechanism i e facilitation interference avoidance conclusion ptsd symptom in older trauma survivor are associated with ab overall participant with ptsd symptom did not show greater impairment of cognitive control in comparison to both control group result also illustrate that methodological difference between task version need to be considered more thoroughly

Title: Is trait resilience characterized by specific patterns of attentional bias to emotional stimuli and attentional control?
Authors: Schafer, J.; Wittchen, H. U.; Hofler, M.; Heinrich, A.; Zimmermann, P.; Siegel, S.; Schonfeld, S.
Abstract: background and objective attentional process have been suggested to play a crucial role in resilience defined a positive adaptation facing adversity however research is lacking on association between attentional bias to positive and threat related stimulus attentional control and trait resilience method data stem from the follow up assessment of a longitudinal study investigating mental health and related factor among german soldier trait resilience wa assessed with the connor davidson resilience scale and attentional control with the attentional control scale a subset of n 198 soldier also completed a dot probe task with happy neutral and threatening face result attentional control wa positively related to trait resilience result revealed no association between both attentional bias and trait resilience however there wa a negative association between attentional bias to threat and trait resilience when attentional control wa low and a positive association between attentional bias to threat and trait resilience when attentional control wa high no such association were found for attentional bias to positive stimulus limitation generalizability to other population may be limited since we exclusively focused on male soldier also the cross sectional design doe not allow for causal conclusion conclusion finding suggest that attentional processing may promote trait resilience future research on preventive intervention should consider these finding

Title: Guided reactivation of personal phobic memories prior to exposure exercises prevents the renewal of fear responses in subjects with claustrophobic fears
Authors: Hollandt, M.; Richter, J.
Abstract: background and objective basic research suggest behavioral strategy for interferencing the reconsolidation of fear memory to be a promising approach in reducing clinical fear however first clinical study revealed mixed result highlighting the need to identify boundary condition we experimentally tested the specific hypothesis that post retrieval threat exposure prevents context renewal usually observed in protocol without fear memory reactivation method in a preliminary investigation forty three individual with claustrophobic fear reactivated the individual phobic memory or not during a guided emotional imagery task and then performed standardized threat exposure to provide new information for updating the original memory during retests seven and 28 day later the context wa different from that during treatment in half of the subject result in those who were guided the fear memory wa successfully reactivated a indexed by increased skin conductance level scl during the imagery of personal scene relative to neutral scene during retests the subject of the memory non activation group showed a return of reported fear after context change that however wa not observed after post retrieval exposure in line autonomic arousal scl decreased over time in the memory reactivation group only if the context changed during retest limitation limited sample size and the inclusion of an analog sample reduce the generalizability of the result conclusion the reactivation of fear memory prior to treatment through guided imagery of past personal phobic situation prevented contextual renewal of phobic fear which wa observed in those subject without reactivation of memory

Title: Body-related cognitions, affect and post-event processing in body dysmorphic disorder
Authors: Kollei, I.; Martin, A.
Abstract: background and objective cognitive behavioural model postulate that individual with bdd engage in negative appearance related appraisal and affect external representation of one s appearance are thought to activate a specific mode of processing characterized by increased self focused attention and an activation of negative appraisal and affect method the present study used a think aloud approach including an in vivo body exposure to examine body related cognition and affect in individual with bdd n 30 a compared to individual with major depression n 30 and healthy control n 30 participant were instructed to think aloud during baseline exposure and follow up trial result individual with bdd verbalized more body related and more negative body related cognition during all trial and reported higher degree of negative affect than both control group a weaker increase of positive body related cognition during exposure a stronger increase of sadness and anger after exposure and higher level of post event processing were specific process in individual with bdd limitation individual with major depression were not excluded from the bdd group this is associated with a reduction of internal validity a the two clinical group are somewhat interwoven key finding need to be replicated conclusion the finding indicate that outcome such a negative appearance related cognition and affect are specific to individual with bdd an external representation of one s appearance activates a specific mode of processing in bdd manifesting itself in the absence of positive body related cognition increased anger and sadness and high level of post event processing these specific process may contribute toward maintenance of bdd psychopathology

Title: Implicit aggressiveness in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder as assessed by an Implicit Association Test
Authors: Cludius, B.; Schmidt, A. F.; Moritz, S.; Banse, R.; Jelinek, L.
Abstract: background and objective cognitive model of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd highlight the role of cognitive bias for the development of the disorder one of these bias an inflated sense of responsibility ha been associated with higher anger score and latent aggression on self report scale especially in patient with compulsive checking validity of self report assessment is however compromised by inaccuracy social desirability and low metacognitive awareness of trait and behavior in patient the aim of the present study wa to extend the research on latent aggression in individual with ocd by using an indirect implicit measure of aggression method fifty eight patient with ocd and 25 healthy control were assessed with an aggressiveness implicit association test iat which is a reaction time task that a the strength of association between the concept of aggressiveness and me compared to others result contrary to our expectation ocd patient with checking symptom showed a more peaceful implicit self concept than healthy control this result wa corroborated by negative correlation between checking symptom and implicit aggressiveness in the ocd sample limitation no self report measure on aggression or anger were included in the study conclusion in comparison to previous research using self report measure our study indicates that implicit aspect of aggression do indeed differ from controlled aspect in patient with checking compulsion future research is necessary to better understand the role of aggressiveness in ocd and to derive implication for therapy

Title: Cognitive restructuring and imagery modification for posttraumatic stress disorder (CRIM-PTSD): A pilot study
Authors: Muller-Engelmann, M.; Steil, R.
Abstract: background and objective cognitive restructuring and imagery modification for ptsd crim ptsd is a new short intervention it consists of the cognitive restructuring of core trauma related dysfunctional belief about the self and the use of imagery to encourage more functional belief a randomized controlled trial showed that crim wa effective for reducing posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd in survivor of childhood sexual abuse csa when it focused on the feeling of being contaminated for this study crim wa adapted to treat ptsd symptom more generally and after various type of trauma by addressing the patient negative self concept method ten patient with ptsd received two assessment session two treatment session and a booster session the clinician administered ptsd scale cap wa administered prior to and four week after treatment self rating e g the posttraumatic diagnostic scale pd and the posttraumatic cognition inventory ptci were administered at baseline immediately posttreatment and four week after treatment result the participant showed significant improvement in both clinician rated d 2 55 p 0 01 and self reported ptsd symptom d 1 47 p 0 01 one month after treatment 9 patient no longer fully met the diagnostic criterion for ptsd limitation the result are limited by the small sample size and the lack of a control group conclusion this pilot study suggests that addressing the negative self concept of ptsd patient using a combination of cognitive technique and imagery modification can effectively reduce ptsd symptom further research is needed to a the treatment s effect and stability in a randomized controlled trial

Title: The relation between generalized anxiety disorder symptoms and content-specific interpretation biases for auditory stimuli in children
Authors: Klein, A. M.; Bakens, R.; van Niekerk, R. E.; Ouwens, M. A.; Rapee, R. M.; Bogels, S. M.; Becker, E. S.; Rinck, M.
Abstract: background and objective cognitive theory of fear suggest that bias in interpretation are content specific fearful child should only interpret material negatively if they are specifically related to the content of their fear so far there are only a few study available that report on this postulated content specificity of interpretation process in childhood fear the goal of this study wa to examine interpretation bias and it content specificity in child with varying level of generalized anxiety disorder gad symptom method in an auditory interpretation task ait two word that differ by one phoneme are acoustically blended so that one can hear only one of the word in the current ait we included gad related blend negatively valenced fear related blend and positive blend multiple choice n 371 or open ended n 295 response were collected from 666 nonclinical child between 7 and 13 year of age result child with higher level of self reported gad showed significantly more negative interpretation of ambiguous gad related blend in the multiple choice version than child with lower level of gad there were no difference when interpreting the other ambiguous blend this result wa not found with the open ended version limitation effect were relatively small some gad stimulus were sub optimal and the task wa administered in a classroom setting even though we ensured that all child were able to hear all word clearly this may have impacted the result conclusion the finding only partly support the idea that fearful child display cognitive bias specific for fear relevant stimulus and more research is needed to replicate the result and test the usability of the ait

Title: Biases in attention, interpretation, memory, and associations in children with varying levels of spider fear: Inter-relations and prediction of behavior
Authors: Klein, A. M.; van Niekerk, R.; Ten Brink, G.; Rapee, R. M.; Hudson, J. L.; Bogels, S. M.; Becker, E. S.; Rinck, M.
Abstract: background and objective cognitive theory suggest that cognitive bias may be related and together influence the anxiety response however little is known about the interrelation of cognitive bias task and whether they allow for an improved prediction of fear related behavior in addition to self report this study simultaneously addressed several type of cognitive bias in child to investigate attention bias interpretation bias memory bias and fear related association their interrelation and the prediction of behavior method eighty one child varying in their level of spider fear completed the spider anxiety and disgust screening for child and performed two emotional stroop task a free recall task an interpretation task including size and distance indication an affective priming task and a behavioral assessment test result we found an attention bias interpretation bias and fear related association but no evidence for a memory bias the bias showed little overlap attention bias interpretation bias and fear related association predicted unique variance in avoidance of spider interpretation bias and fear related association remained significant predictor even when self reported fear wa included a a predictor limitation child were not seeking help for their spider fear and were not tested on clinical level of spider phobia conclusion this is the first study to find evidence that different cognitive bias each predict unique variance in avoidance behavior furthermore it is also the first study in which we found evidence for a relation between fear of spider and size and distance indication we showed that this bias is distinct from other cognitive bias

Title: The Influence of Alcohol on Rumination and Metacognitions in Major Depressive Disorder
Authors: Gawron, L.; Pohl, A.; Gerlach, A. L.
Abstract: background and objective comorbidity between major depressive disorder mdd and alcohol use disorder aud is highly prevalent but reason for this association are unclear rumination may activate metacognitive belief that contribute to the development and maintenance of rumination and depression negative metacognitions can further lead to other dysfunctional coping strategy i e consumption of alcohol we examined whether alcohol reduces state metacognitions rumination and other disorder specific process in a group of individual suffering from mdd method in an experiment with three randomized condition we investigated whether the consumption of alcohol placebo or no alcohol orange juice affect meta cognition depressive symptom and or psychophysiological variable while participant ruminate result voluntary rumination increased self reported sadness tension and rumination tensed facial muscle and increased heart rate but did not affect state metacognitions and heart rate variability the consumption of alcohol did not influence rumination metacognitions depressive or psychophysiological measure limitation we recruited a depressed population but excluded pathological alcohol use due to ethical consideration conclusion we found no evidence that alcohol consumption affect rumination metacognitions and other disorder specific process in mdd however rumination had a negative effect on various depression specific process although it did not activate negative state metacognitions

Title: [Posttraumatic Stress and Depressive Symptoms amongst Asylum Seekers]
Authors: Kroger, C.; Frantz, I.; Friel, P.; Heinrichs, N.
Abstract: background and objective currently there is a large number of refugee that are coming to germany from civil war zone the aim of this study wa to estimate the extent of posttraumatic stress and depressive symptom amongst asylum seeker in germany method in the summer of 2015 280 adult refugee 88 2 men were interviewed with the support of translator in the lower saxony state refugee reception center brunswick data wa categorized due to country of origin balkan state middle east northern africa rest of africa the posttraumatic diagnostic scale 8 pd 8 and the patient health questionnaire phq 8 were employed a screening measure if the threshold value of 12 in the pd 8 or 15 in the phq are exceeded respectively the diagnosis of ptsd or depression is highly likely result participant reported an overall high number of potentially traumatic experience 72 5 war experience 67 9 violent attack 51 4 another very burdensome experience 50 0 torture 47 9 imprisonment 11 1 sexual assault whereby multiple answer were possible the prevalence rate for possible ptsd were 16 1 balkan state 20 5 middle east 23 4 rest of africa and 28 1 northern africa rate for a possible depression varied between the country of origin from 17 9 35 9 28 1 to 24 0 respectively conclusion compared to the german population the rate of traumatic experience and the prevalence of a possible ptsd were significantly higher amongst asylum seeker of the present sample this wa not the case for depression the integration of affected asylum seeker may be considerably complicated due to health impairment e g with regard to learning the german language and admission to educational or occupational service

Title: Body dysmorphic concerns, social adaptation, and motivation for psychotherapeutic support in dermatological outpatients
Authors: Ritter, V.; Fluhr, J. W.; Schliemann-Willers, S.; Elsner, P.; Strauss, B.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: background and objective dermatologist are increasingly confronted with patient affected by body dysmorphic disorder bdd bdd is characterized by excessive preoccupation with one or more perceived defect s or flaw s in physical appearance which are not observable or appear slight to others so far there have been only few study examining the prevalence of bdd in dermatological outpatient in addition the need for psychotherapeutic support in dermatological outpatient with body dysmorphic concern ha not yet been systematically examined the objective of the present study wa therefore to investigate the frequency of body dysmorphic concern a well a social adaptation and the need for psychotherapeutic support in the aforementioned patient group patient and method a total of 252 dermatological outpatient seen at a german university hospital were consecutively enrolled and examined using the dysmorphic concern questionnaire the social adaptation self evaluation scale and the german version of the university of rhode island change assessment scale result 7 9 of all outpatient unselected sample showed positive test result suggesting clinically relevant body dysmorphic concern patient with clinically relevant body dysmorphic concern exhibited poor social adaptation contrary to expectation these patient revealed a high motivation for change indicating the necessity for psychotherapeutic support conclusion our finding confirm previous prevalence rate of bdd in dermatological outpatient and highlight the need for providing psychotherapeutic support to dermatological patient

Title: Reducing analogue trauma symptoms by computerized reappraisal training - considering a cognitive prophylaxis?
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Postma, P.; Holmes, E. A.; Mackintosh, B.
Abstract: background and objective distressing intrusion are a hallmark of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd dysfunctional appraisal of these symptom may exacerbate the disorder and conversely may lead to further intrusive memory this raise the intriguing possibility that learning to reappraise potential symptom more functionally may protect against such symptom woud holmes postma dalgleish and mackintosh 2012 found that reappraisal training when delivered after an analogue stressful event reduced later intrusive memory and other posttraumatic symptom the present study aimed to investigate whether reappraisal training administered before a stressful event is also beneficial method participant first received positive or negative reappraisal training cbm app training using a series of scripted vignette subsequently participant were exposed to a film with traumatic content effect of the cbm app training procedure were assessed via three distinct outcome measure namely a post training appraisal of novel ambiguous vignette b change score on the post traumatic cognition inventory ptci and c intrusive symptom diary result cbm app training successfully induced training congruent appraisal style moreover those trained positively reported le distress arising from their intrusive memory of the trauma film during the subsequent week than those trained negatively however the induced appraisal bias only partly affected ptci score limitation participant used their own negative event a a reference for the ptci assessment the event may have differed regarding their emotional impact there wa no control group conclusion cbm app training ha also some beneficial effect when applied before a stressful event and may serve a a cognitive prophylaxis against trauma related symptomatology

Title: Body-related attentional biases in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder resulting from childhood sexual abuse with and without co-occurring borderline personality disorder
Authors: Witthoft, M.; Borgmann, E.; White, A.; Dyer, A.
Abstract: background and objective disturbed body perception is a common characteristic of patient with posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd after childhood sexual abuse csa we examined the extent to which biased information processing of body related stimulus wa related to csa method patient with ptsd after csa ptsd group n 61 were compared to healthy control hc group n 30 the ptsd group wa subdivided into patient with comorbid borderline personality disorder bpd ptsd group and patient without bpd ptsd group we used an emotional stroop task est with body related word to a biased information processing result only patient in the ptsd group but not in the ptsd group showed a significantly stronger attentional bias to body related word compared to the hc group p 009 limitation recruitment in in patient setting might have led to a non representative sample of ptsd patient the ptsd patient were not characterized regarding anything other than the mentioned mental disorder potentially the body related word may have been associated with offender body area but not with the patient conclusion we found that patient with ptsd and comorbid bpd had a stronger attentional bias towards body related stimulus in comparison to other group this suggests that the observed attentional bias is a product of csa combined with the emotion regulation difficulty characteristic of bpd future study should test whether directly targeting body related abnormality in information processing can improve existing treatment for patient with csa and bpd

Title: The approach-avoidance task as an online intervention in cigarette smoking: a pilot study
Authors: Wittekind, C. E.; Feist, A.; Schneider, B. C.; Moritz, S.; Fritzsche, A.
Abstract: background and objective dual process model posit that addictive behavior are characterized by strong automatic process that can be assessed with implicit measure the present study investigated the potential of a cognitive bias modification paradigm the approach avoidance task aat for retraining automatic behavioral tendency in cigarette smoking method the study wa set up a an online intervention after completing an online survey 257 smoker were randomly allocated either to one of two experimental condition aat or a waitlist control group participant responded to different picture by pushing or pulling the computer mouse depending on the format of the picture picture in portrait format depicted smoking related item and were associated with pushing picture in landscape format depicted neutral item and were associated with pulling one version of the aat provided individual feedback after each trial whereas the standard version did not after four week participant were re assessed in an online survey result analysis revealed that the standard aat in particular led to a significant reduction in cigarette consumption cigarette dependence and compulsive drive no effect wa found in the control group limitation interpretability of the study is constrained by the fact that no active control condition wa applied conclusion notwithstanding the limitation our finding indicate that the aat might be a feasible instrument to reduce tobacco dependence and can be applied a an online intervention future study should investigate whether the effect of behavior therapy can be augmented when combined with retraining intervention

Title: [Burn-On Instead of Burn-Out: Self-Care and Functional Coping Strategies Protect Psychotherapists from Psychological Stress During the Corona Pandemic]
Authors: Schwartzkopff, L.; Schuller, J.; Muller-Engelmann, M.
Abstract: background and objective due to the corona pandemic psychotherapist are confronted with new professional challenge regarding the patient care to be provided the question of risk and protective factor for maintaining well being during the pandemic appears relevant to prevent negative long term consequence such a burnout this is the first study investigating the influence of coping and self care strategy on the psychological distress of psychotherapist in germany during the corona pandemic method from april to june 2020 155 psychotherapist completed an online questionnaire additionally to job related change stress level symptom of burnout and well being were assessed furthermore the influence of active and passive coping strategy a well a of different area of self care e g professional support cognitive awareness for work related stress and work life balance on psychological burden wa examined result psychotherapist worked an average of 1 22 hour le per week during the pandemic than before on average 38 of treatment were delivered via video therapy avoidant coping strategy were associated with increased stress level which predicted higher burnout score and lower well being in contrast a good work life balance a good daily balance at work and active coping had a positive effect contrary to expectation cognitive awareness for work related stress wa related to lower well being discussion work life balance can serve a a preventive strategy to reduce stress during the corona pandemic and thereby reduce the risk for burnout and improve well being avoidant coping strategy on the other hand are a risk factor for increased stress level during pandemic and promote burnout and lower well being conclusion this study contributes to our knowledge regarding preventive measure to prevent stress and to maintain the well being of psychotherapist in order to contribute to ongoing high quality patient care during the pandemic

Title: Introducing an EXperimental Paradigm to investigate Expectation Change (EXPEC)
Authors: Kube, T.; Rief, W.; Gollwitzer, M.; Glombiewski, J. A.
Abstract: background and objective dysfunctional expectation are considered to be core feature of various mental disorder clinical observation suggest that people suffering from mental disorder such a major depression tend to maintain dysfunctional expectation despite expectation disconfirming evidence surprisingly this clinically relevant phenomenon ha not yet sufficiently been investigated in empirical study therefore we developed an experimental paradigm to investigate expectation change v maintenance and the first step to test it validity is to apply it in healthy individual method after conducting two pilot study n 28 n 37 the present study systematically examined whether it is possible to change healthy individual n 102 task specific and generalized performance expectation through expectation disconfirming experience using a standardized instruction we initially induced non positive expectation regarding participant ability to successfully work on an unknown test then participant received standardized performance feedback that either confirmed or disconfirmed their expectation before assessing participant expectation again after completing the test for the measure of emotional intelligence result result indicate that expectation disconfirming feedback led to a significant change of both task specific and generalized performance expectation there wa no expectation change in the expectation confirming condition limitation a the present study examined expectation change among healthy individual the next step is to apply this paradigm in a clinical sample and to examine whether expectation change is le likely among people suffering from depression or other mental disorder characterized by dysfunctional expectation conclusion focusing more rigorously on expectation maintenance among people with mental disorder could enable therapist to develop expectation focused intervention aiming at enhancing expectation change

Title: Preventive efforts in the aftermath of analogue trauma: The effects of Tetris and exercise on intrusive images
Authors: Bruhl, A.; Heinrichs, N.; Bernstein, E. E.; McNally, R. J.
Abstract: background and objective efficacious intervention soon after trauma exposure to prevent posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd are scarce evidence suggests that post trauma reminder cue to reactivate trauma memory followed by a cognitive visuospatial task such a tetri reduce later intrusive image furthermore study indicate that aerobic exercise may reduce ptsd symptom the present study aimed to test whether playing tetri without prior reminder cue after an experimental trauma limit the development of analogue symptom and to compare tetri to aerobic exercise which could plausibly alter cognitive affective processing of the trauma a well method participant n 71 watched a distressing film and were randomly assigned to either playing tetri cycling or remaining sedentary for 25 min without prior reminder cue intrusive image and co occurring distress were recorded in a diary during the following week after one week participant completed a recognition test to a voluntary memory of the film result neither tetri nor exercise without prior memory reactivation reduced intrusive image and associated distress nor impeded voluntary memory compared to the control condition there were no effect of physical fitness level at baseline or voluntary exercise during the subsequent week on analogue symptom limitation although participant were instructed to record intrusion a they occurred in diary they did not receive additional reminder throughout the follow up period conclusion our finding suggest that neither a single bout of aerobic exercise nor playing tetri without prior memory reactivation after an analogue trauma reduces stress symptom potential explanation and clinical implication are discussed

Title: Remembering rejection: specificity and linguistic styles of autobiographical memories in borderline personality disorder and depression
Authors: Rosenbach, C.; Renneberg, B.
Abstract: background and objective high level of rejection sensitivity are assumed to be the result of early and prolonged experience of rejection aim of this study wa to investigate autobiographical memory of rejection in clinical sample high in rejection sensitivity borderline personality disorder bpd and major depressive disorder mdd and to identify group difference in the quality of the memory method memory of rejection were retrieved using an adapted version of the autobiographical memory test amt five positive cue word five cue word referring to rejection specificity of memory and linguistic word usage wa analyzed in 30 patient with bpd 27 patient with mdd and 30 healthy control result patient with bpd retrieved le specific memory compared to the healthy control group whereas patient with mdd did not differ from control in this regard the group difference wa no longer significant when controlling for rejection sensitivity linguistic analysis indicated that compared to both other group patient with bpd showed a higher self focus used more anger related word referred more frequently to social environment and rated memory of rejection a more relevant for today s life limitation clinical symptom were not assessed in the control group moreover the written form of the amt might reduce the total number of specific memory conclusion the level of rejection sensitivity influenced the specificity of the retrieved memory analysis of linguistic style revealed specific linguistic pattern in bpd compared to non clinical a well a depressed participant

Title: The effects of retrieval versus rehearsal of online problem-solving therapy sessions on recall, problem-solving skills and distress in distressed individuals: An experimental study
Authors: Bruijniks, S. J. E.; Sijbrandij, M.; Huibers, M. J. H.
Abstract: background and objective improving memory for the content of therapy session might increase the effect of psychological intervention previous study showed that healthy individual who took a memory test retrieval of studied material showed better long term memory retention than individual who restudied rehearsal the material the aim of the current study wa to find out whether we can translate these finding to a subclinical setting method individual with moderate level of distress were randomized into retrieving n 46 or rehearsing n 49 four weekly session of online problem solving therapy pst session recall problem solving skill and distress were measured at baseline three day after each session and at one week follow up result retrieval led to overall higher recall but this difference disappeared when controlling for the time spent on retrieval versus rehearsal retrieval did not lead to better problem solving skill or le distress compared to rehearsal baseline working memory performance moderated the effect of condition on recall after controlling for the time spent on retrieval versus rehearsal the effect of retrieval compared to rehearsal on recall wa larger for individual with lower working memory performance limitation the sample mostly consisted of university student with overall high working memory score conclusion this study provided the first evidence that retrieval of the content of pst session may lead to better session recall compared to rehearsal of the pst session in individual with a low working memory score implication for the use of cognitive support strategy within a therapeutic setting are discussed

Title: Effects of induced appearance-related interpretation bias: A test of the cognitive-behavioral model of body dysmorphic disorder
Authors: Dietel, F. A.; Mobius, M.; Steinbach, L.; Dusend, C.; Wilhelm, S.; Buhlmann, U.
Abstract: background and objective interpretation bias are hypothesized to maintain body dysmorphic disorder bdd although their existence and malleability have been investigated in clinical study their causal status in the maintenance of bdd remains unclear this study examined the effect of a single session appearance related interpretation bias training cbm i on bias index and stress reactivity i e distress appearance dissatisfaction self esteem perceived physical attractiveness exploring the causality predicted in cognitive behavioral model method we used a modified version of the word sentence association paradigm wsap assessing explicit i e decision rate and more implicit interpretation bias component i e reaction time mentally healthy student n 112 were randomized to training condition enhancing positive interpretation pattern pt v negative interpretation pattern nt v a no feedback control condition cc stress reactivity wa assessed during the cyberball paradigm result the pt showed a pre post increase in adaptive bias pattern regarding decision and a differential pre post decrease in reaction time for the rejection of negative interpretation compared to the other group there were no condition congruent post training difference in stress reactivity however residual interpretation bias change wa significantly correlated with state distress self esteem and appearance dissatisfaction during stressor exposure limitation limitation pertaining to sample characteristic training and assessment overlap and stressor task design are discussed conclusion finding suggest that appearance related interpretation bias is modifiable both explicitly and more implicitly via cbm i in a mentally healthy sample the causal status of interpretation bias in bdd maintenance warrant further investigation

Title: Enhanced association between perceptual stimuli and trauma-related information in individuals with posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms
Authors: Lin, M.; Hofmann, S. G.; Qian, M.; Li, S.
Abstract: background and objective intrusive memory in traumatized individual are often triggered by stimulus that are perceptually rather than conceptually similar to those present just before or during the trauma the present study examined whether those individual with high level of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd symptom show a memory bias recall to perceptual cue and trauma target word compared to those with low level of ptsd method the sample consisted of 30 adult participant who were involved in motor vehicle or work related accident 15 of the participant endorsed clinically elevated symptom of ptsd while a comparison group of 15 participant reported low level of symptom participant performed an associative recognition task with conceptual or perceptual cue word and trauma related or neutral target word participant were tested for their recognition accuracy by reporting the corresponding target when a cue wa given result both group performed better for the perceptual word pair than for the conceptual word pair irrespective of the target word type however only the high ptsd symptom group exhibited an additional enhancement in performance for the perceptual word pair with trauma related target word limitation a nonclinical sample wa utilized for this study although ptsd wa assessed diagnosis were not confirmed in addition there wa lack of a healthy non traumatized control group conclusion these result provide partial support for the cognitive model and the notion that intrusive memory are specific to the trauma related event rather than to a general associative learning bias

Title: If the discrepancy between expectations and actual information is too large, expectation change decreases - A replication study
Authors: Kube, T.
Abstract: background and objective mental disorder have been related to aberration in using novel positive information to revise established negative belief previous research used to make a binary distinction between belief confirming v disconfirming information but recently it ha been examined how varying level of positive information is used to update belief the present study aimed to replicate a recent finding suggesting that positive information that deviate to a large extent from people s prior expectation raise doubt about the credibility of new information and therefore hardly lead to change in expectation method in a heterogenous sample n 144 participant were provided with slightly positive moderately positive or extremely positive information in relation to their prior expectation about other people s behaviour result replicating previous research the present study found that expectation change wa greatest for moderately positive information it also provided evidence for a possible mechanism underlying the inverse u shaped relationship between the positivity of new information and change in expectation extremely positive information wa devalued through defensive cognitive strategy referred to a cognitive immunisation limitation unlike previous research the belief update task used in this study did not show any association with depressive symptom so it is questionable how suitable it is to study biased belief updating in depression conclusion unlike traditional learning model the present result suggest a tipping point above which the discrepancy between expectation and outcome is suspiciously large so that the degree of expectation change decrease

Title: Disrupted joint action accounts for reduced likability of socially anxious individuals
Authors: Gunak, M. M.; Clark, D. M.; Lommen, M. J. J.
Abstract: background and objective motivated by their fear of disapproval individual with social anxiety continually monitor their own behaviour during social interaction hoping to prevent dreaded negative outcome ironically they do evoke le positive reaction from others this study investigated whether lower engagement in the interpersonal process of joint action by socially anxious individual lead them to attract le positive rating by their conversation partner method high socially anxious hsa n 36 and low socially anxious individual lsa n 36 had separate conversation with a naive conversation partner n 36 conversation were filmed and analysed for joint action using the conventional manual way and a more exploratory automated way conversation partner rated the quality of the interaction and the person they talked to result conversation partner rated hsa participant le positively than lsa participant the conventional manual method showed le joint action in conversation with lsa participant and crucially joint action served a mediator between social anxiety status and general impression quality of interaction and desire to meet again these result were not replicated with the automated method limitation the study used an analogue sample and future research should investigate whether these finding also apply to a clinical sample future study should further explore the utility of automated technique to measure joint action conclusion reduced joint action may explain why socially anxious individual tend to be perceived le positively by others the finding emphasise the importance of taking an interpersonal and holistic approach to understanding aspect of social anxiety disorder

Title: Haunting self-images? The role of negative self-images in adolescent social anxiety disorder
Authors: Schreiber, F.; Steil, R.
Abstract: background and objective negative distorted self image nsi allegedly maintain social anxiety in adult suffering from social anxiety disorder sad these nsi are activated in feared social situation and are often linked to past socially traumatic event however because empirical evidence on the presence and characteristic of such nsi in adolescent suffering from sad is limited the aim of the present study is to examine the nature of nsi in adolescent sad patient method using a semi structured interview 31 adolescent with a primary diagnosis of sad and 31 healthy adolescent ha who were matched for age and gender completed a questionnaire set assessing the characteristic of nsi social anxiety and depression result relative to the ha group those suffering from sad reported experiencing nsi significantly more frequently more vividly and with greater distress no significant difference between the group emerged regarding a link between the nsi and an autobiographical event however nsi were reported a more often having an observer perspective in the sad a compared to the ha group hierarchical regression analysis revealed that certain characteristic of the nsi predict social anxiety beyond the influence of depression in adolescent with sad discussion nsi seem to be an important feature of adolescent sad and phenomenological comparable to nsi in adult suffering from sad conclusion specific intervention aiming to correct nsi which have proven to be highly effective in adult should be developmentally adapted and evaluated in future study

Title: The perils of aiming too high: Discrepancy between goals and performance in individuals with depressive symptoms
Authors: Arens, E. A.; Zeier, P.; Schwieren, C.; Huisgen, H.; Barnow, S.
Abstract: background and objective negative evaluation process play a pivotal role in the development and maintenance of depressive symptom however it remains to be understood whether evaluation process in depression are impaired by maladaptive goal setting method in a non clinical sample n 50 of individual with high bdi ii score 13 29 and low bdi ii score 0 3 level of depressive symptom goal setting prior to working on a cognitive task wa measured goal feasibility wa experimentally manipulated using an easy and a difficult version of the task result when goal feasibility wa low a high level of depressive symptom wa associated with setting unattainable goal whereas individual with low level of depressive symptom adjusted their goal to a lower more realistic level when task difficulty increased individual with high level of depressive symptom initially adhered to significantly higher goal so that their performance failed to meet their self set standard after depressed individual revised their goal downwards their subsequent performance on the task also worsened limitation the use of a non clinical sample with self reported depressive symptom limit the generalizability of our finding to a clinical population future research would benefit from the use of a larger sample with patient suffering from clinical depression conclusion the finding support the notion that negative evaluation process in depressed individual might be linked with their tendency to generate intractable conflict between self set inappropriate high goal and their own capacity to perform however the finding need to be confirmed in clinical sample to draw conclusion about the role of goal setting in negative evaluation process in depression

Title: Nocebo hyperalgesia induced by implicit conditioning
Authors: Brascher, A. K.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: background and objective nocebo hyperalgesia i e increased pain sensitivity based on expectation can be induced by conditioning but is supposed to be mediated by conscious expectation although recent evidence point to the feasibility of subliminal conditioning of nocebo hyperalgesia with masked face face processing might be a special case and the practical implication of subliminal conditioning remain questionable this study aimed to implicitly condition nocebo hyperalgesia using supraliminal cue method implicit differential nocebo conditioning n 48 healthy participant wa implemented by coupling high and low painful electric stimulus to varying visual stimulus that only differed in the symmetry asymmetry of one component c c and contained further distracting component in the test phase only the low painful stimulus followed both c to test for conditioned nocebo effect in intensity and aversiveness rating and electrodermal activity a behavioral contingency test and a post experimental questionnaire assessed contingency awareness result a conditioned effect emerged in the aversiveness p 036 eta 2 0 09 but not in the intensity rating p 195 while controlling for contingency awareness further increased skin conductance level in response to c emerged irrespective of contingency awareness p 014 eta 2 0 13 no conditioned response in skin conductance response emerged p 872 limitation expected effect only emerged in part of the outcome variable conclusion the result support the notion that implicit conditioning of nocebo hypoalgesia is feasible using a novel experimental conditioning design with supraliminal stimulus presentation although further research is needed so far implicitly conditioned nocebo effect might have been underestimated despite vast clinical implication

Title: The relationship between drinking motives and alcohol-related interpretation biases
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Becker, E. S.; Rinck, M.; Salemink, E.
Abstract: background and objective numerous study have investigated drinking motif and alcohol related interpretation bias ibs separately however le is known about the relationship between them therefore the present study examined whether coping and enhancement drinking motif were specifically related to negative and positive alcohol related ibs respectively furthermore it wa investigated whether such bias predict future drinking especially in individual with low level of executive control ec method participant were male and female university student the drinking motif questionnaire revised dmq r cooper 1994 wa administered to measure participant drinking motif to measure alcohol related ibs an adapted version of the encoding recognition task ert wa used during the ert participant were asked to read ambiguous alcohol related scenario in a subsequent recognition phase participant interpreted these scenario a classical stroop wa applied to a level of ec result coping motif but not enhancement motif were a unique predictor of the tendency to interpret negatively valenced ambiguous alcohol relevant situation in an alcohol related manner this relationship wa significant even when controlling for other relevant predictor neither coping nor enhancement motif were predictive of positive alcohol related ibs concerning the prediction of prospective drinking result showed that particularly the negative alcohol related ib predicted prospective drinking however ec did not moderate the prediction of prospective drinking by either positive or negative interpretation bias limitation the alcohol ert might not be the most optimal paradigm for assessing implicit alcohol related ibs conclusion the present result emphasize the role of negative affect in the context of drinking motif and alcohol related ibs follow up study are needed to test the robustness of these finding and to further explore the general interplay between drinking motif and alcohol related ibs

Title: Assessment of automatic associations with bodily sensations and agoraphobic situations in panic disorder
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Becker, E. S.; Rinck, M.; Harmer, C. J.; Reinecke, A.
Abstract: background and objective one of the central assumption of cognitive model of panic disorder pd is that automatic panic related association are a core feature of pd however empirical finding are mixed and inconsistent rendering it difficult to evaluate the role of panic related association adequately particularly in relation to the relevant theory the present study aimed to further advance our understanding of automatic association in pd and therefore applied a paradigm novel in this context namely an extrinsic affective simon task east method participant involved treatment seeking unmedicated panic patient n 45 and healthy control n 38 the east wa applied prior to treatment it included the following stimulus a target panic related bodily sensation and agoraphobia related situation and a attribute pleasant versus unpleasant fear related word result contrary to our expectation panic patient did not show stronger negative than positive automatic association for either panic related symptom or agoraphobia related situation compared to healthy control moreover east effect did not correlate with panic related self report measure limitation although the present study involved patient who were actively seeking treatment panic related association might not have been activated sufficiently hence a brief activation procedure e g hyperventilation might have been needed to optimize the assessment condition conclusion the present finding do not support contemporary theory of panic related association therefore follow up work is needed to disentangle their functional and operational property more thoroughly

Title: Risky decision-making under risk in schizophrenia: A deliberate choice?
Authors: Pedersen, A.; Goder, R.; Tomczyk, S.; Ohrmann, P.
