Abstract: background and objective patient with schizophrenia reveal impaired decision making strategy causing social financial and health care problem the extent to which deficit in decision making reflect intentional risky choice in schizophrenia is still under debate based on previous study we expected patient with schizophrenia to reveal a riskier performance on the gdt and to make more disadvantageous decision on the igt method in the present study we investigated 38 patient with schizophrenia and 38 matched healthy control subject with two competing paradigm regarding feedback 1 the game of dice task gdt in which the probability of winning or losing are stable and explicitly disclosed to the subject to a decision making under risk and 2 the iowa gambling task igt which requires subject to infer the probability of winning or losing from feedback to investigate decision making under ambiguity result patient with schizophrenia revealed an overall riskier performance on the gdt although they adjusted their strategy over the course of the gdt they still made significantly more disadvantageous choice than control more positive symptom in patient with schizophrenia indicated by higher pan positive score were associated with riskier choice and le use of negative feedback compared to healthy control they were not impaired in net score but chose more disadvantageous card than control on the first block of the igt limitation effect of medication at the time of testing cannot be ruled out conclusion our finding suggest that patient with schizophrenia make riskier decision and are le able to regulate their decision making to implement advantageous strategy even when the probability of winning or losing are explicitly disclosed the dissociation between performance on the gdt and igt suggests a pronounced impairment of executive function related to the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex

Title: Age effect on autobiographical memory specificity: A study on autobiographical memory specificity in elderly survivors of childhood trauma
Authors: Wittekind, C. E.; Jelinek, L.; Kleim, B.; Muhtz, C.; Moritz, S.; Berna, F.
Abstract: background and objective post traumatic stress disorder ptsd is accompanied by altered autobiographical memory am of the traumatic incident itself a well a of non trauma related event several study have shown that trauma exposed individual developing ptsd have a reduced capacity to access specific past event that are not related to the traumatic event compared to those who do not develop ptsd however one study including a group of elderly adult did not find significant difference in am between ptsd and non ptsd participant the present study investigated whether ptsd is associated with impaired am of trauma related and non trauma related memory in the elderly method forty four elderly participant displaced during childhood from former german territory after the end of world war ii wwii were examined this group comprised 19 participant with and 25 participant without ptsd these participant were compared to 23 non traumatized non displaced elderly participant result ptsd non ptsd and non traumatized participant do not differ significantly in their ability to recall specific memory of their past moreover participant with ptsd did not recall more trauma related memory than non ptsd participant limitation the traumatized participant reached for assessment might represent the most resilient individual which might constrain generalizability of our result to other trauma population conclusion this study confirms preliminary evidence that ptsd is not associated with am impairment in the elderly we suggest that aging may alter the relationship between trauma and am impairment in traumatized participant with ptsd which need to be confirmed by longitudinal study

Title: Linking Depression with Negative Alcohol-Related Consequences: A Structural Equation Model Among a Clinically Depressed Population
Authors: Gawron, L.; Gerlach, A. L.
Abstract: background and objective previous research suggests that rumination act a a mediating mechanism in the association between depression and drinking motif particularly drinking to cope a well a negative alcohol related consequence in this study we tested the connection between depressive symptom rumination drinking motif alcohol consumption and alcohol related problem in a clinically depressed population n 209 method structural equation modeling wa used to test the model specification were based on the result of a previously evaluated model in a sample of college student result the complex model showed a significant positive association between depressive symptom and rumination drinking motif enhancement and coping were linked to more negative alcohol related consequence in a simplified model pronounced depressive symptom were associated with both increased ruminative thinking and more negative alcohol related problem rumination wa connected with stronger drinking motif combined in one general factor which were again associated with alcohol consumption and alcohol related problem limitation the use of self report measure to determine diagnostic validity conclusion in a clinically depressed sample depressive symptom were linked to increased negative alcohol related consequence this association wa partially explained by rumination and drinking motif however rumination wa le relevant than previous study suggested

Title: Grab it or not? Measuring avoidance of spiders with touchscreen-based hand movements
Authors: Rinck, M.; Dapprich, A.; Lender, A.; Kahveci, S.; Blechert, J.
Abstract: background and objective previous study have shown that human particularly those with high level of spider fear show automatic avoidance of spider however most task used in these study employ symbolic approach avoidance movement instead of naturalistic movement method the current study employed a touchscreen based approach avoidance task in which 86 female participant made hand and arm movement that mimic the real life touching grasping and moving of spider using a large touchscreen they had to reach for picture of spider and neutral object leaf touch them and drag them either away from themselves or towards themselves to draw attention to stimulus content picture of butterfly were used in additional nogo trial they required participant to not move their hand result avoidance of spider wa observed in both the pre movement time time to lift the hand from a starting position and the grabbing time time to reach the picture and this avoidance wa larger for more spider fearful participant the dragging time time to swipe the picture however revealed a relative spider approach tendency compared to leaf participant were faster to drag spider closer than to swipe them away limitation we discus potential reason for this mixed pattern of result including the low reliability of the dragging time conclusion we recommend the use of touchscreen for the assessment of approach avoidance tendency and we suggest avenue for further research

Title: Changes in negative implicit evaluations in patients of hypochondriasis after treatment with cognitive therapy or exposure therapy
Authors: Schreiber, F.; Witthoft, M.; Neng, J. M.; Weck, F.
Abstract: background and objective previous study using modified version of the affect misattribution procedure amp payne cheng govorun stewart 2005 have revealed that there is an implicit negative evaluation bias of illness related information in patient with hypochondriasis hyp which might be a maintaining feature of hyp however there is no evidence on whether this bias might be targeted successfully by effective treatment such a exposure therapy et or cognitive therapy ct this is the first study to examine the change in negative implicit evaluation in a randomized controlled trial including individual ct and et compared to a wait list control group for hyp method an amp with illness symptom and neutral prime wa used in 70 patient with hyp before and after treatment wait list respectively result there wa no significant change in negative implicit affective evaluation in both ct and et compared to wait list however comparison between the two active treatment revealed an interaction effect that only for ct were the affective reaction on illness a well a symptom related prime trial but not neutral prime significantly more positive at post compared to pre treatment in ct but not in et the reduction of implicit negative evaluation bias regarding symptom related prime wa significantly related to the reduction of self reported health anxiety limitation the small subsample size for ct and et in comparison to wait list prohibit the detection of smaller effect conclusion formal cognitive restructuring is necessary for reducing implicit negative evaluation bias in hyp but the latter is not a prerequisite for reducing health anxiety thus the importance of the negative implicit evaluation bias for the maintenance of hyp remains questionable

Title: Social interactions in virtual reality exposure therapy: A proof-of-concept pilot study
Authors: Morina, N.; Brinkman, W. P.; Hartanto, D.; Kampmann, I. L.; Emmelkamp, P. M.
Abstract: background and objective research on virtual reality exposure therapy vret ha demonstrated good treatment efficacy with regard to several anxiety disorder yet there is lack of knowledge about the value of integrating interaction between client and virtual human in vret such interaction might prove effective in treating psychological complaint that involve social interaction such a social anxiety method a vret system specifically designed to expose client with social anxiety disorder to anxiety provoking social situation wa applied to 16 and 18 individual with high and low level of social anxiety respectively participant engaged in two exposure session in several free speech dialogue with virtual human while being monitored by a therapist result participant with high level of social anxiety reported significantly lower level of social anxiety three month after exposure to two virtual reality interaction session than before treatment p 0 01 in the group with low level of social anxiety no significant change of social anxiety wa reported between pre treatment and follow up additionally participant in both group reported higher self efficacy three month after treatment than before treatment p 0 001 conclusion these finding indicate that virtual reality technology that incorporates social interaction may be successfully applied for therapeutic purpose

Title: A virtual reality-integrated program for improving social skills in patients with schizophrenia: a pilot study
Authors: Rus-Calafell, M.; Gutierrez-Maldonado, J.; Ribas-Sabate, J.
Abstract: background and objective social skill training sst intervention ha shown it efficacy to improve social dysfunction in patient with psychosis however the implementation of new skill into patient everyday functioning is difficult to achieve in this study we report result from the application of a virtual reality vr integrated program a an adjunct technique to a brief social skill intervention for patient with schizophrenia it wa predicted that the intervention would improve social cognition and performance of patient a well a generalisation of the learned response into patient s daily life method twelve patient with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder completed the study they attended sixteen individual one hour session and outcome assessment were conducted at pre treatment post treatment and four month follow up result the result of a series of repeated measure anova revealed significant improvement in negative symptom psychopathology social anxiety and discomfort avoidance and social functioning objective score obtained through the use of the vr program showed a pattern of learning in emotion perception assertive behaviour and time spent in a conversation most of these gain were maintained at four month follow up limitation the reported result are based on a small uncontrolled pilot study although there wa an independent rater for the self reported and informant questionnaire assessment were not blinded conclusion the result showed that the intervention may be effective for improving social dysfunction the use of the vr program contributed to the generalisation of new skill into the patient s everyday functioning

Title: Schema therapy for chronic depression: Results of a multiple single case series
Authors: Renner, F.; Arntz, A.; Peeters, F. P.; Lobbestael, J.; Huibers, M. J.
Abstract: background and objective the aim of this study wa to test the effect of individual schema therapy st for patient with chronic depression method using a multiple baseline single case series design patient with chronic major depressive disorder n 25 first entered a 6 24 week baseline phase this phase functioned a a no treatment control condition then patient started a 12 week exploration phase during which symptom and underlying schema were explored this phase functioned a an attention control condition next patient received up to 65 session of individual st the beck depression inventory ii bdi ii and the quick inventory of depressive symptomatology qids were the primary outcome measure the bdi ii wa assessed once a week during all phase of the study resulting in 100 repeated assessment per participant on average mixed regression analysis wa used to contrast change in symptom during the intervention with change in symptom during the baseline and exploration control phase result when compared to the no treatment control period the intervention had a significant large effect on depressive symptom cohen s d bdi ii 1 30 cohen s d qids 1 22 effect on secondary continuous outcome were moderate to large limitation the small sample size and lack of a control group conclusion these finding provide evidence that st might be an effective treatment for patient with chronic depression

Title: Interpreting and responding to ambiguous natural images in spider phobia
Authors: Haberkamp, A.; Schmidt, F.; Biafora, M.; Schmidt, T.
Abstract: background and objective the fast detection of and response to threatening stimulus is an important task of the human visual and motor system and is especially challenging when stimulus are ambiguous this study investigates the perception evaluation and fast response to ambiguous natural spider stimulus in spider fearful and non anxious participant method stimulus were created by gradually morphing natural image of spider and non spider a crab a starfish a bunch of key and a flower in study 1 participant rated the image on perceptual and emotional dimension and responded to them in a response priming task to measure rapid information processing in study 2 result were validated and extended in a different paradigm by using a go no go task result a expected spider fearful participant showed an interpretative bias for ambiguous stimulus i e perceived them a more similar to spider and rated spider like stimulus a more unpleasant arousing and disgusting in study 1 spider stimulus were preferentially processed in spider fearful participant a observed in faster response to spider target however response were not different to comparison participant for ambiguous stimulus study 2 suggests that this finding can be explained by difference in stimulus duration limitation no participant with positive attitude towards spider or a second fearful comparison group were included conclusion we suggest that these finding can be explained by the nature of the applied task that tap into early phase of visual processing thereby relying on feedforward mediated low spatial frequency information extracted via the fast subcortical path to the amygdala

Title: Cognitive-affective reactions to a non-judgmental and judgmental mirror gazing task in individuals with body dysmorphic concerns
Authors: Schoenenberg, K.; Martin, A.
Abstract: background and objective the look into the mirror represents a typical trigger situation for people with body dysmorphic concern mirror exposure on the other hand is commonly used in the treatment of body dysmorphic disorder even though little is known about it precise effect this study aimed to investigate cognitive affective process related to mirror gazing method a total of 125 individual screening for body dysmorphic concern n bdd 56 negative n bdd 69 participated in a laboratory study using a guided 10 min mirror gazing task participant were randomized to one of two experimental condition a non judgmental and judgmental description of the own body during mirror gazing distress self hostile cognition and post event processing were assessed after the task and at follow up result participant with body dysmorphic concern showed higher value regarding subjective appearance distortion stress induced by the exposure distress self hostile cognition and post event processing compared to the symptom negative group the two condition did not yield differential effect limitation the short duration of the mirror gazing and the only internal description of the body may have contributed to a missing effect for the approach conclusion the result indicate the importance of cognitive and affective process in reaction to mirror exposure they support the cognitive model of bdd and suggest post event processing a a relevant factor requiring further investigation in future research

Title: Social consequences of subclinical negative symptoms: An EMG study of facial expressions within a social interaction
Authors: Riehle, M.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: background and objective the negative symptom of schizophrenia are related to lower social functioning even in non clinical sample but little is known about the distinct social consequence of motivational and expressive negative symptom in this study we focused on expressive negative symptom and examined how these symptom and varying degree of pro social facial expressiveness smiling and mimicry of smiling relate to the social evaluation by face to face interaction partner and to social support method we examined 30 dyadic interaction within a sample of non clinical participant n 60 who were rated on motivational and expressive negative symptom with the clinical assessment interview for negative symptom cain we collected data on both interaction partner smiling muscle zygomaticus major activation simultaneously with electromyography and assessed the general amount of smiling and the synchrony of smiling muscle activation between interaction partner mimicry of smiling interaction partner rated their willingness for future interaction with each other after the interaction result interaction partner of participant scoring higher on expressive negative symptom expressed le willingness for future interaction with these participant r 0 37 p 0 01 smiling behavior wa negatively related to expressive negative symptom but also explained by motivational negative symptom mimicry of smiling and both negative symptom domain were also associated with participant satisfaction with their social support network limitation non clinical sample with relatively low level of symptom conclusion expressive negative symptom have tangible negative interpersonal consequence and directly relate to diminished pro social behavior and social support even in non clinical sample

Title: Social and monetary incentives counteract fear-driven avoidance: Evidence from approach-avoidance decisions
Authors: Pittig, A.; Hengen, K.; Bublatzky, F.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: background and objective the reduction of avoidance behavior is a central target in the treatment of anxiety disorder but it ha rarely been studied how approach of fear relevant stimulus may be initiated in two study the impact of hypothetical monetary and symbolic social incentive on approach avoidance behavior wa examined method in study 1 individual high or low on fear of spider n 84 could choose to approach a fear relevant versus a neutral stimulus which were equally rewarded in a subsequent micro intervention approaching the fear relevant stimulus wa differentially rewarded either by monetary or social incentive in study 2 n 76 initial incentive for approach were discontinued to investigate the stability of approach result hypothetical monetary and symbolic social incentive reduced or eliminated initial avoidance even in highly fearful individual approach resulted in a decrease of self reported aversiveness towards the fear relevant stimulus however even after successful approach fearful individual showed significant avoidance behavior when incentive for approach were discontinued limitation future research should investigate the long term effect of prolonged approach incentive on multiple level of fear e g self report behavioral physiological it should also be tested if such an intervention actually improves compliance with exposure based intervention conclusion the present finding highlight that incentive are useful to initiate initial approach towards a feared stimulus although incentive based approach may neither fully eliminate avoidance nor negative feeling towards the feared stimulus such operant intervention may set the stage for more extensive extinction training

Title: Exploring mechanisms of change in schema therapy for chronic depression
Authors: Renner, F.; DeRubeis, R.; Arntz, A.; Peeters, F.; Lobbestael, J.; Huibers, M. J. H.
Abstract: background and objective the underlying mechanism of symptom change in schema therapy st for chronic major depressive disorder cmdd have not been studied the aim of this study wa to explore the impact of two potentially important mechanism of symptom change maladaptive schema proxied by negative idiosyncratic core belief and the therapeutic alliance method we drew data from a single case series of st for cmdd patient with cmdd n 20 received on average 78 repeated weekly assessment over a course of up to 65 individual session of st focusing on repeated assessment within individual we used mixed regression to test whether change in core belief and therapeutic alliance preceded followed or occurred concurrently with change in depressive symptom result change in core belief did not precede but were concurrently related to change in symptom repeated goal and task agreement rating specific aspect of alliance of the same session completed on separate day were at least in part associated with concurrent change in symptom limitation by design this study had a small sample size and no control group conclusion contrary to what would be expected based on theory our finding suggest that change in core belief doe not precede change in symptom instead change in these variable occurs concurrently moreover alliance rating seem to be at least in part colored by change in current mood state

Title: The manipulation of alcohol-related interpretation biases by means of Cognitive Bias Modification--Interpretation (CBM-I)
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Hutschemaekers, M. H.; Rinck, M.; Becker, E. S.
Abstract: background and objective there is a large body of evidence demonstrating that alcohol abuse and misuse is characterized by alcohol related interpretation bias ibs the present study tested whether alcohol related ibs can be trained and whether this ha an effect on alcohol related association and drinking behavior a newly developed alcohol cognitive bias modification interpretation cbm i training wa employed the potential moderating effect of executive control on cbm i training effect wa tested method participant were hazardously male drinking student a classical stroop wa used to a level of executive control half of the sample wa trained to interpret ambiguous alcohol related scenario in an alcohol related manner alcohol training group whereas the other half wa trained to interpret ambiguous alcohol related scenario in a neutral manner neutral training group a single target implicit association test stiat wa used to test whether the training would generalize to implicit alcohol related association target word alcohol attribute positive v neutral to test the training s effect on drinking behavior a bogus taste test and a one week follow up measure assessing participant s real life drinking behavior were used result the cbm i training wa partly successful when presented with novel ambiguous alcohol related scenario participant of the alcohol training group interpreted these scenario a more alcohol related after the training however there wa no reduction in alcohol related ibs in the neutral training group result of the stiat demonstrated that both training group showed stronger positive than neutral alcohol related association however there were no between group difference in alcohol related association moreover the cbm i training s effect wa not moderated by level of executive control finally no group difference were found on level of alcohol consumption bogus taste test and at one week follow up limitation the neutral training might have been operationalized sub optimally a multi session training might have resulted in stronger effect conclusion these finding are the first to show that alcohol related ibs can be trained however the training effect only partly generalized so more research is needed to advance our understanding of alcohol cbm i effect

Title: The Tele.TAnDem Intervention: Telephone-based CBT for Family Caregivers of People With Dementia
Authors: Wilz, G.; Reder, M.; Meichsner, F.; Soellner, R.
Abstract: background and objective this study evaluated the effectiveness of a telephone based cognitive behavioral therapy for family caregiver of people with dementia in existing health care provision structure research design and method two hundred seventy three family caregiver of people with dementia were randomly assigned to receive the intervention or usual care usual care included unrestricted access to community resource intervention group participant received twelve 50 min session of individual cognitive behavioral therapy by trained psychotherapist within 6 month symptom of depression emotional well being physical health symptom burden of care coping with the care situation and challenging behavior were assessed after the intervention ended and at a 6 month follow up intention to treat analysis using latent change model were applied result intention to treat analysis showed improved emotional well being gamma 9 59 p 001 fewer symptom of depression gamma 0 23 p 043 fewer physical health symptom gamma 0 25 p 019 improved coping with the care situation gamma 0 25 p 005 and the behavior of the care recipient gamma 0 23 p 034 compared with usual care effect for coping gamma 0 28 p 006 and gamma 0 39 p 001 respectively and emotional well being gamma 7 61 p 007 were also found at follow up discussion and implication the cbt based telephone intervention increased mental and physical health a well a coping ability of family caregiver of people with dementia the intervention can be delivered by qualified cbt therapist after an 8 h training session in existing health care provision structure

Title: Does rumination mediate the relationship between emotion regulation ability and posttraumatic stress disorder?
Authors: Ehring, T.; Ehlers, A.
Abstract: background and objective trauma related rumination ha been suggested to be involved in the maintenance of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd this view ha empirically been supported by extensive evidence using cross sectional prospective and experimental design however it is unclear why trauma survivor engage in rumination despite it negative consequence the current study aimed to explore the hypothesis that low emotion regulation ability underlies trauma related rumination method emotion regulation ability and trauma related rumination were assessed in 93 road traffic accident survivor 2 week post trauma in addition symptom level of ptsd were assessed at 2 week a well a 1 3 and 6 month follow up result emotion regulation ability wa significantly related to trauma related rumination a well a level of ptsd symptom in addition the association between low emotion regulation ability and ptsd wa mediated by rumination conclusion the finding support the view that rumination is used a a dysfunctional emotion regulation strategy by trauma survivor

Title: Costly avoidance in anxious individuals: Elevated threat avoidance in anxious individuals under high, but not low competing rewards
Authors: Pittig, A.; Scherbaum, S.
Abstract: background and objective when avoiding threat conflict with approaching reward balanced response to threat and reward information is required to guide functional behavior elevated threat avoidance characterizes anxious psychopathology however little is known about the mutual impact of threat and reward information on approach avoidance behavior and it link to anxiety method high trait anxious and low anxious individual n 74 repeatedly choose between two option a threat high reward option wa linked to two outcome a varying chance to receive an aversive stimulus and a varying high reward a safe low reward option wa linked to absence of the aversive stimulus and a low reward result avoidance of the threat high reward option increased with increasing threat despite threat low anxious individual increasingly approached the threat high reward option when reward increased high compared to low anxious individual showed elevated avoidance but only in the presence of high competing reward limitation future research should examine boundary condition by manipulating type and motivational value of appetitive and aversive outcome e g food a primary reinforcer conclusion these finding suggest that a weaker impact of reward competing with threat contributes to elevated threat avoidance in anxious psychopathology costly avoidance may thus be a factor involved in anxious psychopathology

Title: How we walk affects what we remember: gait modifications through biofeedback change negative affective memory bias
Authors: Michalak, J.; Rohde, K.; Troje, N. F.
Abstract: background and object several study have shown that physical exercise such a walking ha effect on depression these study have focused on increasing intensity and amount of physical activity in the present study we investigated whether not only the intensity but also the style of physical activity affect depression related process method using an unobtrusive biofeedback technique we manipulated participant 39 undergraduate to change their walking pattern to either reflect the characteristic of depressed patient or a particularly happy walking style the intensity of walking i e walking speed wa held constant across condition during walking participant first encoded and later recalled a series of emotionally loaded term result the difference between recalled positive and recalled negative word wa much lower in participant who adopted a depressed walking style a compared to participant who walked a if they were happy limitation the effect of gait manipulation were investigated in a non clinical group of undergraduate conclusion the observed change in memory bias support the idea that beyond the intensity of walking the style of walking ha effect on the vulnerability to depression

Title: Biased Perception of Physiological Arousal in Child Social Anxiety Disorder Before and After Cognitive Behavioral Treatment
Authors: Asbrand, J.; Schulz, A.; Heinrichs, N.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.
Abstract: background a biased perception of physiological hyperreactivity to social evaluative situation is crucial for the maintenance of social anxiety disorder sad alteration in interoceptive accuracy iac when confronted with social stressor may play a role for sad in child we expected a biased perception of hyperarousal in child with sad before treatment and consequently a reduced bias after successful cognitive behavioral therapy cbt method in two center 64 child with the diagnosis of sad and 55 healthy control hc child both 9 to 13 year participated in the trier social stress test for child tsst c which wa repeated after child with sad were assigned to either a 12 week group cbt n 31 or a waitlist condition n 33 perception of and worry about physiological arousal and autonomic variable heart rate skin conductance were assessed after each tsst c all child further completed a heartbeat perception task to a iac result before treatment child with sad reported both a stronger perception of and more worry about their heart rate and skin conductance than hc child while the objective reactivity of heart rate did not differ additionally child with sad reported heightened perception of and increased worry about trembling throughout the tsst c compared to hc child but reported increased worry about blushing only after the stress phase of the tsst c compared to hc child child with and without sad did not differ in iac contrary to our hypothesis after treatment child in the cbt group reported heightened perception of physiological arousal and increased worry on some parameter after the baseline phase of the tsst c whereas actual iac remained unaffected iac before and after treatment were significantly related conclusion increased self reported perception of physiological arousal may play a role in childhood sad and could be an important target in cbt however further study should examine if this is an epiphenomenon a temporarily occurring and necessary condition for change or indeed an unwanted adverse intervention effect

Title: Munich Alliance Against Depression
Authors: Mergl, R.; Heinz, I.; Allgaier, A. K.; Hegerl, U.
Abstract: background a four level community based intervention aiming simultaneously to improve the care for depression and to prevent suicidal behavior ha been implemented in the german city munich aim change in suicide rate in munich during 2009 2014 were analyzed with respect to a 10 year baseline the same wa true for a control region cologne and germany minus munich method the intervention included training of primary care provider a public awareness campaign training of community facilitator and support for patient and relative analysis included repeated measure generalized linear model result in munich the suicide rate significantly decreased during the intervention period compared to baseline percentage change 15 0 p 001 198 compared to 222 suicide per year difference in the change for munich and the change for the control location cologne 1 7 p 71 and germany minus munich 6 2 p 09 were not significant limitation data on suicide attempt were unavailable conclusion in munich a clinically and statistically significant decrease in suicide rate wa found this change wa numerically but not significantly larger than in the control region the result are promising however because of low suicide base rate and limited power no strong conclusion can be drawn concerning suicide preventive effect of the intervention

Title: Negative Effects of a Multimodal Inpatient CBASP Program: Rate of Occurrence and Their Impact on Treatment Outcome in Chronic and Treatment-Resistant Depression
Authors: Herzog, P.; Hausler, S.; Normann, C.; Brakemeier, E. L.
Abstract: background a growing number of study indicate that the cognitive behavioral analysis system of psychotherapy cbasp is effective in treating chronic depression however there is no systematic research into possible negative effect therefore the objective of the study were to investigate the rate of occurrence of negative effect of an inpatient cbasp program and their impact on treatment response method patient with chronic depression and treatment resistance who completed the 12 week multimodal inpatient cbasp treatment program in an open trial n 52 retrospectively completed the inventory for the assessment of negative effect of psychotherapy inep during follow up data collection severity of depressive symptom wa assessed self and observer rated at admission discharge and 6 month follow up rate of occurrence of negative effect were calculated and binary logistic regression analysis were conducted to determine the relationship to treatment outcome result the result indicate that 92 3 of patient reported having experienced at least one negative effect and 45 2 indicated dependence on their therapist stigmatization and financial concern a well a intrapersonal change were reported by about one third only dependence on the therapist negatively impacted treatment outcome in both outcome measure conclusion while almost all patient reported at least one negative effect of a multimodal inpatient cbasp treatment program most of the reported negative effect appear to be benign however dependence on the therapist seems to have a negative impact on treatment outcome if these result can be replicated in future large scale randomized controlled prospective study cbasp therapist should be aware of possible dependence and consciously address it during treatment

Title: Lifestyle choices and mental health: a longitudinal survey with German and Chinese students
Authors: Velten, J.; Bieda, A.; Scholten, S.; Wannemuller, A.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background a healthy lifestyle can be beneficial for one s mental health thus identifying healthy lifestyle choice that promote psychological well being and reduce mental problem is useful to prevent mental disorder the aim of this longitudinal study wa to evaluate the predictive value of a broad range of lifestyle choice for positive mental health pmh and mental health problem mhp in german and chinese student method data were assessed at baseline and at 1 year follow up sample included 2991 german m age 21 69 sd 4 07 and 12 405 chinese m age 20 59 sd 1 58 university student lifestyle choice were body mass index frequency of physical and mental activity frequency of alcohol consumption smoking vegetarian diet and social rhythm irregularity pmh and mhp were measured with the positive mental health scale and a 21 item version of the depression anxiety and stress scale the predictive value of lifestyle choice for pmh and mhp at baseline and follow up were assessed with single group and multi group path analysis result better mental health higher pmh and fewer mhp at baseline wa predicted by a lower body mass index a higher frequency of physical and mental activity non smoking a non vegetarian diet and a more regular social rhythm when controlling for baseline mental health age and gender physical activity wa a positive predictor of pmh smoking wa a positive predictor of mhp and a more irregular social rhythm wa a positive predictor of pmh and a negative predictor of mhp at follow up the good fit of a multi group model indicated that most lifestyle choice predict mental health comparably across sample some country specific effect emerged frequency of alcohol consumption for example predicted better mental health in german and poorer mental health in chinese student conclusion our finding underline the importance of healthy lifestyle choice for improved psychological well being and fewer mental health difficulty effect of lifestyle on mental health are comparable in german and chinese student some healthy lifestyle choice i e more frequent physical activity non smoking regular social rhythm are related to improvement in mental health over a 1 year period

Title: Optimizing expectations and distraction leads to lower cortisol levels after acute stress
Authors: Salzmann, S.; Euteneuer, F.; Strahler, J.; Laferton, J. A. C.; Nater, U. M.; Rief, W.
Abstract: background a new approach of psychological intervention prior to stress aiming to optimize expectation may have beneficial effect on a person s health status by reducing physiological stress the purpose of this experiment wa to determine whether a brief psychological intervention designed to optimize personal control expectation prior to acute stress would affect perceived and biological stress responsiveness in comparison to two more established intervention fostering gratitude or distraction in a healthy sample method 74 healthy participant were randomized to one of three psychological intervention prior to stress i writing about way to influence stress to optimize personal control expectation expectation ii writing a gratitude letter gratitude iii or a distraction writing task distraction after completing the intervention the maastricht acute stress test wa administered to induce psychosocial and physiological stress assessment took place at baseline post intervention 15 min writing task and after stress induction additional salivary assessment 15 and 30 min after stress main outcome were expectation emotion perceived stress salivary cortisol and alpha amylase personality trait eg optimism were assessed at baseline result expectation specifically increased personal control expectation p 016 d 72 and gratitude specifically increased gratitude p 026 d 68 expectation and distraction led to lower cortisol concentration after stress induction than gratitude time x group interaction p 001 d 88 we detected no intervention effect on alpha amylase or perceived stress optimism moderated intervention effect on cortisol p 023 d 74 conclusion brief psychological intervention aiming to optimize expectation or distraction prior to stress reduce the cortisol response in healthy participant after an acute stressor

Title: Pain assessment for cognitively impaired older adults: Do items of available observer tools reflect pain-specific responses?
Authors: Kappesser, J.; Voit, S.; Lautenbacher, S.; Hermann, C.
Abstract: background a number of observational tool are available to a pain in cognitively impaired older adult however none of them can yet be regarded a a gold standard an international research initiative ha created a meta tool compiling the facial vocalization and body movement item of the majority of available tool objective of this study wa to investigate the pain specificity and the validity of these item method n 34 older adult with or without cognitive impairment were videotaped in three different condition one reference two painful condition in their nursing home they were further asked to self report their pain in each condition the occurrence of non verbal behaviour wa coded a present or absent using the item of the meta tool result the majority of non verbal behaviour wa not pain sensitive a they occurred le than three time across participant and condition of the remaining item two facial item pained expression and raising upper lip one vocalization item using pain related word and one body movement item guarding were found to be pain specific and valid one additional item the vocalization item gasping wa pain specific but not associated with pain self report and three additional item the facial item frowning and narrowing eye and the vocalization item mumbling were correlated with pain self report but did not help to separate pain from non pain condition conclusion systematic evaluation of item of existing observational pain assessment tool under naturalistic condition seems a promising approach in the process of further investigating and improving tool significance only few item stemming from observational pain assessment tool were found to be pain sensitive and specific a well a valid in this study the investigation of existing tool not only on tool but additionally on item level can provide helpful insight and thereby can help to improve the original tool and establish a gold standard for nonverbal pain assessment in older adult with cognitive impairment

Title: Drawing the borderline: Predicting treatment outcomes in patients with borderline personality disorder
Authors: Herzog, P.; Feldmann, M.; Voderholzer, U.; Gartner, T.; Armbrust, M.; Rauh, E.; Doerr, R.; Rief, W.; Brakemeier, E. L.
Abstract: background a routinely collected big data set wa analyzed to determine the effectiveness of naturalistic inpatient treatment and to identify predictor of treatment outcome and discontinuation method the sample included 878 patient with borderline personality disorder who received non manualized dialectic behavioral therapy in a psychosomatic clinic effect size hedge s g were calculated to determine effectiveness a bootstrap enhanced regularized regression with 91 potential predictor wa used to identify stable predictor of residualized symptom and functional change and treatment discontinuation result were validated in a holdout sample and repeated cross validation result effect size were small to medium g 0 28 0 51 positive symptom related outcome wa predicted by low affect regulation skill and no previous outpatient psychotherapy lower age absence of work disability high emotional and physical role limitation and low bodily pain were associated with greater improvement in functional outcome higher education and comorbid recurrent depressive disorder were the main predictor of treatment completion the predictive quality of the model varied with the best being found for symptom related outcome r 2 18 conclusion while the exploratory process of variable selection replicates previous finding the validation result suggest that tailoring treatment to the individual patient might not be based solely on sociodemographic clinical and psychological baseline data

Title: Inpatient psychotherapy for depression in a large routine clinical care sample: A Bayesian approach to examining clinical outcomes and predictors of change
Authors: Herzog, P.; Feldmann, M.; Kube, T.; Langs, G.; Gartner, T.; Rauh, E.; Doerr, R.; Hillert, A.; Voderholzer, U.; Rief, W.; Endres, D.; Brakemeier, E. L.
Abstract: background a routinely collected dataset wa analyzed 1 to determine the naturalistic effectiveness of inpatient psychotherapy for depression in routine psychotherapeutic care and 2 to identify potential predictor of change method in a sample of 22 681 inpatient with depression pre post and pre follow up effect size were computed for various outcome variable to build a probabilistic model of predictor of change an independent component analysis generated component from demographic and clinical data and bayesian efa extracted factor from the available pre test post test and follow up questionnaire in a subsample n 6377 to select the best fitted model the bic of different path model were compared a bayesian path analysis wa performed to identify the most important factor to predict change result effect size were large for the primary outcome and moderate for various secondary outcome almost all pretreatment factor exerted significant influence on different baseline factor several factor were found to be resistant to change during treatment suicidality agoraphobia life dissatisfaction physical disability and pain the strongest cross loading were observed from suicidality on negative cognition from agoraphobia on anxiety and from physical disability on perceived disability limitation no causal conclusion can be drawn directly from our result a we only used cross lagged panel data without control group conclusion the result indicate large effect of inpatient psychotherapy for depression in routine clinical care the direct influence of pretreatment factor decreased over the course of treatment however some factor appeared stable and difficult to treat which might hinder treatment outcome finding of different predictor of change are discussed

Title: Increasing motivation in effort-based decision-making tasks: effects of salience and reward expectancy manipulations
Authors: Renz, K. E.; Pillny, M.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: background a significant proportion of patient with affective and psychotic disorder show a marked reduction in goal directed behaviour which is also reflected in the behavioural outcome of effort based decision making paradigm the factor underlying this reduction are not yet fully understood reward salience and reward expectancy have been discussed a factor that potentially influence approach behaviour the aim of this study wa thus to test their effect on behaviour in an effort based decision making paradigm method in two study with community sample we applied a modified version of the balloon task in study 1 we manipulated reward salience in a within subject design n 32 by highlighting the monetary reward in study 2 we manipulated reward expectancy in a between subject design n 72 by adding five practice trial with either positive or negative feedback prior to the task result the salience of reward manipulation significantly increased effort expenditure and the allocation of effort to the level of reward whereas the reward expectancy manipulation did not conclusion the finding that increasing the salience of reward increase motivated behaviour in an effort based decision making paradigm offer promising possibility for intervention in disorder characterised by motivational deficit such asaffective and psychotic disorder

Title: Abnormalities in white matter tracts in the fronto-striatal-thalamic circuit are associated with verbal performance in 22q11.2DS
Authors: Heller, C.; Steinmann, S.; Levitt, J. J.; Makris, N.; Antshel, K. M.; Fremont, W.; Coman, I. L.; Schweinberger, S. R.; Weiss, T.; Bouix, S.; Kubicki, M. R.; Kates, W. R.; Kikinis, Z.
Abstract: background abnormality in fronto striatal thalamic fst sub circuit are present in schizophrenia and are associated with cognitive impairment however it remains unknown whether abnormality in fst sub circuit are present before psychosis onset this may be elucidated by investigating 22q11 2 deletion syndrome 22q11ds a genetic syndrome associated with a 30 risk for developing schizophrenia in adulthood and a decline in verbal iq viq preceding psychosis onset here we examined white matter wm tract in fst sub circuit especially those in the dorsolateral dlpfc and ventrolateral prefrontal cortex vlpfc sub circuit and their association with viq in young adult with 22q11ds method diffusion mri scan were acquired from 21 individual with 22q11ds with prodromal symptom of schizophrenia 30 individual with 22q11ds without prodromal symptom and 30 healthy control mean age 21 2 year wm tract were reconstructed between striatum and thalamus with rostral middle frontal gyrus rmfg and inferior frontal gyrus ifg representing dlpfc and vlpfc respectively fractional anisotropy fa and radial diffusivity rd were used for group comparison viq wa assessed and association with the diffusion measure were evaluated result fa wa significantly increased and rd decreased in most tract of the dlpfc and vlpfc sub circuit in 22q11ds verbal iq score correlated negatively with fa and at trend level positively with rd in the right thalamus ifg tract in 22q11ds with prodromal symptom conclusion while abnormality in fst sub circuit are associated with schizophrenia we observed that these abnormality are also present in 22q11ds individual with prodromal symptom and are associated with verbal performance in the right thalamus ifg tract

Title: Predicting patients who will drop out of out-patient psychotherapy using machine learning algorithms
Authors: Bennemann, B.; Schwartz, B.; Giesemann, J.; Lutz, W.
Abstract: background about 30 of patient drop out of cognitive behavioural therapy cbt which ha implication for psychiatric and psychological treatment finding concerning drop out remain heterogeneous aim this paper aim to compare different machine learning algorithm using nested cross validation evaluate their benefit in naturalistic setting and identify the best model a well a the most important variable method the data set consisted of 2543 out patient treated with cbt assessment took place before session one twenty one algorithm and ensemble were compared two parameter brier score area under the curve auc were used for evaluation result the best model wa an ensemble that used random forest and nearest neighbour modelling during the training process it wa significantly better than generalised linear modelling glm brier score d 2 93 95 ci 3 95 1 90 auc d 0 59 95 ci 0 11 to 1 06 in the holdout sample the ensemble wa able to correctly identify 63 4 of case of patient whereas the glm only identified 46 2 correctly the most important predictor were lower education lower score on the personality style and disorder inventory pssi compulsive scale younger age higher score on the pssi negativistic and pssi antisocial scale a well a on the brief symptom inventory bsi additional scale mean of the four additional item and bsi overall scale conclusion machine learning improves drop out prediction however not all algorithm are suited to naturalistic data set and binary event tree based and boosted algorithm including a variable selection process seem well suited whereas more advanced algorithm such a neural network do not

Title: Capacity limitations in neurology patients, with and without comorbid mental disorders
Authors: Neue, D. C.; Linden, M.; Muschalla, B.
Abstract: background according to the international classification of functioning disability and health icf symptom of illness and capacity limitation must be kept apart and assessed separately psychological capacity are more important than physical capacity in today s world patient with neurological disorder not only show limitation in physical but also in psychological capacity a in many case there is comorbidity of neurological and mental disorder the question is to what degree this can increase psychological incapacity method using a cross sectional study design neurological patient with and without mental comorbidity were recruited in a department of neurological phase d rehabilitation a total of 114 inpatient with both neurological and mental disorder nm were compared with 214 unselected patient with neurological disorder only n mental comorbidity wa diagnosed with the standardized international neuropsychiatric interview capacity limitation were assessed with the activity and participation in psychological disorder according to the international classification of functioning disability and health scale mini icf app qualitative report of patient were used to validate the mini icf app rating clinical diagnosis were taken from the routine patient evaluation result severe capacity limitation which are in need of support by others could be observed especially for endurance nm 73 7 v n 59 8 of patient flexibility nm 43 0 v n 22 4 professional competency nm 36 0 v n 16 8 structuring of task nm 32 5 v n 15 0 least frequent were impairment in dyadic relationship nm 23 7 v n 7 9 the rank order and the qualitative description of impairment were similar in both group conclusion patient with neurological disorder in general show a relevant degree of capacity limitation this is further substantially increased by mental comorbidity specific treatment is necessary

Title: Healthy women with severe early life trauma show altered neural facilitation of emotion inhibition under acute stress
Authors: Golde, S.; Wingenfeld, K.; Riepenhausen, A.; Schroter, N.; Fleischer, J.; Prussner, J.; Grimm, S.; Fan, Y.; Hellmann-Regen, J.; Beck, A.; Gold, S. M.; Otte, C.
Abstract: background across psychopathology trauma exposed individual suffer from difficulty in inhibiting emotion and regulating attention in trauma exposed individual without psychopathology only subtle alteration of neural activity involved in regulating emotion have been reported it remains unclear how these neural system react to demanding environment when acute non traumatic but ordinary stress serf to perturbate the system moreover association with subthreshold clinical symptom are poorly understood method the present fmri study investigated response inhibition of emotional face before and after psychosocial stress situation specifically it compared 25 woman mean age 31 5 9 7 year who had suffered severe early life trauma but who did not have a history of or current psychiatric disorder with 25 age and education matched trauma naive woman result under stress response inhibition related to fearful face wa reduced in both group compared to control trauma exposed woman showed decreased left inferior frontal gyrus ifg activation under stress when inhibiting response to fearful face while activation of the right anterior insula wa slightly increased also group differed in brain behaviour correlation whereas stress induced false alarm rate on fearful stimulus negatively correlated with stress induced ifg signal in control in trauma exposed participant they positively correlated with stress induced insula activation conclusion neural facilitation of emotion inhibition during stress appears to be altered in trauma exposed woman even without a history of or current psychopathology decreased activation of the ifg in concert with heightened bottom up salience of fear related cue may increase vulnerability to stress related disease

Title: Relationship between sense of control, psychological burden, sources of information and adherence to anti-COVID-19 rules
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background adherence to anti covid 19 rule is important to slow down the pandemic spread the present study investigated potential predictor of the adherence method data of 1 247 participant from germany age m sd 22 99 6 18 were assessed via online survey in autumn and winter 2020 the focus of the data collection wa on adherence to anti covid 19 rule sense of control psychological burden and source of covid 19 information result in moderated mediation analysis the positive relationship between sense of control and adherence to anti covid 19 rule wa significantly mediated by the level of psychological burden experienced by the covid 19 situation the source of covid 19 information significantly moderated the negative association between burden and adherence specifically the higher the use of social medium e g facebook twitter and the lower the use of official governmental site and of television report the closer the link between high burden and low adherence limitation due to the cross sectional study design the present finding allow only hypothetical assumption of causality conclusion the present result disclose potential mechanism that could contribute to the adherence to anti covid 19 rule they emphasize the role of the covid 19 information source for the adherence level potential way of how the level of adherence could be enhanced are discussed

Title: Self-reported PTSD is associated with increased use of MDMA in adolescents with substance use disorders
Authors: Basedow, L. A.; Kuitunen-Paul, S.; Wiedmann, M. F.; Roessner, V.; Golub, Y.
Abstract: background adolescent patient with a substance use disorder sud often fulfil the criterion for a co occurring post traumatic stress disorder ptsd however it is not clear if these dual diagnosed adolescent present with unique level of substance use and how their substance use relates to ptsd symptom cluster objective to investigate substance use in adolescent with co occurring ptsd and sud additionally we explored how the use of specific substance is related to specific ptsd symptom cluster method we recruited n 121 german adolescent sud patient in three group no history of traumatic event te n 35 te but not ptsd n 48 probable ptsd n 38 all group were administered a trauma questionnaire and were asked to report their past month substance use result adolescent with probable ptsd and sud report a higher frequency of mdma use than adolescent with no ptsd and no te ptsd v note u 510 5 p 016 ptsd v te u 710 0 p 010 the use of mdma wa more frequent in adolescent with avoidance symptom x 2 1 6 0 p 014 participant report using substance at a younger age ptsd v note u 372 0 p 001 ptsd v te u 653 5 p 022 and ptsd symptom onset wa on average 2 2 year earlier than first mdma use t 26 2 89 p 008 conclusion adolescent sud patient with probable ptsd are more likely to use mdma than sud patient without ptsd the use of mdma wa associated with reported avoidance symptom the first age of mdma use is initiated after ptsd onset it is unclear whether the association of mdma use with avoidance symptom is due to effort to reduce these symptom or a result of regular mdma use

Title: Feasibility and potential efficacy of a guided internet- and mobile-based CBT for adolescents and young adults with chronic medical conditions and comorbid depression or anxiety symptoms (youthCOACH(CD)): a randomized controlled pilot trial
Authors: Geirhos, A.; Domhardt, M.; Lunkenheimer, F.; Temming, S.; Holl, R. W.; Minden, K.; Warschburger, P.; Meissner, T.; Mueller-Stierlin, A. S.; Baumeister, H.
Abstract: background adolescent and young adult aya with a chronic medical condition show an increased risk for developing mental comorbidities compared to their healthy peer internet and mobile based cognitive behavioral therapy icbt might be a low threshold treatment to support affected aya in this randomized controlled pilot trial the feasibility and potential efficacy of youthcoach cd an icbt targeting symptom of anxiety and depression in aya with chronic medical condition wa evaluated method a total of 30 aya m age 16 13 sd 2 34 73 female aged 12 21 year either suffering from cystic fibrosis juvenile idiopathic arthritis or type 1 diabetes were randomly assigned to either a guided version of the icbt youthcoach cd ig n 15 or to a waitlist control group cg n 15 receiving an unguided version of the icbt six month post randomization participant of the ig and the cg were assessed before t0 twelve week after t1 and six month after t2 randomization primary outcome wa the feasibility of the icbt different parameter of feasibility e g acceptance client satisfaction or potential side effect were evaluated first indication of the possible efficacy with regard to the primary efficacy outcome the patient health questionnaire anxiety and depression scale and further outcome variable were evaluated using linear regression model adjusting for baseline value result regarding feasibility intervention completion wa 60 intervention satisfaction m 25 42 sd 5 85 and perceived therapeutic alliance m 2 83 sd 1 25 were moderate and comparable to other icbts no pattern emerged regarding subjective and objective negative side effect due to participation in youthcoach cd estimate of potential efficacy showed between group difference with a potential medium term benefit of youthcoach cd beta 0 55 95 ci 1 17 0 07 but probably not short term beta 0 20 95 ci 0 47 0 88 conclusion our result point to the feasibility of youthcoach cd and the implementation of a future definitive randomized controlled trial addressing it effectiveness and cost effectiveness due to the small sample size conclusion are premature however further strategy to foster treatment adherence should be considered trial registration the trial wa registered at the who international clinical trial registry platform via the german clinical trial register id drks00016714 25 03 2019

Title: Impaired Emotional Mirroring in Parkinson's Disease-A Study on Brain Activation during Processing of Facial Expressions
Authors: Pohl, A.; Anders, S.; Chen, H.; Patel, H. J.; Heller, J.; Reetz, K.; Mathiak, K.; Binkofski, F.
Abstract: background affective dysfunction are common in patient with parkinson s disease but the underlying neurobiological deviation have rarely been examined parkinson s disease is characterized by a loss of dopamine neuron in the substantia nigra resulting in impairment of motor and non motor basal ganglion cortical loop concerning emotional deficit some study provide evidence for altered brain processing in limbic and lateral orbitofrontal gating loop in a second line of evidence human premotor and inferior parietal homologs of mirror neuron area were involved in processing and understanding of emotional facial expression we examined deviation in brain activation during processing of facial expression in patient and related these to emotion recognition accuracy method 13 patient and 13 healthy control underwent an emotion recognition task and a functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri measurement in the emotion hexagon test participant were presented with blend of two emotion and had to indicate which emotion best described the presented picture blended picture with three level of difficulty were included during fmri scanning participant observed video clip depicting emotional non emotional and neutral facial expression or were asked to produce these facial expression themselves result patient performed slightly worse in the emotion recognition task but only when judging the most ambiguous facial expression both group activated inferior frontal and anterior inferior parietal homologs of mirror neuron area during observation and execution of the emotional facial expression during observation response in the par opercularis of the right inferior frontal gyrus in the bilateral inferior parietal lobule and in the bilateral supplementary motor cortex were decreased in patient furthermore in patient activation of the right anterior inferior parietal lobule wa positively related to accuracy in the emotion recognition task conclusion our data provide evidence for a contribution of human homologs of monkey mirror area to the emotion recognition deficit in parkinson s disease

Title: Brain structural correlates of alexithymia in patients with major depressive disorder
Authors: Forster, K.; Enneking, V.; Dohm, K.; Redlich, R.; Meinert, S.; Geisler, A. I.; Leehr, E. J.; Kugel, H.; Baune, B. T.; Arolt, V.; Zwitserlood, P.; Grotegerd, D.; Dannlowski, U.
Abstract: background alexithymia is a risk factor for major depressive disorder mdd and ha been associated with diminished treatment response neuroimaging study have revealed structural aberration of the anterior cingulate cortex and the fusiform gyrus in healthy control with high level of alexithymia the present study tried to corroborate and extend these result to patient with mdd compared with healthy control method we investigated the relationship between alexithymia depression and grey matter volume in 63 patient with mdd mean age standard deviation 42 43 yr 11 91 33 female and 46 healthy control 45 35 yr 8 37 22 female we assessed alexithymia using the toronto alexithymia scale we conducted an alexithymia x group analysis of covariance we used a region of interest approach including the fusiform gyrus and anterior cingulate cortex and conducted whole brain analysis using voxelbased morphometry result our analysis revealed a significant alexithymia x group interaction in the fusiform gyrus left pfwe 0 031 right pfwe 0 010 higher alexithymia score were associated with decreased grey matter volume in patient with mdd pfwe 0 009 but with increased grey matter volume of the fusiform gyrus in healthy control pfwe 0 044 we found no significant main effect in the region of interest analysis limitation owing to the naturalistic nature of our study patient with mdd and healthy control differed significantly in their alexithymia score conclusion our result showed the fusiform gyrus a a correlate of alexithymia we also found difference related to alexithymia between patient with mdd and healthy control in the fusiform gyrus our study encourages research related to the transition from risk to mdd in people with alexithymia

Title: Alexithymic Trait, Painful Heat Stimulation, and Everyday Pain Experience
Authors: Pollatos, O.; Dietel, A.; Gundel, H.; Duschek, S.
Abstract: background alexithymia wa found to be associated with a variety of somatic complaint including somatoform pain symptom this study addressed the question of whether the different facet of alexithymia are related to response in heat pain stimulation and it interrelation with level of everyday pain a assessed by self report method in the study sensitivity to heat pain wa assessed in 50 healthy female participant alexithymia facet were assessed by the toronto alexithymia scale pain threshold and tolerance were determined using a testing the limit procedure participant furthermore rated subjective intensity and unpleasantness of tonic heat stimulus 45 5 47 5 degree c on visual analog scale and on a questionnaire possible confounding with temperature sensitivity and mood wa controlled everyday pain wa assessed by self report addressing everyday pain frequency intensity and impairment experienced over the last 2 month result main result were that the facet of alexithymia were differentially associated with pain perception the affective scale difficulty in describing feeling wa associated with hyposensitivity to pain a indicated by higher pain tolerance score furthermore everyday pain frequency wa related to increased alexithymia value on the affective scale difficulty in identifying feeling whereas higher value on the cognitive alexithymia scale externally oriented thinking were related to lower pain impairment and intensity conclusion we conclude that the different facet of alexithymia are related to alternation in pain processing further research on clinical sample is necessary to elucidate whether different aspect of alexithymia act a a vulnerability factor for the development of pain symptom

Title: Ventral Striatal-Hippocampus Coupling During Reward Processing as a Stratification Biomarker for Psychotic Disorders
Authors: Schwarz, K.; Moessnang, C.; Schweiger, J. I.; Harneit, A.; Schneider, M.; Chen, J.; Cao, H.; Schwarz, E.; Witt, S. H.; Rietschel, M.; Nothen, M.; Degenhardt, F.; Wackerhagen, C.; Erk, S.; Romanczuk-Seiferth, N.; Walter, H.; Tost, H.; Meyer-Lindenberg, A.
Abstract: background altered ventral striatal vst activation to reward expectancy is a well established intermediate phenotype for psychiatric disorder specifically schizophrenia sz preclinical research suggests that striatal alteration are related to a reduced inhibition by the hippocampal formation but it role in human transdiagnostic reward network dysfunction is not well understood method we performed functional magnetic resonance imaging during reward processing in 728 individual including healthy control subject n 396 patient sz n 46 bipolar disorder n 45 major depressive disorder n 60 and unaffected first degree relative sz n 46 bipolar disorder n 50 major depressive disorder n 85 we assessed disorder specific difference in functional vst hippocampus coupling and transdiagnostic association with dimensional measure of positive negative and cognitive symptom we also probed the genetic underpinning using polygenic risk score for sz in a subset of healthy participant n 295 result functional vst hippocampus coupling wa 1 reduced in patient with sz and bipolar disorder p fwe 05 small volume corrected svc 2 associated transdiagnostically to dimensional measure of positive p fwe 01 svc and cognitive p fwe 02 svc but not negative p fwe 05 svc symptom and 3 reduced in first degree relative of patient with sz p fwe 017 svc and linked to the genetic risk for sz in healthy participant p 035 conclusion we provide evidence that reduced vst hippocampus coupling during reward processing is an endophenotype for sz linked to positive and cognitive symptom supporting current preclinical model of the emergence of psychosis moreover our data indicate that vst hippocampus coupling is familial and linked to polygenic score for sz supporting the use of this measure a an intermediate phenotype for psychotic disorder

Title: Differentiating early-onset chronic depression from episodic depression in terms of cognitive-behavioral and emotional avoidance
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Kulessa, D.; Hautzinger, M.; Bents, H.; Backenstrass, M.
Abstract: background although chronic depression is associated with lower global functioning and poorer treatment response than episodic depression little is known about the difference between these two form of depression in term of psychological factor thus the present study aimed at differentiating chronic and episodic depression regarding cognitive behavioral and emotional avoidance that have been proposed a important risk factor for depression and promising target for the treatment of depression method thirty patient with early onset chronic depression were compared with 30 patient with episodic depression and 30 healthy never depressed control in term of self reported cognitive behavioral social and non social and emotional avoidance result chronically depressed patient reported more avoidance than healthy control in each of the measure moreover they reported more cognitive nonsocial and behavioral nonsocial a well a behavioral social and emotional avoidance in the form of restricted emotional expression to others than patient with episodic depression this kind of emotional avoidance also separated best between chronically and episodically depressed patient furthermore general emotion avoidance and behavioral social avoidance were positively correlated with level of depression in chronically depressed patient limitation the result are based on self report data and should thus be interpreted with caution additionally the cross sectional design limit any causal conclusion conclusion the finding underscore the relevance of cognitive behavioral and emotional avoidance in differentiating chronic from episodic depression and healthy control and advocate a stronger focus on maladaptive avoidance process in the treatment of chronic depression

Title: Severely Burdened Individuals Do Not Need to Be Excluded From Internet-Based and Mobile-Based Stress Management: Effect Modifiers of Treatment Outcomes From Three Randomized Controlled Trials
Authors: Weisel, K. K.; Lehr, D.; Heber, E.; Zarski, A. C.; Berking, M.; Riper, H.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: background although internet based and mobile based stress management intervention ismis may be a promising strategy to reach employee suffering from high chronic stress it remains unknown whether participant with high symptom severity of depression or anxiety also benefit from ismis or should be excluded objective this study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ismis in subgroup with high symptom severity and to test whether baseline symptom severity moderate treatment outcome method data from three randomized controlled trial n 791 were pooled to identify effect modifier and to evaluate efficacy in subgroup with different level of initial symptom severity the outcome perceived stress perceived stress scale p depression severity center for epidemiological depression scale ce d and anxiety hospital anxiety and depression scale hads symptom severity were assessed at baseline 7 week postassessment and 6 month follow up potential moderator were tested in predicting difference in the change of outcome in multiple moderation analysis simple slope analysis evaluated efficacy of the ismi comparing the intervention group with the waitlist control group in subgroup with low moderate and severe initial symptomology based on mean and sd of the study population in addition subgroup with clinical value of depression ce d 16 and anxiety hads 8 at baseline were explored and response rate rrs 50 symptom reduction and symptom free sf status ce d 16 hads 8 were reported result individual with high stress p 30 depression ce d 33 anxiety hads 15 and emotional exhaustion mbi 5 6 benefited significantly from the intervention with great reduction of stress d post 0 86 1 16 d fu 0 93 1 35 depression d post 0 69 1 08 d fu 0 91 1 19 and anxiety d post 0 79 1 19 d fu 1 06 1 21 and effect were sustained at 6 month follow up symptom severity moderated treatment outcome a individual with higher symptom severity at baseline benefited significantly more from the intervention than individual with lower symptom severity furthermore 82 9 656 791 of individual had clinical depression value at baseline of which significantly more individual in the intervention group reached at least 50 symptom reduction or fell under clinical cut off rr 29 2 93 318 sf 39 6 126 318 compared with the waitlist control group rr 8 0 27 338 sf 18 6 63 338 at postassessment significantly more individual with clinical anxiety value at baseline hads 8 85 3 675 791 in the intervention group achieved at least 50 symptom reduction or fell under clinical cut off rr 27 7 94 339 sf 39 8 135 339 compared with the wlc rr 4 8 16 336 sf 15 5 52 336 conclusion highly burdened individual benefit greatly from ismis and therefore should not be excluded from participation stress management may be a valid entry point to reach highly burdened individual who otherwise may not seek treatment trial registration 1 german clinical trial register drks00005112 http www drks de drks00005112 archived by webcite at http www webcitation org 6zmizwvda 2 german clinical trial register drks00005384 http www drks de drks00005384 archived by webcite at http www webcitation org 6zmierdtr and 3 german clinical trial register drks00004749 http www drks de drks00004749 archived by webcite at http www webcitation org 6zmijdqpx

Title: The effect of salience of rewards on effort-based decision making in psychotic disorders
Authors: Renz, K. E.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: background although motivational negative symptom account for reduced functioning and quality of life in individual with psychotic disorder the underlying mechanism are yet not fully understood neuroimaging study suggest that an impaired perception of reward cue could result in a lack of incentive value that then lead to a decrease in goal directed behavior therefore the aim of this study wa to test the effect of increasing the salience of reward cue on goal directed behavior method we recruited a sample of n 30 participant with a psychotic disorder and at least mild negative symptom and n 30 healthy control we used the balloon effort task an effort based decision making paradigm to a amotivation on a behavioral level we manipulated the salience of reward in the paradigm by highlighting the monetary reward in half of the trial result total effort expenditure did not differ between participant with and without psychotic disorder but participant with psychotic disorder showed a significantly reduced effort allocation to the level of reward the salience of reward manipulation significantly increased effort expenditure both in participant with psychotic disorder and in the healthy control but had no impact on effort allocation conclusion increasing the salience of reward cue promotes goal directed behavior this open up new possibility for intervention addressing amotivation in individual with negative symptom by facilitating the perception of reward cue

Title: Indicated Web-Based Prevention for Women With Anorexia Nervosa Symptoms: Randomized Controlled Efficacy Trial
Authors: Jacobi, C.; Vollert, B.; Hutter, K.; von Bloh, P.; Eiterich, N.; Gorlich, D.; Taylor, C. B.
Abstract: background although preventive intervention for eating disorder in general have shown promise intervention specifically targeting individual at risk for anorexia nervosa an are lacking objective the aim of this study wa to determine the efficacy of a guided indicated web based prevention program for woman at risk for an method we conducted a randomized controlled efficacy trial for woman at risk for an assessment were carried out at baseline before the intervention after the intervention 10 week after baseline and at 6 and 12 month follow ups fus a total of 168 woman with low body weight 17 5 kg m 2 bmi 19 kg m 2 and high weight concern or with normal body weight 19 kg m 2 bmi 25 kg m 2 high weight concern and high restrained eating were recruited from 3 german university a well a on the web and randomized to student body an sb an intervention group ig or a wait list control group cg the exclusion criterion were current diagnostic and statistical manual of mental
