disorder fourth edition based full syndrome eating disorder and serious medical or mental problem the intervention were a cognitive behavioral guided web based prevention program sb an over 10 week ig and a wait list cg the primary outcome were clinically significant change in disordered eating attitude and behavior and change in bmi at 12 month fu in the group of participant who were underweight the secondary outcome were new onset of eating disorder symptom of disordered eating and associated psychopathology result data were available for 81 5 137 168 of the woman after the intervention and for 69 116 168 of the woman at 12 month fu at 12 month fu the ig participant showed larger decrease in eating disorder examination total score 38 48 79 v 33 58 57 than the cg participant and the ig participant who were underweight also showed larger clinically relevant increase in bmi 15 31 49 v 10 32 32 than the cg participant but these difference were not significant in addition after the intervention and at 12 month fu we found a significant increase in continuously measured bmi for the participant who were underweight and significant improvement in disordered eating attitude and behavior eg restrained eating a well a weight and shape concern at all time point the rate of new onset eating disorder case were nonsignificantly lower in the ig than in the cg and the reduction in diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder fifth edition based eating disorder syndrome were nonsignificantly higher in the ig than in the cg conclusion sb an is the first preventive intervention shown to significantly reduce specific risk factor for and symptom of an and show promise for reducing full syndrome an onset trial registration isrctn registry isrctn70380261 http www isrctn com isrctn70380261

Title: How social rejection expectations and depressive symptoms bi-directionally predict each other - A cross-lagged panel analysis
Authors: Kirchner, L.; Schummer, S. E.; Krug, H.; Kube, T.; Rief, W.
Abstract: background although research suggests that social rejection expectation play a crucial role in the development and maintenance of depressive symptom it is not clear whether such expectation are a risk factor for depression or rather a consequence thereof the present study addressed this issue by investigating the time lagged bi directional effect of social rejection expectation and depressive symptom method in an online survey participant n 347 completed measure of social rejection expectation depressive symptom interpersonal competency and perceived social support at baseline and 2 month later the relationship between the variable were examined using path model and cross lagged path analysis result cross lagged path analysis provided evidence for a substantial positive effect of social rejection expectation at baseline on depressive symptom at follow up in addition to the reverse effect a mediator analysis indicated that neither interpersonal competency nor perceived social support mediated these bi directional effect conclusion the current result demonstrate that social rejection expectation and depressive symptom bi directionally predict each other thus social rejection expectation appears to be both a risk factor for and a symptom of depression in order to prevent a vicious circle of social rejection expectation and depressive symptom we recommend the early detection and treatment of social rejection expectation moreover social rejection expectation should be specifically addressed in cognitive behavioural treatment of depression

Title: Neural correlates of an attentional bias to health-threatening stimuli in individuals with pathological health anxiety
Authors: Mier, D.; Bailer, J.; Ofer, J.; Kerstner, T.; Zamoscik, V.; Rist, F.; Witthoft, M.; Diener, C.
Abstract: background an attentional bias to health threat stimulus is assumed to represent the primary pathogenetic factor for the development and maintenance of pathological health anxiety pha formerly termed hypochondriasis however little is known about the neural basis of this attentional bias in individual with pha method a group of patient with pha a group of depressed patient and a healthy control group completed an emotional stroop task with health threat body symptom and illness word and neutral control word while undergoing functional mri result we included 33 patient with pha 28 depressed patient and 31 control in our analysis a reflected in reaction time patient with pha showed a significantly stronger attentional bias to health threat word than both control group in addition patient with pha showed increased amygdala and rostral anterior cingulate cortex activation for body symptom but not for illness word moreover only in patient with pha amygdala activation in response to symptom word wa positively associated with higher arousal and more negative valence rating of the body symptom word material limitation a control group of patient with an anxiety disorder but without pha would have helped to define the specificity of the result for pha conclusion the attentional bias observed in patient with pha is associated with hyperactivation in response to body symptom word in brain region that are crucial for an arousal related fear response e g the amygdala and for resolving emotional interference e g the rostral anterior cingulate cortex the finding have important implication for the nosological classification of pha and suggest the application of innovative exposure based intervention for the treatment of pha

Title: Olfaction as a marker for depression in humans
Authors: Croy, I.; Symmank, A.; Schellong, J.; Hummel, C.; Gerber, J.; Joraschky, P.; Hummel, T.
Abstract: background animal study show a strong link between the loss of olfactory function and depressive behavior we analyzed whether olfactory function is a marker for depression in human if so reduced olfactory function can be expected in depression that improves to level of normality after successful antidepressive treatment method twenty seven female in patient with depression were compared to 28 healthy age matched woman at the beginning and at the end of antidepressive therapy or at two visit respectively olfactory function wa assessed comprehensively including threshold discrimination and identification testing chemosensory event related potential and olfactory functional magnetic resonance imaging result at the beginning of psychotherapy the patient exhibited reduced olfactory discrimination prolonged latency of the event related potential and reduced activation in secondary olfactory structure thalamus insula and left middle orbitofrontal after therapy patient improved significantly in all of the parameter and consequently the difference between control group and patient vanished limitation and conclusion we conclude that olfaction is a marker for depression however the result are limited to a relatively selective sample of depressed woman

Title: Defensive Mobilization During Anticipation of Symptom Provocation: Association With Panic Pathology
Authors: Benke, C.; Alius, M. G.; Hamm, A. O.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: background anxious apprehension about feared body symptom is thought to play a crucial role in the development chronicity and treatment of panic disorder pd in this study we therefore aimed to elucidate the role of defensive reactivity to anticipated unpleasant symptom in pd that can contribute to a better understanding of pathomechanisms of pd a well a identification of potential target in pd focused intervention by measuring amygdala dependent potentiation of the startle reflex we aimed to investigate whether 1 patient with pd exhibit a specifically increased defensive reactivity to anticipated unpleasant body symptom and 2 whether clinical severity of panic symptomatology varies with magnitude of defensive activation method defensive mobilization to anticipated threat wa investigated in 73 patient with a primary diagnosis of pd with agoraphobia pda and 52 healthy control subject threat of symptom provocation wa established by a standardized hyperventilation task and contrasted to threat of shock to the forearm of the participant result patient with pda and healthy control subject did not differ in their defensive response during anticipation of shock in contrast patient with severe pda a compared with healthy control subject exhibited increased defensive response mobilization and reported more anxiety and panic symptom during anticipation of feared body symptom moreover startle potentiation during anticipation of hyperventilation covaried with the severity of panic symptomatology conclusion the present finding suggest that increased defensive mobilization during anticipation of body symptom is a neurobiological correlate of severe pda that should be specifically targeted in pd intervention and might be used to monitor treatment success

Title: Transdiagnostic culturally adapted CBT with Farsi-speaking refugees: a pilot study
Authors: Kananian, S.; Ayoughi, S.; Farugie, A.; Hinton, D.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: background approximately half of all asylum seeker suffer from trauma related disorder requiring treatment among them posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd depression anxiety and somatic symptom there is a lack of easily accessible low threshold treatment taking the cultural background into account culturally adapted cbt ca cbt is a well evaluated transdiagnostic group intervention for refugee using psychoeducation meditation and yoga like exercise objective an uncontrolled pilot study with male farsi speaking refugee from afghanistan and iran wa conducted to investigate feasibility with this ethnic group a group for which no previous cbt trial have been reported method the participant were nine farsi speaking male refugee with m i n i dsm iv diagnosis comprising ptsd major depressive disorder and anxiety disorder treatment component were adapted to the specific cultural framework of perception of symptom cause idea of healing and local therapeutic process before and after 12 week of treatment the primary outcome wa assessed using the general health questionnaire ghq 28 secondary outcome measure were the posttraumatic checklist patient health questionnaire somatic symptom scale world health organization quality of life questionnaire whoqol bref affective style questionnaire asq and emotion regulation scale er result seven participant completed treatment in the completer analysis improvement were found on almost all questionnaire large effect size were seen for the ghq 28 d 2 0 whoqol bref scale d 1 0 2 3 asq tolerating subscale d 2 2 and er d 1 7 with respect to feasibility cultural adaptation seemed to be a crucial mean to promote effectiveness conclusion ca cbt may reduce general psychopathological distress and improve quality of life improvement in emotion regulation strategy may mediate treatment effect more support should be provided to enhance coping with the uncertainty of asylum status and stressful housing condition ca cbt appears to be a promising transdiagnostic treatment serving a an initial low threshold therapy in a stepped care approach

Title: A pilot study on ecological momentary assessment in asylum-seeking children and adolescents resettled to Germany: Investigating compliance, post-migration factors, and the relation between daily mood, sleep patterns, and mental health
Authors: Muller, L. R. F.; Gossmann, K.; Schmid, R. F.; Rosner, R.; Unterhitzenberger, J.
Abstract: background asylum seeking child and adolescent ascs resettled to western country show elevated level of psychological distress while research on the mental health of ascs is increasing le is known about their day to day living experience such a their daily mood sleep pattern and post migration factor moreover no examination in situ using smartphone assisted ecological momentary assessment ema ha been conducted up to now among ascs furthermore we do not know if screening measure succeed in reflecting the daily mood of ascs experienced in everyday life method we undertook a smartphone assisted ema study over a two week period with 3 measurement a day participant were n 40 ascs from 10 different country who had resettled to germany they completed standardized questionnaire screening for history of trauma and clinical symptom post traumatic stress symptom depression and anxiety that were carried out in interview like setting and they participated in the subsequent ema where they rated mood sleep parameter and post migration factor on a daily basis multilevel model of clinical symptom daily mood and sleep parameter were computed based on a total of 680 measurement result the multiply traumatized and highly distressed participant reported different level of discrimination and various social activity and contact in the ema the overall compliance rate wa shown to be 40 5 higher pt and anxiety score were associated with lower level of daily mood and poorer outcome of some sleep parameter depression score were not associated with any of the variable assessed in the ema conclusion smartphone assisted ema among ascs resettled to germany proved to be implementable despite a rather low compliance rate not only do ascs show high symptom level they are also affected by these symptom in their daily life the result emphasize the need for concise screening and psychological treatment for this high risk population limitation include the convenient nature of the sample and the lack of a comparison group

Title: 1-year follow-up of the mental health and stress factors in asylum-seeking children and adolescents resettled in Germany
Authors: Muller, L. R. F.; Gossmann, K.; Hartmann, F.; Buter, K. P.; Rosner, R.; Unterhitzenberger, J.
Abstract: background asylum seeking child and adolescent ascs who have resettled in western country show elevated rate of psychological distress including posttraumatic stress symptom pt depression and anxiety most longitudinal data suggest a relatively stable course of symptom during the first year in exile however no longitudinal examination of the mental health of ascs who resettled in europe in the wake of the 2015 17 european migrant crisis ha been conducted so far method a prospective cohort study looked at 98 ascs who resettled in southern germany throughout 2015 17 they mainly came from afghanistan syria eritrea and iraq baseline assessment were undertaken 22 month on average after resettlement and follow up assessment 1 year thereafter seventy two ascs could be secured for the follow up the measure included self report questionnaire screening for pt depression anxiety externalizing behavior and post migration factor that were administered in an interview like setting result were analyzed using hierarchical multiple regression analysis result participating ascs reported on average eight potentially traumatic experience and high level of psychological distress at baseline that had significantly declined at follow up at follow up rate of clinically significant symptom ranged from 9 7 externalizing behavior to 37 5 pt there wa considerable individual variation in symptom change resulting in multiple mental health trajectory ascs whose asylum application had been rejected presented significantly more symptom than ascs whose asylum application had been accepted between assessment baseline psychopathology and asylum status predicted follow up symptom severity conclusion in contrast to earlier study the symptom severity in this sample of ascs in germany ameliorated between assessment decision on the asylum application of ascs are thought to contribute to the course of symptom since level of psychological distress were still high dissemination and implementation of appropriate treatment for ascs is crucial

Title: Attentional Bias Temporal Dynamics Predict Posttraumatic Stress Symptoms: A Prospective-Longitudinal Study among Soldiers
Authors: Schafer, J.; Bernstein, A.; Zvielli, A.; Hofler, M.; Wittchen, H. U.; Schonfeld, S.
Abstract: background attentional bias ab to threat is thought to play a key role in the development and maintenance of posttraumatic stress symptomatology pt empirical evidence though is inconsistent some study report association between ab towards threat and pt other study report association between ab away from threat and pt yet other study fail to find any association we propose that prospective longitudinal study of ab a a dynamic process expressed from moment to moment in time may help to understand these mixed finding and the role of ab in pt method we tested cross sectional and prospective longitudinal association between ab and pt among german soldier from pre to post deployment in afghanistan n 144 ab to threat and positive emotion stimulus angry happy face wa measured using the dot probe task pt wa assessed by the ptsd checklist the number of traumatic experience wa assessed using cidi traumatic experience list for military result we found that ab dynamic i e towards away temporal variability at pre and post deployment with respect to angry and happy face predicted higher level of pt after deployment a a function of number of intermediate traumatic experience traditional aggregated mean bias score did not similarly prospectively predict pt post deployment conclusion finding indicate that ab to emotionally arousing stimulus may play an important function in the development and maintenance of pt we argue that mixed and null finding appear to be due to failure to model the within subject temporal variability in ab expression theoretical empirical and clinical implication of these finding are discussed

Title: Attentional avoidance in peer victimized individuals with and without psychiatric disorders
Authors: Iffland, B.; Weitkamper, A.; Weitkamper, N. J.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: background attentional bias are a relatively robust phenomenon among clinical population but le pronounced in healthy participant however regarding the component of attentional bias and the direction of attention allocation there are several inconsistency in the literature the present study examined whether these inconsistency can be traced back to previous experience of relational peer victimization in clinical population method participant were subject with a diagnosed psychiatric disorder n 30 and healthy control n 31 additionally the sample wa divided into two subgroup according to the participant report of previous relational peer victimization high peer victimization n 28 low peer victimization n 33 attentional bias were measured by the emotional stroop task and a dot probe task result in both sample peer victimized participant showed delayed response time when color naming negative and positive compared to neutral adjective in the emotional stroop task likewise the dot probe task indicated attentional avoidance of both negative and positive word in peer victimized participant with and without a psychiatric disorder interestingly presence of a psychiatric disorder did not have a significant effect on attentional bias conclusion both task could detect that attentional process were linked to the experience of peer victimization rather than to the current diagnostic status of the participant attentional avoidance of emotional stimulus may prevent victimized individual from responding adequately to environmental stimulus which may increase the risk for the development of psychopathology

Title: Effects of intranasal oxytocin on the neural basis of face processing in autism spectrum disorder
Authors: Domes, G.; Heinrichs, M.; Kumbier, E.; Grossmann, A.; Hauenstein, K.; Herpertz, S. C.
Abstract: background autism spectrum disorder asd is associated with altered face processing and decreased activity in brain region involved in face processing the neuropeptide oxytocin ha been shown to promote face processing and modulate brain activity in healthy adult the present study examined the effect of oxytocin on the neural basis of face processing in adult with asperger syndrome a method a group of 14 individual with a and a group of 14 neurotypical control participant performed a face matching and a house matching task during functional magnetic resonance imaging the effect of a single dose of 24 iu intranasally administered oxytocin were tested in a randomized placebo controlled within subject cross over design result under placebo the a group showed decreased activity in the right amygdala fusiform gyrus and inferior occipital gyrus compared with the control group during face processing after oxytocin treatment right amygdala activity to facial stimulus increased in the a group conclusion these finding indicate that oxytocin increase the saliency of social stimulus and in asd and suggest that oxytocin might promote face processing and eye contact in individual with asd a prerequisite for neurotypical social interaction

Title: A Gamified Smartphone-Based Intervention for Depression: Randomized Controlled Pilot Trial
Authors: Lukas, C. A.; Eskofier, B.; Berking, M.
Abstract: background available smartphone based intervention for depression predominantly use evidence based strategy from cognitive behavioral therapy cbt but patient engagement and reported effect size are small recently study have demonstrated that smartphone based intervention combining cbt with gamified approach avoidance bias modification training aamt can foster patient engagement and reduce symptom of several mental health problem objective based on these finding we developed a gamified smartphone based intervention mentalis phoenix mt phoenix and hypothesized the program would both engage patient and produce preliminary evidence for the reduction of depressive symptom method to test this hypothesis we evaluated mt phoenix in a randomized controlled pilot trial including 77 individual with elevated depression score patient health questionnaire 9 score 5 participant were either instructed to train for 14 day with mt phoenix or assigned to a waitlist control condition engagement with the intervention wa measured by assessing usage data the primary outcome wa reduction in depressive symptom severity at postassessment result data from this pilot trial show that participant in the intervention group used the smartphone based intervention for 46 of all day 6 4 14 and reported a significantly greater reduction of depressive symptom than did participant in the control condition f 1 74 19 34 p 001 with a large effect size d 1 02 effect were sustained at a 3 month follow up conclusion a gamified smartphone based intervention combining cbt with aamt may foster patient engagement and effectively target depressive symptom future study should evaluate the effectiveness of this intervention in a phase 3 trial using clinical sample moreover the intervention should be compared to active control condition trial registration german clinical trial registry drks00012769 http tinyurl com 47mw8du7

Title: Health anxiety is associated with fearful imagery of contracting COVID-19: An experimental study
Authors: Benke, C.; Schonborn, T.; Habermann, N.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: background aversive mental image of contracting or having a severe disease are assumed to contribute to the development and maintenance of health anxiety ha via the elicitation of fear arousal and defensive mobilization the current covid 19 pandemic is known to trigger fear of contracting covid 19 method in this study we used an experimental approach to investigate whether covid 19 related mental image lead to a fearful response and whether this is associated with level of ha 139 participant vividly imagined neutral standard fear and covid 19 related narrative scene result standard fear and covid 19 script prompted higher anxiety arousal displeasure and avoidance tendency a compared to neutral script ha wa associated with higher anxiety arousal displeasure imagery vividness and stronger avoidance tendency during imagery of covid 19 scene no association were found for anxiety sensitivity trait anxiety a well a depressive and anxiety symptom moreover there wa no association of ha with emotional response during imagery of standard fear scene limitation fear response were assessed via verbal report future study should also a behavioral and physiological correlate of fear conclusion the present result indicate that individual with high level of ha are prone to fearful mental imagery of contracting covid 19 which might be crucial factor contributing to the exacerbation and chronicity of excessive ha in time of a pandemic

Title: Cognitive emotion regulation in euthymic bipolar disorder
Authors: Wolkenstein, L.; Zwick, J. C.; Hautzinger, M.; Joormann, J.
Abstract: background based on finding indicating increased stress reactivity and prolonged stress recovery in individual with bipolar disorder bd it ha been proposed that emotion regulation er deficit lie at the core of this disorder recent study show an increased use of maladaptive er strategy and a decreased use of adaptive er strategy in bd whether this pattern is merely a correlate of affective episode or might be a stable characteristic of bd however remains to be explored in addition it is unclear whether these deficit in er are specific to people with a history of bd method we examined whether euthymic bd individual differ from healthy control hc and individual with a history of major depressive disorder mdd with respect to the cognitive er strategy they habitually use cerq in response to negative affect the sample consisted of 42 bipolar patient 43 patient with mdd and 39 hc result compared to hc euthymic bd and mdd individual reported increased use of rumination catastrophizing and self blame alongside decreased use of positive reappraisal and putting into perspective no difference were found between bd and mdd group limitation these finding are based on self report reflecting the habitual use of er strategy the use of more objective method and the examination of the spontaneous use of er strategy in euthymic bd would be desirable conclusion deficit in the habitual use of er strategy may characterize bd and mdd individual even outside of an acute episode and thereby play a role in the recurrence of affective disorder

Title: Behavioral and Magnetoencephalographic Correlates of Fear Generalization Are Associated With Responses to Later Virtual Reality Exposure Therapy in Spider Phobia
Authors: Roesmann, K.; Leehr, E. J.; Bohnlein, J.; Steinberg, C.; Seeger, F.; Schwarzmeier, H.; Gathmann, B.; Siminski, N.; Herrmann, M. J.; Dannlowski, U.; Lueken, U.; Klucken, T.; Hilbert, K.; Straube, T.; Junghofer, M.
Abstract: background because overgeneralization of fear is a pathogenic marker of anxiety disorder we investigated whether pretreatment level of fear generalization in spider phobic patient are related to their response to exposure based treatment to identify pretreatment moderator of treatment success method a total of 90 patient with spider phobia completed pretreatment clinical and magnetoencephalography assessment one session of virtual reality exposure therapy and a posttreatment clinical assessment based on the primary outcome 30 symptom reduction in self reported symptom they were categorized a responder or nonresponders in a pretreatment magnetoencephalography fear generalization paradigm involving fear conditioning with 2 unconditioned stimulus ucs we obtained fear rating ucs expectancy rating and event related field to conditioned stimulus c c c and 7 different generalization stimulus on a perceptual continuum from c to c result before treatment nonresponders showed behavioral overgeneralization indicated by more linear generalization gradient in fear rating analysis of magnetoencephalography source estimation revealed that nonresponders showed a decline of their inhibitory frontal activation to safety signaling c and generalization stimulus compared with c over time while responder maintained these activation at early 300 m and late processing stage conclusion result provide initial evidence that pretreatment difference of behavioral and neural marker of fear generalization may act a moderator of later response to behavioral exposure stimulating further research on fear generalization a a potential predictive marker our finding are an important first step in the attempt to identify patient who may not benefit from exposure therapy and to personalize and optimize treatment strategy for this vulnerable patient group

Title: Efficacy of Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for the Prophylaxis of Migraine in Adults: A Three-Armed Randomized Controlled Trial
Authors: Klan, T.; Gaul, C.; Liesering-Latta, E.; Both, B.; Held, I.; Hennemann, S.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: background behavioral approach are central to the preventive treatment of migraine but empirical evidence regarding efficacy and effectiveness is still sparse this study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a newly developed migraine specific integrative cognitive behavioral therapy program micbt combining several approach trigger and stress management coping with fear of attack relaxation training by comparing it with a single behavioral approach relaxation training rlx a an active control group and a waiting list control group wlc method in a three armed open label randomized controlled trial 121 adult with migraine were assigned to either micbt rlx or wlc the outpatient group therapy micbt or rlx consisted of seven session each 90 min participant who completed the wlc were subsequently randomized to one of the two treatment group primary outcome were headache day headache related disability emotional distress and self efficacy the baseline wa compared to post treatment and followed by assessment 4 and 12 month post treatment to compare micbt and rlx result mixed model analysis intention to treat sample 106 participant showed significantly stronger pre post improvement in self efficacy assessed by the headache management self efficacy scale hmse g sf in both treatment group compared to the wlc mean difference at post micbt 4 67 0 55 8 78 p 0 027 rlx 4 42 0 38 to 8 46 p 0 032 whereas no other significant between group difference were observed the follow up analysis revealed significant within group improvement from baseline to 12 month follow up in all four primary outcome for both treatment however between group effect micbt v rlx were not significant at follow up conclusion the micbt ha no better treatment effect compared to rlx in migraine prophylaxis both treatment effectively increase patient self efficacy trial registration german clinical trial register www drks de drks id drks00011111

Title: Fear of positive evaluation in borderline personality disorder
Authors: Weinbrecht, A.; Roepke, S.; Renneberg, B.
Abstract: background being afraid of others positive appraisal of oneself is called fear of positive evaluation fear of positive evaluation ha been studied intensively in the context of social anxiety disorder sad it is not known if individual with borderline personality disorder bpd fear positive evaluation and which factor are associated with fear of positive evaluation in bpd method we applied the fear of positive evaluation scale and further self report measure e g social phobia inventory rejection sensitivity questionnaire to 36 patient with bpd 29 patient with sad and 35 healthy control hc result a one way anova revealed that patient with bpd and patient with sad reported significantly higher fear of positive evaluation than hc patient with bpd and sad did not differ in their fear of positive evaluation a hierarchical regression analysis revealed an association between rejection sensitivity and fear of positive evaluation in the bpd sample however this association disappeared when controlling for social anxiety conclusion our result indicate that individual with bpd fear positive evaluation a much a individual with sad do which ha implication for clinical practice our result further imply that social anxiety is decisive for high fear of positive evaluation in patient with sad and patient with bpd

Title: Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for Postbariatric Surgery Patients With Mental Disorders: A Pilot Study
Authors: Rudolph, A.; Hilbert, A.
Abstract: background binge eating disorder bed and major depressive disorder mdd following bariatric surgery are significant predictor for le post operative weight loss and or weight regain however cognitive behavioral therapy cbt addressing these disorder following surgery ha not been investigated so far objective this study examined feasibility of a short term cbt based on evidence based manual for bed and mdd that were adapted to patient following bariatric surgery and investigated it effectiveness in improving weight loss outcome psychopathology and psychosocial functioning material and method in an uncontrolled proof of concept study the cbt manual wa piloted in n 7 patient who had undergone roux en y gastric bypass surgery at least 6 month before weight loss eating disorder psychopathology depressive symptom and self esteem were assessed using clinical interview and self report questionnaire at pre treatment post treatment and in a 3 month follow up result a significant reduction of body weight wa found a well a medium to large effect in the improvement of eating disorder psychopathology depressive symptom and self esteem from pre treatment to post treatment were found most of those change remained stable during the 3 month follow up period study retention wa 71 4 conclusion feasibility and effectiveness of cbt were documented for patient with bed or mdd following bariatric surgery adaptation of the study procedure for proof of efficacy in randomized controlled study are discussed

Title: Neural Correlates of Own- and Other-Face Perception in Body Dysmorphic Disorder
Authors: Ritter, V.; Kaufmann, J. M.; Krahmer, F.; Wiese, H.; Stangier, U.; Schweinberger, S. R.
Abstract: background body dysmorphic disorder bdd is characterized by an excessive preoccupation with one or more perceived flaw in one s own appearance previous study provided evidence for deficit in configural and holistic processing in bdd preliminary evidence suggests abnormality at an early stage of visual processing the present study is the first examining early neurocognitive perception of the own face in bdd by using electroencephalography eeg we investigated the face inversion effect in which inverted upside down face are disproportionately poorly processed compared to upright face this effect reflects a disruption of configural and holistic processing and in consequence a preponderance of featural face processing method we recorded face sensitive event related potential erps in 16 bdd patient and 16 healthy control all unmedicated participant viewed upright and inverted upside down image of their own face and an unfamiliar other face each in two facial emotional expression neutral v smiling we calculated the early erp component p100 n170 p200 n250 and the late positive component lpc and compared amplitude among both group result in the early p100 no face inversion effect were found in both group in the n170 both group exhibited the common face inversion effect with significantly larger n170 amplitude for inverted than upright face in the p200 both group exhibited larger inversion effect to other relative to own face with larger p200 amplitude for other upright than inverted face in the n250 no significant group difference were found in face processing in the lpc both group exhibited larger inversion effect to other relative to own face with larger lpc amplitude for other inverted than upright face these overall pattern appeared to be comparable for both group smaller inversion effect to own relative to other face were observed in none of these component in bdd relative to control conclusion the finding suggest no evidence for abnormality at all level of early face processing in our observed sample of bdd patient further research should investigate the neural substrate underlying bdd symptomatology

Title: Trait-Based Emotional Intelligence, Body Image Dissatisfaction, and HRQoL in Children
Authors: Pollatos, O.; Georgiou, E.; Kobel, S.; Schreiber, A.; Dreyhaupt, J.; Steinacker, J. M.
Abstract: background body image dissatisfaction bid is related to an increased risk for various health issue including descreased health related quality of life hrqol the development of problematic eating behavior and obesity previous research indicates that emotional intelligence is one important factor related to bid in adult whether this is the case in child remains yet unknown taking this into consideration the aim of this study wa to explore the relationship between bid and trait based emotion intelligence tei a well a hrqol in female and male primary school child material and method tei and bid were assessed via self report a well a hrqol via parental report in a large sample of 991 primary school child 429 girl within the baden wurttemberg study which evaluated the effectiveness of the health prevention programm join the healthy boat in southwestern germany result our finding demonstrated the interrelation between higher level of tei and lower level of bid among girl and boy positive association were found between better hrqol better intrapersonal and stress management abilites subscales of tei and lower bid a reflected by parental and self report conclusion our result reveal an interconnectivity between tei bid and better hrqol in female and male primary school child although the observed correlation were rather small they nervertheless support the idea that tei consists a key factor for the self regulation of health related behavior prevention program could benefit from including process that sough to improve aspect of emotional intelligence such a intrapersonal interpersonal ability and adaptability a an effort of preventing problematic habit or lifestyle that could lead to disordered eating behavior a well a to obesity in middle childhood

Title: Enhanced detection of emotional facial expressions in borderline personality disorder
Authors: Schulze, L.; Domes, G.; Koppen, D.; Herpertz, S. C.
Abstract: background borderline personality disorder bpd is commonly proposed to be characterized by an enhanced sensitivity for emotional stimulus in the present study we investigated whether bpd patient show a superior detection of emotional facial expression relative to healthy control the detection of emotional information in the environment represents an important facet of emotional sensitivity sampling and method twenty patient with bpd were compared with 25 healthy control the participant were presented a rapid continuous stream of neutral and randomly inserted emotional facial expression and were asked to report the presentation of an emotional facial stimulus after each trial availability of cognitive resource wa manipulated via two different task demand result the participant with bpd performed significantly better in the detection of positive and negative facial expression compared to the healthy control false alarm rate did not differ significantly between the two group conclusion the bpd participant showed an enhanced detection of emotional expression that might be related to the emotional disturbance they experience in particular we will discus the role of this superior emotion detection in combination with previously reported deficit in the labeling of emotional state for the understanding of emotional instability in bpd

Title: Motivational processes in mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer's disease: results from the Motivational Reserve in Alzheimer's (MoReA) study
Authors: Forstmeier, S.; Maercker, A.
Abstract: background brain reserve i e the ability of the brain to tolerate age and disease related change in a way that cognitive function is still maintained is assumed to be based on the lifelong training of various ability the motivational reserve in alzheimer s morea is a longitudinal study that aim to examine motivational process a a protective factor in mild alzheimer s dementia ad and mild cognitive impairment mci this paper present the result of motivational variable frequency of diagnosis and prediction of global cognition a well a depression in a one year longitudinal study method the sample consists of 64 subject with mci and 47 subject with mild ad at baseline at baseline the physical neurological examination standard clinical assessment neuropsychological testing and assessment of motivational variable were performed at follow up fu one year later neuropsychological testing including cognition functional ability behavioral and affective symptom and global clinical assessment of severity have been repeated result ad case have lower motivational capacity a measured with a midlife motivation related occupational score and informant reported present motivational process but do not differ with regard to delay of gratification dog and self reported motivational process dog and delay discounting dd were relatively stable during the measurement interval however 20 of the mci case converted to mild ad at fu and 17 of the mild ad case converted to moderate ad the rate of depression of alzheimer s disease wa 9 at baseline and 21 at fu and the rate of apathy wa 7 and 14 respectively global cognition at fu wa mainly predicted by baseline global cognition but also by one of the motivational variable scenario test depression at fu wa predicted mainly by two motivational variable self reported and informant reported motivational process conclusion this research might inform motivation related strategy for prevention and early intervention with older people or people at risk for ad

Title: Thwarted Belongingness and Perceived Burdensomeness Mediate the Association Between Bullying and Suicide Ideation
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Ujma, M.; Friedrich, S.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: background bullying ha regularly been shown to be associated with suicide ideation however so far only a few study have examined the mechanism underlying the relationship between bullying and suicide ideation within a theory of suicide aim the aim of the present study wa to investigate whether thwarted belongingness and perceived burdensomeness mediate the association between bullying and suicide ideation method a total of 267 outpatient 63 3 female m age 37 52 sd age 12 80 completed online measure of bullying suicide ideation thwarted belongingness and perceived burdensomeness result thwarted belongingness a well a perceived burdensomeness fully mediated the association between bullying and suicide ideation controlling for gender and age limitation given the cross sectional nature of the data only hypothetical conclusion on causality can be drawn conclusion our result support the hypothesized and theory derived relation between bullying thwarted belongingness perceived burdensomeness and suicide ideation in anti bullying program it seems to be of particular importance to counter impression of thwarted belongingness and perceived burdensomeness

Title: Are some therapists better at facilitating and consolidating sudden gains than others?
Authors: Deisenhofer, A. K.; Rubel, J. A.; Bennemann, B.; Aderka, I. M.; Lutz, W.
Abstract: background change during psychotherapy often include sudden symptom improvement called sudden gain sg which have been identified a being superior to gradual symptom change with regard to treatment success this study investigates the role of therapist in initiating and or consolidating sg method the analysis are based on a sample of patient n 1937 who were seen by 155 therapist and received individual psychotherapy at a university outpatient clinic first the therapist effect te on sg wa investigated using multilevel modeling mlm second mlm wa used to explore the relative importance of patient and therapist variability in sg a they relate to outcome result the te on sg accounted for 1 8 of variance meaning that therapist are accountable for inter individual difference in their patient likelihood to experience sg furthermore result revealed a significant effect of sg on outcome for both level while therapist difference regarding the consolidation of sg were not significant conclusion the analysis indicated that some therapist are better in facilitating and initiating sg the process of triggering sg seems to be a therapist skill or competence which open up an additional pathway to positive outcome that could be used to improve clinical training

Title: Harsh discipline relates to internalizing problems and cognitive functioning: findings from a cross-sectional study with school children in Tanzania
Authors: Hecker, T.; Hermenau, K.; Salmen, C.; Teicher, M.; Elbert, T.
Abstract: background child maltreatment pose a risk to child and adolescent mental health and may also affect cognitive functioning also harsh discipline ha been frequently associated with mental health problem however within society in which harsh disciplinary method are culturally normed and highly prevalent le is known about the association between harsh punishment mental health problem and cognitive functioning method in a cross sectional study we conducted structured clinical interview with a sample of tanzanian primary school student assessing exposure to harsh discipline maltreatment and abuse chronology of exposure internalizing problem strength and difficulty questionnaire child s depression inventory and working memory corsi blocktapping task school performance wa measured by using the exam grade in 4 core subject the 409 child 52 boy had a mean age of 10 5 year range 6 15 result using structural equation modeling a strong relationship wa found between harsh discipline and internalizing problem beta 47 which were related to lower working memory capacity beta 17 and school performance beta 17 conclusion the present study suggests that harsh discipline is closely linked to child s internalizing mental health problem which are in turn associated with lower cognitive functioning and school performance given the high rate of harsh discipline experienced by child in east african home and elsewhere the finding of the present study emphasize the need to inform the population at large about the potentially adverse consequence associated with harsh discipline

Title: Child maltreatment, peer victimization, and social anxiety in adulthood: a cross-sectional study in a treatment-seeking sample
Authors: Bruhl, A.; Kley, H.; Grocholewski, A.; Neuner, F.; Heinrichs, N.
Abstract: background childhood adversity especially emotional abuse emotional neglect and peer victimization are considered to be crucial risk factor for social anxiety disorder sad we investigated whether particular form of retrospectively recalled childhood adversity are specifically associated with sad in adulthood or whether we find similar link in other anxiety or depressive disorder method prevalence of adversity assessed with the childhood trauma questionnaire ctq and a questionnaire of stressful social experience fbs were determined in n 1091 outpatient adversity severity among patient with sad only n 25 specific phobia only n 18 and generalized anxiety disorder only n 19 were compared difference between patient with anxiety disorder only n 62 and depressive disorder only n 239 a well a between sad with comorbid depressive disorder n 143 and sad only were tested result none of the adversity type were found to be specifically associated with sad and severity did not differ among anxiety disorder but patient with depressive disorder reported more severe emotional abuse physical abuse and sexual abuse than patient with anxiety disorder sad patient with a comorbid depressive disorder also reported more severe adversity across all type compared to sad only conclusion finding indicate that particular form of recalled childhood adversity are not specifically associated with sad in adulthood previously established link with sad may be better explained by comorbid depressive symptom

Title: Attention deficit disorder, stimulant use, and childhood body mass index trajectory
Authors: Schwartz, B. S.; Bailey-Davis, L.; Bandeen-Roche, K.; Pollak, J.; Hirsch, A. G.; Nau, C.; Liu, A. Y.; Glass, T. A.
Abstract: background childhood attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd ha been associated with childhood and adult obesity and stimulant use with delayed childhood growth but the independent influence are unclear no longitudinal study have examined association of adhd diagnosis and stimulant use on bmi trajectory throughout childhood and adolescence method we used longitudinal electronic health record data from the geisinger health system on 163 820 child age 3 to 18 year in pennsylvania random effect linear regression model were used to model bmi trajectory with increasing age in relation to adhd diagnosis age at first stimulant use and stimulant use duration while controlling for confounding variable result mean sd age at first bmi wa 8 9 5 0 year and child provided a mean sd of 3 2 2 4 annual bmi measurement on average bmi trajectory showed a curvilinear relation with age there were consistent association of unmedicated adhd with higher bmi during childhood compared with those without adhd or stimulant younger age at first stimulant use and longer duration of stimulant use were each associated with slower bmi growth earlier in childhood but a more rapid rebound to higher bmi in late adolescence conclusion the study provides the first longitudinal evidence that adhd during childhood not treated with stimulant wa associated with higher childhood bmi in contrast adhd treated with stimulant wa associated with slower early bmi growth but a rebound later in adolescence to level above child without a history of adhd or stimulant use the finding have important clinical and neurobiological implication

Title: Childhood maltreatment compromises resilience against occupational trauma exposure: A retrospective study among emergency medical service personnel
Authors: Behnke, A.; Rojas, R.; Karabatsiakis, A.; Kolassa, I. T.
Abstract: background childhood maltreatment cm compromise resilience against stress and trauma throughout life therefore it could present a major risk factor for the health of frequently trauma exposed professional such a emergency medical service em personnel objective we investigated whether em personnel s history of cm increased their risk for mental and physical stress symptom after occupational trauma exposure participant and setting data from 103 german em personnel age mdn qd 26 00 8 50 year were collected a part of a cross sectional survey distributed among employee of the regional german red cross em division response rate 46 6 the sample corresponded well to the division s entire staff in term of socio anagraphic characteristic method cm and occupational trauma exposure a well a posttraumatic depressive and somatic symptom were assessed with self report questionnaire result moderation analysis indicated stronger positive association between occupational trauma exposure and the severity of posttraumatic beta 30 p 001 depressive beta 20 p 026 and somatic symptom beta 18 p 059 among em personnel who reported a higher exposure to cm conclusion our study provides initial evidence that cm could increase the em personnel s vulnerability to the detrimental consequence of critical incident on duty future research is needed i to replicate and generalize our observation on various trauma exposed profession a well a ii to develop preventive measure for targeting the mediating and protective factor which influence the relationship between cm and the negative consequence of occupational trauma exposure

Title: Social support and hippocampal volume are negatively associated in adults with previous experience of childhood maltreatment
Authors: Forster, K.; Danzer, L.; Redlich, R.; Opel, N.; Grotegerd, D.; Leehr, E. J.; Dohm, K.; Enneking, V.; Meinert, S.; Goltermann, J.; Lemke, H.; Waltemate, L.; Thiel, K.; Behnert, K.; Brosch, K.; Stein, F.; Meller, T.; Ringwald, K.; Schmitt, S.; Steinstrater, O.; Jansen, A.; Krug, A.; Nenadic, I.; Kircher, T.; Hahn, T.; Kugel, H.; Heindel, W.; Repple, J.; Dannlowski, U.
Abstract: background childhood maltreatment ha been associated with reduced hippocampal volume in healthy individual whereas social support a protective factor ha been positively associated with hippocampal volume in this study we investigated how social support is associated with hippocampal volume in healthy people with previous experience of childhood maltreatment method we separated a sample of 446 healthy participant into 2 group using the childhood trauma questionnaire 265 people without maltreatment and 181 people with maltreatment we measured perceived social support using a short version of the social support questionnaire we examined hippocampal volume using automated segmentation freesurfer we conducted a social support x group analysis of covariance on hippocampal volume controlling for age sex total intracranial volume site and verbal intelligence result our analysis revealed significantly lower left hippocampal volume in people with maltreatment left f1 432 5 686 p 0 018 right f1 433 3 371 p 0 07 but no main effect of social support emerged however we did find a significant social support x group interaction for left hippocampal volume left f1 432 5 712 p 0 017 right f1 433 3 480 p 0 06 in people without maltreatment we observed a trend toward a positive association between social support and hippocampal volume in contrast social support wa negatively associated with hippocampal volume in people with maltreatment limitation because of the correlative nature of our study we could not infer causal relationship between social support maltreatment and hippocampal volume conclusion our result point to a complex dynamic between environmental risk protective factor and brain structure in line with previous evidence suggesting a detrimental effect of maltreatment on hippocampal development

Title: The effect of oxytocin on attention to angry and happy faces in chronic depression
Authors: Domes, G.; Normann, C.; Heinrichs, M.
Abstract: background chronic depression is characterized by a high degree of early life trauma psychosocial impairment and deficit in social cognition undisturbed recognition and processing of facial emotion are basic prerequisite for smooth social interaction intranasal application of the neuropeptide oxytocin ha been reported to enhance emotion recognition in neuropsychiatric disorder and healthy individual we therefore investigated whether oxytocin modulates attention to emotional face in patient with chronic depression method in this double blind randomized controlled study 43 patient received a single dose of oxytocin or placebo nasal spray and were tested while fulfilling a facial dot probe task we assessed reaction time to neutral probe presented at the location of one of two face depicting happy angry or neutral expression a a prime result when comparing reaction time to the congruent prime and probe at the same location with incongruent presentation of facial emotion neither the placebo nor oxytocin group showed an attentional preference for emotional facial expression in term of a threat bias however oxytocin treatment did reveal two specific effect it generally reduced the allocation of attention towards angry facial expression and it increased sustained attention towards happy face specifically under condition of heightened awareness i e trial with longer prime conclusion we investigated a heterogeneous group of medicated male and female patient we conclude that oxytocin doe modulate basic factor of facial emotion processing in chronic depression our finding encourage further investigation assessing the therapeutic potential of oxytocin in chronic depression trial registration eudra ct 2010 020956 69 date registered 23 february 2011

Title: The German version of the H-YBOCS for the assessment of hypochondriacal cognitions and behaviors: development, reliability and validity
Authors: Weck, F.; Gropalis, M.; Neng, J. M.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: background clinician administered interview are essential for assessing the efficacy of treatment study and constitute an important instrument for clinical practice recently the yale brown obsessive compulsive scale wa adapted for the dimensional assessment of hypochondriacal characteristic h ybocs and yielded promising result purpose this study aimed to develop and validate a german version of the h ybocs method altogether 101 patient with hypochondriasis and 49 patient with anxiety disorder were diagnosed using the german version of the h ybocs well established questionnaire for assessing hypochondriacal characteristic and the general psychopathology were administered a well result exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis suggested a three factor structure for the german version of the h ybocs cognitive factor behavioral factor and insight factor the current version of h ybocs demonstrated high internal consistency alpha 0 93 and inter rater reliability icc 97 convergent and discriminant validity were also confirmed by high correlation with questionnaire such a the illness attitude scale r 0 81 and non significant correlation with the brief symptom inventory r 0 12 the h ybocs discriminated between patient with hypochondriasis and those with anxiety disorder with high sensitivity 0 94 and specificity 0 78 conclusion the german version of the h ybocs proved to be a highly effective interview instrument for the dimensional assessment of hypochondriacal characteristic and therefore constitutes an important contribution to scientific research and clinical practice

Title: Effect of a single dialysis session on cognitive function in CKD5D patients: a prospective clinical study
Authors: Schneider, S. M.; Malecki, A. K.; Muller, K.; Schonfeld, R.; Girndt, M.; Mohr, P.; Hiss, M.; Kielstein, H.; Jager, K.; Kielstein, J. T.
Abstract: background cognitive function decline in parallel to the decrease in glomerular filtration rate best epitomized by the markedly reduced cerebral performance in patient undergoing maintenance haemodialysis chronic kidney disease stage 5 dialysis ckd5d aside from structural permanent damage there seems to be a reversible part of low cognitive performance the potential effect of a single dialysis session on cognitive function remains still elusive the aim of the study wa to a cognitive function using a widespread test battery and avoiding excluding effect of circadian variation method twenty eight medically stable ckd5d patient age 54 9 13 2 year dialysis vintage 46 2 51 0 month at two tertiary care centre with outpatient dialysis unit were enrolled cognitive testing wa always performed twice within 24 h 1 h prior to haemodialysis t1pre dialysis a well a 19 h after the end of dialysis t2post dialysis including assessment of memory attention and concentration executive functioning word fluency and psychomotor speed by using a well validated neuropsychological test battery patient were randomized into two group one group wa examined before t1pre dialysis and after t2post dialysis dialysis session 1 the other group wa first examined the day after dialysis session 1 t2post dialysis and then before dialysis session 2 t1pre dialysis in order to exclude potential learning effect twenty age matched subject with normal excretory renal function were used for comparison result neuropsychological testing found that the ckd5d performed significantly worse on measure of alertness attention working memory logical and visual memory word fluency and executive function compared with non ckd subject no difference in short term memory selective attention a well a problem solving and planning were found between ckd5d patient and non ckd subject a single haemodialysis session led to a significant improvement in logical rivermead behaviour memory test story p 0 001 and visual memory rey osterrieth complex figure test rcft memory quotient p 0 001 psychomotor speed trail making test tmt b p 0 020 activity planning executive function rcft copy point deduction p 0 001 and concentration tmt a p 0 001 conclusion our data demonstrate improvement in memory function executive function and psychomotor ability after a single dialysis session pointing to a reversible component of low cognitive performance in ckd5d

Title: No Evidence for the Involvement of Cognitive Immunisation in Updating Beliefs About the Self in Three Non-Clinical Samples
Authors: Kube, T.; Glombiewski, J. A.
Abstract: background cognitive immunisation against disconfirmatory evidence i e devaluing expectation disconfirming information through cognitive mechanism ha recently been discussed a an obstacle to the revision of dysfunctional belief in mental disorder such a depression yet it is unclear whether cognitive immunisation is also involved in belief updating in non clinical sample method using a three group modulation protocol promotion v inhibition of cognitive immunisation v control group we examined how cognitive immunisation influence belief updating in response to performance feedback in three non clinical sample in experiment 1 n 99 and 2 n 93 participant received unexpectedly negative feedback whereas participant from experiment 3 n 118 received unexpectedly positive feedback depressive symptom and dispositional optimism were examined a additional predictor of belief updating result in all experiment participant adjusted their expectation in line with the feedback received but this effect wa not influenced by the cognitive immunisation manipulation in experiment 3 expectation change remained stable over 2 week depressive symptom were associated with a reduced integration of positive feedback but not with an increased sensitivity to negative feedback conclusion whereas previous research ha shown that cognitive immunisation contributes to persistent belief in clinical population the present finding suggest that it doe not affect belief updating in non clinical sample supplementary information the online version contains supplementary material available at 10 1007 s10608 021 10256 y

Title: Communicating the diagnosis of cancer or depression: Results of a randomized controlled online study using video vignettes
Authors: Kuhne, F.; Fauth, H.; Ay-Bryson, D. S.; Visser, L. N. C.; Weck, F.
Abstract: background communicating a diagnosis is highly important yet complex especially in the context of cancer and mental disorder the aim wa to explore the communication style of an oncologist v psychotherapist in an online study method patient n 136 65 cancer 71 depression were randomly assigned to watch a standardized video vignette with one of two communication style empathic v unempathic outcome measure of affectivity information recall communication skill empathy and trust were applied result regardless of diagnosis empathic communication wa associated with the perception of a significantly more empathic p 0 001 etapartial2 0 08 and trustworthy practitioner p 0 014 etapartial2 0 04 with better communication skill p 0 013 etapartial2 0 05 cancer patient reported a larger decrease in positive affect p 0 001 etapartial2 0 15 and a larger increase in negative affect p 0 001 etapartial2 0 14 from pre to post video than depressive patient highly relevant information wa recalled better in both group p 0 001 d 0 61 1 06 conclusion the result highlight the importance of empathy while communicating both a diagnosis of cancer and a mental disorder further research should focus on the communication of a mental disorder in association with cancer

Title: Unraveling the comorbidity of depression and anxiety in a large inpatient sample: Network analysis to examine bridge symptoms
Authors: Kaiser, T.; Herzog, P.; Voderholzer, U.; Brakemeier, E. L.
Abstract: background comorbidities in mental disorder are often understood by assuming a common cause the network theory of mental disorder offer an alternative to this assumption by understanding comorbidities a mutually reinforced problem in this study we used network analysis to examine bridge symptom between anxiety and depression in a large sample method using data from a sample of patient diagnosed with both depression and an anxiety disorder before and after inpatient treatment n 5 614 mean age 42 24 63 59 female average treatment duration 48 12 day network model of depression and anxiety symptom are estimated topology the centrality of node stability and change in network structure are analyzed symptom that drive comorbidity are determined by bridge node analysis a an alternative to network community based on categorical diagnosis we performed a community analysis and propose empirically derived symptom subset result the obtained network model are highly stable sad mood and the inability to control worry are the most central psychomotor agitation or retardation is the strongest bridge node between anxiety and depression followed by concentration problem and restlessness change in appetite and suicidality were unique to depression community analysis revealed four symptom group conclusion the estimated network structure of depression and anxiety symptom prof to be highly accurate result indicate that some symptom are considerably more influential than others and that only a small number of predominantly physical symptom are strong candidate for explaining comorbidity future study should include physiological measure in network model to provide a more accurate understanding

Title: The Relationship of Shopping-Related Decisions with Materialistic Values Endorsement, Compulsive Buying-Shopping Disorder Symptoms and Everyday Moral Decision Making
Authors: Muller, A.; Georgiadou, E.; Birlin, A.; Laskowski, N. M.; Jimenez-Murcia, S.; Fernandez-Aranda, F.; Hillemacher, T.; de Zwaan, M.; Brand, M.; Steins-Loeber, S.
Abstract: background compulsive buying shopping disorder cbsd is associated with high materialistic value endorsement and excessive purchasing of consumer good a subgroup of individual with cbsd engage in socially unacceptable behavior to continue shopping despite negative consequence this investigation aimed at exploring possible link between ego oriented shopping related decision materialism symptom of cbsd and close to everyday moral decision making method in study 1 patient with cbsd were interviewed to develop a list of conflict situation capturing typical shopping related dilemma in study 2 the shopping related dilemma from study 1 standardized close to everyday moral dilemma the material value scale and pathological buying screener were administered to a web based convenience sample n 274 result the main effect of a moderated hierarchical regression analysis revealed an association of more ego oriented shopping related decision with both higher materialistic value endorsement and more cbsd symptom but not with everyday moral decision making however a more egoistic everyday moral decision making style moderated the effect of cbsd symptom on ego oriented shopping related decision conclusion the finding indicate that a more egoistic everyday moral decision making style is not directly linked to domain specific shopping related decision making but strengthens the link between symptom of cbsd and ego oriented shopping related decision
Journal: Int J Environ Res Public Health

Title: Neural correlates of affective empathy and reinforcement learning in boys with conduct problems: fMRI evidence from a gambling task
Authors: Schwenck, C.; Ciaramidaro, A.; Selivanova, M.; Tournay, J.; Freitag, C. M.; Siniatchkin, M.
Abstract: background conduct problem cp comprise abnormal behavior associated with aberrant aspect of affective empathy a well a learning however behavioral measure for affective empathy are challenging and previous result concerning learning in patient with cp are inconsistent method nineteen boy with cp and 24 typically developing td boy aged 11 17 year m 14 34 sd 1 93 participated in the study an ultimatum game wa applied in order to elicit the feeling of like or dislike towards the opponent for a subsequent gambling task which wa played by the opponent other condition and by the participant themselves self condition functional mri data were recorded throughout the experiment result in accordance with the model of insensitivity to punishment hypo activation of the left amygdala left anterior insula ventral medial prefrontal cortex mpfc and bilateral temporo parietal junction tpj wa observed a a response to losing in participant with cp during the self condition callous unemotional cu trait correlated negatively with activation of amygdala and right tpj during the other condition td participant showed activation in brain area associated with theory of mind right tpj left ifg and affect regulation right dlpfc rather than area associated with affective empathy this pattern wa not found in adolescent with cp moreover and independently of individual characteristic of their opponent adolescent with cp demonstrated reward associated activation ventral striatum observing others win which wa positively correlated with cu trait this may be interpreted in line with the theory of reward dominance conclusion the current study provides support for the theory of abnormal learning processing in adolescent with cp which yield implication for further research a well a clinical practice the gambling task did not activate affective empathy network but wa specific for cognitive empathy inhibition and affect regulation

Title: Open-Label Placebo Effects on Psychological and Physical Well-Being: A Conceptual Replication Study
Authors: Brascher, A. K.; Ferti, I. E.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: background contrary to traditional placebo open label placebo olp abstain from deception i e participant are openly informed to receive an inert substance study in clinical and healthy sample evidence the efficacy of olps this study aim to conceptually replicate and expand finding of a recent olp study in healthy participant while implementing a within subject design and daily instead of retrospective assessment additionally the effect of a brand name on the medicine container is tested and possible predictor of the olp effect are explored method healthy participant n 75 received olp and no placebo for 5 day each randomized sequence and answered daily questionnaire on sleep quality bodily symptom mental well being and psychological distress the medicine container of half the participant had a brand name the remaining did not different personality trait and situational factor were assessed result mental and physical well being did not differ between olp and control phase i e overall no olp effect emerged contrast analysis indicated that an olp effect emerged for sleep quality and psychological distress when no brand name wa present further an olp effect emerged in person with higher expectation for bodily symptom r 23 p 046 and psychological distress r 24 p 037 conclusion methodological difference to the original study are discussed a an explanation for the failure to induce overall olp effect future study should continue to replicate previous finding and determine the exact condition of successful implementation of olp effect in healthy a well a clinical sample

Title: The 5-HTTLPR polymorphism is associated with altered hemodynamic responses during appetitive conditioning
Authors: Klucken, T.; Wehrum, S.; Schweckendiek, J.; Merz, C. J.; Hennig, J.; Vaitl, D.; Stark, R.
Abstract: background current model suggest that a variation in the promoter region of the serotonin transporter gene 5 httlpr is associated with altered amygdala reactivity not only towards negative but also towards positive stimulus which ha been neglected in the past this association may possibly convey an elevated vulnerability for psychopathology like abuse craving and relapse since appetitive conditioning is a crucial mechanism in the pathogenesis of these psychiatric disorder the identification of specific factor contributing to interindividual variation is important method in the present study n 86 an appetitive conditioning paradigm wa conducted in which a neutral stimulus c wa associated with appetitive stimulus while a second stimulus c predicted their absence subject were genotyped according to the 5 httlpr genotype result a the main result we report a significant association between the 5 httlpr genotype and hemodynamic response individual with the s allele displayed elevated conditioned bilateral amygdala activity in contrast to l l allele carrier further increased hemodynamic response in s allele carrier were also found in the extended emotional network including the orbitofrontal cortex the thalamus and the ventral striatum conclusion the present finding indicate an association of the 5 httlpr and altered conditioned response in appetitive conditioning further the finding contribute to the ongoing debate on 5 httlpr dependent hemodynamic response pattern by emphasizing that s allele carrier are not exclusively biased towards fearful but also towards positive stimulus in conclusion our result imply that s allele carrier might be better described a hyper reactive towards salient stimulus which may convey vulnerability for the development of psychiatric disorder

Title: Gender and Emotional Representation Matter: Own Illness Beliefs and Their Relationship to Obesity
Authors: Henning, C.; Schroeder, S.; Steins-Loeber, S.; Wolstein, J.
Abstract: background current treatment of obesity often fail to consider gender and psychological aspect which are essential for weight loss and weight maintenance the aim of our study wa to analyze subjective illness representation sir of adult with obesity according to the common sense self regulation model csm by assessing their association with weight related variable and gender method data wa collected via online self assessment between april 2017 and march 2018 sir were operationalized by the revised illness perception questionnaire ipq r and illness outcome according to the csm were defined a bmi eating behaviour physical wellbeing bodyweight satisfaction and shape concern the sample consisted of 427 adult m 42 2 year sd 10 9 82 female with obesity bmi m 42 3 kg m 2 sd 9 0 student s t test and multiple hierarchical regression analysis were conducted with the control variable age and bmi and subjective illness representation and gender a independent variable result the explanation of outcome variance wa moderate to high 21 43 except for restraint eating behaviour 10 subjective illness representation showed several significant association with weight related variable especially timeline and emotional representation female gender wa significantly associated with more restraint eating behaviour f 1 400 4 19 p 0 001 and female had unfavourable value of the weight related variable a well a a more cyclic t 425 3 68 p 0 001 and more emotional representation t 100 5 17 p 0 001 of their obesity conclusion the result of this study indicate that gender and subjective illness representation especially the emotional representation play an important role for weight related variable therefore the assessment of sir may constitute an economic tool to identify specific individual deficit of self regulation

Title: Defeat, entrapment, and suicidal ideation: Twelve-month trajectories
Authors: Holler, I.; Rath, D.; Teismann, T.; Glaesmer, H.; Lucht, L.; Paashaus, L.; Schonfelder, A.; Juckel, G.; Forkmann, T.
Abstract: background defeat and entrapment have been highlighted in the development of suicidal ideation within the integrated motivational volitional model of suicidal behavior research suggests that entrapment ha to be differentiated into internal and external entrapment the aim of this study wa to investigate the association between defeat internal external entrapment and suicidal ideation within and prospectively over measurement method a sample of 308 psychiatric inpatient 53 female aged 18 to 81 year m 36 92 sd 14 30 wa assessed for the four construct after admission to a psychiatric ward and six nine and twelve month later multilevel analysis were conducted to examine association result defeat wa associated with a change in internal and external entrapment defeat predicted a change in internal entrapment over time defeat and internal but not external entrapment were associated with a change in suicidal ideation internal entrapment wa able to predict suicidal ideation internal entrapment and defeat predicted a change in suicidal ideation over time conclusion result highlight the importance to distinguish between internal and external entrapment and their specific association with suicidal ideation perception of internal entrapment are of central relevance when experiencing suicidal ideation and should be considered in clinical practice

Title: Challenging control over emotions in borderline personality disorder - a tDCS study
Authors: Wolkenstein, L.; Rombold-Bruehl, F.; Bingmann, T.; Sommer, A.; Kanske, P.; Plewnia, C.
Abstract: background deficient cognitive control cc over emotional distraction is a central characteristic of borderline personality disorder bpd reduced activation of the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc ha been linked to this deficit this study investigates whether it is possible to ameliorate cc deficit via anodal tdcs over the left dlpfc in bpd furthermore we investigate whether the extent of cc impairment influence how well one responds to tdcs method the effect of a single session tdcs 1 ma for 20 min reference electrode on the contralateral mastoid bone to the left dlpfc f3 on the cc of patient with bpd n 20 and healthy control participant hcs n 20 wa examined in a double blinded balanced randomized sham controlled crossover trial a delayed response working memory task with negative neutral and positive picture presented during the delay period wa conducted to a cc stimulation wa applied simultaneously with the task result negative picture caused prolonged response time a compared to a control condition in patient with bpd and hcs anodal tdcs to the left dlpfc did not significantly reduce this interference effect in the overall sample further analysis showed however that participant with impaired cc profited the most from anodal tdcs in the subgroup of participant who actually showed an interference effect we found the expected significant amelioration of cc under tdcs conclusion the present study demonstrates that anodal tdcs applied to the left dlpfc improves deficient cc thereby base level performance moderate tdcs effect hence tdcs might be suitable to support behavioral training to enhance cc specifically in people whose impairment in cc are comparably high

Title: Amelioration of cognitive control in depression by transcranial direct current stimulation
Authors: Wolkenstein, L.; Plewnia, C.
