Abstract: background deficient cognitive control over emotional distraction is a central characteristic of major depressive disorder mdd hypoactivation of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc ha been linked with this deficit in this study we aimed to enhance the activity of the dlpfc in mdd patient by anodal transcranial direct current stimulation tdcs and thus ameliorate cognitive control method in a double blinded balanced randomized sham controlled crossover trial we determined the effect of a single session tdcs to the left dlpfc on the cognitive control in 22 mdd patient and 22 healthy control subject to a the cognitive control we used a delayed response working memory task with picture of varying content emotional v neutral presented during the delay period result emotional picture presented during the delay period impaired accuracy and response time of patient with mdd indicating an attentional bias for emotional stimulus anodal tdcs to the dlpfc wa associated with an enhanced working memory performance both in patient and control subject specifically in subject with mdd the attentional bias wa completely abolished by anodal tdcs conclusion the present study demonstrates that anodal tdcs applied to the left dlpfc improves deficient cognitive control in mdd based on these data tdcs might be suitable to support the effect of behavioral training to enhance cognitive control in mdd

Title: Pilot testing of an adaptive, individualized inhibitory control training for binge drinking: first evidence on feasibility, acceptance, and efficacy
Authors: Reichl, D.; Enewoldsen, N.; Muller, A.; Steins-Loeber, S.
Abstract: background deficit in inhibitory control seem to promote habit behavior and therefore play an important role in the development and maintenance of addictive disease although several training approach have been suggested there is a considerable lack of knowledge about the best way to improve inhibitory control based on a literature review regarding shortcoming of existing training an individualized adaptive inhibitory control training wa developed we aimed to a feasibility and acceptance of this training and to provide preliminary result on it efficacy regarding inhibitory control and binge drinking method sixty one individual 30 female with binge drinking behavior were randomly allocated to either an experimental group receiving three session of the inhibitory control training or a waitlist control group receiving no training before and after the training the participant performed a go nogo task to a inhibitory control commission error and false reaction time completed a questionnaire on drinking related self control and reported drinking behavior result although the training wa feasible and accepted by participant it did not affect self control over drinking inhibitory control or drinking behavior the relationship between session number and false reaction time wa linear for alcohol stimulus but squared for neutral stimulus conclusion although our finding have to be interpreted in the light of some shortcoming they demonstrate that further research is needed to enhance our understanding of how to improve inhibitory control and which factor might moderate this process

Title: Depression and suicidal ideation in high-performance athletes suffering from low back pain: The role of stress and pain-related thought suppression
Authors: Konietzny, K.; Chehadi, O.; Levenig, C.; Kellmann, M.; Kleinert, J.; Mierswa, T.; Hasenbring, M. I.
Abstract: background depression and suicidal ideation are important health problem in athlete suffering from pain dysfunctional pain cognition that is pain related thought suppression pt may play an important role in their aetiology thought suppression wa shown to increase depressive mood particularly in highly stressed individual this cross sectional study examines the relationship between pt and stress on depression and suicidal ideation in athlete with pain method a total of 159 athlete with non specific low back pain completed a set of questionnaire to measure pt depression and stress participant were split into group with high and low stress and high and low pt two way anova calculated main effect for pt stress and a pt stress interaction with depressive symptom a dependent subsequently distribution test were calculated investigating if the presence of clinically relevant depression and suicidal ideation is dependent of condition of high low pt and stress result a main effect of stress demonstrated higher depression score in highly stressed athlete further a significant pt stress interaction showed elevated depression score in athlete with high pt and high stress distribution analysis revealed positive association between pt stress and depression with depression being most frequent among athlete with high pt and high stress suicidal ideation wa not significantly associated with pt and only weakly correlated with stress conclusion our finding show that pt is the most common pain response in athlete with pain the result indicate a higher prevalence of depression and elevated depressive symptom in athlete experiencing high stress seemingly more pronounced when highly engaging in pt significance this study contributes to the understanding of depression in athlete with pain suggesting stress and pain related thought suppression to increase symptom and prevalence of depression a athlete often experience acute or chronic pain understanding the impact of pain cognition on health outcome is an important step in the optimization of treatment

Title: Clinical correlates of sex hormones in women: The study of health in Pomerania
Authors: Kische, H.; Gross, S.; Wallaschofski, H.; Volzke, H.; Dorr, M.; Nauck, M.; Haring, R.
Abstract: background despite association of sex hormone in woman with increased cardiometabolic risk and mortality the clinical correlate of altered sex hormone concentration in woman are le clearly understood we investigated a broad range of clinical correlate of sex hormone in woman from a large population based sample method data from 2560 woman from two cohort of the study of health in pomerania were used stepwise multivariable regression model were implemented to investigate a broad range of behavioral socio demographic and cardiometabolic clinical correlate related to total testosterone tt free testosterone ft androstenedione asd dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate dheas estrone e1 estradiol e2 and sex hormone binding globulin shbg result waist circumference and bmi beta coefficient 0 03 95 ci 0 04 0 03 were inversely related to shbg and bmi wa positively related to tt beta coefficient 0 005 95 ci 0 001 0 009 ft e1 and e2 smoking wa positively related to tt beta coefficient 0 04 95 ci 0 01 0 06 asd and ft systolic blood pressure tt beta coefficient 0 002 95 ci 0 001 0 003 hypertension tt beta coefficient 0 05 95 ci 0 003 0 11 low density lipoprotein ldl cholesterol tt beta coefficient 0 02 95 ci 0 01 0 05 and total cholesterol tt beta coefficient 0 03 95 ci 0 01 0 05 were positively related to tt and asd finally type 2 diabetes mellitus t2dm and metabolic syndrome mets were positively related to ft but inversely related to shbg conclusion our population based study with sex hormone concentration measured by liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry revealed association between clinical correlate including waist circumference smoking cohabitation systolic blood pressure cholesterol and mets with sex hormone thus sex hormone and shbg may play a role in the cardiovascular risk profile of woman

Title: Recognizing obsessive-compulsive disorder: how suitable is the German Zohar-Fineberg obsessive-compulsive screen?
Authors: Kuhne, F.; Paunov, T.; Weck, F.
Abstract: background despite the prevalence of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd it precise identification remains challenging with the zohar fineberg obsessive compulsive screen zf ocs 5 or 6 item a brief instrument is widely available mainly in english a there is a lack of empirical study on the zf ocs the aim of the present study wa to translate the item into german and investigate the instrument in a nonclinical sample method in two consecutive online survey n 304 and n 51 student participated besides the zf ocs they answered established measure on ocd depression health anxiety general anxiety and health related well being result whereas internal consistency wa low alpha 53 72 omega 55 69 retest reliability r t1 t2 89 at two week wa high a expected we found high correlation with other ocd instrument r 61 convergent validity and significantly weaker correlation with measure of depression r 39 health anxiety r 29 and health related well being r 28 divergent validity nonetheless the correlation with general anxiety were somewhere in between r 52 conclusion due to heterogeneous ocd subtypes the zf ocs asks diverse question which probably resulted in the present internal consistency nevertheless the result on retest reliability and validity were promising a for other ocd instrument divergent validity regarding general anxiety seems problematic to establish even so the zf ocs seems valuable for screening purpose a it is short and easy to administer and may facilitate initiating subsequent clinical assessment further study should determine the instrument s diagnostic accuracy

Title: Gray matter abnormalities in patients with narcissistic personality disorder
Authors: Schulze, L.; Dziobek, I.; Vater, A.; Heekeren, H. R.; Bajbouj, M.; Renneberg, B.; Heuser, I.; Roepke, S.
Abstract: background despite the relevance of narcissistic personality disorder npd in clinical setting there is currently no empirical data available regarding the neurobiological correlate of npd in the present study we performed a voxel based morphometric analysis to provide initial insight into local abnormality of gray matter gm volume method structural brain image were obtained from patient with npd n 17 and a sample of healthy control n 17 matched regarding age gender handedness and intelligence group were compared with regard to global brain tissue volume and local abnormality of gm volume region of interest analysis were calculated for the anterior insula result relative to the control group npd patient had smaller gm volume in the left anterior insula independent of group gm volume in the left anterior insula wa positively related to self reported emotional empathy complementary whole brain analysis yielded smaller gm volume in fronto paralimbic brain region comprising the rostral and median cingulate cortex a well a dorsolateral and medial part of the prefrontal cortex conclusion here we provide the first empirical evidence for structural abnormality in fronto paralimbic brain region of patient with npd the result are discussed in the context of npd patient restricted ability for emotional empathy

Title: Dialectical behaviour therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder related to childhood sexual abuse: a pilot study in an outpatient treatment setting
Authors: Steil, R.; Dittmann, C.; Muller-Engelmann, M.; Dyer, A.; Maasch, A. M.; Priebe, K.
Abstract: background dialectical behaviour therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder dbt ptsd which is tailored to treat adult with ptsd and co occurring emotion regulation difficulty ha already demonstrated it efficacy acceptance and safety in an inpatient treatment setting it combine element of dbt with trauma focused cognitive behavioural intervention objective to investigate the feasibility acceptance and safety of dbt ptsd in an outpatient treatment setting by therapist who were novice to the treatment we treated 21 female patient suffering from ptsd following childhood sexual abuse csa plus difficulty in emotion regulation in an uncontrolled clinical trial method the clinician administered ptsd symptom scale cap the davidson trauma scale dts the borderline section of the international personality disorder examination ipde and the borderline symptom list bsl 23 were used a primary outcome for secondary outcome depression and dissociation were assessed assessment were administered at pretreatment post treatment and six week follow up result improvement wa significant for ptsd a well a for borderline personality symptomatology with large pretreatment to follow up effect size for completers based on the cap cohens d 1 30 dts d 1 50 ipde d 1 60 and bsl 23 d 1 20 conclusion the outcome suggests that outpatient dbt ptsd can safely be used to reduce ptsd symptom and comorbid psychopathology in adult who have experienced csa

Title: Peer Victimization Influences Attention Processing Beyond the Effects of Childhood Maltreatment by Caregivers
Authors: Iffland, B.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: background different type of maltreatment emotional physical and sexual lead to distortion in emotion and attention processing the present study investigated whether the experience of peer victimization in childhood and adolescence ha an additional influence on attention processing in adulthood method two non clinical sample consisting of individual with different level of experience of maltreatment were recruited in an evaluative conditioning task image of face with neutral emotional expression were either associated with short video of intense negative statement or associated with neutral video subsequently these face were used a stimulus in an emotional stroop task a well a a dot probe task result in both task hierarchical regression analysis revealed that retrospective report of relational peer victimization made an incremental contribution to the prediction of attentional bias beyond child maltreatment in the emotional stroop task emotional abuse wa the strongest predictor for an attentional bias showing delayed response to negatively associated face while peer victimization wa associated with faster response to negatively associated face in the dot probe task relational peer victimization wa the strongest predictor for an attentional bias when the attentional bias wa examined in more detail though peer victimization did not show incremental contribution although emotional abuse remained the strongest predictor for facilitated attention toward negatively associated neutral face conclusion experience of peer victimization leave additional cognitive scar beyond effect of childhood maltreatment by caregiver it is likely that attentional bias in the aftermath of victimization put individual at risk for the development of psychopathology

Title: Aberrant adapting of beliefs under stress: a mechanism relevant to the formation of paranoia?
Authors: Krkovic, K.; Nowak, U.; Kammerer, M. K.; Bott, A.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: background difficulty in the ability to adapt belief in the face of new information are associated with psychosis and it central symptom paranoia a cognitive process and psychotic symptom are both known to be sensitive to stress the present study investigated the exact association between stress adapting of belief reversal learning rl bias against disconfirmatory evidence bade and jumping to conclusion jtc and paranoia we hypothesized that paranoia would increase under stress and that difficulty in adapting of belief would mediate or moderate the link between stress and paranoia furthermore we hypothesized that the investigated effect would be strongest in the group of individual diagnosed with a psychotic disorder method we exposed 155 participant 38 diagnosed with a psychotic disorder 40 individual with attenuated psychotic symptom 39 clinical control diagnosed with an obsessive compulsive disorder and 38 healthy control to a control condition and a stress condition in which we assessed their level of paranoia and their ability to adapt belief we applied multilevel model to analyze the data result paranoia wa higher in the stress condition than in the control condition b 1 142 s e 0 338 t 150 3 381 p 0 001 rl bade and jtc did not differ between condition and did not mediate or moderate the association between stress and paranoia all p 0 05 conclusion the result support the assumption that stress trigger paranoia however the link between stress and paranoia doe not seem to be affected by the ability to adapt belief

Title: Genetics of preparation and response control in ADHD: the role of DRD4 and DAT1
Authors: Albrecht, B.; Brandeis, D.; Uebel-von Sandersleben, H.; Valko, L.; Heinrich, H.; Xu, X.; Drechsler, R.; Heise, A.; Kuntsi, J.; Muller, U. C.; Asherson, P.; Steinhausen, H. C.; Rothenberger, A.; Banaschewski, T.
Abstract: background difficulty with performance and brain activity related to attentional orienting cue p3 cognitive or response preparation cue cnv and inhibitory response control nogo p3 during task tapping executive function are familial in adhd and may represent endophenotypes the aim of this study wa to clarify the impact of dopamine receptor d4 drd4 and dopamine transporter dat1 gene polymorphism on these process in adhd and control child method behavioural and electrophysiological parameter from cued continuous performance test with low and high attentional load were assessed in boy with adhd combined type n 94 and control without family history of adhd n 31 both group were split for the presence of at least one drd4 7 repeat allele and the dat1 10 6 haplotype result child with adhd showed diminished performance and lower cue p3 cnv and nogo p3 amplitude child with drd4 7r showed similar performance problem and lower cue p3 and cnv but nogo p3 wa not reduced child with the dat1 10 6 haplotype had no difficulty with performance or cue p3 and cnv but contrary to expectation increased nogo p3 there were no genotype by adhd interaction conclusion this study detected specific effect of drd4 7r on performance and brain activity related to attentional orienting and response preparation while dat1 10 6 wa associated with elevated brain activity related to inhibitory response control which potentially compensates increased impulsivity a these genotype effect were additive to the impact of adhd the current result indicate that drd4 and dat1 polymorphism are functionally relevant risk factor for adhd and presumably other disorder sharing these endophenotypes

Title: Out of sight, out of mind? High discrepancy between observer- and patient-reported outcome after routine inpatient treatment for depression
Authors: Kaiser, T.; Herzog, P.; Voderholzer, U.; Brakemeier, E. L.
Abstract: background divergent outcome of treatment for depression occur regularly but often go undetected by clinical judgment alone to date no comprehensive study are available on what the detection rate of divergent outcome is in routine care method we analyzed a large n 20 882 database of clinician rated and patient reported outcome from routine inpatient treatment for depression result there wa little agreement 57 7 on the gaf 7 8 on the cgi i between clinician rating and patient not showing clinically significant change there wa virtually no agreement 0 6 on the gaf 2 on the cgi i between clinician rating and self report scale in deteriorated patient multiple regression showed that clinician rating of change were influenced primarily by symptom severity at discharge rather than change from admission limitation only symptom scale were available a patient reported outcome although clinician rating may be based on other source of information in addition no information wa available on clinician experience with the rating scale used nor is it clear how carefully the rating were made discussion it can be concluded that failure to achieve treatment success and worsening after routine treatment for depression often go undetected on clinical rating scale suggesting that such case frequently remain undetected clinician should generally obtain patient reported outcome during treatment to detect these case

Title: Psychological distress, exhaustion, and work-related correlates among interpreters working in refugee care: results of a nationwide online survey in Germany
Authors: Geiling, A.; Knaevelsrud, C.; Bottche, M.; Stammel, N.
Abstract: background due to language barrier interpreter are crucial for refugee care in the country of resettlement however interpreter are often faced with distressing working condition such a precarious work circumstance lack of supervision or exposure to their client traumatic experience recent study examining interpreter mental health focussed primarily on secondary traumatic stress the present study aimed to gain a better understanding of psychological distress and exhaustion among interpreter in refugee care by examining these factor in the work context a well a their possible work related correlate method an online survey wa carried out in germany which included several standardized questionnaire regarding distress work and client related exhaustion job satisfaction and trauma exposure bsi 18 cbi j htq pcl 5 interpreter were recruited primarily through psychosocial treatment centre and interpreter pool in germany result in total 164 interpreter were included in the analysis the participant showed increased psychological distress and around 7 screened positive for posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd in an exploratory regression analysis younger age beta 25 p 004 emerged a correlate of psychological distress whereas dissatisfaction with payment beta 21 p 04 and a higher amount of traumatic content beta 22 p 001 were associated with work related exhaustion and dissatisfaction with recognition wa associated with client related exhaustion beta 35 p 001 conclusion the result point to increased stress level among interpreter for refugee moreover they indicate that interpreter distress is primarily correlated with work related circumstance thus suggesting the need for a greater work related support structure for interpreter

Title: Prolonged grief disorder three decades post loss in survivors of the Khmer Rouge regime in Cambodia
Authors: Stammel, N.; Heeke, C.; Bockers, E.; Chhim, S.; Taing, S.; Wagner, B.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: background during the khmer rouge kr regime from 1975 to 1979 million of cambodian were confronted with the death or murder of family member the long term psychological consequence of these traumatic loss have not yet been investigated the purpose of this study wa to determine the rate and potential predictor of prolonged grief disorder pgd in survivor of the kr regime method the inventory of complicated grief revised icg r wa administered in a sample of n 775 cambodian in face to face interview who had lost at least one family member during the kr regime symptom of ptsd were assessed with the ptsd checklist civilian version and symptom of depression and anxiety with the hopkins symptom checklist 25 result the prevalence of pgd in the sample wa 14 3 pgd wa moderately associated with symptom of depression anxiety and ptsd the loss of a spouse a child or a parent wa associated with higher symptom severity of pgd than wa the loss of a sibling or distant relative pgd wa predicted by the relationship to the deceased and symptom of depression and ptsd limitation limitation of the study include the non random sampling recruitment the icg r ha not been validated for use in cambodia conclusion the vast majority of cambodian lost family member during the kr regime even three decade later pgd wa prevalent in a substantial proportion of the present sample and related to other psychiatric disorder the result underline the importance of examining pgd in study of war related psychological impairment

Title: Association Between Prolonged Grief and Attitudes Toward Reconciliation in Bereaved Survivors of the Khmer Rouge Regime in Cambodia
Authors: Stammel, N.; Heinzl, L.; Heeke, C.; Bottche, M.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: background during the khmer rouge regime in cambodia about a quarter of the population died resulting in many individual losing close relative still today many individual are suffering from the psychological consequence of these loss which might also affect the process of reconciliation within the cambodian society the aim of this paper is therefore to investigate the association between symptom of prolonged grief and attitude toward reconciliation method a sample of 775 survivor of the khmer rouge regime who lost relative during the conflict were interviewed about their loss and traumatic event prolonged grief pg complicated grief assessment self report cga sr posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd checklist civilian version and attitude toward reconciliation readiness to reconcile inventory rri result a higher symptom severity of pg wa significantly associated with readiness to reconcile even when controlling for other relevant variable beta 0 22 p 001 person who met caseness criterion for pg were significantly le ready to reconcile t 773 5 47 p 001 than person who did not meet caseness for pg conclusion pg seems to be a relevant mental health correlate of attitude toward reconciliation the result of the current study underline the importance of also considering pg with regard to the reconciliation process in cambodia and possibly also in other post conflict region

Title: Response to unexpected social inclusion: A study using the cyberball paradigm
Authors: Groth, R. M.; Rief, W.
Abstract: background dysfunctional expectation are considered core characteristic of major depressive disorder mdd and should be focused in psychotherapy dysfunctional expectation are especially pronounced in the interpersonal area social expectation in the present study we examine the effect of unexpected social inclusion expectation violation on the change of generalized and specific depression typical social expectation method we conducted an online study to investigate the impact of social inclusion after a period of social exclusion unexpected social inclusion on social expectation change sample size 144 in a non clinical sample depressive symptom were assessed via self reporting participant took part in two round of the online ball game cyberball in the first round all participant were socially excluded by their two co player acquisition of negative social expectation in the second round participant were either once more excluded expectation confirmation or included equally expectation violation by the same co player specific and generalized social expectation were assessed after each round result specific and generalized social expectation increased following expectation violation even though depressive symptom were related to lower level of social expectation we found that depressive symptom did not moderate expectation change after positive expectation violation conclusion in the present experimental setup including the use of the online ball game cyberball the establishment and change of social expectation can be experimentally manipulated under the given circumstance and in a non clinical sample negative expectation can be updated after unexpected positive experience regardless of the number of depressive symptom the result are discussed in the context of current model of major depressive disorder mdd expectation change and cognitive behavioral therapy

Title: Integrating situation-specific dysfunctional expectations and dispositional optimism into the cognitive model of depression - A path-analytic approach
Authors: Kube, T.; Siebers, V. H. A.; Herzog, P.; Glombiewski, J. A.; Doering, B. K.; Rief, W.
Abstract: background dysfunctional expectation are considered to be core feature of mental disorder and in particular major depression the aim of the present study wa to integrate two important type of expectation into the cognitive model of depression situation specific dysfunctional expectation sde and dispositional optimism do it wa hypothesized that the influence of both do and intermediate belief ib on depressive symptom would be mediated via sde method we examined 95 individual age m 40 7 68 1 female with a diagnosed major depressive disorder from two inpatient clinic and one outpatient clinic measurement used in the study included the depressive expectation scale dysfunctional attitude scale life orientation test revised and beck s depression inventory ii relationship between the construct were analyzed using path analytic model with bias corrected bootstrapping confidence interval result result indicate that the effect of ib on depressive symptom wa fully mediated via sde while the effect of do on depressive symptom wa partly mediated via sde ib and do moderately correlated with each other limitation due to the cross sectional design of the study it is not possible to draw unambiguous conclusion regarding the causality of the suggested relationship conclusion the present study stress the crucial role of dysfunctional expectation for major depression moreover it reveals that sdes a expectation with a high level of situational specificity may pose an important link between global cognition and depressive symptom given this situational specificity sdes are amenable to disconfirmation through behavioral experiment and may therefore be a promising target for cognitive behavioral intervention

Title: Early posttraumatic autonomic and endocrine markers to predict posttraumatic stress symptoms after a preventive intervention with oxytocin
Authors: Engel, S.; van Zuiden, M.; Frijling, J. L.; Koch, S. B. J.; Nawijn, L.; Yildiz, R. L. W.; Schumacher, S.; Knaevelsrud, C.; Bosch, J. A.; Veltman, D. J.; Olff, M.
Abstract: background efficient prevention of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd need to target individual with an increased risk for adverse outcome after trauma prognostic or prescriptive biological marker assessed early posttrauma may inform personalized treatment recommendation objective to test prognostic and prescriptive effect of early posttraumatic autonomic and endocrine marker on ptsd symptom development method autonomic and endocrine marker were assessed within 12 day posttrauma and before treatment initiation within a randomized placebo controlled trial investigating repeated oxytocin administration a preventive intervention for ptsd linear mixed effect model were used to test the effect of heart rate variability resting cortisol morning cortisol and cortisol awakening response car cortisol suppression by dexamethasone and resting oxytocin on ptsd symptom 1 5 3 and 6 month posttrauma in men n 54 woman using hormonal contraception n 27 and cycling woman n 19 result we found significant prognostic effect of resting oxytocin and cortisol suppression in woman using hormonal contraception higher oxytocin wa associated with higher ptsd symptom across follow up stronger cortisol suppression by dexamethasone reflecting increased glucocorticoid receptor feedback sensitivity wa associated with lower ptsd symptom across follow up in men but with higher symptom at 1 5 month in woman using hormonal contraception these effect were independent of treatment condition no further significant prognostic or prescriptive effect were detected conclusion our exploratory study indicates that resting oxytocin and glucocorticoid receptor feedback sensitivity early posttrauma are associated with subsequent ptsd symptom severity notably prognostic effect depended on sex and hormonal contraception use emphasizing the necessity to consider these factor in biomedical ptsd research

Title: Effects of electroconvulsive therapy on amygdala function in major depression - a longitudinal functional magnetic resonance imaging study
Authors: Redlich, R.; Burger, C.; Dohm, K.; Grotegerd, D.; Opel, N.; Zaremba, D.; Meinert, S.; Forster, K.; Repple, J.; Schnelle, R.; Wagenknecht, C.; Zavorotnyy, M.; Heindel, W.; Kugel, H.; Gerbaulet, M.; Alferink, J.; Arolt, V.; Zwanzger, P.; Dannlowski, U.
Abstract: background electroconvulsive therapy ect is one of the most effective treatment for severe depression however little is known regarding brain functional process mediating ect effect method in a non randomized prospective study functional magnetic resonance imaging data during the automatic processing of subliminally presented emotional face were obtained twice about 6 week apart in patient with major depressive disorder mdd before and after treatment with ect ect n 24 additionally a control sample of mdd patient treated solely with pharmacotherapy med n 23 and a healthy control sample hc n 22 were obtained result before therapy both patient group equally showed elevated amygdala reactivity to sad face compared with hc after treatment a decrease in amygdala activity to negative stimulus wa discerned in both patient sample indicating a normalization of amygdala function suggesting mechanism potentially unspecific for ect moreover a decrease in amygdala activity to sad face wa associated with symptomatic improvement in the ect sample r spearman 0 48 p 0 044 and by tendency also for the med sample r spearman 0 38 p 0 098 however we did not find any significant association between pre treatment amygdala function to emotional stimulus and individual symptom improvement neither for the ect sample nor for the med sample conclusion in sum the present study provides first result regarding functional change in emotion processing due to ect treatment using a longitudinal design thus validating and extending our knowledge gained from previous treatment study a limitation wa that ect patient received concurrent medication treatment

Title: Looking at food in sad mood: do attention biases lead emotional eaters into overeating after a negative mood induction?
Authors: Werthmann, J.; Renner, F.; Roefs, A.; Huibers, M. J.; Plumanns, L.; Krott, N.; Jansen, A.
Abstract: background emotional eating is associated with overeating and the development of obesity yet empirical evidence for individual trait difference in emotional eating and cognitive mechanism that contribute to eating during sad mood remain equivocal aim the aim of this study wa to test if attention bias for food moderate the effect of self reported emotional eating during sad mood v neutral mood on actual food intake it wa expected that emotional eating is predictive of elevated attention for food and higher food intake after an experimentally induced sad mood and that attentional maintenance on food predicts food intake during a sad versus a neutral mood method participant n 85 were randomly assigned to one of the two experimental mood induction condition sad neutral attentional bias for high caloric food were measured by eye tracking during a visual probe task with pictorial food and neutral stimulus self reported emotional eating wa assessed with the dutch eating behavior questionnaire debq and ad libitum food intake wa tested by a disguised food offer result hierarchical multivariate regression modeling showed that self reported emotional eating did not account for change in attention allocation for food or food intake in either condition yet attention maintenance on food cue wa significantly related to increased intake specifically in the neutral condition but not in the sad mood condition discussion the current finding show that self reported emotional eating based on the debq might not validly predict who overeats when sad at least not in a laboratory setting with healthy woman result further suggest that attention maintenance on food relates to eating motivation when in a neutral affective state and might therefore be a cognitive mechanism contributing to increased food intake in general but maybe not during sad mood

Title: Validation and application of the Non-Verbal Behavior Analyzer: An automated tool to assess non-verbal emotional expressions in psychotherapy
Authors: Terhurne, P.; Schwartz, B.; Baur, T.; Schiller, D.; Eberhardt, S. T.; Andre, E.; Lutz, W.
Abstract: background emotion play a key role in psychotherapy however a problem with examining emotional state via self report questionnaire is that the assessment usually take place after the actual emotion ha been experienced which might lead to bias and continuous human rating are time and cost intensive using the ai based software package non verbal behavior analyzer nova video based emotion recognition of arousal and valence can be applied in naturalistic psychotherapeutic setting in this study four emotion recognition model erm each based on specific feature set facial openface openface aureg body openpose activation openpose energy were developed and compared in their ability to predict arousal and valence score correlated to panas emotion score and process of change interpersonal experience coping experience affective experience a well a symptom depression and anxiety in hscl 11 material and method a total of 183 patient therapy video were divided into a training sample 55 patient a test sample 50 patient and a holdout sample 78 patient the best erm wa selected for further analysis then erm based arousal and valence score were correlated with patient and therapist estimate of emotion and process of change furthermore using regression model arousal and valence were examined a predictor of symptom severity in depression and anxiety result the erm based on openface produced the best agreement to the human coder rating arousal and valence correlated significantly with therapist rating of sadness shame anxiety and relaxation but not with the patient rating of their own emotion furthermore a significant negative correlation indicates that negative valence wa associated with higher affective experience negative valence wa found to significantly predict higher anxiety but not depression score conclusion this study show that emotion recognition with nova can be used to generate erms associated with patient emotion affective experience and symptom nevertheless limitation were obvious it seems necessary to improve the erms using larger database of session and the validity of erms need to be further investigated in different sample and different application furthermore future research should take erms to identify emotional synchrony between patient and therapist into account

Title: Look at the Audience? A Randomized Controlled Study of Shifting Attention From Self-Focus to Nonsocial vs. Social External Stimuli During Virtual Reality Exposure to Public Speaking in Social Anxiety
Authors: Wechsler, T. F.; Pfaller, M.; van Eickels, R. E.; Schulz, L. H.; Muhlberger, A.
Abstract: background enhanced self focused attention play a central role in the maintenance and treatment of social anxiety and is targeted in contemporary cognitive behavioral therapy actual development use virtual reality vr for behavioral training however no vr attention training combining exposure to public speaking with shifting attention from self focus to external focus ha been investigated and no experimental evidence exists on different kind of external cue a target of attention therefore we investigated the effect of an attention training during public speaking in vr and examined differential effect of an external focus on nonsocial v social stimulus method in this randomized controlled study highly socially anxious participant were instructed to focus on either object or the audience within a virtual speech task we assessed the pre post effect on affective reaction self perception and attentional process during public speaking a well a general social anxiety using subjective physiological and eye tracking measure repeated measure analysis of variance anova were calculated to detect change from pretest to posttest over both group and time x group interaction effect result within the analysis sample n 41 anxiety during public speaking and fear of negative evaluation significantly decreased with no significant difference between group no significant time effect but a significant time x group effect wa found for the looking time proportion on the audience member head follow up test confirmed a significant increase in the social focus group and a significant decrease in the nonsocial focus group for all other variable except external focus and fear of public speaking significant improvement were found over both group further significant time x group effect were found for positive affect during public speaking with a significant increase in the social focus and no significant change in the nonsocial focus group conclusion our finding suggest that attention training to reduce self focus can be successfully conducted in vr both training version showed positive short term effect in the highly socially anxious with particular advantage of an external social focus concerning eye contact to the audience and positive affect further research should investigate whether social focus is even more advantageous long term and if reinterpretation of dysfunctional belief could be achieved by not avoiding social cue

Title: Benefits of Individualized Feedback in Internet-Based Interventions for Depression: A Randomized Controlled Trial
Authors: Zagorscak, P.; Heinrich, M.; Sommer, D.; Wagner, B.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: background even though there is an increasing number of study on the efficacy of internet based intervention ibi for depression experimental trial on the benefit of added guidance by clinician are scarce and inconsistent this study compared the efficacy of semistandardized feedback provided by psychologist with fully standardized feedback in ibi method participant with mild to moderate depression n 1 089 66 female from the client pool of a health insurance company participated in a cognitive behavioral ibi targeting depression over 6 week individual were randomized to weekly semistandardized e mail feedback from psychologist individual counseling ic or to automated standardized feedback where a psychologist could be contacted on demand cod the content and task were identical across condition the primary outcome wa depression secondary outcome included anxiety rumination and well being outcome were assessed before and after the intervention and 3 6 and 12 month later change in outcome were evaluated using latent change score modeling result both intervention yielded large pre post effect on depression beck depression inventory ii dic 1 53 dcod 1 37 patient health questionnaire 9 dic 1 20 dcod 1 04 a well a significant improvement of all other outcome measure the effect remained significant after 3 6 and 12 month the group differed with regard to attrition ic 17 3 cod 25 8 p 0 001 between group effect were statistically nonsignificant across outcome and measurement occasion conclusion adding semistandardized guidance in ibi for depression did not prove to be more effective than fully standardized feedback on primary and secondary outcome but it had positive effect on attrition

Title: Do lifetime anxiety disorders (anxiety liability) and pregnancy-related anxiety predict complications during pregnancy and delivery?
Authors: Hoyer, J.; Wieder, G.; Hofler, M.; Krause, L.; Wittchen, H. U.; Martini, J.
Abstract: background evidence suggests that maternal anxiety is associated with adverse pregnancy and delivery outcome such a preterm birth vaginal bleeding and low birth weight aim to examine the association of lifetime anxiety disorder and pregnancy related anxiety and complication during pregnancy and delivery study design prospective longitudinal study mari subject n 306 pregnant woman who were investigated repeatedly during the peripartum period outcome measure information on lifetime anxiety disorder wa assessed using a dimensional score lifetime anxiety liability index based on the standardized composite international diagnostic interview for woman cidi v pregnancy related anxiety wa surveyed with the pregnancy and childbirth related fear pcf questionnaire common pregnancy e g vaginal bleeding and delivery complication e g labor induction were assessed via medical record interview and questionnaire result the global test on the association between lifetime anxiety liability and pregnancy complication and on the association between pregnancy related anxiety and pregnancy delivery complication revealed significant association further analysis revealed association of lifetime anxiety liability with preterm labor or 1 6 95 ci 1 2 2 0 a well a pregnancy related anxiety with vaginal bleeding or 1 4 95 ci 1 0 1 8 preterm labor or 1 3 95 ci 1 0 1 7 gestational diabetes or 0 5 95 ci 0 2 0 9 labor induction or 1 5 95 ci 1 1 1 9 and use of labor medication or 1 6 95 ci 1 2 2 0 after adjustment for maternal age maternal body mass index maternal smoking socioeconomic status occupation household income and social support cohabitation the association between pregnancy related anxiety and labor induction a well a use of labor medication remained significant conclusion pregnancy related anxiety should be regularly assessed and if necessary treated during early pregnancy to minimize risk for complication during delivery

Title: Transdiagnostic efficacy of a group exercise intervention for outpatients with heterogenous psychiatric disorders: a randomized controlled trial
Authors: Zeibig, J. M.; Seiffer, B.; Sudeck, G.; Rosel, I.; Hautzinger, M.; Wolf, S.
Abstract: background exercise efficaciously reduces disorder specific symptom of psychiatric disorder the current study aimed to examine the efficacy of a group exercise intervention on global symptom severity and disorder specific symptom among a mixed outpatient sample method group of inactive outpatient waiting for psychotherapy with depressive disorder anxiety disorder insomnia and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder were randomized to a manualized 12 week exercise intervention combining moderate to vigorous aerobic exercise with technique for sustainable exercise behaviour change n 38 female 71 1 n 27 m age 36 66 or a passive control group n 36 female 75 0 n 27 m age 34 33 primary outcome were global symptom severity and disorder specific symptom measured with the symptom checklist 90 revised and pittsburgh sleep quality index pre and post treatment secondary outcome wa the self reported amount of exercise physical activity exercise and sport questionnaire measured pre treatment intermediate and post treatment intention to treat analysis were conducted using linear mixed model linear regression were conducted to examine the effect of the change of exercise behaviour on the change of symptom result the intervention significantly improved global symptom severity d 0 77 p 007 depression d 0 68 p 015 anxiety d 0 87 p 002 sleep quality d 0 88 p 001 and increased the amount of exercise d 0 82 p 001 compared to the control group post treatment difference between group were significant for depression d 0 63 p 031 sleep quality d 0 61 p 035 and the amount of exercise d 1 45 p 001 across both group the reduction of global symptom severity wa significantly predicted by an increase of exercise b 35 p 012 conclusion the exercise intervention showed transdiagnostic efficacy among a heterogeneous clinical sample in a realistic outpatient setting and led to sustained exercise behaviour change exercise may serve a an efficacious and feasible transdiagnostic treatment option improving the existing treatment gap within outpatient mental health care setting trial registration the study wa registered on clinicaltrials gov id nct03542396 25 04 2018

Title: How expectancy violations facilitate learning to cope with pain - An experimental approach
Authors: Kube, T.; Korfer, K.; Riecke, J.; Glombiewski, J. A.
Abstract: background expectation of painful sensation constitute a core feature of chronic pain an important clinical question is whether such expectation are revised when disconfirming experience are made e g le pain than expected this study examined how people adjust their pain expectation when the experience of decreasing pain is expected v unexpected method in a novel randomized between subject design a subclinical sample of people who frequently experience pain wa provided with painful thermal stimulation unbeknownst to participant the temperature applied wa decreased from trial to trial based on the experimental instruction provided this experience of decreasing pain wa expected in one condition expectation confirmation n 34 whereas it wa unexpected in another expectation disconfirmation n 39 result perceived pain intensity wa lower in the expectation confirmation condition than in the expectation disconfirmation condition p 014 eta p 2 0 083 the expectation confirmation condition also showed a greater adjustment of their pain expectation than the expectation disconfirmation condition p 046 eta p 2 0 047 across group large expectation violation i e le pain than expected were associated with increase in pain tolerance and the ability to cope with pain at a one week follow up conclusion in term of assimilation perceived pain intensity wa shaped in the direction of pain expectation the greater adjustment of expectation in the expectation confirming condition is consistent with a confirmation bias in pain perception though participant who experienced large discrepancy between expected and experienced pain were hesitant to adjust their pain expectation immediately expectation violation increased their ability to cope with pain one week later suggesting some beneficial longer term effect of expectation violation

Title: Mechanisms of exposure and response prevention in obsessive-compulsive disorder: effects of habituation and expectancy violation on short-term outcome in cognitive behavioral therapy
Authors: Elsner, B.; Jacobi, T.; Kischkel, E.; Schulze, D.; Reuter, B.
Abstract: background exposure and response prevention is effective and recommended a the first choice for treating obsessive compulsive disorder ocd it mechanism of action are rarely studied but two major theory make distinct assumption while the emotional processing theory assumes that treatment effect are associated with habituation within and between exposure session the inhibitory learning approach highlight the acquisition of additional association implying alternative mechanism like expectancy violation the present study aimed to investigate whether process variable derived from both theory predict short term outcome method in a university outpatient unit 110 patient 63 female with ocd received manual based cognitive behavioral therapy with high standardization of the first two exposure session specifically therapist repeated the first exposure session identically and assessed subjective unit of distress a well a expectancy rating in the course of exposure session based on these data individual score for habituation and distress related expectancy violation were calculated and used for prediction of both percentage change on the yale brown obsessive compulsive scale y bocs and remission status after 20 therapy session result in a multiple regression model for percentage change within session habituation during the first exposure wa a significant predictor while in a logistic regression predicting remission status distress related expectancy violation during the first exposure revealed significance a path model further supported these finding conclusion the result represent first evidence for distress related expectancy violation and confirm preliminary finding for habituation suggesting that both process contribute to treatment benefit of exposure in ocd and both mechanism appear to be independent

Title: How am I doing compared to different standards? Comparative thinking and well-being following exposure to a vehicle-ramming attack
Authors: Morina, N.
Abstract: background exposure to potentially adverse event might intensify thinking about different comparison standard in relation to one s own well being objective to examine how frequently survivor of a recent potentially traumatic event use different comparison standard to evaluate their current well being method a survey with 223 participant directly or indirectly exposed to a vehicle ramming attack wa conducted symptom of post traumatic stress disorder ptsd and depression quality of life and the sum score of the frequency of different type of comparison standard were assessed the latter consisted of temporal counterfactual social dimensional and criterion based comparison result in total 98 of participant reported some form of comparative thinking during the last two week the most frequent comparison type were temporal and dimensional comparison with 94 and 87 of participant reporting them respectively notably comparative thinking predicted unique variance in ptsd symptom over and above depressive symptom conclusion the result suggest that comparative thinking may be a significant factor in understanding psychological distress following exposure to aversive event replication of the result in larger sample and using longitudinal and experimental design is clearly necessary

Title: Generalizability of harm and pain expectations after exposure in chronic low back pain patients
Authors: Riecke, J.; Rief, W.; Vlaeyen, J. W. S.; Glombiewski, J. A.
Abstract: background exposure treatment are shown to be effective in reducing pain related fear and the perceived harmfulness of physical activity however due to the fragility of extinction it stability is questionable we investigated the generalizability of exposure effect in chronic low back pain clbp patient by integrating a behavioral test in the context of an intervention study method the study is an additional analysis of a randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of exposure in vivo a total of 67 clbp patient were randomly assigned to one of the three group exposure short exp s exposure long exp l and cognitive behavioral therapy cbt participant rated the expected harmfulness of daily activity photograph series of daily activity before and after therapy post treatment participant were confronted with an individually tailored threatening movement in a new context harm and pain expectation before the exposure were compared to the actual experience after exposure result we found that exp lead to more strongly reduced harm expectation f 2 50 11 37 p 001 eta 2 0 31 compared to cbt regardless of the duration of exp after therapy patient expected le harm f 2 50 3 61 p 034 eta 2 0 13 but not le pain f 2 50 3 61 p 034 eta 2 0 13 when confronted with a novel movement conclusion exposure successfully reduced harm but not pain expectation in patient with clbp further preliminary result showed that these specific exposure effect were generalized to a novel activity in a different context outside therapy significance this study investigats the generalizability and stability of exposure effect in patient with clbp by combining a behavioral test with an intervention study we found strong and stable effect on harm expectation but not on pain expectation result show promising preliminary evidence that reduced harm expectation can be generalized to a novel threatening activity in a new context clinical implication of our finding suggest that exposure treatment would benefit from a clear focus on harm expectation

Title: Individual differences in cognitive reappraisal usage modulate the time course of brain activation during symptom provocation in specific phobia
Authors: Hermann, A.; Leutgeb, V.; Scharmuller, W.; Vaitl, D.; Schienle, A.; Stark, R.
Abstract: background extinction learning is proposed to be one key mechanism of action underlying exposure based cognitive behavioral therapy cbt in specific phobia beyond that cognitive reappraisal one important strategy to regulate negative emotion is a crucial component of cbt intervention but ha been disregarded in previous study investigating neural change process in specific phobia the aim of this study wa to investigate the association of individual difference in habitual dispositional cognitive reappraisal usage and the time course of brain activation during phobic stimulation in specific phobia method dental phobic patient and healthy control subject participated in a functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri study whilst being confronted with phobic disgust fear and neutral picture individual difference in cognitive reappraisal usage were assessed via a self report questionnaire and correlated with activation decrease over the course of time result phobic individual with higher dispositional cognitive reappraisal score showed a more pronounced activation decline in the right dorsomedial prefrontal cortex dmpfc which might be associated with a diminution of explicit cognitive emotion regulation over the course of time le decrease of activation in the right ventromedial prefrontal cortex vmpfc and the lateral orbitofrontal cortex lofc over time in subject with higher cognitive reappraisal score might be related to a stronger automatic regulation of emotion or even emotional relearning additionally phobic subject compared with healthy control showed a stronger habituation of the left dmpfc over the course of symptom provocation conclusion the result of this study show for the first time that individual difference in cognitive reappraisal usage are associated with the time course of brain activation during symptom provocation in specific phobia additionally the present study give first indication for the importance of considering individual difference in cognitive reappraisal usage in the treatment of specific phobia

Title: Brain structural connectivity and context-dependent extinction memory
Authors: Hermann, A.; Stark, R.; Blecker, C. R.; Milad, M. R.; Merz, C. J.
Abstract: background extinction of conditioned fear represents an important mechanism in the treatment of anxiety disorder return of fear after successful extinction or exposure therapy in patient with anxiety disorder might be linked to poor temporal or contextual generalization of extinction due to individual difference in brain structural connectivity the goal of this magnetic resonance imaging study wa therefore to investigate the association of context dependent extinction recall with brain structural connectivity method diffusion tensor imaging wa used to determine the fractional anisotropy a a measure of white matter structural integrity of fiber tract connecting central brain region of the fear and extinction circuit uncinate fasciculus cingulum forty five healthy men participated in a two day fear conditioning experiment with fear acquisition in context a and extinction learning in context b on the first day extinction recall in the extinction context a well a renewal in the acquisition context and a novel context c took place one day later result renewal of conditioned fear skin conductance response in the acquisition context wa associated with higher structural integrity of the hippocampal part of the cingulum conclusion enhanced structural integrity of the cingulum might be related to stronger hippocampal modulation of the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex a region important for modulating conditioned fear output by excitatory projection to the amygdala this finding underpins the crucial role of individual difference in the structural integrity of relevant fiber tract for context dependent extinction recall and return of fear after exposure therapy in anxiety disorder

Title: Neurophysiological correlates of holistic face processing in adolescents with and without autism spectrum disorder
Authors: Naumann, S.; Senftleben, U.; Santhosh, M.; McPartland, J.; Webb, S. J.
Abstract: background face processing ha been found to be impaired in autism spectrum disorder asd one hypothesis is that individual with asd engage in piecemeal compared to holistic face processing strategy to investigate the role of possible impairment in holistic face processing in individual with autism the current study investigated behavioral and electroencephalography eeg correlate of face processing p1 n170 and gamma band activity in adolescent with asd and sex age and iq matched neurotypical control method participant were presented with upright and inverted mooney stimulus black and white low information face that are only perceived a face when processed holistically participant indicated behaviorally the detection of a face eeg wa collected time locked to the presentation of the stimulus result adolescent with asd perceived mooney stimulus a face suggesting ability to use holistic processing but displayed a lower face detection rate and slower response time erp component suggest slowed temporal processing of mooney stimulus in the asd compared to control group for p1 latency but no difference between group for p1 amplitude and at the n170 increase in gamma band activity wa similar during the perception of the mooney image by group but the asd group showed prolonged temporal elevation in activity conclusion overall our result suggest that adolescent with asd were able to utilize holistic processing to perceive a face within the mooney stimulus delay in early processing marked by the p1 and elongated elevation in gamma activity indicate that the neural system supporting holistic processing are slightly altered suggesting a le automatic and le efficient facial processing system trial registration non applicable

Title: Developmental aspects of fear generalization - A MEG study on neurocognitive correlates in adolescents versus adults
Authors: Roesmann, K.; Wessing, I.; Krass, S.; Leehr, E. J.; Klucken, T.; Straube, T.; Junghofer, M.
Abstract: background fear generalization is pivotal for the survival promoting avoidance of potential danger but if too pronounced it promotes pathological anxiety similar to adult patient with anxiety disorder healthy child tend to show overgeneralized fear response objective this study aim to investigate neuro developmental aspect of fear generalization in adolescence a critical age for the development of anxiety disorder method we compared healthy adolescent 14 17 year with healthy adult 19 34 year regarding their fear response towards tilted gabor grating conditioned stimulus c and slightly differently titled generalization stimulus g in the conditioning phase c were paired c or remained unpaired c with an aversive stimulus unconditioned stimulus u in the test phase behavioral peripheral and neural response to c and g were captured by fear and ucs expectancy rating a perceptual discrimination task pupil dilation and source estimation of event related magnetic field result closely resembling adult adolescent showed robust generalization gradient of fear rating pupil dilation and estimated neural source activity however in the ucs expectancy rating adolescent revealed shallower generalization gradient indicating overgeneralization moreover adolescent showed stronger visual cortical activity after a compared to before conditioning to all stimulus conclusion various aspect of fear learning and generalization appear to be mature in healthy adolescent yet cognitive aspect might show a slower course of development

Title: Conflict monitoring and adaptation as reflected by N2 amplitude in obsessive-compulsive disorder
Authors: Riesel, A.; Klawohn, J.; Kathmann, N.; Endrass, T.
Abstract: background feeling of doubt and perseverative behaviour are key symptom of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd and have been linked to hyperactive error and conflict signal in the brain while enhanced neural correlate of error monitoring have been robustly shown far le is known about conflict processing and adaptation in ocd method we examined event related potential during conflict processing in 70 patient with ocd and 70 matched healthy comparison participant focusing on the stimulus locked n2 elicited in a flanker task conflict adaptation wa evaluated by analysing sequential adjustment in n2 and behaviour i e current conflict effect a a function of preceding conflict result patient with ocd showed enhanced n2 amplitude compared with healthy control further patient showed stronger conflict adaptation effect on reaction time and n2 amplitude thus the effect of previous compatibility wa larger in patient than in healthy participant a indicated by greater n2 adjustment in change trial i e ic ci a a result of stronger conflict adaptation in patient n2 amplitude were comparable between group in incompatible trial following incompatible trial conclusion larger n2 amplitude and greater conflict adaptation in ocd point to enhanced conflict monitoring leading to increased recruitment of cognitive control in patient this wa most pronounced in change trial and wa associated with stronger conflict adjustment in n2 and behaviour thus hyperactive conflict monitoring in ocd may be beneficial in situation that require a high amount of control to resolve conflict but may also reflect an effortful process that is linked to distress and symptom of ocd

Title: Maternal avoidance, anxiety cognitions and interactive behaviour predicts infant development at 12 months in the context of anxiety disorders in the postpartum period
Authors: Reck, C.; Van Den Bergh, B.; Tietz, A.; Muller, M.; Ropeter, A.; Zipser, B.; Pauen, S.
Abstract: background few study have examined the relation between anxiety disorder in the postpartum period and cognitive a well a language development in infancy aim this longitudinal study investigated whether anxiety disorder in the postpartum period is linked to infant development at twelve month a closer look wa also taken at a possible link between maternal interaction and infant development study design subject were videotaped during a face to face still face interaction with their infant m 4 0 month specific maternal anxiety symptom were measured by self report questionnaire anxiety cognition questionnaire acq body sensation questionnaire bsq mobility inventory mi to check for a connection with infant development the bayley scale of infant and toddler development iii bayley iii were used to a infant language and cognitive development at one year of age subject n 34 mother with anxiety disorder scid i dsm iv and n 47 healthy mother with their infant outcome measure infant performance on bayley iii language and cognitive scale result infant of mother with anxiety disorder yielded significantly lower language score than infant of control no significant group difference were found regarding infant cognitive development exploratory analysis revealed the vital role of maternal avoidance accompanied in infant language and cognitive development maternal neutral engagement which lack positive affect and vocalisation turned out a the strongest negative predictor of cognitive development maternal anxiety cognition and joint activity in mother infant interaction were the strongest predictor of infant language performance conclusion result underline the importance to also consider the interaction behaviour of woman with anxiety disorder to prevent adverse infant development

Title: A comprehensive model of food addiction in patients with binge-eating symptomatology: The essential role of negative urgency
Authors: Wolz, I.; Granero, R.; Fernandez-Aranda, F.
Abstract: background food addiction ha been widely researched in past year however there is a debate on the mechanism underlying addictive eating and a better understanding of the process associated to these behavior is needed previous study have found characteristic psychological correlate of food addiction such a high negative urgency emotion regulation difficulty and low self directedness in different sample of adult with addictive eating pattern still it seems difficult to disentangle effect independent from general eating disorder psychopathology therefore this study aimed to test a comprehensive model under control of eating disorder severity in order to find independent predictor of food addiction method 315 patient with eating disorder diagnosis on the binge eating spectrum were assessed in personality emotion regulation negative urgency eating disorder symptomatology and food addiction by self report hypothesis driven structural equation modeling wa conducted to test the comprehensive model result the only independent predictor found for food addiction wa negative urgency while self directedness and emotion regulation predicted negative urgency and were highly related to eating disorder symptomatology but not to food addiction conclusion altogether the model suggests that low self directedness and difficulty in emotion regulation are related to higher eating disorder symptomatology in general those patient who in addition to these trait tend to act impulsively when in negative mood state are at risk for developing addictive eating pattern urgency based treatment are therefore recommended for this subgroup of patient

Title: Stress reactivity in childhood functional abdominal pain or irritable bowel syndrome
Authors: Gulewitsch, M. D.; Weimer, K.; Enck, P.; Schwille-Kiuntke, J.; Hautzinger, M.; Schlarb, A. A.
Abstract: background frequent abdominal pain ap in childhood ha been shown to be associated with elevated experience of stress and with deficit in stress coping but psychophysiological stress reactivity ha been studied rarely method we examined whether child with frequent ap show altered reaction of the parasympathetic nervous system and the hypothalamic pituitary adrenal hpa axis during and following an afternoon laboratory social stress task in comparison to healthy child and child with anxiety disorder twenty four child with frequent ap 18 with functional ap and six with irritable bowel syndrome m 9 9 year and 24 healthy control underwent stressful free speech and arithmetic task twelve child with anxiety disorder served a second comparison sample group were compared regarding parasympathetic reaction and saliva cortisol concentration result we found no difference in parasympathetic withdrawal between the group concerning the hpa axis we detected an attenuated cortisol reactivity in child with ap compared to both other group conclusion this study provides preliminary evidence that childhood ap is not associated with altered parasympathetic withdrawal during stress it seems to be related to a down regulated reactivity of the hpa axis this pattern wa ascertained in comparison to healthy child and also in comparison to child with anxiety disorder significance childhood abdominal pain could be related to down regulated hpa axis reactivity to stress but not to altered parasympathetic reaction child with abdominal pain and child with anxiety disorder exhibit a divergent stress related hpa axis reaction

Title: Distress criterion influences prevalence rates of functional gastrointestinal disorders
Authors: Markert, C.; Suarez-Hitz, K.; Ehlert, U.; Nater, U. M.
Abstract: background functional gastrointestinal disorder fgid are defined by a combination of chronic or recurrent gastrointestinal symptom prevalence rate of fgid are high symptom are associated with distress and sufferer show high stress level however the current diagnostic criterion do not consider subjective distress elicited by the symptom thus potentially leading to overestimated prevalence rate the aim of this study wa to explore the reduction in prevalence rate when distress is considered in the diagnostic criterion method in this web based study fgid were diagnosed using the rome ii criterion prevalence rate with and without subjective distress elicited by the symptom were computed additionally stress level and stress reactivity were assessed result prevalence rate of fgid in our sample were similar to those in other study however when considering the distress criterion on average a decrease of 38 51 wa found in the prevalence rate of fgid sufferer who were subjectively distressed by their symptom reported significantly higher stress level than non distressed subject all p 0 001 conclusion the consideration of a criterion of subjective distress in the diagnosis of fgid ha consequence for actual prevalence rate of fgid distressed subject differ markedly from non distressed subject in term of their stress level the inclusion of a distress criterion in the ongoing development of diagnostic criterion for fgid is therefore warranted

Title: Trauma, attentional dysregulation, and the development of posttraumatic stress: An investigation of risk pathways
Authors: Schafer, J.; Zvielli, A.; Hofler, M.; Wittchen, H. U.; Bernstein, A.
Abstract: background fundamental question regarding the nature and function of attentional bias ab to threat in the etiology of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd remain unanswered we tested the temporal interplay between trauma exposure dysregulated attentional processing of threatening information pre and post trauma and the development of posttraumatic intrusion method response time to trauma related threat trauma unrelated threat a well a to trauma related but typically emotionally neutral stimulus wa assessed using the dot probe task before and one week after watching a violent movie scene that served a a trauma analogue ab wa analyzed a a dynamic process by mean of a recently developed approach indexing momentary fluctuation of ab toward and away from emotional stimulus posttraumatic intrusion were measured daily over the week following analogue trauma exposure result we found that key feature of ab dynamic to trauma related stimulus at post but not pre trauma exposure were associated with posttraumatic intrusion notably these post trauma exposure effect were specific to biased attentional processing of trauma related but not threatening stimulus unrelated to the traumatic event in line with a growing body of finding pre and post trauma exposure traditional aggregated mean ab score were not similarly associated with posttraumatic intrusion conclusion we conclude that one mechanism through which trauma exposure may contribute to the development of ptsd is through it dysregulation of attentional processing of trauma event related cue future work may focus on delineating the developmental course through which attentional dysregulation post trauma and posttraumatic intrusion unfold and interact

Title: Separating generalized anxiety disorder from major depression using clinical, hormonal, and structural MRI data: A multimodal machine learning study
Authors: Hilbert, K.; Lueken, U.; Muehlhan, M.; Beesdo-Baum, K.
Abstract: background generalized anxiety disorder gad is difficult to recognize and hard to separate from major depression md in clinical setting biomarkers might support diagnostic decision this study used machine learning on multimodal biobehavioral data from a sample of gad md and healthy subject to differentiate subject with a disorder from healthy subject case classification and to differentiate gad from md disorder classification method subject with gad n 19 md without gad n 14 and healthy comparison subject n 24 were included the sample wa matched regarding age sex handedness and education and free of psychopharmacological medication binary support vector machine were used within a nested leave one out cross validation framework clinical questionnaire cortisol release gray matter gm and white matter wm volume were used a input data separately and in combination result questionnaire data were well suited for case classification but not disorder classification accuracy 96 40 p 001 56 58 p 22 the opposite pattern wa found for imaging data case classification gm wm 58 71 p 09 43 18 p 66 disorder classification gm wm 68 05 p 034 58 27 p 15 and for cortisol data 38 02 p 84 74 60 p 009 all data combined achieved 90 10 accuracy p 001 for case classification and 67 46 accuracy p 0268 for disorder classification conclusion in line with previous evidence classification of gad wa difficult using clinical questionnaire data alone particularly cortisol and gm volume data were able to provide incremental value for the classification of gad finding suggest that neurobiological biomarkers are a useful target for further research to delineate their potential contribution to diagnostic process

Title: Internet-Based Cognitive-Behavioural Intervention for Women with Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder: A Randomized Controlled Trial
Authors: Weise, C.; Kaiser, G.; Janda, C.; Kues, J. N.; Andersson, G.; Strahler, J.; Kleinstauber, M.
Abstract: background given the high prevalence of clinically relevant premenstrual symptom and the associated impairment there is a need for effective treatment initial evidence suggests cognitive behavioural therapy cbt a an effective treatment for premenstrual dysphoric disorder pmdd the aim of the current randomized clinical trial wa to evaluate an internet based cbt icbt to reduce the burden of pmdd method in all 174 woman with pmdd were recruited via newspaper article flyer and social medium they were randomized to a treatment group tg n 86 or waitlist control group cg n 88 woman of the tg received an 8 week therapist guided icbt data were assessed before and after treatment waiting and 6 month after intervention with prospective symptom diary and questionnaire in the premenstrual phase treatment effect and moderator were analysed using hierarchical linear modelling result significant time x group interaction effect on functional impairment and psychological impairment impact on everyday life symptom intensity and symptom disability in favour of the tg indicated the efficacy of the treatment follow up assessment demonstrated treatment effect to be stable until 6 month after treatment additionally significant interaction with moderator variable were found in the tg higher level of active coping and lower level of support seeking coping were associated with stronger improvement in interference in everyday life and symptom intensity in addition lower level of perceived stress were associated with stronger improvement in functional impairment conclusion the icbt wa highly effective in reducing the burden of pmdd it appears to be particularly important to address coping style and stress management in the treatment

Title: Neuronal and behavioral correlates of health anxiety: results of an illness-related emotional Stroop task
Authors: Witthoft, M.; Mier, D.; Ofer, J.; Muller, T.; Rist, F.; Kirsch, P.; Bailer, J.; Diener, C.
Abstract: background health anxiety ha is defined a the objectively unfounded fear or conviction of suffering from a severe illness predominant attention allocation to illness related information is regarded a a central process in the development and maintenance of ha yet little is known about the neuronal correlate of this attentional bias method an emotional stroop task with body symptom illness and neutral word wa employed to elicit emotional interference in healthy participant with high ha n 12 and low ha n 12 ha during functional magnetic resonance imaging result prolonged reaction time for indicating the color of symptom word and a decrease in rostral anterior cingulate cortex racc activation were seen in ha participant emotional interference effect on the behavioral level were negatively related to racc activity over the whole group group did not differ during the processing of threatening illness word conclusion the result indicate stronger attention allocation toward body symptom word already in subclinical ha this attentional bias appears to be linked to hypoactivity of the racc which impedes effective emotional interference reduction leading instead to a ruminative processing of the stimulus content

Title: Increased impulsivity as a vulnerability marker for bipolar disorder: evidence from self-report and experimental measures in two high-risk populations
Authors: Wessa, M.; Kollmann, B.; Linke, J.; Schonfelder, S.; Kanske, P.
