Abstract: background heightened impulsivity ha been suggested a a possible risk factor for bipolar disorder bd however study on high risk population are scarce and have mainly focused on individual with a genetic risk the present study investigated two high risk sample for bd with regard to several aspect of the impulsivity construct method unaffected relative of bd patient genetically defined high risk group n 29 and participant scoring high on the hypomanic personality scale psychometrically defined high risk sample n 25 were being compared to respective control group n 27 and n 25 using a multi method approach participant were accessed on the barratt impulsiveness scale 11 bi 11 trait impulsivity the stop signal task response inhibition and the cambridge gambling task impulsive behavior in decision making process result both high risk group reported heightened impulsivity on the bi 11 a well a impulsive decision making whereas no significant group difference in response inhibition were observed limitation limitation were the lack in specificity of the result for bd and the cross sectional study design which doe not allow conclusion about the influence of impulsivity on the development of or resilience for bd in risk group conclusion our finding support the assumption that increased trait impulsivity and impulsive decision making are a vulnerability marker for and an endophenotype of bd

Title: Reward-related decision making and long-term weight loss maintenance
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Simon, J. J.; Becker, A.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: background heightened sensitivity towards reward and insensitivity towards disadvantageous consequence may constitute a driving factor underlying unrestricted food intake and consequent weight gain in people with overweight and obesity therefore the present study applied a behavioral economics approach to investigate the potential contribution of poor reward related decision making to unsuccessful long term weight loss maintenance i e weight cycling based on previous research it wa expected that successful long term weight loss maintainer would show a better performance in a gambling task than their le successful counterpart method reward related decision making wa assessed post hoc using the game of dice task in a total of 33 overweight and obese woman who had either a successfully maintained initial weight loss of at least 10 of their body weight over one year or b had regained weight until at least their initial body weight prior to weight reduction i e showed weight cycling result the group did not differ in term of age current body weight magnitude of initial weight reduction educational level and global intelligence level a hypothesized however the group of successful long term weight loss maintainer performed significantly better i e showed le impulsive more advantageous choice in the game of dice task than their le successful counterpart conclusion the finding suggest that poor reward related decision making is associated with weight cycling which is considered a key concern in weight loss treatment for overweight and obesity furthermore the finding speak in favor of specific psychological intervention that are designed to bolster reward related decision making

Title: Presupplementary Motor Area Contributes to Altered Error Monitoring in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
Authors: Grutzmann, R.; Endrass, T.; Kaufmann, C.; Allen, E.; Eichele, T.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: background hyperactive performance monitoring a measured by the error related negativity ern in the event related potential is a reliable finding in obsessive compulsive disorder ocd research and may be an endophenotype of the disorder imaging study revealed inconsistent result a to which brain region are involved in altered performance monitoring in ocd we investigated performance monitoring in ocd with simultaneous recording of electroencephalography eeg and functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri signal to determine the neural source of the enhanced ern method concurrent eeg and fmri data were collected from 20 patient with ocd and 22 healthy control subject during a flanker task independent component analysis wa used separately on eeg and fmri to segment the data functionally and focus on process of interest the ern hemodynamic response following error and intraindividual correlation of the ern and blood oxygen level dependent activity were compared between group result patient with ocd showed significantly increased ern amplitude blood oxygen level dependent activity in midcingulate cortex wa not significantly different between group increased activation of the right amygdala and the subgenual anterior cingulate cortex following error wa observed in patient with ocd increased intraindividual correlation of the ern and activity of the presupplementary motor area wa found in patient with ocd compared with healthy control conclusion higher error related activity wa found in the amygdala and subgenual anterior cingulate cortex suggesting a stronger affective response toward error in patient with ocd additionally increased correlation of the ern and presupplementary motor area may indicate stronger recruitment of proactive control in ocd

Title: Alpha-2 Adrenoreceptor Antagonist Yohimbine Potentiates Consolidation of Conditioned Fear
Authors: Sperl, M. F. J.; Panitz, C.; Skoluda, N.; Nater, U. M.; Pizzagalli, D. A.; Hermann, C.; Mueller, E. M.
Abstract: background hyperconsolidation of aversive association and poor extinction learning have been hypothesized to be crucial in the acquisition of pathological fear previous animal and human research point to the potential role of the catecholaminergic system particularly noradrenaline and dopamine in acquiring emotional memory here we investigated in a between participant design with 3 group whether the noradrenergic alpha 2 adrenoreceptor antagonist yohimbine and the dopaminergic d2 receptor antagonist sulpiride modulate long term fear conditioning and extinction in human method fifty five healthy male student were recruited the final sample consisted of n 51 participant who were explicitly aware of the contingency between conditioned stimulus c and unconditioned stimulus after fear acquisition the participant were then randomly assigned to 1 of the 3 group and received either yohimbine 10 mg n 17 sulpiride 200 mg n 16 or placebo n 18 between fear acquisition and extinction recall of conditioned non extinguished c v c and extinguished fear extinguished c v c wa assessed 1 day later and a 64 channel electroencephalogram wa recorded result the yohimbine group showed increased salivary alpha amylase activity confirming a successful manipulation of central noradrenergic release elevated fear conditioned bradycardia and larger differential amplitude of the n170 and late positive potential component in the event related brain potential indicated that yohimbine treatment compared with a placebo and sulpiride enhanced fear recall during day 2 conclusion these result suggest that yohimbine potentiates cardiac and central electrophysiological signature of fear memory consolidation they thereby elucidate the key role of noradrenaline in strengthening the consolidation of conditioned fear association which may be a key mechanism in the etiology of fear related disorder

Title: Lifestyle choices and mental health: a representative population survey
Authors: Velten, J.; Lavallee, K. L.; Scholten, S.; Meyer, A. H.; Zhang, X. C.; Schneider, S.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background identifying healthy lifestyle behaviour that promote psychological wellbeing is crucial to preventing mental disorder the aim of the current study wa to evaluate the individual and combined association between different aspect of everyday life and mental health within a representative community sample in germany method the study wa conducted in 2012 2013 and included 7 937 participant representative of the german population lifestyle factor were assessed via self report and included frequency of physical and mental activity alcohol consumption smoking body mass index a well a circadian and social regularity outcome variable were depression anxiety stress and satisfaction with life result all lifestyle factor were associated with the mental health outcome better mental health wa linked to higher frequency of physical and mental activity moderate alcohol consumption i e not increased or no alcohol consumption non smoking a body mass index within the range of normal to overweight i e not underweight or obese and a regular life rhythm the more healthy lifestyle choice an individual make the higher life satisfaction and lower psychological distress he or she tends to have conclusion the current study underline the importance of healthy lifestyle choice in respect to psychological wellbeing

Title: Long-term effects of imaginal retraining in overweight and obesity: A controlled study
Authors: Gehlenborg, J.; Goritz, A. S.; Moritz, S.; Kuhn, S.
Abstract: background imaginal retraining ir is a self help technique that target automatic approach tendency toward appetitive stimulus in a randomized controlled trial rct n 384 ir reduced craving for high calorie food after a six week intervention period small effect the aim of the present study wa to evaluate long term effect of ir in this sample method one year after baseline participant from the initial rct were recontacted a visual analogue scale measuring craving the food craving questionnaire trait reduced fcq t r the three factor eating questionnaire the beck depression inventory quality of life and subjective appraisal of the intervention were assessed online participant were classified a user or nonusers based on self reported usage of ir over the previous year result linear mixed model showed no significant interaction effect of time and group for any outcome trend level effect were found for two subscales of the fcq t r yet higher usage of ir wa associated with greater symptom reduction although overall subjective appraisal of the intervention wa comparably good to the initial study usage of ir and completion rate were unsatisfactory limitation main limitation of the present study include the nonrandomized group allocation and the low completion rate conclusion this study did not find evidence for the long term efficacy of ir in individual with craving for high calorie food only upon high usage of ir improvement wa found however low completion rate and usage of the intervention may have resulted in a type ii error future study may consider low intensity professional guidance to increase adherence and a the long term effect of ir in rcts

Title: Trauma and perceived social rejection among Yazidi women and girls who survived enslavement and genocide
Authors: Ibrahim, H.; Ertl, V.; Catani, C.; Ismail, A. A.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: background in august 2014 the islamic state of iraq and syria isi a terrorist organization attacked the yazidi s ancestral homeland in northwestern iraq among other atrocity they abducted thousand of woman and girl and traded many of them into sexual slavery the aim of this study is to determine the mental health of woman and girl survivor of these event in relation to enslavement and experience with genocide related event a well a perceived social rejection in their community method between february and july 2017 trained local assessor interviewed a sample of 416 yazidi woman and girl 65 of whom had survived sexual enslavement aged between 17 and 75 year and living in internally displaced person camp in the kurdistan region of iraq post traumatic stress disorder ptsd and depression symptom were assessed using validated kurdish version of standard instrument scale for trauma exposure and perceived rejection were developed for the purpose of this study result participant reported a high number of traumatic event more than 80 of girl and woman and almost all participant who were formerly enslaved met criterion for a probable dsm 5 ptsd diagnosis trauma exposure and enslavement predicted poor mental health in addition among formerly enslaved girl and woman perceived social rejection in their community mediated the relationship between traumatic enslavement event and depression symptom conclusion in a context of maximum adversity enslavement and war related event contribute to high level of ptsd and depression perceived social rejection seems to play a role in the relationship between trauma exposure and mental health among abducted genocide survivor providing psychosocial support and treatment for yazidi people is essential and urgently required

Title: What Are Reasons for the Large Gender Differences in the Lethality of Suicidal Acts? An Epidemiological Analysis in Four European Countries
Authors: Mergl, R.; Koburger, N.; Heinrichs, K.; Szekely, A.; Toth, M. D.; Coyne, J.; Quintao, S.; Arensman, E.; Coffey, C.; Maxwell, M.; Varnik, A.; van Audenhove, C.; McDaid, D.; Sarchiapone, M.; Schmidtke, A.; Genz, A.; Gusmao, R.; Hegerl, U.
Abstract: background in europe men have lower rate of attempted suicide compared to woman and at the same time a higher rate of completed suicide indicating major gender difference in lethality of suicidal behaviour the aim of this study wa to analyse the extent to which these gender difference in lethality can be explained by factor such a choice of more lethal method or lethality difference within the same suicide method or age in addition we explored gender difference in the intentionality of suicide attempt method and finding method design epidemiological study using a combination of self report and official data setting mental health care service in four european country germany hungary ireland and portugal data basis completed suicide derived from official statistic for each country 767 act 74 4 male and assessed suicide attempt excluding habitual intentional self harm 8 175 act 43 2 male main outcome measure and data analysis we collected data on suicidal act in eight region of four european country participating in the eu funded ospi europe project www ospi europe com we calculated method specific lethality using the number of completed suicide per method 100 number of completed suicide per method number of attempted suicide per method we tested gender difference in the distribution of suicidal act for significance by using the chi2 test for two by two table we assessed the effect size with phi coefficient phi we identified predictor of lethality with a binary logistic regression analysis poisson regression analysis examined the contribution of choice of method and method specific lethality to gender difference in the lethality of suicidal act finding main result suicidal act fatal and non fatal were 3 4 time more lethal in men than in woman lethality 13 91 regarding 4106 suicidal act versus 4 05 regarding 4836 suicidal act the difference being significant for the method hanging jumping moving object sharp object and poisoning by substance other than drug median age at time of suicidal behaviour 35 44 year did not differ between male and female the overall gender difference in lethality of suicidal behaviour wa explained by male choosing more lethal suicide method odds ratio or 2 03 95 ci 1 65 to 2 50 p 0 000001 and additionally but to a lesser degree by a higher lethality of suicidal act for male even within the same method or 1 64 95 ci 1 32 to 2 02 p 0 000005 result of a regression analysis revealed neither age nor country difference were significant predictor for gender difference in the lethality of suicidal act the proportion of serious suicide attempt among all non fatal suicidal act with known intentionality nfsai wa significantly higher in men 57 1 1 207 of 2 115 nfsai than in woman 48 6 1 508 of 3 100 nfsai chi2 35 74 p 0 000001 main limitation of the study due to restrictive data security regulation to ensure anonymity in ireland specific age could not be provided because of the relatively low absolute number of suicide in the irish intervention and control region therefore analysis of the interaction between gender and age could only be conducted for three of the four country attempted suicide were assessed for patient presenting to emergency department or treated in hospital an unknown rate of attempted suicide remained undetected this may have caused an overestimation of the lethality of certain method moreover the detection of attempted suicide and the registration of completed suicide might have differed across the four country some suicide might be hidden and misclassified a undetermined death conclusion men more often used highly lethal method in suicidal behaviour but there wa also a higher method specific lethality which together explained the large gender difference in the lethality of suicidal act gender difference in the lethality of suicidal act were fairly consistent across all four european country examined male and female did not differ in age at time of suicidal behaviour suicide attempt by male were rated a being more serious independent of the method used with the exception of attempted hanging suggesting gender difference in intentionality associated with suicidal behaviour these finding contribute to understanding of the spectrum of reason for gender difference in the lethality of suicidal behaviour and should inform the development of gender specific strategy for suicide prevention

Title: The role of KIBRA in reconstructive episodic memory
Authors: Zlomuzica, A.; Preusser, F.; Roberts, S.; Woud, M. L.; Lester, K. J.; Dere, E.; Eley, T. C.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background in order to retrieve episodic past event the missing information need to be reconstructed using information stored in semantic memory failure in these reconstructive process are expressed a false memory kibra single nucleotide polymorphism rs17070145 ha been linked to episodic memory performance a well a an increased risk of alzheimer s disease and post traumatic stress disorder ptsd method here the role of kibra rs17070145 polymorphism male and female cc v ct tt carrier in reconstructive episodic memory in the deese roediger mcdermott drm paradigm wa investigated in n 219 healthy individual result female participant outperformed male in the free recall condition furthermore a trend towards a gender x genotype interaction wa found for false recognition rate female ct tt carrier exhibited a lower proportion of false recognition rate for associated critical lure a compared to male ct tt additionally an association between kibra rs17070145 genotype familiarity and recollection based recognition performance wa found in trial with correct recognition of listed item ct tt carrier showed more remember but fewer know response a compared to cc carrier discussion and conclusion our finding suggest that the t allele of kibra rs17070145 support recollection based episodic memory retrieval and contributes to memory accuracy in a gender dependent manner finding are discussed in the context of the specific contribution of kibra related snp to reconstructive episodic memory and it implication for cognitive and emotional symptom in dementia and ptsd

Title: Web-based psychotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorder in war-traumatized Arab patients: randomized controlled trial
Authors: Knaevelsrud, C.; Brand, J.; Lange, A.; Ruwaard, J.; Wagner, B.
Abstract: background in recent year armed conflict in the middle east have resulted in high rate of exposure to traumatic event despite the increasing demand of mental health care provision ongoing violence limit conventional approach of mental health care provision internet based intervention for posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd have proved feasible and effective in western country but their applicability and efficacy in war and conflict region remains unknown objective this study investigated the efficacy of a cognitive behavioral internet based intervention for war traumatized arab patient with focus on iraq method a total of 159 individual with ptsd participated in a parallel group randomized trial participant were randomly allocated by a computer generated sequence to a treatment group n 79 or a waiting list control group n 80 the treatment group received 2 weekly 45 minute cognitive behavioral intervention via internet over a 5 week period 10 session in total the primary outcome wa recovery from posttraumatic stress symptom result posttraumatic stress symptom were significantly reduced from baseline to posttreatment intention to treat analysis in the treatment group relative to the control group f1 157 44 29 p 001 d 0 92 treatment effect were sustained at 3 month follow up completer analysis indicated that 29 of 47 patient 62 in the treatment group had recovered from posttraumatic stress symptom at posttreatment reliable change and posttraumatic stress diagnostic scale score 20 versus 1 patient 2 in the control group or 74 19 95 ci 9 93 585 8 p 001 indicating that the chance of recovering wa 74 19 time higher in the treatment than in the control group conclusion the result indicate even in unstable and insecure setting with ongoing exposure to human right violation through war and dictatorship people with posttraumatic stress symptom benefit from a cognitive behavioral treatment provided entirely through the internet this method of delivery could improve patient access to humanitarian aid in the form of e mental health service trial registration australian new zealand clinical trial registry actrn12611001019998 http www anzctr org au trial registration trialreview aspx id 347505 archived by webcite at http www webcitation org 6wto4hcdh

Title: Putative juvenile terrorists: the relationship between multiple traumatization, mental health, and expectations for reintegration among Islamic State recruited adolescent and young adult fighters
Authors: Mohammed, R.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: background in several conflict worldwide child are recruited a fighter in irregular force these child need to be reintegrated into the society after the conflict however concurrent to various reservation in the community the reintegration of former child soldier is challenged by the fact that many of the affected child were indoctrinated by the armed group and traumatized through war event even several year after the defeat of the terrorist organization isi in iraq systematic effort towards the reintegration of child who had been recruited by isi are notably absent method we conducted clinical interview with a sample of n 59 adolescent and young adult who were incarcerated for terrorism in the prison of the kurdistan region of iraq to a level and type of trauma exposure ptsd depression readiness to reintegrate and ongoing identification with isi result we found high level of ptsd and depression that were associated with trauma exposure the subjective readiness to reintegrate into the community wa associated with trauma exposure and wa mediated by depression even after controlling for the influence of ongoing identification with the armed group conclusion the study indicates that trauma related mental ill health should be considered in effort to reintegrate young former terrorist

Title: Aggression inoculates against PTSD symptom severity-insights from armed groups in the eastern DR Congo
Authors: Hecker, T.; Hermenau, K.; Maedl, A.; Schauer, M.; Elbert, T.
Abstract: background in the ongoing conflict in the democratic republic of the congo drc combatant are exposed to massive form of violence and other traumatic stressor nevertheless many combatant do not suffer from trauma related disorder although they have experienced numerous traumatizing event perceiving aggressive behavior a fascinating and arousing might be a defense against trauma related disorder in the violent environment of war and conflict objective thus in this study we investigated the relationship between the exposure to traumatic stressor appetitive aggression and posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd symptom severity we hypothesized that cumulative traumatic experience correlated positively and appetitive aggression negatively with ptsd symptom severity method in total 105 voluntary male combatant from different armed group in the eastern drc took part in this study in a semistructured interview respondent were questioned about their exposure to traumatic stressor the extent of appetitive aggression appetitive aggression scale and their ptsd symptom severity ptsd symptom scale interview result a multiple sequential regression analysis showed that traumatic event were positively related to ptsd symptom severity for participant with low to medium ptsd symptom severity appetitive aggression correlated negatively with ptsd symptom severity conclusion the result of this study provide further support for earlier finding that repeated exposure to traumatic stressor cumulatively heightens the risk of ptsd and revealed that appetitive aggression buffer the risk of developing ptsd symptom under certain circumstance thus the perception of aggressive behavior a fascinating and arousing seem to help combatant to adapt to violent environment but may also be one reason for recurrent failure of reintegration program for excombatants

Title: How negative mood hinders belief updating in depression: results from two experimental studies
Authors: Kube, T.; Kirchner, L.; Gartner, T.; Glombiewski, J. A.
Abstract: background in two experimental study we tested the hypothesis that negative mood would hinder the revision of negative belief in response to unexpectedly positive information in depression whereas positive mood wa expected to enhance belief updating method in study 1 n 101 we used a subclinical sample to compare the film based induction of sad v happy mood with a distraction control group subsequently participant underwent a well established paradigm to examine intra individual change in performance related expectation after unexpectedly positive performance feedback in study 2 we applied the belief updating task from study 1 to an inpatient sample n 81 and induced sad v happy mood via film clip v recall of autobiographic event result the result of study 1 showed no significant group difference in belief updating the severity of depressive symptom wa a negative predictor of belief revision though and there wa a non significant trend suggesting that the presence of sad mood hindered belief updating in the subgroup of participant with a diagnosed depressive episode study 2 revealed that participant updated their expectation significantly le in line with positive feedback when they underwent the induction of negative mood prior to feedback relative to positive mood conclusion by indicating that the presence of negative mood can hinder the revision of negative belief in clinically depressed people our finding suggest that learning from new experience can be hampered if state negative mood is activated thus intervention relying on learning from novel positive experience should aim at reducing state negative mood in depression

Title: Error-related brain activity as a transdiagnostic endophenotype for obsessive-compulsive disorder, anxiety and substance use disorder
Authors: Riesel, A.; Klawohn, J.; Grutzmann, R.; Kaufmann, C.; Heinzel, S.; Bey, K.; Lennertz, L.; Wagner, M.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: background increased neural error signal have been observed in obsessive compulsive disorder ocd anxiety disorder and inconsistently in depression reduced neural error signal have been observed in substance use disorder sud thus alteration in error monitoring are proposed a a transdiagnostic endophenotype to strengthen this notion data from unaffected individual with a family history for the respective disorder are needed method the error related negativity ern a a neural indicator of error monitoring wa measured during a flanker task from 117 ocd patient 50 unaffected first degree relative of ocd patient and 130 healthy comparison participant family history information indicated that 76 healthy control were free of a family history for psychopathology whereas the remaining had first degree relative with depression n 28 anxiety n 27 and or sud n 27 result increased ern amplitude were found in ocd patient and unaffected first degree relative of ocd patient in addition unaffected first degree relative of individual with anxiety disorder were also characterized by increased ern amplitude whereas relative of individual with sud showed reduced amplitude conclusion alteration in neural error signal in unaffected first degree relative with a family history of ocd anxiety or sud support the utility of the ern a a transdiagnostic endophenotype reduced neural error signal may indicate vulnerability for under controlled behavior and risk for substance use whereas a harm or error avoidant response style and vulnerability for ocd and anxiety appears to be associated with increased ern this add to finding suggesting a common neurobiological substrate across psychiatric disorder involving the anterior cingulate cortex and deficit in cognitive control

Title: Increased Anxiety of Public Situations During the COVID-19 Pandemic: Evidence From a Community and a Patient Sample
Authors: Pittig, A.; Gluck, V. M.; Boschet, J. M.; Wong, A. H. K.; Engelke, P.
Abstract: background increase in emotional distress in response to the global outbreak of the sars cov 2 covid 19 pandemic have been reported so far little is known about how anxiety response in specific everyday public life situation have been affected method self reported anxiety in selected public situation which are relevant in the covid 19 pandemic wa investigated in non representative sample from the community n 352 and patient undergoing psychotherapy n 228 situational anxiety in each situation wa rated on a 5 point likert scale 0 no anxiety at all to 4 very strong anxiety situational anxiety during the pandemic wa compared with retrospectively reported situational anxiety before the pandemic direct change and with anxiety level in a matched sample assessed before the pandemic n 100 indirect change result in the community and patient sample indirect and direct change analysis demonstrated an increase in anxiety in relevant public situation but not in control situation average anxiety level during the pandemic were moderate but 5 28 of participant reported high to very high level of anxiety in specific situation interestingly the direct increase in anxiety level wa higher in the community sample patient reported higher anxiety level than the community sample before but not during the pandemic finally a higher increase in situational anxiety wa associated with a higher perceived danger of covid 19 a higher perceived likelihood of contracting covid 19 and stronger symptom of general anxiety and stress conclusion preliminary finding demonstrate an increase in anxiety in public situation during the covid 19 pandemic in a community and a patient sample moderate anxiety may facilitate compliance with public safety measure however high anxiety level may result in persistent impairment and should be monitored during the pandemic

Title: Error-Related Brain Activity in Patients With Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder and Unaffected First-Degree Relatives: Evidence for Protective Patterns
Authors: Grutzmann, R.; Kaufmann, C.; Wudarczyk, O. A.; Balzus, L.; Klawohn, J.; Riesel, A.; Bey, K.; Wagner, M.; Heinzel, S.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: background indicator of increased error monitoring are associated with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd a shown in electroencephalography and functional magnetic resonance imaging study a most study used strictly controlled sample excluding comorbidity and medication it remains open whether these finding extend to naturalistic setting thus we assessed error related brain activity in a large naturalistic ocd sample we also explored which activity pattern might qualify a vulnerability endophenotypes or protective factor for the disorder to this aim a sample of unaffected first degree relative of patient with ocd wa also included method participant 84 patient with ocd 99 healthy control participant and 37 unaffected first degree relative of patient with ocd completed a flanker task while blood oxygen level dependent response were measured with functional magnetic resonance imaging aberrant error related brain activity in patient and relative wa identified result patient with ocd showed increased error related activity in the supplementary motor area and within the default mode network specifically in the precuneus and postcentral gyrus unaffected first degree relative showed increased error related activity in the bilateral inferior frontal gyrus conclusion increased supplementary motor area and default mode network activity in patient with ocd replicates previous study and might indicate excessive error signal and increased self referential error processing increased activity of the inferior frontal gyrus in relative may reflect increased inhibition impaired response inhibition in ocd ha been demonstrated in several study and might contribute to impairment in suppressing compulsive action thus increased inferior frontal gyrus activity in the unaffected relative of patient with ocd may have contributed to protection from symptom development

Title: Real-life self-control conflicts in anorexia nervosa: An ecological momentary assessment investigation
Authors: Furtjes, S.; Seidel, M.; Diestel, S.; Wolff, M.; King, J. A.; Hellerhoff, I.; Bernadoni, F.; Gramatke, K.; Goschke, T.; Roessner, V.; Ehrlich, S.
Abstract: background individual with anorexia nervosa an are often thought to show heightened self control and increased ability to inhibit desire in addition to inhibitory self control antecedent focused strategy e g cognitive reconstrual the re evaluation of tempting situation might contribute to disorder maintenance and enable disorder typical maladaptive behavior method over a period of 14 day 40 acutely underweight young female patient with anorexia nervosa an and 40 healthy control hc participant reported their affect and behavior in self control situation via ecological momentary assessment during inpatient treatment an and everyday life hc data were analyzed via hierarchical analysis linear and logistic modeling result conflict strength had a significantly lower impact on self control success in an compared to hc while an and hc did not generally differ in the number or strength of self control conflict or in the percentage of self control success an reported self controlled behavior to be le dependent on conflict strength conclusion while patient with an were not generally more successful at self control they appeared to resolve self control conflict more effectively these finding suggest that the magnitude of self control conflict ha comparatively little impact on individual with an possibly due to the use of antecedent focused strategy if confirmed cognitive behavioral therapy might focus on and help patient to exploit these alternative self control strategy in the battle against their illness

Title: Taking a walk through time: aversive memory re-experiencing may be linked to spatio-temporal distance
Authors: Meyer, T.; Nelson, J.; Morina, N.
Abstract: background individual with posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd often report intrusive memory that appear to lack the appropriate spatio temporal context objective we examined whether focusing on the spatio temporal context of aversive autobiographical memory reduces negative emotion appraisal and re experiencing symptom method we recruited 109 healthy adult and had them rate emotionality vividness and re experiencing of an aversive autobiographical memory furthermore we assessed automatic association of idiosyncratic memory trigger with the concept past v now and self reported sense of memory closure and distancing to manipulate spatio temporal memory re organization the experimental group n 53 performed a lifeline exercise in virtual reality vr where participant symbolically placed memory trigger along a path representing their own personal life story the control group n 56 completed a non personalized vr task result we found a marked decrease in negative emotion negative appraisal and re experiencing in the following week but on average the lifeline exercise wa not superior to the control condition however those in the lifeline group with stronger trigger past association subsequently exhibited a more pronounced reduction in re experiencing also participant with a higher subjective sense of memory distancing reported le re experiencing conclusion the finding lend tentative support for theoretical assumption about ptsd but the potential causal role of automatic association with spatio temporal information remains to be clarified

Title: User Experience and Effects of an Individually Tailored Transdiagnostic Internet-Based and Mobile-Supported Intervention for Anxiety Disorders: Mixed-Methods Study
Authors: Weisel, K. K.; Zarski, A. C.; Berger, T.; Krieger, T.; Moser, C. T.; Schaub, M. P.; Gorlich, D.; Berking, M.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: background internet intervention have been shown to be effective in treating anxiety disorder most intervention to date focus on single disorder and disregard potential comorbidities objective the aim of this mixed method study wa to investigate feasibility user experience and effect of a newly developed individually tailored transdiagnostic guided internet intervention for anxiety disorder method this study is an uncontrolled within group baseline postintervention pilot trial with an embedded qualitative and quantitative process and effect evaluation in total 49 adult with anxiety disorder generalized anxiety disorder n 20 social phobia n 19 agoraphobia without panic n 12 panic with agoraphobia n 6 panic without agoraphobia n 4 subclinical depression n 41 received access to the 7 session intervention we examined motivation and expectation intervention use user experience impact and modification request qualitative data were assessed using semistructured interview and analyzed by qualitative content analysis quantitative outcome included symptom severity of anxiety and depression hamilton anxiety rating scale ham a quick item inventory of depressive symptomatology clinician rating qids c diagnostic status in clinical interview mini international neuropsychiatric interview mini and web based self report generalized anxiety disorder 7 gad 7 center for epidemiological study depression scale ce d beck anxiety inventory bai panic and agoraphobia scale pa social phobia scale sps patient health questionnaire 9 phq 9 at baseline and postassessment quantitative data wa analyzed by comparing within group mean expressed a cohen d result anxiety symptom severity ham a d 1 19 and depressive symptom qids c d 0 42 improved significantly and 54 21 39 no longer were diagnosed a having any anxiety disorder the main positive effect were the general improvement of disease burden and attentiveness to feeling and risk situation while the main negative effect experienced were lack of change in disease burden and symptom deterioration the most prevalent reason for participation were the advantage of online treatment symptom burden and openness toward online treatment helpful factor included support psychoeducation and practicing strategy in daily life the main hindering factor were too little individualization and being overwhelmed by the content and pace conclusion the intervention wa found to be feasible and result show preliminary data indicating potential efficacy for improving anxiety and depression the next step should be the evaluation within a randomized controlled trial concerning intervention development it wa found that future intervention should emphasize individualization even more in order to further improve the fit to individual characteristic preference and need

Title: Treating tinnitus distress via the Internet: A mixed methods approach of what makes patients seek help and stay motivated during Internet-based cognitive behavior therapy
Authors: Heinrich, S.; Rozental, A.; Carlbring, P.; Andersson, G.; Cotter, K.; Weise, C.
Abstract: background internet based cognitive behavioral therapy icbt ha proven to be an effective treatment in improving patient ability to cope with tinnitus however some patient prefer face to face therapy to icbt and a few study have shown considerable dropout rate if the treatment is not guided this render it important to identify factor that contribute to the commencement and continuation of icbt program aim because treatment motivation and expectation are important factor in psychological treatment the aim of our study wa to investigate what lead tinnitus patient to seek out icbt what help them to keep up with the treatment and what if any impact these factor have on dropout rate and treatment outcome method 112 tinnitus patient taking part in icbt for tinnitus responded to symptom related questionnaire at three point in time pre treatment post treatment and one year follow up and to a questionnaire consisting of open ended question about their treatment motivation and expectation before beginning treatment data were analyzed using qualitative content analysis and the result were used to divide the participant into group the treatment outcome of these group were compared using t test chi 2 test and both one factorial and mixed anova result four main category emerged a factor conducive to starting treatment 1 target participant wanted to address 2 circumstance that led to participation 3 attitude towards the treatment and 4 training feature participant identified six facilitator for continuing the treatment success training individual attitude hope evidence and support naming specific tinnitus associated problem a target wa associated with greater improvement from pre treatment to 1 year follow up describing an active involvement in the treatment wa related to increased improvement from post treatment to follow up conclusion there are several motivational factor that tinnitus patient consider relevant for beginning and continuing icbt particularly focusing on specific target that do not involve the tinnitus itself and encouraging participant to take an active role in treatment may increase treatment effectiveness however further hypothesis guided research is necessary to confirm our explorative result

Title: Is only one cognitive technique also effective? Results from a randomized controlled trial of two different versions of an internet-based cognitive behavioural intervention for post-traumatic stress disorder in Arabic-speaking countries
Authors: Bottche, M.; Wagner, B.; Vohringer, M.; Heinrich, M.; Stein, J.; Selmo, P.; Stammel, N.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: background internet based cognitive behavioural intervention seem to be effective for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd in arabic speaking country in the mena region however due to high prevalence rate of trauma related mental disorder in this region it is important to scale up existing internet based intervention in order to increase the number of client objective the aim of the study wa to examine whether a brief internet based intervention with one cognitive technique tf short 6 assignment result in the same ptsd symptom change and lower dropout compared to a longer intervention with two cognitive technique tf reg 10 assignment method a total of 224 arab participant 67 4 female m 25 3 year old with ptsd were randomly assigned to internet based cbt with either a tf reg protocol n 110 or a tf short protocol n 114 symptom of ptsd and secondary outcome anxiety depression somatic complaint quality of life were self assessed online at baseline and post treatment treatment associated change were estimated using multigroup latent difference score model result the overall ptsd score assessed with the pd decreased by about 15 point in both condition the between group difference tf reg v tf short at post assessment were non significant delta 0 29 p 896 d 0 02 95 ci 0 30 0 34 like the primary outcome all within group change for the secondary outcome throughout the intervention were statistically significant and all between group effect were non significant overall the dropout rate did not differ between the two condition chi2 1 n 175 0 83 p 364 conclusion the finding suggest that the shorter condition result in the same symptom change and dropout rate a the longer condition this highlight the potential of shorter more scalable internet based intervention in socially restricted and post conflict society clinicaltrialsgov id nct01508377

Title: Barriers to and Facilitators of Engaging With and Adhering to Guided Internet-Based Interventions for Depression Prevention and Reduction of Pain-Related Disability in Green Professions: Mixed Methods Study
Authors: Braun, L.; Freund, J.; Thielecke, J.; Baumeister, H.; Ebert, D. D.; Titzler, I.
Abstract: background internet based intervention ibis are effective for the prevention and treatment of mental disorder and are valuable addition for improving routine care however the uptake of and adherence to ibis are often limited to increase the actual use of ibis it is important to identify factor for engaging with and adhering to ibis objective we qualitatively evaluated barrier and facilitator regarding a portfolio of guided ibis in green profession farmer gardener and forester method interview participant were selected from 2 randomized controlled trial for either the prevention of depression prevention of depression in agriculturist prod a or the reduction of pain interference preventive acceptance and commitment therapy for chronic pain in agriculturist pact a in green profession the intervention group in prod a n 180 participated in an ibi program receiving access to 1 of 6 symptom tailored ibis the intervention group in pact a n 44 received access to an ibi for chronic pain overall 41 semistructured qualitative interview were conducted and transcribed verbatim barrier and facilitator were identified via inductive qualitative content analysis with 2 independent coder reaching almost perfect intercoder reliability cohen kappa 0 92 a quantitative follow up survey 30 41 73 wa conducted to validate the result subgroup analysis were performed based on intervention characteristic result we identified 42 barrier and 26 facilitator which we assigned to 4 superordinate category related to the intervention 20 barrier 17 facilitator work 4 barrier 1 facilitator individual 13 barrier 8 facilitator and technical 5 barrier 0 facilitator aspect key barrier identified by at least 50 of the interviewee were time consuming work life 29 40 73 and time consuming private life 23 40 58 similarly the most frequently identified facilitator included presence of motivation curiosity interest and perseverance 30 40 75 flexible time management at work 25 40 63 and support from family and friend 20 40 50 although agreement with barrier in the quantitative follow up survey wa rather low mean 24 sd 11 agreement with facilitator wa substantially higher mean 80 sd 13 difference in agreement rate were found particularly between intervention completers and noncompleters completers agreed significantly more often that perceived ibi success being motivated curious interested and perseverant and having a persisting level of psychological strain have been facilitating noncompleters agreed more often with experiencing the e coach contact a insufficient and technical problem a hindering for intervention completion conclusion based on these result strategy such a customization of module for more flexible and adaptive use video chat option with the e coach option to facilitate social support by family friend or other participant or using prompt to facilitate training completion can be derived these approach could be evaluated in further quantitative research design in term of their potential to enhance intervention use in this occupational group trial registration german clinical trial register drks00014000 http tinyurl com 3bukfr48 german clinical trial register drks0001461 http tinyurl com ebsn4sns

Title: Listen to Your Heart-Ecological Momentary Assessment of Interoceptive Accuracy, Awareness and Sensibility: A Pilot Study
Authors: Holler, I.; Stenzel, J. S.; Rath, D.; Forkmann, T.
Abstract: background interoception is a multi facetted phenomenon including interoceptive accuracy awareness and sensibility deficit in interoception have been associated with psychological distress however little is known about the course of interoception over time the present study aimed at examining interoception in an ecological momentary assessment ema setting method a seven day smartphone based ema wa conducted in a community sample of sixty one participant age m 24 1 sd 7 00 n 54 female 88 5 to control for potential practice effect of repeated assessment during the ema phase participant were randomly assigned to a control n 30 and an interoception n 31 group the latter wa assessed for interoceptive accuracy awareness and sensibility before and after the ema phase all participant were assessed for interoception in the laboratory result multilevel analysis revealed significant fluctuation for all three interoceptive facet around 50 of variance wa due to within person variability there were only practice effect for the subscale attention regulation measuring interoceptive sensibility conclusion the facet of interoception can be assessed in an ema setting repeated interoceptive assessment do not necessarily lead to an improvement of participant interoceptive ability it could be shown that all interoceptive facet fluctuate which should be considered in future research
Journal: Int J Environ Res Public Health

Title: Atypical Self-Focus Effect on Interoceptive Accuracy in Anorexia Nervosa
Authors: Pollatos, O.; Herbert, B. M.; Berberich, G.; Zaudig, M.; Krauseneck, T.; Tsakiris, M.
Abstract: background interoceptive ability are known to be affected in anorexia nervosa an previous study could show that private self focus can enhance interoceptive accuracy iacc in healthy participant a body dissatisfaction is high in an confrontation with bodily feature such a the own face might have a directly opposed effect in an whether patient with an can benefit from self focus in their iacc and whether this pattern change over the time course of cognitive behavioral therapy wa investigated in this study method fifteen patient with an from the psychosomatic clinic in windach were assessed three time in the time course of a standardized cognitive behavioral therapy they were compared to 15 control recruited from ulm university and tested in a comparable setting both group performed the heartbeat perception task assessing iacc under two condition either enhancing self or decreasing other self focused attention furthermore body dissatisfaction wa assessed by a subscale of the eating disorder ed inventory 2 result patient with an scored higher in iacc when watching others face a compared to one s own face while performing the heartbeat perception task the opposite pattern wa observed in control iacc remained reduced in an a compared to control in the time course of cognitive behavioral therapy while body dissatisfaction improved in an high body dissatisfaction wa related to poorer iacc in the self condition conclusion our finding suggest that using self focused attention reduces iacc in an while the opposite pattern wa observed in control confronting anorexic patient with bodily feature might increase body related avoidance and therefore decrease iacc the current study introduces a new perspective concerning the role of interoceptive process in an and generates further question regarding the therapeutic utility of method targeting self focus in the treatment of an

Title: The Effects of a Standardized Cognitive-Behavioural Therapy and an Additional Mindfulness-Based Training on Interoceptive Abilities in a Depressed Cohort
Authors: Karanassios, G.; Schultchen, D.; Mohrle, M.; Berberich, G.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: background interoceptive accuracy and sensibility are decreased in depressive sample however different study showed that cognitive behavioural therapy cbt and mindfulness intervention are promising approach to improve interoceptive ability based on these finding the study aim to investigate the pre post effect of cbt in a depressive sample additionally we examined the effect of mindfulness based stress reduction mbsr training in the context of cbt method sixty depressive patient were investigated over four week with two condition cbt v cbt mbsr further the change in interoceptive ability interoceptive accuracy and sensibility of the depressive patient were compared to baseline data of healthy control result the depressive patient showed significantly higher level of depression and lower mindfulness and interoceptive ability than healthy control the depressive sample showed a significant decrease in depressive symptom and increased mindfulness and interoceptive ability after cbt lastly depressive patient of the cbt mbsr condition did not differ from those who only received cbt in the level of depression mindfulness or interoceptive ability over the time course discussion this study demonstrates a positive effect of cbt on interoceptive ability in a depressive sample it is shown that the depressive sample did not profit from additional mindfulness training it can be concluded that cbt is an efficient treatment resulting in increased interoceptive ability unexpectedly the combination of cbt and mbsr ha no additional effect on these change future study should investigate the effect of mbsr a a stand alone therapy

Title: Sense it and use it: interoceptive accuracy and sensibility in suicide ideators
Authors: Forkmann, T.; Volz-Sidiropoulou, E.; Helbing, T.; Druke, B.; Mainz, V.; Rath, D.; Gauggel, S.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: background interoceptive deficit have been found to be associated with suicidal ideation and behavior however an objective measure of interoceptive accuracy ha not been investigated in participant with suicide ideation by now this study aimed at investigating interoceptive accuracy and sensibility in person with and without suicide ideation si while controlling for severity of depressive symptom method ninety five participant age m 34 8 sd 11 6 n 56 female 58 9 n 51 patient with a major depressive disorder and n 44 healthy participant were assessed for interoceptive accuracy and sensibility depression and si result twenty five participant 26 reported si they showed interoceptive accuracy comparable to person without si t 81 p 422 but significantly lower interoceptive sensibility after controlling for severity of depressive symptom in a hierarchical linear regression analysis most association between interoceptive sensibility and si disappeared conclusion result suggest that suicide ideators do not lack the ability to perceive their own bodily signal but they feel le able to use them in a way that is advantageous for them difference between suicide ideators and non ideators appear to be largely driven by depressive symptom depression bias

Title: A comparison of interpreters' wellbeing and work-related characteristics in the care of refugees across different work settings
Authors: Geiling, A.; Bottche, M.; Knaevelsrud, C.; Stammel, N.
Abstract: background interpreter in the care of refugee work in various different setting qualitative study suggest that interpreter are confronted with a variety of demand depending on the context in which they work which may in turn influence their wellbeing to date no larger scale study ha investigated difference between work setting regarding interpreter work related characteristic or wellbeing objective the aim of this study wa to compare the work related characteristic and possible change in the wellbeing of interpreter between four main work setting psychotherapy counselling medical setting and authority in the care of refugee method interpreter in refugee care were recruited for a nationwide online survey in germany with two measurement time point participant provided socio demographic data and answered question about the working condition in their respective main work setting in addition psychological distress brief symptom inventory bsi 18 work related exhaustion copenhagen burnout inventory cbi and compassion satisfaction professional quality of life proqol were assessed result overall 158 interpreter were included at t1 of whom 63 were also included at t2 significantly more traumatic content wa interpreted in counselling setting and psychotherapy than in medical and authority setting h 3 26 09 p 001 the highest proportion of interpreter with an interpreting degree worked in the authority setting fisher s exact test p 002 significant difference between the four setting were found for psychological distress kruskal wallis test h 3 12 02 p 01 and work related exhaustion kruskal wallis test h 3 8 10 p 04 but not for compassion satisfaction conclusion the presented result indicate difference regarding working condition psychological distress and work related exhaustion between different work setting of interpreter future study may explore each setting in greater detail and include a larger sample size to reach a better understanding of the relationship between setting specific challenge and interpreter wellbeing

Title: Seeing in the Mind's eye: Imagery rescripting for patients with body dysmorphic disorder. A single case series
Authors: Ritter, V.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: background intrusive image of appearance play an important role in the maintenance of body dysmorphic disorder bdd and are often linked to negative autobiographical experience however to date there is no study examining the use and efficacy of imagery rescripting in bdd method this study investigated imagery rescripting in six patient with bdd using a single case series a b design the intervention consisted of two treatment session t1 t2 bdd and depressive symptom were evaluated prior to t1 post t2 and two week after intervention fu using the yale brown obsessive compulsive scale for bdd bdd ybocs the body dysmorphic symptom inventory and the beck depression inventory result at post treatment significant reduction in negative affect distress vividness and encapsulated belief associated with image and memory a well a an increased control were observed for five of six patient these were maintained or decreased at two week follow up score on the bdd ybocs indicated a significant 26 improvement in bdd severity at follow up for the whole group considering response a a 30 reduction in bdd ybocs score four of six patient were classified a treatment responder at follow up significant improvement in bdd and depressive symptom were observed for the whole group limitation the small sample size and the lack of a control group limit the generalizability of our result conclusion the finding indicate the potential efficacy of imagery rescripting and highlight the need for further controlled trial imagery rescripting should be considered a a treatment technique within the cognitive framework of bdd

Title: Drinking to ease the burden: a cross-sectional study on trauma, alcohol abuse and psychopathology in a post-conflict context
Authors: Ertl, V.; Saile, R.; Neuner, F.; Catani, C.
Abstract: background it is likely that alcohol use and abuse increase during and after violent conflict the most prominent explanation of this phenomenon ha been referred to a self medication hypothesis it predicts that psychotropic substance are consumed to deal with conflict related psychic strain and trauma in northern uganda a region that ha been affected by a devastating civil war and is characterized by high level of alcohol abuse we examined the association between war trauma childhood maltreatment and problem related to alcohol use deducing from the self medication hypothesis we assumed alcohol consumption moderate the relationship between trauma exposure and psychopathology method a cross sectional epidemiological survey targeting war affected family in post conflict northern uganda included data of male n 304 and female n 365 guardian we used standardized questionnaire in an interview format to collect data on the guardian socio demography trauma exposure alcohol consumption and symptom of alcohol abuse ptsd and depression result symptom of current alcohol use disorder were present in 46 of the male and 1 of the female respondent a multiple regression model revealed the unique contribution of emotional abuse in the family of origin and trauma experienced outside the family context in the prediction of men s alcohol related symptom we found that alcohol consumption moderated the dose effect relationship between trauma exposure and symptom of depression and ptsd significant interaction indicated that men who reported more alcohol related problem experienced le increase in symptom of ptsd and depression with increasing trauma exposure conclusion the gradual attenuation of the dose effect the more alcohol related problem were reported is consistent with the self medication hypothesis hence the functionality of alcohol consumption ha to be considered when designing and implementing addiction treatment in post conflict context

Title: The significance of job-anxiety in a working population
Authors: Muschalla, B.; Heldmann, M.; Fay, D.
Abstract: background job anxiety a distinguished from trait anxiety is associated with long term sickness absence the prevalence of job anxiety within a working population is not known identifying individual who would benefit from intervention might be useful aim to investigate job anxiety in employee not undergoing treatment for mental health illness firstly by assessing the level of job anxiety and work related avoidance tendency in a working sample and secondly by testing whether job anxiety is distinguishable from trait anxiety method cross sectional survey of a convenience sample obtained through personal contact distribution employee from different professional setting completed an anonymous questionnaire and provided information on their employment status the state trait anxiety inventory stai t wa used to measure trait anxiety and the job anxiety scale jas wa used to a job state anxiety result there wa a 69 response rate 240 response 188 response were available for analysis of whom 62 were woman there were no employee with high trait anxiety ten employee 5 reported increased job anxiety and of these nine employee reported high tendency of avoidance and workplace absence avoidance wa most often accompanied by the comorbid job anxiety job related social anxiety fear of change at work and fear of existence anticipatory and conditioned job anxiety and panic symptom conclusion in this sample self reported job anxiety appeared a a specific type of anxiety a opposed to trait anxiety in the workplace job anxiety can present a job avoidance and sickness absence and should be distinguished from trait anxiety in practice employer and occupational health practitioner should be aware of those employee prone to sickness absence

Title: Tracking Stress, Mental Health, and Resilience Factors in Medical Students Before, During, and After a Stress-Inducing Exam Period: Protocol and Proof-of-Principle Analyses for the RESIST Cohort Study
Authors: Fritz, J.; Stochl, J.; Kievit, R. A.; van Harmelen, A. L.; Wilkinson, P. O.
Abstract: background knowledge of mental distress and resilience factor over the time span from before to after a stressor is important to be able to leverage the most promising resilience factor and promote mental health at the right time to shed light on this topic we designed the resist resilience study study in which we assessed medical student before during and after their yearly exam period exam time is generally a period of notable stress among medical student and it ha been suggested that exam time trigger mental distress objective in this paper we aim to describe the study protocol and to examine whether the exam period indeed induces higher perceived stress and mental distress we also aim to explore whether perceived stress and mental distress coevolve in response to exam method resist is a cohort study in which exam stress function a a within subject natural stress manipulation in this paper we outline the sample n 451 procedure assessed measure including demographic perceived stress mental distress 13 resilience factor and adversity and ethical consideration moreover we conducted a series of latent growth model and bivariate latent change score model to analyze perceived stress and mental distress change over the 3 time point result we found that perceived stress and mental distress increased from the time before the exam to the exam period and decreased after the exam to a lower level than before the exam our finding further suggest that higher mental distress before exam increased the risk of developing more perceived stress during exam higher perceived stress during exam in turn increased the risk of experiencing a le successful or quick recovery of mental distress after exam conclusion a expected the exam period caused a temporary increase in perceived stress and mental distress therefore the resist study lends itself well to exploring resilience factor in response to naturally occurring exam stress such knowledge will eventually help researcher to find out which resilience factor lend themselves best a prevention target and which lend themselves best a treatment target for the mitigation of mental health problem that are triggered or accelerated by natural exam stress the finding from the resist study may therefore inform student support service mental health service and resilience theory

Title: Wealth, justice and freedom: Objective and subjective measures predicting poor mental health in a study across eight countries
Authors: Scholten, S.; Velten, J.; Neher, T.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background macro level factor mf such a wealth justice and freedom measured with objective country level indicator objective mf for instance the gross domestic product gdp have been investigated in relation to health and well being but rarely in connection with depression anxiety and stress subsumed a poor mental health also a combination of different objective mf and of how individual perceive those mf subjective mf ha not been taken into consideration in the present study we combined subjective and objective measure of wealth justice and freedom and examined their relationship with poor mental health method population based interview were conducted in france germany poland russia spain sweden u k and u s a n approximately 1000 per country gdp gini coefficient justice index and freedom index were used a objective mf whereas subjective mf were perceived wealth justice and freedom measured at the individual level poor mental health wa assessed a a combination of symptom of depression anxiety and stress result in a random intercept model gini coefficient and freedom index were significant positive country level and perceived wealth justice and freedom significant negative individual level predictor of symptom of poor mental health conclusion multiple subjective and objective mf should be combined to a the macrosystem s relationship with poor mental health more precisely the relationship between mf and poor mental health indicates that the macrosystem should be taken into account a relevant context for mental health problem too

Title: Effectiveness of guided internet-based interventions in the indicated prevention of depression in green professions (PROD-A): Results of a pragmatic randomized controlled trial
Authors: Braun, L.; Titzler, I.; Terhorst, Y.; Freund, J.; Thielecke, J.; Ebert, D. D.; Baumeister, H.
Abstract: background major depressive disorder mdd ha a major impact on public health reduction of depression burden in general population is of greatest importance and might be achieved by implementation of depression prevention measure into routine care we evaluate an online prevention measure a part of a national project aiming to reduce depression in the occupational group of green profession method this two armed pragmatic rct n 360 evaluates the effectiveness of a tailored internet based intervention imi program compared to enhanced treatment a usual the imi program entailed access to one of six guided imis each focusing on different symptom area depressive mood with optional comorbid diabetes perceived stress insomnia panic and agoraphobia and harmful alcohol consumption eligible were entrepreneur spouse family member and pensioner in green profession with adequate insurance status and at least subthreshold depression phq 5 primary outcome wa depressive symptom severity qids sr16 at 9 week post treatment t1 various secondary outcome were assessed at t1 result a small effect of depression reduction d 0 28 95 ci 0 50 to 0 07 wa found at t1 favouring the imi program beta 0 22 95 ci 0 41 to 0 02 p 033 categorical analysis indicated a reduced risk of potential mdd with nntb 28 11 adherence to the imi program at t1 wa exceptionally low limitation result are limited to green profession and representativeness might be restricted by self selection of participant conclusion depression burden in green profession can be reduced by this online prevention measure yet short term effectiveness is restricted by low adherence rate trial registration german clinical trial registration drks00014000 registered 09 april 2018

Title: Cognitive and affective trait and state factors influencing the long-term symptom course in remitted depressed patients
Authors: Timm, C.; Ubl, B.; Zamoscik, V.; Ebner-Priemer, U.; Reinhard, I.; Huffziger, S.; Kirsch, P.; Kuehner, C.
Abstract: background major depressive disorder mdd is characterized by a high risk for relapse and chronic development clinical characteristic such a residual symptom have been shown to negatively affect the long term course of mdd however it is unclear so far how trait repetitive negative thinking rnt a well a cognitive and affective momentary state the latter experienced during daily life affect the long term course of mdd method we followed up 57 remitted depressed rmdd individual six t2 and 36 t3 month after baseline clinical outcome were time to relapse time spent with significant symptom a a marker of chronicity and level of depressive symptom at t2 and t3 predictor assessed at baseline included residual symptom and trait rnt furthermore momentary daily life affect and momentary rumination and their variation over the day were assessed at baseline using ambulatory assessment aa result in multiple model residual symptom and instability of daily life affect at baseline independently predicted a faster time to relapse while chronicity wa significantly predicted by trait rnt multilevel model revealed that depressive symptom level during follow up were predicted by baseline residual symptom level and by instability of daily life rumination both instability feature were linked to a higher number of anamnestic mdd episode conclusion our finding indicate that trait rnt but also affective and cognitive process during daily life impact the longer term course of mdd future longitudinal research on the role of respective aa phenotype a potential transdiagnostic course modifier is warranted

Title: Barriers and Facilitators for Referrals of Primary Care Patients to Blended Internet-Based Psychotherapy for Depression: Mixed Methods Study of General Practitioners' Views
Authors: Titzler, I.; Berking, M.; Schlicker, S.; Riper, H.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: background major depressive disorder mdd is highly prevalent and often managed by general practitioner gps gps mostly prescribe medication and show low referral rate to psychotherapy many patient remain untreated blended psychotherapy bpt combine internet based intervention with face to face psychotherapy and could increase treatment access and availability effectively implementing bpt in routine care requires an understanding of professional user perspective and behavior objective this study aim to identify barrier and facilitator perceived by gps in referring patient to bpt explanation for variation in referral rate were examined method semistructured interview were conducted with 12 of 110 gps participating in a german randomized controlled trial rct to investigate barrier to and facilitator for referral to bpt for mdd 10 web based module app based assessment and 6 face to face session the interview guide wa based on the theoretical domain framework the interview were audio recorded and transcribed verbatim and the qualitative content wa analyzed by 2 independent coder intercoder agreement k 0 71 a follow up survey with 12 interviewed gps enabled the validation of emergent theme the difference in the barrier and facilitator identified between group with different characteristic eg gps with high or low referral rate were described correlation between referral and characteristic self rated competence and experience managing depression of the rct gps n 76 were conducted result gps referred few patient to bpt although varied in their referral rate and interviewee referred more than twice a many patient a rct gps interview gps mean 6 34 sd 9 42 rct gps mean 2 65 sd 3 92 a negative correlation wa found between gps referral and their self rated pharmacotherapeutic competence r 73 0 31 p 001 the qualitative finding revealed a total of 19 barrier b and 29 facilitator f at the level of gp b 4 and f 11 patient b 11 and f 9 gp practice b 1 and f 3 and sociopolitical circumstance b 3 and f 6 key barrier stated by all interviewed gps included little knowledge about internet based intervention and patient lack of familiarity with technology internet medium number of statement each k 22 key facilitator were perceived patient suitability e g well educated young k 22 and no conflict with gp s role k 16 the follow up survey showed a very high agreement rate of at least 75 for 71 34 48 of the identified theme descriptive finding indicated difference between gps with low and high referral rate in term of which and how many barrier low mean 9 75 sd 1 83 high mean 10 50 sd 2 38 and facilitator low mean 18 25 sd 4 13 high mean 21 00 sd 3 92 they mentioned conclusion this study provides insight into factor influencing gps referral to bpt a gatekeeper to depression care barrier and facilitator should be considered when designing implementation strategy to enhance referral rate the finding should be interpreted with care because of the small and self selected sample and low response rate

Title: Sustainability of effects and secondary long-term outcomes: One-year follow-up of a cluster-randomized controlled trial to prevent maltreatment in institutional care
Authors: Hecker, T.; Mkinga, G.; Hartmann, E.; Nkuba, M.; Hermenau, K.
Abstract: background many orphan in east africa are living in institutional care facility where they experience poor quality of care and ongoing maltreatment we report on the extension of a cluster randomized controlled trial aiming to replicate and show sustainability of previous found effect and to discover long term effect of the intervention interaction competency with child for caregiver icc c 12 month after the intervention s conclusion method conducting a robust 2x3 analysis of variance we investigated the change over time in the waitlist orphanage n 75 62 7 female mage 37 63 year sdage 11 81 which participated in the intervention after first follow up and in the initial intervention orphanage n 81 61 7 female mage 38 73 year sdage 11 94 result the caregiver in the waitlist orphanage reported le reported level of maltreatment d 0 09 fewer positive attitude towards violent discipline d 0 44 and increased childcare knowledge d 1 26 three month after intervention replicating our finding of the initial intervention condition in addition these effect were maintained in the intervention orphanage 12 month post intervention furthermore we found long term improvement in negative caregiver child relationship d 0 83 caregiver stress level d 0 98 and their mental health problem d 0 61 conclusion the replication and maintenance of the intervention effect and first hint to additional long term effect substantiates the effectiveness of icc c a long a alternative care cannot be provided for all child in need brief caregiver training can make an important contribution to enlarge the opportunity for many child trial registration clinicaltrials gov nct03594617 registered on 20 july 2018

Title: Individual changes in stress, depression, anxiety, pathological worry, posttraumatic stress, and health anxiety from before to during the COVID-19 pandemic in adults from Southeastern Germany
Authors: Wechsler, T. F.; Schmidmeier, M.; Biehl, S.; Gerczuk, J.; Guerrero-Cerda, F. M.; Muhlberger, A.
Abstract: background many study have previously compared the prevalence or sample mean of distress and mental health problem from before to during the covid 19 pandemic while result on change at the individual level and regarding multiple outcome measure are demanded method this online study investigated individual change in stress and mental health from before the covid 19 pandemic to the first lockdown in adult from southeastern germany this region wa selected a it wa where sars cov 2 wa first documented in germany and also due to the implementation of strict stay at home order and social contact prohibition from april 10 27 2020 we collected state measure and their clinical relevance for the subareas of perceived stress worry tension joy and demand we also collected information regarding the following mental health problem depression anxiety pathological worry posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd and health anxiety a well a retrospective measure of how participant felt they have changed in comparison to before the pandemic ranging from worse to better result the analytical sample comprised 396 adult participant on average participant experienced increase in worry tension and lack of joy and increase in mental health problem but a decrease in demand perceived increase in symptom of depression 26 0 and ptsd 25 5 were significantly more frequent than in symptom of anxiety particularly acute fear and panic 5 6 pathological worry 9 8 and health anxiety 7 3 p 001 one per 10 participant 10 4 reported an increase in depressive symptom and nearly two per 10 18 4 an increase in ptsd symptom and additionally showed a clinically relevant symptom strain during lockdown interestingly mainly non specific ptsd symptom associated with a general stress reaction were experienced to be increased conclusion the finding suggest a dissociation of perceived change in subareas of stress and mental health with a particular experience of increase in depressive and general stress symptom and a decrease in external demand this point to a need for a more differentiated view on the impact of the covid 19 pandemic on stress and mental health and for targeted intervention for mental health problem arising frequently during the pandemic

Title: Intergenerational Transmission of Internalizing Behavior: The Role of Maternal Psychopathology, Child Responsiveness and Maternal Attachment Style Insecurity
Authors: Reck, C.; Nonnenmacher, N.; Zietlow, A. L.
Abstract: background maternal depression and anxiety disorder are risk factor for the development of internalizing disorder in offspring maternal attachment ha been discussed a one factor accounting
