for transmission the aim of this study wa to investigate child internalizing behavior at preschool age on a symptomatic and behavioral level and possible link to maternal mental health over time and maternal attachment style insecurity in a sample of postpartum depressed and anxious mother sampling and method child internalizing behavior at preschool age wa rated by the child behavior checklist cbcl the caregiver teacher report form c trf and during a mother child free play situation we focused on child responsiveness a it ha been linked to child internalizing behavior maternal attachment style insecurity wa tested to mediate the link between maternal mental health assessed postpartum and at preschool age with the structured clinical interview for dsm iv axis i disorder scid i and child internalizing behavior child responsiveness of the overall sample n 58 28 woman were diagnosed with postpartum depression and or anxiety disorder according to dsm iv and 30 were healthy control data were collected 3 9 month after delivery and at preschool age mean 4 6 year result at preschool age child of postpartum depressed and anxious mother were rated significantly higher on child internalizing behavior by mother father and additional caregiver compared to the control group child internalizing behavior rated by mother wa influenced by current psychiatric symptom maternal attachment style insecurity did not mediate this link during interaction child in the clinical group displayed significantly le child responsiveness compared to the control group maternal attachment style insecurity mediated the relationship between maternal mental health over time and child responsiveness conclusion the result emphasize the need for intervention focusing on mother child interaction and maternal attachment

Title: Examining differences in cognitive and affective theory of mind between persons with high and low extent of somatic symptoms: an experimental study
Authors: Preis, M. A.; Golm, D.; Kroner-Herwig, B.; Barke, A.
Abstract: background medically unexplained somatic symptom are common associated with disability and strongly related to depression and anxiety disorder one interesting but to date rarely tested hypothesis is that deficit in both theory of mind tom and emotional awareness may undergird the phenomenon of somatization this study sought to investigate whether or not difference in tom functioning and self reported emotional awareness are associated with somatic symptom in a sample from the general population method the sample consisted of 50 healthy participant 37 female 13 male aged between 22 and 64 year 46 8 11 7 of whom 29 reported a high extent of somatic symptom hsr whereas 21 reported a low extent of somatic symptom lsr based on the 30 highest and lowest percentile of the symptom list norm the participant affective and cognitive tom were assessed with two experimental paradigm by experimenter who were blind to the participant group membership in addition self report regarding emotional awareness alexithymia depressive and anxiety symptom and current affect were collected result in the experimental task hsr showed lower affective tom than lsr but the group did not differ in cognitive tom although hsr reported lower emotional awareness than lsr in the self report measure this group difference vanished when we controlled for anxiety and depression depression anxiety emotional awareness and alexithymia were correlated positively conclusion the data supported the hypothesis that deficit in affective tom are related to somatic symptom neither cognitive tom nor self reported emotional awareness were associated with somatic symptom self reported emotional awareness alexithymia and symptom of depression and anxiety shared a considerable amount of variance

Title: Effectiveness of an Internet- and App-Based Intervention for College Students With Elevated Stress: Randomized Controlled Trial
Authors: Harrer, M.; Adam, S. H.; Fleischmann, R. J.; Baumeister, H.; Auerbach, R.; Bruffaerts, R.; Cuijpers, P.; Kessler, R. C.; Berking, M.; Lehr, D.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: background mental health problem are highly prevalent among college student most student with poor mental health however do not receive professional help internet based self help format may increase the utilization of treatment objective the aim of this randomized controlled trial wa to evaluate the efficacy of an internet based app supported stress management intervention for college student method college student n 150 with elevated level of stress perceived stress scale 4 item version p 4 8 were randomly assigned to either an internet and mobile based stress intervention group with feedback on demand or a waitlist control group self report data were assessed at baseline posttreatment 7 week and 3 month follow up the primary outcome wa perceived stress posttreatment p 4 secondary outcome included mental health outcome modifiable risk and protective factor and college related outcome subgroup analysis were conducted in student with clinically relevant symptom of depression center for epidemiological study depression scale 17 result a total of 106 participant 76 8 indicated that they were first time help seeker and 77 3 intervention group 58 75 waitlist control group 58 75 showed clinically relevant depressive symptom at baseline finding indicated significant effect of the intervention compared with the waitlist control group for stress d 0 69 95 ci 0 36 1 02 anxiety d 0 76 95 ci 0 43 1 09 depression d 0 63 95 ci 0 30 0 96 college related productivity d 0 33 95 ci 0 01 0 65 academic work impairment d 0 34 95 ci 0 01 0 66 and other outcome after 7 week posttreatment response rate for stress symptom were significantly higher for the intervention group 69 52 75 compared with the waitlist control group 35 26 75 p 001 number needed to treat 2 89 95 ci 2 01 5 08 at posttest 7 week effect were sustained at 3 month follow up and similar finding emerged in student with symptom of depression conclusion internet and mobile based intervention could be an effective and cost effective approach to reduce consequence of college related stress and might potentially attract student with clinically relevant depression who would not otherwise seek help trial registration german clinical trial register drks00010212 http www drks de drks_web navigate do navigationid trial html trial_id drks00010212 archived by webcite at http www webcitation org 6w55ewhjd

Title: Work-Anxiety Rather Than Cognitive Performance Contributes to Workability Decisions in Patients With Mental Disorders
Authors: Muschalla, B.
Abstract: background mental workability decision must be based on information on person s symptom load cognitive performance and workplace condition this investigation explores in which way these factor contribute to workability in person with common mental disorder cmds method one thousand five hundred seventy cmd patient underwent multimodal medical diagnostic participant filled in questionnaire on work phobic anxiety and general mental symptom load they were also investigated concerning their cognitive performance sick leave duration workplace problem and subjective workability were assessed physician decision on the person workability fit or unfit for work wa given 5 week later result negative workability perception long previous sick leave duration and high work phobic anxiety explained unfitness for work whereas general symptom load and general cognitive performance did not conclusion work directed diagnostics and intervention must address work phobic anxiety and subjective workability perception

Title: Verbal learning impairment in adolescents with methamphetamine use disorder: a cross-sectional study
Authors: Basedow, L. A.; Kuitunen-Paul, S.; Wiedmann, M. F.; Ehrlich, S.; Roessner, V.; Golub, Y.
Abstract: background methamphetamine ma use ha been shown to be associated with deficit in impulsivity verbal learning and working memory additionally methamphetamine use disorder mud is related to various brain change especially in adolescent user who might be more vulnerable to detrimental effect on brain development however little is known about the relationship between adolescent ma use and cognitive impairment this cross sectional study aim to explore how the presence of a mud in adolescent is related to impairment of verbal memory inhibition and alertness method n 18 psychiatric outpatient with mud were matched in term of depressivity age and gender to n 18 adolescent with other substance use disorder suds a well a n 18 control without suds we compared these three group on the verbal learning and memory task vlmt and the alertness and go nogo subtests of the test of attentional performance tap additionally spearman s rank order correlation coefficient were calculated to investigate whether cognitive functioning wa directly associated with frequency of past year ma use result the three group differed significantly in their verbal learning performance h 2 11 7 p 003 eta p 2 19 but not in short term memory inhibition cued recall or alertness post hoc test revealed significant difference in verbal learning between the ma using group and the control group without a sud u 56 5 p 001 eta p 2 31 frequency of past year ma use correlated negatively with short term memory rho 25 p 01 and verbal learning rho 41 p 01 no other cognitive variable correlated significantly with ma use frequency significant p value were considered significant after bonferroni correction conclusion adolescent mud outpatient with regular ma use show specific impairment in verbal learning performance but not in other basal cognitive function when compared to adolescent without a mud verbal learning and short term memory performance is negatively associated with the frequency of ma use future research should apply longitudinal design to investigate long term effect of methamphetamine and reversibility of these effect on cognitive functioning

Title: The Return of Fear: Variation of the Serotonin Transporter Gene Predicts Outcome of a Highly Standardized Exposure-Based One-Session Fear Treatment
Authors: Wannemuller, A.; Moser, D.; Kumsta, R.; Johren, H. P.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background methodological problem of existing research such a the application of unstandardized treatment in heterogeneous sample ha hampered clear conclusion about the extent and direction to which allelic variation of the serotonin transporter gene linked polymorphic region 5 httlpr is associated with a differential response to psychological treatment the present study aimed to investigate the effect of the 5 httlpr genotype on treatment outcome under highly standardized environmental condition method we treated 222 medication free adult highly fearful of spider dental surgery or blood injury and injection with a highly standardized exposure based 1 session treatment and genotyped them for the 5 httlpr participant subjective fear wa assessed before immediately after treatment and at 7 month of follow up result there were no difference between 5 httlpr genotype in treatment outcome effect at the immediate posttreatment assessment however we observed a highly significant genotype x treatment effect p 0 004 at the 7 month follow up fear level of homozygous s allele carrier differed from those heterozygous p 0 026 and homozygous p 0 012 for the l allele compared to posttreatment assessment ll allele carrier exhibited a further fear decrease at the follow up assessment in contrast s allele carrier displayed a strong return of fear conclusion result suggest that genetic variation of the serotonin transporter is associated with differential stability of inhibitory learning process potentially reflecting heightened susceptibility for context related process that facilitate a return of fear in s allele carrier if replicated result suggest the 5 httlpr might represent a biomarker for the long term outcome of brief exposure based fear treatment and might inform genotype based selection of psychotherapeutic intervention

Title: Action inhibition in individuals with high obsessive-compulsive trait of incompleteness: An ERP study
Authors: Dominke, C.; Graham-Schmidt, K.; Gentsch, A.; Schutz-Bosbach, S.
Abstract: background missing action completion signal are assumed to trigger repetitive behavior and feeling of the action not being right this proposal is based mostly on individual s self report here we investigated the influence of experimentally manipulated action completion experience and the obsessive compulsive oc trait of incompleteness on behavioral and neurophysiological measure of action inhibition method action completion wa manipulated in an adapted go nogo task and oc trait incompleteness wa assessed in healthy participant more commission error and faster response were expected after missing action completion especially for individual with high oc trait incompleteness the inhibition related event related potential erps n200 and p300 were also measured result high oc trait incompleteness led to more error following omitted and faster response during commission error following incongruent outcome furthermore lower n200 wa associated with worse response inhibition and high oc trait incompleteness wa associated with reduced n200 but not reduced p300 amplitude these finding provide evidence that trait like feeling of incompleteness may underlie maladaptive action repetition and impaired inhibitory control a observed in ocd

Title: Alcohol-related interpretation bias in alcohol-dependent patients
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Pawelczak, S.; Rinck, M.; Lindenmeyer, J.; Souren, P.; Wiers, R. W.; Becker, E. S.
Abstract: background model of addictive behavior postulate that implicit alcohol related memory association and biased interpretation process contribute to the development and maintenance of alcohol misuse and abuse the present study examined whether alcohol dependent patient ap show an alcohol related interpretation bias second the relationship between the interpretation bias and level of harmful drinking wa investigated method the sample included 125 clinically diagnosed ap and 69 clinically diagnosed control patient cp who had either a mood or an anxiety disorder participant completed a booklet containing 12 open ended ambiguous scenario seven scenario were alcohol relevant and 5 were emotionally relevant that is panic or depression relevant participant were asked to read each scenario and to generate a continuation in addition the alcohol use disorder identification test audit and beck depression inventory were administered result logistic multivariate multilevel analysis revealed that ap probability of generating an alcohol related continuation on all 3 scenario type wa higher than that of cp moreover alcohol related interpretation bias were positively associated with level of harmful drinking i e audit score conclusion these finding are the first to show that ap show an alcohol related interpretation bias which generalizes to other ambiguous emotionally relevant context and therefore advance our understanding of the role of implicit biased alcohol related memory association and interpretation process

Title: Neural correlates of fear conditioning are associated with treatment-outcomes to behavioral exposure in spider phobia - Evidence from magnetoencephalography
Authors: Roesmann, K.; Toelle, J.; Leehr, E. J.; Wessing, I.; Bohnlein, J.; Seeger, F.; Schwarzmeier, H.; Siminski, N.; Herrmann, M. J.; Dannlowski, U.; Lueken, U.; Klucken, T.; Straube, T.; Junghofer, M.
Abstract: background model of anxiety disorder and the rationale of exposure therapy et are grounded on classical fear conditioning yet it is unclear whether lower fear rating of conditioned safety versus threat cue and corresponding neural marker of safety learning and or fear inhibition assessed before treatment would predict better outcome of behavioral exposure method sixty six patient with spider phobia completed pre treatment clinical and experimental fear conditioning assessment one session of virtual reality et a post treatment clinical assessment and a 6 month follow up assessment tilted gabor grating served a conditioned stimulus c that were either paired c or remained unpaired c with an aversive phobia related and phobia unrelated unconditioned stimulus ucs c c difference in fear rating and magnetoencephalographic event related field erfs were related to percentual symptom reduction from pre to post treatment a assessed via spider phobia questionnaire spq behavioral avoidance test bat and remission status at 6 month follow up result we observed no association between pre treatment c c difference in fear rating and any treatment outcome c c difference in source estimation of erfs revealed that higher c activity in bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc wa related with spq and bat reduction association between c c difference and treatment outcome were also observed in left ventromedial prefrontal cortex vmpfc region which additionally revealed association with the follow up remission status conclusion result provide initial evidence that neural pre treatment c c difference may hold predictive information regarding outcome of behavioral exposure our finding highlight a key role of neural response to safety cue with potentially inhibitory effect on affect generating structure during fear conditioning

Title: Meta-analysis of interventions for posttraumatic stress disorder and depression in adult survivors of mass violence in low- and middle-income countries
Authors: Morina, N.; Malek, M.; Nickerson, A.; Bryant, R. A.
Abstract: background most survivor of mass violence live in low and middle income country lmics we conducted a meta analysis of randomized controlled psychotherapy trial for adult posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd and or depression in lmics method we included 18 clinical trial 3 058 participant in which 25 and 18 treatment arm measured symptom of ptsd and depression respectively result active treatment for ptsd yielded a large aggregated pre post effect size g 1 29 95 ci 0 99 1 59 and a small to medium effect size at posttreatment when compared to control condition g 0 39 95 ci 0 24 0 55 effect size were similar for pretreatment versus follow up g 1 75 95 ci 1 17 2 32 and in comparison to waitlist at follow up g 0 93 95 ci 0 56 1 31 active treatment for depression produced large pre post g 1 28 95 ci 0 96 1 61 and controlled effect size posttreatment comparison to control condition g 0 86 95 ci 0 54 1 18 conclusion our finding suggest that psychological intervention can effectively reduce symptom of ptsd and depression in lmics future research need to focus on cost effective intervention that are likely to be disseminated to the large number of war survivor in lmics

Title: Dropout among patients in qualified alcohol detoxification treatment: the effect of treatment motivation is moderated by Trauma Load
Authors: Odenwald, M.; Semrau, P.
Abstract: background motivation to change ha been proposed a a prerequisite for behavioral change although empirical result are contradictory traumatic experience are frequently found amongst patient in alcohol treatment but this ha not been systematically studied in term of effect on treatment outcome this study aimed to clarify whether individual trauma load explains some of the inconsistency between motivation to change and behavioral change method over the course of two month in 2009 55 patient admitted to an alcohol detoxification unit of a psychiatric hospital were enrolled in this study at treatment entry we assessed lifetime trauma load and motivation to change mode of discharge wa taken from patient file following therapy we tested whether trauma load moderate the effect of motivation to change on dropout from alcohol detoxification using multivariate method result 55 4 dropped out of detoxification treatment while 44 6 completed the treatment age gender and day in treatment did not differ between completers and dropout patient who dropped out reported more traumatic event type on average than completers treatment completers had higher score in the urica subscale maintenance multivariate method confirmed the moderator effect of trauma load among participant with high trauma load treatment completion wa related to higher maintenance score at treatment entry this wa not true among patient with low trauma load conclusion we found evidence that the effect of motivation to change on detoxification treatment completion is moderated by trauma load among patient with low trauma load motivation to change is not relevant for treatment completion among highly burdened patient however who a priori have a greater risk of dropping out a high motivation to change might make the difference this finding justifies targeted and specific intervention for highly burdened alcohol patient to increase their motivation to change

Title: Multidisciplinary treatment for traumatized refugees in a naturalistic setting: symptom courses and predictors
Authors: Stammel, N.; Knaevelsrud, C.; Schock, K.; Walther, L. C. S.; Wenk-Ansohn, M.; Bottche, M.
Abstract: background multidisciplinary treatment approach are commonly used in specialized psychosocial centre for the treatment of traumatized refugee but empirical evidence for their efficacy is inconsistent objective in order to obtain more evidence on the development of mental health and well being of traumatized refugee who receive multidisciplinary treatment symptom course of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd anxiety depression and somatoform symptom a well a in the subjective quality of life were investigated in the course of a multidisciplinary treatment in addition it wa analysed if sociodemographic variable were predictor for possible change in symptomatology and quality of life method n 76 patient of the outpatient clinic of a psychosocial centre for traumatized refugee receiving regular multidisciplinary treatment were surveyed using standardized questionnaire at three measurement point at the beginning of treatment and after an average of 7 and 14 month of treatment in a single group design result multilevel analysis showed significant improvement of symptom of ptsd p 001 depression p 001 anxiety p 001 and somatoform symptom p 002 a well a of the subjective quality of life p 001 over time among the tested predictor gender age country of origin age wa a significant predictor for the course of somatoform symptom p 05 younger patient showed greater improvement in symptomatology over time than older one conclusion the result suggest that the received multidisciplinary treatment had a positive effect on trauma related symptom a well a on quality of life of traumatized refugee there wa no indication that sociodemographic characteristic predicted the symptom course of the patient except for somatoform symptom younger patient benefitted more from multidisciplinary treatment than older one

Title: The Impact of Negative Mood on Event-Related Potentials When Viewing Pornographic Pictures
Authors: Markert, C.; Baranowski, A. M.; Koch, S.; Stark, R.; Strahler, J.
Abstract: background negative affective state may increase the risk for problematic pornography use underlying neurophysiological mechanism are however not completely understood previous research suggests that the participant emotional state may affect neural processing of sexual stimulus the aim of this study wa to investigate neural correlate of negative affect induced alteration in sexual cue reactivity in healthy men the moderating effect of habitual porn consumption trait sexual motivation and symptom of cybersex addiction were also considered method sixty four healthy men engaged in a sexual cue reactivity task passive viewing of explicit sexual picture and neutral picture depicting scene of social interaction during negative n 32 v neutral affect n 32 induced via tailored feedback on a performance task self reported sexual arousal and event related brain potential indicated cue reactivity and motivated attention symptom of cybersex addiction and trait sexual motivation were assessed with the help of the short internet addiction test adapted to online sexual activity and the trait sexual motivation questionnaire result negative feedback increased negative affect after the performance task while sexual picture compared to neutral picture elicited significantly larger p300 and late positive potential lpp amplitude there wa no general effect of negative feedback on sexual stimulus related p300 and lpp amplitude in the negative feedback group men with higher solitary sexual motivation level showed higher p300 lpp difference amplitude for sexual stimulus compared to men with lower level of solitary sexual motivation the opposite effect wa found in the group with neutral feedback there wa no link to other aspect of trait sexual motivation and symptom of cybersex addiction conclusion result suggest that higher level of solitary sexual motivation may enhance motivated attention toward sexual stimulus among men receiving negative performance feedback other characteristic of sexual behavior and trait provided no exploratory value future study extending onto men suffering from compulsive sexual behavior disorder will have to closer look at the neurophysiological base of why and when some men develop an addictive pornography consumption

Title: Comparing PTSD symptom networks in type I vs. type II trauma survivors
Authors: Stefanovic, M.; Ehring, T.; Wittekind, C. E.; Kleim, B.; Rohde, J.; Kruger-Gottschalk, A.; Knaevelsrud, C.; Rau, H.; Schafer, I.; Schellong, J.; Dyer, A.; Takano, K.
Abstract: background network analysis ha gained increasing attention a a new framework to study complex association between symptom of post traumatic stress disorder ptsd a number of study have been published to investigate symptom network on different set of symptom in different population and the finding have been inconsistent objective we aimed to extend previous research by testing whether difference in ptsd symptom network can be found in survivor of type i single event sudden and unexpected high level of acute threat v type ii repeated and or protracted anticipated trauma with regard to their index trauma method participant were trauma exposed individual with elevated level of ptsd symptomatology most of whom 94 were undergoing assessment in preparation for ptsd treatment in several treatment centre in germany and switzerland n 286 with type i and n 187 with type ii trauma we estimated bayesian gaussian graphical model for each trauma group and explored group difference in the symptom network result first for both trauma type our analysis identified the edge that were repeatedly reported in previous network study second there wa decisive evidence that the two network were generated from different multivariate normal distribution i e the network differed on a global level third explorative edge wise comparison showed moderate or strong evidence for specific 12 edge edge which emerged a especially important in distinguishing the network were between intrusion and flashback highlighting the stronger positive association in the group of type ii trauma survivor compared to type i survivor flashback showed a similar pattern of result in the association with detachment and sleep problem type ii type i conclusion our finding suggest that trauma type contributes to the heterogeneity in the symptom network future research on ptsd symptom network should include this variable in the analysis to reduce heterogeneity

Title: Neural Correlates of Empathy with Pain Show Habituation Effects. An fMRI Study
Authors: Preis, M. A.; Kroner-Herwig, B.; Schmidt-Samoa, C.; Dechent, P.; Barke, A.
Abstract: background neuroimaging study have demonstrated that the actual experience of pain and the perception of another person in pain share common neural substrate including the bilateral anterior insular cortex and the anterior midcingulate cortex a many fmri study include the exposure of participant to repeated similar stimulus we examined whether empathic neural response were affected by habituation and whether the participant prior pain experience influenced these habituation effect method in 128 trial four run 62 participant 31 woman 23 0 4 2 year were shown picture of hand exposed to painful pressure pain picture and unexposed neutral picture after each trial the participant rated the pain of the model prior to the experiment participant were either exposed to the same pain stimulus pain exposure group or not touch exposure group in order to a possible habituation effect linear change in the strength of the bold response to the pain picture relative to the neutral picture and in the rating of the model s pain were evaluated across the four run result although the rating of the model s pain remained constant over time we found neural habituation in the bilateral anterior midinsular cortex the posterior midcingulate extending to dorsal posterior cingulate cortex the supplementary motor area the cerebellum the right inferior parietal lobule and the left superior frontal gyrus stretching to the pregenual anterior cingulate cortex the participant s prior pain experience did neither affect their rating of the model s pain nor their maintenance of bold activity in area associated with empathy interestingly participant with high trait personal distress and fantasy tended to show le habituation in the anterior insula conclusion neural structure showed a decrease of the bold signal indicating habituation over the course of 45 minute this can be interpreted a a neuronal mechanism responding to the repeated exposure to pain depiction which may be regarded a functional in a range of context

Title: Sex differences in PTSD risk: evidence from post-conflict populations challenges the general assumption of increased vulnerability in females
Authors: Wilker, S.; Kolassa, S.; Ibrahim, H.; Rajan, V.; Pfeiffer, A.; Catani, C.; Kolassa, I. T.
Abstract: background next to the dose dependent effect of trauma load female sex represents a well established risk factor for ptsd exposure to particularly toxic traumatic event type different coping style and biological risk factor are frequently listed a potential cause for the increased ptsd vulnerability in female nevertheless sex difference have not been consistently observed in all study population objective to investigate sex difference in ptsd risk in post conflict population from different country while considering trauma load method in civilian post conflict sample from northern uganda n 1665 rwanda n 433 syria n 974 and sri lanka n 165 we investigated sex difference in ptsd risk while taking trauma load into account ptsd and trauma load were assessed using standardized diagnostic interview potential sex difference in ptsd risk were analysed by logistic regression analysis considering trauma load result across all sample male reported more traumatic event than female both sex predominantly reported war related traumatic event without considering trauma load sex effect in ptsd risk were only detected in the syrian sample when taking trauma load into account evidence for an increased ptsd vulnerability in female wa found in the syrian sample and to a much lesser extent in the northern ugandan sample conclusion in contrast to the literature we did not find evidence for a general increased ptsd vulnerability in female the dose response effect of trauma load wa a much stronger predictor of ptsd risk than sex across all sample

Title: Differential Classical Conditioning of the Nocebo Effect: Increasing Heat-Pain Perception without Verbal Suggestions
Authors: Brascher, A. K.; Kleinbohl, D.; Holzl, R.; Becker, S.
Abstract: background nocebo effect including nocebo hyperalgesia are a common phenomenon in clinical routine with manifold negative consequence both explicit expectation and learning by conditioning are known to induce nocebo effect but the specific role of conditioning remains unclear because conditioning is rarely implemented independent of verbal suggestion further although pain is a multidimensional phenomenon nocebo effect are usually assessed in subjective rating only neglecting e g behavioral aspect the aim of this study wa to test whether nocebo hyperalgesia can be learned by conditioning without explicit expectation to a nocebo effect in different response channel and to exploratively a whether contingency awareness is a necessary condition for conditioned nocebo hyperalgesia method twenty one healthy volunteer were classically conditioned using painful and non painful heat stimulus that followed two different cue the conditioned nocebo effect wa assessed by subjective rating of perceived stimulation intensity on a visual analog scale and a behavioral discrimination task assessing sensitization and habituation in response to the same stimulation following the two cue result result show a conditioned nocebo effect indicated by the subjective intensity rating conditioned effect were also seen in the behavioral response but paradoxically behavioral response indicated decreased perception after conditioning but only for subject successfully conditioned a indicated by the subjective rating explorative analysis suggested that awareness of the contingency and the different cue wa not necessary for successful conditioning conclusion nocebo effect can be learned without inducing additional explicit expectation the dissociation between the two response channel possibly representing the conditioned and a compensatory response highlight the importance of considering different outcome in nocebo response to fully understand underlying mechanism the present result challenge the role of explicit expectation in conditioned nocebo effect and are relevant with implication in clinical context e g when transient adverse effect become conditioned

Title: Internet-based motivation program for women with eating disorders: eating disorder pathology and depressive mood predict dropout
Authors: von Brachel, R.; Hotzel, K.; Hirschfeld, G.; Rieger, E.; Schmidt, U.; Kosfelder, J.; Hechler, T.; Schulte, D.; Vocks, S.
Abstract: background one of the main problem of internet delivered intervention for a range of disorder is the high dropout rate yet little is known about the factor associated with this we recently developed and tested a web based 6 session program to enhance motivation to change for woman with anorexia nervosa bulimia nervosa or related subthreshold eating pathology objective the aim of the present study wa to identify predictor of dropout from this web program method a total of 179 woman took part in the study we used survival analysis cox regression to investigate the predictive effect of eating disorder pathology assessed by the eating disorder examination questionnaire ede q depressive mood hopkins symptom checklist motivation to change university of rhode island change assessment scale urica and participant age at dropout to identify predictor we used the least absolute shrinkage and selection operator lasso method result the dropout rate wa 50 8 91 179 and wa equally distributed across the 6 treatment session the lasso analysis revealed that higher score on the shape concern subscale of the ede q a higher frequency of binge eating episode and vomiting a well a higher depression score significantly increased the probability of dropout however we did not find any effect of the urica or age on dropout conclusion woman with more severe eating disorder pathology and depressive mood had a higher likelihood of dropping out from a web based motivational enhancement program intervention such a ours need to address the specific need of woman with more severe eating disorder pathology and depressive mood and offer them additional support to prevent them from prematurely discontinuing treatment

Title: Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation of the Ventromedial Prefrontal Cortex Modulates Perceptual and Neural Patterns of Fear Generalization
Authors: Roesmann, K.; Kroker, T.; Hein, S.; Rehbein, M.; Winker, C.; Leehr, E. J.; Klucken, T.; Junghofer, M.
Abstract: background overgeneralization of fear is a pathogenic marker of anxiety and stress related disorder and ha been linked with perceptual discrimination deficit reduced fear inhibition and prefrontal hyporeactivity to safety signaling stimulus we aimed to examine whether behavioral and neural pattern of fear generalization are influenced by the fear inhibiting ventromedial prefrontal cortex vmpfc method three group of healthy participant received excitatory n 27 inhibitory n 26 or sham n 26 transcranial direct current stimulation of the vmpfc after a fear conditioning phase and before a fear generalization phase we obtained a dependent variable fear rating and unconditioned stimulus expectancy rating perceptual aspect of fear generalization perceptual discrimination pupil dilation and source estimation of event related field elicited by conditioned and generalization stimulus result after inhibitory compared with excitatory and sham vmpfc stimulation we observed reduced performance in perceptual discrimination and le negative inhibitory gradient in frontal structure at midlatency and late time interval fear and unconditioned stimulus expectancy rating a well a pupil dilation remained unaffected by stimulation conclusion these finding reveal a causal contribution of vmpfc reactivity to generalization pattern and suggest that vmpfc hyporeactivity consequent on inhibitory vmpfc stimulation may serve a a model for pathological process of fear generalization reduced discrimination impaired fear inhibition via frontal brain structure this encourages further basic and clinical research on the potential of targeted brain stimulation to modulate fear generalization and overgeneralization

Title: Elevated costly avoidance in anxiety disorders: Patients show little downregulation of acquired avoidance in face of competing rewards for approach
Authors: Pittig, A.; Boschet, J. M.; Gluck, V. M.; Schneider, K.
Abstract: background pathological avoidance is a transdiagnostic characteristic of anxiety disorder avoidance conditioning re emerged a a translational model to examine mechanism and treatment of avoidance however it validity for anxiety disorder remains unclear method this study tested for altered avoidance in patient with anxiety disorder compared to matched control n 40 group using instrumental conditioning assessing low cost avoidance avoiding a single aversive outcome and costly avoidance avoidance conflicted with gaining reward autonomic arousal and threat expectancy were assessed a indicator of conditioned fear association with dimensional symptom severity were examined result patient and control showed frequent low cost avoidance without group difference control subsequently inhibited avoidance to gain reward which wa amplified when aversive outcome discontinued in contrast patient failed to reduce avoidance when aversive and positive outcome competed elevated costly avoidance and showed limited reduction when aversive outcome discontinued persistent costly avoidance interestingly elevated costly avoidance wa not linked to higher conditioned fear in patient moreover individual data revealed a bimodal distribution of costly avoidance some patient showed persistent avoidance others showed little to no avoidance persistent versus low avoiders did not differ in other task related variable response to gain and loss in absence of threat sociodemographic data or clinical characteristic conclusion finding suggest that anxious psychopathology is associated with a deficit to inhibit avoidance in presence of competing positive outcome this offer novel perspective for research on mechanism and treatment of anxiety disorder

Title: Familiality of neural preparation and response control in childhood attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder
Authors: Albrecht, B.; Brandeis, D.; Uebel, H.; Valko, L.; Heinrich, H.; Drechsler, R.; Heise, A.; Muller, U. C.; Steinhausen, H. C.; Rothenberger, A.; Banaschewski, T.
Abstract: background patient with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd exhibit difficulty in multiple attentional function although high heritability rate suggest a strong genetic impact aetiological pathway from gene and environmental factor to the adhd phenotype are not well understood tracking the time course of deviant task processing using event related electrophysiological brain activity should characterize the impact of familiality on the sequence of cognitive function from preparation to response control in adhd method preparation and response control were assessed using behavioural and electrophysiological parameter of two version of a cued continuous performance test with varying attentional load in boy with adhd combined type n 97 their non affected sibling n 27 and control child without a family history of adhd n 43 result child with adhd and non affected sibling showed more variable performance and made more omission error than control the preparatory cue p3 and contingent negative variation cnv following cue were reduced in both adhd child and their non affected sibling compared with control the nogo p3 wa diminished in adhd compared with control whilst non affected sibling were located intermediate but did not differ from both other group no clear familiality effect were found for the go p3 better task performance wa further associated with higher cnv and p3 amplitude conclusion impairment in performance and electrophysiological parameter reflecting preparatory process and to some extend also for inhibitory response control especially under high attentional load appeared to be familially driven in adhd and may thus constitute functionally relevant endophenotypes for the disorder

Title: Feeling excluded no matter what? Bias in the processing of social participation in borderline personality disorder
Authors: Weinbrecht, A.; Niedeggen, M.; Roepke, S.; Renneberg, B.
Abstract: background patient with borderline personality disorder bpd feel ostracized even when they are included this might be due to a biased processing of social participation in bpd we examined whether patient with bpd also process social overinclusion in a biased manner i e whether they feel ostracized even when the degree of social participation is increased method an eeg compatible version of cyberball wa used to investigate the effect of inclusion and overinclusion 33 v 45 ball receipt on perceived ostracism need threat and p3 amplitude an eeg indicator for expectancy violation twenty nine patient with bpd 28 patient with social anxiety disorder sad and 28 healthy control hc participated result the p3 amplitude wa enhanced for patient with bpd and sad compared to hcs independent of condition both patient group reported more perceived ostracism relative to hcs in the inclusion but not in the overinclusion condition only patient with bpd reported stronger need threat in both condition conclusion the eeg result imply that being socially included violates the expectation of patient with bpd irrespective of the actual degree of social participation however when overincluded patient with bpd no longer feel ostracized except for need threat patient with sad might show a comparable bias in the processing of social participation a patient with bpd

Title: Neural correlates of self-referential processing and implicit self-associations in chronic depression
Authors: Renner, F.; Siep, N.; Lobbestael, J.; Arntz, A.; Peeters, F. P.; Huibers, M. J.
Abstract: background patient with depression tend to process negative information with regard to the self i e self referential processing a better understanding of the neural underpinnings of self referential processing in patient with depression is clinically important a it can inform on potential treatment target method this fmri study sought to study the neural correlate of self referential processing in patient with chronic major depressive disorder cmdd n 17 and non patient control n 18 using a passive processing paradigm stimulus consisted of positive negative negative depression related and neutral personality trait word or non word participant were instructed to indicate whether a presented word wa an existing word or a non word while undergoing an fmri scan participant also completed an explicit and an implicit measure of positive and negative self association outside the scanner result non patient control had relatively increased activity in the medial prefrontal cortex mpfc during processing of negative depression related v neutral word whereas patient with cmdd had relatively decreased activity non patient control had relatively increased dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc activity during processing of positive v neutral word whereas patient with cmdd had relatively decreased activity explicit but not implicit self association with depression related word were associated with neural activity in the mpfc and the dlpfc limitation the study did not include a clinical control group and therefore the specificity of finding remains unknown conclusion the distinct neural processing of emotional self relevant stimulus in the mpfc and the dlpfc in patient with cmdd might represent an emotional blunting response towards negative self relevant stimulus

Title: Uncertainty increases neural indices of attention in obsessive-compulsive disorder
Authors: Dieterich, R.; Endrass, T.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: background patient with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd experience abnormally high level of uncertainty and unpredictability is evaluated negatively and not well tolerated the current study examined neural correlate of attentional processing in response to experimentally induced uncertainty in ocd method twenty four ocd patient and 24 healthy control performed a task where neutral and negative picture were preceded by a cue either being predictive certain condition or nonpredictive uncertain condition of subsequent picture valence we examined prepicture anticipatory attention through alpha approximately 8 12 hz suppression and attentional allocation during picture presentation with the p1 n1 p2 n2 and late positive potential lpp of the event related potential additionally we tested how clinical measure related to these attentional marker result subjectively patient overestimated the frequency of negative picture after nonpredictive cue patient but not control showed upper alpha 10 12 hz suppression after nonpredictive and predictive negative cue relative to predictive neutral cue only patient showed increased p2 and decreased n2 amplitude for picture after nonpredictive cue and whereas both group showed increased lpp amplitude for picture after nonpredictive cue this modulation wa more pronounced in ocd during the early lpp 1 000 m in patient p2 and lpp amplitude for negative picture were associated positively with anxiety and negatively with depression conclusion these result suggest that ocd patient process anticipation of inevitable and potential threat similarly and highlight the substantial motivational impact of uncertain event to ocd patient finally the correlation with anxiety implies that anxiety represents the source of hypervigilance during uncertainty resolution

Title: An experimental study on the effectiveness of emotion regulation in patients with acute delusions
Authors: Opoka, S. M.; Ludwig, L.; Mehl, S.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: background patient with psychotic disorder report to apply more maladaptive and le adaptive emotion regulation er strategy compared to healthy control however few study have used experimental design to investigate the success in er and the result of those at hand are equivocal aim this study investigated whether patient with delusion show problem in downregulating negative affect via cognitive er strategy method patient with schizophrenia spectrum disorder and acute delusion n 78 and healthy control n 41 took part in an er experiment in which they were instructed to downregulate anxiety and sadness via three er strategy reappraisal distraction acceptance or not to regulate their emotion control condition er success wa measured a the change in subjective emotion intensity and physiological indicator skin conductance and heart rate from before to after regulation and wa analyzed with mixed repeated measure anova result we found a significant effect of the er strategy in the sense that the subjective emotion intensity wa significantly lower after applying the reappraisal and distraction strategy than after the just view condition p s 001 this effect wa not found for the acceptance strategy p 060 there wa no er strategy time group interaction effect f 4 918 575 416 0 778 p 564 n 2 partial 0 007 in all condition skin conductance decreased from pre to post regulation p 001 conclusion our result indicate that patient with acute delusion can successfully apply cognitive er strategy before pursuing the relevant clinical implication of this finding further research is needed to explore the role that the type of instruction ha on er success and the extent to which the finding can be generalized to real life setting

Title: Habitual aversive and appetitive well-being comparisons in dysphoria: Introducing the Comparison Standards Scale for well-being
Authors: Morina, N.; Schlechter, P.
Abstract: background people are constantly preoccupied with how they are doing compared to different standard this preoccupation influence judgment of well being including depression however research on well being comparison is scarce also due to a lack of a measure of multi standard comparison method our research goal were twofold first we validated the comparison standard scale for well being c w second by drawing on central proposition of the general comparative processing model we examined the association of habitual well being comparison their perceived discrepancy with the standard and engendered affect with depressive symptom and psychological well being in dysphoric participant n 500 the c w a habitual social temporal counterfactual and criterion based upward and downward comparison regarding their a frequency b perceived discrepancy and c engendered affect result the finding confirmed the theoretically expected two factor solution representing aversive mostly upward and appetitive mostly downward comparison comparison frequency discrepancy and engendered affect were associated with depression and well being yet aversive comparison displayed higher association with the outcome than appetitive comparison in particular frequency of appetitive comparison wa not significantly correlated to depression in line with our central theory driven hypothesis the relationship between frequency of aversive comparison with depression wa partially mediated by serial effect of comparison discrepancy and affect whereas the relationship with well being wa fully mediated by comparison discrepancy and affect limitation the cross sectional design of the study doe not allow for conclusion of causal relation between the measured variable conclusion the presented framework prof useful in examining significant comparison process in well being and depression

Title: Belief updating in depression is not related to increased sensitivity to unexpectedly negative information
Authors: Kube, T.; Kirchner, L.; Rief, W.; Gartner, T.; Glombiewski, J. A.
Abstract: background people with depression differ from healthy people in the extent to which they use novel positive information to adjust negative expectation in this study we examined whether the two group also differ in updating positive expectation after receiving unexpectedly negative information method examining 76 people with depressive symptom and 81 healthy control we used an adapted version of a previously validated paradigm after the initial establishment of positive performance expectation participant worked on the temint performance test whereupon half of the participant received standardized feedback that confirmed previous positive expectation while the other half received disconfirming negative feedback subsequently participant performance expectation were assessed again additionally we assessed participant appraisal of the feedback particularly whether they tended to disregard it result result indicated that healthy subject had overall more positive expectation than people with depressive symptom but the two sample did not differ in updating their expectation both group changed their expectation in a negative direction after receiving negative feedback similarly there were no difference between the two sample after receiving confirmatory positive feedback both people with and without depressive symptom were more likely to disregard the feedback received if the feedback wa negative and such a negative appraisal of the feedback wa associated with smaller expectation update conclusion in combination with prior work the current finding suggest that people with depressive symptom do not over sensitively react to unexpectedly negative information rather the main problem of depression seems to be the integration of novel positive information a shown previously

Title: Are perinatal measures associated with adolescent mental health? A retrospective exploration with original data from psychiatric cohorts
Authors: Basedow, L. A.; Kuitunen-Paul, S.; Roessner, V.; Moll, G. H.; Golub, Y.; Eichler, A.
Abstract: background perinatal marker of prenatal development are associated with offspring psychiatric symptom however there is little research investigating the specificity of perinatal marker for the development of specific disorder this study aimed to explore if perinatal marker are specifically associated with adolescent substance use disorder suds method adolescent participant from two study center one for sud patient n 196 and one for general psychopathology n 307 were recruited for participation since the sud participant presented with a number of comorbid disorder we performed a 1 on 1 matching procedure based on age gender and specific pattern of comorbid disorder this procedure resulted in n 51 participant from each group from all participant and their mother we recorded perinatal marker mode of birth week of completed pregnancy birth weight apgar score after 5 min a well a intelligence quotient iq the sud sample additionally filled out the youth safe report ysr a well a the pq 16 and the dudit we aimed to distinguish the two group sud sample v general psychiatric sample based on the perinatal variable via a logistic regression analysis additionally linear regression were performed for the total group and the subgroup to a the relationship between perinatal variable and iq ysr dudit and pq 16 result the perinatal variable were not able to predict group membership x 2 4 4 77 p 312 cox snell r 2 0 053 odds ratio indicated a small increase in probability to belonging to the general psychiatric sample instead of the sud sample if birth wa completed via c section after bonferroni correction the linear regression model showed no relation between perinatal marker and iq p 60 r 2 0 068 ysr p 09 r 2 0 121 dudit p 65 r 2 0 020 and pq 16 p 73 r 2 0 021 conclusion perinatal marker were not able to distinguish sud patient from patient with diverse psychopathology this pattern contradicts previous finding perhaps because our chosen marker reflect general process instead of specific mechanistic explanation future study should take care to investigate specific prenatal marker and associate them with psychopathology on the symptom level

Title: Group cohesion in group-based personal practice
Authors: Maass, U.; Kuhne, F.; Hahn, D.; Weck, F.
Abstract: background personal practice pp is an integral component of many psychotherapy training programme it aim to promote personal and professional growth and is often conducted in a group format g pp group cohesion is one of the most researched mechanism in group psychotherapy but ha rarely been studied in the context of g pp aim and method this exploratory study examines the association between cohesion satisfaction with g pp it impact on personal and professional development and theoretical orientation in a sample of n 329 german psychotherapy trainee cohesion wa assessed with the group questionnaire gq d positive bonding positive working negative relationship result overall participant reported high level of all outcome variable positive bonding wa the strongest predictor of satisfaction with g pp beta 0 46 p 001 while trainee in cognitive behaviour therapy reported significantly better cohesion score d 0 31 trainee in psychodynamic therapy reported significantly higher satisfaction with g pp and it impact on their development d 0 30 conclusion group cohesion appears to be an important factor in g pp that should be actively promoted by group leader however longitudinal study design are needed to better understand the emergence of cohesion in g pp a well a potential moderating factor

Title: Interaction of physical activity and interoception in children
Authors: Georgiou, E.; Matthias, E.; Kobel, S.; Kettner, S.; Dreyhaupt, J.; Steinacker, J. M.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: background physical activity pa is associated with positive health outcome whereas physical inactivity is related to an increased risk for various health issue including obesity and cardiovascular disease previous research indicates that interindividual difference in the perception of bodily process interoceptive sensitivity is interact with the degree of pa in adult whether there is a similar relationship between pa and is in child ha not been investigated yet therefore the aim of this study wa to investigate the interaction between is and pa during physical performance task and in everyday situation method is wa assessed using a heartbeat perception task in a sample of 49 child within the health promotion program join the healthy boat which is implemented in several primary school in the southwest of germany pa wa examined using a physical performance task assessing the distance covered during a standardized 6 min run in a subsample of 21 child everyday pa wa measured by a multi sensor device actiheart camntech cambridge uk during five consecutive day with more than 10 h of daily data collection result child with higher is performed better in the physical performance task additionally based on energy expenditure defined a metabolic equivalent is wa positively correlated with the extent of light pa level in the morning and afternoon conclusion our finding reveal that is interacts positively with the degree of pa in child supporting the idea that interoception is important for the self regulation of health related behavior

Title: Bits and pieces. Food texture influences food acceptance in young children
Authors: Werthmann, J.; Jansen, A.; Havermans, R.; Nederkoorn, C.; Kremers, S.; Roefs, A.
Abstract: background picky or fussy eating is common in early childhood and associated with a decreased preference for a variety of food the aim of the current study wa to test experimentally which sensory food feature influence food acceptance which in turn is an indication for fussy eating in young child 32 48 month another aim wa to evaluate if the behavioural measurement of food acceptance is related to parental report of their child s fussy eating behaviour parental feeding style and child s bmi method in a repeated measure design three sensory feature were manipulated separately i e colour texture and taste while keeping the other two feature constant the baseline measurement consisted of a well liked yoghurt which wa presented before each manipulation variant the number of spoon that child n 32 consumed from each variant were registered a behavioural indication for food acceptance parental report of child s eating behaviour and parental feeding style and child s bmi were also measured result the manipulation of food texture caused a significant decrease in intake colour and taste manipulation of the yoghurt did not affect child s intake parental report of child s fussy eating behaviour and parental feeding style were not related to the behavioural observation of food acceptance the behavioural measurement of food acceptance and parental account of fussy eating were not related to child s bmi conclusion food texture but not taste or colour alternation affected food acceptance at least when consuming variation of a well liked yoghurt this knowledge is important for further research on picky eating intervention parental report of fussy eating did not concur with the behavioural observation of food acceptance further research is warranted to test whether these finding generalize to other food type

Title: Positive mental health moderates the association between suicide ideation and suicide attempts
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Forkmann, T.; Glaesmer, H.; Paashaus, L.; Rath, D.; Schonfelder, A.; Juckel, G.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: background positive mental health pmh ha been shown to confer resilience against suicide ideation however it is unclear whether pmh also buffer the relationship between suicide ideation and suicide attempt the current study aimed to determine whether pmh moderate the association between lifetime suicide ideation and lifetime suicide attempt method a total of 199 psychiatric inpatient with lifetime suicide attempt female n 109 age m 37 56 sd 14 38 range 18 81 were interviewed on lifetime suicide ideation behavior and completed a measure on pmh result pmh moderated the impact of lifetime suicide ideation on lifetime suicide attempt for those individual who reported high level of pmh the rate of lifetime suicide attempt wa reduced even when experiencing frequent episode of lifetime suicide ideation limitation given the cross sectional nature of the data conclusion on causality should be handled carefully conclusion pmh seems to confer resilience and should be taken into account when assessing individual for suicide risk

Title: Post-stroke depression and functional impairments - A 3-year prospective study
Authors: Schottke, H.; Gerke, L.; Dusing, R.; Mollmann, A.
Abstract: background post stroke depression psd is a severe condition affecting about 30 of stroke survivor within a five year period after stroke post stroke functional impairment fi and social support are associated with psd it is inconclusive whether one of the factor post stroke fi and psd show a stronger predictive value on the respective other over time the aim of the present study were to 1 investigate the relationship between psd fi and social support of stroke patient in a 3 year prospective design and 2 address methodological shortcoming of previous study method we investigated 174 stroke survivor and assessed psd with a structured clinical interview and a dimensional symptom rating scale we conducted regression analysis and applied the approach of multiple imputation mi for missing data due to dropout during follow up result psd prevalence wa 32 2 in the acute phase after stroke individual with a psd in this phase revealed a fivefold higher risk for psd 3 year later fi in the acute phase did not additionally contribute to the prediction of psd at follow up compared to individual without psd in the acute phase individual with psd had an increased risk for fi at follow up limitation regarding sample characteristic design and dropout are discussed conclusion result indicate that psd rather than fi represents a crucial risk factor for negative long term consequence regarding physical and psychological health after stroke post stroke treatment might be optimized by a routine assessment of psd and fi after stroke and considering the result for personalized treatment option

Title: The influence of early depressive symptoms, social support and decreasing self-efficacy on depression 6 months post-stroke
Authors: Volz, M.; Mobus, J.; Letsch, C.; Werheid, K.
Abstract: background post stroke depression psd is the most frequent mental disorder after stroke affecting about 30 of stroke survivor despite extensive research little is known about the influence of general self efficacy gse on psd we investigated the effect of gse on depression six month post stroke while controlling for established risk factor method eighty eight patient from two rehabilitation center with first ever ischemic stroke were assessed around 8 week and 6 month after stroke baseline assessment included demographic variable gse scale physical disability barthel index stroke severity modified nih scale pre stroke mental illness cognitive status mini mental state test social support f sozu questionnaire and depressiveness geriatric depression scale gd follow up assessment included dsm iv depression gd and gse the influence of each risk factor on psd wa analyzed by binary hierarchical regression result baseline depressiveness or 1 41 p 01 and social support or 95 p 03 predicted psd decreasing gse wa associated with high baseline gse r 51 p 01 and influenced later psd or 1 39 p 01 limitation patient range of impairment may have been limited a sufficient speech comprehension and capacity for interview participation were required causal relationship between decreasing gse and increasing gd cannot be assumed based on correlation discussion decreasing gse wa linked to psd especially in patient with high baseline gse this effect may be due to dissatisfaction with recovery following high expectation early depressive symptom and low social support predicted psd early screening for depressive symptom and focusing on self efficacy might help to prevent later depression

Title: Coping motives mediate the relationship between PTSD and MDMA use in adolescents with substance use disorders
Authors: Basedow, L. A.; Wiedmann, M. F.; Roessner, V.; Golub, Y.; Kuitunen-Paul, S.
Abstract: background post traumatic stress disorder ptsd and substance use disorder suds often co occur in adolescent patient previous research ha shown that these patient differ from sud patient without ptsd in term of their substance use pattern in this study we aimed to test whether substance use in this population is related to an attempt to self medicate ptsd related symptom method german adolescent patient aged 13 18 year at an outpatient clinic for sud treatment n 111 43 female completed a self designed questionnaire on use motif a measure of ptsd related experience and underwent a standardized psychiatric interview including structured substance use question participant were subsequently classified a no traumatic experience note but sud traumatic experience but no current ptsd diagnosis te with sud and ptsd with sud after establishing a self designed motive measurement through exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis we calculated non parametric group difference and a mediation analysis in a linear regression framework result the past year frequency of mdma use wa highest in the ptsd group and lowest in the note group h 2 7 2 p 027 eta 2 058 but no difference were found for frequency of tobacco alcohol cannabis or stimulant use all h 4 9 p 085 eta 2 033 while controlling for sex the three group showed a similar pattern highest in the ptsd group and lowest in the note group for coping score f 103 5 77 p 004 eta 2 101 finally mediation analysis revealed an indirect effect of coping score b 0 61 95 ci 0 29 1 58 p 145 on the association between group membership and mdma use frequency conclusion in adolescent sud patient we found an association of current ptsd and lifetime traumatic experience with higher mdma use that could be partially explained by substance use being motivated by an attempt to cope with mental health symptom this indicates a coping process involved specifically in mdma use compared to the use of other psychoactive substance possibly due to unique psychoactive effect of mdma

Title: Associations between oxytocin and vasopressin concentrations, traumatic event exposure and posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms: group comparisons, correlations, and courses during an internet-based cognitive-behavioural treatment
Authors: Engel, S.; Schumacher, S.; Niemeyer, H.; Kuester, A.; Burchert, S.; Klusmann, H.; Rau, H.; Willmund, G. D.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: background posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd is characterized by impairment in extinction learning and social behaviour which are targeted by trauma focused cognitive behavioural treatment tf cbt the biological underpinnings of tf cbt can be better understood by adding biomarkers to the clinical evaluation of intervention due to their involvement in social functioning and fear processing oxytocin and arginine vasopressin might be informative biomarkers for tf cbt but to date this ha never been tested objective to differentiate the impact of traumatic event exposure and ptsd symptom on blood oxytocin and vasopressin concentration further to describe course of ptsd symptom oxytocin and vasopressin during an internet based tf cbt and explore interaction between these parameter method we compared oxytocin and vasopressin between three group of active and former male service member of the german armed force n 100 ptsd patient n 39 deployed healthy control who experienced a deployment related traumatic event n 33 and non deployed healthy control who never experienced a traumatic event n 28 ptsd patient underwent a 5 week internet based tf cbt we correlated ptsd symptom with oxytocin and vasopressin before treatment onset further we analysed course of ptsd symptom oxytocin and vasopressin from pre to post treatment and 3 month follow up a well a interaction between the three parameter result oxytocin and vasopressin did not differ between the group and were unrelated to ptsd symptom ptsd symptom were highly stable over time whereas the endocrine parameter were not and they also did not change in mean oxytocin and vasopressin were not associated with ptsd symptom longitudinally conclusion mainly due to their insufficient intraindividual stability single measurement of endogenous oxytocin and vasopressin concentration are not informative biomarkers for tf cbt we discus how the stability of these biomarkers might be increased and how they could be better related to the specific impairment targeted by tf cbt

Title: The role of memory-related gene WWC1 (KIBRA) in lifetime posttraumatic stress disorder: evidence from two independent samples from African conflict regions
Authors: Wilker, S.; Kolassa, S.; Vogler, C.; Lingenfelder, B.; Elbert, T.; Papassotiropoulos, A.; de Quervain, D. J.; Kolassa, I. T.
Abstract: background posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd result from the formation of a strong memory for the sensory perceptual and affective representation of traumatic experience which is detached from the corresponding autobiographical context information because wwc1 the gene encoding protein kibra is associated with long term memory performance we hypothesized that common wwc1 allele influence the risk for a lifetime diagnosis of ptsd method traumatic load and diagnosis of current and lifetime ptsd were assessed in two independent african sample of survivor from conflict zone who had faced severe trauma n 392 rwanda and n 399 northern uganda respectively array based single nucleotide polymorphism snp genotyping wa performed the influence of wwc1 tagging snp and traumatic load on lifetime ptsd wa estimated by mean of logistic regression model with correction for multiple comparison in the rwandan sample replication analysis wa performed in the independent ugandan sample result an association of two neighboring snp in almost complete linkage disequilibrium rs10038727 and rs4576167 with lifetime ptsd wa discovered in the rwandan sample although each traumatic event added to the probability of lifetime ptsd in a dose dependent manner in both genotype group carrier of the minor allele of both snp displayed a diminished risk p 007 odds ratio 29 95 confidence interval 15 54 this effect wa confirmed in the independent ugandan sample conclusion this study reveals an association between two wwc1 snp and the likelihood of ptsd development indicating that this memory related gene might be involved in process that occur in response to traumatic stress and influence the strengthening of fear memory

Title: Preoperative anxiety and its association with patients' desire for support - an observational study in adults
Authors: Salzmann, S.; Rienmuller, S.; Kampmann, S.; Euteneuer, F.; Rusch, D.
Abstract: background preoperative anxiety is prevalent and ha harmful effect on postoperative outcome however to date it is still unclear i to what extent patient perceive preoperative anxiety a emotionally distressful ii whether patient would welcome support from anesthesiologist in coping with their anxiety and iii whether anxiety score are useful for everyday clinical practice to determine patient need for support method 1082 patient scheduled to undergo elective procedure under general anesthesia were eligible for this cross sectional study carried out at a university hospital preoperative anxiety resulting in emotional distress and patient desire for anesthesiologist support in coping with their anxiety were assessed dichotomously no v yes and analyzed descriptively the intensity of anxiety wa evaluated using the amsterdam preoperative anxiety and information scale range 4 20 association between the intensity of anxiety and the resulting desire for support were analyzed using logistic regression receiver operating characteristic analysis were performed to identify anxiety level that best predict desire for support result among the 1000 537 female m sd 57 18 year subject evaluated 493 318 65 female reported anxiety anxiety wa associated with emotional distress in 320 65 and desire for support in 291 59 patient increased preoperative anxiety level were associated with higher rate of desire for support b 0 270 odds ratio 1 31 95 ci 1 22 1 41 an anxiety score 9 wa best to predict a desire for support sensitivity 0 861 specificity 0 724 however desire for support wa even present in some patient with lowest anxiety score 5 or 6 conclusion all patient undergoing surgery should be screened for preoperative anxiety and the resulting desire for support to be able to determine who would welcome support anxiety scoring tool do not seem to be useful to identify these patient by helping patient experience le preoperative anxiety anesthesiologist may not only reduce patient emotional distress but also have a positive impact on postoperative outcome trial registration german clinical trial register drks 00013319 23 november 2017

Title: Previous experiences with illness and traumatic experiences: a specific risk factor for hypochondriasis?
Authors: Weck, F.; Neng, J. M. B.; Goller, K.; Muller-Marbach, A. M.
Abstract: background previous experience with illness and traumatic experience are considered a important risk factor for the development of health anxiety and hypochondriasis however empirical research is insufficient and lack adequate comparison group objective therefore we sought to determine whether experience with illness and traumatic experience are really specific risk factor for hypochondriasis method in the current study patient with the diagnosis of hypochondriasis n 80 patient with a primary anxiety disorder n 80 and healthy control n 83 were investigated regarding their previous experience with illness self and other and traumatic childhood experience result we found that patient with hypochondriasis reported a higher level of experience with illness and with traumatic childhood experience than healthy control however no difference were found between patient with hypochondriasis and those with an anxiety disorder regarding their level of experience with illness and traumatic experience conclusion previous experience with illness and traumatic childhood experience did not prove to be specific risk factor for the development of hypochondriasis the importance of both experience with illness and traumatic experience a risk factor a considered in the diagnostic and statistical manual and in established cognitive behavioral model doe not seem to be supported empirically further research should therefore also consider other potential risk factor discussed in the literature

Title: Testosterone is not associated with traits of optimism or pessimism: Observational evidence from the prospective DETECT study
Authors: Kische, H.; Hoyer, J.; Pieper, L.; Venz, J.; Klotsche, J.; Marz, W.; Koch-Gromus, U.; Pittrow, D.; Lehnert, H.; Silber, S.; Stalla, G. K.; Zeiher, A. M.; Wittchen, H. U.; Haring, R.
Abstract: background previous experimental research on testosterone t and psychological trait is inconclusive thus we performed the first large scale observational study of the association between t and dispositional optimism pessimism method we used prospective data from 6 493 primary care patient 3 840 woman of the detect study diabetes cardiovascular risk evaluation target and essential data for commitment of treatment including repeated immunoassay based measurement of serum t and optimism pessimism assessed by the revised life orientation test lot r cross sectional and longitudinal association of baseline t and one year change in t with optimism and pessimism were investigated using age and multivariable adjusted regression model result cross sectional analysis showed no association of t with optimism or pessimism in both sex longitudinal analysis also showed no association of baseline t with optimism or pessimism at four year follow up multivariable analysis of total lot r score yielded similarly non significant result beta coefficient per unit change in t for men 0 01 95 ci 0 24 0 22 woman 0 08 0 03 0 20 furthermore change in t wa not related to optimism or pessimism at four year follow up conclusion the present observational study of a large scale prospective sample showed no association of t with optimism or pessimism integrating further experimental and interventional evidence from alternative methodological approach would strengthen this conclusion and establish stronger evidence about the potential hormonal basis of psychological trait

Title: Using bodily postures to reduce anxiety and improve interoception: A comparison between powerful and neutral poses
Authors: Weineck, F.; Schultchen, D.; Hauke, G.; Messner, M.; Pollatos, O.
