Abstract: background previous research ha shown that anxiety syndrome are highly prevalent among university student effective treatment are needed to reduce the burden of anxiety in this population powerful posture have been found to impact affective state a well a interoception i e the ability to perceive inner bodily signal however no previous study ha compared the effect of powerful and neutral posture in regard to anxiety and interoceptive ability method the first part of the study measured the single session effect of adopting powerful v neutral posture on student n 57 interoceptive ability and state anxiety the second part of the study measured the effect of adopting powerful or neutral posture twice daily for two week on individual interoceptive ability and trait anxiety result state anxiety decreased in both condition whereas interoceptive accuracy only increased in the power posing condition after a single session interoceptive accuracy increased in both group after two week of training limitation the study included no comparison to a condition where individual adopted their natural i e usual bodily posture conclusion embodiment intervention that include element of adopting an open or expansive bodily posture whilst maintaining a self focus can help to reduce state anxiety and improve interoceptive accuracy in student population power posing doe not seem to be superior to holding a neutral posture to improve interoceptive accuracy or anxiety one reason therefore could be that both condition include the manipulation of self focus and a postural change that diverges from individual normal posture

Title: Familial transmission of a body-related attentional bias - An eye-tracking study in a nonclinical sample of female adolescents and their mothers
Authors: Bauer, A.; Schneider, S.; Waldorf, M.; Adolph, D.; Vocks, S.
Abstract: background previous research indicates that body image disturbance is transmitted from mother to daughter via modeling of maternal body related behavior and attitude indirect transmission and via maternal body related feedback direct transmission so far the transmission of body related attentional bias which according to cognitive behavioral theory play a prominent role in the development and maintenance of eating disorder ha not been analyzed the current eye tracking study applied the concept of direct and indirect transmission to body related attentional bias by examining body related viewing pattern on self and other picture within mother daughter dyad method eye movement of n 82 participant n 41 healthy female adolescent mean age 15 82 year sd 1 80 and their mother mean age 47 78 year sd 4 52 were recorded while looking at whole body picture of themselves and a control peer based on fixation on self defined attractive and unattractive body area visual attention bias score were calculated for mother and daughter representing the pattern of body related attention allocation based on mother fixation on their own daughter s and the adolescent peer s body a second visual attention bias score wa calculated reflecting the mother viewing pattern on their own daughter result analysis of variance revealed an attentional bias for self defined unattractive body area in adolescent the girl visual attention bias score correlated significantly with their mother bias score indicating indirect transmission and with their mother second bias score indicating direct transmission moreover the girl bias score correlated significantly with negative body related feedback from their mother conclusion female adolescent show a deficit oriented attentional bias for one s own and a peer s body the correlated body related attention pattern imply that attentional bias might be transmitted directly and indirectly from mother to daughter result underline the potential relevance of maternal influence for the development of body image disturbance in girl and suggest specific family based approach for the prevention and treatment of eating disorder

Title: Impaired cognitive control over emotional material in euthymic bipolar disorder
Authors: Wolkenstein, L.; Kanske, P.; Bailer, J.; Wessa, M.; Hautzinger, M.; Joormann, J.
Abstract: background previous research suggests that bipolar disorder bd is characterized by deficit in cognitive control cc impaired cc ha been found in high risk sample and is associated with the maintenance of bd symptom it remains unclear however whether bd is characterized by a general deficit in cc or by a deficit that is specifically related to the processing of emotional material method the sample consisted of 42 remitted bipolar patient and 39 healthy control hc we examined whether bd individual display impaired cc when confronted with negative a well a positive material using an arithmetic inhibition task that required inhibition of pictorial stimulus material result whereas both group showed difficulty in exerting cc over negative material only bd individual exhibited deficient cc over positive material limitation even though we intended the negative and positive picture in the arithmetic inhibition task to be similarly arousing participant in the current study rated the negative compared to the positive picture a more arousing conclusion bd is associated with impaired cc when processing emotional especially positive stimulus even when patient are in remission possible implication of this deficit especially for emotion regulation are discussed

Title: Mood-incongruent processing during the recall of a sad life event predicts the course and severity of depression
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Kulessa, D.; Hautzinger, M.; Bents, H.; Backenstrass, M.
Abstract: background previous study suggest that mood incongruent processing constitutes an adaptive mood regulation strategy and that difficulty in this process may contribute to the maintenance of depression however no study ha yet examined whether mood incongruent processing predicts the course and severity of clinical depression method to address this question the present study used a prospective longitudinal design to examine the effect of mood incongruent processing in a sample of 59 clinically depressed patient at baseline participant were asked to recall and describe a sad and a happy life event participant utterance were transcribed and analysed using computerized text analysis negated emotion word were excluded the proportion of positive emotion word during sad memory recall wa used a an indicator of mood incongruent processing after 6 month participant were re assessed for symptom level and the criterion of major depressive disorder mdd during the follow up period result higher relative frequency of positive emotion word during sad memory recall wa associated with le symptom of depression at follow up and shorter time to recovery from mdd over and above baseline symptom of depression the effect wa not just due to increased general positivity in emotional expression or emotional expressiveness per se limitation the sample size and the timeframe for the follow up assessment were limited furthermore it is unknown to which degree word use reflects the actual experience of the expressed emotion conclusion the finding highlight the role of mood incongruent processing in the maintenance of depression and advocate a stronger focus on mood incongruent processing in the treatment of depression

Title: [How frequently are depressive disorders recognized in primary care patients? : A cross-sectional epidemiological study in Germany]
Authors: Beesdo-Baum, K.; Knappe, S.; Einsle, F.; Knothe, L.; Wieder, G.; Venz, J.; Rummel-Kluge, C.; Heinz, I.; Koburger, N.; Schouler-Ocak, M.; Wilbertz, T.; Unger, H. P.; Walter, U.; Hein, J.; Hegerl, U.; Lieb, R.; Pfennig, A.; Schmitt, J.; Hoyer, J.; Wittchen, H. U.; Bergmann, A.
Abstract: background primary care physician pcp play a crucial role for guideline oriented intervention in patient with depression objective based on a diagnostic screening questionnaire this study investigates the sensitivity of pcp to recognize patient with depression a well a the factor facilitating recognition and concordant diagnostic decision method in a cross sectional epidemiological study in six region of germany 3563 unselected patient filled in questionnaire on mental and physical complaint and were diagnostically evaluated by their pcp n 253 the patient report on an established depression screening questionnaire dsq which allows the approximate derivation of an icd 10 depression diagnosis were compared with the physician diagnosis n 3211 in a subsample of discordant case a comprehensive standardized clinical diagnostic interview dia x cidi wa applied result on the study day the prevalence of icd 10 depression wa 14 3 according to the dsq and 10 7 according to the physician diagnosis half of the patient identified by dsq were diagnosed with depression by their physician and two third were recognized a mental disorder case more severe depression symptomatology and the persistent presence of main depression symptom were related to better recognition and concordant diagnostic decision diagnostic validation interview confirmed the dsq diagnosis in the majority of the false negative case indication for at least a previous history of depression were found in up to 70 of false positive case conclusion given the high prevalence of depression in primary care patient there is continued need to improve the recognition and diagnosis of these patient to assure guideline oriented treatment

Title: Prevalence of prolonged grief disorder in a sample of female refugees
Authors: Steil, R.; Gutermann, J.; Harrison, O.; Starck, A.; Schwartzkopff, L.; Schouler-Ocak, M.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: background prolonged grief disorder pgd is a distinct syndrome that follows bereavement it is different from other mental disorder and is characterized by symptom such a yearning for the bereaved or intense emotional pain or distress violent loss is one major risk factor for the development of pgd objective pgd ha been studied in different population mostly in small sample with only a few of them being representative although research highlighted that traumatic experience paired with challenge related to migration make refugee particularly vulnerable to pgd pgd ha only rarely been studied in refugee thus this article a examines the prevalence of pgd in female refugee in germany according to the criterion proposed by prigerson and colleague in 2009 and b associate pgd with other common psychopathology e g anxiety depression somatization and trauma method a total of 106 female refugee were assessed for bereavement and pgd of these 106 individual 85 were interviewed using the prolonged grief disorder scale pg 13 symptom of anxiety and depression were assessed by the hopkins symptom checklist 25 hscl 25 somatization wa assessed by the somatization subscale of the symptom checklist 90 scl 90 and the number of witnessed and experienced trauma wa assessed by the posttraumatic diagnostic scale pd htq result ninety of the 106 participant had experienced bereavement and among those 9 41 met criterion for pgd the most frequent pgd symptom were bitterness longing or yearning for the bereaved and lack of acceptance of the loss furthermore grief symptom were significantly associated with symptom of depression anxiety somatization and the number of experienced traumatic event conclusion the pgd prevalence rate found corresponds with previous study demonstrating that prevalence rate for pgd are especially high in refugee high prevalence rate of bereavement a well a pgd highlight the need for assessment and specifically tailored treatment of pgd in refugee pgd go along with significant psychopathology which further emphasizes the need for treatment

Title: Early Adverse Effects of Behavioural Preventive Strategies During the COVID-19 Pandemic in Germany: An Online General Population Survey
Authors: Witthoft, M.; Jungmann, S. M.; Germer, S.; Brascher, A. K.
Abstract: background quarantine and physical distancing represent the two most important non pharmaceutical action to contain the covid 19 pandemic comparatively little is known about possible adverse consequence of these behavioural measure in germany this study aimed at investigating potential early adverse effect associated with quarantine and physical distancing at the beginning of the countrywide lockdown in germany in march 2020 method using a cross sectional online survey n 4 268 adverse consequence attributed to physical distancing symptom of psychopathology and sociodemographic variable were explored in the total sample a well a in high risk group i e people with a physical or mental condition result the most frequently reported adverse effect were impairment of spare time activity job related impairment and adverse emotional effect e g worry sadness participant with a mental disorder reported the highest level of adverse consequence across all domain compared to participant with a physical disease or participant without any mental or physical condition no significant association between the duration of the behavioural protective measure and the severity of adverse mental health effect wa observed conclusion result showed that non pharmaceutical action were associated with adverse effect particularly in people with mental disorder the finding are of relevance for tailoring support to special at risk group in time of behavioural preventive strategy

Title: Brain structural alterations associated with dysfunctional cognitive control of pain in patients with low back pain
Authors: Chehadi, O.; Rusu, A. C.; Konietzny, K.; Schulz, E.; Koster, O.; Schmidt-Wilcke, T.; Hasenbring, M. I.
Abstract: background recent evidence ha shown that chronic back pain cbp can lead to functional alteration in the circuitry underlying the cognitive control of pain thought suppression t is a common type of cognitive control of pain previous research ha shown that t ha paradoxical effect that may increase the awareness of pain pain related t may also increase individual attention to pain which may also increase pain sensation but thus far the relationship between pain related t and structural brain alteration is unknown method in this study we investigated a group of 30 patient 6 month after lumbar disc surgery by applying voxel based morphometry vbm to identify brain region correlated with t score result since pain related t ha been positively correlated with depression all calculation were controlled for depression and age vbm revealed a negative correlation between the t score and regional grey matter volume gmv in the left superior temporal gyrus lstg and the left middle temporal gyrus l mtg which is part of the left temporoparietal junction l tpj in addition a mediation analysis revealed a significant mediation effect of the pain related t on the association between gmv of the left tpj and reported pain intensity in the last 7 day conclusion these finding are consistent with previous research on the dysfunctional cognitive control of pain and may therefore provide potential insight into the neural substrate of obstructive cognitive control in chronic low back pain with a special emphasis on pain related t significance the link between pain related thought suppression and brain morphology may provide a new perspective on the understanding of cognitive control of pain in chronic low back pain which may help improve cognitive behavioural therapy

Title: Understanding the link between child maltreatment and adolescent future expectations in Northern Uganda: A serial mediation analysis
Authors: Saupe, L. B.; Gossmann, K.; Catani, C.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: background recent research ha identified high level of child maltreatment and harsh parenting in post war society which have had detrimental effect on child s development future expectation are an important aspect of adolescent development particularly in the challenging context of post war society where social instability and violence are prevalent to date however the link between child maltreatment and adolescent future expectation remains understudied objective by applying a socio ecological perspective this study aimed to investigate risk internalizing symptom and protective factor community integration linking experience of harsh parenting with adolescent future expectation participant and setting data wa collected from n 199 northern ugandan adolescent 40 2 female m age 14 56 year with structured interview method serial mediation analysis were calculated with child maltreatment a the predictor future expectation a the outcome and internalizing symptom a well a community integration a mediating variable result result of the mediation model r 2 22 f 5193 10 54 p 001 total effect b 0 28 p 005 revealed a direct effect of child maltreatment on future expectation effect size 20 95 bootstrap ci 0 40 01 a well a an indirect effect of child maltreatment via internalizing symptom and community integration on future expectation effect size of 07 95 bootstrap ci 0 14 0 01 conclusion child maltreatment wa found to be linked to negative future expectation among northern ugandan adolescent and both internalizing symptom a well a community integration played mediating role in the association intervention should take psychopathology and community factor into account

Title: Interpretation bias modification to reduce body dissatisfaction - a randomized controlled pilot study in women with elevated weight and shape concerns
Authors: Bradatsch, S.; Vahl, M. D.; Potterton, R.; Gordon, G.; Schmidt, U.; Brockmeyer, T.
Abstract: background recent research ha identified several cognitive bias in patient with eating disorder such a a tendency to interpret ambiguous information about one s own body in a negative way the so called negative interpretation bias is considered to be a key factor in maintaining maladaptive cognition and behavior in eating disorder study on modification of the negative interpretation bias in eating disorder have yielded mixed result this randomized controlled pilot study examined whether a specially adapted computerized version of the scrambled sentence task modifies negative interpretation bias in woman with elevated body dissatisfaction method the sample consisted of 40 normal weight woman with elevated body dissatisfaction randomly assigned either to an intervention or a no intervention control group each n 20 the intervention group received six session within two week of a newly developed interpretation bias modification training that involved unscrambling positively valenced body image related sentence the control group received no intervention in both group body image related negative interpretation bias main outcome trait body dissatisfaction and thin ideal cue reactivity were assessed at baseline and two week later additionally in the intervention condition the trajectory of expected reduction in the thin ideal internalization wa measured during each training session result in both condition body image related negative interpretation bias and trait body dissatisfaction decreased significantly from pre to post assessment however a specific effect imparted by the interpretation bias modification training wa not found group did not differ in thin ideal cue reactivity in the intervention group thin ideal internalization decreased significantly over the training session conclusion the finding do not support use of body image related interpretation bias modification in it current form in the treatment of body dissatisfaction further research involving different version of the training and clinical sample is warranted

Title: Differential associations of positive and negative expectations with depressive symptoms
Authors: Kube, T.; Herzog, P.
Abstract: background recent research suggests that dysfunctional expectation are a particularly important subtype of cognition in depression however it is unclear whether depressive symptom are related to the presence of negative expectation the absence of positive expectation or both method using hierarchical linear regression analysis the present study examined the predictive value of positive situation specific expectation negative situation specific expectation dispositional optimism and dysfunctional attitude for depressive symptom 8 week later in a nonclinical sample n 157 it also examined whether the relationship between dispositional optimism and dysfunctional attitude with depressive symptom is mediated through situational expectation result cross sectionally depressive symptom were more strongly associated with the presence of negative expectation than with the absence of positive expectation in the longitudinal and mediation analysis none of the cognitive variable had significant association with depressive symptom at follow up beyond the strong influence of baseline depressive symptom conclusion the presence of negative expectation wa cross sectionally more strongly associated with depressive symptom than a lack of positive expectation presumably due to higher variability in negative expectation in this nonclinical sample the longitudinal and mediation analysis failed to find significant incremental effect of any of the cognitive variable because baseline depression explained the largest proportion of variance

Title: Even when you know it is a placebo, you experience less sadness: First evidence from an experimental open-label placebo investigation
Authors: Hahn, A.; Gohler, A. C.; Hermann, C.; Winkler, A.
Abstract: background recent study demonstrate substantial effect of deceptive placebo on experimentally induced sadness even on autonomic activity whether deception is necessary remains to be elucidated we investigated the effect of an open label placebo olp treatment i e an openly administered placebo delivered with a convincing rationale for it sadness protecting effect method eighty four healthy female were randomized to an olp group or a no treatment control group all participant received the same detailed information about the olp effect only the olp group received an olp nasal spray before and after the olp intervention participant underwent a sad mood induction procedure combining self deprecating statement velten s method and sad music sadness wa assessed by the positive and negative affect schedule panas x autonomic activity wa measured continuously result participant in the olp group reported a significantly attenuated increase in sadness upon mood induction and le sadness after induction compared to the control group d 0 79 regardless of intervention heart rate decreased during mood induction with a more pronounced deceleration in the second mood induction limitation generalizability is limited due to the selective sample and the reliance on an experimentally controlled mood induction conclusion olp treatment had a beneficial effect on perceived sadness at least at the subjective level hence deception may not necessarily be required for placebo to modulate experienced sad mood investigating the beneficial effect of olp in sub clinical sample would seem a promising and required next step towards a clinical use of placebo associated positive treatment expectation

Title: An exploratory study of associations between the ICD-11 personality disorder model and eating pathology
Authors: Stricker, J.; Barthels, F.; Muller, R.; Pietrowsky, R.
Abstract: background recently the international classification of disease 11th revision icd 11 ha introduced a paradigm shift in personality disorder conceptualization the novel icd 11 personality disorder model comprises a dimensional assessment of personality dysfunction and five maladaptive personality trait domain maladaptive personality play a central role in eating pathology yet relation between the icd 11 personality disorder model and eating pathology are to date unclear thus this study aimed to explore the bivariate incremental and interactive association of the icd 11 personality disorder model component with eating pathology domain method a predominantly female 85 sample of 888 german speaking community adult completed validated self report measure of personality dysfunction the icd 11 personality trait domain and five eating pathology domain drive for thinness bulimia body dissatisfaction orthorexia binge eating bivariate and hierarchical regression model were used to investigate bivariate incremental and interactive relation between the icd 11 personality disorder model component and eating pathology result personality dysfunction and the icd 11 personality trait domain showed statistically significant bivariate relation with eating pathology additionally personality dysfunction and most icd 11 personality trait domain displayed incremental link with eating pathology finally the relation of the icd 11 personality trait domain with eating pathology were largely independent of the severity of personality dysfunction conclusion this study indicated that all icd 11 personality disorder model component are uniquely linked to eating pathology beyond maladaptive personality trait domain the strong and incremental relation of personality dysfunction with eating pathology have potential implication for theory building further research using longitudinal design is needed to evaluate causal link between the icd 11 personality disorder model component and eating pathology the international classification of disease 11th revision icd 11 contains a novel personality disorder model we explored how this model s component i e personality dysfunction five maladaptive personality trait relate to eating pathology the model component were significantly and complementarily related to a drive for thinness bulimia body dissatisfaction orthorexia and binge eating hence the icd 11 personality disorder model may potentially prove helpful in better understanding individual difference in eating pathology eng

Title: You Were Better Than Expected-An Experimental Study to Examine Expectation Change in a Non-clinical Sample
Authors: Groth, R. M.; Rief, W.
Abstract: background reduced sensitivity to reward a well a the tendency to maintain dysfunctional expectation despite expectation disconfirming evidence cognitive immunization are considered core feature of various mental disorder it is therefore important for clinical research to have paradigm that are suitable to study these phenomenon we developed a new experimental paradigm to study explicit expectation change after prior expectation induction and violation it validity is tested by applying the paradigm to healthy individual material and method in the main part of the study experiment 1 we examined whether it is possible to change healthy individual sample size 56 task specific and generalized performance expectation through expectation disconfirming experience we used a high difficulty performance task to induce initially negative expectation regarding participant ability to successfully work on that unknown task in the second part of the study the difficulty of the test wa lowered in one experimental condition in order to disconfirm the negative expectation of the first part while the other group continued with high test difficulty to confirm the negative expectation we measured the participant s explicit performance expectation before and after completing the test in experiment 2 sample size 57 we investigated the impact of different test instruction on expectation change using the same paradigm a in experiment 1 we added an immunization inhibiting manipulation for one group and an immunization enhancing manipulation for the other group result in experiment 1 we were able to show that individual changed their expectation according to variation of task difficulty adding instruction to manipulate cognitive immunization inhibited expectation change regardless of condition experiment 2 conclusion our approach allowed u to examine the effect of implicitly acquired performance expectation on explicit verbalized expectation change the new experimental paradigm used in this study is suitable to induce performance expectation and to examine expectation change among healthy individual experiment 1 instruction to enhance or inhibit cognitive immunization process both inhibited expectation change experiment 2 the result are discussed within the context of current model of expectation change cognitive immunization and reward sensitivity

Title: Reduced olfactory bulb volume in depression-A structural moderator analysis
Authors: Rottstadt, F.; Han, P.; Weidner, K.; Schellong, J.; Wolff-Stephan, S.; Strauss, T.; Kitzler, H.; Hummel, T.; Croy, I.
Abstract: background removal of the olfactory bulb ob lead to depression like behavior in rodent a link between depression and olfactory function is also established in human we hypothesized that the human ob volume relates to depressive state and tested whether such a potential coherence is moderated by structural alteration in other brain region method eighty three participant 32 patient with major depression and 51 matched healthy control underwent structural mr scanning individual ob volume were compared between patient and control and the impact of depression and comorbidity wa analyzed with multiple regression analysis whole brain voxel based morphometry revealed structure co varying with both depressive state and ob volume result the ob volume of patient wa significantly reduced and this reduction averaged out at 17 compared to the control the ob volume wa correlated to the volume of the insula superior temporal cortex and amygdala the independent variable of depression beta 37 age beta 25 and gender beta 40 explained the individual ob volume variation r 2 37 the correlation between ob volume and depression wa moderated by volumetric reduction in a cluster including the insula and superior temporal gyrus stg conclusion the ob volume relates to depression in human and to the volume of structure which are critical for salience detection we assume that a reduced ob volume cause diminished neural olfactory input which facilitates volume reduction in the insula and stg the ob volume may hence constitute a factor of vulnerability to depression olfactory based deep brain stimulation is discussed a a future therapeutic approach

Title: Repetitive Negative Thinking About Suicide: Associations With Lifetime Suicide Attempts
Authors: Teismann, T.; Forkmann, T.; Michalak, J.; Brailovskaia, J.
Abstract: background repetitive negative thinking ha been identified a an important predictor of suicide ideation and suicidal behavior yet only few study have investigated the effect of suicide specific rumination i e repetitive thinking about death and or suicide on suicide attempt history on this background the present study investigated whether suicide specific rumination differentiates between suicide attempter and suicide ideators is predictive of suicide attempt history and mediates the association between suicide ideation and suicide attempt method a total of 257 participant with a history of suicide ideation 55 6 female age m 30 56 age sd 11 23 range 18 73 year completed online measure on suicidality general and suicide specific rumination result suicide specific rumination differentiated suicide attempter from suicide ideators predicted suicide attempt status above age gender suicide ideation general rumination and fully mediated the association between suicide ideation and lifetime suicide attempt conclusion overall though limited by the use of a non clinical sample and a cross sectional study design the present result suggest that suicide specific rumination might be a factor of central relevance in understanding transition to suicidal behavior

Title: Frequency of child maltreatment in a representative sample of the German population
Authors: Iffland, B.; Brahler, E.; Neuner, F.; Hauser, W.; Glaesmer, H.
Abstract: background representative data about the frequency of child maltreatment is needed in order to estimate the extent of the problem in the wider population a well a to provide the basis for interpretation of frequency rate in clinical sample however previous representative study on the frequency of child maltreatment in germany and other country were limited a they focused on the assessment of physical and sexual abuse whilst emotional form of maltreatment were ignored in addition previous study applied scale that had not been validated against external criterion method in a cross sectional study standardized questionnaire were administered to a representative sample of the german population maltreatment in childhood and adolescence wa assessed using the german version of the childhood trauma questionnaire empirically derived threshold value for the five different type of child maltreatment including emotional maltreatment were applied to determine presence of abuse and neglect result complete data wa available from n 2 500 subject prevalence rate were 13 9 for emotional neglect 10 2 for emotional abuse 12 0 for physical abuse 48 4 for physical neglect and 6 2 for sexual abuse difference between sex were found for the frequency of sexual abuse conclusion although our analysis ha found lower rate of child maltreatment than previous report that used le well validated criterion the result of this study confirm that child abuse with it many different facet is a significant problem in germany

Title: Why dysfunctional expectations in depression persist - Results from two experimental studies investigating cognitive immunization
Authors: Kube, T.; Rief, W.; Gollwitzer, M.; Gartner, T.; Glombiewski, J. A.
Abstract: background research ha revealed that negative expectation impact depressive symptom however research on the change of dysfunctional expectation in depression is lacking so far therefore the present research aimed to fill this gap by testing the hypothesis that people with the major depressive disorder mdd contrary to healthy individual maintain their expectation despite experience that positively disconfirm expectation further it wa hypothesized that cognitive immunization a cognitive reappraisal of the disconfirming evidence is a mechanism underlying the persistence of expectation method in study 1 we compared individual with mdd n 58 to healthy individual n 59 participant worked on the same performance test and received standardized feedback that either confirmed or disconfirmed their initial performance expectation in study 2 we investigated the effect of cognitive immunization on expectation change among 59 individual reporting elevated level of depression by varying the appraisal of expectation disconfirming feedback result result from study 1 show that in the expectation disconfirming condition healthy individual changed their expectation whereas individual with mdd did not no such difference between the two group wa found for expectation confirming feedback result from study 2 indicated that varying cognitive immunization impacted expectation change thus suggesting a crucial role of cognitive immunization in expectation change conclusion these two study indicated that individual suffering from depression have more difficulty in changing their expectation after disconfirming experience than do healthy individual and cognitive immunization might be a core mechanism underlying expectation persistence therefore psychotherapeutic intervention should aim to inhibit cognitive immunization process to enhance expectation change

Title: How to modify persisting negative expectations in major depression? An experimental study comparing three strategies to inhibit cognitive immunization against novel positive experiences
Authors: Kube, T.; Glombiewski, J. A.; Gall, J.; Touissant, L.; Gartner, T.; Rief, W.
Abstract: background research ha shown that negative expectation in major depressive disorder mdd often persist despite positive disconfirming experience to explain this phenomenon the concept of cognitive immunization ha been introduced that is individual with mdd reappraise disconfirming positive evidence in such a way that negative expectation are maintained in this study we examined whether it is possible to inhibit cognitive immunization to facilitate expectation update method we examined 113 people with mdd being treated in an inpatient psychosomatic hospital using a previously validated paradigm participant worked on a standardized performance test we examined change in negative performance related expectation after positive expectation disconfirming feedback one experimental group received additional information increasing the value of the positive feedback information another group wa instructed to recall the feedback after completing the task recall in a third group participant attention wa shifted to potential expectation disconfirming feedback attention in addition a control group underwent the standard procedure of the paradigm result the result showed significant group difference in the change in generalized performance expectation with the largest change in participant from the information group all experimental group had lower value for cognitive immunization than the control group limitation given that this proof of concept study wa the first to examine strategy to inhibit cognitive immunization the finding need to be replicated in future study conclusion the present study confirms that cognitive immunization in mdd can be inhibited thus facilitating adjusting negative expectation the most promising result were found for the information group providing information to emphasize the relevance of expectation disconfirming information

Title: Sad as a Matter of Evidence: The Desire for Self-Verification Motivates the Pursuit of Sadness in Clinical Depression
Authors: Arens, E. A.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: background research on desired emotion revealed that individual want to feel negative emotion if they expect these emotion to yield certain benefit in previous study the pursuit of sadness e g via pursuing art that evokes sadness ha been attributed to hedonic motif i e to feel pleasure we propose that in individual with major depressive disorder mdd the pursuit of sadness may be more strongly related to self verification motif i e to sustain their sense of self through feeling sad method participant with mdd n 50 were compared to non depressed control n 50 in their desired emotional state a indicated by selected music sad happy and neutral and in their motif hedonic v self verification for choosing sad music group were also compared in their self reported general preference for sadness and the perceived functionality of sadness result mdd participant showed a significant higher desire for sadness more than half of them deliberately chose sad music whereas mdd participant had a marked preference for self verification over hedonic motif the reverse wa true for non depressed control mdd participant also agreed more strongly with self verifying function of sadness and expressed a stronger general preference for sadness conclusion finding indicate that emotion regulation in mdd might be driven by self verification motif they point to the relevance of exploring patient desired emotional state and associated motif the systematic integration of positive affect into the self image of depressed patient might help to deemphasize the self verifying function of sadness thereby overcoming the depression

Title: Effectiveness of a web-based cognitive behavioural intervention for subthreshold depression: pragmatic randomised controlled trial
Authors: Buntrock, C.; Ebert, D.; Lehr, D.; Riper, H.; Smit, F.; Cuijpers, P.; Berking, M.
Abstract: background research on the effectiveness of treatment for subthreshold depression sd is still scarce the aim of the study wa to evaluate the efficacy of a web based guided self help intervention get on mood enhancer in the treatment of sd method participant with sd n 406 recruited from the general population via a large health insurance company were randomly allocated to a web based cognitive behavioural intervention or to enhanced care a usual the primary outcome wa the reduction in depressive symptom severity a measured with the center for epidemiological study depression scale at post treatment and at 6 month follow up result participant in the intervention group showed a significantly greater pre post reduction in depressive symptom severity d 1 06 95 ci 0 86 1 27 compared to the control condition d 0 29 95 ci 0 10 0 49 the corresponding between group effect size wa d 0 69 95 ci 0 49 0 89 at 6 month follow up the effect wa reduced to d 0 28 95 ci 0 09 0 48 but wa still statistically significant f1 403 9 240 p 0 003 conclusion this study lends support to the idea that problem solving coupled with behavioural activation is an effective treatment for sd in addition the delivery of this intervention over the internet might be a promising strategy for the dissemination of psychological intervention for sd on a large scale

Title: Placebo prevents rumination: An experimental study
Authors: Rebstock, L.; Schafer, L. N.; Kube, T.; Ehmke, V.; Rief, W.
Abstract: background rumination is a risk factor for the development and maintenance of depressive symptom and represents an important target for the treatment of depression in the present study we aimed to examine whether rumination can be reduced when participant are led to believe that they would receive medication that would prevent them from ruminating method in healthy participant n 91 an initial dysphoric state wa induced via mood suggestive music and autobiographic recall subsequently participant were randomly assigned to one of two group an experimental group that received a deceptive active placebo via intranasal application accompanied by expectancy enhancing instruction v a no treatment control group then rumination wa induced via a rumination activating task the primary outcome wa current rumination experienced sadness wa considered a secondary outcome result consistent with the hypothesis participant receiving the placebo reported a significantly lower increase in current rumination d 0 57 and a higher decrease in sadness d 0 69 after the experimental induction than the control group limitation the external validity of this study might be limited due to the highly educated student sample conclusion the result suggest that rumination process a well a experienced sadness can be positively influenced by placebo treatment to evaluate it clinical potential placebo induced expectancy effect in rumination research should be further examined particularly with clinically depressed patient also the result imply that clinician might consider the effect of expectation on patient rumination tendency for example by explicitly addressing patient expectation about rumination mood and the treatment in general

Title: Psychophysiological mechanisms underlying the failure to speak: a comparison between children with selective mutism and social anxiety disorder on autonomic arousal
Authors: Vogel, F.; Schwenck, C.
Abstract: background selective mutism sm ha been conceptualized a an extreme variant of social anxiety disorder sad in which the failure to speak function a an avoidance mechanism leading to a reduction of intense fear arousal however psychophysiological study in child with sm are scarce and physiological mechanism underlying the failure to speak are largely unknown in contrast child with sad are characterized by a combination of a chronically elevated physiological arousal and a blunted physiological fear response to social stress due to the large overlap between sm and sad similar mechanism might apply to both disorder while difference might explain why child with sm fail to speak the aim of our study is to investigate psychophysiological mechanism of the failure to speak in child with sm method we assessed in a total of n 96 child 8 12 year sm n 31 sad n 32 typical development td n 33 resting baseline arousal in absence of social threat and the course of physiological fear response in two social stress paradigm differing in term of whether the child are expected to speak verbal task or not nonverbal task result child with sm were characterized by increased tonic arousal compared to the other two group and by a more inflexible stress response in the nonverbal but not in the verbal task compared to td child further analysis revealed that child with sm who did not speak during the verbal task already demonstrated reduced arousal in anticipation of the verbal task conclusion the increased tonic arousal generalized to non social situation in sm could indicate a long term alteration of the autonomic nervous system furthermore the differential physiological stress response may indicate that silence act a a maladaptive compensatory mechanism reducing stress in verbal social situation which doe not function in nonverbal situation our finding support the idea that the failure to speak might function a an avoidance mechanism which is already active in anticipation of a verbal situation treatment of sm should take into account that child with sm may suffer from chronically elevated stress level and that different mechanism might operate in verbal and nonverbal social situation

Title: The relationship between attachment to pets and mental health: the shared link via attachment to humans
Authors: Lass-Hennemann, J.; Schafer, S. K.; Sopp, M. R.; Michael, T.
Abstract: background several study have investigated the relationship between emotional attachment to pet and mental health with the majority of study finding a negative relationship between emotional attachment to pet and mental health interestingly attachment to pet differs from attachment to human with study showing that human with an insecure attachment style form a particularly strong emotional attachment to their companion animal human attachment style is also related to mental health with secure attachment being associated with superior mental health building on those finding the current study aimed at exploring the role of attachment to human in the relationship between emotional attachment to pet and mental health method in this cross sectional online survey n 610 we assessed the strength of emotional attachment to pet and attachment to human we further collected pet specific data a well a mental health burden in a sample of german dog owner m age 33 12 92 79 woman we used a mediation model estimating the indirect link between emotional attachment to pet and mental health burden via human attachment and the direct link between emotional attachment to pet and mental health burden simultaneously result we found that attachment to human fully mediated the positive association between emotional attachment to pet and mental health burden a stronger emotional attachment to one s dog wa associated with lower comfort with depending on or trusting in others whereby lower comfort with depending on or trusting in others wa related to higher mental health burden moreover a stronger attachment to one s dog wa also related to a greater fear of being rejected and unloved anxiety which wa in turn associated with a higher mental health burden conclusion our finding suggest that the positive link between emotional attachment to pet and mental health burden is fully accounted for by it shared variance with insecure attachment to human in a sample mostly comprising self identified woman future study need to examine whether strong emotional bond with pet may evolve a a compensatory strategy to buffer difficult childhood bonding experience

Title: Discrepancies Between Explicit Feelings of Power and Implicit Power Motives Are Related to Anxiety in Women With Anorexia Nervosa
Authors: Weineck, F.; Schultchen, D.; Dunker, F.; Hauke, G.; Lachenmeir, K.; Schnebel, A.; Karacic, M.; Meule, A.; Voderholzer, U.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: background several study identified low subjective feeling of power in woman with anorexia nervosa an however little is known about implicit power motif and the discrepancy between explicit feeling of power and implicit power motif in an aim the study investigated the discrepancy between explicit feeling of power and implicit power motif and it relationship to anxiety in patient with an method fifty three outpatient and inpatient with an and 48 participant without an were compared regarding subjective feeling of power and anxiety explicit power investigated with the personal sense of power scale trait focus and a visual analog scale state focus implicit power motif investigated with the multi motive grid mmg and trait anxiety measured with the state trait anxiety inventory stai were assessed result explicit feeling of power state and trait level were lower in patient with an compared to non an participant no difference in implicit power motif were found when comparing the group against each other however looking at the group separately woman with an had similar level of implicit fear of losing power and hope for power whereas woman without an had significantly lower fear of losing power than hope for power focusing on discrepancy between powerful feeling and power motif result were mixed depending on the subscale of the mmg lastly discrepancy between implicit power motif and explicit feeling of power were positively correlated with trait anxiety in an patient conclusion these finding underline that individual with an display significantly lower explicit feeling of power however they show similar implicit power motif compared to individual without an the discrepancy between explicit feeling of power and implicit power motif is related to anxiety in an and may represent a vulnerability factor to illness maintenance

Title: Silence and related symptoms in children and adolescents: a network approach to selective mutism
Authors: Vogel, F.; Reichert, J.; Schwenck, C.
Abstract: background silence in certain situation represents the core symptom of selective mutism sm however it is unclear what additional symptom are part of this disorder although knowledge of symptom is essential for diagnostics and intervention to date only scarce research exists on circumscribed symptom of sm given the large overlap between sm and social anxiety disorder sad it remains also unclear which symptom can differentiate both disorder method a network analysis of potential symptom of sm wa performed based on a mixed sample of n 899 child and adolescent with and without indication of sm n 629 with silence in certain situation in a preliminary analysis we demonstrated that child with and without silence in certain situation do not differ with respect to their network structure justifying an analysis on the entire mixed sample possible community symptom cluster within the network and thus potential latent variable were examined and symptom were analyzed in term of their centrality the extent to which they are associated with other symptom in the network to investigate the differentiability of symptom of the sm network from symptom of sad we computed a network that additionally contains symptom of sad result in the resulting network on symptom of sm silence wa a expected the symptom with the highest centrality we identified two community symptom cluster 1 symptom associated with the fear response of freezing 2 symptom associated with speech production and avoidance sm network symptom and sad symptom largely formed two separate symptom cluster with only selectivity of speaking behavior more talkative at home and taciturn or mute outside the home falling into a common cluster with sad symptom conclusion silence appears to have been confirmed by analysis a a core symptom of sm additional anxiety related symptom such a avoidance behavior or motor inhibition associated with freezing seem to co occur with silence the two community of sm potentially indicate different mechanism of silence the symptom of sm appear to be distinguishable from those of sad although there seems to be overlap in term of difficulty speaking in situation outside the home

Title: Post-traumatic stress disorder and depression among Syrian refugees residing in the Kurdistan region of Iraq
Authors: Mahmood, H. N.; Ibrahim, H.; Goessmann, K.; Ismail, A. A.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: background since the syrian civil war began in march 2011 more than half of the syrian population wa forced to escape from their home and more than 5 million of them fled their country the aim of the present study is to estimate the psychological consequence of this conflict among the refugee population who fled to iraq method in 2017 a team of locally trained psychologist and social worker interviewed 494 married couple 988 individual who were syrian kurdish refugee in the kurdistan region of iraq validated kurdish kurmanji and arabic version of post traumatic stress disorder ptsd checklist for dsm 5 and depression section of hopkins symptom checklist 25 were used for assessing ptsd and depression symptom result almost all of the participant 98 5 had experienced at least one traumatic event and 86 3 of them experienced three or more traumatic event type the prevalence of probable ptsd wa about 60 gender length of time in the camp area in which participant were grown up and the number of traumatic event type were significant predictor for the presence of ptsd symptom approximately the same rate of participant 59 4 experienced probable depression which wa associated with gender age time spent in the camp and the number of traumatic event type conclusion ptsd and depression are prevalent among refugee exposed to traumatic event and various variable play important role the pattern of risk factor in this population is consistent with finding from war affected population in other region and should be considered for intervention within this population and more broadly

Title: Visual Triggers of Skin Picking Episodes: An Experimental Study in Self-Reported Skin Picking Disorder and Atopic Dermatitis
Authors: Mehrmann, L. M.; Urban, A.; Gerlach, A. L.
Abstract: background skin picking disorder spd is a new diagnosis with limited information available about trigger of picking episode itch can be induced via audio visual stimulus and the effect of contagious itch is stronger for those affected by atopic dermatitis we examined if picking related visual stimulus can trigger the urge to pick skin in self reported spd we compared itch and the urge to pick in a sample of ad and or spd affected to control without either method urge to pick skin and or scratch when viewing 24 itch related picking related or neutral online picture wa assessed in adult female who self report skin picking spd only n 147 and or atopic dermatitis ad only n 47 ad spd n 46 a well a in skin healthy control hc n 361 result all participant reported a stronger urge to pick for picking related picture compared to neutral content f 1 597 533 96 p 001 etap2 472 and more itch for itch related picture compared to neutral stimulus f 1 597 518 73 p 001 etap2 465 spd all spd only ad spd reported stronger urge to pick for picking related v other stimulus compared to the ad only and hc group p 001 etap2 047 likewise ad all ad only ad spd reported significantly stronger itching for itch related v other stimulus compared to spd only and hc p 001 etap2 019 conclusion analog to visual provocation of itch the urge to pick can be triggered by visual stimulus treatment for spd and ad may profit from addressing visual stimulus

Title: The effect of depressive symptomatology on the association of vitamin D and sleep
Authors: Mergl, R.; Dogan-Sander, E.; Willenberg, A.; Wirkner, K.; Kratzsch, J.; Riedel-Heller, S.; Allgaier, A. K.; Hegerl, U.; Sander, C.
Abstract: background sleep disorder and vitamin d deficiency are highly prevalent health problem few study examined the effect of vitamin d concentration on objectively measured sleep with high methodological quality and temporal proximity previous analysis within the life adult study suggested that a lower concentration of serum vitamin d wa associated with both shorter and later night sleep however no conclusion about underlying mechanism could be drawn we addressed the question whether this relationship is explained by the presence of depressive syndrome which are linked to both vitamin d deficiency and sleep disturbance method it wa investigated whether the association of vitamin d concentration and night sleep parameter is mediated or moderated by depressive symptomatology we investigated a subset n 1252 of the community sample from the life adult study in which sleep parameter had been objectively assessed using actigraphy based on which two sleep parameter were calculated night sleep duration and midsleep time serum 25 oh d concentration were measured using an electrochemiluminescence immunoassay depressive symptomatology wa evaluated with the centre for epidemiological study depression scale the mediation effect wa analyzed by using hayes process macro tool for spss for window result the depressive symptomatology wa neither significantly associated with night sleep duration nor midsleep time the association between vitamin d concentration and night sleep duration midsleep time through mediation by depressive symptomatology were not significant corresponding moderator analysis were also non significant conclusion the association between vitamin d concentration and night sleep parameter sleep duration and midsleep time seem to be neither mediated nor moderated by depressive symptomatology

Title: Sleep and somatic complaints in university students
Authors: Schlarb, A. A.; Classen, M.; Hellmann, S. M.; Vogele, C.; Gulewitsch, M. D.
Abstract: background sleep problem are common among university student poor sleep is associated with impaired daily functioning increased risk of psychiatric symptom and somatic complaint such a pain previous result suggest that poor sleep exacerbates pain which in turn negatively affect sleep the purpose of the present study wa to determine prevalence rate comorbidity and role of depression a a factor of moderating the relationship between sleep and physical complaint in german university student sample and method in total 2443 german university student 65 woman completed a web survey self report measure included the pittsburg sleep quality index three module of the patient health questionnaire and a questionnaire on the functional somatic syndrome f result more than one third 36 9 reported poor sleep a assessed by the pittsburgh sleep quality index somatoform syndrome wa identified in 23 5 and the prevalence of any f wa 12 8 self reported sleep quality sleep onset latency sleep disturbance use of sleep medication and daytime dysfunctioning were significant predictor of somatoform syndrome whereas sleep efficiency and sleep duration influenced somatic complaint indirectly moderate correlation were found between stress anxiety somatoform syndrome depression and overall sleep quality the effect of somatic complaint on sleep quality wa associated with the severity of depression anxiety show direct effect on somatization and depression but only indirect association with sleep quality

Title: Differences between self- and peer-rated likability in relation to social anxiety and depression in adolescents with mild intellectual disabilities
Authors: Klein, A. M.; Houtkamp, E. O.; Salemink, E.; Baartmans, J. M. D.; Rinck, M.; van der Molen, M. J.
Abstract: background social anxiety and depressive symptom are relatively common in adolescent with mild to borderline intellectual disability mbid unfortunately there are only a few study that focus on examining process underlying social anxiety and depression in these adolescent aim the aim wa to examine the difference between self and peer rated likability in relation to social anxiety and depression in the classroom environment method and procedure 631 normative non clinical adolescent with mbid completed questionnaire to measure social anxiety depression and the estimation of their own likability by peer peer reported likability wa derived from peer rating scale on likability outcome and result adolescent with higher level of social anxiety significantly rated their own likability a lower than their non anxious peer however socially adolescent were equally liked by their peer adolescent with higher level of depression were significantly le liked by their peer but still underestimated their own likability than adolescent with lower level of depression conclusion and implication social anxiety and depression are linked to a biased interpretation of likability but only depression is linked to actually being le liked by peer social anxiety and depression are partly based on similar underlying cognitive bias

Title: Inferring other people's states of mind: Comparison across social anxiety, body dysmorphic, and obsessive-compulsive disorders
Authors: Buhlmann, U.; Wacker, R.; Dziobek, I.
Abstract: background social anxiety disorder sad and body dysmorphic disorder bdd are characterized by fear of negative evaluation by others related to one s own incompetence or flawed appearance respectively previous research ha shown that individual with sad and bdd exhibit difficulty identifying facial expression and interpretive bias for threat in social situation the current study aimed at further investigating social cognition in sad bdd and mentally healthy control 35 individual per group respectively further 35 individual with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd a a clinical control group not characterized by evaluation fear were included method the movie for the assessment of social cognition masc wa applied it consists of 45 video sequence depicting interaction among four people at a dinner party participant are instructed to evaluate each scenario with respect to the character emotion thought and intention from a bystander perspective i e other referent context result only the socially anxious group sad and bdd were overall le accurate than the other group in correctly interpreting the social situation whereas no difference wa obtained between the ocd and the control group further analysis indicated that the sad and bdd group were le accurate in identifying other people s thought and intention whereas again no difference wa observed between the ocd and control group in addition the sad group wa le accurate in inferring thought and intention than the ocd group interestingly the group did not differ with respect to identifying other people s emotion conclusion these result mostly confirm existing cognitive behavioral model of sad and bdd emphasizing that biased interpretation of what others think or intend is one of the key factor maintaining social anxiety and appearance related concern our study show that this bias generalizes to social situation in which individual take a third person observer perspective

Title: Familial Accumulation of Social Anxiety Symptoms and Maladaptive Emotion Regulation
Authors: Asbrand, J.; Svaldi, J.; Kramer, M.; Breuninger, C.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.
Abstract: background social anxiety is thought to be strongly related to maladaptive emotion regulation er a social anxiety symptom accumulate in family we hypothesize that maladaptive er is also more prevalent in family with anxious child thus we analyze difference in emotion regulation of both child and mother in relation to social anxiety a well a both their er strategy in dealing with anxiety further a positive relation between child and maternal er strategy is assumed method child aged 9 to 13 year with social anxiety disorder sad n 25 and healthy control hc n 26 a well a their mother completed several measure of social anxiety and trait er strategy towards anxiety a er of child is still in development age is considered a covariate result sad child and their mother reported more maladaptive er strategy than hc dyad maternal maladaptive er wa related negatively to child adaptive er which wa further moderated by the child s age discussion maladaptive er strategy seem to contribute to the exacerbation of social anxiety in both mother and child mother reporting maladaptive er may have difficulty supporting their child in coping with social anxiety while simultaneously also experiencing heightened level of anxiety deeper understanding of interactional process between mother and child during development can assist the comprehension of factor maintaining sad implication for future research and possible consequence for intervention are discussed

Title: The trauma of peer abuse: effects of relational peer victimization and social anxiety disorder on physiological and affective reactions to social exclusion
Authors: Iffland, B.; Sansen, L. M.; Catani, C.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: background social exclusion elicits emotional distress negative mood and physiological stress recent study showed that these effect were more intense and persisting in socially anxious subject the present study examined whether the abnormal reaction of socially anxious subject can be traced back to previous experience of relational peer victimization during childhood and adolescence method participant n 74 were patient with a diagnosis of social anxiety disorder a well a healthy control the patient and control group were subdivided into two subgroup according to the subject s report about previous relational peer victimization immediate and delayed physiological skin conductance level and heart rate and affective reaction to a simulated social exclusion in a ball toss game cyberball were recorded result overall subject immediate reaction to social exclusion were an increase in skin conductance and a reduction of positive affect regardless of the diagnostic status subject with a history of relational peer victimization showed a more intense self reported affective change that wa accompanied by a blunted skin conductance response however the mood of the subject with a history of peer victimization recovered during a 15 min waiting period a diagnosis of social anxiety disorder did not affect the reaction to social exclusion on any measure conclusion finding indicate that stress reaction to social exclusion depend more on previous experience of peer victimization than on a diagnosis of social anxiety disorder the finding indicate that memory of negative social experience can determine the initial stress reaction to social threat

Title: Rapid heartbeat, but dry palms: reactions of heart rate and skin conductance levels to social rejection
Authors: Iffland, B.; Sansen, L. M.; Catani, C.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: background social rejection elicits negative mood emotional distress and neural activity in network that are associated with physical pain however study assessing physiological reaction to social rejection are rare and result of these study were found to be ambiguous therefore the present study aimed to examine and specify physiological effect of social rejection method participant n 50 were assigned to either a social exclusion or inclusion condition of a virtual ball tossing game cyberball immediate and delayed physiological skin conductance level scl and heart rate reaction were recorded in addition subject reported level of affect emotional state and fundamental need result subject who were socially rejected showed increased heart rate however social rejection had no effect on subject scls both condition showed heightened arousal on this measurement furthermore psychological consequence of social rejection indicated the validity of the paradigm conclusion our result reveal that social rejection evokes an immediate physiological reaction accelerated heart rate indicate that behavior activation rather than inhibition is associated with socially threatening event in addition result revealed gender specific response pattern suggesting that sample characteristic such a difference in gender may account for ambiguous finding of physiological reaction to social rejection

Title: Social Rhythm and Mental Health: A Cross-Cultural Comparison
Authors: Margraf, J.; Lavallee, K.; Zhang, X.; Schneider, S.
Abstract: background social rhythm refers to the regularity with which one engages in social activity throughout the week and ha established link with bipolar disorder a well a some link with depression and anxiety the aim of the present study is to examine social rhythm and it relationship to various aspect of health including physical health negative mental health and positive mental health method questionnaire data were obtained from a large scale multi national sample of 8095 representative participant from the u s russia and germany result result indicated that social rhythm irregularity is related to increased reporting of health problem depression anxiety and stress in contrast greater regularity is related to better overall health state life satisfaction and positive mental health the effect are generally small in size but hold even when controlling for gender marital status education income country and social support further social rhythm mean differ across russia the u s and germany relationship with mental health are present in all three country but differ in magnitude conclusion social rhythm irregularity is related to mental health in russia the u s and germany

Title: Feasibility of a Software agent providing a brief Intervention for Self-help to Uplift psychological wellbeing ("SISU"). A single-group pretest-posttest trial investigating the potential of SISU to act as therapeutic agent
Authors: Bendig, E.; Erb, B.; Meissner, D.; Bauereiss, N.; Baumeister, H.
Abstract: background software agent are computer program that conduct conversation with a human the present study evaluates the feasibility of the software agent sisu aiming to uplift psychological wellbeing method within a one group pretest posttest trial n 30 german speaking participant were recruited assessment took place before t1 during t2 and after t3 the intervention the ability of sisu to guide participant through the intervention acceptability and negative effect were investigated data analysis are based on intention to treat principle linear mixed model will be used to investigate short term change over time in mood depression anxiety intervention the intervention consists of two session each session comprises writing task on autobiographical negative life event and an acceptance and commitment therapy based exercise respectively participant interact with the software agent on two consecutive day for about 30 min each result all participant completed all session within two day user experience wa positive with all subscales of the user experience questionnaire ueq m 0 8 participant experienced their writing a highly self relevant and personal however 57 of the participant reported at least one negative effect attributed to the intervention result on linear mixed model indicate an increase in anxiety over time beta 1 33 p 001 qualitative user feedback revealed that the best thing about sisu wa it innovativeness 13 and anonymity 13 a worst thing about sisu participant indicated that the conversational style of sisu often felt unnatural 73 conclusion sisu successfully guided participant through the two day intervention moreover sisu ha the potential to enter the inner world of participant however intervention content have the potential to evoke negative effect in individual expectable short term symptom deterioration due to writing about negative autobiographical life event could not be prevented by acceptance and commitment therapy based exercise hence result suggest a revision of intervention content a well a of the conversational style of sisu the good adherence rate indicates the useful and acceptable format of sisu a a mental health chatbot overall little is known about the effectiveness of software agent in the context of psychological wellbeing result of the present trial underline that the innovative technology bear the potential of sisu to act a therapeutic agent but should not be used with it current intervention content trial registration the trial is registered at the who international clinical trial registry platform via the german clinical study register drks drks00014933 date of registration 20 06 2018 link http www drks de drks_web navigate do navigationid trial html trial_id drks00014933

Title: Catastrophizing misinterpretations predict somatoform-related symptoms and new onsets of somatoform disorders
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Zhang, X. C.; Becker, E. S.; Zlomuzica, A.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background somatoform disorder are characterized by multiple recurring symptom that resemble physical illness but defy medical explanation psychological model suggest that catastrophizing misinterpretation of harmless physical symptom play a key role however the question of whether such bias predict somatoform related symptom and the onset of somatoform disorder ha not been adressed hence the aim of the present study wa to further advance our understanding of the role of catastrophizing misinterpretation in somatoform disorder method in the present study we used data from the dresden predictor study n 1538 in which an epidemiologic sample of young german woman wa tested at two time point approximately 17 month apart each participant completed a diagnostic interview an interpretation questionnaire for somatoform and hypochondriacal symptom and three measure of such symptomatology somatization subscale of the symptom checklist 90 revised scl 90 r whiteley index wi body sensation questionnaire bsq result at follow up 33 woman were diagnosed with new onset of lifetime somatoform disorder result showed that catastrophizing misinterpretation assessed at baseline were predictive of somatoform related symptom at follow up i e symptom assessed with the wi and bsq moreover catastrophizing misinterpretation were predictive of new onset of somatoform disorder even after controlling for general threat related misinterpretation and index of somatoform symptom i e scl 90 r and bsq conclusion this is the first prospective longitudinal study to demonstrate that catastrophizing misinterpretation have incremental validity a predictor of future somatoform related symptomatology and somatoform disorder

Title: How individuals change during internet-based interventions for depression: A randomized controlled trial comparing standardized and individualized feedback
Authors: Zagorscak, P.; Heinrich, M.; Bohn, J.; Stein, J.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: background standardized and individualized internet based intervention ibi for depression yield significant symptom improvement however change pattern during standardized or individualized ibi are unknown identifying subgroup that experience different symptom course during ibi and their characteristic is vital for improving response method mildly to moderately depressed individual according to self report n 1 089 were randomized to receive module wise feedback that wa either standardized or individualized by a counselor within an otherwise identical cognitive behavioral ibi for depression seven module over six week depressive symptom were assessed at baseline and before each module patient health questionnaire phq 9 other individual characteristic self report and the presence of an affective disorder structured clinical interview were assessed at baseline growth mixture modeling wa used to identify and compare subgroup with discernable change pattern and associated client variable across condition result model comparison suggest equal change pattern in both condition across condition a group of immediate 62 5 and a group of delayed improver 37 5 were identified immediate improver decreased their phq 9 score by 5 5 point from pre to post with 33 of improvement occurring before treatment commenced delayed improver were characterized by stable symptom severity during the first two module and smaller overall symptom decrease 3 4 point higher treatment expectation a current major depressive disorder interview and lower social support were associated with delayed improvement conclusion internet based intervention for depression with individualized and with standardized feedback lead to comparable pattern of change expectation management and bolstering of social support are promising strategy for individual that are at risk for delayed improvement

Title: Acute stress differentially affects spatial configuration learning in high and low cortisol-responding healthy adults
Authors: Meyer, T.; Smeets, T.; Giesbrecht, T.; Quaedflieg, C. W.; Merckelbach, H.
Abstract: background stress and stress hormone modulate memory formation in various way that are relevant to our understanding of stress related psychopathology such a posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd particular relevance is attributed to efficient memory formation sustained by the hippocampus and parahippocampus this process is thought to reduce the occurrence of intrusion and flashback following trauma but may be negatively affected by acute stress moreover recent evidence suggests that the efficiency of visuo spatial processing and learning based on the hippocampal area is related to ptsd symptom objective the current study investigated the effect of acute stress on spatial configuration learning using a spatial contextual cueing task scct known to heavily rely on structure in the parahippocampus method acute stress wa induced by subjecting participant n 34 to the maastricht acute stress test mast following a counterbalanced within subject approach the effect of stress and the ensuing hormonal i e cortisol activity on subsequent scct performance were compared to scct performance following a no stress control condition result acute stress did not impact scct learning overall but opposing effect emerged for high versus low cortisol responder to the mast learning score following stress were reduced in low cortisol responder while high cortisol responding participant showed improved learning conclusion the effect of stress on spatial configuration learning were moderated by the magnitude of endogenous cortisol secretion these finding suggest a possible mechanism by which cortisol response serve an adaptive function during stress and trauma and this may prove to be a promising route for future research in this area

Title: Hair-based biomarkers in women with major depressive disorder: Glucocorticoids, endocannabinoids, N-acylethanolamines, and testosterone
Authors: Behnke, A.; Gumpp, A. M.; Krumbholz, A.; Bach, A. M.; Schelling, G.; Kolassa, I. T.; Rojas, R.
