Abstract: background stress related alteration in the regulation of several endocrine system including the hypothalamus pituitary adrenal hpa and gonadal hpg ax and the endocannabinoid system are proposed to be involved in the etiology of major depressive disorder mdd therefore this study examines whether altered concentration of glucocorticoid testosterone endocannabinoids and related n acylethanolamines accumulated in hair are present in mdd method female participant range 19 59 mdn 30 5 year were recruited including n 21 with a current mdd episode and n 27 nondepressed control without any current mental disorder weight standardized sample of 3 cm hair segment were analyzed which equal to three month of retrospectively assessed biomarkers in hair concentration of cortisol cortisone testosterone endocannabinoids i e anandamide aea 2 arachidonylglycerol 2 ag and selected n acylethanolamines i e stearoylethanolamide sea oleoylethanolamide oea palmitoylethanolamide pea were measured using mass spectrometry result female mdd patient exhibited lower cortisol and cortisone level in hair than nondepressed control whereas the hair concentration of endocannabinoids n acylethanolamines and testosterone did not differ between the group conclusion our result add to the heterogeneous body of finding on alteration in hair stored glucocorticoid and endocannabinoids in mdd a in previous study there wa no evidence of altered testosterone concentration in the hair of mdd patient larger and longitudinal study are needed to comprehensively explore the overall picture of endocrine alteration in mdd

Title: Positive Mental Health, Stressful Life Events, and Suicide Ideation
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Teismann, T.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background stressful life event and suicide ideation regularly occur together yet little is known about factor that buffer individual against the development of suicide ideation aim in a long term follow up study design it wa investigated whether positive mental health that is high level of subjective and psychological well being buffer the association between stressful life event and suicide ideation method a total of 126 german student 80 2 female age m 24 29 sd 5 21 were assessed at a baseline evaluation and again 24 month later data were collected using self report questionnaire result linear hierarchical regression analysis wa used to analyze the data positive mental health wa considered to moderate the impact of stressful life event on suicide ideation controlling for age and gender limitation current result are limited to university student conclusion positive mental health interacts with stressful life event such that those with high level of positive mental health show an attenuated increase in suicide ideation at elevated level of stress positive mental health seems to confer resilience and should be focused on in counseling center for student

Title: The association between recalled parental rearing behavior and depressiveness: a comparison between 1st immigrants and non-immigrants in the population-based Gutenberg Health Study
Authors: Klein, E. M.; Brahler, E.; Petrowski, K.; Tibubos, A. N.; Ernst, M.; Wiltink, J.; Michal, M.; Wild, P. S.; Schulz, A.; Munzel, T.; Konig, J.; Lackner, K.; Pfeiffer, N.; Beutel, M. E.
Abstract: background study in immigrant youth have suggested difference in parenting pattern by immigration status knowledge of variation in recalled parenting pattern and it distinctive impact on mental health in adult immigrant however is limited therefore the purpose of the current study wa to investigate similarity and difference in recalled maternal and paternal rearing behavior and it association with depressiveness in adult 1st generation immigrant compared to non immigrant method seven hundred and forty three 1st generation immigrant m 57 4 sd 10 1 year and 6518 non immigrant m 60 3 sd 10 7 year participated in a population based study regarding country of origin the largest subgroup were immigrant from eastern europe former su and arabic islamic country all participant completed the ultra short version of the recalled parental rearing behavior questionnaire and the phq 9 assessing depressiveness multiple linear regression with depressiveness a outcome variable were analyzed separately for each facet of parental rearing behavior adjusting for socio demographic and migration related variable result in addition to difference in depressiveness and socioeconomic status 1st generation immigrant recalled both their mother and father a more controlling and overprotecting than non immigrant parental emotional warmth wa negatively associated with depressiveness across all group the relationship between parental control respectively parental rejection and depressiveness however varied in direction and severity between the group conclusion the result support the notion that parental warmth is a universal protective factor against depressiveness whereas the impact of parental control on mental health might be more culturally influenced analysis point to the importance of considering the unique contribution of father rearing behavior on mental health particularly in immigrant sample

Title: Associations between patient personality, symptomatic change and therapy dropout
Authors: Immel, N.; Dagnino, P.; Hunger-Schoppe, C.
Abstract: background study show that 16 to 77 of psychotherapy patient abandon therapy within the first session the aim of this study is to examine how patient personality variable specifically the patient structural integration and the personality trait dependency and self criticism are associated with symptomatic change and therapy dropout method we analysed data from 96 patient age m 30 56 sd 11 39 78 5 woman 44 6 student 28 3 employee a hierarchical logistic regression analysis wa carried out to determine whether patient structural integration assessed via the opd sq and their level of dependency and self criticism deq can predict therapy dropout in addition a multiple regression wa used to analyse how these variable affect symptomatic change oq 45 2 symptom subscale result the interaction of structural integration level and dependency best predicts therapy dropout for the prediction of symptomatic change both structural integration and dependency were significant however their interaction showed no significant result discussion the patient s structural integration wa associated to both symptomatic change and dropout therapist training should include technique addressing patient structural integration and degree of dependency to prevent patient dropout from therapy

Title: Mental health and associated stress factors in accompanied and unaccompanied refugee minors resettled in Germany: a cross-sectional study
Authors: Muller, L. R. F.; Buter, K. P.; Rosner, R.; Unterhitzenberger, J.
Abstract: background study throughout europe have shown that asylum seeking child and adolescent asc are at risk of developing mental disorder the most common mental health problem in asc include posttraumatic stress symptom pt internalizing symptom such a depression and anxiety and externalizing behaviour being an unaccompanied refugee minor urm wa found to be highly predictive for higher level of psychological distress within asc nevertheless and even though germany is europe s biggest host country for asc study that reliably examine the mental health of both urm and accompanied refugee minor arm in germany with psychometrically tested measure are still lacking method a cross sectional survey in 19 facility for minor refugee in bavaria germany screening for pt depression anxiety externalizing behaviour and post migration factor wa conducted participant were 98 asc urm n 68 arm n 30 primarily from afghanistan syria and eritrea in 35 7 of interview interpreter were involved result both urm and arm reported high level of psychological distress and large number of potentially traumatic event with 64 7 of urm and 36 7 of arm scoring above the clinical cut off for pt 42 6 of urm and 30 of arm for depression and 38 2 of urm and 23 3 of arm for anxiety the total number of traumatic experience wa found to be the most robust predictor for pt depression and anxiety lower level of individual resource lower level of social support in the host country and poorer german language proficiency were associated with higher level of psychological distress within both group urm reported significantly more traumatic event than arm conclusion asc in germany are severely distressed and burdened by the experience of various type of potentially traumatic event the level of distress found in the current study correspond with rate that have been reported in previous study with asc throughout europe limitation of the present study include the convenience sample and the cross sectional nature of finding

Title: Suicidal ideation in primary care patients suffering from panic disorder with or without agoraphobia
Authors: Teismann, T.; Lukaschek, K.; Hiller, T. S.; Breitbart, J.; Brettschneider, C.; Schumacher, U.; Margraf, J.; Gensichen, J.; Jena Paradies Study, Group
Abstract: background suicidal ideation is common in patient suffering from panic disorder the present study investigated rate of suicidal ideation and risk factor for suicidal ideation in a sample of primary care patient suffering from panic disorder with or without agoraphobia method a total of n 296 patient n 215 72 6 woman age m 43 99 sd 13 44 were investigated anxiety severity anxiety symptom avoidance behavior comorbid depression diagnosis severity of depression age sex employment status living situation and frequency of visit at the general practitioner were considered a risk factor of suicidal ideation result suicidal ideation wa experienced by 25 of the respondent in a logistic regression analysis depression diagnosis and depression severity emerged a significant risk factor for suicidal ideation anxiety measure were not associated with suicidal ideation conclusion suicidal ideation is common in primary care patient suffering from panic disorder with or without agoraphobia individual with greater burden of mental illness in term of mood disorder comorbidity and depressive symptomatology are especially likely to suffer from suicidal ideation

Title: Suicide Attempters, Suicide Ideators, and Non-Ideators
Authors: Teismann, T.; Paashaus, L.; Siegmann, P.; Nyhuis, P.; Wolter, M.; Willutzki, U.
Abstract: background suicide ideation is a prerequisite for suicide attempt however the majority of ideators will never act on their thought it is therefore crucial to understand factor that differentiate those who consider suicide from those who make suicide attempt aim our aim wa to investigate the role of protective factor in differentiating non ideators suicide ideators and suicide attempter method inpatient without suicide ideation n 32 were compared with inpatient with current suicide ideation n 37 and with inpatient with current suicide ideation and a lifetime history of suicide attempt n 26 regarding positive mental health self esteem trust in higher guidance social support and reason for living result non ideators reported more positive mental health social support reason for living and self esteem than suicide ideators and suicide attempter did no group difference were found regarding trust in higher guidance suicide ideators and suicide attempter did not differ regarding any of the study variable limitation result stem from a cross sectional study of suicide attempt thus neither directionality nor generalizability to fatal suicide attempt can be determined conclusion various protective factor are best characterized to distinguish ideators from nonsuicidal inpatient however the same variable seem to offer no information about the difference between ideators and attempter

Title: Remission of suicidal thoughts: Findings from a longitudinal epidemiological study
Authors: Teismann, T.; Forkmann, T.; Glaesmer, H.; Egeri, L.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background suicide ideation is common in young woman the present study investigated factor associated with the remission of suicidal thought in a representative sample of woman aged 18 24 year method a total of 1389 woman were interviewed at a baseline assessment and again 17 month later social support satisfaction with life self efficacy and positive mental health were considered a predictor of remission of suicidal thought controlling for severity of psychopathology result remission of suicidal thought wa experienced by 67 4 of the respondent whereas 32 6 continued to have suicide ideation at both assessment in multiple logistic regression analysis social support and positive mental health emerged a significant predictor of remission severity of psychopathology did not predict the course of suicide ideation limitation suicide ideation wa assessed only with the respective item of the beck depression inventory conclusion protective factor especially social support and positive mental health outperform psychopathology in predicting the course of suicide ideation

Title: Momentary interpersonal processes of suicidal surges in borderline personality disorder
Authors: Kaurin, A.; Dombrovski, A. Y.; Hallquist, M. N.; Wright, A. G. C.
Abstract: background suicide rate are high in borderline personality disorder bpd where interpersonal problem trigger intense affective dysregulation and impulse to act on suicidal thought to date however no study ha examined how interpersonal stressor contribute to momentary within person link among affect and impulsivity with suicidal ideation si and how those link vary over time in people s daily life method a total of 153 individual diagnosed with bpd and 52 healthy control completed a 21 day ecological momentary assessment protocol of these 153 individual with bpd 105 had a history of suicide attempt multilevel structural equation modeling wa used to examine dynamic link among interpersonal perception affect state impulsivity and suicidal intent result aggregated across interaction lower perceived warmth in others wa associated with si this direct relationship however did not extend to momentary within person association instead interpersonal conflict were linked to si indirectly via greater negative affect and lower positive affect while a robust within person link between interpersonal perception and impulsivity emerged impulsivity did not account for the relationship between interpersonal perception and si conclusion this intensive longitudinal study illustrates momentary interpersonal signature of an emerging suicidal crisis among people with bpd at high risk for suicide interpersonal trigger initiate a cascade of affective dysregulation which in turn give rise to si

Title: Negative mood-induction modulates default mode network resting-state functional connectivity in chronic depression
Authors: Renner, F.; Siep, N.; Arntz, A.; van de Ven, V.; Peeters, Fpml; Quaedflieg, Cwem; Huibers, M. J. H.
Abstract: background the aim of this study wa to investigate the effect of sad mood on default mode network dmn resting state connectivity in person with chronic major depressive disorder cmdd method participant with a diagnosis of cmdd n 18 and age gender and education level matched participant without a diagnosis of depression n 18 underwent a resting state fmri scan before and after a sad mood induction the posterior cingulate cortex pcc wa used a a seed for dmn functional connectivity across the two resting state measurement result mood rating decreased in both group following the sad mood induction procedure pcc connectivity with the parahippocampal gyrus the superior temporal gyrus and the anterior inferior temporal cortex increased in cmdd patient following the sad mood induction whereas it decreased in non patient control pcc connectivity with the anterior prefrontal cortex and the precuneus decreased in cmdd patient following the sad mood induction whereas it increased in non patient control limitation limitation of this study include the relatively small sample size and lack of a clinical control group conclusion these finding are in line with neurobiological model of depression suggesting that the observed change in dmn connectivity following the sad mood induction might reflect a failure to exert cognitive control over negative memory retrieval in patient with cmdd

Title: Externalizing problems mediate the relation between teacher and peer violence and lower school performance
Authors: Masath, F. B.; Scharpf, F.; Dumke, L.; Hecker, T.
Abstract: background the association between child s exposure to family violence and poor academic outcome is well established le is known about how exposure to violence in the school context i e by teacher and by peer affect academic functioning moreover the role of child s mental health problem in this link ha hardly been examined objective we examined direct and indirect association between child s experience of violence by teacher and peer and child s mental health and school functioning while controlling for child s experience of parental violence participant using a multistage random sampling approach we obtained a representative sample of 914 student 50 5 girl m age 12 58 year from 12 primary school in tanzania method in structured interview student experience of violence and mental health problem were assessed student academic performance and absenteeism were documented using school record association were examined using structural equation modeling result experience of more teacher and peer violence were each significantly associated with higher externalizing problem teacher beta 0 27 95 ci 0 12 0 47 peer beta 0 17 95 ci 0 07 0 32 higher externalizing problem were significantly associated with poorer academic performance beta 0 13 95 ci 0 23 0 02 implying significant indirect association between student experience of teacher violence beta 0 04 95 ci 0 08 0 01 and peer violence beta 0 02 95 ci 0 05 0 01 and their academic performance via externalizing problem conclusion exposure to violence at school may impair child s academic performance indirectly by increasing attention and behaviour problem further investigation in longitudinal study and implementation of intervention to reduce violence in school are indicated

Title: Longitudinal change instead of baseline testosterone predicts depressive symptoms
Authors: Kische, H.; Pieper, L.; Venz, J.; Klotsche, J.; Marz, W.; Koch-Gromus, U.; Pittrow, D.; Lehnert, H.; Silber, S.; Stalla, G. K.; Zeiher, A. M.; Wittchen, H. U.; Haring, R.
Abstract: background the association between total testosterone t and depression mostly relies on single sex hormone assessment and remains inconclusive thus we investigated the comparative predictive performance of baseline t and change in t with development of depressive symptom and incident depressive episode method we used data from 6493 primary care patient 2653 men and 3840 woman of the detect study diabetes cardiovascular risk evaluation target and essential data for commitment of treatment including four year follow up repeated immunoassay based measurement of serum t and depressive symptom assessed by the depression screening questionnaire dsq cross sectional and longitudinal association of baseline t and one year change in t with prevalent and incident depression were investigated using age and multivariable adjusted regression model result baseline t showed no association with prevalent or incident depressive symptom and episode in both sex in men a positive change in t higher t at one year follow up compared to baseline wa associated with a lower burden of depressive symptom beta coefficient per unit change in t 0 17 95 ci 0 31 to 0 04 and lower risk of incident depressive symptom odds ratio per unit change in t 0 84 95 ci 0 72 0 98 at four year follow up in woman the association of t change with incident depressive episode wa rendered non significant after multivariable adjustment discussion the present study observed a sex specific inverse association of t change but not baseline t with increased depressive symptom burden in men future study should a longitudinal change in sex hormone status a predictor of adverse health outcome related to low t

Title: Comparing the Efficacy of CBASP with Two Versions of CBT for Depression in a Routine Care Center: A Randomized Clinical Trial
Authors: Rief, W.; Bleichhardt, G.; Dannehl, K.; Euteneuer, F.; Wambach, K.
Abstract: background the cognitive behavioral analysis system of psychotherapy cbasp wa developed for the treatment of chronic early onset depression however it is unclear whether this approach can be recommended for depression in general episodic and chronic and no direct comparison between cbasp with different version of cognitive behavioral therapy cbt exist method a randomized controlled trial compared 3 treatment condition all lasting 16 session with a waiting list group wl cbasp cbt with a focus on physical exercise cbt e and cbt with a focus on pleasurable low energy and mindful activity cbt m we included 173 patient and involved 41 therapist assessment were at baseline after session 8 and at the end of treatment result our primary outcome beck depression inventory ii indicated a general advantage of the cbt arm compared to cbasp f 6 154 5 4 2 p 0 001 with significant contrast in particular in favor of cbt e effect size against wl were d 0 91 cbt e 0 87 cbt m and 0 47 cbasp a triple interaction with an additional factor chronic versus episodic depression f 6 142 7 2 2 p 0 048 indicated that the treatment resulted in different outcome with best result again for cbt e in particular in episodic depression responder rate indicated significant improvement 56 in both cbt arm 34 in the cbasp arm 3 4 in wl intention to treat sample a compared to cbasp response rate were significantly higher for cbt e or 2 48 95 ci 1 02 6 00 and cbt m or 2 46 95 ci 1 01 6 01 conclusion cbasp wa more effective than wl but le effective than the 2 cbt arm this wa mainly caused by an advantage of cbt intervention in episodic depression

Title: COVID-19-related distress is associated with analogue PTSD symptoms after exposure to an analogue stressor
Authors: Friesen, E.; Michael, T.; Schafer, S. K.; Sopp, M. R.
Abstract: background the covid 19 outbreak in early 2020 wa associated with an immediate increase in mental health problem in a significant percentage of the general population therefore it is crucial to investigate how the covid 19 pandemic a a psychosocial stressor affected the aetiological process of mental disorder previous research ha shown that stress potentiates associative fear learning and analogue symptom of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd and that analogue ptsd symptom can emerge in response to associative learning objective we investigated whether distress in response to the covid 19 outbreak support the development of intrusion and rumination after exposure to a non covid 19 related analogue trauma moreover we examined if these effect are mediated by the strength of associative learning during analogue trauma method 122 undergraduate university student participated in an online experiment between march and july 2020 they completed questionnaire measuring distress and rumination related to the covid 19 outbreak on a subsequent day they went through an associative learning task in which neutral stimulus were paired with the appearance of a highly aversive film clip subjective rating were assessed a indicator of associative learning on the next day participant documented film related intrusion and rumination result covid 19 related distress but not rumination wa associated with post film intrusion and rumination load these effect were mediated by associative learning conclusion the current finding are in line with the assumption that stress enhanced both associative learning and ptsd symptom specifically they indicate that prolonged psychosocial stress like during the covid 19 outbreak is linked to individual difference in memory processing of aversive event further confirmatory research is needed to replicate these result

Title: Who is seeking help for psychological distress associated with the COVID-19 pandemic? Characterization of risk factors in 1269 participants accessing low-threshold psychological help
Authors: Hilbert, K.; Boeken, O.; Asbrand, J.; Seemann, S.; Langhammer, T.; Praxl, B.; Horvath, L.; Ertle, A.; Lueken, U.
Abstract: background the covid 19 pandemic and accompanying restriction are associated with substantial psychological distress however it is unclear how this increased strain translates into help seeking behavior here we aim to characterize those individual who seek help for covid 19 related psychological distress and examine which factor are associated with their level of distress in order to better characterize vulnerable group method we report data from 1269 help seeking participant subscribing to a stepped care program targeted at mental health problem due to the covid 19 pandemic sample characteristic were compared to population data and linear regression analysis were used to examine which risk factor and stressor were associated with current symptom level result seeking for help for covid 19 related psychological distress wa characterized by female gender younger age and better education compared to the general population the majority reported mental health problem already before the pandemic 74 5 of this help seeking sample also exceeded clinical threshold for depression anxiety or somatization higher individual symptom level were associated with higher overall level of pandemic stress younger age and pre existing mental health problem but were buffered by functional emotion regulation strategy conclusion result suggest a considerable increase in demand for mental healthcare in the pandemic aftermath comparison with the general population indicate diverging pattern in help seeking behavior while some individual seek help themselves others should be addressed directly individual that are young have pre existing mental health problem and experience a high level of pandemic stress are particularly at risk for considerable symptom load mental healthcare provider should use these result to prepare for the significant increase in demand during the broader aftermath of the covid 19 pandemic a well a allocate limited resource more effectively

Title: The Impact of COVID-19 Lockdown on Daily Activities, Cognitions, and Stress in a Lonely and Distressed Population: Temporal Dynamic Network Analysis
Authors: Haucke, M.; Heinz, A.; Liu, S.; Heinzel, S.
Abstract: background the covid 19 pandemic and it associated lockdown measure impacted mental health worldwide however the temporal dynamic of causal factor that modulate mental health during lockdown are not well understood objective we aimed to understand how a covid 19 lockdown change the temporal dynamic of loneliness and other factor affecting mental health this is the first study that compare network characteristic between lockdown stage to prioritize mental health intervention target method we combined ecological momentary assessment with wrist worn motion tracking to investigate the mechanism and change in network centrality of symptom and behavior before and during lockdown a total of 258 participant who reported at least mild loneliness and distress were assessed 8 time a day for 7 consecutive day over a 213 day period from august 8 2020 through march 9 2021 in germany covering a no lockdown and a lockdown stage covid 19 related worry information seeking perceived restriction and loneliness were assessed by digital visual analog scale ranging from 0 to 100 social activity wa assessed on a 7 point likert scale while physical activity wa recorded from wrist worn actigraphy device result we built a multilevel vector autoregressive model to estimate dynamic network to compare network characteristic between a no lockdown stage and a lockdown stage we performed permutation test during lockdown loneliness had the highest impact within the network a indicated by it centrality index ie an index to identify variable that have a strong influence on the other variable moreover during lockdown the centrality of loneliness significantly increased physical activity contributed to a decrease in loneliness amid the lockdown stage conclusion the covid 19 lockdown increased the central role of loneliness in triggering stress related behavior and cognition our study indicates that loneliness should be prioritized in mental health intervention during lockdown moreover physical activity can serve a a buffer for loneliness amid social restriction

Title: Associations of Depressive Symptoms, COVID-19-Related Stressors, and Coping Strategies. A Comparison Between Cities and Towns in Germany
Authors: Meyer, C.; El-Haj-Mohamad, R.; Stammel, N.; Lotzin, A.; Schafer, I.; Knaevelsrud, C.; Bottche, M.
Abstract: background the covid 19 pandemic ha led to a wide range of stressor related to depressive symptom prevention measure like physical distancing have burdened the general population especially in highly urbanized area however little is known about the association between pandemic related stressor coping strategy and depressive symptom in highly urbanized v le urbanized environment method participant were recruited in a cross sectional online survey in germany propensity score matching yielded a matched sample of city n 453 and town n 453 inhabitant depressive symptom covid 19 related stressor and coping strategy were compared between city and town multiple regression analysis wa performed to determine association between pandemic related stressor and depressive symptom for the two group separately result city inhabitant showed significantly higher depression score than town inhabitant t 2 11 df 897 95 p 0 035 seven coping strategy were more often used by the city sample depressive symptom were associated with restricted physical social contact and difficult housing condition adjusted r 2 0 19 f 9 443 12 52 p 0 001 in city inhabitant and with fear of infection and difficult housing condition adjusted r 2 0 20 f 9 443 13 50 p 0 001 in town inhabitant limitation the data were collected at the end of the first wave and represent a snapshot without causal inference pandemic related stressor were measured with a newly developed scale conclusion depressive symptom perceived stressor and approach avoidance coping strategy differed between city v town inhabitant these difference should be considered in policy making and mental health care

Title: In the Face of Potential Harm: The Predictive Validity of Neural Correlates of Performance Monitoring for Perceived Risk, Stress, and Internalizing Psychopathology During the COVID-19 Pandemic
Authors: Riesel, A.; Harpfer, K.; Kathmann, N.; Klawohn, J.
Abstract: background the covid 19 pandemic is a major life stressor posing serious threat not only to physical but also to mental health to better understand mechanism of vulnerability and identify individual at risk for psychopathological symptom in response to stressor is critical for prevention and intervention the error related negativity ern ha been discussed a a neural risk marker for psychopathology and this study examined it predictive validity for perceived risk stress and psychopathological symptom during the covid 19 pandemic method a total of 113 individual who had participated a healthy control participant in previous electroencephalography study 2014 2019 completed a follow up online survey during the first covid 19 wave in germany association of pre pandemic ern and correct response negativity crn with perceived risk regarding covid 19 infection stress and internalizing symptom during the pandemic were examined using mediation model result pre pandemic ern and crn were associated with increased perceived risk regarding a covid 19 infection via this perceived risk the ern and crn were associated with increased stress during the pandemic furthermore risk perception and stress mediated indirect effect of ern and crn on internalizing psychopathology including anxiety depression and obsessive compulsive symptom while controlling for the effect of pre pandemic symptom level conclusion in summary heightened pre pandemic performance monitoring showed indirect association with increase in psychopathological symptom during the first covid 19 wave via effect on perceived covid 19 risk and stress these result further strengthen the notion of performance monitoring event related potential a transdiagnostic neural risk marker and highlight the relevance of stress a a catalyst for symptom development

Title: Mental health and the wish to have a child: a longitudinal, cross-cultural comparison between Germany and China
Authors: Margraf, J.; Lavallee, K. L.; Zhang, X. C.; Woike, J. K.; Schneider, S.
Abstract: background the desire to have child ha been declining globally especially in industrialized nation this study examines the physical health correlate and positive and negative mental health correlate of the wish to have a child across time and in two country method questionnaire data were obtained from large scale university sample of 12 574 participant in germany and china result the wish to have a child child wish is related to positive and negative mental health in china and to a lesser degree in germany child wish is positively related to some aspect of mental and somatic health for chinese woman and men negatively to depression for chinese and german men and chinese woman and positively to stress for german men with generally small effect effect hold when controlling for age partnership status and family affluence most relationship were almost equal between woman and men in both china and germany and between country with the exception of two different path in each gender group that is having a partner is associated with a higher child wish in both chinese and german female student in china older female student are more likely to want to have a child while older female student in germany are le likely to want to have a child neither partnership nor age predict child wish for the next year conclusion in sum chinese student reported feeling more positively about having child when they were happy and healthy with the exception that highly satisfied chinese male report lower child wish in the next year more depressed chinese and german men and chinese woman reported lowered child wish and stressed german men reported more child wish older student reported more chinese or le german child wish depending on country

Title: Psychopathology mediates between maltreatment and memory functioning in Burundian refugee youth
Authors: Scharpf, F.; Mueller, S. C.; Masath, F. B.; Nkuba, M.; Hecker, T.
Abstract: background the detrimental impact of child maltreatment on child and adolescent academic achievement and later socioeconomic wellbeing is well known however it is still unclear 1 whether maltreatment is actually linked to youth s long and short term memory deficit and 2 whether potential impairment are due to maltreatment per se or related psychopathology objective based on the attentional control theory we investigated a mediational model in which maltreatment would be related to psychopathology internalizing symptom posttraumatic stress symptom posttraumatic cognition which would in turn be related to impaired memory functioning participant and setting we drew on a sample of 155 burundian refugee youth aged 11 to 15 currently living in refugee camp in tanzania and at high risk of experiencing ongoing maltreatment by parent method youth reported on their experience of maltreatment and psychopathology in structured clinical interview and completed visuospatial memory task involving a short term and a working memory component corsi block tapping test and delayed recall from long term memory rey osterrieth complex figure result structural equation modeling showed that psychopathology mediated the association between increased maltreatment and reduced working memory capacity beta 0 07 p 02 with a trend towards mediation for short term memory beta 0 05 p 06 higher level of maltreatment but not psychopathology were directly linked to long term memory deficit beta 0 20 p 02 conclusion preventive effort targeting maltreatment and intervention focusing on related psychopathology are needed to counter memory deficit and their potential negative implication for academic and socioeconomic outcome

Title: The Persistence of the Impact of COVID-19-Related Distress, Mood Inertia, and Loneliness on Mental Health During a Postlockdown Period in Germany: An Ecological Momentary Assessment Study
Authors: Haucke, M.; Liu, S.; Heinzel, S.
Abstract: background the first wave of the covid 19 pandemic in early 2020 increased mental health problem globally however little is known about mental health problem during a low incidence period of the pandemic without strict public health measure objective we aim to investigate whether covid 19 related risk factor for mental health problem persist beyond lockdown measure we targeted a vulnerable population that is at risk of developing low mental health and assessed their daily dynamic of mood and emotion regulation after a strict lockdown method during a postlockdown period in germany between august 8 2020 and november 1 2020 we conducted an ecological momentary assessment with 131 participant who experienced at least mild covid 19 related distress and loneliness to estimate negative mood inertia we built a lag 1 three level autoregressive model result we found that information exposure and active daily covid 19 case did not have an impact on negative mood amid a postlockdown period however there wa a day to day carryover effect of negative mood in addition worrying about covid 19 feeling restricted by covid 19 and feeling lonely increased negative mood conclusion the mental health of a vulnerable population is still challenged by covid 19 related stressor after the lifting of a strict lockdown this study highlight the need to protect mental health during postpandemic period

Title: High place phenomenon: prevalence and clinical correlates in two German samples
Authors: Teismann, T.; Brailovskaia, J.; Schaumburg, S.; Wannemuller, A.
Abstract: background the high place phenomenon that is a sudden urge to jump when in a high place is an experience known to many people that ha rarely been studied the present study aimed to a the prevalence of the high place phenomenon in a non clinical and a clinical german sample furthermore clinical correlate of the experience were assessed method the study sample comprised 276 participant 67 female m age 32 08 sd age 10 73 who took part in an online assessment and 94 patient 73 4 female m age 49 26 sd age 13 32 suffering from clinically relevant fear of flying participant filled out questionnaire on experience with the high place phenomenon depression anxiety suicide ideation and anxiety sensitivity result the high place phenomenon wa known to nearly 60 of the online sample and to 45 of the patient sample suicide ideation a well a anxiety sensitivity were positively associated with experience with the high place phenomenon in the online sample depression anxiety and suicide ideation were unrelated to experience with the phenomenon in the patient sample conclusion the high place phenomenon is commonly reported by lifetime current suicide ideators however it is also a common experience in individual who have never suffered from suicide ideation it is therefore cautioned not to interpret such experience a an expression of a hidden death wish

Title: Interpersonal theory of suicide: prospective examination
Authors: Forkmann, T.; Glaesmer, H.; Paashaus, L.; Rath, D.; Schonfelder, A.; Stengler, K.; Juckel, G.; Assion, H. J.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: background the interpersonal theory of suicide ipts is one of the most intensively researched contemporary theory on the development of suicidal ideation and behaviour however there is a lack of carefully conducted prospective study aim to evaluate the main prediction of the ipts regarding the importance of perceived burdensomeness thwarted belongingness and capability for suicide in predicting future suicide attempt in a prospective design method psychiatric in patient n 308 53 6 n 165 female mean age 36 82 year s d 14 30 range 18 81 admitted for severe suicidal ideation n 145 47 1 or a suicide attempt completed self report measure of thwarted belongingness perceived burdensomeness capability for suicide hopelessness depression and suicidal ideation a well a interview on suicide intent and suicide attempt and were followed up for 12 month logistic regression and receiver operating characteristic roc analysis were conducted result the interaction of perceived burdensomeness thwarted belongingness and capability for suicide wa not predictive of future suicide attempt but perceived burdensomeness showed a significant main effect z 3 49 p 0 01 or 2 34 95 ci 1 59 3 58 and moderate performance in screening for future suicide attempt area under the curve auc 0 729 p 0 01 conclusion the result challenge the theoretical validity of the ipts and it clinical utility at least within the methodological limitation of the current study yet finding underscore the importance of perceived burdensomeness in understanding suicidal ideation and behaviour

Title: What Dyadic Reparation Is Meant to Do: An Association with Infant Cortisol Reactivity
Authors: Muller, M.; Zietlow, A. L.; Tronick, E.; Reck, C.
Abstract: background the latency to reparation of interactive mismatch interactive repair is argued to regulate infant distress on a psychobiological level and maternal anxiety disorder might impair infant regulation sampling and method a total of 46 dyad 19 mother with an anxiety disorder 27 control were analyzed for association between interactive repair and infant cortisol reactivity during the face to face still face paradigm 3 4 month postpartum missing cortisol value n 16 were imputed analysis were conducted on both the original and the pooled imputed data result interactive repair during the reunion episode wa associated with infant cortisol reactivity original data p 0 01 pooled data p 0 01 but not maternal anxiety disorder p 0 23 additional stepwise regression analysis found that latency to repair during play p 0 01 an interaction between distress during the first trimester of pregnancy and latency to repair during reunion p 0 01 and infant self comforting behavior during the reunion episode p 0 04 made independent contribution to cortisol reactivity in the final regression model conclusion this is the first study demonstrating that interactive repair is related to infant psychobiological stress reactivity the lack of a relation to maternal anxiety disorder may be due to the small sample size however this result emphasizes that infant respond to what they experience and not to the maternal diagnostic category

Title: Myofascial Tissue and Depression
Authors: Michalak, J.; Aranmolate, L.; Bonn, A.; Grandin, K.; Schleip, R.; Schmiedtke, J.; Quassowsky, S.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: background the myofascial system play a fundamental role in the mechanic of the body in body tension regulation and the etiology of pathological state like chronic pain moreover it contains contractile element and preliminary evidence suggests that it property are linked to psychological factor the aim of the present research wa to investigate characteristic of the myofascial tissue in patient with major depressive disorder mdd and to examine whether the state of the myofascial tissue causally affect pathopsychological process in mdd method in study 1 stiffness and elasticity of the myofascial tissue of 40 inpatient suffering from mdd measured with a tissue compliance meter were compared with those of 40 matched never depressed participant in study 2 69 mdd patient were randomly assigned to single session self myofascial release intervention smri or a placebo intervention effect on memory bias and affect were investigated result result showed that mdd patient displayed heightened stiffness and reduced elasticity of the myofascial tissue and that patient in the smri group showed a reduced negative memory bias and more positive affect compared to patient in the placebo condition conclusion the preliminary result of our study indicate that the myofascial tissue might be part of a dysfunctional body mind dynamic that maintains mdd supplementary information the online version contains supplementary material available at 10 1007 s10608 021 10282 w

Title: Intranasal oxytocin increases covert attention to positive social cues
Authors: Domes, G.; Sibold, M.; Schulze, L.; Lischke, A.; Herpertz, S. C.; Heinrichs, M.
Abstract: background the neuropeptide oxytocin ot ha positive effect on the processing of emotional stimulus such a facial expression to date research ha focused primarily on condition of overt visual attention method we investigated whether a single intranasal dose of ot 24 iu would modulate the allocation of attentional resource towards positive and negative facial expression using a dot probe paradigm in a sample of 69 healthy men attentional capacity for these facial cue wa limited by presentation time 100 or 500 m in addition we controlled for overt visual attention by recording eye movement using a remote eye tracker result reaction time rts in the dot probe paradigm revealed a pronounced shift of attention towards happy facial expression presented for 100 m after ot administration whereas there were no ot induced effect for longer presentation time 500 m the result could not be attributed to modulation of overt visual attention a no substance effect on gaze towards the facial target were observed conclusion the result suggest that ot increased covert attention to happy face thereby supporting the hypothesis that ot modulates early attentional process that might promote prosocial behavior

Title: Resting vagal tone is negatively associated with suicide ideation
Authors: Forkmann, T.; Meessen, J.; Teismann, T.; Sutterlin, S.; Gauggel, S.; Mainz, V.
Abstract: background the present study aimed at investigating whether resting vagally mediated heart rate variability hrv a a trait like biomarker of cognitive inhibitory control capacity is related to suicide ideation in a sample without suicide attempt history method thirty seven healthy student participated voluntarily 18 to 34 year m 24 5 sd 4 1 73 0 female time and frequency measure of hrv were derived from an electrocardiogram that wa recorded using einthoven s triangle lead ii participant filled in the rasch based depression screening and four question concerning lifetime suicide ideation si bivariate pearson s and partial controlling for depression severity correlation coefficient were calculated between si and measure of vagally mediated hrv result a significant correlation between the ln10 transformed high frequency band of resting vagally mediated hrv and si wa found r 33 p 05 correlation did not change substantially when controlling for depression mean heart rate a a time domain measure also significantly correlated with si while controlling for depression r 36 p 05 a trend correlation between si and root mean square of successive difference between interbeat interval emerged limitation si wa assessed with a composite score of four item measuring si future study should consider using more comprehensive assessment instrument conclusion the relation between resting vagally mediated hrv and suicide ideation may be interpreted a indicating that reduced inhibitory cognitive control capacity may be a risk factor for suicidality it may act already early in the suicidal process before suicidal behavior develops and should be further investigated a potentially clinically important physiological predictor of suicidality

Title: Comparing mental health of Facebook users and Facebook non-users in an inpatient sample in Germany
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.; Schillack, H.; Kollner, V.
Abstract: background the present study aimed to investigate difference in variable of positive mental health pmh i e emotional psychological and social well being and negative mental health nmh i e somatoform complaint depressiveness social stress and insomnia between clinical inpatient who use the social platform facebook and those who do not use facebook furthermore the link between duration of daily facebook use and mental health should be considered method in two subsamples of inpatient of a psychosomatic rehabilitation clinic in germany facebook user n 336 facebook non user n 265 use of facebook pmh and nmh were assessed via a computer survey result facebook user had significantly higher value of three variable of nmh i e depressiveness social stress and insomnia and significantly lower value of pmh than facebook non user duration of daily facebook use wa significantly negatively associated with pmh and significantly positively with all variable of nmh limitation given the cross sectional study design current data do not imply causality conclusion current result indicate that facebook use is negatively associated with pmh and positively with nmh in clinical inpatient thus future research should investigate whether and how facebook use may have a negative effect on the recovery process of the inpatient

Title: The role of pre-pandemic depression for changes in depression, anxiety, and loneliness during the COVID-19 pandemic: Results from a longitudinal probability sample of adults from Germany
Authors: Benke, C.; Asselmann, E.; Entringer, T. M.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: background the present study aim to delineate the role of preexisting depression for change in common mental health problem during the covid 19 pandemic method using mixed effect linear regression model we analyzed data on the course of depressive patient health questionnaire 2 and anxiety generalized anxiety disorder 2 symptom a well a loneliness three item ucla loneliness scale in a subset of the socio economic panel study a large and nationally representative household panel study from germany participant were assessed during the first covid 19 wave in germany march 31 to july 4 2020 n 6 694 and prospectively followed up at the peak of the second covid 19 wave january 18 to february 15 2021 n 6 038 result overall anxiety and depressive symptom decreased whereas loneliness increased from the first to the second covid 19 wave however depressive symptom increased and the surge in loneliness wa steeper in those with versus without clinically relevant depressive symptom in 2019 or a history of a depressive disorder before the covid 19 pandemic anxiety symptom remained stable throughout the pandemic in individual with versus without clinically relevant depressive symptom in 2019 pre pandemic depression wa associated with overall higher depressive and anxiety symptom and loneliness across both assessment the stringency of lockdown measure did not affect the result conclusion our finding suggest that individual with a history of depressive symptom before the covid 19 pandemic are at increased risk to experience an escalation of mental health problem due to the covid 19 pandemic therefore they might particularly profit from targeted prevention and early intervention program

Title: Daily stress reactivity: The unique roles of personality and social support
Authors: Kaurin, A.; Wright, A. G. C.; Kamarck, T. W.
Abstract: background the process through which social support exerts it influence in daily life are not well understood arguably it salutary effect a an environmental variable might be construed a shared effect of personality method to test this possibility we investigated the unique and shared effect of personality and social support on daily stressor exposure social conflict task strain and on the within person association of stressor exposure with perceived stress a community sample of n 391 adult completed an ambulatory assessment protocol for two 2 day period with fixed hourly interval spread across 16 hr result consistent with our preregistered hypothesis multilevel structural equation model returned that both personality and perceived social support predicted daily stressor exposure and moderated within person effect of daily stressor on perceived stress in contrast to our hypothesis received social support had no effect on daily stress process when extraversion neuroticism and social support were added a joint predictor neuroticism and extraversion were related to stressor exposure and further moderated the within person link between stressor exposure and stress experience while perceived social support had an incremental beneficial effect on social conflict exposure and stress appraisal conclusion social support doe not increment the well established relationship between neuroticism or extraversion and stress reactivity

Title: The relevance of goal-orientation for motivation in high versus low proneness to negative symptoms
Authors: Schlier, B.; Engel, M.; Fladung, A. K.; Fritzsche, A.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: background the psychological mechanism of why individual with negative symptom fail to initiate and perform goal directed behavior are not well understood drawing on the reward sensitivity and expectancy value theory we investigate whether negative symptom like experience nsle are associated with generating le approach goal aimed at reaching a positive outcome and more avoidance goal aimed at avoiding a negative outcome and whether this type of goal orientation explains motivational deficit i e perceiving goal a le feasible and important and being le committed to them method based on the continuum model of negative symptom we identified two parallelized extreme group with high and low level of nsle n 37 respectively in an ad hoc online sample of healthy individual n 262 using the community assessment of psychic experience in an online study these participant were instructed to generate approach and avoidance goal and to rate each goal in term of feasibility importance and goal commitment result participant with low level of nsle generated more approach than avoidance goal participant with high level of nsle showed no such difference due to increased number of avoidance goal furthermore avoidance goal orientation predicted reduced subjective feasibility and importance of goal and le goal commitment limitation result are based on a healthy sample rather than people with psychosis no longitudinal or behavioral data for goal striving wa collected conclusion people with nsle generate more avoidance goal than control this is dysfunctional because it correlate with feeling le committed to reach one s goal optimizing goal setting could be a promising starting point for psychological intervention aimed at reducing negative symptom

Title: Differential effects of visually induced analgesia and attention depending on the pain stimulation site
Authors: Cordier, L.; Ullrich, E. M.; Herpertz, S.; Zieglgansberger, W.; Trojan, J.; Diers, M.
Abstract: background the term visually induced analgesia describes a reduced pain perception induced by watching the painful body part a opposed to watching a neutral object in chronic back pain patient experimental pain movement induced pain and habitual pain can be reduced with visual feedback visual feedback can also enhance the effect of both massage treatment and manual therapy the impact of somatosensory attentional process remains unclear method in the current study participant received painful electrical stimulus to their thumb and back while being presented with either a real time video of their thumb or back factor feedback in addition using an oddball paradigm they had to count the number of deviant stimulus applied to either their back or thumb factor attention and rate the pain intensity result we found a significant main effect for attention with decreased pain rating during attention there wa no main effect for visual feedback and no significant interaction between visual feedback and attention post hoc test revealed that the lowest pain intensity rating were achieved during visual feedback of the back thumb and counting at the back thumb conclusion these data suggest that the modulation of perceived acute pain by visually induced analgesia may be influenced by a simultaneous somatosensory attention task significance somatosensory attention reduced experimental pain intensity in the thumb and back in the presence of both congruent and incongruent visual feedback we found no significant visual feedback effect on the complex interplay between visual feedback and somatosensory attention

Title: Gaze behavior is associated with the cortisol response to acute psychosocial stress in the virtual TSST
Authors: Vatheuer, C. C.; Vehlen, A.; von Dawans, B.; Domes, G.
Abstract: background the trier social stress test tsst is a reliable tool for psychobiological stress induction because of it socio evaluative nature it ha been useful for investigating gaze behavior it ha been shown that healthy people avoid looking toward face when under stress a finding that corroborates study demonstrating avoidance of eye contact in social anxiety disorder yet little is known about the relationship between gaze behavior and the biological stress response method in a final sample of 74 healthy male a virtual reality version of the trier social stress test tsst vr with an integrated eye tracker wa implemented to investigate gaze behavior during acute stress induction stress response measure were collected via saliva sample and subjective stress rating additional questionnaire were administered for examining the influence of social anxiety trait result the tsst vr elicited a significant psychobiological stress response overall higher gaze time on judge compared to surroundings were found in the speech task while this pattern wa reversed in the arithmetic task critically there wa a significant negative association between gaze time on judge and cortisol output in cortisol responder conclusion in a non clinical sample avoidance of gaze is associated with a stronger cortisol response to acute stress this study demonstrates the potential of eye tracking to disentangle the effect of acute stress on social interaction warranting further investigation in clinical population characterized by high level of anxiety in social situation such a social anxiety and autism spectrum disorder

Title: Daily dynamic assessment and modelling of intersession processes in ambulatory psychotherapy: A proof of concept study
Authors: Kaiser, T.; Laireiter, A. R.
Abstract: background the typical mode of assessment in study on intersession process isp in psychotherapy is using cross sectional or weekly measurement daily dynamic of intersession process have not yet been studied method intersession process data from 22 ambulatory psychotherapy case were collected in a naturalistic study with high temporal resolution resulting in a total of 1026 daily measurement multilevel vector autoregressive var modelling wa applied to discover the temporal course and causal influence among intersession process centrality analysis wa applied to discover unique function of various intersession process variable result a group level network structure wa discovered offering first insight on the role of different intersession process during psychotherapy centrality analysis revealed unique role for various aspect of the intersession process temporal distance from the last session had only weak influence on the isp conclusion using short daily measure the unique role of various aspect of the isp were uncovered some aspect of the isp like recalling session content or reflection on future session content are facilitator of overall isp intensity other aspect like thought on payment or appointment or negative treatment related emotion are likely to suppress isp

Title: Applicability of the ICD-11 proposal for PTSD: a comparison of prevalence and comorbidity rates with the DSM-IV PTSD classification in two post-conflict samples
Authors: Stammel, N.; Abbing, E. M.; Heeke, C.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: background the world health organization recently proposed significant change to the posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd diagnostic criterion in the 11th edition of the international classification of disease icd 11 objective the present study investigated the impact of these change in two different post conflict sample method prevalence and rate of concurrent depression and anxiety socio demographic characteristic and indicator of clinical severity according to icd 11 in 1 075 cambodian and 453 colombian civilian exposed to civil war and genocide were compared to those according to the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder fourth edition dsm iv result result indicated significantly lower prevalence rate under the icd 11 proposal 8 1 cambodian sample and 44 4 colombian sample compared to the dsm iv 11 2 cambodian sample and 55 0 colombian sample participant meeting a ptsd diagnosis only under the icd 11 proposal had significantly lower rate of concurrent depression and a lower concurrent total score depression and anxiety compared to participant meeting only dsm iv diagnostic criterion there were no significant difference in socio demographic characteristic and indicator of clinical severity between these two group conclusion the lower prevalence of ptsd according to the icd 11 proposal in our sample of person exposed to a high number of traumatic event may counter criticism of previous ptsd classification to overuse the ptsd diagnosis in population exposed to extreme stressor also another goal to better distinguish ptsd from comorbid disorder could be supported with our data

Title: Interplay of demographic variables, birth experience, and initial reactions in the prediction of symptoms of posttraumatic stress one year after giving birth
Authors: Konig, J.; Schmid, S.; Loser, E.; Neumann, O.; Buchholz, S.; Kastner, R.
Abstract: background there ha been increasing research on posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd following childbirth in the last two decade the literature on predictor of who develops posttraumatic stress symptom p suggests that both vulnerability and birth factor have an influence but many study measure predictor and outcome simultaneously objective in this context we aimed to examine indirect and direct effect of predictor of p which were measured longitudinally method we assessed woman within the first day n 353 6 week and 12 month n 183 after having given birth to a healthy infant the first assessment included question on demographic pregnancy and birth experience the second and third assessment contained screening for postpartum depression ptsd and general mental health problem a well a assessing social support and physical well being we analysed our data using structural equation modelling technique n 277 result our final model showed good fit and wa consistent with a diathesis stress model of p woman who had used antidepressant medication in the 10 year before childbirth had higher p at 6 week independent of birth experience subjective birth experience wa the early predictor with the highest total effect on later p interestingly a probable migration background also had a small but significant effect on p via more episiotomy the null result for social support may have been caused by a ceiling effect conclusion given that we measured predictor at different time point our result lend important support to the etiological model namely that there is a vulnerability pathway and a stress pathway leading to p p and other psychological measure stayed very stable between 6 week and 1 year postpartum indicating that it is possible to identify woman developing problem early highlight of the article our result are consistent with a diathesis stress model vulnerability antidepressant use in the previous 10 year influenced posttraumatic stress symptom at 6 week and 1 year independently of stress birth related variable the strongest predictor of posttraumatic stress symptom 1 year postpartum wa posttraumatic stress symptom 6 week postpartum this mean that woman who develop problem could be identified during routinely offered postpartum care woman with a probable migration background experienced more p 1 year after the birth which wa an indirect effect through more episiotomy and more p after 6 week

Title: Anti-Suicide Function of Nonsuicidal Self-Injury in Female Inpatient Adolescents
Authors: Kraus, L.; Schmid, M.; In-Albon, T.
Abstract: background there have been numerous study investigating the relationship between nonsuicidal self injury nssi and suicidality on the one side nssi is an important risk factor for suicidality including suicidal thought and behavior on the other side it ha been suggested that one function of nssi might be a a coping mechanism that can help individual in the short term avoid suicide the present study investigated the relationship between suicidality and nssi in female inpatient adolescent focusing on nssi a an anti suicide strategy method subject were 56 female adolescent aged 12 18 year m 15 95 year sd 1 27 recruited from different inpatient child and adolescent psychiatric unit all participant fulfilled the dsm 5 research criterion for nonsuicidal self injury disorder nssi d to a suicidality nssi d and current and past diagnosis a structured clinical interview wa conducted result nssi a a short term coping strategy for avoiding suicide wa indicated by one third 32 1 of the participant before participant engaged in nssi the anti suicide function wa reported more frequently than reducing interpersonal problem d 59 getting relief from negative emotion and inducing positive feeling were reported at the same frequency a avoiding suicide before nssi participant engaging in nssi to avoid suicide and those reporting other function did not significantly differ regarding other nssi characteristic suicidality or psychopathology result indicate that the anti suicide function significantly predicts the duration of current suicidal ideation beta 557 conclusion this study provides preliminary support for the idea that nssi is frequently used by female adolescent with nssi d to avoid suicide given the high co occurrence of nssi and suicidality our result underline the importance of clinical assessment of suicidality and several nssi function including the anti suicide function in adolescent with nssi

Title: Effects of a Single Yoga Session on Cardiac Interoceptive Accuracy and Emotional Experience
Authors: Schillings, C.; Schultchen, D.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: background there is an increasing body of research supporting the idea that cardiac interoceptive accuracy iac can be improved by training finding concerning the effect of a single yoga session on iac and the related construct emotional experience are sparse the aim of this study wa to examine if a single yoga session increase iac and improves emotional experience method 137 student were randomly assigned to a 20 min yoga session n 47 an endurance session n 46 or an inactive control condition n 44 iac and emotional experience were assessed before and after the session result there were no significant change in iac or positive and negative affect iac at baseline and the change in positive effect were found a predictor for iac after the yoga session conclusion a 20 min yoga session seems to be not applicable to improve iac and emotional experience future study should investigate long term intervention and diverse healthy and clinical population

Title: [Psychological Abnormalities in Children from the Perspective of Parents with a Mental Disorder]
Authors: Holler, I.; Forkmann, T.; Natrop, L.; Hundlings, A.; Specka, M.; Scherbaum, N.
Abstract: background there is increased risk for child with a mentally ill parent to get a mental illness in germany it is assumed that the risk for psychological abnormality in child with a mentally ill parent is increased by a factor of 2 4 the aim of this study wa to give an overview of psychological abnormality in child with mentally ill parent method patient were asked about their child and possible psychological abnormality in their child during their stay in a psychiatric ward data of n 118 child 51 7 of psychiatric inpatient could be used for analysis result one fourth of the child showed psychological abnormality according to their parent one fourth wa also in psychotherapeutic psychiatric treatment there were no difference in the abnormality associated with sociodemographic factor of the parent conclusion our result show that child of a mentally ill parent also suffer from psychological abnormality more explicit analysis of the care situation of these child a well a data from direct interview with them are needed

Title: The efficacy of a family-based cognitive-behavioral treatment for separation anxiety disorder in children aged 8-13: a randomized comparison with a general anxiety program
Authors: Schneider, S.; Blatter-Meunier, J.; Herren, C.; In-Albon, T.; Adornetto, C.; Meyer, A.; Lavallee, K. L.
Abstract: background this randomized controlled trial examines the relative efficacy of a disorder specific treatment program trennungsangstprogramm fur familien taff english separation anxiety family therapy for child suffering from separation anxiety disorder sad in comparison with a general anxiety program method sixty four child aged 8 13 with sad and their parent were assigned either to a 16 session disorder specific sad treatment program including parent training and classical cognitive behavioral therapy cbt component taff or to a general child focused 16 week comparison group coping cat cc without any parent training diagnosis and parent cognition were assessed at baseline and at follow ups global success rating were collected at end of treatment and at follow up rating for anxiety impairment distress and life quality were collected at baseline 1 again after a 4 week waiting period repeatedly throughout treatment at 4 week and at 1 year follow up result the response rate no sad diagnosis at 4 week follow up among the 52 treatment completers wa 87 5 v 82 1 taff v cc intent to treat 67 7 v 69 7 at 1 year follow up the response wa 83 3 versus 75 taff v cc intent to treat 64 5 v 63 6 difference were nonsignificant result from rating scale indicated improvement for both group across time point and assessment area with few between group difference and some small effect favoring the taff program both treatment program yielded a reduction in parental dysfunctional belief conclusion result indicate a slight advantage of the taff program over a general child based treatment for sad however these difference were le strong than hypothesized indicating that the inclusion of parent training doe not add large effect to classical child based cbt in school age child with sad psycinfo database record c 2013 apa all right reserved

Title: Impulsive decision-making predicts the course of substance-related and addictive disorders
Authors: Kraplin, A.; Hofler, M.; Pooseh, S.; Wolff, M.; Kronke, K. M.; Goschke, T.; Buhringer, G.; Smolka, M. N.
Abstract: background this study investigated whether pattern of impulsive decision making i differ between individual with dsm 5 substance use disorder sud or non substance related addictive disorder nd and healthy control and ii predict the increase of sud and nd severity after one year method in a prospective longitudinal community study 338 individual 19 27 year 59 female were included in one of three group sud n 100 nd n 118 or healthy control n 120 group difference in four impulsive decision making facet were analyzed with the bayesian prior delay discounting mean 0 37 variance 0 02 probability discounting for gain and for loss each 0 16 0 02 and loss aversion 0 44 0 02 sud and nd severity were assessed at baseline and after 1 year n 312 92 predictive association between decision making and sud nd severity change were analyzed with the bayesian prior mean 0 25 variance 0 016 result compared with control the sud group displayed steeper delay discounting and lower probability discounting for loss the nd group displayed lower probability discounting for loss posterior probability 98 sud symptom increase after 1 year wa predicted by steeper delay discounting and lower loss aversion nd symptom increase by lower probability discounting for loss and lower loss aversion posterior probability 98 there wa low evidence for predictive relation between decision making and the quantity frequency of addictive behaviour discussion impulsive decision making characterizes sud and nd and predicts the course of sud and nd symptom but not the engagement in addictive behaviour strength of evidence differed between different facet of impulsive decision making and wa mostly weaker than a priori expected

Title: The impact of maternal anxiety disorder on mother-infant interaction in the postpartum period
Authors: Reck, C.; Tietz, A.; Muller, M.; Seibold, K.; Tronick, E.
Abstract: background this study investigated whether postpartum anxiety disorder is associated to altered pattern of infant a well a maternal engagement in a face to face still face interaction ffsf sampling and method n 39 woman with postpartum dsm iv anxiety disorder and n 48 healthy mother were videotaped during a ffsf with their infant m 4 1 month result infant of the clinical group showed significantly le positive engagement during the play episode than infant of control this result depended on infant sex male control demonstrated more positive interaction than male of anxious mother there wa no such effect for female infant who engaged significantly le positively during the play episode than male and did not change their positive engagement during the ffsf these finding imply pronounced interactive positivity and early vulnerability to maternal anxiety symptom in male infant only the infant of the control showed the still face effect they also protested significantly more during the still face while the clinical infant protest increased significantly during the reunion woman of both group did not differ in their interaction maternal intrusiveness wa associated to infant protest in the course of the ffsf conclusion result suggest that mother infant intervention should consider affect regulation and infant sex specific characteristic in anxious mother infant dyad

Title: Placebo nasal spray protects female participants from experimentally induced sadness and concomitant changes in autonomic arousal
Authors: Gohler, A. C.; Haas, J. W.; Sperl, M. F. J.; Hermann, C.; Winkler, A.
Abstract: background to investigate the powerful placebo effect in antidepressant drug trial and their mechanism recent pioneering experimental study showed that expectation manipulation combined with an active placebo attenuated induced sadness in the present study we aimed at extending these finding by assessing the psychophysiological response in addition to mere self report method one hundred and thirteen healthy female student were randomly assigned to a drug expectation group active placebo positive treatment expectation placebo expectation group active placebo no treatment expectation or a no treatment group no placebo no treatment expectation after placebo intake sadness wa induced by self deprecating statement using the velten method combined with sad music including a rumination phase sadness wa measured using the positive and negative affect schedule expanded form panas x heart rate and skin conductance were assessed continuously result after mood induction and after rumination self reported sadness wa significantly lower and skin conductance level wa significantly higher in the drug expectation group than in the no treatment group the mood induction wa further accompanied by a heart rate deceleration within all group limitation generalizability is limited by sample selectivity and focusing on sadness a a symptom of depression exclusively conclusion expectation induced placebo effect significantly influenced sadness correlated change in autonomic arousal and not only subjectively reported sadness indicating that placebo effect in the context of affect are not merely due to subjective response bias the systematic modification of treatment expectation could be utilized in clinical practice to optimize current therapeutic approach to improve mood regulation

Title: Predictors of successful discontinuation of antipsychotics and antidepressants
Authors: Lincoln, T. M.; Sommer, D.; Quazzola, M.; Witzgall, T.; Schlier, B.
Abstract: background to offer support for patient who decide to discontinue antipsychotic and antidepressant medication identifying which potentially modifiable factor correlate with discontinuation success is crucial here we analyzed the predictive value of the professional support received circumstance prior to discontinuation a strategy of discontinuation and use of functional and non functional coping strategy during discontinuation on self reported discontinuation success and on objective discontinuation method patient who had attempted discontinuing antipsychotic ap and or antidepressant ad during the past 5 year n 316 completed an online survey including question on subjective and objective discontinuation success sociodemographic clinical and medication related factor and scale to a the putative predictor result a regression model with all significant predictor explained 20 30 of the variance in discontinuation success for ad and 30 40 for ap after controlling for baseline sociodemographic clinical and medication related factor the most consistent predictor of subjective discontinuation success wa self care behavior in particular mindfulness relaxation and making use of supportive relationship other predictor depended on the type of medication for ad good alliance with the prescribing physician predicted higher subjective success whereas gradual tapering per se wa associated with lower subjective success and a lower chance of full discontinuation in those tapering off ap leaving time to adjust between dose reduction wa associated with higher subjective success and fewer negative effect conclusion the finding can inform evidence based clinical guideline and intervention aiming to support patient during discontinuation further study powered to take interaction between variable into account are needed to improve the prediction of successful discontinuation

Title: Fostering compliance with physical distancing by interactive feedback in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic: A web-based randomized controlled trial
Authors: Kaiser, T.; Mogling, I.; Feldmann, M.; Hamm, A.; Brakemeier, E. L.
