Abstract: background to slow down the spread of covid 19 the observance of basic hygiene measure and physical distancing is recommended initial finding suggest that physical distancing in particular can prevent the spread of covid 19 objective to investigate how information to prevent the spread of infectious disease should be presented to increase willingness to comply with preventive measure method in a preregistered online experiment 817 subject were presented with either interactively controllable graphic on the spread of covid 19 and information that enable them to recognize how much the spread of covid 19 is reduced by physical distancing experimental group or text based information about quantitative evidence control group it wa hypothesized that participant receiving interactive information on the prevention of covid 19 infection show a significantly higher willingness to comply with future containment measure than participant reading the text based information explorative analysis were conducted to examine whether other factor influence compliance result a predicted we found a small effect d 0 22 95 ci 0 11 0 23 p 001 for the tested intervention the exploratory analysis suggests a decline in compliance later in the study r 0 10 95 ci 0 15 0 07 another significant predictor of change in compliance wa health related anxiety but the effect wa trivial conclusion when presented interactively information on how the own behavior can help prevent infectious disease can lead to slightly stronger change in attitude towards behavioral prevention measure than just text based information given the scalability of this simple internet based intervention it could play a role in fostering compliance during a pandemic within universal prevention strategy future work on the predictive validity of self reported compliance and the real world effect on the intervention is needed

Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak: Addictive social media use, depression, anxiety and stress in quarantine - an exploratory study in Germany and Lithuania
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Truskauskaite-Kuneviciene, I.; Margraf, J.; Kazlauskas, E.
Abstract: background to slow down the spread of the covid 19 pandemic government of many country introduced various behavioral measure starting march 2020 the measure included domestic quarantine not leaving home for infected or potentially infected people due to the need for social distancing online activity increased in spring 2020 this could foster the risk for addictive social medium use smu the present study investigated tendency of addictive smu and their relationship with depression anxiety and stress symptom specifically among individual who stayed in domestic quarantine due to covid 19 in germany and lithuania method in germany n 529 quarantine group n 157 non quarantine group n 372 and in lithuania n 325 quarantine group n 54 non quarantine group n 271 data were assessed via online survey in spring 2020 result in both country person in quarantine had higher level of addictive smu depression anxiety and stress symptom than individual who were not in quarantine the difference wa significant only for addictive smu in the german sample the significant positive correlation between addictive smu and symptom of depression anxiety and stress were stronger in both quarantine group than in the non quarantine group limitation the mostly female young and well educated composition of both investigated sample limit generalizability of the current finding conclusion result reveal first evidence that the use of social medium during domestic covid 19 quarantine might contribute to the increase of addictive tendency and negatively impact well being alternative way of daily routine during the quarantine are discussed

Title: Effects of Electrical Transcutaneous Vagus Nerve Stimulation on the Perceived Intensity of Repetitive Painful Heat Stimuli: A Blinded Placebo- and Sham-Controlled Randomized Crossover Investigation
Authors: Janner, H.; Klausenitz, C.; Gurtler, N.; Hahnenkamp, K.; Usichenko, T. I.
Abstract: background transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation tvns is a promising treatment for acute and chronic pain however experimental study yielded controversial result we examined if tvns reduces the perceived intensity of repetitive painful heat stimulation and temporal summation of pain tsp in healthy volunteer in comparison with placebo and sham stimulation a well a no intervention method in 4 session 90 heat pulse stimulus at individual pain tolerance temperature were applied to the ventral forearm of 49 healthy volunteer 25 woman using a contact heat evoked potential stimulator thermode medoc ramat yishai israel pain intensity wa assessed with verbal rating on a numeric pain scale 0 100 at every tenth heat pulse after the first session in which pain intensity without intervention were evaluated participant completed 3 session in a single blinded randomized crossover manner 1 sham stimulation applied at the earlobe 2 placebo stimulation inactive device or 3 tvns applied at the cymbas concha primary data were analyzed using analysis of variance for repeated measure and t test for paired sample result pain intensity decreased during all intervention a compared to no intervention etap 0 22 p 001 mean difference tvns versus no intervention 9 5 95 confidence interval ci 3 6 15 4 p 001 hypoalgesic effect of tvns wa better than that of placebo and sham in men before the onset of tsp mean difference for tvns versus placebo 6 2 95 ci 0 2 12 1 tvns versus sham 6 2 95 ci 0 2 12 1 p 05 in woman tsp response under tvns wa decreased if compared to no intervention median difference 7 5 95 ci 3 5 15 0 p 003 conclusion tvns placebo and sham stimulation exerted comparable effect under experimental heat pain stimulation only in male participant tvns wa superior to sham and placebo condition in the reduction of heat pain before the onset of tsp

Title: Individual treatment selection for patients with posttraumatic stress disorder
Authors: Deisenhofer, A. K.; Delgadillo, J.; Rubel, J. A.; Bohnke, J. R.; Zimmermann, D.; Schwartz, B.; Lutz, W.
Abstract: background trauma focused cognitive behavioral therapy tf cbt and eye movement desensitization and reprocessing emdr are two highly effective treatment option for posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd yet on an individual level ptsd patient vary substantially in treatment response the aim of the paper is to test the application of a treatment selection method based on a personalized advantage index pai method the study used clinical data for patient accessing treatment for ptsd in a primary care mental health service in the north of england ptsd patient received either emdr n 75 or tf cbt n 242 the patient health questionnaire phq 9 wa used a an outcome measure for depressive symptom associated with ptsd variable predicting differential treatment response were identified using an automated variable selection approach genetic algorithm and afterwards included in regression model allowing the calculation of each patient s pai result age employment status gender and functional impairment were identified a relevant variable for tf cbt for emdr baseline depressive symptom a well a prescribed antidepressant medication were selected a predictor variable fifty six percent of the patient n 125 had a pai equal or higher than one standard deviation from those patient 62 50 did not receive their model predicted treatment and could have benefited from a treatment assignment based on the pai conclusion using a pai based algorithm ha the potential to improve clinical decision making and to enhance individual patient outcome although further replication is necessary before such an approach can be implemented in prospective study

Title: Social cognition and social problem solving abilities in individuals with alcohol use disorder
Authors: Schmidt, T.; Roser, P.; Juckel, G.; Brune, M.; Suchan, B.; Thoma, P.
Abstract: background up to now little is known about higher order cognitive ability like social cognition and social problem solving ability in alcohol dependent patient however impairment in these domain lead to an increased probability for relapse and are thus highly relevant in treatment context method this cross sectional study assessed distinct aspect of social cognition and social problem solving in 31 hospitalized patient with alcohol use disorder aud and 30 matched healthy control hc three ecologically valid scenario based test were used to gauge the ability to infer the mental state of story character in complicated interpersonal situation the capacity to select the best problem solving strategy among other le optimal alternative and the ability to freely generate appropriate strategy to handle difficult interpersonal conflict standardized test were used to a executive function attention trait empathy and memory and correlation were computed between measure of executive function attention trait empathy and test of social problem solving result aud patient generated significantly fewer socially sensitive and practically effective solution for problematic interpersonal situation than the hc group furthermore patient performed significantly worse when asked to select the best alternative among a list of presented alternative for scenario containing sarcastic remark and had significantly more problem to interpret sarcastic remark in difficult interpersonal situation conclusion these specific pattern of impairment should be considered in treatment program addressing impaired social skill in individual with aud

Title: Visual Attention to Sexual Stimuli in Women With Clinical, Subclinical, and Normal Sexual Functioning: An Eye-Tracking Study
Authors: Velten, J.; Milani, S.; Margraf, J.; Brotto, L. A.
Abstract: background visual attention to sexual stimulus is an important mean to facilitate sexual arousal and is thereby relevant for healthy sexual functioning experimental study suggest that sexual dysfunction is associated with le attention toward sexual stimulus aim the goal of this study wa to use an eye tracking based free viewing paradigm to investigate whether woman in the clinical range of sexual function attend to a genital area in visual sexual stimulus differently than woman with subclinical sexual function or those with normal sexual functioning method toward this goal 69 woman m age 27 77 sd 8 00 range 19 54 with clinical n 30 subclinical n 23 and normal n 16 level of sexual functioning watched a series of 10 picture depicting heterosexual couple during vaginal intercourse while their eye movement were recorded each picture wa presented twice once with a distracting object eg a to do list or household appliance present in the picture and once without for 8 second each outcome 5 eye tracking measure indicative of different aspect of initial and sustained attention were analyzed result a hypothesized 3 out of 5 eye tracking measure ie first fixation duration number of first fixation and total fixation duration indicated that woman in the clinical group attended le to the genital area in the picture than woman with normal sexual functioning for 2 index ie first fixation duration and total fixation duration woman with subclinical v normal sexual functioning also attended le to the genital area in contrast to our hypothesis the presence of a distracting object did not influence attention to the genital area in either of the sexual function group clinical implication this study provides further evidence of the role of attentional bias in sexual dysfunction in woman strength and limitation eye tracking methodology allows for a continuous measurement of visual attention this is one of the first study using this methodology to a difference in visual attention in woman with and without sexual dysfunction however the cross sectional nature of this study prevents causal interpretation of finding conclusion future study should use experimental paradigm to determine the causal role of visual attention for the development or maintenance of sexual dysfunction velten j milani s margraf j et al visual attention to sexual stimulus in woman with clinical subclinical and normal sexual functioning an eye tracking study j sex med 2021 18 144 155

Title: The Relevance of Emotion Regulation in Explaining Why Social Exclusion Triggers Paranoia in Individuals at Clinical High Risk of Psychosis
Authors: Lincoln, T. M.; Sundag, J.; Schlier, B.; Karow, A.
Abstract: background vulnerability stress model postulate that social stress trigger psychotic episode in vulnerable individual however experimental evidence for the proposed causal pathway is scarce and the translating mechanism are insufficiently understood the study assessed the impact of social exclusion on paranoid belief in a quasi experimental design and investigated the role of emotion regulation er a a vulnerability indicator and emotional response a a putative translating mechanism method participant fulfilling criterion for clinical high risk of psychosis chr n 25 control with anxiety disorder ac n 40 and healthy control hc n 40 were assessed for dysfunctional eg rumination catastrophizing blaming and functional er strategy eg reappraising accepting refocusing they were then exposed to social exclusion during a virtual ball game cyberball and assessed for change in self reported emotion and paranoid belief result the chr sample showed a significantly stronger increase in paranoid belief from before to after the social exclusion than both control group this wa accounted for by lower level of functional and higher level of dysfunctional er compared to hc and by a stronger increase in self reported negative emotion in the chr group compared to ac and hc conclusion the result confirm the role of negative emotion on the pathway from social stressor to psychotic symptom and indicate that both the use of dysfunctional er strategy and difficulty in employing functional strategy add to explaining why people at risk of psychosis respond to a social stressor with increased paranoia

Title: How the integration of normal medical test results can be improved in patients with somatoform disorders-An experimental study
Authors: Kube, T.; Riecke, J.; Heider, J.; Ballou, S. K.; Glombiewski, J. A.; Rief, W.; Barsky, A. J.
Abstract: background we examined whether the difficulty of patient with somatoform disorder sfds in integrating medical reassurance can be altered by preventing patient from devaluing reassuring information through defensive cognitive strategy method patient with sfd n 60 patient with major depression n 32 and healthy volunteer n 37 watched a videotaped doctor s report which provided medical reassurance for gastroenterological complaint subsequently participant were asked about their perception of the report in the sfd sample patient appraisal of the reassuring wa experimentally modulated in one condition doubt about the validity of the doctor s diagnostic assessment were triggered in another condition the devaluation of medical reassurance wa blocked through underscoring the validity of the doctor s diagnostic assessment and a control condition received no manipulation result a evident on all outcome variable patient with sfd had more difficulty integrating medical reassurance than depressed and healthy people within the sfd sample participant from the experimental condition blocking the devaluation of medical reassurance rated the likelihood of an undetected serious disease to be significantly lower than the other two condition they also reported le emotional concern and a lower desire to seek the opinion of another doctor conclusion by comparing patient with sfd to both a healthy and a clinical control group the current study suggests that the difficulty in processing reassuring medical information is a specific psychopathological feature of sfd furthermore our result suggest that the integration of medical reassurance can be improved by preventing patient from devaluing reassuring information through dismissive cognitive strategy psycinfo database record c 2023 apa all right reserved

Title: Return to work and depressive symptoms in young stroke survivors after six and twelve months: cross-sectional and longitudinal analyses
Authors: Volz, M.; Ladwig, S.; Werheid, K.
Abstract: background while depression after stroke is common and stroke prevalence globally increase in working age population the role of return to work rtw in the pathogenesis of post stroke depression psd remains unclear this study examined if rtw is linked to psd within the first year after ischemic stroke independently from established risk factor method stroke survivor n 176 in their working age 65 year recruited from two rehabilitation clinic were assessed for established risk factor pre stroke depression activity of daily living stroke severity cognitive impairment and social support rtw and depressive symptom geriatric depression scale gd 15 were assessed six and twelve month post stroke multivariate regression analysis were used to a the cross sectional and longitudinal relationship between rtw and gd 15 while controlling for established psd risk factor result successful rtw wa independently associated with lower gd 15 at both measurement occasion p 05 next to the absence of pre stroke depression and higher social support stroke severity predicted gd 15 at twelve month the predictive value of six month rtw for subsequent depressive symptom beyond the influence of established risk factor wa s 1 73 p 09 discussion rtw wa independently associated with psd in young stroke survivor within the first year post stroke and exerted a marginally significant effect on subsequent depression our study highlight the relevance of rtw for young stroke survivor psd beyond the influence of established risk factor further assessment examining to what extent fostering rtw contributes to mental well being after stroke might be promising for psd prevention next to evident beneficial economic effect

Title: Homesickness in asylum seekers: The role of mental health and migration-related factors
Authors: Rosner, R.; Hagl, M.; Bucheler, L.; Comtesse, H.
Abstract: background while homesickness in refugee is a recurring theme in clinical practice respective research in this population is scarce the utrecht homesickness scale uhs allows distinguishing between certain aspect of homesickness namely genuine separation distress like missing family and friend or yearning for home on the one side and problem regarding adjustment to the new situation on the other so far the instrument wa applied mainly in sample of university student and never in refugee objective we aimed to explore homesickness in a refugee population and it association with mental health symptom and migration related factor in addition we wanted to evaluate the uhs s factor structure in a sample other than student method individual from different country n 99 seeking asylum in germany were assessed for homesickness migration related variable e g number of loss and stage of the asylum proceeding and mental health symptom symptom of depression posttraumatic stress and prolonged grief after exploratory factor analysis standardized mean factor score were fed into subsequent correlational and regression analysis to identify the most prominent predictor of homesickness score result the participant showed substantial level of homesickness we found a three factor solution that implied distinct factor regarding 1 adjustment difficulty and loneliness 2 rumination about home and 3 missing family and or friend the total homesickness score wa associated with mental health but regression analysis with the three mean factor score showed differential association with mental health and migration related variable while adjustment difficulty and loneliness were besides time since arrival in germany associated with mental health problem depressive and posttraumatic stress symptom ruminating about home wa predicted by migration related variable number of loss and asylum status for the factor score regarding missing family and or friend the regression model wa not significant conclusion the assessment of homesickness in refugee population is feasible and of clinical importance especially when distinguishing between separation distress and difficulty with adjusting to the new situation

Title: Typologies of posttraumatic stress disorder in treatment-seeking older adults
Authors: Bottche, M.; Pietrzak, R. H.; Kuwert, P.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: background while it is well known that posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd is characterized by heterogeneous symptom cluster little is known about predominant typology of ptsd symptom in older adult method latent profile analysis lpas were employed to evaluate predominant typology of ptsd symptom in a sample of 164 treatment seeking older adult with childhood war related trauma multinomial logistic regression were conducted to evaluate predictor of class membership result lpas revealed that a 3 class solution best fit the data these included an intermediate disturbance class 50 0 and two pervasive disturbance class which differed with respect to severity of avoidance symptom pervasive disturbance low avoidance 33 5 pervasive disturbance high avoidance 16 5 a greater number of traumatic event predicted membership in the pervasive disturbance class the pervasive disturbance low avoidance class had a higher level of education than the pervasive disturbance high avoidance class compared to the intermediate disturbance class the pervasive disturbance class had the highest level of depression anxiety and somatization symptom conclusion these result suggest that ptsd in treatment seeking older adult may be characterized by three predominant typology which are differentiated by overall severity and avoidance symptom lifetime trauma burden education level and comorbid depression anxiety and somatization symptom these result underscore the importance of considering heterogeneity in the phenotypic presentation of ptsd in assessment and treatment approach for this disorder in older adult

Title: Regulating negative emotions of others reduces own stress: Neurobiological correlates and the role of individual differences in empathy
Authors: Guendelman, S.; Bayer, M.; Prehn, K.; Dziobek, I.
Abstract: background while witnessing the suffering of other people result in personal distress it is not clear whether regulating others emotion in such situation also come at an emotional cost for the observer method this study included 62 subject and used a newly developed functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri paradigm to investigate mechanism of self and other emotion regulation via reappraisal while the subject and an interaction partner outside the scanner were facing the same distressing situation simultaneously the relationship between distress level and individual difference in emotional and cognitive empathy were also assessed result we found that individual exhibited especially high level of personal distress when relating with a partner while both being exposed to aversive photograph and that especially highly empathetic individual were prone to such personal distress moreover when engaging in social emotion regulation personal distress wa reduced in the observer at a similar rate a in self emotion regulation fmri analysis revealed increased activation for other v self emotion regulation in the precuneus and the left temporo parietal junction which are commonly engaged in social cognition furthermore this activation wa associated with lower self reported stress and decreased sympathetic autonomic activity while regulating others precuneus activation exhibited a distinctive functional connectivity profile with parietal emotion regulation region conclusion this study demonstrates benefit of actively regulating another person s emotion for reducing one s own distress and identifies the precuneus a an important node for social emotion regulation given the novelty of the study design the result are of exploratory and preliminary nature

Title: Trapped in my inner prison-Cross-sectional examination of internal and external entrapment, hopelessness and suicidal ideation
Authors: Holler, I.; Kremers, A.; Schreiber, D.; Forkmann, T.
Abstract: background within the integrated motivational volitional model of suicidal behavior entrapment that consecutively lead to hopelessness is considered a a proximal risk factor for suicidal ideation entrapment can refer to both external and internal circumstance whereby result of recent study indicate that internal entrapment play a more important role than external entrapment in the development of suicidal ideation it ha been considered that to escape internal entrapment might be more complicated than to change external circumstance however it remains unclear whether the greater effect of internal entrapment on suicidal ideation is due to greater feeling of hopelessness therefore the aim of this study wa to address this research gap and to examine the effect of internal and external entrapment on hopelessness and suicidal ideation method n 454 participant from a community sample 75 female aged between 18 and 73 year m 29 91 sd 11 56 conducted a cross sectional online survey all participant were assessed for suicidal ideation hopelessness and internal a well a external entrapment pearson product moment correlation and two mediation analysis were conducted result all construct were significantly correlated for both internal and external entrapment an effect on suicidal ideation wa found both effect were partially mediated by hopelessness this mediation wa larger for external entrapment the completely standardized indirect effect used to compare the mediation model wa larger for external entrapment than for internal entrapment conclusion hopelessness mediated the association between external entrapment a well a internal entrapment and suicidal ideation this effect wa larger for external entrapment

Title: Social media use, mental health, and suicide-related outcomes in Russian women: A cross-sectional comparison between two age groups
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Krasavtseva, Y.; Kochetkov, Y.; Tour, P.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background woman who belong to the age group emerging adulthood 18 to 29 year are vulnerable to mental health issue and suicide related outcome objective this study investigated potential predictor of suicide related outcome in female emerging adulthood and compared them to older woman design and method data of 2537 woman from russia group 18 to 29 year n 1123 group 29 year n 1414 on lifetime suicide related outcome problematic social medium use daily stress depression and anxiety symptom and positive mental health were assessed via online cross sectional survey result the younger group spent significantly more time on social medium use than the older group it had significantly higher level of daily stress problematic social medium use depression and anxiety symptom and suicide related outcome the older group showed significantly higher level of positive mental health only in the younger group problematic social medium use significantly mediated the relationship between daily stress and suicide related outcome in a moderated mediation analysis positive mental health significantly moderated the association between problematic social medium use and suicide related outcome specifically the higher the positive mental health level the le close the link between both variable conclusion the current result reveal that young woman in russia could be at enhanced risk for daily stress problematic social medium use and low level of mental health the interaction between these variable could foster suicide related outcome public governmental communication in russia should call attention to potential negative impact of intensive social medium use

Title: Sources of social support for postpartum women with a history of childhood maltreatment: Consequences for perceived stress and general mental health in the first year after birth
Authors: Hitzler, M.; Behnke, A.; Gundel, H.; Ziegenhain, U.; Kindler, H.; Kolassa, I. T.; Zimmermann, J.
Abstract: background woman with a history of childhood maltreatment cm experience the postpartum period a particularly stressful and may benefit le from social support implicating a higher risk for mental health problem and higher stress level in mother with cm objective thus we investigated the complex relationship of cm and social support provided by different source intimate partner parent parent in law friend in predicting stress perception and mental health over the course of the first year postpartum participant in n 295 postpartum woman we assessed cm experience stress perception perceived social support and general mental health 3 and 12 month postpartum method linear mixed effect model were used to examine the course of social support over the first year postpartum and path analysis were used to investigate mediation and moderation effect result we found that cm wa linked to lower level of perceived social support accounted for more mental health problem and amplified the negative association between perceived stress and maternal mental health most importantly we showed that only partner support wa beneficial for maternal mental health and this association wa mediated by reduction in perceived stress conclusion cm a a major risk factor for mental health impairs the stress resilience of affected postpartum woman extending previous research our result reveal that the source of postpartum social support determines it benefit for maternal health our finding emphasize the need of at risk mother to be provided with additional source of support to cope with daily practical organizational and emotional challenge

Title: Self-reported workplace perception as indicators of work anxieties
Authors: Muschalla, B.; Fay, D.; Linden, M.
Abstract: background work anxiety is a potentially disabling mental health problem which can cause long term sickness absence in many case patient do not openly report their anxiety and tend to give externalizing explanation of inner problem therefore people with work anxiety may perceive their workplace more negatively than those without such anxiety aim to investigate the relation between subjective work description and work anxiety method work anxiety wa investigated with a standardized interview in a sample of employed psychosomatic rehabilitation inpatient suffering from common mental disorder we assessed their subjective perception and evaluation of workplace condition with the short questionnaire for job analysis kfza and compared their result with those from a sample of employee in the general population result there were 148 inpatient participant and 8015 general population control patient with work anxiety described their workplace significantly more negatively than patient without work anxiety and employee in the general population with no difference in workplace description between psychosomatic patient without work anxiety and the general population sample the type of complaint about work condition wa related to the specific type of work anxiety conclusion report about workplace burden can be indicative of work anxiety and should prompt further in depth assessment the content of complaint about work condition may point to the type of underlying work anxiety

Title: Negative work perception not changed in a short work-anxiety-coping group therapy intervention
Authors: Muschalla, B.
Abstract: background work anxiety is often associated with long term sick leave and requires early intervention work anxiety are associated with negative work perception therefore one aim in early intervention is a cognitive reframing of dysfunctional perception of workplace characteristic method a psychotherapeutic specialist conducted two group program of four session each one hundred twenty three rehabilitation in patient with work anxiety were randomly assigned either to a work anxiety coping group or to a recreational group the short questionnaire for work analysis kfza wa administered before and after the group treatment to measure perception of working condition result participant from the work anxiety coping group did not see their work in a significantly more positive light at the end of the intervention compared to participant from the recreational group conclusion a short work anxiety coping group did not initiate a consistent positive re appraisal of work employer and occupational physician should not expect positive change of work perception when an employee return from short medical rehabilitation including work directed treatment additional support from the workplace must be considered e g employer physician employee conversation preceding return to work or temporary work adjustment

Title: Does Emotion Dysregulation Mediate the Relationship between Early Maltreatment and Later Substance Dependence? Findings of the CANSAS Study
Authors: Wolff, S.; Holl, J.; Stopsack, M.; Arens, E. A.; Hocker, A.; Staben, K. A.; Hiller, P.; Klein, M.; Schafer, I.; Barnow, S.; Cansas Study Group
Abstract: background aim maltreatment in childhood and adolescence is a risk factor for substance use disorder suds in adulthood this association ha rarely been investigated in the light of emotion dysregulation to fill this gap this study examines emotion dysregulation and suds among adult with a history of early maltreatment method comparison of emotion dysregulation in adult with a history of early abuse and neglect who developed either an sud n 105 or no mental disorder n 54 further a mediation model for the association between the severity of early maltreatment and suds wa tested participant completed research diagnostic interview for psychopathology the difficulty in emotion regulation scale and the childhood trauma questionnaire result by using hierarchical regression technique and mediational analysis controlling for age and gender it wa possible to provide evidence for the mediating role of emotion dysregulation between early emotional and physical maltreatment and later suds conclusion emotion dysregulation is a potential mechanism underlying the relationship between early emotional and physical maltreatment and the development of suds in light of these finding focusing on the early training of adaptive emotion regulation strategy after childhood maltreatment might be of considerable relevance to prevent the development of suds

Title: Effects of Maternal Anxiety Disorders on Infant Self-Comforting Behaviors: The Role of Maternal Bonding, Infant Gender and Age
Authors: Muller, M.; Tronick, E.; Zietlow, A. L.; Nonnenmacher, N.; Verschoor, S.; Trauble, B.
Abstract: background aim we investigated the link between maternal bonding maternal anxiety disorder and infant self comforting behavior furthermore we looked at the moderating role of infant gender and age method our sample n 69 comprised 28 mother with an anxiety disorder according to dsm iv criterion and 41 control each with their 2 5 to 8 month old infant 41 female and 28 male infant behavior were recorded during the face to face still face paradigm maternal bonding wa assessed by the postpartum bonding questionnaire result conditional process analysis revealed that lower maternal bonding partially mediated between maternal anxiety disorder and increased self comforting behavior but only in older female infant over 5 5 month of age however considering maternal anxiety disorder without the influence of bonding older female infant over 5 5 month of age showed decreased rate of self comforting behavior while younger male infant under 3 month of age showed increased rate in the case of maternal anxiety disorder conclusion the result suggest that older female infant over 5 5 month of age are more sensitive to lower maternal bonding in the context of maternal anxiety disorder furthermore result suggest a different use of self directed regulation strategy for male and female infant of mother with anxiety disorder and low bonding depending on infant age the result are discussed in the light of gender specific developmental trajectory

Title: Positive mental health moderates the association between depression and suicide ideation: A longitudinal study
Authors: Teismann, T.; Forkmann, T.; Brailovskaia, J.; Siegmann, P.; Glaesmer, H.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background objective depression and suicide ideation regularly occur together yet little is known about factor that buffer individual against the development of suicide ideation the present study investigated whether positive mental health buffer the association between depression and suicide ideation in a longitudinal study design method a total of 207 german student 70 3 female age m 26 04 sd 5 33 were assessed at a baseline evaluation and again twelve month later data were collected using self report questionnaire linear hierarchical regression analysis wa used to analyze the data positive mental health wa considered to moderate the impact of depression on suicide ideation controlling for age and gender result positive mental health wa shown to moderate the impact of depression on suicide ideation in those student who reported higher level of positive mental health depression severity showed no association with suicide ideation over time conclusion positive mental health seems to confer resilience and should be taken into account when assessing individual for suicide risk

Title: Positive mental health, positive affect and suicide ideation
Authors: Teismann, T.; Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background objective positive mental health pmh ha been shown to confer resilience against suicide ideation however the mechanism underlying the positive effect of pmh on suicide ideation behavior are largely unknown the current study aimed to determine whether positive affect mediates the association between pmh and suicide ideation method a total of 150 adult outpatient 65 3 female age m sd 37 79 13 50 range 18 77 completed measure on pmh positive and negative affect a well a suicide ideation data were collected using self report questionnaire linear hierarchical regression analysis wa used to analyze the data positive affect wa considered to mediate the association between positive mental health and suicide ideation result while positive affect fully mediated the significant negative association between pmh and suicide ideation negative affect did not reveal to be a significant mediator of this relationship conclusion the protective influence of pmh against suicide ideation is due to heightened positive affect if positive mental health translates into positive affect then suicide ideation becomes le likely

Title: Suicide ideation as a predictor of treatment outcomes in cognitive-behavioral therapy for unipolar mood disorders
Authors: von Brachel, R.; Teismann, T.; Feider, L.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background objective suicide ideation is common in depressed patient however no study to date have examined whether pretreatment suicide ideation is associated with poorer outcome after cognitive behavioral therapy for adult depression method 475 depressed outpatient age m 39 9 year sd 11 71 60 2 female took part in a pre treatment and a post treatment assessment pre treatment suicide ideation measured with the bdi suicide item wa considered a a predictor of treatment outcome controlling for age gender number of attended therapy session a well a pre treatment depression severity result hierarchical regression revealed that age gender number of completed therapy session and depression severity at baseline could explain 25 of the variance in post treatment bdi score adding suicide ideation significantly improved the amount of variance explained to 27 treatment outcome were worse for patient with more severe depression suicidal patient patient receiving more therapy session and older patient conclusion suicide ideation added only little incremental variance to the prospective prediction of post treatment depression severity depressed patient with suicide ideation can attain almost a good treatment outcome a patient without suicide ideation which is a clinically encouraging result

Title: Predicting adaptive and maladaptive responses to the Coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak: A prospective longitudinal study
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: background objective the outbreak of covid 19 and the lack of vaccine made extraordinary action such a social distancing necessary while some individual experience the restriction on daily life a a heavy burden others adapt to the situation and try to make the best of it the present longitudinal study investigated the extent and predictor of the burden induced by the outbreak of covid 19 in germany method data were assessed in october 2019 using the da 21 and the pmh scale and in march 2020 adding a six item measure of burden and a 2 item rating of sense of control result in a sample of 436 participant about 28 stayed in self quarantine 22 person had relevant symptom and one person wa positively tested for covid 19 most participant experienced medium to high level of burden but tried to make the best of it stress symptom in 2019 predicted a higher level of burden and pmh predicted a lower level of burden in march 2020 remarkably depression and anxiety symptom did not significantly predict burden the protective effect of pmh and the negative impact of stress symptom were mediated by perceived sense of control conclusion the result emphasize the protective effect of pmh in extraordinary situation such a the current outbreak of covid 19

Title: From Memories of Past Experiences to Present Motivation? A Meta-analysis on the Association Between Episodic Memory and Negative Symptoms in People With Psychosis
Authors: Pillny, M.; Krkovic, K.; Buck, L.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: based on finding from cognitive science it ha been theorized that the reduction in motivation and goal directed behavior in people with psychosis could stem from impaired episodic memory in the current meta analysis we investigated this putative functional link between episodic memory deficit and negative symptom we hypothesized that episodic memory deficit in psychosis would be related to negative symptom in general but would be more strongly related to amotivation than to reduced expressivity we included 103 eligible study 13 622 participant in the analysis result revealed significant moderate negative association of episodic memory with negative symptom in general k 103 r 23 z 13 40 p 001 95 ci 26 20 with amotivation k 16 r 18 z 6 6 p 001 95 ci 23 13 and with reduced expressivity k 15 r 18 z 3 30 p 001 95 ci 29 07 these association were not moderated by sociodemographic characteristic positive symptom depression antipsychotic medication or type of negative symptom scale although these finding provide sound evidence for the association between episodic memory deficit and amotivation the rather small magnitude and the unspecific pattern of this relationship also indicate that episodic memory deficit are unlikely to be the only factor relevant to amotivation this implicates that future research should investigate episodic memory in conjunction with other factor that could account for the association of episodic memory deficit and amotivation in psychosis

Title: Sitting posture makes a difference-embodiment effects on depressive memory bias
Authors: Michalak, J.; Mischnat, J.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: basic research ha shown that the motoric system i e motor action or stable posture can strongly affect emotional process the present study sought to investigate the effect of sitting posture on the tendency of depressed individual to recall a higher proportion of negative self referent material thirty currently depressed inpatient either sat in a slumped depressed or in an upright non depressed posture while imagining a visual scene of themselves in connection with positive or depression related word presented to them on a computer screen an incidental recall test of these word wa conducted after a distraction task result of a mixed anova showed a significant posture x word type interaction with upright sitting patient showing unbiased recall of positive and negative word but slumped patient showing recall biased towards more negative word the finding indicate that relatively minor change in the motoric system can affect one of the best documented cognitive bias in depression practical implication of the finding are discussed

Title: Acute stress leaves fear generalization in healthy individuals intact
Authors: Kausche, F. M.; Zerbes, G.; Kampermann, L.; Muller, J. C.; Wiedemann, K.; Buchel, C.; Schwabe, L.
Abstract: because threatening situation often occur in a similar manner the generalization of fear to similar situation is adaptive and can avoid harm to the organism however the overgeneralization of fear to harmless stimulus is maladaptive and assumed to contribute to anxiety disorder thus elucidating factor that may modulate fear over generalization is important based on the known effect of acute stress on learning which are at least partly due to noradrenergic arousal we investigated whether stress may promote fear overgeneralization and whether we could counteract this effect by reducing noradrenergic arousal in a placebo controlled double blind between subject design 120 healthy participant underwent a fear conditioning procedure on day 1 approximately 24 hour later participant received orally either a placebo or the beta adrenergic receptor antagonist propranolol and were exposed to a stress or control manipulation before they completed a test of fear generalization skin conductance response a well a explicit rating data showed a successful acquisition of conditioned fear on day 1 and a pronounced fear generalization 24 hour later although physiological data confirmed the successful stress manipulation and reduction of noradrenergic arousal the extent of fear generalization remained unaffected by stress and propranolol the absence of a stress effect on fear generalization wa confirmed by a second study and a bayesian analysis across both data set our finding suggest that acute stress leaf fear generalization process intact at least in a sample of healthy young individual

Title: The behavior avoidance test: Association with symptom severity and treatment outcome in obsessive-compulsive disorderDifferential memory effects for encoding and retrieving disorder-relevant contents in relation to checking
Authors: Hansmeier, Jana; Haberkamp, Anke; Glombiewski, Julia; Exner, Cornelia; Hansmeier, J.; Glombiewski, J. A.; Rief, W.; Exner, C.
Abstract: behavior therapy of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd aim to reduce avoidance ritual and discomfort in ocd relevant situation the behavioral avoidance test bat measure these behavior related outcome in individually challenging ocd related situation the association of the bat with ocd severity measure and it relevance for treatment outcome is however still unclear the current study investigates 1 if reaction on the bat are related to ocd severity measure in an ocd sample n 28 2 if treatment with two variant of cognitive behavior therapy exposure and response prevention versus metacognitive therapy change the bat score and 3 if these change a well a pretreatment bat avoidance are relevant for ocd treatment outcome a measured by the yale brown obsessive compulsive scale y bocs participant rated avoidance ritual and discomfort in three individually challenging ocd related situation before and after therapy for one of these situation bat dimension were rated by the therapist and an independent rater in addition to the patient rating correlational analysis found significant correlation between bat discomfort and ocd severity measure like the y bocs a repeated measure anova with pre and posttest score showed that all three bat dimension significantly decreased during both treatment hierarchical regression analysis controlling for y bocs pretest score revealed that change in bat discomfort a well a pretreatment bat avoidance score predicted the y bocs posttest score these finding suggest that the bat is a distinct measure of behavior related outcome partly being relevant for ocd treatment outcome
Journal: Journal of Behavior Therapy and Experimental Psychiatry

Title: The Behavior Avoidance Test: Association With Symptom Severity and Treatment Outcome in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
Authors: Hansmeier, J.; Haberkamp, A.; Glombiewski, J. A.; Exner, C.
Abstract: behavior therapy of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd aim to reduce avoidance ritual and discomfort in ocd relevant situation the behavioral avoidance test bat measure these behavior related outcome in individually challenging ocd related situation the association of the bat with ocd severity measure and it relevance for treatment outcome is however still unclear the current study investigates with a retrospective analysis of a subsample of a pilot study 1 if reaction on the bat are related to ocd severity measure in an ocd sample n 28 2 if treatment with two variant of cognitive behavior therapy exposure and response prevention v metacognitive therapy change the bat score and 3 if these change a well a pretreatment bat avoidance are relevant for ocd treatment outcome a measured by the yale brown obsessive compulsive scale y bocs participant rated avoidance ritual and discomfort in three individually challenging ocd related situation before and after therapy for one of these situation bat dimension were rated by the therapist and an independent rater in addition to the patient rating correlational analysis found significant correlation between bat discomfort and ocd severity measure like the y bocs a repeated measure anova with pre and posttest score showed that all three bat dimension significantly decreased during both treatment hierarchical regression analysis controlling for y bocs pretest score revealed that change in bat discomfort a well a pretreatment bat avoidance score predicted the y bocs posttest score these finding suggest that the bat is a distinct measure of behavior related outcome partly being relevant for ocd treatment outcome

Title: Behavioral measures to fight COVID-19: An 8-country study of perceived usefulness, adherence and their predictors
Authors: Margraf, J.; Brailovskaia, J.; Schneider, S.
Abstract: behavioral measure such a the wearing of facemasks and maintaining of distance to other people have been central in fighting the covid 19 pandemic and will continue to be important in curbing it spread we therefore investigated their perceived usefulness adherence and their predictor in representative online sample in eight country france germany poland russia spain sweden u k u s of the 7 658 participant 77 4 rated governmental measure highest germany lowest france a useful and 91 7 reported adherence to them adherence wa lowest in russia and poland where people felt particularly left alone and not well supported and in the u s and sweden where government showed ambivalent attitude towards the measure the highest adherence wa reported in country with very high mortality u k spain france or very positively perceived government communication germany female gender higher age belonging to a risk group being affected physically and mentally perception of governmental communication a guided by the interest of people feeling of being well informed and the level of positive mental health positively predicted both outcome while being affected economically negatively predicted both outcome country specific result are considered in the light of the protection motivation theory and the theory of planned behavior together with potential way to improve active participation of the population overall we recommend the government and authority to stress that each individual can contribute to the control of the covid 19 situation by adherence to the measure in the public communication moreover they should emphasize the risk of unconscious infection of older individual by younger people a well a the importance of physical activity for the protection of mental and physical health especially during the pandemic

Title: Interpretation bias and contamination-based obsessive-compulsive symptoms influence emotional intensity related to disgust and fear
Authors: Fink-Lamotte, J.; Widmann, A.; Fader, J.; Exner, C.
Abstract: biased processing of disgust related stimulus is increasingly discussed in addition to fear related processing a a maintenance factor for contamination based obsessive compulsive disorder c ocd however the differential impact of fear and disgust on biased processing in c ocd is not yet completely understood because it is difficult to distinguish the two emotion in self report assessment by directly addressing the specific emotion a text paragraph based interpretation bias paradigm wa applied to more implicitly a emotion for the text based interpretation bias paradigm disgust related fear related disgust fear ambiguous and neutral text paragraph describing everyday life situation were developed and validated in a pre study n 205 fifty nine healthy participant watched either disgust or fear inducing movie and afterwards rated their experienced emotional response to the text paragraph the result show that fear and disgust component of an emotional response to mixed emotional situation are strongly influenced by the situational context and across the level of trait contamination fear people did not differ in their fear experience to everyday situation which wa overall strong but in their disgust experience these finding highlight the strength of situational context on interpretation bias for mixed emotional disorder and the important role of disgust for c ocd

Title: Approach-avoidance modification as an add-on in smoking cessation: A randomized-controlled study
Authors: Wittekind, C. E.; Reibert, E.; Takano, K.; Ehring, T.; Pogarell, O.; Ruther, T.
Abstract: bias in information processing are attributed an important role in the maintenance of tobacco dependence a these bias are not sufficiently taken into account in current treatment the aim of the present study wa to investigate whether clinical outcome can be improved by combining treatment a usual tau with approach avoidance modification training aamt a two group parallel 1 1 randomized controlled single blind study with adult smoker n 105 wa conducted drks00011406 participant received three session of tau and either six session of aamt or sham training during aamt participant were trained to implicitly avoid all smoking related and to approach all smoking unrelated picture while the contingency wa 50 50 in sham training participant were assessed after the intervention and 6 month later primary outcome wa daily cigarette consumption at follow up participant receiving tau aamt did not show a significantly greater reduction of daily cigarette consumption at follow up compared to tau sham per protocol 95 ci 2 56 4 89 p 608 intention to treat 95 ci 3 11 2 96 p 968 using an implicit aamt v sham a an add on to tau did not improve clinical outcome however no consistent evidence for a change of bias wa found it is important for future research to explore the effectiveness of optimized training version e g explicit instruction pre registration german clinical trial register drks00011406

Title: Impact of an acceptance facilitating intervention on psychotherapists' acceptance of blended therapy
Authors: Baumeister, H.; Terhorst, Y.; Grassle, C.; Freudenstein, M.; Nubling, R.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: blended therapy is a new approach combining advantage of face to face psychotherapy and internet and mobile based intervention acceptance is a fundamental precondition for it implementation the aim of this study wa to a 1 the acceptance of psychotherapist towards blended therapy 2 the effectiveness of an acceptance facilitating intervention afi on psychotherapist acceptance towards blended therapy and 3 to identify potential effect moderator psychotherapist n 284 were randomly assigned to a control cg or an intervention group ig the ig received a short video showing an example of blended therapy the cg an attention placebo video both group received a reliable online questionnaire assessing acceptance effort expectancy performance expectancy facilitating condition social influence and internet anxiety between group difference were examined using t test and mann whitney test exploratory analysis wa conducted to identify moderator psychotherapist in cg showed mixed baseline acceptance towards blended therapy low 40 moderate 33 high 27 ig showed significantly higher acceptance compared to cg d 27 pone sided 029 low 24 moderate 47 high 30 bootstrapped confidence interval were overlapping performance expectancy d 35 effort expectancy d 44 and facilitating condition d 28 were significantly increased p 05 no effect on social influence and internet anxiety were found p 05 exploratory analysis indicated psychodynamic oriented psychotherapist profiting particularly from the afi blended therapy is a promising approach to improve healthcare psychotherapist show mixed acceptance which might be improvable by afis particularly in subpopulation of initially rather skeptical psychotherapist forthcoming study should extend the present study by shifting focus from attitude to the impact of different form of afis on uptake

Title: Gender Differences in Affective and Evaluative Responses to Experimentally Induced Body Checking of Positively and Negatively Valenced Body Parts
Authors: Tanck, J. A.; Vocks, S.; Riesselmann, B.; Waldorf, M.
Abstract: body checking bc is defined a behavior aimed at gaining information on body shape size or weight besides it occurrence a a transdiagnostic symptom in eating disorder ed bc is widespread in non clinical population it is associated with body dissatisfaction and the development of body image disturbance and ed male and female differ in term of body dissatisfaction and associated bc strategy however the question of a gender related intensity of negative affect and state body satisfaction a reaction to bc remains open therefore the present experimental study aimed to examine gender difference in affective and evaluative response to bc we tested n 60 woman and n 60 men in a crossover design implementing two experimental condition and one control condition in the negative body checking condition nbc participant received standardized instruction to check negatively valenced body part in the positive body checking condition pbc by contrast participant were asked to check positively valenced body part the control condition cbc consisted of playing a computer game before and after checking of one s own body participant rated negative body related affect i e guilt shame and disgust and state body satisfaction the result indicate that both nbc and pbc led to an increase in negative affect for men and woman eating pathology predicted negative affect after checking in nbc for both gender men reported a significantly higher state body satisfaction in all condition whereas only woman showed decreased body satisfaction in nbc these finding suggest that bc of any body part i e positively or negatively valenced lead to increased negative affect for both gender eating pathology significantly influence the affective response to bc for both gender change in state body satisfaction however only occur in female an explanation might be that men generally report higher body satisfaction resulting in a more stable body image female and male with pathological eating behavior seem to be more vulnerable to change in negative affect a negative affect is equally increased after nbc and pbc for both gender bc might play a central role in the maintenance of body image disturbance in male and female

Title: Revisiting the Postulates of Etiological Models of Eating Disorders: Questioning Body Checking as a Longer-Term Maintaining Factor
Authors: Opladen, V.; Vivell, M. B.; Vocks, S.; Hartmann, A. S.
Abstract: body checking bc is not only inherent to the maintenance of eating disorder but is also widespread among healthy female according to etiological model while bc serf a an affect regulating behavior in the short term in the longer term it is assumed to be disorder maintaining and also produce more negative affect the present study therefore aimed to empirically examine the proposed longer term consequence of increased bc in an online study n 167 woman tracked their daily amount of bc over a total of 7 day following a 1 day baseline assessment of typical bc participant were asked to check their body in an typical manner for 3 day and with a 3 fold increased frequency for 3 day before and after each bc episode the impact of bc on affect eating disorder symptom general pathology and endorsement of different function of bc wa assessed participant showed longer term consequence of increased bc in term of increased negative affect and general pathology while eating disorder symptom remained unaffected in the case of typical bc participant showed decreased general pathology and anxiety furthermore the endorsement of a higher number of bc function led to increased negative affect and an increased amount of typical bc the finding support the theoretically assumed role of maladaptive bc in maintaining negative emotion in the longer term however though requiring replication our finding of positive effect of typical bc call into question the overall dysfunctionality of bc among non clinical woman who are not at risk of developing an eating disorder

Title: Emotion recognition in body dysmorphic disorder: application of the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Task
Authors: Buhlmann, U.; Winter, A.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: body dysmorphic disorder bdd is characterized by perceived appearance related defect often tied to aspect of the face or head e g acne deficit in decoding emotional expression have been examined in several psychological disorder including bdd previous research indicates that bdd is associated with impaired facial emotion recognition particularly in situation that involve the bdd sufferer him herself the purpose of this study wa to further evaluate the ability to read other people s emotion among 31 individual with bdd and 31 mentally healthy control we applied the reading the mind in the eye task in which participant are presented with a series of pair of eye one at a time and are asked to identify the emotion that describes the stimulus best the group did not differ with respect to decoding other people s emotion by looking into their eye finding are discussed in light of previous research examining emotion recognition in bdd

Title: Body Dissatisfaction, Importance of Appearance, and Body Appreciation in Men and Women Over the Lifespan
Authors: Quittkat, H. L.; Hartmann, A. S.; Dusing, R.; Buhlmann, U.; Vocks, S.
Abstract: body image disturbance is associated with several mental disorder previous research on body image ha focused mostly on woman largely neglecting body image in men moreover only a small number of study have conducted gender comparison of body image over the lifespan and included participant aged 50 year and older with regard to measurement body image ha often been assessed only in term of body dissatisfaction disregarding further aspect such a body appreciation or the importance of appearance the aim of this cross sectional study wa to explore different aspect of body image in the general german speaking population and to compare men and woman of various age participant completed an online survey comprising questionnaire about body image body dissatisfaction importance of appearance the number of hour per day participant would invest and the number of year they would sacrifice to achieve their ideal appearance and body appreciation were assessed and analyzed with respect to gender and age difference we hypothesized that body dissatisfaction and importance of appearance would be higher in woman than in men that body dissatisfaction would remain stable across age in woman and that importance of appearance would be lower in older woman compared to younger woman body appreciation wa predicted to be higher in men than in woman general and generalized linear model were used to examine the impact of age and gender in line with our hypothesis body dissatisfaction wa higher in woman than in men and wa unaffected by age in woman and importance of appearance wa higher in woman than in men however only in men did age predict a lower level of the importance of appearance compared to men woman stated that they would invest more hour of their life to achieve their ideal appearance for both gender age wa a predictor of the number of year participant would sacrifice to achieve their ideal appearance contrary to our assumption body appreciation improved and wa higher in woman across all age than in men the result seem to suggest that men s and woman s body image are dissimilar and appear to vary across different age

Title: Effects of transcranial direct current stimulation on the cognitive control of negative stimuli in borderline personality disorder
Authors: Schulze, L.; Grove, M.; Tamm, S.; Renneberg, B.; Roepke, S.
Abstract: borderline personality disorder bpd is characterized by impairment in the cognitive control of negative information these impairment in cognitive control are presumably due to blunted activity of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc along with enhanced activation of the limbic system however the impact of an excitatory stimulation of the dlpfc still need to be elucidated in the present study we therefore assigned 50 patient with bpd and 50 healthy control to receive either anodal or sham stimulation of the right dlpfc in a double blind randomized between subject design participant performed a delayed working memory task with a distracter period during which a grey background screen or neutral or negative stimulus were presented this experimental paradigm wa first evaluated in a pilot study with 18 patient with bpd and 19 healthy control in both study patient with bpd showed an impairment of cognitive control when negative distracters were presented in the delay period of a working memory task however excitatory stimulation of the right dlpfc did not ameliorate cognitive control of negative stimulus in bpd which raise question about the specific role of the right dlpfc for the understanding of bpd psychopathology methodological limitation are discussed

Title: Effects of intranasal oxytocin administration on empathy and approach motivation in women with borderline personality disorder: a randomized controlled trial
Authors: Domes, G.; Ower, N.; von Dawans, B.; Spengler, F. B.; Dziobek, I.; Bohus, M.; Matthies, S.; Philipsen, A.; Heinrichs, M.
Abstract: borderline personality disorder bpd is characterized by severe interpersonal dysfunction with problem in social cognition empathy and social approach although the neuropeptide oxytocin is known to regulate complex social cognition and behavior in healthy individual and clinical population there is still a lack of evidence for a potential beneficial effect of oxytocin administration on social cognition and social approach in bpd fifty one woman with bpd and 51 matched healthy control were randomized to a double blind placebo controlled between subject experimental trial we administered a single dose of 24 iu oxytocin or placebo intranasally prior to a standardized task measuring affective and cognitive empathy and approach motivation all participant were free of hormonal contraception and tested in the mid luteal phase of their menstrual cycle in the placebo condition patient with bpd showed reduced cognitive and affective empathy and le approach behavior motivation than healthy control intranasal oxytocin significantly increased affective empathy and approach motivation in both bpd patient and healthy control compared to placebo more importantly oxytocin administration led to similar score between bpd and healthy control these finding provide the first evidence for a beneficial effect of oxytocin on deficit in affective empathy and approach motivation of bpd our result indicate a beneficial effect of a single dose of oxytocin on affective empathy and approach motivation in woman with bpd adapting their level of social functioning to healthy control future clinical trial will need to investigate the long term effect and effectiveness of oxytocin a an add on treatment for social impairment in bpd

Title: Combining mental and physical stress: Synergy or interference?
Authors: Finke, J. B.; Zhang, X.; Plein, D.; Schilling, T. M.; Schachinger, H.; Larra, M. F.
Abstract: both cognitive stressor such a mental arithmetic task and physical stressor such a the cold pressor test cp are among the most widely employed tool in acute stress research and there is growing evidence for a high degree of stimulus response specificity rather than uniformity in the human stress response however little is known about potential synergistic or interfering effect during concurrent administration while cognitive task have been hypothesized to attenuate pain perception during cp they are also thought to enhance physiological reactivity conversely physical stress might interfere with effective stress induction by cognitive challenge to address these question 56 participant underwent either the cp 3 min ice water immersion of foot or a warm water control condition in half of the sample the paced auditory serial addition task pasat wa performed simultaneously fully crossed intervention salivary cortisol cardiovascular parameter and subjective rating a well a voice pitch f0 were assessed result show that cortisol response self reported pain and subjective arousal were mainly driven by cold exposure which also led to increased f0 the pasat incrementally enhanced cardiovascular reaction but did not affect pain rating nor cortisol response to the cp however intra individual concordance between elevated blood pressure and other reactivity measure wa enhanced by pasat administration during the cp importantly performance decrement in the mental arithmetic task were not associated with diminished stress response in conclusion our result speak against any strong interference when administering cognitive and painful physical stressor simultaneously pointing rather to specific additive effect particularly regarding cardiovascular reactivity

Title: Performance monitoring in obsessive-compulsive undergraduates: Effects of task difficulty
Authors: Riesel, A.; Richter, A.; Kaufmann, C.; Kathmann, N.; Endrass, T.
Abstract: both obsessive compulsive disorder and subclinical obsessive compulsive oc symptom seem to be associated with hyperactive error related brain activity the current study examined performance monitoring in subject with subclinical oc symptom using a new task with different level of difficulty nineteen subject with high and 18 subject with low oc characteristic performed a random dot cinematogram rdc task with three level of difficulty the high and low oc group did not differ in error related negativity ern correct related negativity crn and performance irrespective of task difficulty the amplitude of the ern decreased with increasing difficulty whereas the magnitude of crn did not vary ern and crn approached in size and topography with increasing difficulty which suggests that error and correct response are processed more similarly these result add to a growing number of study that fail to replicate hyperactive performance monitoring in individual with oc symptom in task with higher difficulty or requiring learning together with these finding our result suggest that the relationship between oc symptom and performance monitoring may be sensitive to type of task and task characteristic and cannot be observed in a rdc that differs from typically used task in difficulty and the amount of response conflict

Title: The BDNF Val66Met polymorphism modulates the generalization of cued fear responses to a novel context
Authors: Muhlberger, A.; Andreatta, M.; Ewald, H.; Glotzbach-Schoon, E.; Troger, C.; Baumann, C.; Reif, A.; Deckert, J.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: brain derived neurotrophic factor bdnf ha a crucial role in activity dependent synaptic plasticity and learning and memory the human functional single nucleotide bdnf rs6265 val66met polymorphism ha been found to be associated with alteration in neural bdnf release and function correlating with altered emotional behavior here we investigated for the first time the hypothesis that this polymorphism in human modulates the context dependency of conditioned fear response applying a new paradigm examining generalization of cued fear across context 70 participant stratified for bdnf val66met polymorphism were guided through two virtual office context in which briefly illuminated blue and yellow light served a cue in the fear context one light conditioned stimulus c but not the other light c wa associated with an electric shock unconditioned stimulus u in the safety context both light were presented too but no u wa delivered during the test phase light were presented again both in learning context and in a novel generalization context without any u all participant showed clear fear conditioning to the c in the fear context a indicated by potentiation of startle response and report of fear no fear reaction were found for the c in the safety context importantly generalization of fear response indicated by the potentiation of startle response to the c compared with the c in the novel context wa evident only in the met carrying group these are the first result to provide evidence in human that bdnf modulates the generalization of fear response such context dependent generalization process might predispose met carrier for affective and anxiety disorder

Title: Neurofeedback Against Binge Eating: A Randomized Controlled Trial in a Female Subclinical Threshold Sample
Authors: Schmidt, J.; Martin, A.
Abstract: brain directed treatment technique such a neurofeedback have recently been proposed a adjunct in the treatment of eating disorder to improve therapeutic outcome in line with this recommendation a cue exposure eeg neurofeedback protocol wa developed the present study aimed at the evaluation of the specific efficacy of neurofeedback to reduce subjective binge eating in a female subthreshold sample a total of 75 subject were randomized to eeg neurofeedback mental imagery with a comparable treatment set up or a waitlist group at post treatment only eeg neurofeedback led to a reduced frequency of binge eating p 015 g 0 65 the effect remained stable to a 3 month follow up eeg neurofeedback further showed particular beneficial effect on perceived stress and dietary self efficacy difference in outcome did not arise from divergent treatment expectation because eeg neurofeedback showed a specific efficacy it may be a promising brain directed approach that should be tested a a treatment adjunct in clinical group with binge eating copyright c 2016 john wiley son ltd and eating disorder association

Title: Bullying History and Mental Health In University Students: The Mediator Roles of Social Support, Personal Resilience, and Self-Efficacy
Authors: Lin, M.; Wolke, D.; Schneider, S.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: bullying victimization by peer is highly prevalent in childhood and adolescence there is convincing evidence that victimization is associated with adverse mental health consequence in contrast it ha been found that perpetrator suffer no adverse mental health consequence these finding originate from western country such a germany but have rarely been investigated in collectivistic society such a china furthermore it ha been rarely studied whether positive intrapersonal characteristic e g personal resilience and self efficacy and interpersonal positive resource e g social support may mediate the impact of bullying on mental health the current study used a path analytic model to examine firstly whether previous bullying experience both victimization and perpetration are associated with current positive and negative mental health in university student and secondly whether these influence are mediated by social support resilience and self efficacy the model wa tested in 5 912 chinese and 1 935 german university student it wa found that in both country higher victimization frequency wa associated with lower level of social support personal resilience and self efficacy which in turn predicted poorer mental health moreover and only in china perpetration wa negatively associated with social support and personal resilience but not self efficacy in contrast in the german sample perpetration experience wa found to enhance one s self efficacy and the later wa associated with better mental health the result support a mediation model in which social support personal resilience and self efficacy partially mediate the influence of victimization on mental health in both country for the relationship between perpetration and mental health self efficacy wa the only full mediator in germany whereas in china both social support and personal resilience were partial mediator in conclusion peer victimization ha adverse effect on mental health in both germany and china only in china however is perpetration also associated with adverse mental health outcome in contrast getting ahead by bullying in an individualistic society such a germany is associated with increased self efficacy and mental health the difference found between an individualistic country and a collectivistic country have important implication for understanding and planning intervention to reduce bullying

Title: Olfactory processing: detection of rapid changes
Authors: Croy, I.; Krone, F.; Walker, S.; Hummel, T.
Abstract: change in the olfactory environment have a rather poor chance of being detected aim of the present study wa to determine whether the same cued or different uncued odor can generally be detected at short inter stimulus interval isi below 2 5 s furthermore we investigated whether inhibition of return an attentional phenomenon facilitating the detection of new stimulus at longer isi is present in the domain of olfaction thirteen normosmic people 3 men 10 woman age range 19 27 year mean age 23 year participated stimulation wa performed using air dilution olfactometry with 2 odor phenylethylalcohol and hydrogen disulfide reaction time to target stimulus wa assessed in cued and uncued condition at isi of 1 1 5 2 and 2 5 s there wa a significant main effect of isi indicating that odor presented only 1 s apart are missed frequently uncued presentation facilitated detection at short isi implying that change of the olfactory environment are detected better than presentation of the same odor again effect in relation to olfactory inhibition of return on the other hand are not supported by our result this suggests that attention work different for the olfactory system compared with the visual and auditory system

Title: Child neglect and its relation to emotional and behavioral problems: A cross-sectional study of primary school-aged children in Tanzania
Authors: Hecker, T.; Boettcher, V. S.; Landolt, M. A.; Hermenau, K.
