Abstract: child maltreatment is known to engender negative emotional and behavioral consequence although neglect is the most frequent form of maltreatment it ha thus far only received little attention especially when looking at low resource country the current study investigated possible association between neglect and internalizing and externalizing problem a neglect and abuse often co occur the latter wa controlled for in total 409 tanzanian primary school student 52 boy m 10 5 year range 6 15 participated in the cross sectional study structured clinical interview were conducted assessing maltreatment internalizing problem and externalizing problem overall 31 n 128 of the child reported at least one type of physical neglect and 31 n 127 of emotional neglect using structural equation modeling we found a significant association between neglect and internalizing beta 0 59 p lt 01 and externalizing problem beta 0 35 p lt 05 however these association could only be detected in younger child age 6 9 whereas in older child age 10 15 mental health problem were significantly related to violence and abuse our finding suggest that the current age may influence the association between maltreatment type and the development of internalizing and or externalizing problem

Title: Mood and neural responses to social rejection do not seem to be altered in resilient adolescents with a history of adversity
Authors: Fritz, J.; Stretton, J.; Askelund, A. D.; Schweizer, S.; Walsh, N. D.; Elzinga, B. M.; Goodyer, I. M.; Wilkinson, P. O.; van Harmelen, A. L.
Abstract: childhood adversity ca increase the risk of subsequent mental health problem adolescent social support from family and or friend reduces the risk of mental health problem after ca however the mechanism of this effect remain unclear and we speculate that they are manifested on neurodevelopmental level therefore we investigated whether family and or friendship support at age 14 and 17 function a intermediate variable for the relationship between ca before age 11 and affective or neural response to social rejection feedback at age 18 we studied 55 adolescent with normative mental health at age 18 26 with ca and therefore considered resilient from a longitudinal cohort participant underwent a social feedback task in the magnetic resonance imaging scanner social rejection feedback activated the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex and the left anterior insula ca did not predict affective or neural response to social rejection at age 18 yet ca predicted better friendship at age 14 and age 18 when adolescent with and without ca had comparable mood level thus adolescent with ca and normative mood level have more adolescent friendship support and seem to have normal mood and neural response to social rejection

Title: Neurophysiological markers of ADHD symptoms in typically-developing children
Authors: Hilger, K.; Sassenhagen, J.; Kuhnhausen, J.; Reuter, M.; Schwarz, U.; Gawrilow, C.; Fiebach, C. J.
Abstract: child with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd are characterized by symptom of inattention impulsivity and hyperactivity neurophysiological correlate of adhd include change in the p3 component of event related brain potential erps motivated by recent advance towards a more dimensional understanding of adhd we investigate whether adhd related erp marker relate to continuous variation in attention and executive functioning also in typically developing child erps were measured while 31 school child 9 11 year completed an adapted version of the continuous performance task that additionally to inhibitory process also isolates effect of physical stimulus salience child with higher level of parent reported adhd symptom did not differ in task performance but exhibited smaller p3 amplitude related to stimulus salience furthermore adhd symptom were associated with the variability of neural response over time child with higher level of adhd symptom demonstrated lower variability in inhibition and salience related p3 amplitude no effect were observed for erp latency and the salience related n2 by demonstrating that adhd associated neurophysiological mechanism of inhibition and salience processing covary with attention and executive functioning in a child community sample our study provides neurophysiological support for dimensional model of adhd also temporal variability in event related potential is highlighted a additional indicator of adhd requiring further investigation

Title: Emotion recognition in children and adolescents with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
Authors: Schwenck, C.; Schneider, T.; Schreckenbach, J.; Zenglein, Y.; Gensthaler, A.; Taurines, R.; Freitag, C. M.; Schneider, W.; Romanos, M.
Abstract: child with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd are impaired in social adaptation and display deficit in social competence deficient emotion recognition ha been discussed to underlie these social problem however comorbid conduct problem have not been considered in the majority of study conducted so far and the influence of medication on emotion recognition ha rarely been studied here emotion recognition performance wa assessed in child with adhd without medication compared with child with adhd under stimulant medication and a matched control group in order to rule out confounding by externalizing symptom child with comorbid conduct problem were excluded video clip with neutral face developing a basic emotion happiness sadness disgust fear and anger were presented in order to a emotion recognition result indicated between group difference neither concerning the number of correctly identified emotion nor concerning reaction time and their standard deviation thus we suggest that adhd per se is not associated with deficit in emotion recognition

Title: Long-Term Outcomes of a Multimodal Day-Clinic Treatment for Chronic Pain under the Conditions of Routine Care
Authors: Preis, M. A.; Vogtle, E.; Dreyer, N.; Seel, S.; Wagner, R.; Hanshans, K.; Reyersbach, R.; Pieh, C.; Muhlberger, A.; Probst, T.
Abstract: chronic pain ha high prevalence rate and is one of the top cause of year lived with disability the aim of the present study wa to evaluate the long term effect of a multimodal day clinic treatment for chronic pain the sample included 183 chronic pain patient 114 female and 69 male 53 3 9 8 year who participated in a four week multimodal day clinic treatment for chronic pain the patient average current pain intensity nrs sensory and affective pain pain perception scale and depression and anxiety hads were assessed at pre and posttreatment a well a at three follow ups one month six month and twelve month after completion of the treatment multilevel model for discontinuous change were performed to evaluate the change of the outcome variable improvement from pretreatment to posttreatment and from pretreatment to all follow ups emerged for pain intensity nrs 0 54 d 0 74 affective pain pain perception scale 0 24 d 0 47 depression hads 0 38 d 0 53 and anxiety hads 0 26 d 0 43 all p 0 05 sensory pain a assessed with the pain perception scale did not show any significant change patient suffering from chronic pain benefited from the multimodal pain treatment up to twelve month after completion of the treatment

Title: Acute stress enhances pupillary responses to erotic nudes: Evidence for differential effects of sympathetic activation and cortisol
Authors: Finke, J. B.; Behrje, A.; Schachinger, H.
Abstract: chronic stress attenuates reproductive behavior in many specie but evidence regarding the impact of acute stress on human sexual arousability is insufficient stressor specific effect might result from divergent role of both stress response system social self threat linked to affiliation oriented coping might also influence sexual responsivity to investigate stress induced modulation of the processing of sexual cue and it relationship with cortisol 58 participant underwent either a predominantly sympathetic stressor 3 min sustained handgrip or similar control procedure in both condition half of the sample wa monitored by an opposite sex person social evaluation pupillary response to erotic nude were recorded and dissociated into fast and slow pca component physically stressed participant showed enhanced slow dilation to explicit picture cortisol level after stress negatively predicted rapid response to opposite sex and marginally explicit stimulus our result suggest that acute sympathetic stress exposure facilitates cognitive sexual processing whereas subsequent hpa axis activation may induce counteracting effect

Title: Cognitive Variables in Social Anxiety Disorder in Children and Adolescents: A Network Analysis
Authors: Vogel, F.; Reichert, J.; Hartmann, D.; Schwenck, C.
Abstract: clark and well prominent model of social anxiety disorder sad assumes that cognitive variable such a negative expectation or dysfunctional cognition play a central role in the symptomatology of sad in contrast to adult it is le clear how well the cognitive model can be applied to child and adolescent a network analysis with seven node wa conducted to explore the importance of cognitive variable and their interaction with symptom of sad based on n 205 child and adolescent 8 18 year m 11 54 year cognitive variable had a high but differential impact within the positively connected network of sad dysfunctional cognition were most strongly connected within the network dysfunctional cognition a predicted by clark and well model seem to act a a hub affecting several symptom the association between negative expectation and avoidance indicates that negative expectation may particularly contribute to the maintenance of sad

Title: Induction of a depression-like negativity bias by cathodal transcranial direct current stimulation
Authors: Wolkenstein, L.; Zeiller, M.; Kanske, P.; Plewnia, C.
Abstract: cognitive control cc over emotional distraction is of particular importance for adaptive human behaviour and is associated with activity in the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc deficient cc e g presenting a negativity bias ha been suggested to underlie many of the core symptom of major depression md and is associated with impairment of dlpfc function correspondingly enhancement of dlpfc activity with anodal transcranial direct current stimulation tdcs can ameliorate these impairment in patient with md here we tested the hypothesis that a reduction of dlpfc activity by cathodal tdcs induces cc deficit thus triggering a depression like negativity bias in healthy subject twenty eight individual participated in a double blinded balanced randomized crossover trial of cathodal 1 ma 20 min and sham tdcs applied to the left dlpfc to a cc we conducted a delayed response working memory dwm task and an arithmetic inhibition task ait with picture of varying valent content negative neutral positive during and immediately after stimulation cathodal tdcs led to impaired cc specifically over negative material a assessed by reduced response accuracy in the dwm and prolonged response latency in the ait hence the current study support the notion that left dlpfc is critically involved in cc over negative material together with previously reported beneficial anodal effect it indicates that the hypoactivation of left dlpfc cause deficit in cc over negative material which is a possible aetiological mechanism of depression

Title: Context-specific adjustment of cognitive control: Transfer of adaptive control sets
Authors: Surrey, C.; Dreisbach, G.; Fischer, R.
Abstract: cognitive control protects processing of relevant information from interference by irrelevant information the level of this processing selectivity can be flexibly adjusted to different control demand e g frequency of conflict associated with a certain context leading to the formation of specific context control association in the present study we investigated the robustness and transferability of the acquired context control demand to new situation in three experiment we used a version of the context specific proportion congruence cspc paradigm in which each context e g location is associated with a specific conflict frequency determining high and low control demand in a learning phase association between context and control demand were established in a subsequent transfer block stimulus response mapping whole task set or context control demand changed result showed an impressive robustness of context control association a context specific adjustment of control from the learning phase were virtually unaffected by new stimulus and task in the transfer block only a change of the context control demand eliminated the context specific adjustment of control these finding suggest that context control association that have proven to be adaptive in the past are continuously applied despite major change in the task structure a long a the context control association remain the same

Title: Cognitive emotion regulation withstands the stress test: An fMRI study on the effect of acute stress on distraction and reappraisal
Authors: Sandner, M.; Zeier, P.; Lois, G.; Wessa, M.
Abstract: cognitive emotion regulation is a key mechanism for the maintenance of mental health but may fail when individual are exposed to acute stress to date it is not well understood whether and to what extent acute stress effect contribute to impairment in emotion regulation capacity a the sparse existing study have yielded heterogeneous result indicating that stress timing might be a crucial factor in the present study 81 healthy participant underwent either an acute stress task scanstress c n 40 or a control condition n 41 while lying in the mri scanner in the subsequent cognitive emotion regulation task cert participant were confronted with neutral or negative picture and instructed to either view them or regulate their upcoming emotion using either distraction or reappraisal subjective rating of affective state a well a functional brain imaging data served to indicate emotion regulation the result showed a successful stress manipulation a indicated by group difference in subjective wellbeing saliva cortisol concentration heart rate and functional brain activity in region implicated in stress processing with respect to emotion regulation cert data revealed a significant regulation effect at the neural and behavioral level le negative emotional rating after reappraisal and distraction trial compared to view trial in both group however no significant group difference were observed neither in bold response to the cert nor in behavioral rating contrary to previous study our study did not reveal further evidence of stress related effect on emotion regulation potentially being related to difference between study in experimental setting timing and procedure this study therefore underline the need of future study that disentangle the complex interplay of stress and emotion regulation and identify different factor influencing their bidirectional relationship

Title: Neural correlates of immediate and prolonged effects of cognitive reappraisal and distraction on emotional experience
Authors: Hermann, A.; Kress, L.; Stark, R.
Abstract: cognitive emotion regulation strategy are important component of cognitive behavioral therapy cbt additionally up regulation and difficulty in the down regulation of negative feeling are associated with mental disorder however little is known about the lasting effect of cognitive emotion regulation strategy on emotional experience and associated neural activation therefore this study investigated immediate and prolonged effect of emotion regulation using cognitive reappraisal and distraction on subjective report and it neural correlate twenty seven healthy female took part in a 2 day functional magnetic resonance imaging study they were instructed to either up regulate or down regulate their negative feeling using a situation focused cognitive reappraisal strategy to distract themselves by imagining a specific neutral situation or to passively look at repeatedly presented aversive and neutral picture re exposure to the same stimulus without a regulation instruction wa conducted one day later self reported negative feeling and blood oxygen level dependent response served a main outcome variable a expected the result show successful immediate up or down regulation of negative feeling by cognitive reappraisal and down regulation of negative feeling by distraction furthermore these change in negative feeling were correlated with amygdala activation a lasting effect on emotional experience associated with stronger ventromedial prefrontal cortex activation wa found for down regulation of negative feeling via cognitive reappraisal compared to distraction down regulation via cognitive reappraisal led to reduced negative feeling and stronger dorso and ventrolateral prefrontal cortex response one day later while cognitive reappraisal and distraction are both effective strategy during active regulation only cognitive reappraisal had a lasting effect these finding might have implication for cbt

Title: Assessing Cognitive Appraisals Related to Sexual Function: A Scenario-Based Approach
Authors: Velten, J.; Blackwell, S. E.; Margraf, J.; Woud, M. L.
Abstract: cognitive factor play an important role in the etiology and maintenance of sexual difficulty to date research ha mostly relied on self report measure to a negative cognition related to low sexual function to overcome the limitation of self report questionnaire a series of open ended ambiguous sexual scenario were developed and presented to participant n 600 m age 34 2 year who were asked to generate an ending by entering a continuation for each scenario valence of completed scenario wa rated by the participant and scenario ending were coded by two independent raters on three dimension namely reference to sexual problem sexual communication and the use of sexually explicit language sexual function wa assessed with the female sexual function index and the international index of erectile function multiple regression analysis were performed to a whether the scenario based task wa associated with sexual function above and beyond other predictor e g sexual distress individual with lower sexual function rated the completed scenario more negatively and their ending included more reference to problem related to low sexual function in woman with low sexual function fewer ending included sexual communication with a partner or sexually explicit language our finding suggest that individual with low sexual function appraise ambiguous sexual situation more negatively than other individual future study may investigate whether such bias can be experimentally manipulated and whether change in cognitive bias may in turn lead to improvement in sexual function

Title: Attention allocation in social anxiety during a speech
Authors: Lin, M.; Hofmann, S. G.; Qian, M.; Kind, S.; Yu, H.
Abstract: cognitive model assume that social anxiety is associated with and maintained by biased information processing leading to change in attention allocation which can be measured by examining eye movement however little is known about the distribution of attention among positive neutral and negative stimulus during a social task and the relative importance of positive versus negative bias in social anxiety in this study eye movement subjective state anxiety and psychophysiology of individual with high trait social anxiety hsa and low trait social anxiety lsa were measured during a speech task with a pre recorded audience the hsa group showed longer total fixation on negative stimulus and shorter total fixation on positive stimulus compared to the lsa group we observed that the lsa group shifted attention away from negative stimulus whereas the hsa group showed no differential attention allocation the total duration of fixation on negative stimulus predicted subjective anxiety rating these result point to a negative bias a well a a lack of a positive bias in hsa individual during social threat

Title: The association between ruminative thinking and negative interpretation bias in social anxiety
Authors: Badra, M.; Schulze, L.; Becker, E. S.; Vrijsen, J. N.; Renneberg, B.; Zetsche, U.
Abstract: cognitive model propose that both negative interpretation of ambiguous social situation and ruminative thought about social event contribute to the maintenance of social anxiety disorder it ha further been postulated that ruminative thought fuel biased negative interpretation however evidence is rare the present study used a multi method approach to a ruminative processing following a social interaction post event processing by self report questionnaire and social rumination by experience sampling method and negative interpretation bias via two separate task in a student sample n 51 screened for high hsa and low social anxiety lsa result support the hypothesis that group difference in negative interpretation of ambiguous social situation in hsas v lsas are mediated by higher level of post event processing assessed in the questionnaire exploratory analysis highlight the potential role of comorbid depressive symptom the current finding help to advance the understanding of the association between two cognitive process involved in social anxiety and stress the importance of ruminative post event processing

Title: Brain structural basis of cognitive reappraisal and expressive suppression
Authors: Hermann, A.; Bieber, A.; Keck, T.; Vaitl, D.; Stark, R.
Abstract: cognitive reappraisal and expressive suppression two major emotion regulation strategy are differentially related to emotional well being the aim of this study wa to test the association of individual difference in these two emotion regulation strategy with gray matter volume of brain region that have been shown to be involved in the regulation of emotion based on high resolution magnetic resonance image of 96 young adult voxel based morphometry wa used to analyze the gray matter volume of the a priori region of interest including amygdala insula dorsal anterior cingulate and paracingulate cortex medial and lateral prefrontal cortex pfc and their association with cognitive reappraisal and expressive suppression usage a well a neuroticism a positive association of cognitive reappraisal with right and tendentially left amygdala volume and of neuroticism with left amygdala volume marginally significant wa found expressive suppression wa related to dorsal anterior cingulate paracingulate cortex and medial pfc gray matter volume the result of this study emphasize the important role of the amygdala in individual difference in cognitive reappraisal usage a well a neuroticism additionally the association of expressive suppression usage with larger volume of the medial pfc and dorsal anterior paracingulate cortex underpins the role of these region in regulating emotion expressive behavior

Title: Content-specific interpretation biases in clinically anxious children
Authors: Klein, A. M.; Rapee, R. M.; Hudson, J. L.; Morris, T. M.; Schneider, S. C.; Schniering, C. A.; Becker, E. S.; Rinck, M.
Abstract: cognitive theory of anxiety suggest that anxious child interpret negatively only those material specifically related to the content of their anxiety so far there are only a few study available that report on this postulated content specificity of interpretation process across different anxiety disorder in child and most of them focused on social anxiety therefore we examined interpretation bias and it content specificity in a group of clinically anxious child between the age of 6 12 year with various anxiety disorder using an ambiguous scenario task child were asked to finish scenario that were related to either social threat general threat or separation threat in total 105 clinically anxious child 21 control child and their mother were assessed with the adis c p and the spence child s anxiety scale a expected clinically anxious child provided significantly more negative ending to the scenario than control child within the clinically anxious group specific interpretation bias were found interpretation of scenario related to social threat general threat and separation threat were only predicted by the child s self reported level of social anxiety generalized anxiety and separation anxiety respectively these finding support the content specificity hypothesis that clinically anxious child display interpretation bias that are specific to fear relevant stimulus

Title: Implicit affective evaluation bias in hypochondriasis: findings from the Affect Misattribution Procedure
Authors: Schreiber, F.; Neng, J. M.; Heimlich, C.; Witthoft, M.; Weck, F.
Abstract: cognitive theory of hypochondriasis hyp suggest that catastrophic misinterpretation of benign body sensation are a core feature for the maintenance of the disorder there is tentative support from an analog sample that the interpretation of illness related information also involves an implicit affective component this is the first study to examine this negative affective evaluation bias implicitly in patient with hyp an adapted version of the affect misattribution procedure amp with illness symptom and neutral prime wa used in 80 patient with hyp and compared to 83 patient with an anxiety disorder ad a well a 90 healthy control cg the hyp group showed significantly more negative affective reaction in illness prime trial compared to both control group a well a more negative implicit evaluation on symptom prime trial compared to the cg significant inverse relationship were observed only between the implicit evaluation of illness word and health anxiety questionnaire thus an implicit negative affective evaluation bias of serious illness rather than symptom is a unique feature of hyp

Title: Seeing "changes" that aren't there: facial and object discrimination in body dysmorphic disorder
Authors: Buhlmann, U.; Rupf, L.; Gleiss, M. J.; Zschenderlein, K.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: cognitive behavioral model of body dysmorphic disorder bdd suggest the disorder is characterized by several interpretive attentional and perceptual bias that contribute to it maintenance or even development in addition the role of aesthetic sensitivity ha been discussed in bdd however previous research examining the ability to identify subtle change in facial feature and geometrical object ha produced mixed result the purpose of the current study wa to further evaluate facial and object discrimination among individual with bdd n 35 individual with a dermatological condition n 35 and mentally healthy control participant n 35 using a facial and object discrimination paradigm assessing the sensitivity for change in symmetry color and size overall the group did not differ with respect to their performance in detecting actual change in facial or object image however there wa a significant group difference when they were presented with a series of unchanged facial but not object image the bdd group rated identical facial image significantly more often a being changed relative to individual without bdd the current result are discussed in light of the existing literature on facial and object discrimination in bdd

Title: Prospective relations among internalization of beauty ideals, body image concerns, and body change behaviors: Considering thinness and muscularity
Authors: Hoffmann, S.; Warschburger, P.
Abstract: common model propose that the internalization of societal beauty ideal influence disordered eating behavior and muscularity oriented behavior via body image concern however previous study addressing these pathway have been mainly cross sectional and primarily included female sample we investigated these pathway prospectively in male and female adolescent and young adult examining two pathway a weight shape pathway linking thin ideal internalization weight shape concern and restrained eating and a muscularity pathway linking athletic ideal internalization muscularity concern and muscularity oriented behavior across three time point 973 participant from the german general population were assessed although the hypothesized pathway could not be supported in their complete temporal sequence several hypothesized pathway occurred across two time point among others weight shape concern predicted restrained eating and the athletic ideal played a prominent role in the prediction of muscularity oriented behavior in both gender

Title: Costly avoidance of Pavlovian fear stimuli and the temporal dynamics of its decision process
Authors: Boschet, J. M.; Scherbaum, S.; Pittig, A.
Abstract: conflict between avoiding feared stimulus versus approaching them for competing reward are essential for functional behavior and anxious psychopathology yet little is known about the underlying decision process we examined approach avoidance decision and their temporal dynamic when avoiding pavlovian fear stimulus conflicted with gaining reward first a formerly neutral stimulus c wa repeatedly paired with an aversive stimulus u to establish pavlovian fear another stimulus c wa never paired with the u a control group received neutral tone instead of aversive u next in each of 324 trial participant chose between a c low reward and a c high reward option for the latter probability of c presentation pavlovian fear information and reward magnitude reward information varied computer mouse movement were tracked to capture the decision dynamic although no more u occurred pronounced and persistent costly avoidance of the pavlovian fear c wa found time continuous multiple regression of movement trajectory revealed a stronger and faster impact of pavlovian fear compared to reward information during decision making the impact of fear information but not reward information modestly decreased across trial these finding suggest a persistently stronger weighting of fear compared to reward information during approach avoidance decision which may facilitate the development of pathological avoidance

Title: Sex Hormones and Sleep in Men and Women From the General Population: A Cross-Sectional Observational Study
Authors: Kische, H.; Ewert, R.; Fietze, I.; Gross, S.; Wallaschofski, H.; Volzke, H.; Dorr, M.; Nauck, M.; Obst, A.; Stubbe, B.; Penzel, T.; Haring, R.
Abstract: context and objective association between sex hormone and sleep habit originate mainly from small and selected patient based sample we examined data from a population based sample with various sleep characteristic and the major part of sex hormone measured by mass spectrometry design setting and participant we used data from 204 men and 213 woman of the cross sectional study of health in pomerania trend main outcome and measure association of total t tt and free t androstenedione asd estrone estradiol e2 dehydroepiandrosterone sulphate shbg and e2 to tt ratio with sleep measure including total sleep time sleep efficiency wake after sleep onset apnea hypopnea index ahi insomnia severity index epworth sleepiness scale and pittsburgh sleep quality index were assessed by sex specific multivariable regression model result in men age adjusted association of tt odds ratio 0 62 95 confidence interval ci 0 46 0 83 free t and shbg with ahi were rendered nonsignificant after multivariable adjustment in multivariable analysis asd wa associated with epworth sleepiness scale beta coefficient per sd increase in asd 0 71 95 ci 1 18 to 0 25 in woman multivariable analysis showed positive association of dehydroepiandrosterone sulphate with wake after sleep onset beta coefficient 16 95 ci 0 03 0 28 and of e2 and e2 to tt ratio with epworth sleepiness scale additionally free t and shbg were associated with ahi in multivariable model among premenopausal woman conclusion the present cross sectional population based study observed sex specific association of androgen e2 and shbg with sleep apnea and daytime sleepiness however multivariable adjusted analysis confirmed the impact of body composition and health related lifestyle on the association between sex hormone and sleep

Title: Cortisol in hair and the metabolic syndrome
Authors: Stalder, T.; Kirschbaum, C.; Alexander, N.; Bornstein, S. R.; Gao, W.; Miller, R.; Stark, S.; Bosch, J. A.; Fischer, J. E.
Abstract: context although exposure to supraphysiological level of glucocorticoid is known to contribute to the development of the metabolic syndrome mets the importance of physiological variation in basal cortisol secretion is le clear this issue can be addressed by using hair cortisol analysis which for the first time allows the assessment of long term integrated hormone level objective and design we used the analysis of cortisol in hair hairf to examine association of long term cortisol level with prevalence of mets and individual cardiometabolic parameter in a large occupational cohort in additional exploratory analysis we also studied cardiometabolic association with hair cortisone level participant participant included 1258 employee of a large aerospace company aged 16 64 year 84 8 male who partook in a voluntary health assessment main outcome measure the first 3 cm of scalp near hair were analyzed for glucocorticoid concentration using liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry relevant cardiometabolic risk factor were assessed and mets wa diagnosed according to 2009 international task force criterion result a higher prevalence of mets wa seen in individual falling into the third odds ratio 1 71 95 confidence interval 1 08 2 69 or fourth hairf quartile odds ratio 2 42 95 confidence interval 1 55 3 75 compared with the first quartile in fully adjusted analysis hairf also showed positive association with weight related anthropometric measure body mass index waist to hip ratio waist circumference and glycated hemoglobin the exploratory analysis of hair cortisone also indicated relevant association with cardiometabolic parameter conclusion normal physiological difference in long term cortisol secretion a assessed in hair show relevant relationship with mets and individual cardiometabolic parameter

Title: Initial and sustained brain responses to contextual conditioned anxiety in humans
Authors: Andreatta, M.; Glotzbach-Schoon, E.; Muhlberger, A.; Schulz, S. M.; Wiemer, J.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: contextual fear conditioning take place if the occurrence of threat cannot be predicted by specific cue a a consequence the context becomes the best predictor of the threat and later induces anxiety sustained fear response previous study suggest that both the amygdala and the hippocampus are crucial for contextual fear conditioning first we wanted to further elucidate the neuronal correlate of long lasting contextual threat within a highly ecologically setting created in virtual reality vr second we wanted to distinguish between initial and sustained component of the anxiety response to a threatening situation twenty four participant were guided through two virtual office for 30 each they received unpredictable electric stimulus unconditioned stimulus u in one office anxiety context cxt but never in the second office safety context cxt successful contextual fear conditioning wa indexed by higher anxiety and enhanced u expectancy rating for cxt versus cxt initial neural activity wa assessed by modeling the onset of both context and sustained neural activity by considering the entire context duration contrast cxt cxt amygdala and hippocampus revealed sustained activity initial and sustained activity were found in the middle temporal gyrus and primary motor cortex m1 additional initial activity wa obvious in orbitofrontal ofc dorsomedial dmpfc and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc these result suggest that entering a threatening context initially induces conditioned fear reaction m1 recall of contingency awareness dlpfc and explicit threat appraisal dmpfc ofc while remaining in the threatening context might involve anxiety like conditioned response amygdala m1 and the generation of a spatial map to predict where and when a threatening event may occur hippocampus we conclude that in human initial versus sustained anxiety response triggered by a threat associated context are associated with distinguishable brain activation pattern involving a fear network and a contingency cognitive network respectively

Title: Context-dependent generalization of conditioned responses to threat and safety signals
Authors: Andreatta, M.; Genheimer, H.; Wieser, M. J.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: contextual information can modulate the conditioned response to a threat signal conditioned stimulus c fear response are either potentiated or attenuated depending on whether the context is threatening or safe in this study we investigated the influence of context on conditioned fear a well a on generalization of conditioned fear thirty two participant underwent a cue in context learning protocol in virtual reality vr on day 1 acquisition participant received a mild painful electric shock unconditioned stimulus u in one virtual room fear context ctx at the offset of one colored light c but never at the offset of another colored light c in a second room safety context ctx the two light were also presented but not the u successful cue conditioning wa indicated by aversive rating and startle potentiation but not skin conductance response scr to c versus c in ctx and not in ctx on day 2 generalization participant re visited both fear and safety context plus a generalization context g ctx which wa an equal mix of ctx and ctx the two c were shown again in all three context generalization of conditioned fear wa revealed in affective rating c wa rated more aversive than c in g ctx but not in physiological measure equal startle potentiation to c versus c in all context in sum contextual information modulates the response to a threat signal such that a safety context can inhibit conditioned fear interestingly generalization process also depend on contextual information

Title: Your Fear is My Fear: The Relationship Between Parental and Offspring Anxieties
Authors: Adolph, D.; Margraf, J.; Schneider, S.
Abstract: contrary to the well documented link between parental and offspring clinical anxiety little is known about the relationship between parental everyday life anxiety e g concerning family finance health and offspring anxiety to close this gap we assessed the frequency of parental symptom of dsm iv anxiety disorder and everyday life anxiety a well a the frequency of offspring anxiety symptom in a representative sample by self report parent reported that 48 4 of the child were free of specific symptom of dsm iv anxiety disorder within the last 12 month 39 2 showed low symptom load 1 3 symptom and 12 4 were moderately or severely strained 4 10 symptom replicating previous study parental dsm iv symptom increased offspring risk for the same symptom in addition parental everyday life anxiety showed a positive relationship with offspring symptom severity demographic variable female sex low socioeconomic status and younger age and parental anxiety marker explained 18 of variance in offspring symptom severity the data are discussed in light of current model of familial transmission

Title: Loving-Kindness Meditation to Target Affect in Mood Disorders: A Proof-of-Concept Study
Authors: Hofmann, S. G.; Petrocchi, N.; Steinberg, J.; Lin, M.; Arimitsu, K.; Kind, S.; Mendes, A.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: conventional treatment for mood disorder primarily focus on reducing negative affect but little on enhancing positive affect loving kindness meditation lkm is a traditional meditation practice directly oriented toward enhancing unconditional and positive emotional state of kindness towards oneself and others we report here two independent and uncontrolled study carried out at different center one in boston usa n 10 and one in frankfurt germany n 8 to examine the potential therapeutic utility of a brief lkm group intervention for symptom of dysthymia and depression result at both center suggest that lkm wa associated with large sized effect on self reported symptom of depression d 3 33 and 1 90 negative affect d 1 98 and 0 92 and positive affect d 1 63 and 0 94 large effect were also found for clinician reported change in depression rumination and specific positive emotion and moderate effect for change in adaptive emotion regulation strategy the qualitative data analysis provide additional support for the potential clinical utility of the intervention this proof of concept evaluation of lkm a a clinical strategy warrant further investigation

Title: The challenge of living on: psychopathology and its mediating influence on the readjustment of former child soldiers
Authors: Ertl, V.; Pfeiffer, A.; Schauer-Kaiser, E.; Elbert, T.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: current civil war are characterized by the increasing involvement of civilian population and the systematic employment of child soldier an example of such war wa the conflict in northern uganda where the war affected population is still challenged by the reintegration of formerly abducted child and youth a cross sectional population based survey using a multistage cluster sampling approach of 1 113 northern ugandan aged between 12 and 25 in camp for internally displaced person and locally validated instrument wa conducted to a symptom and diagnosis of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd and probable depression in war affected a well a formerly abducted individual further objective were to determine predictor of psychopathology and to relate indicator of maladjustment i e impairment in daily and community functioning somatic complaint suicidality aggressiveness and discrimination to abduction level of exposure to violence and psychopathology 43 of the sample reported abduction by the rebel army exposure to violence among this group wa higher than for non abducted youth t 28 05 p 001 ptsd point prevalence rate were 25 among former child soldier and 7 among the comparison group high suicidal ideation wa present in 16 and 6 respectively a higher amount of experienced and witnessed event type beta 32 p 001 loss of first degree relative beta 13 p 001 and the number of event type involving forced perpetration beta 23 p 001 were identified a risk factor of ptsd symptom in former child soldier the association between abductee status and indicator of maladjustment were fully mediated by level of trauma exposure and psychopathology result show that child soldiering and it psychological sequela affect a substantial proportion of child and youth after release or flight their readjustment depends at least partly on their level of mental traumatization

Title: Cyberbullying, positive mental health and suicide ideation/behavior
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Teismann, T.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: cyberbullying ha regularly been shown to be associated with suicide ideation behavior the present study investigated whether positive mental health i e high level of emotional cognitive and psychological well being buffer the association between cyberbullying and suicide ideation behavior a total of 225 student completed measure of cyberbullying suicide ideation behavior and positive mental health positive mental health fully mediated the association between cyberbullying and suicide ideation behavior positive mental health seems to confer resilience and should be taken into account in clinical and preventive program for student population

Title: Transient hippocampal CA1 lesions in humans impair pattern separation performance
Authors: Hanert, A.; Pedersen, A.; Bartsch, T.
Abstract: day to day life involves the perception of event that resemble one another for the sufficient encoding and retrieval of similar information the hippocampus provides two essential computational process pattern separation refers to the differentiation of overlapping memory representation whereas pattern completion reactivates memory based on noisy or degraded input evidence from human and rodent study suggest that pattern separation specifically relies on neuronal ensemble activity in hippocampal subnetworks in the dentate gyrus and ca3 although a role for ca1 in pattern separation ha been shown in animal model it contribution in the human hippocampus remains elusive in order to elucidate the contribution of ca1 neuron to pattern separation we examined 14 patient with an acute transient global amnesia tga a rare self limiting dysfunction of the hippocampal system showing specific lesion to ca1 patient pattern separation performance wa tested during the acute amnestic phase and follow up using an established mnemonic similarity test patient in the acute phase showed a profound deficit in pattern separation p 05 a well a recognition memory p 001 that recovered during follow up specifically patient tested in a later stage of the amnesia were le impaired in pattern separation than in recognition memory considering the time dependency of lesion associated hippocampal deficit in early and late acute stage of the tga we showed that the pattern separation function recovered significantly earlier than recognition memory our result provide causal evidence that hippocampal ca1 neuron are critical to pattern separation performance in human

Title: Automatic facial coding versus electromyography of mimicked, passive, and inhibited facial response to emotional faces
Authors: Hofling, T. T. A.; Alpers, G. W.; Gerdes, A. B. M.; Fohl, U.
Abstract: decoding someone s facial expression provides insight into his or her emotional experience recently automatic facial coding afc software ha been developed to provide measurement of emotional facial expression previous study provided first evidence for the sensitivity of such system to detect facial response in study participant in the present experiment we set out to generalise these result to affective response a they can occur in variable social interaction thus we presented facial expression happy neutral angry and instructed participant n 64 to either actively mimic to look at them passively n 21 or to inhibit their own facial reaction n 22 a video stream for afc and an electromyogram emg of the zygomaticus and corrugator muscle were registered continuously in the mimicking condition both afc and emg differentiated well between facial expression in response to the different emotional picture in the passive viewing and in the inhibition condition afc did not detect change in facial expression whereas emg wa still highly sensitive although only emg is sensitive when participant intend to conceal their facial reaction these data extend previous finding that automatic facial coding is a promising tool for the detection of intense facial reaction

Title: Predictors of improved functioning in patients with psychosis: The role of amotivation and defeatist performance beliefs
Authors: Pillny, M.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: defeatist performance belief dpbs are associated with the severe impairment in functioning of patient with negative symptom of schizophrenia this association ha been found to be mediated by amotivation a core aspect of negative symptom although causality is assumed longitudinal evidence for this is lacking the current study aimed to extend previous finding by investigating both cross sectional and longitudinal association between dpbs motivational impairment and functioning in a sample of patient with psychotic disorder n 58 we hypothesized that dpbs would be related to functioning in cross sectional and longitudinal analysis and that this link would be mediated by motivational impairment data wa assessed at baseline and post treatment in a trial on the effect of cognitive behavior therapy for psychosis at baseline amotivation mediated the association between dpbs and functioning from baseline to post treatment reduction of amotivation wa associated with improvement of functioning significantly whereas reduction of dpbs wa unrelated to improvement in functioning or amotivation the finding suggest that improvement in amotivation account for favorable treatment outcome in regard to functioning but question the causal role of dpbs in negative symptom and functioning

Title: Social aversive generalization learning sharpens the tuning of visuocortical neurons to facial identity cues
Authors: Stegmann, Y.; Ahrens, L.; Pauli, P.; Keil, A.; Wieser, M. J.
Abstract: defensive system activation promotes heightened perception of threat signal and excessive attention to threat signal ha been discussed a a contributory factor in the etiology of anxiety disorder however a mechanistic account of attentional modulation during fear relevant process especially during fear generalization remains elusive to test the hypothesis that social fear generalization prompt sharpened tuning in the visuocortical representation of social threat cue 67 healthy participant underwent differential fear conditioning followed by a generalization test in which participant viewed face varying in similarity with the threat associated face we found that generalization of social threat sharpens visuocortical tuning of social threat cue whereas rating of fearfulness showed generalization linearly decreasing with decreasing similarity to the threat associated face moreover individual who reported greater anxiety in social situation also showed heightened sharpened tuning of visuocortical neuron to facial identity cue indicating the behavioral relevance of visuocortical tuning during generalization learning

Title: Impaired regulation of emotion: neural correlates of reappraisal and distraction in bipolar disorder and unaffected relatives
Authors: Kanske, P.; Schonfelder, S.; Forneck, J.; Wessa, M.
Abstract: deficient emotion regulation ha been proposed a a crucial pathological mechanism in bipolar disorder bd we therefore investigated emotion regulation impairment in bd the related neural underpinnings and their etiological relevance for the disorder twenty two euthymic patient with bipolar i disorder and 17 unaffected first degree relative of bd i patient a well a two group of healthy gender age and education matched control n 22 17 respectively were included participant underwent functional magnetic resonance imaging while applying two different emotion regulation technique reappraisal and distraction when presented with emotional image bd patient and relative showed impaired downregulation of amygdala activity during reappraisal but not during distraction when compared with control this deficit wa correlated with the habitual use of reappraisal the negative connectivity of amygdala and orbitofrontal cortex ofc observed during reappraisal in control wa reversed in bd patient and relative there were no significant difference between bd patient and relative a being observed in bd patient and unaffected relative deficit in emotion regulation through reappraisal may represent heritable neurobiological abnormality underlying bd the neural mechanism include impaired control of amygdala reactivity to emotional stimulus and dysfunctional connectivity of the amygdala to regulatory control region in the ofc these are thus important aspect of the neurobiological basis of increased vulnerability for bd

Title: Predicting Real-Life Self-Control From Brain Activity Encoding the Value of Anticipated Future Outcomes
Authors: Kronke, K. M.; Wolff, M.; Mohr, H.; Kraplin, A.; Smolka, M. N.; Buhringer, G.; Goschke, T.
Abstract: deficient self control lead to shortsighted decision and incurs severe personal and societal cost although neuroimaging ha advanced our understanding of neural mechanism underlying self control the ecological validity of laboratory task used to a self control remains largely unknown to increase ecological validity and to test a specific hypothesis about the mechanism underlying real life self control we combined functional mri during value based decision making with smartphone based assessment of real life self control in a large community sample n 194 result showed that an increased propensity to make shortsighted decision and commit self control failure both in the laboratory task a well a during real life conflict wa associated with a reduced modulation of neural value signal in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex in response to anticipated long term consequence these result constitute the first evidence that neural mechanism mediating anticipation of future consequence not only account for self control in laboratory task but also predict real life self control thereby bridging the gap between laboratory research and real life behavior

Title: Emotion regulation predicts symptoms of depression over five years
Authors: Berking, M.; Wirtz, C. M.; Svaldi, J.; Hofmann, S. G.
Abstract: deficit in emotion regulation have been identified a an important risk and maintaining factor for depression the aim of this study wa to examine the long term effect of emotion regulation on symptom of depression moreover we investigated which specific emotion regulation skill were associated with subsequent symptom of depression participant were 116 individual 78 woman average age 35 2 year who registered for an online based assessment of depression and it risk factor and reported at least some symptom of depression successful application of emotion regulation skill and depressive symptom severity were assessed twice over a 5 year period we utilized cross lagged panel analysis to a whether successful skill application would be negatively associated with subsequent depressive symptom severity cross lagged panel analysis identified successful skill application a a significant predictor for depressive symptom severity even when controlling for the effect of initial symptom of depression a comparison of the effect size for different emotion regulation skill on subsequent depressive symptom suggests that most of the skill included have similar predictive value these finding provide preliminary evidence for the hypothesis that deficit in emotion regulation may contribute to the development of depression and that intervention systematically enhancing adaptive emotion regulation skill may help prevent and treat depressive symptom

Title: Evidence for altered amygdala activation in schizophrenia in an adaptive emotion recognition task
Authors: Mier, D.; Lis, S.; Zygrodnik, K.; Sauer, C.; Ulferts, J.; Gallhofer, B.; Kirsch, P.
Abstract: deficit in social cognition seem to present an intermediate phenotype for schizophrenia and are known to be associated with an altered amygdala response to face however current result are heterogeneous with respect to whether this altered amygdala response in schizophrenia is hypoactive or hyperactive in nature the present study used functional magnetic resonance imaging to investigate emotion specific amygdala activation in schizophrenia using a novel adaptive emotion recognition paradigm participant comprised 11 schizophrenia outpatient and 16 healthy control who viewed face stimulus expressing emotion of anger fear happiness and disgust a well a neutral expression the adaptive emotion recognition approach allows the assessment of group difference in both emotion recognition performance and associated neuronal activity while also ensuring a comparable number of correctly recognized emotion between group schizophrenia participant were slower and had a negative bias in emotion recognition in addition they showed reduced differential activation during recognition of emotional compared with neutral expression correlation analysis revealed an association of a negative bias with amygdala activation for neutral facial expression that wa specific to the patient group we replicated previous finding of affected emotion recognition in schizophrenia furthermore we demonstrated that altered amygdala activation in the patient group wa associated with the occurrence of a negative bias these result provide further evidence for impaired social cognition in schizophrenia and point to a central role of the amygdala in negative misperceptions of facial stimulus in schizophrenia

Title: Neural and psychophysiological markers of delay aversion in attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder
Authors: Wilbertz, G.; Trueg, A.; Sonuga-Barke, E. J.; Blechert, J.; Philipsen, A.; Tebartz van Elst, L.
Abstract: delay aversion dav is thought to be a crucial factor in the manifestation of impulsive behavior in patient with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd the imposition of delay is predicted to elicit negative emotional reaction in adhd the present study offer a multimodal approach to the investigation of dav twelve adult patient with adhd and 12 matched healthy control were tested on a new task with several level of anticipated delay during functional magnet resonance imaging fmri behavioral measure of delay discounting dav and delay frustration were collected skin conductance and finger pulse rate were assessed result indicated a group difference in response to change in delay in the right amygdala for control participant activity decreased with longer delay whereas activity tended to increase for adhd patient the degree of amygdala increase wa correlated with the degree of behavioral dav within the adhd group patient also exhibited increased emotional arousal on physiological measure these result support the notion of an exacerbated negative emotional state during the anticipation and processing of delay in adhd

Title: Religious beliefs buffer the impact of depression on suicide ideation
Authors: Teismann, T.; Willutzki, U.; Michalak, J.; Siegmann, P.; Nyhuis, P.; Wolter, M.; Forkmann, T.
Abstract: depression and suicide ideation co occur regularly the present study investigated whether religious belief i e trust in higher guidance buffer the association between depression and suicide ideation a total of 427 participant n 93 inpatient n 334 online sample completed measure of suicide ideation trust in higher guidance and depression trust in higher guidance moderated the impact of depression on suicide ideation trust in higher guidance seems to confer resilience and should be taken into account when assessing individual for suicide risk

Title: "She finds you abhorrent" - The impact of emotional context information on the cortical processing of neutral faces in depression
Authors: Iffland, B.; Klein, F.; Schindler, S.; Kley, H.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: depression is associated with abnormality in pattern of information processing particularly in the context of processing of interpersonal information the present study wa designed to investigate the difference in depressive individual in cortical processing of facial stimulus when neutral face were presented in a context that involved information about emotional valence a well a self reference in 21 depressive patient and 20 healthy control event related potential erps were recorded during the presentation of neutral facial expression which were accompanied by affective context information that wa either self or other related across condition depressive patient showed larger mean p100 amplitude than healthy control furthermore mean late positive potential lpp amplitude of depressive patient were larger in response to face in self related than in other related context in addition irrespective of self reference mean lpp response of depressive patient to face presented after socially threatening sentence were larger compared with face presented after neutral sentence result regarding self reference supported result of previous study indicating larger mean amplitude in self related condition finding suggest a general heightened initial responsiveness to emotional cue and a sustained emotion processing of socially threatening information in depressive patient

Title: Effect of an internet- and app-based stress intervention compared to online psychoeducation in university students with depressive symptoms: Results of a randomized controlled trial
Authors: Harrer, M.; Apolinario-Hagen, J.; Fritsche, L.; Salewski, C.; Zarski, A. C.; Lehr, D.; Baumeister, H.; Cuijpers, P.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: depression is highly prevalent among university student internet based intervention have been found to be effective in addressing depressive symptom but it is open if this also applies to intervention directed at academic stress it is also largely unclear if the technique employed in such program provide significant additional benefit when controlling for non specific intervention effect a sample of n 200 student with elevated level of depression ce d 16 of a large distance learning university were randomly assigned to either an internet and app based stress intervention group ig n 100 or an active control group cg n 100 receiving an internet based psychoeducational program of equal length self report data wa assessed at baseline post treatment 7 week and three month follow up the primary outcome wa depression ce d post treatment secondary outcome included mental health outcome modifiable risk factor and academic outcome we found significant between group effect on depressive symptom severity d 0 36 95 ci 0 08 0 64 a well a behavioral activation d 0 61 95 ci 0 30 0 91 perceived stress d 0 45 95 ci 0 18 0 73 anxiety d 0 35 95 ci 0 03 0 67 and other secondary outcome post treatment effect on depression were sustained at three month follow up response rate for depressive symptom were significantly higher in the ig 26 than the cg 14 at post test chi 2 4 5 p 0 04 but not at three month follow up p 0 454 we also found significant effect on relevant academic outcome including work impairment follow up d 0 36 work output post treatment d 0 27 and work cutback follow up d 0 36 the intervention wa more effective for depressive symptom compared to the cg and so controlling for unspecific intervention effect this suggests that specific technique of the intervention may provide significant additional benefit on depressive symptom trial registration german clinical trial registration drks drks00011800 http www drks de drks_web navigate do navigationid trial html trial_id drks00011800

Title: The impact of comorbid depression on recovery from personality disorders and improvements in psychosocial functioning: results from a randomized controlled trial
Authors: Renner, F.; Bamelis, L. L.; Huibers, M. J.; Speckens, A.; Arntz, A.
Abstract: depressive disorder often co occur with personality disorder the extent to which depressive disorder influence treatment outcome in personality disorder remains unclear the aim of this study wa to determine the impact of co morbid depression on recovery from personality disorder and improvement in psychosocial functioning this study drew data from a randomized controlled trial in which patient n 320 with cluster c 92 paranoid histrionic and or narcissistic personality disorder received schema therapy treatment a usual or clarification oriented psychotherapy recovery from personality disorder at three year follow up and improvement in psychosocial functioning over a course of three year wa predicted by the diagnostic status of depressive disorder at baseline using mixed model regression analysis based on the number of axis i and axis ii disorder personality disorder severity and global symptomatic distress and functioning a baseline severity index wa computed and included in subsequent analysis to test the specificity of baseline depression in predicting outcome patient with co occurring depression reported higher baseline severity compared to patient without co occurring depression depression at baseline wa associated with lower recovery rate at three year follow up p 0 01 but this effect disappeared after controlling for baseline severity patient with depression at baseline reported higher psychosocial impairment throughout treatment p 0 001 depression at baseline did not moderate treatment effect except for one psychosocial outcome measure in conclusion depression is associated with lower recovery rate from personality disorder but this effect disappears when general severity is taken into account patient with primarily cluster c personality disorder and co occurring depression might benefit from additional depression treatment in term of improved psychosocial functioning

Title: Motherhood and theory of mind: increased activation in the posterior cingulate cortex and insulae
Authors: Plank, I. S.; Hindi Attar, C.; Kunas, S. L.; Dziobek, I.; Bermpohl, F.
Abstract: despite growing evidence on effect of parenthood on social understanding little is known about the influence of parenthood on theory of mind tom the capacity to infer mental and affective state of others it is also unclear whether any possible effect of parenthood on tom would generalise to inferring state of adult or are specific to child we investigated neural activation in mother and woman without child while they predicted action intention from child and adult face region of interest analysis showed stronger activation in mother in the bilateral posterior cingulate cortex precuneus tom related area and insulae emotion related area whole brain analysis revealed that mother compared to non mother more strongly activated area including the left angular gyrus and the ventral prefrontal cortex but le strongly activated the right supramarginal gyrus and the dorsal prefrontal cortex these difference were not specific to child stimulus but occurred in response to both adult and child stimulus and might indicate that mother and non mother employ different strategy to infer action intention from affective face whether these general difference in affective tom between mother and non mother are due to biological or experience related change should be subject of further investigation

Title: Real-Life Self-Control is Predicted by Parietal Activity During Preference Decision Making: A Brain Decoding Analysis
Authors: Kronke, K. M.; Mohr, H.; Wolff, M.; Kraplin, A.; Smolka, M. N.; Buhringer, G.; Ruge, H.; Goschke, T.
Abstract: despite it relevance for health and education the neurocognitive mechanism of real life self control is largely unknown while recent research revealed a prominent role of the ventromedial prefrontal cortex in the computation of an integrative value signal the contribution and relevance of other brain region for real life self control remains unclear to investigate neural correlate of decision in line with long term consequence and to a the potential of brain decoding method for the individual prediction of real life self control we combined functional magnetic resonance imaging during preference decision making with ecological momentary assessment of daily self control in a large community sample n 266 decision in line with long term consequence were associated with increased activity in bilateral angular gyrus and precuneus region involved in different form of perspective taking such a imagining one s own future and the perspective of others applying multivariate pattern analysis to the same cluster revealed that individual pattern of activity predicted the probability of real life self control brain activation are discussed in relation to episodic future thinking and mentalizing a potential mechanism mediating real life self control

Title: Functional connectivity in a triple-network saliency model is associated with real-life self-control
Authors: Kronke, K. M.; Wolff, M.; Shi, Y.; Kraplin, A.; Smolka, M. N.; Buhringer, G.; Goschke, T.
Abstract: despite it significance for health and education the neurocognitive mechanism of real life self control remains unclear while recent study focused on task related brain activation pattern a predictor of self control the contribution and relevance of functional connectivity between large scale brain network mediating higher order cognition is largely unknown using a saliency based triple network model of cognitive control we tested the hypothesis that cross network interaction among the salience network sn the central executive network cen and the default mode network dmn are associated with real life self control to this end a large community sample n 294 underwent ecological momentary assessment of daily self control a well a task free fmri to examine intrinsic inter network organization and determine a sn centered network interaction index nii logistic multilevel regression analysis showed that higher nii score were associated with increased real life self control this suggests that the assumed role of the sn in initiating switching between the dmn and cen is an important part of self control

Title: Goal-directed behavior under emotional distraction is preserved by enhanced task-specific activation
Authors: Wessa, M.; Heissler, J.; Schonfelder, S.; Kanske, P.
Abstract: despite the distracting effect of emotional stimulus on concurrent task performance human are able to uphold goal directed behavior here we investigated the hypothesis that this effect is due to the enhanced recruitment of task specific neural resource in a two step functional magnetic resonance imaging study we first localized those area involved in mental arithmetic by contrasting arithmetic problem with a number detection task the resulting activation map were then used a mask in a second experiment that compared the effect of neutral and emotional distracter image on mental arithmetic we found increased response time in the emotional distracter condition accompanied by enhanced activation in task specific area including superior parietal cortex dorsolateral and dorsomedial prefrontal cortex this activation increase correlated with larger behavioral impairment through emotional distraction similar error rate in both condition indicate that cognitive task performance is preserved through enhanced recruitment of task specific neural resource when emotional distracter stimulus are present

Title: Lessons learned from an attempted randomized-controlled feasibility trial on "WIDeCAD" - An internet-based depression treatment for people living with coronary artery disease (CAD)
Authors: Bendig, E.; Bauereiss, N.; Buntrock, C.; Habibovic, M.; Ebert, D. D.; Baumeister, H.
Abstract: despite the high prevalence of comorbid depression in people living with coronary artery disease cad uptake of psychological treatment is generally low this study wa designed to investigate the feasibility of an internet based cognitive behavioral icbt depression intervention for people with cad and depressive symptom method people with cad and depressive symptom phq 9 5 were randomly assigned to the eight module comprising icbt n 18 or waitlist control n 16 measure were taken at baseline t1 and at post treatment eight week after randomization t2 feasibility related outcome were recruitment strategy study attrition intervention dropout satisfaction negative effect a well a the potential of the intervention to affect likely outcome in a future full scale trial depression anxiety quality of life fear of progression data analysis were based on intention to treat principle linear regression model were used to detect between group difference linear mixed model were used to model potential change over time result this trial wa terminated prior to a priori defined sample size ha been reached given low recruitment success a well a high intervention dropout 88 and study attrition 23 on average participant in the intervention group completed m 2 78 sd 3 23 module participant in the waitlist control group barely started one module m 0 82 sd 1 81 the satisfaction with the intervention wa low m 20 6 sd 0 88 participant reported no negative effect attributed to the icbt difference between group with regard to depression anxiety fear of progression and quality of life remained non significant p 0 05 conclusion this trial failed to recruit a sufficient number of participant future work should explore potential pitfall with regard to the reach and persuasiveness of internet intervention for people living with cad the study give important indication for future study with regard to the need for new idea to reach and treat people with cad and depression

Title: Monitor yourself! Deficient error-related brain activity predicts real-life self-control failures
Authors: Kronke, K. M.; Wolff, M.; Mohr, H.; Kraplin, A.; Smolka, M. N.; Buhringer, G.; Goschke, T.
Abstract: despite their immense relevance the neurocognitive mechanism underlying real life self control failure scfs are insufficiently understood whereas previous study have shown that scfs were associated with decreased activity in the right inferior frontal gyrus rifg a region involved in cognitive control here we consider the possibility that the reduced implementation of cognitive control in individual with low self control may be due to impaired performance monitoring following a brain a predictor approach we combined experience sampling of daily scfs with functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri in a stroop task in our sample of 118 participant proneness to scf wa reliably predicted by low error related activation of a performance monitoring network comprising anterior mid cingulate cortex presupplementary motor area and anterior insula low posterror rifg activation and reduced posterror slowing remarkably these neural and behavioral measure predicted variability in scfs beyond what wa predicted by self reported trait self control these result suggest that real life scfs may result from deficient performance monitoring leading to reduced recruitment of cognitive control after response that conflict with superordinate goal

Title: Cognitive functioning and emotion processing in breast cancer survivors and controls: An ERP pilot study
Authors: Wirkner, J.; Weymar, M.; Low, A.; Hamm, C.; Struck, A. M.; Kirschbaum, C.; Hamm, A. O.
Abstract: diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer is a very emotionally aversive and stressful life event which can lead to impaired cognitive functioning and mental health breast cancer survivor responding with repressive emotion regulation strategy often show le adaptive coping and adverse outcome we investigated cognitive functioning and neural correlate of emotion processing using erps self report measure of depression anxiety and fatigue a well a hair cortisol a an index of chronic stress were assessed twenty breast cancer survivor bcs and 31 carefully matched healthy control participated in the study after neuropsychological testing and subjective assessment participant viewed 30 neutral 30 unpleasant and 30 pleasant picture and erps were recorded recognition memory wa tested 1 week later bcs reported stronger complaint about cognitive impairment and more symptom of depression anxiety and fatigue moreover they showed elevated hair cortisol level except for verbal memory cognitive functioning wa predominantly in the normative range recognition memory performance wa decreased in cancer survivor especially for emotional content in erps survivor showed smaller late positive potential amplitude for unpleasant picture relative to control in a later time window which may indicate le elaborative processing of this material taken together we found cognitive impairment in bcs in verbal memory impaired emotional picture memory accuracy and reduced neural activity when breast cancer survivor were confronted with unpleasant material further study and larger sample size however are needed to evaluate the relationship between altered emotion processing and reduced memory in bcs in order to develop new treatment strategy

Title: The wandering mind in borderline personality disorder: Instability in self- and other-related thoughts
Authors: Kanske, P.; Schulze, L.; Dziobek, I.; Scheibner, H.; Roepke, S.; Singer, T.
Abstract: diagnostic criterion for borderline personality disorder bpd include instability in identity and interpersonal relationship here we probed whether instability is already present in bpd patient thought about themselves and others we tested bpd patient n 27 and healthy control n 25 with a mind wandering task that a content and variability of stimulus independent self generated thought multi level modeling revealed that while bpd patient and healthy control mind wander to a similar extent bpd patient thought are colored predominantly negatively most importantly although their thought concerned the self and others a much a in control they fluctuated more strongly in the degree to which their thought concerned themselves and others and also gave more extreme rating self and other related thought that were more extreme were also more negative in valence the increased variability support current conceptualization of bpd and may account for the instability in identity and interpersonal relationship

Title: Linking Personality Traits to Individual Differences in Affective Spaces
Authors: Levine, S. M.; Alahaivala, A. L. I.; Wechsler, T. F.; Wackerle, A.; Rupprecht, R.; Schwarzbach, J. V.
Abstract: different individual respond differently to emotional stimulus in their environment therefore to understand how emotion are represented mentally will ultimately require investigation into individual level information here we tasked participant with freely arranging emotionally charged image on a computer screen according to their subjective emotional similarity yielding a unique affective space for each participant and subsequently sought external validity of the layout of the individual affective space through the five factor personality model neuroticism extraversion openness to experience agreeableness conscientiousness assessed via the neo five factor inventory applying agglomerative hierarchical clustering to the group level affective space revealed a set of underlying affective cluster whose within cluster dissimilarity per individual wa then correlated with individual personality score these cluster based analysis predominantly revealed that the dispersion of the negative cluster showed a positive relationship with neuroticism and a negative relationship with conscientiousness a finding that would be predicted by prior work such result demonstrate the non spurious structure of individualized emotion information revealed by data driven analysis of a behavioral task and validated by incorporating psychological measure of personality and corroborate prior knowledge of the interaction between affect and personality future investigation can similarly combine hypothesis and data driven method to extend such finding potentially yielding new perspective on underlying cognitive process disease susceptibility or even diagnostic prognostic marker for mental disorder involving emotion dysregulation

Title: Reward Processing in Unipolar and Bipolar Depression: A Functional MRI Study
Authors: Redlich, R.; Dohm, K.; Grotegerd, D.; Opel, N.; Zwitserlood, P.; Heindel, W.; Arolt, V.; Kugel, H.; Dannlowski, U.
