Abstract: differentiating bipolar disorder bd from unipolar depression ud remains a major clinical challenge the identification of neurobiological marker may help to differentiate these disorder particularly during depressive episode this cross sectional study including 33 patient with ud 33 patient with bd and 34 healthy control is one of the first to directly compare ud and bd with respect to reward processing a card guessing paradigm wa employed and brain activity associated with reward processing wa investigated by mean of fmri a 3 group x 2 condition reward control loss control anova wa conducted using the nucleus accumbens nacc a roi furthermore a whole brain approach wa applied a functional connectivity analysis wa performed to characterize diagnosis related alteration in the functional coupling between the nacc and other brain area the anova revealed higher activity for healthy control hcs than for bd and ud in the nacc during reward processing moreover ud showed a higher functional connectivity between the nacc and the vta than hc the patient group could be differentiated in that bd showed a decreased activation in the reward condition of the nacc caudate nucleus thalamus putamen insula and prefrontal area compared with ud these result may help to refine the understanding of neural correlate of reward processing in both disorder and to understand the neural underpinnings of anhedonia a core symptom of depressive episode

Title: [Difficult situations in psychotherapy and how therapists deal with them]
Authors: Henkel, M.; Michel, S.; Gaubatz, S.; Keymer, A.; Brakemeier, E. L.; Benecke, C.
Abstract: difficult situation in psychotherapy and how therapist deal with them objective in theory and research it is assumed that therapeutic competence are especially relevant in difficult situation in the present study we collected and categorized situation that psychotherapist subjectively evaluated a difficult additionally we inspected therapist reaction to these situation and considered correlation between situation and reaction method in an online survey 101 therapist described difficult situation and their corresponding reaction the report were analyzed by qualitative content analysis mayring 2015 and resulted in two category system for the difficult situation and the reaction result difficult situation reached from everyday conflict to extreme situation e g threat the most frequent difficult situation were in context of therapeutic frame aspect of disorder and critic demand accusation of patient the most frequent reaction concerned therapeutic frame external help and supportive intervention we found significant correlation between difficult situation due to aspect of disorder and asking for external help conclusion although category were sometimes difficult to isolate and few cognitive behavioral therapist participated the collection of difficult situation can be of help for therapist and their training

Title: Do People With Psychosis Have Specific Difficulties Regulating Emotions?
Authors: Lincoln, T. M.; Hartmann, M.; Kother, U.; Moritz, S.
Abstract: difficulty in emotion regulation er are present in psychotic disorder but their precise nature is not yet fully understood and it is unclear which difficulty are unique to psychosis compared with other disorder this study investigated whether er difficulty in psychosis are more prominent for the ability to modify emotion or for the ability to tolerate and accept them furthermore it investigated whether er difficulty occur for sadness anxiety anger and shame likewise er skill were assessed in participant with psychotic disorder n 37 participant with depression n 30 and healthy control n 28 using the emotion regulation skill questionnaire that asks participant to rate the intensity of different emotion over the past week and the skill employed to handle each of them compared with healthy control participant with psychosis showed reduced skill related to awareness understanding and acceptance of potentially distressing emotion but not in the ability to modify them these difference remained significant after controlling for depression participant with psychosis showed reduced er skill in regard to all of the assessed emotion compared with the healthy control despite the fact that they only reported sadness a being significantly more intense the participant with depression showed a similar pattern of er skill to the psychosis sample although with a tendency towards even more pronounced difficulty it is concluded that psychosis is characterized by difficulty in using specific er skill related to awareness understanding and acceptance to regulate anger shame anxiety and sadness these difficulty are not unique to psychosis but nevertheless present a promising treatment target key practitioner message the participant with psychosis found it more difficult to be aware of their emotion to understand them and to accept them than the healthy control group however they reported equal skill when it came to actively modifying emotion the difficulty in emotion regulation reported by the participant with psychosis were comparable with those reported by the participant with depression and they occurred for all type of negative emotion likewise the difficulty in using specific er skill related to awareness understanding and acceptance are a promising target for psychological treatment of psychosis intervention that are aimed specifically at increasing these skill need to be further developed

Title: Out of control? Acting out anger is associated with deficient prefrontal emotional action control in male patients with borderline personality disorder
Authors: Bertsch, K.; Krauch, M.; Roelofs, K.; Cackowski, S.; Herpertz, S. C.; Volman, I.
Abstract: difficulty in anger control and anger related aggressive outburst against others are frequently reported by patient with borderline personality disorder bpd although male sex is a known predictor for aggression hardly any study ha addressed the neural correlate of deficient anger control in male patient with bpd building on previous report in female bpd we investigated the involvement of lateral antero and dorsal prefrontal cortex in the control of fast emotional action and it relation to self reported tendency to act out anger 15 medication free male patient with bpd and 25 age and intelligence matched healthy men took part in a social approach avoidance task in the mr scanner this task allows the measurement of neural correlate underlying the control of fast behavioral tendency to approach happy and avoid angry face hypothesis driven region of interest and exploratory whole brain analysis were used to test for activation of antero and dorsolateral prefrontal region and their relation with the amygdala during emotional action control a well a their association with self reported anger out in male patient with bpd and healthy volunteer male patient with bpd showed reduced anterolateral prefrontal activation during emotional action control compared to healthy volunteer furthermore anger out wa negatively related to antero and dorsolateral prefrontal activation while it wa positively related to amygdala activity in male patient with bpd the current result suggest the involvement of antero and dorsolateral prefrontal region in controlling and overriding fast emotional action deficit in lateral prefrontal emotion control seem to be a common neural mechanism underlying anger related aggression this article is part of the special issue entitled current status of the neurobiology of aggression and impulsivity

Title: The sensory channel of presentation alters subjective ratings and autonomic responses toward disgusting stimuli-Blood pressure, heart rate and skin conductance in response to visual, auditory, haptic and olfactory presented disgusting stimuli
Authors: Croy, I.; Laqua, K.; Suss, F.; Joraschky, P.; Ziemssen, T.; Hummel, T.
Abstract: disgust cause specific reaction pattern observable in mimic response and body reaction most research on disgust deal with visual stimulus however picture may cause another disgust experience than sound odor or tactile stimulus therefore disgust experience evoked by four different sensory channel wa compared a total of 119 participant received 3 different disgusting and one control stimulus each presented through the visual auditory tactile and olfactory channel rating of evoked disgust a well a response of the autonomic nervous system heart rate skin conductance level systolic blood pressure were recorded and the effect of stimulus labeling and of repeated presentation wa analyzed rating suggested that disgust could be evoked through all sen they were highest for visual stimulus however autonomic reaction toward disgusting stimulus differed according to the channel of presentation in contrast to the other olfactory disgust stimulus provoked a strong decrease of systolic blood pressure additionally labeling enhanced disgust rating and autonomic reaction for olfactory and tactile but not for visual and auditory stimulus repeated presentation indicated that participant s disgust rating diminishes to all but olfactory disgust stimulus taken together we argue that the sensory channel through which a disgust reaction is evoked matter

Title: Dissociation of neuronal, electrodermal, and evaluative responses in disgust extinction
Authors: Klucken, T.; Schweckendiek, J.; Merz, C. J.; Vaitl, D.; Stark, R.
Abstract: disgust extinction is an important mechanism relevant for the treatment of psychiatric disorder however only a few study have investigated disgust extinction moreover because disgust sensitivity d is considered a a relevant factor for learning process this study also investigated the potential relationship between d and disgust extinction learning the aim of this study wa to explore the neuronal correlate of disgust extinction a well a change in skin conductance response scrs and evaluative conditioning twenty subject were exposed to a differential extinction paradigm in which a previous conditioned and now unreinforced stimulus conditioned stimulus c wa compared to a second stimulus c which wa previously not associated with the unconditioned stimulus ucs extinction learning wa measured on three different response level bold response scrs and evaluative conditioning regarding evaluative conditioning the c wa rated a more unpleasant than the c interestingly significantly increased amygdala response and scrs toward to the c were observed finally a negative trend wa found between d score and bold response of the prefrontal cortex the present finding showed a dissociation of different response level the increased c response could be explained by the assumption that the increased amygdala activity may reflect a safety learning signal during the first extinction trial and the subjective focus may therefore shift from the c to the c the correlation finding support previous study postulating that d hamper extinction process the present result point toward dissociation between the response level in context of extinction process

Title: Attentional Processing of Disgust and Fear and Its Relationship With Contamination-Based Obsessive-Compulsive Symptoms: Stronger Response Urgency to Disgusting Stimuli in Disgust-Prone Individuals
Authors: Fink-Lamotte, J.; Widmann, A.; Sering, K.; Schroger, E.; Exner, C.
Abstract: disgust ha recently been characterized a a low urgency emotion particularly compared to fear the aim of the present study is to clarify whether behavioral inhibition during disgust engagement is characteristic of a low urgency emotion and thus indicates self imposed attentional avoidance in comparison to fear therefore 54 healthy participant performed an emotional go no go task with disgust and fear relevant a well a neutral picture furthermore heart rate activity and facial muscle activity on the fear specific m corrugator supercilli and the disgust specific m levator labii were assessed the result partially support the temporal urgency hypothesis of disgust the emotion condition significantly differed in emotional engagement and in the facial muscle activity of the m levator labii a expected however contrary to our expectation no difference between the emotion condition regarding behavioral inhibition a well a heart rate change could be found furthermore individual with a higher trait disgust proneness showed faster reaction and higher activity of the m levator labii in response to disgust stimulus the result show that different trait level influence attentional engagement and physiological parameter but have only a small effect on behavioral inhibition

Title: Effects of a best-possible-self mental imagery exercise on mood and dysfunctional attitudes
Authors: Renner, F.; Schwarz, P.; Peters, M. L.; Huibers, M. J.
Abstract: dispositional optimism ha been related to positive physical and mental health outcome increased positive mood rating and cognition about the future in order to determine the causal relation between optimism and mood and cognition optimism should be manipulated experimentally the current study tested the effect of a best possible self mental imagery exercise on affect and mood rating and dysfunctional cognition following a sad mood induction in undergraduate student n 40 participant in the experimental condition wrote about their best possible self in the future for 15 min and engaged in a mental imagery task about their best possible self in the future for 5 min in order to experimentally induce optimism participant in the control condition wrote about a typical day for 15 min and engaged in mental imagery about a typical day for 5 min we assessed affect mood and dysfunctional cognition before and after the experimental manipulation participant in the experimental condition had higher positive mood rating and higher positive affect compared to participant in the control condition participant in the control condition reported decreased dysfunctional cognition whereas dysfunctional cognition in the experimental group remained unchanged future study should replicate these finding in clinical group with more profound level of negative affect and dysfunctional cognition

Title: The role of auditory transient and deviance processing in distraction of task performance: a combined behavioral and event-related brain potential study
Authors: Berti, S.
Abstract: distraction of goal oriented performance by a sudden change in the auditory environment is an everyday life experience different type of change can be distracting including a sudden onset of a transient sound and a slight deviation of otherwise regular auditory background stimulation with regard to deviance detection it is assumed that slight change in a continuous sequence of auditory stimulus are detected by a predictive coding mechanism and it ha been demonstrated that this mechanism is capable of distracting ongoing task performance in contrast it is open whether transient detection which doe not rely on predictive coding mechanism can trigger behavioral distraction too in the present study the effect of rare auditory change on visual task performance is tested in an auditory visual cross modal distraction paradigm the rare change are either embedded within a continuous standard stimulation triggering deviance detection or are presented within an otherwise silent situation triggering transient detection in the event related brain potential deviant elicited the mismatch negativity mmn while transient elicited an enhanced n1 component mirroring pre attentive change detection in both condition but on the basis of different neuro cognitive process these sensory component are followed by attention related erp component including the p3a and the reorienting negativity ron this demonstrates that both type of change trigger switch of attention finally distraction of task performance is observable too but the impact of deviant is higher compared to transient these finding suggest different route of distraction allowing for the automatic processing of a wide range of potentially relevant change in the environment a a pre requisite for adaptive behavior

Title: [Accessing Disturbances of Attachment Symptoms Using Interview Technique]
Authors: Kliewer-Neumann, J.; Bovenschen, I.; Lang, K.; Spangler, G.; Nowacki, K.; Roland, I. C.
Abstract: disturbance of attachment represent a clinically significant disorder and seriously impair social behavioural functioning to date there ha been little research and valid diagnostic method are lacking in the present study a german version of the disturbance of attachment interview developed by smyke and zeanah 1999 wa used to a disturbance of attachment in a sample of foster child and the validity of the translation is investigated furthermore the strength and difficulty questionnaire goodman 1997 wa used to examine the discriminative validity the result show a satisfying reliability and the scale of attachment disorder declare the main of the variance there is a weak association between the disinhibited scale and hyperactivity in the sdq overall the disinhibited disorder can be distinguished from other behaviour pattern regarding the inhibited scale there are association with all sdq scale and the inhibited category seems harder to distinguish from other deviant developmental issue the method is evaluated a a qualified approach to the diagnosis of attachment disorder in the context of a multimethodical approach furthermore the finding suggest further examination of the construct of attachment disturbance

Title: Presence of a dog reduces subjective but not physiological stress responses to an analog trauma
Authors: Lass-Hennemann, J.; Peyk, P.; Streb, M.; Holz, E.; Michael, T.
Abstract: dog are known to have stress and anxiety reducing effect several study have shown that dog are able to calm people during cognitive and performance stressor recently therapy dog have been proposed a a treatment adjunct for post traumatic stress disorder patient in this study we aimed to investigate whether dog also have anxiety and stress reducing effect during traumatic stressor 80 healthy female participant were randomly assigned to one of four condition they were exposed to a traumatic film clip trauma film paradigm for one group of participant a friendly dog wa present during the film one group of participant wa accompanied by a friendly human another control group watched the film with a toy animal and the last group watched the film clip alone participant that were accompanied by the dog during the film reported lower anxiety rating and le negative affect after the film clip a compared to the toy dog group and the alone group result of the dog group were comparable to the group that wa accompanied by a friendly human there were no difference in physiological stress response between the four condition our result show that dog are able to lessen subjectively experienced stress and anxiety during a traumatic stress situation this effect wa comparable to that of social support by a friendly person implication for ptsd patient are discussed

Title: The dopamine D2 receptor mediates approach-avoidance tendencies in smokers
Authors: Zlomuzica, A.; Machulska, A.; Roberts, S.; von Glischinski, M.; Rinck, M.; Lester, K. J.; Eley, T. C.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: dopamine d2 receptor drd2 have been strongly implicated in reward processing of natural stimulus and drug using the approach avoidance task aat we recently demonstrated that smoker show an increased approach bias toward smoking related cue but not toward naturally rewarding stimulus here we examined the contribution of the drd2 taq1b polymorphism to smoker and non smoker responsivity toward smoking versus naturally rewarding stimulus in the aat smoker carrying the minor b1 allele of the drd2 taq1b polymorphism showed reduced approach behavior for food related picture compared to non smoker with the same allele in the group of smoker a higher approach bias toward smoking related compared to food related picture wa found in carrier of the b1 allele this pattern wa not evident in smoker homozygous for the b2 allele in addition smoker with the b1 allele reported fewer attempt to quit smoking relative to smoker homozygous for the b2 allele this is the first study demonstrating that behavioral shift in response to smoking relative to natural reward in smoker are mediated by the drd2 taq1b polymorphism our result indicate a reduced natural reward brain reactivity in smoker with a genetically determined decrease in dopaminergic activity i e reduction of drd2 availability it remains to be determined whether this pattern might be related to a different outcome after psychological cessation intervention i e aat modification paradigm in smoker

Title: Context counts! social anxiety modulates the processing of fearful faces in the context of chemosensory anxiety signals
Authors: Adolph, D.; Meister, L.; Pause, B. M.
Abstract: during emotion perception context is an important source of information whether contextual cue from modality other than vision or audition influence the perception of social emotional information ha not been investigated thus the present study aimed at testing emotion perception and regulation in response to fearful facial expression presented in the context of chemosensory stimulus derived from sweat of anxious individual in group of high hsa and low socially anxious lsa participant we recorded the startle reflex experiment i and analysed event related potential erps experiment ii while they viewed anxious facial expression in the context of chemosensory anxiety signal and chemosensory control stimulus result revealed that n1 p1 and n170 amplitude were larger while late positive potential lpp activity wa smaller for facial expression presented in the context of the anxiety and the chemosensory control stimulus a compared to facial expression without a chemosensory context furthermore hsa participant were highly sensitive to the contextual anxiety signal they showed enhanced motivated attention allocation lpp study ii a well a larger startle response toward face in the context of chemosensory anxiety signal than did lsa participant study i chemosensory context had no effect on emotion regulation and both lsa and hsa participant showed effective emotion regulation study i and ii in conclusion both anxiety and chemosensory sport context stimulus enhanced early attention allocation and structural encoding but diminished motivated attention allocation to the facial expression the current result show that visual and chemosensory information is integrated on virtually all level of stimulus processing and that socially anxious individual might be especially sensitive to chemosensory contextual social information

Title: Effects of appraisal training on responses to a distressing autobiographical event
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Zlomuzica, A.; Cwik, J. C.; Margraf, J.; Shkreli, L.; Blackwell, S. E.; Gladwin, T. E.; Ehring, T.
Abstract: dysfunctional appraisal are a key factor suggested to be involved in the development and maintenance of ptsd research ha shown that experimental induction of a positive or negative appraisal style following a laboratory stressor affect analogue posttraumatic stress symptom this support a causal role of appraisal in the development of traumatic stress symptom and the therapeutic promise of modifying appraisal to reduce ptsd symptom the present study aimed to extend previous finding by investigating the effect of experimentally induced appraisal on reaction to a naturally occurring analogue trauma and by examining effect on both explicit and implicit appraisal participant who had experienced a distressing life event were asked to imagine themselves in the most distressing moment of that event and then received either a positive or negative cognitive bias modification training targeting appraisal cbm app the cbm app training induced training congruent appraisal but group difference in change in appraisal over training were only seen for explicit and not implicit appraisal however participant trained positively reported le intrusion distress over the subsequent week than those trained negatively and lower level of overall posttraumatic stress symptom these data support the causal relationship between appraisal and trauma distress and further illuminate the mechanism linking the two

Title: Efficacy of Cognitive Therapy for Body Dysmorphic Disorder: A Randomized Controlled Pilot Trial
Authors: Ritter, V.; Schuller, J.; Berkmann, E. M.; von Soosten-Hollings-Lilge, L.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: dysfunctional cognitive process and maladaptive interpersonal pattern have been postulated to maintain body dysmorphic disorder bdd the present trial evaluated ct for bdd ct bdd which includes module targeting maladaptive cognitive processing in bdd a well a element of schema therapy related to interpersonal problem we investigated whether a ct bdd is effective a compared with a wait list wl group at week 12 b outcome of ct bdd is maintained at posttreatment and 3 and 6 month follow up and c whether change in shame and insight mediate change in bdd symptom severity forty adult with bdd were randomized to 36 week immediate ct bdd n 21 or to 12 week wl n 19 at week 12 immediate ct bdd wa significantly superior to wl in clinician rated bdd symptom severity insight self reported bdd symptom shame depression general symptomatology and life satisfaction change in outcome were associated with moderate to large effect size at week 12 reduction in shame and increase in insight separately mediated change in bdd symptom severity during treatment at week 12 from baseline to posttreatment significant improvement occurred within ct bdd in clinician rated symptom severity insight depression global functioning self reported bdd symptom shame depression general symptomatology and life satisfaction at posttreatment improvement were associated with large effect size and were maintained at 3 and 6 month follow up preliminary result support the efficacy of ct bdd addressing interpersonal problem in addition to cognitive dysfunction may increase the benefit of cbt for bdd patient

Title: Dysfunctional decision-making in pathological gambling: pattern specificity and the role of impulsivity
Authors: Kraplin, A.; Dshemuchadse, M.; Behrendt, S.; Scherbaum, S.; Goschke, T.; Buhringer, G.
Abstract: dysfunctional decision making in individual with pathological gambling pgs may result from dominating reward driven process indicated by higher impulsivity in the current study we examined 1 if pgs show specific decision making impairment related to dominating reward driven process rather than to strategic planning deficit and 2 whether these impairment are related to impulsivity nineteen pgs according to dsm iv and 19 matched control subject undertook the cambridge gambling task cgt to a decision making the delay discounting paradigm ddp a well a the upps impulsive behavior scale measuring urgency premeditation perseverance and sensation seeking were administered a multidimensional measure of impulsivity result revealed that 1 pgs exhibited higher risk seeking and an immediate reward focus in the cgt and in contrast comparable strategic planning to the control group 2 decision making impairment were related to more severe delay discounting and specifically to increased urgency and le premeditation our finding suggest 1 the necessity to disentangle decision making component in order to improve etiological model of pgs and 2 that urgency and premeditation are specifically related to disadvantageous decision making and should be tackled in intervention strategy focusing on emotion tolerance and control strategy

Title: Emotional neglect in childhood shapes social dysfunctioning in adults by influencing the oxytocin and the attachment system: Results from a population-based study
Authors: Muller, L. E.; Bertsch, K.; Bulau, K.; Herpertz, S. C.; Buchheim, A.
Abstract: early life maltreatment elm is the major single risk factor for impairment in social functioning and mental health in adulthood one of the most prevalent and most rapidly increasing form of elm is emotional neglect according to bio behavioral synchrony assumption the oxytocin and attachment system play an important mediating role in the interplay between emotional neglect and social dysfunctioning therefore the aim of the present study wa to investigate whether fear and avoidance of social functioning two important and highly prevalent facet of social dysfunctioning in adulthood are shaped by emotional neglect plasma oxytocin level and attachment representation we assessed emotional neglect a well a other form of elm with the childhood trauma questionnaire current attachment representation with the adult attachment projective picture system and fear and avoidance of social situation with the liebowitz social anxiety scale in a population based sample of n 121 men and woman furthermore 4 9 ml blood sample were drawn from each participant to a peripheral plasma oxytocin level applying a sequential mediation model result revealed that emotional neglect wa associated with lower plasma oxytocin level which in turn were associated with insecure attachment representation which were related to elevated fear and avoidance of social situation a 1 d 21 b 2 f 3 117 20 84 p 001 plasma oxytocin and current attachment representation hence fully and sequentially mediate the effect of emotional neglect on social fear and avoidance two important facet of adult social dysfunctioning confirming bio behavioral synchrony assumption

Title: Early life maltreatment but not lifetime depression predicts insecure attachment in women
Authors: Zietlow, A. L.; Nonnenmacher, N.; Reck, C.; Mueller, M.; Herpertz, S. C.; Neukel, C.; Fuchs, A.; Bermpohl, F.; Fuehrer, D.; Kluczniok, D.; Attar, C. H.; Jaite, C.; Dittrich, K.; Boedeker, K.
Abstract: early life maltreatment elm pose a risk for the development of insecure attachment and depression over the life span depending on the type of maltreatment physical sexual emotional neglect and it severity the aim of this study wa to investigate the influence of elm and lifetime depression on adult insecure attachment in a female sample n 188 consisting of n 81 woman with elm and n 107 without elm woman with elm reported significantly higher score on insecure attachment than woman without elm a significant interaction effect for elm x lifetime depression wa found contradictory to the hypothesis woman with elm but without lifetime depression scored highest on avoidant attachment differing significantly from woman with elm and lifetime depression even though the severity of elm wa higher among woman with elm and lifetime depression and they experienced significantly more severe neglect and sexual abuse but not physical or emotional abuse regression analysis revealed that elm wa the only predictor of avoidant attachment explaining 15 5 of the variance result underline the strong influence of elm on adult attachment and are of special importance for prevention and intervention program

Title: Effects of Four Different EEG-Neurofeedback Reinforcement Types in Healthy Individuals - A Pilot Study
Authors: Mergl, R.; Karch, S.; Henl, J.; Meindl, D.; Schopf, F.; Szabo, S. I.; Hallweger, P.; Heiler, P.; Maywald, M.; Tschentscher, N.; Allgaier, A. K.; Pogarell, O.
Abstract: eeg neurofeedback eeg nfb is a promising tool for the treatment of depressive disorder however many method for the presentation of neurobiological reaction are available and it is widely unknown which of these feedback option are preferrable moreover the influence of motivation on nfb training success is insufficiently studied this study analyzed the efficacy of a novel eeg protocol fc3 pz based on finding for nfb in depression the role of four feedback option rumination anxiety meditation master moving art from the nfb software brain assistant and motivation in eeg based nfb performance wa studied regarding anxiety and rumination visual feedback wa used to evoke emotion reinforcement both negative and positive operant conditioning wa continuous regarding meditation master visual feedback wa combined with continuous positive reinforcement regarding moving art 20 min calm nature film with neutral character were used both visual and auditive feedback were applied the reinforcement wa positive and continuous 13 healthy participant completed 15 eeg session over four month combining simultaneous frontal aim reduction of theta alpha and high beta activity increase of low and mid beta activity and parietal training aim reduction of theta alpha 1 mid and high beta activity increase of alpha 2 and low beta activity we observed significantly more pronounced percentage change in the expected direction for anxiety than moving art mean difference 3 32 p 0 003 the association between motivation and performance wa non significant based on these result we conclude that feedback with both negative and positive operant conditioning and emotion evoking effect should be preferred

Title: Learning dynamics of electrophysiological brain signals during human fear conditioning
Authors: Sperl, M. F. J.; Wroblewski, A.; Mueller, M.; Straube, B.; Mueller, E. M.
Abstract: electrophysiological study in rodent allow recording neural activity during threat with high temporal and spatial precision although fmri ha helped translate insight about the anatomy of underlying brain circuit to human the temporal dynamic of neural fear process remain opaque and require eeg to date study on electrophysiological brain signal in human have helped to elucidate underlying perceptual and attentional process but have widely ignored how fear memory trace evolve over time the low signal to noise ratio of eeg demand aggregation across high number of trial which will wash out transient neurobiological process that are induced by learning and prone to habituation here our goal wa to unravel the plasticity and temporal emergence of eeg response during fear conditioning to this end we developed a new sequential set fear conditioning paradigm that comprises three successive acquisition and extinction phase each with a novel c c set each set consists of two different neutral face on different background color which serve a c and c respectively thereby this design provides sufficient trial for eeg analysis while tripling the relative amount of trial that tap into more transient neurobiological process consistent with prior study on erp component data driven topographic eeg analysis revealed that erp amplitude were potentiated during time period from 33 60 m 108 200 m and 468 820 m indicating that fear conditioning prioritizes early sensory processing in the brain but also facilitates neural responding during later attentional and evaluative stage importantly averaging across the three c c set allowed u to probe the temporal evolution of neural process response during each of the three time window gradually increased from early to late fear conditioning while long latency 460 730 m electrocortical response diminished throughout fear extinction our novel paradigm demonstrates how short mid and long latency eeg response change during fear conditioning and extinction finding that enlighten the learning curve of neurophysiological response to threat in human

Title: Autonomic responses and neural-cardiac coupling during individually tailored symptom provocation in obsessive-compulsive disorder
Authors: Simon, D.; Kaufmann, C.; Kniesche, R.; Kischkel, E.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: elevated anxiety in obsessive compulsive disorder ocd ha been linked to cortico limbic hyperactivation whereas hyperarousal of the autonomous nerve system an ha inconsistently been found we investigate an functioning during symptom provocation with individually tailored ocd relevant picture in 14 unmedicated patient and 14 control and link it to activation in brain area involved in an regulation in addition to ocd trigger aversive and neutral control stimulus were included both group showed increased skin conductance and heart rate change to aversive control stimulus whereas only patient demonstrated augmented skin conductance response to ocd trigger overall an hyperarousal in patient relative to control wa found at trend level activity in limbic and paralimbic area in ocd patient wa increased to both generally aversive and ocd relevant stimulus whereas dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc hyperactivation covarying with cardiac response in patient but not in control wa present for disorder relevant trigger only despite the small study group these preliminary finding suggest an hyperactivity during ocd symptom provocation that could reflect arousal to the perceived threatening value of ocd trigger and might mediate elevated anxiety

Title: Dealing with feeling: Specific emotion regulation skills predict responses to stress in psychosis
Authors: Lincoln, T. M.; Hartmann, M.; Kother, U.; Moritz, S.
Abstract: elevated negative affect is an established link between minor stressor and psychotic symptom le clear is why people with psychosis fail to regulate distressing emotion effectively this study test whether subjective psychophysiological and symptomatic response to stress can be predicted by specific emotion regulation er difficulty participant with psychotic disorder n 35 and healthy control n 28 were assessed for er skill at baseline they were then exposed to a noise versus no stressor on different day during which self reported stress response state paranoia and skin conductance level scl were assessed participant with psychosis showed a stronger increase in self reported stress and scl in response to the stressor than healthy control stronger increase in self reported stress were predicted by a reduced ability to be aware of and tolerate distressing emotion whereas increase in scl were predicted by a reduced ability to be aware of tolerate accept and modify them although paranoid symptom were not significantly affected by the stressor individual variation in paranoid response wa also predicted by a reduced ability to be aware of and tolerate emotion difference in stress response in the sample were no longer significant after controlling for er skill thus intervention that improve er skill could reduce stress sensitivity in psychosis

Title: Deconstructing Traumatic Mission Experiences: Identifying Critical Incidents and Their Relevance for the Mental and Physical Health Among Emergency Medical Service Personnel
Authors: Behnke, A.; Rojas, R.; Karrasch, S.; Hitzler, M.; Kolassa, I. T.
Abstract: emergency medical service em personnel frequently encounter emotionally stressful or even traumatic incident in their line of duty in this study a checklist of emotionally stressful event for the german em wa introduced a mixed method approach wa used to identify mission event that were critical for the development of mental and physical stress symptom data were collected in a cross sectional sample of 102 em employee a quantitative content analysis of the participant worst experience on duty indicated traumatic mission to be a concatenation of two to five emotionally stressful event rescue mission were experienced a traumatic if i em personnel became victim of attack or threat ii certain circumstance caused them to give up their professional detachment from patient iii em personnel perceived the overall mission a exceptionally tragic in subsequent correlation analysis the corresponding checklist item showed consistent positive association with the post traumatic depressive and physical stress symptom among the study cohort within the exploratory regression the sum score of critical on duty exposure contributed incrementally to the prediction of mental and physical stress symptom when non work related trauma exposure and perceived social support were also considered finding point toward the importance of considering the cumulative burden of critical incident for the long term health of em personnel future research is needed to investigate how on duty trauma affect the social support em personnel received from their work and personal relationship

Title: Event-related brain responses to emotional words, pictures, and faces - a cross-domain comparison
Authors: Bayer, M.; Schacht, A.
Abstract: emotion effect in event related brain potential erps have previously been reported for a range of visual stimulus including emotional word picture and facial expression still little is known about the actual comparability of emotion effect across these stimulus class the present study aimed to fill this gap by investigating emotion effect in response to word picture and facial expression using a blocked within subject design furthermore rating of stimulus arousal and valence were collected from an independent sample of participant modulation of early posterior negativity epn and late positive complex lpc were visible for all stimulus domain but showed clear difference particularly in valence processing while emotion effect were limited to positive stimulus for word they were predominant for negative stimulus in picture and facial expression these finding corroborate the notion of a positivity offset for word and a negativity bias for picture and facial expression which wa assumed to be caused by generally lower arousal level of written language interestingly however these assumed difference were not confirmed by arousal rating instead word were rated a overall more positive than picture and facial expression taken together the present result point toward systematic difference in the processing of written word and pictorial stimulus of emotional content not only in term of a valence bias evident in erps but also concerning their emotional evaluation captured by rating of stimulus valence and arousal

Title: Associated valence impacts early visual processing of letter strings: Evidence from ERPs in a cross-modal learning paradigm
Authors: Bayer, M.; Grass, A.; Schacht, A.
Abstract: emotion effect in event related potential erps during reading have been observed at very short latency of around 100 to 200 m after word onset the nature of these effect remains a matter of debate first it is possible that they reflect semantic access which might thus occur much faster than proposed by most reading model second it is possible that associative learning of a word s shape might contribute to the emergence of emotion effect during visual processing the present study addressed this question by employing an associative learning paradigm on pronounceable letter string pseudowords in a learning session letter string were associated with positive neutral or negative valence by mean of monetary gain loss or zero outcome crucially half of the stimulus were learned in the visual modality while the other half wa presented acoustically allowing for experimental separation of associated valence and physical percept in a test session one or two day later acquired letter string were presented in an old new decision task while we recorded erps behavioural data showed an advantage for gain associated stimulus both during learning and in the delayed old new task early emotion effect in erps were limited to visually acquired letter string but absent for acoustically acquired letter string these result imply that associative learning of a word s visual feature might play an important role in the emergence of emotion effect at the stage of perceptual processing

Title: Cognitive flexibility, heart rate variability, and resilience predict fine-grained regulation of arousal during prolonged threat
Authors: Hildebrandt, L. K.; McCall, C.; Engen, H. G.; Singer, T.
Abstract: emotion regulation in the ongoing presence of a threat is essential for adaptive behavior threatening situation change over time and a a consequence require a fine tuned dynamic regulation of arousal to match the current state of the environment construct such a cognitive flexibility heart rate variability and resilience have been proposed a resource for adaptive emotion regulation especially in a moment to moment fashion nevertheless none of these construct ha been empirically related to the dynamic regulation of arousal a it unfolds over the course of a prolonged threatening episode here we do so by placing participant in a threatening and evolving immersive virtual environment called room 101 while recording their skin conductance subsequently participant rated their subjective arousal continuously over the course of the experience participant who had shown greater cognitive flexibility in a separate task i e fewer task switching cost when switching to evaluating the valence of positive stimulus showed better regulation of physiological arousal skin conductance level during le threatening phase of room 101 individual with higher trait resilience and individual with higher resting heart rate variability showed more regulation in term of their subjective arousal experience the result indicate that emotional cognitive and physiological flexibility support nuanced adaptive regulation of objective and experienced arousal in the ongoing presence of threat furthermore the result indicate that these form of flexibility differentially affect automatic and objective versus reflective and subjective process

Title: Life contexts make a difference: emotional stability in younger and older adults
Authors: Brose, A.; Scheibe, S.; Schmiedek, F.
Abstract: emotional stability a indicated by low affect variability and low affective reactivity to daily event for example tends to increase across the adult life span this study investigated a contextual explanation for such age difference relating affect variability and affective reactivity to age group specific life context a sample of 101 younger and 103 older adult reported daily stressor and negative affect across 100 day compared with younger adult older adult a experienced fewer stressor overall b had le heterogeneous stressor profile and c reported that stressor had le impact on daily routine a expected these contextual factor were relevant for interindividual difference in emotional stability multiple regression analysis revealed that reduced affect variability and affective reactivity in older adult were associated with these age group specific life context moreover matching younger and older adult on the contextual factor to explore the effect of context on age group difference further provided support for the partially contextual explanation of age difference in emotional stability matched subgroup of younger and older adult that were comparable on contextual variable were identified affective variability but not affective reactivity wa more similar in the matched subsamples than in the total sample of younger and older adult we conclude that context in which affective experience emerge require more attention when aiming to explain interindividual and age group difference in emotional stability moreover future study need to disentangle the extent to which context interact with active self regulatory process to shape affective experience across adulthood

Title: The impact of personal relevance on emotion processing: evidence from event-related potentials and pupillary responses
Authors: Bayer, M.; Ruthmann, K.; Schacht, A.
Abstract: emotional stimulus attract attention and lead to increased activity in the visual cortex the present study investigated the impact of personal relevance on emotion processing by presenting emotional word within sentence that referred to participant significant others or to unknown agent in event related potential personal relevance increased visual cortex activity within 100 m after stimulus onset and the amplitude of the late positive complex lpc moreover personally relevant context gave rise to augmented pupillary response and higher arousal rating suggesting a general boost of attention and arousal finally personal relevance increased emotion related erp effect starting around 200 m after word onset effect for negative word compared to neutral word were prolonged in duration source localization of these interaction revealed activation in prefrontal region in the visual cortex and in the fusiform gyrus taken together these result demonstrate the high impact of personal relevance on reading in general and on emotion processing in particular

Title: The impact of different emotional states on the memory for what, where and when features of specific events
Authors: Zlomuzica, A.; Preusser, F.; Totzeck, C.; Dere, E.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: emotion can modulate the encoding and recollection of personal event in the present study we investigated the effect of different emotional state pleasant neutral or anxious on episodic memory formation in a virtual reality vr setting emotional state were induced by pleasant neutral or anxiety inducing movie clip prior to the presentation of specific event in a vr scenario episodic memory performance of healthy participant in whom an anxious emotional state had been induced wa inferior to those of the neutral and pleasant condition in the anxious condition participant were particularly impaired regarding their memory for the location of event a correlational analysis indicated that high level of negative arousal were associated with poor memory for the temporal and spatial context of event in contrast high level of happiness were associated with better memory for the spatial context of event our data provide evidence that emotional arousal can modulate memory for what happened where and when

Title: Increased activation in the bilateral anterior insulae in response to others in pain in mothers compared to non-mothers
Authors: Plank, I. S.; Hindi Attar, C.; Kunas, S. L.; Dziobek, I.; Bermpohl, F.
Abstract: empathy allows u to share emotion and encourages u to help others it is especially important in the context of parenting where child s wellbeing is dependent on their parent understanding and fulfilment of their need to date little is known about difference in empathy response of parent and non parent using stimulus depicting adult and child in pain this study focus on the interaction of motherhood and neural response in area associated with empathy mother showed higher activation to both adult and child in pain in the bilateral anterior insulae key region of empathy for pain additionally mother more strongly activated the inferior frontal superior temporal and the medial superior frontal gyrus difference between adult and child stimulus were only found in occipital area in both mother and non mother our result suggest a stronger neural response to others in pain in mother than non mother regardless of whether the person is a child or an adult this could indicate a possible influence of motherhood on overall neural response to others in pain rather than motherhood specifically shaping child related response alternatively stronger response to others in pain could increase the likelihood for woman to be in a relationship and subsequently to have a child

Title: Electrophysiological evidence for an attentional bias in processing body stimuli in bulimia nervosa
Authors: Mai, S.; Gramann, K.; Herbert, B. M.; Friederich, H. C.; Warschburger, P.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: empirical evidence suggests abnormality in the processing of body stimulus in bulimia nervosa bn this study investigated central marker of processing body stimulus by mean of event related potential in bn eeg wa recorded from 20 woman with bn and 20 matched healthy control while watching and evaluating underweight normal and overweight female body picture bulimic evaluated underweight body a le unpleasant and overweight body a bigger and more arousing a higher p2 to overweight stimulus occurred in bn only in contrast to control no n2 increase to underweight body wa observed in bn p3 wa modulated by stimulus category only in healthy control late slow wave to underweight body were more pronounced in both group p2 amplitude to overweight stimulus were correlated with drive for thinness and body dissatisfaction we present novel support for altered perceptual and cognitive affective processing of body image in bn on the subjective and electrophysiological level

Title: Encoding into Visual Working Memory: Event-Related Brain Potentials Reflect Automatic Processing of Seemingly Redundant Information
Authors: Berti, S.; Roeber, U.
Abstract: encoding and maintenance of information in visual working memory in an s1 s2 task with a 1500 m retention phase were investigated by mean of event related brain potential erps participant were asked to decide whether two visual stimulus were physically identical identity comparison ic task or belonged to the same set or category of equivalent pattern category comparison cc task the stimulus differ with regard to two feature 1 each pattern can belong to a set of either four e 4 or eight e 8 equivalent pattern mirroring difference in the complexity with regard to the representational structure of each pattern i e equivalence set size e 2 the set of pattern differ with regard to the rated complexity memory performance obtained the effect of the task instruction ic versus cc and the e e 4 versus e 8 but not of the rated complexity erps in the retention interval reveal that the stimulus related factor subjective complexity and e affect the encoding of the stimulus a mirrored by the pronounced p3b amplitude in e 8 compared to e 4 pattern importantly these effect are independent of task instruction the pattern of result suggests an automatic processing of the e in the encoding phase

Title: Disentangling the effects of trait and state worry on error-related brain activity: Results from a randomized controlled trial using worry manipulations
Authors: Harpfer, K.; Carsten, H. P.; Lowisch, K.; Westermann, N.; Riesel, A.
Abstract: enhanced amplitude of the error related negativity ern have been suggested to be a transdiagnostic neural risk marker for internalizing psychopathology previous study propose worry to be an underlying mechanism driving the association between enhanced ern and anxiety the present preregistered study focused on disentangling possible effect of trait and state worry on the ern by utilizing a cross sectional observational and a longitudinal randomized controlled experimental design to this end we examined the ern of n 90 student during a flanker task t0 which were then randomly assigned to one of three group worry induction worry reduction passive control group following the intervention participant performed another flanker task t1 to determine potential alteration of their ern manipulation check revealed that compared to the control group state worry increased in the induction but also in the reduction group ern amplitude did not vary a a function of state worry an association of trait worry with larger ern amplitude wa only observed in female furthermore we found larger ern amplitude in participant with a current or lifetime diagnosis of internalizing disorder in summary our finding suggest that the ern seems to be insensitive to variation in state worry but that an elevated ern is associated with the trait like tendency to worry and internalizing psychopathology which is consistent with the notion that the ern likely represents a trait like neural risk associated with anxiety

Title: Generalization of Contextual Fear in Humans
Authors: Andreatta, M.; Leombruni, E.; Glotzbach-Schoon, E.; Pauli, P.; Muhlberger, A.
Abstract: enhanced fear response to cue which were not associated with the threat but share perceptual characteristic with the threat signal indicate generalization of conditioned fear here we investigated for the first time generalization process in contextual fear conditioning thirty two participant were guided through two virtual office acquisition phase mildly painful electric shock unconditioned stimulus u were unpredictably delivered in one office anxiety context ctx but never in the other office safety context ctx during the generalization test participant were guided through ctx ctx and the generalization context g ctx which contained feature of both the ctx and the ctx but no u wa delivered we found successful contextual fear conditioning i e the ctx compared to the ctx elicited potentiated startle response and wa rated with more negative valence higher arousal and higher anxiety importantly implicit and explicit response dissociated in the generalization test thus participant rated the g ctx a more arousing and anxiogenic than the ctx indicating anxiety generalization but they showed enhanced startle response to the ctx only while the g ctx and the ctx did not differ in summary healthy participant on an explicit level responded to the generalization context like to the anxiety context but on an implicit level responded to the generalization context like to the safety context possibly this dissociation suggests distinct and specific generalization process underlying contextual fear

Title: Self-focused attention vs. negative attentional bias during public speech task in socially anxious individuals
Authors: Lin, M.; Wen, X.; Qian, M.; He, D.; Zlomuzica, A.
Abstract: enhanced self focused attention sfa and negative attentional bias nab towards social cue are characteristic hallmark of social anxiety it is essential to investigate these two attentional phenomenon under socially relevant situation using comparable stimulus in the present study individual with high social anxiety hsa n 32 and low social anxiety lsa n 29 were compared according to their attention toward self related stimulus and toward positive neutral and negative feedback related stimulus video stimulus of moving indicator of self anxiety status and positive neutral and negative feedback from an audience were presented during an impromptu speech task high anxiety condition and a re watching phase low anxiety condition eye movement in response to the different stimulus served a readout for attentional preference an interaction effect suggested that the hsa group directed more attention to self related stimulus relative to other stimulus and the lsa group only during the high anxiety condition the lsa group exhibited a general attentional preference toward positive feedback especially during the low anxiety condition meanwhile only the total duration of fixation on positive feedback negatively correlated with subjective anxiety rating our result point to increased sfa rather than nab in hsa individual under social threat

Title: The role of BDNF methylation and Val(66) Met in amygdala reactivity during emotion processing
Authors: Redlich, R.; Schneider, I.; Kerkenberg, N.; Opel, N.; Bauhaus, J.; Enneking, V.; Repple, J.; Leehr, E. J.; Grotegerd, D.; Kahler, C.; Forster, K.; Dohm, K.; Meinert, S.; Hahn, T.; Kugel, H.; Schwarte, K.; Schettler, C.; Domschke, K.; Arolt, V.; Heindel, W.; Baune, B. T.; Zhang, W.; Hohoff, C.; Dannlowski, U.
Abstract: epigenetic alteration of the brain derived neurotrophic factor bdnf gene have been associated with psychiatric disorder in human and with difference in amygdala bdnf mrna level in rodent this human study aimed to investigate the relationship between the functional bdnf val 66 met polymorphism it surrounding dna methylation in bdnf exon ix amygdala reactivity to emotional face and personality trait healthy control hc n 189 underwent functional mri during an emotional face matching task harm avoidance novelty seeking and reward dependence were measured using the tridimensional personality questionnaire tpq individual bdnf methylation profile were ascertained and associated with several bdnf single nucleotide polymorphism surrounding the bdnf val 66 met amygdala reactivity novelty seeking and harm avoidance higher bdnf methylation wa associated with higher amygdala reactivity x 34 y 0 z 26 t 166 3 00 tfce 42 39 p fwe 045 whereby the bdnf val 66 met genotype per se did not show any significant association with brain function furthermore novelty seeking wa negatively associated with bdnf methylation r 19 p 015 and amygdala reactivity r 17 p 028 while harm avoidance showed a trend for a positive association with bdnf methylation r 14 p 066 the study provides first insight into the relationship among bdnf methylation bdnf genotype amygdala reactivity and personality trait in human highlighting the multidimensional relation among genetics epigenetics and neuronal function the present study suggests a possible involvement of epigenetic bdnf modification in psychiatric disorder and related brain function whereby high bdnf methylation might reduce bdnf mrna expression and upregulate amygdala reactivity

Title: Emotions and persecutory ideation in daily life: On the trail of the "chicken and egg" problem
Authors: Krkovic, K.; Clamor, A.; Schlier, B.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: etiological model highlight the importance of emotion for the emergence of persecutory ideation to increase our understanding of their exacerbation we tested whether this process can be explained by a vicious cycle of negative emotion and persecutory ideation in daily life furthermore we examined whether this process differs in people with and without a psychotic disorder by testing a sample of 34 individual with elevated psychotic experience without a diagnosis subclinical sample and a sample of 33 individual diagnosed with schizophrenia spectrum disorder clinical sample in both sample we applied the experience sampling method for 1 week to acquire repeated measure of sadness fear anger shame and persecutory ideation multilevel model showed that all tested negative emotion were associated with persecutory ideation measured at the same time point p 05 in both sample fear predicted subsequent persecutory ideation p 05 there wa a moderating effect between sample and anger and sample and sadness predicting subsequent persecutory ideation p 05 with these association being stronger in the subclinical sample finally persecutory ideation predicted subsequent fear anger sadness and shame p 05 without a moderating effect of the sample hence the result showed an emotion unspecific rather than an emotion specific vicious cycle of negative emotion and persecutory ideation which possibly contributes to symptom exacerbation and maintenance potential difference in mechanism relating to emotion and persecutory ideation before and after the manifestation of the disorder are discussed psycinfo database record c 2020 apa all right reserved

Title: Negative association between depression and diabetes control only when accompanied by diabetes-specific distress
Authors: Schmitt, A.; Reimer, A.; Kulzer, B.; Haak, T.; Gahr, A.; Hermanns, N.
Abstract: evidence of the negative impact of depression on glycaemic control is equivocal and diabetes related distress ha been proposed a potential mediator 466 diabetes patient were cross sectionally assessed for depression center for epidemiologic study depression scale diabetes related distress diabetes distress scale and glycaemic control hba1c we distinguished the association of depression and diabetes distress with glycaemic control using analysis of variance and multiple regression neither patient with depression only nor diabetes distress only differed significantly from control regarding hba1c however hba1c wa substantially increased when both condition were present 9 2 v 8 6 p 0 01 a in previous study we observed a significant association between depression and hyperglycaemia p 0 01 however a mediation analysis revealed that this association in fact depended on the presence of diabetes distress p 0 01 depression seems to be associated with hyperglycaemia particularly when accompanied by diabetes distress suggesting that adjusting clinical procedure regarding diabetes distress may facilitate the identification and care of high risk patient

Title: Frontal EEG asymmetry as predictor of physiological responses to aversive memories
Authors: Meyer, T.; Quaedflieg, C. W.; Giesbrecht, T.; Meijer, E. H.; Abiad, S.; Smeets, T.
Abstract: evidence suggests that asymmetry in frontal electrical activity predicts response to aversive experience such that higher left sided activity might dampen response to trauma reminder we measured frontal asymmetry at rest and during viewing of a trauma film and assessed startle response to film reminder image to explore potential moderator we compared two film study 1 n 64 and modulated reappraisal study 2 n 72 a expected left frontal activation during film viewing predicted dampened response in individual who viewed a staged road accident however this effect tended to be reversed when a genocide documentary wa used in study 2 all participant viewed the genocide film left frontal activity at rest again predicted higher startle response while reappraisal did not moderate the effect thus the type of trauma film play a crucial role in the effect of frontal asymmetry which warrant further critical investigation

Title: Predictors of behavioral avoidance during respiratory symptom provocation
Authors: Benke, C.; Krause, E.; Hamm, A. O.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: excessive anxiety and avoidance during provocation of body symptom are core feature of anxiety related disorder and might contribute to the development and maintenance of these disorder previous study examined psychological anxiety sensitivity fear of suffocation and trait anxiety and biobehavioral breath holding time predictor of reported anxiety during symptom provocation however the role of these predictor on avoidance of feared body symptom remains unclear therefore the present work aimed at investigating the main and interactive effect of psychological and biobehavioral variable in predicting avoidance during provocation of dyspnea that successively increased in severity 28 of 69 participant prematurely terminated the provocation sequence thus preventing further progression of symptom provocation logistic regression revealed that higher anxiety sensitivity and lower breath holding time were significantly associated with avoidance during exposure suffocation fear and trait anxiety were not related to avoidance moreover there wa a significant interaction between breath holding time and anxiety sensitivity in predicting avoidance participant with a lower breath holding time showed more avoidance behavior when reporting high a compared to low anxiety sensitivity the data suggest that anxiety sensitivity and breath holding time increase the risk to show avoidance and thus might contribute to the development and maintenance of anxiety related disorder

Title: Emotion regulation as a moderator of the interplay between self-reported and physiological stress and paranoia
Authors: Krkovic, K.; Krink, S.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: experience sampling method esm study have found an association between daily stress and paranoid symptom but it is uncertain whether these finding generalize to physiological indicator of stress moreover the temporality of the association and it moderating factor require further research here we investigate whether physiological and self rated daily stress predict subsequent paranoid symptom and analyze the role of emotion regulation a a putative moderator we applied esm during 24 h to repeatedly a heart rate self rated stress and subclinical paranoia in a sample of 67 psychosis prone individual a measured with community assessment for psychotic experience cape adaptive and maladaptive emotion regulation wa assessed at baseline with the emotion regulation skill questionnaire ersq e and the cognitive emotion regulation questionnaire cerq linear mixed model were used to analyze the data heart rate b 0 004 p 0 05 and self rated stress b 0 238 p 0 001 predicted subsequent paranoia the reverse effect paranoia a a predictor of subsequent heart rate b 0 230 p 0 615 or self rated stress b 0 009 p 0 751 wa non significant maladaptive emotion regulation wa a significant predictor of paranoia b 0 740 p 0 01 and moderated the path from self rated stress to paranoia b 0 188 p 0 05 but not the path from heart rate to paranoia b 0 005 p 0 09 our finding suggest a one way temporal link between daily stress and paranoia and highlight the importance of emotion regulation a a vulnerability factor relevant to this process

Title: Arousal Predisposition as a Vulnerability Indicator for Psychosis: A General Population Online Stress Induction Study
Authors: Clamor, A.; Warmuth, A. M.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: explanatory model ascribe to arousability a central role for the development of psychotic symptom thus a disposition to hyperarousal i e increased arousal predisposition ap may serve a an underlying vulnerability indicator for psychosis by interacting with stressor to cause symptom in this case ap stress response and psychotic symptom should be linked before the development of a diagnosable psychotic disorder we conducted a cross sectional online study in a population sample n 104 m age 27 7 year sd 11 2 range 18 70 participant rated their ap and subclinical psychotic symptom participant reported their stress level before and after two stress induction including an arithmetic and a social stressor the participant with an increased ap generally felt more stressed however ap wa not associated with the specific stress response a expected positive psychotic symptom were significantly associated with ap but this wa not mediated by general stress level it association to subtle nonclinical psychotic symptom support our assumption that ap could be a vulnerability indicator for psychosis the trait is easily accessible via a short self report and could facilitate the identification of people at risk and be a promising target for early stress management further research is needed to clarify it predictive value for stress response

Title: Multiple extinction contexts modulate the neural correlates of context-dependent extinction learning and retrieval
Authors: Hermann, A.; Stark, R.; Muller, E. A.; Kruse, O.; Wolf, O. T.; Merz, C. J.
Abstract: exposure therapy is a successful treatment for patient with anxiety and fear related disorder extinction of conditioned fear comprises one important mechanism underlying the effect of exposure therapy yet relapse frequently occur in the long term probably related to difficulty in generalizing the extinction of conditioned fear to new context leading to renewal of conditioned fear extinction training in multiple extinction context depicts a promising opportunity to reduce this renewal of conditioned fear however the underlying neural correlate are unknown yet in this functional magnetic resonance imaging study 49 healthy men participated in a fear conditioning paradigm with fear acquisition training in context a on a first day extinction training in a single context b1 or in four different context b1 b4 one day later and fear and extinction recall and reinstatement in context b1 and a novel context c on a third day one week later multiple extinction context led to a stronger differential activation decrease in the hippocampus during extinction learning compared to a single extinction context one week later the multiple context group compared with the single context group showed reduced differential amygdala activation during fear renewal in the novel context c compared with the extinction context b1 furthermore multiple extinction context diminished amygdala activation during a subsequent reinstatement test in context b1 however there were no significant difference in differential conditioned scrs these result indicate that the use of multiple extinction context during extinction training lead to reduced conditioned response in the amygdala hippocampus complex

Title: Facilitating translational science in anxiety disorders by adjusting extinction training in the laboratory to exposure-based therapy procedures
Authors: Hollandt, M.; Wroblewski, A.; Yang, Y.; Ridderbusch, I. C.; Kircher, T.; Hamm, A. O.; Straube, B.; Richter, J.
Abstract: extinction learning is suggested to be a central mechanism during exposure based cognitive behavioral psychotherapy a positive association between the patient pretreatment extinction learning performance and treatment outcome would corroborate the hypothesis indeed there is first correlational evidence between reduced extinction learning and therapy efficacy however the result of these association study may be hampered by extinction training protocol that do not match treatment procedure therefore we developed an extinction training protocol highly tailored to the procedure of exposure therapy and tested it in two sample of 46 subject in total by using instructed fear acquisition training including a consolidation period overnight we wanted to ensure that the conditioned fear response wa well established prior to extinction training which is the case in patient with anxiety disorder prior to treatment moreover the extinction learning process wa analyzed on multiple response level comprising unconditioned stimulus u expectancy rating autonomic response defensive brain stem reflex and neural activation using functional magnetic resonance imaging using this protocol we found robust fear conditioning and slow speed extinction learning we also observed within group heterogeneity in extinction learning albeit a stable fear response at the beginning of the extinction training finally we found discordance between different response system suggesting that multiple process are involved in extinction learning the paradigm presented here might help to ameliorate the association between extinction learning performance assessed in the laboratory and therapy outcome and thus facilitate translational science in anxiety disorder

Title: Face masks impair facial emotion recognition and induce specific emotion confusions
Authors: Rinck, M.; Primbs, M. A.; Verpaalen, I. A. M.; Bijlstra, G.
Abstract: face mask are now worn frequently to reduce the spreading of the sars cov 2 virus their health benefit are undisputable but covering the lower half of one s face also make it harder for others to recognize facial expression of emotion three experiment were conducted to determine how strongly the recognition of different facial expression is impaired by mask and which emotion are confused with each other in each experiment participant had to recognize facial expression of happiness sadness anger surprise fear and disgust a well a a neutral expression displayed by male and female actor of the radboud face database on half of the 168 trial the lower part of the face wa covered by a face mask in all experiment facial emotion recognition fer wa about 20 worse for masked face than for unmasked one 68 correct v 88 the impairment wa largest for disgust followed by fear surprise sadness and happiness it wa not significant for anger and the neutral expression a predicted participant frequently confused emotion that share activation of the visible muscle in the upper half of the face in addition they displayed response bias in these confusion they frequently misinterpreted disgust a anger fear a surprise and sadness a neutral whereas the opposite confusion were le frequent we conclude that face mask do indeed cause a marked impairment of fer and that a person perceived a angry surprised or neutral may actually be disgusted fearful or sad respectively this may lead to misunderstanding confusion and inadequate reaction by the perceiver

Title: The Influence of Task-Irrelevant Flankers Depends on the Composition of Emotion Categories
Authors: Schulte Holthausen, B.; Regenbogen, C.; Turetsky, B. I.; Schneider, F.; Habel, U.
Abstract: face recognition usually take place in a social context where face are surrounded by other stimulus these can act a distracting flanker which impair recognition previous work ha suggested that flanker expressing negative emotion distract more than positive one however the various negative emotion differ in their relative impact and it is unclear whether all negative emotion are equally distracting we investigated the impact of three negative angry fearful sad and one positive happy facial flanker condition on target recognition in an emotion discrimination task we examined the effect of the receiver s gender and the impact of two different temporal delay between flanker and target onset a stimulus onset asynchrony is assumed to affect distractor strength participant identified and rated the emotional intensity of target face surrounded by either face emotional and neutral or non face flanker target face were presented either simultaneously with the flanker or delayed by 300 m contrary to our hypothesis negative flanker did not exert stronger distraction effect than positive or neutral flanker however happy flanker reduced recognition performance result of a follow up experiment with a balanced number of emotion category one positive one negative and one neutral flanker condition suggest that the distraction effect of emotional flanker depends on the composition of the emotion category additionally congruency effect were found to be valence specific and overruled by threat stimulus female responded more quickly and rated target in happy flanker a le intense this indicates a gender difference in emotion processing with greater sensitivity to facial flanker in woman target were rated a more intense when they were presented without a temporal delay possibly due to a stronger flanker contrast these three experiment show that an exceptional processing of threat related flanker stimulus depends on emotion category composition which should be considered a mediating factor when examining emotional context effect

Title: Returning a smile: Initiating a social interaction with a facial emotional expression influences the evaluation of the expression received in return
Authors: Kroczek, L. O. H.; Muhlberger, A.
Abstract: face to face social interaction are characterized by the reciprocal exchange of facial emotion between interaction partner typically facial emotional expression have been studied in passive observation paradigm while interactive mechanism remain unknown in the current study we investigate how sending a facial emotional expression influenced the evaluation of an emotional expression received in return sixty eight participant were cued to direct a facial emotional expression happy angry neutral towards a virtual agent in front of them the virtual agent then responded with either the same or another emotional expression happy angry evaluation of the response expression wa measured via rating of valence and arousal a well a emg recording of the m corrugator supercilii and the m zygomaticus major result revealed a significant interaction between the emotion of the initial facial expression and the response expression valence of happy response expression were increased when participant had initially displayed a smile compared to a neutral expression or a frown this wa also reflected in the emg response initiating an interaction with a smile increased zygomaticus activation for happy relative to angry response expression compared to when the interaction wa initiated with a frown in contrast no interplay of the initial and the response expression wa observed in the corrugator these finding demonstrate that smiling or frowning at another person can modulate socio emotional processing of subsequent social cue therefore the present study highlight the interactive nature of facial emotional expression

Title: Intranasal oxytocin modulates brain responses to voice-identity recognition in typically developing individuals, but not in ASD
