Authors: Borowiak, K.; von Kriegstein, K.
Abstract: face and voice are prominent cue for person identity recognition face recognition behavior and associated brain response can be enhanced by intranasal administration of oxytocin it is unknown whether oxytocin can also augment voice identity recognition mechanism to find it out is particularly relevant for individual who have difficulty recognizing voice identity such a individual diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder asd we conducted a combined behavioral and functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri study to investigate voice identity recognition following intranasal administration of oxytocin or placebo in a group of adult diagnosed with asd full scale intelligence quotient 85 and pairwise matched typically developing td control a single dose of 24 iu oxytocin wa administered in a randomized double blind placebo controlled and cross over design in the control group but not in the asd group administration of oxytocin compared to placebo increased response to recognition of voice identity in contrast to speech in the right posterior superior temporal sulcus gyrus pst g a region implicated in the perceptual analysis of voice identity information in the asd group the right pst g response were positively correlated with voice identity recognition accuracy in the oxytocin condition but not in the placebo condition oxytocin did not improve voice identity recognition performance at the group level the asd compared to the control group had lower right pst g response to voice identity recognition since asd is known to have atypical pst g the result indicate that the potential of intranasal oxytocin to enhance mechanism for voice identity recognition might be variable and dependent on the functional integrity of this brain region

Title: Dorsal-movement and ventral-form regions are functionally connected during visual-speech recognition
Authors: Borowiak, K.; Maguinness, C.; von Kriegstein, K.
Abstract: face convey social information such a emotion and speech facial emotion processing is supported via interaction between dorsal movement and ventral form visual cortex region here we explored for the first time whether similar dorsal ventral interaction assessed via functional connectivity might also exist for visual speech processing we then examined whether altered dorsal ventral connectivity is observed in adult with high functioning autism spectrum disorder asd a disorder associated with impaired visual speech recognition we acquired functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri data with concurrent eye tracking in pairwise matched control and asd participant in both group dorsal movement region in the visual motion area 5 v5 mt and the temporal visual speech area tvsa were functionally connected to ventral form region i e the occipital face area ofa and the fusiform face area ffa during the recognition of visual speech in contrast to the recognition of face identity notably part of this functional connectivity were decreased in the asd group compared to the control i e right v5 mt right ofa left tvsa left ffa the result confirmed our hypothesis that functional connectivity between dorsal movement and ventral form region exists during visual speech processing it partial dysfunction in asd might contribute to difficulty in the recognition of dynamic face information relevant for successful face to face communication

Title: Acute stress enhances the sensitivity for facial emotions: a signal detection approach
Authors: Domes, G.; Zimmer, P.
Abstract: facial emotion recognition is an important prerequisite for social cognition there is however limited evidence on how the ability to detect facial emotion is influenced by acute stress and the associated physiological reaction in this study two group of healthy male participant were either exposed to a psychosocial stressor an adaptation of the trier social stress test in virtual reality n 23 or a non stressful control task in the virtual environment n 20 afterwards both group completed a computerized facial recognition task based on the signal detection theory presenting happy v angry face with three different expression intensity saliva sample were taken at seven time point over the course of the experiment and used to analyze concentration of free salivary cortisol and alpha amylase analysis using repeated measure analysis of variance revealed a significant increase in emotion detection performance and significantly shorter response latency in the stress group independent of emotional valence or emotion intensity however increased task performance in the stress group could not be predicted by stress induced cortisol or alpha amylase secretion the result suggest that enhanced detection of emotional cue after stress might be an adaptive response a an increased sensitivity to social cue might help individual to detect potential threat or source of social support in their social environment lay summary socially evaluative stress facilitates the subsequent recognition of emotion after having performed a task in a virtual environment two group of participant were asked to detect emotion expression on picture of face that were presented to them on a computer screen statistical comparison of group indicates that the group that had previously been subjected to a stressful job interview showed better result and became faster in detecting displayed emotion than the control group that had previously performed a non stressful task

Title: Read My Face: Automatic Facial Coding Versus Psychophysiological Indicators of Emotional Valence and Arousal
Authors: Hofling, T. T. A.; Gerdes, A. B. M.; Fohl, U.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: facial expression provide insight into a person s emotional experience to automatically decode these expression ha been made possible by tremendous progress in the field of computer vision researcher are now able to decode emotional facial expression with impressive accuracy in standardized image of prototypical basic emotion we tested the sensitivity of a well established automatic facial coding software program to detect spontaneous emotional reaction in individual responding to emotional picture we compared automatically generated score for valence and arousal of the facereader fr noldus information technology with the current psychophysiological gold standard of measuring emotional valence facial electromyography emg and arousal skin conductance sc we recorded physiological and behavioral measurement of 43 healthy participant while they looked at pleasant unpleasant or neutral scene when viewing pleasant picture fr valence and emg were both comparably sensitive however for unpleasant picture fr valence showed an expected negative shift but the signal differentiated not well between response to neutral and unpleasant stimulus that were distinguishable with emg furthermore fr arousal value had a stronger correlation with self reported valence than with arousal while sc wa sensitive and specifically associated with self reported arousal this is the first study to systematically compare fr measurement of spontaneous emotional reaction to standardized emotional image with established psychophysiological measurement tool this novel technology ha yet to make stride to surpass the sensitivity of established psychophysiological measure however it provides a promising new measurement technique for non contact assessment of emotional response

Title: Startling similarity: Effects of facial self-resemblance and familiarity on the processing of emotional faces
Authors: Finke, J. B.; Larra, M. F.; Merz, M. U.; Schachinger, H.
Abstract: facial self resemblance ha been associated with positive emotional evaluation but this effect may be biased by self face familiarity here we report two experiment utilizing startle modulation to investigate how the processing of facial expression of emotion is affected by subtle resemblance to the self a well a to familiar face participant of the first experiment i n 39 were presented with morphed face showing happy neutral and fearful expression which were manipulated to resemble either their own or unknown face at soas of either 300 m or 3500 4500 m after picture onset startle response were elicited by binaural burst of white noise 50 m 105 db and recorded at the orbicularis oculus via emg manual reaction time wa measured in a simple emotion discrimination paradigm picture preceding noise burst by short soa inhibited startle prepulse inhibition ppi both affective modulation and ppi of startle in response to emotional face wa altered by physical similarity to the self a indexed both by relative facilitation of startle and faster manual response self resemblance apparently induced deeper processing of facial affect particularly in happy face experiment ii n 54 produced similar finding using morphs of famous face yet showed no impact of mere familiarity on ppi effect or response time either the result are discussed with respect to differential presumably pre attentive effect of self specific v familiar information in face processing

Title: Task-irrelevant fear enhances amygdala-FFG inhibition and decreases subsequent face processing
Authors: Schulte Holthausen, B.; Habel, U.; Kellermann, T.; Schelenz, P. D.; Schneider, F.; Christopher Edgar, J.; Turetsky, B. I.; Regenbogen, C.
Abstract: facial threat is associated with change in limbic activity a well a modification in the cortical face related n170 it remains unclear if task irrelevant threat modulates the response to a subsequent facial stimulus and whether the amygdala s role in early threat perception is independent and direct or modulatory in 19 participant crowd of emotional face were followed by target face and a rating task while simultaneous eeg fmri were recorded in addition to conventional analysis fmri informed eeg analysis and fmri dynamic causal modeling dcm were performed fearful crowd reduced eeg n170 target face amplitude and increased response in a fmri network comprising insula amygdala and inferior frontal cortex multimodal analysis showed that amygdala response wa present approximately 60 m before the right fusiform gyrus derived n170 dcm indicated inhibitory connection from amygdala to fusiform gyrus strengthened when fearful crowd preceded a target face result demonstrated the suppressing influence of task irrelevant fearful crowd on subsequent face processing the amygdala may be sensitive to task irrelevant fearful crowd and subsequently strengthen it inhibitory influence on face responsive fusiform n170 generator this provides spatiotemporal evidence for a feedback mechanism of the amygdala by narrowing attention in order to focus on potential threat

Title: The effect of inherently threatening contexts on visuocortical engagement to conditioned threat
Authors: Stegmann, Y.; Andreatta, M.; Wieser, M. J.
Abstract: fear and anxiety are crucial for adaptive responding in life threatening situation whereas fear is a phasic response to an acute threat accompanied by selective attention anxiety is characterized by a sustained feeling of apprehension and hypervigilance during situation of potential threat in the current literature fear and anxiety are usually considered mutually exclusive with partially separated neural underpinnings however there is accumulating evidence that challenge this distinction between fear and anxiety and simultaneous activation of fear and anxiety network ha been reported therefore the current study experimentally tested potential interaction between fear and anxiety fifty two healthy participant completed a differential fear conditioning paradigm followed by a test phase in which the conditioned stimulus were presented in front of threatening or neutral contextual image to capture defense system activation we recorded subjective threat u expectancy physiological skin conductance heart rate and visuocortical steady state visual evoked potential response to the conditioned stimulus a a function of contextual threat result demonstrated successful fear conditioning in all measure in addition threat and u expectancy rating cardiac deceleration and visuocortical activity were enhanced for fear cue presented in threatening compared with neutral context these result are in line with an additive or interactive rather than an exclusive model of fear and anxiety indicating facilitated defensive behavior to imminent danger in situation of potential threat

Title: No evidence for blocking the return of fear by disrupting reconsolidation prior to extinction learning
Authors: Klucken, T.; Kruse, O.; Schweckendiek, J.; Kuepper, Y.; Mueller, E. M.; Hennig, J.; Stark, R.
Abstract: fear extinction is a central model for the treatment of anxiety disorder initial research ha reported that the single presentation of a conditioned stimulus prior to extinction learning can permanently block the return of fear however only few study have explored this issue and could not always replicate the finding the present study examined human fear extinction using a four day design on the first day two neutral stimulus were paired with electrical stimulation ucs while a third stimulus c wa not twenty four hour later one conditioned stimulus c rem and the c were reminded once 10 min before extinction learning while the other conditioned stimulus c non rem wa not presented prior to extinction learning all stimulus were presented during extinction learning and during two re extinction session 24 h and 6 month after extinction learning without reinforcement blood oxygen level dependent bold response and skin conductance response scrs to both c and the c were explored during acquisition extinction and in both re extinction session regarding scrs the result showed that a single presentation of a conditioned stimulus did not block the return of fear during re extinction fear recovery during re extinction 24 h and 6 month after extinction learning wa observed for both c compared with the c with no difference between c rem and c non rem regarding bold response no significant difference between c rem and c non rem were found in region of interest roi analysis amygdala ventromedial prefrontal cortex during extinction learning and both re extinction session whole brain analysis showed increased bold response to the c non rem a compared to the c rem in several region e g middle frontal gyrus during extinction learning and re extinction 24 h after extinction learning the present finding suggest that the effect of preventing the return of fear by disrupting reconsolidation seems to be a more labile phenomenon than previously assumed possible boundary condition and implication are discussed

Title: Hear it, fear it: Fear generalizes from conditioned pictures to semantically related sounds
Authors: Gerdes, A. B. M.; Fraunfelter, L.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: fear generalization is thought to be an important mechanism in the acquisition and maintenance of anxiety disorder previous study have investigated fear generalization within one sensory modality mainly within the visual domain however a growing body of evidence show that emotional information is processed in more than one sensory modality based on network theory we expected that fear may also generalize from stimulus in one sensory modality to another to test our hypothesis 42 participant underwent a differential conditioning paradigm during which picture were either presented with vcs or without vcs an aversive electric stimulus after the acquisition phase generalization wa tested in the crossmodal group n 21 by presenting sound which were semantically congruent to the visual vcs i e the ag or the vcs i e the ag a a control the unimodal group n 21 saw the picture again for the crossmodal group we could show that u expectancy rating generalized from conditioned picture vcs to semantically related sound ag moreover when the vcs wa presented during extinction fear of the ag extinguished whereas extinction training with the ag wa found to be le effective for the vcs the finding are relevant for crossmodal fear acquisition and exposure therapy

Title: Individual differences in neural correlates of fear conditioning as a function of 5-HTTLPR and stressful life events
Authors: Klucken, T.; Alexander, N.; Schweckendiek, J.; Merz, C. J.; Kagerer, S.; Osinsky, R.; Walter, B.; Vaitl, D.; Hennig, J.; Stark, R.
Abstract: fear learning is a crucial process in the pathogeneses of psychiatric disorder which highlight the need to identify specific factor contributing to interindividual variation we hypothesized variation in the serotonin transporter gene 5 httlpr and stressful life event sle to be associated with neural correlate of fear conditioning in a sample of healthy male adult n 47 subject were exposed to a differential fear conditioning paradigm after being preselected regarding 5 httlpr genotype and sle individual difference in brain activity a measured by functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri skin conductance response and preference rating were assessed we report significant variation in neural correlate of fear conditioning a a function of 5 httlpr genotype specifically the conditioned stimulus c elicited elevated activity within the fear network amygdala insula thalamus occipital cortex in subject carrying two copy of the 5 httlpr s allele moreover our result revealed preliminary evidence for a significant gene by environment interaction such a homozygous carrier of the 5 httlpr s allele with a history of sle demonstrated elevated reactivity to the c in the occipital cortex and the insula our finding contribute to the current debate on 5 httlpr x sle interaction by investigating crucial alteration on an intermediate phenotype level which may convey an elevated vulnerability for the development of psychopathology

Title: Noradrenergic stimulation increases fear memory expression
Authors: Kausche, F. M.; Zerbes, G.; Kampermann, L.; Muller, J. C.; Wiedemann, K.; Buchel, C.; Schwabe, L.
Abstract: fear response are typically not limited to the actual threatening stimulus but generalize to other stimulus resembling the threatening stimulus although this fear generalization is generally adaptive fear overgeneralization is maladaptive and assumed to contribute to anxiety disorder despite the clinical relevance of fear over generalization how the extent of fear generalization is modulated remains not well understood based on the known effect of stress on learning and memory we tested here the impact of major stress mediator glucocorticoid and noradrenergic arousal on fear generalization in a laboratory based placebo controlled double blind between subject design 125 healthy participant first underwent a fear conditioning procedure about 24 h later participant received orally either a placebo hydrocortisone the alpha2 adrenoceptor antagonist yohimbine leading to increased noradrenergic stimulation or both drug before a test of fear generalization skin conductance response a well a explicit rating data revealed that yohimbine intake led to enhanced fear memory expression i e an enhanced responding to the c but not to stimulus resembling the c moreover neither enhanced safety learning nor a mere enhancement of perceptual discrimination ability could explain this result in contrast to yohimbine hydrocortisone had no significant effect on fear memory these finding suggest that noradrenergic arousal strengthens fear memory expression and have important implication for mental disorder in which the overgeneralization of conditioned fear is prominent

Title: Effects of intranasal insulin as an enhancer of fear extinction: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled experimental study
Authors: Ferreira de Sa, D. S.; Romer, S.; Bruckner, A. H.; Issler, T.; Hauck, A.; Michael, T.
Abstract: fear extinction based psychotherapy exposure is the most effective method for treating anxiety disorder notwithstanding since some patient show impairment in the unlearning of fear and insufficient fear remission there is a growing interest in using cognitive enhancer a adjuvant to exposure a insulin play a critical role in stress process and act a a memory enhancer this study aimed to a the capacity of intranasal insulin to augment fear extinction a double blind placebo controlled differential fear conditioning paradigm wa conducted in 123 healthy participant 63 female picture of face with neutral expression were used a conditioned stimulus and electric shock a unconditioned stimulus the paradigm consisted of four phase presented on three consecutive day acquisition day 1 extinction day 2 reinstatement and re extinction day 3 a single intranasal dose of insulin 160 iu or placebo wa applied on day 2 45 min before fear extinction skin conductance response scr fear potentiated startle fps and expectancy rating were assessed during extinction the insulin group independent of sex showed a significantly stronger decrease in differential fps in comparison with the placebo group furthermore a sex specific effect wa found for scr with woman in the insulin group showing a greater decrease of differential scr both at early extinction and at late re extinction our result provide first evidence that intranasal insulin facilitates fear extinction process and is therefore a promising adjuvant for extinction based therapy in anxiety and related disorder sex specific effect should be taken into consideration in future study

Title: Supracategorical fear information revealed by aversively conditioning multiple categories
Authors: Levine, S. M.; Kumpf, M.; Rupprecht, R.; Schwarzbach, J. V.
Abstract: fear generalization is a critical function for survival in which an organism extract information from a specific instantiation of a threat e g the western diamondback rattlesnake in my front yard on sunday and learns to fear and accordingly respond to pertinent higher order information e g snake live in my yard previous work investigating fear conditioning in human ha used functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri to demonstrate that activity pattern representing stimulus from an aversively conditioned category c are more similar to each other than those of a neutral category c here we used fmri and multiple aversively conditioned category to ask whether we would find only similarity increase within the c category or also similarity increase between the c category using representational similarity analysis we correlated several model to activity pattern underlying different brain region and found that following fear conditioning between category and within category similarity increased for the c category in the insula superior frontal gyrus sfg and the right temporal pole when specifically investigating fear generalization these between and within category effect were detected in the sfg these result advance prior pattern based neuroimaging work by exploring the effect of aversively conditioning multiple category and indicate an extended role for such region in potentially representing supracategorical information during fear learning

Title: Self-compassion buffers the link between self-criticism and depression in trauma-exposed firefighters
Authors: Kaurin, A.; Schonfelder, S.; Wessa, M.
Abstract: firefighter are frequently exposed to highly stressful potentially traumatic event ptes more than 50 however show no significant elevation in trauma related symptomatology e g depression in the past self compassion ha been discussed to promote psychological and behavioral flexibility that is vital to a successful adaptation to ptes the goal of this study wa to understand whether and how self compassion may alleviate personal suffering in the face of ptes we hypothesized that individual who encounter their profession related affective experience with greater self compassion show lower level of depressive symptom because self compassion buffer process that perpetuate negative affectivity in response to ptes i e self critical tendency male firefighter n 123 completed self report questionnaire about the severity of current depressive symptom prior traumatic duty related event and the self compassion scale that a two distinct factor self criticism and self compassion a stepwise regression model wa employed to examine differential and interactive contribution of self criticism and self compassion to symptom of depression across the cumulative range of exposure to ptes our result indicate that the positive association between self criticism and depression is buffered by enhanced level of self compassion this moderation however only emerged for firefighter with substantial amount of ptes experience in the past the present work provides insight into protective effect of self compassion in the face of cumulative ptes it suggests that particularly for severely trauma exposed firefighter self compassion may confer resilience that is act a a protective factor from the development of depressive symptom finding are discussed in light of counseling implication psycinfo database record

Title: Retronasal testing of olfactory function: an investigation and comparison in seven countries
Authors: Croy, I.; Hoffmann, H.; Philpott, C.; Rombaux, P.; Welge-Luessen, A.; Vodicka, J.; Konstantinidis, I.; Morera, E.; Hummel, T.
Abstract: flavor perception is to a large extent determined by olfaction and person who lost their sense of smell consequently complain about strongly reduced enjoyment of food the retronasal olfactory function is especially important for flavor appreciation the aim of this study wa to compare retronasal function across different culture and to develop a test that is applicable across culture identification of 39 retronasal applied odor probe wa tested in a total of 518 participant of seven country 292 of them were healthy and 226 exhibited a smell disorder a retest wa performed with 224 of the healthy participant furthermore all participant were tested for orthonasal threshold identification and discrimination ability significant cultural difference in identification ability were found in 92 of the probe the 20 probe that could be identified above chance in healthy participant of all country and that could differentiate between patient and control were selected for the final retronasal test this test wa well able to differentiate between control and patient in different country and showed a good coherence with the orthonasal test r 0 80 and a good retest reliability r 0 76 furthermore it is age independent the strong cultural difference observed in retronasal identification underline the necessity to develop a culturally independent instrument this retronasal test is easy to apply and can be used across different country for diagnostics and clinical research

Title: "Smile away your cravings" - Facial feedback modulates cue-induced food cravings
Authors: Schmidt, J.; Martin, A.
Abstract: food craving are common experience that precede dysfunctional eating behavior such a overeating and binge eating these craving are often related to negative affect especially in emotional eater recent study have revived interest in a theory on the implicit modulation of affect the facial feedback hypothesis this theory claim that mimic expression influence affective experience given the association between negative affect and food craving facial feedback could provide a mean to reduce or prevent food craving in an experimental study using a read aloud task we examined whether an implicit modulation of facial muscle activity zygomatic muscle smiling ff and corrugator muscle frowning ff would alter food cue induced craving in healthy young woman n 60 we further examined if trait in emotional eating influence the facial feedback effect the activation of the zygomatic muscle prevented the occurrence of food craving after exposure with palatable food cue food craving only increased in the ff group p 0 029 the facial feedback effect wa especially pronounced in emotional eater indicated by a significant moderation p 0 041 in participant with high degree of emotional eating food craving wa reduced in the ff group and amplified in the ff group the result indicate that mimic expression might influence food craving on implicit pathway existing approach that target implicit behavior modification via facial feedback may be transferable to eating behavior these method could potentially help in altering dysfunctional eating associated with food craving especially in individual prone to emotional eating

Title: Can't decide how much to EAT? Effort variability for reward is associated with cognitive restraint
Authors: van den Hoek Ostende, M. M.; Neuser, M. P.; Teckentrup, V.; Svaldi, J.; Kroemer, N. B.
Abstract: food intake is inherently variable and often characterized by episodical restraint or overeating uncontrolled eating such heightened variability in intake ha been associated with higher variability in the brain response to food reward but it is an open issue whether comparable association with elevated variability in reward seeking exist here we assessed whether restraint and uncontrolled eating a marker of trait like variability in eating are associated with higher intra individual variability in reward seeking a captured by a cost benefit paradigm to test this hypothesis 81 healthy overnight fasting participant m bmi 23 0 kg m 2 3 0 completed an effort allocation task eat twice in the eat participant had to exert physical effort to earn monetary and food reward and indicated level of wanting through visual analog scale va a predicted we found that greater trial by trial effort variability wa associated with lower score on cognitive restraint r p 78 0 28 p 011 controlled for average effort in line with previous finding higher wanting variability wa associated with higher bmi r p 78 0 25 p 026 controlled for average effort collectively our result support the idea that higher variability in reward seeking is a potential risk factor for eating beyond homeostatic need since association with variability measure of reward exceeded association with average reward seeking our finding may indicate that variability in the representation of the reward value could be a crucial aspect driving fluctuation in food intake

Title: Lower body weight is associated with less negative emotions in sad autobiographical memories of patients with anorexia nervosa
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Grosse Holtforth, M.; Bents, H.; Herzog, W.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: food restriction and weight loss have been proposed to represent pathogenic mechanism of emotion regulation in anorexia nervosa an however there is a lack of study empirically examining this hypothesis therefore the present study compared 25 woman with an and 25 healthy control woman hc regarding spontaneous emotional processing of autobiographic memory participant idiographic memory of sad autobiographic event were analyzed using computerized quantitative text analysis a an unobtrusive approach of nonreactive assessment compared to hc an patient retrieved more negative but a comparable number of positive emotion moreover the lesser the body weight in an patient the lesser negative emotion they retrieved irrespective of current level of depressive symptom and duration of illness no such association wa found in hc these preliminary finding are in line with model of an proposing that food restriction and weight loss may be negatively reinforced by the alleviation of aversive emotional response

Title: Stick with your group: young children's attitudes about group loyalty
Authors: Misch, A.; Over, H.; Carpenter, M.
Abstract: for adult loyalty to the group is highly valued yet little is known about how child evaluate loyalty we investigated child s attitude about loyalty in a third party context in the first experiment 4 and 5 year old watched a video of two group competing two member of the losing group then spoke the disloyal individual said she wanted to win and therefore would join the other group the loyal individual said she also wanted to win but would stay with her group child were then asked five forced choice question about these two individual niceness trustworthiness morality and deservingness of a reward the 5 year old preferred the loyal person across all question result for the 4 year old were considerably weaker but in the same direction the second experiment investigated the direction of the effect in 5 year old in this experiment child answered question about either a loyal individual a disloyal individual or a neutral individual child rated both the loyal and neutral individual more positively than the disloyal individual across a number of measure thus whereas disloyal behavior is evaluated unfavorably by child loyal behavior is the expected norm these result suggest that at least from 5 year of age child understand that belonging to a group entail certain commitment this mark an important step in their own ability to negotiate belonging and become trustworthy and reliable member of their social group

Title: Dominance of texture over shape in facial identity processing is modulated by individual abilities
Authors: Itz, M. L.; Golle, J.; Luttmann, S.; Schweinberger, S. R.; Kaufmann, J. M.
Abstract: for face recognition observer utilize both shape and texture information here we investigated the relative diagnosticity of shape and texture for delayed matching of familiar and unfamiliar face experiment 1 and identifying familiar and newly learned face experiment 2 within each familiarity condition pair of 3d captured face were morphed selectively in either shape or texture in 20 step holding the respective other dimension constant we also assessed participant individual face processing skill via the bielefelder famous face test bfft the glasgow face matching test and the cambridge face memory test cfmt using multilevel model analysis we examined probability of same versus different response experiment 1 and of original identity versus other unknown identity response experiment 2 overall texture wa more diagnostic than shape for both delayed matching and identification particularly so for familiar face on top of these overall effect above average bfft performance wa associated with enhanced utilization of texture in both experiment furthermore above average cfmt performance coincided with slightly reduced texture dominance in the delayed matching task experiment 1 and stronger sensitivity to morph based change overall that is irrespective of morph type in the face identification task experiment 2 our finding 1 show the disproportionate importance of texture information for processing familiar face identity and 2 provide further evidence that familiar and unfamiliar face identity perception are mediated by different underlying process

Title: Emotional sounds guide visual attention to emotional pictures: An eye-tracking study with audio-visual stimuli
Authors: Gerdes, A. B. M.; Alpers, G. W.; Braun, H.; Kohler, S.; Nowak, U.; Treiber, L.
Abstract: for the realm of visual cue it ha been well documented that attention is preferentially oriented toward emotionally relevant cue preliminary evidence suggests that emotional cue from other sensory modality may also steer visual attention toward emotional picture however more research is needed to elucidate the mechanism that are involved therefore a novel design wa used to investigate whether emotional sound promote attentional orientation toward emotional picture to this end 48 participant viewed pair of picture with either neutral or unpleasant content in a free viewing paradigm in addition neutral or unpleasant sound were presented either on the left hand or on the right hand side of the monitor eye movement were recorded a an index of visual spatial attention toward the picture most interestingly position and valence of the sound independently modulated visual orienting towards unpleasant picture for initial capture and sustained attention orienting towards unpleasant picture wa significantly enhanced when any sound wa heard on the same side a the unpleasant picture in addition unpleasant sound irrespective of the side boosted leftward bias of initial attention toward emotionally congruent picture taken together this study clearly show that emotional auditory cue guide visual spatial allocation of attention specifically to emotionally congruent picture psycinfo database record c 2021 apa all right reserved

Title: Differential Associations Among PTSD and Complex PTSD Symptoms and Traumatic Experiences and Postmigration Difficulties in a Culturally Diverse Refugee Sample
Authors: Hecker, T.; Huber, S.; Maier, T.; Maercker, A.
Abstract: forced migration is one of the major challenge currently facing the international community many refugee have been affected by traumatic experience at home and during their flight putting them at a heightened risk of developing trauma related disorder the new version of the international classification of disease icd 11 introduced two sibling disorder posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd and complex ptsd cptsd so far little is known about risk and protective factor in refugee that are specifically associated with the disturbance in self organization dso characteristic of cptsd in this study we aimed to investigate the association between ptsd and dso symptom and traumatic experience postmigration difficulty and social support in a culturally diverse sample of refugee who resettled in switzerland a total of 94 refugee 85 1 male m age 31 60 year sd 10 14 range 18 61 year participated in this study trained assessor performed either guided questionnaire assessment or structured interview in our advice and help seeking sample 32 9 of individual suffered from ptsd and 21 3 from cptsd after controlling for potential gender difference we found positive association between ptsd symptom and trauma exposure beta 22 a well a between dso symptom and postmigration living difficulty beta 42 and lack of social support beta 22 our finding support the notion that it is highly important to consider differential association among ptsd and dso symptom and risk and protective factor to gain a deeper understanding of the trauma related problem refugee face

Title: Frontal alpha asymmetry in OCD patients and unaffected first-degree relatives
Authors: Grutzmann, R.; Riesel, A.; Klawohn, J.; Heinzel, S.; Kaufmann, C.; Bey, K.; Lennertz, L.; Wagner, M.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: frontal electroencephalographic alpha asymmetry a an indicator of trait approach and trait inhibition system ha previously been studied in individual with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd with mixed result we explored frontal alpha asymmetry a a possible risk factor in ocd by investigating a large sample of ocd patient n 113 healthy control participant n 113 and unaffected 1st degree relative of ocd patient n 37 additionally the relationship between ocd symptom dimension and frontal alpha asymmetry wa explored ocd patient and healthy control participant did not differ in alpha asymmetry score hence the current result do not support the notion that ocd a a diagnostic entity is associated with a shift in frontal cortical activity furthermore alpha asymmetry score were not statistically related to specific ocd symptom dimension reason for inconsistent result in ocd are discussed and should be explored in future study compared to ocd patient and healthy control participant unaffected 1st degree relative of ocd patient showed increased left frontal activity such asymmetry ha previously been found to be associated with positive affect and adaptive emotion regulation under stress because stressful life event play an important role in the onset and exacerbation of ocd increased left frontal activity might serve a a resilience factor in unaffected 1st degree relative future study should follow up on these result with longitudinal risk study and pre and posttherapy assessment to further explore causality of this putative factor psycinfo database record

Title: Role of the ventral striatum in developing anorexia nervosa
Authors: Fladung, A. K.; Schulze, U. M.; Scholl, F.; Bauer, K.; Gron, G.
Abstract: functional imaging data in adult patient with anorexia nervosa an support a dysfunctional signal in the ventral striatum a neural signature of an in the present study development of this signal wa investigated with the prediction that a characteristic pattern of ventral striatal signalling will be shown in response to cue associated with food restriction that reflects the evolvement of starvation dependence over time the signal wa assessed in adolescent patient with an whose duration of illness wa about five time shorter relative to the adult sample during functional magnetic resonance imaging subject were required to estimate weight of body image underweight normal weight overweight and to process each stimulus in a self referring way relative to age matched young healthy control underweight stimulus were already associated with greater activity of the ventral striatum and processing of normal weight stimulus elicited already reduced signalling subjective preference showed exactly the same pattern of result relative to adult an the present data reveal a developing dysfunctional signal that if untreated will essentially contribute to the maintenance of an we discus putative mechanism that may play a crucial role in the development of an and also deduce new hypothesis about the involvement of the midbrain dopamine system of which illness related alteration may contribute to the development of an

Title: The Design Matters: How to Detect Neural Correlates of Baby Body Odors
Authors: Schafer, L.; Hummel, T.; Croy, I.
Abstract: functional magnetic resonance imaging of body odor is challenging due to methodological obstacle of odor presentation in the scanner and low intensity of body odor hence few imaging study investigated neural response to body odor those differ in design characteristic and have shown varying result evidence on central processing of baby body odor ha been scarce but might be important in order to detect neural correlate of bonding in mother a suitable paradigm for investigating perception of baby body odor ha still to be established we compared neural response to baby body odor in a new to a conventional block design in a sample of ten normosmic mother for the new short design 6 s of continuous odor presentation were followed by 19 s baseline and 13 repetition were performed for the conventional long design 15 s of pulsed odor presentation were followed by 30 s of baseline and eight repetition were performed neural response were observed in brain structure related to basal and higher order olfactory processing such a insula orbitofrontal cortex and amygdala neural response following the short design were significantly higher in comparison to the long design this effect wa based on higher number of repetition but affected olfactory area differently the bold signal in the primary olfactory structure wa enhanced by short and continuous stimulation secondary structure did profit from longer stimulation with many repetition the short design is recommended a a suitable paradigm in order to detect neuronal correlate of baby body odor

Title: Making sense of what you sense: Disentangling interoceptive awareness, sensibility and accuracy
Authors: Forkmann, T.; Scherer, A.; Meessen, J.; Michal, M.; Schachinger, H.; Vogele, C.; Schulz, A.
Abstract: garfinkel and critchley 2013 recently proposed a three level model of interoception only few study however have empirically tested this theoretical model thus far the present study aimed at investigating 1 the central assumption of this model i e that accuracy sensibility and awareness are distinguishable facet of interoception and that interoceptive accuracy is the basic level of interoception and 2 whether cardiovascular activation a indexed by heart rate is differentially related to the three facet of interoception analysis were conducted on a total sample of n 159 healthy participant 118 female 74 2 mean age 23 9years sd 3 3 range 19 45 who performed either the heartbeat tracking task the heartbeat discrimination task or both the result suggest that accuracy sensibility and awareness are empirically distinct facet of interoception showing no correlation when based on heartbeat tracking but moderate correlation when based on heartbeat discrimination the assumption that interoceptive accuracy is the basic level of interoception could only be partially confirmed instead we conclude that the level of objective physiological state should be considered a the most basic level of interoceptive signal processing

Title: What's in a gaze, what's in a face?: The direct gaze effect can be modulated by emotion expression
Authors: Pittig, R.; van der Wel, Rprd; Welsh, T. N.; Bockler, A.
Abstract: gaze direction and emotion expression are salient facial feature that facilitate social interaction previous study addressed how gaze direction influence the evaluation and recognition of emotion expression but few have tested how emotion expression influence attentional processing of direct versus averted gaze face the present study examined whether the prioritization of direct gaze toward the observer relative to averted gaze away from the observer is modulated by the emotional expression of the observed face participant identified target presented on the forehead of one of four face in a 2 x 2 design gaze direction direct averted motion sudden static emotion expression of the face neutral angry fearful happy disgusted differed across participant direct gaze effect emerged response time were shorter for target on direct gaze than on averted gaze face this direct gaze effect wa enhanced in angry face approach oriented and reduced in fearful face avoidance oriented weaker approach and avoidance oriented expression happy and disgusted did not modulate the direct gaze effect these finding suggest that the context of facial emotion expression influence attentional processing psycinfo database record c 2023 apa all right reserved

Title: Intelligence is associated with the modular structure of intrinsic brain networks
Authors: Hilger, K.; Ekman, M.; Fiebach, C. J.; Basten, U.
Abstract: general intelligence is a psychological construct that capture in a single metric the overall level of behavioural and cognitive performance in an individual while previous research ha attempted to localise intelligence in circumscribed brain region more recent work focus on functional interaction between region however even though brain network are characterised by substantial modularity it is unclear whether and how the brain s modular organisation is associated with general intelligence modelling subject specific brain network graph from functional mri resting state data n 309 we found that intelligence wa not associated with global modularity feature e g number or size of module or the whole brain proportion of different node type e g connector hub or provincial hub in contrast we observed characteristic association between intelligence and node specific measure of within and between module connectivity particularly in frontal and parietal brain region that have previously been linked to intelligence we propose that the connectivity profile of these region may shape intelligence relevant aspect of information processing our data demonstrate that not only region specific difference in brain structure and function but also the network topological embedding of fronto parietal a well a other cortical and subcortical brain region is related to individual difference in higher cognitive ability i e intelligence

Title: Individual patterns of visual exploration predict the extent of fear generalization in humans
Authors: Reutter, M.; Gamer, M.
Abstract: generalization of fear is considered an important mechanism contributing to the etiology and maintenance of anxiety disorder although previous study have identified the importance of stimulus discrimination for fear generalization it is still unclear to what degree overt attention to relevant stimulus feature might mediate it magnitude to test the prediction that visual preference for distinguishing stimulus aspect are associated with reduced fear generalization we developed a set of facial stimulus that wa meticulously manipulated such that pair of face could either be distinguished by looking into the eye or into the region around mouth and nose respectively these pair were then employed a c and c in a differential fear conditioning paradigm followed by a generalization test with morphs in step of 20 shock expectancy rating indicated a moderately curved fear generalization gradient that is typical for healthy sample but it shape wa altered depending on individual attentional deployment particpants who dwelled on the distinguishing facial feature faster and for longer period of time exhibited le fear generalization although both pupil and heart rate response also showed a generalization gradient with pupil diameter and heart rate deceleration increasing a a function of threat these response were not significantly related to visual exploration in total the current result indicate that the extent of explicit fear generalization depends on individual pattern of attentional deployment future study evaluating the efficacy of perceptual training that aim to augment stimulus discriminability in order to reduce over generalization seem desirable psycinfo database record c 2022 apa all right reserved

Title: Comorbid Depression and Diabetes Are Associated with Impaired Health-Related Quality of Life in Chronic Kidney Disease Patients
Authors: Wirkner, J.; Scheuch, M.; Dabers, T.; Freiin von Rheinbaben, S.; Fiene, B.; Aymanns, S.; Endlich, K.; Endlich, N.; Lendeckel, U.; Rettig, R.; Grabe, H. J.; Stracke, S.
Abstract: given the increasing prevalence of chronic kidney disease ckd and it impact on health care it is important to better understand the multiple factor influencing health related quality of life hrqol particularly since they have been shown to affect ckd outcome determinant of hrqol a measured by the validated kidney disease quality of life questionnaire kdqol and the patient health questionnaire depression screener phq 9 were assessed in a routine ckd patient sample the greifswald approach to individualized medicine gani_med renal cohort n 160 including a wide range of self reported data sociodemographic and laboratory measure compared to the general population ckd patient had lower hrqol index dialysis wa associated with 1 low level of physical functioning 2 increased impairment by symptom and problem and 3 more effect and burden of kidney disease hrqol is seriously affected in ckd patient however impairment were found irrespective of egfr decline and albuminuria rather the comorbid condition of depression and diabetes predicted a lower hrqol physical component score further study should address whether recognizing and treating depression may not only improve hrqol but also promote survival and lower hospitalization rate of ckd patient

Title: Mental health stigma and professional help-seeking attitudes a comparison between Cuba and Germany
Authors: Nohr, L.; Lorenzo Ruiz, A.; Sandoval Ferrer, J. E.; Buhlmann, U.
Abstract: globally the burden due to mental disorder is continuously increasing still professional help seeking behavior is not fully understood to conceive cultural determinant of help seeking is crucial to reduce personal and social cost of untreated mental disorder the current study investigates mental health stigma and help seeking attitude in a cuban n 195 and a german n 165 sample in a questionnaire survey we asked for attitude towards mental illness and professional help seeking in the general cuban and german population the cultural context wa associated with mental health stigma and professional help seeking attitude interestingly cuban participant reported stronger mental health stigma and more willingness to seek help in multiple hierarchical regression analysis community attitude towards the mentally ill significantly predicted help seeking attitude especially in the cuban sample only in the german sample more negative individual belief about mental illness predicted more self stigma on help seeking beyond that cultural context moderated the association between mental health stigma and help seeking attitude with a stronger association between the measure in the german sample however gender did not predict help seeking attitude and self stigma on help seeking and no interaction between community attitude cultural context and gender were found in the prediction of help seeking attitude similarity and difference between the sample are discussed in the light of the cultural context and peculiarity of the current sample concluding implication of the current finding are reviewed

Title: I won't tell: Young children show loyalty to their group by keeping group secrets
Authors: Misch, A.; Over, H.; Carpenter, M.
Abstract: group loyalty is highly valued however little is known about young child s loyal behavior this study tested whether 4 and 5 year old n 96 remain loyal to their group even when betraying it would be materially advantageous child and four puppet were allocated to novel group two of these puppet either in group or out group member then told child a group secret and urged them not to disclose the secret another puppet not assigned to either group then bribed child with sticker to tell the secret across age child were significantly le likely to reveal the secret in the in group condition than in the out group condition thus even young child are willing to pay a cost to be loyal to their group

Title: Elevated hair cortisol levels in chronically stressed dementia caregivers
Authors: Stalder, T.; Tietze, A.; Steudte, S.; Alexander, N.; Dettenborn, L.; Kirschbaum, C.
Abstract: hair cortisol concentration hcc are assumed to reflect integrated long term cortisol level and have been proposed a a promising endocrine marker of chronic psychological stress the current study examined hcc in relation to caregiving burden a well established naturalistic model of chronic stress in human hcc and relevant psychosocial data were examined in 20 caregiver of relative with dementia and 20 non caregiver control matched for age and sex result revealed elevated hcc in dementia caregiver compared to non caregiver control f 1 38 4 4 p 04 etap2 10 further within caregiver a trend for a positive association of hcc with self reported caregiving burden r 43 p 058 and a positive association with depressiveness r 48 p 045 were observed no other association between hcc and subjective measure were seen these finding concur with the notion that hcc sensitively capture endocrine aberration in stress exposed group

Title: Mental distress and perceived wealth, justice and freedom across eight countries: The invisible power of the macrosystem
Authors: Scholten, S.; Velten, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: health and well being have been related to macro level factor such a income income inequality or socioeconomic status with regard to the increasing burden of disease due to mental disorder worldwide the association between the macrosystem and mental distress should be further explored too in this context the subjective evaluation of the macrosystem might play an important role in the present exploratory study we assessed symptom of depression anxiety and stress a well a perceived wealth justice and freedom in population based survey in spain france germany poland russia sweden the united kingdom and the united state of america n approximately 1000 per country the swedish sample presented the lowest symptom rating of depression anxiety and stress and the highest self rated health the result also indicated that the subjective evaluation of the macrosystem matter in respect to mental distress the complete model including the control variable country gender age and education and perceived wealth justice and freedom predicted depression anxiety and stress symptom explained 8 of the variance of each symptom cluster the present result encourage research to consider the macrosystem and the subjective evaluation of macro level factor a a relevant component in biopsychosocial model of mental distress

Title: Interoception is associated with heartbeat-evoked brain potentials (HEPs) in adolescents
Authors: Mai, S.; Wong, C. K.; Georgiou, E.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: heartbeat evoked brain potential heps are an index of the cortical reflection of cardiac interoceptive signal study which have examined interoception in adolescent with the use of heps are not known to the author so far this study investigated the function of the hep a a marker of interoception in adolescent eeg and ecg were recorded in 46 adolescent during a resting condition and during a heartbeat detection task participant were asked for confidence in their interoceptive accuracy during heartbeat perception heps appeared during both condition showing maximal activity over frontocentral electrode in the heartbeat condition and highest activity over occipital location in the resting condition interoceptive accuracy iac wa positively associated with the hep at frontocentral location only for the heartbeat condition interoceptive sensibility wa not associated with the hep no significant association between iac and interoceptive sensibility wa revealed our result highlight the relevance of the hep a a neural marker of interoception in adolescent it use a an indicator of vulnerability for affective physical and mental dysfunction during adolescence should be exploited in future study

Title: The causal role of prefrontal hemispheric asymmetry in valence processing of words - Insights from a combined cTBS-MEG study
Authors: Roesmann, K.; Dellert, T.; Junghoefer, M.; Kissler, J.; Zwitserlood, P.; Zwanzger, P.; Dobel, C.
Abstract: hemispheric asymmetry play an important role in multiple cerebral function asymmetry in prefrontal cortex pfc function have been suggested to regulate emotional processing in that right hemispheric dominance bias towards negative affect whereas left pfc dominance favor positive affect this study used transcranial magnetic stimulation to test the causal role of prefrontal asymmetry in the processing of emotional stimulus to experimentally induce hemispheric asymmetry 21 healthy volunteer underwent two separate session of inhibitory continuous theta burst stimulation ctbs to the left versus right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex each stimulation wa followed by magnetoencephalographic meg recording of event related field elicited by visually presented emotional word in a silent reading task and a subsequent behavioral emotion categorization task the asymmetry manipulation influenced valence processing of word in early mid latency and late time interval in right occipitotemporal and parietal brain region left sided ctbs inducing right hemispheric dominance consistently resulted in enhanced brain response to negative word while right sided ctbs inducing left hemispheric dominance enhanced response to positive word on a behavioral level right hemispheric dominance resulted in more categorization match of negative compared to positive word while left hemispheric dominance resulted in reverse effect these result provide direct evidence that bottom up valence processing is influenced by prefrontal hemispheric asymmetry

Title: Measuring extinction learning across the lifespan - Adaptation of an optimized paradigm to closely match exposure treatment procedures
Authors: Adolph, D.; Flasinski, T.; Lippert, M. W.; Pflug, V.; Hamm, A. O.; Richter, J.; Margraf, J.; Schneider, S.
Abstract: here we tested the feasibility of a new paradigm developed to investigate the mechanism of exposure therapy the protocol wa previously developed for the use with adult and optimized to closely model the mechanism underlying exposure i e extinction learning we adapted this paradigm for the use with child and tested it feasibility in child and adult participant we used an aversive acoustic unconditioned stimulus u picture based rating scale and a child oriented instruction practice procedure result indicate robust fear acquisition extinction and reinstatement on a self report u expectancy and on a physiological startle reflex level we found evidence for the paradigm sensitivity to age and anxiety dependent individual difference in fear learning and extinction we conclude that the present paradigm is capable of modeling the key mechanism of exposure therapy that is extinction learning and can be accomplished with child adolescent and adult rendering it promising to bridge the gap between experimental protocol and treatment across the lifespan

Title: Negative reactivity in toddlers born prematurely: indirect and moderated pathways considering self-regulation, neonatal distress and parenting stress
Authors: Voigt, B.; Brandl, A.; Pietz, J.; Pauen, S.; Kliegel, M.; Reuner, G.
Abstract: high negative reactivity in early childhood interferes with later academic and behavioral adjustment thus investigating the origin of high negative affectivity in early childhood is of high relevance for understanding emotional morbidity after preterm birth the present work explored 1 direct prematurity related consequence for negative reactivity 2 self regulatory deficit a a mechanism indirectly relating prematurity to negative affectivity and 3 the implication of the interplay between procedural distress in the neonatal period and parenting stress for preterm child s negative reactivity the sample wa comprised of 146 preterm child very v moderately to late preterm and 86 healthy full term child both free of major neurological impairment assessment involved negative affect and parenting stress parent report 12 24 month corrected age ca effortful control behavioral battery parent report 24 month ca and the number of potentially distressing neonatal intensive care procedure a well a severity of illness during the neonatal period retrospective chart review there wa no direct link from prematurity to a disposition for high negative reactivity in early childhood nor wa prematurity indirectly associated with higher negative reactivity through lower level of effortful control the relation between neonatal pain and distress and negative affectivity depended on the level of parenting stress with low parenting stress at the end of the first year of child s life buffering the negative influence of neonatal distress the present finding underscore the importance of complex interaction among environmental factor in process of emotional plasticity after preterm birth thereby providing critical suggestion for follow up care

Title: Subjective craving and event-related brain response to olfactory and visual chocolate cues in binge-eating and healthy individuals
Authors: Wolz, I.; Sauvaget, A.; Granero, R.; Mestre-Bach, G.; Bano, M.; Martin-Romera, V.; Veciana de Las Heras, M.; Jimenez-Murcia, S.; Jansen, A.; Roefs, A.; Fernandez-Aranda, F.
Abstract: high sugar high fat food are related to binge eating behaviour and especially people with low inhibitory control may encounter elevated difficulty to resist their intake incentive sensitization to food related cue might lead to increased motivated attention towards these stimulus and to cue induced craving to investigate the combined influence of olfactory and visual stimulus on craving inhibitory control and motivated attention 20 healthy control and 19 individual with binge eating viewed chocolate and neutral picture primed by chocolate or neutral odour subjective craving and electroencephalogram activity were recorded during the task n2 and late positive potential lpp amplitude were analysed patient reported higher craving than control subjective craving n2 and lpp amplitude were higher for chocolate versus neutral picture patient showed a higher relative increase in n2 amplitude to chocolate versus neutral picture than control chocolate image induced significant increase in craving motivated attention and measure of cognitive control chocolate odour might potentiate the craving response to visual stimulus especially in patient with binge eating

Title: Fear Extinction Recall Modulates Human Frontomedial Theta and Amygdala Activity
Authors: Sperl, M. F. J.; Panitz, C.; Rosso, I. M.; Dillon, D. G.; Kumar, P.; Hermann, A.; Whitton, A. E.; Hermann, C.; Pizzagalli, D. A.; Mueller, E. M.
Abstract: human functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri and electroencephalography eeg study a well a animal study indicate that the amygdala and frontomedial brain region are critically involved in conditioned fear and that frontomedial oscillation in the theta range 4 8 hz may support communication between these brain region however few study have used a multimodal approach to probe interaction among these key region in human here our goal wa to bridge the gap between prior human fmri eeg and animal finding using simultaneous eeg fmri recording 24 h after fear conditioning and extinction conditioned stimulus presented c e c e and not presented during extinction c n c n were compared to identify effect specific to extinction versus fear recall differential c v c electrodermal frontomedial theta eeg and amygdala response fmri were reduced for extinguished versus nonextinguished stimulus importantly effect on theta power covaried with effect on amygdala activation fear and extinction recall a indicated by theta explained 60 of the variance for the analogous effect in the right amygdala our finding show for the first time the interplay of amygdala and frontomedial theta activity during fear and extinction recall in human and provide insight into neural circuit consistently linked with top down amygdala modulation in rodent

Title: Subjective reward value of visual sexual stimuli is coded in human striatum and orbitofrontal cortex
Authors: Klein, S.; Kruse, O.; Markert, C.; Tapia Leon, I.; Strahler, J.; Stark, R.
Abstract: human neuroimaging research suggests the existence of one core network for the subjective valuation of reward including the striatum and orbitofrontal cortex however there is little research on the neural representation of subjective reward value of visual sexual stimulus v and on the role of these subjective valuation in the development of related addictive behavior here we investigate how neural reactivity to v is connected to individual preference using functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri during the fmri scan 72 men viewed different v film clip rating regarding valence and sexual arousal were collected and used a parametric modulators in the fmri analysis subject also filled out questionnaire on self reported symptom of problematic pornography use ppu firstly we found that neural reactivity towards v clip in the nucleus accumbens caudate nucleus and orbitofrontal cortex wa positively correlated with individual rating of the respective v in all subject second the strength of the association between neural activity and sexual arousal rating wa positively correlated with self reported symptom of ppu the first result suggests a precise appraisal of v according to individual preference in established reward valuation region secondly stronger neural differentiation based on preference in participant with more ppu symptom indicates an increased importance of v preference fit in these individual this heightened correspondence between individual liking and neural activity may facilitate ppu development by increased signaling of incentive salience thus boosting motivation to seek out and respond to these preferred stimulus

Title: Flexibility of error-monitoring in obsessive-compulsive disorder under speed and accuracy instructions
Authors: Riesel, A.; Kathmann, N.; Klawohn, J.
Abstract: hyperactive error monitoring is a robust neurocognitive characteristic in obsessive compulsive disorder ocd yet relatively little is known about the flexibility and potential moderator of error monitoring in ocd the current study investigates error monitoring in 30 healthy participant and 28 patient with ocd using a flanker task in 2 condition either emphasizing speed or accuracy result indicate that no group difference is observable in error related negativity ern under the accuracy focused condition both group show an ern attenuation in the speed condition however this reduction is larger in healthy control leading to pronounced group difference in the speed focused condition similarly receiver operating characteristic analysis yield an area under the curve auc of 62 in the accuracy focused condition whereas under speed instruction an auc of 85 suggests a marked increase in classification accuracy behavioral result and result from a drift diffusion model of decision making indicate a more cautious response strategy and le adaptability to experimental manipulation in ocd overall result suggest that the observed increase in error related neural activity in ocd might stem from a reduced flexibility and diminished ability to disengage from an accuracy oriented error avoidant response style further the present result suggest that emphasizing speed in experimental instruction may lead to a better neural differentiation between patient with ocd and healthy control which ha important implication for the use of the ern a a risk indicator psycinfo database record c 2019 apa all right reserved

Title: Hyperactive performance monitoring as a transdiagnostic marker: Results from health anxiety in comparison to obsessive-compulsive disorder
Authors: Riesel, A.; Goldhahn, S.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: hyperactive error related brain activity ha been found in individual with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd generalized and social anxiety a well a depression and ha been proposed a a transdiagnostic marker the specific phenotype to which it is related is still debated and anxious apprehension threat sensitivity and checking have been proposed a promising candidate to validate the idea that hyperactive performance monitoring is shared by anxiety and anxiety related disorder and to refine our knowledge about it specificity data from further anxiety and anxiety related disorder are required we examined performance monitoring in 24 participant with health anxiety and 24 healthy participant further we compared result to performance monitoring data from 24 patient with ocd taken from a previously published study riesel et al 2014 the three group were matched with regard to age gender and level of education the error related and correct related negativity ern crn derived during a flanker task served a neural indicator of performance monitoring participant with health anxiety showed enhanced ern amplitude compared to healthy control and did not differ from ocd patient in ern the health anxiety and healthy control group did not differ in crn amplitude while ocd patient showed enhanced crn amplitude the result suggest that health anxiety is characterized by hyperactive error monitoring that seems to represent a common information processing dysfunction in health anxiety and ocd this validates the idea that hyperactive error monitoring cut across diagnosis and seems to be a transdiagnostic trait shared by individual that are highly sensitive to the commission of error

Title: Suggested deafness during hypnosis and simulation of hypnosis compared to a distraction and control condition: A study on subjective experience and cortical brain responses
Authors: Franz, M.; Schmidt, B.; Hecht, H.; Naumann, E.; Miltner, W. H. R.
Abstract: hypnosis is a powerful tool to affect the processing and perception of stimulus here we investigated the effect of hypnosis on the processing of auditory stimulus the time course of event related potential erp n1 and p3b amplitude and the activity of cortical source of the p3b component forty eight participant completed an auditory oddball paradigm composed of standard distractor and target stimulus during a hypnosis hyp a simulation of hypnosis sim a distraction dis and a control con condition during hyp participant were suggested that an earplug would obstruct the perception of tone and during sim they should pretend being hypnotized and obstructed to hear the tone during dis participant attention wa withdrawn from the tone by focusing participant attention onto a film in each condition subject were asked to press a key whenever a target stimulus wa presented behavioral data show that target hit rate and response time became significantly reduced during hyp and sim and loudness rating of tone were only reduced during hyp distraction from stimulus by the film wa le effective in reducing target hit rate and tone loudness although the n1 amplitude wa not affected by the experimental condition the p3b amplitude wa significantly reduced in hyp and sim compared to con and dis in addition source localization result indicate that only a small number of neural source organize the difference of tone processing between the control condition and the distraction hypnosis and simulation of hypnosis condition these source belong to brain area that control the focus of attention the discrimination of auditory stimulus and the organization of behavioral response to target our data confirm that deafness suggestion significantly change auditory processing and perception but complete deafness is hard to achieve during hyp therefore the term deafness may be misleading and should better be replaced by hypoacusis

Title: Brain activation during social cognition predicts everyday perspective-taking: A combined fMRI and ecological momentary assessment study of the social brain
Authors: Hildebrandt, M. K.; Jauk, E.; Lehmann, K.; Maliske, L.; Kanske, P.
Abstract: identifying distinct neural network underlying social affect empathy compassion and social cognition theory of mind ha advanced our understanding of social interaction however little is known about the relation of activation in these network to psychological experience in daily life this study n 122 examined the ecological validity of neural activation pattern induced by a laboratory paradigm of social affect and cognition with respect to social interaction in everyday life we used the empatom task a naturalistic video based paradigm for the assessment of empathy compassion and theory of mind and combined it with a subsequent 14 day ecological momentary assessment protocol on social interaction everyday social affect wa predicted by social affect experienced during the empatom task but not by related neural activation in region of interest from the social affect network in contrast everyday social cognition wa predicted by neural activation difference in the medial prefrontal cortex a region of interest from the social cognition network but not by social cognition performance in the empatom task the relationship between medial prefrontal cortex activation and everyday social cognition wa stronger for spontaneous rather than deliberate perspective taking during the empatom task pointing to a distinction between propensity and capacity in social cognition finally this neural indicator of theory of mind explained variance in everyday social cognition to a similar extent a an established self report scale taken together this study provides evidence for the ecological validity of lab based social affect and cognition paradigm when considering relevant moderating factor

Title: Investigating individual stress reactivity: High hair cortisol predicts lower acute stress responses
Authors: Sandner, M.; Lois, G.; Streit, F.; Zeier, P.; Kirsch, P.; Wust, S.; Wessa, M.
Abstract: identifying individual difference in stress reactivity is of particular interest in the context of stress related disorder and resilience previous study already identified several factor mediating the individual stress response of the hypothalamus pituitary adrenal axis hpa however the impact of long term hpa axis activity on acute stress reactivity remains inconclusive to investigate association between long term hpa axis variation and individual acute stress reactivity we tested 40 healthy volunteer for affective endocrine physiological and neural reaction to a modified compact version of the established in mr stress paradigm scanstress scanstress c hair cortisol concentration hcc served a an integrative marker of long term hpa axis activity first the scanstress c version proved to be valid in evoking a subjective endocrine physiological and neural stress response with enhanced self reported negative affect and cortisol level increased heart rate a well a increased activation in the anterior insula and the dorso anterior cingulate cortex dacc second and interestingly result indicated a lower neuroendocrine stress response in individual with higher hcc hcc wa negatively correlated with the area under the curve respect to increase auci of saliva cortisol and with a stress related increase in dacc activity the present study explicitly targeted the relationship between hcc and acute stress reactivity on multiple response level i e subjective endocrine and neural stress response the lower stress reactivity in individual with higher hcc level indicates the need for further research evaluating the role of long term hpa axis alteration in the context of vulnerability or immunization against acute stress and following stress related impairment

Title: Positive facial affect - an fMRI study on the involvement of insula and amygdala
Authors: Pohl, A.; Anders, S.; Schulte-Ruther, M.; Mathiak, K.; Kircher, T.
Abstract: imitation of facial expression engages the putative human mirror neuron system a well a the insula and the amygdala a part of the limbic system the specific function of the latter two region during emotional action is still under debate the current study investigated brain response during imitation of positive in comparison to non emotional facial expression difference in brain activation of the amygdala and insula were additionally examined during observation and execution of facial expression participant imitated executed and observed happy and non emotional facial expression a well a neutral face during imitation higher right hemispheric activation emerged in the happy compared to the non emotional condition in the right anterior insula and the right amygdala in addition to the pre supplementary motor area middle temporal gyrus and the inferior frontal gyrus region of interest analysis revealed that the right insula wa more strongly recruited by i imitation and execution than by observation of facial expression that ii the insula wa significantly stronger activated by happy than by non emotional facial expression during observation and imitation and that iii the activation difference in the right amygdala between happy and non emotional facial expression were increased during imitation and execution in comparison to sole observation we suggest that the insula and the amygdala contribute specifically to the happy emotional connotation of the facial expression depending on the task the pattern of the insula activity might reflect increased bodily awareness during active execution compared to passive observation and during visual processing of the happy compared to non emotional facial expression the activation specific for the happy facial expression of the amygdala during motor task but not in the observation condition might reflect increased autonomic activity or feedback from facial muscle to the amygdala

Title: Decision-making and inhibitory control after smoking-related priming in nicotine dependent smokers and never-smokers
