Authors: Kraplin, A.; Scherbaum, S.; Buhringer, G.; Goschke, T.
Abstract: impaired decision making and inhibitory control are important characteristic of nicotine dependence nd we aimed to test 1 the effect of smoking related priming cue on subsequent decision making and inhibitory control in nd and 2 how these priming effect are related to valence rating nicotine deprivation and craving a sample of 27 smoker with nd according to dsm iv and a control group of 33 never smoker performed an intertemporal choice task and a go no go task before each trial of the task a priming cue appeared that wa either smoking related or neutral valence rating nicotine deprivation and craving were assessed with self report after smoking related compared to neutral prime the nd group exhibited increased delay discounting beta 0 07 95 confidence interval ci 0 01 0 14 and shorter go reaction time beta 0 13 ci 0 32 to 0 01 compared to the never smoker group the speed up in go trial after smoking related compared to neutral cue wa significantly related to more pleasant valence rating beta 0 07 ci 0 01 0 13 a longer time since last cigarette beta 0 17 ci 0 30 to 0 03 and increased craving beta 0 19 ci 0 33 to 0 06 within the nd group we found evidence for small group effect indicating that individual with nd compared to never smoker decide more dysfunctional and react faster after smoking related compared to neutral cue faster reaction after smoking related cue within the nd group especially in state of increased nicotine deprivation and craving without more error could be explained by an increased attentional focus cue induced alteration in decision making and inhibitory control in nd highly depend on the temporal sequence of cue presentation

Title: Learning mechanisms underlying threat absence and threat relief: Influences of trait anxiety
Authors: Andreatta, M.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: impaired safety learning ha been proposed asa risk factor for anxiety disorder but safety can be indicated by either threat absence or threat termination i e relief here we investigated the role of trait anxiety for both kind of safety learning ninety one participant underwent an acquisition phase during which one shape threat c predicted a painful electric shock unconditioned stimulus u one shape relief c followed the u and one shape absence c became never associated with the u in a following extinction phase the three cue were presented again plus a control shape control c we found successful threat conditioning a threat c wa rated a more aversive negative arousing anxiogenic and associated with u than the other cue and it elicited startle potentiation a well asa larger skin conductance response scr safety cue were rated equally positive and non anxiogenic but still lower than control c whereas physiologically relief c elicited stronger appetitive response startle attenuation and low scr than absence c interestingly an increase in trait anxiety wa associated with a decrease in the difference between absence c and threat c response reflected in contingency rating during extinction a well a stronger fear startle response to absence c in sum physiological response but not rating triggered by a relief signal compared to a threat absence signal indicated that the former is more appetitive than the latter strikingly trait anxiety specifically mediated learning of threat absence but not of threat termination indicating that high trait anxious individual experience relief normally but have deficit in identifying signal of threat absence

Title: Mental state decoding and mental state reasoning in recently detoxified alcohol-dependent individuals
Authors: Thoma, P.; Winter, N.; Juckel, G.; Roser, P.
Abstract: impaired social cognition ha been associated with interpersonal problem and with the development of and relapse into alcohol abuse in the present study self reported trait empathy decoding of complex mental state and cognitive and affective mental state reasoning were assessed in alcohol dependent participant and the association with executive function and psychopathological characteristic wa investigated twenty recently detoxified alcohol dependent patient and 20 matched healthy control were assessed with an abbreviated german version of the interpersonal reactivity index the revised reading the mind in the eye test the faux pa story test the trail making test and the letter number sequencing test patient were impaired relative to control with regard to mental state decoding on the eye test and showed reduced faux pa detection and impaired mental state reasoning reflected by lower faux pa understanding and faux pa empathy score there were no group difference regarding self reported trait empathy performance on the sociocognitive measure wa related to executive functioning and the severity of depressive symptom although self report measure might not always reliably detect impairment of social cognition behavioural measure suggest pronounced impairment of mental state decoding and mental state reasoning in association with alcohol dependence finding ought to be incorporated into current treatment strategy

Title: Effect of Developmentally Adapted Cognitive Processing Therapy for Youth With Symptoms of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder After Childhood Sexual and Physical Abuse: A Randomized Clinical Trial
Authors: Rosner, R.; Rimane, E.; Frick, U.; Gutermann, J.; Hagl, M.; Renneberg, B.; Schreiber, F.; Vogel, A.; Steil, R.
Abstract: importance despite the high prevalence evidence based treatment for abuse related posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd in adolescent have rarely been studied objective to examine whether developmentally adapted cognitive processing therapy d cpt is more effective than a wait list condition with treatment advice wl ta among adolescent with ptsd related to childhood abuse design setting and participant this rater blinded multicenter randomized clinical trial stratified by center enrolled treatment seeking adolescent and young adult aged 14 21 year with childhood abuse related ptsd at 3 university outpatient clinic in germany from july 2013 to june 2015 with the last follow up interview conducted by may 2016 of 194 patient 88 were eligible for randomization intervention participant received d cpt or wl ta cognitive processing therapy wa enhanced by a motivational and alliance building phase by including emotion regulation and consideration of typical developmental task and by higher session frequency in the trauma focused core cpt phase in wl ta participant received treatment advice with respective recommendation of clinician and were offered d cpt after 7 month main outcome and measure all outcome were assessed before treatment baseline approximately 8 week after the start of treatment after the end of treatment posttreatment and at the 3 month follow up the primary outcome ptsd symptom severity wa assessed in clinical interview clinician administered ptsd scale for child and adolescent for dsm iv cap ca secondary outcome were self reported ptsd severity depression borderline symptom behavior problem and dissociation result the 88 participant 75 85 female had a mean age of 18 1 year 95 ci 17 6 18 6 year in the intention to treat analysis the 44 participant receiving d cpt 39 89 female demonstrated greater improvement than the 44 wl ta participant 36 82 female in term of ptsd severity mean cap ca score 24 7 95 ci 16 6 32 7 v 47 5 95 ci 37 9 57 1 hedge g 0 90 this difference wa maintained through the follow up mean cap ca score 25 9 95 ci 16 2 35 6 v 47 3 95 ci 37 8 56 8 hedge g 0 80 treatment success wa greatest during the trauma focused core phase the d cpt participant also showed greater and stable improvement in all secondary outcome with between group effect size ranging from 0 65 to 1 08 at the posttreatment assessment eg for borderline symptom 14 1 95 ci 8 0 20 2 v 32 0 95 ci 23 8 40 2 hedge g 0 91 conclusion and relevance adolescent and young adult with abuse related ptsd benefited more from d cpt than from wl ta treatment success wa stable at the follow up and generalized to borderline symptom and other comorbidities trial registration german clinical trial register identifier drks00004787

Title: Prediction of Individual Response to Electroconvulsive Therapy via Machine Learning on Structural Magnetic Resonance Imaging Data
Authors: Redlich, R.; Opel, N.; Grotegerd, D.; Dohm, K.; Zaremba, D.; Burger, C.; Munker, S.; Muhlmann, L.; Wahl, P.; Heindel, W.; Arolt, V.; Alferink, J.; Zwanzger, P.; Zavorotnyy, M.; Kugel, H.; Dannlowski, U.
Abstract: importance electroconvulsive therapy ect is one of the most effective treatment for severe depression however biomarkers that accurately predict a response to ect remain unidentified objective to investigate whether certain factor identified by structural magnetic resonance imaging mri technique are able to predict ect response design setting and participant in this nonrandomized prospective study gray matter structure wa assessed twice at approximately 6 week apart using 3 t mri and voxel based morphometry patient were recruited through the inpatient service of the department of psychiatry university of muenster from march 11 2010 to march 27 2015 two patient group with acute major depressive disorder were included one group received an ect series in addition to antidepressant n 24 a comparison sample wa treated solely with antidepressant n 23 both group were compared with a sample of healthy control participant n 21 main outcome and measure binary pattern classification wa used to predict ect response by structural mri that wa performed before treatment in addition univariate analysis wa conducted to predict reduction of the hamilton depression rating scale score by pretreatment gray matter volume and to investigate ect related structural change result one participant in the ect sample wa excluded from the analysis leaving 67 participant 27 men and 40 woman mean sd age 43 7 10 6 year the binary pattern classification yielded a successful prediction of ect response with accuracy rate of 78 3 18 of 23 patient in the ect sample and sensitivity rate of 100 13 of 13 who responded to ect furthermore a support vector regression yielded a significant prediction of relative reduction in the hamilton depression rating scale score the principal finding of the univariate model indicated a positive association between pretreatment subgenual cingulate volume and individual ect response montreal neurological institute mni coordinate x 8 y 21 z 18 z score 4 00 p 001 peak voxel r 0 73 furthermore the analysis of treatment effect revealed a increase in hippocampal volume in the ect sample mni coordinate x 28 y 9 z 18 z score 7 81 p 001 that wa missing in the medication only sample conclusion and relevance a relatively small degree of structural impairment in the subgenual cingulate cortex before therapy seems to be associated with successful treatment with ect in the future neuroimaging technique could prove to be promising tool for predicting the individual therapeutic effectiveness of ect

Title: Effect of a Web-Based Guided Self-help Intervention for Prevention of Major Depression in Adults With Subthreshold Depression: A Randomized Clinical Trial
Authors: Buntrock, C.; Ebert, D. D.; Lehr, D.; Smit, F.; Riper, H.; Berking, M.; Cuijpers, P.
Abstract: importance evidence based treatment for major depressive disorder mdd are not very successful in improving functional and health outcome attention ha increasingly been focused on the prevention of mdd objective to evaluate the effectiveness of a web based guided self help intervention for the prevention of mdd design setting and participant two group randomized clinical trial conducted between march 1 2013 and march 4 2015 participant were recruited in germany from the general population via a large statutory health insurance company ie insurance funded by joint employer employee contribution participant included 406 self selected adult with subthreshold depression centre for epidemiologic study depression scale score 16 no current mdd according to diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder fourth edition text revision criterion intervention all participant had unrestricted access to usual care visit to the primary care clinician and were randomized to either a web based guided self help intervention cognitive behavioral and problem solving therapy supported by an online trainer n 202 or a web based psychoeducation program n 204 main outcome and measure the primary outcome wa time to onset of mdd in the intervention group relative to the control group over a 12 month follow up period a assessed by blinded diagnostic raters using the telephone administered structured clinical interview for dsm iv axis disorder at 6 and 12 month follow up covering the period to the previous assessment result among 406 randomized patient mean age 45 year 73 9 woman 335 82 completed the telephone follow up at 12 month fifty five participant 27 in the intervention group experienced mdd compared with 84 participant 41 in the control group cox regression analysis controlling for baseline depressive symptom severity revealed a hazard ratio of 0 59 95 ci 0 42 0 82 p 002 at 12 month follow up the number needed to treat to avoid 1 new case of mdd wa 5 9 95 ci 3 9 14 6 conclusion and relevance among patient with subthreshold depression the use of a web based guided self help intervention compared with enhanced usual care reduced the incidence of mdd over 12 month further research is needed to understand whether the effect are generalizable to both first onset of depression and depression recurrence a well a efficacy without the use of an online trainer trial registration german clinical trial registry identifier drks00004709

Title: Risk of Suicide Attempt in Patients With Recent Diagnosis of Mild Cognitive Impairment or Dementia
Authors: Gunak, M. M.; Barnes, D. E.; Yaffe, K.; Li, Y.; Byers, A. L.
Abstract: importance little is known about the association between mild cognitive impairment mci and suicide most study have focused on dementia and suicidal behavior with inconsistent result objective to examine the association between diagnosis of mci and dementia and suicide attempt and explore potential psychiatric moderator and to a whether the association differs based on recency of diagnosis design setting and participant this nationwide cohort study integrated 5 national database from the department of veteran affair va and center for medicare medicaid service and included all va medical center in the u u veteran 50 year or older with mci diagnosis at baseline october 1 2011 to september 30 2013 or earlier october 1 2007 to september 30 2011 were propensity matched 1 3 with 1 patient with dementia diagnosis and 2 patient without either diagnosis based on demographic characteristic and the charlson comorbidity index diagnosis of mci or dementia were defined a recent if there were no diagnosis code before baseline data were analyzed from march 16 2020 to january 15 2021 main outcome and measure information on suicide attempt through december 31 2016 provided by the national suicide prevention application network nonfatal and mortality data repository fatal result the study population of 147 595 participant included 21 085 patient with mci 63 255 with dementia and 63 255 in the propensity matched comparison group participant had a mean sd age of 74 7 10 3 year 143 353 97 1 were men 4242 2 9 were woman and 127 065 86 1 were non hispanic white a total of 138 patient with mci 0 7 and 400 patient with dementia 0 6 attempted suicide during follow up compared with 253 patient without mci or dementia 0 4 exploratory analysis revealed that no psychiatric comorbidity moderated the association between mci or dementia and suicide attempt after adjustment for demographic detail and medical and psychiatric comorbidities risk of suicide attempt wa consistently highest for patient with a recent mci or dementia diagnosis with adjusted hazard ratio hr of 1 73 95 ci 1 34 2 22 p 001 for recent mci and 1 44 95 ci 1 17 1 77 p 001 for recent dementia risk associated with prior diagnosis wa not significant hr for prior mci 1 03 95 ci 0 78 1 36 p 84 hr for prior dementia 1 14 95 ci 0 95 1 36 p 15 conclusion and relevance this study found that older adult with recent mci or dementia diagnosis were at increased risk of attempting suicide these finding suggest that involvement of supportive service at the time of or soon after diagnosis of mci or dementia may help mitigate risk of suicide attempt

Title: Prevalence, Onset, and Course of Suicidal Behavior Among Adolescents and Young Adults in Germany
Authors: Voss, C.; Ollmann, T. M.; Miche, M.; Venz, J.; Hoyer, J.; Pieper, L.; Hofler, M.; Beesdo-Baum, K.
Abstract: importance suicidal behavior is a leading cause of death among adolescent and young adult in light of the ideation to action framework the delineation of frequency and temporal characteristic of such behavior during this developmental period is crucial objective to provide lifetime and 12 month prevalence estimate of suicidal behavior including ideation plan and attempt in adolescent and young adult of the general population and to provide information about age at onset temporal characteristic of suicidal behavior including duration number of year between onset and last occurrence and frequency number of episode and transition pattern across suicidal behavior design setting and participant a cross sectional epidemiological study wa conducted in a random community sample of 1180 adolescent and young adult aged 14 to 21 year assessed in 2015 to 2016 in dresden germany data analysis wa performed from october 2018 to march 2019 main outcome and measure lifetime and 12 month suicidal behavior ideation plan and attempt were assessed with a standardized diagnostic interview munich composite international diagnostic interview by trained clinical interviewer the onset frequency and duration of suicidal behavior were assessed by questionnaire result of the 1180 participant 495 male weighted percentage 51 7 mean sd age 17 9 2 3 year 130 participant 10 7 95 ci 9 0 12 8 65 participant 5 0 95 ci 3 9 6 5 and 41 participant 3 4 95 ci 2 4 4 7 reported lifetime suicidal ideation plan and attempt respectively any lifetime suicidal behavior wa reported by 138 participant 11 5 95 ci 9 7 13 7 age specific cumulative incidence estimate indicated an increase in suicidal behavior during adolescence starting at age 10 year 1 increasing slightly until the age of 12 year 2 2 and then increasing sharply thereafter until age 20 year 13 5 there were different pattern among female and male participant for ideation plan and attempt with an overall higher incidence among female participant for ideation hazard ratio 1 51 95 ci 1 02 2 22 p 04 for plan hazard ratio 3 31 95 ci 1 72 6 36 p 001 and among those older than 14 year for attempt hazard ratio 3 07 95 ci 1 11 8 49 p 03 of those with suicidal ideation 66 0 reported persistent or recurrent ideation over more than 1 year with 75 0 reporting more than 1 episode of the participant with lifetime suicidal ideation 47 0 reported a suicide plan and 23 9 reported a suicide attempt the transition to suicide plan or attempt occurred mainly in the year of onset of suicidal ideation or plan of those who transitioned 74 9 transitioned from ideation to plan 71 2 transitioned from ideation to attempt and 85 4 transitioned from plan to attempt in the same year conclusion and relevance there is an urgent public health need for timely identification of suicidal behavior in adolescent and young adult to terminate persistent or recurrent suicidal tendency and to interrupt the ideation to action transition

Title: Cortical Representation of Afferent Bodily Signals in Borderline Personality Disorder: Neural Correlates and Relationship to Emotional Dysregulation
Authors: Muller, L. E.; Schulz, A.; Andermann, M.; Gabel, A.; Gescher, D. M.; Spohn, A.; Herpertz, S. C.; Bertsch, K.
Abstract: importance the ability to perceive and regulate one s own emotion ha been tightly linked to the processing of afferent bodily signal interoception thus disturbed interoception might contribute to the core feature of emotional dysregulation in borderline personality disorder bpd a increased level of depersonalization body image disturbance and reduced sensitivity to physical pain suggest poor body awareness in bpd objective to determine neural correlate of disturbed body awareness in bpd and it association with emotional dysregulation and to explore improvement in body awareness with bpd symptom remission design setting and participant case control study performed at heidelberg university hospital heidelberg germany heartbeat evoked potential heps an indicator of the cortical representation of afferent signal from the cardiovascular system were investigated in 34 medication free patient with bpd 31 healthy volunteer and 17 medication free patient with bpd in remission the heps were assessed using 5 minute resting state electroencephalogram and parallel electrocardiogram core bpd symptom history of childhood traumatization and psychiatric disorder were assessed by mean of self report and structured interview to measure neural correlate of disturbed body awareness high resolution t1 weighted structural magnetic resonance imaging scan were collected and analyzed using voxel based morphometry and region of interest based approach the study wa performed between 2012 and 2014 and data analysis wa performed in 2014 main outcome and measure mean hep amplitude in resting state electroencephalogram and their correlation with self reported emotional dysregulation a well a with gray matter volume result patient with bpd had significantly reduced mean hep amplitude compared with healthy volunteer f1 61 11 32 p 001 whereas the mean hep amplitude of patient with bdp in remission lie somewhere in between these 2 group of participant p 05 the hep amplitude were negatively correlated with emotional dysregulation r 0 30 p 01 and positively associated with gray matter volume in the left anterior insula r 0 53 p 05 and the bilateral dorsal anterior cingulate cortex r 0 47 p 05 2 structure that have been identified a core region for interoception conclusion and relevance the result indicate state dependent deficit in the cortical processing of bodily signal in patient with bpd which appear to be associated with core feature of bpd the analysis of patient with bpd in remission suggests an improvement in cortical representation of bodily signal with symptom remission result recommend the integration of technique to strengthen bodily awareness in psychotherapeutic intervention of bpd

Title: Brain morphometric biomarkers distinguishing unipolar and bipolar depression. A voxel-based morphometry-pattern classification approach
Authors: Redlich, R.; Almeida, J. J.; Grotegerd, D.; Opel, N.; Kugel, H.; Heindel, W.; Arolt, V.; Phillips, M. L.; Dannlowski, U.
Abstract: importance the structural abnormality in the brain that accurately differentiate unipolar depression ud and bipolar depression bd remain unidentified objective first to investigate and compare morphometric change in ud and bd and to replicate the finding at 2 independent neuroimaging site second to differentiate ud and bd using multivariate pattern classification technique design setting and participant in a 2 center cross sectional study structural gray matter data were obtained at 2 independent site pittsburgh pennsylvania and munster germany using 3 t magnetic resonance imaging voxel based morphometry wa used to compare local gray and white matter volume and a novel pattern classification approach wa used to discriminate between ud and bd while training the classifier at one imaging site and testing in an independent sample at the other site the pittsburgh sample of participant wa recruited from the western psychiatric institute and clinic at the university of pittsburgh from 2008 to 2012 the munster sample wa recruited from the department of psychiatry at the university of munster from 2010 to 2012 equally divided between the 2 site were 58 currently depressed patient with bipolar i disorder 58 age and sex matched unipolar depressed patient and 58 matched healthy control main outcome and measure magnetic resonance imaging wa used to detect structural difference between group morphometric analysis were applied using voxel based morphometry pattern classification technique were used for a multivariate approach result at both site individual with bd showed reduced gray matter volume in the hippocampal formation and the amygdala relative to individual with ud montreal neurological institute coordinate x 22 y 1 z 20 k 1938 voxels t 4 75 whereas individual with ud showed reduced gray matter volume in the anterior cingulate gyrus compared with individual with bd montreal neurological institute coordinate x 8 y 32 z 3 k 979 voxels t 6 37 all corrected p 05 reduction in white matter volume within the cerebellum and hippocampus were found in individual with bd pattern classification yielded up to 79 3 accuracy p 001 by differentiating the 2 depressed group training and testing the classifier at one site and up to 69 0 accuracy p 001 training the classifier at one imaging site pittsburgh and testing it at the other independent sample munster medication load did not alter the pattern of result conclusion and relevance individual with ud and those with bd are differentiated by structural abnormality in neural region supporting emotion processing neuroimaging and multivariate pattern classification technique are promising tool to differentiate ud from bd and show promise a future diagnostic aid

Title: The Effect of Hunger and Satiety on Mood-Related Food Craving
Authors: Reents, J.; Seidel, A. K.; Wiesner, C. D.; Pedersen, A.
Abstract: in addition to hunger which result from food deprivation fasting or restrained eating food craving is thought to be one of the major factor influencing eating behavior although food craving occurs in healthy human with normal eating behavior research suggests pronounced food craving to be a risk factor for binging food which in turn might cause weight gain and obesity in addition negative mood seems to induce binge eating although the underlying process are not clearly understood to examine these effect on momentary food craving more closely we implemented a food cue reactivity paradigm in 33 normal weight female mean age 25 1 year mean bmi 21 6 mood negative v neutral and state of food deprivation hunger v satiety were varied systematically self rated craving wa significantly higher in hungry compared to sated state moreover in neutral mood high caloric food modulated craving i e hungry and sated participant preferred savory food and sweet food respectively in negative mood this differential effect of savory and sweet item wa absent in summary the state of hunger ha a huge impact on food craving which is further modulated by emotional state future research should consider hunger to be of high relevance for effect investigated in food related paradigm our finding in healthy woman of normal weight support etiological model of disturbed eating behavior and are in line with common intervention targeting eating schedule and mood regulation

Title: The Influence of Physiological and Psychological Learning Mechanisms in Neurofeedback vs. Mental Imagery Against Binge Eating
Authors: Schmidt, J.; Martin, A.
Abstract: in biofeedback research the debate on physiological versus psychological learning ha a long tradition and is still relevant today regarding new development of biofeedback for behavior modification analyzing the role of these learning mechanism may help improving the protocol and answer the question whether feedback of physiological function is necessary to modify a target behavior we explored the presence and impact of physiological eeg change versus psychological learning change in somatic self efficacy in a recently developed eeg neurofeedback protocol for binge eating the protocol target a reduction of food cue induced cortical arousal through regulation of eeg high beta activity in an experimental study accompanying a randomized controlled trial pre and post treatment eeg measurement were analyzed in a neurofeedback group n 18 and an active mental imagery control group without physiological feedback n 18 physiological learning in term of eeg high beta reduction only occurred in the neurofeedback group post treatment participant with successfully reduced binge eating episode 50 reduction showed lower eeg high beta activity than unsuccessful participant p 02 after neurofeedback but not after mental imagery further lower eeg high beta activity at post treatment predicted fewer binge eating episode in neurofeedback only in mental imagery somatic self efficacy predicted treatment success instead of eeg activity altogether the result indicate that physiological change serve a a specific treatment mechanism in neurofeedback against binge eating reducing cortical arousal may improve eating behavior and corresponding neurofeedback technique should therefore be considered in future treatment

Title: Appetitive vs. Aversive conditioning in humans
Authors: Andreatta, M.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: in classical conditioning an initially neutral stimulus conditioned stimulus c becomes associated with a biologically salient event unconditioned stimulus u which might be pain aversive conditioning or food appetitive conditioning after a few association the c is able to initiate either defensive or consummatory response respectively contrary to aversive conditioning appetitive conditioning is rarely investigated in human although it importance for normal and pathological behavior e g obesity addiction is undeniable the present study intent to translate animal finding on appetitive conditioning to human using food a an u thirty three participant were investigated between 8 and 10 am without breakfast in order to assure that they felt hungry during two acquisition phase one geometrical shape avcs predicted an aversive u painful electric shock another shape appcs predicted an appetitive u chocolate or salty pretzel according to the participant preference and a third shape c predicted neither u in a extinction phase these three shape plus a novel shape new were presented again without u delivery valence and arousal rating a well a startle and skin conductance scr response were collected a learning index we found successful aversive and appetitive conditioning on the one hand the avcs wa rated a more negative and more arousing than the c and induced startle potentiation and enhanced scr on the other hand the appcs wa rated more positive than the c and induced startle attenuation and larger scr in summary we successfully confirmed animal finding in hungry human by demonstrating appetitive learning and normal aversive learning

Title: Connections are not enough for membership: Letter/non-letter distinction persists through phonological association learning
Authors: Schmitt, A.; van Leeuwen, C.; Lachmann, T.
Abstract: in compound hierarchical stimulus also known a navon figure a global precedence effect gpe can reliably be observed for both letter and non letter however when presentation condition sufficiently resemble those of reading the gpe for letter ha occasionally been found to disappear we corroborate this effect in a study with a large group of participant in addition in between two session participant were trained in associating the non letter with either phonological or non phonological sound we reasoned that learning distinctive phonological association might be akin to the acquisition of letter knowledge this might eliminate the gpe also for the non letter however the gpe persisted for the trained non letter in both condition the large number of participant in this study revealed additional effect in the letter condition which enabled further insight in the processing dissociation between letter and non letter shape

Title: Emotional sounds modulate early neural processing of emotional pictures
Authors: Gerdes, A. B.; Wieser, M. J.; Bublatzky, F.; Kusay, A.; Plichta, M. M.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: in our natural environment emotional information is conveyed by converging visual and auditory information multimodal integration is of utmost importance in the laboratory however emotion researcher have mostly focused on the examination of unimodal stimulus few existing study on multimodal emotion processing have focused on human communication such a the integration of facial and vocal expression extending the concept of multimodality the current study examines how the neural processing of emotional picture is influenced by simultaneously presented sound twenty pleasant unpleasant and neutral picture of complex scene were presented to 22 healthy participant on the critical trial these picture were paired with pleasant unpleasant and neutral sound sound presentation started 500 m before picture onset and each stimulus presentation lasted for 2 s eeg wa recorded from 64 channel and erp analysis focused on the picture onset in addition valence and arousal rating were obtained previous finding for the neural processing of emotional picture were replicated specifically unpleasant compared to neutral picture were associated with an increased parietal p200 and a more pronounced centroparietal late positive potential lpp independent of the accompanying sound valence for audiovisual stimulation increased parietal p100 and p200 were found in response to all picture which were accompanied by unpleasant or pleasant sound compared to picture with neutral sound most importantly incongruent audiovisual pair of unpleasant picture and pleasant sound enhanced parietal p100 and p200 compared to pairing with congruent sound taken together the present finding indicate that emotional sound modulate early stage of visual processing and therefore provide an avenue by which multimodal experience may enhance perception

Title: When dyspnea gets worse: Suffocation fear and the dynamics of defensive respiratory responses to increasing interoceptive threat
Authors: Benke, C.; Hamm, A. O.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: in patient with anxiety and or respiratory disease body sensation particularly from the respiratory system may increase in intensity and aversiveness and thus lead into defensive action e g escape or panic the process however that might contribute to the culmination of symptom and the switch into defensive action have not been well understood yet the current study aimed at evaluating an experimental paradigm to characterize the dynamic of defensive mobilization to body sensation increasing in intensity and aversiveness person reporting low and high suffocation fear sf n 69 were exposed to increasingly unpleasant feeling of dyspnea induced by inspiratory resistive load and a breathing occlusion requiring voluntary breath holding respiratory response were assessed along with subjective report of anxiety and panic symptom presentation of respiratory load with increasing physical resistance led to increasingly unpleasant feeling of dyspnea twenty eight participant terminated the exposure prematurely at least once when dyspnea wa severe high compared to low sf person exhibited an increased respiratory rate that wa accompanied by report of more intense panic symptom premature termination of exposure were preceded by a surge in anxiety breathing frequency and mouth pressure and a decrease in tidal volume we successfully established an experimental paradigm to a change in defensive responding with increasing intensity of an interoceptive threat the current data foster our understanding of behavioral expression pattern observed in patient with anxiety and or respiratory disease and the process involved in the culmination of bodily sensation and anxiety into panic

Title: Bridging psychophysiological and phenomenological characteristics of psychosis--Preliminary evidence for the relevance of emotion regulation
Authors: Clamor, A.; Schlier, B.; Kother, U.; Hartmann, M. M.; Moritz, S.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: in psychosis the alleged increased subjective stress sensitivity is reflected in abnormal physiological arousal such a higher heart rate elevated skin conductance level decreased vagal activity and unusual cortisol level despite ongoing research possible mechanism that explain the interplay between the phenomenological i e subjective stress and symptom and psychophysiological process are not thoroughly understood building on the model of neurovisceral integration by thayer and lane 2000 that focus on regulative mechanism we postulate that emotion regulation will be associated with vagal activity and with both subjective and physiological stress in the present analysis we used data from a baseline relaxation period including a 5 minute assessment of heart rate variability hrv salivary cortisol and momentary subjective stress rating from a sample of 19 participant with psychosis mean age 40 9 sd 11 1 36 8 female emotion regulation modification skill were assessed for specific emotion i e stress and arousal anxiety anger sadness shame if these were present during the previous week vagal hrv wa significantly and moderately associated with emotion regulation both stress parameter i e cortisol subjective stress were significantly associated with emotion regulation but not with hrv we provide preliminary support for the notion that emotion regulatory process represent a crucial link between phenomenological and psychophysiological phenomenon in psychosis a potential model that ascribes emotion regulation a central role in the restoration of homeostasis is discussed future study are needed to verify it generalizability and predictive value

Title: The Use of Digitally Assessed Stress Levels to Model Change Processes in CBT - A Feasibility Study on Seven Case Examples
Authors: Hehlmann, M. I.; Schwartz, B.; Lutz, T.; Gomez Penedo, J. M.; Rubel, J. A.; Lutz, W.
Abstract: in psychotherapy research the measurement of treatment process and outcome are predominantly based on self report however given new technological development other potential source can be considered to improve measurement in a feasibility study we examined whether ecological momentary assessment ema using digital phenotyping stress level can be a valuable tool to investigate change process during cognitive behavioral therapy cbt seven outpatient undergoing psychological treatment were assessed using ema continuous stress level heart rate variability were assessed via fitness tracker garmin every 3 min over a 2 week time period 6 720 measurement per patient time varying change point autoregressive tvcp ar model were employed to detect both gradual and abrupt change in stress level result for seven case example indicate differential pattern of change process in stress more precisely inertia of stress level changed gradually over time in one of the participant whereas the other participant showed both gradual and abrupt change this feasibility study demonstrates that intensive longitudinal assessment enriched by digitally assessed stress level have the potential to investigate intra and interindividual difference in treatment change process and their relation to treatment outcome further implementation issue and implication for future research and development using digital phenotyping are discussed

Title: Brief Report: Character Strengths in Adults with Autism Spectrum Disorder Without Intellectual Impairment
Authors: Kirchner, J.; Ruch, W.; Dziobek, I.
Abstract: in the current study we assessed character strength in individual with autism spectrum disorder asd n 32 and neurotypical control n 32 using the value in action inventory via is peterson and seligman 2004 and explored association with level of satisfaction with life swl the most frequently endorsed signature strength i e five top ranked strength within an individual s strength ranking were emotional humour love and interpersonal strength kindness fairness in the control group the most frequently endorsed signature strength in the asd group were intellectual strength open mindedness creativity love of learning interpersonal and emotional strength had however the highest positive association with swl in the asd group

Title: Fear conditioning and extinction learning in the mood and anxiety disorders spectrum - Associations with the outcome of cognitive behavior therapy
Authors: Adolph, D.; Teismann, T.; Wannemuller, A.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: in the current study we test for the specificity of deficit in fear acquisition and extinction for the anxiety disorder spectrum we compared fear acquisition and fear extinction learning between a group of patient with either an anxiety disorder n 93 or depression n 103 attending for treatment in our outpatient center and a sample of healthy control participant n 60 to a the specificity of the predictive validity of extinction learning and safety learning for the outcome of exposure based treatment patient additionally underwent disorder specific cognitive behavior therapy cbt we found only very little evidence for difference in safety or extinction learning between healthy control and patient with anxiety disorder or depression using both a group based categorical analytic approach a well a a trans diagnostic dimensional analytic approach on the contrary for anxiety patient only more favorable extinction learning and more favorable safety learning wa associated with more favorable treatment outcome in sum this specific prediction of treatment outcome in anxiety patient confirms and extends current theoretical model of exposure based treatment for anxiety disorder but doe not support the notion of general extinction learning deficit in the anxiety disorder spectrum

Title: Working memory load-dependent brain response predicts behavioral training gains in older adults
Authors: Heinzel, S.; Lorenz, R. C.; Brockhaus, W. R.; Wustenberg, T.; Kathmann, N.; Heinz, A.; Rapp, M. A.
Abstract: in the domain of working memory wm a sigmoid shaped relationship between wm load and brain activation pattern ha been demonstrated in younger adult it ha been suggested that age related alteration of this pattern are associated with change in neural efficiency and capacity at the same time wm training study have shown that some older adult are able to increase their wm performance through training in this study functional magnetic resonance imaging during an n back wm task at different wm load level wa applied to compare blood oxygen level dependent bold response between younger and older participant and to predict gain in wm performance after a subsequent 12 session wm training procedure in older adult we show that increased neural efficiency and capacity a reflected by more youth like brain response pattern in region of interest of the frontoparietal wm network were associated with better behavioral training outcome beyond the effect of age sex education gray matter volume and baseline wm performance furthermore at low difficulty level decrease in bold response were found after wm training result indicate that both neural efficiency i e decreased activation at comparable performance level and capacity i e increasing activation with increasing wm load of a wm related network predict plasticity of the wm system whereas wm training may specifically increase neural efficiency in older adult

Title: Perceived Vulnerability to Disease, Knowledge and Preventive Behavior Related to COVID-19 in Farsi and Arabic Speaking Refugees
Authors: Kananian, S.; Al-Sari, S.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: in the face of the worldwide coviv 19 pandemic refugee represent a particularly vulnerable group with respect to access to health care and information regarding preventive behavior in an online survey the perceived vulnerability to disease scale self reported change in preventive and risk behavior knowledge about covid 19 and psychopathological symptom phq 4 were assessed the convenience sample consisted of n 76 refugee n 45 arabic speaking n 31 farsi speaking refugee and n 76 german control matched with respect to age and sex refugee reported a significantly larger fear of infection significantly le knowledge about covid 19 and a higher frequency of maladaptive behavior a compared to the control group this study show that refugee are more vulnerable to fear of infection and maladaptive behavior than control culturally adapted easily accessible education about covid 19 may be beneficial in improving knowledge and preventive behavior related to covid 19

Title: Dealing With the COVID-19 Infodemic: Distress by Information, Information Avoidance, and Compliance With Preventive Measures
Authors: Siebenhaar, K. U.; Kother, A. K.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: in the ongoing coronavirus disease 2019 covid 19 pandemic medium report have caused anxiety and distress in many in some individual feeling distressed by information may lead to avoidance of information which ha been shown to undermine compliance with preventive health behavior in many health domain e g cancer screening we set out to examine whether feeling distressed by information predicts higher avoidance of information about covid 19 avoidance hypothesis and whether this in turn predicts worse compliance with measure intended to prevent the spread of covid 19 compliance hypothesis thus we conducted an online survey with a convenience sample n 1 059 79 4 female and assessed distress by information information avoidance and compliance with preventive measure furthermore we inquired about participant information seeking behavior and medium usage their trust in information source and level of ehealth literacy a well a generalized anxiety we conducted multiple linear regression analysis to predict distress by information information avoidance and compliance with preventive measure overall distress by information wa associated with better compliance however distress wa also linked with an increased tendency to avoid information avoidance hypothesis and this reduced compliance with preventive measure compliance hypothesis thus distress may generally induce adaptive behavior in support of crisis management unless individual respond to it by avoiding information these finding provide insight into the consequence of distress by information and avoidance of information during a global health crisis these result underscore that avoiding information is a maladaptive response to distress by information which may ultimately interfere with effective crisis management consequently we emphasize the need to develop measure to counteract information avoidance

Title: The influence of general anxiety and childbirth-specific anxiety on birth outcome
Authors: Reck, C.; Zimmer, K.; Dubber, S.; Zipser, B.; Schlehe, B.; Gawlik, S.
Abstract: in the present study we examined a german sample to determine whether anxiety symptom during pregnancy had an impact on the duration and method of childbirth data of n 88 woman recruited at the heidelberg university hospital were used in the analysis prepartum anxiety symptom were assessed with the state trait anxiety inventory stai general anxiety and the pregnancy related anxiety questionnaire praq r pregnancy specific anxiety obstetric outcome wa taken from birth record and operationalized by two parameter the total duration of birth dilation and fetal expulsion and the incidence of pregnancy or birth related intervention ventouse planned and unplanned cesarean section the data show that childbirth specific anxiety assessed by the praq r is an important predictor of total birth duration in contrast general anxiety measured by the stai had no effect the incidence of birth intervention wa explained by parity anxiety however had no predictive value in addition to medical factor childbirth specific anxiety during pregnancy play an important role in the process of childbirth the finding of the present study point to the need of implementing psychological intervention to reduce childbirth specific anxiety and thereby positively influencing birth outcome

Title: Associating Emergency Medical Services personnel's workload, trauma exposure, and health with the cortisol, endocannabinoid, and N-acylethanolamine concentrations in their hair
Authors: Behnke, A.; Karabatsiakis, A.; Krumbholz, A.; Karrasch, S.; Schelling, G.; Kolassa, I. T.; Rojas, R.
Abstract: in their line of duty emergency medical service em personnel are exposed to chronically stressful working condition and recurrent traumatic event which increase their risk for detrimental health outcome here we investigated whether this risk is due to altered regulation of the hypothalamus pituitary adrenal hpa axis and the endocannabinoid system therefore 1 cm hair strand were collected from a cohort of 72 german em personnel in order to measure concentration of cortisol endocannabinoids i e anandamide aea 2 arachidonoylglycerol 2 ag and n acylethanolamines i e stearoylethanolamide sea oleoylethanolamide oea and palmitoylethanolamide pea rank correlation analysis were conducted to test association of cortisol endocannabinoid and n acylethanolamine concentration with the em personnel s workload lifetime trauma exposure and mental and physical health problem we found a negative correlation between cortisol and 2 ag concentration in hair higher hair cortisol wa associated with higher workload reported traumatic stress during childhood and later in life a well a more severe depressive and physical stress symptom were associated with elevated 2 ag sea oea and pea concentration future longitudinal research need to address the prospect of tracing biomolecular marker of glucocorticoid endocannabinoid and n acylethanolamine activity a a predicting value of the long term course of mental and physical well being

Title: Attachment-Related Regulatory Processes Moderate the Impact of Adverse Childhood Experiences on Stress Reaction in Borderline Personality Disorder
Authors: Ehrenthal, J. C.; Levy, K. N.; Scott, L. N.; Granger, D. A.
Abstract: in this study the author explored whether attachment insecurity moderate the effect of adverse childhood experience on stress reactivity in the context of borderline personality disorder bpd participant were 113 woman 39 with bpd 15 with some bpd criterion present 59 without any bpd symptom who participated in the trier social stress test saliva sample were collected before and after the stressor and assayed for salivary alpha amylase saa and cortisol adverse childhood experience were measured using the childhood trauma questionnaire and attachment by the experience in close relationship revised questionnaire result revealed that attachment avoidance and a combination of more adverse childhood experience and attachment insecurity resulted in higher saa level and difference in reactivity to the stressor interaction between attachment anxiety and adverse childhood experience were related to blunted cortisol reactivity the result suggest that the influence of adverse childhood experience on stress regulation in bpd may be moderated by attachment related regulatory process

Title: Synchronous Stimulation With Light and Heat Induces Body Ownership and Reduces Pain Perception
Authors: Cordier, L.; Fuchs, X.; Herpertz, S.; Trojan, J.; Diers, M.
Abstract: in this study we investigated whether illusionary body ownership over artificial hand and non corporeal object modulates pain perception previous research ha yielded to mixed result but ha separated painful stimulation used to test pain perception from the stimulation that wa used to induce the illusion here we used a variant of the rubber hand illusion rhi paradigm and induced the illusion directly via a combination of visual and painful stimulus we presented heat pain stimulus at the real hand and visual stimulus beneath a rubber hand part1 or a glass ball part2 illusion rating were higher and pain rating were lower in the synchronous compared to the asynchronous condition in both part of the experiment this study demonstrated the successful induction of a body illusion using a new visual thermal method with painful stimulus we showed that the rhi and interestingly also the glass ball ha an analgesic effect on the perception of the heat pain stimulus our data suggests that induced ownership over artificial limb but also over non corporeal object can reduce the perceived pain perception this might be mediated via a partial referral of the perceived location of pain or respectively a distribution of pain over 2 location perspective this article present a new visual thermal method with painful stimulus for the induction of the rubber hand illusion an illusionary body ownership over artificial hand and non corporeal ha an analgesic effect on the perception of pain similar approach might be useful to alleviate chronic pain but need further testing

Title: Abnormal processing of interpersonal cues during an aggressive encounter in women with borderline personality disorder: Neural and behavioral findings
Authors: Bertsch, K.; Buades-Rotger, M.; Krauch, M.; Ueltzhoffer, K.; Kleindienst, N.; Herpertz, S. C.; Kramer, U. M.
Abstract: inappropriate aggression is a prominent and clinically relevant interpersonal dysfunction of individual with borderline personality disorder bpd previous study have shown that individual with bpd interpret interpersonal signal in a hostile manner but it is uncertain how this negativity bias impact decision making during aggressive encounter in the present neuroimaging study 48 medication free woman with bpd and 28 age and intelligence matched woman played the social threat aggression paradigm stap a competitive reaction time task in which the winner delivers an aversive sound blast to the loser crucially in the stap the alleged opponent display either an angry or neutral facial expression at the beginning of each trial and selects increasingly loud blast in order to provoke participant relative to healthy control woman with bpd differentiated le between angry and neutral facial expression both in term of aggressive behavior and of activity in medial prefrontal cortex amygdala and temporal pole on the one hand and contrary to our hypothesis neural and behavioral response to angry face were reduced in woman with bpd compared to healthy woman on the other hand provocation heightened subsequent amygdala response to neutral face in bpd and this wa in turn associated with aggressive behavior supporting a default negativity bias in bpd the neurocognitive process by which these alteration might guide aggressive behavior irrespective of interpersonal cue are presented and discussed psycinfo database record c 2022 apa all right reserved

Title: "I Know What I Like" - Indecisiveness Is Unrelated to Behavioral Indicators of Evaluation Difficulties
Authors: Appel, H.; Englich, B.; Burghardt, J.
Abstract: indecisiveness the subjective inability to make satisfying decision is an individual difference trait that may impede effective action mechanism underlying indecisiveness are largely unknown in four study we tested the prediction that indicator of evaluation difficulty were associated with indecisiveness in simple evaluation across study indecisiveness wa measured via self report while evaluation difficulty were derived behaviorally from three indicator difficulty distinguishing between similar evaluation object i e standard deviation of evaluation rating evaluation duration reaction time and implicit evaluation evaluative priming effect using familiar everyday object study 1 n 151 wa based on attractiveness evaluation of portrait study 2a n 201 and 2b n 211 used chocolate a evaluation object and manipulated to what extent the evaluation were equivalent to a decision in study 3 n 80 evaluation were measured implicitly through evaluative priming using food picture contrary to our prediction indecisiveness showed no reliable association to any indicator of evaluation difficulty regardless of type of evaluation object equivalence of evaluation and decision and whether evaluation difficulty wa based on explicit or implicit evaluation all null finding were supported by bayes factor these counterintuitive result are a first step toward investigating evaluation process a potential mechanism underlying indecisiveness showing that for both explicit and implicit measurement indecisiveness is not characterized by difficulty when evaluating familiar everyday object

Title: Temporal stability of functional brain modules associated with human intelligence
Authors: Hilger, K.; Fukushima, M.; Sporns, O.; Fiebach, C. J.
Abstract: individual difference in general cognitive ability i e intelligence have been linked to individual variation in the modular organization of functional brain network however these analysis have been limited to static time averaged connectivity and have not yet addressed whether dynamic change in the configuration of brain network relate to general intelligence here we used multiband functional mri resting state data n 281 and estimated subject specific time varying functional connectivity network modularity optimization wa applied to determine individual time variant module partition and to a fluctuation in modularity across time we show that higher intelligence indexed by an established composite measure the wechsler abbreviated scale of intelligence wasi is associated with higher temporal stability lower temporal variability of brain network modularity post hoc analysis reveal that subject with higher intelligence score engage in fewer period of extremely high modularity which are characterized by greater disconnection of task positive from task negative network further we show that brain region of the dorsal attention network contribute most to the observed effect in sum our study suggests that investigating the temporal dynamic of functional brain network topology contributes to our understanding of the neural base of general cognitive ability

Title: Acquisition of behavioral avoidance: task-irrelevant conditioned stimuli trigger costly decisions
Authors: Pittig, A.; Schulz, A. R.; Craske, M. G.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: individual avoid stimulus which are associated with aversive experience to preserve safety however behavioral avoidance also cause impairment and prevents the individual from attaining positive reward little is known about the link between fear acquisition and the development of behavioral avoidance in the presence of potential reward therefore two experiment investigated the impact of fear conditioning on a subsequent gambling task in an experimental group n 30 advantageous choice higher reward probability were linked to a fear relevant stimulus that wa associated with an aversive unconditioned stimulus u during fear conditioning conditioned stimulus c a disadvantageous choice lower reward probability wa however linked to a safe stimulus that wa never associated with the u c in a control group n 25 fear conditioning wa followed by a similar gambling task with novel stimulus a second experiment focused on individual predictor of avoidant decision n 81 compared with the control group individual in the experimental group avoided the advantageous c choice despite fewer gain the predictor analysis further clarified that avoidant decision were pronounced in highly trait anxious participant who exhibited higher fear response on the other hand finding also indicated a reduction in absolute avoidance across the task combined these finding demonstrate that fear conditioning can lead to avoidant decision making especially in vulnerable individual the resulting cost parallel impairment caused by behavioral avoidance such an emotional decision making style may be a link between aversive experience and the development of habitual pathological avoidance introducing reward for approach however may counteract avoidant decision

Title: [Cognitive and Affective Processes in Body Integrity Dysphoria (BID): A Pilot Study]
Authors: Behrens, C.; Friel, P.; Grocholewski, A.; Dombert, E.; Bruhl, A.; Kasten, E.; Heinrichs, N.
Abstract: individual suffering from body integrity dysphoria bid have the longstanding desire for amputation bid a or palsy bid p most finding on mental aspect of bid are based on self report from sufferer the aim of this pilot study is to examine cognitive and affective process beyond what is accessible by self report therefore n 5 bid a n 3 bid p sufferer n 22 healthy control and n 8 patient with body dysmorphic disorder a further group with a strong desire for body modification were tested selective attention bias eye tracking tendency towards false memory drm paradigm and lack of affective involvement in the unwanted body part induction and destruction of a rubber hand foot illusion were examined descriptive comparison of the group showed that bid a sufferer fixated amputation stump faster and longer than any other group and showed a reduced fear response when the body illusion wa destroyed there wa no indication of a higher tendency towards false memory in either bid group due to the small sample size these result cannot be generalized however finding showed that bid symptom and underlying process can be accessed in more way than through self report moreover result indicate that bid a sufferer selective attention and affective involvement differ from people not desiring an amputation understanding these process may help developing an etiological model identifying subtypes and deriving treatment approach

Title: The Neural Correlates of Probabilistic Classification Learning in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: A Pilot Study
Authors: Hansmeier, J.; Exner, C.; Zetsche, U.; Jansen, A.
Abstract: individual suffering from obsessive compulsive disorder ocd have been found to show deficit in implicitly learning probabilistic association between event neuroimaging study have associated these implicit learning deficit in ocd individual with aberrant activation of the striatal system recent behavioral study have highlighted that probabilistic classification learning pcl deficit in ocd individual only occur in a disorder specific context while pcl remains intact in a neutral context the neural correlate of implicit learning in an ocd specific context however have not yet been investigated using functional magnetic resonance imaging during a neutral prediction of weather and an ocd specific variant prediction of a virus epidemic of a pcl paradigm we assessed brain activity associated with implicit learning process in 10 participant with ocd and 10 matched healthy control region of interest roi were the striatum and the medial temporal lobe roi analysis revealed a significantly higher activity in the bilateral putamen and the left hippocampus of ocd participant a compared to healthy control during both pcl task the group difference could partly be subsumed under a group x task interaction effect with ocd participant showing a significantly higher activity than healthy control in the left putamen and the left hippocampus in the ocd specific task variant only these result suggest a compensation of aberrant striatal activity by an augmented engagement of the explicit memory system particularly in a disorder relevant context in ocd participant

Title: The cost of fear: avoidant decision making in a spider gambling task
Authors: Pittig, A.; Brand, M.; Pawlikowski, M.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: individual with anxiety disorder typically avoid fear relevant stimulus even if they miss potential reward however few study have accounted for such cost of fear related avoidance in doing so in this study 51 spider fearful and 49 non fearful participant completed the spider gambling task our modification of the iowa gambling task to investigate whether fear relevant stimulus trigger avoidant decision in the presence of potential reward in one version advantageous choice were associated with picture of spider whereas the same picture were associated with disadvantageous choice in another version fearful participant generally avoided choice associated with picture of spider which resulted in lower overall gain in the version with advantageous spider deck although this relative avoidance wa sustained fearful participant progressively approach more advantageous spider choice these finding demonstrate that phobic fear result in irrational avoidant decision which can result in considerable cost potential long term reward for approach may however diminish absolute avoidance behavior

Title: Temporal dynamics of insight in body dysmorphic disorder: An ecological momentary assessment study
Authors: Schulte, J.; Dietel, F. A.; Wilhelm, S.; Nestler, S.; Buhlmann, U.
Abstract: individual with body dysmorphic disorder bdd often lack insight into the nature of their perceived appearance flaw that are slight if they exist at all despite the generally held assumption that insight fluctuates over time within individual with bdd it temporal instability and associated feature remain unstudied we examined insight a a multidimensional contextually embedded and dynamic factor using ecological momentary assessment ema further assessing affect and self esteem a potentially associated state thirty individual with bdd and 30 mentally healthy control hcs completed 6 day of ema m 8 54 assessment per day n 3075 assessment in total multilevel analysis revealed substantial intraindividual fluctuation of insight dimension across 30 min to hour that were more pronounced for individual with bdd than for hcs poorer insight correlated with higher negative affect lower positive affect and lower self esteem at concurrent time point in the bdd group considering all predictor at the same time point poorer insight wa characterized by lower self esteem and partly negative affect in the bdd group across time self esteem and insight influenced each other reciprocally with comparatively stronger effect for the prediction of poorer insight by previously lower self esteem these finding demonstrate that insight is a highly variable phenomenon in bdd further suggesting a clinically and etiologically relevant link between self esteem and insight in symptom maintenance psycinfo database record c 2021 apa all right reserved

Title: Reduced vagal activity in borderline personality disorder is unaffected by intranasal oxytocin administration, but predicted by the interaction between childhood trauma and attachment insecurity
Authors: Back, S. N.; Schmitz, M.; Koenig, J.; Zettl, M.; Kleindienst, N.; Herpertz, S. C.; Bertsch, K.
Abstract: individual with borderline personality disorder bpd show self regulatory deficit associated with reduced heart rate variability hrv however result on reduced hrv in bpd remain heterogeneous thus encouraging the search for developmental construct explaining this heterogeneity the present study first examined predictor of reduced resting state hrv in bpd namely the interaction between self reported adult attachment insecurity and childhood trauma second we investigated if alteration in resting state hrv are modified by intranasal oxytocin administration a oxytocin may enhance hrv and is implicated in the interaction between childhood trauma and disturbed attachment for the pathogenesis of bpd in a randomized placebo controlled trial 53 unmedicated woman with bpd and 60 healthy control hc self administered either 24 i u of oxytocin or placebo and underwent a 4 min electrocardiogram our result replicate significantly reduced hrv in woman with bpd explained up to 16 by variation in childhood trauma and attachment insecurity at high level of acute attachment insecurity higher level of childhood trauma significantly predicted reduced hrv in bpd however our result do not support a significant effect of oxytocin on mean hrv and no interaction effect emerged including childhood trauma and attachment insecurity our finding highlight a complex interaction between reduced vagal activity and developmental factor in bpd

Title: The Relationship between Dog Ownership, Psychopathological Symptoms and Health-Benefitting Factors in Occupations at Risk for Traumatization
Authors: Lass-Hennemann, J.; Schafer, S. K.; Sopp, M. R.; Michael, T.
Abstract: individual working in high risk occupation e g emergency staff are exposed to high level of occupational stress including traumatic event correspondingly several study report high rate of mental health problem among these occupation pet ownership ha been associated with better mental health however to date a study on the association between pet ownership and indicator of mental health in these occupation is missing the present cross sectional survey n 580 investigated pet ownership attachment to pet health benefitting factor i e sense of coherence trait resilience locus of control and psychopathological symptom i e general mental health problem posttraumatic stress burnout in medical staff police officer and firefighter dog owner and non dog owner showed comparable level of psychopathological distress and health benefitting factor compared to cat owner dog owner demonstrated stronger emotional attachment to their pet moreover a stronger attachment wa also linked to higher level of psychopathological symptom and lower level of health benefitting factor however the relationship between attachment to pet and health benefitting factor could be explained by their overlap with psychopathological symptom level overall our finding are not in line with the notion that pet ownership generally ha a health benefitting effect future study need to investigate circumstance that modulate positive effect of pet ownership
Journal: Int J Environ Res Public Health

Title: Effects of a three-week executive control training on adaptation to task difficulty and emotional interference
Authors: Grutzmann, R.; Kathmann, N.; Heinzel, S.
Abstract: intact executive function are characterized by flexible adaptation to task requirement while these effect are reduced in internalizing disorder furthermore a executive function play an important role in emotion regulation deficit in executive function may contribute to symptom generation in psychological disorder through increased emotional interference thus the present study investigated transfer effect of a three week executive control training on adaptation to task difficulty and emotional interference in healthy participant n 24 to further explore the training s suitability for clinical application to a the adaptation to task difficulty the proportion congruency effect on behavioral data response time error rate and erp measure n2 crn wa assessed in a flanker task with varying frequency of incompatible trial 25 75 to quantify emotional interference flanker stimulus were superimposed on neutral or negative picture replicating previous result the training increased interference control a indexed by decreased response time and error rate increased n2 amplitude and decreased crn amplitude in incompatible trial after training proportion congruency effect were weaker than expected and not affected by the training intervention the training lead to a shift in the time point of emotional interference before training negative picture lead to a reduction in crn amplitude while after training this reduction wa observed for the n2 this pattern illustrates that the training lead to a change in task processing mode from predominant response related cognitive control to predominant stimulus related cognitive control n2 indicating a proactive processing mode

Title: Multitask brain network reconfiguration is inversely associated with human intelligence
Authors: Thiele, J. A.; Faskowitz, J.; Sporns, O.; Hilger, K.
Abstract: intelligence describes the general cognitive ability level of a person it is one of the most fundamental concept in psychological science and is crucial for the effective adaption of behavior to varying environmental demand changing external task demand have been shown to induce reconfiguration of functional brain network however whether neural reconfiguration between different task is associated with intelligence ha not yet been investigated we used functional magnetic resonance imaging data from 812 subject to show that higher score of general intelligence are related to le brain network reconfiguration between resting state and seven different task state a well a to network reconfiguration between task this association hold for all functional brain network except the motor system and replicates in two independent sample n 138 and n 184 our finding suggest that the intrinsic network architecture of individual with higher intelligence score is closer to the network architecture a required by various cognitive demand multitask brain network reconfiguration may therefore represent a neural reflection of the behavioral positive manifold the essence of the concept of general intelligence finally our result support neural efficiency theory of cognitive ability and reveal insight into human intelligence a an emergent property from a distributed multitask brain network

Title: Interoceptive accuracy is related to long-term stress via self-regulation
Authors: Schultchen, D.; Bayer, J.; Kuhnel, J.; Melchers, K. G.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: interoception describes the ability to perceive internal bodily signal previous research found a relationship between interoceptive accuracy iacc and cardiovascular outcome during or after acute stress so far the association between iacc and long term stress ha not been investigated although this would be important to identify a starting point to prevent long term stress to address this idea in the current study we examined the relationship between iacc and long term stress which wa assessed with different questionnaire and biological marker including cortisol and dehydroepiandrosterone dhea furthermore we investigated self regulation a a mechanism linking iacc to long term stress the sample consisted of 98 participant to measure iacc participant completed the heartbeat perception task perceived long term stress and self regulation were assessed via an online questionnaire moreover hair sample were taken from 65 participant to determine long term stress with cortisol and dhea a well a the ratio of both result showed that iacc wa positively related to dhea and weakly negatively related to the other indicator of long term stress except for the nonsignificant relationship to the indicator cortisol and stress experience due to negative event furthermore these relationship were mediated by participant enhanced self regulation thus our result suggest that enhanced self regulation could be a mechanism explaining why iacc is associated with long term stress

Title: I see neither your Fear, nor your Sadness - Interoception in adolescents
Authors: Georgiou, E.; Mai, S.; Fernandez, K. C.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: interoception describes the mapping of the body s internal landscape and ha been connected to greater intensity of emotional experience the goal of the current study wa to explore the relationship between interoception and emotion face recognition in healthy adolescent the heartbeat perception task wa used to a interoceptive accuracy iac and participant were asked to recognize different facial expression eeg activity wa recorded providing data for the p100 the n170 and the p300 erp component result indicated high sensitivity to negative affect a well a low accuracy in the recognition of fear and sadness among adolescent high in iac reflected by amplitude modulation in the n170 and the p300 the interpretation of these result focus on the intensity experienced in negative facial emotion modified by iac a well a on emotional valence and arousal these finding emphasize the dynamic integration of body and mind for shaping emotion recognition in adolescence

Title: Interoceptive deficits in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder in the time course of cognitive-behavioral therapy
Authors: Schultchen, D.; Zaudig, M.; Krauseneck, T.; Berberich, G.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: interoception is impaired in different psychiatric disorder and is also associated with emotion only one study could show a higher interoceptive accuracy iacc in patient with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd based on the predictive coding system we assume contrary result indicating a decreased iacc in patient with ocd so far there is no study investigating the effect of cognitive behavioral therapy on iacc in patient with ocd therefore we hypothesize that patient with ocd improve their iacc during the time course of therapy compared to healthy control twenty six patient with ocd from the psychosomatic clinic in windach were examined in the time course of cognitive behavioral therapy they were compared to 26 matched healthy control iacc via the heartbeat perception task a well a questionnaire data ocd depression and anxiety symptom were assessed result showed that iacc ocd depression and anxiety symptom were attenuated in patient with ocd patient recovered in the time course of therapy regarding ocd depression and anxiety symptom interoceptive deficit did not change in the time course of cognitive behavioral therapy we demonstrated that iacc is affected in patient with ocd and this deficit doe not change during the time course of a standardized therapy future study should investigate whether an inaccuracy in perceiving one s bodily signal constitutes a risk factor for relapse further it could be examined if iacc can be increased via self and body focus intervention in patient with ocd

Title: Improving interoceptive ability through the practice of power posing: A pilot study
Authors: Weineck, F.; Messner, M.; Hauke, G.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: interoception refers to the detection and perception of signal from the inner body deficit in this domain have been linked to psychopathology prompting the search for strategy to improve this ability preliminary study have shown that interoception could be enhanced through the manipulation of subjective feeling of power we tested the effect of adopting powerful posture on different facet of interoception firstly we measured the impact of a single power posing session on interoceptive ability in 41 healthy female then the same participant were randomly assigned to two condition daily power posing practice v no practice after one week the condition alternated interoceptive accuracy measured by the heartbeat tracking task interoceptive sensibility measured by the body perception questionnaire bpq and confidence rating a well a subjective feeling of power were assessed at baseline after a single power posing session and after one week of training a single power posing session significantly increased individual interoceptive accuracy also power posing reduced individual score on the bpq after one week of daily practice and increased subjective feeling of power after one session and one week of daily practice these finding suggest that adopting powerful posture ha the potential to increase interoceptive accuracy a well a subjective feeling of power and to reduce interoceptive sensibility measured by questionnaire

Title: A latent state-trait analysis of interoceptive accuracy
Authors: Wittkamp, M. F.; Bertsch, K.; Vogele, C.; Schulz, A.
