Abstract: interoceptive accuracy iac that is the ability to accurately perceive one s own bodily signal is widely assumed to be a trait although experimental manipulation such a stress may affect iac we used structural equation modeling to estimate the reliability of iac and the proportion of individual difference in iac explained by a trait and occasion specific effect of situation and person situation interaction we assessed iac in 59 healthy participant 40 woman m age 23 4 year on three consecutive measurement occasion approximately 1 week apart in a rest and poststress condition using a heartbeat counting and a heartbeat discrimination task the result showed fair temporal stability intraclass correlation coefficient 0 38 and good reliability mdn 63 range 49 83 for both method while around 40 of the variance of a single iac measurement could be explained by a trait approximately 27 wa accounted for by occasion specific effect of situation and person situation interaction these result suggest that iac measure are relatively consistent and that situation and person situation interaction impact iac a measured at a certain point in time an aggregation across at least two measurement is recommended when using iac a a trait variable

Title: Cue and context conditioning to respiratory threat: Effects of suffocation fear and implications for the etiology of panic disorder
Authors: Benke, C.; Alius, M. G.; Hamm, A. O.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: interoceptive threat play a crucial role in the etiology of panic disorder pd while body sensation may become conditioned stimulus c when paired with such interoceptive threat cue conditioning the environment in which such interoceptive threat occur may also be learned a a predictor of threat context conditioning suffocation fear sf might facilitate these associative learning process if threat of suffocation become relevant a unconditioned stimulus u to investigate whether sf affect associative learning during such respiratory threat we used mild dyspnea a c that predicted the occurrence of strong dyspnea u in one context predictable wa not related to the occurrence of the u in another context unpredictable or wa presented in a different context safe in which no u wa delivered startle eyeblink response and subjective report were assessed in 34 participant during learning individual reporting high sf showed a clear potentiation of the startle response during the interoceptive c predicting the occurrence of interoceptive threat u such startle potentiation wa not observed when the c remained unpaired safe or unpredictable context moreover high sf person also showed a significant startle potentiation to the threatening context when the c did not predict the onset of the u no such learning effect were observed for low sf individual the data support the view that defensive response mobilization can be triggered by cue but also by context that predict the occurrence of interoceptive threat if these threat are relevant for the individual supporting learning account for the development of pd

Title: A rare scare: The role of intolerance of uncertainty in startle responses and event-related potentials in anticipation of unpredictable threat
Authors: Carsten, H. P.; Harpfer, K.; Riesel, A.
Abstract: intolerance of uncertainty iu represents a transdiagnostic risk factor for internalizing psychopathology however little is known regarding it psychophysiological correlate iu is thought to render individual hypersensitive to threatening event even if the occurrence probability is low to test this we recruited 90 student who completed two npu threat test separating temporal unpredictability from probabilistic unpredictability i e probability of occurrence first a npu version in which the timing of threat i e shock wa either predictable or unpredictable but the shock probability wa 100 in each trial second a probabilistic npu version in which the timing of the shock wa also either predictable or unpredictable but the shock probability wa 33 in each trial startle reflex event related potential n1 and p3 locked to auditory startle probe and anxiety rating were analyzed a expected temporally unpredictable threat modulated startle n1 and anxiety rating iu predicted increased startle to lower shock probability regardless of the temporal predictability no evidence emerged for iu affecting n1 or p3 however iu predicted anxiety rating to threat condition regardless of temporal or probabilistic predictability individual difference in iu shape startle response to eventual threat iu increase automatic defensive responding to unpredictable and potentially threatening situation if the threat probability is low individual with higher iu may tend to err on the side of caution with a mismatch between physiological preparation and threat probability such that the effect of iu are particularly observable in low threat probability condition

Title: Treatment of acquired patella baja by proximalization tibial tubercle osteotomy significantly improved knee joint function but overall patient-reported outcome measures remain diminished after two to four years of follow-up
Authors: Schmidt, S.; Mengis, N.; Rippke, J. N.; Zimmermann, F.; Milinkovic, D. D.; Balcarek, P.
Abstract: introduction acquired patella baja is often characterized by painful limitation of knee joint range of motion and anterior knee pain akp only few study have evaluated the effectiveness of surgical treatment in term of patient reported outcome measure prom s and sport activity thus the goal of this study wa to a prom s and sport activity after proximalization tibial tubercle osteotomy p tto in patient with symptomatic patella baja method between 2016 and 2018 a case series of 11 patient male female 4 7 age 48 12 year were treated by p tto and were retrospectively evaluated after a mean of 33 7 month range 24 51 month the tegner activity score and the kujala anterior knee pain scale were used in addition to a visual analogue scale va 0 10 regarding self reported knee joint function and intensity of akp radiographic assessment included the measure of patellar height using the caton deschamps cd and blackburne peel bp index result postoperatively both the cd and the bp index increased to normality p 0 0001 p 0 0012 knee joint flexion improved from 100 32 degree preoperatively to 123 14 degree postoperatively p 0 0235 akp decreased from 6 5 2 1 point preoperatively to 3 7 2 1 point postoperatively p 0 0061 this wa accompanied by a significant increase in self reported knee joint function from 1 8 1 2 point preoperatively to 6 8 2 3 point postoperatively p 0 0001 and an increase of the tegner activity score from 1 8 1 6 point preoperatively to 3 9 1 5 point postoperatively p 0 0074 although the kujala score improved significantly by an average of 31 55 point p 0 001 overall score result remained reduced at 65 6 17 9 point at final follow up conclusion p tto yielded significant improvement in term of akp subjective knee joint function and sport activity however the overall kujala score result remained reduced indicating that surgical correction of patellar height is not sufficient to relieve all patient complaint in addition the incidence of postoperative complication wa high

Title: Suicide ideation during the COVID-19 outbreak in German university students: Comparison with pre-COVID 19 rates
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Teismann, T.; Friedrich, S.; Schneider, S.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: introduction an increase of suicidal thinking within the covid 19 pandemic ha been postulated yet direct comparison with pre covid 19 rate are missing method the present study investigated whether level and rate of suicidal ideation have changed between 2016 and 2020 data of n 664 university student five cohort 2016 n 105 2017 n 117 2018 n 108 2019 n 154 2020 n 180 were collected by online survey result the rate of student suffering from suicidal ideation wa twice a high in 2020 than in previous year furthermore level of suicidal thinking and of depression were higher in 2020 than in 2019 and 2016 limitation the sample size of the current study wa rather modest and suicide ideation wa assessed with a single item only conclusion the rate of student suffering from suicidal ideation wa twice a high in 2020 than in previous year help line and online counselling should be promoted to the public and the possibility of telepsychotherapy for suicidal people should be used and expanded

Title: Long-Term Consequences of Childhood Maltreatment Among Postpartum Women-Prevalence of Psychosocial Risk Factors for Child Welfare: An Independent Replication Study
Authors: Hitzler, M.; Bach, A. M.; Kohler-Dauner, F.; Gundel, H.; Kolassa, I. T.
Abstract: introduction a an especially burdensome experience childhood maltreatment cm can have lifelong consequence on the mental health and wellbeing of an individual well into adulthood we have previously reported that cm constitutes a central risk factor not only for the development of mental problem but also for facing additional psychosocial risk endangering healthy development of mother and offspring throughout life e g financial problem intimate partner violence substance use this study wa designed to replicate these finding in a larger independent study cohort method in this cross sectional replication study an independent cohort of 533 healthy postpartum woman wa interviewed within seven day after parturition cm experience were assessed retrospectively using the german version of the childhood trauma questionnaire ctq and current psychosocial risk factor for child welfare were assessed using the konstanzer index kindex result of all woman 16 1 experienced emotional and 10 1 physical abuse 28 5 emotional neglect 9 4 physical neglect and 10 3 experienced sexual abuse most importantly the higher the cm load the more psychosocial stressor existed in woman s life in particular woman with higher cm load had a higher risk for mental health problem intimate partner violence financial problem and a higher postnatal stress load conclusion in an independent sample this study replicated the previous finding that cm and psychosocial risk factor for child welfare were strongly associated in a dose response manner our result emphasize the higher vulnerability of woman with a cm history in the postpartum period to avoid negative consequence for mother and child a regular and evidence based screening for cm and psychosocial risk factor during pregnancy and puerperium is needed to identify at risk mother early during pregnancy and to provide appropriate support hence our finding highlight the mandatory requirement for an interdisciplinary collaboration of gynecological practice hospital and midwife along with psychologist and psychotherapist and child and youth welfare service

Title: Unprotected Intercourse and One-Night Stands: Impact of Sexual Excitation, Sexual Inhibition, and Atypical Sexual Arousal Patterns on Risky Sexual Behaviors in Women
Authors: Velten, J.; Scholten, S.; Graham, C. A.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: introduction association among sexual excitation sexual inhibition atypical sexual arousal pattern and risky sexual behavior have been reported in study involving men and woman to date longitudinal study have not evaluated the predictive value of these propensity for future sexual behavior in woman aim to investigate association among sexual excitation sexual inhibition atypical sexual arousal pattern and potentially risky sexual behavior in woman method overall 2 214 woman mean age 30 65 year standard deviation 9 91 year participated in a baseline web based survey the 1 and 2 year follow up survey included 396 and 382 participant respectively correlational analysis and multiple linear regression analysis were conducted to analyze the relation between predictor and outcome variable main outcome measure number of partner number of one time sexual encounter and number of partner with whom no condom were used during the 12 month period before each of the three data assessment point result all five lower order factor of sexual excitation showed positive correlation and all three lower order factor of sexual inhibition showed negative correlation with outcome at baseline and follow up atypical sexual arousal pattern the tendency to become aroused in unusual sexual situation and the importance of relationship factor such a trust for sexual arousal were the strongest predictor for sexual behavior at baseline these variable also predicted the number of sexual partner and the number of one night stand at follow up conclusion the finding suggest that increased sexual arousal when experiencing negative mood might be a risk factor for potentially health threatening sexual decision and support the assumption of the dual control model that sexual excitation is positively and sexual inhibition is negatively predictive of risky sexual behavior in woman

Title: Configural processing of emotional bodies and faces in patients with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
Authors: Thoma, P.; Soria Bauser, D.; Edel, M. A.; Juckel, G.; Suchan, B.
Abstract: introduction attention deficit disorder adhd is associated with interpersonal problem and difficulty in inferring other people emotion previous research ha focused on face processing mostly in child our study investigated configural processing of emotional body and face in adult with adhd in comparison with healthy control analyzing p100 n170 and p250 event related potential erps and relating them to socio cognitive functioning method nineteen patient with adhd and 25 healthy control were presented upright and inverted body and face which had to be categorized a neutral happy or angry while erps were recorded additionally sociocognitive and executive functioning wa assessed result in adhd patient relative to control recognition of emotion depicted by body but not by face wa impaired and p100 amplitude were enhanced for angry body furthermore patient showed enhanced p250 amplitude in response to both body and face specifically for happy and neutral emotion larger n170 amplitude to body and face correlated with lower alexithymia score only in control while enhanced p250 amplitude to both category were associated with poorer inhibition only in patient conclusion adult with adhd show potentially compensatory enhanced semantic processing of emotional body and face a reflected by increased p250 amplitude associated with poorer executive functioning and subtle alteration of emotional and configural processing a reflected by erps

Title: Fostering coping as a mechanism of symptom change in cognitive behavioural therapy for psychosis
Authors: Schlier, B.; Ludwig, L.; Wiesjahn, M.; Jung, E.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: introduction cognitive behavioural therapy for psychosis cbtp ha been repeatedly shown to ameliorate psychotic symptom however so far we have little understanding of the mechanism of change in cbtp in this study we tested whether improved cognitive and behavioural effort to manage taxing external or internal demand coping constitute a mechanism of change in cbtp method using data from a published trial for a secondary analysis we tested whether the continuous symptomatic improvement of patient n 57 who received up to 45 session of cbtp and completed weekly self assessment of symptom suspiciousness individualised positive and negative symptom and individualised symptom of depression wa mediated by preceding improvement in self assessed coping using multilevel analysis a reverse model in which symptom improvement predicted improved coping wa also tested result continuous improvement in suspiciousness negative symptom and depression over the course of cbtp wa preceded by improvement in coping improvement in suspiciousness or positive symptom did not predict subsequent improvement in coping whereas improvement in negative symptom and depression predicted subsequent improvement in coping conclusion coping constitutes a mechanism of change albeit to a different extent for different symptom cluster further research need to explore how best to utilise this mechanism and optimise it integration with other active ingredient of cbtp to maximise therapeutic gain

Title: Blended Care in In-Patient Acute Psychiatric Care. The Example of a Group Training for Social Competences in Adults-A Pretest-Posttest Feasibility Study
Authors: Bendig, E.; Kuchler, A. M.; Baumeister, H.; Becker, T.
Abstract: introduction deficit in social skill can be an important modulating factor in the development and progress of various mental disorder however limited resource in inpatient care often impede effective social skill training this study investigates the feasibility of a blended group training for social skill sst in an inpatient psychiatric setting method and analysis for this one group pretest posttest trial inpatient with a diagnosed mental disorder were recruited participation in the blended sst lasted four week and took place within usual inpatient psychiatric care the blended intervention comprised four face to face group session and three complementary online module within four week assessment took place before t1 and after t2 the training feasibility outcome use acceptance satisfaction implementability into usual psychiatric inpatient care and effectiveness outcome regarding social skill were assessed result n 15 participant were recruited most patient completed all questionnaire 93 and all module of the blended sst concept 60 all participant 100 would recommend the blended intervention to a friend regarding social skill exploratory analysis revealed a non significant medium sized effect cohen s d 0 5 95 ci 0 3 to 1 25 p 0 08 discussion this trial show that a blended care sst is feasible for the use in acute psychiatric inpatient care setting although the ward were acute with high turnover and change of inpatient 60 of participant were treated per protocol over four week overall the evidence on blended care concept in psychiatric care setting is extremely poor to date hence this trial should encourage intensified blended inpatient psychiatric care research
Journal: Int J Environ Res Public Health

Title: Evaluation of a Stepped Care Approach to Manage Depression and Diabetes Distress in Patients with Type 1 Diabetes and Type 2 Diabetes: Results of a Randomized Controlled Trial (ECCE HOMO Study)
Authors: Schmitt, A.; Kulzer, B.; Reimer, A.; Herder, C.; Roden, M.; Haak, T.; Hermanns, N.
Abstract: introduction depression is a common and serious complication of diabetes treatment approach addressing the specific demand of affected patient are scarce objective the aim of this work wa to test whether a stepped care approach for patient with diabetes and depression and or diabetes distress yield greater depression reduction than treatment a usual method two hundred and sixty patient with diabetes and elevated depressive symptom ce d 16 and or elevated diabetes distress paid 40 were randomized to stepped care for depression or diabetes treatment a usual the primary outcome wa the rate of meaningful depression reduction at the 12 month follow up according to the hamd score 9 or reduction by 50 secondary outcome were change in depression score hamd ce d diabetes distress paid diabetes acceptance aadq well being who 5 quality of life eq 5d sf 36 self care behavior sdsca dsmq hba1c and biomarkers of inflammation result one hundred and thirty one individual were assigned to stepped care and 129 to treatment a usual overall 15 4 were lost to follow up meaningful depression reduction wa observed in 80 2 versus 51 2 in stepped care versus treatment a usual p 0 001 intention to treat analysis of the secondary measure the hamd 3 2 p 0 001 who 5 1 5 p 0 007 and aadq 1 0 p 0 008 displayed significant treatment effect while effect on ce d 2 3 p 0 065 paid 3 5 p 0 109 and sdsca 0 20 p 0 081 were not significantly different both group showed comparable change in eq 5d sf 36 dsmq hba1c and biomarkers of inflammation all p 0 19 conclusion the stepped care approach improved depression well being and acceptance the result support that increasing treatment intensity on demand is effective and can help provide more optimal treatment the inclusion of diabetes specific intervention may be beneficial for patient with diabetes and elevated depression

Title: Internet-Based Guided Self-Help for Vaginal Penetration Difficulties: Results of a Randomized Controlled Pilot Trial
Authors: Zarski, A. C.; Berking, M.; Fackiner, C.; Rosenau, C.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: introduction difficulty with vaginal penetration can severely affect a woman s desire to have sexual intercourse her sexual and general well being or her partnership however treatment opportunity for vaginismus are scarce aim to evaluate the efficacy of an internet based guided self help intervention for vaginismus in a randomized controlled pilot trial method seventy seven woman with vaginismus primary inclusion criterion no intercourse 6 month were randomly assigned to an intervention group ig and a waitlist control group wcg the intervention consisted of 10 session involving psychoeducation relaxation exercise sensate focus and gradual exposure with dilator participant received written feedback on completed session from an ecoach main outcome measure the primary outcome wa successful sexual intercourse secondary outcome were non intercourse penetration fear of coitus sexual functioning and dyadic coping self reported assessment were scheduled at baseline 10 week and 6 month result more participant 10 of 40 34 48 in the ig had intercourse compared with those in the wcg 6 of 37 20 69 at least once at 10 week or 6 month odds ratio 2 02 the difference wa not significant chi 2 1 1 38 p 38 but in the ig there wa a significant increase in intercourse penetration from baseline to 6 month d 0 65 no such increase wa found in the wcg d 0 21 there were significant between group effect concerning non intercourse penetration self insertion of a finger or dilator or insertion by the partner in favor of the ig fear of coitus and dyadic coping significantly decreased in the ig overall satisfaction with the training wa high conclusion this randomized controlled trial showed promising effect of an internet based intervention by increasing participant ability to have intercourse and non intercourse penetration while experiencing high treatment satisfaction the wcg also showed improvement although participant had vaginismus for an average duration of 6 year internet based intervention could be a treatment modality to complement other method in stepped care for vaginal penetration difficulty

Title: The Effects of Modifying Dysfunctional Appraisals in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder Using a Form of Cognitive Bias Modification: Results of a Randomized Controlled Trial in an Inpatient Setting
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Blackwell, S. E.; Shkreli, L.; Wurtz, F.; Cwik, J. C.; Margraf, J.; Holmes, E. A.; Steudte-Schmiedgen, S.; Herpertz, S.; Kessler, H.
Abstract: introduction dysfunctional appraisal about traumatic event and their sequela are a key mechanism in posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd experimental study have shown that a computerized cognitive training cognitive bias modification for appraisal cbm app can modify dysfunctional appraisal and reduce analogue trauma symptom amongst healthy and subclinical volunteer objective we aimed to test whether cbm app could reduce dysfunctional appraisal related to trauma reaction in ptsd patient and whether this would lead to improvement in ptsd symptom method we compared cbm app to sham training in a parallel arm proof of principle double blind randomized controlled trial amongst 80 ptsd patient admitted to an inpatient clinic both arm comprised a training schedule of 8 session over a 2 week period and were completed a an adjunct to the standard treatment programme result in intention to treat analysis participant receiving cbm app showed a greater reduction in dysfunctional appraisal on a scenario task from pre to posttraining primary outcome assessment compared to those receiving sham training d 1 30 95 ci 0 82 1 80 with between group difference also found on the posttraumatic cognition inventory ptci d 0 85 95 ci 0 39 1 32 and the ptsd checklist for dsm 5 pcl 5 d 0 68 95 ci 0 23 1 14 but not for long term cortisol concentration d 0 25 95 ci 0 28 to 0 78 reduction in dysfunctional appraisal assessed via the scenario task correlated with reduction on the ptci pcl 5 and hair cortisol concentration from pre to posttraining time point conclusion result support dysfunctional appraisal a a modifiable cognitive mechanism and that their proximal modification transfer to downstream ptsd symptom these finding could open new avenue for improving present therapeutic approach

Title: Prevalence and Correlates of Embitterment in a National Representative Sample
Authors: Muschalla, B.
Abstract: introduction embitterment may occur after stressful but normal life event such a job loss divorce or unjust event embitterment is a normal affect but it may become clinically relevant in case it becomes very strong and long lasting and impairs daily functioning objective until now no epidemiological data on the frequency of high embitterment in the general population have been available method a national representative survey of 2 531 people wa carried out in germany in 2019 the participant gave rating for their embitterment due to perceived event posttraumatic embitterment scale their psychological capacity profile mini icf app s sick leave duration and sociodemographics result about 11 7 of the investigated representative population report moderate embitterment and another 3 8 high embitterment embitterment wa only low correlated with other psychopathology here work anxiety r 0 281 there are no difference between embittered and nonembittered in respect to age sex household member and professional distribution those with the highest embitterment have been unemployed more often and have lower income at least 7 2 of those with high embitterment have a severe psychological capacity impairment and are in need of support by third to fulfill daily duty in 55 of the 802 who reported a stressful event injustice by an important person ha been reported injustice by an institution 14 or societal injustice 12 wa least often reported a a relevant stressful event conclusion physician therapist and public health must be aware of embitterment a a specific mental health problem which occurs frequently and may become chronic with work and life participation problem

Title: Does cognitive behavior therapy alter emotion regulation in inpatients with a depressive disorder?
Authors: Forkmann, T.; Scherer, A.; Pawelzik, M.; Mainz, V.; Drueke, B.; Boecker, M.; Gauggel, S.
Abstract: introduction emotion regulation play an important role in the development and treatment of depression the present study investigated whether the emotion regulation strategy expressive suppression e and cognitive reappraisal cr change in the course of cognitive behavior therapy cbt of depressive inpatient furthermore it also examined whether change in cr and e correlated with positive treatment outcome method forty four inpatient from a psychotherapeutic hospital who suffered from a depressive disorder mean age 36 4 year standard deviation 13 4 year 63 6 female filled in the emotion regulation questionnaire and the beck depression inventory at admission and discharge to detect change in emotion regulation and depression across treatment data were analyzed using multivariate analysis of variance manova for repeated measure effect size and spearman correlation a p value of 0 05 wa considered statistically significant result depression severity f 1 10 42 p 0 003 eta 2 0 22 and cr f 1 4 71 p 0 04 eta 2 0 11 changed significantly across cbt treatment e remained virtually stable post treatment score of cr were also positively correlated with reduction in depressive symptom across treatment rho 0 30 p 0 05 conclusion the result suggest that cbt affect emotion regulation in depressive inpatient only for cr and that higher post treatment score in cr were related to greater reduction in depressive symptom across treatment

Title: Telephone coaching for the prevention of depression in farmers: Results from a pragmatic randomized controlled trial
Authors: Thielecke, J.; Buntrock, C.; Titzler, I.; Braun, L.; Freund, J.; Berking, M.; Baumeister, H.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: introduction farmer have a high risk for depression mdd preventive measure targeting this often remotely living population might reduce depression burden the study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of personalized telephone coaching in reducing depressive symptom severity and preventing mdd in farmer compared to enhanced treatment a usual tau method in a two armed pragmatic randomized controlled trial n 314 with post treatment at 6 month farming entrepreneur collaborating family member and pensioner with elevated depressive symptom phq 9 5 were randomized to personalized telephone coaching or tau the coaching wa provided by psychologist and consists on average of 13 7 session a 48 min 15 over 6 month the primary outcome wa depressive symptom severity qids sr16 result coaching participant showed a significantly greater reduction in depressive symptom severity compared to tau d 0 39 whereas reliable symptom deterioration wa significantly lower in the intervention group compared to tau no significant group difference were found for reliable improvement and in depression onset further significant effect in favor of the intervention group were found for stress d 0 34 anxiety d 0 30 somatic symptom d 0 39 burnout risk d 0 24 0 40 and quality of life d 0 28 discussion limiting we did not apply an upper cutoff score for depressive symptom severity or controlled for previous mdd episode leaving open whether the coaching wa recurrence relapse prevention or early treatment nevertheless personalized telephone coaching can effectively improve mental health in farmer it could play an important role in intervening at an early stage of mental health problem and reducing disease burden related to mdd trial registration number and trial register german clinical trial registration drks00015655

Title: Babies Smell Wonderful to Their Parents, Teenagers Do Not: an Exploratory Questionnaire Study on Children's Age and Personal Odor Ratings in a Polish Sample
Authors: Croy, I.; Frackowiak, T.; Hummel, T.; Sorokowska, A.
Abstract: introduction infant body odor is subjectively pleasant to parent and activates reward area in the brain hence body odor perception might contribute to parental bonding however it is unknown whether the perceived pleasantness of child s body odor varies over the course of a child s development method two hundred and thirty five parent m 36 9 year sd 7 3 were asked to a the personal odor pleasantness of their child n 367 m 9 3 year sd 6 4 result odor pleasantness wa found to decrease a a function of child s age neither sex of the parent nor sex of the child contributed significantly to this effect conclusion we propose that the effect of age related change on personal odor pleasantness reflects olfactory modulation of parental child relationship implication our study suggests that perception of young child s personal odor a pleasant may contribute to bonding and thereby caretaking which is needed to a lesser degree after puberty than before

Title: Increased impulsivity in pathological gambling: Considering nicotine dependence
Authors: Kraplin, A.; Behrendt, S.; Scherbaum, S.; Dshemuchadse, M.; Buhringer, G.; Goschke, T.
Abstract: introduction it ha been highlighted that increased impulsivity is an important etiological factor in pathological gambling pg however the role of the highly prevalent comorbid mental disorder in pg remains unclear this is of special concern a the highest comorbidity wa found between pg and nicotine dependence nd which in turn ha also been associated with heightened impulsivity this study aimed to find out whether increased impulsivity in pg is a specific characteristic related to comorbid mental disorder in general or especially to nd method a cross sectional study wa designed that included a healthy control group and three disorder group with comorbid pg excluding nd comorbid pg including nd and nd alone according to the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder fourth edition impulsivity wa assessed according to the dimension response and choice impulsivity applying behavioral and self report measure result we found a increased response impulsivity in the comorbid pg group when compared to the control group furthermore increased choice impulsivity wa found b in comorbid pg excluding nd and c in comorbid pg including nd when compared to nd alone other group difference did not reach significance conclusion our finding highlight that comorbid pg share deficit in inhibitory control with nd in contrast maladaptive choice are a specific disorder characteristic of comorbid pg when compared to nd if replicated in further study intervention strategy strengthening cognitive control skill might be effective for comorbid pg a well a nd whereas strategy enhancing maladaptive valuation of reward might be specifically effective in comorbid pg

Title: Gray matter alteration associated with pain catastrophizing in patients 6 months after lumbar disk surgery: a voxel-based morphometry study
Authors: Chehadi, O.; Suchan, B.; Konietzny, K.; Koster, O.; Schmidt-Wilcke, T.; Hasenbring, M. I.
Abstract: introduction pain catastrophizing pc the increased attention to harmful aspect of pain magnification and the belief of low controllability helplessness ha been shown to be important in the maintenance of pain a growing research on structural alteration in chronic pain revealed an association between pc and brain area that are involved in affective and cognitive pain processing however little is known about a differential effect of the component magnification and helplessness objective the aim of this study wa to identify brain region associated with overall pc and with the single component of magnification and helplessness method we investigated 29 patient 6 month after lumbar disk surgery using voxel based morphometry magnification and helplessness were assessed with subscales of the avoidance endurance questionnaire aeq overall pc wa computed using the sum score the structural brain imaging data were preprocessed and analyzed using spm8 and vbm8 multiple regression analysis were performed with pc scale a predictor and depression a covariate result pain catastrophizing wa significantly associated with cortical gray matter in brain area involved in processing attentional sensory and affective aspect of pain including the left posterior cingulate cortex supplementary motor area and medial frontal gyrus in addition we provide preliminary evidence for brain structure association related to magnification and helplessness conclusion this study provides evidence for pc related structural alteration in patient with low back pain which are consistent with finding from previous research in different chronic pain disorder this study is the first to evaluate brain change related to differential domain of pc

Title: Self-Stigma Among People With Mental Health Problems in Terms of Warmth and Competence
Authors: Gartner, L.; Asbrock, F.; Euteneuer, F.; Rief, W.; Salzmann, S.
Abstract: introduction self stigma arising from public stigma is a heavy burden for people suffering from mental health problem both public stigma and self stigma encompass the same three element stereotype prejudice and discrimination public stigma ha already been successfully explored by the stereotype content model scm and the behavior from intergroup affect and stereotype bias map however this is not the case for self stigma therefore this is the first study that applies scm and the bias map to self stigma by examining whether the effect of self stereotype on self directed discrimination would be mediated by self directed prejudice in people with mental health problem method within a total sample of n 823 participant who took part in an online survey n 336 people reported mental health problem mental health and self stereotype warmth competence self directed prejudice negative emotion and self directed discrimination active passive self harm were assessed result structural equation modeling supported the hypothesis that the stereotype dimension warmth and competence negatively related to prejudice while stronger prejudice wa associated with more discrimination active passive self harm prejudice fully mediated the relationship between stereotype and discrimination the indirect effect of warmth and competence on active and passive self harm were moderated by competence and warmth discussion implication for further research on self stigma and the usage of scm and bias map are discussed

Title: Evidence of an IFN-gamma by early life stress interaction in the regulation of amygdala reactivity to emotional stimuli
Authors: Redlich, R.; Stacey, D.; Opel, N.; Grotegerd, D.; Dohm, K.; Kugel, H.; Heindel, W.; Arolt, V.; Baune, B. T.; Dannlowski, U.
Abstract: introduction since numerous study have found that exposure to early life stress lead to increased peripheral inflammation and psychiatric disease it is thought that peripheral immune activation precedes and possibly mediates the onset of stress associated psychiatric disease despite early study ifngamma ha received little attention relative to other inflammatory cytokine in the context of the pathophysiology of affective disorder neuroimaging endophenotypes have emerged recently a a promising mean of elucidating these type of complex relationship including the modeling of the interaction between environmental factor and genetic predisposition here we investigate the gxe relationship between early life stress and genetic variant of ifngamma on emotion processing method to investigate the impact of the relationship between genetic variant of ifngamma rs1861494 rs2069718 rs2430561 and early life stress on emotion processing a sample of healthy adult n 409 undergoing an emotional face paradigm in an fmri study were genotyped and analysed information on early life stress wa obtained via childhood trauma questionnaire ctq result a positive association between early life stress and amygdala reactivity wa found specifically the main effect of genotype of rs1861494 on amygdala reactivity indicates a higher neural response in c allele carrier compared to t homozygote while we did not find main effect of rs2069718 and rs2430561 importantly interaction analysis revealed a specific interaction between ifngamma genotype rs1861494 and early life stress affecting amygdala reactivity to emotional face resulting from a positive association between ctq score and amygdala reactivity in c allele carrier while this association wa absent in t homozygote conclusion our finding indicate that firstly the genetic variant of ifngamma rs1861494 is involved with the regulation of amygdala reactivity to emotional stimulus and secondly that this genetic variant moderate effect of early life stress on emotion processing these finding reiterate the importance that inflammatory gene play in the interaction with early life stress and the regulation of emotion processing

Title: Effects of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy on self-reported suicidal ideation: results from a randomised controlled trial in patients with residual depressive symptoms
Authors: Forkmann, T.; Wichers, M.; Geschwind, N.; Peeters, F.; van Os, J.; Mainz, V.; Collip, D.
Abstract: introduction the aim of the present study wa to investigate the effect of mindfulness based cognitive therapy mbct on suicidal ideation in an open label randomised controlled trial of patient with residual depressive symptom furthermore this study aimed at examining whether an effect of mbct on suicidal ideation wa dependent on a reduction in depression severity worry and rumination or an increase in mindfulness method one hundred and thirty participant were randomised to a treatment arm treatment a usual plus mbct or a wait list arm change in depression change in worry change in rumination and change in mindfulness were entered a covariates in a repeated measure anova in order to a to what degree mbct induced change in suicidal ideation were independent from change in these parameter result there wa a significant groupxtime pre v post interaction on suicidal ideation indicating a significant reduction of suicidal ideation in the mbct group but not in the control group the interaction remained significant after addition of the above covariates change in worry wa the only covariate associated with change in suicidal ideation causing a moderate reduction in the interaction effect size conclusion the result suggest that mbct may affect suicidal ideation in patient with residual depressive symptom and that this effect may be mediated in part by participant enhanced capacity to distance themselves from worrying thought

Title: Frequency and correlates of maladaptive responses to paranoid thoughts in patients with psychosis compared to a population sample
Authors: Lincoln, T. M.; Mobius, C.; Huber, M. T.; Nagel, M.; Moritz, S.
Abstract: introduction the aim of this study were to identify whether response to paranoid thought distinguish patient with psychotic disorder from people in the population who have paranoid thought occasionally and to identify factor that are associated with and might explain the different way of responding method paranoid thought were assessed in patient diagnosed with a psychotic disorder n 32 and a population control sample n 34 with the paranoia checklist response to paranoid thought were assessed with the reaction to paranoid thought scale rept and social support self efficacy and cognitive insight were assessed a potential correlate of the response to paranoid thought result the patient showed significantly more depressed physical and devaluating response to paranoid thought and employed le normalising response than the control the difference in normalising response were explained by perceived social integration whereas the difference in depressive response were explained by the overall level of depression and partly explained by externality and social integration conclusion maladaptive response to paranoid thought could be relevant to the pathogenesis and maintenance of persecutory delusion intervention aimed at reducing paranoia could benefit from targeting dysfunctional response to paranoid thought and by placing a stronger emphasis on treating depression and improving social integration

Title: Psychedelic Experiences During the Early COVID-19 Pandemic: Findings From an International Online Survey
Authors: Evens, R.; Reiche, S.; Marek, R. M.; Moon, D. U.; Gross, R. E.; Romanello, A.; Jalilzadeh Masah, D.; Scicchitano Bockheler, M.; Gutwinski, S.; Montag, C.; Mick, I.; Majic, T.
Abstract: introduction the current corona virus disease covid 19 pandemic ha caused a serious global health crisis that ha affected large part of the public and private life worldwide including the use of psychoactive substance in this study we investigated the effect of the covid 19 pandemic on the use of serotonergic psychedelics i e the setting in which people use psychedelics the motif of usage and the subjective quality of psychedelic experience method the study wa part of an international cross sectional internet based survey n 5 049 available in five language english german spanish italian and korean carried out during the early phase of the pandemic from april to august 2020 participant were asked to retrospectively rate setting and motif of psychedelic substance use before the pandemic and in the last 4 week during the pandemic a well a change in psychedelic experience result of n 1 375 participant that reported the use psychedelics in 2019 or 2020 n 642 46 6 also took psychedelics during the pandemic during the pandemic participant used psychedelics significantly le often in setting that were outside their home top motif to use psychedelics were comparable before and during the pandemic but participant consumed le out of curiosity to celebrate or because friend took it and more out of boredom an increase in positively connoted often pro social experience wa observed two third of participant who used psychedelics during the pandemic claimed that psychedelics had helped them to deal better with the corona pandemic at least slightly discussion change in setting and motif were mostly in line with restriction caused by control measure to contain the spread of the virus the unexpected increase in positively connoted experience possibly reflects a favorable interaction of environmental macro and individual micro context during the pandemic e g by reducing the use in more uncontrolled recreational setting or by encouraging a strong self selection of substance user due to the expectation of bad trip increased pro social feeling under psychedelics might reflect a desire for social interaction in time of social distancing and pandemic related stress and anxiety

Title: Weight/shape and muscularity concerns and emotional problems in adolescent boys and girls: A cross-lagged panel analysis
Authors: Hoffmann, S.; Cortes-Garcia, L.; Warschburger, P.
Abstract: introduction the goal of the present study wa to identify the prospective relation between weight shape and muscularity concern and emotional problem in adolescent method self report data of 966 german male and female adolescent were analyzed in a cross lagged panel design result analysis of latent mean revealed significant correlation between weight shape concern and emotional problem a well a between muscularity concern and emotional problem in both gender moreover weight shape concern predicted emotional problem prospectively but only in girl regarding muscularity concern we could not find any prospective relation with emotional problem in boy or girl from the general population conclusion it is assumed that a appearance is highly relevant for the self concept in girl concern about the look might promote emotional problem thus weight shape concern should be addressed in the prevention of emotional problem in adolescent girl whereas further research is necessary investigating the contribution of muscularity concern in this context

Title: Patients Characteristics and Psychosocial Treatment in Psychodynamic and Cognitive Behavior Therapy
Authors: Muschalla, B.; Linden, M.; Rose, M.
Abstract: introduction the most prevalent psychotherapy school are psychodynamic pdt and cognitive behavior therapy cbt there are no scientific guideline on which type of patient should be treated by which therapist and how they can find the best one part of the answer can be derived from data on who is treated in which way objective objective of this study wa to compare patient in routine pdt and cbt to describe similarity and difference in regard to patient status and treatment material and method a research psychotherapist visited 73 cognitive behavior therapist and 58 psychodynamic psychotherapist in their office and asked them to report about the last case they had seen there were 188 cbt and 134 pd case report result there were no significant difference in socio demographic between pdt and cbt patient the average number of treatment session so far wa significantly higher in pdt than cbt there were longer duration of illness more parallel medical treatment and higher rate of sick leave in cbt patient while assessment of capacity with the mini icf app showed no difference more participation restriction were found in cbt patient correspondingly there were more sociomedical intervention especially in regard to work conclusion the difference between pdt and cbt may be explained by the fact that pdt requires analytical capability on the side of the patient which may exclude patient with social problem while cbt is coping oriented which allows the inclusion of all kind of patient still in both treatment mode complex patient are treated with multidimensional intervention

Title: The relationship between social media use, stress symptoms and burden caused by coronavirus (Covid-19) in Germany and Italy: A cross-sectional and longitudinal investigation
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Cosci, F.; Mansueto, G.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: introduction the need for social distancing to reduce the spread of covid 19 is accompanied by an increase of social medium use smu many people engage in intensive online activity to find information about the current covid 19 situation and to interact about it with other user the present study investigated the extent of smu a covid 19 information source and it relationship with stress symptom and burden caused by the pandemic in germany and italy method cross national longitudinal germany n 501 3 month period and cross sectional italy n 951 data on covid 19 information source stress symptom and burden caused by covid 19 were collected via online survey result about 50 of the german sample and about 60 of the italian sample frequently used sm a covid 19 information source cross sectional analysis in both country revealed that smu is positively associated with stress symptom and experienced burden moreover stress symptom mediated the link between smu and burden this wa also confirmed by longitudinal analysis in germany burden assessed three month after smu and stress symptom limitation the mostly female and relatively young sample composition limit the generalizability of present finding only two european country were investigated conclusion the present finding reveal a potential negative impact of enhanced smu on individual mental health state and behavior additionally they emphasize the significance of a conscious and cautious use of sm a information source specifically during the pandemic

Title: Association of NPSR1 gene variation and neural activity in patients with panic disorder and agoraphobia and healthy controls
Authors: Gechter, J.; Liebscher, C.; Geiger, M. J.; Wittmann, A.; Schlagenhauf, F.; Lueken, U.; Wittchen, H. U.; Pfleiderer, B.; Arolt, V.; Kircher, T.; Straube, B.; Deckert, J.; Weber, H.; Herrmann, M. J.; Reif, A.; Domschke, K.; Strohle, A.
Abstract: introduction the neurobiological mechanism behind panic disorder with agoraphobia pd ag are not completely explored the functional a t single nucleotide polymorphism snp rs324981 in the neuropeptide s receptor gene npsr1 ha repeatedly been associated with panic disorder and might partly drive function respectively dysfunction of the neural fear network we aimed to investigate whether the npsr1 t risk allele wa associated with malfunctioning in a fronto limbic network during the anticipation and perception of agoraphobia specific stimulus method 121 patient with pd ag and 77 healthy control hc underwent functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri using the disorder specific westphal paradigm it consists of neutral and agoraphobia specific picture half of the picture were cued to induce anticipatory anxiety result risk allele carrier showed significantly higher amygdala activation during the perception of agoraphobia specific stimulus than a a homozygote a linear group x genotype interaction during the perception of agoraphobia specific stimulus showed a strong trend towards significance patient with the one or two t allele displayed the highest and hc with the a a genotype the lowest activation in the inferior orbitofrontal cortex iofc discussion the study demonstrates an association of the npsr1rs324981 genotype and the perception of agoraphobia specific stimulus these result support the assumption of a fronto limbic dysfunction a an intermediate phenotype of pd ag

Title: The relationship between narcissism, intensity of Facebook use, Facebook flow and Facebook addiction
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Bierhoff, H. W.; Rohmann, E.; Raeder, F.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: introduction the present study investigated mechanism that may contribute to the enhanced risk of narcissistic individual to develop facebook addiction method in a sample of 449 facebook user age m sd 31 07 9 52 range 18 65 the personality trait narcissism facebook flow intensity of facebook use and facebook addiction were assessed by an online survey result in a moderated mediation analysis the positive relationship between narcissism and facebook addiction wa positively mediated by the level of flow experienced on facebook intensity of facebook use moderated the positive association between facebook flow and facebook addiction conclusion excessive facebook use may cause psychological dependence narcissistic individual are at enhanced risk for this form of dependence that is fostered by experience of flow during facebook use and intensity of facebook use current result should be taken into account when assessing individual at risk for pathological facebook use and when planning specific intervention to deal with it

Title: Altered Appetitive Conditioning and Neural Connectivity in Subjects With Compulsive Sexual Behavior
Authors: Klucken, T.; Wehrum-Osinsky, S.; Schweckendiek, J.; Kruse, O.; Stark, R.
Abstract: introduction there ha been growing interest in a better understanding of the etiology of compulsive sexual behavior csb it is assumed that facilitated appetitive conditioning might be an important mechanism for the development and maintenance of csb but no study thus far ha investigated these process aim to explore group difference in neural activity associated with appetitive conditioning and connectivity in subject with csb and a healthy control group method two group 20 subject with csb and 20 control were exposed to an appetitive conditioning paradigm during a functional magnetic resonance imaging experiment in which a neutral stimulus c predicted visual sexual stimulus and a second stimulus c did not main outcome measure blood oxygen level dependent response and psychophysiologic interaction result a a main result we found increased amygdala activity during appetitive conditioning for the c v the c and decreased coupling between the ventral striatum and prefrontal cortex in the csb v control group conclusion the finding show that neural correlate of appetitive conditioning and neural connectivity are altered in patient with csb the increased amygdala activation might reflect facilitated conditioning process in patient with csb in addition the observed decreased coupling could be interpreted a a marker for impaired emotion regulation success in this group

Title: Effectiveness of a Guided Internet- and Mobile-Based Intervention for Patients with Chronic Back Pain and Depression (WARD-BP): A Multicenter, Pragmatic Randomized Controlled Trial
Authors: Baumeister, H.; Paganini, S.; Sander, L. B.; Lin, J.; Schlicker, S.; Terhorst, Y.; Moshagen, M.; Bengel, J.; Lehr, D.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: introduction there is neither strong evidence on effective treatment for patient with chronic back pain cbp and depressive disorder nor sufficiently available mental health care offer objective the aim is to a the effectiveness of internet and mobile based intervention imi a a scalable approach for treating depression in a routine care setting method this is an observer masked multicenter pragmatic randomized controlled trial with a randomization ratio of 1 1 patient with cbp and diagnosed depressive disorder mild to moderate severity were recruited from 82 orthopedic rehabilitation clinic across germany the intervention group ig received a guided depression imi tailored to cbp next to treatment a usual tau including medication while the control group cg received tau the primary outcome wa observer masked clinician rated hamilton depression severity 9 week follow up the secondary outcome were further depression outcome pain related outcome health related quality of life and work capacity biostatistician blinded analysis using regression model were conducted by intention to treat and per protocol analysis result between october 2015 and july 2017 we randomly assigned 210 participant ig n 105 cg n 105 mostly with only a mild pain intensity but substantial pain disability no statistically significant difference in depression severity between ig and cg wa observed at the 9 week follow up beta 0 19 95 ci 0 43 to 0 05 explorative secondary depression 4 9 and pain related 4 6 outcome were in part significant p 0 05 health related quality of life wa significantly higher in the ig no difference were found in work capacity conclusion the result indicate that an imi for patient with cbp and depression in a routine care setting ha limited impact on depression benefit in pain and health related outcome suggest that an imi might still be a useful measure to improve routine care

Title: Sleep problems in university students - an intervention
Authors: Schlarb, A. A.; Friedrich, A.; Classen, M.
Abstract: introduction up to 60 of all college student suffer from a poor sleep quality and 7 7 meet all criterion of an insomnia disorder sleep problem have a great impact on the student daily life for example the grade point average due to irregular daytime routine chronotype change side job and exam period they need specialized treatment for improving sleep studieren wie im schlaf swis studying in your sleep is a multicomponent sleep training that combine cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia and hypnotherapy for insomnia to improve student sleep insomnia symptom and nightmare the aim of the present study is to evaluate the acceptance feasibility and the first effect of swis method twenty seven student mean 24 24 standard deviation 3 57 participated in a study of pre post design the acceptance and feasibility were measured with questionnaire in addition the pittsburgh sleep quality index psqi sleep log and actigraphy were implemented further variable encompassed daytime sleepiness sleep related personality trait and cognition about sleep result seventy four percent of the participant reported symptom of an insomnia disorder and 51 9 fulfilled all criterion of an insomnia disorder according to the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder fifth edition correspondingly the student suffered from clinically relevant sleep problem according to the psqi the swis sleep training is a well accepted and feasible program significant improvement were observed in the subjective sleep quality and sleep related personality trait a well a clinical improvement in objective sleep measure discussion finding showed that swis is a feasible program for the treatment of sleep problem in college and university student due to it various effect on sleep and cognitive outcome further evaluation of follow up measurement and additional variable that is cognitive performance and mental health is needed

Title: Associations of Buying-Shopping Disorder Symptoms with Identity Confusion, Materialism, and Socially Undesirable Personality Features in a Community Sample
Authors: Muller, A.; Claes, L.; Birlin, A.; Georgiadou, E.; Laskowski, N. M.; Steins-Loeber, S.; Brand, M.; de Zwaan, M.
Abstract: introduction while identity problem and materialistic value endorsement have been described a predisposing factor for buying shopping disorder bsd in the literature little empirical data are available on the role of socially undesirable personality feature that may contribute to financial misconduct and manipulative interpersonal behavior in bsd the dark triad of personality refers to such offensive yet non pathological personality trait and ha been applied to addictive behavior in the past the aim of the present study wa to investigate whether the dark triad dimension machiavellianism subclinical narcissism and subclinical psychopathy predict symptom of bsd above and beyond identity confusion and materialism or moderate the relationship between materialism and symptom of bsd method the participant comprised a convenience sample n 272 72 4 woman aged between 18 and 67 year assessment included standard questionnaire for bsd identity problem materialism and the dark triad of personality result zero order correlation indicate a weak association between bsd and the dark triad dimension machiavellianism and narcissism but not psychopathy result of a moderated regression analysis with bsd symptom a a dependent variable revealed significant main effect for materialism female gender and a significant narcissism by materialism effect after accounting for identity confusion synthesis and the single dark triad trait conclusion the finding suggest that individual with bsd attempt to address their narcissistic deficit via materialistic possession this assumption warrant further investigation in a clinical sample

Title: Investigating the effect of proactive interference control training on intrusive memories
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Heeren, A.; Shkreli, L.; Meyer, T.; Egeri, L.; Cwik, J. C.; Zlomuzica, A.; Kessler, H.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: intrusive re experiencing is a hallmark symptom of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd according to prominent model of intrusive phenomenon intrusive memory may result from impairment in the efficiency of working memory capacity wmc more specifically proactive interference control yet experimental research is scarce therefore the present study aimed to investigate experimentally the role of proactive interference control in intrusive memory we randomly assigned 57 healthy participant to either receive a high interference control training or a low interference control training participant were then exposed to highly distressing film clip wmc wa assessed before and after the training intrusion symptom were assessed directly post training and after one week using an intrusion provocation task ipt a one week intrusion diary and the retrospective intrusion subscale of the impact of event sale revised y r result indicated that both group reported improvement in wmc and fewer intrusion on the second ipt post training with no difference between group similarly no group difference on intrusion were found at one week follow up i e intrusion diary and y r to conclude these data are not consistent with the hypothesis that wmc play a role in intrusive re experiencing implication for future research are discussed

Title: Automatic and Controlled Processing: Implications for Eating Behavior
Authors: Furtjes, S.; King, J. A.; Goeke, C.; Seidel, M.; Goschke, T.; Horstmann, A.; Ehrlich, S.
Abstract: it is a widely held view that human have control over their food choice and consumption however research also suggests that eating behavior is often triggered by contextual cue and guided by automaticities and habit interestingly the dichotomy between automatic and controlled processing ha recently been challenged suggesting that they may be intertwined in a large female sample n 567 we investigated the hypothesis that task based and self reported measure of automatic and controlled processing would interact and impact self reported eating behavior result analyzed via structural equation modeling suggest that automatic but not controlled processing during a modified flanker task including a context specific proportion congruent cspc manipulation wa inversely associated with self reported self control the influence of self control on unhealthy eating behavior i e uncontrolled and emotional eating heightened consumption of fat and sugar wa only indirect via habitual behavior which itself had a strong direct impact unhealthy eating wa further associated with real life outcome e g body mass index bmi our finding suggest that eating behavior may indeed be guided primarily by automaticities and habit whereas self control might facilitate this association having self control over eating might therefore be most effective by avoiding contextual cue eliciting undesired automatic behavior and establishing habit that serve long term goal

Title: The extent and origin of discordance between self- and observer-rated depression in patients with psychosis
Authors: Hartmann, M. M.; Fritzsche, A.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: it is assumed that patient with psychosis have difficulty indicating clinical symptom accurately in self reported measure the present study investigated the ability of self rating scale to detect symptom of depression in patient with psychosis and aimed at identifying demographic clinical and neurocognitive factor that predict the discordance between self rating and observer rating inpatient and outpatient with psychosis n 118 were assessed for depression by applying two observer rating and two self rating scale we found reasonable correlation score between the rating by patient and observer range r 0 50 0 57 in half of the patient 49 2 the self rating corresponded well with the rating of clinician patient who rated their depressive symptom a le severe than the clinician demonstrated more negative symptom such a blunted affect and poor affective rapport patient who rated their depression symptom a being more severe were characterized by more self reported general psychopathology the concordance rate indicate that self rating of depression can be a valid additional tool in clinical assessment of patient with psychosis however clinician should be attentive to the fact that some patient might have a general tendency to over report symptom and that patient with negative symptom tend to be rated a more depressed in observer rating compared with self assessment

Title: Stability of trauma-related symptoms during acute substance use treatment
Authors: Herzog, E.; Odenwald, M.; Proescholdt, M.; Haubold, A.; Bohnacker, I.; Flogel, M.; Linde, A.; Muller, S.; Wiesbeck, G.; Lang, U.; Walter, M.; Vogel, M.
Abstract: it is unclear whether post traumatic stress disorder symptom and report of traumatic childhood experience decline during substance withdrawal a convenience sample of 34 inpatient of the psychiatric university clinic in basel wa recruited and general psychopathological and trauma related symptom were assessed with the brief symptom checklist post traumatic stress diagnostic scale and childhood trauma questionnaire in the 1st and 3rd week of substance use treatment the average age of the sample wa 41 9 sd 9 1 year and 26 5 were female hyperarousal mt1 4 51 versus mt2 3 61 z 2 38 p 017 and avoidance symptom mt1 6 24 versus mt2 4 27 z 2 59 p 010 declined significantly but re experiencing symptom mt1 4 00 versus mt2 3 45 z 50 p 617 did not post traumatic stress disorder assessment according to the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder 4th edition criterion remained constant for 28 of 34 patient likewise self reported childhood trauma experience decreased yet the number of elevated subscale score remained stable post traumatic stress disorder symptom are not adequately treated by substance withdrawal alone trauma specific diagnostics can be initiated with sufficient quality a early a the first week of withdrawal treatment

Title: How do I know how I am doing? Use of different types of comparison in judgment of well-being in patients seeking psychological treatment and healthy controls
Authors: Morina, N.; Meyer, T.; Sickinghe, M.
Abstract: judgment of well being is formed on the spot and we know little about it foundation we aimed at examining the role of comparison standard in informing evaluation of well being in a clinical and a nonclinical sample in a semi structured face to face interview individual seeking psychological treatment and healthy control individual rated how they have been feeling in general and relative to specific comparison standard and were each time invited to substantiate their rating independent coder assessed number type direction and specificity of reported comparison when asked to explain why they chose a particular rating of their well being 93 of clinical participant and 61 of nonclinical participant spontaneously reported some type of comparison standard both group reported highest well being rating relative to social and past temporal comparison and lowest relative to prospective temporal comparison furthermore clinical participant engaged in more upward than downward comparison whereas this wa not the case for healthy control participant our finding suggest that evaluation of well being are informed by different comparison type and that individual with clinical complaint use more comparison when evaluating their well being the result encourage further investigation of comparative thinking a an underlying mechanism of judgment of well being and ill being

Title: Do Gender and Country of Residence Matter? A Mixed Methods Study on Lay Causal Beliefs about PTSD
Authors: Meyer, C.; Heinzl, L.; Kampisiou, C.; Triliva, S.; Knaevelsrud, C.; Stammel, N.
Abstract: layperson causal belief about mental disorder can differ considerably from medical or psychosocial clinician model a they are shaped by social and cultural context and by personal experience this study aimed at identifying difference in causal belief about post traumatic stress disorder ptsd by country and gender a cross sectional vignette based online survey wa conducted with 737 participant from germany greece ecuador mexico and russia participant were presented with a short unlabeled case vignette describing a person with symptom of ptsd causal belief were assessed using an open ended question asking for the three most likely cause answer were analyzed using thematic analysis afterwards theme were transformed into categorical variable to analyze difference by country and by gender qualitative analysis revealed a wide range of different causal belief theme differed by gender with woman tending to mention more external causal belief theme also differed between the five country but the difference between country were more pronounced for woman than for men in conclusion causal belief were multifaceted among layperson and shared basic characteristic with empirically derived risk factor the more pronounced difference for woman suggest that potential gender effect should be considered in cross cultural research
Journal: Int J Environ Res Public Health
Notes: Louis Schiekiera (2023-06-08 09:06:40)(Screen): inclusion but no quant results;

Title: Opposing roles for amygdala and vmPFC in the return of appetitive conditioned responses in humans
Authors: Ebrahimi, C.; Koch, S. P.; Pietrock, C.; Fydrich, T.; Heinz, A.; Schlagenhauf, F.
Abstract: learning account of addiction and obesity emphasize the persistent power of pavlovian reward cue to trigger craving and increase relapse risk while extinction can reduce conditioned responding pavlovian relapse phenomenon the return of conditioned responding following successful extinction challenge the long term success of extinction based treatment translational laboratory model of pavlovian relapse could therefore represent a valuable tool to investigate the mechanism mediating relapse although so far human research ha mostly focused on return of fear phenomenon to this end we developed an appetitive conditioning paradigm with liquid food reward in combination with a 3 day design to investigate the return of appetitive pavlovian response and the involved neural structure in healthy subject pavlovian conditioning day 1 wa assessed in 62 participant and a subsample n 33 further completed extinction day 2 and a reinstatement test day 3 conditioned responding wa assessed on explicit pleasantness rating and implicit measure reaction time skin conductance heart rate startle response and reinstatement effect were further evaluated using fmri we observed a return of conditioned responding during the reinstatement test evident by enhanced skin conductance response accompanied by enhanced bold response in the amygdala on an individual level psychophysiological reinstatement intensity wa significantly anticorrelated with ventromedial prefrontal cortex vmpfc activation and marginally anticorrelated with enhanced amygdala vmpfc connectivity during late reinstatement our result extend evidence from return of fear phenomenon to the appetitive domain and highlight the role of the vmpfc and it functional connection with the amygdala in regulating appetitive pavlovian relapse

Title: Blocking under stress: Sustained attention to stimuli without predictive value?
Authors: Kausche, F. M.; Schwabe, L.
Abstract: learning is blocked when a stimulus is followed by an outcome that is identical to what wa expected and thus contains no new information this classic blocking effect exemplifies that learning is driven by the predictive value of stimulus which in turn should guide the allocation of attentional resource stress is known to be a powerful modulator of learning and memory however whether stress may affect attentional processing during predictive learning is largely unknown here we combined electroencephalography and eye tracking with an experimental stress manipulation and a fear conditioning paradigm designed to probe the blocking effect to determine if and how stress impact efficient attentional processing during predictive learning participant explicit rating indicated irrespective of stress a blocking effect the control group further showed preferential attentional processing of predictive v unpredictive stimulus reflected in differential fixation duration and a differential n2pc stress abolished this differentiation and led even to sustained attention indicated by higher late positive potential to stimulus with low predictive value moreover stress resulted in an overall increase in the p3b during the blocking phase suggesting increased attentional processing presumably due to impaired access to previously learned association together our result suggest that while control participant paid particular attention to predictive stimulus and reduced attention to unpredictive stimulus in line with the classic blocking effect stress before learning reduced this preferential processing thus the present finding highlight the role of attention allocation for predictive fear learning and suggest that stress may impair efficient information processing against the background of prior experience

Title: The time course of speaker-specific language processing
Authors: Kroczek, L. O. H.; Gunter, T. C.
Abstract: listener are sensitive to a speaker s individual language use and generate expectation for particular speaker it is unclear however how such expectation affect online language processing in the present eeg study we presented thirty two participant with auditory sentence stimulus of two speaker speaker differed in their use of two particular syntactic structure easy subject initial sov structure and more difficult object initial osv structure one speaker the sov speaker had a high proportion of sov sentence 75 and a low proportion of osv sentence 25 and vice versa for the osv speaker participant were exposed to the speaker individual language use in a training session followed by a test session on the consecutive day erp result show that early stage of sentence processing are driven by syntactic processing only and are unaffected by speaker specific expectation in a late stage however an interaction between speaker and syntax information wa observed for the sov speaker condition the classical p600 effect reflected the effort of processing difficult and unexpected sentence structure for the osv speaker condition both structure elicited different response on frontal electrode possibly indexing effort to switch from a local speaker model to a global model of language use overall the study identifies distinct neural mechanism related to speaker specific expectation

Title: High frequency heart rate variability: Evidence for a transdiagnostic association with suicide ideation
Authors: Adolph, D.; Teismann, T.; Forkmann, T.; Wannemuller, A.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: low level of high frequency heart rate variability hf hrv have been shown to be associated with suicidal ideation and behavior in student and depressed patient the goal of the present study wa to examine association between suicide ideation and resting hf hrv a well a hf hrv reactivity in a diagnostically heterogeneous sample of adult outpatient with or without concurrent suicide ideation participant were n 85 outpatient 67 1 female age m 38 8 sd 13 72 hf hrv reactivity wa assessed using a sad film induction method association between resting hf hrv hf hrv reactivity and suicide ideation were analyzed using linear regression modeling controlling for depression anxiety and stress hf hrv reactivity towards the sad film but not low resting hf hrv baseline wa predictive of higher score on suicidal ideation within the whole sample in woman lower resting a well a perturbed hf hrv reactivity wa associated with higher score on suicidal ideation result suggest that suicide ideators have a reduced capacity to regulate their response to stress

Title: Specificity of resting-state heart rate variability in psychosis: A comparison with clinical high risk, anxiety, and healthy controls
Authors: Clamor, A.; Sundag, J.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: maladaptability particularly of autonomic activity is described a a central component of vulnerability stress model for the pathogenesis of psychotic symptom investigating heart rate variability hrv a an index of autonomic adaptability is thus likely to improve our understanding of psychosis in clinically vulnerable group for psychosis it is unclear whether maladaptability is already evident moreover to investigate specificity direct comparison to other mental disorder are required in the present study we analyzed 3 min of resting state heart rate hrv and negative affect in 130 participant consisting of participant with psychotic disorder psy n 44 clinical high risk for psychosis chr n 22 anxiety disorder anxiety control ac n 29 and healthy control hc n 35 ancovas controlling for age revealed significant group difference for both investigated vagal hrv parameter which were reduced in psy compared to hc the high frequency domain hrv in psy wa also lower than in chr and in a non significant trend than in ac also anova for heart rate and negative affect revealed significant increase in psy compared to hc exploratory analysis of medication effect showed moderate dosage association with heart rate and high frequency hrv thus in the present study the activity of the autonomic nervous system wa altered in psychosis but not in an at risk group a potential specificity of the effect can be speculated in contrast to anxiety disorder future study should investigate the predictive value of hrv for increased stress sensitivity or transition to clinical symptom a well a the implication for daily threat perception and symptom maintenance

Title: Incentive-based extinction of safety behaviors: Positive outcomes competing with aversive outcomes trigger fear-opposite action to prevent protection from fear extinction
Authors: Pittig, A.
