Abstract: maladaptive safety behavior maintains fear and anxiety by prohibiting inhibitory learning about the non occurrence of feared outcome known a protection from extinction not engaging in safety behavior however requires to act opposite to fear motivated behavioral tendency the initiation of such fear opposite action by positive outcome which were in conflict with safety behavior wa tested following fear acquisition to a warning signal c participant acquired safety behavior to prevent the aversive outcome n 48 next safety behavior also prevented gaining reward in a control group n 50 neutral outcome were presented to control for novelty effect of the second outcome subsequently no aversive outcome occurred anymore phase with safety behavior were intermitted by phase without safety behavior being available to examine cognitive and physiological indicator of fear and anxiety without competing positive outcome safety behavior wa frequently executed persisted in absence of the aversive outcome and prohibited extinction learning positive outcome clearly reduced safety behavior despite equal level of acquired fear this enabled fear extinction a soon a the aversive outcome wa absent importantly this extinction learning resulted in attenuated fear and anxiety response when safety behavior became unavailable post hoc finding indicated that the mere anticipation of positive outcome slightly reduced safety behavior thus competing positive outcome triggered fear opposite action that prevented persistent safety behavior and protection from extinction

Title: Fuel to the fire: The escalating interplay of attachment and maltreatment in the transgenerational transmission of psychopathology in families living in refugee camps
Authors: Scharpf, F.; Mkinga, G.; Neuner, F.; Machumu, M.; Hecker, T.
Abstract: maltreatment by parent can be conceptualized a pathogenic escalation of a disturbed parent child relationship that have devastating consequence for child s development and mental health although parental psychopathology ha been shown to be a risk factor both for maltreatment and insecure attachment representation these factor joint contribution to child psychopathology ha not been investigated in a sample of burundian refugee family living in refugee camp in western tanzania the association between attachment representation maltreatment and psychopathology were examined by conducting structured interview with 226 child aged 7 to 15 and both their parent structural equation modeling revealed that child s insecure attachment representation and maltreatment by mother fully mediated the relation between maternal and child psychopathology model fit comparative fit index cfi 0 96 root mean square error of approximation rmsea 0 05 a direct association between paternal and child psychopathology wa observed model fit cfi 0 96 rmsea 0 05 the finding suggest a vicious cycle wherein an insecure attachment to a mother suffering from psychopathology may be linked to child s risk to be maltreated which may reinforce insecure representation and perpetuate the pathogenic relational experience intervention targeting the attachment relationship and parental mental health may prevent negative child outcome

Title: No matter of etiology: biogenetic, psychosocial and vulnerability-stress causal explanations fail to improve attitudes towards schizophrenia
Authors: Schlier, B.; Schmick, S.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: many anti stigma campaign emphasize biogenetic cause to convey that schizophrenia is an illness like others a growing body of study show that although biogenetic explanation reduce blame they tend to reinforce prognostic pessimism and harsher treatment of people with schizophrenia in contrast psychosocial explanation attenuate prognostic pessimism and perceived otherness but seem le suitable to reduce blame we hypothesized that a vulnerability stress model that combine biogenetic and psychosocial explanation would yield clearer stigma reducing effect than the mono causal model in an online experiment 416 participant from the general population randomly received either a vulnerability stress biogenetic psychosocial or control intervention which consisted of information text and video presentation of a case example causal belief stereotype and desired social distance were assessed by self report baseline causal belief were weakly associated with stereotype the vulnerability stress intervention did not reduce stigma more effectively than the biogenetic or psychosocial intervention and wa le effective in reducing perceived blame than the biogenetic intervention compared to the control intervention no intervention showed significant stigma reducing effect but the psychosocial and vulnerability stress condition both increased blame we found no evidence for vulnerability stress explanation a a mean to reduce stigma we propose further research to identify more effective way to tackle stigma

Title: The Benefits of Physical Activity and Positive Mental Health for Reducing the Burden of COVID-19: Validation from a Cross-sectional and Longitudinal Investigation in China and Germany
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Zhang, X. C.; Cai, D.; Lu, S.; Gao, Z. H.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: many people experience high burden by the outbreak of the coronavirus disease covid 19 and it consequence for health and everyday life the present cross national study investigated potential factor that can reduce the burden by covid 19 in china and germany cross sectional and longitudinal china n 474 baseline bl 2015 follow up fu 2020 germany n 359 bl 2019 fu 2020 data on physical activity e g jogging bl fu positive mental health pmh bl fu and burden by covid 19 fu were collected via online survey in both country physical activity wa positively associated with pmh and both variable were negatively related to burden by covid 19 furthermore pmh mediated the link between physical activity and burden the mediation model wa significant when physical activity and pmh were assessed at the bl while burden wa measured at the fu and it wa also significant when all variable were assessed at the fu the present finding reveal that physical activity in combination with pmh can reduce the experience of burden by covid 19 conscious fostering of physical activity and pmh is supported a an effective strategy to reduce the negative impact of the pandemic outbreak on mental and physical health additional benefit such a increased adherence to governmental measure around covid 19 are discussed

Title: Individual Variability of Pleasantness Ratings to Stroking Touch Over Different Velocities
Authors: Croy, I.; Bierling, A.; Sailer, U.; Ackerley, R.
Abstract: many study have investigated the perception of tactile pleasantness over a range of stroking velocity on average pleasantness is low at slow e g 0 3 cm s and fast e g 30 cm s stroking velocity but is rated highest at velocity between 1 and 10 cm s on a group level this result in an inverted u shape pleasantness rating curve which is described statistically by a negative quadratic equation we reanalyzed the data from five earlier study to investigate whether the inverted u shape pleasantness curve at the group level is also present at the level of the individual a precondition for using tactile pleasantness perception a a diagnostic marker we pooled the data from five study with a total of 127 participant each study included a standard condition of stroking on the dorsal forearm over different velocity 0 3 1 3 10 30 cm s and participant rated the pleasantness factor other than stroking velocity were also varied in these study on the whole group level and in each study pleasantness rating produced a significant negative quadratic pleasantness curve over the stroking velocity in individual participant rating varied greatly and only 42 of the participant showed a significant negative quadratic curve the steepness of the inverted u correlated only moderately across other experimental condition showing that the experimental circumstance can influence pleasantness rating our finding have important implication for future work where difference in the tactile pleasantness curve should not be used to predict or diagnose issue at an individual level

Title: Postpartum bonding: the impact of maternal depression and adult attachment style
Authors: Nonnenmacher, N.; Noe, D.; Ehrenthal, J. C.; Reck, C.
Abstract: maternal depression pose a risk for the developing mother infant relationship similarly maternal insecure attachment style may limit the ability to adequately connect with the newborn during the postpartum period the aim of this study wa to investigate the effect of maternal depression and insecure attachment insecure and dual disorganized on maternal bonding in a sample of n 34 woman with depression according to dsm iv and n 59 healthy woman maternal depression wa assessed 3 to 4 month postpartum with the structured clinical interview for dsm iv axis i disorder scid i bonding with the postpartum bonding questionnaire and maternal attachment style with the attachment style interview woman with current and lifetime depression a well a woman with dual disorganized attachment style reported lower bonding explorative analysis revealed that depression partially mediated the link between dual disorganized attachment style and bonding with a medium sized mediation effect the combination of maternal depression and dual disorganized attachment style may pose a special risk constellation for the developing mother infant bond that should be addressed in prevention and early intervention program

Title: How "mere" is the mere ownership effect in memory? Evidence for semantic organization processes
Authors: Englert, J.; Wentura, D.
Abstract: memory is better for item arbitrarily assigned to the self than for item assigned to another person mere ownership effect moe in a series of six experiment we investigated the role of semantic process for the moe following successful replication we investigated whether the moe wa contingent upon semantic processing for meaningless stimulus there wa no moe testing for a potential role of semantic elaboration using meaningful stimulus in an encoding task without verbal label we found evidence of spontaneous semantic processing irrespective of self or other assignment when semantic organization wa manipulated the moe vanished if a semantic classification task wa added to the self other assignment but persisted for a perceptual classification task furthermore we found greater clustering of self assigned than of other assigned item in free recall taken together these result suggest that the moe could be based on the organizational principle of a me versus not me categorization

Title: Keep calm! Gender differences in mental rotation performance are modulated by habitual expressive suppression
Authors: Fladung, A. K.; Kiefer, M.
Abstract: men have been frequently found to perform more accurately than woman in mental rotation task however men and woman also differ with regard to the habitual use of emotion regulation strategy particularly with regard to expressive suppression i e the suppression of emotional expression in behavior a emotional suppression is more often used by men emotion regulation strategy might be a variable modulating gender difference in mental rotation performance the present study therefore examined the influence of gender and emotion regulation strategy on mental rotation performance accuracy and feedback processing twenty eight men and 28 woman matched for relevant demographic variable performed mental rotation task of varying difficulty over a prolonged time emotional feedback wa given immediately after each trial result showed that woman reported to use expressive suppression le frequently than men woman made more error in the mental rotation task than men confirming earlier demonstration of gender difference furthermore woman were more impaired by the negative feedback a indicated by the increased likelihood of subsequent error compared with men task performance of woman not habitually using expressive suppression wa most inferior and most strongly influenced by failure feedback compared with men woman using expressive suppression more habitually did not significantly differ in mental rotation accuracy and feedback processing from men hence expressive suppression reduces gender difference in mental rotation accuracy by improving cognitive performance following failure feedback

Title: The relationship between therapist competence and homework compliance in maintenance cognitive therapy for recurrent depression: secondary analysis of a randomized trial
Authors: Weck, F.; Richtberg, S.; Esch, S.; Hofling, V.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: meta analysis reveal that homework compliance is associated with a better treatment outcome however little is known about the process that could be responsible for patient compliance with homework it ha been proposed that therapist competence in particular with respect to reviewing homework is highly relevant for homework compliance the present study is a secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial altogether 54 patient with recurrent depressive disorder currently in remission who were treated with maintenance cognitive therapy mct were considered one videotaped treatment session of each patient wa randomly selected and therapist competence general competence and specific competence in setting and reviewing homework wa assessed by 2 independent raters furthermore both patient and therapist view of the therapeutic alliance were evaluated by questionnaire in this therapy session homework compliance considering quantitative a well a qualitative aspect in the following session wa evaluated by 2 additional raters these 2 raters were blinded regarding the rating of the therapeutic competence in a multilevel path analysis model a significant association between the therapeutic competence in reviewing homework and homework compliance wa detected while the therapeutic alliance and several patient characteristic were not associated with homework compliance we found no relationship between homework compliance and treatment outcome our result demonstrate that a specific therapeutic competence i e competence in reviewing homework is associated with patient compliance with homework and therefore provides further empirical evidence of the importance of therapist competence in the psychotherapeutic process

Title: [Metacognitions and interoceptive sensibility in the perception of premonitory urges in tic disorders across the lifespan]
Authors: Schutteler, C.; Gerlach, A. L.
Abstract: metacognitions and interoceptive sensibility in the perception of premonitory urge in tic disorder across the lifespan abstract objective depending on contextual factor the prevalence of premonitory urge pu in patient with tic disorder td increase with age and varies both intra and interindividually in youth pu correlate with metacognitions in both youth and adult interoceptive sensibility is altered compared to healthy control we examined the relationship between pu tic metacognitions and interoceptive sensibility across the lifespan regarding tic severity method in an online survey 53 participant reported their pu on the premonitory urge for tic scale put and tic severity on the symptom checklist for tic disorder sbb tic we assessed interoceptive sensibility via the body perception questionnaire bpq a and metacognitions regarding tic with the belief about tic scale bat result adult scored higher on the put than youth in youth interoceptive sensibility increased with age interoceptive sensibility correlated with put metacognitions and interoceptive sensibility explained a significant amount of variance in premonitory urge even after controlling for tic severity and age conclusion the presumed cause of age dependent development of pu in youth lie in their neurophysiological maturing process however negative metacognitions and interoceptive ability also play an important role in the development and maintenance of pu and might be of therapeutic use in the treatment of td

Title: Metacognitive Change During Exposure and Metacognitive Therapy in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
Authors: Hansmeier, J.; Haberkamp, A.; Glombiewski, J. A.; Exner, C.
Abstract: metacognitive therapy mct ha been shown to be a promising treatment approach for obsessive compulsive disorder ocd the changeability of metacognitions by metacognitive treatment and it relevance to treatment outcome is however still unclear the current study investigates 1 if treatment with mct or exposure and response prevention erp in a randomized controlled pilot trial n 24 patient with ocd change ocd specific metacognitions of thought fusion belief belief about ritual and stop signal and 2 if these change are relevant for the treatment outcome in term of patient and therapist rated ocd symptom anova with pretest posttest and follow up score could show that all three metacognitions significantly decreased during both treatment regarding thought fusion belief a significant interaction effect indicated a higher decrease after mct than erp treatment in hierarchical regression analysis change in stop signal from pre to post treatment significantly predicted patient rating ocd symptom at post treatment and follow up at 3 month after treatment these change were even predictive of post treatment outcome after controlling for general metacognitions and dysfunctional cognitive belief these finding support the assumption that metacognitions can change during both treatment and that change in stop signal might be relevant for the treatment outcome on the symptom level in ocd

Title: Adolescents' neural reactivity to acute psychosocial stress: dysfunctional regulation habits are linked to temporal gyrus response
Authors: Golde, S.; Gleich, T.; Romund, L.; Stippl, A.; Pelz, P.; Raufelder, D.; Lorenz, R. C.; Beck, A.
Abstract: mid adolescence is a critical time for the development of stress related disorder and it is associated with significant social vulnerability however little is known about normative neural process accompanying psychosocial stress at this time previous research found that emotion regulation strategy critically influence the relationship between stress and the development of psychiatric symptom during adolescence using functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri we examined neural response to acute stress and analyzed whether the tendency to use adaptive or maladaptive emotion regulation strategy is related to neural and autonomic stress response result show large linear activation increase from low to medium to high stress level mainly in medial prefrontal insulae and temporal area caudate and subgenual anterior cingulate cortex neural area related to reward and affective valuation showed linearly decreasing activation in line with our hypothesis the current adolescent neural stress profile resembled social rejection and wa characterized by pronounced activation in insula angular and temporal cortex moreover result point to an intriguing role of the anterior temporal gyrus stress related activity in the anterior temporal gyrus wa positively related to maladaptive regulation strategy and stress induced autonomic activity maladaptive coping might increase the social threat and reappraisal load of a stressor relating to higher stress sensitivity of anterior temporal cortex

Title: Disentangling the Sources of Mimicry: Social Relations Analyses of the Link Between Mimicry and Liking
Authors: Salazar Kampf, M.; Liebermann, H.; Kerschreiter, R.; Krause, S.; Nestler, S.; Schmukle, S. C.
Abstract: mimicry is an important interpersonal behavior for initiating and maintaining relationship by observing the same participant n 139 in multiple dyadic interaction 618 data point in a round robin design we disentangled the extent to which mimicry is due to a the mimicker s general tendency to mimic imitativity b the mimickee s general tendency to evoke mimicry imitatability and c the unique dyadic relationship between the mimicker and the mimickee we explored how these mimicry component affected liking and metaperceptions of liking i e metaliking employing social relation model we found substantial interindividual difference in imitativity which predicted popularity however we found only small interindividual difference in imitatability we found support for our proposition that mimicry is a substantially dyadic construct explained mostly by the unique relationship between two people finally we explored the link between dyadic mimicry and liking and we found that a person s initial liking of his or her interaction partner led to mimicry which in turn increased the partner s liking of the mimicker

Title: Effects of a Mindfulness Task on Women's Sexual Response
Authors: Velten, J.; Margraf, J.; Chivers, M. L.; Brotto, L. A.
Abstract: mindfulness based intervention are effective at improving symptom of sexual dysfunction in woman the mechanism by which mindfulness improves sexual function are le clear the main objective of our study wa to investigate the impact of a mindfulness task on sexual response in woman forty one woman mean age 27 2 sd 5 6 participated in two laboratory session that each included two erotic film and one attention task that were presented in counterbalanced order both attention task consisted of a six minute audio recording of either a modified body scan focusing on genital arousal sensation mindfulness condition or a visualization exercise subjective and genital sexual arousal were measured continuously during stimulus presentation the mindfulness task led to greater subjective and lower genital arousal the agreement of subjective and genital sexual arousal i e concordance wa greater in the mindfulness condition trait mindfulness wa related to lower sexual arousal but also greater sexual concordance in woman mindfulness based intervention that encourage woman to focus on physical arousal sensation in the here and now may be associated with woman s improved sexual function by enhancing feeling of sexual arousal during sexual activity and by increasing concordance between subjective and genital sexual arousal

Title: Effects of full-body mirror exposure on eating pathology, body image and emotional states: Comparison between positive and negative verbalization
Authors: Tanck, J. A.; Hartmann, A. S.; Svaldi, J.; Vocks, S.
Abstract: mirror exposure me is an effective technique to improve body image however evidence on the underlying mechanism and the optimal verbalization instruction during me is lacking therefore this experimental study analyzed mechanism of me and therapeutic outcome by comparing positive pv and negative nv full body verbalization n 73 healthy female were randomized to a pv or an nv condition pv participant verbalized positively while nv participant verbalized negatively about their whole body each participant underwent three standardized me session before and after each me session positive affect negative affect and body satisfaction were assessed before the first and after the third me participant completed questionnaire on cognitive affective and behavioral aspect of body image eating pathology and self esteem regarding within me change the result indicate that positive affect and body satisfaction decreased while negative affect increased in the nv group but not in the pv group in contrast regarding between me change decreased negative affect a well a positive affect and increased body satisfaction were observed in both group however eating pathology remained stable whereas body checking behavior increased and the pv condition wa followed by higher level of self esteem compared to the nv condition these finding suggest that both pv and nv improve negative affect and body satisfaction between me and thus seem to be effective me instruction given that nv led to increased negative affect within me and did not influence self esteem pv might represent the favorable instruction during me for body satisfied woman

Title: Testing a gamified Spider App to reduce spider fear and avoidance
Authors: Haberkamp, A.; Walter, H.; Althaus, P.; Schmuck, M.; Rief, W.; Schmidt, F.
Abstract: mobile application are increasingly part of mental health program and various apps have been developed for treating anxiety disorder typically they aim to improve anxiety symptom via established cbt technique such a exposure principle which are considered extremely unpleasant for fearful individual we combined in a mobile application exposure principle with gamification element e g narrative background level progression point and feedback these element should increase the motivation for confronting spider image and decrease the experienced distress to evaluate the application two group of spider fearful individual played either the spider app experimental group or a non spider associated app control group twice a day for approximately 12 min for 7 day after this week participant of the experimental group showed le avoidance behavior of spider bat a well a lower anxiety of spider spq fa group were not different in measure of depression or psychological distress interestingly participant playing the spider app reported higher anxiety disgust and arousal rating shortly after playing the app however anxiety disgust and arousal rating decreased from day to day we discus our finding with respect to implication for the clinical practice

Title: Taking a Closer Look at Social Performance in Childhood Social Anxiety Disorder: Biopsychosocial Context Considerations and Effects of Cognitive Behavior Therapy
Authors: Asbrand, J.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.
Abstract: model of social anxiety disorder sad describe shortfall in child social performance whereas empirically child often show a deficit only in subjective and not objective performance we examined social performance in relation to possible change before and after cognitive behavior therapy cbt including social skill training and to an objective parameter vocal arousal child with sad were expected to subjectively judge their behavior a le competent than healthy control hc child despite a lack of objective difference child receiving cbt were expected to show a change in subjective and objective social performance in comparison to child waiting for treatment exploratory correlation analysis were used to disentangle the relation between social performance and vocal arousal one hundred and nineteen child 64 with and 55 without sad aged 9 13 year completed a trier social stress test tsst child with sad participated in a second tsst after cbt or waiting performance wa assessed by self report and by blinded observer vocal arousal wa analyzed by audio recording child with sad were objectively assessed a more socially competent than hc child subjectively child with sad showed lower social performance cbt showed no effect on subjective or objective performance rating vocal arousal did not correlate with social performance result need to be considered carefully a psychometric problem appeared that had not been considered in previous study the surprising lack of cbt effect suggests a need to focus on cognition surrounding social performance further social skill training should not be a standard sad treatment component but used only if necessary

Title: Autonomic Dysregulation in Child Social Anxiety Disorder: An Experimental Design Using CBT Treatment
Authors: Asbrand, J.; Vogele, C.; Heinrichs, N.; Nitschke, K.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.
Abstract: model of social anxiety disorder sad stress the relevance of physiological arousal so far limited research ha been conducted in child with sad in experimental stress design thus examining autonomic arousal child with and without sad completed a standardized social stressor trier social stress test for child c tsst c pre existing difference to healthy control hc were expected to decrease after receiving cognitive behavior therapy cbt child with sad n 64 and hc child n 55 completed a tsst c child with sad participated in a second tsst c after either cognitive behavioral treatment or a waitlist control period wlc a expected child with sad showed blunted heart rate reactivity compared to hc child further child with sad had elevated level of tonic sympathetic arousal a indexed by skin conductance level compared to hc child with sad showed lower parasympathetic arousal during the baseline compared to hc child receiving treatment did not differ from child in the wlc condition in a repeated social stress test psychophysiological difference between child with sad and hc child could be confirmed a indicated by previous research the lack of physiological effect of the intervention a an experimental manipulation might be related to slower change in physiology compared to e g cognition

Title: Electrocortical correlates of impaired motor inhibition and outcome processing are related in high binge-watching
Authors: Dieterich, R.; Wullhorst, V.; Berghauser, J.; Overmeyer, R.; Endrass, T.
Abstract: model posit problematic binge watching to involve a vicious circle of low motivation for alternative activity low sensitivity for the consequence of neglected goal and low self control a such simultaneously impaired feedback and inhibitory functioning might contribute to binge watching we tested the hypothesis that blunted feedback related brain activity is coupled with attenuated inhibitory brain activity in binge watcher high n 32 and non binge watcher n 31 performed go nogo inhibition and stop signal stopping task and a flanker paradigm with performance feedback during electroencephalography we examined how neural correlate of inhibition and stopping were associated with outcome processing in each group we assessed the temporospatial relationship using a single trial regression approach high binge watcher but not non binge watcher who differentiated le between gain and loss at the neural level feedback p3b also recruited le brain activity during both inhibition and stopping inhibition p3 and stopping p3 exploratory analysis suggested that these relationship were most prominent in high binge watcher with high loss of control over watching main effect of the group in performance or eeg did not emerge these result suggest a potentially problematic interaction between outcome and inhibitory function in binge watcher insensitivity to behavioral consequence along with inhibitory impairment may also confer a long term risk for compulsive watching our multi modal approach may be particularly suited to detect such an underlying risk marker

Title: Embodiment in Virtual Reality Intensifies Emotional Responses to Virtual Stimuli
Authors: Gall, D.; Roth, D.; Stauffert, J. P.; Zarges, J.; Latoschik, M. E.
Abstract: modulating emotional response to virtual stimulus is a fundamental goal of many immersive interactive application in this study we leverage the illusion of illusory embodiment and show that owning a virtual body provides mean to modulate emotional response in a single factor repeated measure experiment we manipulated the degree of illusory embodiment and assessed the emotional response to virtual stimulus we presented emotional stimulus in the same environment a the virtual body participant experienced higher arousal dominance and more intense valence in the high embodiment condition compared to the low embodiment condition the illusion of embodiment thus intensifies the emotional processing of the virtual environment this result suggests that artificial body can increase the effectiveness of immersive application psychotherapy entertainment computer mediated social interaction or health application

Title: The mental health of forcibly displaced couples
Authors: Mahmood, H. N.; Ibrahim, H.; Ismail, A. A.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: most current research investigating traumatic stress is focused on it effect at the individual level utilizing the implicit assumption that trauma related disorder are mutually independent within family and community however there is reason to assume that trauma related symptom within couple are influenced by each partner s risk factor and symptom using the actor partner interdependence model this study aimed to test whether symptom of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd and depression were predicted by participant partner s exposure to traumatic event over and above the influence of the participant s own experience for this purpose we interviewed 687 heterosexual married iraqi and syrian couple in iraq s kurdistan region who had been forcefully displaced we assessed symptom of ptsd and depression using locally validated scale nearly all participant 98 8 reported exposure to at least one traumatic event with husband reporting exposure to a higher number of traumatic event than wife d 0 48 p 001 more than half of the participant met the criterion for a probable ptsd 61 1 or major depressive disorder diagnosis 60 4 within couple significant actor effect of experienced trauma exposure on personal ptsd and depressive symptom were observed for both husband and wife further there were significant partner effect of wife traumatic experience on husband ptsd and depressive symptom a well a of husband traumatic experience on wife ptsd and depressive symptom the finding argue for the interdependence of trauma related symptom within dyad in a dual trauma context suggesting the presence of intracouple transmission of trauma related symptom

Title: Predictors of Prolonged Grief Disorder in a German Representative Population Sample: Unexpectedness of Bereavement Contributes to Grief Severity and Prolonged Grief Disorder
Authors: Doering, B. K.; Barke, A.; Vogel, A.; Comtesse, H.; Rosner, R.
Abstract: most people adapt to bereavement over time for a minority the grief persists and may lead to a prolonged grief disorder pgd identifying griever at risk of pgd may enable specific prevention measure the present study examined the extent to which the subjective unexpectedness of the death predicted grief outcome above and beyond known sociodemographic and objective loss related variable in a sample drawn from a population representative investigation in our sample n 2 531 811 participant m age 55 1 17 8 year 59 2 woman had experienced the loss of a significant person six or more month ago participant provided demographic and loss related information perception of the unexpectedness of the death and completed the prolonged grief disorder 13 9 pg 13 9 the pg 13 9 wa used to determine pgd caseness a binary logistic regression investigated predictor of pgd caseness and a linear regression predictor of grief severity ancovas compared pgd symptom between the group who had experienced an expected v unexpected loss while controlling for the relationship to the deceased and time since loss the loss of a child or 23 66 95 ci 6 03 68 28 or a partner or 5 32 95 ci 1 79 15 83 the time since loss or 0 99 95 ci 0 99 1 00 and the unexpectedness of the death or 3 58 95 ci 1 70 7 69 were significant predictor of pgd caseness nagelkerke s r 2 0 25 and grief severity participant who had experienced the loss a unexpected v expected reported higher score on all pgd symptom unexpectedness of the death emerged a significant risk factor for pgd even after controlling for demographic and other loss related variable while our finding replicate previous research on the importance of the relationship to the deceased a a risk factor for pgd they also highlight the importance of assessing the subjective unexpectedness of a death and may help to identify risk group who can profit from preventive intervention

Title: The socially evaluated handgrip test: Introduction of a novel, time-efficient stress protocol
Authors: Finke, J. B.; Kalinowski, G. I.; Larra, M. F.; Schachinger, H.
Abstract: most widely used stress induction procedure such a the tsst and the cold pressor test require considerable effort and overhead in term of preparation logistics and staff recruitment moreover while known to reliably induce hpa axis activation especially when combined with social self threat most conventional laboratory stressor cannot be flexibly adapted to elicit either a mainly autonomic or an additional endocrine stress response being a promising alternative approach a new version of the isometric handgrip test enriched by a social evaluative component wa evaluated in the present study on two consecutive session forty participant 20 woman performed a handgrip task at both 45 stress and 10 control of maximum voluntary isometric contraction lasting for 3min during the stress test continuous visual feedback on performance wa given participant in the social evaluative condition 50 were observed and evaluated by a previously unknown person of the opposite sex whereas in the standard condition feedback wa provided via a computer monitor cardiovascular measure heart rate blood pressure a well a additional index of autonomic reactivity skin conductance heart rate variability were registered before during and after stress induction moreover change in salivary cortisol and in subjective well being were assessed relative to control significant increase in cardiovascular and sympathetic activity were found irrespective of experimental group importantly however additional social evaluation resulted in elevated cortisol level furthermore evidence for reduced vagal tone during sustained socially evaluated handgrip emerged in conclusion the socially evaluated handgrip test represents a versatile time efficient method to induce stress in small laboratory setting

Title: Mother-child bonding is associated with the maternal perception of the child's body odor
Authors: Croy, I.; Mohr, T.; Weidner, K.; Hummel, T.; Junge-Hoffmeister, J.
Abstract: mother can recognize the odor of their baby and typically adore this odor in line with this observation infant body odor activate reward related brain area in the mother in some mother child dyad however the mutual bond is impaired and mother have trouble engaging in interaction with their child we aimed to examine how mother with bonding difficulty perceive their child s body odor in total 75 mother of baby aged 0 12 month were examined twenty five of those were recruited in a psychosomatic day hospital ward which is specialized for mother child bonding disorder fifty age matched healthy woman and their baby served a control body odor sample of each baby were collected from bodysuits in a highly standardized procedure thereafter each mother rated the sample of her own and two other infant in a blind and randomized design in addition general olfactory function in term of threshold and identification ability wa tested and the mother reported the bonding to her baby in a standardized questionnaire healthy mother showed a clear preference of their own compared to odor of other infant s while mother with bonding difficulty did not furthermore the degree of preference wa negatively correlated to self reported bonding difficulty mother with bonding difficulty could not identify their own infant s odor above chance while control mother could both group did not differ in general olfactory function we assume that reduced close body contact and interaction time associated with bonding difficulty may lead to reduced exposure and hinder the recognition of the infantile body odor within a vicious cycle a reduced hedonic experience smelling their own baby may prevent woman from deliberately approaching the baby thus the positive and bond building consequence of bodily and sensory interaction cannot unfold a the baby s odor is normally perceived a very pleasant and rewarding the conscious perception of the infantile body odor may be an additive therapeutic approach for mother with bonding difficulty

Title: Children's Body Odors: Hints to the Development Status
Authors: Schafer, L.; Sorokowska, A.; Weidner, K.; Croy, I.
Abstract: mother can recognize their own child by body odor besides signaling familiarity child s body odor may provide other information relevant to maternal caregiving behavior such a the child s developmental status thus we explored whether mother are able to classify body odor on pre v postpubertal status above chance level in total 164 mother were presented with body odor sample of their own and four unfamiliar sex matched child who varied in age range 0 18 year pubertal status wa measured by a determining the child s steroid hormone level and b parental assessment of the child s developmental stage using the pubertal development scale mother classified developmental status with an accuracy of about 64 maternal assessment were biased toward pre puberty classification wa predicted by perceptual evaluation of the body odor i e intensity and pleasantness and by the child s developmental stage but not by hormone in specific mother with pubertal aged child classified body odor using the child s developmental status whereas mother with younger child only classified body odor using perceptual information i e intensity and pleasantness our data suggests that body odor convey developmental cue but how this developmental information is manifested in body odor remains unclear

Title: Replication of fMRI group activations in the neuroimaging battery for the Mainz Resilience Project (MARP)
Authors: Kampa, M.; Schick, A.; Sebastian, A.; Wessa, M.; Tuscher, O.; Kalisch, R.; Yuen, K.
Abstract: motivated by the recent replicability crisis we tested replicability of functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri group activation in two independent sample an identical behavioral and fmri test battery for the longitudinal investigation of stress resilience mechanism wa developed for the mainz resilience project marp and conducted in a discovery n 54 and a replication sample n 103 the test battery consisted of a stress reactivity task a reward sensitivity task a fear conditioning and extinction paradigm two volitional reappraisal task and an emotional interference inhibition task replicability of group activation wa tested with the jaccard index and the intra class correlation icc overall we observed good to excellent replicability of activation at the whole brain level only a minority of contrast showed unsatisfactory replicability replicability at the level of individual region of interest roi wa generally lower task with stronger activation in the discovery sample showed better replicability

Title: Independent effects of motivation and spatial attention in the human visual cortex
Authors: Bayer, M.; Rossi, V.; Vanlessen, N.; Grass, A.; Schacht, A.; Pourtois, G.
Abstract: motivation and attention constitute major determinant of human perception and action nonetheless it remains a matter of debate whether motivation effect on the visual cortex depend on the spatial attention system or rely on independent pathway this study investigated the impact of motivation and spatial attention on the activity of the human primary and extrastriate visual cortex by employing a factorial manipulation of the two factor in a cued pattern discrimination task during stimulus presentation we recorded event related potential and pupillary response motivational relevance increased the amplitude of the c1 component at approximately 70 m after stimulus onset this modulation occurred independently of spatial attention effect which were evident at the p1 level furthermore motivation and spatial attention had independent effect on preparatory activation a measured by the contingent negative variation and pupil data showed increased activation in response to incentive target taken together these finding suggest independent pathway for the influence of motivation and spatial attention on the activity of the human visual cortex

Title: Lessons Learned from an Attempted Pragmatic Randomized Controlled Trial for Improvement of Chronic Pain-Associated Disability in Green Professions: Long-Term Effectiveness of a Guided Online-Based Acceptance and Commitment Therapy  (PACT-A)
Authors: Braun, L.; Terhorst, Y.; Titzler, I.; Freund, J.; Thielecke, J.; Ebert, D. D.; Baumeister, H.
Abstract: musculoskeletal symptom are increased in farmer whereas the prevalence of chronified pain is unknown online intervention based on acceptance and commitment therapy act have shown encouraging result in the general population representing a promising approach for reducing pain interference in green profession i e farmer forester gardener we conducted a pragmatic rct comparing a guided act based online intervention to enhanced treatment a usual in entrepreneur contributing spouse family member and pensioner in green profession with chronic pain cpg grade ii 6 month recruitment wa terminated prematurely after 2 5 year at n 89 of planned n 286 assessment were conducted at 9 week t1 6 month t2 and 12 month t3 post randomization the primary outcome wa pain interference t1 the secondary outcome encompassed pain health and intervention related variable no treatment effect for reduction of pain interference wa found at t1 beta 0 16 95 ci 0 64 0 32 p 0 256 improvement in cognitive fusion pain acceptance anxiety perceived stress and quality of life were found only at t3 intervention satisfaction a well a therapeutic and technological alliance were moderate and uptake and adherence were low result are restricted by low statistical power due to recruitment issue high study attrition and low intervention adherence standing in contrast to previous study further research is warranted regarding the use of act based online intervention for chronic pain in this occupational group trial registration german clinical trial registration drks00014619 registered 16 april 2018
Journal: Int J Environ Res Public Health

Title: Frequencies and Predictors of Negative Effects in Routine Inpatient and Outpatient Psychotherapy: Two Observational Studies
Authors: Gerke, L.; Meyrose, A. K.; Ladwig, I.; Rief, W.; Nestoriuc, Y.
Abstract: negative effect of psychotherapy nep include side effect malpractice and unethical behavior it setting specific frequency and predictor are mostly unknown the two presented study aim to investigate nep and it predictor systematically across different treatment setting in study 1 n 197 patient of a german outpatient center were recruited on average 3 76 year after the termination of psychotherapy in study 2 data from n 118 patient of two german inpatient clinic were collected at admission t 0 discharge t 1 and 9 month follow up t 2 all participant evaluated the negative effect of their previous out or inpatient psychotherapy with the inventory for the balanced assessment of negative effect in psychotherapy and a priori hypothesized predictor at least one side effect wa reported by 37 3 of inpatient t 2 and 15 2 of outpatient at least one case of malpractice and unethical behavior wa reported by 28 8 of inpatient t 2 and 7 1 of outpatient inpatient reported significantly more side effect u 14347 z 4 70 p 0 001 r 0 26 and malpractice and unethical behavior u 14168 z 5 21 p 0 001 r 0 29 than outpatient rate of severe malpractice in the form of breaking confidentiality and physical and sexual abuse were le than 1 in both setting predictor of side effect were prior experience with psychotherapy and current interpersonal difficulty in the outpatient setting and higher motivation for psychotherapy t 0 in the inpatient setting predictor of malpractice and unethical behavior were younger age in the outpatient setting and poor therapeutic alliance prior negative experience with malpractice and unethical behavior and higher outcome expectation in the inpatient setting nep are common in both in and outpatient setting inpatient are at higher risk for the nep than outpatient to safeguard patient wellbeing the systematic assessment and distinction of side effect and malpractice and unethical behavior should gain more attention in research and clinical practice

Title: Differential caloric intake in overweight females with and without binge eating: effects of a laboratory-based emotion-regulation training
Authors: Svaldi, J.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.; Trentowska, M.; Caffier, D.; Naumann, E.
Abstract: negative emotion are among the best predictor for the occurrence of binge eating attack in binge eating disorder bed evidence from self report and experimental study suggests that this link may be mediated by deficit in emotion regulation er therefore the aim of the present study wa to experimentally test the effect of a short laboratory based er training on caloric intake in bed thirty nine woman with bed and 42 overweight female without bed were randomly assigned to a laboratory based er training focusing on either expressive suppression or cognitive reappraisal they were then given a negative mood induction with the instruction to adopt the learned er strategy which wa followed by a bogus taste test independent of group membership caloric intake wa significantly higher in the suppression compared to the reappraisal condition furthermore the bed group displayed significantly higher habitual suppression and significantly lower habitual reappraisal score than the overweight group the data suggest that therapeutic intervention focusing on the mediation of more adaptive affect regulation skill may be useful for the reduction of binge eating episode

Title: Future expectations in clinical depression: Biased or realistic?
Authors: Zetsche, U.; Burkner, P. C.; Renneberg, B.
Abstract: negative expectation have been highlighted a a key mechanism in the maintenance and recurrence of depression nonetheless no study ha investigated currently depressed individual expectation about their future mood so far this is surprising given that experience of sustained negative mood and lack of positive mood are the hallmark symptom of depression the present study thus assessed depressed individual expectation about their future mood and examined whether these expectation are accurate or negatively biased the study used experience sampling methodology esm to contrast participant expectation with their actually experienced sad and happy mood within a 4 day period at the end of this period participant recalled their past mood all variable were assessed in 30 clinically depressed individual and 37 matched healthy control a well a in 56 undergraduate student with a wide range in depressive symptom result revealed that clinically depressed individual held negatively biased expectation about their future mood they expected more sad and le happy mood than they actually experienced in contrast healthy individual showed realistic expectation about their future mood depressed individual also demonstrated a negative mood recall bias finally individual expectation and memory were more closely linked to depression status than their actually experienced mood although negative mood is the hallmark symptom of depression the expectation and memory of negative mood may be even more central for the understanding of depression psycinfo database record c 2019 apa all right reserved

Title: Optimizing the ingredients for imagery-based interpretation bias modification for depressed mood: is self-generation more effective than imagination alone?
Authors: Rohrbacher, H.; Blackwell, S. E.; Holmes, E. A.; Reinecke, A.
Abstract: negative interpretation is thought to be crucial in the development and maintenance of depression recently developed cognitive bias modification paradigm intending to change these bias towards a more optimistic interpretation tendency cbm i seem to offer new promising implication for cognitive therapy innovation this study aimed to increase our knowledge of the underlying mechanism of action of imagery based cbm i in the context of depressed mood we therefore compared the efficacy of cbm i requiring participant to imagine standardized positive resolution to a novel more active training version that required participant to generate the positive interpretation themselves fifty four participant were randomly allocated to 1 standardized cbm i 2 self generation cbm i or 3 a control group outcome measure included self report mood measure and a depression related interpretation bias measure both positive training variant significantly increased the tendency to interpret fresh ambiguous material in an optimistic manner however only the standardized imagery cbm i paradigm positively influenced mood

Title: The effects of prior pain experience on neural correlates of empathy for pain: An fMRI study
Authors: Preis, M. A.; Schmidt-Samoa, C.; Dechent, P.; Kroener-Herwig, B.
Abstract: neuroimaging study have revealed partially shared neural substrate for both the actual experience of pain and empathy elicited by the pain of others we examined whether prior pain exposure increased neural activity in the anterior midcingulate cortex amcc and bilateral anterior insula ai a a correlate of empathy for pain participant n 64 32 woman 32 men viewed picture displaying exposure to pressure pain pain picture and picture without any cue of pain neutral picture prior to the experiment half of the participant were exposed to the same pain stimulus a the one seen in the pain picture pain exposure condition the other half had no such experience touch exposure condition a balanced sex ratio wa kept to investigate possible sex difference in the region of interest analysis participant of the pain exposure condition showed decreased activity in the right ai and the amcc relative to participant of the touch exposure condition while in men no difference were found in relation to their exposure condition woman with pain exposure showed decreased activity in the amcc and additionally in bilateral ai based on the entire sample whole brain analysis revealed stronger activation in the retrosplenial cortex dorsomedial prefrontal cortex and medial prefrontal cortex in the pain exposure condition in conclusion prior pain exposure did not increase but decreased activity in region regularly associated with empathy for pain however pain experience increased activity in region associated with memory retrieval perspective taking and top down emotion regulation which might facilitate empathizing with others

Title: Nightmare distress is related to traumatic childhood experiences, critical life events and emotional appraisal of a dream rather than to its content
Authors: Mathes, J.; Schuffelen, J.; Gieselmann, A.; Pietrowsky, R.
Abstract: nightmare are a substantial burden for sleep quality previous study have shown that traumatic experience can increase the probability of nightmare and also waking life distress can enhance this effect there is evidence that the intensity of negative dream emotion is more responsible for rating a dream a a nightmare than threatening dream content however there is still a lack of research concerning effect on nightmare distress we hypothesise that traumatic childhood experience such a emotional abuse obtained by the childhood trauma questionnaire critical life event obtained by the social readjustment rating scale and threatening dream content are associated with nightmare distress a sample of n 103 participant kept a dream diary over 28 consecutive day about 60 of the sample were frequent nightmare dreamer the participant recorded their violent dream content and dream emotion in their diary to predict nightmare distress regression model were constructed nightmare distress wa measured with the nightmare distress questionnaire result showed that emotional abuse in childhood and critical life event predicted nightmare distress moreover violent dream content were associated with nightmare distress but after we controlled for nightmare frequency and the intensity of negative dream emotion the significant impact of violent dream content decreased the result suggest that the emotional appraisal of a dream ha a substantial influence on nightmare in addition to traumatic childhood experience and critical life event

Title: When a dream turns into a nightmare: Due to negative dream content or to negative appraisal?Gender differences in dream content: Are they related to personality?Threats in dreams: Are they related to waking-life?Clinical judgement heuristics: Methods and models
Authors: Mathes, Jonas; Gieselmann, Annika; Pietrowsky, Reinhard; Mathes, Jonas; Schredl, Michael; Mathes, Jonas; Schredl, Michael; Kappesser, J.; de C Williams, A. C.
Abstract: nightmare are a well known phenomenon the content of aversive dream seems to be ubiquitous in dream nevertheless a dream containing aversive content doe not necessarily have to be a nightmare we hypothesize that nightmare are rather caused by a more negative appraisal of the content of aversive dream than by the dream content itself to investigate this question n 99 participant kept dream diary over 28 consecutive day an experimental group included person with frequent nightmare and a control group of person without nightmare violent dream content and emotion during the dream were analyzed by the dreamer themselves and a well a by four external raters regarding violent dream content in non nightmare dream report the external raters usually agreed with the dreamer rating however there wa significant disagreement regarding the nightmare report furthermore external raters significantly rated the dream a le positive than the dreamer did and external raters rated the nightmare report a more negative than the dreamer themselves did taken together the result support the hypothesis that the classification of a dream a a nightmare doe not only depend on it content but also on other factor this suggests that the dreamer rating of a dream a a nightmare are based on more factor than dream content gender difference in dream content have been studied quite extensively the present study focused on two dream characteristic the ratio of male and female dream character and the occurrence of weapon and clothes in dream a sample of 1612 diary dream reported by 425 participant wa analyzed using external rating by a blind judge whereas the gender difference regarding the ratio of male and female dream character wa not significant men reported more weapon dream but dream with reference to clothing le often which is in line with previous research the explorative analysis indicated that some of the big five personality dimension might be associated with these dream characteristic e g extraverted men s dream included more female character compared to the dream of introverted men research thus far and this study indicate that waking life preoccupation with clothes medium showing weapon waking life social contact etc strongly affect these dream characteristic but study explicitly measuring and correlating waking life experience and dream content are still missing according to the threat simulation theory tst dreaming ha developed and wa maintained during evolution because it function of rehearsing threat is essential for survival the present study analyzed 1612 diary dream reported by 425 participant mainly psychology student the study result indicate that threat play an important role in dream and thus support the idea that dreaming might have a function of rehearsing problematic or threatening situation comparing the present result to previous finding show a considerably large variability regarding the number of threat per dream the proportion of minor threat and the reality of threat a neuroticism and openness to experience were related to the number of threat per dream future research should investigate inter individual difference in waking life which might help explain the variability regarding the dream threat characteristic

Title: Symptom dynamics among nightmare sufferers: An intensive longitudinal study
Authors: Dumser, B.; Werner, G. G.; Ehring, T.; Takano, K.
Abstract: nightmare are considerably prevalent in the general population and are known to be closely associated with a variety of mental disorder however not much is known about the immediate antecedent and consequence of nightmare therefore we used intensive longitudinal assessment to investigate the night to night within person association between nightmare on the one hand and fear of sleep somatic a well a cognitive pre sleep arousal and sleep quality on the other hand young woman with regular nightmare n 16 maintained a sleep diary for around 30 day upon awaking the participant reported on nightmare and sleep quality during the past night a well a the pre sleep level of arousal and fear of sleep which resulted in 461 observation participant also wore an actigraph which provided objective sleep parameter multilevel modeling showed that higher level of fear of sleep and lower subjective sleep quality were significantly associated with higher level of nightmare distress furthermore we found individual difference in the strength of these association which implies that factor proximate to nightmare may vary across individual pre sleep arousal however did not show expected within person association with nightmare or fear of sleep these finding highlight the crucial role of fear of sleep in the etiology of nightmare and sleep disturbance while pointing to the importance of pursuing individual personalised model that explain heterogeneity in the process of triggering nightmare

Title: [Emotion Regulation in Adolescents with Nonsuicidal Self-Injury]
Authors: In-Albon, T.; Tschan, T.; Schwarz, D.; Schmid, M.
Abstract: nonsuicidal self injury nssi is a prevalent and impairing condition that wa newly included in dsm 5 in the section iii criterion for further research difficulty in emotion regulation play an important role in the development and maintenance of nssi this study investigated the emotion regulation in female adolescent with nssi according to dsm 5 n 55 clinical control adolescent with mental disorder without nssi n 30 and nonclinical control adolescent n 58 using self report questionnaire and interview a expected result indicated that adolescent with nssi have significantly more difficulty in emotion regulation compared to healthy control in addition adolescent with nssi reported also significantly more difficulty in impulse control lack of emotional clarity difficulty engaging in goal directed behavior and limited access to emotion regulation strategy compared to nonclinical and clinical control adolescent with nssi felt significantly more often sadness compared to clinical control d 0 66 and compared to other emotion adolescent with nssi indicated significantly le often happiness compared to nonclinical control d 1 83 result support that adolescent with nssi have difficulty in emotion regulation and that these difficulty are even more pronounced than in adolescent with other mental disorder clinical implication will be discussed

Title: The effectiveness of cognitive behavioural therapy for social anxiety disorder in routine clinical practice
Authors: Morina, N.; Seidemann, J.; Andor, T.; Sondern, L.; Burkner, P. C.; Drenckhan, I.; Buhlmann, U.
Abstract: numerous randomized controlled trial have shown cognitive behaviour therapy cbt to be effective in treating social anxiety disorder sad yet le is known about the effectiveness of cbt for sad conducted by psychotherapist in training in routine clinical practice in this study 231 patient with sad were treated with cbt under routine condition and were examined at pre and post treatment a well a at 6 and 12 month follow up we applied self report to a symptom of sad defined a primary outcome depression and psychological distress defined a secondary outcome we conducted both completer and intent to treat analysis and also assessed the reliability of change with the reliable change index result revealed significant reduction in symptom of sad between pre and post assessment with effect size ranging from d 0 9 to 1 2 depending on the sad specific questionnaire applied 47 8 to 73 5 of the sample showed a reliable positive change whereas 1 9 to 3 8 showed a reliable negative change depressive symptom and psychological distress also decreased significantly from pre to post assessment with large effect size significant treatment gain regarding both primary and secondary outcome were further observed at 6 and 12 month follow up the current finding based on a large sample of patient suggest that psychotherapist in cbt training working under routine condition can effectively treat symptom of sad depression and psychological distress

Title: Enhanced visuomotor processing of phobic images in blood-injury-injection fear
Authors: Haberkamp, A.; Schmidt, T.
Abstract: numerous study have identified attentional bias and processing enhancement for fear relevant stimulus in individual with specific phobia however this ha not been conclusively shown in blood injury injection bii phobia which ha rarely been investigated even though it ha feature distinct from all other specific phobia the present study aim to fill that gap and compare the time course of visuomotor processing of phobic stimulus i e picture of small injury in bii fearful n 19 and non anxious control participant n 23 by using a response priming paradigm in bii fearful participant phobic stimulus produced larger priming effect and lower response time compared to neutral stimulus whereas non anxious control participant showed no such difference because these effect are fully present in the fastest response they indicate an enhancement in early visuomotor processing of injury picture in bii fearful participant these result are comparable to the enhanced processing of phobic stimulus in other specific phobia i e spider phobia

Title: Prediction of BMI at age 11 in a longitudinal sample of the Ulm Birth Cohort Study
Authors: Christiansen, H.; Brandt, S.; Walter, V.; Wabitsch, M.; Rothenbacher, D.; Brenner, H.; Schimmelmann, B. G.; Hirsch, O.
Abstract: obesity is one of the greatest public health challenge in the world with childhood prevalence rate between 20 26 and numerous associated health risk the aim of the current study wa to analyze the 11 year follow up data of the ulm birth cohort study ubcs to identify whether abnormal eating behavior pattern especially restrained eating predict body mass index bmi at 11 year of age and to explore other factor known to be longitudinally associated with it of the original ubcs n 422 child 40 of the original sample and their parent participated in the 11 year follow up bmi at age 8 and 11 a well a information on restrained eating psychological problem depressive symptom lifestyle and iq at age 8 were assessed partial least square structural equation modeling pls sem wa used to predict child s bmi score at age 11 pls sem explained 68 of the variance of bmi at age 11 with bmi at age 8 being the most important predictor restrained eating via bmi at age 8 a well a parental bmi had further weak association with bmi at age 11 no other predictor wa statistically significant since established overweight at age 8 already predicts bmi score at age 11 longitudinally obesity intervention should be implemented in early childhood

Title: Pain localization in cluster headache patients: Onset, peak, and radiation
Authors: Schroder, P.; Gaul, C.; Drabik, A.; Molsberger, A.
Abstract: objective and aim to describe difference in pain location for onset peak and radiation aspect of cluster headache ch attack method and material data were collected for 23 month using a cross sectional online survey composed of 117 question on pain location demographic and clinical feature 5260 datapoints on 44 pain location from 631 respondent were analyzed result during the onset and peak of attack pain is concentrated periorbitally pain location outside the periorbital region were reported more frequently for radiation than for onset and peak of attack dorsal occipital neck shoulder pain wa reported more frequently in connection with onset and radiation than during peak onset 13 versus peak 6 p 0 001 and radiation 22 versus peak 6 p 0 001 there wa no significant difference in dorsal pain frequency for onset 13 v radiation 22 p 0 552 furthermore the frequency with which individual pain location were reported differed significantly for onset peak and radiation in ch conclusion analysis of the pain location data show specific frequency and distribution of pain location for three aspect of ch attack the frequency with which individual pain point were reported differed significantly for onset peak and radiation in general dorsal pain point were reported more frequently for onset and radiation than for peak pain pain location beyond the eye extraorbital point were more frequently reported in connection with radiating pain our finding could serve a a basis for future research correlating ch pain pattern with the outcome of treatment approach

Title: Eye-tracking study on the effects of happiness and sadness on body dissatisfaction and selective visual attention during mirror exposure in bulimia nervosa
Authors: Naumann, E.; Biehl, S.; Svaldi, J.
Abstract: objective abundant research point to the central role of body image disturbance in the occurrence of eating disorder ed while emotional arousal ha been identified a a trigger for binge eating in bulimia nervosa bn empirical knowledge on the influence of emotion on body image in individual with bn is scarce the present study sought to experimentally examine effect of a positive and negative emotion induction on body dissatisfaction and selective attention towards negatively valenced body part among people with bn method in a randomized controlled cross over design happiness and sadness were induced by film clip one week apart in woman with bn n 23 and non ed control n 26 after the emotion induction participant looked at their body in a full length mirror while their attentional allocation wa recorded with the help of a mobile eye tracker participant repeatedly rated their momentary body dissatisfaction result induction of happiness led to a significant decrease in self reported body dissatisfaction furthermore attentional bias higher gaze duration and frequency towards the most disliked body part relative to the most liked body part wa significantly greater in the sadness than happiness condition in bn no significant effect of emotion induction on gaze duration and gaze frequency during mirror exposure were found for control discussion in line with assumption of current model on ed finding support the notion that emotional state influence the body image of patient with bn

Title: Somatosensory Illusions Elicited by Sham Electromagnetic Field Exposure: Experimental Evidence for a Predictive Processing Account of Somatic Symptom Perception
Authors: Wolters, C.; Harzem, J.; Witthoft, M.; Gerlach, A. L.; Pohl, A.
Abstract: objective according to the predictive processing theory of somatic symptom generation body sensation are determined by somatosensory input and central nervous prediction about this input we examined how expectation shape prediction and consequently bodily perception in a task eliciting illusory sensation a laboratory analogue of medically unexplained symptom method using the framework of signal detection theory the influence of sham wi fi on response bias c and somatosensory sensitivity d for tactile stimulus wa examined using the somatic signal detection task ssdt a healthy student sample n 83 completed the ssdt twice sham wi fi on off in a randomized order after watching a film that promoted adverse health effect of electromagnetic field result when expecting a wi fi signal to be present participant showed a significantly more liberal response bias c p 010 etap2 0 08 for tactile stimulus in the ssdt a evidence of a higher propensity to experience somatosensory illusion no significant alteration of somatosensory sensitivity d p 76 etap2 0 002 wa observed conclusion negative expectation about the harmfulness of electromagnetic field may foster the occurrence of illusory symptom perception via alteration in the somatosensory decision criterion the finding are in line with central tenet of the predictive processing account of somatic symptom generation this account proposes a decoupling of percept and somatosensory input so that perception becomes increasingly dependent on prediction this biased perception is regarded a a risk factor for somatic symptom disorder

Title: Altered Interoceptive Awareness in High Habitual Symptom Reporters and Patients With Somatoform Disorders
Authors: Flasinski, T.; Dierolf, A. M.; Rost, S.; Lutz, A. P. C.; Voderholzer, U.; Koch, S.; Bach, M.; Asenstorfer, C.; Munch, E. E.; Mertens, V. C.; Vogele, C.; Schulz, A.
Abstract: objective altered interoception may play a major role in the etiology of medically unexplained symptom mu it remains unclear however if these alteration concern noticing of signal or if they are limited to the interpretation of signal we investigated whether individual with mu differ in interoceptive awareness a assessed with the multidimensional assessment of interoceptive awareness maia questionnaire method study 1 a total of 486 individual completed the screening for somatoform disorder som 2 thirty two individual each of the upper and lower decile of the som distribution low symptom reporter lsr high symptom reporter hsr completed the maia study 2 maia score of individual diagnosed with somatoform disorder sfd n 26 were compared to individual with major depressive disorder mdd n 25 and healthy control hc n 26 result hsr had lower score than lsr on the maia scale not distracting and not worrying the sfd and mdd group showed lower score than hc on the maia scale not distracting self regulation and trusting the mdd group scored lower than the other two group on the scale body listening and attention regulation there were no group difference on the scale noticing conclusion hsr sfd and mdd patient do not differ from hc in the awareness of noticing of interoceptive signal processing whereas cognitive facet of interoception such a distraction or self regulation are differentially affected this highlight the necessity of including specifically targeted intervention which improve interoceptive awareness in the prevention and treatment of sfds

Title: Efficacy and Feasibility of a Therapist-Guided Internet-Based Intervention for Older Persons with Childhood Traumatization: A Randomized Controlled Trial
Authors: Knaevelsrud, C.; Bottche, M.; Pietrzak, R. H.; Freyberger, H. J.; Kuwert, P.
Abstract: objective although cognitive behavioral treatment approach for post traumatic stress disorder ptsd exist only a small proportion of older adult seek psychological treatment alternative treatment approach are thus needed to fill the gap between provision and use of psychological intervention this study aimed to investigate the efficacy and feasibility of an internet based therapist guided cognitive behavioral therapy internet based cbt for older individual with ptsd symptom method patient with clinically meaningful i e subsyndromal or greater ptsd symptom were randomly assigned to a 6 week treatment group of therapist guided internet based cbt n 47 treatment group or a wait list group n 47 wl the treatment group wa assessed pre and post treatment a well a at 3 6 and 12 month follow ups result linear mixed effect analysis showed a significant interaction between group treatment versus wl and time pre versus post for ptsd symptom with a moderate between group effect size in favor of the treatment group d 0 42 effect in the treatment group were maintained up to the 12 month follow up finding indicate a significant interaction group x time for quality of life d 0 39 and self efficacy d 0 38 with regard to the feasibility attrition rate wa very low in both group treatment group 12 8 wl 6 4 and working alliance wa very high conclusion result suggest that therapist guided internet based cbt is associated with a substantial reduction in ptsd symptom and increase in resource related variable in older adult with subsyndromal ptsd this internet based intervention may offer a promising option in a stepped care approach for older trauma affected person who may otherwise not pursue mental health treatment

Title: Predictors of the application of exposure in vivo in the treatment of agoraphobia in an outpatient clinic: An exploratory approach
Authors: Klan, T.; Jasper, F.; Hiller, W.
Abstract: objective although exposure in vivo is considered to be the most effective therapy component in the treatment of agoraphobia ag there is a remarkable lack of it application in psychotherapeutic routine care we examined the severity of anxiety psychological distress comorbidity therapeutic process alliance and sociodemographic status a potential predictor of in vivo exposure method we applied correlational analysis and logistic regression analysis in a sample of n 92 patient main diagnosis ag in an outpatient setting result logistic regression analysis did not yield any significant single predictor whereas a combination of a subset of predictor significantly predicted the application of exposure in vivo in the completer sample r 2 24 p 041 conclusion the application of in vivo exposure may be predicted by a complex pattern of patient characteristic

Title: Eating disorder psychopathology: The role of attachment anxiety, attachment avoidance, and personality functioning
Authors: Klein, E. M.; Benecke, C.; Kasinger, C.; Brahler, E.; Ehrenthal, J. C.; Strauss, B.; Ernst, M.
Abstract: objective although the relationship between insecure attachment pattern and eating disorder ed psychopathology ha repeatedly been demonstrated the underlying mechanism of this association are not fully understood therefore the current study aimed to examine personality functioning defined a an impairment in self and interpersonal functioning a a mediator between attachment insecurity and ed psychopathology method in a representative population based sample n 2508 age range 14 92 year ed symptomatology personality functioning and attachment insecurity anxiety and avoidance were assessed besides descriptive uni bivariate analysis path analysis wa used to test a mediation model while controlling for the effect of age gender mental distress and bmi result ed symptomatology wa associated with lower level of personality functioning r 0 22 and higher level of attachment anxiety r 0 14 but did not correlate with attachment avoidance r 0 02 path analysis revealed that personality functioning fully mediated the effect of attachment anxiety on ed symptomatology the indirect effect via personality functioning beta 0 04 p 001 accounted for 77 of the total effect fit index were excellent sensitivity analysis revealed that the main result were mainly applicable to woman and the middle age group conclusion the present finding contribute to the growing body of research using dimensional conceptualization of personality functioning suggesting that it provides an informative overarching framework for understanding and treating ed psychopathology finding indicate that underlying individual difference e g with respect to insecure attachment configuration have relevant implication for symptom manifestation potential clinical implication and avenue for future research are discussed

Title: Internet-based interpretation bias modification for body dissatisfaction: A three-armed randomized controlled trial
Authors: Dietel, F. A.; Zache, C.; Burkner, P. C.; Schulte, J.; Mobius, M.; Bischof, A.; Wilhelm, S.; Buhlmann, U.
