Abstract: objective appearance related interpretation bias is postulated to play a role in the maintenance of body dissatisfaction bd a risk factor for body dysmorphic disorder bdd and eating disorder ed cognitive bias modification for interpretation cbm i ha been shown to reduce maladaptive interpretation bias and symptom in various emotional disorder this study investigated the acceptability and efficacy of an easily disseminable web based cbm i program for bd method individual with high bd n 318 were randomized to a multi session cbm i sentence word association paradigm swap with feedback v control swap without feedback versus waitlist condition interpretation bias bd and associated symptom were assessed at baseline and post intervention symptom were monitored up to 1 week and 4 week follow up we further investigated transference effect to stress reactivity a predicted by cognitive behavioral model at post intervention result appearance related cbm i led to a differential pre post increase in adaptive interpretation pattern particularly for appearance related and social situation d 0 65 1 18 both cbm i and control training reduced bd bdd symptom severity and depression however cbm i v control and waitlist improved appearance related quality of life d 0 51 self esteem d 0 52 and maladaptive appearance related belief d 0 47 state stress reactivity wa overall reduced in the cbm i condition v waitlist intervention effect largely held stable up to follow ups treatment satisfaction wa comparable to other cbm i study with low rate of adverse reaction discussion these finding support assumption of cognitive behavioral model for bd bdd and ed and suggest that web based cbm i is an efficacious and acceptable intervention option

Title: An app-based blended intervention to reduce body dissatisfaction: A randomized controlled pilot study
Authors: Kollei, I.; Lukas, C. A.; Loeber, S.; Berking, M.
Abstract: objective a a common experience in the general population dissatisfaction with one s body is associated with a variety of psychological problem and unhealthy behavior including the development of eating disorder therefore the purpose of the present study wa to develop and evaluate an app based intervention to reduce body dissatisfaction method participant reporting elevated level of body dissatisfaction were randomly allocated to an app based intervention n 26 or to a wait list group n 27 the app based intervention included a brief counseling session and 14 day of training with the mindtastic body dissatisfaction app mt bd the mt bd app u gamification strategy to systematically foster approach of functional and avoidance of dysfunctional stimulus the primary outcome wa body dissatisfaction a assessed with the body dissatisfaction scale of the eating disorder inventory 2 garner 1991 secondary outcome measure included severity of eating disorder symptom and depressive symptom result participant in the intervention group showed significantly greater reduction in body dissatisfaction compared to the wait list group d 0 62 the intervention group also showed greater reduction in eating disorder symptom compared to the wait list group d 0 46 reduction in body dissatisfaction and eating disorder symptom were sustained at a 1 month follow up conclusion we found preliminary evidence that an app based intervention may significantly reduce body dissatisfaction further research using larger sample and targeting clinical population is necessary to evaluate the potential of intervention such a mt bd psycinfo database record

Title: Relations between criteria for somatic symptom disorder and quality of life in asylum seekers living in Germany
Authors: Giesebrecht, J.; Grupp, F.; Reich, H.; Weise, C.; Mewes, R.
Abstract: objective asylum seeker often suffer from medically unexplained symptom that affect their quality of life qol the present study is the first to investigate the extent to which somatic symptom and the b criterion for the dsm 5 somatic symptom disorder ssd are associated with the qol of asylum seeker living in germany method in 144 asylum seeker somatic symptom phq 15 b criterion for ssd symptom of posttraumatic stress pd depressive symptom phq 9 post migration living difficulty pmld and qol eurohis were assessed cross sectionally multiple regression in the total sample and in group of somatic symptom severity mild moderate and severe were conducted to examine the association between somatic symptom and b criterion with qol result sleep problem and pain were the most frequently reported somatic symptom sixteen 11 participant met one b criterion 24 17 met two and 84 58 met all three criterion qol correlated negatively with somatic symptom r 0 56 p 001 and with the existence of at least one b criterion r 0 24 p 001 in the total sample stronger depressive and somatic symptom were related to lower qol adjusted r 2 0 53 while the b criterion were not in person with severe somatic symptom severity the b criterion behavior wa associated with lower qol conclusion in addition to stronger somatic and depressive symptom the psychological b criterion behavior seems to play an important role in the lower qol of asylum seeker with severe somatic symptom

Title: Same, same but different: Attention bias for food cues in adults and adolescents with anorexia nervosa
Authors: Werthmann, J.; Simic, M.; Konstantellou, A.; Mansfield, P.; Mercado, D.; van Ens, W.; Schmidt, U.
Abstract: objective attention processing for food may be biased in people with anorexia nervosa an however previous study have had inconsistent result this is likely to be due to indirect assessment of attention which doe not inform on the underlying attention process and or the heterogeneity of participant across study testing either adult or adolescent with an that is people at very different developmental and illness stage method eye tracking wa employed a a direct assessment of attention during a visual probe task with food versus non food picture attention bias for food wa measured in 39 adult and 34 adolescent with an and in 53 adult and 31 adolescent without an result all participant had a direction bias for food specifically for high calorie food however adult with an subsequently avoided maintaining attention on food versus non food cue compared to adult without an adolescent with or without an demonstrated increased attention maintenance on food versus non food cue and contrary to our hypothesis did not differ in their attention bias for food cue accordingly adult with an differed significantly from adolescent with an in attention maintenance for food cue while adolescent with an showed significantly increased attention maintenance on food stimulus adult avoided maintaining attention on food cue discussion adult with an may apply attention strategy to facilitate restrictive eating this strategy is absent in adolescent with an this difference in food related attention bias between adolescent and adult with an suggests that attention bias develop over time a the illness progress

Title: Movement-based patient-therapist attunement in psychological therapy and its association with early change
Authors: Schwartz, B.; Rubel, J. A.; Deisenhofer, A. K.; Lutz, W.
Abstract: objective attunement is a novel measure of nonverbal synchrony reflecting the duration of the present moment shared by two interaction partner this study examined it association with early change in outpatient psychotherapy method automated video analysis based on motion energy analysis mea and cross correlation of the movement time series of patient and therapist wa conducted to calculate movement synchrony for n 161 outpatient movement based attunement wa defined a the range of connected time lag with significant synchrony latent change class in the hscl 11 were identified with growth mixture modeling gmm and predicted by pre treatment covariates and attunement using multilevel multinomial regression result gmm identified four latent class high impairment no change class 1 high impairment early response class 2 moderate impairment class 3 and low impairment class 4 class 2 showed the strongest attunement the largest early response and the best outcome stronger attunement wa associated with a higher likelihood of membership in class 2 b 0 313 p 007 class 3 b 0 251 p 033 and class 4 b 0 275 p 043 compared to class 1 for highly impaired patient the probability of no early change class 1 decreased and the probability of early response class 2 increased a a function of attunement conclusion among patient with high impairment stronger patient therapist attunement wa associated with early response which predicted a better treatment outcome video based assessment of attunement might provide new information for therapist not available from self report questionnaire and support therapist in their clinical decision making

Title: Implicit approach-avoidance tendencies toward food and body stimuli absent in individuals with anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and healthy controls
Authors: Kollei, I.; Leins, J.; Rinck, M.; Waldorf, M.; Kuhn, M.; Rauh, E.; Steins-Loeber, S.
Abstract: objective body and food related information are thought to activate cognitive bias and contribute to the maintenance of eating disorder ed approach avoidance bias may play an important role in the maintenance of dietary restriction and excessive food intake therefore the present study aimed to examine approach avoidance bias toward food and body stimulus in individual with anorexia nervosa an bulimia nervosa bn and healthy control hc method the study included 42 individual with an 24 individual with bn and 38 hcs we used two implicit approach avoidance task aat to a approach avoidance bias participant completed a food aat high calorie v low calorie food and a body aat thin v normal weight body additionally explicit rating of food and body stimulus were assessed result there were no significant group x stimulus x direction interaction in the implicit food aat or implicit body aat in explicit rating individual with an and bn reported le urge to eat and more regret if they ate high calorie and low calorie food individual with an and bn rated normal weight body a le normal weight le attractive and le desirable than hcs there were no group difference in explicit rating of the thin body discussion we did not find evidence for biased approach avoidance tendency toward food or body stimulus in individual with an or bn future study are necessary to understand conflicting finding regarding approach avoidance bias toward food and body stimulus in individual with ed

Title: The effects of pre-intervention mindset induction on a brief intervention to increase risk perception and reduce alcohol use among university students: A pilot randomized controlled trial
Authors: Buchele, N.; Keller, L.; Zeller, A. C.; Schrietter, F.; Treiber, J.; Gollwitzer, P. M.; Odenwald, M.
Abstract: objective brief intervention based on personalized feedback have shown promising result in reducing risky alcohol use among university student we investigated the effect of activating deliberative predecisional or implemental postdecisional mindset on the effectiveness of a standardized brief intervention the assist linked brief intervention this intervention comprises a personalized feedback and a decisional balance exercise we hypothesized that participant in a deliberative mindset should show better outcome related to risk perception and behavior than participant in an implemental mindset method a sample of 257 student provided baseline measure on risk perception readiness to change and alcohol use of those 64 student with risky alcohol use were randomly allocated to one of two mindset induction condition deliberative or implemental mindset thereafter they received the assist linked brief intervention and completed self report questionnaire on change in risk perception alcohol use and readiness to change at post intervention and four week follow up result in contrast to our hypothesis the four week follow up revealed that participant in the implemental mindset consumed significantly le alcohol than participant in a deliberative mindset did the former decreased and the latter increased their alcohol intake resistance to the brief intervention wa stronger in the latter condition however neither deliberative nor implemental mindset participant showed any change in risk perception or in their readiness to change alcohol consumption conclusion these finding suggest that mindset induction is a powerful moderator of the effect of the assist linked brief intervention we argue that systematic research on mindset effect on brief intervention technique aimed to reduce risky alcohol use is highly needed in order to identify the process involved with commitment and resistance being the main candidate

Title: Social cognition in anorexia nervosa: Specific difficulties in decoding emotional but not nonemotional mental states
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Pellegrino, J.; Munch, H.; Herzog, W.; Dziobek, I.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: objective building on recent model of anorexia nervosa an that emphasize the importance of impaired social cognition in the development and maintenance of the disorder the present study aimed at examining whether woman with an have more difficulty with inferring other people s emotional and nonemotional mental state than healthy woman method social cognition wa assessed in 25 adult woman with an and 25 age matched healthy woman to overcome limitation of previous research on social cognition in an the processing of social information wa examined in a more complex and ecologically valid manner the movie for the assessment of social cognition masc reflects complex real life social interaction and allows for disentangling emotional and non emotional mental state inference a well a different type of error in mentalizing result woman with an showed poorer emotional mental state inference whereas non emotional mental state inference wa largely intact group did not differ in undermentalizing overly simplistic theory of mind and overmentalizing overly complex or over interpretative mental state reasoning performance in the masc wa independent of level of eating disorder psychopathology and symptom of depression and anxiety discussion the finding suggest that an is associated with specific difficulty in emotional mental state inference despite largely intact nonemotional mental state inference upon replication in larger sample these finding advocate a stronger emphasis on socio emotional processing in an treatment c 2016 wiley periodical inc int j eat disord 2016 49 883 890

Title: Approach bias modification training in bulimia nervosa and binge-eating disorder: A pilot randomized controlled trial
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Friederich, H. C.; Kuppers, C.; Chowdhury, S.; Harms, L.; Simmonds, J.; Gordon, G.; Potterton, R.; Schmidt, U.
Abstract: objective bulimia nervosa bn and binge eating disorder bed are associated with poorly controlled approach behavior toward food resulting in binge eating approach bias modification abm may reduce these automatic action tendency i e approach bias toward food and may thus decrease binge eating and related symptom method a total of 56 patient with bn bed participated in this double blind randomized controlled trial rct comparing real and sham abm the real abm condition adopted an implicit learning paradigm in which participant were trained to show avoidance behavior in response to food cue participant in the sham condition used a similar task but were not trained to avoid food cue both condition comprised 10 training session within 4 week result participant in both group experienced significant reduction in binge eating eating disorder symptom trait food craving and food cue reactivity real abm tended to result in greater reduction in eating disorder symptom than sham abm food intake approach bias and attention bias toward food did not change discussion this is the first rct on abm in eating disorder the finding provide limited support for the efficacy of abm in bn bed and pose question regarding it active ingredient and it usefulness a a stand alone treatment for eating disorder

Title: The association between psychopathology, childhood trauma, and emotion processing
Authors: Flechsenhar, A.; Seitz, K. I.; Bertsch, K.; Herpertz, S. C.
Abstract: objective childhood trauma is highly prevalent and can have a negative impact on the development of socioemotional process resulting in a higher vulnerability for mental disorder in adulthood previous study have associated the severity of childhood trauma with deficit in social functioning such a a negative attention bias suggesting altered social information processing a a mechanism underlying the association between childhood trauma and transdiagnostic psychopathology method in a cross sectional setup with a total of 103 participant 26 with major depressive disorder mdd 24 with posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd 22 with somatic symptom disorder sdd and 31 healthy volunteer hv this study applied eye tracking in an emotion recognition paradigm reaction time accuracy and gaze behavior were analyzed for 4 different facial expression a a function of self reported childhood trauma and diagnosis the aim wa to investigate to what extent emotion processing is associated with a childhood trauma b psychopathology and c respective interacting effect result patient showed higher reaction time and error rate overall in classifying emotion than hvs especially for the recognition of anger and fear individual with a diagnosis of ptsd and mdd were particularly slow in their response to these emotion higher score of reported childhood trauma were associated with faster response for classifying anger and fear and slower initiation of eye movement for ssd mdd and hvs for anger conclusion these finding indicate that childhood trauma may contribute to attentional and information processing bias relevant for social interaction identifying individual social deficit offer implication for tailored therapeutic intervention psycinfo database record c 2022 apa all right reserved

Title: Visual selective attention in body dysmorphic disorder, bulimia nervosa and healthy controls
Authors: Kollei, I.; Horndasch, S.; Erim, Y.; Martin, A.
Abstract: objective cognitive behavioral model postulate that selective attention play an important role in the maintenance of body dysmorphic disorder bdd it is suggested that individual with bdd overfocus on perceived defect in their appearance which may contribute to the excessive preoccupation with their appearance method the present study used eye tracking to examine visual selective attention in individual with bdd n 19 a compared to individual with bulimia nervosa bn n 21 and healthy control hcs n 21 participant completed interview questionnaire rating scale and an eye tracking task eye movement were recorded while participant viewed photograph of their own face and attractive a well a unattractive other face result eye tracking data showed that bdd and bn participant focused le on their self rated most attractive facial part than hcs scanning pattern in own and other face showed that bdd and bn participant paid a much attention to attractive a to unattractive feature in their own face whereas they focused more on attractive feature in attractive other face hcs paid more attention to attractive feature in their own face and did the same in attractive other face conclusion result indicate an attentional bias in bdd and bn participant manifesting itself in a neglect of positive feature compared to hcs perceptual retraining may be an important aspect to focus on in therapy in order to overcome the neglect of positive facial aspect future research should aim to disentangle attentional process in bdd by examining the time course of attentional processing

Title: Mechanisms of Change in Trauma-Focused Treatment for PTSD: The Role of Rumination
Authors: Schumm, H.; Kruger-Gottschalk, A.; Dyer, A.; Pittig, A.; Cludius, B.; Takano, K.; Alpers, G. W.; Ehring, T.
Abstract: objective cognitive behavioral therapy cbt ha been well established in the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd in recent year researcher have begun to investigate it underlying mechanism of change dysfunctional cognitive content i e excessively negative appraisal of the trauma or it consequence ha been shown to predict change in ptsd symptom over the course of treatment however the role of change in cognitive process such a trauma related rumination need to be addressed the present study investigates whether change in rumination intensity precede and predict change in symptom severity we also explored the extent to which symptom severity predicts rumination method a part of a naturalistic effectiveness study evaluating cbt for ptsd in routine clinical care eighty eight patient with ptsd completed weekly measure of rumination and symptom severity lagged association between rumination and symptom in the following week were examined using linear mixed model result over the course of therapy both ruminative thinking and ptsd symptom decreased rumination wa a significant predictor of ptsd symptom in the following week although this effect wa at least partly explained by the time factor e g natural recovery or inseparable treatment effect symptom severity predicted ruminative thinking in the following week even with time a an additional predictor conclusion the present study provides preliminary evidence that rumination in ptsd is reduced by cbt for ptsd but doe not give conclusive evidence that rumination is a mechanism of change in trauma focused treatment for ptsd

Title: Selective Visual Attention during Mirror Exposure in Anorexia and Bulimia Nervosa
Authors: Tuschen-Caffier, B.; Bender, C.; Caffier, D.; Klenner, K.; Braks, K.; Svaldi, J.
Abstract: objective cognitive theory suggest that body dissatisfaction result from the activation of maladaptive appearance schema which guide mental process such a selective attention to shape and weight related information in line with this the present study hypothesized that patient with anorexia nervosa an and bulimia nervosa bn are characterized by increased visual attention for the most dissatisfying ugly body part compared to their most satisfying beautiful body part while a more balanced viewing pattern wa expected for control without eating disorder cg method eye movement were recorded in a group of patient with an n 16 bn n 16 and a cg n 16 in an ecologically valid setting i e during a 3 min mirror exposure result evidence wa found that patient with an and bn display longer and more frequent gaze towards the most dissatisfying relative to the most satisfying and towards their most ugly compared to their most beautiful body part whereas the cg showed a more balanced gaze pattern discussion the result converge with theoretical model that emphasize the role of information processing in the maintenance of body dissatisfaction given the etiological importance of body dissatisfaction in the development of eating disorder future study should focus on the modification of the reported pattern

Title: Cognitive therapy and exposure therapy for hypochondriasis (health anxiety): A 3-year naturalistic follow-up
Authors: Weck, F.; Nagel, L. C.; Hofling, V.; Neng, J. M. B.
Abstract: objective cognitive behavioral therapy cbt ha been shown to be effective in treating hypochondriasis however there are doubt regarding the long term effectiveness of cbt for hypochondriasis in particular for follow up period longer than 1 year the aim of the present study wa to evaluate the long term effectiveness of cognitive therapy ct and exposure therapy et for the treatment of hypochondriasis method seventy five patient with a diagnosis of hypochondriasis who were previously treated with ct or et were contacted 3 year after treatment fifty 67 patient participated and were interviewed by an independent and blinded diagnostician using standardized interview result we found further improvement after therapy in primary outcome measure d 37 general functioning d 38 and reduced doctor visit d 30 during the naturalistic follow up period at the 3 year follow up 72 of the patient no longer fulfilled the diagnosis of hypochondriasis based on the main outcome measure we found response rate of 76 and remission rate of 68 at follow up only 4 of patient were taking antidepressant medication additional psychological treatment wa utilized by 18 of the patient during the follow up period only 8 because of health anxiety we found no overall difference between ct and et only a trend for a greater deterioration rate in ct 13 in comparison to et 0 wa found conclusion our result suggest that 2 3 of the patient with hypochondriasis were remitted in the long term thus remission rate after cbt were twice a high a in untreated sample psycinfo database record

Title: Cognitive control functions in individuals with obesity with and without binge-eating disorder
Authors: Kollei, I.; Rustemeier, M.; Schroeder, S.; Jongen, S.; Herpertz, S.; Loeber, S.
Abstract: objective deficit in cognitive control are thought to contribute to the maintenance of obesity ob cognitive control is referred to a impulsivity and binge eating disorder bed is characterized by high level of impulsivity the present study sought to elucidate which cognitive control function differentiate between severe ob with and without bed also taking into account hunger a a moderating factor method the study included 48 individual with ob and bed ob bed 48 individual with ob and no bed ob bed and 48 normal weight control nwc hunger wa systematically manipulated participant were instructed to refrain from eating before testing and received either a liquid meal or flavored water then a comprehensive test battery wa administered including a food related go no go task and several subtests from the cantab result there were no difference between the group with regard to food related response inhibition however while manipulating hunger had no impact on performance in the go no go task self reported hunger significantly influenced task performance by increasing inhibition deficit to high caloric stimulus in ob bed with regard to general cognitive control function we found that deficit in attention and impulse control in decision making distinguished ob from nwc while reversal learning and risk taking in decision making appeared to be relevant factor when distinguishing ob bed from ob bed discussion our result indicate that self reported hunger differentially affected food related response inhibition group difference in general cognitive control function were limited to attention reversal learning and decision making future research need to account for other possible moderating factor such a mood food craving or stress

Title: Deficits in general emotion regulation skills-Evidence of a transdiagnostic factor
Authors: Lukas, C. A.; Ebert, D. D.; Fuentes, H. T.; Caspar, F.; Berking, M.
Abstract: objective deficit in emotion regulation er skill are discussed a a transdiagnostic factor contributing to the development and maintenance of various mental disorder however systematic comparison of a broad range of er skill across diagnostic group that are based on comparable definition and measure of er are still rare method therefore we conducted two study assessing a broad range of er skill with the emotion regulation skill questionnaire in individual meeting criterion for mental disorder n 1 1448 n 2 137 and in a general population sample n 214 result consistent across the two study participant in the clinical sample reported lower general and lower specific er skill than participant in the general population sample also consistent across the two study diagnostic subgroup of the clinical sample differed significantly with regard to general and specific er skill conclusion the study provide evidence that deficit in er are associated with various form of psychopathology however mental disorder seem to differ with regard to how strongly they are linked to er skill

Title: Impaired Behavioral Inhibition in Implicit Sequence Learning in Adult ADHD
Authors: Pedersen, A.; Ohrmann, P.
Abstract: objective deficit in explicit learning and memory have consistently been reported in adult adhd but it is le clear whether these deficit reflect deficient attentional process or specific dysfunction in memory process study on implicit learning and memory which are le dependent on the allocation of attention have rarely been conducted on adult adhd method we implemented a modified serial reaction time task that involves distracting stimulus to investigate implicit sequence learning in 32 adult participant with adhd and in 32 matched healthy control participant result the participant with adhd revealed unimpaired implicit learning performance but they made significantly more error than the control participant there wa no evidence for impaired error monitoring in the participant with adhd reflected by a comparable degree of double error and post error slowing in the two group conclusion reduced efficiency of the inhibition of incorrect response in implicit sequence learning support previous finding of impaired behavioral inhibition in adult adhd

Title: Modeling in psychotherapy training: A randomized controlled proof-of-concept trial
Authors: Kuhne, F.; Heinze, P. E.; Maass, U.; Weck, F.
Abstract: objective despite the importance of modeling for learning it ha only so far been investigated in a few controlled study in psychotherapy training we therefore investigated across several study outcome whether modeling outperformed a control group method sixty nine trainee i e psychology student mean age 25 58 year 81 2 woman and 81 2 caucasian were randomly assigned to the intervention group ig manual reading plus modeling or control group cg manual reading after manual reading ig participant watched a video of a skillfully conducted therapy session whereas cg participant watched an unspecific tutorial e g solving a rubik s cube trainee then demonstrated cognitive behavioral intervention in videotaped role play with sps psychotherapeutic competence and counseling skill were rated by two independent raters on the cognitive therapy scale ct and the clinical communication skill scale short form cc s in addition raters trainee and sps assessed empathy empathy scale e and alliance helping alliance questionnaire haq result multilevel modeling revealed significant time x group effect that is psychotherapy competence ct beta 26 p 026 and counseling skill cc s beta 31 p 004 to increase more pre post in the ig than in the cg rater perspective the same applied to the alliance haq from the external rater and sp perspective trainee evaluated the alliance a improving in both group from pre to post training main effect conclusion the result provide initial support for modeling a important for fostering psychotherapy skill future study should focus on more complex training and real patient encounter psycinfo database record c 2023 apa all right reserved

Title: Emotional Reactivity, Emotion Regulation, and Regulatory Choice in Somatic Symptom Disorder
Authors: Schnabel, K.; Schulz, S. M.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: objective despite the transdiagnostic importance of emotional dysregulation in psychopathology the exact nature of emotional dysregulation in somatic symptom disorder ssds is still unclear the present study compared measure of emotional reactivity emotion regulation er and regulatory choice between n 62 individual with ssd diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder fifth edition and n 61 healthy participant method participant underwent two er task assessing a efficacy of reappraisal and suppression and 2 regulatory choice while electrodermal activity and heart rate variability were recorded in addition self report emotion reactivity scale emotion regulation questionnaire difficulty in emotion regulation scale regarding habitual emotional reaction and regulation strategy were assessed result individual with ssd reported significantly higher trait emotional reactivity emotion reactivity scale p 001 d 1 61 significantly more trait er difficulty difficulty in emotion regulation scale p 001 d 1 62 and significantly lower reappraisal use in daily life emotion regulation questionnaire p 001 d 0 75 on a behavioral and physiological level no significant group difference were found regarding emotional reactivity subjective rating of emotional stimulus in task 1 p value 653 667 electrodermal activity p value 224 837 er task 1 p value 077 731 heart rate variability p value 522 832 or regulatory choice task 2 p 380 although individual with ssd were equally effective in state er task 1 they perceived er during the task a significantly more effortful p 038 d 0 38 conclusion result suggest that dysregulated emotion might not result from lacking ability in implementing er effectively but rather could arise from le frequent er initiation because er is perceived a more effortful

Title: Associations between informant ratings of personality disorder traits, self-reports of personality, and directly observed behavior
Authors: Kaurin, A.; Sauerberger, K. S.; Funder, D. C.
Abstract: objective diagnosis of personality disorder pd must rely on judgment of observer either clinician or acquaintance because personality disorder are primarily defined in term of maladaptive interpersonal behavior little is known however about how closely acquaintance judgment of pd trait relate to self report of theoretically relevant big five trait or directly observed behavioral outcome in interpersonal situation the present study examines association between judgment of the 10 pd trait provided by close acquaintance self report of pd relevant big five personality trait and observed interpersonal behavior across three different three person laboratory interaction i e unstructured chat cooperative task competitive game method the sample consisted of 256 undergraduate student 130 female m age 19 83 sd 1 25 four unacquainted observer independently rated participant behavior from video recording result in line with previous work informant report of pd trait demonstrate strong convergent validity with relevant self reported big five trait a identified by lynam widiger 2001 directly observed behavior is meaningfully associated with acquaintance judgment and self report of pd relevant trait and the association between these judgment and behavior are strongest for trait associated with histrionic and schizoid pd vector correlation between behavioral profile associated with informant and self report show that both assessment have similar behavioral correlate association between pd trait rating and behavior appeared to differ a a function of gender with male showing more and stronger correlation conclusion informant rating of pd trait are impressively accurate converging both with self report of relevant trait and directly observed interpersonal behavior therefore a comprehensive understanding of pd and associated trait can be augmented by information from multiple acquaintance who have the opportunity to observe how an individual interacts with others on a daily basis across diverse context

Title: Interpersonal Emotion Dynamics in Couples With Somatic Symptom Disorder: Dyadic Coherence in Facial Temperature During Emotional Interactions
Authors: Okur Guney, Z. E.; Cardone, D.; Sattel, H.; Ariens, S.; Witthoft, M.; Merla, A.; Kuppens, P.; Henningsen, P.
Abstract: objective disturbance in emotional process are commonly reported in patient with a somatic symptom disorder ssd although emotion usually occur in social interaction little is known about interpersonal emotion dynamic of ssd patient during their actual emotional encounter this study examined physiological coherence linkage between ssd patient and their partner and in healthy couple during their emotional interaction secondarily we explored group level relationship between participant and their partner subjective affect method twenty nine romantic couple 16 healthy and 13 ssd patient couple underwent a dyadic conversation task with neutral and anger eliciting topic followed by a guided relaxation partner cutaneous facial temperature wa recorded simultaneously by functional infrared thermal imaging immediately after each condition participant reported on their pain intensity self affect and perceived partner affect result emotional condition and having a partner with an ssd significantly affected coherence amplitude on the forehead f 2 54 4 95 p 011 and nose tip temperature f 2 54 3 75 p 030 from baseline to anger condition coherence amplitude significantly increased in the patient couple whereas it decreased in the healthy couple correlation change between partner subjective affect comparably accompanied the change in physiological coherence in healthy and patient couple conclusion inability to reduce emotional interdependence in sympathetic activity and subjective affect during a mutual conflict observed in ssd patient couple seems to capture emotion co dysregulation intervention should frame patient emotional experience a embodied and social functional infrared thermal imaging confirms to be an ecological and reliable method for examining autonomic change in interpersonal context registration page http osf io 8eyjr

Title: Obsessive-compulsive symptoms in eating disorders: A network investigation
Authors: Meier, M.; Kossakowski, J. J.; Jones, P. J.; Kay, B.; Riemann, B. C.; McNally, R. J.
Abstract: objective eating disorder ed are complex heterogeneous and severe psychiatric syndrome they are highly comorbid with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd which exacerbates the course of illness and impedes treatment however the direct functional relation between ed and ocd symptom remain largely unexplored hence using network analysis we investigated the relationship between ed and ocd at the level of symptom in a heterogeneous clinical sample method we used cross sectional data of 303 treatment seeking patient with clinically relevant ed and ocd pathology we constructed a regularized partial correlation network that featured both ed and ocd symptom a node to determine each symptom s influence we calculated expected influence ei a an index of symptom centrality i e importance bridge symptom i e symptom from one syndromic cluster that have strong connection to symptom of another syndromic cluster were identified by computing bridge expected influence metric result fear of weight gain and dietary restraint were especially important among the ed symptom interference due to obsession wa the key feature of ocd ed and ocd clustered distinctly with few potential bridge between cluster discussion this study underscore the importance of cognitive symptom for both ed and ocd although direct functional link between the two cluster are missing potentially a network incorporating node capturing feature of personality may account for diagnostic comorbidity better than specific symptom of ed or feature of ocd do

Title: Emotional reactivity, suppression of emotions and response inhibition in emotional eaters: A multi-method pilot study
Authors: Wolz, I.; Biehl, S.; Svaldi, J.
Abstract: objective emotional eating ha been associated with high emotional reactivity suppression of negative emotion and inhibitory control difficulty the current study aimed to address the association of these factor and their combined effect on emotional eating method twenty eight participant conducted an emotional go nogo task including picture of neutral negative and positive scene and an additional emotion suppression condition electroencephalographic eeg activity wa recorded continuously emotional eating and habitual emotion suppression were assessed through questionnaire emotional reactivity to affective picture wa measured through a visual analogue scale and the amplitude of the electrophysiological late positive potential lpp inhibition parameter were assessed behaviorally i e commission error and through event related potential of the eeg i e n2 p3 amplitude result the trait questionnaire data revealed that emotional eating wa not correlated with habitual emotion suppression during the emotional go nogo paradigm higher emotional eating score were positively related to higher lpp amplitude in response to negative affective scene inhibitory control capacity were not related to emotional eating while watching neutral or negative picture but higher emotional eating score were associated with more commission error when negative emotion were suppressed discussion emotional eating tendency seem to be related to higher reactivity when confronted with negative affective information and inhibitory control deficit may arise especially when an effort is made to suppress these negative emotion therefore a focus on adaptive emotion regulation in treatment of emotional eating seems to be important solely targeting inhibitory control capacity may not be sufficient in order to help people with emotional eating to regulate their food intake

Title: Modest, yet progressive: Effective therapists tend to rate therapeutic change less positively than their patients
Authors: Ziem, M.; Hoyer, J.
Abstract: objective empirical finding on self serving bias amongst psychotherapist are inconsistent we tested in a large naturalistic data set if therapist are prone to illusory superiority when estimating their patient outcome and whether this effect is buffered by therapist effectiveness method a post hoc analysis with n 69 therapist who treated n 1080 patient wa conducted therapist and patient mean rating for therapeutic improvement in the clinical global impression scale cgi were compared using a multilevel modelling approach we further investigated the relation between the patient therapist divergence in the cgi and actual therapeutic change in the global severity index gsi of the brief symptom inventory and in the satisfaction with life scale swls result rating in the cgi did not show significant difference between patient and therapist assessment of therapeutic change lower estimation by therapist compared to patient self report were associated with greater therapeutic change in gsi and swls conclusion therapist on a whole did not seem to be prone to illusory superiority when assessing therapeutic outcome contrary the more modest the therapist estimation of therapeutic outcome wa the greater the actual therapeutic change

Title: Approach bias and cue reactivity towards food in people with high versus low levels of food craving
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Hahn, C.; Reetz, C.; Schmidt, U.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: objective even though people suffering from high level of food craving are aware of the negative consequence of binge eating they cannot resist automatic action tendency i e approach bias towards food cue that operate outside conscious control may contribute to this dysfunctional behavior the present study aimed to examine whether people with high level of food craving show a stronger approach bias for food than those with low level of food craving and whether this bias is associated with cue elicited food craving method forty one individual reporting either extremely high or extremely low level of trait food craving were recruited via an online screening and compared regarding approach bias towards visual food cue by mean of an implicit stimulus response paradigm i e the food approach avoidance task state level of food craving were assessed before and after cue exposure to indicate food cue reactivity result a expected high food cravers showed stronger automatic approach tendency towards food than low food cravers also in line with the hypothesis approach bias for food wa positively correlated with the magnitude of change in state level of food craving from pre to post cue exposure in the total sample discussion the finding suggest that an approach bias in early stage of information processing contributes to the inability to resist food intake and may be of relevance for understanding and treating dysfunctional eating behavior

Title: Are guided internet-based interventions for the indicated prevention of depression in green professions effective in the long run? Longitudinal analysis of the 6- and 12-month follow-up of a pragmatic randomized controlled trial (PROD-A)
Authors: Braun, L.; Titzler, I.; Terhorst, Y.; Freund, J.; Thielecke, J.; Ebert, D. D.; Baumeister, H.
Abstract: objective evidence of long term stability for positive mental health effect of internet based intervention ibis for depression prevention is still scarce we evaluate long term effectiveness of a depression prevention program in green profession i e agriculture horticulture forestry method this pragmatic rct n 360 compare a tailored ibi program to enhanced treatment a usual tau in green profession with at least subthreshold depression phq 5 intervention group ig received one of six ibis shown previously to efficaciously reduce depressive symptom we report 6 and 12 month follow up measure for depression mental health and intervention related outcome intention to treat and per protocol regression analysis were conducted for each measurement point and complemented by latent growth modeling result after 6 month depression severity beta 0 30 95 ci 0 52 0 07 insomnia beta 0 22 95 ci 0 41 0 02 pain associated disability beta 0 26 95 ci 0 48 0 04 and quality of life beta 0 29 95 ci 0 13 0 45 in ig were superior to tau onset of possible depression wa not reduced after 12 month no intervention effect were found longitudinal modeling confirmed group effect attenuating over 12 month for most outcome after 12 month 55 56 of ig had completed at least 80 of their ibi conclusion stability of intervention effect along with intervention adherence wa restricted measure enhancing long term effectiveness of ibis for depression health promotion are indicated in green profession trial registration german clinical trial registration drks00014000 registered 09 april 2018

Title: Central Nervous System Processing of Emotions in Children with Fecal Incontinence and Constipation
Authors: Equit, M.; Niemczyk, J.; Kluth, A.; Thomas, C.; Rubly, M.; von Gontard, A.
Abstract: objective fecal incontinence and constipation are common disorder in childhood the enteric nervous system and the central nervous system are highly interactive along the brain gut axis the interaction is mainly afferent these afferent pathway include center that are involved in the central nervous processing of emotion a the mid posterior insula and the anterior cingulate cortex a previous study revealed altered processing of emotion in child with fecal incontinence the present study replicates these result method in order to analyze the processing of emotion we compared the event related potential of 25 child with fecal incontinence and constipation to those of 15 control child during the presentation of positive negative and neutral picture result child with fecal incontinence and constipation showed altered processing of emotion especially in the parietal and central cortical region conclusion the main study result of the previous study were replicated increasing the certainty and validity of the finding

Title: Does Social Exclusion Alter Sensory and Pain Thresholds in Children and Adolescents with Functional Abdominal Pain? - Results from a Preliminary Study
Authors: Gulewitsch, M. D.; Jusyte, A.; Weimer, K.; Schonenberg, M.
Abstract: objective functional abdominal pain ap is a prevalent issue in childhood and adolescence the contribution of psychosocial factor in the development and maintenance of this health problem is rather unclear and experimental study about underlying mechanism are lacking this study investigates whether experimentally induced social exclusion decrease sensory and pain threshold in child suffering from ap subject twenty child adolescent with ap and 22 healthy control method child adolescent participated in the cyberball paradigm which affect an experience of social exclusion thermal sensory and pain threshold were measured before and after cyberball result child adolescent with ap showed a divergent reaction regarding their sensory threshold after social exclusion the control group exhibited a tendency toward a decreased sensory threshold whereas the ap group remained stable concerning the pain threshold no effect of social exclusion could be identified the increase of both threshold numbing after cyberball wa positively correlated with symptom of mental health issue conclusion this is the first study to investigate change in sensory and pain threshold following painful social interaction in a sample of child adolescent with a chronic pain condition result suggest that ap and control child differ in their reaction of sensory threshold which might indicate an altered processing of social exclusion replication and further methodological improvement are needed

Title: Describe Your Feelings: Body Illusion Related to Alexithymia in Adolescence
Authors: Georgiou, E.; Mai, S.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: objective having access to bodily signal is known to be crucial for differentiating the self from others and coping with negative feeling the interplay between bodily and emotional process develops in adolescence where vulnerability is high a negative affect state often occur that could hamper the integration of bodily input into the self aim of the present study in healthy adolescent wa to examine whether a disturbed emotional awareness described by the alexithymic construct could trigger a higher malleability in the sense of body ownership method fifty four healthy adolescent aged between 12 to 17 year participated in this study the strength and difficulty questionnaire sdq and the screening psychischer storungen im jugendalter were used to a emotional distress and conduct problem alexithymia wa assessed by the ta 20 the rubber hand illusion wa implemented for examining the malleability of body ownership result a higher body illusion wa found to be connected with difficulty in describing feeling moreover a higher degree of self reported conduct and emotional problem a assessed by the sdq were associated with a more pronounced body illusion further finding revealed an association between emotional distress and the emotional alexithymia subscales difficulty in identifying feeling and difficulty in describing feeling conclusion our finding emphasize a close link between the sense of body ownership and emotional awareness a assessed by emotional facet of the alexithymic trait we suggest that in adolescent with higher malleability of body ownership a vicious circle might occur where affect and integration of different proprioceptive signal regarding the body become more entangled

Title: It's all a matter of necessity and concern: A structural equation model of adherence to antihypertensive medication
Authors: Wilhelm, M.; Rief, W.; Doering, B. K.
Abstract: objective hypertension is often treated pharmacologically yet adherence is poor belief about antihypertensive medicine i e the necessity concern framework ncf are valuable for explaining adherence therefore a model structure is transferred from hypercholesterolemia to hypertension assuming a mediating role of the ncf method patient with hypertension n 273 were surveyed online about demographic health and treatment related factor control belief necessity and concern belief about their medication and adherence the data were analyzed using structural equation modeling sem result necessity wa positively beta 0 26 p 0 009 and concern wa negatively beta 0 51 p 0 020 associated with adherence the ncf mediated the influence of background variable on adherence necessity wa associated with comorbidity beta 0 36 p 0 001 treatment time beta 0 19 p 0 004 emotionally supportive doctor patient communication beta 0 12 p 0 045 side effect beta 0 16 p 0 013 personal control beta 0 13 p 0 022 and treatment control beta 0 29 p 0 001 concern wa associated with side effect beta 0 38 p 0 001 and belief about medicine in general being harmful beta 0 61 p 0 001 the model fit wa acceptable rmsea 0 61 conclusion the transferred adherence model with the necessity concern framework a a mediating factor wa confirmed in hypertension explaining more variance than previous approach 23 practice implication a personalized emotionally supportive doctor patient communication could be key to addressing belief about medicine and therefore to increasing adherence

Title: Somatic Symptom Perception From a Predictive Processing Perspective: An Empirical Test Using the Thermal Grill Illusion
Authors: Brascher, A. K.; Sutterlin, S.; Scheuren, R.; Van den Bergh, O.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: objective in a predictive processing perspective symptom perception result from an integration of preexisting information in memory with sensory input physical symptom can therefore reflect the relative predominance of either sensory input or preexisting information in this study we used the thermal grill illusion tgi which applies interlaced warm and cool temperature to the skin to create a paradoxical heat pain experience assuming that the tgi compared with single temperature stimulation relies more importantly on an active integration process of the brain to create this paradoxical sensation we tested the hypothesis whether a manipulation of the expectation during tgi would have more impact than during single temperature stimulation method sixty four participant received different temperature combination 16 16 degree c 40 40 degree c 16 40 degree c with neutral positive placebo and negative nocebo instruction subjective stimulus intensity wa rated and neuroticism and absorption openness to absorbing and self altering experience served a potential moderating factor result the tgi condition wa rated highest overall negative instruction increased p 001 d 0 58 whereas positive instruction did not significantly change the tgi intensity perception versus neutral p 144 d 0 19 in the tgi condition increased modulation of pain wa observed with higher neuroticism beta 0 33 p 005 and absorption beta 0 30 p 010 conclusion whereas negative instruction induced a nocebo effect no placebo effect emerged after positive instruction the finding are in line with the predictive processing model of symptom perception for participant with higher level of neuroticism and absorption

Title: Parent-Child Diagnostic Agreement on Anxiety Symptoms with a Structured Diagnostic Interview for Mental Disorders in Children
Authors: Popp, L.; Neuschwander, M.; Mannstadt, S.; In-Albon, T.; Schneider, S.
Abstract: objective in clinical structured diagnostic interview diagnosis based on parent and child report have low to moderate agreement the aim of the present study are 1 to examine diagnostic agreement on anxiety disorder between parent and child on the level of current and lifetime diagnostic category and diagnosis focusing in particular on diagnostic criterion and 2 to identify parent and child related predictor for diagnostic agreement method the sample consisted of 166 parent child dyad interviewed with the structured diagnostic interview for mental disorder in child kinder dip schneider et al 2009 the child 51 8 girl were between the age of 7 and 18 year m 10 94 sd 2 22 result overall parent child agreement on the diagnostic category of anxiety disorder k 0 21 k 0 22 and the specific anxiety diagnosis base rate 10 of social phobia specific phobia and separation anxiety disorder k 0 24 0 52 k 0 19 0 43 and corresponding diagnostic criterion k 0 22 0 67 k 0 24 0 41 were low to moderate with the highest agreement on separation anxiety disorder k 0 43 lower maternal depression and higher social support reported by mother and father were associated with higher parent child agreement maternal depression wa indicated a the strongest predictor parental sense of competence parental anxiety the amount of parent child interaction and the child s age and gender had no predictive value conclusion parent child agreement can be expected to be higher on the level of anxiety criterion compared to specific anxiety diagnosis and diagnostic anxiety category psychological strain in the family especially maternal depression and low social support lower the parent child agreement on anxiety symptom child and relation related variable age gender amount of time parent s and child interact play no role in the prediction of low parent child agreement

Title: Predicting psychotherapy outcome based on therapist interpersonal skills: A five-year longitudinal study of a therapist assessment protocol
Authors: Schottke, H.; Fluckiger, C.; Goldberg, S. B.; Eversmann, J.; Lange, J.
Abstract: objective in the past decade variation in outcome between therapist i e therapist effect have become increasingly recognized a an important factor in psychotherapy le is known however about what account for difference between therapist the present study investigates the possibility that therapist basic therapy related interpersonal skill may impact outcome method to examine this psychotherapy postgraduate trainee completed both an observer and an expert rated behavioral assessment the therapy related interpersonal behavior trib trib score were used to predict trainee outcome over the course of the subsequent five year result result indicate that trainee with more positively rated interpersonal behavior assessed in the observer rated group format but not in a single expert rated format showed superior outcome over the five year period this effect remained controlling for therapist characteristic therapist gender theoretical orientation cognitive behavioral or psychodynamic amount of supervision patient s order within therapist s caseload and patient characteristic patient age gender number of comorbid diagnosis global severity and personality disorder diagnosis conclusion these finding underscore the importance of therapist interpersonal skill a a predictor of outcome and source of therapist effect the potential utility of assessing therapist and therapist in training interpersonal skill are discussed

Title: Socioeconomic status and access to psychotherapy
Authors: Niemeyer, H.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: objective individual with low socioeconomic status s have significantly higher prevalence rate of mental disorder than those with higher s but are le likely to receive treatment study from the united state show that individual with higher s are more likely to be offered a therapy place than those with low s in germany where the public health care system is without financial barrier study on access to treatment are lacking method the present study investigated whether the s of person seeking psychotherapeutic help in germany influence psychotherapist decision to provide access to treatment for this purpose 504 licensed outpatient psychological psychotherapist participated in an online study in which they read a series of case vignette and rated how likely they would be to offer treatment in each case s wa operationalized by occupation and language use additionally we investigated whether treatment offer were affected by the disorder and the gender of the help seeker the therapist socioeconomic background and other characteristic in interaction with s bonferroni corrected multifactorial repeated measure analysis of variance anova and mixed anova were calculated result help seeker with low s were 4 1 le likely to be offered treatment than those with moderate to high s f 1 503 115 64 p 0 000 eta 2 0 187 the influence of s on the probability of a therapy place offer varied significantly depending on the patient s disorder p 0 000 s had a greater effect for bulimia than for depression and social anxiety disorder overall the effect wa small eta 2 0 026 no significant interaction between the gender of potential client and s wa found p 0 062 the influence of s on treatment accessibility varied depending on the therapeutic method for which the therapist wa licensed and on the social status of the district in which the therapist s practice wa located the therapist s socioeconomic background parental s did not interact with the potential client s s conclusion therapist bias contributing to unequal access to treatment for individual with low s and other characteristic can aggravate mental health care disparity even though the effect we found were relatively modest awareness of the association between s and offer of therapy place might help practitioner to reflect on their own selection practice

Title: Patients' in-session experiences and symptom change: Session-to-session effects on a within- and between-patient level
Authors: Rubel, J. A.; Rosenbaum, D.; Lutz, W.
Abstract: objective knowledge of patient in session experience that lead to symptom change in psychotherapy is limited this study aim to investigate the within and between patient relationship between three in session process in psychotherapy coping skill therapeutic relationship quality and emotional involvement and symptom change on a session by session level method participant n 1550 with various disorder including primarily depression and anxiety were treated with cbt in a german outpatient clinic symptom distress wa assessed before each session and patient in session experience were assessed at the end of each session using session report person mean centering wa applied to disaggregate within and between patient within and between patient process score were tested in multilevel model a predictor of next session symptom change result on a within patient level better session specific coping skill better therapeutic alliance and deeper emotional involvement were followed by next session symptom improvement in a combined model only coping skill specifically predicted next session symptom change additionally these coping skill were especially helpful when combined with a better therapeutic relationship quality on a between patient level better therapeutic alliance and more coping skill were associated with lower symptom score during treatment while deeper emotional involvement wa associated with higher symptom score testing these between patient effect in a combined model left only coping skill the more the greater symptom improvement and emotional involvement the deeper the le symptom improvement a significant predictor these two also exhibited a combined effect on symptom change on the between patient level discussion the result highlight the importance of a thorough disaggregation of within and between patient variability in psychotherapy process outcome research a well a the consideration of several potentially important time varying covariates while coping skill showed to be the most central for subsequent symptom change therapeutic relationship quality only seemed to be a facilitative factor in enhancing these effect but wa not sufficiently helpful on it own

Title: Professional Burnout, Early Maladaptive Schemas, and Physical Health in Clinical and Counselling Psychology Trainees
Authors: Kaeding, A.; Sougleris, C.; Reid, C.; van Vreeswijk, M. F.; Hayes, C.; Dorrian, J.; Simpson, S.
Abstract: objective little is known about the personal factor that increase vulnerability to job related stress and burnout among psychologist in training this study wa based on a large international sample and aimed to explore the role of early maladaptive schema em in predicting vulnerability to burnout a well a attendant effect on short term physical health in clinical and counseling postgraduate psychology trainee method an online quantitative cross sectional survey method design wa used to collect self report data that measured burnout em and physical health from 1 297 trainee result only the unrelenting standard u schema predicted high burnout among trainee the most commonly endorsed physical health symptom were back and neck pain and tiredness and were more severe for those experiencing high burnout conclusion the current study contributes to our understanding of the role of the u em in the evolution of burnout in trainee and ha implication for the development of self awareness training program for this population

Title: Inhibitory Control and Hedonic Response towards Food Interactively Predict Success in a Weight Loss Programme for Adults with Obesity
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Hamze Sinno, M.; Skunde, M.; Wu, M.; Woehning, A.; Rudofsky, G.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: objective low inhibitory control and strong hedonic response towards food are considered to contribute to overeating and obesity based on previous research the present study aimed at examining the potentially crucial interplay between these two factor in term of long term weight loss in people with obesity method bmi inhibitory control towards food and food liking were assessed in obese adult prior to a weight reduction programme optifast r 52 after the weight reduction phase week 13 and the weight loss maintenance phase week 52 participant bmi wa re assessed result baseline bmi inhibitory control and food liking alone did not predict weight loss a hypothesised however inhibitory control and food liking interactively predicted weight loss from baseline to week 13 and to week 52 albeit the latter effect wa le robust participant with low inhibitory control and marked food liking were le successful in weight reduction conclusion these finding underscore the relevance of the interplay between cognitive control and food reward valuation in the maintenance of obesity

Title: Subjective social status and nocturnal blood pressure dipping
Authors: Neubert, M.; Sussenbach, P.; Euteneuer, F.
Abstract: objective low social status ha been linked to cardiovascular disease subjective social status s which represents one s perceived position in a social hierarchy ha been suggested to predict health outcome beyond objective measure of socioeconomic status the present study examined if lower s is related to reduced nocturnal blood pressure bp dipping a risk factor for cardiovascular disease method in this cross sectional study a community sample of 53 healthy adult underwent 24 h ambulatory bp monitoring all participant provided information on s and objective measure of socioeconomic status i e education occupation and income s wa measured in comparison to others in the country national s a well a in comparison to one s social environment local s using the german version of the macarthur scale result analysis found that participant with low local s exhibited attenuated nocturnal diastolic blood pressure dipping beta 0 29 95 ci 0 01 0 57 p 043 and mean arterial pressure dipping beta 0 29 95 ci 0 01 0 57 p 041 these association remained significant after adjusting for objective socioeconomic status no significant association between national s and cardiovascular measure were observed conclusion in conclusion one s perceived social position in the social environment i e local s is associated with nocturnal bp dipping therefore local s may be an important psychosocial factor linking social inequality and cardiovascular health

Title: Co-occurrence of major depressive episode and posttraumatic stress disorder among survivors of war: how is it different from either condition alone?
Authors: Morina, N.; Ajdukovic, D.; Bogic, M.; Franciskovic, T.; Kucukalic, A.; Lecic-Tosevski, D.; Morina, L.; Popovski, M.; Priebe, S.
Abstract: objective major depressive episode mde and posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd have been shown to be the most common mental disorder following traumatic war experience and have been found to frequently co occur this study designed a a randomized cross sectional interview survey aimed to identify whether the co occurence of mde and ptsd following exposure to war related experience is associated with different demographic exposure to previous traumatic event and clinical characteristic than either condition alone method after a random walk technique wa used to randomly select participant face to face interview were conducted among war affected community sample in 5 balkan country n 3 313 in the year 2006 and 2007 the mean age of participant wa 42 3 year and all participant had experienced potentially traumatic event during war in the country of the former yugoslavia current prevalence rate of mde and ptsd and suicide risk were assessed using the mini international neuropsychiatric interview level of general psychological distress posttraumatic stress and quality of life were assessed with self report result 30 5 of the sample met dsm iv diagnostic criterion for either mde or ptsd and 9 1 had both disorder participant with concomitant mde and ptsd reported significantly higher number of prewar and postwar traumatic event than participant with ptsd only and higher number of war related event than those with mde only all p value 001 participant with both mde and ptsd had significantly higher level of general psychological and posttraumatic stress symptom a higher suicide risk and lower level of quality of life than participant with either condition alone all p value 001 conclusion concomitant mde and ptsd are associated with the experience of different traumatic event and are characterized by more general psychological distress than either condition alone the assessment of concomitant mde and ptsd can facilitate better identification of individual with severe psychopathology and poor quality of life people with co occurrence of mde and ptsd may require specific health care program following war

Title: Are media warnings about the adverse health effects of modern life self-fulfilling? An experimental study on idiopathic environmental intolerance attributed to electromagnetic fields (IEI-EMF)
Authors: Witthoft, M.; Rubin, G. J.
Abstract: objective medically unsubstantiated intolerance to food chemical and environmental toxin are common and are frequently discussed in the medium idiopathic environmental intolerance attributed to electromagnetic field iei emf is one such condition and is characterized by symptom that are attributed to exposure to electromagnetic field emf in this experiment we tested whether medium report promote the development of this condition method participant n 147 were randomly assigned to watch a television report about the adverse health effect of wifi n 76 or a control film n 71 after watching their film participant received a sham exposure to a wifi signal 15 min the principal outcome measure wa symptom report following the sham exposure secondary outcome included worry about the health effect of emf attributing symptom to the sham exposure and increase in perceived sensitivity to emf result 82 54 of the 147 participant reported symptom which they attributed to the sham exposure the experimental film increased emf related worry beta 0 19 p 019 post sham exposure symptom among participant with high pre existing anxiety beta 0 22 p 008 the likelihood of symptom being attributed to the sham exposure among people with high anxiety beta 31 p 001 and the likelihood of people who attributed their symptom to the sham exposure believing themselves to be sensitive to emf beta 0 16 p 049 conclusion medium report about the adverse effect of supposedly hazardous substance can increase the likelihood of experiencing symptom following sham exposure and developing an apparent sensitivity to it greater engagement between journalist and scientist is required to counter these negative effect

Title: What happens in the course of positive mirror exposure? Effects on eating pathology, body satisfaction, affect, and subjective physiological arousal in patients with anorexia and bulimia nervosa
Authors: Tanck, J. A.; Hartmann, A. S.; Svaldi, J.; Hagena, S.; Osen, B.; Stierle, C.; Vocks, S.
Abstract: objective mirror exposure me is a therapeutic technique to improve body image disturbance however evidence on the effectiveness of different form of me in clinical population is lacking the present study therefore analysed effect of me on trait like and state measure of body image in patient with anorexia nervosa an and bulimia nervosa bn method the present study therefore analysed effect of me on trait like and state measure of body image in patient with anorexia nervosa an and bulimia nervosa bn in total 47 inpatient underwent 3 me session guided by a therapist with instruction to exclusively verbalise positively about their whole body participant completed questionnaire on trait like eating pathology and body image at the start and end of the study and instrument on state affect and body satisfaction were administered directly before and after each me session subjective physiological arousal and emotional valence relating to each body part were assessed within each session result the result indicate significant improvement in eating pathology and body image regarding trait like measure in patient with an and bn concerning state measure negative affect significantly decreased and body satisfaction increased during me physiological arousal decreased and positively valenced emotion relating to the various body part increased conclusion these finding suggest that positively verbalising about one s body during me improves eating pathology body image affect and subjective physiological arousal and thus seems to be an effective form of me

Title: Patients' self-perceived strengths increase during treatment and predict outcome in outpatient cognitive behavioral therapy
Authors: Schurmann-Vengels, J.; Teismann, T.; Margraf, J.; Willutzki, U.
Abstract: objective modern conceptualization suggest the independence of positive and negative mental health construct research of positive construct in psychotherapy is scarce this study analyzed the development of patient strength during psychotherapy and whether pre therapy strength incrementally predict treatment outcome method two hundred and two patient 56 44 female mean age 42 49 treated by 54 therapist underwent cognitive behavioral therapy patient strength in different context a well a psychopathology interpersonal problem and self esteem were assessed at the beginning and end of therapy result strength increased in the context of everyday life evdays d 0 44 p 0 001 and current problem probs d 0 70 p 0 001 strength in the context of previous crisis that were managed successfully crisess did not change however baseline score of crisess were a significant incremental predictor of all outcome conclusion a differentiated assessment of positive construct is useful for outcome prediction and the implementation of strength based intervention

Title: Distinct Functional Connectivity Signatures of Impaired Social Cognition in Multiple Sclerosis
Authors: Golde, S.; Heine, J.; Pottgen, J.; Mantwill, M.; Lau, S.; Wingenfeld, K.; Otte, C.; Penner, I. K.; Engel, A. K.; Heesen, C.; Stellmann, J. P.; Dziobek, I.; Finke, C.; Gold, S. M.
Abstract: objective multiple sclerosis m is characterized by impairment in basic cognitive function such a information processing speed a well a in more complex higher order domain such a social cognition however a these deficit often co occur it ha remained challenging to determine whether they have a specific pathological basis or are driven by shared biology method to identify neural signature of social cognition deficit in m data were analyzed from n 29 patient with relapsing remitting m and n 29 healthy control matched for age sex and education we used neuropsychological assessment of information processing speed attention learning working memory and relevant aspect of social cognition theory of mind emotion recognition er empathy and employed neuroimaging of cns network using resting state functional connectivity result m patient showed significant deficit in verbal learning and memory a well a implicit er performance in these domain wa uncorrelated functional connectivity analysis identified a distinct network characterized by significant association between poorer er and lower connectivity of the fusiform gyrus ffg with the right lateral occipital cortex which also showed lower connectivity in patient compared to control moreover while er wa correlated with m symptom such a fatigue and motor sensory functioning on a behavioral level ffg connectivity signature of social cognition deficit showed no overlap with these symptom conclusion our analysis identify distinct functional connectivity signature of social cognition deficit in m indicating that these alteration may occur independently from those in other neuropsychological function

Title: Neural correlates of emotional distractibility in bipolar disorder patients, unaffected relatives, and individuals with hypomanic personality
Authors: Kanske, P.; Heissler, J.; Schonfelder, S.; Forneck, J.; Wessa, M.
Abstract: objective neuropsychological deficit and emotion dysregulation are present in symptomatic and euthymic patient with bipolar disorder however there is little evidence on how cognitive functioning is influenced by emotion what the neural correlate of emotional distraction effect are and whether such deficit are a consequence or a precursor of the disorder the author used functional mri fmri to investigate these question method fmri wa used first to localize the neural network specific to a certain cognitive task mental arithmetic and then to test the effect of emotional distractors on this network euthymic patient with bipolar i disorder n 22 two population at high risk for developing the disorder unaffected first degree relative of individual with bipolar disorder n 17 and healthy participant with hypomanic personality trait n 22 were tested along with three age gender and education matched healthy comparison group n 22 n 17 n 24 respectively result there were no difference in performance or activation in the task network for mental arithmetic however while all participant exhibited slower response when emotional distractors were present this response slowing wa greatly enlarged in bipolar patient similarly task related activation wa generally increased under emotional distraction however bipolar patient exhibited a further increase in right parietal activation that correlated positively with the response slowing effect conclusion the result suggest that emotional dysregulation lead to exacerbated neuropsychological deficit in bipolar patient a evidenced by behavioral slowing and task related hyperactivation the lack of such a deficit in high risk population suggests that it occurs only after disease onset rather than representing a vulnerability marker

Title: Non-suicidal self-injury and its co-occurrence with suicidal behavior: An epidemiological-study among adolescents and young adults
Authors: Voss, C.; Hoyer, J.; Venz, J.; Pieper, L.; Beesdo-Baum, K.
