Abstract: objective non suicidal self injury nssi comprising thought and behavior is common and often co occurring with suicidal behavior like ideation plan and attempt a limited data are available for adolescent and young adult this study aim to present prevalence estimate for lifetime nssi it co occurrence with suicidal behavior conditional probability and their association with socio demographic characteristic severity characteristic of suicidal behavior and health service utilization method the epidemiological behavior and mind health bemind study assessed in 2015 16 a random community sample of n 1180 aged 14 21 year from dresden germany regarding lifetime nssi via self administered questionnaire and suicidal behavior via standardized interview result any lifetime nssi wa reported by 19 3 thought 18 0 behavior 13 6 of the sample with higher prevalence in female or 2 7 95 ci 1 9 3 8 p 0 001 lifetime prevalence of co occurring nssi and suicidal behavior wa 7 7 female had a 3 3 to 8 8 fold odds of co occurrence than male among those with any nssi 39 6 endorsed suicidal behavior and 66 3 of those with any suicidal behavior reported nssi 42 3 of those with any nssi reported to have used mental healthcare service at any time during their life with higher rate in those with co occurring suicidal behavior 62 3 conclusion non suicidal self injury and co occurring suicidal behavior is common in adolescent and young adult especially female the limited utilization of mental healthcare service underpins the need for improving recognition of nssi and suicidal behavior a well a the accessibility of mental healthcare service during adolescence and emerging adulthood

Title: Food through the child's eye: An eye-tracking study on attentional bias for food in healthy-weight children and children with obesity
Authors: Werthmann, J.; Jansen, A.; Vreugdenhil, A. C.; Nederkoorn, C.; Schyns, G.; Roefs, A.
Abstract: objective obesity prevalence among child is high and knowledge on cognitive factor that contribute to child s reactivity to the obesogenic food environment could help to design effective treatment and prevention campaign empirical study in adult suggest that attention bias for food could be a risk factor for overeating accordingly the current study tested if child with obesity have an elevated attention bias for food when compared to healthy weight child another aim wa to explore whether attention bias for food predicted weight change after 3 and 6 month in obese child method obese child n 34 were recruited from an intervention program and tested prior to the start of this intervention healthy weight child n 36 were recruited from local school first attention bias for food were compared between child with obesity n 30 and matched healthy weight child n 30 second regression analysis were conducted to test if food related attention bias predicted weight change after 3 and 6 month in child with obesity following a weight loss lifestyle intervention result result showed that obese child did not differ from healthy weight child in their attention bias to food yet automatically directing attention toward food i e initial orientation bias wa related to a reduced weight loss r 2 14 p 032 after 6 month in child with obesity discussion high palatable food is a salient stimulus for all child irrespective of their weight status however automatically directing attention to food cue might facilitate further weight gain in child with obesity

Title: Exposure and CBT for chronic back pain: An RCT on differential efficacy and optimal length of treatment
Authors: Glombiewski, J. A.; Holzapfel, S.; Riecke, J.; Vlaeyen, J. W. S.; de Jong, J.; Lemmer, G.; Rief, W.
Abstract: objective our aim wa to establish whether exposure a specialized tailored treatment for chronic low back pain ha any advantage over cognitive behavioral therapy cbt among individual with high fear avoidance level second we planned to compare short and long version of exposure third we aimed to investigate whether exposure can be delivered in an outpatient psychological setting method a total of 88 caucasian participant 55 woman were randomized to three different psychological treatment condition exposure long exposure short and cbt all participant were suffering from chronic pain and elevated level of pain related anxiety and disability the primary outcome were disability assessed using two different questionnaire qbpds and pdi and average pain intensity secondary outcome included pain related anxiety psychological flexibility coping strategy and depression assessment took place at pretreatment midtreatment posttreatment and 6 month follow up result exposure wa more effective than cbt at reducing movement related disability assessed with the qbpds exposure and cbt did not differ in reduction of pain intensity or disability assessed using the pdi exposure short outperformed exposure long after 10 session meaning that individual improved faster when they were offered fewer session exposure could be safely delivered in the psychological setting concerning secondary outcome exposure led to greater improvement in psychological flexibility relative to cbt cbt wa more effective than exposure at enhancing coping strategy in exposure significantly more participant dropped out conclusion although being more challenging to patient exposure is an effective treatment which can be delivered in a psychological treatment setting and should be offered a a short term treatment psycinfo database record

Title: Overactive Performance Monitoring as an Endophenotype for Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: Evidence From a Treatment Study
Authors: Riesel, A.; Endrass, T.; Auerbach, L. A.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: objective overactive performance monitoring a measured by the error related negativity in the event related brain potential represents one of the most robust psychophysiological alteration in obsessive compulsive disorder ocd it ha been proposed a an endophenotype for ocd because it is heritable and more prevalent in family of ocd patient consistent with this notion it is also independent of symptom profile and symptom severity in cross sectional study longitudinally it ha been shown to be state independent in pediatric patient with ocd the purpose of the present study wa to investigate the state dependency of error monitoring by examining adult ocd patient before and after symptom reduction through cognitive behavioral therapy cbt method error related and correct related negativity a electrophysiological indicator of performance monitoring were recorded from 45 ocd patient and 39 healthy comparison subject while performing a flanker task patient were assessed before starting and after completing a standard 30 session cbt including exposure and response prevention and healthy comparison subject were tested after a comparable time interval result pretreatment patient with ocd were characterized by enhanced error related and correct related negativity compared with healthy comparison subject this difference persisted after treatment when symptom were substantially reduced there wa no significant correlation between symptom improvement and change in performance monitoring and no difference in performance monitoring between treatment responder and nonresponders conclusion this is the first longitudinal study in adult ocd patient showing stability of enhanced error monitoring following successful symptom reduction through cbt it support the hypothesis that overactive performance monitoring is an endophenotype that indicates vulnerability for ocd

Title: A psycho-oncological online intervention supporting partners of patients with cancer (PartnerCARE): Results from a randomized controlled feasibility trial
Authors: Bodschwinna, D.; Lorenz, I.; Bauereiss, N.; Gundel, H.; Baumeister, H.; Honig, K.
Abstract: objective partner of cancer patient are the primary supporter and burdened at the same time support for partner is hitherto scarce and existing offer are rarely used the partnercare online intervention wa specifically developed to address the caregiving partner need this two arm parallel randomized controlled trial rct evaluates the feasibility acceptability and potential efficacy of partnercare method sixty german speaking partner of patient with various cancer entity were randomized into two condition intervention group ig with partnercare n 30 or waitlist control group n 30 participant completed online questionnaire at baseline t0 post treatment t1 and 4 month follow up t2 feasibility and acceptability outcome included dropout rate use and acceptance of partnercare individual user e coach feedback a well a negative effect relevant efficacy outcome were assessed to test for potential intervention effect result recruitment success illustrates demand for and acceptability of partnercare satisfaction with the intervention wa high client satisfaction questionnaire adapted to internet based intervention t1 m 24 66 sd 6 42 and 73 3 of participant completed the intervention study dropout rate wa low t1 17 t2 29 more positive than negative side effect of the intervention were identified and negative one were mainly related to intrapersonal change for efficacy outcome we found effect over time with strongest effect within the ig from t0 to t1 in psychological distress d 0 73 95 ci 0 34 1 12 and anxiety 0 66 0 26 1 04 but no group effect were significant at t1 and t2 conclusion partnercare is feasible acceptable and potentially efficacious based on received feedback partnercare is currently undergoing further development and subsequently efficacy will be investigated in a rct trial registration german clinical trial registration drks00017019 registered on 08 april 2019

Title: Dyadic coping and social support: Various types of support in hematooncological patients and their spouses-Associations with psychological distress
Authors: Bodschwinna, D.; Ernst, J.; Mehnert-Theuerkauf, A.; Gundel, H.; Weissflog, G.; Honig, K.
Abstract: objective patient and spouse use various support strategy to deal with cancer and it associated burden support can be perceived within the dyad perceived dyadic coping pdc or from others perceived social support p the present study investigates the association of pdc and p with depression and anxiety symptom experienced by hematooncological dyad method a total of 330 hematooncological dyad participated in the study dyadic coping inventory dci including perceived stress communication and four pdc strategy supportive negative delegated common enriched social support instrument essi and patient health questionnaire 4 phq 4 are used for assessment to take nonindependence of patient s and spouse s variable into account data are analyzed with the actor partner interdependence model apim result hematological cancer patient and their spouse reported a similar level of depression and anxiety symptom perceived negative dyadic coping dc wa adversely related with both patient s and spouse s outcome all p 0 01 and perceived positive dc wa adversely related with depression symptom in both and anxiety symptom in spouse all p 0 05 more p wa associated with le depression and anxiety symptom in both all p 0 05 and spouse s p b 0 04 p 0 05 wa significantly associated with patient s depression symptom conclusion this study highlight the association between perceived negative dc perceived positive dc and p with depression and anxiety symptom focus should be on enhancement of p especially in spouse a they experience a comparable amount of psychosocial distress and have considerable impact on the patient s wellbeing

Title: Blunted emotion-modulated startle reflex in anorexia nervosa
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Pellegrino, J.; Maier, C.; Munch, H. M.; Harmer, C. J.; Walther, S.; Herzog, W.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: objective patient with anorexia nervosa an often show difficulty in the perception expression and regulation of emotion and a strong avoidance of aversive feeling according to psychobiological model dietary restraint and accompanying weight loss may serve a a maladaptive mechanism of emotion regulation by attenuating aversive emotional state in an thereby contributing to the maintenance of the disorder method twenty seven woman with an and 26 age matched healthy woman were shown short film clip to elicit fear sadness amusement and neutral emotional state eyeblink startle response wa measured by electromyography in reaction to startle eliciting acoustic stimulus presented 12 time binaurally during each film clip result a compared to healthy control patient with an showed a blunted startle response to the fear but not to the sadness eliciting stimulus discussion the finding support the assumption that underweight is associated with attenuated emotional reactivity to fear eliciting material in an this is in line with the hypothesis that starvation and low body weight constitute a maladaptive mechanism of emotion regulation in an contributing to the maintenance of the disorder

Title: Oxytocin and reduction of social threat hypersensitivity in women with borderline personality disorder
Authors: Bertsch, K.; Gamer, M.; Schmidt, B.; Schmidinger, I.; Walther, S.; Kastel, T.; Schnell, K.; Buchel, C.; Domes, G.; Herpertz, S. C.
Abstract: objective patient with borderline personality disorder are characterized by emotional hyperarousal with increased stress level anger proneness and hostile impulsive behavior they tend to ascribe anger to ambiguous facial expression and exhibit enhanced and prolonged reaction in response to threatening social cue associated with enhanced and prolonged amygdala response because the intranasal administration of the neuropeptide oxytocin ha been shown to improve facial recognition and to shift attention away from negative social information the author investigated whether borderline patient would benefit from oxytocin administration method in a randomized placebo controlled double blind group design 40 nonmedicated adult female patient with a current dsm iv diagnosis of borderline personality disorder two patient were excluded based on hormonal analysis and 41 healthy woman matched on age education and iq took part in an emotion classification task 45 minute after intranasal administration of 26 iu of oxytocin or placebo dependent variable were latency and number or initial reflexive eye movement measured by eye tracking manual response latency and blood oxygen level dependent response of the amygdala to angry and fearful compared with happy facial expression result borderline patient exhibited more and faster initial fixation change to the eye of angry face combined with increased amygdala activation in response to angry face compared with the control group these abnormal behavioral and neural pattern were normalized after oxytocin administration conclusion borderline patient exhibit a hypersensitivity to social threat in early reflexive stage of information processing oxytocin may decrease social threat hypersensitivity and thus reduce anger and aggressive behavior in borderline personality disorder or other psychiatric disorder with enhanced threat driven reactive aggression

Title: Efficacy of Heart Rate Variability Biofeedback for Somatic Symptom Disorder: A Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial
Authors: Krempel, L.; Martin, A.
Abstract: objective patient with somatic symptom disorder ssd often receive targeted intervention only after a long duration of illness moreover the reported effect size of intervention for ssd are small therefore improvement and evaluation of intervention are needed preliminary evidence suggests autonomic imbalance for example lower heart rate variability hrv in ssd hrv biofeedback hrv bf a a method for self regulation show initial positive effect in chronic pain and functional syndrome the aim of this study wa to evaluate the efficacy of a brief hrv bf intervention for ssd method of a total of 50 participant with ssd diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder fifth edition who were recruited and randomly assigned to four session of hrv bf n 25 or autogenic training at n 25 49 participant were analyzed female 77 6 mean standard deviation age 45 3 14 4 year the primary outcome were somatic symptom severity screening for somatoform disorder numeric rating scale and hrv secondary outcome were psychological characteristic of ssd e g the somatic symptom disorder 12 scale health concern emotion regulation the data were collected before and after intervention and were analyzed with repeated measure analysis of variance and post hoc t test result symptom severity improved after both hrv bf and at standard deviation of the nn interval and psychological symptom improved significantly more strongly in the hrv bf than in the at group e g standard deviation of the nn interval etap2 interaction 0 10 p 047 conclusion the improvement in somatic symptom but specifically in cognitive affective symptom and autonomic regulation suggest that hrv bf with only four session is a potentially useful intervention option for ssd thus adding this short hrv bf intervention to existing psychological treatment for ssd may be promising trial registration german clinical trial register identifier drks00017099 http www drks de

Title: Preliminary evidence for increased parasympathetic activity during social inclusion and exclusion in adolescents with functional abdominal pain
Authors: Gulewitsch, M. D.; Jusyte, A.; Mazurak, N.; Weimer, K.; Schonenberg, M.
Abstract: objective peer victimization e g social exclusion ha been shown to be associated with physical health problem such a functional somatic complaint and especially symptom of pain to date no study ha investigated the mechanism underlying this association in clinical pediatric sample the aim of this study wa to evaluate the parasympathetic activity during a social exclusion experience in adolescent with functional abdominal pain fap method twenty adolecents with fap and 21 matched healthy participant were compared regarding parameter of parasympathetic activation before during and after participating in the cyberball game a well established paradigm to induce social exclusion result adolescent with fap showed an increase in parasympathetic activation during both consecutive phase of the cyberball game inclusion a well a exclusion condition whereas the healthy control group remained stable there were no difference in subjective experience of in and exclusion between the group conclusion the parasympathetic activation pattern may indicate altered processing of social stimulus in adolescent with fap

Title: Number of teeth predict depressive symptoms in a longitudinal study on patients with periodontal disease
Authors: Ehrenthal, J. C.; Graetz, C.; Plaumann, A.; Dorfer, C. E.; Herzog, W.
Abstract: objective periodontal disease is associated with a wide range of psychosocial risk factor disease related tooth loss ha been associated with an increase in depressive symptom in cross sectional study however while depression is a known risk factor for the outcome of chronic disease it remains unclear if tooth loss can also predict depressive symptom over the course of treatment aim of the current pilot study wa to test to what extend the number of teeth predict depressive symptom several year later method tooth status of 310 patient with chronic and aggressive periodontitis wa evaluated at the beginning of a specialized university based outpatient treatment we assessed depressive symptom with the patient heath questionnaire phq on average 13years later regression analysis were used to relate initial number of teeth to self reported depression score result fewer teeth at the beginning of the treatment were related to higher score of depressive symptom even when controlling for several covariates conclusion tooth loss is a potential risk factor for the development of depression in periodontal disease further longitudinal study that control for initial depressive symptom are needed to identify disease mechanism

Title: Internet-based CBT for somatic symptom distress (iSOMA) in emerging adults: A randomized controlled trial
Authors: Hennemann, S.; Bohme, K.; Kleinstauber, M.; Baumeister, H.; Kuchler, A. M.; Ebert, D. D.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: objective persistent somatic symptom distress is common in emerging adult and is associated with adverse health outcome and impairment internet based intervention could help to prevent burden and chronicity this randomized controlled trial tested the efficacy of a guided cognitive behavioral internet intervention for somatic symptom distress isoma in emerging adult at risk for somatic symptom disorder compared to a waitlist control condition method 158 participant n 156 analyzed 24 53 year 83 3 female with multiple somatic symptom were recruited among german speaking university and randomly allocated to either receive the 8 week isoma intervention with psychologist support or the waitlist both with access to treatment a usual primary outcome were somatic symptom distress patient health questionnaire somatic symptom scale phq 15 and psychobehavioral feature of somatic symptom disorder 12 ssd 12 assessed at baseline and 8 week postrandomization secondary outcome included depression anxiety illness worry functional impairment and attitude toward psychological treatment result participant in the isoma group showed significantly greater improvement p 001 in primary outcome phq 15 d 0 70 0 36 1 05 ssd 12 d 0 65 0 30 0 99 and secondary outcome p 05 d 0 41 0 52 compared to the waitlist except for attitude toward psychological treatment p 944 satisfaction with isoma wa high 91 0 most participant 72 8 completed at least 4 of 7 module and negative treatment effect were infrequent 14 9 conclusion our intervention had a substantial positive impact on somatic symptom distress across a broad range of persistent physical symptom in a vulnerable target group opening up promising possibility for indicative prevention and blended care for somatic symptom disorder psycinfo database record c 2022 apa all right reserved

Title: Remotely Provided Open-Label Placebo Reduces Frequency of and Impairment by Allergic Symptoms
Authors: Kube, T.; Kirsch, I.; Glombiewski, J. A.; Witthoft, M.; Brascher, A. K.
Abstract: objective placebo being prescribed with full honesty and disclosure i e open label placebo olp have been shown to reduce symptom burden in a variety of condition with regard to allergic rhinitis previous research provided inconclusive evidence for the effect of olp possibly related to a separate focus on either symptom severity or symptom frequency overcoming this limitation of previous research the present study aimed to examine the effect of olp on both the severity and frequency of allergic symptom method in a randomized controlled trial patient with allergic rhinitis n 74 were randomized to olp or treatment a usual tau because of the covid 19 pandemic olp wa administered remotely in a virtual clinical encounter participant took placebo tablet for 14 day the primary outcome were the severity and frequency of allergic symptom the secondary end point wa allergy related impairment result olp did not significantly improve symptom severity over tau f 1 71 3 280 p 074 eta2 0 044 but did reduce symptom frequency f 1 71 7 272 p 009 eta2 0 093 and allergy related impairment more than tau f 1 71 6 445 p 013 eta2 0 083 reflecting medium to large effect the use of other antiallergic medication did not influence the result conclusion although olp wa able to lower the frequency of allergic symptom and allergy related impairment substantially it effect on symptom severity were weaker the remote provision of olp suggests that physical contact between patient and provider might not be necessary for olp to work

Title: Work disability in soldiers with posttraumatic stress disorder, posttraumatic embitterment disorder, and not-event-related common mental disorders
Authors: Muschalla, B.; Rau, H.; Willmund, G. D.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: objective posttraumatic mental disorder may occur with different affect quality best known is posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd a conditioned anxiety reaction with intrusion another event related mental disorder is posttraumatic embitterment pted characterized by affect of embitterment and thought of revenge occurring after an event deeply hurting basic belief knowing about associated disability is important for treatment and sociomedical decision this is the first study to explore work disability in patient with ptsd pted and not event related common mental disorder cmd method in this observational study 101 soldier 85 men 31 year 50 experienced expedition abroad with different mental disorder were investigated concerning common mental disorder mini and accompanying work capacity impairment mini icf app interview were conducted by a state licensed psychotherapist with expertise in sociomedical description of work capacity impairment patient with ptsd pted and other cmd were compared concerning their degree and pattern of work capacity impairment result ptsd patient n 23 were more strongly impaired in mobility a compared to patient with other cmd n 64 or pted patient with pted n 14 were more impaired in interactional capacity contact with others group integration a compared to patient with other cmd or ptsd conclusion ptsd patient need support to improve mobility in work relevant traffic situation apart from this they are not specifically more or le impaired than patient with other cmd pted patient should get attention concerning their interactional problem a these may disturb esprit de corp which is an essential requirement for service in the armed force psycinfo database record

Title: Using bodily postures in the treatment of anorexia nervosa: Effects of power posing on interoception and affective states
Authors: Weineck, F.; Hauke, G.; Lindemann, H.; Lachenmeir, K.; Schnebel, A.; Karacic, M.; Meule, A.; Voderholzer, U.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: objective power posing involves the adoption of an expansive bodily posture this study examined whether power posing could benefit individual with anorexia nervosa an and woman with normal weight in regard to interoceptive ability and affective state method participant included 50 inpatient and outpatient with an a well a 51 normal weight woman interoceptive accuracy iacc measured by the heartbeat tracking task and interoceptive sensibility is measured by confidence rating were assessed at baseline after a single power posing session and after 1 week of daily training also the short term effect of power posing on subjective feeling of dominance pleasantness and arousal were investigated result both group increased in their iacc after one power posing session also there wa a significant main effect of time on feeling of dominance and pleasantness in the short term woman with an displayed lower level of is dominance and pleasantness a well a higher level of arousal than woman without an discussion these finding suggest that power posing ha the potential to increase iacc subjective feeling of power and pleasant affect in the short term further research should investigate which mechanism foster the effectiveness of this intervention to tailor it to the need of woman with an

Title: Do patients with pathological health anxiety fear COVID-19? A time-course analysis of 12 single cases during the "first wave" of the COVID-19 pandemic in Germany
Authors: Sauer, K. S.; Schmidt, A.; Jungmann, S. M.; Bailer, J.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: objective pre existing health anxiety is associated with an intensified affective response to the novel covid 19 pandemic in the general population still result on the reaction of people with a diagnosis of pathological health anxiety i e hypochondriasis are scarce method in the present study we investigated the course of health anxiety related to sars cov 2 covid 19 in comparison to health anxiety related to other severe disease e g cancer in a sample of 12 patient with the diagnosis of pathological health anxiety during the first wave of the covid 19 pandemic in germany both sars cov 2 related anxiety and anxiety related to other severe disease were assessed weekly over 16 measurement point 30 03 19 07 2020 and primarily analyzed with fixed effect regression analysis result unexpectedly sars cov 2 related anxiety wa on average significantly lower than anxiety related to other severe disease d 0 54 p 001 and not significantly associated with anxiety related to other severe disease or pre covid 19 health anxiety conclusion it therefore appears premature to assume that sars cov 2 related anxiety and other health worry are necessarily strongly interrelated and comparably high in people with pathological health anxiety

Title: Improving emotion recognition in anorexia nervosa: An experimental proof-of-concept study
Authors: Preis, M. A.; Schlegel, K.; Stoll, L.; Blomberg, M.; Schmidt, H.; Wunsch-Leiteritz, W.; Leiteritz, A.; Brockmeyer, T.
Abstract: objective previous research ha found increasing evidence for difficulty in emotion recognition ability era and social cognition in anorexia nervosa an and recent model consider these factor to contribute to the development and maintenance of the disorder however there is a lack of experimental study testing this hypothesis therefore the present proof of concept study examined whether era can be improved by a single session of a computerized training in an and whether this ha short term effect on eating disorder symptom method forty inpatient 22 20 7 15 year with an were randomly assigned to receive a single session of computerized training of era tera or a sham training training the recognition of different type of cloud era self reported eating disorder symptom and body mass index bmi were assessed within 3 day before and after training result after training both group showed improved era reduced self reported eating disorder symptom and an increased bmi a compared to patient in the control group patient who received tera showed greater improvement in era and self reported eating disorder symptom discussion era can be effectively trained in patient with an moreover short term improvement in self reported eating disorder symptom provide tentative support for the hypothesis that difficulty in era contribute to the maintenance of an and that specific training of era hold promise a an additional component in an treatment future study are needed to replicate these finding in larger sample and to investigate long term effect and transfer into real world setting

Title: On the Relationship of Interoceptive Accuracy and Attention: A Controlled Study With Depressed Inpatients and a Healthy Cohort
Authors: Schultchen, D.; Schneider, C.; Berberich, G.; Zaudig, M.; Erle, T. M.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: objective previous research ha shown reduced interoceptive accuracy iacc in depression attention deficit represents a key symptom of depression moreover iacc is positively correlated with attention there is no study that investigates the effect of depression on iacc and attention the aim of this study is to examine the mediating effect of iacc on depression and attention method thirty six depressed patient from the psychosomatic clinic in windach were matched with 36 healthy control according to age and sex and were assessed at ulm university all participant completed the beck depression inventory ii the heartbeat perception task to examine iacc and the d2 test assessing selective attention result depressed patient showed attention deficit both for general visual attention and iacc compared to healthy control the mediation analysis revealed that the relationship between depression and attention is not mediated via iacc furthermore depression predicts iacc and attention but these effect are direct and largely unaffected by the respective other variable discussion the result of the present study highlight both interoceptive a well a attention deficit in depressed patient no clear mediation between these variable could be shown in this study more elaborative research is needed to clarify whether different approach to improve iacc are effective for these deficit in depressed patient and could therefore be of importance a an additional aspect of therapy in depression

Title: Negative Mood Increases Selective Attention to Negatively Valenced Body Parts in Female Adolescents with Anorexia Nervosa
Authors: Svaldi, J.; Bender, C.; Caffier, D.; Ivanova, V.; Mies, N.; Fleischhaker, C.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.
Abstract: objective previous research ha yielded evidence of increased attentional processing of negatively valenced body part in woman with anorexia nervosa an especially for those with high depressive symptomatology the present study extended previous research by implementing an experimental mood manipulation method in a within subject design female adolescent with an n 12 and an age matched female control group cg n 12 were given a negative and a positive mood induction at a one week interval after each mood induction participant underwent a 3 min mirror exposure while their eye movement were recorded result after the positive mood induction both an and cg participant displayed longer and more frequent gaze towards their self defined most ugly relative to their self defined most beautiful body part however after the negative mood induction only female with an were characterized by increased attention to their most ugly compared to their most beautiful body part while cg participant attention distribution wa balanced furthermore in the negative but not in the positive mood induction condition gaze frequency and duration towards the most ugly body part wa significantly stronger in the an group relative to the cg discussion the result emphasize the role of negative mood in the maintenance of pathological information processing of the self body this increased body related negativity bias during negative mood may lead to the persistence and aggravation of an patient body image disturbance

Title: Comparison of gut-directed hypnotherapy and unspecific hypnotherapy as self-help format in children and adolescents with functional abdominal pain or irritable bowel syndrome: a randomized pilot study
Authors: Gulewitsch, M. D.; Schlarb, A. A.
Abstract: objective psychosocial treatment for chronic abdominal pain in childhood or adolescence are effective but time consuming and hardly available in the present study gut directed hypnotherapy gdht and unspecific hypnotherapy uht were compared to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of a hypnotherapeutic self help intervention participant and method child adolescent between 6 and 17 year of age with chronic abdominal pain were randomized to gdht or uht the treatment period wa 12 week each measurement were performed before and after treatment the primary outcome wa a pain diary analysis wa carried out a per protocol result of 45 participant included 13 were lost to follow up thirty two participant 14 ghdt 18 uht were analyzed dropout had higher pain severity completers in both condition showed good adherence and a similar decrease in day with pain and pain duration pain intensity decreased only in the uht condition eleven participant two gdht nine uht achieved clinical remission 80 improvement and 13 participant seven gdht six uht improved significantly 30 80 conclusion result suggest a high efficacy of standardized home based hypnotherapy for child adolescent with abdominal pain child adolescent with high pain severity are at risk of dropping out the uht condition showed slight evidence of superiority but condition were equivalent on most outcome taken together self help approach based on hypnotherapy could close a treatment gap and prevent chronification

Title: Reduced emotion recognition from nonverbal cues in anorexia nervosa
Authors: Blomberg, M.; Schlegel, K.; Stoll, L.; Febry, H.; Wunsch-Leiteritz, W.; Leiteritz, A.; Brockmeyer, T.
Abstract: objective recent model of anorexia nervosa an emphasise the role of reduced emotion recognition ability era in the development and maintenance of the disorder however methodological limitation impede conclusion from prior research the current study try to overcome these limitation by examining era with an audio visual measure that focus strictly on multimodal nonverbal cue and allows to differentiate between era for different emotion category method forty woman with an and 40 healthy woman completed the geneva emotion recognition test this test includes 83 video clip in which 10 actor express 14 different emotion while saying a pseudo linguistic sentence without semantic meaning all clip contain multimodal nonverbal cue i e prosody facial expression gesture and posture result patient with an showed poorer era than the healthy control group d 0 71 particularly regarding emotion of negative valence d 0 26 furthermore a lower body weight r 0 41 and longer illness duration rho 0 32 were associated with poorer era in the an group conclusion using an ecologically valid instrument the finding of the study support illness model emphasising poor era in an directly addressing era in the treatment of an with targeted intervention may be promising

Title: A naturalistic investigation of cognitive-affective dysfunction in anorexia nervosa: The role of inefficiency
Authors: Furtjes, S.; Seidel, M.; King, J. A.; Boehm, I.; Jaite, C.; Roessner, V.; Ehrlich, S.
Abstract: objective research ha shown that rumination and negative affect are elevated in patient with anorexia nervosa an but the underlying origin remain unclear drawing from the theoretical framework of the goal progress theory of rumination we propose that heightened feeling of inefficiency i e low self efficacy in an might play an important role in these dysfunctional cognitive affective process method thirty two weight recovered participant with a history of an and 32 healthy control participant filled out questionnaire regarding rumination and affect six time a day over a period of 2 week via ecological momentary assessment in real life result analysis via hierarchical a well a conceptual process modeling suggest that while inefficiency is generally associated with more rumination and negative affect additional amplifying mechanism between these variable exist specifically in recovered participant with a history of an discussion inefficiency a a core aspect of an appears to trigger dysfunctional cognitive affective process which may contribute to vulnerability for an

Title: Body dysmorphic disorder and nonweight-related body image concerns in individuals with eating disorders
Authors: Kollei, I.; Schieber, K.; de Zwaan, M.; Svitak, M.; Martin, A.
Abstract: objective research on the prevalence of body dysmorphic disorder bdd in individual with eating disorder ed is scarce nonweight related appearance concern which can be considered a variant of bdd concern have also rarely been examined in ed this study therefore investigates bdd prevalence and nonweight related appearance concern in ed method one hundred individual with ed 49 inpatient with anorexia nervosa 51 inpatient with bulimia nervosa completed structured diagnostic interview and self report questionnaire result twelve individual with ed 12 0 suffered from comorbid bdd with their body dysmorphic concern being unrelated to weight and shape bdd lifetime prevalence wa 15 0 there wa a high prevalence of dissatisfaction with nonweight related body feature such a skin hair teeth nose and height 20 8 to 53 5 discussion finding indicate that bdd is a frequent comorbid disorder in individual with ed furthermore along with weight and body shape nonweight related appearance concern are also common in individual with ed

Title: Attention bias for food is independent of restraint in healthy weight individuals-an eye tracking study
Authors: Werthmann, J.; Roefs, A.; Nederkoorn, C.; Mogg, K.; Bradley, B. P.; Jansen, A.
Abstract: objective restrained eating style and weight status are highly correlated though both have been associated with an attentional bias for food cue in prior research restraint and bmi were often confounded the aim of the present study wa to determine the existence and nature of an attention bias for food cue in healthy weight female restrained and unrestrained eater when matching the two group on bmi method attention bias for food cue were measured by recording of eye movement during a visual probe task with pictorial food versus non food stimulus healthy weight high restrained n 24 and low restrained eater n 21 were matched on bmi in an attempt to unconfound the effect of restraint and weight on attention allocation pattern result all participant showed elevated attention bias for food stimulus in comparison to neutral stimulus independent of restraint status discussion these finding suggest that attention bias for food related cue are common for healthy weight woman and show that restrained eating per se is not related to biased processing of food stimulus at least not in healthy weight participant

Title: Impact of an Acceptance Facilitating Intervention on Patients' Acceptance of Internet-based Pain Interventions: A Randomized Controlled Trial
Authors: Baumeister, H.; Seifferth, H.; Lin, J.; Nowoczin, L.; Luking, M.; Ebert, D.
Abstract: objective result from clinical trial indicate that internet based psychological pain intervention are effective in treating chronic pain however little is known about patient acceptance of these program and how to positively influence patient intention to engage in them therefore the present study aimed 1 to a patient acceptance of internet based intervention and 2 to examine whether patient acceptance can be increased by an acceptance facilitating intervention method a total of 104 patient with chronic pain from 2 pain unit were randomly allocated to an intervention group ig and a no intervention control group cg the ig wa shown a short informational video about internet based psychological pain intervention before receiving a questionnaire on patient acceptance of internet based psychological pain intervention and predictor of acceptance performance expectancy effort expectancy social influence facilitating condition internet usage and internet anxiety the cg filled out the questionnaire immediately patient acceptance wa measured with a 4 item scale sum score ranging from 4 to 20 result baseline acceptance of internet based intervention wa reported a low sum score 4 9 by 53 8 moderate 10 to 15 by 42 3 and high 16 to 20 by 3 9 of the patient with chronic pain in the cg the ig showed a significantly higher acceptance m 12 17 sd 4 22 than the cg m 8 94 sd 3 71 with a standardized mean difference of d 0 81 95 ci 0 41 1 21 all predictor variable were significantly improved in the ig compared with the cg except for internet usage conclusion patient with chronic pain display a relatively low acceptance of internet based psychological pain intervention which can be substantially increased by a short informational video

Title: Impaired Early-Response Inhibition in Overweight Females with and without Binge Eating Disorder
Authors: Svaldi, J.; Naumann, E.; Biehl, S.; Schmitz, F.
Abstract: objective several study report increased reward sensitivity towards food in overweight individual by contrast data is inconclusive with respect to response inhibition in overweight individual without binge eating disorder bed hence the latter wa addressed in the present study in a group of overweight obese female with and without bed and a normal weight control group without eating disorder method a group of woman with bed n 29 a group of overweight woman without bed n 33 and normal weight female n 30 participated in a pictorial priming paradigm with food item relevant prime and office utensil neutral prime and color blob neutral prime a stimulus increased response priming effect i e priming with switch between stimulus category were taken a indicator of deficient behavioral inhibition result priming effect for neutral prime were moderate and comparable across all group however prime associated with the food task set lead to increased priming effect in both overweight group but effect were comparable for overweight obese participant with and without bed discussion result suggest that early response inhibition in the context of food is impaired in overweight individual compared to normal weight individual

Title: Pathological spirit possession as a cultural interpretation of trauma-related symptoms
Authors: Hecker, T.; Barnewitz, E.; Stenmark, H.; Iversen, V.
Abstract: objective spirit possession is a phenomenon frequently occurring in war torn country it ha been shown to be an idiom of distress entailing dissociative symptom however it association with trauma exposure and trauma related disorder remains unclear this study aimed to explore subjective disease model and the relationship between pathological spirit possession and trauma related disorder in the eastern democratic republic of the congo method seventy three formerly possessed person 74 female mean age 34 year referred by traditional and spiritual healer were interviewed about their experience of pathological spirit possession trauma exposure posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd symptom depressive symptom shame and guilt psychotic symptom somatic complaint and the impairment of psychosocial functioning result the most common disease model for pathological spirit possession wa another person having sent the spirit mostly a family member or a neighbor out of jealousy or conflict over resource significant correlation were found between spirit possession over lifetime and ptsd symptom severity feeling of shame and guilt depressive symptom somatic complaint and psychotic symptom spirit possession during the preceding 4 week wa associated with ptsd symptom severity impairment of psychosocial functioning and psychotic symptom severity conclusion the result of this study indicate that pathological spirit possession is a broad explanatory framework for various subjectively unexplainable mental and physical health problem including but not limited to trauma related disorder understanding pathological spirit possession a a subjective disease model for various mental and physical health problem may help researcher and clinician to develop culturally sensitive treatment approach for affected individual psycinfo database record

Title: Symptom Perception in Pathological Illness Anxiety: Tactile Sensitivity and Bias
Authors: Wolters, C.; Slotta, T.; Ratayczak, J.; Witthoft, M.; Gerlach, A. L.; Pohl, A.
Abstract: objective symptom perception in pathological illness anxiety pia might be biased so that somatic signal are overreported in the somatic signal detection task ssdt performance in detecting weak tactile stimulus give information on overreporting or underreporting of stimulus this task ha not yet been applied in pia method participant with pia n 44 and healthy control n 40 underwent two version of the ssdt in randomized order in the original version tactile and auxiliary light emitting diode led stimulus were each presented in half of the trial in the adapted version illness or neutral word were presented alongside tactile stimulus participant also conducted a heartbeat mental tracking task result we found significantly higher sensitivity and a more liberal response bias in led versus no led trial but no significant difference between word type an interaction effect showed a more pronounced increase of sensitivity from no led to led trial in participant with pia when compared with the adapted ssdt and control group f 1 76 5 34 p 024 eta2 0 066 heartbeat perception score did not differ between group bf01 of 3 63 conclusion the increase in sensitivity from no led to led trial in participant with pia suggests stronger multisensory integration low sensitivity in the adapted ssdt indicates that attentional resource were exhausted by processing word stimulus word effect on response bias might have carried over to the original ssdt when the word version wa presented first compromising group effect regarding bias trial registration the study wa preregistered on osf http osf io sna5v

Title: Effects of Preoperative Psychological Interventions on Catecholamine and Cortisol Levels After Surgery in Coronary Artery Bypass Graft Patients: The Randomized Controlled PSY-HEART Trial
Authors: Salzmann, S.; Euteneuer, F.; Laferton, J. A. C.; Auer, C. J.; Shedden-Mora, M. C.; Schedlowski, M.; Moosdorf, R.; Rief, W.
Abstract: objective the aim of the study wa to examine whether preoperative psychological intervention targeting patient expectation are capable of influencing the biological stress response after coronary artery bypass graft cabg surgery and could thus improve recovery after heart surgery method randomized controlled trial with assessment 10 day before surgery after psychological intervention day of hospital admission but before surgery postoperative 6 8 day later and at follow up 6 month after surgery eligible patient n 124 scheduled for elective on pump cabg or cabg with valve replacement surgery were approached before hospital admission standard medical care smc wa compared with two additional preoperative psychological intervention a an expectation manipulation intervention to optimize patient expectation about course and outcome or b supportive therapy containing the same amount of therapeutic attention but without specifically focusing on expectation postoperative plasma adrenaline noradrenaline and cortisol level were a secondary outcome of our study primary outcome patient disability 6 month after surgery and other secondary patient reported or clinical outcome were reported elsewhere result expectation manipulation intervention 3 68 ln pg ml 95 confidence interval 3 38 3 98 p 015 and supportive therapy 3 70 ln pg ml 95 confidence interval 3 38 4 01 p 026 led to significantly lower postoperative adrenaline level compared with smc 4 26 ln pg ml 95 confidence interval 3 99 4 53 only there were no treatment effect of the preoperative intervention for noradrenaline p 90 or cortisol p 30 higher postoperative adrenaline level predicted disability 6 month after surgery r 258 p 018 conclusion in addition to smc preoperative psychological intervention seem to buffer psychobiological stress response and could thus facilitate recovery from cabg surgery patient postoperative stress response could be an important factor for explaining trajectory of long term outcome clinical trial registration www clinicaltrials gov nct01407055

Title: Efficacy of internet-based treatment for genito-pelvic pain/penetration disorder: Results of a randomized controlled trial
Authors: Zarski, A. C.; Berking, M.; Ebert, D. D.
Abstract: objective the aim of this study wa to evaluate the efficacy of an internet based treatment for genito pelvic pain penetration disorder gpppd which adversely affect woman s sexuality and is associated with reduced well being and mental health comorbidities method two hundred woman with gpppd no penetrative intercourse 6 month were randomly allocated to the intervention group ig or a waitlist control group wcg the intervention included eight module and one booster session and wa delivered through an ehealth platform participant were supported by an ecoach regarding treatment adherence the primary outcome wa intercourse penetration behavior online assessment were scheduled at baseline t1 after session 8 12 week t2 and 6 month t3 after randomization intention to treat analysis were reported result significantly more participant 31 00 n 31 100 in the ig were able to have sexual intercourse at t2 compared to those in the wcg 13 00 n 13 100 chi 2 1 9 44 p 01 at t3 still more participant in the ig had sexual intercourse 29 compared to those in the wcg 20 but the group no longer differed significantly chi 2 1 2 19 p 19 genital pain painful and noncoital penetration behavior and negative penetration related cognition significantly improved with medium to large effect at t2 d 0 66 1 25 and small to large effect at t3 d 0 23 1 32 whereas fear of sexuality overall sexual functioning trait anxiety and well being improved with small to medium effect t2 d 0 20 0 49 t3 d 0 23 0 46 in the ig compared to the wcg on average participant completed 79 of the intervention conclusion internet based treatment ha been shown to be effective for gpppd symptom and could therefore be a promising treatment modality psycinfo database record c 2021 apa all right reserved

Title: Work-Anxiety and Sickness Absence After a Short Inpatient Cognitive Behavioral Group Intervention in Comparison to a Recreational Group Meeting
Authors: Muschalla, B.; Linden, M.; Jobges, M.
Abstract: objective the aim of this study wa to study the effect of a short term cognitive behavior therapy on work anxiety and sickness absence in patient with work anxiety method three hundred forty five inpatient who suffered from cardiologic neurological or orthopedic problem and additionally work anxiety were randomly assigned into two different group intervention patient got four session of a group intervention which either focused on cognitive behavior therapy anxiety management work anxiety coping group wag or unspecific recreational activity rg result no difference were found between wag and rg for work anxiety and subjective work ability when looking at patient who were suffering only from work anxiety and no additional mental disorder the duration of sickness absence until 6 month follow up wa shorter in the wag wag 11 week rg 16 week p 0 050 conclusion a short term wag may help return to work in patient with work anxiety a long a there is no comorbid mental disorder

Title: [An internet-based intervention for health promotion in family caregivers--results of a pilot study]
Authors: Bottche, M.; Klasen, M.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: objective the aim wa to examine the applicability and efficacy of an internet based low threshold psychological intervention for family caregiver with care associated stress method 23 participant were treated in a pilot study with cognitive behavioural and systemic oriented short term intervention sociodemographic a well a psychopathological data were collected at two time point pre post result data show moderate to high level of psychological stress at baseline one way repeated measure analysis of variance show a significant decrease in care associated distress stress anxiety and depressive symptom a well a a significant increase in self efficacy at posttreatmnt conclusion the presented data indicate an effective online based intervention for family caregiver

Title: Attention bias for chocolate increases chocolate consumption--an attention bias modification study
Authors: Werthmann, J.; Field, M.; Roefs, A.; Nederkoorn, C.; Jansen, A.
Abstract: objective the current study examined experimentally whether a manipulated attention bias for food cue increase craving chocolate intake and motivation to search for hidden chocolate method to test the effect of attention for food on subsequent chocolate intake attention for chocolate wa experimentally modified by instructing participant to look at chocolate stimulus attend chocolate group or at non food stimulus attend shoe group during a novel attention bias modification task antisaccade task chocolate consumption change in craving and search time for hidden chocolate were assessed eye movement recording were used to monitor the accuracy during the experimental attention modification task a possible moderator of effect regression analysis were conducted to test the effect of attention modification and modification accuracy on chocolate intake craving and motivation to search for hidden chocolate result result showed that participant with higher accuracy 1 sd ate more chocolate when they had to attend to chocolate and ate le chocolate when they had to attend to non food stimulus in contrast for participant with lower accuracy 1 sd the result were exactly reversed no effect of the experimental attention modification on craving or search time for hidden chocolate were found limitation we used chocolate a food stimulus so it remains unclear how our finding generalize to other type of food conclusion these finding demonstrate further evidence for a link between attention for food and food intake and provide an indication about the direction of this relationship

Title: Competence feedback improves CBT competence in trainee therapists: A randomized controlled pilot study
Authors: Weck, F.; Kaufmann, Y. M.; Hofling, V.
Abstract: objective the development and improvement of therapeutic competency are central aim in psychotherapy training however little is known about which training intervention are suitable for the improvement of competency method in the current pilot study the efficacy of feedback regarding therapeutic competency wa investigated in cognitive behavioural therapy cbt totally 19 trainee therapist and 19 patient were allocated randomly to a competence feedback group cfg or control group cg two experienced clinician and feedback provider who were blind to the treatment condition independently evaluated therapeutic competency on the cognitive therapy scale at five treatment time i e at session 1 5 9 13 and 17 whereas cfg and cg included regular supervision only therapist in the cfg additionally received written qualitative and quantitative feedback regarding their demonstrated competency in conducting cbt during treatment result we found a significant time x group interaction effect eta 2 09 which indicates a larger competence increase in the cfg in comparison to the cg conclusion competence feedback wa demonstrated to be suitable for the improvement of therapeutic competency in cbt these finding may have important implication for psychotherapy training clinical practice and psychotherapy research however further research is necessary to ensure the replicability and generalizability of the finding

Title: Habituation effects of pleasant and unpleasant odors
Authors: Croy, I.; Maboshe, W.; Hummel, T.
Abstract: objective the hedonic value of odor is reflected in chemosensory evoked potential with more salient unpleasant odor being processed differently from pleasant odor however it is not known if this effect is stable over time it wa examined if chemosensory evoked potential towards pleasant and unpleasant odor change with repeated presentation method 42 participant received two pleasant peach and pea and one unpleasant h2s intensity matched odor in a block design intensity and pleasantness were rated after each presentation subjective rating a well a n1 and p2 of the first stimulus of each block were compared with the two following stimulus of each block result early and late component of the chemosensory evoked potential had shorter latency in response to the unpleasant h2s compared to pea and peach pleasantness rating for h2s increased with repeated presentation but were far below neutral even for the third stimulus in a row in line with this for h2s only the p2 amplitude diminished with repeated presentation conclusion we assume that unpleasant stimulus catch more attention first hand however repeated presentation lead to reduced emotional salience of unpleasant stimulus only which is mirrored in a decrease of neuronal activation

Title: A Prospective Examination of Perceived Burdensomeness and Thwarted Belongingness As Risk Factors for Suicide Ideation In Adult Outpatients Receiving Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy
Authors: Teismann, T.; Glaesmer, H.; von Brachel, R.; Siegmann, P.; Forkmann, T.
Abstract: objective the interpersonal psychological theory of suicidal behavior posit that 2 proximal causal and interactive risk factor must be present for someone to desire suicide perceived burdensomeness and thwarted belongingness the purpose of the present study wa to evaluate the predictive power of these 2 risk factor in a prospective study method a total of 231 adult outpatient age mean 38 1 standard deviation 12 3 undergoing cognitive behavioral therapy took part in a pretreatment and a midtreatment assessment after the 10th therapy session result perceived burdensomeness thwarted belongingness and the interaction between these 2 risk factor did not add incremental variance to the prediction of midtreatment suicide ideation after controlling for age gender depression hopelessness impulsivity lifetime suicide attempt and pretreatment suicide ideation the best predictor of midtreatment suicide ideation wa pretreatment suicide ideation conclusion result offer only limited support to the assumption of the interpersonal theory of suicide

Title: Placebo- and Nocebo-Effects in Cognitive Neuroenhancement: When Expectation Shapes Perception
Authors: Winkler, A.; Hermann, C.
Abstract: objective the number of student using prescription drug to improve cognitive performance ha increased within the last year there is first evidence that the expectation to receive a performance enhancing drug alone can result in improved perceived and actual cognitive performance suggesting a substantial placebo effect in addition expecting a placebo can result in lower perceived and actual cognitive performance suggesting a nocebo effect yet the underlying mechanism of these effect remain to be elucidated the aim of our study wa to investigate whether the expectation of receiving a performance increasing drug or a performance impairing drug lead to change in actual and perceived cognitive performance compared to a control group without expectation manipulation method a total of n 75 healthy adult were recruited for an experiment to try cognitive performance modulating drug a participant s actual cognitive performance alertness working memory sustained attention and divided attention using the standardized test of attentional performance tap a well a their performance expectation were assessed participant were randomly assigned in equal number to either receiving a placebo performance increasing nasal spray modafinil or a nocebo performance impairing nasal spray vividrin r or no nasal spray natural history after placebo nocebo nasal spray administration cognitive performance wa reassessed subsequent to the second assessment participant rated their perceived change in cognitive performance a well a adverse symptom result unlike hypothesized a positive or negative performance expectation did not result in change in actual performance corresponding to the induced expectation participant in the placebo modafinil group rated their perceived change in cognitive performance subsequent to the application of the nasal spray significantly better d 1 16 compared to the nocebo vividrin r group additionally participant who expected to receive modafinil felt le tired than participant in the vividrin r group d 0 96 conclusion manipulation of performance expectation affect the perceived change in performance and tiredness but not the actual cognitive performance in healthy adult this may explain why college student use such drug despite their little impact on actual cognitive functioning

Title: Individual differences in response to once versus twice weekly sessions of CBT and IPT for depression
Authors: Bruijniks, S. J. E.; van Bronswijk, S. C.; DeRubeis, R. J.; Delgadillo, J.; Cuijpers, P.; Huibers, M. J. H.
Abstract: objective the personalized advantage index pai is a method to guide treatment selection by investigating which of two or more treatment is optimal for a given individual recently it wa shown that on average twice weekly session of psychotherapy for depression lead to better outcome compared to once weekly session the present study applied the pai method to a if subgroup of patient may have a differential response to psychotherapy frequency method data came from a clinical trial n 200 randomizing depressed patient into different session frequency weekly session versus twice weekly session machine learning technique were used to select pretreatment variable and develop a multivariable prediction model that calculated each patient s pai difference in observed depression post treatment score beck depression inventory ii bdi ii were tested between patient that received their pai indicated versus non indicated session frequency between group effect size cohen s d were reported result we identified prognostic indicator generally associated with lower post treatment bdi ii regardless of treatment assignment in addition we identified specific demographic and psychometric feature associated with differential response to weekly versus twice weekly therapy session observed post treatment bdi ii score were significantly different between individual receiving the pai indicated versus non indicated session frequency d 37 conclusion although a higher session frequency is more effective on average different session frequency seem beneficial for different patient future study should externally validate these finding before they can be generalized to other setting psycinfo database record c 2022 apa all right reserved

Title: Congruence of therapeutic bond perceptions and its relation to treatment outcome: Within- and between-dyad effects
Authors: Rubel, J. A.; Bar-Kalifa, E.; Atzil-Slonim, D.; Schmidt, S.; Lutz, W.
Abstract: objective the present study investigates the association between congruence of patient and therapist perception of the therapeutic bond and symptom improvement method bond congruence outcome association were examined on the within and between dyad level for 580 patient mainly depression and anxiety receiving cognitive behavioral therapy symptom change wa assessed on a session to session level a well a from pre to posttreatment for the between dyad analysis the truth and bias model wa applied for the within dyad analysis polynomial regression and response surface analysis were conducted result on the between dyad level higher temporal congruence between patient and therapist bond rating i e their correlation wa associated with better treatment outcome additionally the average discrepancy between therapist and patient bond rating showed a significant quadratic association with treatment outcome a tendency for therapist to moderately rate the bond lower than their patient showed lowest posttreatment symptom score on the within dyad level we found that when patient and therapist rating were in agreement higher bond score were associated with fewer next session symptom for disagreement the result showed that if therapist rated the bond a weak whereas their patient rated it a strong higher subsequent symptom distress wa observed than if patient rated the bond a weak and their therapist rated it a strong conclusion the present study highlight the importance of therapist being vigilant to session to session change in the therapeutic bond to adjust their intervention accordingly psycinfo database record

Title: Weight, shape, and muscularity concerns in male and female adolescents: Predictors of change and influences on eating concern
Authors: Hoffmann, S.; Warschburger, P.
Abstract: objective the purpose of this study wa to examine the impact of age and weight status on adolescent body dissatisfaction and it change over 20 month in a gender comparing design the influence of body image concern on eating concern wa also investigated method in a prospective study 675 male and female adolescent aged 12 16 were assessed using self report questionnaire on weight shape muscularity and eating concern height and weight measurement were taken by trained personnel data were analyzed using structural equation modeling result analysis of latent mean revealed more pronounced weight shape concern in female than male and more pronounced muscularity concern in male than female weight shape concern increased in female over time whereas muscularity concern remained stable in both gender baseline level of weight shape concern could be predicted by age and weight status in female and by weight status in male the only predictor of change in weight shape concern wa weight status in male baseline level of muscularity concern could be predicted by age in female and by weight status in male similar effect were found for change in muscularity concern in both gender increase in weight shape and muscularity concern were associated with more pronounced eating concern discussion the result confirm gender difference in distinctive facet of body image concern and it prediction the relevance of increase in body image concern in adolescent is underlined by it association with eating concern in both gender further explanatory variable for change in body dissatisfaction should be examined in future study c 2016 wiley periodical inc int j eat disord 2017 50 139 147

Title: Associations between Grawe's general mechanisms of change and Young's early maladaptive schemas in psychotherapy research: a comparative study of change processes
Authors: Mander, J. V.; Jacob, G. A.; Gotz, L.; Sammet, I.; Zipfel, S.; Teufel, M.
Abstract: objective the study aimed at analyzing association between grawe s general mechanism of change and young s early maladaptive schema em method therefore 98 patient completed the scale for the multiperspective assessment of general change mechanism in psychotherapy sacip the young shema questionnaire short form revised ysq s3r and diverse outcome measure at the beginning and end of treatment result our result are important for clinical application a we demonstrated strong predictive effect of change mechanism on schema domain using regression analysis and cross lagged panel model conclusion resource activation experience seem to be especially crucial in fostering alteration in em a this change mechanism demonstrated significant association with several schema domain future research should investigate these aspect in more detail using observer based micro process analysis

Title: Disruptive Behaviors across Different Disorders: Evaluation of a Clinical Sample Using the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory
Authors: Heinrichs, N.; Kamp-Becker, I.; Bussing, R.; Schimek, M.; Becker, A.; Briegel, W.
Abstract: objective the study report the prevalence of disruptive behavior in a help seeking sample of young child across a diverse range of clinical diagnosis based on icd 10 method the eyberg child behavior inventory ecbi a parent rating scale of disruptive behavior wa completed on 310 child 2 11 year at three child and adolescent psychiatry clinic in three german state bavaria hesse lower saxony the majority of child were outpatient result mean intensity score of disruptive behavior differed significantly by diagnostic group with the lowest rating within a community sample and increasingly higher score in child with a diagnosis from the internalizing spectrum those with pervasive developmental disorder and finally those with externalizing disorder e g hyperkinetic disorder conduct disorder seventy percent of the clinical sample compared to only 17 of the community sample exceeded the normative cut off score of 111 indicating that disruptive behavior are common in young german child seeking help for different mental health problem conclusion these finding support the research domain criterion approach by showing that disruptive behavior cross our current diagnostic label and may need to be assessed and conceptualized in treatment planning even in child without a primary diagnosis from the externalizing spectrum

Title: Approach and avoidance bias for thin-ideal and normal-weight body shapes in anorexia nervosa
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Burdenski, K.; Anderle, A.; Voges, M. M.; Vocks, S.; Schmidt, H.; Wunsch-Leiteritz, W.; Leiteritz, A.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: objective the two study aimed to examine implicit affective evaluation of thin ideal and normal weight body shape in woman with anorexia nervosa an taking identification with body shape into account method in study 1 approach avoidance bias for thin ideal and normal weight body wa assessed in 40 woman with an and 40 healthy woman by using an approach avoidance task and female avatar body with a standard face a stimulus in study 2 39 woman with an and 38 healthy woman underwent a similar task but identification with body wa manipulated by presenting body once with the participant s own face and once with another woman s face result in study 1 patient with an did not differ from healthy participant in their automatic approach avoidance tendency towards thin ideal and normal weight body in study 2 no definite approach bias for a thin self and no avoidance bias for thin other woman or for a normal weight self were found however a compared to healthy woman those with an showed a le positive implicit evaluation of thin other woman and an implicit preference for thin body depicted a themselves over thin body depicted a another woman conclusion the finding suggest that intra sexual competition for being slim is increased in an

Title: Visual processing of one's own body over the course of time: Evidence for the vigilance-avoidance theory in adolescents with anorexia nervosa?
Authors: Bauer, A.; Schneider, S.; Waldorf, M.; Cordes, M.; Huber, T. J.; Braks, K.; Vocks, S.
Abstract: objective the vigilance avoidance theory postulate a specific threat related pattern of attention deployment characterized by initial orientation towards fear evoking stimulus and subsequent directing of attention away from them the current eye tracking study wa the first to examine the applicability of the theory for patient with eating disorder who perceive their own body a a highly aversive threat evoking stimulus method n 56 female adolescent with anorexia nervosa an and n 43 healthy control hc aged 13 18 viewed own body picture while their eye movement were recorded relative fixation time on self defined unattractive body area were compared between the group by sequencing the overall presentation time of 6 000 m into six interval a 1 000 m result participant with an showed a significantly stronger attentional bias for unattractive body area than hc within the time interval 1 2 and 3 however for interval 4 5 and 6 no significant group difference occurred within the an group the bias for unattractive body area wa significantly stronger in interval 1 compared to interval 4 5 and 6 whereas within the hc group a stable pattern of attention deployment emerged in an early attention deployment wa positively correlated with the negative affect reported after photo presentation discussion the early vigilance in an and the subsequent decrease in attention to unattractive body part is in line with our assumption however no indication of attentional avoidance wa found the current finding partially support the vigilance avoidance theory for the exposure to one s own body in adolescent with an

Title: The Influence of Methylphenidate on Hyperactivity and Attention Deficits in Children With ADHD: A Virtual Classroom Test
Authors: Muhlberger, A.; Jekel, K.; Probst, T.; Schecklmann, M.; Conzelmann, A.; Andreatta, M.; Rizzo, A. A.; Pauli, P.; Romanos, M.
Abstract: objective this study compare the performance in a continuous performance test within a virtual reality classroom cpt vrc between medicated child with adhd unmedicated child with adhd and healthy child method n 94 child with adhd n 26 of them received methylphenidate and n 68 were unmedicated and n 34 healthy child performed the cpt vrc omission error reaction time variability commission error and body movement were assessed furthermore adhd questionnaire were administered and compared with the cpt vrc measure result the unmedicated adhd group exhibited more omission error and showed slower reaction time than the healthy group reaction time variability wa higher in the unmedicated adhd group compared with both the healthy and the medicated adhd group omission error and reaction time variability were associated with inattentiveness rating of experimenter head movement were correlated with hyperactivity rating of parent and experimenter conclusion virtual reality is a promising technology to a adhd symptom in an ecologically valid environment

Title: Body image disturbance and associated eating disorder and body dysmorphic disorder pathology in gay and heterosexual men: A systematic analyses of cognitive, affective, behavioral und perceptual aspects
Authors: Schmidt, M.; Taube, C. O.; Heinrich, T.; Vocks, S.; Hartmann, A. S.
Abstract: objective this study contributes to the quantitatively large yet narrow in scope research on body image in gay men by assessing whether gay and heterosexual men systematically differ on various dimension of body image disturbance and associated pathology i e eating disorder and body dysmorphic disorder symptom moreover we examined the influence of general everyday discrimination experience and involvement with the gay community on body image method n 216 men n 112 gay men n 104 heterosexual men participated in an online survey measuring the discrepancy between self rated current and ideal body fat muscularity drive for leanness muscularity and thinness body satisfaction body related avoidance and checking appearance fixing overall body image disturbance eating disorder and body dysmorphic disorder pathology general everyday discrimination experience and involvement with the gay community result gay men showed a greater discrepancy between self rated current and ideal body fat higher drive for thinness body related avoidance appearance fixing overall body image disturbance eating disorder and body dysmorphic disorder pathology and lower body appreciation than heterosexual men all p 05 contrary to expectation everyday discrimination experience were more strongly associated with body image disturbance and eating disorder body dysmorphic disorder pathology in heterosexual men than in gay men all p 05 gay community involvement wa not associated with any body image disturbance ed or bdd aspect in gay men all p 20 discussion the result suggest greater body image disturbance in gay men than in heterosexual men regarding cognition emotion behavior and perception a well a higher eating disorder and body dysmorphic disorder pathology the result also suggest the dilemma of a thin yet muscular body ideal in gay men surprisingly discrimination experience and involvement with the gay community did not explain difference in body image disturbance gay men may have become resilient to discrimination over time and body ideal might differ across gay sub community

Title: Feedback and therapist effects in the context of treatment outcome and treatment length
Authors: Lutz, W.; Rubel, J.; Schiefele, A. K.; Zimmermann, D.; Bohnke, J. R.; Wittmann, W. W.
