Abstract: objective this study estimate feedback and therapist effect and test the predictive value of therapist and patient attitude toward psychometric feedback for treatment outcome and length method data of 349 outpatient and 44 therapist in private practice were used separate multilevel analysis were conducted to estimate predictor and feedback and therapist effect result around 5 88 of the variability in treatment outcome and 8 89 in treatment length were attributed to therapist there wa no relationship between the average effectiveness of therapist and the average length of their treatment initial impairment early alliance number of diagnosis feedback a well a therapist and patient attitude toward feedback were significant predictor of treatment outcome treatment tended to be longer for patient with a higher number of approved session by the insurance company with higher level of interpersonal distress at intake and for those who developed negatively negative feedback over the course of their treatment conclusion therapist effect on treatment outcome and treatment length in routine care seem to be relevant predictor in the context of feedback study therapist attitude toward and use of feedback a well a patient attitude toward feedback should be further investigated in future research on psychometric feedback

Title: Psychotherapist trainees' professional self-doubt and negative personal reaction: Changes during cognitive behavioral therapy and association with patient progress
Authors: Odyniec, P.; Probst, T.; Margraf, J.; Willutzki, U.
Abstract: objective this study examined psychotherapist trainee experience of professional self doubt psd and negative personal reaction npr during cognitive behavioral therapy cbt and their association with patient symptom and interpersonal problem method forty therapist treating 621 patient were analyzed patient symptom and interpersonal problem were collected repeatedly during therapy data about patient interpersonal problem were available only for 106 patient and 18 therapist therapist difficulty were assessed a trait based one assessment across all patient and a state based repeated assessment for each individual patient difficulty multilevel model were performed result none of the trait based difficulty correlated with the change of the patient symptom yet more npr at the trait level predicted a more favorable change whereas higher psd at the trait level showed an opposite effect on change of patient interpersonal problem regarding state based difficulty psd a well a npr decreased significantly over the course of cbt patient whose therapist experienced psd to increase during cbt were at risk of a le favorable patient progress regarding symptom whereas the change of interpersonal problem wa not significantly associated with change in therapist difficulty conclusion patient progress is associated with therapist experience of difficulty yet trait and state based difficulty lead to different result

Title: Manualized cognitive therapy versus cognitive-behavioral treatment-as-usual for social anxiety disorder in routine practice: A cluster-randomized controlled trial
Authors: Hoyer, J.; Colic, J.; Pittig, A.; Crawcour, S.; Moeser, M.; Ginzburg, D.; Lin, J.; Wiltink, J.; Leibing, E.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: objective this study examined the effectiveness of manualized cognitive therapy mct following the clark well approach versus non manualized cognitive behavioral treatment a usual cbtau for social anxiety disorder sad in routine practice method forty eight private practitioner were recruited within a multi center trial and either received training in manualized ct for sad or no such training practitioner treated 162 patient with sad in routine practice n 107 completers n 57 for mct n 50 for cbtau social anxiety symptom liebowitz social anxiety scale lsas and secondary measure were assessed before treatment at treatment hour 8 15 and 25 at end of treatment a well a 6 and 12 month after treatment result patient in both group showed significant reduction of sad severity after treatment d 1 91 mct and d 1 80 cbtau within group effect size intent to treat analysis lsas observer rating which remained stable at follow up there were no difference between group in term of symptom reduction and treatment duration conclusion the present trial confirms the high effectiveness of cbtau and mct for sad when practitioner conduct the treatment in routine practice additional training in the ct manual did not result in significant between group effect on therapy outcome explanation for this unexpected result are discussed

Title: Mental health, partnerships, and sexual behavior of German university students after the third wave of the COVID-19 pandemic
Authors: Supke, M.; Hahlweg, K.; Kelani, K.; Muschalla, B.; Schulz, W.
Abstract: objective this study examined the state of mental health partnership and sexual activity of german university student after the third wave of the covid 19 pandemic participant and method in june and july 2021 928 student 23 6 year 63 5 female from four university in germany participated in an online survey that assessed depressive and anxiety symptom a well a data on partnership and sexuality result of the student 56 4 were above the cutoff for clinically relevant depressive symptom and 35 7 were above the cutoff for clinically relevant anxiety symptom female gender higher academic related stress lower financial resource higher strain due to covid 19 and more loneliness were associated with more severe symptom a quarter of the student each reported an improvement or deterioration in their partnership conclusion student mental health appears to be worse compared to pre pandemic and first wave data it should be examined whether symptom decrease when university reopen

Title: Interpersonal motives in anorexia nervosa: the fear of losing one's autonomy
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Holtforth, M. G.; Bents, H.; Kammerer, A.; Herzog, W.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: objective this study examined the widely held but insufficiently studied hypothesis of autonomy disturbance in anorexia nervosa method a total sample of 112 participant comprising patient with acute anorexia nervosa an woman recovered from anorexia nervosa rec clinical control cc and healthy control hc completed measure of dependency and intimacy striving a well a measure of frustration of these same striving result in comparison to hc and cc an showed a stronger motivation to avoid dependency and lower striving for intimacy compared with hc but not with cc an also showed stronger frustration of the same motif whereas rec did not differ from an regarding avoidance of dependency they reported lower frustration of dependency avoidance i e le actual experience of dependency finally rec reported higher intimacy motivation a well a better satisfaction of intimacy motivation a compared with an conclusion the present finding suggest that a pronounced motive of avoiding dependency may be a vulnerability factor for anorexia nervosa that is disorder specific and trait like frustration of this motive seem to be associated with psychopathology

Title: Beliefs about exercise: relationship to eating psychopathology and core beliefs among young female exercisers
Authors: Meyer, C.; Blissett, J.; Alberry, R.; Sykes, A.
Abstract: objective this study had two objective first to determine link between level of eating psychopathology and belief about exercise among young woman second to determine the predictive effect of unhealthy core belief on exercise belief method a convenience sample of 185 young female exerciser completed the eating disorder inventory edi the exercise belief questionnaire ebq and the young schema questionnaire ysq result the participant mean score on the edi were a follows drive for thinness 0 69 sd 0 82 body dissatisfaction 1 30 sd 0 86 and bulimia 0 33 sd 0 42 there were significant positive correlation of all three edi scale with ebq social and ebq appearance subscales in addition ysq defectiveness shame belief predicted ebq social score while ysq unrelenting standard predicted ebq appearance score discussion those woman with relatively unhealthy eating attitude are likely to believe that exercise will prevent negative social consequence and are likely to be motivated to exercise in order to preserve or enhance their physical appearance these same type of exercise belief regarding social consequence and appearance are predicted by feeling of defectiveness and shame and by unrelenting high personal standard

Title: Depression is linked to hyperglycaemia via suboptimal diabetes self-management: A cross-sectional mediation analysis
Authors: Schmitt, A.; Reimer, A.; Hermanns, N.; Kulzer, B.; Ehrmann, D.; Krichbaum, M.; Huber, J.; Haak, T.
Abstract: objective to analyse if the association between depressive symptom and hyperglycaemia is mediated by diabetes self management method 430 people with diabetes 57 7 type 1 42 3 type 2 were cross sectionally assessed using validated self report scale for depressive symptom center for epidemiologic study depression scale ce d and diabetes self management diabetes self management questionnaire dsmq hba 1c wa analysed simultaneously in a central laboratory structural equation modelling wa used to test if the association between depressive symptom and hyperglycaemia hba 1c wa mediated by suboptimal self management in people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes result the hypothesised model of depressive symptom diabetes self management and hyperglycaemia fit the data well for both diabetes type srmr 0 04 tli 0 99 cfi 0 99 rmsea 0 02 for both model in both the type 1 and type 2 diabetes group higher depressive symptom were associated with lower self management p 0 001 and lower self management wa associated with higher hba 1c p 0 001 result indicated that the association between depressive symptom and hyperglycaemia wa significantly mediated by suboptimal diabetes self management in both type 1 and type 2 diabetes patient p 0 001 significant direct association between depressive symptom and hyperglycaemia not mediated by self management could not be observed conclusion this study provides good evidence supporting that depression is linked to hyperglycaemia via suboptimal diabetes self management in both major diabetes type

Title: Associations of depression and diabetes distress with self-management behavior and glycemic control
Authors: Schmitt, A.; Bendig, E.; Baumeister, H.; Hermanns, N.; Kulzer, B.
Abstract: objective to analyze the independent association of depression and diabetes distress with self management and glycemic outcome in type i t1dm and type 2 diabetes t2dm method six hundred six people with t1dm or t2dm participated in a cross sectional survey including measure of depression phq 9 diabetes distress paid 5 self management behavior dsmq and glycemic outcome hba1c structural equation modeling wa performed to analyze the independent linear association standardized coefficient between these variable result in those with t1dm n 339 both depressive symptom and diabetes distress were associated with lower self management 0 34 p 001 and 0 16 p 007 respectively and thereover indirectly with higher hba1c 0 20 p 001 and 0 10 p 016 respectively direct association with hba1c were not observed in those with t2dm n 267 only depressive symptom were associated with lower self management 0 41 p 001 and thus indirectly with higher hba1c 0 17 p 001 diabetes distress by contrast wa directly associated with higher hba1c 0 20 p 003 but not with self management conclusion the result are consistent with the hypothesis that depression is linked to le optimal diabetes self management thus leading to le optimal glycemic outcome the association were relatively consistent across diabetes type diabetes distress wa additionally associated with higher glycemic level suggesting that people with both depression and diabetes distress might have the least optimal outcome the conclusion are limited by the cross sectional study design self report assessment of behavior and potential bias arising from questionnaire measure further research is needed to support these finding psycinfo database record c 2021 apa all right reserved

Title: Children's concepts of the urinary tract
Authors: Equit, M.; Sambach, H.; Niemczyk, J.; von Gontard, A.
Abstract: objective to a child s body concept about anatomy and physiology of the urinary tract child drew picture responding to the question where do you believe urine come from subject and method a total of 152 child in three group were examined 81 child were out patient of these 36 child were being seen for the first time and 45 child had previously undergone bladder and bowel group training they were compared to 71 continent control child were given a body silhouette in which they drew their view of the urinary tract result half of the child 52 6 drew a bladder and other organ nearly 43 drew a tube or other anatomically incorrect picture significant difference were found for group and age child who had undergone the group training more often drew a bladder and other organ 80 correct picture and picture of bladder and other organ were more common from child aged 11 16 year conclusion child have subjective concept of the urinary tract which do not follow actual anatomy and physiology for medical intervention a well a any training programme it is essential to understand these concept and provide instruction in a child centred and developmentally adequate way

Title: Characteristics and survival of patients with cancer with intended off-label use-a cohort study
Authors: Schmitt, A. M.; Walter, M.; Herbrand, A. K.; Jorger, M.; Moffa, G.; Novak, U.; Hemkens, L.; Kasenda, B.
Abstract: objective to describe the characteristic and the survival of patient with cancer with intended off label use olu cancer treatment and reimbursement request design cohort study using medical record data setting three major cancer centre in switzerland participant 519 patient with cancer and a reimbursement request for olu between january 2015 and july 2018 main outcome characteristic of patient with cancer with and without access to intended olu characteristic included the glasgow prognostic score gps which includes c reactive protein and albumin and discriminates prognostic group result olu wa intended for 519 17 of 3046 patient with cancer a first line treatment in 51 n 264 and second line in 31 n 162 of the 519 patient 63 n 328 were male 63 n 329 had solid cancer and 21 n 111 had a haematological malignancy their median overall survival wa 23 6 month 95 ci 19 0 to 32 5 access to olu had 389 75 patient who were compared with patient without access on average 4 9 year younger mean 95 ci 1 9 to 7 9 year had a better overall prognosis according to the gps 51 with gps of 0 v 39 or 1 62 95 ci 1 01 to 2 59 had le frequently solid cancer 62 v 71 or 0 66 95 ci 0 41 to 1 05 and advanced stage cancer 53 v 70 or 0 48 95 ci 0 30 to 0 75 were more frequently treatment naive 53 v 43 or 1 55 95 ci 1 01 to 2 39 and were more frequently in an adjuvant neoadjuvant treatment setting 14 v 5 or 3 39 95 ci 1 45 to 9 93 patient with access to olu had a median o of 31 1 month versus 8 7 month for patient without access unadjusted hr 0 54 95 ci 0 41 to 0 70 conclusion contrary to the common assumption olu in oncology is typically not primarily intended for patient with exhausted treatment option patient characteristic largely differ between patient with and without access to intended olu more systematic evaluation of the benefit and harm of olu in cancer care and the regulation of it access is warranted

Title: Does clinically relevant psychopathology in adolescents necessarily require treatment or does it "grow out"?
Authors: Volz, M.; Ehrenthal, J. C.; Seiffge-Krenke, I.
Abstract: objective to determine the treatment effect of psychodynamic therapy for adolescent in comparison to normative developmental progression in two group without treatment healthy adolescent and adolescent with juvenile diabetes research design and method in a 3 wave longitudinal study n 531 adolescent n 303 treated adolescent n 119 healthy n 109 with diabetes and their parent filled out psychopathology questionnaire youth self report ysr and child behaviour checklist cbcl growth curve modeling gcm wa used to examine within person change in psychopathology while controlling for stable between person difference result gcm analysis revealed significant within person reduction in patient ysr and cbcl d 1 02 1 99 at the end of treatment when accounted for the control group developmental progression d 14 94 patient within person change remained significantly higher d 48 82 in all three group parent rated the severity of psychopathology significantly lower and within person change significantly higher than the adolescent him herself conclusion psychodynamic therapy led to a significant symptom reduction in treated adolescent and wa superior to development related symptom change occurring in the two control group hence clinically relevant symptom in adolescent do not grow out but require psychotherapeutic treatment difference between adolescent and their parent in the evaluation of symptom severity and change require attention in psychotherapy treatment and research

Title: Emotion regulation in patients with heart failure: Its relationship with depressive symptoms and rehospitalization
Authors: Chavanon, M. L.; Meyer, T.; Belnap, B. H.; Huang, Y.; Abebe, K. Z.; Rollman, B. L.; Herrmann-Lingen, C.
Abstract: objective to examine the role of emotion regulation and it relationship to mental and physical health in patient with heart failure hf method patient hospitalized with hf were screened for depressive symptom with the two item patient health questionnaire phq 2 and classified a screen positive if endorsing 1 item and otherwise a screen negative one month after hospital discharge the emotion regulation questionnaire erq wa administered to a suppression and reappraisal a emotion regulation strategy in all participant who completed the erq n 394 all cause rehospitalization and depressive symptom using the phq 9 were assessed at 1 3 and 6 month after hospital discharge result overall phq 9 score decreased by 6 month 0 13 point month p 003 and although suppression showed a small association with depression neither strategy modulated the slope of the decline in depressive symptom multivariable adjusted cox model showed that reappraisal and suppression were not related to all cause rehospitalization in the entire cohort however increasing reappraisal reduced rehospitalization risk by 24 for screen positive patient n 311 hr 0 76 p 02 but increased it by 94 in screen negative patient n 83 hr 1 94 p 009 conclusion suppression and reappraisal showed specific and divergent association in patient with hf suppression may relate to depressive symptom reappraisal wa associated with rehospitalization but differently for patient with a positive v negative depression screen further study are needed to examine whether emotion regulation skill training can improve mental and physical health in depressed patient with hf or ameliorate depression in those at risk

Title: Symptoms of depression and anxiety in adults with type 1 diabetes: Associations with self-care behaviour, glycaemia and incident complications over four years - Results from diabetes MILES-Australia
Authors: Schmitt, A.; McSharry, J.; Speight, J.; Holmes-Truscott, E.; Hendrieckx, C.; Skinner, T.; Pouwer, F.; Byrne, M.
Abstract: objective to examine whether symptom of depression or anxiety predict glycaemia and incident diabetes complication four year later and whether diabetes self care behaviour mediate these association in adult with type 1 diabetes t1dm method data of 205 adult with t1dm from the 2011 and 2015 diabetes mile australia survey were analysed variable of interest were baseline depression and anxiety phq 8 and gad 7 respectively symptom hba 1c and incident complication at four year follow up and self care behaviour at both time point longitudinal association were analysed using structural equation modelling result forty two participant 20 6 reported incident complication baseline depressive symptom predicted higher hba 1c at follow up indirectly via le optimal self care at follow up beta 0 19 p 0 011 baseline anxiety wa not independently associated with hba 1c or self care at follow up p 0 64 neither depressive nor anxiety symptom predicted incident complication although depressive symptom were associated with le optimal self care at baseline beta 0 67 p 0 001 and this predicted microvascular complication beta 0 38 p 0 044 however the indirect association via self care wa not significant beta 0 25 p 0 067 limitation participant were self selected all study variable were assessed using self report measure and adjusting for baseline hba 1c wa not possible conclusion depressive symptom predicted suboptimal self care behaviour and glycaemic outcome four year later while anxiety symptom did not the finding suggest that tailored diabetes care should take the potential impact of comorbid depression into consideration to help people improve their diabetes self care and achieve best possible health outcome

Title: General and food-specific inhibitory deficits in binge eating disorder
Authors: Svaldi, J.; Naumann, E.; Trentowska, M.; Schmitz, F.
Abstract: objective to investigate behavioral inhibition in individual with binge eating disorder bed compared with overweight and obese individual without bed no bed method participant with bed n 31 and the weight matched no bed group n 29 completed an inhibitory control task stop signal task sst with food and neutral stimulus result the bed group needed more time to stop an ongoing response a indicated by increased stop signal reaction time ssrt relative to the no bed group additionally compared with the no bed group the bed group displayed more difficulty inhibiting response elicited by food stimulus the deficit in behavioral response inhibition were also found to be related to the severity of reported symptom discussion there is a general deficit in late stage behavioral inhibition in bed and this may be particularly pronounced in the context of food stimulus

Title: Prevalence and Characteristics of Work Anxiety in Medical Rehabilitation Patients: A Cross-Sectional Observation Study
Authors: Muschalla, B.; Jobges, M.
Abstract: objective to investigate frequency type and characteristic of work anxiety in patient with somatic illness design cross sectional observation study setting neurology orthopedic and cardiology rehabilitation clinic participant patient n 1610 age 18 65y with work anxiety intervention not applicable main outcome measure patient who scored high on at least 2 of 9 item in the work anxiety screening questionnaire and who reported impairment were investigated with a differential diagnostic interview on work anxiety and with the mini international neuropsychiatric interview on non work related common mental disorder patient also filled out a self rating questionnaire on their subjective symptom load and sociodemographic data result approximately 20 to 27 of the investigated inpatient in somatic rehabilitation altogether n 393 received a work anxiety diagnosis patient with orthopedic illness report highest work anxiety and have previous longest sick leave 20 6wk in the past 12mo patient with orthopedic illness suffer from work related adjustment disorder with anxiety social anxiety and workplace phobia whereas patient with cardiac illness are more often affected by hypochondriac anxiety anxiety of insufficiency and worrying occur equally in all indication conclusion about a quarter of patient in somatic rehabilitation are in need of additional diagnostic attention owing to work anxiety differential diagnostic of work anxiety is needed for initiating adequate therapeutic action somatic rehabilitation physician should be aware of work anxiety in their patient especially in patient with orthopedic illness with previous long term sick leave

Title: Psychological capacity limitations according to Mini-ICF-APP are differently related with sick leave in patients from different professional fields
Authors: Muschalla, B.
Abstract: objective up to 29 of the working population suffer from chronic mental disorder and work disability a different profession pose different psychological capacity demand one core aspect for describing work disability is psychological capacity limitation the distribution of capacity limitation in patient with chronic mental disorder cmd from different professional field is unknown a well a their relation with sick leave objective are there different work ability limitation in cmd patient working in different profession method 263 cmd patient from different profession were investigated cross sectionally in a thorough medical and psychological assessment by a trained psychosomatic study physician besides cmd diagnostic mini and subjective work ability limitation imet an observer rating on capacity limitation wa conducted with mini icf app result no relevant difference in perceived work ability limitation were found between the profession difference of capacity limitation were better explained by psychopathology than by profession but capacity limitation were differently related with sick leave in different profession and there are difference in sick leave duration conclusion the variance of capacity limitation wa explained by psychopathology the variance of sick leave duration wa explained by profession similar capacity limitation are associated differently with sick leave in different profession different professional field may have different tolerance towards the same capacity limitation therefore similar capacity limitation are more or le strongly associated with sick leave in different profession

Title: No effect of very brief exposure to masked food pictures on fear of food in anorexia nervosa
Authors: Palmer, S.; Gronemann, J.; Mattler, U.; Febry, H.; Wunsch-Leiteritz, W.; Leiteritz, A.; Brockmeyer, T.
Abstract: objective very brief exposure to masked image of spider stimulus can facilitate approach behaviour towards spider in fearful subject we hypothesized that a similar effect might occur for fear of food in patient with anorexia nervosa an possibly offering a new treatment approach with advantage over other method of food exposure method patient with an n 60 were randomly assigned to one of three experimental condition and received a single session of exposure to either masked and very briefly presented food image clearly visible food image or masked non food image i e household item effect of the three exposure condition on fear of food and food avoidance were examined result contrary to our expectation very brief food cue exposure wa not superior to the control condition regarding fear of food and approach behaviour towards food immediately after the intervention and body mass index four week later conclusion this finding suggests important difference between fear of food in an and specific phobia such a fear of spider the absence of an effect reveals limitation of the very brief exposure method which might be better suited for evolutionarily relevant threat stimulus

Title: Do you see what I feel?--Electrophysiological correlates of emotional face and body perception in schizophrenia
Authors: Thoma, P.; Soria Bauser, D.; Norra, C.; Brune, M.; Juckel, G.; Suchan, B.
Abstract: objective we aimed to elucidate whether impaired affective face processing behaviourally and with regard to p100 and n170 component is paralleled by similar deficit in body processing in schizophrenia furthermore we aimed to a modulation by the processing of emotional or personal identity of the stimulus method fourteen patient with schizophrenia and 15 healthy control were assessed with a delayed matching to sample task involving variation of the emotional same v different valence and personal identity same v different person of body and face result patient showed overall poorer behavioural performance in control p100 amplitude were enhanced in the same identity different emotion v same identity same emotion condition and n170 amplitude were larger for different v same emotion in the patient p100 amplitude were enhanced in the right relative to the left hemisphere for face but not for body conclusion patient with schizophrenia show deficient modulation of the p100 and n170 component by emotional and personal identity of face and body which may relate to deficient context processing significance our finding suggest for the first time alteration of the electrophysiological correlate of body processing in schizophrenia

Title: The specific social costs of expressive negative symptoms in schizophrenia: reduced smiling predicts interactional outcome
Authors: Riehle, M.; Mehl, S.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: objective we tested whether people with schizophrenia and prominent expressive negative symptom en show reduced facial expression in face to face social interaction and whether this expressive reduction explains negative social evaluation of these person method we compared participant with schizophrenia with high en n 18 with participant with schizophrenia with low en n 30 and with healthy control n 39 participant engaged in an affiliative role play that wa coded for the frequency of positive and negative facial expression and rated for social performance skill and willingness for future interaction with the respective role play partner result participant with schizophrenia with high en showed significantly fewer positive facial expression than those with low en and control and were also rated significantly lower on social performance skill and willingness for future interaction participant with schizophrenia with low en did not differ from control on these measure the group difference in willingness for future interaction wa significantly and independently mediated by the reduced positive facial expression and social performance skill conclusion reduced facial expressiveness in schizophrenia is specifically related to en and ha negative social consequence these finding highlight the need to develop aetiological model and targeted intervention for en and it social consequence

Title: Change in mental health symptoms during the COVID-19 pandemic: The role of appraisals and daily life experiences
Authors: Brose, A.; Blanke, E. S.; Schmiedek, F.; Kramer, A. C.; Schmidt, A.; Neubauer, A. B.
Abstract: objective when confronted with major threat people often experience decline in well being the central purpose of this study wa to identify mechanism underlying change of well being in time of threat using the example of the covid 19 pandemic with a focus on appraisal of the pandemic and affective state stress a well a mindfulness in daily life method we conducted a study across 3 5 week including pretest posttest and a diary phase in between we worked with a sample of 460 adult pre and post test information a well a 7 189 observation from the diary phase result result showed that deterioration in mental health symptom across the duration of the study wa associated with a change towards le fortunate appraisal of the pandemic and b more negative affect and le mindfulness in daily life furthermore appraisal of the pandemic at pretest predicted experience in daily life with more negative appraisal of the pandemic predicting more negative affect and stressor occurrence a well a le mindfulness conclusion these finding speak to the dynamic nature of well being and appraisal in time of threat and highlight the role of experience in daily life in change in well being

Title: Treatment for Pediatric Functional Abdominal Pain: An Initial Examination of Reciprocal Associations Between Pain, Functional Impairment, and Parental Distress
Authors: Calvano, C.; Warschburger, P.
Abstract: objective while cross sectional study underline that child and parent factor in pediatric chronic pain are reciprocally related so far little is known on their prospective relationship especially in treatment context this study aim to analyze direction of influence between child and parental outcome using data from an intervention study method the sample covered 109 family with child aged 7 13 year diagnosed with functional abdominal pain fap child outcome included pain and impairment and parental outcome covered caregiver specific distress including both parental personal time burden i e le time available for personal need and emotional burden due to child s pain i e increased worry cross lagged panel analysis examined the direction of the relation between child and parental outcome across time pretreatment t1 post treatment t2 and 3 month follow up and 12 month follow up t3 t4 result first a significant improvement over time in all measure wa observed cross lagged effect were found for le parental personal time burden at t2 predicting both le pain beta 0 254 p 004 and le impairment beta 0 150 p 039 at t3 higher baseline pain wa predictive for higher parental emotional burden after treatment beta 0 130 p 049 and reversely for le emotional burden at 12 month follow up beta 0 261 p 004 conclusion addressing parental personal time burden in fap treatment might possibly support the improvement on the child level replication of result in larger sample is warranted to gain more insight into the direction of influence and in that way to optimize treatment for pediatric fap

Title: Somatosensory amplification moderates the efficacy of internet-delivered CBT for somatic symptom distress in emerging adults: Exploratory analysis of a randomized controlled trial
Authors: Hennemann, S.; Witthoft, M.; Kleinstauber, M.; Bohme, K.; Baumeister, H.; Ebert, D. D.; Probst, T.
Abstract: objective while study mainly provide positive evidence for the efficacy of internet delivered cognitive behavioral therapy icbt for various persistent somatic symptom it remains largely unclear for whom these intervention work or not this exploratory analysis aimed to identify moderator for the outcome between icbt for somatic symptom distres and a waitlist control group wl in a vulnerable target group of emerging adult method based on data from a randomized controlled trial on 156 university student with varying degree of somatic symptom distress who were allocated to either an eight week therapist guided icbt isoma or to the wl we examined pretreatment demographic characteristic health related variable e g somatic symptom duration mental distress e g depression anxiety and cognitive emotional factor emotional reactivity somatosensory amplification a candidate moderator of the outcome somatic symptom distress assessed by the patient health questionnaire phq 15 from pre to posttreatment result somatosensory amplification assessed by the somatosensory amplification scale ssa moderated the outcome in favor of isoma b 0 17 se 0 08 p 0 031 i e higher pretreatment somatosensory amplification wa associated with better outcome in the active compared to the control intervention no significant moderation effect were found among demographic characteristic health related variable or mental distress conclusion our finding suggest that an internet delivered cbt for somatic symptom distress should be preferred over no active treatment particularly in individual with moderate to high level of somatosensory amplification which a a next step should be tested against further treatment and in clinical population trial registration german clinical trial register drks00014375

Title: On the origin of worries about modern health hazards: Experimental evidence for a conjoint influence of media reports and personality traits
Authors: Witthoft, M.; Freitag, I.; Nussbaum, C.; Brascher, A. K.; Jasper, F.; Bailer, J.; Rubin, G. J.
Abstract: objective worry about health threatening effect of potential health hazard of modern life e g electric device and pollution represent a growing phenomenon in western country yet little is known about the cause of this growing special case of affective risk perception termed modern health worry mhw the purpose of this study is to examine a possible role of biased medium report in the formation of mhw design in two experiment we investigated whether typical television report affect mhw in study 1 130 participant were randomly assigned to a film on idiopathic environmental intolerance iei or a control film about cystic fibrosis in study 2 82 participant were randomly assigned to either a film on the danger of electromagnetic field or a control condition main outcome measure increase in mhw after sensational medium report result in study 1 only participant high on the personality trait of absorption revealed increased mhw after watching the iei film in study 2 specifically worry about radiation were found to be elevated after watching the film on the danger of electromagnetic field compared to the control film conclusion the result of both study reveal a significant and specific influence of sensational short mass medium report on mhw the influence of potential moderator such a absorption remains to be clarified

Title: Capacity Limitations and Workplace Problems in Patients With Mental Disorders
Authors: Muschalla, B.; Linden, M.
Abstract: objective according to the bio psycho social health model of the who chronic illness should not only be described at the level of symptom but in respect to capacity limitation method patient with common mental disorder n 1143 n 808 employed n 581 workplace problem were investigated concerning their self rated capacity mini icf app s result employed patient reported better capacity than unemployed patient among the employed patient those without workplace problem reported better capacity than those with workplace problem different type of workplace problem were related with specific capacity level for example problem with bullying or conflict were associated with lower interactional capacity assertiveness group integration dyadic relation whereas patient with over taxation problem perceived lower level of flexibility competency structuring of task proactivity and endurance conclusion the capacity self rating mini icf app s can depict differentiated capacity profile that may be indicative for specific type of workplace problem

Title: Recalled parental rearing behavior in adult women and men with depressive and anxiety symptoms: Findings from a community study
Authors: Klein, E. M.; Brahler, E.; Petrowski, K.; Tibubos, A. N.; Burghardt, J.; Wiltink, J.; Michal, M.; Wild, P. S.; Schulz, A.; Munzel, T.; Konig, J.; Lackner, K.; Pfeiffer, N.; Beutel, M. E.
Abstract: objective addressing the lack of population based data the purpose of this representative study wa to a sex and age specific association of maternal and paternal rearing behavior with depressiveness and anxiety controlling for sociodemographic and somatic variable method 8 175 subject participating in a population based study completed standardized questionnaire measuring recalled parental rearing behavior and distress result woman recalled their father a more controlling and warmer and their mother a more rejecting than men comparison between age group 60 v 60 year revealed that younger participant recalled more parental control and emotional warmth in addition to sociodemographic and somatic risk factor paternal rejection and maternal control were associated with depressiveness and anxiety both for woman and men or 1 58 1 96 or 1 37 1 66 maternal warmth wa negatively related to distress or 0 66 0 69 conclusion finding suggested sex and age specific difference in recalled maternal and paternal rearing behavior the current result highlighted the important role of recalled parental rearing behavior besides sociodemographic factor and somatic disease for the occurrence of depression and anxiety symptom across the age group

Title: Traumatic Events and Substance Use Disorders in Adolescents
Authors: Basedow, L. A.; Kuitunen-Paul, S.; Roessner, V.; Golub, Y.
Abstract: objective adolescent with substance use disorder sud frequently report traumatic event te and symptom of post traumatic stress disorder ptsd this study aimed to a whether lifetime prevalence rate of te and ptsd are related to sud severity in adolescent psychiatric patient method we analyzed n 114 self report of treatment seeking german adolescent aged 12 to 18 year who visited a specialized sud outpatient unit standardized questionnaire were applied to a sud severity the number of te and dsm iv ptsd criterion result patient fulfilling ptsd criterion 28 of the total sample had a higher drug use disorder identification test dudit score compared to non ptsd patient with te p 001 and compared to adolescent without te or ptsd p 003 additionally sud severity wa positively associated with the number of te and the number of intrusion hyperarousal and avoidance symptom all r 33 to 48 all p 01 discussion adolescent patient with sud reported 3 time higher rate of te and a 5 time higher prevalence of ptsd following te than the general adolescent population adolescent sud patient with ptsd reported more severe substance use problem than patient without ptsd regardless of previous te longitudinal study are needed in order to investigate the temporal relationship between te ptsd and sud

Title: Are effort-based decision-making tasks worth the effort?-A study on the associations between effort-based decision-making tasks and self-report measures
Authors: Renz, K. E.; Schlier, B.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: objective amotivation is a common symptom in various mental disorder including psychotic or depressive disorder effort based decision making ebdm task quantifying amotivation at a behavioral level have been on the rise task performance ha been shown to differentiate patient group from healthy control however finding on indicator of construct validity such a the correlation between different task and between task and self reported observer rated amotivation in clinical and healthy sample have been inconclusive method in a representative community sample n 90 we tested the construct validity of the deck choice task the expenditure for reward task and the balloon task we calculated correlation between the ebdm task and between the ebdm task and self reported amotivation apathy anticipatory pleasure and bi ba result correlation between task were low to moderate 0 198 r 0 358 with the balloon task showing the largest correlation with the other task but no significant correlation between any ebdm task and the self report measure conclusion although different ebdm task are conceptualized to measure the same construct a large part of what each task measure could not be accounted for by the other task moreover the task did not appear to substantially capture what wa measured in established self report instrument for amotivation in our sample which could be interpreted a questioning the construct validity of ebdm task

Title: Associations of androgens with depressive symptoms and cognitive status in the general population
Authors: Kische, H.; Gross, S.; Wallaschofski, H.; Grabe, H. J.; Volzke, H.; Nauck, M.; Haring, R.
Abstract: objective association between androgen and depressive symptom were mostly reported from cross sectional and patient based study study design main outcome measure longitudinal data from 4 110 participant of the study of health in pomerania were used to a sex specific association of baseline total and free testosterone androstenedione and sex hormone binding globulin with incident depressive symptom and cognitive status at 5 and 10 year follow up result despite sex specific difference in depressive symptom prevalence at baseline woman 17 4 men 8 1 cross sectional analysis showed no association between sex hormone and depressive symptom in age adjusted longitudinal analysis total testosterone wa associated with incident depressive symptom relative risk at 5 year follow up 0 73 95 confidence interval 0 58 0 92 similarly age adjusted analysis showed a positive association between sex hormone binding globulin and cognitive status in men beta coefficient per standard deviation 0 44 95 confidence interval 0 13 0 74 in woman age adjusted association of androstenedione with baseline depressive symptom relative risk 0 88 95 confidence interval 0 77 0 99 were found none of the observed association remained after multivariable adjustment conclusion the present population based longitudinal study revealed inverse association between sex hormone and depressive symptom however the null finding after multivariable adjustment suggests that the observed association were not independent of relevant confounders including body mass index smoking and physical inactivity furthermore the low number of incident endpoint in our non clinical population based sample limited the statistical power and reduced the chance to detect a statistically significant effect

Title: Hyperactivity and impulsivity in adult attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder is related to glutamatergic dysfunction in the anterior cingulate cortex
Authors: Bauer, J.; Werner, A.; Kohl, W.; Kugel, H.; Shushakova, A.; Pedersen, A.; Ohrmann, P.
Abstract: objective attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd is closely linked to the dysregulation of dopaminergic and noradrenergic neurotransmission in the fronto striatal neural network including the anterior cingulate cortex acc and the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc additionally increasing evidence support the involvement of the glutamatergic system in the pathophysiology of adhd impulsivity a core symptom in patient with adhd ha been repeatedly associated with glutamatergic neurotransmission and pharmacological treatment of adhd ha been shown to reduce glutamate level in the prefrontal cortex method we investigated glutamate level in the acc and the dlpfc in 30 adult with adhd and 30 healthy control using single voxel proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy on a 3t scanner result the adhd group showed a significant increase in glutamate in the acc compared to control no significant difference in metabolite were observed in the dlpfc overall glutamate level in the acc were positively correlated with adhd symptomatology especially hyperactivity and impulsivity symptom conclusion increased level of glutamate in the acc which were positively correlated with hyperactivity and impulsivity support the hypothesis that dysfunctional glutamatergic neurotransmission is at least partially responsible for adhd symptomatology modulation of glutamatergic neurotransmission might therefore be a promising avenue for future pharmacological intervention

Title: The efficacy of a transdiagnostic emotion regulation skills training in the treatment of binge-eating disorder-Results from a randomized controlled trial
Authors: Berking, M.; Eichler, E.; Naumann, E.; Svaldi, J.
Abstract: objective deficit in emotion regulation er have been shown to be associated with binge eating disorder bed to further clarify the causal nature of this association we tested whether systematically enhancing er skill would reduce symptom of bed method we randomly allocated n 101 individual meeting the criterion for bed to a transdiagnostic er skill training or to a waitlist control condition wlc primary outcome wa the reduction in binge during the treatment v waiting period a assessed with the eating disorder examination ede interview result mixed model anova indicated that the average pre to post decrease in binge assessed with the ede wa significantly greater in the er skill training condition than in the wlc d 0 66 these effect were stable over the 6 month follow up period d 0 72 remission rate at post follow up were 34 4 45 0 in the skill training and 7 5 20 0 in the wlc additionally we found a greater reduction in general eating disorder psychopathology of food consumption in a bogus taste test and of depression in the er skill training condition moreover the greater reduction in binge eating episode in the training condition wa partially mediated by a greater increase in er skill conclusion the finding provide further support for the assumed importance of deficit in er a a maintaining factor and hence a a target in the treatment of bed a er skill training have been shown to also reduce other kind of psychopathology they might be considered a promising transdiagnostic add on component to disorder specific intervention

Title: Autistic traits and empathy in chronic vs. episodic depression
Authors: Domes, G.; Spenthof, I.; Radtke, M.; Isaksson, A.; Normann, C.; Heinrichs, M.
Abstract: objective difficulty in social interaction are characteristic for depressive disorder and one of the cardinal symptom of autism spectrum disorder asd it ha been proposed that chronically depressed person have profoundly impaired empathic ability in comparison to episodically depressed person and that specifically they exhibit a deficit in cognitive empathy but not in affective empathy a pattern also reported in asd this study aimed to explore autistic trait and empathy deficit in chronic depression and identify specific difference to episodic depression method autistic trait and multimodal empathy were assessed in chronically depressed patient n 59 episodically depressed patient n 40 and a healthy control group n 55 using standardized questionnaire result regardless of the disorder s chronicity depressed patient exhibited higher level of autistic trait and lower level of perspective taking than healthy control chronically depressed patient reported significantly higher impairment in social skill and higher level of personal distress in social interaction than episodic patient discussion our result suggest that patient with chronic depression share two distinct characteristic namely lower level of social skill and higher level of distress in tense social situation than patient with episodic depression future study will need to determine whether the elevated autistic trait in chronic depression are specific to chronic depression or represent the general tendency to withdraw from social situation we conclude that chronically depressed patient are not specifically impaired in understanding another person s state of mind but are unable to deal with another person s suffering or negative affective state

Title: Are psychotherapeutic effects on family caregivers of people with dementia sustainable? Two-year long-term effects of a telephone-based cognitive behavioral intervention
Authors: Wilz, G.; Meichsner, F.; Soellner, R.
Abstract: objective evaluation of long term effect of an individualized short term telephone intervention seven session based on a comprehensive cognitive behavioral therapy cbt approach the study goal wa to evaluate the maintenance of intervention effect regarding well being quality of life and health at two year post treatment method participant n 105 were partly randomized after baseline assessment in a two arm study intervention control group usual care depressive symptom were assessed with the german version of the center for epidemiologic study depression scale ce d caregiver physical complaint were measured with the giessener beschwerdebogen gbb 24 and quality of life with the world health organization quality of life bref whoqol bref emotional well being and perceived health status were assessed using thermometer scaling data were analyzed by intention to treat analysis including for those who terminated the intervention prematurely but still delivered data using ancovas result long term intervention effect were found for emotional well being p 0 019 for the subgroup of caregiver who were still caring at home at follow up the intervention led to an increased health status p 0 023 fewer bodily complaint global measure p 0 014 rheumatic pain p 0 027 heart trouble p 0 042 and a higher quality of life overall p 0 044 and subscale environment p 0 030 conclusion the short term cbt intervention via telephone showed long term effect two year after treatment on emotional well being health status bodily complaint and quality of life

Title: Neural correlates of performance monitoring in adult patients with Gilles de la Tourette syndrome: A study of event-related potentials
Authors: Warren, C.; Seer, C.; Lange, F.; Kopp, B.; Muller-Vahl, K.
Abstract: objective gilles de la tourette syndrome gts is a neuropsychiatric condition characterized by motor and vocal tic there is undoubtedly basal ganglion involvement which are also important for cognitive process including performance monitoring and interference resolution we investigated these function in adult patient with gts compared to healthy control hcs method we compared a group of n 23 adult patient with gts to n 27 hc on a flanker task during an eeg recording reaction time and error rate were recorded a well a n2 and n e ern amplitude the n2 is an index of interference resolution the n e ern is a negative fronto central component occurring when participant make mistake result patient reaction time were enhanced on incongruent trial compared to hc electrophysiological data revealed more frontal component a well a significantly increased n e ern amplitude in patient with gts compared to hc p 0 026 conclusion altered electrophysiological correlate of error processing in adult patient with gts compared to hc cannot be attributed to differential error probability potentially patient recruit compensatory resource from frontal network to maintain behavioural performance significance this study give further insight into cognitive deficit of patient with gts and the underlying neural process of these function

Title: Patient survey on Invisalign((R)) treatment comparing [corrected] the SmartTrack((R)) material to the previously used [corrected] aligner material
Authors: Brascher, A. K.; Zuran, D.; Feldmann, R. E., Jr.; Benrath, J.
Abstract: objective in 2013 a novel material smarttrack r wa introduced to replace the previous material used for invisalign r aligners we conducted this study to test how this transition wa accepted by patient during ongoing invisalign r treatment method we surveyed a total of 72 patient 68 woman 32 men mean age 29 3 9 2 year who had worn the new material for a mean of 6 month they completed a questionnaire with 25 item that compared both material in term of pain pressure upon insertion comfort mucosal irritation phonetics discoloration and taste result on a numerical rating scale nrs ranging from 0 to 10 the new aligner material wa rated by the respondent to cause significantly p 0 001 le maximum pain than the old material 2 8 v 3 8 significant reduction were obtained for duration of pain p 0 001 and duration of pressure 2 5 v 1 9 day p 0 001 upon insertion of the aligners over 90 of the respondent indicated le or equal pain during eating felt that the new material offered a tighter fit and provided more favorable rating for impairment durability and discoloration improved comfort wa reported by 50 of the respondent conclusion the new material wa favorably rated by the patient and showed significant reduction in pain intensity pain duration and pressure upon insertion important clinical parameter like overall comfort and impairment also were improved the clinical effectiveness of the new material remains to be investigated

Title: [Patienten mit komorbiden somatischen und psychischen Erkrankungen haben ahnliche Fahigkeitsbeeintrachtigen wie Patienten mit psychischen Erkrankungen]
Authors: Muschalla, B.; Jobges, M.
Abstract: objective in patient with somatic illness and additional mental disorder not only motor or sensory function may be impaired but also psychological capacity these become more and more important for work ability in our modern working world there are presently no data about the type and distribution of psychological capacity impairment in patient with comorbid somatic and mental disorder these data are however important for estimation of diagnostic and therapy requirement method 402 orthopedic cardiological and neurological patient with additional mental disorder were investigated with a structured clinical assessment for mental disorder mini and psychological capacity impairment mini icf app result in all three somatic indication at least half of the comorbid patient had any clinically relevant psychological capacity impairment neurological patient 67 and orthopedic patient 72 were more often affected than cardiological patient 50 5 orthopedic patient are slightly more impaired in self care neurological and orthopedic patient are more impaired in mobility and cardiological patient are le impaired in assertiveness conclusion in comparison of all three somatic patient group with mental disorder the number of psychological capacity impairment is similar in contrast to patient with mental disorder only i e those without somatic comorbidity the psychological impairment quality in comorbid patient may be influenced by the somatic illness the data from this study are important in order to estimate diagnostic and therapeutic need such a capacity training or compensation of psychological capacity impairment

Title: Empathy, compassion, and theory of mind in obsessive-compulsive disorder
Authors: Salazar Kampf, M.; Kanske, P.; Kleiman, A.; Haberkamp, A.; Glombiewski, J.; Exner, C.
Abstract: objective individual with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd often suffer from impairment in social functioning this study investigates difference in empathy compassion and theory of mind tom in individual with ocd a a possible cause for social functioning deficit design sixty four individual diagnosed with ocd and 62 healthy individual completed a naturalistic behavioural task empatom and a self report measure interpersonal reactivity index iri method three preregistered repeated measure analysis of variance anova result people with ocd exhibited higher empathy level namely increased sharing of others suffering in the empatom task and reported more distress iri compared with healthy individual furthermore no difference in compassion empatom between both group emerged although people with ocd reported more concern for others iri compared with healthy individual concerning the tom no group difference were detected neither in the behavioural task nor self report conclusion by investigating ocd with diverse scientific practice we shed light on the higher level of empathy exhibited by individual with ocd which are relevant for clinical practice and our understanding of ocd symptomatology practitioner point people with obsessive compulsive disorder show higher level of empathy that is the increased sharing of others suffering compared with healthy individual in both a traditional self report and a naturalistic task regarding compassion that is caring for others their self reported compassion wa higher in people with ocd in theory of mind that is cognitively understanding the situation of another person no difference have been found neither at self report nor in a naturalistic task compared with healthy individual independent of traditional intervention it could prove useful to improve emotion regulation skill so people with ocd learn to cope with empathic distress furthermore it might strengthen the treatment gain and lower dropout rate if the social mind and consequently social relationship become a topic in the treatment and prevention of ocd

Title: Plasma mid-regional pro-adrenomedullin levels are inversely associated with anxiety but unrelated to depression: Results from the observational DIAST-CHF study in patients with cardiovascular risk factors
Authors: Meyer, T.; Herrmann-Lingen, C.; Chavanon, M. L.; Pieske, B.; Wachter, R.; Edelmann, F.
Abstract: objective it ha been postulated that patient with heart failure have a high risk of ventricular arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death resulting from anxiety induced autonomic arousal in the prospective and multicenter diast chf diagnostic trial on prevalence and clinical course of diastolic dysfunction and heart failure study we therefore tested the hypothesis that adrenomedullin adm a well established predictor for cardiovascular outcome is associated with self rated anxiety symptom in patient at risk of suffering from or actually with overt heart failure participant and measure study participant with risk factor for diastolic dysfunction were requested to complete the hospital anxiety and depression scale hads and plasma mid regional pro adrenomedullin mr proadm concentration were measured result in bivariate analysis we found significantly lower plasma mr proadm level in patient with elevated hads anxiety score above the clinically relevant cut off level of 11 n 118 536pmol l interquartile range iqr 449 626 a compared to non anxious study participant n 1 292 573pmol l iqr 486 702 p 0 001 a set of multivariate model adjusted for potential confounders confirmed the negative association between self rated anxiety symptom and plasma mr proadm in similar model no significant association wa detected between hads depression score and mr proadm conclusion the inverse relationship between plasma mr proadm and anxiety observed in patient with cardiovascular risk factor support a previous experimental study using a mutant mouse line with a brain specific loss of adm expression which displayed hyperactive and over anxious behavior further experimental and clinical study are warranted to test the hypothesis that also in human adm act a a neuromodulator with anxiolytic property

Title: Identifying CBT non-response among OCD outpatients: A machine-learning approach
Authors: Hilbert, K.; Jacobi, T.; Kunas, S. L.; Elsner, B.; Reuter, B.; Lueken, U.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: objective machine learning model predicting treatment outcome for individual patient may yield high clinical utility however few study tested the utility of easy to acquire and low cost sociodemographic and clinical data in previous work we reported significant prediction still insufficient for immediate clinical use in a sample with broad diagnostic spectrum we here examined whether prediction will improve in a diagnostically more homogeneous yet large and naturalistic obsessive compulsive disorder ocd sample method we used sociodemographic and clinical data routinely acquired during cbt treatment of n 533 ocd subject in a specialized outpatient clinic result remission wa predicted with 65 p 0 001 balanced accuracy on unseen data for the best model higher ocd symptom severity predicted non remission while higher age of onset of first ocd symptom and higher socioeconomic status predicted remission for dimensional change prediction achieved r 0 31 p 0 001 between predicted and actual value conclusion the comparison with our previous work suggests that prediction within a diagnostically homogeneous sample here ocd are not per se superior to a more diverse sample including several diagnostic group using refined psychological predictor associated with disorder etiology and maintenance or adding further data modality a neuroimaging or ecological momentary assessment are promising in order to further increase prediction accuracy

Title: Circulating inflammatory markers, cell-free mitochondrial DNA, cortisol, endocannabinoids, and N-acylethanolamines in female depressed outpatients
Authors: Behnke, A.; Gumpp, A. M.; Rojas, R.; Sanger, T.; Lutz-Bonengel, S.; Moser, D.; Schelling, G.; Krumbholz, A.; Kolassa, I. T.
Abstract: objective major depressive disorder mdd involves peripheral low grade pro inflammatory activity this multi biomarker case control study characterises the proinflammatory status in mdd beyond c reactive protein crp and interleukin il 6 level through investigating concomitant alteration of immunoregulatory biomolecules method in 20 female mdd patient and 24 non depressed woman circulating level of crp il 6 cortisol selected endocannabinoids ec anandamide aea 2 arachidonylglycerol 2 ag and n acylethanolamines naes a well a circulating cell free mitochondrial dna ccf mtdna were measured result we found higher serum crp and plasma aea level in mdd and a positive association of crp and aea level with current depressive symptom blood level of cortisol ccf mtdna 2 ag and naes did depend on mdd diagnosis nor correlated with the severity of current depressive symptom crp correlated positively with aea and aea showed positive association with 2 ag and nae level conclusion in this study female mdd outpatient with mild to moderate disorder severity did not substantially differ from non depressed control in the resting level of multiple immunoregulatory marker in peripheral blood instead of investigating resting level future research on the role of inflammatory activity in mdd should focus on investigating the reactivity of pathway modulating the immune system upon exposure to physical and psychosocial stressor

Title: Serum androgen concentrations and subclinical measures of cardiovascular disease in men and women
Authors: Kische, H.; Gross, S.; Wallaschofski, H.; Volzke, H.; Dorr, M.; Nauck, M.; Felix, S. B.; Haring, R.
Abstract: objective most of the observed association of androgen and sex hormone binding globulin shbg with subclinical cardiovascular disease cvd stem from selected study sample with immunoassay based hormone measurement thus we used a large population based sample with total testosterone tt and androstenedione asd concentration measured by liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry design data of 2140 individual mean age 60 8 year from the cohort study of health in pomerania were assessed at baseline and 5 year follow up method multivariable regression model were implemented to a cross sectional and longitudinal association of tt free testosterone ft asd shbg and dehydroepiandrosterone sulphate dheas with measure of subclinical cvd including intima medium thickness imt carotid plaque left ventricular mass lvm fractional shortening f relative wall thickness rwt and left ventricular geometry result cross sectional analysis yielded an association of tt with imt in woman beta coefficient per log unit increase 0 02 95 ci 0 007 0 45 and asd with f in both sex men beta coefficient 2 94 95 ci 4 75 1 12 woman beta coefficient 1 64 95 ci 0 55 2 73 in longitudinal analysis dheas wa positively associated with f change beta coefficient 2 34 95 ci 0 59 4 08 in woman shbg wa positively associated with incident plaque q1 v q3 ref beta coefficient 1 35 95 ci 1 04 1 74 in both sex longitudinal analysis showed no consistent association of tt with subclinical cvd conclusion despite several sex specific association of androgen and shbg with subclinical cvd the present representative study for the age group 45 year among men and woman from the general population detected no consistent association in longitudinal analysis

Title: Associations of saliva cortisol and hair cortisol with generalized anxiety, social anxiety, and major depressive disorder: An epidemiological cohort study in adolescents and young adults
Authors: Kische, H.; Ollmann, T. M.; Voss, C.; Hoyer, J.; Ruckert, F.; Pieper, L.; Kirschbaum, C.; Beesdo-Baum, K.
Abstract: objective most of the observed association of generalized anxiety disorder gad social anxiety disorder sad and major depressive disorder mdd with cortisol concentration came from clinical and adult study sample with inconsistent finding partly due to method variance we examined cross sectional and longitudinal association between gad sad and mdd with saliva and hair cortisol a well a hair cortisol change in a population based sample of adolescent and young adult considering relevant co factor design epidemiological cohort study in dresden germany data of 1050 individual mean age 17 2 year assessed at baseline 11 2015 12 2016 and of 605 individual assessed at 1 year follow up fu1 are used method multivariable regression model were implemented to a cross sectional and longitudinal association of dsm 5 defined 12 month diagnosis of gad sad and mdd with short term saliva cortisol cortisol awakening response car and area under the curve auc a total cortisol and long term hair cortisol cortisol index multivariable model were adjusted for age or tanner stage waist circumference tobacco and alcohol consumption physical inactivity and hair cortisol dependent confounder sex specific analysis were additionally conducted result cross sectional analysis revealed positive association between sad and baseline saliva cortisol in multivariable model car beta coefficient 0 12 95 ci 0 01 0 23 but could not be confirmed after adjusting for tanner stage or comorbid depression cross sectional analysis concerning gad and mdd in the full baseline sample yielded no significant association sex specific linear model revealed a significant inverse cross sectional association between mdd beta coefficient 2 21 95 ci 3 64 0 79 a well a sad beta coefficient 2 21 95 ci 4 03 0 38 with baseline hair cortisol in male but not in female in longitudinal analysis no significant association were found in the fully adjusted model except for a positive association between hair cortisol change between baseline and fu1 and fu1 sad or 1 07 95 ci 1 02 1 12 conclusion result confirmed sex specificity and the role of pubertal development in the association between cortisol with sad and mdd while no association emerged regarding cortisol and gad future research in adolescent focusing on the role of cortisol in the pathogenesis of anxiety and depressive disorder would benefit from considering factor like sex specificity and puberty development a well a comorbidity

Title: Reduced pleasant touch appraisal in the presence of a disgusting odor
Authors: Croy, I.; Angelo, S. D.; Olausson, H.
Abstract: objective odor are powerful emotional stimulus influencing mood attention and behavior here we examined if odor change the perception of pleasant touch in line with the warning function of the olfactory system we proposed that especially unpleasant odor will reduce touch pleasantness presumably through a disgust related mechanism method forty five healthy participant mean age 23 3 3years sd 24 female were presented to slow 3 cm s and fast 30 cm s brush stroking delivered by a robot to the forearm touch pleasantness under the influence of an unpleasant odor civette smelling like feces and an intensity matched pleasant odor rose wa compared to an odorless control condition in a pilot study with 30 participant mean age 25 9 6 year 21 female the odor were matched according to their intensity and we studied the influence of disgust sensitivity on the perception of 4 different odor quality result the unpleasant odor decreased touch pleasantness for both stroking velocity compared to the odorless control p 0 005 whereas the rose odor did not change touch pleasantness significantly disgust sensitivity wa correlated with the modulation of touch pleasantness the pilot study revealed a significant correlation between disgust sensitivity and the perception of the unpleasant odor quality r 0 56 p 0 007 but not with any of the other odor conclusion unpleasant odor are powerful in modulating touch pleasantness and disgust might be a moderating variable

Title: Bidirectional relationship of stress and affect with physical activity and healthy eating
Authors: Schultchen, D.; Reichenberger, J.; Mittl, T.; Weh, T. R. M.; Smyth, J. M.; Blechert, J.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: objective physical activity and healthy eating seem to be protective against experiencing stress and negative affect a well a increase positive affect at the same time previous study showed that people reduce salutogenic behaviour such a physical activity and healthy eating in the face of stress and negative affect while increasing such behaviour in the context of positive affect due to daily fluctuation of these behaviour the present study examined these relationship in daily life using ecological momentary assessment ema design and method fifty one university student responded to six daily prompt during 7 day via smartphone based ema item examined stress emotional experience physical activity duration and healthy eating result higher stress and negative affect a well a lower positive affect were related to a reduction in subsequent physical activity higher physical activity level in turn were associated with le subsequent stress and negative affect a well a more positive affect no such effect for stress and affect on healthy eating or vice versa were found conclusion engaging in physical activity is related to better mood and le stress negative affect over the next several hour in daily life prevention effort therefore may benefit by focusing on promoting physical activity particularly when stress negative affect is high to break the cycle of inactivity stress and negative affect potential effect of healthy eating might be more subtle and characterized by interindividual difference or state effect statement of contribution what is already known on this subject physical activity can reduce stress a well a negative emotion and can enhance positive emotion people tend to eat le healthy food during stressful time and healthy eating can increase general health physical activity and healthy eating have been mostly assessed separately and through retrospective method what doe this study add this is an ema study investigating bidirectional effect of stress emotion and salutogenic behaviour after physical activity people felt le stressed negative and more positive feeling better and le stressed resulted in more physical activity healthy eating wa not associated with stress or emotion level and vice versa

Title: Testing Bayesian models of belief updating in the context of depressive symptomatology
Authors: Feldmann, M.; Kube, T.; Rief, W.; Brakemeier, E. L.
Abstract: objective predictive processing approach to belief updating in depression propose that depression is related to more negative and more precise prior also belief updating is assumed be negatively biased in comparison to normative bayesian updating there is a lack of efficient method to mathematically model belief updating in depression method we validated a novel performance belief updating paradigm in a nonclinical sample n 133 participant repeatedly participated in a non self related emotion recognition task and received false feedback effect of the feedback manipulation and difference in depressive symptom on belief updating were analysed in bayesian multilevel analysis result belief were successfully manipulated through the feedback provided depressive symptom were associated with more negative updating than normative bayesian updating but result were influenced by few case no evidence of biased change in belief or overly precise prior wa found depressive symptom were associated with more negative updating of generalised performance belief conclusion there wa cautious support for negatively biased belief updating associated with depressive symptom especially for generalised belief the content of the task may not be self relevant enough to cause strong bias further explication of bayesian model of depression and replication in clinical sample is needed

Title: Effects of psychosocial stress and performance feedback on pain processing and its correlation with subjective and neuroendocrine parameters
Authors: Schneider, S. K.; Pauli, P.; Lautenbacher, S.; Reicherts, P.
Abstract: objective previous research on stress induced pain modulation suggests that moderate psychological stress usually lead to hyperalgesia while more severe threat result in hypoalgesia however existing study often lack suitable control condition imperative to identify mere stress effect similarly research mainly focused on pure anticipation of a social threat not taking into consideration actual experience of social evaluation therefore we set out to investigate actual social up and downgrading combined with a standardized stress paradigm to evaluate short term and prolonged change in pain perception and their potential association with neuroendocrine and subjective stress parameter method we allocated 177 healthy woman to four experimental condition either the standard version of the trier social stress test tsst followed by positive negative or no performance feedback or a well matched but le demanding placebo version of the tsst stress response were assessed with rating salivary alpha amylase and salivary cortisol to capture putative effect of stress on pain heat pain threshold rating of phasic heat pain stimulus and conditioned pain modulation were measured result despite a largely successful stress induction result do not support a reliable influence of experimentally induced social stress with or without subsequent performance feedback on pain in woman further we found no clear association of pain modulation and change in neuroendocrine or subjective stress response conclusion our result contrast previous study which repeatedly demonstrated stress induced hypo or hyperalgesia this might be due to methodological reason a former research wa often characterized by high heterogeneity regarding the applied stressor low sample size and lacking or inconclusive control condition thus our result raise the question whether pain modulation in woman by experimental psychosocial stress might have been overestimated in the past future research is necessary which should employ parametric stress induction method including well matched control task taking into consideration the participant gender sex and the time course of the stress response relative to pain assessment the study is registered a drks00026946 at deutsches register klinischer studien drks and can be also found at the world health organization s search portal

Title: Reduced embodied simulation in psychopathy
Authors: Mier, D.; Haddad, L.; Diers, K.; Dressing, H.; Meyer-Lindenberg, A.; Kirsch, P.
Abstract: objective psychopathy is characterized by severe deficit in emotion processing and empathy these emotional deficit might not only affect the feeling of own emotion but also the understanding of others emotional and mental state the present study aim on identifying the neurobiological correlate of social cognitive related alteration in psychopathy method we applied a social cognitive paradigm for the investigation of face processing emotion recognition and affective theory of mind tom to 11 imprisoned psychopath and 18 healthy control functional magnetic resonance imaging wa used to measure task related brain activation result while showing no overall behavioural deficit psychopathy wa associated with altered brain activation psychopath had reduced fusiform activation related to face processing related to affective tom psychopath had hypoactivation in amygdala inferior prefrontal gyrus and superior temporal sulcus area associated with embodied simulation of emotion and intention furthermore psychopath lacked connectivity between superior temporal sulcus and amygdala during affective tom conclusion these result replicate finding of alteration in basal face processing in psychopathy in addition they provide evidence for reduced embodied simulation in psychopathy in concert with a lack of communication between motor area and amygdala which might provide the neural substrate of reduced feeling with others during social cognition

Title: Deceptive and Nondeceptive Placebos to Reduce Pain: An Experimental Study in Healthy Individuals
Authors: Kube, T.; Rief, W.; Vivell, M. B.; Schafer, N. L.; Vermillion, T.; Korfer, K.; Glombiewski, J. A.
