Abstract: objective recent research ha shown that placebo can be effective even if they are openly prescribed to participant yet it is unclear how such open label placebo olps compare to deceptive placebo dp and what the mechanism of action are in this study we therefore compared 2 version of olp to dp and no treatment nt material and method using a standard heat pain paradigm 117 healthy volunteer underwent a baseline and a posttreatment pain assessment with the exception of nt all group received an inert placebo cream after the first assessment olp wa administered by either evoking positive expectancy or by raising hope for placebo analgesia thus distinguishing for the first time conceptually between expectancy and hope in experimental pain research the primary outcome wa pre post change in pain tolerance result increase in pain tolerance wa larger in the 3 treatment group compared with nt whereas the treatment group did not differ from each other further result showed that participant receiving dp reported a large reduction of subjective pain intensity and unpleasantness whereas no such reduction wa found for the 2 olp group the 2 olp version did not differ in term of their analgesic effect discussion the study provided evidence for traditional placebo analgesia on the basis of deception for olp we found that olp indeed increased pain tolerance however participant receiving olp were reluctant to report any subjective analgesic effect combined with previous study the present finding suggest that the effect of olp are weaker in healthy volunteer than in clinical sample

Title: Catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) genotype affects age-related changes in plasticity in working memory: a pilot study
Authors: Heinzel, S.; Riemer, T. G.; Schulte, S.; Onken, J.; Heinz, A.; Rapp, M. A.
Abstract: objective recent work suggests that a genetic variation associated with increased dopamine metabolism in the prefrontal cortex catechol o methyltransferase val158met comt amplifies age related change in working memory performance research on younger adult indicates that the influence of dopamine related genetic polymorphism on working memory performance increase when testing the cognitive limit through training to date this ha not been studied in older adult method here we investigate the effect of comt genotype on plasticity in working memory in a sample of 14 younger aged 24 30 year and 25 older aged 60 75 year healthy adult participant underwent adaptive training in the n back working memory task over 12 session under increasing difficulty condition result both younger and older adult exhibited sizeable behavioral plasticity through training p 001 which wa larger in younger a compared to older adult p 001 age related difference were qualified by an interaction with comt genotype p 001 and this interaction wa due to decreased behavioral plasticity in older adult carrying the val val genotype while there wa no effect of genotype in younger adult discussion our finding indicate that age related change in plasticity in working memory are critically affected by genetic variation in prefrontal dopamine metabolism

Title: Neural response during anticipation of monetary loss is elevated in adult attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
Authors: Wilbertz, G.; Delgado, M. R.; Tebartz Van Elst, L.; Maier, S.; Philipsen, A.; Blechert, J.
Abstract: objective risky behaviour seriously impact the life of adult patient with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd such behaviour have often been attributed to their exaggerated reward seeking but dysfunctional anticipation of negative outcome might also play a role method the present study compared adult patient with adhd n 28 with matched healthy control n 28 during anticipation of monetary loss versus gain while undergoing functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri and skin conductance recording result skin conductance wa higher during anticipation of loss compared to gain in both group affective rating of predictive cue did not differ between group adhd patient showed increased activity in bilateral amygdala left anterior insula region of interest analysis and left temporal pole whole brain analysis compared to healthy control during loss versus gain anticipation in the adhd group higher insula and temporal pole activation went along with more negative affective rating conclusion neural correlate of loss anticipation are not blunted but rather increased in adhd possibly due to a life history of repeated failure and the respective environmental sanction behavioural adaptation to such loss however might differentiate them from control future research should study whether negative affect might drive more risk seeking than risk avoidance

Title: Predictors of outcome of an Internet-based cognitive-behavioural therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in older adults
Authors: Bottche, M.; Kuwert, P.; Pietrzak, R. H.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: objective the aim of this study wa to evaluate the role of resource oriented variable such a self efficacy locus of control loc and post traumatic growth ptg in predicting treatment response in older adult with post traumatic stress method fifty eight older adult with subsyndromal or greater severity of war associated post traumatic stress disorder ptsd symptom completed a randomized controlled internet based cognitive behavioural therapy cbt with immediate and delayed treatment group assessment of ptsd severity and resource oriented variable of self efficacy loc and ptg were conducted at baseline post treatment and at a 6 month follow up result result revealed that pre treatment score on measure of internal loc and ptg predicted ptsd symptom severity at post treatment even after controlling for initial ptsd at a 6 month follow up internal loc continued to predict ptsd symptom severity in addition repeated measure analysis of variance revealed that relative to older adult with low internal loc and ptg older adult with high internal loc and ptg respectively did not differ with respect to initial ptsd severity but they showed a more pronounced response to treatment conclusion these finding suggest that greater locus of control and post traumatic growth is associated with greater improvement in ptsd symptom following internet based cbt assessment of these construct may be useful in identifying trauma survivor who are most likely to respond to cbt practitioner point greater internal locus of control and post traumatic growth is associated with greater improvement in ptsd symptom following internet based cbt older adult with initial high internal locus of control and post traumatic growth respectively did not differ with respect to initial ptsd severity but they showed a more pronounced response to treatment it could be assumed that patient with initial functional appraisal could benefit easier and faster from a trauma focused cognitive behavioural therapy compared to individual with lower internal locus of control and post traumatic growth

Title: Ascending Aortic Disease is Associated with Earlier Menopause and Shorter Reproductive Life Span
Authors: Schuster, V.; Eggersmann, T. K.; Eifert, S.; Ueberfuhr, P.; Zugenmaier, B.; Kolben, T. M.; Thaler, C. J.; Kublickiene, K.; Rieger, A.; Reichart, B.; Hagl, C.; Pichlmaier, M. A.; Guethoff, S.
Abstract: objective the incidence of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in premenopausal woman is comparatively low but increase sharply after menopause the principal aim of this study wa to determine whether woman with ascending aortic disease aad have a different reproductive history from that of an age matched control group method in this retrospective study woman who had undergone ascending aortic aneurysm ascaa repair between 2000 and 2010 were asked to complete a questionnaire concerning risk factor and reproductive history data from 142 woman with aad were evaluated and a subgroup n 64 with ascaa 5 cm wa analyzed and compared to an age matched random control group without known aortic disease result almost all woman were menopausal at the time of the questionnaire 98 4 v 90 6 ascaa 5 cm subcohort v control p 0 12 and all subject presented with a comparable age of menarche 13 7 2 6 year v 14 2 1 8 year ascaa 5 cm subcohort v control log rank 0 04 p 0 84 however mean menopausal age wa significantly lower in the case subcohort than in control 48 1 4 8 year v 50 6 5 8 year ascaa 5 cm subcohort v control log rank 8 35 p 0 004 and reproductive life span wa correspondingly shorter 34 2 5 2 year v 36 2 5 7 year p 0 04 furthermore hypertension wa more prevalent in woman with ascaa 5 cm compared to control 89 1 v 61 9 ascaa 5 cm subcohort v control p 0 001 conclusion woman who experience menopause at an earlier age than the regional mean could profit from screening for cardiovascular disease in general and particularly for aad screening would enable early aneurysm detection and could therefore reduce morbidity and mortality

Title: Pragmatic Effectiveness of Face-to-Face Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for Family Caregivers of People with Dementia
Authors: Topfer, N. F.; Wrede, N.; Wilz, G.
Abstract: objective the objective wa to investigate the pragmatic effectiveness of face to face cognitive behavioral therapy f2f cbt for family caregiver of people with dementia pwd implemented in a routine care setting relative to usual care in a quasi experimental study method participant indicating that attendance of f2f cbt wa possible were assigned to f2f cbt n 49 f2f cbt consisted of 12 session over 6 month effect were evaluated at posttest and 6 month follow up on a variety of outcome relative to usual care cg n 134 result at posttest f2f cbt yielded significantly fewer symptom of depression d 0 37 better emotional well being d 0 64 and better coping with the care situation d 0 52 than cg at 6 month follow up the effect on emotional well being wa retained d 0 44 and social relationship were rated significantly better in f2f cbt than cg d 0 34 conclusion f2f cbt proved to be effective in supporting family caregiver of pwd however only relatively few caregiver were able to regularly attend face to face session clinical implication cbt seems particularly suitable for supporting family caregiver of pwd in coping with the complex psychological burden delivery via telephone or internet could be a necessary alternative to f2f cbt for reducing barrier to participation

Title: "Food Addiction" in Patients with Eating Disorders is Associated with Negative Urgency and Difficulties to Focus on Long-Term Goals
Authors: Wolz, I.; Hilker, I.; Granero, R.; Jimenez-Murcia, S.; Gearhardt, A. N.; Dieguez, C.; Casanueva, F. F.; Crujeiras, A. B.; Menchon, J. M.; Fernandez-Aranda, F.
Abstract: objective the present study aimed to investigate if eating disorder patient differ in specific personality trait depending on a positive screening of food addiction fa and to find a model to predict fa in eating disorder patient using measure of personality and impulsivity method two hundred seventy eight patient having an eating disorder self reported on fa impulsivity personality eating and general psychopathology patient were then split into two group depending on a positive or negative result on the fa screening analysis of variance wa used to compare mean between the two group stepwise binary logistic regression wa used to obtain a predictive model for the presence of fa result patient with fa had lower self directedness and more negative urgency and lack of perseverance than patient not reporting addictive eating the probability of fa can be predicted by high negative urgency high reward dependence and low lack of premeditation conclusion eating disorder patient who have more problem to pursue task to the end and to focus on long term goal seem to be more likely to develop addictive eating pattern

Title: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) as a Standalone Intervention for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder after Mixed Traumatic Events: A Mixed-Methods Feasibility Study
Authors: Muller-Engelmann, M.; Wunsch, S.; Volk, M.; Steil, R.
Abstract: objective there is promising evidence that mindfulness based intervention are effective in reducing the symptom of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd however until now study have often lacked a full clinical ptsd assessment and intervention are often administered in addition to other intervention this study examined the feasibility of mindfulness based stress reduction mbsr a a standalone intervention in patient with ptsd who have experienced mixed traumatic event method fourteen patient participated in 8 week of mbsr the patient were assessed prior to treatment post treatment and at a 1 month follow up through self rating e g the davidson trauma scale and the clinician administered ptsd scale to determine the effect of the intervention furthermore after the intervention the patient participated in qualitative interview regarding their experience with mbsr and their idea for future improvement result nine patient finished the program and these patient considered the exercise to be applicable and helpful in the clinician administered ptsd scale we found large effect regarding the reduction of ptsd symptom among completers cohen s d 1 2 in the davidson trauma scale the effect size were somewhat lower cohen s d 0 6 but nevertheless confirmed the efficacy of mbsr in reducing ptsd symptom in the qualitative interview the patient reported an augmentation of wellbeing and improvement regarding the handling of difficult situation and more distance from the traumatic event conclusion despite the large effect the high dropout rate and the result of the post treatment interview suggest that the intervention should be better adapted to the need of ptsd patient e g by giving more information regarding the exercise and by including shorter exercise to manage acute distress

Title: Sleep disturbances and mental strain in university students: results from an online survey in Luxembourg and Germany
Authors: Schlarb, A. A.; Classen, M.; Grunwald, J.; Vogele, C.
Abstract: objective this study examined the prevalence of sleep disturbance and mental strain in student from two european country luxembourg and germany method a total of 2831 student took part in an online survey with 2777 student from germany and 184 student from luxembourg sleep disturbance were assessed with the pittsburgh sleep quality index and the epworth sleepiness scale and aspect of mental strain using the patient health questionnaire the social interactive anxiety scale the self efficacy questionnaire and the test anxiety questionnaire in addition we also assessed student chronotypes result across the whole sample mean score on the sleep questionnaire were above the cut off for clinically relevant sleep problem indicating an increased prevalence of sleep disturbance in student from both country sleep quality wa impaired in 42 8 and 17 9 showed clinically relevant score overall 25 5 reported elevated depression and 13 3 social phobia symptom while 45 indicated elevated stress level sleep quality daytime sleepiness chronotype depression score stress level test anxiety and self efficacy differed significantly between men and woman but there were no difference between country conclusion sleep disturbance and mental strain in student are common with the current result replicating previous finding student from luxembourg and germany are affected equally

Title: ACTonDiabetes-a guided psychological internet intervention based on Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) for adults living with type 1 or 2 diabetes: results of a randomised controlled feasibility trial
Authors: Bendig, E.; Bauereiss, N.; Schmitt, A.; Albus, P.; Baumeister, H.
Abstract: objective this two group randomised controlled trial evaluates the feasibility of an acceptance and commitment therapy act based internet intervention for diabetes distress in people with diabetes type 1 or type 2 participant were assigned to a guided self help intervention eg or waitlist control group cg setting recruitment took place following an open recruitment strategy including different diabetes centre self help group and social medium platform participant eligibility criterion comprised being 18 year of age or older self reported diagnosis of type 1 or type 2 diabetes internet access sufficient german language skill and written informed consent intervention actondiabetes is an internet based and mobile based intervention and comprises an introduction and seven module one module per week processing time about 45 60 min intervention content are based on act primary and secondary outcome measure participant were assessed before and 8 week after randomisation primary outcome wa feasibility trial recruitment acceptability potential group difference in diabetes distress and other outcome at follow up were analysed using linear regression model with baseline value a predictor all analysis were based on an intention to treat principle potential negative effect were analysed on per protocol basis result from october 2017 to april 2018 n 42 people with diabetes consented and were randomised eg n 21 cg n 21 forty three per cent of the eg completed all treatment module within 8 week across module formative user feedback revealed that content could be optimised regarding comprehensibility 34 individualisation 20 and text amount 21 overall 57 of participant dropped out prior to full treatment completion there were reduction of diabetes distress in the eg d 0 65 p 0 042 conclusion modification of the intervention content according to the user feedback will be performed to further improve acceptability mechanism to foster intervention adherence should be considered for lowering the attrition rate actondiabetes is feasible for the implementation in a confirmatory trial trial registration number who international clinical trial registry platform via the german clinical trial register drks drks00013193

Title: Internet-Delivered Cognitive-Behavior Therapy for Tinnitus: A Randomized Controlled Trial
Authors: Weise, C.; Kleinstauber, M.; Andersson, G.
Abstract: objective tinnitus ha a substantially negative impact on quality of life in up to 5 of the general population internet based cognitive behavioral treatment icbt ha been shown to be effective in a few trial the aim of our study wa to investigate icbt for tinnitus by using a randomized controlled trial method patient with severe tinnitus related distress were randomly assigned to therapist guided icbt n 62 or to a moderated online discussion forum n 62 standardized self report measure for tinnitus related distress tinnitus handicap inventory mini tinnitus questionnaire and associated symptom tinnitus acceptance anxiety depression and insomnia were assessed at pretreatment and posttreatment 6 month and 1 year follow up clinical significance wa assessed with the reliable change index result multivariate analysis of variance revealed significant main effect for time group and interaction in favor of the icbt group with regard to tinnitus related distress the significant univariate interaction effect time by group were supported by large effect size tinnitus handicap inventory g 0 83 95 confidence interval 0 47 1 20 mini tinnitus questionnaire g 1 08 95 confidence interval 0 71 1 64 for the secondary outcome significant interaction with small to medium effect size were found within group effect for the icbt from pretreatment to follow up were substantial in regard to tinnitus related distress 1 38 d 1 81 and small to large for secondary outcome 0 39 d 1 04 conclusion using a randomized controlled trial design we replicated prior finding regarding positive effect of internet delivered cbt on tinnitus related distress and associated symptom implementing icbt for tinnitus into regular health care will be an important next step to increase access to treatment for patient with tinnitus trial registration clinicaltrials gov identifier nct01205919

Title: Rome III criteria in parents' hands: pain-related functional gastrointestinal disorders in community children and associations with somatic complaints and mental health
Authors: Gulewitsch, M. D.; Enck, P.; Schwille-Kiuntke, J.; Weimer, K.; Schlarb, A. A.
Abstract: objective to determine a the prevalence of rome iii abdominal pain related functional gastrointestinal disorder in a western community sample of child b their association with sociodemographic factor and c whether child fulfilling rome iii abdominal pain diagnosis show higher rate of psychological distress and somatization method data were collected from parent of 6 10 year old child who were recruited from 22 public grammar school in germany a total of 1537 questionnaire were included in the analysis abdominal pain related functional gastrointestinal disorder were diagnosed on the basis of questionnaire response by rome iii criterion further somatic complaint a well a emotional and behavioral problem were assessed result in total 7 7 of child aged 6 10 year fulfilled the criterion for at least one rome iii abdominal pain related functional gastrointestinal disorder according to their parent the most prevalent diagnosis were irritable bowel syndrome 4 9 and functional abdominal pain 2 0 assigned diagnosis were not associated with sociodemographic factor we could confirm that abdominal pain related functional disorder especially irritable bowel syndrome were strongly associated with somatization and emotional problem in community conclusion rome iii abdominal pain related functional gastrointestinal disorder are a common health problem in child and are even in community strongly associated with other somatic complaint and psychological distress

Title: Effects of train noise and vibration on human heart rate during sleep: an experimental study
Authors: Croy, I.; Smith, M. G.; Waye, K. P.
Abstract: objective transportation of good on railway is increasing and the majority of the increased number of freight train run during the night transportation noise ha adverse effect on sleep structure affect the heart rate hr during sleep and may be linked to cardiovascular disease freight train also generate vibration and little is known regarding the impact of vibration on human sleep a laboratory study wa conducted to examine how a realistic nocturnal railway traffic scenario influence hr during sleep design case control setting healthy participant participant 24 healthy volunteer 11 men 13 woman 19 28 year spent six consecutive night in the sleep laboratory intervention all participant slept during one habituation night one control and four experimental night in which train noise and vibration were reproduced in the experimental night 20 or 36 train with low vibration or high vibration characteristic were presented primary and secondary outcome measure polysomnographical data and ecg were recorded result the train exposure led to a significant change of hr within 1 min of exposure onset p 0 002 characterised by an initial and a delayed increase of hr the high vibration condition provoked an average increase of at least 3 bpm per train in 79 of the participant cardiac response were in general higher in the high vibration condition than in the low vibration condition p 0 006 no significant effect of noise sensitivity and gender wa revealed although there wa a tendency for men to exhibit stronger hr acceleration than woman conclusion freight train provoke hr acceleration during sleep and the vibration characteristic of the train are of special importance in the long term this may affect cardiovascular functioning of person living close to railway

Title: Reduced activity and connectivity of left amygdala in patients with schizophrenia treated with clozapine or olanzapine
Authors: Mier, D.; Schirmbeck, F.; Stoessel, G.; Esslinger, C.; Rausch, F.; Englisch, S.; Eisenacher, S.; de Haan, L.; Meyer-Lindenberg, A.; Kirsch, P.; Zink, M.
Abstract: obsessive compulsive symptom ocs in patient with schizophrenia are a common co occurring condition often associated with additional impairment a subgroup of these patient develops ocs during treatment with second generation antipsychotic sgas most importantly clozapine and olanzapine so far little is known about possible neural mechanism of these sgas which seem to aggravate or induce ocs to investigate the role of sga treatment on neural activation and connectivity during emotional processing patient were stratified according to their monotherapy into two group group i clozapine or olanzapine n 20 group ii amisulpride or aripiprazole n 20 we used an fmri approach applying an implicit emotion recognition task group comparison showed significantly higher frequency and severity of comorbid ocs in group i than group ii task specific activation wa attenuated in group i in the left amygdala furthermore functional connectivity from left amygdala to right ventral striatum wa reduced in group i reduced amygdala activation wa associated with ocs severity recent literature suggests an involvement of an amygdala cortico striatal network in the pathogenesis of obsessive compulsive disorder the observed differential activation and connectivity pattern of the amygdala might thus indicate a neural mechanism for the development of sga associated ocs in patient with schizophrenia further neurobiological research and interventional study are needed for causal inference

Title: Offenders with antisocial personality disorder show attentional bias for violence-related stimuli
Authors: Domes, G.; Mense, J.; Vohs, K.; Habermeyer, E.
Abstract: offender with antisocial personality disorder aspd may be characterized by a lack in emotional functioning that manifest in irritability and a lack of remorse the proposed link between aspd and negative emotionality led to the question of emotional processing anomaly in aspd furthermore the effect of childhood maltreatment abuse on emotional processing wa tested in the present study violent and sexual offender with aspd n 35 without aspd n 34 and healthy non criminal control n 24 were compared in an emotional stroop task est using neutral negative and violence related word secondary analysis focused on the effect of psychopathic trait and childhood maltreatment offender with aspd showed a stronger attentional bias to violence related and negative word a compared to control comparable result were obtained when grouping offender to high medium and low psychopathic subgroup offender with childhood maltreatment specifically showed stronger violence related attentional bias than non maltreated offender the data suggest that enhanced attention to violence related stimulus in adult criminal offender is associated with adverse developmental experience and delinquency but to a lesser extent with antisocial or psychopathic trait

Title: Sexual desire after olfactory loss: Quantitative and qualitative reports of patients with smell disorders
Authors: Schafer, L.; Mehler, L.; Hahner, A.; Walliczek, U.; Hummel, T.; Croy, I.
Abstract: olfaction moderate human sexual experience and smell disorder patient sometimes spontaneously complain about impairment in their sexual life the aim of the present study wa to systematically investigate the impact of olfactory dysfunction on sexual desire we compared a sample of n 100 n 52 woman aged 23 51 year m 40 1 sd 8 2 outpatient with olfactory disorder to a sample of n 51 healthy control n 32 woman aged 21 63 year m 39 2 sd 13 1 sexual desire wa assessed with a standardized questionnaire and with two additional item asking for quantitative and qualitative change of sexual desire since the onset of olfactory loss in addition subject completed questionnaire about mood and partnership attachment within the patient group 29 of the subject reported decreased sexual desire since the onset of olfactory loss this change wa predicted by depressive symptom and olfactory function qualitative report revealed for instance that the lack of attraction due to the other s body odor impedes partnership intimacy the change of sexual desire wa significantly related to depression and severity of olfactory impairment but not to partnership attachment however in the standardized questionnaire about sexual desire we observed no difference between patient and control to sum up a considerable number of patient state sexual impairment a a concomitant complaint of olfactory dysfunction patient do typically not spontaneously report those intimate problem routine care setting should inform about this common side effect and explicitly ask for sexual life

Title: Men without a sense of smell exhibit a strongly reduced number of sexual relationships, women exhibit reduced partnership security - a reanalysis of previously published data
Authors: Croy, I.; Bojanowski, V.; Hummel, T.
Abstract: olfactory function influence social behavior for instance olfaction seems to play a key role in mate choice and help detecting emotion in other people in a previous study we showed that people who were born without a sense of smell exhibit enhanced social insecurity based on the comment to this article we decided to have a closer look to whether the absence of the sense of smell affect men and woman differently under this focus questionnaire data of 32 patient diagnosed with isolated congenital anosmia 10 men 22 woman and 36 age matched healthy control 15 men 21 woman wa reanalyzed in result men and woman without a sense of smell reported enhanced social insecurity but with different consequence men who were born without a sense of smell exhibit a strongly reduced number of sexual relationship and woman are affected such that they feel le secure about their partner this emphasizes the importance of the sense of smell for intimate relationship

Title: New learning following reactivation in the human brain: targeting emotional memories through rapid serial visual presentation
Authors: Wirkner, J.; Low, A.; Hamm, A. O.; Weymar, M.
Abstract: once reactivated previously consolidated memory destabilize and have to be reconsolidated to persist a process that might be altered non invasively by interfering learning immediately after reactivation here we investigated the influence of interference on brain correlate of reactivated episodic memory for emotional and neutral scene using event related potential erps to selectively target emotional memory we applied a new reactivation method rapid serial visual presentation rsvp rsvp lead to enhanced implicit processing pop out of the most salient memory making them vulnerable to disruption in line interference after reactivation of previously encoded picture disrupted recollection particularly for emotional event furthermore memory impairment were reflected in a reduced centro parietal erp old new difference during retrieval of emotional picture these result provide neural evidence that emotional episodic memory in human can be selectively altered through behavioral interference after reactivation a finding with further clinical implication for the treatment of anxiety disorder

Title: Girls' Stuff? Maternal Gender Stereotypes and Their Daughters' Fear
Authors: Gerdes, A. B. M.; Fraunfelter, L. A.; Braband, M.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: one of the most robust finding in psychopathology is the fact that specific phobia are more prevalent in woman than in men although there are several theoretical account for biological and social contribution to this gender difference empirical data are surprisingly limited interestingly there is evidence that individual with stereotypical feminine characteristic are more fearful than those with stereotypical masculine characteristic this is beyond biological sex because gender role stereotype are reinforced by parental behavior we aimed to examine the relationship of maternal gender stereotype and child s fear dyad of 38 mother and their daughter between age 6 and 10 were included we assessed maternal implicit and explicit gender stereotype a well a their daughter self reported general fearfulness specific fear of snake and approach behavior toward a living snake first mother fear of snake significantly correlated with their daughter fear of snake second mother gender stereotype significantly correlated with their daughter self reported fear specifically maternal implicit gender stereotype were associated with daughter fear of snake and fear rating in response to the snake moreover in child self reported fear correlated with avoidance of the fear relevant animal together these result provide first evidence for a potential role of parental gender stereotype in the development and maintenance of fear in their offspring

Title: Evaluation of an Early Intervention Model for Child and Adolescent Victims of Interpersonal Violence
Authors: Calvano, C.; Murray, E.; Bentz, L.; Bos, S.; Reiter, K.; Ihme, L.; Winter, S. M.
Abstract: only the minority of youth exposed to traumatic event receive mental health care a trauma informed clinical service are lacking or are poorly accessible in order to bridge this gap the outpatient trauma clinic otc wa founded an easily accessible early short time intervention with onward referral to follow up treatment this report present the otc s interventional approach and first outcome data using a retrospective naturalistic design we analyzed trauma and intervention related data of the sample n 377 55 4 female mean age 10 95 sd 4 69 following drop out analysis predictor for treatment outcome were identified by logistic regression the majority 81 9 wa suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd or adjustment disorder around one forth dropped out of treatment these case showed higher avoidance symptom at presentation in 91 psychological symptom improved experience of multiple traumatic event wa the strongest predictor for poor treatment outcome b 0 823 se 0 313 or 0 439 95 ci 0 238 0 811 around two third were connected to follow up treatment the otc realized a high retention rate initial improvement of symptom and referral to subsequent longer term psychotherapeutic treatment in the majority further dissemination of comparable early intervention model is needed in order to improve mental health care for this vulnerable group

Title: The modulation of social behavior and empathy via oral contraceptives and female sex hormones
Authors: Strojny, J.; Domes, G.; Fischbacher, U.; von Dawans, B.
Abstract: oral contraceptive oc and endogenous female sex hormone in naturally cycling woman nc are related to a wide range of psychological variable eg cognition and affect little research on social behavior ha been done one study documented a tendency towards more prosocial behavior in nc than oc woman but the underlying neuroendocrine mechanism remain unknown the sex hormone progesterone and estradiol are potential candidate we analyzed social decision making and social behavior in 83 healthy woman 38 oc and 45 nc via the social value orientation svo and in real social interaction within a paradigm adapted from behavioral economics we also measured empathy and collected saliva sample to quantify the basal level of estradiol and progesterone our analysis revealed higher level of prosocial behavior and emotional empathy in nc than in oc woman a finding supported by higher level of prosocial decision in nc than oc woman in the svo regarding the underlying biological mechanism we detected lower progesterone level in oc than nc woman exploratory analysis revealed a negative correlation between progesterone and trust on the trend level we found no correlation between estradiol and behavior our finding provide evidence that oc modulate social behavior and initial indication of a possible modulation by progesterone further research is needed to replicate our finding and extend them to other social behavior

Title: fMRI adaptation reveals: The human mirror neuron system discriminates emotional valence
Authors: Schmidt, S. N. L.; Sojer, C. A.; Hass, J.; Kirsch, P.; Mier, D.
Abstract: our ability to infer other individual emotion is central for successful social interaction based on the theory of embodied simulation our mirror neuron system mn provides the essential link between the observed facial configuration of another individual and our inference of the emotion by mean of common neuronal activation however so far it is unknown whether the mn differentiates the valence of facial configuration to increase the precision of our fmri measurement we used an adaptation design which allows insight into whether the same neuronal population is active for subsequent stimulus of facial configuration 76 participant were shown congruent or incongruent consecutive pair of facial configuration expressing fear or happiness significant activation for change in emotional valence from adaptor to target wa revealed in fusiform gyrus superior temporal sulcus amygdala insula inferior parietal lobe and brodmann area 44 in addition activation change wa higher in superior temporal sulcus insula and inferior frontal gyrus for a switch from happiness to fear than for fear to happiness our result suggest an involvement of the mn in valence discrimination and a higher sensitivity of the mn to negative than positive valence these finding point to a role of the mn that go beyond the mere coding of a motor state

Title: Nice or effective? Social problem solving strategies in patients with major depressive disorder
Authors: Thoma, P.; Schmidt, T.; Juckel, G.; Norra, C.; Suchan, B.
Abstract: our study addressed distinct aspect of social problem solving in 28 hospitalized patient with major depressive disorder mdd and 28 matched healthy control three scenario based test assessed the ability to infer the mental state of story character in difficult interpersonal situation the capacity to freely generate good strategy for dealing with such situation and the ability to identify the best solution among le optimal alternative also standard test assessing attention memory executive function and trait empathy were administered compared to control mdd patient showed impaired interpretation of other people sarcastic remark but not of the mental state underlying other people action furthermore mdd patient generated fewer strategy that were socially sensitive and practically effective at the same time or at least only socially sensitive overall while the free generation of adequate strategy for difficult social situation wa impaired recognition of optimal solution among alternative wa spared in mdd patient higher generation score were associated with higher trait empathy and cognitive flexibility score we suggest that this specific pattern of impairment ought to be considered in the development of therapy addressing impaired social skill in mdd

Title: Comparing Facebook Users and Facebook Non-Users: Relationship between Personality Traits and Mental Health Variables - An Exploratory Study
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: over one billion people use facebook a a platform for social interaction and self presentation making it one of the most popular online site the aim of the present study wa to investigate difference in various personality trait and mental health variable between facebook user and people who do not use this platform the data of 945 participant 790 facebook user 155 facebook non user were collected result indicate that facebook user score significantly higher on narcissism self esteem and extraversion than facebook non user furthermore they have significantly higher value of social support life satisfaction and subjective happiness facebook non user have marginally significantly higher value of depression symptom than facebook user in both group extraversion self esteem happiness life satisfaction resilience and social support on the one hand and depression anxiety and stress symptom on the other hand are negatively correlated neuroticism is positively associated with depression anxiety and stress symptom however significant difference exist between facebook user and facebook non user regarding some association of personality trait and mental health variable compared to facebook non user the present result indicate that facebook user have higher value of certain personality trait and positive variable protecting mental health these finding are of particular interest considering the high importance of social online platform in the daily life of many people

Title: Overactive performance monitoring in obsessive-compulsive disorder is independent of symptom expression
Authors: Riesel, A.; Kathmann, N.; Endrass, T.
Abstract: overactive performance monitoring ha been consistently reported in obsessive compulsive disorder ocd ocd is a clinically heterogeneous disorder and is characterized by several symptom dimension that may have partially distinct neural correlate we examined whether performance monitoring alteration are related to symptom severity and symptom dimension electrocortical correlate of performance monitoring were assessed in 72 ocd patient and 72 matched healthy comparison participant during a flanker task amplitude of the error and correct related negativity a well a delta and theta power were used to quantify performance monitoring activity and a composite measure wa derived using factor analysis symptom dimension score were obtained from the yale brown obsessive compulsive scale symptom checklist ocd patient showed increased electrocortical response associated with correct and erroneous response compared to healthy comparison participant in patient no correlation were obtained between performance monitoring and global symptom severity a well a lifetime symptom dimension score only a statistical trend wa found that higher symmetry hoarding score were associated with reduced performance monitoring activity for present symptom dimension score an association with ritual superstitious symptom wa obtained such that higher score were associated with greater performance monitoring activity however for both dimension subject with low score or high score on each dimension were characterized by overactive performance monitoring compared to healthy control overactive brain process during performance monitoring are a neural correlate of ocd that is independent of global symptom severity and can be observed for all symptom dimension this support the notion of overactive performance monitoring being a candidate endophenotype for ocd

Title: Performance monitoring in obsessive-compulsive disorder and social anxiety disorder
Authors: Endrass, T.; Riesel, A.; Kathmann, N.; Buhlmann, U.
Abstract: overactive performance monitoring indexed by greater error related brain activity ha been frequently observed in individual with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd similar alteration have been found in individual with major depressive and generalized anxiety disorder the main objective wa to extend these finding by investigating performance monitoring in individual with social anxiety disorder sad and to evaluate the specificity of performance monitoring change in ocd event related potential were used to examine error related brain activity during a flanker task in 24 individual with ocd 24 individual with sad and 24 healthy control with no history of neurological or psychiatric disorder error related negativity ern and correct related negativity served a electrophysiological indicator for performance monitoring enhanced ern wa expected for both clinical group but differential association with clinical symptom were explored ern amplitude were larger in individual with ocd and sad than in healthy control correlational analysis did not reveal significant association between ern and clinical symptomatology in ocd but a significant correlation with depressive symptom wa found in the sad group these finding further strengthen the idea that overactive performance monitoring is independent of clinical symptom in ocd furthermore it may also represent a transdiagnostic vulnerability indicator although the relationship with clinical symptom observed in the sad group need additional evaluation

Title: Differences in Food Craving in Individuals With Obesity With and Without Binge Eating Disorder
Authors: Reents, J.; Pedersen, A.
Abstract: overeating behavior is supposedly a major contributing factor to weight gain and obesity binge eating disorder bed with reoccurring episode of excessive overeating is strongly associated with obesity learning model of overeating behavior and bed assume that mere confrontation with food lead to a conditioned response that is experienced a food craving accordingly individual with obesity and bed were shown to have high trait food craving to date little is known about difference in state food craving and cue reactivity at the sight of palatable food in individual with obesity and bed compared to individual with obesity without bed therefore the aim of our study wa to examine difference in cue induced state and trait food craving in people with obesity with and without bed we found that all aspect of food craving were more prevalent in individual with obesity and bed than in individual without bed by implementing a food cue reactivity paradigm our result show that individual with obesity with bed have more cue induced craving than individual with obesity without bed moreover these cue induced craving in individual with obesity and bed were highest for high fat and high sugar food a opposed to low calorie food thus our result emphasize the role of increased cue reactivity and craving at the sight of palatable food in individual with obesity and bed hence our finding support etiological model of conditioned binge eating and are in line with intervention targeting cue reactivity in bed

Title: Neurofeedback reduces overeating episodes in female restrained eaters: a randomized controlled pilot-study
Authors: Schmidt, J.; Martin, A.
Abstract: overeating episode despite of intention to control weight are a common problem among woman recurring episode of overeating and dietary failure have been reported to result in higher body mass index and to induce severe distress even in non clinical group based on finding from physiological research on eating behavior and craving a well a previous biofeedback study we derived a cue exposure based eeg neurofeedback protocol to target overeating episode the treatment wa evaluated in a randomized controlled trial comparing a neurofeedback group nfg n 14 with a waiting list control group wlg n 13 in a sub clinical sample of female restrained eater at post treatment the number of weekly overeating episode and subsequent distress were significantly reduced in the nfg compared to the wlg p 01 r 50 in a 3 month follow up effect in the nfg remained stable a secondary outcome perceived dieting success wa enhanced after the treatment at follow up additional beneficial effect on trait food craving were observed altogether we found preliminary evidence for the cue exposure neurofeedback against overeating episode in female restrained eater although specific effect and underlying mechanism still have to be explored in future research

Title: Individuals With OCD Lack Unrealistic Optimism Bias in Threat Estimation
Authors: Zetsche, U.; Rief, W.; Exner, C.
Abstract: overestimating the occurrence of threatening event ha been highlighted a a central cognitive factor in the maintenance of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd the present study examined the different facet of this cognitive bias it underlying mechanism and it specificity to ocd for this purpose threat estimation probabilistic classification learning pcl and psychopathological measure were assessed in 23 participant with ocd 30 participant with social phobia and 31 healthy control whereas healthy participant showed an optimistic expectation bias regarding positive and negative future event ocd participant lacked such a bias this lack of an optimistic expectation bias wa not specific to ocd compared to healthy control ocd participant overestimated their personal risk for experiencing negative event but did not differ from control in their risk estimation regarding other people finally ocd participant bias in the prediction of checking related event were associated with their impairment in learning probabilistic cue outcome association in a disorder relevant context in sum the present result add to a growing body of research demonstrating that cognitive bias in ocd are context dependent

Title: Effects of rumination and acceptance on body dissatisfaction in binge eating disorder
Authors: Svaldi, J.; Naumann, E.
Abstract: overvaluation of shape and weight and the corresponding body dissatisfaction are a maintenance factor for the psychopathology of binge eating disorder bed evidence suggests potential benefit of various emotion regulation er strategy in the modification of body dissatisfaction therefore in the present study body dissatisfaction wa experimentally induced in woman with bed n 30 using model picture then participant were instructed to either ruminate on present emotion and thought or accept whatever thought and feeling come up body dissatisfaction and mood were assessed prior to immediately after and 4 minute after the induction main result reveal that er strategy had no differential impact on body dissatisfaction however in the rumination condition mood significantly worsened over time overall the result suggest that er strategy have a limited impact on the experience of body dissatisfaction in bed however having an impact on mood they may be important with regard to the maintenance of pathological eating behaviour in bed association

Title: Neural mechanisms of pain processing differ between endurance athletes and nonathletes: A functional connectivity magnetic resonance imaging study
Authors: Geisler, M.; Ritter, A.; Herbsleb, M.; Bar, K. J.; Weiss, T.
Abstract: pain perception and the ability to modulate arising pain vary tremendously between individual it ha been shown that endurance athlete posse higher pain tolerance threshold and a greater effect of conditioned pain modulation than nonathletes both indicating a more efficient system of endogenous pain inhibition the aim of the present study wa to focus on the neural mechanism of pain processing in endurance athlete that have not been investigated yet therefore we analyzed the pain processing of 18 male athlete and 19 healthy male nonathletes using functional magnetic resonance imaging we found lower pain rating in endurance athlete compared to nonathletes to physically identical painful stimulation furthermore brain activation of athlete versus nonathletes during painful heat stimulation revealed reduced activation in several brain region that are typically activated by nociceptive stimulation this included the thalamus primary and secondary somatosensory cortex insula anterior cingulate cortex midcingulate cortex dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and brain stem b functional connectivity analysis revealed stronger network during painful heat stimulation in athlete between the analyzed brain region except for connection with the b that showed reduced functional connectivity in athlete post hoc correlation analysis revealed association of the subject s fitness level and the brain activation strength subject s fitness level and functional connectivity and brain activation strength and functional connectivity together our result demonstrate for the first time that endurance athlete do not only differ in behavioral variable compared to nonathletes but also in the neural processing of pain elicited by noxious heat

Title: Decreased defensive reactivity to interoceptive threat after successful exposure-based psychotherapy in patients with panic disorder
Authors: Benke, C.; Alius, M. G.; Hamm, A. O.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: panic disorder pd is characterized by a dysfunctional defensive responding to panic related body symptom that is assumed to contribute to the persistence of panic symptomatology the present study aimed at examining whether this dysfunctional defensive reactivity to panic related body symptom would no longer be present following successful cognitive behavior therapy cbt but would persist when patient show insufficient symptom improvement therefore in the present study effect of cbt on reported symptom and defensive response mobilization during interoceptive challenge were investigated using hyperventilation a a respiratory symptom provocation procedure change in defensive mobilization to body symptom in the course of cbt were investigated in patient with a primary diagnosis of pd with or without agoraphobia by applying a highly standardized hyperventilation task prior to and after a manual based cbt n 38 or a waiting period wait list control n 20 defensive activation wa indexed by the potentiation of the amygdala dependent startle eyeblink response all patient showed a pronounced defensive response mobilization to body symptom at baseline after treatment no startle reflex potentiation wa found in those patient who showed a clinically significant improvement however wait list control and treatment non responder continued to show increased defensive response to actually innocuous body symptom after the treatment waiting period the present result indicate that the elimination of defensive reactivity to actually innocuous body symptom might be a neurobiological correlate and indicator of successful cbt in patient with pd which may help to monitor and optimize cbt outcome

Title: From Early Micro-Temporal Interaction Patterns to Child Cortisol Levels: Toward the Role of Interactive Reparation and Infant Attachment in a Longitudinal Study
Authors: Muller, M.; Zietlow, A. L.; Klauser, N.; Woll, C.; Nonnenmacher, N.; Tronick, E.; Reck, C.
Abstract: parental mental disorder increase the risk for insecure attachment in child however the quality of caregiver infant interaction play a key role in the development of infant attachment dyadic interaction is frequently investigated via global scale which are too rough to uncover micro temporal mechanism prior research found that the latency to reparation of uncoordinated dyadic state is associated with infant behavioral and neuroendocrine regulation we investigated the hypothesis that this interactive mechanism is critical in predicting secure v insecure attachment quality in infancy we also assessed the predictive quality of infant attachment regarding neuroendocrine reactivity later in childhood a subsample of n 58 dyad n 22 mother with anxiety disorder n 36 control from a larger study were analyzed at 3 8 month postpartum maternal anxiety disorder were diagnosed via a structured clinical interview a well a dyadic interaction during the face to face still face ffsf wa observed and coded on a micro temporal scale infant attachment quality wa assessed with the strange situation paradigm at 12 24 month of age in an overlapping subsample of n 39 n 13 mother with anxiety disorder n 26 control we assessed child cortisol reactivity at 5 to 6 year of age generalized linear modeling revealed that longer latency to interactive reparation during the reunion episode of the ffsf a well a maternal diagnosis at 3 8 month of age predict insecure attachment in child aged 12 24 month cox regression demonstrated that dyad with infant who developed insecure attachment at 12 24 month of age were 48 le likely to achieve an interactive reparation at 3 8 month of age mixed model revealed that compared to securely attached child child who had developed an insecure attachment at 12 24 month of age had an increased cortisol reactivity at 5 to 6 year of age during free play the result confirm the hypothesis that the development of attachment is affected by experienced micro temporal interactive pattern besides diagnostic category they also showed that infant of mother with postpartum anxiety disorder have a more than fivefold increased risk of developing an insecure attachment than the infant of the control group moreover result imply that these pattern may influence neurohormonal regulation even in preschool aged child

Title: Factors Contributing to Violence Against Children: Insights From a Multi-informant Study Among Family-Triads From Three East-African Refugee Camps
Authors: Hecker, T.; Kyaruzi, E.; Borchardt, J.; Scharpf, F.
Abstract: parental violence pose a considerable yet mitigable risk for the mental health and well being of refugee child living in resource poor refugee camp however little is known about potential risk factor for parental violence in these setting using an ecological system perspective and a multi informant approach we investigated ontogenic parental childhood experience of violence microsystem parent and child s psychopathology and exosystem family monthly household income risk factor for child directed parental violence in a sample of 226 burundian family living in refugee camp in tanzania data were collected through individual structured clinical interview with mother father and child in the child report path model chi 2 6 7 752 p 257 comparative fit index cfi 0 99 root mean square error of approximation rmsea 0 036 p 562 child s posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd symptom externalizing symptom and paternal ptsd symptom were positively associated with violence by both parent maternal psychosocial impairment wa positively associated with child reported paternal violence in the parent report path model chi 2 6 7 789 p 254 cfi 0 97 rmsea 0 036 p 535 child s externalizing problem a well a a lower monthly household income were positively related to maternal violence each parent s childhood victimization wa positively linked to their use of violence against child maternal psychosocial impairment and paternal alcohol abuse were positively associated with paternal violence child and paternal psychopathology maternal psychosocial impairment parent childhood victimization and family socioeconomic status may be important target for prevention and intervention approach aiming to reduce parental violence against refugee child living in camp

Title: Families in the COVID-19 pandemic: parental stress, parent mental health and the occurrence of adverse childhood experiences-results of a representative survey in Germany
Authors: Calvano, C.; Engelke, L.; Di Bella, J.; Kindermann, J.; Renneberg, B.; Winter, S. M.
Abstract: parenting during the covid 19 pandemic is highly challenging with parent having to meet various demand simultaneously an increase in adverse childhood experience ace ha been widely predicted but empirical evidence is still scarce this study aimed to 1 generate representative data on pandemic related stress parental stress general stress parental subjective and mental health and the occurrence of ace 2 identify risk factor for an increase in ace and 3 provide qualitative data on parent experience a representative survey wa conducted in germany in august 2020 with 1024 parent of underage child m age 41 70 50 9 female more than 50 of parent reported being stressed by social distancing and the closure of school and childcare facility parental stress increased significantly during the pandemic d 0 21 subgroup of parent also reported very high level of depressive symptom 12 3 and anxiety 9 7 up to one third of the sample reported ace in the child s lifetime in this group 29 1 reported an increase in child witnessing domestic violence during the pandemic and 42 2 an increase verbal emotional abuse these family were characterized by higher parental stress job loss and younger parent and child age positive aspect of the pandemic related primarily to personal or family life e g slower pace of life increase in family time while some parent coped well a particularly negative pattern wa observed in a subgroup of family that experienced an increase in ace parental stress emerged a important target point for intervention addressing the negative sequela of the pandemic

Title: Mothers need more information to recognise associated emotions in child facial expressions
Authors: Plank, I. S.; Christiansen, L. N.; Kunas, S. L.; Dziobek, I.; Bermpohl, F.
Abstract: parenting requires mother to read social cue and understand their child it is particularly important that they recognise their child s emotion to react appropriately for example with compassion to sadness or compersion to happiness despite this importance it is unclear how motherhood affect woman s ability to recognise emotion associated with facial expression in child using video of an emotionally neutral face continually and gradually taking on a facial expression associated with an emotion we quantified the amount of information needed to match the emotion with the facial expression mother needed more information than non mother to match the emotion with the facial expression both mother and non mother performed equally on a control task identifying animal instead of emotion and both group needed le information when recognising the emotion associated with facial expression in adolescent than pre schoolers these result indicate that mother need more information for to correctly recognise typically associated emotion in child facial expression but not for similar task not involving emotion a possible explanation is that child facial expression associated with emotion may have a greater emotional impact on mother than non mother leading to task interference but possibly also to increased compassion and compersion

Title: Social problem solving in adult patients with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
Authors: Thoma, P.; Sonnenburg, S.; Marcinkowski, N.; Juckel, G.; Edel, M. A.; Suchan, B.
Abstract: patient with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd experience interpersonal difficulty potentially linked to impaired social cognition we aimed to investigate social problem solving strategy in adult with adhd nineteen patient with adhd and 20 healthy control were assessed with a scenario based battery gauging the ability to understand other people s mental state to recognize interpersonal conflict and to generate and identify optimal i e both socially sensitive and practically effective solution to these conflict furthermore measure of socioemotional and executive functioning were administered patient and control performed on a similar level with respect to theory of mind the generation of the best solution to problematic social situation and the selection of the optimal solution out of alternative however in a fluency task patient generated fewer optimal solution while the number of only socially sensitive only practically effective or irrelevant solution wa comparable in both group the overall ability to freely generate problem solution wa not linked to executive functioning or trait empathy but better generation ability were related to lower social interaction anxiety in the patient only this suggests impaired generation fluency of optimal interpersonal conflict solution in patient with adhd which might contribute to higher level of anxiety in social interaction

Title: Neuronal correlates of social cognition in borderline personality disorder
Authors: Mier, D.; Lis, S.; Esslinger, C.; Sauer, C.; Hagenhoff, M.; Ulferts, J.; Gallhofer, B.; Kirsch, P.
Abstract: patient with borderline personality disorder bpd have severe problem in social interaction that might be caused by deficit in social cognition since the finding about social cognitive ability in bpd are inhomogeneous ranging from deficit to superior ability we aimed to investigate the neuronal basis of social cognition in bpd we applied a paradigm with three social cognition task differing in their complexity basal processing of face with a neutral expression recognition of emotion and attribution of emotional intention affective tom a total of 13 patient with bpd and 13 healthy matched control hcs were included in a functional magnet resonance imaging study bpd patient showed no deficit in social cognition on the behavioral level however while hcs showed increasing activation in area of the mirror neuron system with increasing complexity in the social cognitive task bpd patient had hypoactivation in these area and hyperactivation in the amygdala which were not modulated by task complexity this activation pattern seems to reflect an enhanced emotional approach in the processing of social stimulus in bpd that allows good performance in standardized social cognitive task but might be the basis of social cognitive deficit in real life social interaction

Title: Reduced risk avoidance and altered neural correlates of feedback processing in patients with borderline personality disorder
Authors: Endrass, T.; Schuermann, B.; Roepke, S.; Kessler-Scheil, S.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: patient with borderline personality disorder bpd show deficit in reward guided decision making and learning the present study examined risk taking behavior in combination with feedback processing eighteen bpd patient and 18 healthy control performed a probabilistic two choice gambling task while an electroencephalogram wa recorded option differed in risk but were identical in expected value and outcome probability the feedback related negativity frn and the feedback related p300 were analyzed healthy control preferred low risk over high risk option whereas bpd patient chose both option with equal probability frn amplitude were reduced in bpd but effect of feedback valence and risk did not differ between group this suggests attenuated outcome processing in the anterior cingulate cortex but intact reward prediction error signaling furthermore the modulation of the feedback related p300 with feedback valence and risk wa smaller in bpd patient and decreased p300 amplitude were associated with increased behavioral risk taking behavior these finding could relate to the reduced ability of bpd patient to learn and adequately adjust their behavior based on feedback information possibly due to reduced significance of negative feedback

Title: Impaired differential learning of fear versus safety signs in obsessive-compulsive disorder
Authors: Elsner, B.; Reuter, B.; Said, M.; Linnman, C.; Kathmann, N.; Beucke, J. C.
Abstract: pavlovian learning mechanism are of great importance both for model of psychiatric disorder and treatment approach but understudied in obsessive compulsive disorder ocd using an established pavlovian fear conditioning and reversal procedure we studied skin conductance response in 41 patient with ocd and in 32 matched healthy control participant within both group fear acquisition and reversal effect were evident when comparing group patient showed impaired differential learning of threatening and safe stimulus consistent with previous research in contrast to prior finding differential learning impairment were restricted to fear acquisition and not observed in the reversal stage of the experiment a previous and present fear reversal experiment in ocd differed in the use of color coding to facilitate stimulus discrimination the study converge to suggest that differential learning of threatening versus safe stimulus is impaired in ocd but manifest itself differently depending on the difficulty of the association to be learned when supported by the addition of color patient with ocd previously appeared to acquire an association early but failed to reverse it according to changed contingency in absence of such color coding of stimulus our data suggest that patient with ocd already show differential learning impairment during fear acquisition which may relate to finding of altered coping with uncertainty previously observed in ocd impaired differential learning of threatening versus safe stimulus should be studied further in ocd in order to determine whether impairment in differential learning predict treatment outcome in patient and whether they are etiologically relevant for ocd

Title: Are media reports able to cause somatic symptoms attributed to WiFi radiation? An experimental test of the negative expectation hypothesis
Authors: Brascher, A. K.; Raymaekers, K.; Van den Bergh, O.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: people suffering from idiopathic environmental intolerance attributed to electromagnetic field iei emf experience numerous non specific symptom that they attribute to emf the cause of this condition remains vague and evidence show that psychological rather than bioelectromagnetic mechanism are at work we hypothesized a role of medium report in the etiology of iei emf and investigated how somatosensory perception is affected 65 healthy participant were instructed that emf exposure can lead to enhanced somatosensory perception participant were randomly assigned to watch either a television report on adverse health effect of emf or a neutral report during the following experiment participant rated stimulus intensity of tactile electric stimulus while being exposed to a sham wifi signal in 50 of the trial sham wifi exposure led to increased intensity rating of tactile stimulus in the wifi film group especially in participant with higher level of somatosensory amplification participant of the wifi group reported more anxiety concerning wifi exposure than the control group and tended to perceive themselves a being more sensitive to emf after the experiment compared to before sensational medium report can facilitate enhanced perception of tactile stimulus in healthy participant people tending to perceive bodily symptom a intense disturbing and noxious seem most vulnerable receiving sensational medium report might sensitize people to develop a nocebo effect and thereby contribute to the development of iei emf by promoting catastrophizing thought and increasing symptom focused attention perception might more readily be enhanced and misattributed to emf

Title: Expanding the positivity offset theory of anhedonia to the psychosis continuum
Authors: Riehle, M.; Pillny, M.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: people with schizophrenia and negative symptom show diminished net positive emotion in low arousing context diminished positivity offset and co activate positive and negative emotion more frequently increased ambivalence here we investigated whether diminished positivity offset and increased ambivalence covary with negative symptom along the continuum of psychotic symptom we conducted an online study in an ad hoc community sample n 261 participant self reported on psychotic symptom negative symptom depression positive symptom anhedonia and rated positivity negativity and arousal elicited by pleasant unpleasant and neutral stimulus the data were analyzed with multilevel linear model increasing level of all assessed symptom area showed significant association with diminished positivity offset increased ambivalence wa related only to positive symptom our result show that the diminished positivity offset is associated with psychotic symptom in a community sample including but not limited to negative symptom ecological validity and symptom specificity require further investigation

Title: Investigating the social costs of schizophrenia: Facial expressions in dyadic interactions of people with and without schizophrenia
Authors: Riehle, M.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: people with schizophrenia show marked reduction in their emotional expressiveness generally known a blunted affect in this study we tested whether interaction partner would evaluate community dwelling participant with schizophrenia le favorably than healthy control and whether this difference would be explained by reduced smiling behavior related to schizophrenia we also tested whether deficient affect recognition would predict reduced smiling we created 3 study group consisting of 28 participant each participant with schizophrenia sz healthy control hc and naive healthy interaction partner ip ip engaged in 2 separate same sex dyadic interaction with matched member of each of the other 2 group sz and hc in a repeated measure study design during the interaction we assessed the amount of smiling and mimicry of smiling via electromyography after the interaction ip rated their willingness for future interaction with sz and hc respectively ip indicated le willingness for future interaction with sz than with hc participant d 0 72 but sz and hc did not differ with respect to smiling or affect recognition better affect recognition predicted more smiling more smiling predicted more favorable social evaluation within sz participant disorganization symptom but no other symptom dimension were associated with the social evaluation in conclusion community dwelling people with schizophrenia face social challenge that go beyond the adverse effect of stigmatization future work need to clarify the role of different symptom dimension and behavioral aspect contributing to the interpersonal cost of schizophrenia to derive intervention targeted at social reintegration psycinfo database record

Title: Perceived burdensomeness and suicide ideation in adult outpatients receiving exposure therapy for anxiety disorders
Authors: Teismann, T.; Forkmann, T.; Rath, D.; Glaesmer, H.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: perceived burdensomeness is considered a proximal risk factor for suicide ideation however there is a lack of prospective study furthermore it is unclear in a much psychotherapy for anxiety disorder is associated with a decrease in suicide ideation a total of 105 adult outpatient suffering from panic disorder agoraphobia or specific phobia received manualized exposure therapy perceived burdensomeness wa considered a predictor of suicide ideation concurrently after the fourth and the tenth therapy session and posttreatment controlling for baseline symptom distress suicide ideation number of therapy session and age furthermore pre to post change in suicide ideation and perceived burdensomeness were assessed perceived burdensomeness emerged a a significant predictor of suicidal ideation concurrently and after the fourth and the tenth therapy session but not at the end of therapy treatment had no effect on suicide ideation and only a marginal effect on perception of burdensomeness in conclusion the current study highlight the importance of perception of burdensomeness in understanding suicide ideation

Title: Why are you looking like that? How the context influences evaluation and processing of human faces
Authors: Schwarz, K. A.; Wieser, M. J.; Gerdes, A. B.; Muhlberger, A.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: perception and evaluation of facial expression are known to be heavily modulated by emotional feature of contextual information such contextual effect however might also be driven by non emotional aspect of contextual information an interaction of emotional and non emotional factor and by the observer inherent trait therefore we sought to a whether contextual information about self reference in addition to information about valence influence the evaluation and neural processing of neutral face furthermore we investigated whether social anxiety moderate these effect in the present functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri study participant viewed neutral facial expression preceded by a contextual sentence conveying either positive or negative evaluation about the participant or about somebody else contextual influence were reflected in rating and fmri measure with strong effect of self reference on brain activity in the medial prefrontal cortex and right fusiform gyrus additionally social anxiety strongly affected the response to face conveying negative self related evaluation a revealed by the participant rating pattern and brain activity in cortical midline structure and region of interest in the left and right middle frontal gyrus these result suggest that face perception and processing are highly individual process influenced by emotional and non emotional aspect of contextual information and further modulated by individual personality trait

Title: Perceptual and processing differences between physical and dichorhinic odor mixtures
Authors: Schutze, M.; Negoias, S.; Olsson, M. J.; Hummel, T.
Abstract: perceptual integration of sensory input from our two nostril ha received little attention in comparison to lateralized input for vision and hearing here we investigated whether a binary odor mixture of eugenol and l carvone smell of clove and caraway would be perceived differently if presented a a mixture in one nostril physical mixture v the same two odorants in separate nostril dichorhinic mixture in parallel we investigated whether the different type of presentation resulted in difference in olfactory event related potential oerp psychophysical rating showed that the dichorhinic mixture were perceived a more intense than the physical mixture a tendency for shift in perceived quality wa also observed in line with these perceptual change the oerp showed a shift in latency and amplitude for early more sensory peak p1 and n1 whereas no significant difference were observed for the later more cognitive peak p2 the result altogether suggest that the peripheral level is a site of interaction between odorants both psychophysical rating and for the first time electrophysiological measurement converge on this conclusion

Title: Value priorities and value conflicts in patients with mental disorders compared to a general population sample
Authors: Arens, E. A.; Christoffel, M.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: personal value are considered a guiding principle for human attitude and behavior what make them an essential component of mental health although these notion are widely recognized investigation in clinical sample examining the link between value and mental health are lacking we assessed n 209 patient with affective disorder neurotic disorder reaction to severe stress and adjustment disorder and personality disorder and compared them to a stratified random sample n 209 drawn from the european social survey personal value were assessed using the portrait value questionnaire severity of psychopathology wa assessed using the beck depression inventory and the brief symptom inventory clinical participant showed a higher preference for the value power achievement and tradition conformity and a lower preference for hedonism compared to control patient exhibited more incompatible value pattern than control across diagnostic group patient with neurotic disorder reported incompatible value most frequently value priority and value conflict may have the potential to contribute to a better understanding of current and future action and experience in patient with mental disorder

Title: Interpersonal Distance During Real-Time Social Interaction: Insights From Subjective Experience, Behavior, and Physiology
Authors: Kroczek, L. O. H.; Pfaller, M.; Lange, B.; Muller, M.; Muhlberger, A.
