Abstract: physical distance is a prominent feature in face to face social interaction and allows regulating social encounter close interpersonal distance ipd increase emotional response during interaction and ha been related to avoidance behavior in social anxiety however a systematic investigation of the effect of ipd on subjective experience combined with measure of physiological arousal and behavioral response during real time social interaction ha been missing virtual reality allows for a controlled manipulation of ipd while maintaining naturalistic social encounter the present study investigates ipd in social interaction using a novel paradigm in virtual reality thirty six participant approached virtual agent and engaged in short interaction ipd wa varied between 3 5 and 1 m by manipulating the distance at which agent reacted to the participant s approach closer distance were rated a more arousing le pleasant and le natural than longer distance and this effect wa significantly modulated by social anxiety score skin conductance response were also increased at short distance compared to longer distance finally an interaction of ipd and social anxiety wa observed for avoidance behavior measured a participant backward motion during interaction with stronger avoidance related to close distance and high value of social anxiety these result highlight the influence of ipd on experience physiological response and behavior during social interaction the interaction of social anxiety and ipd suggests including the manipulation of ipd in behavioral test in virtual reality a a promising tool for the treatment of social anxiety disorder

Title: Neutral is negative enough-Peer victimization influences cardiac, facial-muscular and experiential reactions to both negative evaluative and neutral social stimuli
Authors: Iffland, B.; Wiggert, N.; Neuner, F.; Blechert, J.
Abstract: physiological stress response vary a a function of adverse childhood experience however previous study concentrate on familial source of childhood adversity potential long term effect of peer victimization on physiology and affective response are le known this study examined cardiac facial muscular and experiential response to social evaluative stimulus in ninety four healthy subject with various degree of experienced peer victimization in a social conditioning task peer victimization wa associated with similarly attenuated cardiac and facial muscular response to negative and neutral stimulus while differentiated physiological response to negative and neutral stimulus were found in subject without peer victimization overall increased rating of arousal valence and disapproval for negative compared to neutral stimulus were found contrary to the physiological response peer victimization wa associated with more negative rating of negative stimulus one month after acquisition the result suggest that the physiological and experiential reactivity towards both negative and neutral social stimulus is affected by the experience of peer victimization peer victimization cause generalized autonomic dysregulation and memory recall bias during social learning impeding adequate response preparation to social stressor

Title: Post-traumatic Stress Disorder Symptoms Resulting from Torture and Other Traumatic Events among Syrian Kurdish Refugees in Kurdistan Region, Iraq
Authors: Ibrahim, H.; Hassan, C. Q.
Abstract: political violence is known to cause psychological distress there is a large body of empirical study drawing correlation between war trauma torture and post traumatic stress disorder ptsd however there are few study on the effect of war related trauma among syrian refugee after event following the arab spring uprising between 2010 and 2012 this study examines the association of ptsd symptom with torture and other traumatic event among syrian kurdish refugee living in kurdistan region iraq the experience and ptsd symptom among 91 syrian kurdish refugee in the arbat camp in the sulaymaniyah governorate of the kurdistan region of iraq were assessed using the harvard trauma questionnaire section i iv and v result showed that the estimated level of ptsd symptom were high between 35 and 38 there were no significant gender difference in the occurrence of ptsd symptom however men reported more general traumatic experience than woman there were significant positive correlation between ptsd symptom with traumatic event and torture r 0 500 r 0 366 respectively examining the mental health impact of torture and other traumatic event among refugee ha possible implication for organization managing rehabilitation program for individual who have been exposed to traumatic event

Title: Neurocognitive deficits or stress overload: Why do individuals with schizophrenia show poor performance in neurocognitive tests?
Authors: Krkovic, K.; Moritz, S.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: poor performance in neurocognitive task is consistently found across study in all stage of schizophrenia spectrum disorder and is interpreted a an underlying brain function related neurocognitive deficit however neurocognitive test performance in schizophrenia might be compromised by patient increased stress level we investigated group difference in neurocognitive performance while accounting for psychophysiological salivary cortisol heart rate skin conductance level and self reported stress we included 35 patient with schizophrenia 29 participant with attenuated psychotic symptom 26 first degree relative of individual with schizophrenia and 28 healthy control participant completed a neurocognitive test battery that assessed processing speed task switching attention working memory verbal episodic memory and verbal comprehension multivariate analysis of covariance mancova were calculated to test for main effect of group on neurocognitive performance thereby not accounting versus accounting for confounding effect of stress a expected patient with schizophrenia scored lower than the other group in all neurocognitive domain participant with attenuated psychotic symptom first degree relative and healthy individual did not differ from each other in their performance after accounting for heart rate and self reported stress the multivariate effect of group on neurocognition remained significant but wa rendered non significant for specific domain working memory capacity episodic memory and long term memory the finding imply that stress is relevant to neurocognitive performance and this should be taken into account when interpreting the origin of performance deficit in schizophrenia patient

Title: Daily fluctuations in positive affect positively co-vary with working memory performance
Authors: Brose, A.; Lovden, M.; Schmiedek, F.
Abstract: positive affect is related to cognitive performance in multiple way it is associated with motivational aspect of performance affective state capture attention and information processing mode are a function of affect in this study we examined whether these link are relevant within individual across time when they experience minor ups and down of positive affect and work on cognitive task in the laboratory on a day to day basis using a microlongitudinal design 101 younger adult 20 31 year of age worked on 3 working memory task on about 100 occasion every day they also reported on their momentary affect and their motivation to work on the task in 2 of the 3 task performance wa enhanced on day when positive affect wa above average this performance enhancement wa also associated with more motivation importantly increase in task performance on day with above average positive affect were mainly unrelated to variation in negative affect this study s result are in line with between person finding suggesting that high level of well being are associated with successful outcome they imply that success on cognitively demanding task is more likely on day when feeling happier

Title: Dual factor model of mental health: Co-occurrence of positive mental health and suicide ideation in inpatients and outpatients
Authors: Teismann, T.; Brailovskaia, J.; Siegmann, P.; Nyhuis, P.; Wolter, M.; Willutzki, U.
Abstract: positive and negative mental health are independent but correlated concept yet it is unknown whether positive mental health doe co occur with suicide ideation the present study aimed to determine the proportion of patient who have positive mental health a well a suicide ideation inpatient n 100 and outpatient n 182 completed self report measure of positive mental health suicide ideation and lifetime suicide attempt eleven outpatient 6 and ten inpatient 10 with suicide ideation reported moderate to high level of positive mental health lifetime suicide attempt were le likely in inpatient who suffered from suicide ideation in the presence of positive mental health positive mental health doe co occur with suicide ideation and should be considered a a protective factor in suicide risk assessment

Title: Predictors of remission from panic disorder, agoraphobia and specific phobia in outpatients receiving exposure therapy: The importance of positive mental health
Authors: Teismann, T.; Brailovskaia, J.; Totzeck, C.; Wannemuller, A.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: positive mental health ha been shown to predict remission from anxiety disorder in community sample however it is unclear whether positive mental health is also predictive of symptom severity and remission from anxiety disorder in patient receiving exposure therapy a total of 130 adult outpatient suffering from panic disorder agoraphobia or specific phobia received manualized exposure therapy positive mental health wa considered a a predictor of symptom severity and remission at the post treatment assessment and at the follow up assessment six month after treatment termination controlling for depression anxiety anxiety cognition bodily sensation number of treatment session age and gender pre treatment positive mental health wa the only predictor of post treatment symptom severity and remission status post treatment positive mental health and avoidance behavior predicted symptom severity and remission status at the follow up assessment in conclusion the current study highlight the importance of positive mental health in understanding remission from anxiety disorder

Title: The traces of imagination: early attention bias toward positively imagined stimuli
Authors: Bar, H. E.; Werthmann, J.; Paetsch, A.; Renner, F.
Abstract: positively imagined activity may capture visual attention due to an increase in positive value increasing attention toward activity in turn may prove useful for clinical intervention aiming to motivate behavioral engagement employing a within subject experimental design we examined the effect of positive imagery on attention using a visual probe task with concurrent eye tracking adult from the general population n 54 imagined performing activity involving visually presented object in a positive focusing on the positive emotional impact or neutral focusing on a neutral circumstance manner they then completed a visual probe task using picture stimulus depicting one object per type of imagery positive compared to neutral imagery increased self reported behavioral motivation and biased the direction but not the duration of gaze toward object associated with the imagined activity an exploratory analysis showed a positive association between the direction bias and depressive symptom our finding build on existing literature on positive imagery a a motivational amplifier by highlighting early attention a an underlying cognitive mechanism

Title: General self-efficacy as a driving factor of post-stroke depression: A longitudinal study
Authors: Volz, M.; Voelkle, M. C.; Werheid, K.
Abstract: post stroke depression psd is the most common psychiatric condition after stroke affecting one third of survivor despite identification of meaningful predictor knowledge about the interplay between these factor remains fragmentary general self efficacy gse is closely linked to psd yet direction and magnitude of this relationship remains unclear the author assessed the relationship between gse and depression during the first two year post stroke while controlling for stable inter individual difference using continuous time ct structural equation modelling sem patient of two german rehabilitation centre n 294 mean age 63 78 year sd 10 83 were assessed six week after ischemic stroke and at four follow ups covering two year gse scale and geriatric depression scale gd were used to a gse and depression ct analysis revealed significantly higher within person cross effect of gse on gd a 21 29 than vice versa a 12 17 maximal cross lagged effect emerged six month post stroke our result show that decreasing gse led to increasing depressiveness and only to a smaller extent vice versa this suggests that fostering gse by strengthening perceived control after stroke can counter psd emersion and exacerbation six month post stroke when patient face social re integration programme focusing on gse could potentially help to prevent later psd

Title: Gender differences in post-stroke depression: A longitudinal analysis of prevalence, persistence and predictive value of known risk factors
Authors: Volz, M.; Ladwig, S.; Werheid, K.
Abstract: post stroke depression psd is the most frequent psychiatric condition after stroke with a prevalence of approximately 33 in the general population depression is consistently reported to be more frequent in woman than in men evidence about gender difference in psd remains inconclusive and it is unknown if established risk factor exert gender specific influence the author examined gender difference in psd prevalence persistence and influence of established risk factor using chi 2 and welch s t test and continuous time structural equation modelling ct sem patient n 301 from the longitudinal berlin psd study were assessed six week baseline and up to four time during the first 2 5 year post stroke using dsm 5 depression criterion and the geriatric depression scale gd established risk factor were assessed at baseline woman showed higher psd prevalence and severity at baseline p 01 but not thereafter p 43 ct sem analysis revealed that known risk factor predicted depression yet predictive value and persistence did not differ between gender our result showed that established psd risk factor influence both gender to a similar extent and that in contrast to depression in the general population gender difference in psd prevalence and severity disappeared within six month post stroke thus for reason yet to be deciphered gender difference in psd appear to be time dependent after stroke

Title: Cardiac reactions to emotional words in adolescents and young adults with PTSD after child abuse
Authors: Iffland, B.; Klein, F.; Rosner, R.; Renneberg, B.; Steil, R.; Neuner, F.
Abstract: post traumatic stress disorder ptsd is associated with alteration in cardiac reactivity to threat cue meta analysis have summarized that adult with ptsd have increased heart rate in response to trauma related stimulus however the opposite effect i e cardiac hyporeactivity ha recently been reported in subgroup of ptsd patient in child and adolescent with ptsd report of cardiac alteration are rare and ambiguous so far most study in adolescent and young adult are restricted to victim of accident even though ptsd is highly prevalent in victim of child maltreatment the present study aimed at investigating cardiac reaction in adolescent and young adult with ptsd after child abuse cardiac response to standardized emotional word were studied in 39 adolescent and young adult ptsd patient after childhood sexual and or physical abuse a compared to 39 healthy control subject age range 15 20 year the experimental paradigm consisted of a passive reading task with neutral positive physically threatening and socially threatening swear word result showed that cardiac reaction to negative stimulus particularly physically threatening stimulus were le pronounced in ptsd patient than in control moreover cardiac reaction in response to socially threatening word were le variable in the ptsd group no difference between and within group were present in reaction to neutral or positive stimulus finding suggest that a physiologically blunted subtype of ptsd may already manifest during adolescence and young adulthood moreover the result of the present study emphasize the relevance of individual trauma history for physiological reaction

Title: Expression of DNA repair genes and its relevance for DNA repair in peripheral immune cells of patients with posttraumatic stress disorder
Authors: Behnke, A.; Mack, M.; Fieres, J.; Christmann, M.; Burkle, A.; Moreno-Villanueva, M.; Kolassa, I. T.
Abstract: posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd involves elevated level of cellular oxidative stress which jeopardizes the integrity of essential cell compartment previously we demonstrated higher level of dna lesion in peripheral blood mononuclear cell pbmcs in ptsd retaining vital level of dna integrity requires cell to mobilize compensatory effort in elevating their dna repair capacity accordingly we hypothesized to find increased expression rate of the dna repair gene x ray repair cross complementing 1 xrcc1 poly adp ribose polymerase 1 parp1 and polymerase beta polbeta in pbmcs of ptsd patient a compared to control leading to functionally relevant change in dna repair kinetics in a cohort of 14 refugee with ptsd and 15 without ptsd we found significantly higher xrcc1 expression in ptsd patient than control u 161 0 p 0 009 cohen s r 0 49 and positive correlation between the severity of ptsd symptom and the expression of xrcc1 r s 0 57 p 0 002 and parp1 r s 0 43 p 0 022 higher xrcc1 f 2 39 p 0 010 eta 2 p 0 10 and parp1 f 2 15 p 0 022 eta 2 p 0 09 expression accounted for slower repair of experimentally x ray irradiation induced dna damage highlighting the possible physiological relevance of altered dna repair gene expression in ptsd our study provides first evidence for a compensatory regulation of dna repair mechanism in ptsd we discus the implication of increased dna damage and altered dna repair mechanism in immune senescence premature aging and increased physical morbidity in ptsd

Title: Does napping enhance the effects of Cognitive Bias Modification-Appraisal training? An experimental study
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Cwik, J. C.; Blackwell, S. E.; Kleim, B.; Holmes, E. A.; Adolph, D.; Zhang, H.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd is characterised by dysfunctional appraisal of the trauma and it consequence including one s own symptom experimental study have shown that cognitive bias modification appraisal cbm app training can reduce dysfunctional interpretation and analog trauma symptom one important question is how to enhance the effect of cbm app following work suggesting that sleep ha beneficial effect on consolidation process and can thus improve learning the present study investigated whether a brief period of sleep i e a nap enhances the effect of cbm app all participant watched a stressful movie a an analogue trauma induction after that participant received either positive or negative cbm app training within each training half of the participant then had a 90 minute nap or watched a neutral movie result showed that the cbm training induced training congruent appraisal sleep did not enhance this effect participant who slept however experienced fewer intrusive memory of the analogue trauma but this effect wa independent of the cbm condition these result provide valuable information about the effect of sleep during a 90 minute nap period on encoding of analogue trauma and emotional learning in the context of appraisal and highlight the importance of sleep a a focus for continued research

Title: Nocturnal Olfactory Stimulation for Improvement of Sleep Quality in Patients With Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Randomized Exploratory Intervention Trial
Authors: Schafer, L.; Schellong, J.; Hahner, A.; Weidner, K.; Huttenbrink, K. B.; Trautmann, S.; Hummel, T.; Croy, I.
Abstract: posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd is characterized by sleep impairment and nightmare a pleasant odor presented during sleep affect the emotional tone of dream without inducing arousal we investigated whether sleep pattern in ptsd can be improved via nocturnal olfactory stimulation participant were 40 inpatient with ptsd n 35 woman age range 20 59 year who completed a randomized patient blind placebo controlled trial baseline measurement for 5 consecutive night wa followed by a 5 night experimental intervention or placebo trial during the intervention patient received nocturnal stimulation with a pleasant odor odor condition or clean air placebo condition via an olfactometer that delivered inspiration triggered stimulus in a nasal tube or via an odorized nasal clip after each night the patient completed standardized questionnaire that assessed sleep parameter and dream content each night sleep efficiency sleep onset latency and wakefulness after sleep onset were monitored with a motion biosensor baseline assessment revealed that ptsd severity wa associated with poorer sleep outcome an interaction effect showed that nocturnal odorization affected dream intensity post hoc test revealed an improvement in the group that used the nasal clip a compared to baseline d 0 68 no negative effect were observed after odorization with the nasal clip considering the limited sample size the study indicates that nocturnal olfactory stimulation may serve a a low cost concomitant intervention to improve sleep quality in ptsd

Title: The endocannabinoid system in humans: significant associations between anandamide, brain function during reward feedback and a personality measure of reward dependence
Authors: Redlich, C.; Dlugos, A.; Hill, M. N.; Patel, S.; Korn, D.; Enneking, V.; Foerster, K.; Arolt, V.; Domschke, K.; Dannlowski, U.; Redlich, R.
Abstract: preclinical evidence indicates that the endocannabinoid system is involved in neural response to reward this study aimed to investigate association between basal serum concentration of the endocannabinoids anandamide aea and 2 arachidonylglycerol 2 ag with brain functional reward processing additionally a personality measure of reward dependence wa obtained brain functional data were obtained of 30 right handed adult by conducting fmri at 3 tesla using a reward paradigm reward dependence wa obtained using the subscale reward dependence of the tridimensional personality questionnaire tpq basal concentration of aea and 2 ag were determined in serum analyzing the fmri data for aea and 2 ag ancovas were calculated using a full factorial model with condition reward control loss control and concentration for aea and 2 ag a factor regression analysis were conducted for aea and 2 ag on tpq rd score a whole brain analysis showed a significant interaction effect of aea concentration by condition positive v negative within the putamen x 26 y 16 z 8 f13 51 tfce 1 54 771 68 k 70 p fwe 0 044 resulting from a positive association of basal aea concentration and putamen activity to rewarding stimulus while this association wa absent in the loss condition aea concentration were significantly negatively correlated with tpq reward dependence score r spearman 0 56 p 0 001 these result show that circulating aea may modulate brain activation during reward feedback and that the personality measure reward dependence is correlated with aea concentration in healthy human volunteer future research is needed to further characterize the nature of the lipid influence on reward processing the impact on reward anticipation and outcome and on vulnerability for psychiatric disorder

Title: Education and mental health: Do psychosocial resources matter?
Authors: Niemeyer, H.; Bieda, A.; Michalak, J.; Schneider, S.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: prevalence rate for mental health problem are higher when an individual s socioeconomic status s is low but the underlying mechanism are not clearly understood we investigated association between education a indicator for s and depressive symptom a well a positive mental health pmh moreover we hypothesized that low education is associated with a lack of psychosocial resource and more daily hassle which in turn mediate the relationship between education and mental health in a german representative sample n 7937 we cross sectionally first examined whether a person s educational level wa associated with depressive symptom and pmh educational level wa defined a the highest academic qualification achieved second we investigated whether also sense of control resilience delay of gratification cultural activity and daily hassle followed gradient along the educational level third we investigated whether they mediated the relationship between education and mental health result showed that depressive symptom measured by item from the da 42 depression subscale were more prevalent for person with a low educational level pmh operationalized by the positive mental health scale wa equally distributed and all psychosocial characteristic followed the gradient of educational level in addition the group with a high school diploma wa particularly burdened structural equation modeling indicated that the association between education and mental health were mediated by all psychosocial characteristic and daily hassle apart from the delay of gratification in the group with the lowest educational level the model fit index for depressive symptom and pmh were acceptable chi2 10007 243 627 cfi 0 869 rmsea 0 04 90 ci 0 04 0 04 srmr 0 05 and chi2 12779 968 741 cfi 0 86 rmsea 0 05 90 ci 0 05 0 05 srmr 0 05 respectively the effect size p m refers to the proportion of the total effect that is mediated by one or more variable m and the effect size of all indirect effect in the model for depressive symptom wa p m 80 and for pmh it wa p m 68 the result support our hypothesis that low education is associated with le psychosocial resource which in turn serve together with daily hassle a pathway between education and depressive symptom a well a pmh building on these finding longitudinal study are necessary to investigate causality

Title: Performance monitoring and empathy during active and observational learning in patients with major depression
Authors: Thoma, P.; Norra, C.; Juckel, G.; Suchan, B.; Bellebaum, C.
Abstract: previous literature established a link between major depressive disorder mdd and altered reward processing a well a between empathy and observational reward learning the aim of the present study wa to a the effect of mdd on the electrophysiological correlate the feedback related negativity frn and the p300 of active and observational reward processing and to relate them to trait cognitive and affective empathy eighteen patient with mdd and 16 healthy control performed an active and an observational probabilistic reward learning task while event related potential were recorded also participant were assessed with regard to self reported cognitive and affective trait empathy relative to healthy control patient with mdd showed overall impaired learning and attenuated frn amplitude irrespective of feedback valence and learning type active v observational but comparable p300 amplitude in the patient group but not in control higher trait perspective taking score were significantly correlated with reduced frn amplitude the pattern of result suggests impaired prediction error processing and a negative effect of higher trait empathy on feedback based learning in patient with mdd

Title: Event-related potentials of emotional and neutral memories: The role of encoding position and delayed testing
Authors: Wirkner, J.; Ventura-Bort, C.; Schulz, P.; Hamm, A. O.; Weymar, M.
Abstract: previous research found that memory is not only better for emotional information but also for neutral information that ha been encoded in the context of an emotional event in the present erp study we investigated two factor that may influence memory for neutral and emotional item temporal proximity between emotional and neutral item during encoding and retention interval immediate v delayed forty nine female participant incidentally encoded 36 unpleasant and 108 neutral picture 36 neutral picture preceded an unpleasant picture 36 followed an unpleasant picture and 36 neutral picture were preceded and followed by neutral picture and participated in a recognition memory task either immediately n 24 or 1 week n 25 after encoding result showed better memory for emotional picture relative to neutral picture in accordance enhanced centroparietal old new difference 500 900 m during recognition were observed for unpleasant compared to neutral picture most pronounced for the 1 week interval picture position effect however were only subtle during encoding late positive potential for neutral picture were slightly lower for neutral picture following unpleasant one but only at trend level to summarize we could replicate and extend previous erp finding showing that emotionally arousing event are better recollected than neutral event particularly when memory is tested after longer retention interval picture position during encoding however had only small effect on elaborative processing and no effect on memory retrieval

Title: Emotional interference under low versus high executive control
Authors: Grutzmann, R.; Riesel, A.; Kaufmann, C.; Kathmann, N.; Heinzel, S.
Abstract: previous research ha demonstrated that task irrelevant emotional distractors interfere with task performance especially under low phasic executive control i e in nonconflict trial in the present study we measured medio frontal erps n2 and correct related negativity crn to elucidate which aspect of task performance are affected by emotional interference in a flanker task to create emotional interference negative and neutral picture were presented during the flanker stimulus n2 and crn were reduced after negative picture indicating that conflict processing and performance monitoring are both affected by emotional interference on the behavioral level prolonged response time after negative picture were observed under low phasic executive control i e in compatible trial additionally we explored whether emotional interference is modulated not only by phasic change in executive control i e conflict v nonconflict trial but also by tonic change in executive control i e low v high overall conflict frequency to this end the flanker task consisted of two block with 25 versus 75 incompatible trial prolonged response time after negative picture in compatible trial were observed only under low tonic executive control but not under high executive control

Title: Aroused at Home: Basic Autonomic Regulation during Orthostatic and Physical Activation is Altered in Children with Social Anxiety Disorder
Authors: Asbrand, J.; Blechert, J.; Nitschke, K.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.; Schmitz, J.
Abstract: previous research ha documented altered autonomic nervous system an reactivity to laboratory based social stress task in child with social anxiety disorder sad it is unclear however whether these alteration are caused by the unfamiliar and possibly threatening lab environment or whether they generalize to other more representative context sympathetic and parasympathetic autonomic functioning wa assessed in the home minimizing environmental threat during a supine baseline phase and two physical activation phase orthostatic stress stair stepping in child 9 13 year with sad n 27 and healthy control child n 27 relative to control child with sad showed tonic autonomic hyperarousal a indicated by higher heart rate and electrodermal activity during the supine baseline phase further there wa evidence for stronger cardiac and vascular sympathetic reactivity t wave amplitude pulse wave transit time to moderate physical activation in child with sad higher autonomic arousal during rest wa related to measure of trait social anxiety and general psychopathology group did not differ on parasympathetic parameter our result extend previous laboratory finding and provide the first evidence for alteration in child with sad during basal autonomic regulation and in the absence of explicit social evaluative threat they may further help to clarify conflicting study result from previous laboratory study the finding underline the importance of psychophysiological assessment using different environment and task to elucidate the physiological base of sad

Title: Acoustic startle reactivity while processing reward-related food cues during food deprivation: evidence from women in different menstrual cycle phases and men
Authors: Ferreira de Sa, D. S.; Plein, D. E.; Schulz, A.; Oitzl, M. S.; Blumenthal, T. D.; Schachinger, H.
Abstract: previous research ha shown that food deprivation enhances the acoustic startle reflex when it is elicited during presentation of visual food cue frustrative nonreward may explain this effect since visual food cue are also rated to be more appetitive and arousing during food deprivation however the impact of menstrual cycle and sex on this effect remains unclear and it is also not known whether this effect is influenced by hunger and motivation to eat according to a within study design 20 healthy woman in different menstrual cycle phase and 14 healthy men participated twice in normal and food deprived condition after 18 h of food deprivation acoustic startle wa attenuated by appetitive nonfood foreground picture but enhanced by presentation of food picture no difference between menstrual cycle phase and sex appeared the effect correlated with hunger change suggesting that motivational factor play a role

Title: Applied relaxation and cortisol secretion: findings from a randomized controlled indicated prevention trial in adults with stress, anxiety, or depressive symptoms
Authors: Kische, H.; Zenker, M.; Pieper, L.; Beesdo-Baum, K.; Asselmann, E.
Abstract: previous research ha shown that relaxation intervention can reduce distress anxiety and depression the exact mechanism that underlie the efficacy of relaxation intervention remain unresolved this study aimed to investigate whether applied relaxation ar lead to change in cortisol secretion and whether these effect mediate fewer symptom due to ar data come from a randomized controlled preventive interventional trial n 277 with elevated tension distress anxiety or depressive symptomatology participant were randomized to an intervention group ig n 139 received ar training or a non interventional control group cg n 138 psychopathological symptom were assessed with da 21 and diagnosis of mental disorder via dia x 5 cortisol wa measured a short term index in saliva six time d for 2 d at pre post and follow up fu assessment and long term index in hair sample once at pre assessment and fu respectively data were analyzed a pre specified secondary analysis of the randomized controlled trial rct on completer basis n 134 cg n 102 ig using multivariable adjusted linear regression model and mediation analysis the da 21 change in the ig v cg with cortisol area under the curve auc a mediator from pre to post assessment total daily salivary cortisol auc decreased more strongly in the ig v cg beta coefficient 13 83 95 confidence interval ci 26 85 to 0 81 but wa rendered non significant when adjusting for pre assessment auc this effect wa not found for the cortisol awakening response car or hair cortisol there wa no evidence for a mediation of cortisol auc these finding provide little support for the idea that cortisol reduction explain the beneficial effect of ar on mental health

Title: Neural correlates of working memory deficits and associations to response inhibition in obsessive compulsive disorder
Authors: Heinzel, S.; Kaufmann, C.; Grutzmann, R.; Hummel, R.; Klawohn, J.; Riesel, A.; Bey, K.; Lennertz, L.; Wagner, M.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: previous research in patient with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd ha indicated performance decrement in working memory wm and response inhibition however underlying neural mechanism of wm deficit are not well understood to date and empirical evidence for a proposed conceptual link to inhibition deficit is missing we investigated wm performance in a numeric n back task with four wm load condition during functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri in 51 patient with ocd and 49 healthy control participant who were matched for age sex and education additionally a stop signal task wa performed outside the mri scanner in a subsample on the behavioral level a significant wm load by group interaction wa found for both accuracy p 0 02 and reaction time measure p 0 03 indicating increased reaction time a well a reduced accuracy specifically at high wm load 3 back in patient with ocd whole brain analysis of fmri data identified neural correlate of a load dependent wm decrement in ocd in the supplementary motor area sma and the inferior parietal lobule ipl within the ocd sample sma activity a well a n back performance were correlated with stop signal task performance result from behavioral and fmri analysis indicate a reduced wm load dependent modulation of neural activity in ocd and suggest a common neural mechanism for inhibitory dysfunction and wm decrement in ocd

Title: Endogenous cortisol levels influence exposure therapy in spider phobia
Authors: Lass-Hennemann, J.; Michael, T.
Abstract: previous research in patient with phobia showed that the administration of glucocorticoid reduces fear in phobic situation and enhances exposure therapy glucocorticoid underlie a daily cycle with a peak in the morning and low level during the evening and night the aim of the present study wa to investigate whether exposure is more effective when conducted in the morning when endogenous cortisol level are high sixty patient meeting dsm iv criterion for specific phobia animal type were randomly assigned to one session exposure treatment either at 08 00 a m high cortisol group or at 06 00 p m low cortisol group participant returned for a posttreatment assessment one week after therapy and a follow up assessment three month after therapy both group showed good outcome but patient treated in the morning exhibited significantly le fear of spider in the behavioral approach test bat and a trend for lower score on the fear of spider questionnaire fsq than patient treated in the evening this effect wa present at posttreatment and follow up our finding indicate that exposure therapy is more effective in the morning than in the evening we suggest that this may be due to higher endogenous cortisol level in the morning group that enhance extinction memory

Title: Chronic stress and emotion: Differential effects on attentional processing and recognition memory
Authors: Wirkner, J.; Ventura-Bort, C.; Schwabe, L.; Hamm, A. O.; Weymar, M.
Abstract: previous research indicates that acute stress around the time of learning facilitates attention and memory for emotionally salient information despite accumulating evidence for these acute stress effect le is known about the role of chronic stress in the present study we therefore tested emotional and neutral scene processing and later recognition memory in female participant using hair cortisol concentration a a biological marker for chronic stress event related potential recorded during picture viewing indicated enhanced late positive potential lpps for emotional relative to neutral content these brain potential varied a a function of long term hair cortisol level hair cortisol level were positively related to overall lpp amplitude result from recognition memory testing one week after encoding revealed better memory for emotional relative to neutral scene hair cortisol level however were related to poorer memory accuracy taken together our result indicate that chronic stress enhanced attentional processing during encoding of new stimulus and impaired later recognition memory result are discussed with regard to putatively opposite effect of chronic stress on certain brain region e g amygdala and hippocampus

Title: Individual differences in human fear generalization-pattern identification and implications for anxiety disorders
Authors: Stegmann, Y.; Schiele, M. A.; Schumann, D.; Lonsdorf, T. B.; Zwanzger, P.; Romanos, M.; Reif, A.; Domschke, K.; Deckert, J.; Gamer, M.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: previous research indicates that anxiety disorder are characterized by an overgeneralization of conditioned fear a compared with healthy participant therefore fear generalization is considered a key mechanism for the development of anxiety disorder however systematic investigation on the variance in fear generalization are lacking therefore the current study aim at identifying distinctive phenotype of fear generalization among healthy participant to this end 1175 participant completed a differential fear conditioning phase followed by a generalization test to identify pattern of fear generalization we used a k mean clustering algorithm based on individual arousal generalization gradient subsequently we examined the reliability and validity of the cluster and phenotypical difference between subgroup on the basis of psychometric data and marker of fear expression cluster analysis reliably revealed five cluster that systematically differed in mean response differentiation between conditioned threat and safety and linearity of the generalization gradient though mean response level accounted for most variance remarkably the pattern of mean response were already evident during fear acquisition and corresponded most closely to psychometric measure of anxiety trait the identified cluster reliably described subgroup of healthy individual with distinct response characteristic in a fear generalization test following a dimensional view of psychopathology these cluster likely delineate risk factor for anxiety disorder a crucial group characteristic were already evident during fear acquisition our result emphasize the importance of average fear response and differentiation between conditioned threat and safety a risk factor for anxiety disorder

Title: Taking a closer look: autonomic dysregulation in socially anxious children
Authors: Schmitz, J.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.; Wilhelm, F. H.; Blechert, J.
Abstract: previous research on autonomic characteristic of social anxiety in child and adolescent ha produced highly inconsistent result which may partially be due to task difference and a limited breadth of autonomic measurement here we investigated a sample of high hsa and low socially anxious lsa child aged 10 12 year before during and after a standardized evaluated speech task while acquiring a broad set of autonomic and experiential measure during baseline we found evidence for tonically higher sympathetic autonomic activity in hsa child indicated by higher low frequency heart rate variability lf and a trend for higher lf to high frequency heart rate variability ratio lf hf in response to the speech task hsa child showed blunted cardiac responding evidenced by slower increase and delayed recovery of heart rate and a similar significant trend on lf hf value self reported anxiety by contrast showed enhanced reactivity from baseline to anticipation in the hsa compared to the lsa group the result suggest a restricted cardiac flexibility in hsa child and illustrate that broad autonomic assessment during a well structured naturalistic task may improve our understanding of the autonomic physiology of socially anxious child the result have implication for current theory of social anxiety

Title: Training approach-avoidance of smiling faces affects emotional vulnerability in socially anxious individuals
Authors: Rinck, M.; Telli, S.; Kampmann, I. L.; Woud, M. L.; Kerstholt, M.; Te Velthuis, S.; Wittkowski, M.; Becker, E. S.
Abstract: previous research revealed an automatic behavioral bias in high socially anxious individual hsas although their explicit evaluation of smiling face are positive they show automatic avoidance of these face this is reflected by faster pushing than pulling of smiling face in an approach avoidance task aat heuer et al 2007 the current study addressed the causal role of this avoidance bias for social anxiety to this end we used the aat to train hsas either to approach smiling face or to avoid them we examined whether such an aat training could change hsas automatic avoidance tendency and if yes whether aat effect would generalize to a new approach task with new facial stimulus and to mood and anxiety in a social threat situation a video recorded self presentation we found that hsas trained to approach smiling face did indeed approach female face faster after the training than hsas trained to avoid smiling face moreover approach face training reduced emotional vulnerability it led to more positive mood and lower anxiety after the self presentation than avoid face training these result suggest that automatic approach avoidance tendency have a causal role in social anxiety and that they can be modified by a simple computerized training this may open new avenue in the therapy of social phobia

Title: State anxiety by itself does not change political attitudes: A threat of shock experiment
Authors: Muller, U. W. D.; Bahnsen, O.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: previous research suggests that state anxiety may sway political attitude however previous experimental procedure induced anxiety using political context e g social or economic threat in a pre registered laboratory experiment we set out to examine if anxiety that is unrelated to political context can influence political attitude we induced anxiety with a threat of shock paradigm void of any political connotation all participant were instructed that they might receive an electric stimulus during specified threat period and none during safety period participant were randomly assigned to one of two condition political attitude implicit and explicit were assessed under safety in one condition and under threat in the other psychometric a well a physiological data skin conductance heart rate confirmed that anxiety wa induced successfully however this emotional state did not alter political attitude in a bayesian analytical approach we confirmed the absence of an effect our result suggest that state anxiety by itself doe not sway political attitude previously observed effect that were attributed to anxiety may be conditional on a political context of threat

Title: Emotional empathy and psychopathy in offenders: an experimental study
Authors: Domes, G.; Hollerbach, P.; Vohs, K.; Mokros, A.; Habermeyer, E.
Abstract: previous study associated psychopathy in adult with deficit in empathy but these study did not directly compare cognitive and emotional facet of empathy the present study sought to establish whether psychopathy is associated with impairment in emotional empathy among adult offender participant were 90 male offender scoring low n 29 medium n 33 or high n 28 on the psychopathy checklist revised pcl r and n 28 male noncriminal control empathy functioning wa assessed through self report and computerized decision task differentiating between perspective taking cognitive empathy and compassion emotional empathy against expectation level of psychopathy among the offender wa not associated with either emotional or cognitive empathy offender however had lower score for both cognitive and emotional component of empathy functioning than control both facet of empathy showed small but significant positive correlation with education level and social desirability the method employed to a difference in empathy functioning may not be sensitive enough to a difference in forensic sample

Title: Personality Disorders in Hypochondriasis: A Comparison to Panic Disorder and Healthy Controls
Authors: Weck, F.; Nagel, L. C.; Richtberg, S.; Neng, J. M. B.
Abstract: previous study found high prevalence rate of personality disorder pd in patient with hypochondriasis however assessment wa often based only on questionnaire in the current study a sample of 68 patient with hypochondriasis wa compared to 31 patient with panic disorder and to 94 healthy control participant were investigated with the structured clinical interview for dsm iv personality disorder questionnaire scid ii questionnaire and the scid ii interview based on the cut off score of the scid ii questionnaire we found a prevalence rate of 45 6 for pd in patient with hypochondriasis in comparison to healthy control patient with hypochondriasis showed characteristic of paranoid borderline avoidant and dependent pd in the dimensional assessment significantly more often however no significant difference were found between the clinical sample based on the scid ii interview only 2 9 of the patient with hypochondriasis fulfilled the criterion for a pd these result suggest that pd are not a specific characteristic of hypochondriasis

Title: Effects of internet-based stress management on acute cortisol stress reactivity: Preliminary evidence using the Trier Social Stress Test for Groups (TSST-G)
Authors: Domes, G.; Stachele, T.; von Dawans, B.; Heinrichs, M.
Abstract: previous study have demonstrated the effectiveness of face to face stress management program in reducing psychological and endocrine response to acute psychosocial stress exposure with the present pilot study we compare the effect of a brief internet based stress management ibsm intervention versus relaxation training on subjective autonomic and endocrine stress response to a standardized psychosocial laboratory stressor trier social stress test for group tsst g a group of male participant receiving ibsm wa compared to a group receiving progressive muscle relaxation pmr training and a waiting list control group all group underwent the tsst g following a 6 week training waiting period both the ibsm and pmr group reported lower subjective stress level than the control group however the ibsm group exhibited the lowest free salivary cortisol response to the tsst g with significantly lower level than the pmr group the waiting list control group exhibited an intermediate cortisol response these preliminary result suggest that a 6 week internet based stress management program is effective in reducing the subjective stress level and might be associated with an attenuated salivary cortisol response to an acute stressor

Title: Attentional Selection of Social Features Persists Despite Restricted Bottom-Up Information and Affects Temporal Viewing Dynamics
Authors: Flechsenhar, A.; Rosler, L.; Gamer, M.
Abstract: previous study have shown an attentional bias towards social feature during free viewing of naturalistic scene this social attention seems to be reflexive and able to defy top down demand in form of explicit search task however the question remains whether social feature continue to be prioritized when peripheral information is limited thereby reducing the influence of bottom up image information on gaze orienting therefore we established a gaze contingent viewing paradigm in which the visual field wa constrained and updated in response to the viewer s eye movement participant viewed social and non social image that were randomly allocated to a free and a gaze contingent viewing condition while their eye movement were tracked our result revealed a strong attentional bias towards social feature in both condition however gaze contingent viewing altered temporal and spatial dynamic of viewing behavior additionally recurrent fixation were more frequent and closer together in time for social compared to non social stimulus in both viewing condition taken together this study implies a predominant selection of social feature when bottom up influence are diminished and a general influence of social content on visual exploratory behavior thus highlighting mechanism of social attention

Title: Increased insula and amygdala activity during selective attention for negatively valenced body parts in binge eating disorder
Authors: Press, S. A.; Biehl, S. C.; Domes, G.; Svaldi, J.
Abstract: previous study indicate that participant with eating disorder show an attentional bias for the negatively valenced body part of their own body however the neural basis underlying these process ha not been investigated we conducted a preregistered combined functional mri fmri eye tracking study and presented 35 woman with binge eating disorder bed and 24 weight matched control subject cg with body part image of their own body and a weight matched unknown body after the fmri examination participant rated the attractiveness of the presented body part a expected woman with bed responded with significantly higher insula and amygdala activity when viewing the negatively valenced body part of their own body compared to all other combination however individual with bed did not deviate from the cg in the processing of these stimulus in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex the extrastriate body area or the fusiform body area our result indicate that the negative valued body part carry a particularly strong emotional valence in individual with bed these result further emphasize the relevance of processing bias for negatively valenced body part in the pathology of bed psycinfo database record c 2023 apa all right reserved

Title: Working memory training improvements and gains in non-trained cognitive tasks in young and older adults
Authors: Heinzel, S.; Schulte, S.; Onken, J.; Duong, Q. L.; Riemer, T. G.; Heinz, A.; Kathmann, N.; Rapp, M. A.
Abstract: previous study on working memory training have indicated that transfer to non trained task of other cognitive domain may be possible the aim of this study is to compare working memory training and transfer effect between younger and older adult n 60 a novel approach to adaptive n back training 12 session wa implemented by varying the working memory load and the presentation speed all participant completed a neuropsychological battery of test before and after the training on average younger training participant achieved difficulty level 12 after training while older training participant only reached difficulty level 5 in younger participant transfer to verbal fluency and digit symbol substitution test wa found in older participant we observed a transfer to digit span forward cerad delayed recall and digit symbol substitution test result suggest that working memory training may be a beneficial intervention for maintaining and improving cognitive functioning in old age
Journal: Neuropsychol Dev Cogn B Aging Neuropsychol Cogn

Title: Normal interoceptive accuracy in women with bulimia nervosa
Authors: Pollatos, O.; Georgiou, E.
Abstract: previous study suggest that patient suffering from bulimia nervosa bn have difficulty in perceiving internal bodily signal mostly assessed by self report questionnaire whether interoception is in this case attenuated or not remains an open question therefore interoceptive process were examined in twenty three patient with current bn and were compared to healthy participant we investigated interoceptive accuracy iac assessed by the heartbeat detection task and interoceptive awareness ia assessed by the eating disorder inventory 2 patient with bn and healthy participant did not differ in term of iac when controlling for bmi depression and anxiety whereas ia among bn patient wa found to have decreased although iac and ia were not related among control we observed an inverse correlation in bn suggesting that an abnormal overlap between these two level of interoceptive signal processing is present in bn the current study introduces a new perspective concerning the role of interoceptive process in bn and generates further question regarding the therapeutic utility of method targeting the interaction between different level of interoception in the treatment of bn

Title: Child abuse predicts adult PTSD symptoms among individuals diagnosed with intellectual disabilities
Authors: Catani, C.; Sossalla, I. M.
Abstract: prior research ha shown that people with intellectual disability id are more likely to experience child abuse a well a other form of traumatic or negative event later in life compared to the general population little is known however about the association of these experience with adult mental health in intellectually disabled individual the present study aimed to a whether child abuse in family and institution a well a other type of adverse life event were associated with current posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd and depression symptom in individual with id we conducted clinical interview which included standardized self report measure for childhood abuse ptsd and depression in an unselected sample of 56 person with a medical diagnosis of id who were attending a specialized welfare center the frequency of traumatic experience wa very high with physical and emotional child abuse being the most common trauma type 87 of the person reported at least one aversive experience on the family violence spectrum and 50 of the sample reported a violent physical attack later in adulthood 25 were diagnosed with ptsd and almost 27 had a critical score on the depression scale physical and emotional child abuse wa positively correlated with the amount of institutional violence and the number of general traumatic event whereas childhood sexual abuse wa related to the experience of intimate partner violence in adult life a linear regression model revealed child abuse in the family to be the only significant independent predictor of ptsd symptom severity the current finding underscore the central role of child maltreatment in the increased risk of further victimization and in the development of mental health problem in adulthood in intellectually disabled individual our data have important clinical implication and demonstrate the need for targeted prevention and intervention program that are tailored to the specific need of child and adult with intellectual disability

Title: NMDA receptor modulation by dextromethorphan and acute stress selectively alters electroencephalographic indicators of partial report processing
Authors: Weckesser, L. J.; Enge, S.; Riedel, P.; Kirschbaum, C.; Miller, R.
Abstract: proceeding from a biophysical network model the present study hypothesized that glutamatergic neurotransmission across the nmda receptor nmdar play a key role in visual perception and it modulation by acute stress to investigate these hypothesis behavioral and electroencephalographic eeg indicator of partial report task processing were assessed in twenty four healthy young men who randomly received a non competitive nmdar antagonist 0 8 mg kg dextromethorphan dxm or a placebo and concurrently accomplished a stress induction mast or control protocol in three consecutive session saliva sample served to quantify cortisol response to the mast whereas a passive auditory oddball paradigm wa implemented to verify the impact of dxm on the eeg derived mismatch negativity component mmn dxm administration significantly increased mmn amplitude but not salivary cortisol concentration by contrast concurrent mast exposure significantly reduced mmn latency but also increased cortisol concentration with regard to eeg indicator dxm administration reduced visually evoked 30hz to 50hz and induced occipital gamma band activity 70hz to 100hz which wa partly compensated by additional mast exposure however neither the intervention nor eeg activity were significantly associated with behavioral partial report sensitivity in summary the present data suggest that glutamatergic neurotransmission across the nmdar is only one among many determinant of intact visual perception accordingly therapeutic do of dxm and their inhibitory modulation by stress probably yield more pronounced electroencephalographic a compared with behavioural effect

Title: Don't panic: interpretation bias is predictive of new onsets of panic disorder
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Zhang, X. C.; Becker, E. S.; McNally, R. J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: psychological model of panic disorder postulate that interpretation of ambiguous material a threatening is an important maintaining factor for the disorder however demonstration of whether such a bias predicts onset of panic disorder are missing in the present study we used data from the dresden prediction study in which a epidemiologic sample of young german woman wa tested at two time point approximately 17 month apart allowing the study of biased interpretation a a potential risk factor at time point one participant completed an interpretation questionnaire including two type of ambiguous scenario panic related and general threat related analysis revealed that a panic related interpretation bias predicted onset of panic disorder even after controlling for two established risk factor anxiety sensitivity and fear of bodily sensation this is the first prospective study demonstrating the incremental validity of interpretation bias a a predictor of panic disorder onset

Title: Eye contact during live social interaction in incarcerated psychopathic offenders
Authors: Gehrer, N. A.; Duchowski, A. T.; Jusyte, A.; Schonenberg, M.
Abstract: psychopathy is characterized by a lack of empathy callousness and a range of severe antisocial behavior a deficit to accurately process social cue which ha been widely documented in psychopathic population is assumed to underlie their pathological development impaired attention to socially salient cue such a the eye of an interaction partner is a possible mechanism compromising the development of social cognition preliminary evidence from static facial stimulus suggests that psychopathy is indeed linked to reduced eye gaze however no study to date ha investigated whether these mechanism apply to naturalistic interaction this study is the first to examine pattern of visual attention during live social interaction and their association with symptom cluster of psychopathy eye contact wa assessed in a sample of incarcerated offender n 30 during semistructured face to face interaction with a mobile eye tracking headset and analyzed using a novel automated area of interest e g eye region labeling technique the interaction included an exchange on neutral predetermined topic and included a condition in which the participant were active talking and passive listening the data reveal that across both listening and talking condition higher affective psychopathy is a significant predictor of reduced eye contact listening r 39 talking r 43 the present finding are in line with previous research suggesting impaired attention to social cue in psychopathy this study is the first to document these deficit in naturalistic live social interaction and therefore provides important evidence for their relevance to real life behavior psycinfo database record c 2020 apa all right reserved

Title: Situational expectations mediate the effect of global beliefs on depressive symptoms: a 1-year prospective study using a student sample
Authors: Kube, T.; Glombiewski, J. A.; Rief, W.
Abstract: purpose of review recent research suggests that expectation might be a particularly important subgroup of cognition in major depression the present study aimed to further specify the role of situation specific dysfunctional expectation sdes in the development of depressive symptom it wa hypothesized that the effect of intermediate belief and dispositional optimism on depressive symptom would be mediated via sdes recent finding we examined 125 student age m 22 05 sd 4 00 74 6 woman using a longitudinal design with a 1 year follow up questionnaire used in the study included the depressive expectation scale dysfunctional attitude scale life orientation test and beck s depression inventory when considering sdes at baseline a mediator variable neither intermediate belief nor dispositional optimism had significant direct effect on depressive symptom instead their effect were fully mediated via sdes when considering sdes at the follow up a the mediator variable sdes partly mediated the effect of intermediate belief and dispositional optimism on depressive symptom summary the study provides further evidence for a cognitive mediational model suggesting that sdes mediate the effect of rather global belief such a intermediate belief and dispositional optimism on depressive symptom due to their high level of situational specificity sdes might be an effective target for cognitive behavioural intervention

Title: Treatment Expectations Towards Different Pain Management Approaches: Two Perspectives
Authors: Schemer, L.; Rief, W.; Glombiewski, J. A.
Abstract: purpose accumulating evidence suggests an association between patient expectation and treatment success across various type of pain treatment expectation among treatment caregiver however are often neglected despite international treatment guideline only a small minority of chronic pain patient undergo psychological intervention therefore our aim wa to explore expectation among treatment receiver and caregiver especially concerning their attitude towards psychological pain treatment method two hundred ten potential treatment receiver n 85 individual suffering from chronic low back pain clbp n 125 healthy control and 237 caregiver n 75 physician n 64 psychotherapist n 98 physiotherapist provided rating of expected treatment success for standardized vignette describing patient suffering from clbp and undergoing a pharmacological psychological or multimodal pain management program result individual suffering from clbp generally had lower treatment expectation than healthy control both psychotherapist and physician had higher treatment expectation from their own individual treatment approach all participant expected the multimodal approach to be most effective the psychological approach wa expected to be more effective than the pharmacological approach except for the physician who expected both treatment approach to be equally effective conclusion there is an urgent need to clarify under which circumstance and how patient expectation can be altered among individual suffering from clbp our result appear to encourage the implementation of multimodal and psychological pain management approach across various setting we invite clinician to reflect whether their own expectation are in line with the recommendation in international treatment guideline

Title: Influence of executive functions on the self-reported health-related quality of life of children with ADHD
Authors: Schworer, M. C.; Reinelt, T.; Petermann, F.; Petermann, U.
Abstract: purpose adhd is regarded a a neurodevelopmental disorder associated with deficit in executive function ef the presence of these deficit is associated with increased symptom severity however so far there is little knowledge whether deficit in efs relate to a reduced health related quality of life hrqol in child with adhd method hence n 100 child with a confirmed adhd diagnosis were compared with a non case group n 100 with regard to their hrqol 6 12 year old the clinical group wa divided into adhd specific drug treatment intake drug treatment n 42 no drug treatment n 58 or deficit in ef n 29 no deficit in ef n 71 result child with adhd without medication reported a significantly worse hrqol than healthy child d 72 when controlled for age and sex even if they were treated with drug treatment they reported a lower hrqol than the non case group in the area family d 53 drug treatment of adhd lead to a significant difference in hrqol in school area d 39 child with adhd and ef problem reported impairment in the social context of hrqol compared to healthy child d 51 to 70 in addition a significant negative association between set shifting and hrqol in child with adhd without drug treatment wa demonstrated r 27 to r 35 conclusion by assessing the hrqol an impairment in the functioning of child with adhd can be detected which is essential for the diagnosis furthermore executive problem have an influence on the social sphere which should be clarified and improved in therapy with the involvement of parent

Title: Orthorexic eating behavior in patients with somatoform disorders
Authors: Barthels, F.; Muller, R.; Schuth, T.; Friederich, H. C.; Pietrowsky, R.
Abstract: purpose although anecdotal report suggest a relation between orthorexic eating behavior and symptom of somatoform disorder this issue ha not yet been investigated the aim of this study wa to compare orthorexic eating behavior and other characteristic of disordered eating behavior in patient with somatoform disorder to a sample of healthy control method 31 patient with somatoform disorder and 30 matched control completed eight questionnaire i a the dusseldorf orthorexia scale three scale of the eating disorder inventory 2 eating attitude test 26 multidimensional inventory of hypochondriacal trait attitude towards body and health questionnaire and screening for somatoform disorder result the patient displayed higher level of orthorexic eating behavior drive for thinness body dissatisfaction bulimia and dieting than the control group in both group orthorexic eating behavior wa associated with higher level of somatization in eating and health habit the control group showed an association of orthorexic eating behavior with catastrophizing cognition and the perceptual component of health anxiety conclusion the result support the hypothesis of a connection between orthorexic eating behavior and somatoform disorder however patient with somatoform disorder do not seem to be at particular risk for orthorexia future study should investigate cause for the relationship between orthorexic eating behavior and characteristic of somatoform disorder in sample of healthy individual level of evidence level v descriptive study with matched control group

Title: Decreasing the Burden of Side Effects Through Positive Message Framing: an Experimental Proof-of-Concept Study
Authors: Wilhelm, M.; Rief, W.; Doering, B. K.
Abstract: purpose informing patient about treatment side effect increase the occurrence and intensity of side effect since the obligatory informed consent procedure in drug treatment requires transparency and nocebo research suggests that the informed consent of a drug lead to an increased occurrence of the mentioned side effect the aim of this proof of concept study wa to determine the effect of two different framing of informed consent on the occurrence intensity and perceived threat of side effect method healthy male participant n 80 were randomized to one of two framing group the positive framing group wa informed that the common side effect dizziness wa a sign that the drug had started to work while the neutral framing group wa told that dizziness is an unpleasant but well known side effect side effect were measured after the administration of metoprolol an antihypertensive agent post hoc moderator analysis investigated the effect of pre existing negative belief about the general harm of medication on the framing manipulation result metoprolol specific drug attributed side effect were rated significantly le threatening in the positive framing group the between group effect size cohen s d wa small d 0 38 p 0 049 exploratory post hoc moderator analysis suggest that participant who believed that medication is a source of harmful effect benefited from positive framing compared to neutral framing of drug attributed side effect conclusion positive framing wa partially effective in decreasing specific side effect measure particularly among participant with a tendency to believe that medicine is harmful informed consent procedure should therefore be personalized focusing on patient with negative treatment belief

Title: Mild Depression in Low Back Pain: the Interaction of Thought Suppression and Stress Plays a Role, Especially in Female Patients
Authors: Konietzny, K.; Chehadi, O.; Streitlein-Bohme, I.; Rusche, H.; Willburger, R.; Hasenbring, M. I.
Abstract: purpose mild depression ha been shown a a precursor and a a consequence of low back pain even in early phase of acute or subacute pain chronic daily life stress a well a dysfunctional pain related cognition such a thought suppression t seem to play a role in the pain depression cycle however the mechanism of these association are le understood experimentally induced t conceived a the attempt to directly suppress sensation such a pain ha been shown to paradoxically cause a delayed and non volitional return of the suppressed thought and sensation and to increase affective distress these dysfunctional process are supposed to increase under high cognitive load such a high stress method in the present cross sectional study we for the first time sought to examine a possible interaction between habitual t and stress on depression in n 177 patient with subacute low back pain slbp using the following questionnaire subscale thought suppression from avoidance endurance questionnaire beck depression inventory and kiel interview of subjective situation a three way anova wa conducted with two group of t high low stress high low and sex a independent factor and depression a dependent result result indicated a significant three way interaction with highest depression score in female patient showing high t and high stress overall main effect for sex and stress indicated higher depression in woman and in highly stressed patient conclusion our finding support the hypothesis that t heightens depressive mood under condition of high cognitive load especially in female patient with slbp indicating a special vulnerability for depressive mood in woman with slbp

Title: Acceptance and barriers to access of occupational e-mental health: cross-sectional findings from a health-risk population of employees
Authors: Hennemann, S.; Witthoft, M.; Bethge, M.; Spanier, K.; Beutel, M. E.; Zwerenz, R.
Abstract: purpose occupational e mental health oemh may extend existing instrument for preservation or restoration of health and work ability a a key precondition to efficient implementation this study examined acceptance and person centered barrier to potential uptake of oemh for work related distress in employee with an elevated risk of early retirement method within the framework of the third german sociomedical panel of employee 1829 employee with prior sickness absence payment filled out a self administered questionnaire participant had a mean age of 49 93 year sd 4 06 6 2 indicated prior use of ehealth intervention potential predictor of acceptance of oemh were examined based on the unified theory of acceptance and use of technology utaut extended by work ability mental health ehealth literacy and demographic characteristic result 89 1 n 1579 showed low to moderate acceptance m 2 20 sd 1 05 range 1 5 a path analysis revealed significant positive direct effect of utaut predictor on acceptance performance expectancy 0 48 se 0 02 p 0 001 effort expectancy 0 20 se 0 02 p 0 001 social influence 0 28 se 0 02 p 0 001 online time and frequency of online health information search were further positive direct predictor of acceptance model fit wa good chi 2 7 12 91 p 0 07 rmsea 0 02 cfi 1 00 tli 0 99 srmr 0 01 conclusion attitude towards oemh are rather disadvantageous in the studied risk group implementation of oemh therefore requires a priori education including promotion of awareness favorable attitude regarding efficacy and usability in a collaborative approach

Title: Orthorexic eating behaviour as a coping strategy in patients with anorexia nervosa
Authors: Barthels, F.; Meyer, F.; Huber, T.; Pietrowsky, R.
Abstract: purpose orthorexia nervosa is defined a the fixation on health conscious eating behaviour and ha recently been discussed a a new variant of disordered eating the aim of the present study wa to analyse orthorexic eating behaviour in an inpatient treatment sample of female anorexic to investigate the relation between anorexic and orthorexic eating behaviour method female anorexic patient with low n 29 and pronounced n 13 orthorexic eating behaviour a well a a matched control group composed of healthy female n 30 were compared with regard to several aspect of disordered eating hypochondriacal trait food consumption frequency and fulfilment of basic psychological need in term of eating orthorexic eating behaviour wa assessed using the dusseldorfer orthorexie skala result fulfilment of basic psychological need with respect to autonomy and competence is higher in anorexic individual with pronounced orthorexic eating behaviour compared to patient with low orthorexic eating behaviour furthermore patient with pronounced orthorexic eating behaviour state eating healthy food regardless of calorie content more often no difference wa found for hypochondriacal trait and eating disordered symptom in general conclusion orthorexic eating behaviour enhances self perception of eating behaviour a autonomous and competent indicating that it might serve a a coping strategy in anorexic individual further research is needed to investigate if this tendency in food selection strategy lead to positive effect in the long term

Title: Orthorexic and restrained eating behaviour in vegans, vegetarians, and individuals on a diet
Authors: Barthels, F.; Meyer, F.; Pietrowsky, R.
Abstract: purpose orthorexic eating behaviour restrained eating and veganism vegetarianism are food selection strategy sharing several characteristic since there are no study investigating their interrelationship aim of the present study wa to analyse orthorexic and restrained eating behaviour in 1 a sample of vegan and vegetarian and 2 a sample of individual on a diet to lose weight method division of sample according to pre defined criterion in 1 vegan n 114 vegetarian n 63 individual with rare meat consumption n 83 and individual with frequent meat consumption n 91 and in 2 participant on a diet with dietary change n 104 without dietary change n 37 and a control group of individual not on a diet n 258 orthorexic eating behaviour wa assessed with the dusseldorfer orthorexie skala and restrained eating wa assessed with the restraint eating scale result vegan and vegetarian do not differ in orthorexic eating behaviour but both group score higher in orthorexic eating behaviour than individual consuming red meat there are no difference regarding restrained eating individual on a diet with dietary change score higher in both orthorexic and restrained eating than individual without dietary change and individual not on a diet conclusion individual who restrict their eating behaviour either predominantly due to ethical reason or with the intention to lose weight display more orthorexic eating behaviour than individual not limiting their food consumption further research is needed to investigate whether veganism vegetarianism or frequent dieting behaviour serve a risk factor for orthorexia level of evidence level v cross sectional descriptive study

Title: Different work capacity impairments in patients with different work-anxieties
Authors: Muschalla, B.
