Abstract: purpose person with work anxiety are especially endangered for work capacity impairment and sick leave work capacity impairment is not directly due to symptom but due to illness related capacity disorder work capacity impairment can be described on different dimension e g social interaction decision making and judgment endurance mobility understanding the type of work capacity impairment is important for reintegration intervention this is the first study to investigate work capacity impairment in risk patient with different work anxiety method two hundred and forty four patient in inpatient rehabilitation suffering from work anxiety were investigated concerning degree of work capacity impairment capacity impairment wa described on 13 capacity dimension according to the internationally evaluated observer rating mini icf app impairment grade 0 4 grade 2 and higher indicating clinically relevant observable impairment a physician s rating on global work ability prognosis wa obtained along with sick leave duration during 6 month after assessment patient with different work anxiety were compared concerning capacity impairment result patient with different work anxiety were impaired in different capacity dimension work related social anxiety went along with clinically relevant impairment in capacity of assertiveness m 2 40 anxiety of insufficiency went along with impaired capacity of endurance m 2 20 and work related generalized worrying wa accompanied by impairment in the capacity for decision making m 1 82 specific capacity impairment dimension were related to sick leave duration while a global work ability prognosis wa not conclusion the capacity approach is useful to describe work impairment more precisely and beyond symptom on this basis reintegration focusing intervention such a capacity training e g social interaction training or work adjustment e g reducing exposure with interactional work task can be initiated

Title: Predicting Self-Rated Health in Diabetes and Chronic Heart Failure - A Multiple Mediation Model
Authors: Bohme, S.; Renneberg, B.
Abstract: purpose self rated health srh is a powerful predictor of health related outcome such a morbidity and mortality aim of the current study wa to examine the role of comorbidity well being functional health and physical limitation a possible predictor of srh in diabetes and chronic heart failure chf method three large sample with person suffering from diabetes n 974 chf n 955 or both disease combined n 934 were analyzed longitudinally over the course of 4 month to test the mediating effect of comorbidity well being functional health and physical limitation in association with former and future srh multiple mediator model were applied result across all group emotional well being wa a consistent and powerful determinant of srh the effect of functional health and physical limitation on srh were also significant but varied between diagnostic group the number of comorbid disease did not predict srh conclusion emotional well being and physical health appraisal were strong predictor of srh thus srh may be improved by influencing well being and physical health appraisal via targeted intervention

Title: Somatosensory Amplification Is a Predictor of Self-Reported Side Effects in the Treatment of Primary Hypertension: a Pilot Study
Authors: Doering, B. K.; Szecsi, J.; Bardos, G.; Koteles, F.
Abstract: purpose side effect consist of drug specific and non specific symptom both component are based on bodily sensation that a person perceives after taking a drug and subsequently attribute to the drug we suggest that somatosensory amplification ssa may explain a proportion of inter individual difference in report of side effect that cannot be accounted for by drug specific safety profile this hypothesis wa investigated in hypertensive patient starting a new pharmacotherapy method this longitudinal study included 50 patient 66 woman aged 55 14 year with a diagnosis of primary hypertension patient completed the somatosensory amplification scale ssa started to take their new medication and recorded side effect on a daily basis for 4 week result after controlling for age gender number of pill taken and previous personal and family experience with medication side effect in the regression analysis ssa score remained a significant predictor of reported side effect over the entire study period week 1 and 2 beta 621 p 001 week 3 and 4 beta 493 p 003 in a subsample comprising patient taking the four most commonly used drug regime ssa wa a significant predictor of side effect even when controlling for type of medication conclusion in this sample of patient undergoing anti hypertensive pharmacotherapy higher ssa score predicted increased report of medication side effect to account for this tendency and to improve compliance with medication regime this group may require special education about the nocebo phenomenon

Title: Unemployment and mental health in the German population: the role of subjective social status
Authors: Neubert, M.; Sussenbach, P.; Rief, W.; Euteneuer, F.
Abstract: purpose subjective social status s reflects individual perceived position in a social hierarchy low s is associated with several mental health impairment the aim of this cross sectional study wa to examine if unemployed individual report lower s in germany national s and lower s in their social community local s than employed individual moreover the relationship between unemployment s and mental health wa examined patient and method 113 unemployed and 1117 employed individual from a representative german panel provided information on their national and local s their monthly income and their mental health s wa assessed with the german version of the macarthur scale mental health wa measured using the mental component scale mc of the sf 12 result unemployed individual reported significantly lower national s local s and mental health compared to employed participant mediational analysis suggest that the negative effect of employment status on mental health wa explained via a reduction of national s local s did not mediate the association of employment status and mental health conclusion unemployment is associated with lower s and reduced mental health the perceived position relative to others in the country ie national s mediates the association between employment status and mental health

Title: CBT-I and HT-I group therapy for adults with insomnia in comparison to those with insomnia and comorbid depression - a pilot study
Authors: Schlarb, A. A.; Faber, J.; Hautzinger, M.
Abstract: purpose the aim of this study wa to examine the effectiveness of a combined cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia cbt i and hypnotherapy for insomnia ht i program for insomnia patient with or without additional depression regarding depressive symptom and various sleep parameter patient and method a sample of 63 patient suffering from insomnia received a six session sleep intervention which combined cognitive behavioral and hypnotherapeutical element due to violating exclusion criterion data of 37 patient were analyzed ten patient had insomnia comorbid with depression whereas 27 patient had insomnia only sleep diary were implemented to measure various sleep parameter whereas depressive symptomatology wa assessed with the anxiety and depression scale and symptom checklist 90 r at baseline before and after the intervention a well a at 3 month follow up result depressive symptom decreased from pre to post measurement and follow up for patient with insomnia comorbid with depression whereas score of patient with only insomnia remained relatively on a low level both group showed a significant increase of sleep efficiency and a significant decrease of the duration of wake after sleep onset however only patient with insomnia and depression revealed a significant reduction of sleep onset latency and a higher level of regeneration nondepressive insomniac on the other hand showed a significant increase of performance from post measurement to follow up for both group no change over time wa found for number of wake after sleep onset total sleep time mood in the morning and evening conclusion combining cbt i and ht i is effective in reducing depressive symptom and improving sleep therefore nonresponders to other form of therapy eg pharmacological interpersonal or cognitive behavioral therapy might benefit from the combined cbt i ht i intervention

Title: Orthorexic eating behavior in vegans is linked to health, not to animal welfare
Authors: Barthels, F.; Poerschke, S.; Muller, R.; Pietrowsky, R.
Abstract: purpose this study aimed to analyze the association between the importance of several reason to follow a vegan diet and the degree of orthorexic eating behavior in a sample of vegan individual n 65 53 8 woman age m 28 22 sd 9 13 year bmi m 22 91 sd 3 44 kg m 2 result the result reveal that orthorexic eating behavior is associated with the importance of the underlying motif health esthetic and healing whereas animal welfare politics and ecology are not linked to orthorexia conclusion hence this study reveals that a vegan lifestyle is not per se associated with orthorexic eating behavior but rather that it varies with the underlying motivation for following a vegan diet

Title: Orthorexic eating behaviour, illness anxiety and dysfunctional cognitions characteristic of somatic symptom disorders in a non-clinical sample
Authors: Barthels, F.; Horn, S.; Pietrowsky, R.
Abstract: purpose to analyse the relation of illness anxiety dysfunctional cognition characteristic of somatic symptom disorder and orthorexic eating behaviour in a non clinical sample method n 445 participant n 363 female completed an online survey with the following questionnaire the dusseldorf orthorexia scale to measure orthorexic eating behaviour the attitude towards body and health questionnaire to a dysfunctional cognition concerning the perception and interpretation of bodily sensation and the multidimensional inventory of hypochondriacal trait to measure illness anxiety result in the total sample orthorexic eating behaviour wa associated with the aforementioned variable to a very low extent however individual with high level of orthorexic eating behaviour n 19 displayed significantly higher level of health habit and of perception of autonomic sensation a well a higher level of hypochondriacal worry and absorption than individual with low level of orthorexic eating behaviour n 19 conclusion orthorexic eating behaviour is associated to some characteristic feature of illness anxiety and dysfunctional cognition characteristic of somatic symptom disorder future study should investigate whether illness anxiety serf a a risk factor for the development of orthorexic eating behaviour level of evidence iii case control analytic study

Title: Orthorexic eating behavior and body dissatisfaction in a sample of young females
Authors: Barthels, F.; Kisser, J.; Pietrowsky, R.
Abstract: purpose to analyze body dissatisfaction in relation to orthorexic eating behavior in a sample of young female to further investigate characteristic feature of orthorexic eating behavior and it association with other eating disorder method n 197 young female age m 29 59 sd 10 85 year completed an online survey with the following questionnaire the dusseldorf orthorexia scale to measure orthorexic eating behavior the eating disorder inventory 2 edi 2 measuring psychopathological aspect of disordered eating behavior the dresden body image questionnaire dkb 35 to measure five component of body image and the body shape questionnaire bsq measuring body dissatisfaction result in the total sample pearson correlation revealed that orthorexic eating behavior wa positively associated with drive for thinness and body dissatisfaction an independent sample t test revealed that female with elevated level of orthorexic eating behavior n 35 displayed higher level of drive for thinness and body dissatisfaction and lower level of self acceptance in comparison to a randomized sample from the remaining female with low level of orthorexic eating behavior n 35 according to a multiple regression analysis drive for thinness and body dissatisfaction measured by the bsq served a positive predictor for orthorexic eating behavior whereas bulimia and body dissatisfaction measured by the edi 2 served a negative predictor conclusion result reveal that orthorexic eating behavior is more closely related to psychopathological aspect of other eating disorder than previously assumed body dissatisfaction a another major feature of orthorexia nervosa should be taken into account in future study level of evidence iii case control analytic study

Title: No elevated levels of orthorexic eating behavior in a sample of adults with allergies and food intolerances
Authors: Barthels, F.; Bamberg, L.; Pietrowsky, R.
Abstract: purpose to compare orthorexic eating behavior in a sample of adult with and without self reported allergy and food intolerance method n 52 individual with and n 102 individual without self reported allergy and food intolerance 80 with medical diagnosis in total 74 6 female 23 7 male age m 28 13 sd 11 96 year completed an online survey with the dusseldorf orthorexia scale and answered several question regarding their allergy intolerance result the group did not differ in their orthorexic eating behavior in the sample of individual with allergy intolerance orthorexic eating behavior correlated with the perceived severity of the allergic symptom and the number of consequence that the allergy had for eating behavior conclusion in line with previous finding orthorexic eating behavior doe not seem to be elevated in individual with allergy intolerance however focusing on a healthy diet despite adverse food reaction and experiencing a number of allergy related consequence for one s eating behavior might be associated with orthorexic eating behavior level of evidence iii case control analytic study

Title: Prospective pilot study to identify psychological factors influencing peri-operative pain in total knee arthroplasty (TKA)
Authors: Schuster, V.; Kinne, R. W.; Knoll, N.; Konczol, C.; Anders, J. O.
Abstract: purpose up to 20 of total knee arthroplasty tka patient remain dissatisfied with chronic pain a the most frequently named cause a pilot study wa conducted to a the progression of peri operative pain intensity and the parallel development of different psychological factor and coping strategy a well a correlation indicating potential inter relationship method pain psychological impairment fesv be and coping strategy fesv bw were assessed before and after tka day 5 to 31 patient were stratified according to the presence or absence of peri operative pain improvement decreasing pain group 1 69 n 36 persisting pain group 2 31 n 16 group 2 wa additionally tested with the toronto alexithymia scale ta and screening for somatoform disorder som result pain intensity in group 1 decreased from significantly higher pre operative level to significantly lower value at 31 day post operatively whereas group 2 did not show significant change concurrently the psychological impairment parameter anxiety an significantly decreased and the pain coping parameter relaxation significantly increased in group 1 but not in group 2 whereas pre operative pain wa positively and significantly correlated with an throughout time in group 2 it wa negatively correlated with relaxation at day 29 in group 1 concerning ta and som considerable percentage of the participant in group 2 37 5 and 68 75 respectively showed value 50 of those in normal control conclusion parallel or anti parallel and partially correlated development of pain improvement and parameter of psychological impairment or coping strategy after tka suggest a pre operative screening with tool like the fesv be and bw or ta and som questionnaire in order to classify individual for peri operative mental training

Title: Mental health problem or workplace problem or something else: what contributes to work perception?
Authors: Muschalla, B.; Henning, A.; Haake, T. W.; Cornetz, K.; Olbrich, D.
Abstract: purpose work perception is an important predictor for work ability and therefore of interest for rehabilitation until now it is unclear to which extent different psychological aspect explain work perception this study investigates in which way workplace problem on the one hand and mental health and coping on the other hand contribute to work perception method a heterogeneous sample of 384 person in working age with and without mental health problem wa recruited participant gave self report on workplace problem mental health problem work coping work anxiety and work perception result person with mental health problem and workplace problem m w perceive the highest degree of work demand followed by person with workplace problem but without mental health problem nm w work anxiety appeared a the strongest factor explaining perception of high work demand whereas general mental health problem did not contribute significantly to variance explanation conclusion person with specific mental health problem in term of work anxiety may be expected to perceive higher work demand they may be detected when asking for work perception e g within the frame of return to work intervention in rehabilitation or in occupational health setting by mental hazard analysis implication for rehabilitationwork perception is an important predictor for work ability work anxiety play a key role for work perception thus work perception and work anxiety should be explored in the diagnostic phase of rehabilitation treatment work anxiety should be considered not only in rehabilitation diagnostics and intervention in clinical setting but considered in preventive activity at work self rating on work anxiety and work perception instead of general wellbeing may be included in assessment for workplace exploration or mental hazard analysis they give hint concerning concrete work related health problem

Title: The developmental trajectories of racial and gender intergroup bias in 5- to 10-year-old children: The impact of general psychological tendencies, contextual factors, and individual propensities
Authors: Misch, A.; Dunham, Y.; Paulus, M.
Abstract: racism and intergroup discrimination are pervasive problem in human society whereas several study have shown that child show bias in the context of many kind of group much le is known about how and when general psychological tendency and contextual factor contribute to the manifestation of intergroup bias across development and whether individual difference play a role in the present study we pursue these question by investigating and comparing the developmental trajectory of intergroup bias in 5 to 10 year old mostly white child n 100 we assessed child s liking and preference towards 4 racial group white east asian black and middle eastern and towards 2 gender group male and female in a within subject design we found that the young child in our sample showed a significant racial and gender ingroup bias speaking to an early and strong manifestation of intergroup bias on the basic ingroup outgroup distinction this bias decreased with age at the same time we found considerable difference between the different type of outgroups from early on furthermore there were remarkable difference between the developmental trajectory of gender and racial intergroup bias highlighting the role of both social and contextual influence finally our result did not reveal consistent evidence for the influence of individual difference on child s intergroup bias

Title: Cortical thickness and trait empathy in patients and people at high risk for alcohol use disorders
Authors: Schmidt, T.; Roser, P.; Ze, O.; Juckel, G.; Suchan, B.; Thoma, P.
Abstract: rationale alcoholism not only affect individual with alcohol use disorder aud but also their biological relative this high risk hr group ha a higher probability to develop aud the aim of our study wa to compare cortical thickness ct in aud patient relative to participant with hr and without non hr familial predisposition for aud we focused on empathy related brain area a sociocognitive impairment represents a known risk factor for aud method we examined 13 individual with aud 14 hr individual and 20 non hr participant using high resolution t1 weighted magnetic resonance image 3 tesla to investigate difference in ct ct wa correlated with self reported empathy in empathy related area result aud patient showed decreased ct in the left inferior and superior frontal gyrus the right precuneus and bilaterally in the middle frontal gyrus the insula relative to the hr group and in the left insula the right middle frontal gyrus and bilaterally in the superior frontal gyrus the precuneus relative to the non hr group all p 0 036 all n p 2 between 0 161 and 0 375 reduced ct in inferior middle and superior frontal gyrus wa related to cognitive all p 0 036 and reduced ct in the inferior frontal gyrus to affective p 0 031 empathy conclusion we present preliminary evidence of ct reduction in empathy associated brain region in patient with aud relative to healthy participant with and without familial predisposition for aud the result have to be interpreted with caution due to low sample size and potential confounding effect of medication gender and withdrawal

Title: The relationship between executive functioning and addictive behavior: new insights from a longitudinal community study
Authors: Kraplin, A.; Joshanloo, M.; Wolff, M.; Kronke, K. M.; Goschke, T.; Buhringer, G.; Smolka, M. N.
Abstract: rationale although there is evidence that impaired executive functioning play a role in addictive behavior the longitudinal relationship between the two remains relatively unknown objective in a prospective longitudinal community study we tested the hypothesis that lower executive functioning is associated with more addictive behavior at one point in time and over time method three hundred and thirty eight individual 19 27 year 59 female from a random community sample were recruited into three group addictive disorder related to substance n 100 or to behavior n 118 or healthy control n 120 at baseline participant completed nine executive function task from which a latent variable of general executive functioning gef wa derived addictive behavior i e quantity and frequency of use and number of dsm 5 criterion met were assessed using standardized clinical interview at baseline and three annual follow ups the trajectory of addictive behavior were examined using latent growth curve modeling result at baseline we found weak to no evidence of an association between gef and addictive behavior we found evidence for an association between a lower gef at baseline and a higher increase in the quantity of use and a smaller decrease in frequency of use over time but no evidence for an association with an increase in the number of dsm 5 criterion met conclusion lower efs appear to lead to a continuing loss of control over use whereas addictive disorder may develop secondarily after a long period of risky use previous etiological model assuming lower ef a a direct vulnerability factor for addictive disorder need to be refined

Title: Effects of anxiety sensitivity and expectations on the modulation of the startle eyeblink response during a caffeine challenge
Authors: Benke, C.; Blumenthal, T. D.; Modess, C.; Hamm, A. O.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: rationale the way in which the tendency to fear somatic arousal sensation anxiety sensitivity in interaction with the created expectation regarding arousal induction might affect defensive responding to a symptom provocation challenge is not yet understood objective the present study investigated the effect of anxiety sensitivity on autonomic arousal startle eyeblink response and reported arousal and alertness to expected v unexpected caffeine consumption method to create a match mismatch of expected and experienced arousal high and low anxiety sensitive participant received caffeine v no drug either mixed in coffee expectation of arousal induction or in bitter lemon soda no expectation of arousal induction on four separate occasion autonomic arousal heart rate skin conductance level respiration end tidal co2 minute ventilation defensive reflex response startle eyeblink and reported arousal and alertness were recorded prior to immediately and 30 min after beverage ingestion result caffeine increased ventilation autonomic arousal and startle response magnitude both group showed comparable level of autonomic and respiratory response the startle eyeblink response were decreased when caffeine induced arousal occurred unexpectedly e g after administering caffeine in bitter lemon this effect wa more accentuated in high anxiety sensitive person moreover in high anxiety sensitive person the expectation of arousal coffee consumption led to higher subjective alertness when administering caffeine and increased arousal even if no drug wa consumed conclusion unexpected symptom provocation lead to increased attention allocation toward feared arousal sensation in high anxiety sensitive person this finding broadens our understanding of modulatory mechanism in defensive responding to bodily symptom

Title: Anxiety sensitivity and expectation of arousal differentially affect the respiratory response to caffeine
Authors: Pane-Farre, C. A.; Alius, M. G.; Modess, C.; Methling, K.; Blumenthal, T.; Hamm, A. O.
Abstract: rationale this study aimed to test how expectation and anxiety sensitivity influence respiratory and autonomic response to caffeine objective the current study investigated the effect of expected v unexpected caffeine ingestion in a group of person prone to the anxiety provoking effect of caffeine high anxiety sensitive person that is person scoring at least one sd above the mean on the anxiety sensitivity index peterson and reiss 1992 a compared to low anxious control method autonomic arousal heart rate skin conductance level respiratory responding expired co2 minute ventilation and subjective report were assessed in high and low anxiety sensitive participant immediately after beverage consumption and at absorption peak 30 min post consumption in four separate session during which either coffee expectation of caffeine or bitter lemon soda no expectation of caffeine wa crossed with 4 mg kg caffeine v no drug result high and low anxiety sensitive person showed comparable autonomic arousal and symptom report to caffeine which wa modulated by expectation i e greater for coffee respiratory responding co2 decrease minute ventilation increase wa more accentuated when caffeine wa both expected and administered in the low anxiety sensitive group but more accentuated when caffeine wa unexpectedly administered in the high anxiety sensitive group autonomic arousal and respiratory effect were observable within a few minute after caffeine administration and were most pronounced at maximum absorption conclusion the result highlight the modulating role of expectancy in respiratory responding to caffeine in low v high anxiety sensitive person and might have important implication for the better understanding of unexpected panic attack

Title: Human olfactory lateralization requires trigeminal activation
Authors: Croy, I.; Schulz, M.; Blumrich, A.; Hummel, C.; Gerber, J.; Hummel, T.
Abstract: rat are able to lateralize odor this ability involves specialized neuron in the orbitofrontal cortex which are able to process the left right and bilateral presentation of stimulus however it is not clear whether this function is preserved in human human are in general not able to differentiate whether a selective olfactory stimulant ha been applied to the left or right nostril however exception have been reported following a screening of 152 individual with an olfactory lateralization test we identified 19 who could lateralize odor above chance level 15 of these lateralizers underwent olfactory fmri scanning in a block design and were compared to 15 control matched for age and sex distribution a a result both group showed comparable activation of olfactory eloquent brain area however subject with lateralization ability had a significantly enhanced activation of cerebral trigeminal processing area somatosensory cortex intraparietal sulcus in contrast to control lateralizers furthermore exhibited no suppression in the area of the trigeminal principal sensory nucleus an exploratory study with an olfactory change detection paradigm furthermore showed that lateralizers oriented faster towards change in the olfactory environment taken together our study suggests that the trigeminal system is activated to a higher degree by the odorous stimulus in the group of lateralizers we conclude that human are not able to lateralize odor based on the olfactory input alone but vary in the degree to which the trigeminal system is recruited

Title: From Abstract Symbols to Emotional (In-)Sights: An Eye Tracking Study on the Effects of Emotional Vignettes and Pictures
Authors: Usee, F.; Jacobs, A. M.; Ludtke, J.
Abstract: reading is known to be a highly complex emotion inducing process usually involving connected and cohesive sequence of sentence and paragraph however most empirical result especially from study using eye tracking are either restricted to simple linguistic material e g isolated word single sentence or disregard valence driven effect the present study addressed the need for ecologically valid stimulus by examining the emotion potential of and reading behavior in emotional vignette often used in applied psychological context and discourse comprehension to allow for a cross domain comparison in the area of emotion induction negatively and positively valenced vignette were constructed based on pre selected emotional picture from the nencki affective picture system nap marchewka et al 2014 we collected rating of perceived valence and arousal for both material group and recorded eye movement of 42 participant during reading and picture viewing linear mixed effect model were performed to analyze effect of valence i e valence category valence rating and stimulus domain i e textual pictorial on rating of perceived valence and arousal eye movement in reading and eye movement in picture viewing result supported the success of our experimental manipulation emotionally positive stimulus i e vignette picture were perceived more positively and le arousing than emotionally negative one the cross domain comparison indicated that vignette are able to induce stronger valence effect than their pictorial counterpart no difference between vignette and picture regarding effect on perceived arousal were found analysis of eye movement in reading replicated result from experiment using isolated word and sentence perceived positive text valence attracted shorter reading time than perceived negative valence at both the supralexical and lexical level in line with previous finding no emotion effect on eye movement in picture viewing were found this is the first eye tracking study reporting superior valence effect for vignette compared to picture and valence specific effect on eye movement in reading at the supralexical level

Title: Effects of pre-encoding stress on brain correlates associated with the long-term memory for emotional scenes
Authors: Wirkner, J.; Weymar, M.; Low, A.; Hamm, A. O.
Abstract: recent animal and human research indicates that stress around the time of encoding enhances long term memory for emotionally arousing event but neural evidence remains unclear in the present study we used the erp old new effect to investigate brain dynamic underlying the long term effect of acute pre encoding stress on memory for emotional and neutral scene participant were exposed either to the socially evaluated cold pressure test secpt or a warm water control procedure before viewing 30 unpleasant 30 neutral and 30 pleasant picture two week after encoding recognition memory wa tested using 90 old and 90 new picture emotional picture were better recognized than neutral picture in both group and related to an enhanced centro parietal erp old new difference 400 800 m during recognition which suggests better recollection most interestingly pre encoding stress exposure specifically increased the erp old new effect for emotional unpleasant picture but not for neutral picture these enhanced erp old new difference for emotional unpleasant scene were particularly pronounced for those participant who reported high level of stress during the secpt the result suggest that acute pre encoding stress specifically strengthens brain signal of emotional memory substantiating a facilitating role of stress on memory for emotional scene

Title: Reprint of "Effortful control, depression, and anxiety correlate with the influence of emotion on executive attentional control"
Authors: Kanske, P.; Kotz, S. A.
Abstract: recent evidence confirms that emotion can trigger executive attentional control participant resolve conflict faster when encountering emotionally negative or positive stimulus this effect is accompanied by an enlarged conflict negativity in event related brain potential erps and activation of the ventral anterior cingulate cortex acc in fmri here we tested whether temperament the trait effortful control and subclinical factor anxiety depression can influence the emotional modulation of executive attention these factor correlated with conflict processing in six experiment that utilized different conflict task flanker simon and different type of emotional stimulus visual auditory participant high in effortful control and low in anxiety and depression responded faster to conflict processing in emotional stimulus showed an enhanced erp conflict negativity and additional activation in the ventral acc the data show that temperamental effortful control depression and anxiety are related to the influence of emotion on executive attention and it underlying neural correlate

Title: Effects of Caricaturing in Shape or Color on Familiarity Decisions for Familiar and Unfamiliar Faces
Authors: Itz, M. L.; Schweinberger, S. R.; Kaufmann, J. M.
Abstract: recent evidence suggests that while reflectance information including color may be more diagnostic for familiar face recognition shape may be more diagnostic for unfamiliar face identity processing moreover event related potential erp finding suggest an earlier onset for neural processing of facial shape compared to reflectance in the current study we aimed to explore specifically the role of facial shape and color in a familiarity decision task using pre experimentally familiar famous and unfamiliar face that were caricatured either in shape only color only or both full shape color by 15 30 or 45 we recorded accuracy mean reaction time and face sensitive erps performance data revealed that shape caricaturing facilitated identity processing for unfamiliar face only in the erp data such effect of shape caricaturing emerged earlier than those of color caricaturing unsurprisingly erp effect were accentuated for larger level of caricaturing overall our finding corroborate the importance of shape for identity processing of unfamiliar face and demonstrate an earlier onset of neural processing for facial shape compared to color

Title: Caricature generalization benefits for faces learned with enhanced idiosyncratic shape or texture
Authors: Itz, M. L.; Schweinberger, S. R.; Kaufmann, J. M.
Abstract: recent finding show benefit for learning and subsequent recognition of face caricatured in shape or texture but there is little evidence on whether this caricature learning advantage generalizes to recognition of veridical counterpart at test moreover it ha been reported that there is a relatively higher contribution of texture information at the expense of shape information for familiar compared to unfamiliar face recognition the aim of this study wa to examine whether veridical face are recognized better when they were learned a caricature compared to when they were learned a veridicals what we call a caricature generalization benefit photorealistic facial stimulus derived from a 3 d camera system were caricatured selectively in either shape or texture by 50 face were learned across different image either a veridicals shape caricature or texture caricature at test all learned and novel face were presented a previously unseen frontal veridicals and participant performed an old new task we assessed accuracy reaction time and face sensitive event related potential erps face learned a caricature were recognized more accurately than face learned a veridicals at learning n250 and lpc were largest for shape caricature suggesting encoding advantage of distinctive facial shape at test lpc wa largest for face that had been learned a texture caricature indicating the importance of texture for familiar face recognition overall our finding demonstrate that caricature learning advantage can generalize to and importantly improve recognition of veridical version of face

Title: Rumination but not distraction increases eating-related symptoms in anorexia and bulimia nervosa
Authors: Naumann, E.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.; Voderholzer, U.; Caffier, D.; Svaldi, J.
Abstract: recent model of eating disorder emphasize the importance of ruminative thinking in the occurrence of unhealthy eating behavior hence the aim of the current study wa to examine the influence of induced rumination and distraction on the desire to engage in eating related symptom in anorexia an and bulimia nervosa bn after a sadness induction either a ruminative or distractive emotion regulation style wa encouraged in woman with an n 38 bn n 37 and non eating disordered control cg n 36 at baseline and after the emotion regulation induction feeling of sadness desire to abstain from eating dta and desire to binge dtb were assessed main result reveal that rumination led to a significant increase of dta in the an group and of dtb in patient with bn in the cg dta significantly decreased after distraction although there were significant increase in subjective sadness in the rumination condition no change were found in the distraction condition the result suggest that rumination in response to sadness ha a detrimental effect on eating related symptom in eating disorder

Title: On the role of sadness in the psychopathology of anorexia nervosa
Authors: Naumann, E.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.; Voderholzer, U.; Svaldi, J.
Abstract: recent model on the development and maintenance of eating disorder propose negative emotion to be important precursor for the occurrence of eating disorder symptomatology in fact previous research on bulimia nervosa bn and binge eating disorder provides evidence that negative emotion are an antecedent condition for binge eating however there is a lack of research examining the influence of negative emotion on restrictive eating and exercising in individual with anorexia nervosa an in an experimental study woman with an n 39 and bn n 34 a well a a non eating disordered control group cg n 34 watched a sadness inducing film clip before and after the film clip participant rated their current desire to engage in dietary restriction dtr and desire to exercise dte main result reveal that dtr significantly increased after the film clip in woman with an only while dte decreased over time in all group result are in line with the notion that negative emotion have a prominent influence on the core eating pathology in an

Title: The Relationship of Acculturation, Traumatic Events and Depression in Female Refugees
Authors: Starck, A.; Gutermann, J.; Schouler-Ocak, M.; Jesuthasan, J.; Bongard, S.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: recent research ha identified significant correlation between traumatic event and depression in refugee however few study have addressed the role of acculturation strategy in this relationship this study explored the relationship between cultural orientation traumatic event and depression in female refugee from syria afghanistan eritrea iran iraq and somalia living in germany we expected acculturation strategy to moderate the effect of traumatic experience on depression the sample included 98 female refugee in germany the depression scale of the hopkins symptom checklist hscl represented the dependent measure the trauma checklist derived from the post traumatic diagnostic scale pd and the harvard trauma questionnaire htq a well a the frankfurt acculturation scale fracc were used a independent measure for traumatic event and orientation toward the host culture a well a orientation toward the culture of origin respectively a moderation analysis wa conducted to examine whether the relationship between the number of traumatic event and depression wa influenced by the woman s orientation toward the culture of origin and the host culture we identified a significant model explaining 26 85 of the variance in depressive symptom cohen s f 2 0 37 the number of traumatic event and the orientation toward the host culture exerted significant effect on depressive symptom the moderating effect wa not significant indicating that the effect of the number of traumatic event wa not influenced by cultural orientation based on our result orientation toward the host culture a well a traumatic experience exert independent effect on depressive symptom in refugee

Title: Avoidant decision making in social anxiety: the interaction of angry faces and emotional responses
Authors: Pittig, A.; Pawlikowski, M.; Craske, M. G.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: recent research indicates that angry facial expression are preferentially processed and may facilitate automatic avoidance response especially in socially anxious individual however few study have examined whether this bias also express itself in more complex cognitive process and behavior such a decision making we recently introduced a variation of the iowa gambling task which allowed u to document the influence of task irrelevant emotional cue on rational decision making the present study used a modified gambling task to investigate the impact of angry facial expression on decision making in 38 individual with a wide range of social anxiety participant were to find out which choice were dis advantageous to maximize overall gain to create a decision conflict between approach of reward and avoidance of fear relevant angry face advantageous choice were associated with angry facial expression whereas disadvantageous choice were associated with happy facial expression result indicated that higher social avoidance predicted le advantageous decision in the beginning of the task i e when contingency were still uncertain interaction with specific skin conductance response further clarified that this initial avoidance only occurred in combination with elevated response before choosing an angry facial expression in addition an interaction between high trait anxiety and elevated response to early loss predicted faster learning of an advantageous strategy these effect were independent of intelligence general risky decision making self reported state anxiety and depression thus socially avoidant individual who respond emotionally to angry facial expression are more likely to show avoidance of these face under uncertainty this novel laboratory paradigm may be an appropriate analog for central feature of social anxiety

Title: Avoidant decision-making in social anxiety disorder: A laboratory task linked to in vivo anxiety and treatment outcome
Authors: Pittig, A.; Alpers, G. W.; Niles, A. N.; Craske, M. G.
Abstract: recent study on reward based decision making in the presence of anxiety related stimulus demonstrated that approach avoidance conflict can be assessed under controlled laboratory condition however the clinical relevance of these decision conflict ha not been demonstrated to this end the present study investigated avoidant decision in treatment seeking individual with social anxiety disorder sad in a gambling task advantageous choice to maximize gain were associated with task irrelevant angry face and disadvantageous choice with happy face the clinical relevance of avoidant decision for in vivo anxiety in a social stress situation public speaking were examined n 44 in a subsample n 20 the predictive value for a reduction of avoidance following behavioral therapy wa also evaluated result indicated a close link between more frequent avoidant decision and elevated in vivo anxiety moreover individual who showed a deficit in the goal directed adjustment of their decision also showed higher and sustained distress during the social stressor and reported le decrease of avoidance following treatment the finding highlight the importance of an avoidant decision making style for the experience of acute distress and the maintenance of avoidance in sad assessing avoidant decision making may help to predict the response to behavioral treatment

Title: The Effects of a 3-Week Heartbeat Perception Training on Interoceptive Abilities
Authors: Schillings, C.; Karanassios, G.; Schulte, N.; Schultchen, D.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: recent study showed promising short term effect of heartbeat perception training on interoceptive ability research on the effect of heartbeat perception training on interoceptive ability over time is sparse therefore the aim of this study wa to examine the short term effect and the effect of a 3 week heartbeat perception training over time on interoceptive ability namely cardiac interoceptive accuracy iac and interoceptive sensibility is a total of 40 healthy participant were randomized to the intervention group n 20 or the control group n 20 the intervention group conducted three cardiac biofeedback session one per week at the laboratory whereas the control group watched a documentary instead interoceptive ability were assessed via the heartbeat perception task iac and confidence rating is at baseline after each laboratory session and 1 week after the last session post measurement iac wa significantly increased in the intervention group compared to the control group after the first training session short term effect there were no significant improvement in is due to the first session and neither on iac nor is over time descriptive trend of improved interoceptive ability over time were found in both group single session of heartbeat perception training seems to be a promising approach to improve iac future research should further investigate the long term effect of diverse heartbeat perception training varying in frequency and intensity of the training session in diverse sample aiming to improve interoceptive ability

Title: It's worth the trouble: Stressor exposure is related to increased cognitive reappraisal ability
Authors: Zeier, P.; Meine, L. E.; Wessa, M.
Abstract: recent theory propose moderate compared to high or no stressor exposure to promote emotion regulation capacity more precisely stressful situation are expected to serve a practice opportunity for cognitive reappraisal cr that is the reinterpretation of a situation to alter it emotional impact accordingly in this study we expect an inverted u shaped relationship between exposure to daily hassle and performance in a cr task that is best reappraisal ability in individual with a history of moderate stressor exposure participant n 165 reported the number of daily hassle during the last week a indicator of stressor exposure and completed the script based reappraisal test srt in the srt participant are presented with fear eliciting script and instructed to either downregulate negative affect via reappraisal reappraisal trial or react naturally control trial two measure indicate cr ability 1 reappraisal effectiveness that is the difference between affective rating in reappraisal and control trial and 2 reappraisal inventiveness that is the number of valid and categorically different reappraisal thought multiple regression analysis revealed positive linear but not quadratic relationship of exposure to daily hassle and both indicator of cr ability potential benefit of stressor exposure for emotion regulation process are discussed

Title: Time is a great healer: Peak-end memory bias in anxiety - Induced by threat of shock
Authors: Muller, U. W. D.; Gerdes, A. B. M.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: recently we demonstrated that the peak end memory bias which is well established in the context of pain can also be observed in anxiety retrospective evaluation of a frightening experience are worse when peak anxiety is experienced at the end of an episode here we set out to conceptually replicate and extend this finding with rigorous experimental control in a threat of shock paradigm we induced two intensity level of anxiety by presenting visual cue that indicated different strength of electric stimulus each of the 59 participant went through one of two condition that only differed in the order of moderate and high threat phase a a manipulation check orbicularis emg to auditory startle probe electrodermal activity and state anxiety confirmed the effect of the specific threat exposure critically after some time had passed participant for whom exposure had ended with high threat reported more anxiety for the entire episode than those for whom it ended with moderate threat moreover they ranked their experience a more aversive when compared to other unpleasant everyday experience this study overcomes several previous limitation and speaks to the generalizability of the peak end bias most notably the finding bear implication for exposure therapy in clinical anxiety

Title: Toward a valid electrocortical correlate of regulation of craving using single-trial regression
Authors: Dieterich, R.; Nickel, S.; Endrass, T.
Abstract: regulation of craving roc is a promising method of intervention in addiction and ha received attention in event related potential erp research investigating the late positive potential lpp however in the face of previously unaligned behavioral and lpp result the present work aimed to take a first step toward more valid electrocortical marker of roc twenty seven smoker 16 female abstinent from smoking for 3 h prior to testing viewed smoking related picture while eeg wa recorded during picture viewing participant were asked to either imagine the short term benefit now condition or long term negative consequence later condition of smoking or engage in an arithmetic task distract condition after each picture participant indicated picture related subjective craving in addition to analyzing classic erps we employed single trial multiple robust regression within subject to relate eeg activity at each time point and electrode to trial wise craving rating craving wa lower in the later and distract than the now condition lpp amplitude 300 1000 m at centro parietal electrode were lower in the distract but not the later compared to the now condition trial wise craving wa captured between 500 and 1100 m and around 2400 m at central midline and left site for distract and associated with a very brief and local signal 900 m at c3 for later this replicates the mismatch between self reported craving and lpp single trial result suggest that the correlate of roc are not entirely compatible with the focus on centro parietal slow wave i e the lpp and that different strategy of roc are characterized by distinct electrocortical marker

Title: Lasting effects of cognitive emotion regulation: neural correlates of reinterpretation and distancing
Authors: Hermann, A.; Neudert, M. K.; Schafer, A.; Zehtner, R. I.; Fricke, S.; Seinsche, R. J.; Stark, R.
Abstract: reinterpretation and distancing are two cognitive reappraisal tactic used to regulate one s emotion in response to emotion eliciting stimulus or situation relatively le is known about their differential lasting effect on emotional responding and related neural correlate this functional magnetic resonance imaging study investigated 85 healthy female participating in a 2 day cognitive emotion regulation experiment on the first day participant were instructed to passively look at reinterpret or distance from repeatedly presented aversive picture one week later they were re exposed to the same stimulus without regulation instruction in order to a lasting effect the main outcome measure comprised rating of negative feeling and blood oxygen level dependent response lasting effect for reinterpretation compared with looking at aversive picture during passive re exposure 1 week later were reflected in stronger activation of the left amygdala the ventromedial prefrontal cortex vmpfc and reduced negative feeling neither distancing compared with looking at aversive picture nor reinterpretation compared with distancing did result in significant effect during re exposure these finding indicate that reinterpretation lead to reduced negative feeling 1 week later which might be mediated by inhibitory vmpfc activation or stronger positive emotion during re exposure however the missing difference compared with distancing question the specificity of the result and the mechanism underlying these two cognitive reappraisal tactic

Title: The differential relationship between trait anxiety, depression, and resting frontal alpha-asymmetry
Authors: Adolph, D.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: relatively larger resting right frontal cortical brain activation ha been labeled a a risk factor for emotion related disorder in light of this framework the present study aim wa twofold first we wanted to determine whether a relationship between symptom of anxiety and depression and frontal asymmetry doe already manifest in a sample of so far healthy individual showing a large symptom range this could be expected if frontal asymmetry constitutes a risk factor for depression and anxiety second we aimed to investigate whether symptom of depression and anxiety are independently related to frontal asymmetry or whether either anxiety or depression is superior in predicting the relationship with frontal asymmetry to address these question trait like resting frontal alpha asymmetry by mean of eeg a well a trait anxiety and depressive symptom by questionnaire were measured from 43 healthy student 28 female result indicate that higher symptom severity of depression and anxiety were both significantly correlated with relatively larger right frontal cortical activation however in a regression analysis frontal asymmetry wa predicted by anxiety only controlling for depression and mood anxiety explained 13 of variance while controlling for mood and anxiety depression did explain 1 of variance within frontal asymmetry in conclusion although both anxiety and depression add to the relationship relatively larger right frontal cortical activity might be influenced more strongly by symptom of anxiety moreover a this effect is present already in healthy individual the finding might further support the notion that right frontal cortical asymmetry constitutes a risk factor for anxiety or depression

Title: Informing About the Nocebo Effect Affects Patients' Need for Information About Antidepressants-An Experimental Online Study
Authors: Nestoriuc, Y.; Pan, Y.; Kinitz, T.; Weik, E.; Shedden-Mora, M. C.
Abstract: relevance understanding patient informational need and adapting drug related information are the prerequisite for a contextualized informed consent current information practice might rather harm by inducing nocebo effect objective to investigate whether informing about the nocebo effect using a short information sheet affect patient need for information about antidepressant method a total of 97 patient taking recently prescribed antidepressant 4 month intake were recruited over the internet and randomized to receiving either a one page written information about the nocebo effect or a control text about the history of antidepressant after experimental manipulation informational need about the side effect and mechanism of antidepressant were assessed with 3 and 7 item on categorical and 5 point likert scale group difference in informational need were calculated with chi square test and anova result patient received antidepressant for depression 84 5 and or anxiety disorder 42 3 three participant 6 0 of the nocebo group reported previous knowledge of the nocebo effect after the experimental manipulation participant in the nocebo group reported a reduced desire for receiving full side effect information x 4 97 2 12 714 cramer s v 0 362 p 0 013 and agreed more frequently to the usefulness of withholding information about possible side effect x 4 97 2 14 878 cramer s v 0 392 p 0 005 furthermore they desired more information about the mechanism of antidepressant f 6 373 p 0 013 partial eta 2 0 063 and specifically non pharmacological mechanism such a the role of positive expectation f 16 857 p 0 001 partial eta 2 0 151 conclusion learning about the nocebo effect can alter patient informational need toward desiring le information about the potential side effect of antidepressant and more information about general mechanism such a expectation the beneficial effect of including nocebo information into contextualized informed consent should be studied clinically concerning more functional information seeking behavior which may ultimately lead to improved treatment outcome such a better adherence and reduced side effect burden

Title: Pain predictability reverses valence ratings of a relief-associated stimulus
Authors: Andreatta, M.; Muhlberger, A.; Glotzbach-Schoon, E.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: relief from pain is positively valenced and entail reward like property notably stimulus that became associated with pain relief elicit reward like implicit response too but are explicitly evaluated by human a aversive since the unpredictability of pain make pain more aversive this study examined the hypothesis that the predictability of pain also modulates the valence of relief associated stimulus in two study we presented one conditioned stimulus forwardcs before a painful unconditioned stimulus u another stimulus backwardcs after the painful u and a third stimulus c wa never associated with the u in study 1 forwardcs predicted half of the u while the other half wa delivered unwarned and followed by backwardcs in study 2 all u were predicted by forwardcs and followed by backwardcs in study 1 both forwardcs and backwardcs were rated a negatively valenced and high arousing after conditioning while backwardcs in study 2 acquired positive valence and low arousal startle amplitude wa significantly attenuated to backwardcs compared to forwardcs in study 2 but did not differ among c in study 1 in summary predictability of aversive event revers the explicit valence of a relief associated stimulus

Title: Repetitive negative thinking mediates the relationship between addictive Facebook use and suicide-related outcomes: A longitudinal study
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: repetitive negative thinking rnt and addictive facebook use have been shown to be associated with suicide ideation and suicidal behavior the present longitudinal study aimed to investigate whether the association between addictive facebook use and suicide related outcome is mediated by rnt data of 191 german facebook user m age 26 17 sd age 6 63 were assessed at two measurement time point over a one year period first measurement t1 second measurement t2 via online survey the significant positive association between addictive facebook use t1 and suicide related outcome t2 wa significantly mediated by rnt t1 in contrast a check test that included rnt t1 a predictor and addictive facebook use t1 a mediator revealed no significant mediation effect the current result demonstrate that if addictive facebook use lead to rnt suicide ideation and attempt become likely therefore rnt and addictive facebook use should be taken into account when assessing individual for risk of suicide

Title: Sleep in Humans Stabilizes Pattern Separation Performance
Authors: Hanert, A.; Weber, F. D.; Pedersen, A.; Born, J.; Bartsch, T.
Abstract: replay of hippocampal neural representation during sleep is thought to promote system consolidation of declarative memory how this reprocessing of memory during sleep affect the hippocampal representation itself is unclear here we tested hippocampal stimulus processing i e pattern separation before and after period of sleep and wakefulness in human female and male participant pattern separation deteriorated across the wake period but remained stable across sleep p 0 013 with this sleep wake difference being most pronounced for stimulus with low similarity to target p 0 006 stimulus with the highest similarity showed a reversed pattern with reduced pattern separation performance after sleep p 0 038 pattern separation performance wa positively correlated with sleep spindle density slow oscillation density and theta power phase locked to slow oscillation sleep presumably by neural memory replay shape hippocampal representation and enhances computation of pattern separation to subsequent presentation of similar stimulus significance statement the consolidation of hippocampus dependent memory is causally related to reactivation during sleep of previously encoded representation here we show that reactivation based consolidation process during sleep shape the hippocampal representation itself we studied the effect of sleep and wakefulness on pattern separation i e orthogonalization of similar representation and completion performance i e recall of a memory in light of noisy input that are essential cognitive element of encoding and retrieval of information by the hippocampus our result demonstrate that pattern separation wa stabilized after sleep but diminished after wakefulness we further showed that pattern separation wa related to eeg oscillatory parameter of non rem sleep serving a marker of sleep dependent memory consolidation and hippocampal reactivation

Title: Decrease of well-being and increase of online media use: Cohort trends in German university freshmen between 2016 and 2019
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: research from the u s described a decrease of subjective well being and an increase of online medium use in young adult today the present study investigated whether similar trend occur in germany data of overall 1985 university freshman four cohort 2016 n 658 2017 n 333 2018 n 562 2019 n 432 were collected by online survey in the year 2016 to 2019 the comparison of the four cohort revealed a significant increase of depression anxiety and stress symptom a well a of the use of social platform from 2016 to 2019 in contrast positive mental health pmh significantly decreased over the year no significant change of the gaming behavior were found a slight significant positive relationship occurred between the negative variable of well being and online medium use the association between pmh and online medium use wa significantly negative thus cohort trend found in the u s can at least rudimentarily be replicated in germany young adult in 2019 seem to have lower level of well being and to engage in more use of social platform than older cohort

Title: Perceived parenting stress in the course of postpartum depression: the buffering effect of maternal bonding
Authors: Reck, C.; Zietlow, A. L.; Muller, M.; Dubber, S.
Abstract: research investigating maternal bonding and parenting stress in the course of postpartum depression is lacking aim of the study wa to investigate the development and potential mediation of both construct in the course of postpartum depression n 31 mother with postpartum depression according to dsm iv and n 32 healthy control completed the german version of the postpartum bonding questionnaire and the parenting stress index at two measuring time acute depression t1 and remission t2 at t1 the clinical group reported lower bonding and higher parenting stress bonding wa found to partially mediate the link between maternal diagnosis and parenting stress furthermore the clinical group reported lower bonding and higher parenting stress averaged over both measurement time however at t2 the clinical group still differed from the control even though they improved in bonding and reported le parenting stress a significant increase of bonding wa also observed in the control group maternal bonding seems to buffer the negative impact of postpartum depression on parenting stress the result emphasize the need for intervention focusing on maternal bonding and mother infant interaction in order to prevent impairment of the mother child relationship

Title: Activity and subsequent depression levels: a causal analysis of behavioural activation group treatment with weekly assessments over 8 weeks
Authors: Hoyer, J.; Hoefler, M.; Wuellhorst, V.
Abstract: research on behavioural activation ba for depression assumes that increasing the rate of rewarding activity lead to reduced depressive mood although the efficacy of ba treatment ha been convincingly demonstrated assumption referring to the mechanism underlying this effect have not been tested decisively yet the behavioural activation scale for depression and the beck depression inventory ii were administered over 8 week in 161 reliably diagnosed patient with unipolar depression who underwent ba treatment in group time lagged association between behavioural activity on depression at subsequent assessment 1 week later and vice versa were modelled a with multilevel model and b dynamic panel model that eliminate shared constant factor and allow for reverse causation e g depression affecting subsequent activation in the model for activation on depression both activation and depression changed significantly model based within effect size for activation 70 and for depression 75 higher activation and lower depression predict each other over time mixed effect time lagged model but this association disappears in dynamic causal model change pattern were only analysed within a time frame of 1 week smaller time interval were not investigated there were no objective observational data of activity pattern in the present study increased behavioural activity and reduced depressive mood co occur on the week scale they predict each other across time but this may be due to shared cause only

Title: Women Know Better What Other Women Think and Feel: Gender Effects on Mindreading across the Adult Life Span
Authors: Wacker, R.; Bolte, S.; Dziobek, I.
Abstract: research recurrently show that female perform better than male on various mindreading task the present study contributes to this growing body of literature by being the first to demonstrate a female own gender mindreading bias using a naturalistic social cognition paradigm including female and male target we found that woman performed better at reading others mind and that they were specifically more capable to read female target an own gender target effect absent in men furthermore a non linear negative effect of perceiver age on mindreading performance wa examined within a sample covering the age range of 17 70 year a indicated by a stronger performance decrease setting on by the age of 30 year and continuing throughout middle and old age these finding add to a more comprehensive understanding of the contextual factor influencing mindreading performance in typically developing adult

Title: Infant distress to novelty is associated with maternal anxiety disorder and especially with maternal avoidance behavior
Authors: Reck, C.; Muller, M.; Tietz, A.; Mohler, E.
Abstract: research suggested that maternal anxiety disorder might be related to infant behavioral inhibition this study investigated whether maternal postpartum anxiety disorder is associated with infant temperament more precisely infant distress to novelty an early predictor of behavioral inhibition difference in the latter were analyzed in a german sample by comparing n 38 healthy mother infant dyad to n 44 dyad comprised of mother diagnosed with a dsm iv anxiety disorder infant age ranged from 2 83 to 7 97 month infant temperament wa measured by mean of the infant behavior questionnaire mother were screened for postpartum anxiety disorder using the structured clinical interview for dsm iv disorder severity of anxiety wa measured by self reported questionnaire anxiety cognition questionnaire body sensation questionnaire and mobility inventory infant salivary cortisol reaction when being confronted with a socio emotional stressor face to face still face paradigm wa assessed to validate infant distress a mann whitney u analysis suggested that infant of mother with an anxiety disorder show more distress to novelty than infant of healthy mother furthermore data reveal a positive spearman s rho correlation between infant distress to novelty and maternal avoidance behavior mobility inventory a strong correlation between infant cortisol reactivity and reported distress to novelty validated the maternal evaluation of infant temperament in our sample result suggest a possible approach to promote infant development by encouraging mother with anxiety symptom to encounter feared stimulus

Title: An experience sampling study on the nature of the interaction between traumatic experiences, negative affect in everyday life, and threat beliefs
Authors: Krkovic, K.; Schlier, B.; Lincoln, T.
Abstract: research suggests that trauma is associated with the development of psychotic experience such a paranoia via affective process however the empirical evidence on the exact mechanism is limited and it is unclear which aspect of trauma are relevant here we tested whether self reported frequency of trauma recurring trauma age and type of trauma are predictive of later threat belief in daily life and which role affective process self reported negative affect and autonomic arousal play in this association we tested two often postulated mechanism mediation with affective process in everyday life explaining the association between trauma and threat belief and moderation with trauma strengthening the association between affective process and threat belief in everyday life trauma wa assessed at baseline with the trauma history questionnaire in 67 individual with attenuated symptom of psychosis we then applied the experience sampling method during 24 h to a negative affect heart rate and threat belief multilevel analysis showed that negative affect p 0 001 and heart rate p 0 05 were predictive of subsequent threat belief there wa no significant mediation effect from any trauma characteristic to threat belief via negative affect and heart rate trauma frequency p 0 001 age at first trauma p 0 001 a well a the presence of physical trauma p 0 001 moderated the path from negative affect to subsequent threat belief our finding indicate that more frequent trauma trauma at young age and physical trauma strengthen the association from negative affect to threat belief and could be relevant to determining the extent of vulnerability to psychosis

Title: To vaccinate or not to vaccinate!? Predictors of willingness to receive Covid-19 vaccination in Europe, the U.S., and China
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Schneider, S.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: researcher team around the globe including the project lightspeed are intensively working on vaccine to fight the covid 19 pandemic however the availability of effective vaccine doe not guarantee the vaccination willingness among the population in spring 2021 we investigated the vaccination willingness and it potential predictor in representative online sample in nine country china france germany poland russia spain sweden u k u s of the 9 264 participant 79 9 revealed covid 19 vaccination willingness the highest willingness wa in the u k followed by spain and china the lowest in russia in most country the perception of governmental covid 19 measure a useful and the use of television report a covid 19 information source positively predicted the willingness further factor such a demographic variable mental and physical health status evaluation of governmental communication social medium use and general adherence to covid 19 measure showed a country specific predictive pattern recommendation how to increase the vaccination willingness are provided

Title: A Network Model of Resilience Factors for Adolescents with and without Exposure to Childhood Adversity
Authors: Fritz, J.; Fried, E. I.; Goodyer, I. M.; Wilkinson, P. O.; van Harmelen, A. L.
Abstract: resilience factor rf help prevent mental health problem after childhood adversity ca rf are known to be related but it is currently unknown how their interrelation facilitate mental health here we used network analysis to examine the interrelation between ten rf in 14 year old adolescent exposed ca n 638 and not exposed to ca no ca n 501 we found that the degree to which rf are assumed to enhance each other is higher in the no ca compared to the ca group upon correction for general distress level the global rf connectivity also differed between the two group more specifically in the no ca network almost all rf were positively interrelated and thus may enhance each other whereas in the ca network some rf were negatively interrelated and thus may hamper each other moreover the ca group showed more direct connection between the rf and current distress therefore ca seems to influence how rf relate to each other and to current distress potentially leading to a dysfunctional rf system translational research could explore whether intervening on negative rf interrelation so that they turn positive and rf can enhance each other may alter rf mental distress relation resulting in a lower risk for subsequent mental health problem

Title: [Resilience: A Longitudinal Study of Children with Risk Factors]
Authors: Job, A. K.; Dalkowski, L.; Hahlweg, K.; Muschalla, B.; Schulz, W.
Abstract: resilience a longitudinal study of child with risk factor this study examines the development of child who have grown up with severe early childhood stress a distinction wa made between resilient and maladapted child development on the one hand the aim wa to identify longitudinal protective factor that can contribute to the development of resilience on the other hand we cross sectionally examined in which psychological area resilience manifest itself the sample consists of 343 child who were examined first in early childhood m 4 year and then ten year later in adolescence 24 of the child belonged to the risk group of which 14 showed a resilient and 9 a maladapted development an active temperament higher intelligence and more self control in early childhood proved to be protective factor with medium effect size the proportion of resilience wa increased among migrant cross sectionally we found difference with small and medium effect size in addictive behavior alcohol tobacco and drug use internet dependency overweight and school grade

Title: Dynamics of defensive response mobilization during repeated terminations of exposure to increasing interoceptive threat
Authors: Benke, C.; Krause, E.; Hamm, A. O.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: resistant avoidance behavior play a crucial role in the maintenance of anxiety disorder and are therefore central target of therapeutic intervention in the present study the development of avoidance behavior wa investigated in 24 healthy participant who repeatedly prematurely terminated the exposure to increasing interoceptive threat i e the feeling of dyspnea induced by increasing inspiratory resistive load that were followed by the ultimate threat a short breathing occlusion physiological response and subjective anxiety preceding termination were compared to matched interval of a matched control group n 24 who completed the exposure initially participant terminated during the ultimate threat i e during occlusion this first termination wa preceded by a strong surge in autonomic arousal and reported anxiety startle reflex and the p3 component of event related brain potential to startle probe were strongly inhibited indicating preparation for defensive action with repetitive termination individual successively terminated earlier avoiding exposure to the occlusion this avoidant behavior wa accompanied by alleviated autonomic arousal a compared to the first termination in addition no indication of physiological response preparation wa found implying that the avoidance behavior wa performed in a rather habitual way matched control did not show any indication of a defensive response surge in the matched interval in matched control no change in physiological response pattern were detected while anxiety level increased with repetition the present result shed new light on our understanding of the motivational basis of avoidance behavior and may help to refine etiological model behavioral analysis and therapeutic strategy in treating anxiety disorder

Title: Prospective associations of negative mood and emotion regulation in the occurrence of binge eating in binge eating disorder
Authors: Svaldi, J.; Werle, D.; Naumann, E.; Eichler, E.; Berking, M.
Abstract: retrospective and experimental data demonstrate the importance of emotion regulation er in the maintenance of binge episode in binge eating disorder bed the current study tested whether mood and er prospectively influence binge episode in individual with bed via ecological momentary assessment ema individual with bed n 79 completed two week of ema each sampling point consisted of a series of question pertaining to participant mood er and eating behaviour successful application of adaptive er strategy predicted subsequent abstinence while rumination predicted subsequent binge episode however neither successful application of adaptive er nor maladaptive er moderated the association between negative mood and probability of binge episode this naturalistic study emphasizes the importance of promoting the successful application of adaptive er skill and cessation of rumination in treatment intervention designed to decrease the occurrence of binge episode in bed

Title: Renewal of conditioned fear in a novel context is associated with hippocampal activation and connectivity
Authors: Hermann, A.; Stark, R.; Milad, M. R.; Merz, C. J.
Abstract: return of fear is a serious problem in exposure based treatment of anxiety disorder renewal of the fear response may occur when re encountering the conditioned stimulus within a novel context finding in rodent underpin the hippocampus role in conditioned fear renewal in novel context but it ha yet to be investigated in human forty six healthy men took part in a 2 day context dependent cued fear conditioning paradigm with fear acquisition extinction learning day 1 and extinction recall in the acquisition extinction and a novel context one day later conditioned evaluative skin conductance response scrs and blood oxygen level dependent response served a dependent variable context dependent fear renewal wa reflected in stronger conditioned scrs in the acquisition context individual with a higher renewal of conditioned scrs showed stronger activation of the fear circuit hippocampal activation distinguished conditioned responding in the novel compared with the extinction context individual with a stronger renewal of conditioned scrs in the novel context showed increased effective connectivity of hippocampal activation focus with structure in the fear and extinction network these result outline the pivotal role of the hippocampus and it connectivity in conditioned fear renewal in a novel context in human and might have important implication for exposure therapy in anxiety disorder
