Title: Same fear responses, less avoidance: Rewards competing with aversive outcomes do not buffer fear acquisition, but attenuate avoidance to accelerate subsequent fear extinction
Authors: Pittig, A.; Dehler, J.
Abstract: reward for approaching a feared stimulus may compete with fear reduction inherent to avoidance and thereby alter fear and avoidance learning however the impact of such competing reward on fear and avoidance acquisition ha rarely been investigated during acquisition participant chose between one option c option associated with a neutral stimulus followed by an aversive unconditioned stimulus u and another option c option associated with another neutral stimulus followed by no u n 223 randomized into three group in a subsequent test no more u occurred in one group competing reward were established by linking the c option to high reward and the c option to low reward during acquisition and test reward group in a second group reward were present during acquisition but discontinued during test initial reward group in a third group reward were completely absent no reward group without competing reward significant avoidance wa acquired and persisted in the absence of the u competing reward attenuated avoidance acquisition already after the first experience of the aversive u avoidance remained attenuated even when reward were discontinued during test reward did however not change the level of fear response to the c u expectancy skin conductance finally reward did not change the level of fear reduction during test which wa however experienced earlier summarized reward for approaching aversive event do not buffer fear acquisition but can prevent avoidance this damping of avoidance may initiate fear extinction

Title: Rumination in anorexia nervosa: Cognitive-affective and neuroendocrinological aspects
Authors: Furtjes, S.; Seidel, M.; King, J. A.; Biemann, R.; Roessner, V.; Ehrlich, S.
Abstract: rumination about body weight figure a well a food is common in patient with anorexia nervosa an and may be a maintenance factor of the disorder while rumination can generally be considered a a cognitive affective process food related rumination may be driven primarily by a physiological response to undernutrition in the current longitudinal study we integrate ecological momentary assessment of rumination and affect and a a biological marker of undernutrition plasma leptin level collected from 33 an patient at the very acute stage and again after short term weight restoration patient answered short questionnaire six time per day over two week analysis via hierarchical linear modelling confirmed that rumination is closely linked to affect in an before and after weight restoration rumination about food decreased during weight restoration and wa correlated with leptin level in contrast rumination about body weight figure wa not linked to leptin persisted after weight gain and showed stronger connection with affect this suggests that rumination about body weight figure seems to be a cognitive affective aspect of the disorder but food related rumination may need to be considered from a physiological perspective it is possible that food related ruminative thought reflect a physiological symptom induced by undernutrition similar to well described leptin associated change in physical activity

Title: Rumination, Entrapment and Suicide Ideation: A Mediational Model
Authors: Teismann, T.; Forkmann, T.
Abstract: rumination ha been shown to be positively associated with suicide ideation yet only few study have attempted to explain potential mediator of this association perception of entrapment are a core component of recent psychological model of suicidality and might mediate the relationship between rumination and suicide ideation possible mediator effect were investigated in an online sample n 142 and a clinical sample n 226 of adult receiving outpatient psychotherapy result demonstrated that perception of entrapment fully mediated the association between ruminative thinking and suicide ideation however the reverse relationship where the association between entrapment and suicide ideation is mediated by ruminative thinking wa not supported these finding suggest that the relationship between rumination and suicide ideation is explained by perception of entrapment theoretical and clinical implication are discussed copyright c 2015 john wiley son ltd key practitioner message ruminative thinking and perception of entrapment are associated with suicidal ideation and suicidal behavior perception of entrapment fully mediate the association between ruminative thinking and suicide ideation clinically it could be useful to incorporate perception of entrapment into the psychosocial risk assessment of person contemplating suicide
Notes: Louis Schiekiera (2023-06-14 22:49:50)(Select): mix; Louis Schiekiera (2023-06-14 22:37:19)(Screen): mix;

Title: Aberrant activity and connectivity of the posterior superior temporal sulcus during social cognition in schizophrenia
Authors: Mier, D.; Eisenacher, S.; Rausch, F.; Englisch, S.; Gerchen, M. F.; Zamoscik, V.; Meyer-Lindenberg, A.; Zink, M.; Kirsch, P.
Abstract: schizophrenia is associated with significant impairment in social cognition these impairment have been shown to go along with altered activation of the posterior superior temporal sulcus pst however study that investigate connectivity of pst during social cognition in schizophrenia are sparse twenty two patient with schizophrenia and 22 matched healthy control completed a social cognitive task for functional magnetic resonance imaging that allows the investigation of affective theory of mind tom emotion recognition and the processing of neutral facial expression moreover a resting state measurement wa taken patient with schizophrenia performed worse in the social cognitive task main effect of group in addition a group by social cognitive processing interaction wa revealed for activity a well a for connectivity during the social cognitive task i e patient with schizophrenia showed hyperactivity of right pst during neutral face processing but hypoactivity during emotion recognition and affective tom in addition hypoconnectivity between right and left pst wa revealed for affective tom but not for neutral face processing or emotion recognition no group difference in connectivity from right to left pst occurred during resting state this pattern of aberrant activity and connectivity of the right pst during social cognition might form the basis of false positive perception of emotion and intention and could contribute to the emergence and sustainment of delusion

Title: Distinct structural alterations independently contributing to working memory deficits and symptomatology in paranoid schizophrenia
Authors: Zierhut, K. C.; Schulte-Kemna, A.; Kaufmann, J.; Steiner, J.; Bogerts, B.; Schiltz, K.
Abstract: schizophrenia is considered a brain disease with a quite heterogeneous clinical presentation study in schizophrenia have yielded a wide array of correlation between structural and functional brain change and clinical and cognitive symptom reduction of grey matter volume gmv in the prefrontal and temporal cortex have been described which are crucial for the development of positive and negative symptom and impaired working memory wm association between gmv reduction and positive and negative symptom a well a wm impairment were assessed in schizophrenia patient symptomatology in 34 wm in 26 and compared to healthy control 36 total wm in 26 gmv wa determined by voxel based morphometry and it relation to positive and negative symptom a well a wm performance wa assessed in schizophrenia patient reduction of gmv were evident in anterior cingulate cortex ventrolateral prefrontal cortex vlpfc superior temporal cortex and insula gmv reduction in the superior temporal gyrus stg were associated with positive symptom severity a well a wm impairment furthermore the absolute gmv of vlpfc wa strongly related to negative symptom these predicted wm performance a well a processing speed the present result support the assumption of two distinct pathomechanisms responsible for impaired wm in schizophrenia 1 gmv reduction in the vlpfc predict the severity of negative symptom increased negative symptom in turn are associated with a slowing down of processing speed and predict an impaired wm 2 gmv reduction in the temporal and mediofrontal cortex are involved in the development of positive symptom and impair wm performance too

Title: Mental health problems moderate the association between teacher violence and children's social status in East Africa: A multi-informant study combining self- and peer-reports
Authors: Hecker, T.; Dumke, L.; Neuner, F.; Masath, F. B.
Abstract: school victimization ha been negatively associated with child s social status however previous study have primarily focused on peer victimization leaving a significant knowledge gap regarding violence by teacher we hypothesized that when almost all child experience violence by teacher not only the experience of violence but also other factor for example mental health problem may influence child s social preference and centrality we therefore examined potential moderation effect of child s internalizing and externalizing problem we implemented a multistage cluster randomized sampling approach to randomly chose fifth and sixth grade student from primary school throughout tanzania using a multi informant approach data were collected from 643 child 51 0 girl m age 12 79 year result showed inconsistent direct association between teacher violence and social status whereas mental health problem were consistently associated with lower social status significant interaction effect were found for internalizing problem that is teacher violence wa associated with lower social status for increasing internalizing problem however no interaction effect were found for externalizing problem the finding underline the burden of exposure to violence by teacher and the importance of mental health for child s social functioning knowledge about interrelation can be applied in intervention to effectively reduce violence by teacher toward student

Title: Increased perceived self-efficacy facilitates the extinction of fear in healthy participants
Authors: Zlomuzica, A.; Preusser, F.; Schneider, S.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: self efficacy ha been proposed a an important element of a successful cognitive behavioral treatment cbt positive change in perceived self efficacy have been linked to an improved adaptive emotional and behavioral responding in the context of anxiety provoking situation furthermore a positive influence of increased self efficacy on cognitive function ha been confirmed the present study examined the effect of verbal persuasion on perceived self efficacy and fear extinction healthy participant were subjected to a standardized differential fear conditioning paradigm after fear acquisition half of the participant received a verbal persuasion aimed at increasing perceived self efficacy the extinction of fear wa assessed immediately thereafter on both the implicit and explicit level our result suggest that an increased perceived self efficacy wa associated with enhanced extinction evidenced on the psychophysiological level and accompanied by more pronounced decrement in conditioned negative valence change in extinction were not due to a decrease in overall emotional reactivity to conditioned stimulus c in addition debriefing participant about the false positive feedback did not affect the processing of already extinguished conditioned response during a subsequent continued extinction phase our result suggest that positive change in perceived self efficacy can be beneficial for emotional learning finding are discussed with respect to strategy aimed at increasing extinction learning in the course of exposure based treatment

Title: A Cross-Lag Panel Analysis of Low Self-Esteem as a Predictor of Adolescent Internalizing Symptoms in a Prospective Longitudinal Study
Authors: In-Albon, T.; Meyer, A. H.; Metzke, C. W.; Steinhausen, H. C.
Abstract: self esteem generally regarded a an important indicator of adolescent mental health wa assessed by a self report questionnaire in a school sample of 593 subject who had been assessed at 3 time point over 7 year between 11 and 25 year of age within the zurich psychology and psychopathology study zapps cross lagged panel analysis of the longitudinal data from zapps indicated that self esteem wa predictive of internalizing problem and had an impact on internalizing symptom when the analysis were adjusted for coping behavior efficiency of social network and impact of stressful life event self esteem wa also stable r 37 60 within the observed age range after controlling for prior level of the predicted variable the finding support the impact of self esteem on mental health and indicate the importance of addressing self esteem in prevention and intervention program

Title: Me, myself, and I: self-referent word use as an indicator of self-focused attention in relation to depression and anxiety
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Zimmermann, J.; Kulessa, D.; Hautzinger, M.; Bents, H.; Friederich, H. C.; Herzog, W.; Backenstrass, M.
Abstract: self focused attention sfa is considered a cognitive bias that is closely related to depression however it is not yet well understood whether it represents a disorder specific or a trans diagnostic phenomenon and which role the valence of a given context is playing in this regard computerized quantitative text analysis offer an integrative psycho linguistic approach that may help to provide new insight into these complex relationship the relative frequency of first person singular pronoun in natural language is regarded a an objective linguistic marker of sfa here we present two study that examined the association between sfa and symptom of depression and anxiety in two different context positive v negative valence a well a the convergence between pronoun use and self reported aspect of sfa in the first study we found that the use of first person singular pronoun during negative but not during positive memory recall wa positively related to symptom of depression and anxiety in patient with anorexia nervosa with varying level of co morbid depression and anxiety in the second study we found the same pattern of result in non depressed individual in addition use of first person singular pronoun during negative memory recall wa positively related to brooding i e the assumed maladaptive sub component of rumination but not to reflection these finding could not be replicated in two sample of depressed patient however non chronically depressed patient used more first person singular pronoun than healthy control irrespective of context taken together the finding lend partial support to theoretical model that emphasize the effect of context on self focus and consider sfa a a relevant trans diagnostic phenomenon in addition the present finding point to the construct validity of pronoun use a a linguistic marker of maladaptive self focus

Title: The effect of trait anxiety on attentional mechanisms in combined context and cue conditioning and extinction learning
Authors: Stegmann, Y.; Reicherts, P.; Andreatta, M.; Pauli, P.; Wieser, M. J.
Abstract: sensory processing and attention allocation are shaped by threat but the role of trait anxiety in sensory processing a a function of threat predictability remains incompletely understood therefore we measured steady state visual evoked potential ssveps a an index of sensory processing of predictable and unpredictable threat cue in 29 low la and 29 high ha trait anxious participant during a modified npu paradigm followed by an extinction phase three different contextual cue indicated safety n predictable p or unpredictable threat u while foreground cue signalled shock in the p condition only all participant allocated increased attentional resource to the central p threat cue replicating previous finding importantly la individual exhibited larger ssvep amplitude to contextual threat u and p than to contextual safety cue while ha individual did not differentiate among contextual cue in general further ha exhibited higher aversive rating of all context compared to la these result suggest that high trait anxious individual might be worse at discriminating contextual threat stimulus and accordingly overestimate the probability and aversiveness of unpredictable threat these finding support the notion of aberrant sensory processing of unpredictable threat in anxiety disorder a this processing pattern is already evident in individual at risk of these disorder

Title: A pragmatic comparison of noise burst and electric shock unconditioned stimuli for fear conditioning research with many trials
Authors: Sperl, M. F. J.; Panitz, C.; Hermann, C.; Mueller, E. M.
Abstract: several method that are promising for studying the neurophysiology of fear conditioning e g eeg meg require a high number of trial to achieve an adequate signal to noise ratio while electric shock and white noise burst are among the most commonly used unconditioned stimulus u in conventional fear conditioning study with few trial it is unknown whether these stimulus are equally well suited for paradigm with many trial here n 32 participant underwent a 260 trial differential fear conditioning and extinction paradigm with a 240 trial recall test 24 h later and neutral face a conditioned stimulus in a between subject design either white noise burst n 16 or electric shock n 16 served a u and intensity were determined using the most common procedure for each u i e a fixed 95 db noise burst and a work up procedure for electric shock respectively in addition to differing u type group also differed in closely linked u associated characteristic e g calibration method stimulus intensity timing subjective rating arousal valence skin conductance and evoked heart period change i e fear bradycardia indicated more reliable extinction resistant and stable conditioning in the white noise burst versus electric shock group in fear conditioning experiment where many trial are presented white noise burst should serve a u

Title: The stigma of mental illness: Testing for the implicit bias in diagnostic labels
Authors: Schlier, B.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: several model that attempt to explain stigmatization of people with mental illness emphasize the relevance of social categorization however research on illness based social category ha been limited to explicit self report measure in this study we explored whether implicit social categorization based on mental illness label can be assessed with the who said what wsw paradigm in this paradigm participant have to allocate a large number of statement to individual who belong to different social group e g mentally ill v healthy due to the amount of statement error in allocation are to be expected a disproportionate amount of erroneous allocation to individual within a social group is interpreted to indicate implicit social categorization in three study we 1 pilot tested a wsw paradigm for mental illness categorization n 24 2 replicated these finding in an independent larger sample n 85 and 3 aimed to rule out alternative explanation for the implicit categorization effect with a modified wsw task and novel stimulus material n 137 we found consistent implicit categorization effect with overall medium to large effect size range 0 41 d 1 01 implicit component of mental illness based social categorization can be assessed with the wsw paradigm future research need to explore the interrelation of implicit categorization implicit v explicit stigmatization and discriminating behavior

Title: One year after the COVID-19 outbreak in Germany: long-term changes in depression, anxiety, loneliness, distress and life satisfaction
Authors: Benke, C.; Autenrieth, L. K.; Asselmann, E.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: several study have linked the covid 19 pandemic to unfavorable mental health outcome however we know little about long term change in mental health due to the pandemic so far here we used longitudinal data from a general population sample of 1388 adult from germany who were initially assessed between april and may 2020 i e at the beginning of the covid 19 pandemic in germany and prospectively followed up after 6 n 1082 and 12 month n 945 depressive and anxiety symptom a well a loneliness did not change from baseline to 6 month follow up while anxiety symptom did not change in the long run depressive symptom and loneliness increased and life satisfaction decreased from baseline to 12 month follow up moreover vulnerable group such a younger individual or those with a history of mental disorder exhibited an overall higher level of psychopathological symptom across all assessment wave our finding suggest a deterioration in mental health during the course of the covid 19 pandemic which emphasizes the importance to implement targeted health promotion to prevent a further symptom escalation especially in vulnerable group

Title: Somatosensory spatial attention modulates amplitudes, latencies, and latency jitter of laser-evoked brain potentials
Authors: Franz, M.; Nickel, M. M.; Ritter, A.; Miltner, W. H.; Weiss, T.
Abstract: several study provided evidence that the amplitude of laser evoked potential leps are modulated by attention however previous report were based on across trial averaging of lep response at the expense of losing information about intertrial variability related to attentional modulation the aim of this study wa to investigate the effect of somatosensory spatial attention on single trial parameter i e amplitude latency and latency jitter of lep component n2 and p2 twelve subject participated in a sustained spatial attention paradigm while noxious laser stimulus left hand and noxious electrical stimulus right hand were sequentially delivered to the dorsum of the respective hand with nonnoxious air puff randomly interspersed within the sequence of noxious stimulus participant were instructed to mentally count all stimulus i e noxious and nonnoxious applied to the attended location laser stimulus presented to the attended hand al elicited larger single trial amplitude of the n2 component compared with unattended laser stimulus uls in contrast single trial amplitude of the p2 component were not significantly affected by spatial attention single trial latency of the n2 and p2 were significantly smaller for al v uls additionally the across trial latency jitter of the n2 component wa reduced for al conversely the latency jitter of the p2 component wa smaller for uls compared with al with the use of single trial analysis the study provided new insight into brain dynamic of leps related to spatial attention our result indicate that single trial parameter of lep component are differentially modulated by spatial attention

Title: Suggested visual blockade during hypnosis: Top-down modulation of stimulus processing in a visual oddball task
Authors: Franz, M.; Schmidt, B.; Hecht, H.; Naumann, E.; Miltner, W. H. R.
Abstract: several theory of hypnosis assume that response to hypnotic suggestion are implemented through top down modulation via a frontoparietal network that is involved in monitoring and cognitive control the current study addressed this issue re analyzing previously published event related potential erp n1 p2 and p3b amplitude and combined it with source reconstruction and connectivity analysis method erp data were obtained from participant engaged in a visual oddball paradigm composed of target standard and distractor stimulus during a hypnosis hyp and a control con condition in both condition participant were asked to count the rare target presented on a video screen during hyp participant received suggestion that a wooden board in front of their eye would obstruct their view of the screen the result showed that participant counting accuracy wa significantly impaired during hyp compared to con erp component in the n1 and p2 window revealed no amplitude difference between con and hyp at sensor level in contrast p3b amplitude in response to target stimulus were significantly reduced during hyp compared to con source analysis of the p3b amplitude in response to target indicated that hyp wa associated with reduced source activity in occipital and parietal brain area related to stimulus categorization and attention we further explored how these brain source interacted by computing time frequency effective connectivity between electrode that best represented frontal parietal and occipital source this analysis revealed reduced directed information flow from parietal attentional to frontal executive source during processing of target stimulus these result provide preliminary evidence that hypnotic suggestion of a visual blockade are associated with a disruption of the coupling within the frontoparietal network implicated in top down control

Title: The multidimensional inventory of hypochondriacal traits: factor structure, specificity, reliability, and validity in patients with hypochondriasis
Authors: Witthoft, M.; Weck, F.; Gropalis, M.
Abstract: severe health anxiety constitutes a disabling and costly clinical condition the multidimensional inventory of hypochondriacal trait miht represents an innovative instrument that wa developed according to cognitive behavioral cognitive perceptual interpersonal and trait model of hypochondriasis we aimed at evaluating the psychometric property of the miht in a sample of patient with the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder 4th ed diagnosis of hypochondriasis using confirmatory factor analysis cfa the postulated four factor structure of the miht wa found in a first cfa in patient with hypochondriasis n 178 and in a second cfa based on a mixed sample with other somatoform disorder n 27 panic disorder n 25 and healthy control n 31 added to the original group of patient with hypochondriasis n 178 in term of specificity patient with hypochondriasis showed larger score on all four miht subscales i e affective cognitive behavioral and perceptual compared to all other group analysis of convergent and discriminant validity revealed promising result concerning the miht affective and perceptual scale but also point to certain problematic issue concerning the miht cognitive and behavioral scale the finding suggest that the proposed structure of the miht is valid also in patient with hypochondriasis and demonstrate the specificity of the four hypochondriacal trait assessed in the miht

Title: Interoception and sexual response in women with low sexual desire
Authors: Velten, J.; Brotto, L. A.
Abstract: sexual concordance is defined a the association between genital response and self reported sexual arousal though one might predict a strong association between sexual concordance and awareness of other internal physiological sensation termed interoception past research on sexually healthy woman ha not found these different domain to be related the aim of the present study wa to test the association between interoception and sexual concordance in a clinical sample of woman with sexual interest arousal disorder siad fifty two woman with siad completed the multidimensional assessment of interoceptive awareness maia a validated self report measure of interoception and completed a heart beat accuracy test an objective measure of interoception they also participated in a laboratory based assessment of physiological sexual arousal and self reported sexual arousal while viewing an erotic film mental and physiological arousal were correlated at r 0 27 range 0 80 to 0 95 there wa no significant association between sexual concordance and woman s heartrate awareness however five aspect of interoceptive awareness noticing emotional awareness self regulation body listening and trusting were predictive of lower and one aspect not distracting wa predictive of higher sexual concordance we discus the finding in relation to the role of emotion and arousal state in the interoception sexual concordance relationship

Title: Exploring the Impact of Personal and Partner Traits on Sexuality: Sexual Excitation, Sexual Inhibition, and Big Five Predict Sexual Function in Couples
Authors: Velten, J.; Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: sexual difficulty are common among woman and men and are associated with various mental and physical health problem although psychological trait are known to impact sexual attitude and behavior sexuality and personality related trait have not been jointly investigated to a their relevance for sexual functioning in couple the aim of this study wa to investigate how psychological trait of two partner influence woman s and men s sexual function data from 964 couple representative of the adult population in germany were analyzed sexual function wa assessed with the female sexual function index fsfi and the international index of erectile function iief sexuality related trait were measured with the sexual excitation sexual inhibition inventory for woman and men sesii w m personality wa measured with self report and partner rating version of the big five inventory bfi sexual excitation wa a positive and sexual inhibition wa a negative predictor of sexual function in both gender woman whose partner were sexually inhibited reported lower sexual function conscientious individual reported better sexual function woman whose partner were more conscientious also had better sexual function assessing partner related factor may be helpful to identify predisposing and maintaining factor of sexual dysfunction especially in woman

Title: No Sex Difference Found: Cues of Sexual Stimuli Activate the Reward System in both Sexes
Authors: Stark, R.; Klein, S.; Kruse, O.; Weygandt, M.; Leufgens, L. K.; Schweckendiek, J.; Strahler, J.
Abstract: sexually explicit material sem is increasingly used in western society one reason for this high usage might be the rewarding property of sem demonstrated in many brain imaging study showing an activation of the reward system during the presentation of sem it is not yet well understood why woman use sem to a remarkably lesser extent than men maybe men react stronger to stimulus so called sem cue which signal the presentation of sem and are therefore more vulnerable to use sem than woman therefore the present study aimed at investigating the sex specific neural correlate towards sem and sem cue we were further interested in whether person characteristic a trait sexual motivation extent of sem use in the last month and age at onset of goal oriented sem use affect the neural response to sem and sem cue the trial of the fmri experiment consisted of an expectation phase with sem or neutral cue and a presentation phase with sem or neutral stimulus respectively analysis showed that the reward circuitry wa activated by sem but also by sem cue there were some sex difference in hemodynamic response to sem during the presentation phase but not during the expectation phase to sem cue in any of the region of interest the influence of the investigated person characteristic wa only small if existent the result suggest that sex specific cue processing cannot explain sex difference in the use of sem

Title: Cross-paradigm integration shows a common neural basis for aversive and appetitive conditioning
Authors: Klein, S.; Kruse, O.; Tapia Leon, I.; Van Oudenhove, L.; van 't Hof, S. R.; Klucken, T.; Wager, T. D.; Stark, R.
Abstract: sharing imaging data and comparing them across different psychological task is becoming increasingly possible a the open science movement advance such cross paradigm integration ha the potential to identify commonality in finding that neighboring area of study thought to be paradigm specific however even the integration of research from closely related paradigm such a aversive and appetitive classical conditioning is rare even though qualitative comparison already hint at how similar the fear network and reward network may be we aimed to validate these theory by taking a multivariate approach to a commonality across paradigm empirically specifically we quantified the similarity of an aversive conditioning pattern derived from meta analysis to appetitive conditioning fmri data we tested pattern expression in three independent appetitive conditioning study with 29 76 and 38 participant each during fmri scanning participant in each cohort performed an appetitive conditioning task in which a c wa repeatedly rewarded with money and a c wa never rewarded the aversive pattern wa highly similar to appetitive c c contrast map across sample and variation of the appetitive conditioning paradigm moreover the pattern distinguished the c from the c with above chance accuracy in every sample these finding provide robust empirical evidence for an underlying neural system common to appetitive and aversive learning we believe that this approach provides a way to empirically integrate the steadily growing body of fmri finding across paradigm

Title: [Simple guideline-oriented supportive tools in primary care: Effects on adherence to the S3/NV guideline unipolar depression]
Authors: Knappe, S.; Einsle, F.; Rummel-Kluge, C.; Heinz, I.; Wieder, G.; Venz, J.; Schouler-Ocak, M.; Wittchen, H. U.; Lieb, R.; Hoye, J.; Schmitt, J.; Bergmann, A.; Beesdo-Baum, K.
Abstract: simple guideline oriented supportive tool in primary care effect on adherence to the s3 nv guideline unipolar depression objective doe the provision of supportive tool improve guideline oriented recognition and treatment of patient with depression in primary care method in a nested intervention study a part of a larger epidemiological study program in german primary care 46 randomly drawn practice received tool to facilitate identification and treatment decision pre post effect were compared to 42 matched control practice without intervention result the proportion of correctly identified depression case wa similar in the intervention 47 2 and the control group 42 3 p 0 537 compared to control practitioner in the intervention group rated their competence in case identification and treatment at post intervention more positively p 0 016 no effect were observed regarding the usage of the tool practitioner attitude towards national depression guideline and depression treatment procedure conclusion since provision of guideline oriented tool did not improve recognition and quality of treatment delineation of alternative strategy for enhanced guideline adherence in primary care for depression is warranted

Title: From low sense of control to problematic smartphone use severity during Covid-19 outbreak: The mediating role of fear of missing out and the moderating role of repetitive negative thinking
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Stirnberg, J.; Rozgonjuk, D.; Margraf, J.; Elhai, J. D.
Abstract: since the outbreak of covid 19 the use of digital device especially smartphones remarkably increased smartphone use belongs to one s daily routine but can negatively impact physical and mental health performance and relationship if used excessively the present study aimed to investigate potential correlate of problematic smartphone use psu severity and the mechanism underlying it development data of 516 smartphone user from germany mage 31 91 sdage 12 96 were assessed via online survey in april and may 2021 psu severity wa significantly negatively associated with sense of control in contrast it wa significantly positively linked to fear of missing out fomo repetitive negative thinking rnt and daily time spent on smartphone use in a moderated mediation analysis the negative relationship between sense of control and psu severity wa significantly mediated by fomo rnt significantly moderated the positive association between fomo and psu severity specifically the higher the rnt the stronger the relationship between fomo and psu the present finding disclose potential mechanism that could contribute to psu potential way of how to reduce psu severity are discussed

Title: Sleep and next-day negative affect and suicidal ideation in borderline personality disorder
Authors: Kaurin, A.; Hisler, G.; Dombrovski, A. Y.; Hallquist, M. N.; Wright, A. G. C.
Abstract: sleep disturbance is associated with elevated suicidal ideation and negative affect to date however no study ha investigated the temporal relationship between sleep and suicidality among those diagnosed with borderline personality disorder bpd this preregistered http osf io 4vugk study tested whether nightly sleep self reported sleep duration sleep onset latency and subjective sleep quality represents a within person short term risk factor for affective dysregulation and increase in suicide risk from day to day a well a whether between person difference in sleep negative affect and suicidality were associated we used a 21 day ecological momentary assessment protocol in a sample of 153 people diagnosed with bpd 105 of which had a history of serious suicide attempt and 52 healthy control n 4076 day we found a within person association between worse subjective sleep quality and greater next day negative affect at the between person level we found positive relationship between sleep latency and suicidal ideation and a negative association between subjective sleep quality and negative affect bpd severity did not significantly moderate the strength of any within person association although bpd wa positively associated with average level of suicidal ideation sleep latency and negative affect and negatively related to subjective sleep quality these finding suggest that the association of sleep with suicidal ideation and bpd exists largely at the between person rather than the within person level disturbed sleep therefore seems to largely coincide rather than specifically contribute to the exacerbation of suicidal crisis in bpd psycinfo database record c 2022 apa all right reserved

Title: Sleep deprivation increases threat beliefs in human fear conditioning
Authors: Zenses, A. K.; Lenaert, B.; Peigneux, P.; Beckers, T.; Boddez, Y.
Abstract: sleep disturbance and anxiety disorder exhibit high comorbidity level but it remains unclear whether sleep problem are cause or consequence of increased anxiety to experimentally probe the aetiological role of sleep disturbance in anxiety we investigated in healthy participant how total sleep deprivation influence fear expression in a conditioning paradigm in a fear conditioning procedure one face stimulus conditioned stimulus c wa paired with electric shock whereas another face stimulus wa not unpaired stimulus c fear expression wa tested the next morning using the two face stimulus from the training phase and a generalization stimulus i e a morph between the c and c stimulus between fear conditioning and test participant were either kept awake in the laboratory for 12 hr n 20 or had a night of sleep at home n 20 irrespective of stimulus type subjective threat expectancy but not skin conductance response were enhanced after sleep deprivation relative to regular sleep these result suggest that sleep disturbance may play a role in anxiety disorder by increasing perceived threat

Title: Repeated stress leads to enhanced cortisol stress response in child social anxiety disorder but this effect can be prevented with CBT
Authors: Asbrand, J.; Heinrichs, N.; Nitschke, K.; Wolf, O. T.; Schmidtendorf, S.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.
Abstract: social anxiety disorder sad is associated with continual social stress in everyday life two physiological component of stress are the hypothalamus pituitary adrenal axis a captured by cortisol reactivity and the autonomous nervous system a captured by salivary alpha amylase saa reactivity in child with sad initial evidence point to dysregulated physiological stress reactivity for both system furthermore hardly any study have assessed stress reactivity twice including exploring possible change after cognitive behavioral therapy cbt child with sad n 65 aged 9 13 year and healthy control hcs n 55 participated in a social stress task trier social stress test for child tsst c which wa repeated with child with sad after either 12 session of cbt or a waiting period to explore possible habituation or sensitization effect before treatment child in the sad and hc group did not differ in their cortisol stress reactivity toward the tsst c but did differ in their saa response with a more pronounced response in the sad group after treatment child with sad in the waitlist group differed from child with sad in the cbt group by showing stronger cortisol reactivity and a higher responder rate indicative of a possible sensitization to stress no difference wa found for saa future research should compare child with sad and hc child concerning the effect of repeated stress on sensitization

Title: Integrative systemic and family therapy for social anxiety disorder: Manual and practice in a pilot randomized controlled trial (SOPHO-CBT/ST)
Authors: Hunger-Schoppe, C.; Schweitzer, J.; Hilzinger, R.; Krempel, L.; Deusser, L.; Sander, A.; Bents, H.; Mander, J.; Lieb, H.
Abstract: social anxiety disorder sad are among the most prevalent mental disorder lifetime prevalence 7 12 with high impact on the life of an affected social system and it individual social system member we developed a manualized disorder specific integrative systemic and family therapy isft for sad and evaluated it feasibility in a pilot randomized controlled trial rct the isft is inspired by helm stierlin s concept of related individuation developed during the early 1980s which ha since continued to be refined it integrates solution focused language social network diagnostics and genogram work a well a resource and problem orientation for both case conceptualization and therapy planning post milan symptom prescription to fluidize the presented symptom is one of the core intervention in the isft theoretically the ifst is grounded in radical constructivism and cybern ethic multi directional partiality and a both and attitude toward a disorder specific v non disorder specific therapy approach sad is understood from the viewpoint of social system theory especially in adaptation to a socio psycho biological explanatory model of social anxiety in a prospective multicenter assessor blind pilot rct we included 38 client with sad icd f40 1 liebowitz social anxiety scale lsas sr 30 18 patient participated in the isft and 20 patient in cognitive behavioral therapy cbt age m 36 year sd 14 within group simple effect intention to treat analysis showed significant reduction in social anxiety lsas sr isft d 1 67 cbt d 1 04 while intention to treat mixed design anova demonstrated the advantage of isft d 0 81 per protocol analysis supported these result the remission rate based on blind diagnostician rating wa good to satisfactory structured clinical interview scid 78 in st 45 in cbt p 0 083 this ha yet to be verified in a subsequent confirmatory rct the article will present the isft rationale and manual including a special focus on multi person setting and the central finding from our pilot rct

Title: When interoception helps to overcome negative feelings caused by social exclusion
Authors: Pollatos, O.; Matthias, E.; Keller, J.
Abstract: social exclusion affect mental and physical health the ability to regulate emotional response to social exclusion is therefore essential for our well being a individual difference in detecting bodily signal interoceptive sensitivity is have been associated with the ability of emotion regulation we aimed at exploring whether is foster coping with social exclusion and flexibility in emotion regulation the first study investigated subjective feeling and behavioral affiliation tendency in response to ostracism using a cyberball paradigm sixty nine participant were assessed who differed with respect to is the second study examined habitual emotion regulation process focusing on suppression and reappraisal a well a is in 116 participant main result were that the effect of ostracism on distress and behavioral affiliation tendency were qualified by is being ostracized had le impact on participant with stronger is furthermore study 2 revealed that is wa associated with habitually stronger emotion regulation strategy we conclude that having access to bodily signal help is reducing aversive state provoked by social exclusion probably due to the fact that is is associated with emotion regulation strategy

Title: Angry facial expressions bias towards aversive actions
Authors: Kroczek, L. O. H.; Lingnau, A.; Schwind, V.; Wolff, C.; Muhlberger, A.
Abstract: social interaction requires fast and efficient processing of another person s intention in face to face interaction aversive or appetitive action typically co occur with emotional expression allowing an observer to anticipate action intention in the present study we investigated the influence of facial emotion on the processing of action intention thirty two participant were presented with video clip showing virtual agent displaying a facial emotion angry v happy while performing an action punch v fist bump directed towards the observer during each trial video clip stopped at varying duration of the unfolding action and participant had to recognize the presented action naturally participant recognition accuracy improved with increasing duration of the unfolding action interestingly while facial emotion did not influence accuracy there wa a significant influence on participant action judgement participant were more likely to judge a presented action a a punch when agent showed an angry compared to a happy facial emotion this effect wa more pronounced in short video clip showing only the beginning of an unfolding action than in long video clip showing near complete action these result suggest that facial emotion influence anticipatory processing of action intention allowing for fast and adaptive response in social interaction

Title: Stressed in afterthought: Neuroendocrine effects of social self-threat during physical effort are counteracted by performance feedback after stress exposure
Authors: Finke, J. B.; Behrje, A.; Hesslenberg, E.; Klucken, T.; Schachinger, H.
Abstract: social self threat during physical stress such a exposure to the cold pressor test and isometric handgrip test ha been shown to induce activation of the hpa axis in addition to autonomic response however previous research ha suggested that dysfunctional post event processing may play a major role in neuroendocrine reactivity at initial a well a subsequent social stress exposure in the present study we investigated how the interplay of context i e performance feedback with state i e self esteem a well a trait like factor i e ruminative tendency affect stress response to repeated short bout of physical activity on two session 1 week apart 53 participant 27 woman performed an isometric handgrip task for 3 min during which they were exposed to social evaluative threat in addition participant received fake feedback on their performance immediately after the task labeling it a either above positive or below average negative in addition to neuroendocrine cortisol cardiovascular heart rate blood pressure and subjective stress reactivity performance related and social dimension of state self esteem were assessed before and after stress induction substantial increase in cardiovascular parameter were found on both day regardless of feedback condition however positive feedback led to significantly diminished neuroendocrine response on day 1 whereas baseline cortisol on session 2 wa significantly higher in the negative feedback group conversely social self esteem decreased after stress induction on both day only for participant who had received negative feedback change in self esteem reported on day 1 were associated with increased baseline cortisol at the second session while interindividual difference in self reported trait rumination were associated with cortisol reactivity at session 1 taken together the result suggest that effect of social evaluation during short period of physical stress rely on post event processing and might be counteracted by positive appraisal directly after stress exposure post hoc framing in term of success v failure may predict subsequent stress related hormonal effect better than task demand per se which should be considered a a potential moderator in future acute stress research but might also be relevant to many practical application in field ranging from sport performance to health psychology

Title: Learning to see the threat: temporal dynamics of ERPs of motivated attention in fear conditioning
Authors: Ferreira de Sa, D. S.; Michael, T.; Wilhelm, F. H.; Peyk, P.
Abstract: social threat detection is important in everyday life study of cortical activity have shown that event related potential erps of motivated attention are modulated during fear conditioning the time course of motivated attention in learning and extinction of fear is however still largely unknown we aimed to study temporal dynamic of learning process in classical fear conditioning to social cue neutral face by selecting an experimental setup that produce large effect on well studied erp component early posterior negativity epn late positive potential lpp stimulus preceding negativity spn and then exploring small consecutive group of trial epn lpp and spn markedly and quickly increased during the acquisition phase in response to the c but not the c these change were visible even at high temporal resolution and vanished completely during extinction moreover some evidence wa found for component difference in extinction learning with difference between c and c extinguishing faster for late a compared to early erp component result demonstrate that fear learning to social cue is a very fast and highly plastic process and conceptually different erps of motivated attention are sensitive to these change at high temporal resolution pointing to specific neurocognitive and affective process of social fear learning

Title: Neural correlates of facilitations in face learning by selective caricaturing of facial shape or reflectance
Authors: Itz, M. L.; Schweinberger, S. R.; Schulz, C.; Kaufmann, J. M.
Abstract: spatially caricatured face were recently shown to benefit face learning schulz et al 2012a moreover spatial information may be particularly important for encoding unfamiliar face but le so for recognizing familiar face kaufmann et al 2013 to directly test the possibility of a major role of reflectance information for the recognition of familiar face we compared effect of selective photorealistic caricaturing in either shape or reflectance on face learning and recognition participant learned 3d photographed face across different viewpoint and different image were presented at learning and test at test performance benefit for both type of caricature were modulated by familiarity benefit for learned face were substantially larger for reflectance caricature whereas benefit for novel face were numerically larger for shape caricature erps confirmed a consistent reduction of the occipitotemporal p200 200 240 m by shape caricaturing whereas the most prominent effect of reflectance caricaturing wa seen in an enhanced posterior n250 240 400 m a component that ha been related to the activation of acquired face representation our result suggest that performance benefit for face learning caused by distinctive spatial versus reflectance information are mediated by different neural process with different timing and support a prominent role of reflectance for the recognition of learned face

Title: Recognizing visual speech: Reduced responses in visual-movement regions, but not other speech regions in autism
Authors: Borowiak, K.; Schelinski, S.; von Kriegstein, K.
Abstract: speech information inherent in face movement is important for understanding what is said in face to face communication individual with autism spectrum disorder asd have difficulty in extracting speech information from face movement a process called visual speech recognition currently it is unknown what dysfunctional brain region or network underlie the visual speech recognition deficit in asd we conducted a functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri study with concurrent eye tracking to investigate visual speech recognition in adult diagnosed with high functioning autism and pairwise matched typically developed control compared to the control group n 17 the asd group n 17 showed decreased blood oxygenation level dependent bold response during visual speech recognition in the right visual area 5 v5 mt and left temporal visual speech area tvsa brain region implicated in visual movement perception the right v5 mt showed positive correlation with visual speech task performance in the asd group but not in the control group psychophysiological interaction analysis ppi revealed that functional connectivity between the left tvsa and the bilateral v5 mt and between the right v5 mt and the left ifg wa lower in the asd than in the control group in contrast response in other speech motor region and their connectivity were on the neurotypical level reduced response and network connectivity of the visual movement region in conjunction with intact speech related mechanism indicate that perceptual mechanism might be at the core of the visual speech recognition deficit in asd communication deficit in asd might at least partly stem from atypical sensory processing and not higher order cognitive processing of socially relevant information

Title: Cortisol, but not intranasal insulin, affects the central processing of visual food cues
Authors: Ferreira de Sa, D. S.; Schulz, A.; Streit, F. E.; Turner, J. D.; Oitzl, M. S.; Blumenthal, T. D.; Schachinger, H.
Abstract: stress glucocorticoid and insulin are important endocrine regulator of energy homeostasis but little is known about their central interaction on the reward related processing of food cue according to a balanced group design healthy food deprived men received either 40iu intranasal insulin n 13 30mg oral cortisol n 12 both n 15 or placebo n 14 acoustic startle responsiveness wa assessed during presentation of food and non food picture cortisol enhanced startle responsiveness during visual presentation of high glycemic food picture but not during presentation of neutral and pleasant non food picture insulin had no effect based on the frustrative nonreward model these result suggest that the reward value of high glycemic food item is specifically increased by cortisol

Title: Emotion regulation as a predictor of the endocrine, autonomic, affective, and symptomatic stress response and recovery
Authors: Krkovic, K.; Clamor, A.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: stress is associated with the development of mental disorder such a depression and psychosis the ability to regulate emotion is likely to influence how individual respond to and recover from acute stress and may thus be relevant to symptom development to test this we investigated whether self reported emotion regulation predicts the endocrine autonomic affective and symptomatic response to and recovery from a stressor social evaluative stress wa induced by the trier social stress test tsst in n 67 healthy individual 53 7 female m age 29 9 self reported habitual emotion regulation skill were assessed at baseline we measured salivary cortisol heart rate negative affect state depression and state paranoia at three time point pre tsst post tsst and after a 10 min recovery phase repeated measure anova showed all indicator to significantly increase in response to the stressor p 001 and decrease during the recovery phase p 001 except for salivary cortisol which showed a linear increase p 001 the habitual use of maladaptive emotion regulation e g rumination catastrophizing significantly predicted an increased affective and reduced cortisol response adaptive emotion regulation e g acceptance reappraisal wa not predictive of the stress response for any of the indicator neither type of emotion regulation predicted response during the stress recovery phase individual who habitually resort to maladaptive emotion regulation strategy show a stronger affective and a blunted endocrine stress response which may make them vulnerable to mental health problem however further research is needed to identify the full scope of skill required for effective stress regulation before this knowledge can be used to develop effective prevention program

Title: Effects of cognitive-behavioral stress management training in individuals with functional somatic symptoms - an exploratory randomized controlled trial
Authors: Markert, C.; Gomm, C.; Ehlert, U.; Gaab, J.; Nater, U. M.
Abstract: stress is discussed a a risk factor in the manifestation and maintenance of functional somatic f symptom however there is a lack of evidence regarding the effect of cognitive behavioral stress management training cbsm on f symptom and the potentially mediating role of the neuroendocrine system this study aim to examine stress related psychological and neuroendocrine change after receiving a brief cbsm in individual with f symptom forty three participant of both sex who reported at least one current f symptom were analyzed treatment group tg n 21 waitlist control group wcg n 22 using mixed model number of symptom psychological stress and salivary cortisol level were assessed at pretreatment posttreatment and 6 month later mixed model analysis did not reveal significant difference between the tg and the wcg regarding number of f symptom p 0 05 psychological stress measure p 0 05 or the cortisol awakening response car p 0 05 the tg presented lower diurnal cortisol level at pretreatment posttreatment and 6 month later p 0 05 we did not find significant beneficial effect that were specific to cbsm further research should be undertaken to investigate the effect of cbsm on real life stress or laboratory stressor in subject with f symptom moreover learning cognitive restructuring and establishing new coping strategy into everyday life might require more time this study is a first step in filling the gap in understanding the influence of cbsm a a brief intervention on psychological and biological aspect of stress in participant with f symptom and will hopefully inform larger trial of cbsm for f symptom

Title: Stress-induced body dissatisfaction in women with binge eating disorder
Authors: Naumann, E.; Svaldi, J.; Wyschka, T.; Heinrichs, M.; von Dawans, B.
Abstract: stress is known to be a trigger for binge eating in individual with binge eating disorder bed however the influence of stressful situation on bed patient body image is le understood our study objective wa to gain insight into the effect of inducing psychosocial stress on body dissatisfaction in woman with bed overweight woman with bed n 29 and without an eating disorder control group cg n 38 underwent the trier social stress test for group tsst g stress and a nonstressful control task tsst g no stress additionally to test for the influence of body salience participant were either exposed or not exposed to a mirror participant repeatedly rated their current body dissatisfaction and psychological distress simultaneously biological stress reactivity wa measured using salivary cortisol and alpha amylase saa participant responded to tsst g stress with significantly higher psychological and biological stress compared to the tsst g control task the psychological distress response wa significantly greater in woman with bed than the cg a hypothesized exposure to acute socioevaluative stress led to exacerbated body dissatisfaction in the bed group only the finding of the present study suggest that acute socioevaluative stress may play an influential role in bed patient body dissatisfaction body image program might benefit from targeting stress management or coping skill in patient with bed psycinfo database record

Title: The effects of psychological stress on approach tendencies for smoking-related cues in smokers
Authors: Zlomuzica, A.; Lange, M.; Reher, S.; Machulska, A.; Rinck, M.
Abstract: stress may potentiate the chronification of nicotine addiction but the exact mechanism remain elusive we performed an explorative pilot study examining the effect of psychological stress administered via the socially evaluated cold pressor task secpt on implicit approach bias for smoking related cue in smoker in the approach avoidance task aat smoker n 24 were subjected to the stress or control condition of the secpt by using a within subject design consistent with previous finding a strong approach bias for smoking related cue in the aat wa found in smoker exposure to stress did not affect the general bias for smoking related cue in the aat relative to the control condition of the secpt in additional explorative analysis an interaction among carbon monoxide co level in expired air cortisol level and stress on approach bias for smoking related cue wa found higher co level possibly due to recent smoking prior to stress exposure were associated with an approach bias for smoking related cue our result suggest that co level in interaction with stress can modulate implicit automatic processing in the context of nicotine addiction our finding might provide novel cue to how stress influence cigarette craving and smoking behavior

Title: The association between the 5-HTTLPR and neural correlates of fear conditioning and connectivity
Authors: Klucken, T.; Schweckendiek, J.; Blecker, C.; Walter, B.; Kuepper, Y.; Hennig, J.; Stark, R.
Abstract: strong evidence link the 5 httlpr genotype to the modulation of amygdala reactivity during fear conditioning which is considered to convey the increased vulnerability for anxiety disorder in s allele carrier in addition to amygdala reactivity the 5 httlpr ha been shown to be related to alteration in structural and effective connectivity the aim of this study wa to investigate the effect of 5 httlpr genotype on amygdala reactivity and effective connectivity during fear conditioning a well a structural connectivity a measured by diffusion tensor imaging dti to integrate different classification strategy we used the bi allelic s allele v l l allele group a well a the tri allelic low functioning v high functioning classification approach s allele carrier showed exaggerated amygdala reactivity and elevated amygdala insula coupling during fear conditioning c c compared with the l l allele group in addition dti analysis showed increased fractional anisotropy value in s allele carrier within the uncinate fasciculus using the tri allelic classification approach increased amygdala reactivity and amygdala insula coupling were observed in the low functioning compared with the high functioning group no significant difference between the two group were found in structural connectivity the present result add to the current debate on the influence of the 5 httlpr on brain functioning these difference between s allele and l l allele carrier may contribute to altered vulnerability for psychiatric disorder

Title: Borderline personality disorder in four different age groups: a cross-sectional study of community residents in Germany
Authors: Arens, E. A.; Stopsack, M.; Spitzer, C.; Appel, K.; Dudeck, M.; Volzke, H.; Grabe, H. J.; Barnow, S.
Abstract: study examining the natural course of borderline personality disorder bpd over the life span have yielded declining prevalence rate in older age group however there is evidence that different bpd symptom have different longitudinal pattern with impulsivity decreasing with advancing age and negative affect remaining stable into late adulthood however since all study dealt with treated clinical sample of bpd patient it is not yet known whether this represents the natural course of bpd symptom or just mirror difference in treatability of these symptom the author addressed this issue by investigating a nonclinical population and compared prevalence of bpd impulsivity and depressivity in various age group from adolescence to late adulthood n 2 488 all individual were assessed by standardized clinical interview syndromal and subsyndromal bpd rate sharply decreased between adolescent and young adult and remained stable thereafter whereas the same course wa found for impulsivity depressivity increased between young middle aged and older adult the present result support the hypothesis that age related decrease in bpd diagnosis might be attributable to declining level of impulsivity whereas the persistence of a subsyndromal bpd might be attributable to an enduring negative affect

Title: Subsequent memory effects on event-related potentials in associative fear learning
Authors: Wiemer, J.; Leimeister, F.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: study of human fear learning suggest that a reliable discrimination between safe and threatening stimulus is important for survival and mental health in the current study we applied the subsequent memory paradigm in order to identify neurophysiological correlate of successful threat and safety learning we recorded event related potential while participant incidentally learned association between multiple neutral face and an aversive outcome unconditioned stimulus u conditioned stimulus c or no outcome nous c we found that an enhanced late positive potential lpp to both c and c during learning predicted subsequent memory a quadratic relationship between lpp and confidence in memory indicates a possible role in both correct and false fear memory importantly the p300 to the omission of the u following c wa enhanced for remembered c while there wa a positive correlation between p300 amplitude to both u occurrence and omission and individual memory performance a following re exposure phase indicated that memory wa indeed related to subjective fear of the c c these result highlight the importance of cognitive resource allocation to both threat and safety for the acquisition of fear and suggest a potential role of the p300 to u omission a an electrophysiological marker of successful safety learning

Title: Brain volumes differ between diagnostic groups of violent criminal offenders
Authors: Bertsch, K.; Grothe, M.; Prehn, K.; Vohs, K.; Berger, C.; Hauenstein, K.; Keiper, P.; Domes, G.; Teipel, S.; Herpertz, S. C.
Abstract: study on structural abnormality in antisocial individual have reported inconsistent result possibly due to inhomogeneous sample calling for an investigation of brain alteration in psychopathologically stratified subgroup we explored structural difference between antisocial offender with either borderline personality disorder aspd bpd or high psychopathic trait aspd pp and healthy control con using region of interest based and voxel based morphometry approach besides common distinct cluster of reduced gray matter volume within the frontal pole and occipital cortex there wa remarkably little overlap in the regional distribution of brain abnormality in aspd bpd and aspd pp when compared to con specific alteration of aspd bpd were detected in orbitofrontal and ventromedial prefrontal cortex region subserving emotion regulation and reactive aggression and the temporal pole which is involved in the interpretation of other people motif volumetric reduction in aspd pp were most significant in midline cortical area involved in the processing of self referential information and self reflection i e dorsomedial prefrontal cortex posterior cingulate precuneus and recognizing emotion of others postcentral gyrus and could reflect neural correlate of the psychopathic core feature of callousness and poor moral judgment the finding of this first exploratory study therefore may reflect correlate of prominent psychopathological difference between the two criminal offender group which have to be replicated in larger sample

Title: Frontal EEG asymmetry during symptom provocation predicts subjective responses to intrusions in survivors with and without PTSD
Authors: Meyer, T.; Quaedflieg, Cwem; Weijland, K.; Schruers, K.; Merckelbach, H.; Smeets, T.
Abstract: study suggest that frontal alpha asymmetry is closely linked to psychological adjustment following stressful experience such that more left sided frontal activation during symptom provocation might predict lower level of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd here we tested whether frontal asymmetry at rest and during exposure to neutral positive negative and trauma related image would be associated with ptsd and particularly with characteristic reexperiencing symptom symptom were assessed in trauma victim with n 24 and without ptsd n 15 using both retrospective measure and 1 week ambulatory assessment with a diary and a smartphone while resting frontal asymmetry wa unrelated to all retrospective measure left sided activation in response to the negative picture correlated with lower level of psychopathology left sided activation in the trauma related picture condition wa more specifically associated with le emotionally intense intrusion and response to viewing the picture even when corrected for other symptom of psychopathology these effect tended to increase when participant with possible overreporting tendency were removed from the analysis moreover trauma victim without ptsd i e relatively more resilient individual displayed higher left sided frontal activation in response to the negative picture also when compared with a third group of healthy trauma free individual n 15 our finding suggest that state dependent change in frontal asymmetry could serve a a biological marker of ptsd symptom and could eventually be used for diagnostic purpose or a a target for neuromodulation intervention future study should establish whether this marker can serve a an early predictor of psychopathology in recently traumatized individual

Title: The effect of subjective social status on depressive thinking: An experimental examination
Authors: Schubert, T.; Sussenbach, P.; Schafer, S. J.; Euteneuer, F.
Abstract: subjective social status s predicts health outcome above and beyond objective measure of social status both objective and subjective measure of social status are strongly related with depression cognitive mechanism such a depressive cognition rumination and a negative cognitive style are seen a both concomitant and antecedent to depression this experiment examined the causal role of s in developing depressive thinking participant were randomly assigned to a low and a high status group and followed a manipulation procedure targeting their s depressive thinking wa subsequently assessed by depressive cognition stress reactive state rumination and negative cognitive style low status participant exhibited higher level of depressive cognition and rumination compared to their high status counterpart but both group did not differ regarding their cognitive style finding support the causal nature of the relationship between s and depressive thinking several mechanism of how low s may lead to depression are discussed

Title: On the impairment of executive control of attention in chronic tinnitus: Evidence from the attention network test
Authors: Jensen, M.; Huttenrauch, E.; Muller-Mazzotta, J.; Stuck, B. A.; Weise, C.
Abstract: subjective chronic tinnitus is a condition that is common in most population whereas many individual tend to habituate to tinnitus over time for some their attention seems pathologically drawn towards the sensation for this subgroup of individual with severe tinnitus dysfunctional executive attention ha been suggested to be implicated in the failure to habituate however since most previous study have used attention test with low validity and specificity in this assessment there is a need for further corroborating study in the present study the attention network test wa used to compare mainly the efficiency of executive attention between a group of individual with chronic tinnitus tg n 33 and a healthy control group cg n 37 the result showed that individual with chronic tinnitus compared to the cg did not present with a specific impairment in executive control of attention nor in any of the other two attention domain these finding are discussed in relation to the sampling characteristic in this study which might have led to the sample being more homogenous and high functioning than sample in tinnitus study generally overall this study suggests that tinnitus and executive control of attention impairment might not be directly related and that the latter might not necessarily be associated with the maintenance of the condition

Title: Learning processes underlying avoidance of negative outcomes
Authors: Andreatta, M.; Michelmann, S.; Pauli, P.; Hewig, J.
Abstract: successful avoidance of a threatening event may negatively reinforce the behavior due to activation of brain structure involved in reward processing here we further investigated the learning related property of avoidance using feedback related negativity frn the frn is modulated by violation of an intended outcome prediction error pe that is the bigger the difference between intended and actual outcome the larger the frn amplitude is twenty eight participant underwent an operant conditioning paradigm in which a behavior button press allowed them to avoid a painful electric shock during two learning block participant could avoid an electric shock in 80 of the trial by pressing one button avoidance button or by not pressing another button punishment button after learning participant underwent two test block which were identical to the learning one except that no shock were delivered participant pressed the avoidance button more often than the punishment button importantly response frequency increased throughout the learning block but it did not decrease during the test block indicating impaired extinction and or habit formation in line with a pe account frn amplitude to negative feedback after correct response i e unexpected punishment wa significantly larger than to positive feedback i e expected omission of punishment and it increased throughout the block highly anxious individual showed equal frn amplitude to negative and positive feedback suggesting impaired discrimination these result confirm the role of negative reinforcement in motivating behavior and learning and reveal important difference between high and low anxious individual in the processing of prediction error

Title: Increased child-evoked activation in the precuneus during facial affect recognition in mothers
Authors: Plank, I. S.; Hindi Attar, C.; Kunas, S. L.; Bermpohl, F.; Dziobek, I.
Abstract: successful parenting requires constant inferring of affective state especially vital is the correct identification of facial affect previous study have shown that infant face are processed preferentially compared to adult face both on the behavioural and the neural level this study specifically investigates the child evoked neural response to affective face and their modulation by motherhood and attention to affect to do so we used a paradigm to measure neural response during both explicit and implicit facial affect recognition far in mother and non mother using child and adult face increased activation to child compared to adult face wa found for mother and non mother in face processing area bilateral fusiform gyrus and area associated with social understanding bilateral insulae and medial superior frontal gyrus when pooling implicit and explicit affect recognition furthermore this child evoked activation wa modulated by motherhood with an increase in mother compared to non mother in the left precuneus additionally explicitly recognising the affect increased child evoked activation in the medial superior frontal gyrus in both mother and non mother these result suggest preferential treatment of affective child over adult face modulated by motherhood and attention to affect

Title: Assessing suicidality in real time: A psychometric evaluation of self-report items for the assessment of suicidal ideation and its proximal risk factors using ecological momentary assessments
Authors: Forkmann, T.; Spangenberg, L.; Rath, D.; Hallensleben, N.; Hegerl, U.; Kersting, A.; Glaesmer, H.
Abstract: suicidal ideation is a major risk factor for suicidal behavior and ha recently been shown to be fluctuating in study applying ecological momentary assessment emas the aim of this study are to introduce a reliable and valid item set for assessing suicidal ideation and relevant proximal risk factor that can be used in future ema study within suicidology additionally we provide data on the ability of the item to capture moment to moment variability and discus feasibility aspect of ema study on suicidal ideation in a clinical sample psychiatric inpatient diagnosed with a depressive disorder n 74 rated a set of 28 item measuring suicidal ideation thwarted belongingness perceived burdensomeness depression anxiety hopelessness and positive affect 10 time per day on 6 consecutive day in addition these construct were assessed by self report questionnaire before and after the ema period intraclass correlation and mean squared successive difference were calculated a indicator of item variability reliability wa calculated at the prompt within person and the person between person level applying an approach based on multilevel factor analysis convergent validity wa assessed by correlating the ema score with a self report questionnaire measuring the same construct all item demonstrated moment to moment variability and substantial within person variance moreover all item and scale except those assessing anxiety showed satisfying reliability at the prompt and the person level and correlation indicated convergent validity of the ema item set compliance with the emas wa excellent 89 7 researcher are encouraged to apply this useful tool in future ema study in the field of suicidology psycinfo database record c 2018 apa all right reserved

Title: Do suicide attempters and suicide ideators differ in capability for suicide?
Authors: Paashaus, L.; Forkmann, T.; Glaesmer, H.; Juckel, G.; Rath, D.; Schonfelder, A.; Engel, P.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: suicide ideation is a prerequisite for suicide attempt however the majority of ideators will never act on their thought it is therefore crucial to understand what differentiates those who consider suicide from those who attempt suicide the aim of this study wa to investigate the role of different aspect of capability for suicide fearlessness about death subjective pain tolerance objective pain persistence in differentiating suicide ideators from suicide attempter single attempter from multiple attempter and recent attempter from distant attempter a total of 308 psychiatric inpatient 53 6 female age m 36 92 sd 14 30 suffering from suicide ideation with or without lifetime suicide attempt were compared regarding fearlessness about death subjective pain tolerance and objective pain persistence assessed with a pressure algometer no difference in fearlessness about death subjective pain tolerance and objective pain persistence were found in suicide ideators v attempter single v multiple attempter and recent v distant attempter it might be presumed that fearlessness about death subjective pain tolerance and objective pain persistence do not offer useful information for the differentiation between suicide ideators and attempter however there are several limitation to take into account further effort is needed to understand more clearly what differentiates suicide ideators from suicide attempter
