Title: Positive Mental Health Mediates the Relationship Between Facebook Addiction Disorder and Suicide-Related Outcomes: A Longitudinal Approach
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Teismann, T.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: suicide related outcome increased among young adult in the last decade excessive use of social medium wa hypothesized to contribute to this development this longitudinal study aimed to investigate whether facebook addiction disorder fad predicts suicide related outcome and whether positive mental health pmh buffer this effect data of 209 german facebook user m age sd age 23 01 4 45 were assessed at two measurement time point over a 1 year period first measurement t1 and second measurement t2 through online survey fad wa measured with the bergen facebook addiction scale pmh wa assessed with the pmh scale and suicide related outcome were measured with the suicidal behavior questionnaire revised the significant positive association between fad t1 and suicide related outcome t2 wa significantly negatively mediated by pmh t1 these result demonstrate that addictive facebook use may enhance the risk of suicide related outcome however pmh contributes to the reduction of this risk therefore addictive facebook use and pmh should be taken into account when assessing individual for suicide of risk

Title: Direct suppression as a mechanism for controlling unpleasant memories in daily life
Authors: Kupper, C. S.; Benoit, R. G.; Dalgleish, T.; Anderson, M. C.
Abstract: suppressing unwanted memory can impair their later recall recent work show that this forgetting is achieved by at least two mechanism supported by distinct neural system thought substitution and direct suppression benoit anderson 2012 here we examined whether direct suppression thought to be achieved by down regulation of hippocampal activity can disrupt memory of aversive scene and if so whether this disruption is linked to people s perception of their ability to control intrusive thought we presented participant with strong naturalistic reminder to aversive scene and asked them to either covertly retrieve or directly suppress the associated scene later participant were cued with the reminder and asked to recall the scene in detail direct suppression reduced recall probability of the scene and also reduced the number of detail recalled even when scene were remembered deficit in recall arose for minor detail but also for detail central to each scene s gist participant with higher self perceived control ability over intrusive thought showed greater forgetting than did those reporting lower level of control these finding suggest that inhibitory process underlying direct suppression can disrupt retention of aversive visual memory and link those process to individual difference in control over intrusive thought in everyday life these finding reinforce the possibility that inhibition may be le efficient in people likely to acquire posttraumatic stress disorder in the wake of a traumatic experience

Title: The Complex Dynamics of Resources and Maintaining Factors in Social Networks for Alcohol-Use Disorders: A Cross-Sectional Study
Authors: Braus, N.; Kewitz, S.; Hunger-Schoppe, C.
Abstract: systemic therapy considers the complex dynamic of relational factor and resource contributing to psychological symptom negative maintaining factor have been well researched for people suffering from alcohol use disorder aud however we know little about the complex dynamic of these negative factor and resource we interviewed fifty five participant suffering or fully remitted from alcohol use disorder in this cross sectional study m 52 year 33 female the interview focused on relational factor e g social support and social negativity referring to a support social network and a craving social network csn the csn included all significant others who were associated with craving situation we compared the network characteristic of the group suffering from alcohol use disorder n 38 to a fully remitted control group n 17 the abstinent group with full remission named on average fewer individual in the csns they had lower social negativity mean score in the support social network compared to the non remitted group d 0 74 in the csn the mean score of social support were significantly higher than the median for both group d 2 50 these finding reveal the complex interplay of relational pattern contributing to the etiology maintenance and recovery from alcohol use disorder a successful recovery can be linked to increased social resource and reduced relation associated with craving however craving associated relation represent an important source of social support future research should investigate this ambivalence for the systemic perspective on the explanation and treatment of alcohol use disorder

Title: Increased neural reactivity to emotional pictures in men with high hair testosterone concentrations
Authors: Klein, S.; Kruse, O.; Tapia Leon, I.; Stalder, T.; Stark, R.; Klucken, T.
Abstract: testosterone ha been linked to alteration in the activity of emotion neurocircuitry including amygdala orbitofrontal cortex ofc and insula and diminished functional amygdala prefrontal coupling such association have only ever been studied using acute measure of testosterone thus little is known about respective relationship with long term testosterone secretion here we examine association between hair testosterone concentration htc an index of long term cumulative testosterone level and neural reactivity during an emotional passive viewing task using functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri forty six men viewed negative positive and neutral picture in the mri htcs were assessed from 2 cm hair segment the emotional paradigm elicited neural activation in the amygdala insula and ofc htcs were associated with increased reactivity to negative picture in the insula and increased reactivity to positive picture in the ofc we show an association of long term testosterone level with increased emotional reactivity in the brain these result suggest a heightened emotional vigilance in individual with high trait testosterone level

Title: Smaller subcortical volumes and enlarged lateral ventricles are associated with higher global functioning in young adults with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome with prodromal symptoms of schizophrenia
Authors: Heller, C.; Weiss, T.; Del Re, E. C.; Swago, S.; Coman, I. L.; Antshel, K. M.; Fremont, W.; Bouix, S.; Kates, W. R.; Kubicki, M. R.; Kikinis, Z.
Abstract: the 22q11 2 deletion syndrome 22q11ds is a developmental genetic syndrome associated with a 30 risk for developing schizophrenia lateral ventricle and subcortical structure are abnormal in this syndrome a well a in schizophrenia here we investigated whether these structure are related in young adult with 22q11ds with and without prodromal symptom p for schizophrenia and whether abnormality in volume are associated with global functioning mr image were acquired on a 3t scanner from 51 individual with 22q11ds and 30 healthy control mean age 21 2 year correlation were performed to evaluate the relationship between ventricular and subcortical volume with global assessment of functioning gaf and premorbid adjustment scale pa in each group lateral ventricular volume correlated negatively with subcortical volume in individual with 22q11ds in individual with 22q11ds with p only gaf correlated positively with volume of the lateral ventricle and negatively with subcortical volume pa correlated negatively with lateral ventricle volume and positively with volume of subcortical structure the result suggest a common neurodevelopmental mechanism related to the growth of these brain structure further the ratio between the volume and clinical measure could potentially be used to characterize individual with 22q11ds and those from the general population for the risk of the development of schizophrenia

Title: Activation of thalamus in motor imagery results from gating by hypnosis
Authors: Muller, K.; Bacht, K.; Prochnow, D.; Schramm, S.; Seitz, R. J.
Abstract: the ability to mentally imagine the performance of automatic movement ha been well established being employed in sport and physiotherapy a a tool for motor learning and rehabilitation this is probably mediated by engagement of the same brain area a during real motor performance here we investigated the effect of hypnotic trance on the cerebral activation pattern engaged in motor imagery in 16 healthy right handed subject using fmri motor imagery a compared with rest wa related to activation in the left medial frontal area presma sma prefrontal and frontal area putamen and inferior parietal area when compared with performance of the same movement motor imagery resulted in activation of the left middle frontal cortex precuneus and posterior cingulate under hypnotic trance there wa one extra activation in the left thalamus which occurred specifically in the motor imagery condition the regional beta index were highly correlated among the area of the cortical subcortical motor network our data accord with the notion that hypnotic trance enhances the motor control circuit engaged in motor imagery by modulating the gating function of the thalamus

Title: Script-based Reappraisal Test introducing a new paradigm to investigate the effect of reappraisal inventiveness on reappraisal effectiveness
Authors: Zeier, P.; Sandner, M.; Wessa, M.
Abstract: the ability to regulate emotion is essential for psychological well being therefore it is particularly important to investigate the specific dynamic of emotion regulation in a new approach we developed a novel paradigm the script based reappraisal test srt to measure the process involved in reappraisal especially reappraisal inventiveness i e the ability to create multiple and differing reappraisal the aim of this study wa twofold 1 experimentally validate the srt and 2 investigate whether reappraisal inventiveness increase reappraisal effectiveness healthy student n 143 completed the srt in this task we presented everyday emotional situation in textual form and instructed participant to either decrease negative emotion by generating different reappraisal reappraisal trial or react naturally control trial to the situation after each trial participant indicated their affective state sam and typed in their reappraisal thought within subject analysis showed significantly le negative affect and arousal in reappraisal trial compared to control trial indicating a successful emotion regulation through reappraisal contrary to our hypothesis reappraisal inventiveness and reappraisal effectiveness were not related the theoretical and practical implication are discussed in the light of a person by situation approach

Title: Modality of fear cues affects acoustic startle potentiation but not heart-rate response in patients with dental phobia
Authors: Wannemuller, A.; Sartory, G.; Elsesser, K.; Lohrmann, T.; Johren, H. P.
Abstract: the acoustic startle response sr ha consistently been shown to be enhanced by fear arousing cross modal background stimulus in phobics intra modal fear potentiation of acoustic sr wa rarely investigated and generated inconsistent result the present study compared the acoustic sr to phobia related sound with that to phobia related picture in 104 dental phobic patient and 22 control acoustic background stimulus were dental treatment noise and birdsong and visual stimulus were dental treatment and neutral control picture background stimulus were presented for 4 s randomly followed by the administration of the startle stimulus in addition to sr heart rate hr wa recorded throughout the trial irrespective of their content background picture elicited greater sr than noise in both group with a trend for phobic participant to show startle potentiation to phobia related picture but not noise unlike control phobics showed hr acceleration to both dental picture and noise hr acceleration of the phobia group wa significantly positively correlated with sr in the noise condition only the acoustic sr to phobia related noise is likely to be inhibited by prolonged sensorimotor gating

Title: Investigating Female Sexual Concordance: Do Sexual Excitation and Sexual Inhibition Moderate the Agreement of Genital and Subjective Sexual Arousal in Women?
Authors: Velten, J.; Scholten, S.; Graham, C. A.; Adolph, D.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the agreement of subjective and genital sexual response also referred to a sexual concordance show substantial variability between woman identifying predictor of sexual arousal and sexual concordance is important to improve our understanding of female sexual response and it relationship to sexual function or dysfunction the aim of this study wa to a the relevance of sexual excitation and sexual inhibition a predictor of subjective sexual arousal genital arousal and sexual concordance in a laboratory setting sexual arousal wa induced by erotic video stimulus subjective sexual arousal wa assessed continuously during stimulus presentation and genital arousal wa measured with vaginal photoplethysmography data of 58 woman m age 24 95 sd 4 65 were analyzed using multilevel analysis hlm this data analytic technique estimate the within subject association of subjective and genital arousal by controlling for between subject difference an interaction term of sexual excitation and sexual inhibition significantly predicted genital sexual arousal in exploratory analysis two lower order factor of sexual inhibition concern about sexual function and arousal contingency were predictive of sexual concordance further examination of these association might increase our knowledge of female sexual function and deepen our understanding of how sexual excitation and sexual inhibition affect sexual arousal and consequently impact sexual behavior in woman

Title: Approach Bias Modification in Food Craving-A Proof-of-Concept Study
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Hahn, C.; Reetz, C.; Schmidt, U.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: the aim of the present proof of concept study wa to test a novel cognitive bias modification cbm programme in an analogue sample of people with subclinical bulimic eating disorder ed psychopathology thirty participant with high level of trait food craving were trained to make avoidance movement in response to visual food stimulus in an implicit learning paradigm the intervention comprised ten 15 minute session over a 5 week course at baseline participant showed approach and attentional bias towards high caloric palatable food that were both significantly reduced and turned into avoidance bias after the training participant also reported pronounced reduction in both trait and cue elicited food craving and in ed symptom a well the overall evaluation of the training by the participant wa positive the specific cbm programme tested in this pilot trial promise to be an effective and feasible way to alter automatic action tendency towards food in people suffering from bulimic ed psychopathology

Title: The thinner the better: self-esteem and low body weight in anorexia nervosa
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Holtforth, M. G.; Bents, H.; Kammerer, A.; Herzog, W.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: the aim of the present study wa to examine the association between self esteem motive satisfaction and body weight in acute acan and recovered recan inpatient with anorexia nervosa an and in healthy control both acan and recan showed lower level of self esteem a compared with healthy control but did not differ from each other in acan decreased body weight wa associated with increased self esteem satisfaction of an achievement motive but not satisfaction of a superiority motive mediated this association no such correlation could be observed in the other group this is the first study to show an often assumed association between decreased body weight and increased self esteem in an patient these preliminary result strengthen the assumption that low body weight may foster self esteem in patient with acan mainly through the satisfaction of an achievement motive key practitioner message self esteem should be focused very early in the treatment of an since weight gain may deprive the patient of an important source of self esteem treatment intervention should be attuned to underlying motif of threatened self esteem in an patient the enhancement of self esteem via weight loss seems to be rather fuelled by the satisfaction of an achievement motive than by the satisfaction of a superiority motive specific training to improve self esteem in an patient seem to be promising a an add on to regular treatment

Title: The Dimensional Structure of the Gambling Attitudes and Beliefs Survey: Challenging the Assumption of the Unidimensionality of Gambling-Specific Cognitive Distortions
Authors: Gehlenborg, J.; Moritz, S.; Bucker, L.
Abstract: the aim of the present study wa to examine the dimensional structure of the gambling attitude and belief survey gab the gab wa administered to a sample of 415 individual with self reported problem or pathological gambling who were taking part in two different treatment study preregistered with the german clinical trial register drks00013888 and clinicaltrials gov nct03372226 exploratory factor analysis revealed a three factor structure we labeled the factor sensation seeking illusion of control luck gambler s fallacy and attitude emotion subsequent confirmatory factor analysis proved the three factor model superior to the one factor model proposed by the developer of the gab all dimension were significantly correlated with symptom severity score group comparison showed significantly higher factor score on the first factor sensation seeking illusion of control for individual reporting both skill based and chance based gambling compared to those reporting only chance based gambling the present study question the unidimensionality of the gab a multidimensional assessment of gambling related cognitive bias belief and positively valued attitude may be useful in determining treatment outcome and goal and in the development of novel intervention

Title: Short-term group schema cognitive-behavioral therapy for young adults with personality disorders and personality disorder features: associations with changes in symptomatic distress, schemas, schema modes and coping styles
Authors: Renner, F.; van Goor, M.; Huibers, M.; Arntz, A.; Butz, B.; Bernstein, D.
Abstract: the aim of this pilot study wa to document the effect of a group schema cognitive behavioral therapy intervention scbt g van vreeswijk broersen 2006 on global symptomatic distress in young adult with personality disorder or personality disorder feature we also sought to determine the stability of maladaptive schema schema mode and coping response throughout treatment a well a relation among these variable with improvement in symptomatic distress during treatment twenty six young adult mean age 22 5 year range 18 29 year with a primary diagnosis of a dsm iv cluster b or cluster c personality disorder or with personality disorder feature participated in the 20 session scbt g protocol global symptomatic distress decreased substantially from pre treatment to post treatment d 0 81 maladaptive schema schema mode and dysfunctional coping response decreased with medium to large effect size d s 0 56 and 0 98 respectively however decrease in maladaptive schema wa not significant after controlling for symptomatic distress adaptive schema mode increased slightly d 0 40 throughout treatment baseline level of maladaptive schema predicted symptomatic distress concurrently and at mid treatment but not at post treatment our finding provide preliminary evidence that scbt g might be an effective treatment for young adult with personality disorder or personality disorder feature in term of improvement in global symptomatic distress and underlying vulnerability

Title: Maternal self-confidence postpartum and at pre-school age: the role of depression, anxiety disorders, maternal attachment insecurity
Authors: Zietlow, A. L.; Schluter, M. K.; Nonnenmacher, N.; Muller, M.; Reck, C.
Abstract: the aim of this study wa to analyze the impact of maternal postpartum depression and or anxiety disorder according to dm iv on maternal self confidence throughout infancy and early childhood exploratively association between maternal attachment insecurity and maternal self confidence at pre school age were examined the sample n 54 of this prospective longitudinal study wa comprised of n 27 woman with postpartum depression and or anxiety disorder according to dsm iv criterion and n 27 healthy woman without present or history of mental health disorder or psychotherapy data wa collected in the postpartum period m 60 08 day and at pre school age m 4 7 year subject were recruited between 2004 and 2011 in south germany data revealed a significant difference in maternal self confidence between clinical and control group at child s pre school age woman with postpartum depression and or anxiety disorder scored lower on maternal self confidence than healthy control but only if they had current scid diagnosis or partly remitted symptom according to explorative analysis maternal attachment insecurity turned out to be the strongest predictor of maternal self confidence at pre school age besides maternal mental health status the result emphasize the impact of attachment insecurity and maternal mental health regarding maternal self confidence leading to potential adverse long term consequence for the mother child relationship attachment based intervention taking maternal self confidence into account are needed

Title: Quality of life and predictors of long-term outcome after severe burn injury
Authors: Renneberg, B.; Ripper, S.; Schulze, J.; Seehausen, A.; Weiler, M.; Wind, G.; Hartmann, B.; Germann, G.; Liedl, A.
Abstract: the aim of this study wa to identify the long term quality of life after severe burn injury in a prospective longitudinal design n 265 burn patient were examined 6 12 24 and 36 month after burn injury a multilevel approach wa used to measure stability and change in self reported health status besides injury related variable self report instrument included measure of quality of life psychological distress personality and specific burn outcome measure fitting of unconditional growth model indicated that there wa significant intra and inter individual variation in self reported physical and mental health short form 12 over the course of 3 year participant reported on average a slight improvement of physical quality of life physical health wa mainly predicted by mobility and level of burn severity variance in mental health status wa mainly predicted by gender mobility neuroticism level of depression and posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd related avoidance thus mobility i e simple ability seems a crucial variable for overall quality of life an early identification and treatment of patient with high level of depression and ptsd related avoidance may contribute to better mental health

Title: Patients' pre- and postoperative expectations as predictors of clinical outcomes six months after cardiac surgery
Authors: Kube, T.; Meyer, J.; Grieshaber, P.; Moosdorf, R.; Boning, A.; Rief, W.
Abstract: the aim of this study wa to investigate not only preoperative expectation a shown previously but also postoperative expectation of patient predict clinical outcome six month after cardiac surgery furthermore the study sought to examine illness behavior a a possible pathway through which expectation may affect postoperative well being seventy patient scheduled for cardiac surgery were examined one day before surgery 7 10 day after surgery and six month after surgery regression analysis indicated that disability at follow up primary outcome wa significantly predicted by postoperative beta 342 p 008 but not by preoperative expectation beta 213 p 069 similar result were found for the secondary outcome i e quality of life and depressive symptom a bootstrapped mediation analysis showed that although both postoperative expectation and illness behavior had significant unique effect on disability there wa no significant mediation effect while previous study have mainly focused on patient preoperative expectation the present is the first to emphasize the predictive value of patient expectation a few day after surgery pointing to the potential of intervention targeting postoperative expectation however given the non significant result of the mediation analysis it remains unclear how exactly patient expectation affect clinical outcome in cardiac surgery

Title: Neurostructural correlates of two subtypes of specific phobia: a voxel-based morphometry study
Authors: Hilbert, K.; Evens, R.; Maslowski, N. I.; Wittchen, H. U.; Lueken, U.
Abstract: the animal and blood injection injury bii subtypes of specific phobia are both characterized by subjective fear but distinct autonomic reaction to threat previous functional neuroimaging study have related these characteristic response to shared and non shared neural underpinnings however no comparative structural data are available this study aim to fill this gap by comparing the two subtypes and also comparing them with a non phobic control group gray and white matter data of 33 snake phobia subject sp 26 dental phobia subject dp and 37 healthy control hc subject were analyzed with voxel based morphometry especially dp differed from hc and sp by showing significantly increased grey matter volume in widespread area including the right subgenual anterior cingulate gyrus left insula left orbitofrontal and left prefrontal pfc cortex in addition white matter volume wa significantly increased in the left pfc in dp compared with sp these result are in line with functional change observed in dental phobia and point toward those brain circuit associated with emotional processing and regulation future study should aim to further delineate functional and structural connectivity alteration in specific phobia

Title: The influence of frontal alpha-asymmetry on the processing of approach- and withdrawal-related stimuli-A multichannel psychophysiology study
Authors: Adolph, D.; von Glischinski, M.; Wannemuller, A.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the approach withdrawal model of hemispheric activation suggests that left frontal cortical area mediate approach while right frontal cortical area mediate withdrawal motivation within this framework the present study investigates the association of frontal cortical asymmetry with attentional and emotional response toward approach and withdrawal related emotional stimulus resting frontal asymmetry wa measured from 43 student before they passively viewed negative neutral and positive emotional picture the startle reflex skin conductance response and subjective rating of valence and arousal were assessed to quantify emotional responding while attention wa assessed with erps we also assessed frontal asymmetry in response to the picture result indicated that relatively stronger right frontal cortical activation wa associated with increased n1 amplitude and more negative subjective emotional evaluation of all stimulus furthermore enhanced right frontal asymmetry state and trait wa associated with diminished emotional modulation of the late positive potential in contrast no association of frontal asymmetry with defensive reflex physiology or activation of sympathetic nervous system activity wa found the current data suggest dissociable influence of resting frontal brain asymmetry on attentional and physiological processing of withdrawal and approach related stimulus that is asymmetrical frontal cortical brain activation might not modulate approach withdrawal related motor response and sympathetic arousal directly but instead enhances allocation of attentional resource to subjectively significant stimulus the result are discussed in term of their potential importance for emotion perception in anxiety disorder and their contribution to the understanding of frontal asymmetry

Title: Emotional inertia contributes to depressive symptoms beyond perseverative thinking
Authors: Brose, A.; Schmiedek, F.; Koval, P.; Kuppens, P.
Abstract: the autocorrelation or inertia of negative affect reflects how much negative emotion carry over from moment to moment and ha been associated with increased depressive symptom in this study we posed three challenge to this association by examining 1 whether emotional inertia is relevant for depressive symptom when assessed on a longer timescale than usual 2 whether inertia is uniquely related to depressive symptom after controlling for perseverative thought and 3 whether inertia is related to depressive symptom over and above the within person association between affect and perseverative thought participant n 101 provided rating of affect and perseverative thought for 100 day depressive symptom were reported before and after the study and again after 2 5 year day to day emotional inertia wa related to depressive symptom over and above trait and state perseverative thought moreover inertia predicted depressive symptom when adjusting for it association with perseverative thought these finding establish the relevance of emotional inertia in depressive symptom independent of perseverative thought

Title: Are you gonna leave me? Separation anxiety is associated with increased amygdala responsiveness and volume
Authors: Redlich, R.; Grotegerd, D.; Opel, N.; Kaufmann, C.; Zwitserlood, P.; Kugel, H.; Heindel, W.; Donges, U. S.; Suslow, T.; Arolt, V.; Dannlowski, U.
Abstract: the core feature of separation anxiety is excessive distress when faced with actual or perceived separation from people to whom the individual ha a strong emotional attachment so far little is known about the neurobiological underpinnings of separation anxiety therefore we investigated functional amygdala responsiveness and functional connectivity during threat related emotion processing and structural grey matter volume imaging marker associated with separation anxiety a measured with the relationship scale questionnaire in a large sample of healthy adult from the munster neuroimaging cohort n 320 we used a robust emotional face matching task and acquired high resolution structural image for morphometric analysis using voxel based morphometry the main result were positive association of separation anxiety score with amygdala reactivity to emotional face a well a increased amygdala grey matter volume a functional connectivity analysis revealed positive association between separation anxiety and functional coupling of the amygdala with area involved in visual process and attention including several occipital and somatosensory area taken together the result suggest a higher emotional involvement in subject with separation anxiety while watching negative facial expression and potentially secondary neuro structural adaptive process these result could help to understand and treat adult separation anxiety

Title: Selecting and imagining rewarding activities during the COVID-19 lockdown: Effects on mood and what moderates them
Authors: Hoyer, J.; Dechmann, J. C. G.; Stender, T.; Colic, J.
Abstract: the covid 19 outbreak strongly restricted daily activity creating a risk factor for negative affect and depression this study assessed the immediate effect of a behavioural activation ba intervention on positive pa and negative na state affect we expected depression and anxiety to function a moderator reducing the intervention effect in a quasi experimental online study 3624 german speaking participant evaluated a list of rewarding activity between 9 april and 26 april 2020 a subsample of 2561 71 additionally engaged in an imagination task depression anxiety socioeconomic variable and covid 19 related burden were assessed a moderator there wa an increase in pa total sample d 13 subsample d 27 and a decrease in na total sample d 0 68 subsample d 0 71 all p 001 the effect rose with higher level of depression and anxiety all p 001 furthermore living with family enhanced the effect on na while additionally having to take care of child reduced them an easy to use intervention prompting ba could improve state mood during lockdown participant with higher depression and anxiety benefit more implication for the prevention of mental health problem during a pandemic are discussed

Title: Mental Health and Loneliness in University Students During the COVID-19 Pandemic in Germany: A Longitudinal Study
Authors: Weber, M.; Schulze, L.; Bolzenkotter, T.; Niemeyer, H.; Renneberg, B.
Abstract: the covid 19 pandemic and it preventive measure had adverse consequence for mental health however knowledge of mental health trajectory across the pandemic is limited this study investigated the mental health level and change among university student during the pandemic and lockdown in germany a well a their associated factor we surveyed student mental health n 363 68 female with the patient health questionnaire phq 8 and the generalized anxiety disorder scale gad 7 during the first easing phase july 2020 time 1 and the second lockdown november 2020 time 2 cut off score from the gad 7 and phq 8 were used to determine clinically relevant symptom and to define trajectory group sociodemographic and pandemic related data were assessed e g coping with academic life social contact a well a loneliness stress repetitive negative thinking quality of life and perceived social support paired t test multiple regression and repeated measure anova were applied mean and prevalence rate for symptom of depression 38 8 and anxiety 25 6 did not differ between time 1 and time 2 and most student were asymptomatic on the phq 8 44 4 and the gad 7 56 3 across the pandemic feeling of loneliness significantly increased from time 1 to time 2 d 0 30 0 47 0 13 with higher symptom level in symptomatic group at time 2 and greater increase in the asymptomatic group level of stress repetitive negative thinking quality of life and social support did not differ during the pandemic at time 1 loneliness and repetitive negative thinking were associated with anxiety and depressive symptom anxiety and depressive symptom were prevalent among student and increased level of loneliness during the pandemic were associated with elevated symptom and differing trajectory further research using representative and larger sample should determine the long term impact of the pandemic on mental health and loneliness to identify vulnerable student and offer adequate support

Title: Impact of COVID-19 pandemic related stressors on patients with anxiety disorders: A cross-sectional study
Authors: Langhammer, T.; Peters, C.; Ertle, A.; Hilbert, K.; Lueken, U.
Abstract: the covid 19 pandemic and related containment measure are affecting mental health especially among patient with pre existing mental disorder the aim of this study wa to investigate the effect of the first wave and it aftermath of the pandemic in germany march july on psychopathology of patient diagnosed with panic disorder social anxiety disorder and specific phobia who were on the waiting list or in current treatment at a german university based outpatient clinic from 108 patient contacted forty nine patient 45 37 completed a retrospective survey on covid 19 related stressor depression and change in anxiety symptom patient in the final sample n 47 reported a mild depression and significant increase in unspecific anxiety d 41 panic symptom d 85 and specific phobia d 38 while social anxiety remained unaltered pandemic related stressor like job insecurity familial stress and working in the health sector were significantly associated with more severe depression and increase in anxiety symptom high pre pandemic symptom severity anxiety depression wa a risk factor whereas meaningful work and being divorced separated were protective factor explained variance 46 5 of change in anxiety and 75 8 in depressive symptom in line with diathesis stress model patient show a positive association between stressor and symptom load health care system are requested to address the need of this vulnerable risk group by implementing timely and low threshold intervention to prevent patient from further deterioration

Title: The effects of momentary loneliness and COVID-19 stressors on hypothalamic-pituitary adrenal (HPA) axis functioning: A lockdown stage changes the association between loneliness and salivary cortisol
Authors: Haucke, M.; Golde, S.; Saft, S.; Hellweg, R.; Liu, S.; Heinzel, S.
Abstract: the covid 19 pandemic can be characterized a a chronic stressor affecting the hypothalamic pituitary adrenal hpa axis indexed by glucocorticoid e g cortisol we investigated whether salivary cortisol level is increased during a lockdown and whether a lockdown condition affect the association between loneliness specific covid 19 related stressor and salivary cortisol level we conducted a smartphone based ecological momentary assessment ema study with 280 participant in germany who experienced at least mild loneliness and distress amid covid 19 from august 2020 to march 2021 we measured their momentary loneliness and covid related stressor including worry information seeking behavior and feeling of restriction during no lockdown or lockdown stage amid covid 19 their salivary cortisol wa measured 4 time on the last day of a 7 day ema study we found a significant increase in salivary cortisol level during lockdown compared to no lockdown lockdown stage wa found to moderate the relationship between momentary loneliness and salivary cortisol level i e loneliness wa positively related to cortisol level specifically during lockdown mechanism explaining the effect of forced social isolation on the association between loneliness and salivary cortisol need to be investigated in future study

Title: Fear learning and generalization during pandemic fear: How COVID-19-related anxiety affects classical fear conditioning with traumatic film clips
Authors: Hauck, A.; Michael, T.; Ferreira de Sa, D. S.
Abstract: the covid 19 pandemic greatly disrupted our daily life worldwide people were confronted with health financial and existential fear or trauma like experience recent study have identified an increase in stress anxiety and fear symptom in connection with the pandemic furthermore fear learning process are central mechanism in the development and maintenance of anxiety disorder patient commonly show impairment not only in fear learning but also in it generalization thus pandemic related anxiety may constitute a risk factor for both enhanced fear acquisition and generalization in a pre registered online study with a final sample of 220 healthy university student we investigated whether participant with higher covid 19 related anxiety covid anxiety show impaired fear learning and generalization for this purpose we used a differential fear conditioning paradigm with a traumatic film clip a the unconditioned stimulus u and collected u expectancy a the main measure of interest participant with high covid anxiety show a tendency toward poorer discrimination between the reinforced conditioned stimulus c and the unreinforced conditioned stimulus c during acquisition and significantly poorer discrimination pattern during generalization furthermore participant with high covid anxiety show greater general fear throughout the whole experiment our result show that the subjective effect of the covid 19 pandemic on psychological well being are associated with impairment in both fear learning and fear generalization a expected high covid anxiety lead to poorer performance in stimulus discrimination and greater level of fear which might contribute to a higher risk of anxiety disorder german clinical trial register drks00022761

Title: Quality of life during the COVID-19 pandemic – Results of the CORONA HEALTH App studyCommunicating and understanding pain: Limitations of pain scales for patients with sickle cell disorder and other painful conditions
Authors: Eicher, Sophie; Pryss, Rüdiger; Baumeister, Harald; Hövener, Claudia; Knoll, Nina; Cohrdes, Caroline; Collins, Peter J.; Renedo, Alicia; Marston, Cicely A.
Abstract: the covid 19 pandemic ha brought about great change to the everyday life of the population in germany social distancing working from home and other measure to contain the pandemic are essentially dominating everyday life with data from the corona health app study we analysed the quality of life of the adult population in germany during the covid 19 pandemic and identified possible risk factor for a poor quality of life in the app based survey carried out between july and december 2020 1 396 respondent woman 46 5 men 52 7 diverse 0 9 mean age mean 42 0 year standard deviation 13 4 provided information on their quality of life using the world health organization quality of life questionnaire whoqol bref univariate and multivariate regression wa used to examine difference in quality of life between different group of people during the covid 19 pandemic and their association with selected predictor in summary woman younger person and job seeker or those who saw their work hour reduced or who could not pursue their regular job presented a lower quality of life in individual area of life than the respective reference group on the other hand a setting that combine working from home and at the regular workplace a well a living together with other people showed partly positive association with quality of life the result have implication for public health intervention a they highlight group requiring closer attention and sufficient support service

Title: COVID Feel Good: Evaluation of a Self-Help Protocol to Overcome the Psychological Burden of the COVID-19 Pandemic in a German Sample
Authors: Meyer, M. L.; Kaesler, A.; Wolffgramm, S.; Peric, N. L.; Bunjaku, G.; Dickmann, L.; Serino, S.; Di Lernia, D.; Tuena, C.; Bernardelli, L.; Pedroli, E.; Wiederhold, B. K.; Riva, G.; Shiban, Y.
Abstract: the covid 19 pandemic ha severe consequence for physical a well a mental well being in time of restricted social contact online self help program offer a low threshold first aid to cope with the psychological burden this current study evaluates the online self help protocol covid feel good in a german sample the multicentric study wa designed a a single cohort with a waiting list control condition the convenience sample consisted of 38 german individual who experienced at least two month of restriction during the covid 19 pandemic the 7 day self help protocol included the vr video secret garden a well a a social or cognitive exercise each day general distress depression anxiety stress and hopelessness were assessed a primary outcome social connectedness and fear of coronavirus were measured a secondary outcome result showed a significant decrease in all primary outcome except for hopelessness furthermore the result indicated a significant improvement in social connectedness treatment effect on general distress depression stress and anxiety persisted for two week after participation the present study indicates that vr based self help protocol can mitigate the psychological burden associated with the pandemic supporting recent finding

Title: Lockdown, quarantine measures, and social distancing: Associations with depression, anxiety and distress at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic among adults from Germany
Authors: Benke, C.; Autenrieth, L. K.; Asselmann, E.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: the covid 19 pandemic is suggested to have a negative impact on mental health to prevent the spread of sars cov 2 government worldwide have implemented different form of public health measure ranging from physical distancing recommendation to stay at home order which have disrupted individual everyday life tremendously however evidence on the association of the covid 19 pandemic and public health measure with mental health are limited so far in this study we investigated the role of sociodemographic and covid 19 related factor for immediate mental health consequence in a nationwide community sample of adult from germany n 4335 specifically we examined the effect of different form and level of restriction resulting from public health measure e g quarantine stay at home order on anxiety and depression symptomatology health anxiety loneliness the occurrence of fearful spell psychosocial distress and life satisfaction we found that higher restriction due to lockdown measure a greater reduction of social contact and greater perceived change in life were associated with higher mental health impairment importantly a subjectively assumed but not an officially announced stay at home order wa associated with poorer mental health our finding underscore the importance of adequate risk communication and targeted mental health recommendation especially for vulnerable group during these challenging time

Title: Emotional and Behavioral Consequences of the COVID-19 Pandemic: The Role of Health Anxiety, Intolerance of Uncertainty, and Distress (In)Tolerance
Authors: Sauer, K. S.; Jungmann, S. M.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: the covid 19 pandemic represents a worldwide threat to mental health to optimize the allocation of health care resource research on specific vulnerability factor such a health anxiety intolerance of uncertainty and distress in tolerance and particularly their effect on the time course of sars cov 2 related anxiety appears crucial for supporting high risk group suffering from elevated mental distress during the pandemic n 887 participant 78 4 female m age 38 15 sd 17 04 completed an online survey in germany april to mid may 2020 comprising measure of sars cov 2 related anxiety health anxiety safety and preventive behavior intolerance of uncertainty and distress intolerance higher level of health anxiety pre and during covid 19 were associated with an initially intensified increase b 1 10 p 0 001 but later on a more rapid dampening b 0 18 p 0 001 of sars cov 2 related anxiety sars cov 2 related preventive behavior wa intensified by both pre b 0 06 p 0 01 and during b 0 15 p 0 001 covid 19 health anxiety while reassurance behavior only wa associated with health anxiety during covid 19 b 0 14 p 0 001 distress intolerance and intolerance of uncertainty did not moderate the relationship between health anxiety and sars cov 2 related anxiety and behavior the result suggest detrimental effect of health anxiety on the emotional and behavioral response to virus outbreak
Journal: Int J Environ Res Public Health

Title: The Role of Social Skills in Predicting Treatment-Recovery in Children with a Social Anxiety Disorder
Authors: Klein, A. M.; Liber, J. M.; van Lang, N. D. J.; Reichart, C.; Nauta, M.; van Widenfelt, B. M.; Utens, Emwj
Abstract: the current study investigated the role of social skill and it interaction with social anxiety a predictor of treatment outcome in child with an anxiety disorder either with or without a social anxiety disorder soad in total 133 child aged 8 to 13 with an anxiety disorder received a 10 session cognitive behavioral treatment friend program pre to post treatment reliable change rc and treatment recovery tr were assessed from a multi informant perspective by including diagnostic information adis c p child reported anxiety symptom masc and parent reported internalizing symptom cbcl int social skill were assessed with the parent rated social skill rating system assertion self control responsibility result showed that 1 parent of child with a soad reported significantly le favorable use of assertive and responsible social behavior in their child pre treatment than parent of child without soad 2 child with higher social skill had a better treatment recovery and 3 child with anxiety and higher responsible behavior pre treatment and without a soad had a better treatment recovery but this effect did not show for child with soad in conclusion better use of social behavior increased the likelihood of treatment recovery but not of reliable change further study on the role of social skill in the treatment of childhood social anxiety are needed to investigate the mechanism by which social skill impact treatment outcome

Title: Delay of Gratification, Delay Discounting and their Associations with Age, Episodic Future Thinking, and Future Time Perspective
Authors: Gollner, L. M.; Ballhausen, N.; Kliegel, M.; Forstmeier, S.
Abstract: the delay of gratification dog in child is widely investigated with an experimental procedure originally called the marshmallow test whereas the study on self regulation sr in adolescent and adult usually use self report questionnaire delay discounting dd measure simplify the dog procedure and focus on monetary reward the aim of this study wa to investigate age difference in dog and dd from childhood to old age using a test that is suitable for both child and adult furthermore investigation were conducted on the association between dog dd and two future orientation construct future time perspective ftp and episodic future thinking eft a well a age difference in these construct participant from five age group 9 14 18 25 35 55 65 80 80 participated in the study n 96 while we found no age difference for dog dd wa the lowest i e self control sc wa the highest in young middle adult however it wa the highest i e sc wa the lowest in child and old oldest adult furthermore we found significant age difference for dd and ftp a predicted there were strong correlation between dog and ftp and between dd and ftp but not between dog dd and eft these result indicate that age difference in sr vary across the measure used individual who generally think and act in a future oriented manner have a stronger ability to delay gratification

Title: Selective Visual Attention Towards Oneself and Associated State Body Satisfaction: an Eye-Tracking Study in Adolescents with Different Types of Eating Disorders
Authors: Bauer, A.; Schneider, S.; Waldorf, M.; Braks, K.; Huber, T. J.; Adolph, D.; Vocks, S.
Abstract: the development of eating disorder is associated with a body related attentional bias although eating disorder are especially prevalent in adolescence so far no study ha analyzed gaze pattern and state body image in response to viewing one s own body in youth to fill this gap the present study aimed to examine a body related attentional bias and state body satisfaction in adolescent with various form of eating disorder girl with anorexia nervosa restrictive type an r n 30 anorexia nervosa binge eating purging type an bp n 26 bulimia nervosa bn n 22 clinical control with anxiety disorder n 20 and healthy control n 43 looked at photograph of their own and a peer s body while their spontaneous eye movement were recorded after stimulus presentation state body satisfaction and individual attractiveness rating for area of the presented stimulus were assessed an analysis of variance revealed that participant of all subgroup showed an attentive preference for unattractive area of one s own body girl with an r attended significantly longer to unattractive body area than both control group and significantly shorter to attractive body area than healthy control state body dissatisfaction wa more prominent in all eating disorder subgroup with significantly lower score in bn compared to an r in general the higher the state body dissatisfaction the stronger wa the deficit orientation on one s own body the attentional bias towards unattractive body area which is most pronounced in an r indicates that intervention aiming to modify distorted attention might be promising in the prevention and treatment of eating disorder in adolescence

Title: The relation of cognitive reappraisal and expressive suppression to suicidal ideation and suicidal desire
Authors: Forkmann, T.; Scherer, A.; Bocker, M.; Pawelzik, M.; Gauggel, S.; Glaesmer, H.
Abstract: the differential relation between the emotion regulation strategy cognitive reappraisal and expressive suppression and suicidality in a mixed inpatient sample n 232 69 4 female of a german psychotherapeutic hospital were examined patient filled in the emotion regulation questionnaire and item on suicidal ideation and desire a structural equation model fitted the data rmsea 044 cfi 96 and revealed that expressive suppression significantly predicted increased suicidal ideation moderation analysis showed that result were independent from a current depressive episode potential implication for psychotherapeutic treatment of suicidality are discussed

Title: How the Dorsolateral Prefrontal Cortex Controls Affective Processing in Absence of Visual Awareness - Insights From a Combined EEG-rTMS Study
Authors: Keuper, K.; Terrighena, E. L.; Chan, C. C. H.; Junghoefer, M.; Lee, T. M. C.
Abstract: the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc play a key role in the modulation of affective processing however it specific role in the regulation of neurocognitive process underlying the interplay of affective perception and visual awareness ha remained largely unclear using a mixed factorial design this study investigated effect of inhibitory continuous theta burst stimulation ctbs of the right dlpfc rdlpfc compared to an active control condition on behavioral n 48 and electroencephalographic n 38 correlate of affective processing in healthy chinese participant event related potential erps in response to passively viewed subliminal and supraliminal negative and neutral natural scene were recorded before and after ctbs application we applied minimum norm approach to estimate the corresponding neuronal source on a behavioral level we found evidence for reduced emotional interference by and le negative and aroused rating of negative supraliminal stimulus following rdlpfc inhibition we found no evidence for stimulation effect on self reported mood or the behavioral discrimination of subliminal stimulus on a neurophysiological level rdlpfc inhibition relatively enhanced occipito parietal brain activity for both subliminal and supraliminal negative compared to neutral image 112 268 m 320 380 m the early onset and localization of these effect suggests that rdlpfc inhibition boost automatic process of emotional attention independently of visual awareness further our study reveals the first available evidence for a differential influence of rdlpfc inhibition on subliminal versus supraliminal neural emotion processing explicitly our finding indicate that rdlpfc inhibition selectively enhances late 292 360 m activity in response to supraliminal negative image we tentatively suggest that this differential frontal activity likely reflects enhanced awareness dependent down regulation of negative scene processing eventually leading to facilitated disengagement from and le negative and aroused evaluation of negative supraliminal stimulus

Title: Temporal Stability of Sexual Excitation and Sexual Inhibition in Women
Authors: Velten, J.; Zahler, L.; Scholten, S.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the dual control model of sexual response proposes two factor sexual excitation se and sexual inhibition si that aim to predict sexual behavior and response while se and si are described a stable trait that influence sexuality related outcome such a sexual function or sexual risk taking only a few study have presented data on the stability of these factor the aim of this study wa to evaluate the temporal stability of se and si and to investigate whether change in sexual function or partnership status influence se and si in a longitudinal sample of woman to address these research question the sexual excitation sexual inhibition inventory for woman sesii w wa administered five time over the course of 4 year the sesii w includes two main scale of se and si which consist of five arousability partner characteristic sexual power dynamic smell and setting and three subscales concern about sexual function arousal contingency relationship importance respectively data from 553 woman m age 31 38 year sd 10 25 range 18 67 who participated in at least two assessment point were included in this study bivariate correlation between baseline and the fifth follow up assessment indicated a high temporal stability of se and si in woman 47 r 71 a series of generalized linear model were conducted to investigate the impact of time change in sexual function partnership status and change in partnership status on se and si partner characteristic se that showed small increase over time across different subscales improvement in sexual function were associated with higher se and lower si change in partnership status and partnership status itself were predictor of one se and three si related scale this study suggests a relatively high temporal stability of se and si in woman and support the dual control model s assertion that both factor are stable individual trait certain life event such a a new partnership or sexual difficulty may however impact time stability of both factor

Title: The time course of pupil dilation evoked by visual sexual stimuli: Exploring the underlying ANS mechanisms
Authors: Finke, J. B.; Deuter, C. E.; Hengesch, X.; Schachinger, H.
Abstract: the early processing of visual sexual stimulus show sign of automaticity moreover there is evidence for sex specific pattern in cognitive and physiological responding to erotica however little is known about the time course of rapid pupillary response to sexual stimulus and their correspondence with other measure of autonomic activity in woman and men to study pupil dilation a an implicit measure of sexual arousal at various stage of picture processing we presented 35 heterosexual participant with picture showing either erotic couple or single male female erotic nude contrasted with people involved in everyday situation brightness adjusted grayscale picture were shown for a duration of 2 500 m within the central visual field alternating with perceptually matched patch left pupil diameter wa recorded at 500 hz using a video based eye tracker skin conductance and heart rate were coregistered and correlated with latent component of pupil dilation dissociated by temporal pca whereas stimulus evoked change in pupil size indicated virtually no initial constriction a rapid effect of appetence emerged dilation to erotica within 500 m response at early stage of processing were remarkably consistent across both sex in contrast later phase of pupil dilation subjective rating and skin conductance response showed a sex specific pattern moreover evidence for an association of early onset pupil dilation and heart rate acceleration wa found suggestive of parasympathetic inhibition whereas the late component wa mainly related to sympathetically mediated skin conductance taken together our result indicate that different temporal component of pupil response to erotic stimulus may reflect divergent underlying neural mechanism

Title: Endocannabinoid concentrations in hair are associated with PTSD symptom severity
Authors: Wilker, S.; Pfeiffer, A.; Elbert, T.; Ovuga, E.; Karabatsiakis, A.; Krumbholz, A.; Thieme, D.; Schelling, G.; Kolassa, I. T.
Abstract: the endocannabinoid system ha been implicated in the regulation of the stress response fear memory formation and inflammatory process posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd can result from exposure to extreme stress and is characterized by strong associative memory for the traumatic event experienced furthermore an elevated physical disease risk ha been observed in ptsd likely to be mediated by inflammatory process therefore altered endocannabinoid regulation can be expected in individual with ptsd however attempt to a ptsd associated difference in the endocannabinoid system from human blood sample have provided inconsistent result possibly due to fluctuating level of endocannabinoids in hair these neuromodulators are accumulated over time and thus give access to a more stable and reliable assessment we therefore investigated ptsd associated difference in hair concentration of endocannabinoids n acyl ethanolamides palmitoylethanolamide pea oleoylethanolamide oea and stearoylethanolamide sea in 38 rebel war survivor from northern uganda suffering from ptsd and n 38 healthy rebel war survivor without current and lifetime ptsd ptsd diagnosis and symptom severity were assessed in structured clinical interview employing the posttraumatic diagnostic scale pd a significant group difference wa observed for oea with ptsd patient showing reduced hair concentration regression analysis further revealed strong negative relationship between all investigated n acyl ethanolamides and symptom severity of ptsd the observed reduction in endocannabinoids might account for the increased inflammatory state a well a for the failure to extinguish fear memory observed in ptsd our finding add to the accumulating evidence suggesting the endocannabinoid system a a target for pharmacological enhancement of exposure based psychotherapy for ptsd

Title: Associations of neural error-processing with symptoms and traits in a dimensional sample recruited across the obsessive-compulsive spectrum
Authors: Riesel, A.; Harpfer, K.; Thoma, L.; Kathmann, N.; Klawohn, J.
Abstract: the error related negativity ern a neural response to error ha been associated with several form of psychopathology and assumed to represent a neural risk marker for obsessive compulsive disorder ocd and anxiety disorder yet it is still unknown which specific symptom or trait best explain ern variation this study investigated performance monitoring in participant n 100 recruited across a spectrum of obsessive compulsive characteristic n 26 patient with ocd n 74 healthy participant including n 24 with low n 24 with medium and n 26 with high oc characteristic several compulsivity and anxiety associated characteristic were assessed and submitted to exploratory principal axis factor analysis association of raw measure and derived factor with ern and correct related negativity crn were examined patient with ocd showed increased ern amplitude compared to healthy participant the ern wa associated with a variety of trait related to anxiety and negative affect factor analysis result revealed a most prominent association of the ern with a composite measure of anxiety and neuroticism whereas the crn wa specifically associated with compulsivity result support differential association for the ern and crn and demonstrate that a dimensional recruitment approach and use of composite measure can improve our understanding of characteristic underlying variation in neural performance monitoring

Title: Endocrine dysregulation in women with irritable bowel syndrome according to Rome II criteria
Authors: Markert, C.; Suarez-Hitz, K.; Ehlert, U.; Nater, U. M.
Abstract: the etiology of the irritable bowel syndrome ibs is unexplained biological psychological and social factor must be considered this study examined if difference in hpa axis activity already exist in those who do not yet fulfill ibs criterion i e subthreshold ibs we also investigated whether there were difference between those who reported clinically relevant i e distressing ibs symptom and those who did not thirty six woman were subdivided into three group ibs group subthreshold ibs group control group result showed difference in morning cortisol level u 11 58 p 0 05 with ibs patient showing a lower cortisol response compared to control subthreshold ibs patient were comparable to control regarding endocrine function diurnal cortisol level did not differ between group group comparison between distressed subject and non distressed subject regarding cortisol level did not reach significance the finding of endocrine abnormality at least in a sub set of patient is important since these might be associated with deficient pain processing in ibs

Title: Prospective study of nocebo effects related to symptoms of idiopathic environmental intolerance attributed to electromagnetic fields (IEI-EMF)
Authors: Brascher, A. K.; Schulz, S. M.; Van den Bergh, O.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: the exact cause of idiopathic environmental intolerance attributed to electromagnetic field iei emf i e experience of somatic symptom attributed to low level electromagnetic field are still unknown psychological causation such a nocebo effect seem plausible this study aimed to experimentally induce a nocebo effect for somatic symptom perception and examined whether it wa reproducible after one week we also examined whether these effect were associated with increased sympathetic activity and whether interoceptive accuracy iacc moderated these relationship participant were recruited from the general population and instructed that electromagnetic exposure can enhance somatosensory perception they participated twice in a cued exposure experiment with tactile stimulation and sham wifi exposure in 50 of trial the two session were scheduled one week apart session 1 n 65 session 2 n 63 before session 1 participant watched either a 6 min film on adverse health effect of emf or a neutral film on trade of mobile phone iacc wa assessed with the heartbeat detection paradigm electrodermal activity served a a measure of sympathetic activation evidence for a nocebo effect i e increased self reported intensity and aversiveness and electrodermal activity during sham wifi exposure wa observed in both session iacc moderated the nocebo effect depending on stimulus intensity contrary to previous finding no difference emerged between the health related emf and the neutral film based on negative instruction somatic perception and physiological responding can be altered this is consistent with the assumption that iei emf could be due to nocebo effect suggesting an important role for psychological intervention

Title: Social phobic beliefs mediate the relationship between post-event processing regarding the worst socially aversive experience and fear of negative evaluation
Authors: Seinsche, R. J.; Walter, B.; Fricke, S.; Neudert, M. K.; Zehtner, R. I.; Stark, R.; Hermann, A.
Abstract: the experience of socially aversive event is proposed to be a critical etiological factor in the development of social anxiety symptom even though the experience itself is also common among healthy individual rather than the event itself accompanying factor such a maladaptive processing might be associated with higher level of social anxiety symptom one hundred seventy four individual participated in this online survey comprising questionnaire regarding social anxiety symptom and retrospective report concerning maladaptive processing of the worst socially aversive event structural equation modelling wa used to analyze the hypothesized mediation of maladaptive processing and fear of negative evaluation by intrusive re experiencing and social phobic belief the positive association between retrospectively evaluated maladaptive processing after the worst socially aversive event and fear of negative evaluation wa mediated by social phobic belief but not by intrusive re experiencing these result point towards the relevance of further investigating processing strategy after socially aversive event a a potential influencing factor for sad development trial registration the trial wa registered at the german clinical trial register drks00021502 on june 3 rd 2020 supplementary information the online version contains supplementary material available at 10 1007 s12144 022 02805 9

Title: Emotional modulation of the attentional blink and the relation to interpersonal reactivity
Authors: Kanske, P.; Schonfelder, S.; Wessa, M.
Abstract: the extent of the attentional blink effect on detection rate in rapid serial visual presentation is modulated by the emotionality of the stimulus emotionally salient stimulus are detected more often even if presented in the attentional blink period and elicit an enlarged p3 response which ha been interpreted a enhanced consolidation this effect correlate with individual difference in trait affectivity such a anxiety or dysphoria here we ask if it is also related to the capacity to detect emotion in others i e to interpersonal social trait we therefore presented emotional and neutral image depicting social scene a target in an attentional blink design and measured detection rate and event related potential in addition we recorded self report of empathy a measured by the interpersonal reactivity index the result show enhanced performance for emotional stimulus and increased p3 amplitude which correlated with individual difference in empathy the data suggest that self reported empathy go along with enhanced processing of emotion in social stimulus even under stimulus condition that are suboptimal for conscious target detection

Title: We prefer what we fear: A response preference bias mimics attentional capture in spider fear
Authors: Haberkamp, A.; Biafora, M.; Schmidt, T.; Weiss, K.
Abstract: the extent to which emotionally significant stimulus capture visual attention remains elusive because a preference for reporting or choosing emotionally significant stimulus could mimic attentional capture by these stimulus we conducted two prior entry experiment to disentangle whether phobic and fear relevant stimulus capture attention or merely produce a response bias in spider fearful participant prior entry denotes the effect that attended stimulus are perceived earlier than unattended stimulus a indicated by temporal order judgment we presented phobic spider fear relevant snake and neutral stimulus in pair with varying temporal onset the participant task wa to indicate which stimulus wa presented first experiment 1 or second experiment 2 in the first experiment spider fearful but not control participant indicated that they had perceived spider a occurring earlier in time suggesting a prior entry effect for spider in this group but surprisingly in the second experiment spider fearful participant indicated more frequently that they had seen spider a being presented second this finding rule out a genuine prior entry effect and instead suggests a strong preference for the response option associated with the feared animal this response bias may result from a hypervigilance toward the feared stimulus and contribute to maintaining avoidance behavior in individual with specific phobia

Title: Influence of suppression and reappraisal on eating-related symptoms and ruminative thinking in anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa
Authors: Naumann, E.; Svaldi, J.
Abstract: the goal of the present study wa to investigate the influence of expressive suppression and cognitive reappraisal on eating related symptomatology in anorexia nervosa an and bulimia nervosa bn secondly on the background of theoretical model proposing a reciprocal relationship between suppression and rumination we sought to understand whether inhibition of emotional expression also affect ruminative thinking in eating disorder woman with an n 39 bn n 37 and a control group cg n 41 were randomly assigned to either engage in suppression or reappraisal during a sadness eliciting film clip level of drive to eat anticipated loss of control over eating and ruminative thought were rated before and after the induction of emotion regulation induced expressive suppression led to a decrease of reported drive to eat in an and an increase of anticipated loss of control over eating in bn all group responded to suppression with greater rumination whereas no significant change were found for reappraisal mediation analysis on trait questionnaire pointed to rumination a a partial mediator of the correlation between suppression and eating disorder pathology result are discussed in line with recent empirical research and current emotion regulation theory

Title: Cognitive Bias Modification Reduces Social Anxiety Symptoms in Socially Anxious Adolescents with Mild Intellectual Disabilities: A Randomized Controlled Trial
Authors: Klein, A. M.; Salemink, E.; de Hullu, E.; Houtkamp, E.; Papa, M.; van der Molen, M.
Abstract: the goal of this study wa to examine the effect of cognitive bias modification training for interpretation cbm i in socially anxious adolescent with mild intellectual disability mid a total of 69 socially anxious adolescent with mid were randomly assigned to either a positive or a neutral control cmb i training training included five session in a 3 week period and each session consisted of 40 training item adolescent in the positive training group showed a significant reduction in negative interpretation bias on the two interpretation bias task after training compared to adolescent in the control training group furthermore in contrast to the control training group adolescent in the positive training reported a significant reduction of their social anxiety symptom 10 week post training

Title: Early prefrontal brain responses to the Hedonic quality of emotional words--a simultaneous EEG and MEG study
Authors: Keuper, K.; Zwitserlood, P.; Rehbein, M. A.; Eden, A. S.; Laeger, I.; Junghofer, M.; Zwanzger, P.; Dobel, C.
Abstract: the hedonic meaning of word affect word recognition a shown by behavioral functional imaging and event related potential erp study however the spatiotemporal dynamic and cognitive function behind are elusive partly due to methodological limitation of previous study here we account for these difficulty by computing combined electro magnetoencephalographic eeg meg source localization technique participant covertly read emotionally high arousing positive and negative noun while eeg and meg were recorded simultaneously combined eeg meg current density reconstruction for the p1 80 120 m p2 150 190 m and epn component 200 300 m were computed using realistic individual head model with a cortical constraint relative to negative word the p1 to positive word predominantly involved language related structure left middle temporal and inferior frontal region and posterior structure related to directed attention occipital and parietal region effect shifted to the right hemisphere in the p2 component by contrast negative word received more activation in the p1 time range only recruiting prefrontal region including the anterior cingulate cortex acc effect in the epn were not statistically significant these finding show that different neuronal network are active when positive versus negative word are processed we account for these effect in term of an emotional tagging of word form during language acquisition these tag then give rise to different processing strategy including enhanced lexical processing of positive word and a very fast language independent alert response to negative word the valence specific recruitment of different network might underlie fast adaptive response to both approach and withdrawal related stimulus be they acquired or biological

Title: The human amygdala drives reflexive orienting towards facial features
Authors: Gamer, M.; Schmitz, A. K.; Tittgemeyer, M.; Schilbach, L.
Abstract: the human amygdala is reliably activated by facial expression 1 but the precise functional relevance of such activity change is not well understood because most previous study did not allow for separating effect of the emotional expression from the distribution of specific facial feature and neglected corresponding attentional process finding on rare patient with bilateral amygdala damage indicate that the amygdala might be involved in triggering shift of overt attention towards specific facial feature such a the eye 2 moreover it wa reported that healthy individual show a preference for attending to the eye region across different emotional expression 3 this early attentional bias wa linked to amygdala activity 4 and wa found to be most pronounced for fearful face and le pronounced for happy facial expression 3 5 these finding indicate that healthy individual show a tendency to automatically attend to facial feature that are diagnostic of the current emotional state of conspecific 6 here we examined an otherwise healthy male adult individual mw with unilateral right sided amygdala loss in a novel eye tracking based face perception task in order to clarify the functional role of the amygdala complex in driving attentional orienting compared to a sample of matched control mw showed an isolated deficit in reflexive gaze shift towards diagnostic emotional facial feature during brief stimulus presentation a compared to normal performance during longer viewing period these result suggest that the amygdala is implicated in quickly detecting diagnostic facial feature in the visual periphery and driving reflexive saccade towards these location

Title: Reduced olfactory bulb volume in adults with a history of childhood maltreatment
Authors: Croy, I.; Negoias, S.; Symmank, A.; Schellong, J.; Joraschky, P.; Hummel, T.
Abstract: the human olfactory bulb ob is the first relay station of the olfactory pathway and may have the potential for postnatal neurogenesis in early childhood in animal chronic stress affect the ob and olfactory functioning for human it ha been shown that major depressive disorder is accompanied by reduced ob volume and reduced olfactory function however it is not clear if major stress in childhood development also affect olfactory functioning and ob volume in human ob volume wa measured and olfactory function wa tested in 17 depressive patient with and 10 without a history of severe childhood maltreatment cm cm patient exhibited a significantly reduced olfactory threshold and identification ability the ob volume of the cm patient wa significantly reduced to 80 of the non cm patient in conclusion postnatal neurogenesis might be by reduced in cm which may affect olfactory function of the brain in later life alternatively a reduced ob volume may enhance psychological vulnerability in the presence of adverse childhood condition although other area not analyzed in this study may also be involved

Title: The demotivating effect of social exclusion: An experimental test of a psychosocial model on the development of negative symptoms in psychosis
Authors: Pillny, M.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: the impairment in social functioning of patient with psychotic disorder is mainly driven by motivational negative symptom with a widely unknown etiology building on the well confirmed link between specific social risk factor and psychosis the current study tested the postulated effect of immediate social exclusion on the development of motivational negative symptom and the association of repeated social exclusion experience with demotivating belief in a community sample n 84 repeated social exclusion experience and demotivating belief were assessed at baseline we randomized the participant to either an exclusion or an inclusion condition of a virtual ball tossing game motivation and anticipatory pleasure were measured before and after the manipulation via self report and via a behavioral effort paradigm we found a significant multivariate effect of social exclusion on self reported motivation f 4 79 4 25 p 01 eta2 18 but not on behavioral effort f 1 82 1 24 p 27 eta2 02 repeated social exclusion wa significantly associated with demotivating belief r 58 p 01 and negative symptom r 43 p 001 our finding support the notion that reduced motivation anticipatory anhedonia and demotivating belief can be understood a motivational and cognitive consequence of social exclusion we also discus the implication for psychological intervention and for further research on the etiology of negative symptom

Title: Entrapment, perceived burdensomeness and thwarted belongingness as predictors of suicide ideation
Authors: Forkmann, T.; Teismann, T.
