Abstract: the integrated motivational volitional imv model of suicide posit that perceived burdensomeness and thwarted belongingness moderate the association between perception of entrapment and suicide ideation however the proposed moderation is yet to be tested possible moderator effect were investigated in an online sample n 480 74 female m age 28 5 sd age 11 1 entrapment and perceived burdensomeness predicted suicide ideation however neither perceived burdensomeness nor thwarted belongingness moderated the association between entrapment and suicide ideation the present result do not support a key assumption of the imv model nonetheless they underscore the importance of perceived burdensomeness and entrapment in the prediction of suicide ideation

Title: Entrapment, positive psychological functioning and suicide ideation: A moderation analysis
Authors: Teismann, T.; Brailovskaia, J.
Abstract: the integrated motivational volitional imv model of suicide posit that the association between perception of entrapment and suicide ideation is buffered by so called motivational moderator the present study investigated whether positive mental health a well a different facet of psychological well being qualify a motivational moderator possible moderator effect were investigated in an online sample n 301 result demonstrated that positive mental health and psychological well being moderate the association between entrapment and suicide ideation these finding underscore the importance of entrapment and positive psychological functioning in understanding pathway to suicide ideation

Title: Influence of violent video gaming on determinants of the acquired capability for suicide
Authors: Teismann, T.; Fortsch, E. M.; Baumgart, P.; Het, S.; Michalak, J.
Abstract: the interpersonal theory of suicidal behavior proposes that fearlessness of death and physical pain insensitivity is a necessary requisite for self inflicted lethal self harm repeated experience with painful and provocative event are supposed to cause an incremental increase in acquired capability the present study examined whether playing a first person shooter game in contrast to a first person racing game increase pain tolerance a dimension of the acquired capability construct and risk taking behavior a risk factor for developing acquired capability n 81 male participant were randomly assigned to either play an action shooter or a racing game before engaging in a game on risk taking behavior and performing a cold pressor task cpt participant exhibited higher pain tolerance after playing an action shooter game than after playing a racing game furthermore playing an action shooter wa generally associated with heightened risk taking behavior group difference were not attributable to the effect of the different type of game on self reported mood and arousal overall these result indicate that action shooter gaming alters pain tolerance and risk taking behavior therefore it may well be that long term consumption of violent video game increase a person s capability to enact lethal self harm

Title: Pain persistence and lethality of suicide attempts
Authors: Paashaus, L.; Forkmann, T.; Glaesmer, H.; Juckel, G.; Rath, D.; Schonfelder, A.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: the interpersonal psychological theory of suicide posit that elevated pain tolerance is necessary to engage in suicidal behaviour it is assumed that suicidal intent only lead to lethal or near lethal suicide attempt when an individual ha the capability to persist the pain involved in dying the aim of this study wa to a whether objective pain persistence moderate the association between suicide intent and lethality of a recent suicide attempt ninety seven inpatient who were hospitalized due to a recent suicide attempt were interviewed regarding lifetime suicide attempt a well a their most recent suicide attempt method of attempt intention to die medical risk of death probability of an intervention and physical condition following the attempt were inquired pain persistence wa examined using a pressure algometer contrary to the expectation pain persistence did not moderate the association between suicide intent and lethality of a recent suicide attempt that is medical risk of death probability of an intervention or physical condition following the attempt future study are needed to examine method specific pain persistence for suicidal behaviour in a longitudinal study design

Title: Increased skin conductance responses and neural activity during fear conditioning are associated with a repressive coping style
Authors: Klucken, T.; Kruse, O.; Schweckendiek, J.; Stark, R.
Abstract: the investigation of individual difference in coping style in response to fear conditioning is an important issue for a better understanding of the etiology and treatment of psychiatric disorder it ha been assumed that an avoidant repressive coping style is characterized by increased emotion regulation effort in context of fear stimulus a compared to a more vigilant coping style however no study so far ha investigated the neural correlate of fear conditioning of repressor and sensitizer in the present fmri study 76 participant were classified a repressor or a sensitizer and were exposed to a fear conditioning paradigm in which the c predicted electrical stimulation while another neutral stimulus c did not in addition skin conductance response scrs were measured continuously a the main finding we found increased neural activity in repressor a compared to sensitizer in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex and the anterior cingulate cortex acc during fear conditioning in addition elevated activity to the c in amygdala insula occipital and orbitofrontal cortex ofc a well a elevated conditioned scrs were found in repressor the present result demonstrate increased neural activation in structure linked to emotion down regulation mechanism like the ventromedial prefrontal cortex which may reflect the increased coping effort in repressor at the same time repressor showed increased activation in arousal and evaluation associated structure like the amygdala the occipital cortex occ and the ofc which wa mirrored in increased scrs the present result support recent assumption about a two process model of repression postulating a fast vigilant response to fear stimulus and a second process associated with the down regulation of emotional response

Title: Mood-congruent memory in depression - the influence of personal relevance and emotional context
Authors: Wittekind, C. E.; Terfehr, K.; Otte, C.; Jelinek, L.; Hinkelmann, K.; Moritz, S.
Abstract: the investigation of veridical mood congruent memory mcm in major depressive disorder mdd ha been subject of many study whereas mood congruent false memory ha received comparatively little attention the present study examined the influence of valence personal relevance and the valence of the context of the learning material on true and false mcm in 20 inpatient with mdd and 20 healthy control sixty positive negative neutral or personally relevant noun were either combined with a positive negative or neutral adjective word pair were presented to participant in a learning trial in a recognition task participant had to identify the previously studied word pair a mcm effect could not be found for hit however in exploratory analysis word pair containing personally relevant noun were more rated towards old by the patient relative to the control group furthermore depressed patient tended to rate item more towards old than control when the word were presented in a negative new context result are in line with previous finding in depression research emphasizing the role of mood congruent false memory for mood disorder

Title: Were we erring? The impact of worry and arousal on error-related negativity in a non-clinical sample
Authors: Harpfer, K.; Carsten, H. P.; Spychalski, D.; Kathmann, N.; Riesel, A.
Abstract: the monitoring of one s own action allows human to adjust to a changing and complex world previous neuroscientific research found overactive action monitoring and increased sensitivity to error to be associated with anxiety and it is assumed to contribute to the development and maintenance of anxiety symptom a largely shared decomposition of anxiety differentiates two dimension anxious apprehension i e worry and anxious arousal i e physiological hyperarousal alteration in neural correlate of error monitoring have been more closely linked to anxious apprehension compared to anxious arousal this study examined the relationship between anxiety dimension and electrophysiological correlate of action monitoring i e error related negativity ern and correct response negativity crn a total of 135 non clinical participant performed a flanker task while their electroencephalogram wa recorded we recruited participant with converging and diverging anxiety dimension profile i e above or below median in anxious apprehension and anxious arousal or above median in one and below in the other dimension this grouping strategy facilitates disentangling possible interaction and allows the investigation of the isolated effect of each anxiety dimension regression analysis did not reveal a significant main or interaction effect of anxiety dimension on ern or crn irrespective of gender in addition bayesian statistical analyzes yielded evidence for the absence of an association between both anxiety dimension and ern and crn altogether our result suggest that the association of anxiety dimension particularly anxious apprehension and action monitoring might be smaller in non clinical sample a previous study indicate

Title: Factors Contributing to Violent Discipline in the Classroom: Findings From a Representative Sample of Primary School Teachers in Tanzania
Authors: Masath, F. B.; Hinze, L.; Nkuba, M.; Hecker, T.
Abstract: the need for intervention strategy aiming to reduce teacher use of violent discipline method ha been expressed repeatedly especially for country where this practice is socially and legally accepted nevertheless initial target for intervention are not clearly identified a factor contributing to teacher use of violence are still understudied in the present study we examined the interplay between teacher own experience of violence their attitude current stress and their use of violent discipline in a representative sample of 173 tanzanian primary school teacher 53 7 female m age 38 1 year sd age 10 using structural equation modeling our model showed good model fit chi 2 48 n 173 78 058 p 004 cfi 962 tli 948 rmsea 060 90 ci 034 084 pclose 233 srmr 048 result indicated direct association between positive attitude toward violent discipline beta 41 stress beta 23 and teacher own experience of violence beta 21 with teacher use of violence teacher own experience of violence were significantly associated with positive attitude beta 39 and these significantly mediated the association between teacher own experience of violence and their use of violent discipline beta 23 our finding underscore the relevance of past experience societal norm and current working condition in understanding teacher violence against student intervention aiming to reduce teacher use of violent discipline may focus on stress management societal norm personal belief on violent discipline and how teacher own previous experience of violence may influence teacher s disciplining behavior

Title: Cough Is Dangerous: Neural Correlates of Implicit Body Symptoms Associations
Authors: Mier, D.; Witthoft, M.; Bailer, J.; Ofer, J.; Kerstner, T.; Rist, F.; Diener, C.
Abstract: the negative interpretation of body sensation e g a sign of a severe illness is a crucial cognitive process in pathological health anxiety ha however little is known about the nature and the degree of automaticity of this interpretation bias we applied an implicit association test iat in 20 subject during functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri to investigate behavioral and neural correlate of implicit attitude toward symptom word on the behavioral level body symptom word elicited strong negative implicit association effect a indexed by slowed reaction time when symptom word were paired with the attribute harmless incongruent condition fmri revealed increased activation in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc and posterior parietal cortex for the comparison of incongruent word with control word a well a with a lower significance threshold also in comparison to congruent word moreover activation in the dlpfc posterior parietal cortex nucleus accumbens and cerebellum varied with individual level of ha again in comparison to control word a well a with a lower significance threshold also in comparison to congruent word slowed reaction time a well a increased activation in dorsolateral prefrontal and posterior parietal cortex point to increased inhibitory demand during the incongruent iat condition the positive association between ha severity and neural activity in nucleus accumbens dorsolateral prefrontal and posterior parietal cortex suggests that ha is characterized by both intensified negative implicit attitude and hampered cognitive control mechanism when confronted with body symptom

Title: Oxytocin promotes facial emotion recognition and amygdala reactivity in adults with asperger syndrome
Authors: Domes, G.; Kumbier, E.; Heinrichs, M.; Herpertz, S. C.
Abstract: the neuropeptide oxytocin ha recently been shown to enhance eye gaze and emotion recognition in healthy men here we report a randomized double blind placebo controlled trial that examined the neural and behavioral effect of a single dose of intranasal oxytocin on emotion recognition in individual with asperger syndrome a a clinical condition characterized by impaired eye gaze and facial emotion recognition using functional magnetic resonance imaging we examined whether oxytocin would enhance emotion recognition from facial section of the eye v the mouth region and modulate regional activity in brain area associated with face perception in both adult with a and a neurotypical control group intranasal administration of the neuropeptide oxytocin improved performance in a facial emotion recognition task in individual with a this wa linked to increased left amygdala reactivity in response to facial stimulus and increased activity in the neural network involved in social cognition our data suggest that the amygdala together with functionally associated cortical area mediate the positive effect of oxytocin on social cognitive functioning in a

Title: Reduced plasma oxytocin levels in female patients with borderline personality disorder
Authors: Bertsch, K.; Schmidinger, I.; Neumann, I. D.; Herpertz, S. C.
Abstract: the neuropeptide oxytocin is involved in social cognition and interaction across specie and play a crucial role in the regulation of affiliative behavior oxytocin level in cerebrospinal fluid csf but also in plasma or urine have been shown to be negatively associated with childhood trauma aggressive behavior and suicide attempt recently an altered activity of the oxytocin system ha been discussed to play a prominent role in borderline personality disorder bpd which is thought to be closely related to traumatic experience in childhood and is characterized by para suicidal behavior a well a aggressive outburst in the present study we compared plasma oxytocin level of woman with and without bpd in the follicular phase and assessed the relationship between oxytocin concentration and childhood trauma woman diagnosed with bpd had significantly reduced oxytocin concentration even after controlling for estrogen progesterone and contraceptive intake in addition plasma oxytocin correlated negatively with experience of childhood trauma in particular with emotional neglect and abuse the result of mediation analysis do not support a model of oxytocin being a prominent mediator in the link between childhood trauma and bpd thus the finding indicate dysregulations in the oxytocin system of patient diagnosed with bpd with more longitudinal research being necessary to disentangle the relationship between childhood adversity oxytocin system and psychopathology

Title: German Anxiety Barometer-Clinical and Everyday-Life Anxieties in the General Population
Authors: Adolph, D.; Schneider, S.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the objective of this study wa to test a time efficient screening instrument to a clinically relevant and everyday life e g economic political personal anxiety furthermore factor influencing these anxiety correlation between clinical and everyday anxiety and for the first time anxiety during different stage of life were assessed in a representative sample of the general population n 2229 around 30 of the respondent manifested at least one disorder specific key symptom within 1 year woman men 8 reported severe anxiety symptom two third of respondent reported minor everyday anxiety and 5 were strongly impaired whereby person with severe clinical symptom were more frequently affected a variety of potential influencing factor could be identified these include in addition to socioeconomic status gender general health risk taking and leisure behavior also some up to now little investigated possible protective factor such a everyday life mental activity the observed effect are rather small which however given the heterogeneity of the general population seems plausible although the correlative design of the study doe not allow direct causal conclusion it can however serve a a starting point for experimental intervention study in the future together with time series from repeated representative survey we expect these data to provide a better understanding of the process that underlie everyday life and clinical anxiety

Title: Efficacy of Applied Relaxation as indicated preventive intervention in individuals at increased risk for mental disorders: A randomized controlled trial
Authors: Beesdo-Baum, K.; Zenker, M.; Ruckert, F.; Kische, H.; Pieper, L.; Asselmann, E.
Abstract: the objective wa to examine the efficacy of applied relaxation ar a indicated preventive intervention to reduce psychopathological symptom and prevent incident mental disorder in a parallel group randomized controlled trial n 277 adult with elevated tension distress anxiety or depressive symptomatology depression anxiety stress scale da 21 but no 12 month dsm 5 diagnosis of any mental disorder assessed via standardized interview dia x 5 were randomized to an intervention group ig n 139 receiving group based ar training or an assessment only control group cg n 138 self report questionnaire at baseline post immediately after the 10 week intervention or a similar time frame in cg and 12 month follow up included the da 21 a primary outcome measure of intervention efficacy incident subthreshold and threshold mental disorder were assessed via dia x 5 at 12 month follow up a primary outcome of prevention efficacy intervention and prevention effect were examined on an intent to treat basis with missing data replaced using chained multiple imputation mixed model analysis revealed accelerated symptom improvement in ig versus cg with a medium baseline to post between group effect size d 0 59 95 ci 0 36 0 82 logistic regression analysis revealed a significantly lower incidence rate for sub threshold mental disorder until 12 month follow up in ig 34 7 versus cg 49 3 odds ratio 0 54 95 ci 0 31 0 92 risk ratio 0 70 95 ci 0 51 0 96 risk difference 0 15 95 ci 0 28 to 0 02 group based ar a a promising indicative preventive intervention should be tested in long term study and relative to a credible alternative intervention to assure that the intervention effect are not entirely due to demand characteristic expectancy or non specific effect

Title: Determining prognostic variables of treatment outcome in obsessive-compulsive disorder: effectiveness and its predictors in routine clinical care
Authors: Herzog, P.; Osen, B.; Stierle, C.; Middendorf, T.; Voderholzer, U.; Koch, S.; Feldmann, M.; Rief, W.; Brakemeier, E. L.
Abstract: the objective of this study were to investigate the naturalistic effectiveness of routine inpatient treatment for patient with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd and to identify predictor of treatment outcome a routinely collected data set of 1 596 ocd inpatient m 33 9 year sd 11 7 60 4 female having received evidence based psychotherapy based on the cognitive behavioral therapy cbt in five german psychotherapeutic clinic wa analyzed effect size hedge g were calculated for several outcome variable to determine effectiveness predictor analysis were performed on a subsample n 514 m 34 3 year sd 12 2 60 3 female for this purpose the number of potential predictor wa reduced using factor analysis followed by multiple regression analysis to identify robust predictor effect size of various outcome variable could be classified a large g 1 34 of ocd symptom change predictor of change in ocd and depressive symptom were symptom severity at admission and general psychopathological distress in addition patient with higher social support and more washing compulsion benefited more from treatment subgroup analysis showed a distinct predictor profile of change in compulsion and obsession the result indicate that an evidence based psychotherapy program for ocd can be effectively implemented in routine inpatient care in addition to well established predictor social support and washing compulsion in particular were identified a important positive predictor specific predictor profile for change in obsession and compulsion are discussed

Title: The relationship between social media use, anxiety and burden caused by coronavirus (COVID-19) in Spain
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Miragall, M.; Margraf, J.; Herrero, R.; Banos, R. M.
Abstract: the outbreak of covid 19 and national restriction to slow down it spread have significantly changed people s everyday life many people engage in intensive social medium use smu to stay up to date about the pandemic the present study investigated the extent of smu a source of covid 19 information and it relationship with anxiety and the experienced burden caused by the pandemic in spain of the 221 participant 52 5 reported to frequently use sm a information source the use of other information source such a print and online newspaper report television report and official governmental online site wa not associated with anxiety and burden caused by the current covid 19 situation however smu wa significantly positively linked to both variable moreover anxiety significantly mediated the relationship between smu and the experienced burden the finding show the potential negative effect of smu on individual emotional state and behavior during the pandemic they emphasize the significance of an accurate and conscious use of sm specifically during extraordinary circumstance such a the covid 19 outbreak

Title: Positive mental health and mindfulness as protective factors against addictive social media use during the COVID-19 outbreak
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the outbreak of covid 19 caused high psychological burden for many people some people tend to excessive social medium use smu to escape the negative emotion which can foster addictive tendency the present study investigated positive mental health pmh and mindfulness a protective factor that could reduce the risk for addictive smu data of 1 049 participant from germany were assessed via online survey in autumn 2021 the current result reveal a positive relationship between covid 19 burden and addictive smu both were negatively linked to pmh and mindfulness in a moderated mediation analysis the relationship between covid 19 burden and addictive smu wa mediated by pmh mindfulness moderated the association between pmh and addictive smu the covid 19 situation can be burdensome and contribute to dysfunctional coping strategy such a addictive smu however pmh and mindfulness serve a protective factor the protective effect of mindfulness could be especially important for person with low pmh

Title: The relationship between burden caused by coronavirus (Covid-19), addictive social media use, sense of control and anxiety
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the outbreak of covid 19 ha significantly restricted people s everyday life and contributed to enhanced social medium use smu the present study investigated the relationship of burden caused by covid 19 and addictive smu data were assessed in a sample of 550 user of social medium age m sd 27 08 6 74 from germany via online survey in spring 2020 in a moderated mediation analysis the positive association between burden and addictive smu wa significantly mediated by the level of perceived sense of control anxiety symptom significantly moderated the relationship between sense of control and addictive smu specifically the link between both variable wa significant only for medium and high level of anxiety symptom the present finding disclose the mechanism that can contribute to the development of addictive tendency during the pandemic outbreak potential practical implication and way of how the negative consequence of burden caused by covid 19 might be prevented are discussed

Title: The association between depression symptoms, psychological burden caused by Covid-19 and physical activity: An investigation in Germany, Italy, Russia, and Spain
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Cosci, F.; Mansueto, G.; Miragall, M.; Herrero, R.; Banos, R. M.; Krasavtseva, Y.; Kochetkov, Y.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the outbreak of covid 19 required the re organization of everyday life while some people accepted this challenge other experienced the current situation a a heavy burden that impedes the adaptation to the new life condition the present study investigated factor that can impact the level of burden caused by covid 19 burden depression symptom and frequency of physical activity e g jogging cycling were assessed via online survey in overall 1 931 people from four country germany n 625 italy n 936 russia n 230 spain n 140 similar result pattern were found in all country specific sample burden by covid 19 wa significantly positively associated with depression symptom while it wa significantly negatively linked to physical activity moreover physical activity buffered the association between depression symptom and burden the present cross national finding emphasize the protective effect of physical activity specifically in time of covid 19 this issue should be addressed in governmental program to longitudinally protect mental and physical health and to enhance the willingness to adhere to the anti covid 19 measure among the population

Title: Enhanced functional connectivity between sensorimotor and visual cortex predicts covariation bias in spider phobia
Authors: Wiemer, J.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: the overestimation of the relationship between fear relevant stimulus and aversive consequence a so called covariation bias might contribute to the maintenance of anxiety disorder in a recent fmri study we confronted spider phobia and healthy participant with picture of spider mushroom and puppy randomly followed by painful electric stimulus u spider phobics overestimated the spider u association and displayed enhanced activity in u related sensorimotor cortex paracentral lobule pcl here we report result from an additional functional connectivity analysis within spider phobics but not in healthy control u after spider led to enhanced connectivity between pcl and left prefrontal cortex pfc most importantly covariation bias in spider phobia wa predicted by connectivity between pcl and visual cortex insula primary sensorimotor cortex and secondary somatosensory cortex reduced covariation bias wa predicted by connectivity between pcl and pfc in response to spider picture the amygdala wa functionally connected to somatosensory and visual area these result suggest that synchronous activity of sensory cortex may promote fear sustaining associative memory bias while right pfc might help to reduce bias

Title: Investigating d-cycloserine as a potential pharmacological enhancer of an emotional bias learning procedure
Authors: Woud, M. L.; Blackwell, S. E.; Steudte-Schmiedgen, S.; Browning, M.; Holmes, E. A.; Harmer, C. J.; Margraf, J.; Reinecke, A.
Abstract: the partial n methyl d aspartate receptor agonist d cycloserine may enhance psychological therapy however it exact mechanism of action is still being investigated cognitive bias modification technique allow isolation of cognitive process and thus investigation of how they may be affected by d cycloserine we used a cognitive bias modification paradigm targeting appraisal of a stressful event cognitive bias modification appraisal to investigate whether d cycloserine enhanced the modification of appraisal and whether it caused greater reduction in index of psychopathology participant received either 250 mg of d cycloserine n 19 or placebo n 19 a a stressor task participant recalled a negative life event followed by positive cognitive bias modification appraisal training before and after cognitive bias modification appraisal appraisal and index of psychopathology related to the stressor were assessed cognitive bias modification appraisal successfully modified appraisal but d cycloserine did not affect appraisal post training there were no post training group difference in frequency of intrusion interestingly d cycloserine led to a greater reduction in distress and impact on state mood from recalling the event and lower distress post training wa associated with fewer intrusion therefore d cycloserine may affect emotional reactivity to recalling a negative event when combined with induction of a positive appraisal style but via a mechanism other than enhanced learning of the appraisal style

Title: All's Bad That Ends Bad: There Is a Peak-End Memory Bias in Anxiety
Authors: Muller, U. W. D.; Witteman, C. L. M.; Spijker, J.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: the peak end memory bias ha been well documented for the retrospective evaluation of pain it describes that the retrospective evaluation of pain is largely based on the discomfort experienced at the most intense point peak and at the end of the episode this is notable because it mean that longer episode with a better ending can be remembered a le aversive than shorter one this is even if the former had the same peak in painfulness and an overall longer duration of pain until now this bias ha not been studied in the domain of anxiety despite the high relevance of variable level of anxiety in the treatment of anxiety disorder therefore we set out to replicate the original study but with an induction of variable level of anxiety of 64 woman half watched a clip from a horror movie which ended at the most frightening moment the other half watched an extended version of this clip with a moderately frightening ending afterward all participant were asked to rate the global anxiety which wa elicited by the video when the film ended at the most frightening moment participant retrospectively reported more anxiety than participant who watched the extended version this is the first study to document that the peak end bias can be found in the domain of anxiety these finding require replication and extension to a treatment context to evaluate it implication for exposure therapy

Title: Gender-Specific Relation Between Olfactory Sensitivity and Disgust Perception
Authors: Croy, I.; Bendas, J.; Wittrodt, N.; Lenk, M.; Joraschky, P.; Weidner, K.
Abstract: the perception of disgust is a powerful but yet puzzling emotion aiming at the prevention of potential microbial pathogen and being directly linked to olfactory processing in it neurophysiological pathway via the anterior insular cortex in sample of healthy participant with a natural variation in olfactory function we investigated the relation between olfactory sensitivity and disgust perception a total of 123 healthy individual were surveyed with a disgust sensitivity questionnaire olfactory threshold wa assessed in all participant using the sniffin stick additionally tactile 2 point discrimination threshold wa tested in a subgroup of the participant a a controlling factor for the specificity of the relationship between olfactory sensitivity and disgust only in men a significant relation between disgust rating and olfactory threshold wa observed men with high olfactory sensitivity reported a high level of disgust a female participant while men with low olfactory sensitivity reported significantly lower disgust than woman there wa no such relation for tactile sensitivity investigating sensory subscales of the disgust questionnaire olfactory sensitivity wa related to olfactory and tactile but not to visual disgust rating in conclusion there is a specific relation between the level of disgust and olfactory sensitivity in men who generally present lower value of disgust than woman when disgust rating are low there seems to be an additional merit in the ability to perceive subtle olfactory stimulus thus high olfactory sensitivity may facilitate the perception of potential pathogenic threat and contribute to the evolutionary function of disgust a disease avoidance mechanism

Title: Microstructural alterations in medial forebrain bundle are associated with interindividual pain sensitivity
Authors: Geisler, M.; Rizzoni, E.; Makris, N.; Pasternak, O.; Rathi, Y.; Bouix, S.; Herbsleb, M.; Bar, K. J.; Weiss, T.; Kikinis, Z.
Abstract: the perception of pain to noxious stimulus also known a pain sensitivity varies among individual the comprised brain structure and their white matter pathway are complex and elusive here we aimed to investigate whether variation of microstructure of the medial forebrain bundle mfb a tract connecting the basal forebrain with the brain stem is associated with interindividual pain sensitivity we assessed interindividual pain sensitivity a a rating of pain intensity to heat stimulus 45 47 and 48 9 degree c in 38 healthy men age 27 05 5 7 year we also reconstructed the mfb using multitensor tractography from diffusion magnetic resonance imaging dmri and calculated free water corrected dmri measure of fractional anisotropy fa t radial diffusivity rd t and axial diffusivity ad t lower rating of interindividual pain intensity correlated with higher fa t and lower rd t of the mfb a change in fa t and rd t may reflect abnormality in myelination the result might be interpreted a that a lower pain rating is associated with higher degree of myelination of the mfb and could represent an inhibitory pathway of pain our result suggest that alteration of microstructure in the mfb contributes to the interindividual variation of pain perception

Title: Interoceptive focus shapes the experience of time
Authors: Pollatos, O.; Laubrock, J.; Wittmann, M.
Abstract: the perception of time is a fundamental part of human experience recent research suggests that the experience of time emerges from emotional and interoceptive bodily state a processed in the insular cortex whether there is an interaction between the conscious awareness of interoceptive state and time distortion induced by emotion ha rarely been investigated so far we aimed to address this question by the use of a retrospective time estimation task comparing two group of participant one group had a focus on interoceptive state and one had a focus on exteroceptive information while watching film clip depicting fear amusement and neutral content main result were that attention to interoceptive process significantly affected subjective time experience fear wa accompanied with subjective time dilation that wa more pronounced in the group with interoceptive focus while amusement led to a quicker passage of time which wa also increased by interoceptive focus we conclude that retrospective temporal distortion are directly influenced by attention to bodily response these effect might crucially interact with arousal level sympathetic nervous system activation affecting memory build up might be the decisive factor influencing retrospective time judgment our data substantially extend former research finding underscoring the relevance of interoception for the effect of emotional state on subjective time experience

Title: Time is of the essence: past selves are not prioritized even when selective discrimination costs are controlled for
Authors: Englert, J.; von Lampe, K.; Morina, N.
Abstract: the perceptual self prioritization effect spe refers to an advantage in attending to stimulus associated with the self relative to those associated with another individual in the perceptual matching task arbitrary pairing between oneself and other person and a geometric shape need to be learned apart from the spe this task also produce high matching performance for a close other while cognitive representation of past self are sometimes viewed a resembling that of an intimate other and while there is some evidence that other type of psychological closeness modulate the spe it remains unclear whether such prioritization effect extend to past self previous experiment on this topic required participant to distinguish between different point in time within the same task raising the possibility that potential past self prioritization wa masked by task difficulty in our experiment we addressed this potential confound by presenting n 118 participant with a simpler version of the matching task we re investigated self prioritization in perceptual matching under condition of mental time travel to the past in line with previous evidence we found clear prioritization of present self which wa evident in response time accuracy and the efficiency of practice performance wa consistently poorest for the past self indicating not only a lack of privileged processing but rather a relative de prioritization performance wa not improved by either increased proximity of the time period in question nor by experimenter induced re imagining of the self our result do not support a perceptual prioritization of past self

Title: The Effects of Obesity-Related Health Messages on Explicit and Implicit Weight Bias
Authors: Rudolph, A.; Hilbert, A.
Abstract: the pervasiveness of explicit and implicit weight bias wb defined a negative stereotype and prejudice regarding one s weight ha been observed among individual of all weight category a a source of wb health message have been discussed due to reinforcing stigmatizing notion the present study sought to investigate whether health message i e eat healthy become physically active have the potential to increase explicit and implicit wb participant n 144 from the community were randomized to either an experimental group eg or a control group cg while the eg wa presented with health message the cg wa presented with neutral information before and after manipulation participant completed measure of explicit and implicit wb paired sample t test revealed no difference in explicit wb after manipulation however a small effect decrease of implicit wb in the eg but not in the cg wa found this study provided evidence that health message might have differential impact to change wb according to dual model approach explicit and implicit wb tap into two different information processing system and thus were differentially affected by health message brief exposure to health message might have the potential to contribute to health behavior and to mitigate implicit wb

Title: Attachment Manifestations in Daily Interpersonal Interactions
Authors: Kaurin, A.; Pilkonis, P. A.; Wright, A. G. C.
Abstract: the predominant focus in attachment research on trait like individual difference ha overshadowed investigation of the way in which working model of attachment represent dynamic interpersonally responsive socio affective system intensive longitudinal design extend previous work by evaluating to what extent attachment varies over social interaction and the functional process that underlie it fluctuation we examined momentary activation of attachment orientation in the stream of people daily life and how those pattern were linked to interpersonal behavior based on an event contingent ambulatory 7 day assessment protocol n 263 3 971 interaction operationalized using contemporary integrative interpersonal theory we examined whether contextually activated working model accounted for pattern of interpersonal anti complementarity our analysis revealed that the situational activation of working model varied a a function of interpersonal perception of warmth which were linked to greater state security and lower level of anxious or avoidant expectation these reactivity pattern in turn accounted for interpersonal complementarity avoidant attachment wa linked to diminished and secure attachment to enhanced expression of warmth the analysis were robust even when controlling for momentary positive and negative affect and closeness of the relationship attachment expectation wax and wane across daily social interaction and such fluctuation are reflective primarily of a process in which perception of others warmth activate secure attachment expectation and lower insecure one supplementary information the online version contains supplementary material available at 10 1007 s42761 022 00117 6

Title: Finding the "sweet spot" of smartphone use: Reduction or abstinence to increase well-being and healthy lifestyle?! An experimental intervention study
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Delveaux, J.; John, J.; Wicker, V.; Noveski, A.; Kim, S.; Schillack, H.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the present experimental study compared the impact of a total abstinence from smartphone use and of a reduction of daily smartphone use by 1 hr on well being and healthy lifestyle participant n total 619 were smartphone user in germany the first experimental group n 200 waived smartphone use for 7 day the second experimental group n 226 reduced it daily use by 1 hr and the control group n 193 used smartphone a usual variable of smartphone use time intensity problematic tendency life satisfaction depressive symptom anxiety symptom physical activity and smoking behavior were assessed via online survey at four measurement time point baseline postintervention 1 and 4 month after postintervention both intervention reduced smartphone use intensity problematic use tendency depressive and anxiety symptom in both group life satisfaction and physical activity increased most effect were stronger and remained more stable over 4 month in the reduction group than in the abstinence group moreover in the reduction group only the number of daily smoked cigarette decreased thus le time spent on the smartphone lead to more well being and a healthier lifestyle a complete smartphone abstinence is not necessary program that focus on the increase of well being and a healthier lifestyle could benefit from the integration of controlled reduction of smartphone use a potential sweet spot of smartphone use is discussed psycinfo database record c 2023 apa all right reserved

Title: Are you looking or looking away? Visual exploration and avoidance of disgust- and fear-stimuli: An eye-tracking study
Authors: Fink-Lamotte, J.; Svensson, F.; Schmitz, J.; Exner, C.
Abstract: the present eye tracking study investigates whether individual with different level of contamination fear are more likely to focus their attention on disgusting stimulus to explore them or to pull their attention away to avoid them ninety two nonclinical participant with varying degree of contamination fear performed a dot probe task eye tracking methodology wa employed to record gaze pattern during the task in each trial participant looked at two picture disgust neutral fear neutral or neutral neutral participant were further asked about the content of the picture and the confidence of their answer the result show that reaction time were slower and fixation were longer and more frequent for disgust target compared with fear and neutral target which wa further amplified in individual with high contamination fear however image detail of disgusting picture were remembered le correctly than detail of fearful picture these finding confirm the idea that attention on disgusting stimulus is maintained further the finding indicate that disgust is processed more superficially and might also be related to disgust associated uncertainty and ambiguity the result may help to understand the difficult to change nature of disgust which could be relevant to habituation and extinction process in exposure therapy psycinfo database record c 2022 apa all right reserved

Title: Changes in implicit and explicit self-esteem following cognitive and psychodynamic therapy in social anxiety disorder
Authors: Ritter, V.; Leichsenring, F.; Strauss, B. M.; Stangier, U.
Abstract: the present investigation is the first to analyse change in implicit and explicit self esteem following cognitive therapy ct and psychodynamic therapy pdt in social anxiety disorder sad we assessed a sub sample of patient with sad n 27 per treatment group n 12 waitlist condition in the course of a randomized controlled trial prior to and following individual treatment or wait assessment with an implicit association test and the rosenberg self esteem scale both ct and pdt consisted of 25 session treatment were effective in enhancing implicit and explicit self esteem in ct and pdt change in explicit self esteem were associated with sad symptom change no such relationship were found in implicit self esteem the result seem to indicate that both ct and pdt are effective in establishing a positive implicit and explicit self esteem in sad the differential relationship of change in implicit and explicit self esteem to treatment effect on social phobic symptom are discussed

Title: Patterns of body image concerns in adolescence and early adulthood: A latent profile analysis
Authors: Hoffmann, S.; Warschburger, P.
Abstract: the present study aimed at identifying latent profile of body image concern in adolescent and young adult subsequently association between these profile and potentially harmful behavior are examined self report data of 758 male and female adolescent aged 14 to 22 year were analyzed participant provided demographic and anthropometric data and completed survey on weight shape and muscularity concern a well a on disturbed eating behavior and dysfunctional exercise latent profile analysis of weight shape concern and muscularity concern were performed separately for each gender the analysis indicated three class solution in men and woman in both gender the inconspicuous class characterized by small amount of weight shape and muscularity concern wa the largest one 86 in men 68 in woman whereas 10 of the men and 23 of the woman were assigned to the borderline class 4 of the men and 8 of the woman formed the conspicuous class marked weight shape and muscularity concern between gender the degree of muscularity concern differed in the borderline and inconspicuous class while the degree of weight shape concern differed in the inconspicuous class only the comparable degree of weight shape and muscularity concern in men and woman in the affected class underline the relevance of both aspect in both gender class could be distinguished by harmful behavior like restrained eating or emotional exercise proving the clinical significance of body image concern

Title: Facebook Addiction Disorder (FAD) among German students-A longitudinal approach
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the present study aimed to investigate facebook addiction disorder fad in a german student sample over a period of one year while mean fad level did not increase during the investigation period a significant increase wa shown in the number of participant reaching the critical cutoff score fad wa significantly positively related to the personality trait narcissism and to negative mental health variable depression anxiety and stress symptom furthermore fad fully mediated the significant positive relationship between narcissism and stress symptom which demonstrates that narcissistic people can be specifically at risk to develop fad present result give a first overview of fad in germany practical application for future study and limitation of present result are discussed

Title: Everyday emotional dynamics in major depression
Authors: Nelson, J.; Klumparendt, A.; Doebler, P.; Ehring, T.
Abstract: the present study aimed to investigate the everyday emotional dynamic of depressed individual especially the role of emotional inertia emotional context insensitivity and emotional variability and instability using ecological momentary assessment 40 currently depressed individual and 40 healthy control reported on their current emotional state and current activity 10 time a day for 4 consecutive day there were no difference in the dynamic of positive affect pa between depressed and healthy subject depressed participant negative affect na however wa found to be more inert than in healthy control while at the same time being more variable and more reactive to positive event there wa also an association between emotional instability and depression but this wa rendered nonsignificant when analysis were controlled for emotional variability altogether emotional dynamic of na appear to be more prominently disturbed in depression compared to pa result support earlier finding on na emotional variability a well a inertia in depressed patient in addition there wa some evidence for a mood brightening effect in depression psycinfo database record c 2020 apa all right reserved

Title: What does media use reveal about personality and mental health? An exploratory investigation among German students
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the present study aimed to investigate the relationship between personality trait mental health variable and medium use among german student the data of 633 participant were collected result indicate a positive association between general internet use general use of social platform and facebook use on the one hand and self esteem extraversion narcissism life satisfaction social support and resilience on the other hand use of computer game wa found to be negatively related to these personality and mental health variable the use of platform that focus more on written interaction twitter tumblr wa assumed to be negatively associated with positive mental health variable and significantly positively with depression anxiety and stress symptom in contrast instagram use which focus more on photo sharing correlated positively with positive mental health variable possible practical implication of the present result for mental health a well a the limitation of the present work are discussed

Title: Longitudinal prediction of positive and negative mental health in Germany, Russia, and China
Authors: Margraf, J.; Zhang, X. C.; Lavallee, K. L.; Schneider, S.
Abstract: the present study examines a broad range of longitudinal predictor of dimensional positive mental health pmh and negative mental health nmh using data from the boom study participant were drawn from university student sample in germany 1 608 russia 677 and china 12 057 a structural equation model wa conducted with four group of predictor and pmh nmh a criterion outcome five of the six salutogenic predictor were predictive of both positive mental health positively and negative mental health a measured by depression negatively pathogenic predictor anxiety and depression were related to future depression but not to positive mental health stress at baseline wa related to both future positive mental health negatively and future depression positively being male in this study wa associated with increased future depression result hold across germany russia and china result support the conceptualization of positive and negative mental health a related but independent dimension across three culture

Title: Cognitive deficits are a matter of emotional context: inflexible strategy use mediates context-specific learning impairments in OCD
Authors: Zetsche, U.; Rief, W.; Westermann, S.; Exner, C.
Abstract: the present study examines the interplay between cognitive deficit and emotional context in obsessive compulsive disorder ocd and social phobia sp specifically this study examines whether the inflexible use of efficient learning strategy in an emotional context underlies impairment in probabilistic classification learning pcl in ocd and whether pcl impairment are specific to ocd twenty three participant with ocd 30 participant with sp and 30 healthy control completed a neutral and an ocd specific pcl task ocd participant failed to adopt efficient learning strategy and showed fewer beneficial strategy switch than control only in an ocd specific context but not in a neutral context additionally ocd participant did not show any explicit memory impairment number of beneficial strategy switch in the ocd specific task mediated the difference in pcl performance between ocd and control participant individual with sp were impaired in both pcl task in contrast to neuropsychological model postulating general cognitive impairment in ocd the present finding suggest that it is the interaction between cognition and emotion that is impaired in ocd specifically activated disorder specific fear may impair the flexible adoption of efficient learning strategy and compromise otherwise unimpaired pcl impairment in pcl are not specific to ocd

Title: Addicted to Facebook? Relationship between Facebook Addiction Disorder, duration of Facebook use and narcissism in an inpatient sample
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.; Kollner, V.
Abstract: the present study explored the facebook addiction disorder fad in an inpatient sample in germany of the 112 facebook user 71 4 woman age year m sd 49 43 9 17 who were patient of a psychosomatic rehabilitation clinic with affective disorder and anxiety disorder a most common diagnosis 28 6 reached the critical polythetic cutoff score of fad 0 9 researched the critical monothetic cutoff score and 86 6 had enhanced value of withdrawal symptom due to facebook use the mean level of fad wa significantly higher in inpatient with week depression than in inpatient with moderate depression in the whole sample fad wa significantly positively linked to duration of facebook use and the personality trait narcissism present result provide first evidence of fad in a non student inpatient sample they contribute to the understanding of the development of fad and demonstrate that addictive facebook use may impact person who suffer from mental disorder especially when they have enhanced level of the personality trait narcissism practical application for research and clinical treatment a well a limitation of present result are discussed

Title: The relationship between daily stress, social support and Facebook Addiction Disorder
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Rohmann, E.; Bierhoff, H. W.; Schillack, H.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the present study investigated the link between daily stress social support facebook use and facebook addiction disorder fad two variety of social support were considered according to the communication channel offline and online in a sample of 309 facebook user age m sd 23 76 4 06 range 18 56 daily stress wa positively related to the intensity of facebook use and to tendency towards facebook addiction the link between daily stress and intensity of facebook use wa negatively moderated by perceived offline social support indicating that individual who received low level of support offline were particularly likely to increase their facebook use at higher level of daily stress perceived online social support partly mediated the positive relationship between facebook use intensity and tendency towards fad it is remarkable that facebook use intensity is systematically related to both positive i e receiving online social support and negative i e building up fad consequence thereby individual who receive high level of social support online tend to be at risk for tendency towards fad thus while offline social support might protect mental health online support might influence it negatively this should be considered when assessing individual at risk for obsessive facebook use and when planning intervention to deal with fad

Title: The brave blue world: Facebook flow and Facebook Addiction Disorder (FAD)
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Rohmann, E.; Bierhoff, H. W.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the present study investigated the relationship between flow experienced when using facebook facebook flow i e experience of intensive enjoyment and pleasure generated by facebook use due to which the facebook activity is continued even at high cost of this behavior and facebook addiction disorder fad in a sample of 398 facebook user age m sd 33 01 11 23 range 18 64 the significant positive association between facebook flow and fad wa positively moderated by the intensity of facebook use exploratory factor analysis revealed that all six item assessing fad loaded on the same factor a two item belonging to the subscale telepresence of facebook flow therefore the close link between facebook flow and fad may in particular result from the immersion in an attractive online world created by facebook where user escape to forget their everyday obligation and problem present result provide first evidence that facebook flow may be an anteceded of fad and indicate the mechanism that may contribute to it development and maintenance practical application for future study and limitation of present result are discussed

Title: Preliminary Evidence for a Nexus between Rumination, Behavioural Avoidance, Motive Satisfaction and Depression
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Holtforth, M. G.; Krieger, T.; Altenstein, D.; Doerig, N.; Zimmermann, J.; Backenstrass, M.; Friederich, H. C.; Bents, H.
Abstract: the present study tested a theoretically derived link between rumination and depressive symptom through behavioural avoidance and reduced motive satisfaction a a key aspect of positive reinforcement rumination behavioural avoidance motive satisfaction and level of depression were assessed via self report measure in a clinical sample of 160 patient with major depressive disorder path analysis based mediation analysis wa used to estimate the direct and indirect effect a proposed by the theoretical model operating in serial behavioural avoidance and motive satisfaction partially mediated the association between rumination and depressive symptom irrespective of gender medication and co morbid anxiety disorder this is the first study investigating the association between behavioural avoidance rumination and depression in a clinical sample of depressed patient the finding are in line with an understanding of rumination in depression a also serving an avoidance function key practitioner message rumination avoidance motive satisfaction and level of depressive symptom were examined in a clinical sample of 160 outpatient with major depressive disorder path analysis based mediation analysis revealed that operating in serial avoidance and motive satisfaction partially mediated the link between rumination and level of depressive symptom finding support an understanding of rumination in depression a serving an avoidance function

Title: Desire lies in the eyes: attention bias for chocolate is related to craving and self-endorsed eating permission
Authors: Werthmann, J.; Roefs, A.; Nederkoorn, C.; Jansen, A.
Abstract: the present study tested the impact of experimentally manipulated perceived availability of chocolate on attention for chocolate stimulus momentary state craving for chocolate and consumption of chocolate in healthy weight female student it wa hypothesized that eating forbiddance would be related to attentional avoidance thus diminished attention focus on food cue in an attempt to prevent oneself from processing food cue and that eating motivation would be related to attentional approach thus maintained attentional focus on food cue high chronic chocolate cravers n 40 and low cravers n 40 participated in one of four perceived availability context required to eat forbidden to eat individual choice to eat and 50 chance to eat following a brief chocolate exposure attention for chocolate wa measured using eye tracking momentary craving from self report and the consumption of chocolate wa assessed from direct observation the perceived availability of chocolate did not significantly influence attention allocation for chocolate stimulus momentary craving or chocolate intake high chocolate cravers reported significantly higher momentary craving for chocolate d 1 29 p 001 and showed longer initial duration of gaze on chocolate than low cravers d 0 63 p 01 in contrast participant who indicated during the manipulation check that they would not have permitted themselves to eat chocolate irrespective of the availability instruction they received showed significantly le craving d 0 96 p 01 and reduced total dwell time for chocolate stimulus than participant who permitted themselves to eat chocolate d 0 53 p 05 thus this study provides evidence that attention bias for food stimulus reflect inter individual difference in eating motivation such a chronic chocolate craving and self endorsed eating permission

Title: Cognitive interference and a food-related memory bias in binge eating disorder
Authors: Svaldi, J.; Schmitz, F.; Trentowska, M.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.; Berking, M.; Naumann, E.
Abstract: the present study wa concerned with cognitive interference and a specific memory bias for eating related stimulus in binge eating disorder bed further objective were to find out under which circumstance such effect would occur and whether they are related with each other and with reported severity of bed symptom a group of woman diagnosed with bed and a matched sample of overweight control completed two paradigm an n back task with lure and a recent probe task the bed group generally experienced more interference in the n back task additionally they revealed selectively increased interference for food item in the recent probe task finding can be reconciled with the view that control function are generally impaired in bed and that there is an additional bias for eating related stimulus both of which were related with reported severity of bed symptom

Title: Interpretation modification training reduces social anxiety in clinically anxious children
Authors: Klein, A. M.; Rapee, R. M.; Hudson, J. L.; Schniering, C. A.; Wuthrich, V. M.; Kangas, M.; Lyneham, H. J.; Souren, P. M.; Rinck, M.
Abstract: the present study wa designed to examine the effect of training in positive interpretation in clinically anxious child a total of 87 child between 7 and 12 year of age were randomly assigned to either a positive cognitive bias modification training for interpretation cmb i or a neutral training training included 15 session in a two week period child with an interpretation bias prior to training in the positive training group showed a significant reduction in interpretation bias on the social threat scenario after training but not child in the neutral training group no effect on interpretation bias were found for the general threat scenario or the non threat scenario furthermore child in the positive training did not self report lower anxiety than child in the neutral training group however mother and father reported a significant reduction in social anxiety in their child after positive training but not after neutral training this study demonstrated that clinically anxious child with a prior interpretation bias can be trained away from negative social interpretation bias and there is some evidence that this corresponds to reduction in social anxiety this study also highlight the importance of using specific training stimulus

Title: Elimination disorders and anxious-depressed symptoms in preschool children: a population-based study
Authors: Equit, M.; Klein, A. M.; Braun-Bither, K.; Graber, S.; von Gontard, A.
Abstract: the prevalence rate of elimination disorder and anxious depressed symptom of a representative sample of young child and their association were assessed 2 079 child in a defined geographical area were examined at school entry a parental questionnaire with 4 question referring to symptom of incontinence and 14 item of the anxious depressed scale of the child behavior checklist cbcl wa administered 9 5 of 6 year old child wet at night 2 7 wet during day and 1 2 had faecal incontinence significantly more boy wet at night 11 7 than girl 7 2 or 0 58 95 ci 0 43 0 78 12 7 had clinically relevant anxious depressed symptom child with at least one elimination disorder had significantly higher t value of the anxious depressed cbcl than continent control child with faecal incontinence had highest t value of the anxious depressed cbcl syndrome scale significantly higher than those of child with other elimination disorder and control elimination disorder a well a anxious depressed symptom are common at a young age boy are more affected by elimination disorder than girl but not by anxious depressed symptom child with faecal incontinence have the highest rate of anxious depressed symptom

Title: Genetic variation is associated with PTSD risk and aversive memory: Evidence from two trauma-Exposed African samples and one healthy European sample
Authors: Wilker, S.; Schneider, A.; Conrad, D.; Pfeiffer, A.; Boeck, C.; Lingenfelder, B.; Freytag, V.; Vukojevic, V.; Vogler, C.; Milnik, A.; Papassotiropoulos, A.; J. F. de Quervain D; Elbert, T.; Kolassa, S.; Kolassa, I. T.
Abstract: the probability to develop posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd characterized by vivid intrusive emotional memory of the encountered traumatic event depends among other factor on the number of previous traumatic experience traumatic load and individual genetic vulnerability so far our knowledge regarding the biological underpinnings of ptsd is relatively sparse genome wide association study gwas followed by independent replication might help to discover novel so far unknown biological mechanism associated with the development of traumatic memory here a gwas wa conducted in n 924 northern ugandan rebel war survivor and identified seven suggestively significant single nucleotide polymorphism snp p 1 x 10 5 for lifetime ptsd risk of these seven snp the association of rs3852144 on chromosome 5 wa replicated in an independent sample of rwandan genocide survivor n 370 p 01 while ptsd risk increased with accumulating traumatic experience the vulnerability wa reduced in carrier of the minor g allele in an additive manner correspondingly memory for aversive picture decreased with higher number of the minor g allele in a sample of n 2698 healthy swiss individual finally investigation on n 90 ptsd patient treated with narrative exposure therapy indicated an additive effect of genotype on ptsd symptom change from pre treatment to four month after treatment but not between pre treatment and the 10 month follow up in conclusion emotional memory formation seems to decline with increasing number of rs3852144 g allele rendering individual more resilient to ptsd development however the impact on therapy outcome remains preliminary and further research is needed to determine how this intronic marker may affect memory process in detail

Title: Changes in interoceptive processes following brain stimulation
Authors: Pollatos, O.; Herbert, B. M.; Mai, S.; Kammer, T.
Abstract: the processing and perception of individual internal bodily signal interoception ha been differentiated to comprise different level and process involved the so called heartbeat evoked potential hep offer an additional possibility to examine automatic processing of cardiac signal knowledge on neural structure potentially supporting different facet of interoception is still sparse one way to get insight into neuroanatomical function is to manipulate the activity of different brain structure in this study we used repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation rtms and a continuous theta burst protocol to inhibit specific central location of the interoceptive network including the right anterior insula and the right somatosensory cortex and assessed effect on interoceptive facet and the hep in 18 male participant main result were that inhibiting anterior insula resulted in a significant decline in cardiac and respiratory interoceptive accuracy iac and in a consistent decrease in perception confidence continuous theta burst stimulation ctbs over somatosensory cortex reduced only cardiac iac and affected perception confidence inhibiting right anterior insula and right somatosensory cortex increased interoceptive sensibility and reduced the hep amplitude over frontocentral location our finding strongly suggest that ctbs is an effective tool to investigate the neural network supporting interoceptive process this article is part of the themed issue interoception beyond homeostasis affect cognition and mental health
Journal: Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci

Title: The phenomenology of the first panic attack in clinical and community-based samples
Authors: Pane-Farre, C. A.; Stender, J. P.; Fenske, K.; Deckert, J.; Reif, A.; John, U.; Schmidt, C. O.; Schulz, A.; Lang, T.; Alpers, G. W.; Kircher, T.; Vossbeck-Elsebusch, A. N.; Grabe, H. J.; Hamm, A. O.
Abstract: the purpose of the study wa to contrast first panic attack pa of patient with panic disorder pd with v without agoraphobia and to explore difference between first pa leading to the development of pd and those that remain isolated data were drawn from a community survey n 2259 including 88 isolated pa and 75 pd case an additional sample of 234 pd patient wa recruited in a clinical setting a standardized interview assessed the symptom of the first pa context of it occurrence and subsequent coping attempt person who developed pd reported more severe first pa more medical service utilization and exposure limiting coping attempt than those with isolated pa the context of the first pa did not differ between pd and isolated pa pd with agoraphobia wa specifically associated with greater symptom severity and occurrence of first attack in public future research should validate these finding using a longitudinal approach

Title: [Parenthood and cancer: dyadic analysis of psychological distress and -health-related quality of life of cancer parents with minor children]
Authors: Kuhne, F.; Krattenmacher, T.; Bergelt, C.; Bierbaum, A. L.; Christine Ernst, J.; Flechtner, H. H.; Keller, M.; Klitzing, K. V.; Romer, G.; Moller, B.
Abstract: the purpose of this study wa the analysis of psychological distress and health related quality of life hrqol of parent with minor child during curative resp palliative treatment cross sectional design with a sample of n 89 parent dyad dyadic analysis of demographic illness and family variable via mixed linear model patient and healthy partner indicated psychological distress on different subscales intradyadic correlation were small moderate most important predictor of psychological distress and hrqol were treatment stadium gender family functioning and employment status dependent on demographic variable psychooncological support wa evident mainly for parent in palliative care and for family with dysfunctional functioning

Title: Perceived Impact of Covid-19 Across Different Mental Disorders: A Study on Disorder-Specific Symptoms, Psychosocial Stress and Behavior
Authors: Quittkat, H. L.; Dusing, R.; Holtmann, F. J.; Buhlmann, U.; Svaldi, J.; Vocks, S.
Abstract: the recent outbreak of the coronavirus disease covid 19 ha plunged country across the world into crisis both in the general population and in specific subgroup such a infected people or health care worker study have reported increased symptom of anxiety depression and stress however the reaction of individual with mental disorder to covid 19 have largely been neglected the present study therefore aimed to investigate the perceived impact of covid 19 and it psychological consequence on people with mental disorder in this online survey participant were asked to evaluate their disorder specific symptom perceived psychosocial stress and behavior related to covid 19 in the current situation and retrospectively before the spread of covid 19 the study included participant with self identified generalized anxiety disorder gad panic disorder and agoraphobia pa illness anxiety disorder ia social anxiety disorder sad depression dp obsessive compulsive disorder ocd body dysmorphic disorder bdd eating disorder ed schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder sp other non specified mental disorder other a well a mentally healthy control hc the result of bayesian parameter estimation suggest that the symptom severity of dp gad ia and bdd ha deteriorated a a reaction to covid 19 across all mental disorder and hc self reported psychosocial stress level were higher during the outbreak of covid 19 compared to before a reduced frequency of social contact and grocery shopping wa found for all participant people with self identified mental disorder showed higher personal worry about covid 19 and a higher fear of contagion with covid 19 than did hc according to our finding covid 19 may reinforce symptom severity and psychosocial stress in individual with mental disorder in time of pandemic special support is needed to assist people with mental disorder and to prevent symptom deterioration

Title: Transdiagnostic Prediction of Affective, Cognitive, and Social Function Through Brain Reward Anticipation in Schizophrenia, Bipolar Disorder, Major Depression, and Autism Spectrum Diagnoses
Authors: Schwarz, K.; Moessnang, C.; Schweiger, J. I.; Baumeister, S.; Plichta, M. M.; Brandeis, D.; Banaschewski, T.; Wackerhagen, C.; Erk, S.; Walter, H.; Tost, H.; Meyer-Lindenberg, A.
Abstract: the relationship between transdiagnostic dimensional and categorical approach to psychiatric nosology is under intense debate to inform this discussion we studied neural system linked to reward anticipation across a range of disorder and behavioral dimension we assessed brain response to reward expectancy in a large sample of 221 participant including patient with schizophrenia sz n 27 bipolar disorder bp n 28 major depressive disorder md n 31 autism spectrum disorder asd n 25 and healthy control n 110 we also characterized all subject with an extensive test battery from which a cognitive affective and social functioning factor wa constructed these factor were subsequently related to functional response in the ventral striatum vst and neural network linked to it we found that blunted vst response were present in sz bp and asd but not in md activation within the vst predicted individual difference in affective cognitive and social functioning across diagnostic boundary network alteration extended beyond the reward network to include region implicated in executive control we further confirmed the robustness of our result in various control analysis our finding suggest that altered brain response during reward anticipation show transdiagnostic alteration that can be mapped onto dimensional measure of functioning they also highlight the role of executive control of reward and salience signaling in the disorder we study and show the power of system level neuroscience to account for clinically relevant behavior

Title: Do patients with chronic pain show autonomic arousal when confronted with feared movements? An experimental investigation of the fear-avoidance model
Authors: Glombiewski, J. A.; Riecke, J.; Holzapfel, S.; Rief, W.; Konig, S.; Lachnit, H.; Seifart, U.
Abstract: the relevance of a phobia based conceptualization of fear for individual with chronic pain ha been much debated in the literature this study investigated whether patient with highly fearful chronic low back pain show distinct physiological reaction pattern compared with le fearful patient when anticipating aversive back pain related movement we used an idiosyncratic fear induction paradigm and collected 2 different measure of autonomic nervous system activation and muscle tension in the lower back we identified 2 distinct psychophysiological response pattern one pattern wa characterized by a moderate increase in skin conductance interbeat interval ibi increase and muscle tension increase in the lower back this response wa interpreted a an attention reaction to a moderately stressful event the other pattern found in 58 of the participant wa characterized by a higher skin conductance response ibi decrease and muscle tension increase in the lower back according to bradley and lang defense cascade model this response is typical of a fear reaction participant showing the psychophysiological pattern typical of fear also had elevated score on some self report measure of component of the fear avoidance model relative to participant showing the reaction pattern characteristic of attention this study is the first to provide psychophysiological evidence for the fear avoidance model of chronic pain

Title: Testing measurement invariance of the Depression, Anxiety, and Stress Scales (DASS-21) across four countries
Authors: Scholten, S.; Velten, J.; Bieda, A.; Zhang, X. C.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: the rising burden of mental and behavioral disorder ha become a global challenge murray et al 2012 measurement invariant clinical instrument are necessary for the assessment of relevant symptom across country the present study tested the measurement invariance of the 21 item version of the depression anxiety and stress scale da lovibond lovibond 1995b in poland russia the united kingdom u k and the united state of america u s telephone interview were conducted with population based sample npl 1003 nru 3020 nu k 1002 nu s 1002 the da 21 show threshold measurement invariance comparison of latent mean did not indicate difference between u k and u s sample however polish and russian sample reported more depressive symptom compared with u k and u s sample the russian sample had the highest level of anxiety symptom and the polish sample demonstrated the highest stress level the da 21 can be recommended to meaningfully compare the relationship between variable across group and to compare latent mean in polish russian and english speaking population psycinfo database record

Title: Familiar Face Priming: The Role of Second-Order Configuration and Individual Face Recognition Abilities
Authors: Itz, M. L.; Schweinberger, S. R.; Kaufmann, J. M.
