Abstract: the role of second order configuration that is metric distance between individual feature for familiar face recognition ha been the subject of debate recent report suggest that better face recognition ability coincide with a weaker reliance on shape information for face recognition we examined contribution of second order configuration to familiar face repetition priming by manipulating metric distance between facial feature s1 comprised familiar face prime a either unaltered with increased or decreased interocular distance with increased or decreased distance between nose and mouth or a different familiar face unprimed participant performed a familiarity decision task on familiar and unfamiliar s2 target and completed a test battery consisting of three face identity processing test accuracy reaction time and inverse efficiency score were assessed for the priming experiment and potential priming cost in inverse efficiency score were correlated with test battery score overall priming wa found and priming effect were reduced only by prime with interocular distance distortion correlational data showed that better face recognition skill coincided with a weaker reliance on second order configuration our finding a suggest an importance of interocular but not mouth to nose distance for familiar face recognition and b show that good face recognizers are le sensitive to second order configuration

Title: Simultaneous EEG-fMRI reveals attention-dependent coupling of early face processing with a distributed cortical network
Authors: Bayer, M.; Rubens, M. T.; Johnstone, T.
Abstract: the speed of visual processing is central to our understanding of face perception yet the extent to which early visual processing influence later processing in distributed face processing network and the top down modulation of such bottom up effect remains unclear we used simultaneous eeg fmri to investigate cortical activity that showed unique covariation with erp component of face processing c1 p1 n170 p3 while manipulating sustained attention and transient cognitive conflict employing an emotional face word stroop task erp marker of visual processing within 100 m after stimulus onset showed covariation with brain activation in precuneous posterior cingulate gyrus left middle temporal gyrus left inferior frontal gyrus and frontal operculum and a left lateral parietal occipital cluster illustrating the impact of early stage processing on higher order mechanism crucially this covariation depended on sustained attentional focus and wa absent for incongruent trial suggesting flexible top down gating of bottom up processing

Title: Purchasing under threat: Changes in shopping patterns during the COVID-19 pandemic
Authors: Schmidt, S.; Benke, C.; Pane-Farre, C. A.
Abstract: the spreading of covid 19 ha led to panic buying all over the world in this study we applied an animal model framework to elucidate change in human purchasing behavior under covid 19 pandemic condition purchasing behavior and potential predictor were assessed in an online questionnaire format n 813 multiple regression analysis were used to evaluate the role of individually perceived threat of covid 19 anxiety related personality trait trait anxiety intolerance of uncertainty and the role of medium exposure in predicting quantity and frequency of purchasing behavior high level of perceived threat of covid 19 were associated significantly with a reported reduction in purchasing frequency b 24 p 001 and an increase in the quantity of product bought per purchase b 22 p 001 these result are comparable to observed change in foraging behavior in rodent under threat condition higher level of intolerance of uncertainty b 19 p 001 and high extend of medium exposure b 27 p 001 were positively associated with perceived threat of covid 19 and an increase in purchasing quantity this study contributes to our understanding of aberrated human purchasing behavior and aim to link finding from animal research to human behavior beyond experimental investigation

Title: Preschoolers' Sensitivity to Negative and Positive Emotional Facial Expressions: An ERP Study
Authors: Naumann, S.; Bayer, M.; Dziobek, I.
Abstract: the study examined processing difference for facial expression happy angry or neutral and their repetition with early p1 n170 and late p3 event related potential erps in young child n 33 eeg wa recorded while child observed sequentially presented pair of facial expression which were either the same repeated trial or differed in their emotion novel trial we also correlated erp amplitude difference with parental and child measure of socio emotional competence emotion recognition empathy p1 amplitude were increased for angry and happy a compared to neutral expression we also detected larger p3 amplitude for angry expression a compared to happy or neutral expression repetition effect were evident at early and late processing stage marked by reduced p1 amplitude for repeated v novel happy expression but enhanced p3 amplitude for repeated v novel facial expression n170 amplitude were neither modulated by facial expression nor their repetition none of the repetition effect were associated with measure of socio emotional competence taken together negative facial expression led to increased neural activation in early and later processing stage indicative of enhanced saliency to potential threating stimulus in young child processing of repeated facial expression seem to be differential for early and late neural stage reduced activation wa detected at early neural processing stage particularly for happy face indicative of effective processing for an emotion which is most familiar within this age range contrary to our hypothesis enhanced activity for repeated v novel expression independent of a particular emotion were detected at later processing stage which may be linked to the creation of new memory trace early and late repetition effect are discussed in light of developmental and perceptual difference a well a task specific load

Title: Efficacy of Cyberbullying Prevention on Somatic Symptoms-Randomized Controlled Trial Applying a Reasoned Action Approach
Authors: Zagorscak, P.; Schultze-Krumbholz, A.; Heinrich, M.; Wolfer, R.; Scheithauer, H.
Abstract: the theory of reasoned action tora ha been proposed a a framework for cyberbullying prevention design targeting attitude and norm in this study effect of a long 10 weekly session and a short one day four session cyberbullying prevention program based on the tora were compared with a control group over 9 month longitudinal data from 722 student mean age 13 36 on cyberbullying somatic symptom attitude and norm were analyzed within a structural equation model participation in the long intervention group significantly reduced cyberbullying d 0 584 and somatic symptom d 0 316 no between group difference emerged for attitude and norm developmental trajectory and association were found to be a suggested by tora in both cross sectional and change score analysis

Title: Neural correlates of a standardized version of the trail making test in young and elderly adults: a functional near-infrared spectroscopy study
Authors: Muller, L. D.; Guhn, A.; Zeller, J. B.; Biehl, S. C.; Dresler, T.; Hahn, T.; Fallgatter, A. J.; Polak, T.; Deckert, J.; Herrmann, M. J.
Abstract: the trail making test tmt is a widely applied diagnostic tool measuring executive functioning in order to discriminate between healthy and pathological aging process however due to it paper and pencil nature it is difficult to adapt for functional brain imaging related neural underpinnings even in healthy aging are mostly unknown since no consistent administration for imaging is available in this study a standardized implementation of the tmt for functional near infrared spectroscopy fnirs is proposed to investigate associated frontal cortex activation in healthy young mean age 25 7 3 02 year and elderly adult mean age 70 95 3 55 year the tmt consisted of a number condition tmt a an alternating number and letter condition tmt b a well a a control task behavioral result demonstrated that elderly participant performed slower but committed a similar number of error compared to younger adult the fnirs result showed that particularly the tmt b provoked bilateral activation in the ventro and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex vlpfc and dlpfc a well a in premotor region elderly participant displayed more significantly activated channel and a different activation pattern compared to younger participant especially manifesting in more bilateral dlpfc activation in line with the hemispheric asymmetry reduction in elderly adult harold model the result were interpreted a an additional need for cognitive control resource in elderly participant this study succeeded in implementing an appropriate version of the tmt for fnirs and help elucidating neural aging effect associated with this task

Title: Craving in alcohol-dependent patients after detoxification is related to glutamatergic dysfunction in the nucleus accumbens and the anterior cingulate cortex
Authors: Bauer, J.; Pedersen, A.; Scherbaum, N.; Bening, J.; Patschke, J.; Kugel, H.; Heindel, W.; Arolt, V.; Ohrmann, P.
Abstract: the upregulation of glutamatergic excitatory neurotransmission is thought to be partly responsible for the acute withdrawal symptom and craving experienced by alcohol dependent patient most physiological evidence supporting this hypothesis is based on data from animal study in addition clinical data show that gabaergic and anti glutamatergic drug ameliorate withdrawal symptom offering indirect evidence indicative of glutamatergic hyperexcitability in alcohol dependent subject we used proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy to quantify the glutamate glu level in healthy control subject and in alcohol dependent patient immediately after detoxification the volume of interest were located in the nucleus accumbens nacc and the anterior cingulate cortex acc which are two brain area that have important function in reward circuitry in addition to glu we quantified the level of combined glu and glutamine gln n acetylaspartate choline containing compound and creatine the glu level in the nacc were significantly higher in patient than in control craving which wa measured using the obsessive compulsive drinking scale correlated positively with level of combined glu and gln in the nacc and in the acc the level of all other metabolite were not significantly different between patient and control the increased glu level in the nacc in alcohol dependent patient shortly after detoxification confirm the animal data and suggest that striatal glutamatergic dysfunction is related to ethanol withdrawal the positive correlation between craving and glutamatergic metabolism in both key reward circuitry area support the hypothesis that the glutamatergic system ha an important role in the later course of alcohol dependence with respect to abstinence and relapse

Title: Heart rate variability as an index of emotion (dys)regulation in psychosis?
Authors: Clamor, A.; Ludwig, L.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: the vagally mediated heart rate variability hrv an indicator of the autonomic nervous system an ha been proposed a a transdiagnostic marker for emotion regulation er in people with psychotic disorder psy hrv is profoundly reduced compared to healthy control hc similarly questionnaire based assessment of adaptive er point to a deficit in psy to address hrv a a potential marker for er in psychosis we investigated a large sample including psy n 40 and hc n 32 a well a vulnerable n 19 clinical high risk and clinical n 28 anxiety disorder control we tested the differential effectiveness of an instructed adaptive er strategy whether resting state hrv predicts adaptive er and whether hrv serf a a state index of er effort the participant repeatedly played a social exclusion ballgame while they applied either cognitive reappraisal or no regulation just play in randomized order psy displayed overall higher level of negative affect and paranoia than hc but both group applied reappraisal successfully i e more benefit lower negative affect and paranoia after reappraisal compared to just play resting state hrv did not predict successful reappraisal in the total sample however within psy a higher resting state hrv predicted more benefit from reappraisal state hrv did not differ between the reappraisal and just play condition contrary to our expectation participant with psychosis applied an instructed adaptive er strategy successfully a expected the an marker of hrv predicted that benefit however this wa only the case in psy overall hrv wa not a robust but a tentative marker of er in the present investigation

Title: Prefrontal-parietal effective connectivity during working memory in older adults
Authors: Heinzel, S.; Lorenz, R. C.; Duong, Q. L.; Rapp, M. A.; Deserno, L.
Abstract: theoretical model and preceding study have described age related alteration in neuronal activation of frontoparietal region in a working memory wm load dependent manner however to date underlying neuronal mechanism of these wm load dependent activation change in aging remain poorly understood the aim of this study wa to investigate these mechanism in term of effective connectivity by application of dynamic causal modeling with bayesian model selection eighteen healthy younger age 20 32 year and 32 older 60 75 year participant performed an n back task with 3 wm load level during functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri behavioral and conventional fmri result replicated age group by wm load interaction importantly the analysis of effective connectivity derived from dynamic causal modeling indicated an age and performance related reduction in wm load dependent modulation of connectivity from dorsolateral prefrontal cortex to inferior parietal lobule this finding provides evidence for the proposal that age related wm decline manifest a deficient wm load dependent modulation of neuronal top down control and can integrate implication from theoretical model and previous study of functional change in the aging brain

Title: Effects of Group-Based CBT on Post-Event Processing in Children with Social Anxiety Disorder Following an Experimental Social Stressor
Authors: Asbrand, J.; Schmitz, J.; Kramer, M.; Nitschke, K.; Heinrichs, N.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.
Abstract: theoretical model and previous research suggest that post event processing pep after social situation maintains social anxiety disorder sad to date little is known about pep in childhood a critical period for disorder development or about possible positive effect of cognitive behavioral therapy cbt on pep in child child with sad n 71 aged 9 13 year and healthy control n 55 participated in a social stress task trier social stress test for child tsst c which wa repeated in child with sad after either 12 session of cbt or a waiting period pep wa assessed daily with regard to both valence and frequency a well a in more detail regarding specific negative and positive ruminative thought 1 week after each tsst c daily pep after the tsst c wa more frequent and more negative in child with sad compared to healthy control in particular during the first 2 day after the tsst c after cbt treatment child with sad reported more positive pep but not le negative pep compared to child in the waitlist control group the current study suggests that negative pep in child with sad is most pronounced in the first day following social stress group based cbt seems to be effective in building up positive cognition after social stress in child but developing specific intervention targeting negative pep immediately after a social stressor may be necessary to further increase treatment efficacy

Title: Difficulties in emotion regulation across the spectrum of eating disorders
Authors: Brockmeyer, T.; Skunde, M.; Wu, M.; Bresslein, E.; Rudofsky, G.; Herzog, W.; Friederich, H. C.
Abstract: theoretical model consider difficulty in emotion regulation er a central trans diagnostic phenomenon across the spectrum of eating disorder ed however there is a lack of study directly comparing ed subtypes regarding er problem furthermore patient with anorexia nervosa restricting type an r and patient with an binge purge type an bp have usually been merged into one overall an group in previous research on er in order to overcome these limitation of previous study the present study investigated specific er difficulty in 120 patient with different ed subtypes including an r an bp bulimia nervosa bn and binge eating disorder bed a compared to 60 healthy normal weight control nwc and 29 healthy over weight control owc all ed subtypes reported greater difficulty in er ed subtypes did not differ regarding most domain of er except bed showing le severe er difficulty in some domain in addition an bp but not bn reported greater impulse control difficulty than an r and bed the finding underscore the relevance of er difficulty in ed and support the trans diagnostic view of er difficulty being present across the whole spectrum of ed in addition the present result suggest that certain domain of er may be linked more closely to certain ed subtypes than to others

Title: The role of disgust in patients with hypochondriasis
Authors: Weck, F.; Esch, S.; Rohrmann, S.
Abstract: theoretically disgust sensitivity and disgust proneness could play an important role in hypochondriasis since disgust is a defensive emotion widely believed to protect the organism from illness however empirical evidence to support this hypothesis ha so far been based only on nonclinical sample so that the importance and specificity of disgust for hypochondriasis remains unclear in the current study 36 patient with hypochondriasis 27 with an anxiety disorder and 29 healthy control completed several measure which included the assessment of disgust sensitivity scale for the assessment of disgust sensitivity and disgust proneness questionnaire for the assessment of disgust proneness we found that patient with hypochondriasis and those with an anxiety disorder had higher score than those of the healthy control for several measure of disgust proneness moreover measure of hypochondriacal characteristic were associated with those of disgust proneness and disgust sensitivity however no difference were found between patient with hypochondriasis and those with anxiety disorder with respect to disgust proneness and disgust sensitivity therefore it can be assumed that disgust proneness and disgust sensitivity seem to be le specific than previously suggested for the development and maintenance of hypochondriasis

Title: Changes in emotional processing following interoceptive network stimulation with rTMS
Authors: Mai, S.; Braun, J.; Probst, V.; Kammer, T.; Pollatos, O.
Abstract: theory of emotion suggest a close relation of interoception and emotion however knowledge of underlying neuronal network is still sparse repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation rtms is one neurostimulation method allowing causal conclusion between function and brain region via stimulation or inhibition of underlying brain structure in this study rtms with a continuous theta burst stimulation ctbs protocol wa used aiming for inhibition of important interoceptive network structure frontotemporal insular network and right somatosensory cortex stimulation effect were investigated on interoceptive accuracy iac emotional evaluation and neuronal correlate of emotional picture processing in 18 male participant the main finding were an emotional flattening in subjective valence for affective stimulus after inhibition of the frontotemporal anterior insular network and of somatosensory cortex being mirrored in visual evoked potential a increased n2 decreased p3 indicating an initial orientation reaction followed by decreased attentional processing of positive stimulus moreover cardiac and respiratory iac were positively associated with p3 amplitude and negatively related to positive valence rating positive association of decrease of cardiac respiratory iac with decrease of arousal rating and decrease of p3 amplitude for negative stimulus after inhibition of the frontotemporal insular network and after inhibition of somatosensory cortex allow the conclusion of a causal relationship between reduced activity in interoceptive network structure and blunted emotional processing of visual stimulus our result suggest that both arousal and valence aspect of emotional processing are disturbed after inhibition of interoceptive network structure confirming core assumption of peripheral theory of emotion and model of interoceptive predictive coding

Title: Can we differentiate between psychoanalytic and psychodynamic psychotherapy? - An empirical investigation of therapists' self-reports
Authors: Henkel, M.; Huber, D.; Ratzek, M.; Benecke, C.; Klug, G.
Abstract: therapy differentiation is a crucial component of psychotherapy research it refers to whether inspected treatment differ from one another in the history of psychoanalysis the differentiation between psychodynamic and analytic psychotherapy wa often discussed but seldom inspected empirically in this study we propose a set of item which should in theory offer the possibility to differentiate between psychodynamic and analytic psychotherapy on session level we inspect these item using therapist self report concerning n 295 case of different psychodynamic and analytic therapy result of an exploratory factor analysis and subsequent inspection of the psychodynamic and analytic item in different form of therapy strengthen the usability of these item for differentiating between psychodynamic and analytic therapy however further study using different perspective e g observer rating are essential the presented item are a promising step towards the development of an instrument for treatment differentiation which could later be used in treatment comparison study

Title: Investigation of implicit avoidance of displacement-related stimuli in offspring of trauma exposed, forcibly-displaced individuals
Authors: Wittekind, C. E.; Muhtz, C.; Moritz, S.; Jelinek, L.
Abstract: there is an ongoing debate a to whether traumatization also affect the close relative of trauma survivor who have symptom of ptsd although many study provide evidence favoring a transgenerational transmission other study have not found evidence to support this idea the present study examined whether adult offspring of individual exposed to trauma during forced displacement with n 22 and without ptsd n 24 exhibit an implicit avoidance of stimulus related to the parental trauma compared to child of non trauma exposed control participant n 23 using an approach avoidance task aat offspring participant were requested to push i e avoidance or pull i e approach displacement related and neutral picture whereby response direction depended on a non affective dimension color of the picture result suggest that the offspring of non ptsd participant exhibit implicit avoidance of displacement related stimulus this rather unexpected finding might either indicate resilience amongst offspring of ptsd participant or that offspring of non ptsd participant are particularly affected if these result were to replicate they suggest that implicit avoidance tendency amongst the offspring of trauma exposed participant might partially contribute to their heightened ptsd vulnerability longitudinal study are needed to elucidate whether implicit avoidance tendency are associated with increased stress vulnerability

Title: Cognitive bias modification in problem and pathological gambling using a web-based approach-avoidance task: A pilot trial
Authors: Wittekind, C. E.; Bierbrodt, J.; Ludecke, D.; Feist, A.; Hand, I.; Moritz, S.
Abstract: there is evidence that training addicted participant to implicitly avoid disorder related stimulus by using a training version of the approach avoidance task aat result in reduced substance consumption i e approach bias modification appbm the aim of the present web based study wa to investigate the feasibility and effectiveness of appbm in reducing gambling related symptom a self selected sample of participant with problem pathological slot machine gambling completed an online survey and received either appbm or sham training final n 131 attrition during study participation wa high 66 in both condition slot machine related and neutral picture were presented within the appbm condition all slot machine related picture had to be pushed and all neutral picture had to be pulled whereas in the sham condition the contingency wa 50 50 eight week after baseline participant were re assessed both group showed a similar reduction in gambling related symptom finding are at odds with the hypothesis claiming that only contingency training yield beneficial effect however it cannot be ruled out that effect result from other factor unrelated to training such a expectancy effect we think this study hold valuable information how to conduct larger trial in the future and may prove helpful to improve training and it delivery

Title: Emotional Stress During Pregnancy - Associations With Maternal Anxiety Disorders, Infant Cortisol Reactivity, and Mother-Child Interaction at Pre-school Age
Authors: Zietlow, A. L.; Nonnenmacher, N.; Reck, C.; Ditzen, B.; Muller, M.
Abstract: there is growing evidence that even milder form of maternal stress or anxiety during pregnancy affect the fetus causing possible long term consequence for infant and child development the mechanism through which prenatal maternal stress may affect the unborn are not yet entirely clarified due to limited self regulatory skill after birth infant depend on sensitive behavior of their parent to regulate affective state and physiological arousal dyadic affect regulation ha been linked to various developmental pattern up to adolescence and thereby represents a key element of early social relationship aim of the study wa to evaluate possible long term consequence of emotional stress during pregnancy and postpartum anxiety disorder a well a infant postpartum cortisol reactivity on mother child interaction at pre school age the sample comprised of n 63 mother infant dyad at study entry n 28 diagnosed with postpartum anxiety disorder according to the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder iv dsm iv n 35 were healthy control mother were interviewed with the structured clinical interview for dsm iv disorder at an average infant age of m 4 1 month and filled out a questionnaire regarding emotional stress during pregnancy further they were videotaped during the face to face still face paradigm ffsf a widely used mild socio emotional stressor for infant to determine infant stress reactivity infant salivary cortisol wa collected before immediately after and 20 min after the ffsf missing value were estimated by multiple imputation at the age of m 5 3 year mother child interaction wa re assessed in a follow up sample of n 30 dyad via a free play situation moreover dimensional measure for anxiety were assessed mother in the clinical group reported significantly higher stress score than the control group infant stress reactivity in the early postpartum period and maternal anxiety symptom at the 5 year follow up assessment were significantly associated with dyadic interaction quality at pre school age even though maternal stress during pregnancy did not directly predict mother child interaction quality at pre school age it wa significantly correlated with infant cortisol reactivity during postpartum period nevertheless caution should be taken when interpreting the result considering the small sample size

Title: Behavioral and electrodermal data on implicit nocebo conditioning using supraliminally presented visual stimuli
Authors: Brascher, A. K.; Witthoft, M.
Abstract: this article contains intensity and aversiveness rating of electrical stimulus and data on electrodermal activity skin conductance level and skin conductance response during an implicit conditioning procedure further answer from a questionnaire on contingency awareness are provided the experiment consisted of three phase in the acquisition two type of visual stimulus c and c were coupled to weakly and moderately painful electrical stimulus presented to the participant n 48 dominant hand in the test phase after both c and c only the weakly painful electrical stimulus were presented in the contingency test phase no more electrical stimulus were presented and participant had the task to rate intensity and aversiveness a if an electrical stimulus had been presented this phase served a a test for first order contingency awareness afterwards participant filled in a questionnaire with five question to a their level of second order contingency awareness for more insight please see nocebo hyperalgesia induced by implicit conditioning brascher and witthoft 2019

Title: Sex Hormones and Hair Loss in Men From the General Population of Northeastern Germany
Authors: Kische, H.; Arnold, A.; Gross, S.; Wallaschofski, H.; Volzke, H.; Nauck, M.; Haring, R.
Abstract: this cohort study of german men investigates cross sectional association between a panel of liquid chromatography mass spectrometry measured sex hormone and hair loss

Title: Biases in attention and interpretation in adolescents with varying levels of anxiety and depression
Authors: Klein, A. M.; de Voogd, L.; Wiers, R. W.; Salemink, E.
Abstract: this is the first study to investigate multiple cognitive bias in adolescence simultaneously to examine whether anxiety and depression are associated with bias in attention and interpretation and whether these bias are able to predict unique variance in self reported level of anxiety and depression a total of 681 adolescent performed a dot probe task dpt an emotional visual search task evst and an interpretation recognition task attention and interpretation bias were significantly correlated with anxiety mixed result were reported with regard to depression evidence wa found for an interpretation bias and for an attention bias a measured with the evst but not with the dpt furthermore interpretation and attention bias predicted unique variance in anxiety and depression score these result indicate that attention and interpretation bias are unique process in anxiety and depression they also suggest that anxiety and depression are partly based on similar underlying cognitive mechanism

Title: The development of time-based prospective memory in childhood: the role of working memory updating
Authors: Voigt, B.; Mahy, C. E.; Ellis, J.; Schnitzspahn, K.; Krause, I.; Altgassen, M.; Kliegel, M.
Abstract: this large scale study examined the development of time based prospective memory pm across childhood and the role that working memory updating and time monitoring play in driving age effect in pm performance one hundred and ninety seven child aged 5 to 14 year completed a time based pm task where working memory updating load wa manipulated within individual using a dual task design result revealed age related increase in pm performance across childhood working memory updating load had a negative impact on pm performance and monitoring behavior in older child but this effect wa smaller in younger child moreover the frequency a well a the pattern of time monitoring predicted child s pm performance our interpretation of these result is that process involved in child s pm may show a qualitative shift over development from simple nonstrategic monitoring behavior to more strategic monitoring based on internal temporal model that rely specifically on working memory updating resource we discus this interpretation with regard to possible trade off effect in younger child a well a alternative account

Title: Testing the Four Main Predictions of the Interpersonal-Psychological Theory of Suicidal Behavior in an Inpatient Sample Admitted Due to Severe Suicidality
Authors: Forkmann, T.; Glaesmer, H.; Paashaus, L.; Rath, D.; Schonfelder, A.; Juckel, G.; Gauggel, S.; Beginn-Gobel, U.; Teismann, T.
Abstract: this study aimed to evaluate four main prediction of the interpersonal psychological theory of suicide ipts the importance of perceived burdensomeness pb thwarted belongingness tb hopelessness h and capability for suicide c for passive active suicide ideation suicide intent and suicide attempt n 308 psychiatric inpatient admitted due to severe suicidality 53 6 female n 165 age m 36 82 sd 14 30 range 18 81 completed self report measure of tb pb h c and suicide ideation a well a interview on suicide intent and suicide attempt tb and pb were associated with passive active suicidal ideation whereas the three way interaction pb tb and h wa not associated with active suicide ideation fearlessness about death in conjunction with active suicidal ideation wa not associated with suicide intent and the interaction of pb tb and c wa neither predictive of recent suicide attempt status nor lifetime number of suicide attempt given the cross sectional nature of the data conclusion on causality should be handled carefully the result challenge the theoretical validity of the ipts and it clinical utility at least within the methodological limitation of the current study yet finding underscore the importance of pb in understanding suicidality

Title: Modern and traditional trance language: a comparison
Authors: Karrasch, S.; Jung, J. A.; Varadarajan, S.; Kolassa, I. T.; Bongartz, W.
Abstract: this study compare the effect of two trance text using different language pattern i e modern trance language mtl characterized by indirect suggestion a well a narrative style and traditional trance language ttl found in traditional society e g navajo san aranda aborigine etc that u multiple repetition along with narrative sequence the phenomenology of consciousness inventory pci wa used to evaluate the effect of both text regarding cognition emotion physical experience and trance depth in this randomized controlled online study 178 participant were assigned either to the mtl group or to the ttl group the pci and other test e g positive and negative affect schedule state trait anxiety inventory were presented to the participant before and after listening to the hypnosis audio of the respective trance text there were no significant difference between group concerning trance depth emotional and physical experience however on the cognitive imaginative level it wa shown that the ttl group experienced more imagination pci subdimension visual imagery p 009 d 0 38 and le cognitive activity pci subdimension inner dialogue p 002 d 0 40 than the mtl group the result indicate that ttl increase imagery and decrease cognitive activity to a larger extent than mtl this further indicates the potential of ttl to facilitate more vivid and intensive trance experience

Title: A Cross-Cultural Study in Germany, Russia, and China: Are Resilient and Social Supported Students Protected Against Depression, Anxiety, and Stress?
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Schonfeld, P.; Zhang, X. C.; Bieda, A.; Kochetkov, Y.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: this study cross culturally investigated resilience and social support a possible protective factor for mental health the value of depression anxiety and stress symptom resilience and social support were collected from german n 4433 russian n 3774 and chinese student n 4982 the sample were split two third v one third to cross validate the result in all sample resilience and social support were significantly negatively associated with depression anxiety and stress symptom while in germany those association were stronger for social support in russia and in china stronger association were found for resilience furthermore in all sample resilience wa found to mediate the association between social support and the negative mental health variable significantly in conclusion resilience and social support are universal interrelated protective factor for mental health independently of historical cultural social and geographical condition of a country

Title: Stress reactivity in salivary cortisol and electrocardiogram in adolescents: Investigating sleep disturbances and insomnia
Authors: Kater, M. J.; Werner, A.; Schlarb, A. A.; Lohaus, A.
Abstract: this study examined the role of sleep disturbance and insomnia in the context of stress reactivity in adolescence one hundred and thirty five 11 18 year old m age 14 2 year sd 1 9 52 female completed the trier social stress test for child salivary cortisol and subjective stress rating were collected at six time point and heart rate a well a heart rate variability were measured pre during and post stress induction additionally sleep disturbance and insomnia diagnosis were assessed by a self report questionnaire and a sleep interview robust mixed model investigated if adolescent with compared with adolescent without a sleep disturbance and b insomnia differ regarding cortisol heart rate heart rate variability and psychological stress reactivity considering gender effect the result indicated that boy with high sleep disturbance showed higher cortisol activity compared with boy with low sleep disturbance b 0 88 p 0 05 moreover in boy with insomnia heart rate and alpha 1 significantly differ le than in boy without insomnia these finding support the notion of sex difference regarding the association between poor sleep and increased activity of the hypothalamic pituitary adrenal axis and a le adaptable autonomic nervous system in boy in response to an experimental social stress task

Title: Optimising the efficacy of a stress-reducing psychological intervention using placebo mechanisms: A randomized controlled trial
Authors: Salzmann, S.; Wilhelm, M.; Schindler, S.; Rief, W.; Euteneuer, F.
Abstract: this study examined whether i brief video aiming to optimise outcome expectation would augment the efficacy of progressive muscle relaxation pmr and ii whether participant characteristic would moderate these effect sixty eight healthy subject randomized to one of three experimental manipulation before undergoing a single pmr session either watched i a video displaying a neutral expert ii a video with a warm expert or iii were part of an active control condition constrained linear mixed model indicated increased relaxation and decreased stress level for all participant after the pmr session the primary outcome wa the change of perceived relaxation stress from pre to post participant with high neuroticism and trait anxiety indicated an augmented pmr s efficacy and increased outcome expectation when watching the warm expert video compared to the control group or the le warm expert brief video displaying an expert aiming to optimise outcome expectation regarding a brief stress reducing psychological intervention may boost or decrease an intervention s efficacy effect may depend on the viewer s personality and the video expert s communication style trial registration the study protocol wa approved by the local ethic committee of the university of marburg germany this study wa registered at www clinicaltrials gov nct03330431

Title: Facebook Addiction Disorder in Germany
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Schillack, H.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: this study explored the facebook addiction disorder fad in germany of the 520 participant 6 2 percent reached the critical polythetic cutoff score and 2 5 percent reached the critical monothetic cutoff score fad wa significantly positively related to facebook use frequency the personality trait narcissism a well a depression and anxiety symptom but also to subjective happiness it association with resilience wa significantly negative furthermore facebook use frequency partly mediated the positive relationship between narcissism and fad current result provide a first overview of fad in germany they demonstrate that fad is not only the consequence of excessive facebook use the positive relationship between fad and happiness contributes to the understanding of the mechanism that are involved in the development and maintenance of fad and partly explains earlier inconsistency practical application for future study and limitation of present result are discussed

Title: Association of parental characteristics and emotion regulation in children and adolescents with and without psychopathology: A case-control study
Authors: Fassot, E. M.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.; Asbrand, J.
Abstract: this study explores the difference in child emotion regulation er and parenting between a heterogeneous clinical sample clins and a community sample coms we hypothesized that parent of the clins would report more dysfunctional child er and more dysfunctional parenting regarding the child s negative emotion than parent of the coms further we aimed to predict child er by parenting behavior parent er and mental health parent of child and adolescent aged 6 18 year seeking treatment at an outpatient clinic were compared to a matched sample of parent in a coms n 57 each group a predicted the child in the clinical group were reported to use le reappraisal and more suppression than coms child no difference wa found in dysfunctional emotion parenting between the group reappraisal in parent and supportive reaction to negative emotion predicted reappraisal in child no predictor wa found for child suppression child emotion regulation and parent psychopathology were not associated these result could suggest new element for prevention and intervention program with parent concerning their own emotion regulation and their reaction to negative emotion in child

Title: Biased interpretation and memory in children with varying levels of spider fear
Authors: Klein, A. M.; Titulaer, G.; Simons, C.; Allart, E.; de Gier, E.; Bogels, S. M.; Becker, E. S.; Rinck, M.
Abstract: this study investigated multiple cognitive bias in child simultaneously to investigate whether spider fearful child display an interpretation bias a recall bias and source monitoring error and whether these bias are specific for spider related material furthermore the independent ability of these bias to predict spider fear wa investigated a total of 121 child filled out the spider anxiety and disgust screening for child sads c and they performed an interpretation task a memory task and a behavioural assessment test bat a expected a specific interpretation bias wa found spider fearful child showed more negative interpretation of ambiguous spider related scenario but not of other scenario we also found specific source monitoring error spider fearful child made more fear related source monitoring error for the spider related scenario but not for the other scenario only limited support wa found for a recall bias finally interpretation bias recall bias and source monitoring error predicted unique variance component of spider fear

Title: Relationship Between Depression Symptoms, Physical Activity, and Addictive Social Media Use
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: this study investigated the link between depression symptom physical activity e g jogging cycling and swimming and addictive social medium use smu in a sample of 638 user of social medium mean m age standard deviation sd age 21 57 4 89 depression symptom physical activity and addictive smu were assessed by an online survey physical activity significantly moderated the positive relationship between depression symptom and addictive smu the higher the physical activity the weaker the link between depression symptom and addictive tendency depressed individual often tend to intensive use of social medium to escape negative mood and to find relief this enhances their risk to develop addictive tendency physical activity may reduce this risk and foster well being therefore person with increased depression symptom should be screened for problematic smu and be motivated to engage in physical activity

Title: Relationship Between Daily Stress, Depression Symptoms, and Facebook Addiction Disorder in Germany and in the United States
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Velten, J.; Margaf, J.
Abstract: this study investigated the link between experience of daily stress depression symptom and the facebook addiction disorder fad in germany and in the united state in sample from both country german sample n 531 u s sample n 909 daily stress wa positively associated with fad depression symptom significantly positively moderated this positive relationship thus current finding demonstrate that depressed individual who often tend to intensively use facebook to escape from daily stress and to find relief and social support are at enhanced risk to develop fad which reinforces their negative symptom therefore intervention for depressed individual should include alternative strategy to cope with daily stressor

Title: Rapid visuomotor processing of phobic images in spider- and snake-fearful participants
Authors: Haberkamp, A.; Schmidt, F.; Schmidt, T.
Abstract: this study investigates enhanced visuomotor processing of phobic compared to fear relevant and neutral stimulus we used a response priming design to measure rapid automatic motor activation by natural image spider snake mushroom and flower in spider fearful snake fearful and control participant we found strong priming effect in all task and condition however result showed marked difference between group most importantly in the group of spider fearful individual spider picture had a strong and specific influence on even the fastest motor response phobic prime entailed the largest priming effect and phobic target accelerated response both effect indicating speeded response activation by phobic image in snake fearful participant this processing enhancement for phobic material wa le pronounced and extended to both snake and spider image we conclude that spider phobia lead to enhanced processing capacity for phobic image we argue that this is enabled by long term perceptual learning process

Title: Transcranial direct current stimulation of the motor cortex in waking resting state induces motor imagery
Authors: Speth, J.; Speth, C.; Harley, T. A.
Abstract: this study investigates if anodal and cathodal transcranial direct current stimulation tdcs of area above the motor cortex c3 influence spontaneous motor imagery experienced in the waking resting state a randomized triple blinded design wa used combining neurophysiological technique with tool of quantitative mentation report analysis from cognitive linguistics the result indicate that while spontaneous motor imagery rarely occurs under sham stimulation general and athletic motor imagery classified a athletic discipline is induced by anodal tdcs this insight may have implication beyond basic consciousness research motor imagery and corresponding motor cortical activation have been shown to benefit later motor performance electrophysiological manipulation of motor imagery could in the long run be used for rehabilitative tdcs protocol benefitting temporarily immobile clinical patient who cannot perform specific motor imagery task such a dementia patient infant with developmental and motor disorder and coma patient

Title: Motor imagery in REM sleep is increased by transcranial direct current stimulation of the left motor cortex (C3)
Authors: Speth, J.; Speth, C.
Abstract: this study investigates if anodal transcranial direct current stimulation tdcs of area above the motor cortex c3 influence the quantity and quality of spontaneous motor imagery experienced in rem sleep a randomized triple blinded design wa used combining neurophysiological technique with a tool of quantitative mentation report analysis developed from cognitive linguistics and generative grammar the result indicate that more motor imagery and more athletic motor imagery is induced by anodal tdcs in comparison to cathodal and sham tdcs this insight may have implication beyond basic consciousness research motor imagery in rem sleep ha been hypothesized to serve the rehearsal of motor movement which benefit later motor performance electrophysiological manipulation of motor imagery in rem sleep could in the long run be used for rehabilitative tdcs protocol benefitting temporarily immobile clinical patient especially those who cannot perform specific motor imagery task such a dementia patient infant with developmental and motor disorder and coma patient

Title: (Peer) Group influence on children's prosocial and antisocial behavior
Authors: Misch, A.; Dunham, Y.
Abstract: this study investigates the influence of moral ingroup versus outgroup behavior on 5 and 6 year old and 8 and 9 year old own moral behavior n 296 after minimal group assignment child in experiment 1 observed adult ingroup or outgroup member engaging in prosocial sharing or antisocial stealing before they themselves had the opportunity to privately donate sticker or take away sticker from others older child shared more than younger child and prosocial model elicited higher sharing surprisingly group membership had no effect experiment 2 investigated the same question using peer model child in the younger age group were significantly influenced by ingroup behavior whereas older child were not affected by group membership additional measure reveal interesting insight into how moral ingroup and outgroup behavior affect intergroup attitude evaluation and choice

Title: Interpretative bias in spider phobia: Perception and information processing of ambiguous schematic stimuli
Authors: Haberkamp, A.; Schmidt, F.
Abstract: this study investigates the interpretative bias in spider phobia with respect to rapid visuomotor processing we compared perception evaluation and visuomotor processing of ambiguous schematic stimulus between spider fearful and control participant stimulus were produced by gradually morphing schematic flower into spider participant rated these stimulus related to their perceptual appearance and to their feeling of valence disgust and arousal also they responded to the same stimulus within a response priming paradigm that measure rapid motor activation spider fearful individual showed an interpretative bias i e ambiguous stimulus were perceived a more similar to spider and rated spider like stimulus a more unpleasant disgusting and arousing however we observed no difference between spider fearful and control participant in priming effect for ambiguous stimulus for non ambiguous stimulus we observed a similar enhancement for phobic picture a ha been reported previously for natural image we discus our finding with respect to the visual representation of morphed stimulus and to perceptual learning process

Title: Who stays, who benefits? Predicting dropout and change in cognitive behaviour therapy for psychosis
Authors: Lincoln, T. M.; Rief, W.; Westermann, S.; Ziegler, M.; Kesting, M. L.; Heibach, E.; Mehl, S.
Abstract: this study investigates the predictor of outcome in a secondary analysis of dropout and completer data from a randomized controlled effectiveness trial comparing cbtp to a wait list group lincoln et al 2012 eighty patient with dsm iv psychotic disorder seeking outpatient treatment were included predictor were assessed at baseline symptom outcome wa assessed at post treatment and at 1 year follow up the predictorxgroup interaction indicate that a longer duration of disorder predicted le improvement in negative symptom in the cbtp but not in the wait list group whereas jumping to conclusion wa associated with poorer outcome only in the wait list group there were no cbtp specific predictor of improvement in positive symptom however in the combined sample immediate cbtp the delayed cbtp group baseline variable predicted significant amount of positive and negative symptom variance at post therapy and 1 year follow up after controlling for pre treatment symptom lack of insight and low social functioning were the main predictor of drop out contributing to a prediction accuracy of 87 the finding indicate that higher baseline symptom severity poorer functioning neurocognitive deficit reasoning bias and comorbidity pose no barrier to improvement during cbtp however in line with previous predictor research the finding imply that patient need to receive treatment earlier

Title: Effects of two cognitive regulation strategies on the processing of food cues in high restrained eaters. An event-related potential study
Authors: Svaldi, J.; Tuschen-Caffier, B.; Biehl, S. C.; Gschwendtner, K.; Wolz, I.; Naumann, E.
Abstract: this study tested the effect of cognitive regulation cr on the attentional processing of food cue in restrained eater re by mean of event related potential erps in a within subject design re n 23 were presented picture of highly palatable food and office item while erps were recorded prior to the presentation of the food stimulus participant were either instructed to engage in reappraisal or to attempt to suppress craving both cognitive regulation cr strategy or to simply watch the picture prior to the presentation of the neutral stimulus participant were instructed to simply watch them following each picture presentation momentary craving wa assessed main result showed that engaging in cr significantly reduced erp amplitude compared to the food watch condition passively attending to food picture yielded significantly higher craving score compared to engaging in cr in addition craving wa significantly lower in the reappraisal than in the suppression condition therefore reappraisal could potentially increase the ability to inhibit the appetitive motivation to eat

Title: Associative learning shapes visual discrimination in a web-based classical conditioning task
Authors: Stegmann, Y.; Andreatta, M.; Pauli, P.; Wieser, M. J.
Abstract: threat detection play a vital role in adapting behavior to changing environment a fundamental function to improve threat detection is learning to differentiate between stimulus predicting danger and safety accordingly aversive learning should lead to enhanced sensory discrimination of danger and safety cue however study investigating the psychophysics of visual and auditory perception after aversive learning show divergent finding and both enhanced and impaired discrimination after aversive learning have been reported therefore the aim of this web based study is to examine the impact of aversive learning on a continuous measure of visual discrimination to this end 205 participant underwent a differential fear conditioning paradigm before and after completing a visual discrimination task using differently oriented grating stimulus participant saw either unpleasant or neutral picture a unconditioned stimulus u result demonstrated sharpened visual discrimination for the u associated stimulus c but not for the unpaired conditioned stimulus c importantly this finding wa irrespective of the u s valence these finding suggest that associative learning result in increased stimulus salience which facilitates perceptual discrimination in order to prioritize attentional deployment

Title: Interpersonal Threat Sensitivity in Borderline Personality Disorder: An Eye-Tracking Study
Authors: Bertsch, K.; Krauch, M.; Stopfer, K.; Haeussler, K.; Herpertz, S. C.; Gamer, M.
Abstract: threat sensitivity is a prominent predictor of interpersonal dysfunction in borderline personality disorder bpd leading to intense aversive feeling of threat and eventually dysfunctional behavior such a aggression in the present study bpd patient and healthy volunteer classified angry fearful neutral and happy face presented for 150 m or 5 000 m to investigate initial saccade and facial scanning patient more often wrongly identified anger responded slower to all face and made faster saccade towards the eye of briefly presented neutral face and slower saccade away from fearful eye compared with healthy volunteer latency of initial saccade and fixation duration correlated negatively with the patient aggressiveness supporting previous result bpd patient did not experience general deficit in facial emotion processing but a specific hypersensitivity for and deficit in detailed evaluation of threat cue which wa particularly enhanced in aggressive patient intervention might benefit from relocating attention towards positive information and detailed evaluation of social cue

Title: Threat induction biases processing of emotional expressions
Authors: Flechsenhar, A.; Levine, S.; Bertsch, K.
Abstract: threat can derive from our physical or social surroundings and bias the way we perceive and interpret a given situation they can be signaled by peer through facial expression a expressed anger or fear can represent the source of perceived threat the current study seek to investigate enhanced attentional state and defensive reflex associated with contextual threat induced through aversive sound presented in an emotion recognition paradigm in a sample of 120 healthy participant response and gaze behavior revealed difference in perceiving emotional facial expression between threat and safety condition response were slower under threat and le accurate happy and neutral facial expression were classified correctly more often in a safety context and misclassified more often a fearful under threat this unidirectional misclassification suggests that threat applies a negative filter to the perception of neutral and positive information eye movement were initiated later under threat but fixation change were more frequent and dwell time shorter compared to a safety context these finding demonstrate that such experimental paradigm are capable of providing insight into how context alters emotion processing at cognitive physiological and behavioral level such alteration may derive from evolutionary adaptation necessary for biasing cognitive processing to survive disadvantageous situation this perspective set up new testable hypothesis regarding how such level of explanation may be dysfunctional in patient population

Title: Sexual Excitation and Sexual Inhibition as Predictors of Sexual Function in Women: A Cross-Sectional and Longitudinal Study
Authors: Velten, J.; Scholten, S.; Graham, C. A.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: to date no longitudinal study have evaluated the predictive value of the two factor of the dual control model sexual excitation se and sexual inhibition si for future sexual function the aim of the present study were to investigate the association between se si and sexual function and estimate their predictive value for future sexual function in a sample of woman overall 2 214 woman participated in a web based survey that assessed se si and sexual function a well a symptom of depression the one and two year follow up survey included 396 and 382 participant respectively correlational analysis and hierarchical regression analysis were conducted to analyze the relationship between predictor and outcome variable four factor of se arousability partner characteristic sexual power dynamic and setting and two factor of si concern about sexual function and arousal contingency a well a symptom of depression and partnership status were significant predictor of concurrent and future sexual function several subscales of se and si contributed to the prediction of future sexual function above and beyond prior sexual function level our study provides the first supportive evidence for the assumption of the dual control model that propensity for low se and high si influence future sexual function

Title: All eyes on me?! Social anxiety and self-directed perception of eye gaze
Authors: Schulze, L.; Lobmaier, J. S.; Arnold, M.; Renneberg, B.
Abstract: to date only little is known about the self directed perception and processing of subtle gaze cue in social anxiety that might however contribute to excessive feeling of being looked at by others using a web based approach participant n 174 were asked whether or not briefly 300 m presented facial expression modulated in gaze direction 0 degree 2 degree 4 degree 6 degree 8 degree and valence angry fearful happy neutral were directed at them the result demonstrate a positive linear relationship between self reported social anxiety and stronger self directed perception of others gaze direction particularly for negative angry fearful and neutral expression furthermore faster responding wa found for gaze more clearly directed at socially anxious individual 0 degree 2 degree and 4 degree suggesting a tendency to avoid direct gaze in sum the result illustrate an altered self directed perception of subtle gaze cue the possibly amplifying effect of social stress on biased self directed perception of eye gaze are discussed

Title: Auditory stroop and absolute pitch: an fMRI study
Authors: Schulze, K.; Mueller, K.; Koelsch, S.
Abstract: to date the underlying cognitive and neural mechanism of absolute pitch ap have remained elusive in the present fmri study we investigated verbal and tonal perception and working memory in musician with and without absolute pitch stimulus were sine wave tone and syllable name of the scale tone presented simultaneously participant listened to sequence of five stimulus and then rehearsed internally either the syllable or the tone finally participant indicated whether a test stimulus had been presented during the sequence for an auditory stroop task half of the tonal sequence were congruent frequency of tone corresponded to syllable which were the name of the scale tone and half were incongruent frequency of tone did not correspond to syllable result indicate that first verbal and tonal perception overlap strongly in the left superior temporal gyrus sulcus stg sts in ap musician only second ap is associated with the categorical perception of tone third the left stg sts is activated in ap musician only for the detection of verbal tonal incongruencies in the auditory stroop task finally verbal labelling of tone in ap musician seems to be automatic overall a unique feature of ap appears to be the similarity between verbal and tonal perception

Title: The psychometric properties and temporal dynamics of subjective stress, retrospectively assessed by different informants and questionnaires, and hair cortisol concentrations
Authors: Weckesser, L. J.; Dietz, F.; Schmidt, K.; Grass, J.; Kirschbaum, C.; Miller, R.
Abstract: to date there is only scarce evidence for a considerable association of subjective and objective stress measure which might be attributable to method bias e g confounding and or asynchrony of their temporal change to validate different subjective stress measure by a physiological measure of long term stress hair cortisol concentration hcc 37 heterosexual couple n 74 completed a 12 week internet based assessment protocol comprised of a weekly hassle scale whs once per week a perceived stress scale p once per month and a chronic stress scale tic once after three month partner provided vicarious stress rating when averaged across time self reported whs significantly predicted hcc r 0 27 whereas the p and tic did not r 0 22 dynamic factor analysis i e state space modelling confirmed that whs wa the most valid indicator of subjective stress explaining up to 16 of the variance in hcc r 0 37 with a time lag of 4 week this temporally delayed effect of subjective stress is consistent with the presumed retrospective character of hcc but also suggests that the majority of variance in hair cortisol is attributable to other cause than subjective stress such a individual disposition to display increased adrenocortical activity

Title: Olfactory modulation of affective touch processing - A neurophysiological investigation
Authors: Croy, I.; Drechsler, E.; Hamilton, P.; Hummel, T.; Olausson, H.
Abstract: touch can be highly emotional and depending on the environment it can be perceived a pleasant and comforting or disgusting and dangerous here we studied the impact of context on the processing of tactile stimulus using a functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri paradigm this wa achieved by embedding tactile stimulation in a variable olfactory environment twenty people were scanned with bold fmri while receiving the following stimulus block slow stroking touch civette odor feces like rose odor touch civette and touch rose rating of pleasantness and intensity of tactile stimulus and rating of disgust and intensity of olfactory stimulus were collected the impact of the olfactory context on the processing of touch wa studied using covariance analysis coupling between olfactory processing and somatosensory processing area wa assessed with psychophysiological interaction analysis ppi a subjectively disgusting olfactory environment significantly reduced the perceived pleasantness of touch the touch fmri activation in the secondary somatosensory cortex operculum 1 op1 wa positively correlated with the disgust towards the odor decreased pleasantness of touch wa related to decreased posterior insula activity ppi analysis revealed a significant interaction between the op1 posterior insula and region processing the disgust of odor orbitofrontal cortex and amygdala we conclude that the disgust evaluation of the olfactory environment moderate neural reactivity in somatosensory region by upregulation of the op1 and downregulation of the posterior insula this adaptive regulation of affective touch processing may facilitate adaptive reaction to a potentially harmful stimulus

Title: Effectiveness and equity evaluation of an insurance-wide telephone-counseling program for self-management of chronic diseases: The Health Coach Study
Authors: Renneberg, B.; Schulze, J.; Bohme, S.; West, S. G.; Schuz, B.
Abstract: trajectory of chronic illness depend on patient socioeconomic status s this study examines main and equity effect age gender education region of residence of a brief telephone self management intervention on self rated health and depressive symptom of health insurance client with chronic illness randomized invitation design n 2628 with predominantly male 82 older individual modal age 65 74 with one or more chronic illness primary outcome self rated health and depressive symptom intervention brief cbt based telephone counseling propensity score matching wa used to equate intervention and control group n 1314 pair change score model were used to analyze change in health related outcome measure the intervention resulted in improvement in self rated health d 37 and fewer depressive symptom d 17 over 4 and 6 month there were comparable effect across education and region but younger and female participant profited more from the intervention compared with older and male participant a brief telephone based intervention led to improved self rated health and well being in a large sample of participant with chronic health condition this effect wa observed over and above regular medical care the intervention wa equitable with respect to education and region but not age and gender

Title: Spatio-temporal associations with memory cues are linked to analogue traumatic intrusions
Authors: Meyer, T.; Ikani, N.; Morina, N.
Abstract: trauma survivor with post traumatic stress disorder ptsd frequently experience intrusive trauma memory associated with a feeling of nowness information processing model of ptsd ascribe these symptom to an insufficient integration of memory with their spatio temporal context in the past turning them into powerful stressor here we tested the idea that automatic association of trauma reminder with the present or the past predict intrusive memory we instructed 96 healthy participant to view two different traumatic film participant then underwent a computerized training that established implicit contingency between film reminder picture with the verbal response now or past to increase and reduce intrusion respectively the training successfully altered implicit spatio temporal association for film reminder stimulus on a subsequent implicit association test iat there were no additional transfer effect for tense usage during a free recall task after one week and for the development of intrusion symptom one week diary retrospective questionnaire however participant who associated one film more strongly with the present and the other with the past consistently reported relatively more intrusive memory related to the former film thus our result lend support to information processing model of ptsd and warrant further investigation of the causal role of implicit association with spatio temporal information

Title: Assessment of implicit health attitudes: a multitrait-multimethod approach and a comparison between patients with hypochondriasis and patients with anxiety disorders
Authors: Weck, F.; Hofling, V.
Abstract: two adaptation of the implicit association task were used to a implicit anxiety iat anxiety and implicit health attitude iat hypochondriasis in patient with hypochondriasis n 58 and anxiety patient n 71 explicit anxiety and health attitude were assessed using questionnaire the analysis of several multitrait multimethod model indicated that the low correlation between explicit and implicit measure of health attitude is due to the substantial methodological difference between the iat and the self report questionnaire patient with hypochondriasis displayed significantly more dysfunctional explicit and implicit health attitude than anxiety patient but no difference were found regarding explicit and implicit anxiety the study demonstrates the specificity of explicit and implicit dysfunctional health attitude among patient with hypochondriasis

Title: Uncertainty is associated with increased selective attention and sustained stimulus processing
Authors: Dieterich, R.; Endrass, T.; Kathmann, N.
Abstract: uncertainty about future threat ha been found to be associated with an overestimation of threat probability and is hypothesized to elicit additional allocation of attention we used event related potential to examine uncertainty related dynamic in attentional allocation exploiting brain potential high temporal resolution and sensitivity to attention thirty participant performed a picture viewing task in which cue indicated the subsequent picture valence a certain neutral and a certain aversive cue accurately predicted subsequent picture valence whereas an uncertain cue did not participant overestimated the effective frequency of aversive picture following the uncertain cue both during and after the task signifying expectancy and covariation bias and they tended to express lower subjective valence for aversive picture presented after the uncertain cue picture elicited increased p2 and lpp amplitude when their valence could not be predicted from the cue for the lpp this effect wa more pronounced in response to neutral picture uncertainty appears to enhance the engagement of early phasic and sustained attention for uncertainly cued target thus defensive motivation related to uncertainty about future threat elicits specific attentional dynamic implicating prioritization at various processing stage especially for nonthreatening stimulus that tend to violate expectation

Title: On the source and scope of priming effects of masked stimuli on endogenous shifts of spatial attention
Authors: Palmer, S.; Mattler, U.
Abstract: unconscious stimulus can influence participant motor behavior a well a more complex mental process previous cue priming experiment demonstrated that masked cue can modulate endogenous shift of spatial attention a measured by choice reaction time task here we applied a signal detection task with masked luminance target to determine the source and the scope of effect of masked stimulus target detection performance wa modulated by prime cue congruency indicating that prime cue congruency modulates signal enhancement at early level of target processing these effect however were only found when the prime wa perceptually similar to the cue indicting that prime influence early target processing in an indirect way by facilitating cue processing together with previous research we conclude that masked stimulus can modulate perceptual and post central level of processing finding mark a new limit of the effect of unconscious stimulus which seem to have a smaller scope than conscious stimulus

Title: Masked stimuli modulate endogenous shifts of spatial attention
Authors: Palmer, S.; Mattler, U.
Abstract: unconscious stimulus can influence participant motor behavior but also more complex mental process recent research ha gradually extended the limit of effect of unconscious stimulus one field of research where such limit have been proposed is spatial cueing where exogenous automatic shift of attention have been distinguished from endogenous controlled process which govern voluntary shift of attention previous evidence suggests unconscious effect on mechanism of exogenous shift of attention here we applied a cue priming paradigm to a spatial cueing task with arbitrary cue by centrally presenting a masked symmetrical prime before every cue stimulus we found priming effect on response time in target discrimination task with the typical dynamic of cue priming effect experiment 1 and 2 indicating that central symmetrical stimulus which have been associated with endogenous orienting can modulate shift of spatial attention even when they are masked prime cue congruency effect of perceptual dissimilar prime and cue stimulus experiment 3 suggest that these effect cannot be entirely reduced to perceptual repetition priming of cue processing in addition priming effect did not differ between participant with good and poor prime recognition performance consistent with the view that unconscious stimulus feature have access to process of endogenous shift of attention

Title: Different Brain Circuitries Mediating Controllable and Uncontrollable Pain
Authors: Brascher, A. K.; Becker, S.; Hoeppli, M. E.; Schweinhardt, P.
Abstract: uncontrollable compared with controllable painful stimulation can lead to increased pain perception and activation in pain processing brain region but it is currently unknown which brain area mediate this effect when pain is controllable the lateral prefrontal cortex pfc seems to inhibit pain processing although it is unclear how this is achieved using fmri in healthy volunteer we examined brain activation during controllable and uncontrollable stimulation to answer these question in the controllable task participant self adjusted temperature applied to their hand of pain or warm intensity to provoke a constant sensation in the uncontrollable task the temperature time course of the controllable task were replayed yoked control and participant rated their sensation continuously during controllable pain trial participant significantly downregulated the temperature to keep their sensation constant despite receiving the identical nociceptive input intensity rating increased during the uncontrollable pain trial this additional sensitization wa mirrored in increased activation of pain processing region such a insula anterior cingulate cortex and thalamus further increased connectivity between the anterior insula and medial pfc mpfc in the uncontrollable and increased negative connectivity between dorsolateral pfc dlpfc and insula in the controllable task were observed this suggests a pain facilitating role of the mpfc during uncontrollable pain and a pain inhibiting role of the dlpfc during controllable pain both exerting their respective effect via the anterior insula these result elucidate neural mechanism of context dependent pain modulation and their relation to subjective perception significance statement pain control is of uttermost importance and stimulus controllability is an important way to achieve endogenous pain modulation here we show differential effect of controllability and uncontrollability on pain perception and cerebral pain processing when pain wa controllable the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex downregulated pain evoked activation in important pain processing region in contrast sensitization during uncontrollable pain wa mediated by increased connectivity of the medial prefrontal cortex with the anterior insula and other pain processing region these novel insight into cerebral pain modulation by stimulus controllability have the potential to improve treatment approach in pain patient

Title: Taking a machine learning approach to optimize prediction of vaccine hesitancy in high income countries
Authors: Lincoln, T. M.; Schlier, B.; Strakeljahn, F.; Gaudiano, B. A.; So, S. H.; Kingston, J.; Morris, E. M. J.; Ellett, L.
Abstract: understanding factor driving vaccine hesitancy is crucial to vaccination success we surveyed adult n 2510 from february to march 2021 across five site australia 502 germany 516 hong kong 445 uk 512 usa 535 using a cross sectional design and stratified quota sampling for age sex and education we assessed willingness to take a vaccine and a comprehensive set of putative predictor predictive power wa analysed with a machine learning algorithm only 57 4 of the participant indicated that they would definitely or probably get vaccinated a parsimonious machine learning model could identify vaccine hesitancy with high accuracy i e 82 sensitivity and 79 82 specificity using 12 variable only the most relevant predictor were vaccination conspiracy belief various paranoid concern related to the pandemic a general conspiracy mentality covid anxiety high perceived risk of infection low perceived social rank lower age lower income and higher population density campaign seeking to increase vaccine uptake need to take mistrust a the main driver of vaccine hesitancy into account

Title: Measuring Patients' Acquisition of Therapy Skills in Psychotherapy for Depression: Assessing the CCTS-SR and the IPSS-SR
Authors: Bruijniks, S. J. E.; Peeters, Fpml; Strunk, D. R.; Huibers, M. J. H.
Abstract: using data from 202 patient with depression the author conducted a psychometric evaluation of the dutch translation of the competency of cognitive therapy scale self report and an initial psychometric evaluation of the newly developed interpersonal psychotherapy skill scale self report

Title: Depression, not PTSD, is associated with attentional biases for emotional visual cues in early traumatized individuals with PTSD
Authors: Wittekind, C. E.; Muhtz, C.; Jelinek, L.; Moritz, S.
