Abstract: using variant of the emotional stroop task est a large number of study demonstrated attentional bias in individual with ptsd across different type of trauma however the specificity and robustness of the emotional stroop effect in ptsd have been questioned recently in particular the paradigm cannot disentangle underlying cognitive mechanism transgenerational study provide evidence that consequence of trauma are not limited to the traumatized people but extend to close relative especially the child to further investigate attentional bias in ptsd and to shed light on the underlying cognitive mechanism s a spatial cueing paradigm with picture of different emotional valence neutral anxiety depression trauma wa administered to individual displaced a child during world war ii wwii with n 22 and without ptsd n 26 a well a to non traumatized control n 22 to a whether parental ptsd is associated with biased information processing in child each one adult offspring wa also included in the study ptsd wa not associated with attentional bias for trauma related stimulus there wa no evidence for a transgenerational transmission of biased information processing however when sample were regrouped based on current depression a reduced inhibition of return ior effect emerged for depression related cue ior refers to the phenomenon that with longer interval between cue and target the validity effect is reversed uncued location are associated with shorter and cued location with longer rts the result diverge from est study and demonstrate that finding on attentional bias yield equivocal result across different paradigm attentional bias for trauma related material may only appear for verbal but not for visual stimulus in an elderly population with childhood trauma with ptsd future study should more closely investigate whether finding from younger trauma population also manifest in older trauma survivor

Title: Do venepuncture procedures induce cortisol responses? A review, study, and synthesis for stress research
Authors: Weckesser, L. J.; Plessow, F.; Pilhatsch, M.; Muehlhan, M.; Kirschbaum, C.; Miller, R.
Abstract: venepuncture procedure are frequently employed to continuously monitor humoral stress marker a such procedure are conceived a potent psychological and physiological stressor there is a need to determine whether venepuncture procedure themselves elicit cortisol response and if so how to deal with them appropriately in order to a the rate of cortisol response to venepuncture we conducted a literature review which suggested that venepuncture procedure induce cortisol response with a probability of approximately 30 by utilizing bayesian analysis this result wa integrated with the cortisol data of 18 healthy men who were exposed to a venepuncture procedure twice time lag 1 week the currently observed response rate of 47 differed substantially from the earlier finding which we attribute to a self selective sampling of participant in addition participant showing a response to the first venepuncture were highly likely to also show a response to the second one in this regard we discus the presumed conditioning of cortisol response to venepuncture procedure to prevent the superposition of venepuncture induced cortisol response and response induced by target stressor we propose a time and selection based strategy cortisol sample taken about 110min after venepuncture should be virtually adjusted for it superimposing effect furthermore previous experience of venepuncture were highly predictive for cortisol responsiveness this association could be utilized in further study to identify participant who will probably show a cortisol response to venepuncture

Title: Teachers' stress intensifies violent disciplining in Tanzanian secondary schools
Authors: Hecker, T.; Goessmann, K.; Nkuba, M.; Hermenau, K.
Abstract: violent form of discipline in school continue to be widespread across the globe despite their damaging effect since little is known about factor influencing the extent of violence applied by teacher this study aimed to investigate the influence of teacher stress work satisfaction and personal characteristic on their disciplining style using structural equation modeling association between violent discipline burnout symptom and job perception pressure and difficulty in class reported by 222 teacher from 11 secondary school in tanzania in 2015 were analyzed result indicated a direct association between perceived stress and emotional violent discipline beta 18 p 05 a well a physical violent discipline beta 37 p 001 perceived stress also mediated the association between job perception and both form of violent disciplining the model showed good model fit chi 2 44 n 222 67 47 p 013 cfi 94 tli 91 ifi 94 rmsea 049 90 ci 02 07 pclose 50 srmr 06 our finding suggest that teacher personal perception of their work a well a their stress burden play a role in their disciplining style our finding underline the importance of integrating topic such a stress and coping a well a positive nonviolent discipline measure into the regular teacher s training and in addition to develop and evaluate school based preventative intervention for teacher

Title: Sense of presence and anxiety during virtual social interactions between a human and virtual humans
Authors: Morina, N.; Brinkman, W. P.; Hartanto, D.; Emmelkamp, P. M.
Abstract: virtual reality exposure therapy vret ha been shown to be effective in treatment of anxiety disorder yet there is lack of research on the extent to which interaction between the individual and virtual human can be successfully implanted to increase level of anxiety for therapeutic purpose this proof of concept pilot study aimed at examining level of the sense of presence and anxiety during exposure to virtual environment involving social interaction with virtual human and using different virtual reality display a non clinical sample of 38 participant wa randomly assigned to either a head mounted display hmd with motion tracker and sterescopic view condition or a one screen projection based virtual reality display condition participant in both condition engaged in free speech dialogue with virtual human controlled by research assistant it wa hypothesized that exposure to virtual social interaction will elicit moderate level of sense of presence and anxiety in both group further it wa expected that participant in the hmd condition will report higher score of sense of presence and anxiety than participant in the one screen projection based display condition result revealed that in both condition virtual social interaction were associated with moderate level of sense of presence and anxiety additionally participant in the hmd condition reported significantly higher level of presence than those in the one screen projection based display condition p 001 however contrary to the expectation neither the average level of anxiety nor the highest level of anxiety during exposure to social virtual environment differed between the group p 97 and p 75 respectively the finding suggest that virtual social interaction can be successfully applied in vret to enhance sense of presence and anxiety furthermore our result indicate that one screen projection based display can successfully activate level of anxiety in social virtual environment the outcome can prove helpful in using low cost projection based virtual reality environment for treating individual with social phobia

Title: Causal Interactive Links Between Presence and Fear in Virtual Reality Height Exposure
Authors: Gromer, D.; Reinke, M.; Christner, I.; Pauli, P.
Abstract: virtual reality play an increasingly important role in research and therapy of pathological fear however the mechanism how virtual environment elicit and modify fear response are not yet fully understood presence a psychological construct referring to the sense of being there in a virtual environment is widely assumed to crucially influence the strength of the elicited fear response however causality is still under debate the present study is the first that experimentally manipulated both variable to unravel the causal link between presence and fear response height fearful participant n 49 were immersed into a virtual height situation and a neutral control situation fear manipulation with either high versus low sensory realism presence manipulation rating of presence and verbal and physiological skin conductance heart rate fear response were recorded result revealed an effect of the fear manipulation on presence i e higher presence rating in the height situation compared to the neutral control situation but no effect of the presence manipulation on fear response however the presence rating during the first exposure to the high quality neutral environment were predictive of later fear response in the height situation our finding support the hypothesis that experiencing emotional response in a virtual environment lead to a stronger feeling of being there i e increase presence in contrast the effect of presence on fear seem to be more complex on the one hand increased presence due to the quality of the virtual environment did not influence fear on the other hand presence variability that likely stemmed from difference in user characteristic did predict later fear response these finding underscore the importance of user characteristic in the emergence of presence

Title: Top-down influence on gaze patterns in the presence of social features
Authors: Flechsenhar, A. F.; Gamer, M.
Abstract: visual saliency map reflecting location that stand out from the background in term of their low level physical feature have proven to be very useful for empirical research on attentional exploration and reliably predict gaze behavior in the present study we tested these prediction for socially relevant stimulus occurring in naturalistic scene using eye tracking we hypothesized that social feature i e human face or body would be processed preferentially over non social feature i e object animal regardless of their low level saliency to challenge this notion we included three task that deliberately addressed non social attribute in agreement with our hypothesis social information especially head wa preferentially attended compared to highly salient image region across all task social information wa never required to solve a task but wa regarded nevertheless more so after completing the task requirement viewing behavior reverted back to that of free viewing with heavy prioritization of social feature additionally initial eye movement reflecting potentially automatic shift of attention were predominantly directed towards head irrespective of top down task demand on these ground we suggest that social stimulus may provide exclusive access to the priority map enabling social attention to override reflexive and controlled attentional process furthermore our result challenge the generalizability of saliency based attention model

Title: Altered autonomic arousal in psychosis: an analysis of vulnerability and specificity
Authors: Clamor, A.; Hartmann, M. M.; Kother, U.; Otte, C.; Moritz, S.; Lincoln, T. M.
Abstract: vulnerability stress model implicate that alteration of the autonomous nervous system contribute to the development of psychosis previous research ha found autonomic arousal alteration in psychotic disorder and at risk individual that are not explained by medication alone to test whether these alteration are associated with the extent of an individual s vulnerability and whether they are specific to psychosis we compared participant with psychosis n 23 first degree relative of individual with psychosis n 21 and healthy participant with attenuated positive symptom n 23 to participant with depression n 24 and healthy control n 24 at rest skin conductance level wa assessed and photoplethysmography wa applied to measure time and frequency domain heart rate variability hrv univariate and multivariate analysis of covariance with perceived stress and psychophysiological value a dependent variable showed significant between group difference for perceived stress p 010 heart rate p 022 time domain hrv index all p 027 and vagal activity p 017 group difference in sympathetic activity were nonsignificant p 069 in an additional analysis with medication a a second between group factor the physiological between group difference remained significant or trend significant all p 060 with the exception of sympathetic activity participant with psychosis exhibited more extreme arousal than the control group first degree relative and participant with attenuated symptom showed comparable autonomic activity to healthy control thus the hypothesized association of an alteration of arousal and vulnerability to psychosis wa not confirmed however particularly low time domain hrv wa found for psychosis with significant difference to healthy control all p 007 and to depression all p 004 with the latter indicating a specificity to psychosis

Title: The anxious addictive narcissist: The relationship between grandiose and vulnerable narcissism, anxiety symptoms and Facebook Addiction
Authors: Brailovskaia, J.; Rohmann, E.; Bierhoff, H. W.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: vulnerable narcissism and grandiose narcissism share the core of the narcissistic self but are considered a separate form of this personality trait while previous research mainly focused on the mechanism that connect grandiose narcissism and addictive use of the social platform facebook it remained unclear why individual with enhanced level of vulnerable narcissism are at risk to develop facebook addiction fa the present study investigated the link between vulnerable and grandiose narcissism anxiety symptom and fa in a sample of 327 facebook user age m sd 23 67 3 96 range 18 56 both form of narcissism were positively related to anxiety symptom and fa moreover the association between both form of narcissism and fa wa partly mediated by anxiety symptom result enter new territory by revealing hidden similarity between vulnerable and grandiose narcissist emphasizing that similar mechanism might explain their enhanced risk to develop addictive tendency of facebook use these finding should be considered when assessing individual at risk for fa and when developing therapeutic intervention program to deal with problematic use of social platform

Title: The Cycle of Violence: Associations Between Exposure to Violence, Trauma-Related Symptoms and Aggression--Findings from Congolese Refugees in Uganda
Authors: Hecker, T.; Fetz, S.; Ainamani, H.; Elbert, T.
Abstract: war related trauma exposure ha been linked to aggression and enhanced level of community and family violence suggesting a cycle of violence reactive aggression an aggressive reaction to a perceived threat ha been associated with posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd in contrast appetitive aggression a hedonic intrinsically motivated form of aggression seems to be negatively related to ptsd in offender and military population this study examined the association between exposure to violence trauma related symptom and aggression in a civilian population in semistructured interview 290 congolese refugee were questioned about trauma exposure ptsd symptom and aggression war related trauma exposure correlated positively with exposure to family and community violence in the past month r 31 p 001 and appetitive r 18 p 002 and reactive aggression r 29 p 001 the relationship between war related trauma exposure and reactive aggressive behavior wa mediated by ptsd symptom and appetitive aggression in a multiple sequential regression analysis trauma exposure beta 43 p 001 and reactive aggression beta 36 p 001 were positively associated with ptsd symptom whereas appetitive aggression wa negatively associated beta 13 p 007 with ptsd symptom our finding were congruent with the cycle of violence hypothesis and indicate a differential relation between distinct subtypes of aggression and ptsd

Title: Transgenerational trauma in a post-conflict setting: Effects on offspring PTSS/PTSD and offspring vulnerability in Cambodian families
Authors: Burchert, S.; Stammel, N.; Knaevelsrud, C.
Abstract: we assessed transgenerational effect of maternal traumatic exposure posttraumatic stress symptom and posttraumatic stress disorder on trauma related symptom in cambodian offspring born after the genocidal khmer rouge regime we conducted a randomized cross sectional study n 378 mother from 4 province of the country and one of each of their grown up child were interviewed lifetime traumatic exposure wa determined using a context adapted event list present posttraumatic stress symptom and a potential posttraumatic stress disorder were assessed using the civilian version of the posttraumatic stress disorder checklist we found no indication of transgenerational effect that were directly related to maternal traumatic exposure posttraumatic stress symptom or posttraumatic stress disorder instead a gender specific moderating effect wa found individual traumatic exposure had a stronger effect on posttraumatic stress symptom in daughter the higher the mother s lifetime traumatic exposure there is evidence of an interaction between lifetime traumatic exposure of mother and their offspring that can be interpreted a an increased vulnerability to symptom of posttraumatic stress in daughter the mechanism of transgenerational trauma in the cambodian context require further research a learning from previous conflict will be instructive when addressing the pressing humanitarian need of today s world

Title: Long-term effects of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder and residual symptoms after cognitive behavioral therapy: Twelve-month follow-up of a randomized controlled trial
Authors: Cludius, B.; Landmann, S.; Rose, N.; Heidenreich, T.; Hottenrott, B.; Schroder, J.; Jelinek, L.; Voderholzer, U.; Kulz, A. K.; Moritz, S.
Abstract: we examined the long term efficacy of mindfulness based cognitive therapy mbct compared to a psychoeducation group a an active control condition in patient with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd with residual symptom of ocd after cognitive behavioral therapy a total of 125 patient were included in a bicentric interviewer blind randomized and actively controlled trial and were assigned to either an mbct group n 61 or a psychoeducation group n 64 patient demographic characteristic and the result from our previous assessment have already been reported kulz et al 2019 at the 12 month follow up the completion rate wa 80 ocd symptom were reduced from baseline to follow up assessment with a large effect but no difference wa found between group exploratory analysis showed that a composite score of time occupied by obsessive thought distress associated with obsessive thought and interference due to obsessive thought differed between group in the per protocol analysis with a stronger reduction in the mbct group at the 12 month follow up the two group showed a similar reduction of symptom however preliminary evidence indicates that mbct ha a superior effect on some aspect of ocd this should be replicated in future study

Title: Baseline Patient Characteristics Predicting Outcome and Attrition in Cognitive Therapy for Social Phobia: Results from a Large Multicentre Trial
Authors: Hoyer, J.; Wiltink, J.; Hiller, W.; Miller, R.; Salzer, S.; Sarnowsky, S.; Stangier, U.; Strauss, B.; Willutzki, U.; Leibing, E.
Abstract: we examined the role of baseline patient characteristic a predictor of outcome end state functioning response and remission and attrition for cognitive therapy ct in social anxiety disorder sad beyond socio demographic and clinical variable such a symptom severity and comorbidity status previously neglected patient characteristic e g personality self esteem shame interpersonal problem and attachment style were analysed method data came from the ct arm of a multicentre rct with n 244 patient having dsm iv sad ct wa conducted according to the manual by clark and well severity of sad wa assessed at baseline and end of treatment with the liebowitz social anxiety scale lsas multiple linear regression analysis and logistic regression analysis were applied result up to 37 of the post treatment variance lsas could be explained by all pre treatment variable combined symptom severity baseline lsas wa consistently negatively associated with end state functioning and remission but not with response number of comorbid diagnosis wa negatively associated with end state functioning and response but not with remission self esteem wa positively associated with higher end state functioning and more shame with better response attrition could not be significantly predicted conclusion the result indicate that the initial probability for treatment success mainly depends on severity of disorder and comorbid condition while other psychological variable are of minor importance at least on a nomothetic level this stand in contrast with effort to arrive at an empirical based foundation for differential indication and argues to search for more potent moderator of therapeutic change rather on the process level key practitioner message personality self esteem shame attachment style and interpersonal problem do not or only marginally moderate the effect of intervention in ct of social phobia symptom severity and comorbid diagnosis might affect treatment outcome negatively beyond these two factor most patient share a similar likelihood of treatment success when treated according to the manual by clark and well copyright c 2014 john wiley son ltd

Title: Processing of increased frequency of social interaction in social anxiety disorder and borderline personality disorder
Authors: Weinbrecht, A.; Niedeggen, M.; Roepke, S.; Renneberg, B.
Abstract: we investigated how patient with social anxiety disorder sad and patient with borderline personality disorder bpd process an increase in the frequency of social interaction we used an eeg compatible version of the online ball tossing game cyberball to induce an increase in the frequency of social interaction in the first condition each player received the ball equally often inclusion 33 ball reception in the following condition the frequency of the ball reception wa increased overinclusion 45 ball reception the main outcome variable wa the event related potential p2 an indicator for social reward processing moreover positive emotion were assessed twenty eight patient with sad 29 patient with bpd and 28 healthy control hcs participated a expected hcs and patient with bpd but not patient with sad showed an increase in the p2 amplitude from the inclusion to the overinclusion condition contrary to our expectation positive emotion did not change from the inclusion to the overinclusion condition eeg result provide preliminary evidence that patient with bpd and hcs but not patient with sad process an increase in the frequency of social interaction a rewarding

Title: The Role of Self-reports and Behavioral Measures of Interpretation Biases in Children with Varying Levels of Anxiety
Authors: Klein, A. M.; Flokstra, E.; van Niekerk, R.; Klein, S.; Rapee, R. M.; Hudson, J. L.; Bogels, S. M.; Becker, E. S.; Rinck, M.
Abstract: we investigated the role of self report and behavioral measure of interpretation bias and their content specificity in child with varying level of spider fear and or social anxiety in total 141 selected child from a community sample completed an interpretation bias task with scenario that were related to either spider threat or social threat specific interpretation bias were found only spider related interpretation bias and self reported spider fear predicted unique variance in avoidance behavior on the behavior avoidance task for spider likewise only social threat related interpretation bias and self reported social anxiety predicted anxiety during the social speech task these finding support the hypothesis that fearful child display cognitive bias that are specific to particular fear relevant stimulus clinically this insight might be used to improve treatment for anxious child by targeting content specific interpretation bias related to individual disorder

Title: The N2pc component reliably captures attentional bias in social anxiety
Authors: Reutter, M.; Hewig, J.; Wieser, M. J.; Osinsky, R.
Abstract: we systematically compared different measure of attentional bias i e reaction time the n2pc component in the eeg and explicit stimulus rating on their ability to reveal attentional engagement to threatening versus neutral facial stimulus in a dot probe task and tested their relation to trait measure of general and social anxiety we found that the n2pc component reflects a bias toward angry face with excellent internal consistency similar result were obtained for explicit rating reaction time rt difference however were not indicative of attentional bias and showed zero odd even reliability we further found that both higher i e more negative n2pc amplitude and earlier peak latency were associated with more severe symptom of social anxiety even when controlling for general trait anxiety the explicit rating bias were also specifically associated with social anxiety conversely the rt bias wa not related to social anxiety level but to general trait anxiety this highlight the importance of valid and reliable outcome measure for intervention such a attentional bias modification protocol mutual exclusivity of different bias operationalizations is discussed

Title: You see what you avoid: Fear of spiders and avoidance are associated with predominance of spiders in binocular rivalry
Authors: Muller, U. W. D.; Gerdes, A. B. M.; Alpers, G. W.
Abstract: what we see is the result of an efficient selection of cue in the visual stream in addition to physical characteristic this process is also influenced by emotional salience of the cue previously we showed in spider phobic patient that fear related picture gain preferential access to consciousness in binocular rivalry we set out to replicate this in an independent unselected sample and examine the relationship of this perceptual bias with a range of symptom cluster to this end we recruited 79 participant with variable degree of fear of spider to induce binocular rivalry a picture of either a spider or a flower wa projected to one eye and a neutral geometric pattern to the other eye participant continuously reported what they saw we correlated index of perceptual dominance first percept dominance duration with individual fear of spider and with score on specific symptom cluster of fear of spider i e vigilance fixation and avoidance coping overall higher fear of spider correlate with more predominace of spider picture in addition this perceptual bias is uniquely associated with avoidance coping interestingly this demonstrates that a perceptual bias which is not intentionally controlled is linked with an instrumental coping behavior that ha been implicated in the maintenance of pathological fear

Title: Indoor or Outdoor? Generalization of Costly Pain-Related Avoidance Behavior to Conceptually Related Contexts
Authors: Kloos, T.; van Vliet, C.; Riecke, J.; Meulders, A.
Abstract: when pain persists beyond healing time and becomes a false alarm of bodily threat protective strategy such a avoidance are no longer adaptive more specifically generalization of avoidance based on conceptual knowledge may contribute to chronic pain disability using an operant robotic arm avoidance paradigm healthy participant n 50 could perform more effortful movement in the threat context eg picture of outdoor scene to avoid painful stimulus whereas no pain occured in the safe context eg picture of indoor scene next we investigated avoidance generalization to conceptually related context ie novel outdoor indoor scene a expected participant avoided more when presented with novel context conceptually related to the threat context than in novel exemplar of the safe context yet exemplar belonging to one category outdoor indoor scene were not interchangeable there wa a generalization decrement posthoc analysis revealed that contingency aware participant n 27 but not non aware participant n 23 showed the avoidance generalization effect and also generalized their differential pain expectancy and pain related fear more to novel background scene conceptually related to the original threat context in contrast the fear potentiated startle response wa not modulated by context perspective this article provides evidence for contextual modulation of avoidance behavior and it generalization to novel exemplar of the learned category based on conceptual relatedness our finding suggest that category based generalization is a plausible mechanism explaining why patient display avoidance behavior in novel situation that were never directly associated with pain

Title: The influence of motivation and emotion on sensorimotor rhythm-based brain-computer interface performance
Authors: Kleih-Dahms, S. C.; Botrel, L.; Kubler, A.
Abstract: while decade of research have investigated and technically improved brain computer interface bci controlled application relatively little is known about the psychological aspect of brain computer interfacing in 35 healthy student we investigated whether extrinsic motivation manipulated via monetary reward and emotional state manipulated via video and music would influence behavioral and psychophysiological measure of performance with a sensorimotor rhythm smr based bci we found increased task related brain activity in extrinsically motivated rewarded a compared with nonmotivated participant but no clear effect of emotional state manipulation our experiment investigated the short term effect of motivation and emotion manipulation in a group of young healthy subject and thus the significance for patient in the locked in state who may be in need of a bci remains to be investigated

Title: Fear processing in dental phobia during crossmodal symptom provocation: an fMRI study
Authors: Hilbert, K.; Evens, R.; Maslowski, N. I.; Wittchen, H. U.; Lueken, U.
Abstract: while previous study successfully identified the core neural substrate of the animal subtype of specific phobia only few and inconsistent research is available for dental phobia these finding might partly relate to the fact that typically visual stimulus were employed the current study aimed to investigate the influence of stimulus modality on neural fear processing in dental phobia thirteen dental phobics dp and thirteen healthy control hc attended a block design functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri symptom provocation paradigm encompassing both visual and auditory stimulus drill sound and matched neutral sinus tone served a auditory stimulus and dentist scene and matched neutral video a visual stimulus group comparison showed increased activation in the insula anterior cingulate cortex orbitofrontal cortex and thalamus in dp compared to hc during auditory but not visual stimulation on the contrary no differential autonomic reaction were observed in dp present result are largely comparable to brain area identified in animal phobia but also point towards a potential downregulation of autonomic outflow by neural fear circuit in this disorder finding enlarge our knowledge about neural correlate of dental phobia and may help to understand the neural underpinnings of the clinical and physiological characteristic of the disorder

Title: Relating experimentally-induced fear to pre-existing phobic fear in the human brain
Authors: Levine, S. M.; Pfaller, M.; Reichenberger, J.; Shiban, Y.; Muhlberger, A.; Rupprecht, R.; Schwarzbach, J. V.
Abstract: while prior work ha demonstrated that fear conditioning change the neural representation of previously neutral stimulus it remains unknown to what extent this new representation abstract away from specific fear and which brain area are involved therein to investigate this question we sought commonality between experimentally induced fear via electric shock and pre existing phobia using functional mri we tested the effect of fear conditioning picture of dog in 21 spider fearful participant across three phase baseline post conditioning and extinction considering phobic stimulus a a reference point for the state of fear allowed u to examine whether fear conditioning render information pattern of previously neutral stimulus more similar to those of phobic stimulus we trained a classification algorithm to discriminate information pattern of neutral stimulus rat and phobic stimulus and then tested the algorithm on information pattern from the conditioned stimulus dog performing this cross decoding analysis at each experimental phase revealed brain region in which dog were classified a rat during baseline a spider following conditioning and again a rat after extinction a follow up analysis showed that change in visual perception information cannot explain the changing classification performance these result demonstrate a common neural representation for processing fear eliciting information either pre existing or acquired by classical conditioning

Title: Do Mothers Benefit from a Child-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Treatment (CBT) for Childhood Functional Abdominal Pain? A Randomized Controlled Pilot Trial
Authors: Calvano, C.; Gross, M.; Warschburger, P.
Abstract: while the efficacy of cognitive behavioral treatment cbt approach for childhood functional abdominal pain fap is well established for child outcome only a few study have reported on parent specific outcome this randomized controlled pilot trial analyzed effect of a group cbt on maternal variable i e pain related behavior worry and self efficacy a well a general psychosocial strain method the sample constituted of 15 mother in the intervention group ig and 14 mother in the waitlist control group wlc outcome measure were assessed pre treatment post treatment and at three month follow up result analysis revealed significant large change in maladaptive maternal reaction related to the child s abdominal pain in the ig compared to the wlc i e reduced attention d 0 95 medical help seeking d 0 92 worry d 1 03 a well a a significant increase in behavior that encourage the child s self management d 1 03 in addition maternal self efficacy in dealing with a child s pain significantly increased in the ig a well d 0 92 treatment effect emerged post treatment and could be maintained until three month follow up there were no effect on general self efficacy and maternal quality of life conclusion while these result are promising and underline the efficacy of the cbt approach for both the child and mother further study including long term follow ups are warranted

Title: A bias toward the unknown: individual and environmental factors influencing exploratory behavior
Authors: Petzke, T. M.; Schomaker, J.
Abstract: with limited resource exploring new opportunity is crucial for survival exploring novel option however come at the cost of uncertainty therefore there is a trade off between exploiting option with a known beneficial outcome and exploring novel option with a potentially higher gain computational model have suggested that novelty may promote exploratory behavior by inducing a so called novelty bonus through reward related process so far few study have provided behavioral evidence for such a novelty bonus in this study we aimed to investigate whether spatial novelty can stimulate exploratory behavior experiment 1 and whether age novelty seeking and reduced action radius or social interaction due to covid 19 restriction influenced the exploration exploitation trade off experiment 2 in both experiment we employed a novel paradigm in which participant made binary decision between food item while on rare trial a surprise option wa presented result from experiment 1 are in line with a novelty bonus with spatial novelty promoting exploratory behavior in experiment 2 we found that exploratory behavior declined with age high novelty seeker made more exploratory choice than low novelty seeker and participant with a smaller action radius made fewer exploratory choice these finding are consistent with previous finding in animal and prediction from computational model

Title: Satisfaction guaranteed? How individual, partner, and relationship factors impact sexual satisfaction within partnerships
Authors: Velten, J.; Margraf, J.
Abstract: within committed relationship a wide range of factor may challenge or facilitate sexual satisfaction the aim of this study wa to clarify which individual partner and partnership related aspect of a sexual relationship are crucial for the prediction of sexual satisfaction the study included data of a representative sample of 964 couple from the general population the actor partner interdependence model wa used to estimate actor and partner effect overall predictor explained 57 of outcome variance actor effect were found for sexual function sexual distress frequency of sexual activity desire discrepancy sexual initiative sexual communication sociosexual orientation masturbation and life satisfaction gender specific partner effect were found for sexual function and sexual distress neither age nor relationship duration were significant predictor to deepen our understanding of sexual satisfaction it is necessary to take quantitative and qualitative aspect of sexual relationship into account and to consider actor partner and relationship related predictor

Title: Does Repeated Testing Impact Concordance Between Genital and Self-Reported Sexual Arousal in Women?
Authors: Velten, J.; Chivers, M. L.; Brotto, L. A.
Abstract: woman show a substantial variability in their genital and subjective response to sexual stimulus the level of agreement between these two aspect of response is termed sexual concordance and ha been increasingly investigated because of it implication for understanding model of sexual response and a a potential endpoint in clinical trial of treatment to improve woman s sexual dysfunction however interpreting change in sexual concordance may be problematic because to date it still is unclear how repeated testing itself influence sexual concordance in woman we are aware of only one study that evaluated temporal stability of concordance in woman and it found no evidence of stability however time stability would be necessary for arguing that concordance is a stable individual difference the main goal of this study wa to investigate the test retest reliability of sexual concordance in a sample of 30 woman with sexual difficulty using hierarchical linear modeling we found that sexual concordance wa not influenced by repeated testing 12 week later but showed test retest reliability suggesting temporal stability our finding support the hypothesis that sexual concordance is a relatively stable individual difference and that change in sexual concordance after treatment or experimental condition could therefore be attributed to effect of those condition

Title: Transfer Effects to a Multimodal Dual-Task after Working Memory Training and Associated Neural Correlates in Older Adults - A Pilot Study
Authors: Heinzel, S.; Rimpel, J.; Stelzel, C.; Rapp, M. A.
Abstract: working memory wm performance decline with age however several study have shown that wm training may lead to performance increase not only in the trained task but also in untrained cognitive transfer task it ha been suggested that transfer effect occur if training task and transfer task share specific processing component that are supposedly processed in the same brain area in the current study we investigated whether single task wm training and training related alteration in neural activity might support performance in a dual task setting thus assessing transfer effect to higher order control process in the context of dual task coordination a sample of older adult age 60 72 wa assigned to either a training or control group the training group participated in 12 session of an adaptive n back training at pre and post measurement a multimodal dual task wa performed in all participant to a transfer effect this task consisted of two simultaneous delayed match to sample wm task using two different stimulus modality visual and auditory that were performed either in isolation single task or in conjunction dual task a subgroup also participated in functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri during the performance of the n back task before and after training while no transfer to single task performance wa found dual task cost in both the visual modality p 0 05 and the auditory modality p 0 05 decreased at post measurement in the training but not in the control group in the fmri subgroup of the training participant neural activity change in left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex dlpfc during one back predicted post training auditory dual task cost while neural activity change in right dlpfc during three back predicted visual dual task cost result might indicate an improvement in central executive processing that could facilitate both wm and dual task coordination

Title: The role of violence perpetration in driving externalizing problems and offending behavior among youth from eastern Democratic Republic of Congo
Authors: Dumke, L.; Haer, R.; Zawadka, A.; Salmen, C.; Hecker, T.
Abstract: youth in conflict affected region are exposed to a multitude of traumatic event these individual often witness violence experience it firsthand and in some case become perpetrator the interplay of event shape systematic trauma history that may have unique implication for youth mental health in a cross sectional study conducted in eastern democratic republic of congo drc we interviewed 295 war affected youth 63 4 boy m age 16 70 year including former child soldier n 171 regarding their traumatic experience and mental health using latent class analysis we identified four common trauma history class categorized by a low exposure b medium exposure c high exposure and d high exposure perpetration across the sample gradual increase in trauma load corresponded with increased vulnerability to posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd symptom eta p 2 36 and internalizing problem eta p 2 12 however only youth from the high exposure perpetration class differed significantly from other youth in their level of externalizing problem eta p 2 13 and offending behavior eta p 2 17 a longer time in armed group wa related to a higher risk of both experiencing and perpetrating violence the result indicate that it is not child soldier status per se but the perpetration of violence that reinforces a cycle of violence in conflict affected society by contributing to increased externalizing problem and offending behavior in conflict region integrated approach are needed to address both trauma and externalizing problem of war affected youth

Title: Gait Patterns and Mood in Everyday Life: A Comparison Between Depressed Patients and Non-depressed Controls
Authors: Adolph, Dirk; Tschacher, Wolfgang; Niemeyer, Helen; Michalak, Johannes
Abstract: abstract background previous laboratory finding suggest deviant gait characteristic in depressed individual i e reduced walking speed and vertical up and down movement larger lateral swaying movement slumped posture however since most study to date assessed gait in the laboratory it is largely an open question whether this association also hold in more naturalistic everyday life setting thus within the current study we 1 aimed at replicating these result in an everyday life and 2 investigated whether gait characteristic could predict change in current mood method we recruited a sample of patient n 35 suffering from major depressive disorder and a sample of age and gender matched non depressed control n 36 during a 2 day assessment we continuously recorded gait pattern general movement intensity and repetitively assessed the participant s current mood result we replicated previous laboratory result and found that patient a compared to non depressed control showed reduced walking speed and reduced vertical up and down movement a well a a slumped posture during everyday life episode of walking moreover independent of clinical diagnosis higher walking speed and more vertical up and down movement significantly predicted more subsequent positive mood while change in mood did not predict subsequent change in gait pattern conclusion in sum our result support expectation that embodiment i e the relationship between bodily expression of emotion and emotion processing itself in depression is also observable in naturalistic setting and that depression is bodily manifested in the way people walk the data further suggest that motor display affect mood in everyday life

Title: 856 – Early detection of depression in children and adolescents: the new children's depression screener (child-s) and the depression screener for teenagers (desteen)
Authors: Allgaier, A.-K.; Dolle, K.; Pietsch, K.; Frühe, B.; Saravo, B.; Schulte-Körne, G.
Abstract: introduction depression in child and adolescent is still underdiagnosed valid and brief screening tool for these age group are missing objective for child and adolescent in particular we developed the screening tool child s and desteen and assessed their validity a opposed to established instrument method both screener were validated in a paediatric 228 child 316 adolescent and a clinical sample 77 child 87 adolescent gold standard for validation were icd 10 diagnosis of a depressive episode or dysthymia based on a structured interview using receiver operating characteristic analysis the area under the curve auc and the cut offs with the highest sum of sensitivity and specificity were computed in addition it wa examined whether the instrument differed significantly in validity measure result point prevalence were 5 3 child and 9 8 adolescent in paediatric care and 23 5 and 26 1 in clinical care the 8 item child s yielded auc of 98 and 93 in the paediatric and in the clinical sample sensitivity were 100 and 94 with specificity of 87 and 78 the abbreviated 6 item desteen showed an auc of 95 in both setting sensitivity were 100 and 91 in the paediatric and in the clinical sample specificity were 82 and 89 being even shorter the two screening tool performed equally well or better than the established instrument conclusion the child s and the desteen discriminate well between depression and depression like symptom in somatic disease a well a between depression and other form of mental disorder valid and brief they can both be recommended for usage in paediatric and clinical setting

Title: 1648 – What do adolescents know about depression? Efficacy and utility of an information booklet
Authors: Allgaier, A.-K.; Schiller, Y.; Eberle-Sejari, R.; Schulte-Körne, G.
Abstract: adolescent still lack knowledge about depression and it treatment a a result depressed adolescent are confronted with stigma that are barrier to treatment seeking study in adult demonstrated that depression literacy can be increased by educational material we developed an information booklet on depression specifically addressing adolescent aged 13 to 17 for the first time it wa examined whether knowledge about depression in youth can be enhanced by reading an educational leaflet the information booklet wa evaluated in 628 german ninth grader m 15 1 year 58 boy in a pre postfollow up design using study specific questionnaire knowledge about seven topic on depression wa assessed key subject were symptom and treatment of depression a well a suicidality in addition student evaluated the booklet s layout content and utility power analysis of the pre post follow up comparison yielded effect size of knowledge enhancement between eta 2 0 07 medium and 0 56 large for all topic of the booklet the largest effect size were found for the topic symptom and antidepressant sub analysis on school type and gender showed the highest increase in knowledge in well educated student and in girl the participating youth assessed the booklet positively regarding all category with a mean overallrating of 2 15 on a scale from 1 very good to 6 fail although student baseline knowledge about depression wa good girl and boy of all school type significantly increased depression literacy thus the booklet can help reducing stigma and treatment barrier in adolescent

Title: Social Comparison, Envy, and Depression on Facebook: A Study Looking at the Effects of High Comparison Standards on Depressed Individuals
Authors: Appel, Helmut; Crusius, Jan; Gerlach, Alexander L.
Abstract: the co occurrence of depression and envy is both plausible and empirically established however little is known about the mechanism underlying this correlation an account is proposed according to which low self esteem in depressed individual lead to upward social comparison and thus make envy more likely this effect should frequently occur in online social network like facebook because they allow for easy impression management and hence provide high comparison standard in a quasi experimental online study depressed and nondepressed participant indicated their self esteem and were then presented with specifically set up facebook profile that were either attractive or unattractive participant were asked to compare themselves to the profile owner and to report their resulting feeling of inferiority and envy depressed participant were more envious especially after seeing the attractive profile envy wa associated with higher self reported inferiority and also correlated negatively with self esteem the connection between depression and envy is demonstrated with an experimental elicitation of envy for the first time the result strongly suggest that low self esteem and consequent feeling of inferiority play a crucial role in depressed individual elevated level of envy practical implication and limitation are discussed
Journal: Journal of Social and Clinical Psychology

Title: Ethnic Variation in Emotion Regulation
Authors: Arens, Elisabeth A.; Balkir, Nazli; Barnow, Sven
Abstract: emotion regulation er via cognitive reappraisal ha been shown to be superior to the use of expressive suppression regarding several aspect of mental well being however a cultural perspective suggests that the consequence of emotional suppression may be moderated by cultural value in order to examine whether this also applies to clinical sample we investigated healthy and depressed german woman and healthy and depressed turkish immigrant living in germany group were compared in term of frequency of er strategy cognitive reappraisal and expressive suppression and with which different aspect of mental well being the same are associated healthy turkish immigrant exhibited a greater er balance frequent use of suppression plus frequent use of reappraisal which wa associated with more positive outcome of expressive suppression in turkish than in german woman none of these difference were found in patient sample both of which showed a greater use of emotional suppression than cognitive reappraisal result suggest that the cultural moderation of the link between emotional suppression and well being is associated with a greater er balance in healthy turkish individual depressed turkish patient may not profit from suppression due to their more rigid use of it

Title: Are Acute Increases and Variability in Emotion Regulation Strategies Related to Negative Affect and Paranoid Thoughts in Daily Life?
Authors: Bahlinger, Katrin; Lincoln, Tania M.; Clamor, Annika
Abstract: abstract background negative affect reliably predicts paranoid thought previous study point to the importance of emotion regulation for paranoid thought but have not yet focused on effect of acute increase and variability in strategy use method we conducted an experience sampling study for one week in a subclinical sample acute increase in the intensity of strategy use from one measurement point until the next between strategy variability i e standard deviation between all strategy at one measurement point and within strategy variability i e standard deviation of each strategy over one day were analyzed for effect on negative affect and paranoid thought result multi level model indicated that acute increase in acceptance and reappraisal are associated with le negative affect acute increase in acceptance but not in reappraisal were related to le paranoid thought in contrast acute increase in rumination and suppression were associated with more negative affect and paranoid thought between and within strategy variability were no significant predictor conclusion acute increase in the intensity of but not variability in emotion regulation strategy are related to negative affect and paranoid thought in daily life future study are needed to examine whether improving emotion regulation lead to sustainable reduction in symptom

Title: Worry behaviour in generalised anxiety disorder
Authors: Beesdo-Baum, K.; Voss, C.; Venz, J.; Poppenhäger, S.; Berwanger, J.; Pieper, L.
Abstract: abuse of widely available over the counter otc drug and supplement such a diet pill laxative and diuretic by adolescent for weight control is well documented yet manufacturer and retailer can sell them to minor without restriction the aim of our study wa to estimate the effect of added taxation of otc drug and dietary supplement sold for weight loss on household purchase of these product with data from 60 538 u s household in the 2012 wave of the nielsen iri national consumer panel ncp and the nielsen iri retail scanner nrs datasets we conducted analysis in 2017 to tally annual quantity and expenditure on otc drug or dietary supplement making weight loss cleanse detox or diuretic claim we estimated the percent reduction in household purchase due to a simulated 20 added tax on each category among the 14 151 household reporting at least one purchase in the three claim category a 20 higher average price of weight loss product wa associated with a 5 2 lower purchase of those product among household with child age 12 to 17 year old present purchase were 17 5 lower and among household with a daughter present purchase were 10 3 lower taxation may be an effective public health strategy to reduce purchasing of potentially dangerous otc drug and supplement sold for weight loss especially for household that include child age 12 17 year old or a daughter

Title: Stay-at-home orders due to the COVID-19 pandemic are associated with elevated depression and anxiety in younger, but not older adults: results from a nationwide community sample of adults from Germany
Authors: Benke, Christoph; Autenrieth, Lara K.; Asselmann, Eva; Pané-Farré, Christiane A.
Abstract: stay at home order due to the covid 19 pandemic are associated with elevated depression and anxiety in younger but not older adult result from a nationwide community sample of adult from germany volume 52 issue 15

Title: Early cortical processing of vection-inducing visual stimulation as measured by event-related brain potentials (ERP)
Authors: Berti, Stefan; Haycock, Bruce; Adler, Julia; Keshavarz, Behrang
Abstract: abstract visual motion stimulus can induce the perception of self motion in stationary observer known a vection in the present study we investigated the sensory processing underlying vection by measuring the human event related brain potential erps elicited by the movement onset of a visual stimulus we presented participant a visual stimulus consisting of alternating black and white vertical bar that moved in horizontal direction creating the sensation of vection the stimulus wa presented on a screen that wa divided into a central and a surrounding peripheral visual area both area moved independently from each other resulting in four different movement pattern the peripheral and the central stimulus moved in the same or opposite direction or one of the two visual area of the stimulus moved while the other remained stable in addition two different stimulus type varying with respect to the bar width narrow v wide were used participant were presented with these stimulus in two phase of the experiment during eeg recording only short phase 2 5 3 5 m of visual motion were applied in a separate rating phase visual motion wa presented for 45 s in this phase vection onset intensity and duration were verbally recorded overall the visual stimulation generated vection with different intensity i e weakest vection with sole central stimulus movement stimulus type did not affect vection in the erps stimulus onset elicited parieto occipital p2 and n2 component the amplitude of the erp component differed significantly between the four movement pattern irrespective of stimulus type however they did not fully align with the subjective vection rating since the erps are associated with early sensory processing preceding vection we argue that the erps mirror the contribution of sensory cortical process to vection rather than the subjective sensation of vection per se

Title: Neural correlates of emotional action control in anger-prone women with borderline personality disorder
Authors: Bertsch, Katja; Roelofs, Karin; Roch, Paul Jonathan; Ma, Bo; Hensel, Saskia; Herpertz, Sabine C.; Volman, Inge
Abstract: difficulty in controlling emotional impulse is a crucial component of borderline personality disorder bpd that often lead to destructive impulsive behaviour against others in line with recent finding in aggressive individual deficit in prefrontal amygdala coupling during emotional action control may account for these symptom to study the neurobiological correlate of altered emotional action control in individual with bpd we asked medication free anger prone female patient with bpd and age and intelligence matched healthy woman to take part in an approach avoidance task while lying in an mri scanner the task required controlling fast behavioural tendency to approach happy and avoid angry face additionally before the task we collected saliva testosterone and self reported information on tendency to act out anger and correlated this with behavioural and functional mri fmri data we included 30 patient and 28 control in our analysis patient with bpd reported increased tendency to act out anger and were faster in approaching than avoiding angry face than with healthy woman suggesting deficit in emotional action control in woman with bpd on a neural level controlling fast emotional action tendency wa associated with enhanced activation in the antero and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex across group healthy woman showed a negative coupling between the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and right amygdala whereas this wa absent in patient with bpd specificity of result to bpd and sex difference remain unknown owing to the lack of clinical control group and male participant the result indicate reduced lateral prefrontal amygdala communication during emotional action control in anger prone woman with bpd the finding provide a possible neural mechanism underlying difficulty with controlling emotional impulse in patient with bpd

Title: The relationship between self-traumatized and self-vulnerable automatic associations and posttraumatic stress symptoms among adults who have experienced a distressing life event
Authors: Blackwell, Simon E.; Ehring, Thomas; Gladwin, Thomas E.; Margraf, Jürgen; Woud, Marcella L.
Abstract: abstract convergent evidence support a crucial role for dysfunctional appraisal in the development and maintenance of post traumatic stress disorder ptsd however most research in this area ha used self report measure assessing only explicit form of such negative cognition the relevance of their more automatically activated counterpart a assumed by cognitive model remains relatively unexplored the current study aimed to further our understanding of the potential utility of measuring automatic dysfunctional association in the context of posttraumatic stress the relationship between score on two different implicit association test iats and posttraumatic stress symptom wa investigated in a sample of adult n 279 who reported having experienced a potentially traumatic negative life event participant completed the two iats one assessing self traumatized association the other self vulnerable association a self report measure of dysfunctional appraisal and measure of posttraumatic stress symptom and other aspect of psychopathology online score indicating higher level of dysfunctional association on both iats were associated with higher level of posttraumatic stress symptom only score on the iat measuring self vulnerable association and not the iat measuring self traumatized association continued to show an association with posttraumatic stress symptom after controlling for explicit dysfunctional appraisal overall the result indicate the value of investigating ptsd relevant automatic association to further develop our understanding of cognitive process implicated in posttraumatic stress

Title: Online-Intervention für Partner und Partnerinnen (PartnerCARE)
Authors: Bodschwinna, Daniela; Baumeister, Harald; Hönig, Klaus
Abstract: backgroundpartners of people with cancer are supporter and affected person at the same time existing psychosocial service e g face to face therapy are often not used due to time and logistical constraint the newly developed online intervention partnercare offer a low threshold service for flexible use the intervention includes psychoeducational behavioral and imaginative content and consists of 6 main session a booster session and 4 optional additional session participant are guided by an e coach through feedback partnercare aim to reduce psychosocial stress and increase quality of life methodsthe partnercare online intervention which wa compared with a wait list control group in a two arm parallel randomized controlled feasibility trial is reported online survey of participant were conducted at three time point baseline posttreatment and follow up resultsthe partnercare online intervention demonstrated good feasibility and high acceptance in addition initial potential evidence of partnercare s effectiveness wa demonstrated conclusionpartnercare is the first german language online psycho oncological intervention developed and evaluated specifically for partner of people with cancer with the help of the result of the feasibility study the partnercare online intervention will be optimized and then tested in a large scale randomized controlled trial

Title: Cross-cultural narcissism on Facebook: Relationship between self-presentation, social interaction and the open and covert narcissism on a social networking site in Germany and Russia
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Bierhoff, Hans-Werner
Abstract: the social platform facebook ha more than one billion member in different country cross culturally the way user behave on this platform relates to some personality trait the aim of the present study wa to investigate whether russian and german facebook user differ in the extent of open and covert narcissism self presentation and social interaction on facebook furthermore we investigated whether there is a comparable relationship between narcissism and facebook use in these country to this end the data of 72 russian platform member were collected and compared with the data of 122 german member the narcissism value did not significantly differ between the two sample this wa also the case with the overall self presentation and interaction in contrast some single measure of online behaviour differ for example german user set more like and had more online friend than russian user russian platform member used more application than german user in each group a positive association between the two form of narcissism and online activity wa found so far the positive relation between narcissism and self presentation and social interaction on facebook seem to be universal in western and eastern country cross culturally narcissism is positively related to online activity on facebook in russia and germany narcissism value do not differ significantly the general level of self presentation and interaction on facebook is also similar german user set more like and have more online friend than russian user russian member use more application on facebook than german member

Title: Loneliness and depression symptoms: The moderating role of narcissism
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Bierhoff, Hans-Werner; Rohmann, Elke
Abstract: the current study investigated the association between loneliness and depression symptom a well a vulnerable and grandiose narcissism an online survey wa conducted obtaining a sample of 701 german speaking participant age m sd 24 17 5 64 range 18 58 a positive association between loneliness and the occurrence of depression symptom wa revealed furthermore the link between loneliness and depression symptom wa moderated by both grandiose and vulnerable narcissism the sample consisted of a majority of university student limiting the generalizability of the finding in addition self report were used without obtaining experimental evidence narcissism is identified a a moderator of the relationship between loneliness and depression symptom more specifically both high grandiose narcissism and high vulnerable narcissism enhance the association between loneliness and depression symptom

Title: Work Overload and Addictive Social Media Use: A Relationship with Depression Symptoms and Life Satisfaction
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Frahsek, Marc; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: abstract work overload is highly related to mental health issue online social medium are often used to escape the feeling of overload in the current study 291 employee from various job sector completed an online survey related to work overload addictive social medium use smu and mental health i e depression symptom life satisfaction work overload wa significantly positively associated with addictive smu r 0 209 p lt 0 001 and depression symptom r 0 190 p lt 0 001 the relationship between work overload and life satisfaction wa significantly negative r 0 175 p lt 0 001 moreover addictive smu significantly mediated the association between work overload and depression symptom total effect p 0 002 direct effect p 0 052 and the association between work overload and life satisfaction total effect p 0 006 direct effect p 0 064 the present result reveals that high work overload could foster addictive smu that could impact employee mental health therefore the attention of employee and employer should be attracted to the potential negative consequence of intensive smu the integration of measure such a a temporary social medium detox and enhanced physical activity in the policy of various organization could be an important step to protect employee mental health and to maintain their productivity
Journal: Journal of Technology in Behavioral Science

Title: I present myself and have a lot of Facebook-friends – Am I a happy narcissist!?
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: abstract for many people facebook use ha become part of daily life earlier research hypothesized that one reason for the high popularity of this social platform is it association with subjective well being and specific personality trait in the present study self report data and objective data from facebook page of 328 facebook user were analyzed result revealed a significant positive association of active facebook use with subjective happiness and narcissism it relationship with depression symptom wa significantly negative furthermore active facebook use significantly positively mediated the positive link between narcissism and happiness this finding contributes to the understanding why narcissistic individual who usually search for attention and admiration to increase their self esteem often engage in intensive active facebook use

Title: The relationship between active and passive Facebook use, Facebook flow, depression symptoms and Facebook Addiction: A three-month investigation
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: active facebook use is positively linked to facebook addiction fa there is no significant link between passive facebook use and fa active facebook use contributes to the experience of facebook related flow in the longer term facebook flow serf a an antecedent of fa particularly individual with enhanced depression symptom are at risk for fa the present study investigated the link of active and passive facebook use facebook flow and depression symptom with facebook addiction fa data of 127 german facebook user m age sd age 25 10 7 03 range 18 58 were assessed at two measurement time point over a period of three month first measurement t1 second measurement t2 via online survey fa t2 wa significantly positively linked to active facebook use t1 facebook flow t1 and depression symptom t1 it relationship with passive facebook use t1 wa non significant facebook flow t1 positively mediated the association between active facebook use t1 and fa t2 in contrast active facebook use t1 did not serve a a mediator between facebook flow t1 and fa t2 given the non experimental design of the present study only hypothetical conclusion on causality can be drawn current result demonstrate that active facebook use could contribute to the experience of flow that serf a an antecedent of fa this is particularly relevant for individual with enhanced depression symptom the finding should be made a subject of discussion in education and prevention program and in therapeutic context

Title: Social Media as Source of Information, Stress Symptoms, and Burden Caused by Coronavirus (COVID-19)
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Margraf, Jürgen; Schneider, Silvia
Abstract: abstract this cross national study investigated the extent of social medium use smu a a source of information about covid 19 and it relationship with the experienced burden caused by the pandemic representative data from eight country france germany poland russia spain sweden the uk the usa were collected online end of may to the beginning of june 2020 of the overall 8 302 participant 48 1 frequently used social medium sm a a covid 19 information source range 31 8 in germany to 65 4 in poland in the overall sample and in all country specific sample regression analysis revealed the experienced burden caused by covid 19 to be positively associated with smu and stress symptom furthermore stress symptom partly mediated the relationship between smu and the burden the result emphasize the significant association between the use of sm a a source of information individual emotional state and behavior during the pandemic a well a the significance of conscious and accurate use of sm specifically during the covid 19 outbreak

Title: A two-week gaming abstinence reduces Internet Gaming Disorder and improves mental health: An experimental longitudinal intervention study
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Meier-Faust, Julius; Schillack, Holger; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: since the covid 19 outbreak digital gaming ha become a welcome pastime and distraction for many people however this phenomenon can have severe consequence intensive digital gaming can foster the internet gaming disorder igd and negatively affect mental health the present experimental longitudinal study investigated the consequence of a conscious abstinence from gaming in a german sample the experimental group n 131 age m 26 21 sd 7 70 did not engage in gaming for two week the control group n 140 age m 25 10 sd 4 94 maintained it gaming time and habit gaming related variable and mental health related variable were assessed via online survey at five measurement time point baseline intermediate status post intervention one month follow up three month follow up the intervention significantly reduced gaming time gaming flow igd daily stress and anxiety symptom moreover we found a significant improvement in positive mental health the effect were stable over the three month of the investigation thus we could show that a conscious and controlled short term abstinence from gaming lead to reduced igd and a better mental health the present result emphasize that conscious period of gaming abstinence could be an effective step in the clinical context and in mental health prevention program especially during a pandemic such a the covid 19 outbreak two week gaming abstinence reduces gaming time and gaming flow longitudinally two week gaming abstinence reduces the level of internet gaming disorder igd two week gaming abstinence reduces the experience of daily stress and anxiety symptom two week gaming abstinence increase positive mental health temporary gaming abstinence can protect mental health during the covid 19 outbreak

Title: How to prevent side effects of social media use (SMU)? Relationship between daily stress, online social support, physical activity and addictive tendencies – A longitudinal approach before and during the first Covid-19 lockdown in Germany
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Ozimek, Phillip; Bierhoff, Hans-Werner
Abstract: daily stress positively predicts addictive social medium use smu three month later during covid 19 lockdown online social support mediates the link between daily stress and addictive smu physical activity moderate the link between online social support and addictive smu physical activity before covid 19 outbreak can contribute to le addictive smu during the pandemic people who experience high level of daily stress often resort to intensive social medium use smu in the short term this can contribute to relief and positive emotion however in the longer term intensive online activity can foster addictive tendency the present longitudinal study investigated the association between daily stress and addictive smu data were assessed in a sample of 211 social medium user m age sd age 22 50 5 00 from germany via online survey at two measurement time point in winter 2020 baseline bl and three month later in spring 2020 during the first covid 19 lockdown follow up fu in moderated mediation analysis the positive relationship between daily stress bl and addictive smu bl and fu wa significantly mediated by the level of perceived online social support bl physical activity bl e g jogging and cycling significantly moderated the relationship between online social support bl and addictive smu bl and fu specifically the association between both variable wa significant for medium and low frequency of physical activity but not for high frequency the mostly female and relatively young sample composition limit the generalizability of the present finding no experimental manipulation of the potential predictor of addictive smu wa introduced limiting the causal interpretation of the current result the current finding disclose mechanism that could reduce the risk of addictive smu specifically a conscious increase of physical activity could prevent the transformation of positive emotion evoked by the perception of online social support into addictive tendency

Title: Less Facebook use – More well-being and a healthier lifestyle? An experimental intervention study
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Ströse, Fabienne; Schillack, Holger; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: use of the social platform facebook belongs to daily life but may impair subjective well being the present experimental study investigated the potential beneficial impact of reduction of daily facebook use participant were facebook user from germany while the experimental group n 140 mage sdage 24 15 5 06 reduced it facebook use for 20 min daily for two week the control group n 146 mage sdage 25 39 6 69 used facebook a usual variable of facebook use life satisfaction depressive symptom physical activity and smoking behavior were assessed via online survey at five measurement time point pre measurement day 0 t1 between measurement day 7 t2 post measurement day 15 t3 follow up 1 one month after post measurement t4 follow up 2 three month after post measurement t5 the intervention reduced active and passive facebook use facebook use intensity and the level of facebook addiction disorder life satisfaction significantly increased and depressive symptom significantly decreased moreover frequency of physical activity such a jogging or cycling significantly increased and number of daily smoked cigarette decreased effect remained stable during follow up three month thus le time spent on facebook lead to more well being and a healthier lifestyle

Title: Suicidal ideation, suicide attempts and positive mental health in Chinese medical students
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Teismann, Tobias; Lewitzka, Ute; Gao, Zhihua; Zhang, Xiao Chi; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: twelve month suicidal ideation is about 10 11 5 in chinese university student medical student have lower depression symptom than student of other discipline medical student have higher positive mental health pmh than other student over 84 of student report complete mental health high pmh low psychopathology student worldwide are at marked risk of suicidal ideation behavior depression and low positive mental health pmh medical student are suspected to be a particularly burdened group on this background the aim of the present study wa to determine prevalence rate of suicidal ideation behavior depression and pmh among chinese medical student compared to student from other discipline a total of 2 695 chinese student 41 2 woman age m 18 86 sd 60 range 18 21 including 461 medical student filled out self report measure on suicidal ideation behavior depression and pmh twelve month suicidal ideation wa reported by 10 2 of the medical student and by 11 5 of the other student medical student had significantly lower level of depression symptom and significantly higher level of pmh than student from other discipline complete mental health according to the dual factor model of mental health wa reported by more than 84 of the total sample data were assessed by a self report survey that is prone to social desirability student in the present study displayed high rate of complete mental health although the survey wa conducted in the midst of the corona pandemic no evidence wa found that medical student are particularly stressed

Title: Physical activity mediates the association between daily stress and Facebook Addiction Disorder (FAD) – A longitudinal approach among German students
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Teismann, Tobias; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: abstract physical activity ha regularly been demonstrated to be a protective factor against stressful experience the present study investigated whether physical activity buffer the association between daily stress and facebook addiction disorder fad over a period of one year first measurement time point t1 october 2016 second measurement time point t2 october 2017 in a sample of 122 german facebook user 82 8 woman age at t1 m 21 70 sd 3 67 range 17 38 physical activity at t1 mediated the significant positive relationship between chronic daily stress at t1 and fad at t2 total effect p 036 direct effect p 164 furthermore at t2 fad wa significantly negatively associated with positive mental health i e high level of emotional social and psychological well being the current study provides first longitudinal result of possible risk associated with and potential protective factor of fad these result demonstrated that this addictive behavior is positively related to chronic daily stress and negatively related to physical activity practical application for future study and limitation of the present result are discussed
