Title: Positive mental health mediates the relationship between physical activity and suicide-related outcomes: a three-year follow-up study
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Teismann, Tobias; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: abstract suicide belongs to the leading cause of death worldwide the present longitudinal study investigated physical activity for example jogging cycling and positive mental health pmh a potential factor that can reduce the risk of suicide ideation and suicidal behavior data of 223 participant 79 4 woman m age sd age 22 85 4 05 were assessed at two measurement time point over a three year period 2016 first measurement baseline bl 2019 second measurement follow up fu via online survey the result reveal a significant positive relationship between higher physical activity bl and higher pmh bl higher score of both variable were significantly negatively linked to lower suicide related outcome fu moreover the association between higher physical activity bl and lower suicide related outcome fu wa significantly mediated by higher pmh bl the current finding demonstrate that physical activity in combination with pmh can reduce the risk of suicide related outcome fostering physical activity and pmh may be relevant strategy in the prevention of suicide ideation and suicide behavior

Title: The patterns of problematic social media use (SMU) and their relationship with online flow, life satisfaction, depression, anxiety and stress symptoms in Lithuania and in Germany
Authors: Brailovskaia, Julia; Truskauskaite-Kuneviciene, Inga; Kazlauskas, Evaldas; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: abstract the present study investigated problematic social medium use smu in lithuania and in germany in two student sample lithuania n 1640 germany n 727 problematic smu flow experienced during smu life satisfaction depression anxiety and stress symptom were assessed by online survey latent class analysis resulted in a four group classification of participant due to their level of problematic smu characteristic low symptom low withdrawal high withdrawal and high symptom the proportion of participant in the low symptom group wa significantly higher in germany than in lithuania in contrast significantly more lithuanian participant belonged to both withdrawal group no significant country difference were found for the composition of the high symptom group in both country a series of structural equation model showed that the level of flow depression anxiety and stress symptom wa the highest in the high symptom group and the lowest in the low symptom group life satisfaction revealed the reversed result pattern the current finding show that student from lithuania and germany can be grouped considering their problematic smu level individual in the four group differ due to their level of mental health especially member of the high symptom group might benefit from external controlling strategy of their time spent on sm while member of the withdrawal group are suggested to train their smu self control

Title: The Differential Relationship Between Self-Reported Interoceptive Accuracy           and Attention With Psychopathology
Authors: Brand, Sebastian; Petzke, Tara M.; Witthöft, Michael
Abstract: abstract background only recently ha interoception been discussed a a common risk factor for psychopathology recent approach distinguish between the ability to accurately perceive interoceptive accuracy and the propensity to attend interoceptive attention to internal signal objective to examine the latent structure of self reported interoceptive accuracy and attention and their relationship to psychopathology method we used a confirmatory factor analysis to clarify the latent structure of interoceptive accuracy and attention structural equation modeling wa utilized to determine relationship between both ability with internalizing and somatoform symptomatology according to the hitop model kotov et al 2017 data from n 619 person from the german general population were analyzed result interoceptive attention showed significant positive relationship with all psychopathological trait r 221 to r 377 whereas interoceptive accuracy wa negatively associated with internalizing symptomatology r 106 conclusion the present finding indicate that personal belief about interoceptive ability have different influence on psychopathological development
Journal: Zeitschrift für Klinische Psychologie und Psychotherapie

Title: Ambivalence over emotional expression in major depression
Authors: Brockmeyer, Timo; Grosse Holtforth, Martin; Krieger, Tobias; Altenstein, David; Doerig, Nadja; Friederich, Hans-Christoph; Bents, Hinrich
Abstract: high ambivalence over the expression of emotion aee ha consistently been associated with high level of depression in previous research however there is a lack of study examining this construct and it association in a clinical sample of patient with major depressive disorder mdd therefore the present study compared 76 mdd with 77 non depressed control nc regarding aee a expected mdd reported greater aee a compared to nd furthermore level of aee and level of depression were positively correlated in the mdd group these finding extend previous work and underline the importance of aee a a central construct in depression targeting aee in treatment of depression may help to modify maladaptive interpersonal pattern of emotional expression

Title: Daily Stressful Experiences Precede But Do Not Succeed Depressive Symptoms: Results from a Longitudinal Experience Sampling Study
Authors: Brose, Annette; Wichers, Marieke; Kuppens, Peter
Abstract: this study investigates the proposition that micro level experience in the realm of stress e g daily stress exposure are among the building block of maladjustment in particular depression data were collected with experience sampling method and in the lab a sample of 202 student who had just entered university participated in a three wave longitudinal study october 2012 october 2013 each wave consisted of the assessment of depressive symptom and the examination of stressful experience in daily life by mean of experience sampling 70 occasion per wave cross lagged panel model revealed that the perceived intensity of daily stressor stressed and depressed feeling in daily life a well a depressed reaction to daily stressor predict an increase in future depressive symptom in young female but not male other cross lagged effect particularly from depressive symptom to stressful experience in daily life were not significant finding are in line with the stress exposure model
Journal: Journal of Social and Clinical Psychology

Title: Updates on the Prevalence of Body Dysmorphic Disorder: A Population-Based Survey
Authors: Buhlmann, Ulrike; Glaesmer, Heide; Mewes, Ricarda; Fama, Jeanne M.; Wilhelm, Sabine; Brähler, Elmar; Rief, Winfried
Abstract: body dysmorphic disorder bdd is characterised by a preoccupation with perceived defect in one s appearance which lead to significant distress and or impairment although several study have investigated the prevalence of bdd many study have methodological limitation e g small sample size and student population and study on the prevalence of bdd in the general population are limited in the current study 2510 individual participated in a representative german nationwide survey diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorder fourth edition dsm iv criterion for bdd and associated characteristic such a suicidality and the prevalence of plastic surgery were examined using self report questionnaire the prevalence of current bdd wa 1 8 n 45 further individual with bdd relative to individual without bdd reported significantly more often a history of cosmetic surgery 15 6 v 3 0 higher rate of suicidal ideation 31 0 v 3 5 and suicide attempt due to appe

Title: Emotions or attention – what are predictors for the development of childhood psychopathology? A longitudinal study with pre- and elementary school children
Authors: Christiansen, Hanna; Hirsch, Oliver; Beheshti, Ashkan; Chavanon, Mira-Lynn
Abstract: abstract current debate ha identified the factor emotion knowledge ek and attention a specific trajectory longitudinally influencing psychopathological development in childhood the emotion knowledge hypothesis assumes that child with great emotion skill have high self regulating ability that result in lower cognitive load and stronger attention capacity attention problem are thus perceived a a consequence of reduced ek according to the competing attention effect hypothesis attention problem and ek deficit are associated because of impaired learning capacity due to attention problem according to this hypothesis attention problem are predictive of impaired ek if those specific trajectory are disrupted this might attenuate the development of later behavior problem the present study test those competing hypothesis replicating previous study in this field to shed light on potential psychopathology trajectory a total of 136 pre and elementary school child a well a their teacher participated in this study child s symptom of inattention a well a their emotional competence were assessed 3 time over a 12 month period we applied multilevel structural equation modelling and cross lagged panel model for data analysis overall we noted a drop in inattention score and rise in emotional competence over the one year course indicating maturation effect there wa a significant but very small effect for attention score predicting emotional competence with respect to the question whether intervention should focus on the emotion knowledge or attention effect hypothesis our finding imply that none of them ha superiority over the other therefore both emotion knowledge and attention are crucial for development and that child with deficit in either domain should receive targeted intervention in order to disrupt potentially harmful developmental pathway

Title: Prevention of ADHD related problems: a universal preschool program
Authors: Christiansen, Hanna; Hirsch, Oliver; König, Anika; Steinmayr, Ricarda; Roehrle, Bernd
Abstract: purpose early onset of behavioral disorder is predictive of long term adverse outcome there are some indicated and selective early prevention program for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd one of the most common behavioral disorder in childhood and adolescence the purpose of this paper is to present a universal preschool program for preventing the development of adhd related symptom for child aged three to six design methodology approach a total of 413 preschool child experimental group eg 193 control group cg 220 and their teacher participated in the study child in the eg were randomized to two condition universal intervention behavior modification bm 99 v additional adhd specific element bm attention training bm at 94 to evaluate effect of a universal intervention v additional adhd specific element the universal intervention trained general behavior modification bm technique to enhance start behavior i e following color based rule positive participation in activity enhancement of skill related to attentional function and to extinguish stop behavior i e hyperactive behavior such a uncontrolled running around disturbing others quarreling etc these technique were based on published intervention program phelan and schonour 2004 the at consisted of thirteen teacher led 45 minute based session in a small group format with an introductory play activity 15 minute picture based at task task analysis action planning action reappraisal a social interaction game and a game to enhance perception of visual auditory olfactory haptic and gustatory sen to determine effect the strength and difficulty questionnaire sdq and the behavior rating for preschooler vbv were used a high risk group with high score on those measure wa analyzed separately finding child in all three group did not differ significantly at baseline in all relevant variable adhd symptom measured with the sdq and vbv socio economic status s gender age mancova f 10 796 1 732 p 0 07 and none of the child had a diagnosis of adhd after training participation child in the eg showed significantly le adhd related problem behavior compared to child in the cg f 8 1 506 2 717 p 0 006 this wa especially so for the high risk group f 4 754 2 60 p 0 035 multi level analysis revealed significant influence of age gender and s on post training symptom rating sdq t statistic 3 03 p 0 003 vbv 3 6 t statistic 4 151 p lt 0 001 research limitation implication this is a quasi experimental study since due to time restriction half the preschool did not want to participate in the experimental study thus participating child were not randomly assigned to the experimental and control condition though child were randomly assigned to two different treatment within the intervention group eg1 eg2 due to the design of the study and to ensure high participation rate only preschool teacher rated child s behavior though the predictive value of teacher adhd symptom exceeds parental one finally inclusion of parent training element would most probably enhance effect practical implication general bm technique are easily taught and seem to positively influence child s adhd related symptom while not harming child without such symptom since study showed that after a bogus instruction teacher expected child to exhibit adhd symptom and rated them a more disturbed rosenthal effect a universal approach is le stigmatizing and possibly more effective especially when intervention start early in life before symptom result in full diagnosis social implication this study established positive universal effect and moderate to large effect for the subgroup of high risk child with adhd related symptom general behavior management in preschool might thus be a possible strategy for preventive intervention of adhd related symptom originality value the is one of the first study on a preventive adhd preschool program general bm technique of this study were easily taught and implemented and showed positive effect since selective and indicated intervention depend on high program fidelity are harder to implement and related to higher cost general bm technique a introduced in this study might be an option for universal prevention strategy for adhd related symptom in preschool setting

Title: Paranoid Delusions as an Adaptive Response to Social Evaluative Stress?
Authors: Clamor, Annika; Krkovic, Katarina
Abstract: abstract learning mechanism may serve a a framework for understanding the formation of paranoia specifically if paranoid thought after social stressor produce a short term benefit for coping e g downregulating arousal the encountered negative reinforcement could lead to their excessive application and subsequently to long term maladaptive conviction the trier social stress test wa utilized in healthy participant to examine this putative benefit participant rated paranoia at baseline and after the stressor subjective stress level negative affect heart rate and heart rate variability were assessed in the following rest phase n 59 semipartial correlation showed that participant who responded with larger increase in paranoia were characterized by a lower heart rate in the subsequent rest phase no association were found with heart rate variability or psychological measure thus paranoid thinking in healthy individual could be an adaptive mean for reestablishing some aspect of physiological homeostasis after a social stressor but further research is needed

Title: Attentional biases of vigilance and maintenance in obsessive-compulsive disorder: An eye-tracking study
Authors: Cludius, Barbara; Wenzlaff, Frederike; Briken, Peer; Wittekind, Charlotte E.
Abstract: attentional bias play an important role in the development and maintenance of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd previous study using reaction time task in ocd have produced inconsistent result this is the first study to measure attentional bias in patient with several subtypes of ocd using eye tracking twenty eight patient with ocd and 21 healthy control were assessed using a free viewing paradigm incorporating contamination related checking related and neutral stimulus attentional pattern were measured using an eye tracker a possible vigilance bias wa assessed using entry time and a possible maintenance bias wa assessed using dwell time patient with checking related symptom of ocd showed a maintenance bias but no vigilance bias in regard to checking related compared to neutral stimulus no difference in attention were found in patient with contamination related symptom internal validity is restricted due to a high overlap between subgroup the lack of negative not ocd related control stimulus and the absence of a clinical control group patient with checking related symptom of ocd showed a maintenance bias to checking related stimulus due to methodological limitation the result should be considered preliminary and need to be replicated before firm conclusion can be drawn
Journal: Journal of Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders

Title: Psychodynamic Psychotherapy with Severely Disturbed Adolescents: Changes in Reflective Functioning
Authors: Cropp, Carola; Taubner, Svenja; Salzer, Simone; Streeck-Fischer, Annette
Abstract: over the last few decade reflective functioning rf ha become an important construct for the understanding and treatment of several patient group while rf ha been well studied in adult sample
Journal: Journal of Infant, Child, and Adolescent Psychotherapy

Title: Interpretation Bias Across Body Dysmorphic, Social Anxiety and Generalized Anxiety Disorder—A Multilevel, Diffusion Model Account
Authors: Dietel, Fanny Alexandra; Möllmann, Anne; Bürkner, Paul-Christian; Wilhelm, Sabine; Buhlmann, Ulrike
Abstract: abstract background interpretation bias are suggested to be transdiagnostic phenomenon but have rarely been compared across different disorder and current concern method we investigated explicit decision based and more implicit reaction time based interpretation bias in individual with body dysmorphic disorder bdd n 29 social anxiety disorder sad n 36 generalized anxiety disorder gad n 22 and non clinical control nc n 32 using an adapted word sentence association paradigm wsap result result indicated that interpretation bias occurred transdiagnostically while content specific bias pattern varied meaningfully across group bdd and sad shared explicit and more inconsistently implicit interpretation bias for appearance related and social situation the gad group exhibited an explicit and implicit negative interpretation bias for general situation and an additional implicit lack of positive bias mechanistic wiener diffusion model analysis revealed that interpretation bias pattern were mainly driven by speeded information uptake potentially mirroring disorder specific associative memory organization conclusion these finding have important implication for understanding interpretation bias a both etiological and treatment factor

Title: Patterns of conflict-related trauma exposure and their relation to psychopathology: A person-centered analysis in a population-based sample from eastern DRC
Authors: Dumke, Lars; van der Haer, Roos; Koos, Carlo; Hecker, Tobias
Abstract: population in war torn region are exposed to a wide array of traumatic event that can cause an enormous psychological burden individual characteristic influence the likelihood of being exposed to certain event pointing to systematic interindividual difference in trauma exposure however there is a dearth of study examining potential pattern of trauma exposure in war region in this cross sectional epidemiological study we applied a person centered approach to identify pattern in the exposure to conflict related traumatic event and determine their impact on commonly reported mental health problem in a population based sample n 1000 from the eastern democratic republic of congo we implemented multi stage random cluster sampling to randomly select adult from 100 village of 1000 adult mage 43 19 year included in the study 50 were female result showed high prevalence of ptsd 17 0 depression 27 8 anxiety 25 4 and suicidality 15 1 following exposure to conflict related traumatic event since 2002 latent class analysis identified three distinct class of trauma exposure class 1 low trauma exposure 51 4 n 514 wa characterized by the lowest probability of trauma exposure class 2 non physical trauma 39 1 n 391 consisted of individual with a high probability for exposure to non physical trauma type only class 3 interpersonal trauma 9 5 n 95 had the overall highest probability of exposure to traumatic event and wa the only class affected by interpersonal trauma type class membership wa related to gender age and place of living vulnerability to mental health problem increased from low trauma exposure to non physical trauma to interpersonal trauma class our finding indicate that the exposure to traumatic event in conflict affected population underlies distinct pattern with interpersonal trauma a a distinguishing marker vulnerability to psychopathology varies with trauma pattern revealing pattern that include both non physical and interpersonal trauma a most detrimental for mental health identification of underlying trauma pattern and their effect may improve mental health care in war affected population

Title: Relations between perceived teacher’s autonomy support, cognitive appraisals and boredom in physics learning among lower secondary school students
Authors: Ekatushabe, Margaret; Kwarikunda, Diana; Muwonge, Charles M.; Ssenyonga, Joseph; Schiefele, Ulrich
Abstract: abstract background boredom during learning activity ha the potential of impeding attention motivation learning and eventually achievement yet research focusing on it possible antecedent seems to have received le attention especially within the physic domain based on assumption of the control value theory of achievement emotion cvtae this study aimed at examining gender difference and structural relationship between student reported perceived teacher autonomy support ptas cognitive appraisal self efficacy and task value and learning related boredom in physic a sample of 375 56 female randomly selected 9 th grade student mean age 15 03 year sd 1 02 from five secondary school in masaka district of uganda took part in the study result data collected from student self report using standardised instrument revealed that higher level of ptas self efficacy and task value were significantly associated with lower level of boredom during physic learning female reported significantly greater task value for learning physic than the male self efficacy β 10 p lt 05 and task value β 09 p lt 01 partially mediated the relationship between ptas and boredom ptas showed significant direct negative contribution to boredom β 34 p lt 001 conclusion these finding provide support for theory and practice about the importance of promoting autonomy among student by adjusting instructional behaviour among teacher of physic teacher autonomy supportive behaviour influence formation of student belief about ability subjective value and learning related boredom in physic implication and suggestion for further research are also discussed in this paper

Title: The Relationship Between Cognitive Activation, Self-Efficacy, Achievement Emotions and (Meta)cognitive Learning Strategies Among Ugandan Biology Learners
Authors: Ekatushabe, Margaret; Nsanganwimana, Florien; Muwonge, Charles M.; Ssenyonga, Joseph
Abstract: according to the control value theory of achievement emotion the influence of cognitive activation teaching strategy on student effective use of cognitive and meta cognitive cmc learning strategy is mediated by control appraisal e g self efficacy and achievement emotion i e enjoyment and boredom however there is limited and contrasting empirical evidence to support this assertion despite claim of cross cultural and domain consistency the present study wa aimed at examining the multiple mediational role of self efficacy and achievement emotion on the relationship between perceived cognitive activation during instruction and four cmc learning strategy among ugandan biology student data were collected using anonymous questionnaire from 587 50 6 female tenth grade student with a mean age of 17 year sd 1 16 from 10 secondary school in uganda we tested the mediation hypothesis in separate model with each cmc learning strategy indirect effect from cognitive activation through self efficacy and or enjoyment to cmc learning strategy were all significant confirming their mediational role there were significant p 0 001 direct effect from cognitive activation to self efficacy β 0 41 enjoyment β 0 26 and cognitive learning strategy i e rehearsal β 0 30 organisation β 0 30 and elaboration β 0 33 self efficacy and enjoyment fully mediated the relationship between cognitive activation and metacognition except for self efficacy direct effect to or from boredom were not significant clearly instructional strategy in biology that stimulate thought among learner are relevant for increasing effective use of any one of cmc learning strategy
Journal: African Journal of Research in Mathematics, Science and Technology Education

Title: Does Oxytocin Impact the Psychotherapeutic Process? An Explorative Investigation of Internet-Based Cognitive-Behavioral Treatment for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder
Authors: Engel, Sinha; Schumacher, Sarah; Niemeyer, Helen; Küster, Annika; Burchert, Sebastian; Rau, Heinrich; Willmund, Gerd-Dieter; Knaevelsrud, Christine
Abstract: lt b gt lt i gt background lt i gt lt b gt oxytocin might promote favorable psychotherapy outcome by strengthening the therapeutic alliance it involvement in psychotherapeutic process especially regarding the therapeutic alliance need further investigation lt b gt lt i gt patient and method lt i gt lt b gt blood oxytocin of 35 male german armed force service member who were seeking treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd wa analyzed before the onset of a 5 week internet based trauma focused psychotherapy we investigated whether oxytocin influenced patient rating of the therapeutic alliance component agreement on collaboration and emotional bond assessed during and after treatment we further explored oxytocin s impact on general change mechanism of psychotherapy and on psychotherapy expectation and evaluation lt b gt lt i gt result lt i gt lt b gt oxytocin had no significant impact on early agreement on collaboration which significantly predicted psychotherapy outcome early emotional bond wa not predicted by oxytocin and wa not predictive for psychotherapy outcome descriptive analysis showed that patient with higher pretreatment oxytocin concentration provided higher rating of general change mechanism of psychotherapy on a descriptive level the association between psychotherapy expectation and evaluation and oxytocin were mixed lt b gt lt i gt discussion and conclusion lt i gt lt b gt we found positive effect of higher pretreatment oxytocin concentration in ptsd patient this descriptive study is limited by it small sample size and need replication in larger independent sample however result indicate possible benefit of oxytocin on trauma focused psychotherapy

Title: Leadership climate prevents emotional exhaustion in German police officers
Authors: Engel, Sinha; Wörfel, Franziska; Maria, Andreas Santa; Wolter, Christine; Kleiber, Dieter; Renneberg, Babette
Abstract: police officer are exposed to a high amount of work effort in their everyday employment this increase their risk of developing emotional exhaustion the key symptom of the burnout syndrome previous research suggests that leadership climate is important for employee health and thus might be protective against emotional exhaustion this study investigated whether a positive leadership climate prevents emotional exhaustion and buffer the negative impact of work effort in police officer data from a cross sectional health survey in a german police department n 570 were used to test the assumption result of the hierarchical linear regression analysis showed that high work effort wa correlated with high level of emotional exhaustion and positive leadership climate wa associated with low level of emotional exhaustion furthermore both predictor variable interacted indicating a buffer effect of a positive leadership climate under stressful working condition this is the first study to show both direct and indirect protective effect of a positive leadership climate in police officer in police work stressful working condition such a high work effort are hard to avoid thus it is crucial to promote preventive factor such a a positive leadership climate to protect police officer health suggestion of how police supervisor and department might establish a positive leadership climate are presented
Journal: International Journal of Police Science & Management

Title: Social anxiety in adolescents and young adults from the general population: an epidemiological characterization of fear and avoidance in different social situations
Authors: Ernst, Julia; Ollmann, Theresa Magdalena; König, Elisa; Pieper, Lars; Voss, Catharina; Hoyer, Jana; Rückert, Frank; Knappe, Susanne; Beesdo-Baum, Katja
Abstract: abstract social anxiety disorder sad and more generally social fear are common in young people although avoidance behavior are known to be an important maintaining factor of social anxiety little is known about the severity and occurrence of avoidance behavior in young people from the general population hampering approach for early identification and intervention symptom syndrome and diagnosis of dsm 5 mental disorder including sad were assessed in a random population based sample of 14 21 year old n 1 180 from dresden germany in 2015 2016 using a standardized diagnostic interview dia x 5 d cidi an adapted version of the liebowitz social anxiety scale wa used to ascertain the extent of social fear and avoidance diagnostic criterion for lifetime sad were met by n 82 participant resulting in a weighted lifetime prevalence of 6 6 social anxiety wa predominantly reported for test situation and when speaking or performing in front of others avoidance wa most prevalent in the latter situation on average anxiety and avoidance first occurred at age 11 and 12 respectively with avoidance occurring in most case either at about the same age a anxiety or slightly later in the total sample lifetime prevalence for most dsm 5 disorder increased with the severity of social anxiety and avoidance result underline the need for preventive or early intervention effort especially regarding test anxiety and fear and avoidance of speaking in front of others these situation are particularly relevant in youth avoidance behavior may also be discussed a diagnostic marker for early case identification

Title: Event-related potentials in an associative word pair learning paradigm
Authors: Farshad, Maryam; Pavlov, Yuri G.; Kotchoubey, Boris
Abstract: the study investigated the effect of unintentional learning of semantically unrelated word pair on event related brain potential two experiment were conducted in whose acquisition phase participant listened to five pair of semantically unrelated word each pair being repeated twenty time in the test phase of experiment 1 these old pair were presented mixed with new pair containing other word in the test phase of experiment 2 a third condition wa added in which the first word in a pair wa one of the word presented during acquisition but the second word wa new in both experiment the second word in new word pair elicited an n400 and a late 550 1000 m frontal positivity the amplitude of the n400 to new second word in experiment 2 wa significantly larger when the first word in the pair wa an old previously learnt word a compared with the condition in which both first and second word were new the result indicate that in addition to a repetition effect unintentional learning of word pair result in building new association between previously unrelated word

Title: Ambient Light Conveying Reliability Improves Drivers’ Takeover Performance without Increasing Mental Workload
Authors: Figalová, Nikol; Chuang, Lewis L.; Pichen, Jürgen; Baumann, Martin; Pollatos, Olga
Abstract: driver of l3 automated vehicle av are not required to continuously monitor the av system however they must be prepared to take over when requested therefore it is necessary to design an in vehicle environment that allows driver to adapt their level of preparedness to the likelihood of control transition this study evaluates ambient in vehicle lighting that continuously communicates the current level of av reliability specifically on how it could influence driver take over performance and mental workload mw we conducted an experiment in a driving simulator with 42 participant who experienced 10 take over request tor the experimental group experienced a four stage ambient light display that communicated the current level of av reliability which wa not provided to the control group the experimental group demonstrated better take over performance based on lower vehicle jerk notably perceived mw did not differ between the group and the eeg index of mw frontal theta power parietal alpha power task load index did not differ between the group these finding suggest that communicating the current level of reliability using ambient light might help driver be better prepared for tor and perform better without increasing their mw

Title: Self-Resemblance Modulates Processing of Socio-Emotional Pictures in a Context-Sensitive Manner
Authors: Finke, Johannes B.; Zhang, Xinwei; Best, Daniel R.; Lass-Hennemann, Johanna; Schächinger, Hartmut
Abstract: abstract relevance of emotional information varies with self involvement the current study wa undertaken to test whether subtle facial self resemblance is sufficient to affect attentional and affective processing of complex socio emotional picture face digitally manipulated to resemble the participant final sample n 21 own versus unfamiliar control face form and color morphs were presented in picture of emotionally evocative social interaction that is threat versus sex scene at stimulus onset asynchrony soas of either 300 m or 3 000 m after picture onset startle response were elicited by acoustic white noise burst 50 m 105 db and recorded at the orbicularis oculus via electromyography emg the majority of participant remained unaware of the morphing manipulation and awareness did not affect the principal result a indexed by inhibition of startle at short lead interval and by picture evoked heart rate deceleration facial self resemblance modulates effect of motivational salience in a context sensitive way increasing prepulse inhibition with threat related but not erotic cue overall the present study suggests that visual cue of general motivational significance and of self relevance are integrated in a fast presumably automatic manner

Title: Cognitive behavior therapy for driving fear: A pilot randomized controlled trial
Authors: Fischer, Carolin; Heider, Jens; Taylor, Joanne E.; Schröder, Annette
Abstract: fear of driving is common in clinical practice while it treatment program are understudied this is the first randomized controlled trial to evaluate a newly developed protocol for cognitive behavior therapy cbt for driving fear compared with a wait list and to use specific assessment scale 34 participant 30 woman 4 men in an outpatient psychotherapy clinic were randomly allocated to either 18 session of cbt or a wait list n 17 each after treatment cbt wa significantly more efficacious than the wait list with large effect size on the instrument for fear of driving ifd cohen s d 2 58 and on the driving cognition questionnaire dcq cohen s d 2 14 driving fear is a condition treatable by cbt and the suggested protocol is safe feasible and acceptable further study with larger sample and active control e g virtual reality therapy are required to draw generalizable conclusion on effect size
Journal: Transportation Research Part F: Traffic Psychology and Behaviour

Title: Identifying characteristics of non-completers in fear conditioning paradigms with children and adolescents
Authors: Flasinski, Tabea; Sommer, Katharina; Schneider, Silvia; Margraf, Jürgen; Pflug, Verena; Lippert, Michael W; Christiansen, Hanna; Cwik, Jan C; Hamm, Alfons O; In-Albon, Tina; Knappe, Susanne; Pauli, Paul; Richter, Jan; Tuschen-Caffier, Brunna; Adolph, Dirk
Abstract: the number of study on fear conditioning in child and adolescent ha increased in recent year most of these study exclusively focus on data of completers while dropout rate reason for dropout and specific characteristic of non completers are underreported this study systematically investigated data of 283 child and adolescent between 8 and 17 year m 11 10 sd 2 14 undergoing a differential fear conditioning paradigm using a female scream a unconditioned stimulus u the sample included 230 child and adolescent with a current primary anxiety disorder separation anxiety disorder social anxiety disorder and specific phobia and 53 non anxious control the dropout rate wa 24 1 the most common reason to discontinue wa being afraid of the u 59 1 followed by the startle probe being too loud 15 2 logistic regression revealed that younger age and a present anxiety disorder predicted dropout there seem to be distinct characteristic potentially predicting dropout from fear conditioning paradigm thus interpretability and generalizability of those paradigm are limited when non completers are not considered future research should conscientiously look at these data more closely and investigate paradigm that work independent of age and diagnostic status

Title: Relationship Between Religious Attitude and Depression, Anxiety, and Stress Symptoms in University Students in Iran
Authors: Forstmeier, Simon; Fereydouni, Shapour; Fereidouny Doshmanzeiary, Samira
Abstract: a considerable proportion of young adult studying at university have a mental disorder previous research ha shown a negative relationship between various religiosity and psychopathology measure with different strength of this correlation depending on the religiosity measure the aim of the present study is to investigate the strength of association between religious attitude and depression anxiety and stress in iranian university student thirty three student from two iranian university filled in the religious attitude scale for university student rasus the beck depression inventory ii bdi ii and the depression anxiety and stress scale da 42 religious attitude correlate negatively with all psychopathological variable with a moderate effect size e g with bdi ii r 47 p 006 when dividing the sample in low v high religious people there were significantly more student without depression symptom in the high religious attitude group than in the low group

Title: INTEGRATIVE COGNITIVE BEHAVIOR THERAPY FOR PEOPLE WITH MILD ALZHEIMER’S DISEASE: RESULTS OF AN RCT
Authors: Forstmeier, S.; Maercker, A.; Savaskan, E.; Roth, T.
Abstract: about 90 of all mild alzheimer dementia ad case experience neuropsychiatric symptom although some research ha supported the effectiveness of specific psychotherapeutic approach for mild ad there are only few attempt to evaluate a multi component treatment programme this randomized controlled trial evaluates the effect of an integrative psychotherapy approach on the health of patient with mild ad and their caregiver it consists of 25 weekly session including eight module goal setting psychoeducation engagement in pleasant activity cognitive restructuring live review behavior management intervention for the caregiver and couple counselling 50 participant and their caregiver have been randomized to either the cbt based intervention group cbt or to the control group which received treatment a usual tau before and after the treatment phase participant have been assessed follow ups took place at 6 and 12 month post treatment the primary outcome wa depression in the patient with ad the secondary outcome measure were apathy other neuropsychiatric symptom functional ability quality of life and quality of the relationship to the caregiver cbt reduced depression significantly more than tau interaction f 5 3 p 05 with a moderate to large effect size d 0 76 there were also a significant advantage for cbt with regard to apathy f 4 7 p 05 d 0 71 and quality of the relationship to the caregiver f 4 3 p 05 d 0 77 there wa no advantage with regard to other neuropsychiatric symptom functional ability and quality of life the result are very encouraging and stimulate an adequately powered multi center study

Title: Deceptive and non-deceptive placebos to reduce sadness: A five-armed experimental study
Authors: Friehs, Thilo; Rief, Winfried; Glombiewski, Julia A.; Haas, Julia; Kube, Tobias
Abstract: objective examining the effect of deceptive and non deceptive placebo in sadness n 147 participant underwent a 2 2 1 design factor placebo rationale style cg deceptive but not open label placebo reduced sadness personalized and scientific rationale style evoked deceptive placebo effect placebo effect play an important role in psychopharmacological treatment of depression among the most potent mechanism are positive treatment expectation however there is large heterogeneity in how they are induced we studied the protective effect against sadness of deceptive dp and open label placebo olp combined with one of two new rationale style healthy participant n 147 were randomly assigned to one of five group in this 2x2 1 design two factor were varied the rationale style personal emotional style v scientific matter of fact style and the type of placebo dp v olp the placebo wa introduced a a protection from sadness in addition there wa a no treatment control group cg participant viewed a sad movie scene after placebo application the primary outcome wa pre post change in sadness a major component of depression participant in the dp group showed a significant protective effect against sadness whereas sadness increased in both the olp group and the cg there were no difference between the rationale style short term induced sadness ha limited external validity in a heterogeneous long term mental disorder like depression in line with other olp study no olp effect could be observed in this healthy sample in contrast dp significantly reduced sadness while placebo effect contribute substantially to antidepressant treatment the potential of olp in the treatment of depression appears to be limited in non clinical sample in addition our result suggest that different way to induce treatment expectation are possible

Title: Investigation of early night sleep effects on subsequent fear extinction learning and recall
Authors: Friesen, Edith; Sopp, M. Roxanne; Brueckner, Alexandra H.; Ferreira de Sá, Diana; Michael, Tanja
Abstract: extinction learning is considered an important underlying process of successful treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd however sleep disturbance may impede this learning process current account postulate that sleep facilitates encoding by promoting neural plasticity during slow wave sleep sw based on this hypothesis we tested whether early night sleep with high amount of sw facilitates subsequent extinction learning and recall sixty three participant took part in a trauma adapted fear conditioning experiment one group received a three hour sleep opportunity in the early night half whereas the other group stayed awake thereafter both group underwent extinction training and a return of fear test retention wa assessed after another sleep opportunity in both group linear mixed effect model and bayesian inference did not support the hypothesis of strengthened fear extinction by prior early night sleep subsequent exploratory analysis in contrast point to a role of rapid eye movement sleep in promoting successful fear extinction learning further confirmatory research should re investigate these effect and their implication for the treatment of ptsd

Title: Artificial intelligence in psychology: How can we enable psychology students to accept and use artificial intelligence?
Authors: Gado, Sabrina; Kempen, Regina; Lingelbach, Katharina; Bipp, Tanja
Abstract: psychologist with their expertise in statistic and regarding human perception and behavior can contribute valuable insight to the development of innovative and useful artificial intelligence ai system therefore we need to raise attention and curiosity for ai and foster the willingness to engage with it among psychology student this requires identifying approach to integrate a general understanding of ai technology into formal psychological training and education this study investigated to what extent psychology student currently accept and use ai and what affect their perception and usage therefore an ai acceptance model based on established technology acceptance model wa developed and tested in a sample of 218 psychology student an acceptable fit with the data wa found for an adapted version perceived usefulness and ease of use were most predictive for the student attitude towards ai attitude itself a well a perceived usefulness social norm and perceived knowledge were predictor for the intention to use ai in summary we identified relevant factor for designing ai training approach in psychology curriculum in this way possible restraint regarding the use of ai can be reduced and it beneficial opportunity exploited in psychological context

Title: Visual angle modulates affective responses to audiovisual stimuli
Authors: Gall, Dominik; Latoschik, Marc Erich
Abstract: what we see influence our emotion technology often mediates the visual content we perceive visual angle is an essential parameter of how we see such content it operationalizes visible property of human computer interface however we know little about the content independent effect of visual angle on emotional response to audiovisual stimulus we show that visual angle alone affect emotional response to audiovisual feature independent of object perception we conducted a 2 2 3 factorial repeated measure experiment with 143 undergraduate student we simultaneously presented monochrome rectangle with pure tone and assessed valence arousal and dominance in the high visual angle condition arousal increased valence and dominance decreased and lightness modulated arousal in the low visual angle condition pitch modulated arousal and lightness affected valence visual angle weight the affective relevance of perception modality independent of spatial representation visual angle serf a an early stage perceptual feature for organizing emotional response control of this presentation layer allows for provoking or avoiding emotional response where intended

Title: You See What you Fear: Spiders Gain Preferential Access to Conscious Perception in Spider-Phobic Patients
Authors: Gerdes, Antje B. M.; Alpers, Georg W.
Abstract: in phobic individual behavioral response to phobia related cue are facilitated and brain response are augmented it ha rarely been investigated whether this preferential processing is accompanied by an altered conscious perception of phobia related cue we used binocular rivalry to investigate conscious perception of phobia related cue in phobic individual 21 spider phobic patient and 20 non anxious control participant viewed picture of spider or flower each paired with a neutral pattern under condition of binocular rivalry spider phobic patient more often reported that they saw spider picture a the first percept and the total duration of seeing spider percept wa significantly longer in patient than in non anxious participant a second experiment wa conducted to rule out that these difference were caused by different response criterion result support the validity of self report in experiment 1 in sum predominance of phobia related cue in binocular rivalry provides evidence that phobia related cue gain preferential access to visual awareness in phobic individual

Title: Metacognitive therapy versus exposure and response prevention for obsessive-compulsive disorder – A pilot randomized trial
Authors: Glombiewski, Julia Anna; Hansmeier, Jana; Haberkamp, Anke; Rief, Winfried; Exner, Cornelia
Abstract: cognitive behaviour therapy especially exposure and response prevention erp is the treatment of choice for obsessive compulsive disorder ocd however a substantial number of patient refuse this method or fail to benefit enough metacognitive therapy mct claim to successfully treat ocd without prolonged exposure however only case series and small mostly uncontrolled trial have been published so far the efficacy and feasibility of mct for ocd compared to erp were investigated in a pilot randomized trial thirty seven outpatient with ocd according to dsm iv criterion were randomly allocated to individual weekly 14 session of therapy with either mct or erp analysis focused on treatment efficacy at post treatment and 3 month follow up treatment fidelity and credibility participant showed a significant reduction in ocd symptom in both treatment condition and with no difference between mct and erp participant in the mct condition required le face to face time with a therapist than those in the erp condition mct and erp were both effective with large effect size there wa no evidence that the two treatment lead to statistically different outcome larger controlled trial are justified
Journal: Journal of Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders

Title: Neural and endocrine stress reactions in healthy women with and without severe early life trauma
Authors: Golde, Sabrina; Wingenfeld, Katja; Otte, Christian
Abstract: maladaptive response to negative affective stimulus are pervasive including clinically ill and healthy people and men and woman respond differently at neural and hormonal level inspired by the research domain criterion initiative we used a transdiagnostic approach to investigate the impact of sex and dysphoric mood on neural hormonal response to negative affective stimulus participant included 99 individual with major depressive disorder psychosis and healthy control functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri wa complemented with real time acquisition of hypothalamo pituitary adrenal hpa and gonadal hpg hormone fmri data were analyzed in spm8 and task related connectivity wa assessed using generalized psychophysiological interaction across all participant elevated cortisol response predicted lower brain activity in orbitofrontal cortex and hypothalamus amygdala connectivity in those with worse dysphoric mood elevated cortisol response predicted lower activity in hypothalamus and hippocampus in woman elevated cortisol response wa associated with lower activity in medial prefrontal cortex and low hypothalamo hippocampal connectivity in woman with high dysphoric mood elevated cortisol response wa associated with low hypothalamo hippocampal connectivity there were no interaction with diagnosis or medication there wa limited power to correct for multiple comparison across total number of roi and connectivity target cortisol response were relatively low we conclude that the pathophysiology in neural hormonal response to negative affective stimulus is shared across healthy and clinical population and varies a a function of sex and dysphoric mood our finding may contribute to the development of hormonal adjunctive therapeutic that are sex dependent underscoring the importance of one s sex to precision medicine

Title: Playing smartphone games while studying: an experimental study on reading interruptions by a smartphone game
Authors: Graben, Katharina; Doering, Bettina K.; Barke, Antonia
Abstract: abstract in this study we investigated whether the use of smartphone game while reading a text reduces learning performance or reading speed we also examined whether this is affected by push notification ninety three student were randomly assigned to three learning condition in the gaming group g participant played a game app for 20 s at 2 min interval while reading in one subgroup the game app sent push notification gn in the other subgroup no notification gn were sent in the control group c participant did not play a game after the reading participant took a multiple choice quiz we compared quiz score and reading time of the group g and c and within the gaming group gn gn and observed no difference since the statistical non significance of these test doe not entail the absence of an effect we conducted equivalence test which did not demonstrate equivalence either the experiment ensured high internal validity yet remained inconclusive reason for the similarity of performance in all group could be non specific exercise effect all participant owned a smartphone low similarity between the task low variance of participant ability and motivation high achieving low adhd score or low game complexity future research should address these question

Title: Receiving push-notifications from smartphone games reduces students learning performance in a brief lecture: An experimental study
Authors: Graben, Katharina; Doering, Bettina K.; Barke, Antonia
Abstract: many university student use mobile phone during study task for unrelated activity it is known that using social networking while studying reduces the learning performance the objective of the present study wa to investigate whether using smartphone game during a lecture reduces the learning performance and whether this is influenced by receiving push notification ninety three student were randomized to three condition in two gaming condition g participant played a custom made gaming app 20 s at 2 min interval while watching a video mimicking a lecture in one subgroup gn the game app sent push notification in the other gn no notification were sent participant in the control group c watched the lecture without playing subsequently participant answered multiple choice question and estimated their own quiz performance comparing the quiz score and subjective performance estimate of the three group showed that the learning performance in gn wa lower than in c d 0 51 no other difference were observed participant subjective performance estimation remained unaffected by the experimental condition possible implication of the divergence of the subjective estimate and objective performance are discussed a well a limitation such a the low complexity of the game used and the short lecture duration not reflective of typical lecture playing an easy smartphone game with push notification during a lecture reduced learning performance subjective performance remained unaffected by experimental condition and were no indicator of objective performance without push notification no negative effect on learning performance due to parallel play of a smartphone game were found

Title: Mental Images in Body Integrity Identity Disorder (BIID) and in Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD): An Exploratory Study
Authors: Grocholewski, Anja; Bücker, Carina; Kasten, Erich; Osen, Bernhard; Heinrichs, Nina
Abstract: abstract little is known about mental image cognitive representation with sensory quality in body integrity identity disorder biid this study aimed to determine whether individual with biid experience mental image and if so whether they differ to those experienced by individual with body dysmorphic disorder bdd and healthy control a semi structured interview on mental image and their quality wa delivered to a sample of 22 individual with biid and 19 with bdd and 22 healthy control both the biid n 15 68 2 and bdd n 14 73 7 group reported significantly more mental image than healthy control n 3 13 6 but no difference between the two clinical group were found while mental image in bdd were focused on flawed body part image in biid involved the desired handicap mental image in biid were experienced a le distressing and more sexually arousing compared to bdd no further difference were found between the group e g regarding sensory multimodality dominance of a specific body part although the two group reported a similar frequency of mental image image appear to serve different function across condition clinically it may be necessary to target the positive mental image in biid to improve treatment outcome

Title: ‘I can succeed at this’: engagement in service learning in schools enhances university students’ self-efficacy
Authors: Gutzweiler, Raphael; Pfeiffer, Simone; In-Albon, Tina
Abstract: engaging in service learning ha been linked to multiple positive outcome in student such a an increase in self efficacy effect have been found on both general and domain specific self efficacy research on service learning ha indicated that feedback and gender had an impact on the increase in self efficacy though finding are mixed the present study aimed to determine how service learning experience at a university can be optimally designed to boost college student self efficacy while examining the effect of feedback and gender on general and teaching self efficacy over 2 year 267 bachelor s student in psychology mage 23 08 year sd 3 61 80 5 female conducted modularized prevention program in the context of mental health at primary and secondary school student rated their general and teaching self efficacy before t1 during t2 and after t3 conducting the program the result indicate a positive effect of engaging in service learning on student general d 0 30 and teaching d 0 68 self efficacy from t1 to t3 with significant increase only in female student and after receiving feedback engaging in service learning reduced gender specific difference in self efficacy feedback increased general and teaching self efficacy female student seemed to benefit more than male student

Title: Contamination-fear in subclinical obsessive-compulsive disorder: A further proof for no preferential processing of disorder-related stimuli
Authors: Haberkamp, Anke; Schmidt, Filipp; Hansmeier, Jana; Glombiewski, Julia Anna
Abstract: abstract how do individual with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd process and respond to image of rotten food or dirty toilet in contrast to other fear related disorder evidence for attentional bias and preferential processing of disorder related stimulus in sample of ocd is mixed to address methodological problem of previous study and to increase validity we used two independent sample of participant with contamination fear and two set of standardized stimulus in an established experimental paradigm in two experiment we compared evaluation and visual processing of contamination fear related cfr stimulus material in individual with high hcf and low lcf contamination fear in experiment 1 we selected cfr stimulus from a database with disgust related image dirti even though the hcf group rated cfr image a being more unpleasant arousing and disgusting we found no indicator of preferential processing larger priming effect or faster response in experiment 2 we selected cfr stimulus from a database with image specifically chosen to evoke symptom related anxiety in ocd patient bocd p again negative evaluation of stimulus did not transfer into enhanced information processing we conclude that early information processing of cfr stimulus is fundamentally different to that of fear related stimulus in anxiety disorder probably because of the triggered disgust response
Journal: Journal of Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders

Title: P58. Sleep in humans stabilizes hippocampal pattern separation performance
Authors: Hanert, A.; Weber, F.D.; Pedersen, A.; Born, J.; Bartsch, T.
Abstract: sleep support the formation of long term memory in an active system consolidation process episodic memory encoded during wakefulness are temporarily stored in the hippocampus before they are transferred to the neocortex for the long term storage during nonrem sleep especially slow wave sleep a reactivation of hippocampal neural representation is thought to promote this transfer via synchronization of distinct oscillatory activity in hippocampus and neocortex however how this reprocessing of memory during sleep affect the memory representation in the hippocampus itself is unclear for this purpose we tested hippocampal stimulus processing i e pattern separation before and after period of sleep and wakefulness in human pattern separation refers to the capability of the hippocampus to form non overlapping orthogonal neural representation from similar episodic stimulus input we found that pattern separation performance deteriorated across the wake period but remained stable across sleep p 0 013 stimulus with highest similarity showed a reversed pattern with reduced pattern separation after sleep p with those feature of nonrem sleep serving a marker of sleep dependent memory consolidation and hippocampal reactivation our finding provide first time evidence in human supporting the notion that reactivation based consolidation process during sleep affect the hippocampal representation itself

Title: A test of the metacognitive model of obsessive-compulsive disorder
Authors: Hansmeier, J.; Exner, C.; Rief, W.; Glombiewski, J.A.
Abstract: abstract the question of the relative importance of dysfunctional cognitive belief and metacognitions in the development and maintenance of obsessive compulsive oc symptom is still a matter of debate this study aim to investigate the relevance of oc specific metacognitions such a thought fusion belief belief about ritual and stop signal for oc symptom patient with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd n 71 anxiety disorder n 51 and depressive disorder n 81 and a nonclinical sample n 300 were assessed for meta cognitive belief and oc symptom analysis of variance indicated that the ocd group reported significantly more positive belief about ritual and stop signal than did the other three group also when controlling for comorbidity of depression disorder no difference were found with regard to thought fusion belief in regression analysis in the ocd sample oc specific metacognitions such a thought fusion belief explained incremental variance in oc symptom when controlling for cognitive belief and general non oc specific metacognitions overall these finding provide further evidence for the relevance of specific metacognitions to ocd metacognitive therapy might address these metacognitive belief and thereby lead to a reduction of oc symptom in ocd patient
Journal: Journal of Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders

Title: Exploring the Potential Distinction Between Continuous Traumatic Stress and Posttraumatic Stress in an East African Refugee Sample
Authors: Hecker, Tobias; Ainamani, Herbert E.; Hermenau, Katharin; Haefele, Eva; Elbert, Thomas
Abstract: posttraumatic stress pt indicates a continuous stress response that persists though threat to life had been experienced in the past however threat to life are frequently ongoing for these context the concept of continuous traumatic stress ct ha been put forward based on structured clinical interview with congolese refugee n 226 this study investigated the ct concept and whether it can be distinguished from pt we found that current exposure to violence correlated positively with concern about it recurrence in the ct group r 46 an ancova indicated that higher intrusion symptom severity in the pt group no symptom reduction under safe condition wa explained by higher lifetime trauma exposure η 2 125 in context of continuous trauma exposure symptom like response may be regarded a appropriate response to realistic danger in these context the possibility that symptom change are a response to real threat should be considered to avoid overestimation of ptsd prevalence

Title: Drugs Boosting Conflict? A Micro-Level Test of the Linkage Between Substance Use and Violence
Authors: Hecker, Tobias; Haer, Roos
Abstract: many study have emphasized the role of natural resource in the onset and duration of armed conflict due to it characteristic narcotic are considered to be one of the most influential resource however the dynamic of how this particular commodity is linked to conflict is still not well understood most scholar have focused on the revenue aspect of narcotic and only a few have mentioned the micro level aspect i e the effect of drug intake and alcohol consumption on combatant behavior during conflict with the help of a dataset based on 224 interview held with former combatant in the democratic republic of the congo we examined this latter dynamic our analysis show after controlling for armed group level and individual level variable that drug intake and alcohol consumption boost the number of violent action perpetrated by combatant

Title: Spatial working memory performance in people with obsessive–compulsive disorder, their unaffected first-degree relatives and healthy controls
Authors: Heinzel, Stephan; Bey, Katharina; Grützmann, Rosa; Klawohn, Julia; Kaufmann, Christian; Lennertz, Leonhard; Wagner, Michael; Kathmann, Norbert; Riesel, Anja
Abstract: summary study have shown that people with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd have impairment in spatial working memory swm performance however it remains unclear whether this deficit represents a cognitive endophenotype preceding symptom or a correlate of ocd we investigated swm in 69 people with ocd 77 unaffected first degree relative of people with ocd and 106 healthy control participant taking age effect into account swm performance wa best in healthy control intermediate in relative and worst in ocd participant however since performance did not differ significantly between healthy control and relative our study doe not fully support swm performance a a core cognitive endophenotype of ocd

Title: Imagine How Good That Feels: The Impact of Anticipated Positive Emotions on Motivation for Reward Activities
Authors: Heise, Max; Werthmann, Jessica; Murphy, Fionnuala; Tuschen-Caffier, Brunna; Renner, Fritz
Abstract: abstract background disease burden and unsatisfactory treatment outcome call for innovation in treatment of depression prospective mental imagery i e future directed voluntary imagery based thought about potentially rewarding activity may offer a mechanistically informed intervention that target deficit in reward processing a core clinical feature of depression we propose that the previously described impact of prospective mental imagery on motivation for everyday activity is facilitated by affective forecasting i e prediction about an individual s emotional response to the imagined activity method participant n 120 self nominated six activity to engage in over the following week and were randomized to either 1 an affective forecasting imagery condition n 40 2 a neutral process imagery condition n 40 or 3 a no imagery control condition n 40 result a predicted increase in motivation rating from pre to post experimental manipulation were significantly higher following affective forecasting imagery compared to both neutral process imagery d 0 62 and no imagery d 0 91 contrary to prediction the number of activity participant engaged in did not differ between condition conclusion result provide initial evidence for a potentially important role of affective forecasting in prospective mental imagery we discus how these finding can inform future research aiming to harness prospective mental imagery s potential for clinical application

Title: Enlarged Lateral Ventricles and Smaller Subcortical Volumes are Associated With Better Premorbid Adjustment in Young Adults With 22q11.2 Deletion Syndrome With Prodromal Symptoms of Schizophrenia
Authors: Heller, Carina; Weiss, Thomas; del Re, Elisabetta C.; Swago, Sophia; Coman, Ioana L.; Antshel, Kevin M.; Fremont, Wanda; Bouix, Sylvain; Kates, Wendy R.; Kubicki, Marek; Kikinis, Zora
Abstract: the size of lateral ventricle and subcortical structure are abnormal in schizophrenia and in 22q11 2 deletion syndrome 22q11ds a developmental genetic syndrome associated with a 30 risk for developing schizophrenia here we investigated whether lateral ventricle and subcortical volume are related in young adult with 22q11ds with and without prodromal symptom p of schizophrenia and whether abnormality in volume are associated with premorbid adjustment

Title: Self- and observer ratings of capacity limitations in patients with neurological conditions
Authors: Henning, Anne; Linden, Michael; Muschalla, Beate
Abstract: abstract objective the purpose of this study wa to compare the self and observer rating of capacity limitation in patient with neurological condition research on this topic is relevant for assessing the patient ability to participate in work and social life and improving collaborative patient clinician relationship method the self and observer rating of capacity limitation in a sample of n 245 patient with neurological condition from a rehabilitation facility were compared and assessed using the short rating of activity limitation and participation restriction in mental disorder according to the international classification of functioning disability and health mini icf app and the equivalent self rating questionnaire mini icf app s result paired sample t test revealed significant difference between the self and observer rating for six out of 13 capacity dimension on average the patient rated the capacity dimension adherence to regulation planning and structuring of task professional competency and endurance a significantly le limited in comparison to the observer small to medium effect size the self rating for limitation of contact with others and self care were only marginally higher than the observer rating conclusion the finding show that psychological capacity limitation occur in patient with neurological condition in clinical practice limitation in each capacity dimension and discrepancy in patient and clinician rating should be thoroughly assessed this is especially relevant in patient with neurological condition who have a potential tendency to underestimate or deny their disability

Title: The benefits of physical exercise on state anxiety: Exploring possible mechanisms
Authors: Herzog, Eva; Voß, Maria; Keller, Viktoria; Koch, Sophia; Takano, Keisuke; Cludius, Barbara
Abstract: although several study have shown that one acute bout of physical exercise can reduce state anxiety in healthy sample study that examine this effect in subclinical and clinical sample are still rare and have found mixed result in the present study we investigated the effect of a single session of acute exercise on state anxiety in a subclinical sample with moderate to high anxiety sensitivity potential mediator including self efficacy self esteem mindfulness subjective vitality rumination and emotional competency were explored participant n 88 with moderate to high anxiety sensitivity were assigned randomly to either an active group n 44 or a control group n 44 state anxiety and the mediator variable were assessed before and after the intervention state anxiety wa reduced from baseline to post intervention but no difference wa found between group exploratory analysis suggested that in the active intervention condition a reduction in state anxiety wa partly mediated by an increase in positive affect and mediated by an increase in subjective vitality one acute bout of exercise might not be enough to decrease state anxiety in subclinical individual with moderate to high anxiety sensitivity however the result of this study suggest that positive affect and subjective vitality could be two mechanism that might explain the beneficial effect of exercise on anxiety this should be further investigated in future study exercise doe not reduce state anxiety more than a control condition positive affect and subjective vitality mediate the reduction of state anxiety one bout of exercise is not sufficient to reduce anxiety in a subclinical sample

Title: How Expectations Shape the Formation of Intrusive Memories: An Experimental Study Using the Trauma Film Paradigm
Authors: Herzog, Philipp; Barth, Charlotte; Rief, Winfried; Brakemeier, Eva-Lotta; Kube, Tobias
Abstract: abstract background although intrusion are the hallmark symptom of posttraumatic stress disorder there is still limited knowledge about the process that contribute to the development of intrusion here we used the well established trauma film paradigm tfp to investigate how expectation about the intensity and controllability of intrusion influence their occurrence method 90 healthy participant underwent the tfp before they were randomized to one of three condition manipulating their expectation about intrusion positive expectation group negative expectation group control group the primary outcome wa the frequency and severity of intrusive memory a assessed with an intrusion diary over seven day result the tfp wa well implemented a indicated by significant post film anxiety and a substantial number of intrusion reported for the subsequent week the three group did not differ in their expectation about intrusion and relatedly in their experience of intrusion a mediation analysis revealed that the influence of post film anxiety on intrusive memory wa fully mediated by expectation conclusion despite the failure of the expectation manipulation the result of the mediation analysis support the hypothesis that post film expectation influence the formation of intrusive memory suggesting that intrusion may result from maladaptive dynamic between emotional and cognitive process following trauma like experience

Title: Valued Living Before and After CBT
Authors: Hoyer, Jürgen; Čolić, Jasmin; Grübler, Gerd; Gloster, Andrew T.
Abstract: whether and to what degree psychotherapy lead to change in patient value based action is not well documented in this study we examined whether cognitive behavioral therapy without explicit value work enhanced value oriented action we also explored the role of change in valued action for subsequent life satisfaction and continued change after therapy additionally data on the reliability and validity of the valued living questionnaire vlq are reported we analyzed the pre post and 6 month follow up data of 3687 patient of a university psychotherapy outpatient clinic most of which suffered from reliably diagnosed anxiety and mood disorder questionnaire included the vlq with 10 item each on the importance and consistency of value symptom scale beck depression inventory brief symptom inventory and the satisfaction with life scale over the course of therapy significant improvement in value oriented action were found d 34 especially in treatment responder d 51 increase of value oriented action significantly explained satisfaction with life at end of treatment even after controlling for symptom reduction temporally preceding improvement on the vlq predicted further symptom reduction until follow up data indicate that psychotherapy positively affect valued living even when it is not explicitly targeted in treatment valued living may have a role in the course and maintenance of therapeutic change

Title: Predictors of mental health symptomatology among Kurdish patients who recovered from COVID-19 in Iraq
Authors: Ibrahim, Hawkar; Goessmann, Katharina; Ahmad, Araz Ramazan; Saeed, Ayoub Kareem; Neuner, Frank
Abstract: abstract while a growing body of research ha documented severe psychosocial consequence of the new coronavirus disease covid 19 for the affected people research mainly focused either on health care worker or the general population there is a dearth of scientific research on the mental health status of recovered patient especially in low and middle income country the purpose of the current study wa to determine the mental health symptomatology and it associated factor among iraqi who recovered from covid 19 participant were iraqi kurdish individual who had previously been diagnosed with covid 19 during the first wave of covid 19 and they were recruited based on list of recovered patient provided by from public health institution using standardized demographic and mental health questionnaire structured telephone interview with 57 recovered patient were contacted it wa found that 31 6 of the participating recovered patient with covid 19 met the diagnostic criterion for post traumatic stress disorder ptsd and 21 05 were classified with probable depression hospitalized survivor had higher ptsd and depression symptom than those not hospitalized we also found that higher level of ptsd and depression symptom were predicted by younger age hospitalization due to covid 19 and having a family member who died from covid 19 in the context of the global covid 19 pandemic psychological and psychiatric treatment may be particularly relevant for younger adult patient and those with more severe covid 19 symptom who experienced hospitalized care

Title: Sharing for relief: associations of trauma-focused interviews and well-being among war-affected displaced populations in the Middle East
Authors: Ibrahim, Hawkar; Goessmann, Katharina; Neuner, Frank
Abstract: nonmaleficence is a key ethical value of research among vulnerable population trauma focused research typically includes detailed interview about traumatic life event and post traumatic symptom this raise concern about causing distress and harm for the affected individual we aimed to determine the immediate effect of trauma focused interview on participant wellbeing we developed the brief distress and harm scale dh7 for the assessment of current symptom of distress and urge to harm oneself or others using data from 332 iraqi and syrian child and both of their parent n 996 we assessed these symptom before and after participating in trauma focused interview result showed that the mean level of self reported distress and harm impulse were significantly decreased among adult and child rather than increased immediately after the interview once measure to safeguard case at risk are carefully implemented in research the potential benefit of participating in trauma focused interview outweigh the risk for individual potential implication of the result for ethical review board evaluating trauma focused study are discussed

Title: Varying Cognitive Scars – Differential Associations Between Types of Childhood Maltreatment and Facial Emotion Processing
Authors: Iffland, Benjamin; Neuner, Frank
