Abstract: distorted cognitive processing ha been found among survivor of child maltreatment however different type of abuse and neglect may bring about difference in emotion and attention processing the present study aimed to detect differential association between various type of childhood maltreatment and attentional bias in facial emotion processing a non clinical sample wa recruited on university campus and consisted of 67 individual with varying degree of maltreatment in an evaluative conditioning task image of face with neutral emotional expression were either associated with short video of intense negative statement or associated with neutral video subsequently these face were used a stimulus in a face in the crowd recognition task in which the familiar face had to be recognized within a crowd of unfamiliar neutral face in multiple linear regression analysis controlling for the intercorrelatedness of type of maltreatment differential relationship between type of maltreatment and attentional bias were found while emotional abuse wa associated with faster detection of negatively associated face emotional neglect wa associated with an impaired recognition of familiar stimulus regardless of the emotional content result indicated that interindividual difference in cognitive bias may be due to the activation of diverse cognitive schema based on differential experience of maltreatment

Title: Who Benefits from Couple Relationship Education? Findings from the Largest German CRE Study
Authors: Job, Ann-Katrin; Baucom, Donald H.; Hahlweg, Kurt
Abstract: abstractin evaluation study on couple relationship enhancement cre program researcher are encouraged to also investigate which couple benefit from program participation the author qualified 104 university student to offer an evidence based cre program up to a 15 month follow up the participating couple n 234 reported a significant decrease in unsolved relationship conflict a 2 day long intensive training led to better result compared with a weekly format regarding dropout couple with lower pretest satisfaction rating reported significant improvement over time whereas couple with initial higher rating reported no change or a deterioration further predictor were identified the finding should be taken into account in future research

Title: Dyadic Coping in Foster and Biological Parents and Its Relation to 					Child Psychopathology
Authors: Job, Ann-Katrin; Kerkhoff, Denise; Nussbeck, Fridtjof W.; Konrad, Kerstin; Heinrichs, Nina; Lohaus, Arnold
Abstract: abstract this study investigated whether foster parent report of their dyadic coping competency differ from biological parent whether there are difference with regard to the temporal association between maternal and paternal dyadic coping in the two sample and whether parental dyadic coping competency predict future mental health problem in child a total of 94 foster child and 157 child living in their biological family both sample aged 2 7 year a well a their foster parent were assessed three time over a 12 month period the mother and father dyadic coping competency were assessed using the dyadic coping inventory dci child psychopathology wa assessed using the child behavior checklist cbcl and a standardized clinical interview kinder dip both mainly based on maternal report foster parent reported better dyadic coping competency across the three assessment than did biological parent there were no significant difference with regard to the temporal association between mother and father report over time between the two sample cross lagged panel model yielded a high within person stability across the three assessment for both mother and father actor effect a well a some significant interpersonal effect primarily from paternal to maternal dyadic coping partner effect in contrast to the expectation mother and father dyadic coping did not predict child mental health problem at the third assessment the result make an important contribution to the research on dyadic coping and on how child mental health problem affect parental dyadic coping competency and vice versa

Title: Achievement and engagement: How student characteristics influence teacher judgments
Authors: Kaiser, Johanna; Retelsdorf, Jan; Südkamp, Anna; Möller, Jens
Abstract: abstract teacher judgment of student characteristic are affected not only by the characteristic in question but also by other factor this article present three study examining whether student achievement influence teacher judgment of their engagement a a proxy for motivation and vice versa first a field study wa conducted with n 52 teacher and n 1135 student structural equation modeling revealed an effect of student achievement on teacher judgment of student engagement and an effect of student engagement on teacher judgment of student achievement above and beyond the association of each student characteristic with teacher judgment of that characteristic these result were then replicated in two experimental study involving a computer simulation of an instructional situation the simulated classroom with n 40 and n 181 teacher candidate respectively the psychological determinant of the effect observed are discussed a are their practical implication

Title: The effects of student characteristics on teachers’ judgment accuracy: Disentangling ethnicity, minority status, and achievement.
Authors: Kaiser, Johanna; Südkamp, Anna; Möller, Jens
Abstract: teacher judgment of student academic achievement are not only affected by the achievement themselves but also by several other characteristic such a ethnicity gender and minority status in real life classroom achievement and further characteristic are often confounded we disentangled achievement ethnicity and minority status and examined whether the achievement of ethnic minority student is judged according to the predominant expectation expectation hypothesis and whether teacher judgment accuracy is influenced by student ethnicity or their minority status ethnicity hypothesis or minority hypothesis we conducted 4 experimental study with a computer simulation the simulated classroom in study 1 and 2 with n 34 and n 30 participant we implemented turkish study 1 and asian student study 2 a minority in contrast to the expectation hypothesis the expectation attributed to the achievement of ethnic minority student did not bias teacher judgment in both study we found greater judgment accuracy for ethnic minority student thereby probing the ethnicity hypothesis in study 3 with n 48 participant we further disentangled ethnicity and minority using german student a minority student thus probing the minority hypothesis again minority student were judged more accurately implementing gender male v female a the minority characteristic in study 4 with n 52 participant yielded the same result minority student were judged more accurately therefore supporting the minority hypothesis thus classroom characteristic need to be considered in research on teacher judgment accuracy to clarify the influence of individual student characteristic and composition effect beyond individual effect psycinfo database record c 2017 apa all right reserved

Title: Nature and evoked culture: Sex differences in personality are uniquely correlated with ecological stress
Authors: Kaiser, Tim
Abstract: abstract sex difference in personality were found to be larger in more developed and more gender equal society however the study that report this effect either have methodological shortcoming or do not take into account possible underlying effect of ecological variable here a large multinational n 867 782 dataset of personality profile wa used to examine sex difference in big five facet score for 50 country gender difference were related to estimate of ecological stress a well a socio cultural variable using a regularized partial correlation approach the unique association of those correlate with sex difference were isolated sex difference were large median mahalanobis d 1 97 and varied substantially across country range 1 49 to 2 48 global sex difference are larger in more developed country with higher food availability le pathogen prevalence higher gender equality and an individualistic culture after controlling for confounds only cultural individualism historic pathogen prevalence and food availability remained sex difference in personality are uniquely correlated to ecological stress previously reported correlation between greater sex difference and socio cultural liberalism could be due to confounding by influence of ecological stress

Title: Time-Lagged Prediction of Food Craving With Qualitative Distinct Predictor Types: An Application of BISCWIT
Authors: Kaiser, Tim; Butter, Björn; Arzt, Samuel; Pannicke, Björn; Reichenberger, Julia; Ginzinger, Simon; Blechert, Jens
Abstract: food craving fc peak are highly context dependent and variable accurate prediction of fc might help preventing disadvantageous eating behavior here we examine whether data from 2 week of ecological momentary assessment ema questionnaire on stress and emotion active ema aema alongside temporal feature and smartphone sensor data passive ema pema are able to predict fcs 2 5 h into the future in n 46 individual a logistic prediction approach with feature dimension reduction via best item scale that is cross validated weighted informative and transparent biscwit wa performed while overall prediction accuracy wa acceptable passive sensing data alone wa equally predictive to psychometric data the frequency of which single predictor were considered for a model wa rather balanced indicating that aema and pema model were fully idiosyncratic

Title: The Effects of a Single Relaxation Hypnosis Session on Mental Stress in           Chronically Stressed Individuals
Authors: Karrasch, Sarah; Bongartz, Walter; Behnke, Alexander; Matits, Lynn; Kolassa, Iris-Tatjana
Abstract: abstract background chronically stressed people often suffer from anxiety and depressive mood hypnosis is a technique that can induce a relaxation response and reduce negative stress symptom objective this explorative study investigated the impact of a single relaxation hypnosis session on stress related psychological symptom method 47 suggestible stressed individual 87 female were randomized to a hypnosis group n 23 20 minute hypnosis or a control group n 24 20 minute scientific documentary before and after the intervention we assessed perceived stress negative affect anxiety and depressive mood result after the hypnosis intervention depressive mood d 0 36 and state anxiety d 1 00 decreased while negative affect remained stable d 0 04 perceived stress wa reduced in both group conclusion a single relaxation hypnosis session decreased stress related symptom in chronically stressed individual our result substantiated the stress alleviating effect of hypnosis
Journal: Zeitschrift für Klinische Psychologie und Psychotherapie

Title: Negative Priming in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder and Schizophrenia: Association with Symptom Patterns
Authors: Kathmann, Norbert; Bogdahn, Bettina; Endrass, Tanja
Abstract: negative priming np is assumed to indicate the effect of an inhibitory mechanism in selective attention previous study showed inconsistent reduction of the np effect in patient with obsessive compulsive disorder ocd and schizophrenia the aim of the present study wa to relate np alteration in two different np task with specific symptom pattern of ocd and schizophrenia patient twenty eight patient with a diagnosis of ocd 27 patient with schizophrenia and 27 healthy comparison participant performed a spatial and an identity priming task robust np effect were found in the spatial priming task across group and symptom pattern however ocd patient with a predominance of obsessive thought a well a schizophrenia patient with predominantly positive symptom showed no identity np effect whereas ocd patient who primarily presented with compulsive ritual and schizophrenia patient with predominant negative symptom tended to have increased identity np compared to healthy participant it is concluded that obsession a well a positive psychotic symptom are related to identity np deficit possibly reflecting a shared basic cognitive mechanism leading to deficient thought control

Title: Selfies reflect actual personality – Just like photos or short videos in standardized lab conditions
Authors: Kaurin, Aleksandra; Heil, Lutz; Wessa, Michèle; Egloff, Boris; Hirschmüller, Sarah
Abstract: abstract social medium site are overflowing with million of selfies because people increasingly share what they do and who they are with the rest of the world we examined whether self expression based on selfies elicit enhanced consensual and accurate interpersonal perception compared to commonly employed laboratory condition perceived narcissism wa relatively higher and conscientiousness lower when rating were based on selfies this effect did not extend to the accuracy of rating across all condition unacquainted observer agreed with each other and their rating were correlated with a criterion measure of target personality except for agreeableness and self esteem accuracy correlation were somewhat higher when rating were based on selfies randomization based exploratory lens model analysis were conducted to bolster the interpretation of our result

Title: M162. FRONTO-STRIATAL-THALAMIC CIRCUITRY ABNORMALITIES IN WHITE MATTER TRACTS IN INDIVIDUALS WITH 22Q11.2 DELETION SYNDROME
Authors: Heller, Carina; Steinmann, Saskia; Makris, Nikos; Charron, Lily; Antshel, Kevin M; Fremont, Wanda; Coman, Ioana L; Schweinberger, Stefan R; Weiß, Thomas; Bouix, Sylvain; Kubicki, Marek; Kates, Wendy; Shenton, Martha; Levitt, James; Kikinis, Zora
Abstract: abstract background cognitive decline is considered a fundamental component in schizophrenia abnormality in fronto striatal thalamic fst sub circuit are present in schizophrenia and are associated with cognitive impairment however it remains unknown whether abnormality in fst sub circuit are present before psychosis onset this may be elucidated by investigating young adult with 22q11 2 deletion syndrome 22q11ds of whom 30 will develop schizophrenia in adulthood in 22q11ds cognitive decline most pronounced in verbal iq viq precedes the onset of psychosis and those who develop psychosis diverge more strongly from a typical cognitive trajectory based on these finding study of young adult with 22q11ds without overt psychosis but with prodromal symptom may increase our understanding of cognitive manifestation and early pathology in fst sub circuit in schizophrenia here we examined white matter wm tract in fst sub circuit especially those involving dorsolateral dlpfc and ventrolateral prefrontal cortex vlpfc and their association with viq in young adult with 22q11ds with and without prodromal symptom method we compared fractional anisotropy fa axial diffusivity ad and radial diffusivity rd in tract of the fst sub circuit in 21 individual with 22q11ds with prodromal symptom age m 21 43 and 30 individual without prodromal symptom age m 20 73 to 30 healthy control age m 20 89 two tensor tractography wa applied to reconstruct wm fiber tract of the whole brain followed by applying the white matter query language wmql method to select tract between striatum and thalamus with the rostral middle frontal gyrus rmfg and inferior frontal gyrus ifg representing dlpfc and vlpfc this yielded four tract of interest thalamus rmfg thalamus ifg striatum rmfg and striatum ifg tract additionally correlation between the dmri measure and score on viq were performed result fa wa significantly increased while rd wa significantly decreased in most wm tract in both 22q11ds group when compared to healthy control in the whole 22q11ds group viq correlated negatively with fa in the right thalamus ifg tract r 0 336 p 018 while rd correlated positively with viq in the right thalamus ifg tract r 0 290 p 043 in individual with 22q11ds such that increased fa and decreased rd were associated with a lower viq we followed up on the result in individual with 22q11ds with prodromal symptom to determine whether the presence of prodromal symptom drove the correlation viq correlated significantly with fa r 0 491 p 0 024 fdr adjusted 0 048 and significantly at trend level with rd r 0 487 p 0 025 fdr adjusted 0 050 in the right thalamus ifg tract in individual with 22q11ds with prodromal symptom discussion microstructural abnormality in brain wm tract connecting the thalamus and the striatum with prefrontal cortex are present in young adult with 22q11ds with and without prodromal symptom compared to healthy control these abnormality are associated with the individual cognitive performance in viq in individual with 22q11ds with prodromal symptom and therefore emphasize the potential involvement of the fst sub circuit in schizophrenia while change in fst circuitry have been reported in patient with schizophrenia we observed that change in fst circuitry are also present in young adult with 22q11ds at risk for but without psychotic symptom our result suggest that psychosis onset in 22q11ds may be associated with a complex pattern of wm alteration furthermore cognitive abnormality especially in viq present an important preclinical risk factor for psychosis in 22q11ds

Title: Toward the Successful Employment of Adults with Autism: A First Analysis of Special Interests and Factors Deemed Important for Vocational Performance
Authors: Kirchner, Jennifer Christina; Dziobek, Isabel
Abstract: abstract background adult with autism spectrum disorder asds and with intelligence quotient in the normal range are disproportionately affected by unemployment objective we sought to a special interest that could bear potential for employment a well a factor deemed relevant for work performance in adult with asd method a newly compiled self report online questionnaire wa administered to high functioning adult with asd to a special interest a well a factor that both interfere with and facilitate work performance result participant reported that they spent an average of 26 hour per week on their special interest and their average level of proficiency wa rated a very good although special interest were reported to be in the social science and the creative field a often a they were in the natural science and technology engineering the most common approach taken within those field wa systemizing rather than a creative or knowledge acquiring pursuit social interaction problem with coworkers and superior a well a sensory issue were most often rated a interfering with work performance in addition mental underload wa rated a an important factor that interfered with work performance whereas excessive demand were not among the factor most often reported to facilitate work performance were employer and colleague awareness of the individual s asd diagnosis conclusion our data suggest that special interest among individual with asd may bear important potential for employment given the focus on systemizing in this population recent effort to create job opportunity in the information technology sector specifically for high functioning individual with asd are a promising start however these effort should be expanded into other field
Journal: Scandinavian Journal of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry and Psychology

Title: Lack of Significant Association between Sex Hormone Concentrations and Atopic Dermatitis in Adolescents and Adults in Two Population-Based Studies
Authors: Kische, Hanna; Hannemann, Anke; Voss, Catharina; Nauck, Matthias; Völzke, Henry; Pieper, Lars; Beesdo-Baum, Katja; Arnold, Andreas
Abstract: atopic dermatitis ad is a chronic pruritic skin disease with increasing incidence mathiesen and thomsen 2019 although ad is classically thought of a a pediatric disease recent study have shown high rate of disease in adult a well with a prevalence in europe between 2 2 and 17 6 kowalska olędzka et al 2019 there is a growing body of evidence that sex hormone play a role in the complex interplay of ad pathophysiology influencing immunological pathway and the skin kanda et al 2019

Title: Cross-sectional and longitudinal associations of saliva cortisol and hair cortisol with generalized and social anxiety disorder and major depressive disorder in adolescents and young adults
Authors: Kische, Hanna; Ollmann, Theresa; Venz, John; Voss, Catharina; Pieper, Lars; Hoyer, Jana; Beesdo-Baum, Katja
Abstract: estrogen potently suppress food intake compelling evidence suggests that estradiol the primary form of estrogen reduces food intake by facilitating other anorectic signal brain derived neurotrophic factor bdnf like estradiol appears to suppress food intake by affecting meal size we hypothesized that estradiol modulates bdnf expression and the anorectic effect of bdnf the first goal wa to determine whether bdnf expression wa regulated by endogenous estradiol of cycling rat and by cyclic estradiol treatment using ovariectomized rat bdnf expression within the ventromedial nucleus of hypothalamus vmh wa temporally elevated at estrus following the estradiol peak which coincided with the decline in feeding at this phase of the ovarian cycle additionally food intake and body weight were increased following ovariectomy with a parallel decrease in bdnf expression in the vmh all of these alteration were reversed by cyclic estradiol treatment suggesting that bdnf expression within the vmh wa regulated in an estradiol dependent manner the second goal wa to determine whether estradiol modulates the anorectic effect of bdnf sham operated estrous rat and ovariectomized rat cyclically treated with estradiol responded to a lower dose of central administration of bdnf to decrease food intake than male rat and oil treated ovariectomized rat implying that endogenous estradiol or cyclic estradiol replacement increased the sensitivity to anorectic effect of bdnf these data indicate that bdnf expression within the vmh and the anorectic effect of bdnf varied depending on plasma estradiol level suggesting that estradiol may regulate bdnf signaling to regulate feeding

Title: ODP029 Associations between Objective and Subjective Indicators of Stress and Sleep Disturbance in Adolescents and Young Adults from the General Population
Authors: Kische, Hanna; Voss, Catharina; Pieper, Lars; Beesdo-Baum, Katja
Abstract: abstract background sleep is a complex and dynamic vital state occupying one third of human s lifetime disturbed sleep can be a symptom of and a risk factor for a wide range of mental disorder and somatic disease one pathway through which sleep problem may lead to health problem is by dysregulation of the body s physiological stress response system a indicated by aberrant cortisol previous finding showed that poor sleep quality and sleep disruption were associated with elevated cortisol level in adult regarding adolescent there is evidence that sleep problem are linked to hyper reactivity to stress with effect being stronger in girl than boy in addition adolescence itself wa associated with decreased sleep quality and an increase in perceived stress dependent on age however little evidence is available for the association between objective and subjective stress marker and sleep in the daily life of adolescent from the general population the aim of this study wa to examine the association between 1 cortisol and 2 subjective stress with sleep in adolescent and young adult method we used baseline data 11 2015 12 2016 of the behavior and mind health bemind study an epidemiological study based on a random community sample of individual aged 14 to 21 year dresden germany n 1 180 we assessed sleep disturbance with the short form of the promis sleep disturbance questionnaire 8 item via ecological momentary assessment conducted on four day directly after awakening calculated mean cortisol wa measured in hair pg mg and saliva nmol l cortisol awakening response and total cortisol were calculated subjective stress wa assessed via 1 the perceived stress scale p 2 the trier inventory of the assessment of chronic stress screening tic and 3 two item for time urgency subjective stress in school at work university and leisure self developed weighted linear regression with robust standard error were performed after exclusion n 1132 48 4 female model were adjusted for sex age pubertal development and rerun in sex specific analysis result mean age wa 17 83 sd 0 07 neither hair nor saliva cortisol wa associated with promis sleep hair cortisol unstandardized β coefficient 0 002 95 confidence interval ci 0 012 0 007 all analyzed subjective stress variable were associated with promis sleep we found positive association between p β coefficient 0 151 95 ci 0 117 0 183 tic β coefficient 0 056 95 ci 0 045 0 066 and time urgency β coefficient 0 114 95 ci 0 061 0 166 with sleep there wa no evidence for sex specific effect conclusion result confirmed the association between perceived stress and sleep in a population based study with adolescent and young adult that wa previously shown mainly in adult no evidence for a link between cortisol and sleep wa found further analysis would benefit from a longitudinal perspective and consideration of mediating moderation variable to elucidate the complex interplay between stress and sleep presentation no date and time listed

Title: The spider anxiety and disgust screening for children: Reliability and validity of a screening for children
Authors: Klein, Anke M.; Niekerk, Rianne E.; Baartmans, Jeanine M.d.; Rinck, Mike; Becker, Eni S.
Abstract: specific fear such a fear of spider are often used a a model for studying the development of other fear because several study suggest that the underlying process of fear are similar for

Title: Nicotine deprivation and craving in smokers are positively related to improved inhibition in smoking-related contexts
Authors: Kräplin, A.; Bühringer, G.; Goschke, T.
Abstract: this paper a the role of carbon dioxide capture and storage cc in addressing challenge in the energy transition in region reliant on carbon intensive industry for employment and a an economic base the assessment is based on semi structured interview with relevant stakeholder and expert in the aberdeen area in scotland the rotterdam harbour or rijnmond area in the netherlands and in norway the interview explored challenge around the role of cc in regional just transition or how to make the transformation of region relying on carbon intensive industry to a low carbon society fair while significant difference in response between the aberdeen area the rijnmond area and norway were found a common understanding showed that for cc to contribute to a just transition it ha to a make a contribution to climate change imperative b help to mitigate the economic and employment effect arising from declining or maturing industry and c be undertaken in a manner that help to redress or at least doe not increase uneven vulnerability and inequality in society five key theme that characterise the opportunity and challenge for cc from a just transition perspective were drawn from the interview skill for a just transition transition a an opportunity responsibility scale of action and viability we recommend that these are added to earlier work on barrier and enablers of cc in area relying on fossil industry

Title: Personality Traits Predict Non-Substance Related and Substance                     Related Addictive Behaviours
Authors: Kräplin, Anja; Kupka, Käthe Friederike; Fröhner, Juliane H.; Krönke, Klaus-Martin; Wolff, Max; Smolka, Michael N.; Bühringer, Gerhard; Goschke, Thomas
Abstract: abstract aim to examine whether personality trait predict the course of addictive behaviour in general and whether predictive association differ between non substance related nr and substance related sr addictive behaviour methodology we recruited 338 individual 19 27 y 59 female from a random community sample with nr sr or no dsm 5 addictive disorder predictor were the big five personality trait neo ffi and reward and punishment sensitivity bi ba questionnaire outcome were the slope of addictive behaviour i e quantity frequency and number of dsm 5 criterion over three year bayesian multiple regression were used to analyse the probability for each hypothesis result the evidence that higher neuroticism lower conscientiousness lower agreeableness higher extraversion lower openness higher reward sensitivity and lower punishment sensitivity predict increased addictive behaviour over time wa overall moderate to high 69 to 99 and varied by trait and outcome predictive association were mostly higher for nr compared with sr addictive behaviour conclusion personality trait predict the course of addictive behaviour but association were only about half a large a expected while some personality trait such a lower conscientiousness predict increase in both nr and sr addictive behaviour over time others such a lower punishment sensitivity seem to specifically predict increase in nr addictive behaviour

Title: Negative interpersonal scenes decrease inhibitory control in healthy individuals but not in gambling disorder patients
Authors: Kräplin, Anja; Scherbaum, Stefan; Bühringer, Gerhard; Goschke, Thomas; Schmidt, André
Abstract: while impaired cognitive control and decision making are clearly related to gambling disorder gd it remains unclear how they are affected by interpersonal problem a contextual cue for gamblin

Title: Teacher evaluation of student ability: what roles do teacher gender, student gender, and their interaction play?
Authors: Krkovic, Katarina; Greiff, Samuel; Kupiainen, Sirkku; Vainikainen, Mari-Pauliina; Hautamäki, Jarkko
Abstract: background recent decade have been marked by an extensive movement to analyze bias in people s thinking especially in gender related issue study have addressed the question of gender bias in classroom on different level the use of gender in book learning opportunity determined by student gender or teacher gender preference purpose in this study we aim to answer the question of whether and under which circumstance the interaction between teacher gender and student gender positively or negatively influence teacher evaluation of student performance while controlling for objective measure of student performance for instance it could be possible that a teacher with the same gender a a student evaluates the student a better than opposite gender student independent of their objective performance sample the sample consisted of n 1 500 finnish 6th grade student mage 12 67 and their respective class teacher design and method student completed several academic skill

Title: Depression is not related to deficits in emotional reasoning skills
Authors: Kube, Tobias; Friehs, Thilo; Glombiewski, Julia Anna; Gollwitzer, Mario
Abstract: several line of research have examined whether people with depressive symptom have deficit in social cognitive ability such a emotional reasoning skill while many depressed people report having such deficit it is le clear whether depressive symptom are related to actual objective performance deficit we examined the relationship between emotional reasoning skill a assessed with the temint and depressive symptom i e bdi ii in a mini meta analysis of 11 study with data from 1503 participant with varying level of depression from healthy people to clinical sample with severely depressed people using a random effect approach we found a small but significant correlation between depressive symptom and temint performance mean r z 0 065 indicating that depressive symptom were associated with higher emotional reasoning skill these finding suggest that depression is unrelated to deficit in emotional reasoning though assessed with only one test if anything depressive symptom are associated with improved performance in the temint the current result point to a discrepancy between depressed people s self evaluation of their ability a shown in previous research and their actual performance our finding also have practical implication a they suggest that clinician may focus on modifying depressed people s negative view of themselves rather than on improving their skill objective to examine the association of depression and emotional reasoning skill depression wa not related to deficit in emotional reasoning skill n 1503 conclusion people with depression may systematically underestimate their ability clinician may focus on improving depressed people s self view rather than skill

Title: How Depressive Symptoms Hinder Positive Information Processing: An Experimental Study on the Interplay of Cognitive Immunisation and Negative Mood in the Context of Expectation Adjustment
Authors: Kube, Tobias; Glombiewski, Julia Anna
Abstract: abstract background people with depression maintain negative expectation despite disconfirming positive experience by reappraising or discarding novel positive information referred to a cognitive immunisation a second body of literature suggests that negative mood can negatively affect information processing bridging these two line of research the present study examined the interplay of cognitive immunisation and negative mood in the context of expectation modification method in a student sample n 152 we used a well established experimental paradigm to examine the adjustment of performance expectation in response to positive performance feedback and it relation to depressive symptom in a 2 2 design participant received either a negative mood induction a cognitive immunisation manipulation both or no further manipulation result participant from all experimental group revised their previous expectation significantly in line with positive performance feedback however depressive symptom were a negative predictor of expectation adjustment and a moderation analysis indicated that this effect wa particularly pronounced if participant underwent the negative mood induction conclusion consistent with previous work depressive symptom were associated with a reduced ability to integrate positive information furthermore our result suggest that the activation of negative mood in people with elevated level of depression may hamper learning from new positive experience

Title: Further Specifying the Cognitive Model of Depression: Situational Expectations and Global Cognitions as Predictors of Depressive Symptoms
Authors: Kube, Tobias; Herzog, Philipp; Michalak, Charlotte M.; Glombiewski, Julia A.; Doering, Bettina K.; Rief, Winfried
Abstract: the cognitive model of depression assumes that depressive symptom are influenced by dysfunctional cognition to further specify this model the present study aimed to examine the influence of different type of cognition on depressive symptom i e situational expectation and global cognition it wa hypothesized that situational expectation predict depressive symptom beyond global cognition the present study examined a clinical n 91 and a healthy sample n 80 using longitudinal data with a baseline assessment and a follow up five month later although the study wa not designed a an interventional trial participant from the clinical study received non manualized cognitive behavioral treatment after the baseline assessment we examined situational expectation intermediate belief dispositional optimism and generalized expectancy for negative mood regulation a predictor of depressive symptom hypothesis were tested using multiple hierarchical linear regression analysis result indicate that although there were significant correlation between the cognitive factor and depressive symptom in both sample neither global cognition nor situational expectation significantly predicted depressive symptom at the five month follow up the present study could contrary to the hypothesis not provide evidence for a significant impact of cognitive vulnerability on depressive symptom presumably due to high drop out rate at follow up limitation of the study and direction for future research are critically discussed situational and global cognition were examined a predictor of depressive symptom in a healthy and a clinical sample cognitive factor were correlated with depressive symptom however in both sample depressive symptom at follow up were not predicted by cognitive factor situational and global cognition were examined a predictor of depressive symptom in a healthy and a clinical sample cognitive factor were correlated with depressive symptom however in both sample depressive symptom at follow up were not predicted by cognitive factor

Title: How the Discrepancy Between Prior Expectations and New Information Influences Expectation Updating in Depression—The Greater, the Better?
Authors: Kube, Tobias; Kirchner, Lukas; Lemmer, Gunnar; Glombiewski, Julia Anna
Abstract: previous research on expectation updating in relation to psychopathology used to treat expectation confirming information and expectation disconfirming information a binary concept here we varied the extent to which new information deviate from prior expectation and examined it influence on expectation adjustment in both a false feedback task study 1 n 379 and a social interaction task study 2 n 292 unlike traditional learning model we hypothesized a tipping point in which the discrepancy between expectation and outcome becomes so large that new information is perceived a lacking credibility thus entailing little updating of expectation consistent with the hypothesized tipping point new information wa deemed most valid if it wa moderately positive moreover descriptively expectation update wa largest for moderate expectation violation but this effect wa small study 2 or even nonsignificant study 1 the finding question the assumption of traditional learning model that the larger the prediction error the larger the update

Title: Bullies Get Away With It, But Not Everywhere: Mental Health Sequelae of Bullying in Chinese and German Students
Authors: Lin, Muyu; Wolke, Dieter; Schneider, Silvia; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: bullying victimization is associated with adverse mental health consequence while bully suffer few or no adverse consequence in western society yet the universality of these consequence across western and eastern culture is unknown the current study investigated retrospective bullying experience in primary and secondary school and it effect on adult mental health depression anxiety stress lifetime suicidal behavior positive mental health life satisfaction social support self efficacy and sense of control in 5 012 chinese and 1 935 german university student school bullying victimization wa far le frequently recalled by the chinese sample 6 2 12 6 than the german sample 29 3 37 0 but victim had similar adverse mental health in both country in germany bully and not involved had equally good mental health whereas bully in china had poor mental health comparable to victim bullying victimization ha similar adverse effect on mental health across country however compared to the german student the prevalence of school bullying is significantly lower and bully are also more likely to suffer mental health problem in adulthood in chinese student the difference of reason for and consequence of being bully are discussed and may have important implication for evolutionary theory and intervention of bullying

Title: Overregulation in Physical Education – Teaching Behavior Effects on Self-Regulated Motor Learning
Authors: Lindberg, Sven; Hasselhorn, Marcus; Lehmann, Martin
Abstract: this study examines student use of self regulated motor learning strategy related to a congruent or incongruent teacher student fit constellation of perceived and preferred teaching behavior in a cross sectional study in german grammar school 1452 student and 18 physical education teacher participated the result of the study indicate that student apply more self regulated motor learning strategy in specific fit constellation in addition when the teacher self perception of teaching behavior exceeds the respective perception and preference of the student this overregulation impairs the satisfaction with and interest in physical education a well a self regulated motor learning
Journal: International Journal of Learning and Development

Title: Gender Differences in Children’s Math Self-Concept in the First Years of Elementary School
Authors: Lindberg, Sven; Linkersdörfer, Janosch; Ehm, Jan-Henning; Hasselhorn, Marcus; Lonnemann, Jan
Abstract: in the course of elementary school child start to develop an academic self concept reflecting their motivation thought and feeling about a specific domain for the domain of mathematics gender difference can emerge which are characterized by a le pronounced math self concept for girl however study are rather sparse regarding the early year of elementary school education hence the point in time when such gender difference emerge yet remains a matter of debate in our study we found that the math self concept of elementary school child n 81 declined from first to second grade while no difference in math achievement were observed between girl and boy it became apparent that girl math self concept wa already le pronounced than the math self concept of boy in the first year of elementary school our finding emphasize the importance of considering such gender difference even at the beginning of school education

Title: Individual Differences in Children’s Early Strategy Behavior in Arithmetic Tasks
Authors: Lindberg, Sven; Linkersdörfer, Janosch; Lehmann, Martin; Hasselhorn, Marcus; Lonnemann, Jan
Abstract: a demonstrated by the overlapping wave model siegler 1996 child s strategy use in arithmetic task is variable adaptive and change gradually with age and experience in this study first grade elementary school child n 73 who scored high middle or low in a standardized scholastic mathematic achievement test were confronted with different arithmetic task simple addition e g 3 2 simple subtraction e g 7 2 and more advanced addition e g 7 9 to evoke different calculation strategy video analysis and child s self report were used to identify individual strategy behavior in accordance with the overlapping wave model child in all achievement group showed variable and multiple strategy usage and adapted their behavior to the task of the different category we demonstrated that not only low achiever differed from normal achiever but also that high achiever exhibited a unique pattern of strategy behavior in early mathematics
Journal: Journal of Educational and Developmental Psychology

Title: Narcissistic self-promotion is not moderated by the strength of situational cues
Authors: Maaß, Ulrike; Ziegler, Matthias
Abstract: the present study examined whether situational difference moderate the influence of narcissism on self promotion a the strong situation hypothesis would assume personality influence would be lowest in strong situation that include clear cue for self promotion therefore 219 participant received different situational cue no prime subliminal prime or explicit request to self present prior to the task to self describe we rated the self description to the degree of a favorable and narcissistic impression in an agentic or communal way result showed that all participant promoted themselves more favorably and narcissistically in situation with an explicit request only the impact of narcissism on self promotion wa invariant across condition it wa concluded that narcissism lead to enhanced self promotion irrespective of situational strength implication for the way we study the strong situation hypothesis are discussed

Title: A Pilot Study on the Effect of an Energy Drink on Interoception in 					High vs. Low Anxiety Sensitivity Individuals
Authors: Mai-Lippold, Sandra A.; Dettlinger, Clara M.; Khalsa, Sahib S.; Pollatos, Olga
Abstract: abstract background the market for energy drink ha grown quickly over the past 20 year while the physiological and psychological effect of different ingredient have been studied the influence of energy drink on interoceptive process is unclear anxiety ha been associated with amplified interoceptive functioning suggesting potentially exaggerated reaction to energy drink aim investigate the effect of energy drink consumption and anxiety sensitivity a a well a their possible interaction on cardiorespiratory dimension of interoception method thirty nine healthy student consumed an energy drink via a placebo controlled counterbalanced crossover design cardiac and respiratory interoceptive accuracy iacc interoceptive sensibility is and interoceptive evaluation ie were assessed heartbeat evoked potential heps were analyzed to evaluate neural processing of the heartbeat result consumption of one energy drink did not influence iacc is or ie however high a subject reported reduced interoceptive confidence after energy drink intake while hep amplitude did not differ depending on the type of drink high a subject showed reduced heps overall compared to low a subject heart rate wa significantly lower following energy drink consumption a compared to the placebo condition limitation the sample size wa small energy dosage low and physiological parameter should be assessed in more detail conclusion energy drink consumption wa associated with an interoceptive bias in high a individual suggesting possible interaction effect between change in physical state interoception and anxiety

Title: The patient perspective on therapeutic change: The investigation of associations between stages of change and general mechanisms of change in psychotherapy research.
Authors: Mander, Johannes; Wittorf, Andreas; Klingberg, Stefan; Teufel, Martin; Zipfel, Stephan; Sammet, Isa
Abstract: in this study we explored intersection between two influential integrative framework in psychotherapy research specifically we analyzed association between stage of change from prochaska s transtheoretical model and general mechanism of change from grawe s psychological therapy in a longitudinal design our central hypothesis which we could derive from theorectical concept of both framework wa a follows experiential change mechanism emotional bond problem actuation and clarification of meaning should be especially relevant in early stage of change precontemplation and contemplation and behavioral change mechanism resource activation mastery and agreement on collaboration should be especially relevant in late stage of change action and maintenance therefore 253 inpatient completed the university of rhode island change assessment short version urica s the scale for the multiperspective assessment of general change mechanism in psychotherapy sacip and diverse outcome measure in early middle and late stage of psychotherapy crosslagged panel analysis and multilevel analysis partially supported our hypothesis and revealed trend for interactive effect between change mechanism and stage of change in outcome prediction more specifically our result suggest that experience of both experiential and behavioral change mechanism predicted increase in the action stage of change contemplation predicted increase in behavioral change mechanism experience clinical implication of these finding are discussed

Title: Well-Being From the Knife? Psychological Effects of Aesthetic Surgery
Authors: Margraf, Jürgen; Meyer, Andrea H.; Lavallee, Kristen L.
Abstract: many people surgically alter their physical appearance with the intent of boosting their social and psychological well being however the long term effectiveness of aesthetic surgery on improving well being is unconfirmed the present comparison controlled study examines outcome in a sample of 544 patient who underwent aesthetic surgery surgery group and 264 participant who were interested in aesthetic surgery but did not undergo it comparison group participant were followed 3 6 and 12 month after aesthetic surgery or after contacting the clinic comparison overall the result reveal positive outcome of receiving aesthetic surgery across area including anxiety social phobia depression body dysmorphia goal attainment quality of life life satisfaction attractiveness mental and physical health well being self efficacy and self esteem among those dissatisfied with a particular physical feature and considering aesthetic surgery undergoing surgery appears to result in positive self reported psychological change

Title: Psychological Health and Aims of Aesthetic Surgery Seekers
Authors: Margraf, Jürgen; Meyer, Andrea H.; Lavallee, Kristen L.
Abstract: the psychological health of people who elect to surgically alter the embodied self is often questioned this study examines characteristic and goal of 546 people who elect aesthetic surgery compared with 264 people who are interested in it and 1 135 population comparison assessment included demographic attractiveness body image importance depression social phobia joy general health life satisfaction and open ended and standard goal surgery and interested group were more likely than the population to be female and younger have lower income and lower body mass index and have higher body image importance the surgery group reported lower general attractiveness life satisfaction and joy but also lower depression and higher overall health than the general population there were no difference in social phobia overall people obtaining and interested in cosmetic surgery appeared generally psychologically healthy the most frequent goal wa to feel better about in one s own body overtly social or unrealistic goal were uncommon

Title: Emerging Street Youth Violent Groups in Musoma: What is the Role of Individual Parents’ Socio-Economic Status (SES)?
Authors: Masath, Faustine
Abstract: this study present finding regarding violence among emerging street youth violent group in musoma tanzania using a total sample of 94 m 20 02 year sd 4 05 respondent purposefully selected from four violent group specific objective included examining the variation in violence involvement among the violent group establishing the level of relationship between individual parent s and the level of violent behaviour among the member of the violent group and examining to determine if individual parent s is a significant predictor of the development of violence among member of the violent group finding revealed higher level of involvement in violent behaviour among group m 70 85 sd 11 14 the anova result indicated a statistical significant difference f 3 90 6 035 p 0 001 in the mean score of the level of involvement in violent behaviour among the violent group comprised of member drawn from different socio economic status the contribution of parent socio economic status s on individual s violent behaviour measured by multiple regression analysis wa weak r² 112 p 161 thus parent s is a weak and non statistical significant predictor for individual s involvement in violence and violent act thus immediate intervention programme such a establishment of rehabilitation centre and counselling service is recommended
Journal: Mkwawa Journal of Education and Development

Title: Prevalence of and factors contributing to violent discipline in families and its association with violent discipline by teachers and peer violence
Authors: Masath, Faustine Bwire; Nkuba, Mabula; Hecker, Tobias
Abstract: using a multi informant approach we assessed 914 child mean age 12 58 year standard deviation sd 1 43 and 893 caregiver 98 3 per cent female mean age 40 07 year sd 11 46 in tanzania result showed that 93 3 per cent n 828 893 of caregiver reported using violent discipline while 91 0 per cent n 832 914 of the child experienced it in their family further 95 0 per cent n 868 914 and 93 7 per cent n 853 914 of student experienced violent discipline by teacher and peer violence at school respectively in a multilevel path model child s mental health problem standardised regression coefficient β 0 192 ci 0 130 0 255 p 0 001 were associated with their experience of violent discipline in family caregiver own childhood experience of violent discipline 𝛽 0 169 ci 0 105 0 232 p 0 001 their positive attitude towards violent discipline 𝛽 0 228 ci 0 166 0 290 p 0 001 and mental health problem 𝛽 0 175 ci 0 113 0 237 p 0 001 were associated with their use of violent discipline violent discipline in family significantly correlated with violent discipline by teacher correlation coefficient r 0 413 ci 0 354 0 472 p 0 001 and peer violence r 0 354 ci 0 294 0 415 p 0 001 implying child s polyvictimisation

Title: The threat simulation in nightmares—Frequency and characteristics of dream threats in frequent nightmare dreamers.
Authors: Mathes, Jonas; Weiger, Naomi; Gieselmann, Annika; Pietrowsky, Reinhard
Abstract: according to the threat simulation theory the function of dream is to rehearse threatening situation which served an evolutionary advantage for our ancestor furthermore the exposure to waking life threat is thus supposed to lead to an increased occurrence or quality of dream threat aim of

Title: Social comparison modulates acute responses to traumatic footage and the development of intrusive memories
Authors: Meyer, Thomas; Morina, Nexhmedin
Abstract: the psychosocial environment is pivotal for the adjustment to traumatic experience yet the role of social cognition in the development of post traumatic stress disorder ptsd remains obscure we theorize that comparison with other trauma survivor reporting high or low level of stress related symptomatology might attenuate or amplify the development of ptsd depending on perceived similarity with the standard 90 healthy participant viewed traumatic footage and read ostensible testimonial from a fellow participant from a similar background reporting high level of ptsd symptom i e a similar vulnerable social comparator low distress similar resilient or by a demographically dissimilar person reporting low distress different resilient a separate no comparison group n 30 served to gauge the presence of assimilative responding relative to similar vulnerable comparison a similar resilient comparator tended to attenuate acute negative affect but this did not translate to a similar effect on seven day intrusive memory here the similar vulnerable group tended to report fewer intrusive memory compared to control indicating a contrastive response taken together we provide preliminary evidence that social comparison modulates the adjustment to adversity whereby acute affect and intrusion development may be influenced differentially

Title: Individual differences in spatial configuration learning predict the occurrence of intrusive memories
Authors: Meyer, Thomas; Smeets, Tom; Giesbrecht, Timo; Quaedflieg, Conny W. E. M.; Girardelli, Marta M.; Mackay, Georgina R. N.; Merckelbach, Harald
Abstract: the dual representation model of posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd brewin gregory lipton burgess psychological review 117 210 232 2010 argues that intrusion occur when people fail to construct context based representation during adverse experience the present study tested a specific prediction flowing from this model in particular we investigated whether the efficiency of temporal lobe based spatial configuration learning would account for individual difference in intrusive experience and physiological reactivity in the laboratory participant n 82 completed the contextual cuing paradigm which a spatial configuration learning that is believed to depend on associative encoding in the parahippocampus they were then shown a trauma film afterward startle response were quantified during presentation of trauma reminder picture versus unrelated neutral and emotional picture ptsd symptom were recorded in the week following participation better configuration learning performance wa associated with fewer perceptual intrusion r 33 p 01 but wa unrelated to physiological response to trauma reminder image p 46 and had no direct effect on intrusion related distress and overall ptsd symptom r 12 p 29 however configuration learning performance tended to be associated with reduced physiological response to unrelated negative image r 20 p 07 thus while spatial configuration learning appears to be unrelated to affective responding to trauma reminder our overall finding support the idea that the context based memory system help to reduce intrusion

Title: Subjective and Objective Measures of Activity in Depressed and Non-depressed Individuals in Everyday Life
Authors: Michalak, Johannes; Niemeyer, Helen; Tschacher, Wolfgang; Baumann, Nico; Chi Zhang, Xiao; Adolph, Dirk
Abstract: reduced physical activity is considered a key feature of major depressive disorder mdd however research directly comparing non depressed control and patient yielded mixed finding in contrast to most previous research this study compared objective a well a subjective activity level of individual with mdd with non depressed control and used an ambulatory assessment method moreover we investigated whether objective and subjective measure of activity could predict mood on two consecutive day physical activity of 35 mdd patient and 36 non depressed control participant were assessed objectively using an accelerometer and subjectively with hourly ecological momentary assessment during the same assessment participant mood wa monitored no significant difference between mdd patient and control participant in objective and most of the subjective activity measure were observed we found significant association between objective and subjective measure of activity in non depressed a well a in mdd patient objective but not subjective measure of activity predicted subsequent mood our result support the notion that the association between mdd and activity level is complex and depends on moderating factor

Title: Temporal dynamics of partisan identity fusion and prosociality during the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election
Authors: Misch, Antonia; Fergusson, Grant; Dunham, Yarrow
Abstract: we investigated the dynamic of identity fusion and prosocial behavior within political group in the four week preceding and following the 2016 u s presidential election the primary question were whether a negative event losing would lead to a more pronounced increase in identity fusion and whether identity fusion would predict prosocial giving we found that while fusion gradually increased in the run up to the election there wa no significant increase after the event for supporter of either party we also found that identity fusion robustly predicted prosocial ingroup giving especially before the election and even when accounting for self reported identification and previous political commitment behavior implication for theory of identity fusion are discussed

Title: Caregiver-specific factors and orphanage-context factors contributing to maltreatment of children in institutional care: A multi-level analysis of 24 orphanages in Tanzania
Authors: Mkinga, Getrude; Kirika, Anette; Nkuba, Mabula; Mgode, Simeon; Huth, Mira; Hecker, Tobias
Abstract: background high rate of maltreatment and low caregiving quality in institutional care setting have been identified in various low and middle income country many study have focused on child living in institution objective this study investigates the prevalence of maltreatment caregiver specific orphanage context factor and their relation to maltreatment of orphan from the caregiver perspective participant and setting in this cross sectional study 227 caregiver 67 female with a mean age of 36 84 year sd age 12 89 of 24 childcare centre in dar e salaam tanzania participated method the primary outcome wa the maltreatment of child assessed through structured interview of caregiver further information on individual like work related stress and structural variable working condition wa gathered result caregiver work under extreme and exhausting condition with very high caregiver child ratio low salary and almost no possibility to recover result also showed significant difference in the maltreatment level and structural and individual factor e g payment and day of entitlement between the orphanage caregiver s positive attitude towards violence ƒ 2 attitude 0 19 and difficulty in the relationship with child ƒ 2 relationship 0 05 significantly predicted maltreatment with moderate and small effect conclusion the overall poor working condition highlight the urgent need to reduce the caregiver burden in addition to this addressing caregiver positive attitude and improving their interaction competency with child may be a starting point to prevent maltreatment of child further investigation of structural factor contributing to maltreatment is essential to develop recommendation for the improvement and re organization of childcare institution

Title: Psychometric properties of the Session Rating Scale 3.0 in a Spanish clinical sample
Authors: Moggia, Danilo; Niño-Robles, Noelia; Miller, Scott D.; Feixas, Guillem
Abstract: the session rating scale 3 0 sr 3 0 is an ultra brief measure of the therapeutic alliance frequently used to provide feedback to the clinician during the therapeutic process prescott et al 2

Title: Work-anxiety-coping intervention improves work-coping perception while a recreational intervention leads to deterioration: Results from a randomized controlled trial
Authors: Muschalla, Beate
Abstract: abstractwork anxiety are costly and need early intervention the perception of being able to cope with work is a basic requirement for work ability this randomized controlled trial investigates whether a cognitive behavioural work anxiety coping group wag intervention lead to better work coping perception than an unspecific recreational group rg heterogeneous people in medical rehabilitation who were due to return to work were interviewed concerning their work anxiety and either randomly assigned to a wag n 85 or a rg n 95 the participant with an average of 50 year old range 23 64 51 woman 70 worker or employee 25 academic 5 unskilled followed the group intervention for four or six session the perceived work coping wa assessed by self rating inventory for job coping and return intention jocori after each group session although participant had a slight temporary decrease in work coping after group session two from m1 2 47 to m2 2 28 dcohen 22 the
Journal: European Journal of Work and Organizational Psychology

Title: Assessing psychological work demands with an ICF-oriented concept of psychological capacities
Authors: Muschalla, Beate
Abstract: exploring psychological work demand is the basis for preventive or rehabilitative action e g mental hazard analysis or work adjustment can description from employee be useful to describe work demand the latter requires that the work description is not confounded with an affective judgment on the workplace e g work anxiety based on an icf based work capacity concept which is standard in socio medical work ability description we did a study with 124 employee from diverse profession they were investigated concerning their work demand and their mental health status in a structured interview by a state licensed socio medically trained psychotherapist additionally participant filled in a capacity oriented self rating questionnaire on their work demand for discriminant validity purpose participant filled in the short questionnaire for work analysis and a questionnaire on work anxiety result show that different psychological work capacity demand are reported in different professional group the work capacity demand self rating is able to differentiate capacity demand in different professional field
Journal: Gruppe. Interaktion. Organisation. Zeitschrift für Angewandte Organisationspsychologie (GIO)

Title: Work Ability Impairment and Facets of Workplace Perception Are Predictive of Sick Leave Duration in Persons With Work Anxiety
Authors: Muschalla, Beate
Abstract: abstract individual with work anxiety are at risk for long term sick leave and create high cost for society company and their own work biography understanding psychological return to work predictor is important for early reintegration of these person into the work context this longitudinal study for the first time investigates the predictive value of workplace perception and objective work ability impairment for future sick leave duration in person with work anxiety the investigation wa carried out with 103 individual with work anxiety they were of working age and confronted with a return to work situation after somatic illness work ability impairment wa assessed in a structured interview by a state licensed sociomedical specialist using the established mini icf app scale participant completed a questionnaire on their workplace perception kfza the degree of work ability impairment mini icf app wa predictive of longer sick leave a well a workplace perception kfza dimension scope of action social support need for cooperation training and return to work support in person with work anxiety should focus on both work ability impairment and on workplace perception
Journal: Zeitschrift für Arbeits- und Organisationspsychologie A&O

Title: Group therapists: combine alliance building with paying specific attention to the patient’s perception
Authors: Muschalla, Beate
Abstract: abstract in slow open group a well a therapy of le than ten session each group session hold importance patient therapist and co therapist have different perspective and may gain different experience from a group session this study investigates the perspective of patient therapist and co therapist on alliance new insight and therapist technique in the same group session do the three actor perceive these group aspect similarly or differently which group aspect are related with the outcome coping one hundred and forty nine session of a cognitive behaviour therapy group have been investigated patient therapist and co therapist gave rating on their perceived alliance group topic and insight a well a therapist technique competency concerning new insight there wa concordance between patient and co therapist r 211 p lt 05 concerning alliance there wa a concordance between patient and therapist r 327 p lt 01 therapist focusing on alliance building wa associated with lower patient outcome in term of work coping β 391 the quality of therapeutic technique wa the same in group with higher and lower outcome patient perception of whether they felt good in the group session wa explanative for session outcome while therapist perception and context condition supervision number of participant wa not patient therapist and co therapist have different perspective on the same group therapy session patient perception are associated with session outcome a lower session outcome must not be associated with a poor technique performance of the therapist therapist should not only be aware of alliance building and correct technical performance but they must also be aware of patient perception of the group process and outcome key learning aim the present research is the first evaluation of group session aspect and session outcome in rehabilitation patient with work anxiety in slow open group we will learn 1 whether patient therapist and co therapist perception of the same group session are similar or different 2 whether group session that result in worse outcome are different from group session resulting in a better outcome 3 which aspect of the group session are predictive for a better outcome

Title: Prevalence and Correlates of Work-Phobic Anxiety in a National Representative           Sample
Authors: Muschalla, Beate
Abstract: abstract work anxiety is a common mental health problem that is often overlooked and often cause long period of sick leave this is the first representative survey on the distribution of work phobic anxiety in germany of the 2 030 working age participant 18 67 year 7 had increased work phobic anxiety of a moderate 5 with score gt 1 5 2 5 on a scale from 0 4 or high 2 with score gt 2 5 4 degree people with high level of work phobic anxiety reported the longest sick leave duration during the past 12 month 8 week and the most period of unemployment in their professional life the three group were similar in age sex and partnership status people with high work phobic anxiety perceived themselves least competent in almost all dimension of psychological capacity occupational health must consider work phobic anxiety a a specific mental health problem closely linked to work ability problem
Journal: Zeitschrift für Arbeits- und Organisationspsychologie A&O

Title: UNWANTED EFFECTS WITHIN A COGNITIVE BEHAVIORAL THERAPY GROUP IN COMPARISON WITH A RECREATIONAL GROUP - A CLUSTER-RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED TRIAL
Authors: Muschalla, Beate; ; Flöge, Bianka; Linden, Michael
Abstract: group intervention can have negative effect for patient with anxiety disorder stimulus which provoke side effect may be the group setting the content or the interaction between the participant in the group this study is the first to report negative effect from a cognitive behavioral group intervention in comparison with an unspecific recreational group for anxiety patient 107 patient with work related anxiety disorder were randomized to either a cognitive behavioral group therapy work coping group wg or an unspecific group encounter aimed at increasing recreational activity recreational group rg patient completed the unwanted event in group therapy scale ue g scale in the work coping group 41 9 of the patient reported at least one relevant side effect a compared to 28 9 in the recreational group these included an increase in the perception of anxiety and work problem feeling of exposure to criticism and the development of negative view on group therapy a such this is the first randomized controlled therapy study in anxiety patient to systematically investigate side effect work coping group intervention have despite their useful main effect specific negative effect when compared with group encounter group psychotherapist or group moderator should be aware of the potential side effect in anxiety patient

Title: Mental work ability: young professionals with mental health problems perceive lower levels of soft skills
Authors: Muschalla, Beate; Kutzner, Isabel
Abstract: abstract this article published in gruppe interaktion organisation gio report study result on soft skill and mental work ability in young professional ready to enter the job market the so called soft skill psychological capacity are nowadays an entrance ticket into the modern working world thus the question is to which degree young professional who will soon enter the labor market are fit in their soft skill are physical or mental health problem related with deficit in soft skill which dimension of soft skill are impaired 365 young professional in advanced education from a technical college who will soon enter the labor market were investigated via online questionnaire participant were asked to rate their self perceived capacity level according to mini icf app mental and physical health problem exam and education related anxiety self efficacy and procrastination student with mental health problem had higher exam anxiety and lower study related self efficacy a compared to student without health problem at all or student with physical health problem but procrastination behavior wa similarly present among student with mental health problem and student with physical health problem student with health problem did not report globally weaker capacity level lower level of capacity depend on the type of health problem in student with mental health problem social soft skill were impaired rather than content related capacity physical health problem do not affect the self perceived psychological capacity in conclusion focusing on specific soft skill in training and work adjustment could be fruitful in addition or a an alternative to training of profession specific expertise
Journal: Gruppe. Interaktion. Organisation. Zeitschrift für Angewandte Organisationspsychologie (GIO)

Title: Specific event-related data presentation changes embitterment affect - an experimental study
Authors: Muschalla, Beate; Monne, Emilia
Abstract: background during the corona pandemic increased rate of embitterment have been found in the general population a embitterment occurs reactive to trigger related to experienced negative event and a people were steadily exposed to pandemic related information the research question arises can embitterment be triggered by pandemic related information in form of infection rate displayed in figure method within an experimental design we investigated whether a figure presenting infection rate in an aggravated manner seemingly strong infection increase and then stable course experimental group eg n 138 lead to stronger embitterment increase a compared to a figure presenting infection rate seemingly stable control group cg n 155 accompanying characteristic with potential influence on embitterment have been assessed wisdom general belief in a just world perceived injustice event during the pandemic result in contrast to the experimental hypothesis the eg decreased in embitterment after reading the aggravated infection rate figure whereas the cg rested stable people with higher wisdom score had a lower embitterment level after watching the infection data there wa no association between perceived pandemic related injustice event and embitterment after watching the infection data belief in a just world slightly decreased over the course in both group discussion by mean of pandemic related data presentation embitterment affect can be changed contradictory to expectation the aggravated presentation led to a reduction of embitterment this example show that even simple but specific information presentation can induce change in state affect and this happens independently from other relevant characteristic such a perceived injustice event during pandemic or general belief in a just world professional who present event related data in public should explain these data and be aware that information and data presentation may relevantly impact on people affect

Title: Capacities rather than psychopathology or information explain how high school finishers are attracted by academic studies
Authors: Muschalla, Beate; Weimann, Margó
Abstract: the number of academic student ha risen but there are difference between academic study and vocational training the fit of one s capacity to the demand is important for education success this study investigates what contributes to high school student perception of academic study a being highly attractive a total of 108 high school student prefinal class were asked for their last school grade school related anxiety self efficacy procrastination psychomental capacity according to mini icf app s and to which degree academic study were attractive for them a brief informatory description of either vocational training or academic study wa randomly given followed by again asking for the attractiveness perception of study especially high school student with higher achievement in social science who perceive themselves strong in self efficacy and low in procrastination tend to perceive academic study a even more attractive information about the alternative option vocational training doe not change the attractiveness perception
Journal: International Journal of Educational Research Open

Title: Prediction of Therapeutic Outcome in a Naturalistic Setting Using Pretreatment Psychological Distress Indicators
Authors: Mütze, Kaline; Witthöft, Michael; Bräscher, Anne-Kathrin
Abstract: background outcome prediction allow to improve psychotherapy and to increase economic benefit the efficient translation into practice requires simple prediction method the present study evaluates the prediction of treatment outcome based on initial distress level method routine data of a university psychotherapy outpatient clinic were used n 3 145 mage 35 8 67 female low versus high distress patient classified by overall psychological distress symptomatology and previous treatment were compared on total reduction in psychopathology early response remission and premature treatment discontinuation using t test and logistic regression response and remission were assessed via relative percentage improvement and absolute measure reliable change index rci result distress level wa inversely related to percentage improvement or 0 62 and remission or 0 34 it wa positively related to total reduction in psychopathology d 0 63 rci response or 2 37 and treatment discontinuation or 2 15 early response and treatment discontinuation partially mediated the relationship between distress level and treatment outcome conclusion treatment success tends to be lower when initial distress is high but this finding appears contingent on the operationalization of treatment outcome the presented classification approach is easy to implement in practice and may be useful in order to counter an excessive workload in psychotherapy trainee

Title: The effects of a self-esteem manipulation on body dissatisfaction in binge eating disorder
Authors: Naumann, Eva; Tuschen-Caffier, Brunna; Trentowska, Monika; Caffier, Detlef; Svaldi, Jennifer
Abstract: current cognitive behavioral model on the etiology of eating disorder propose low self esteem to be causally linked with body image disturbance thus the aim of the present study wa to experimentally test the influence of state self esteem on actual body dissatisfaction in binge eating disorder bed twenty six woman with bed were assigned to either a positive or negative implicit manipulation of self esteem thereafter participant actual body dissatisfaction and emotion were measured prior to and after a one minute mirror exposure main result reveal that after the negative compared to the positive self esteem manipulation body dissatisfaction wa significantly lower both prior to and after the mirror exposure by contrast no effect of the self esteem manipulation were found on emotional rating in line with prediction by current cognitive behavioral model the result yield some evidence of the deteriorating effect of low self esteem on body dissatisfaction in bed

Title: Trait Worry and Neural Correlates of Emotion 					Regulation
Authors: Neudert, Marie Kristin; Stark, Rudolf; Kress, Laura; Hermann, Andrea
Abstract: abstract pathological worrying is of high transdiagnostic relevance and is related to maladaptive emotion regulation process dysfunctional emotion regulation and it underlying neural mechanism might contribute to the maintenance of fear over time therefore this functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri study aim at investigating the association of trait worry with neural correlate of emotion regulation twenty six healthy female were instructed to passively look at aversive picture to distract themselves with a neutral thought or to down and up regulate negative feeling via cognitive reappraisal in response to repeatedly presented aversive picture trait worry wa not related to cognitive reappraisal but to distraction which lead to a greater reduction of self reported negative feeling and insula activation in individual with higher trait worry the current study indicates that the neural mechanism underlying distraction seem to be altered in pathological worrying and may prevent adaptive emotional processing of aversive stimulus leading to the maintenance of fear

Title: Impact of perceived social support on pain perception in virtual reality
Authors: Neumann, Isabel; Käthner, Ivo; Gromer, Daniel; Pauli, Paul
