Abstract: social influence are important modulators of pain experimental study demonstrated analgesic effect of explicit social support a digital health care gain importance this study investigated influence of social support by virtual character and their perceived agency in virtual reality on pain in a within subject design participant experienced painful heat stimulus in vr either a virtual character provided verbal support prior to the pain stimulus or not support v no support condition in addition participant were instructed that a real human avatar condition or a computer script virtual agent controlled the virtual character however in both condition the virtual character wa computer controlled main outcome measure were pain rating and physiological pain response virtual verbal support affected physiological response in term of stress buffering but not pain rating the agency manipulation wa successful a the avatar yielded higher rating of perceived human likeness helpfulness and realism compared to the virtual agent however agency of the character did not affect pain response this study revealed that virtual verbal support positively influence physiological pain response independently of perceived agency the finding have important clinical implication a virtual interaction and digital health intervention are increasingly relevant for pain treatment participant felt more present in the virtual world with a virtual character social support by a virtual character buffered physiological reaction pain rating were not affected by social support provided of virtual character the perceived agency of the virtual character did not affect pain response

Title: Responsibility, metacognition and unrealistic pessimism in obsessive–compulsive disorder
Authors: Niemeyer, Helen; Moritz, Steffen; Pietrowsky, Reinhard
Abstract: abstract cognitive model stress the importance of cognitive belief domain cbd for the pathogenesis of obsessive compulsive disorder ocd however the relative contribution of responsibility and metacognition core aspect of cbd to oc symptom is not fully understood yet furthermore two subcomponents of overestimation of threat oet overestimation of the personal probability unrealistic pessimism and overestimation of the general risk of negative event require clarification first we investigated the relative contribution of responsibility and metacognition to oc symptom second we hypothesized that ocd patient overestimate the personal risk and display unrealistic pessimism thirty four ocd patient and 34 healthy control completed the obsessive belief questionnaire obq and the unrealistic optimism questionnaire uo responsibility significantly predicted obsessive symptom after controlling for metacognition in contrast to previous finding responsibility is not fully explained by metacognition finally our result confirm unrealistic pessimism in ocd even after controlling for depression
Journal: Journal of Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders

Title: Visual search through displays of data
Authors: Nothelfer, Christine; Franconeri, Steven
Abstract: with the increasing availability and importance of data the human visual system serf a a critical tool for analysis of pattern trend and relation among those data building on recent translational visual search work in domain like baggage screening e g mitroff et al 2015 and radiology e g wolfe 2016 we explored how different way of representing data value can lead to efficient or inefficient visual processing of the relation between the value in a data pair we asked participant to find a particular relation among the opposite relation e g small large value pair among large small under a variety of common and manipulated data encoding method bullet graph one value a a bar the other a a threshold dash through the bar line graph connected dash graph area graph dash graph line placed where the top of bar in a bar graph would be adjacent bar and separated bar display were divided into quadrant containing 1 5 data pair each for a total set size of 4 20 item participant were asked to quickly indicate which quadrant contained the target data pair the choice of data depiction led to enormous difference in processing efficiency for relation between value ranked fast to slow in the order listed above from flat search slope line graph medium search slope of 69 m pair dash graph and severely steep search slope of 115 m pair separated bar graph one of the most ubiquitous encoding type visual search for relation can be strikingly serial but performance can improve substantially with small change to display exploring visual search and relation processing in the context of data visualization display may provide a rich case study for both basic research on the mechanism of search but also concrete guideline for the student and scientist who use vision to process and convey pattern in data meeting abstract presented at v 2017

Title: Hemifield-specific resources for controlling apparent motion
Authors: Nothelfer, Christine; Suzuki, Satoru; Franconeri, Steven
Abstract: the visual hemifields contain processing resource that are substantially independent across a handful of task such a object tracking and extraction of visual statistic we add a new task to this category the ability to control ambiguous apparent motion participant viewed two simultaneous and identical dot quartet animation 300ms frame where each could be perceived a undergoing either vertical or horizontal motion the default percept of such dual animation is to see both quartet move in the same manner and careful mental control is needed to perceive them a moving differently each trial began with a cue for mental control see this quartet moving vertically and that quartet moving horizontally the dependent measure wa the amount of proximity based help making dot closer either vertically or horizontally that a participant needed to add using the method of adjustment before they were confident that they could robustly perceive the cued motion pattern differently across the two quartet this threshold level of needed help wa lower when the quartet straddled the hemifield boundary in the lower visual field mean aspect ratio of 1 1 2 compared to when the quartet were contained entirely within the left or right quadrant of the lower visual field mean aspect ratio of 1 1 3 p 0 05 with eccentricity controlled between condition we speculate that the separate resource that underlie this benefit for apparent motion share root with the resource that bring hemifield benefit for object tracking task more efficient deployment of multiple attentional spotlight across the hemifield boundary meeting abstract presented at v 2015

Title: Emotion-Regulation in Psychosis: Patients with Psychotic Disorders Apply Reappraisal Successfully
Authors: Opoka, Sandra M.; Sundag, Johanna; Riehle, Marcel; Lincoln, Tania M.
Abstract: abstract background emotion regulation is assumed to be impaired in psychosis patient with psychotic disorder pd self report to use reappraisal le frequently than healthy control hc but it is uncertain whether they are also le successful in applying reappraisal moreover it ha not been investigated whether the habitual use of reappraisal is associated with the ability to use reappraisal successfully method to address these question pd n 60 a clinical control group of patient with anxiety disorder ad n 40 and hc n 40 completed questionnaire on habitual emotion regulation and alexithymia performed test on neurocognitive functioning and jumping to conclusion bias and were subjected to an emotion regulation paradigm in which they were asked to down regulate induced anxiety and sadness result no difference were found between pd and hc regarding the habitual use of reappraisal but pd reported to use reappraisal more frequently than ad all group were able to down regulate anxiety and sadness via reappraisal following instruction the habitual use of reappraisal and the reduction of anxiety and sadness after instruction were uncorrelated conclusion these finding question the common assumption that pd use reappraisal le often or le successfully at least under laboratory condition pd do not appear to be impaired in reducing negative affect via reappraisal successfully

Title: Single-item predictive validity of the Short-Term Assessment of Risk and Treatability (START) for violent behaviour in outpatient forensic psychiatry
Authors: Paetsch, Andreas; van Os, Titus W. D. P.; Troquete, Nadine A. C.; van den Brink, Rob H. S.
Abstract: the single item predictive validity of the short term assessment of risk and treatability start ha not been thoroughly investigated although this ha great clinical relevance for the selection
Journal: The Journal of Forensic Psychiatry & Psychology

Title: Social Presence as a Moderator of the Effect of Agent Behavior on Emotional Experience in Social Interactions in Virtual Reality
Authors: Pfaller, Michael; Kroczek, Leon O. H.; Lange, Bastian; Fülöp, Raymund; Müller, Mathias; Mühlberger, Andreas
Abstract: background exposure therapy involves exposure to feared stimulus and is considered to be the gold standard treatment for anxiety disorder while it application in virtual reality vr ha been very successful for phobic disorder the effect of exposure to virtual social stimulus in social anxiety disorder are heterogeneous this difference ha been linked to demand on realism and presence particularly social presence a a pre requisite in evoking emotional experience in virtual social interaction so far however the influence of social presence on emotional experience in social interaction with virtual agent remains unknown objective we investigated the relationship between realism and social presence and the moderating effect of social presence on the relationship between agent behavior and experienced emotion in virtual social interaction method healthy participant n 51 faced virtual agent showing supportive and dismissive behavior in two virtual environment short interaction and oral presentation at first participant performed five block of short one on one interaction with virtual agent two male and two female agent per block secondly participant gave five presentation in front of an audience of 16 agent in each scenario agent behavior wa a within subject factor resulting in one block of neutral two block of negative and two block of positive agent behavior rating of agent behavior valence and realism experience valence and arousal and presence physical and social were collected after every block moderator effect were investigated using mixed linear model with random intercept correlation were analyzed via repeated measure correlation result rating of valence of agent behavior showed reliable relationship with experienced valence and le reliable relationship with experienced arousal these relationship were moderated by social presence in the presentation scenario result for the interaction scenario were weaker but potentially promising for experimental study variation in social presence and realism over time were correlated but social presence proved a more reliable moderator conclusion our finding emphasize the role of social presence for emotional experience in response to specific agent behavior in virtual social interaction while these finding should be replicated with experimental design and in clinical sample variability in social presence might account for heterogeneity in efficacy of virtual exposure to treat social anxiety disorder

Title: Barriers to Seeking Psychotherapy for Mental Health Problems in Adolescents: a mixed method study
Authors: Pfeiffer, Simone; In-Albon, Tina
Abstract: abstract given the large discrepancy between prevalence rate of mental disorder in adolescent and actual treatment rate there is a need to understand what prevents this age group from seeking psychotherapy we assessed the barrier to seeking psychotherapy in this age group including their attitude toward people with a mental disorder using a convergent parallel mixed method design participant were 288 adolescent aged 12 21 year m 16 8 year sd 2 3 37 identified a male 63 a female and 0 a nonbinary qualitative data were obtained with open ended question on barrier to initiating psychotherapy and attitude toward people with a mental disorder barrier to seeking psychotherapy and information about psychotherapy were assessed with a questionnaire using a quantitative design the qualitative assessment revealed a the main barrier fear of a negative interaction with a psychotherapist fear of being confronted with their own emotion self stigma and fear of public stigma further lack of accessibility lack of trust in the therapist a desire for social distance from and a negative attitude toward people with a mental disorder were associated with a decreased intention to initiate psychotherapy previous positive experience with a psychotherapist wa a facilitator of seeking psychotherapy we found gender difference with higher desire for social distance and higher optimism bias score a well a poorer mental health knowledge for participant identifying a male integrating result from both approach result in further information for the improvement of prevention program and intervention to lower barrier to seeking psychotherapy gender difference indicate a need for gender role specific intervention
Journal: Journal of Child and Family Studies

Title: Change of Threat Expectancy as Mechanism of Exposure-Based Psychotherapy for Anxiety Disorders: Evidence From 8,484 Exposure Exercises of 605 Patients
Authors: Pittig, Andre; Heinig, Ingmar; Goerigk, Stephan; Richter, Jan; Hollandt, Maike; Lueken, Ulrike; Pauli, Paul; Deckert, Jürgen; Kircher, Tilo; Straube, Benjamin; Neudeck, Peter; Koelkebeck, Katja; Dannlowski, Udo; Arolt, Volker; Fydrich, Thomas; Fehm, Lydia; Ströhle, Andreas; Totzeck, Christina; Margraf, Jürgen; Schneider, Silvia; Hoyer, Jürgen; Rief, Winfried; Craske, Michelle G.; Hamm, Alfons O.; Wittchen, Hans-Ulrich
Abstract: individual response to behavioral treatment of anxiety disorder vary considerably which requires a better understanding of underlying process in this study we examined the violation and change of threat belief during exposure from 8 484 standardized exposure record of 605 patient with different anxiety disorder learning indicator were derived expectancy violation a mismatch between threat expectancy before exposure and threat occurrence expectancy change a difference between original and adjusted expectancy after exposure and prediction error learning rate a extent to which expectancy violation transferred into change throughout session high threat expectancy but low occurrence and adjusted expectancy indicated successful violation and change of threat belief by exposure expectancy violation change and learning rate substantially varied between patient not expectancy violation itself but higher learning rate and expectancy change predicted better treatment outcome successful exposure thus requires expectancy violation to induce actual expectancy change supporting learning from prediction error a transdiagnostic mechanism underlying successful exposure therapy

Title: Smart-Glass Guided Exposure for Anxiety Disorders: A Proof-of-Concept Study
Authors: Pittig, Andre; Hoyer, Jürgen; Noack, René
Abstract: practicability barrier hinder dissemination of exposure smartglass device may enable therapist to guide exposure from their own office smartglass guided exposure wa positively evaluated adverse event were minimal smartglass guided exposure resulted in strong within session fear reduction exposure is a highly effective treatment for pathological fear and anxiety but rarely used in routine care issue of practicability and lack of therapist in rural area are main barrier for the dissemination of exposure smartglass device may enable therapist to guide exposure from their own office via real time feedback and may thereby increase practicability the present study explored the technological usability and clinical feasibility of smartglass guided exposure in a behavioral approach test in spider fearful individual n 40 fearful individual were asked to start the smartglass themselves and established a connection to a therapist who guided the exposure test from afar clinical severity of spider fear wa assessed via questionnaire technological usability wa assessed with established measure of usability user experience and user acceptance exploratory individual characteristic of exposure were collected e g within session fear reduction duration safety behavior overall fearful individual 94 9 and therapist 100 were able to establish a connection usability of smartglass guided exposure wa evaluated a positive within session fear reduction wa large d 1 91 adverse event were minimal there were however some association between exposure characteristic and usability evaluation e g lower user friendliness and exposure duration two case example further highlight chance and risk of smartglass guided exposure these finding provide first evidence that smartglass guided exposure could be useful in exposure therapy smartglass guided exposure may ultimately help to increase practicability of exposure and increase dissemination also in rural area these finding are promising for future research on the long term outcome of evidence based exposure in treatment seeking patient

Title: Reducing the return of avoidance and fear by directly targeting avoidance: Comparing incentive-based and instructed extinction of avoidance to passive fear extinction
Authors: Pittig, Andre; Wong, Alex H. K.
Abstract: enhancing the reduction of avoidance may optimize treatment for anxiety disorder past research focused on boosting fear extinction to reduce avoidance however with limited success directly extinguishing avoidance may be more promising this preregistered study tested the impact of incentive and instruction for non avoidance compared to passive fear extinction on long term avoidance and fear reduction on day 1 participant acquired conditioned fear and avoidance to a conditioned stimulus c paired with an aversive outcome next incentive or instruction encouraged non avoidance to the c which wa no longer reinforced by a u regardless of avoidance incentive and instruction group in a third group avoidance wa unavailable and the c wa passively presented in absence of the u passive fear extinction group on day 2 avoidance retention and reinstatement and return of fear were tested in the short term incentive and instruction strongly reduced avoidance with similar fear reduction compared to passive fear extinction importantly incentive and instruction were linked to lower long term avoidance retention avoidance reinstatement wa evident in all group but avoidance remained higher after passive fear extinction finally incentive yielded a lower return of threat expectancy thus targeting avoidance instead of fear better reduced long term avoidance and for incentive the return of fear especially incentive could be a promising add on to exposure

Title: Just Deal With It: A Network Analysis of Resilience, Coping, and Sense of Belonging Among Children
Authors: Planert, Jari; Krakowczyk, Julia B.; Godor, Brian P.; Van der Hallen, Ruth
Abstract: when considering developmental psychology three concept stand out 1 resilience the resistance to stress 2 coping the strategy used to reduce stress and 3 sense of belonging the connectedness towards peer although all three concept are important for a child s development the academic literature lack research on the interrelation and interplay between them this study employed network analysis to investigate the interplay between resilience coping and sense of belonging in child three hundred and seventy three child aged 10 12 51 boy 49 girl completed a pen and paper survey including the resiliency scale for child and adolescent rsca coping orientation to problem experienced brief cope and pisa sense of belonging scale result revealed resilience to be associated with both coping and sense of belonging yet weaker association emerged between coping and sense of belonging three striking node pattern of high interconnectedness were revealed that further deepen our understanding of the interplay between these concept implication for research and practice and limitation of the current study are discussed

Title: Interoceptive accuracy does not predict emotion perception in daily life
Authors: Pohl, Anna; Dummel, Sebastian; Bothur, Mascha; Gerlach, Alexander L.
Abstract: abstract peripheral emotion theory suggest a crucial role of interoception for emotion perception which in turn facilitates emotion regulation laboratory study found positive relation between interoceptive accuracy and perceived emotion intensity and arousal study in natural setting are largely missing but seem important by virtue of emotional experience and regulation diversity on hundred seven participant underwent a cardiovascular interoceptive accuracy task afterwards participant provided detailed information on perceived emotion and emotion regulation strategy in an ecological momentary assessment ema multilevel model were calculated in consideration of valence emotion intensity arousal intensity of body sensation and emotion regulation success were modeled a a function of centered interoceptive accuracy interoceptive accuracy did not predict any emotion perception criterion lower accuracy wa related to a slightly stronger decrease of perceived arousal after regulation difference in emotion category intensity and sample collection might explain divergence to laboratory study

Title: Training-related changes of brain activation for speech production in healthy speakers – a longitudinal fMRI study to mimic aphasia therapy
Authors: Pohl, Anna; Meyer, Corinna Maria; Deckers, Annika; Eckmann, Teresa; Barthel, Joachim; Huber, Walter; Habel, Ute; Willmes, Klaus; Abel, Stefanie
Abstract: abstractbackground re learning of lexical entry is fundamental to rehabilitation of the common word finding deficit in language disorder after brain damage previous study examined and compared neural correlate of speech production and word learning in aphasic and healthy speaker but longitudinal control study were rarely set out to mimic the lexical confusion and therapeutic remediation in aphasia aim thus we aimed to examine functional brain organisation before familiar word naming during learning phase and after consolidation phase standardised training of speech production modulated by aphasia therapy method procedure during the first functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri measurement participant were asked to name picture using familiar word during learning and in the consolidation phase they were asked to name picture using newly acquired pseudowords to examine differential involvement of brain area dependent on learning and consolidation success we followe

Title: Annoyance of residents induced by wind turbine obstruction lights: A cross-country comparison of impact factors
Authors: Pohl, Johannes; Rudolph, David; Lyhne, Ivar; Clausen, Niels-Erik; Aaen, Sara Bjørn; Hübner, Gundula; Kørnøv, Lone; Kirkegaard, Julia K.
Abstract: larger wind turbine are developed to harvest greater amount of wind energy this development increase the dilemma between ensuring aviation safety through obstruction light and reducing citizen annoyance and possible stress effect caused by obstruction light in this study a unique danish sample is contrasted with a combined german swiss sample stronger stress effect due to the light for the danish sample compared to the german swiss study were found an issue that could be related to the specific technical and site condition the prevalence of strongly annoyed resident wa low significant factor for predicting obstruction light annoyance stress were identified including perceived fairness consideration of the interest of the community landscape change annoyance stress number of visible wind turbine and age it is recommended to enhance the planning process to reduce the stress among citizen e g through improved communication and to enhance the participation of resident in a way that allows for a meaningful consideration of people s concern stress effect from obstruction light at wind turbine are assessed obstruction light can induce strong stress effect under certain condition perceived fairness and stress during planning process are significant predictor distance to wind turbine is not correlated with obstruction light annoyance stress

Title: Contextual cueing in older adults: Slow initial learning but flexible use of distractor configurations
Authors: Preuschhof, Claudia; Sharifian, Fariba; Rosenblum, Lisa; Pohl, Tanja Maria; Pollmann, Stefan
Abstract: learned spatial regularity can efficiently guide visual search this effect ha been extensively studied using the contextual cueing paradigm we investigated age related change in the initial l

Title: Usability and applicability of a mindfulness based online intervention developed for people with problematic internet gaming behavior
Authors: Reichrath, Benedict; Pietrowsky, Reinhard
Abstract: in this study the usability and applicability of a mindfulness based online administered gamified short term intervention for people suffering from internet gaming disorder is investigated in a subclinical sample n nbsp nbsp 49 within a four week intervention program room2respawn participant were randomly allocated to a gamified condition experimental or a neutral condition control participant were provided with three intervention session per week consisting of psychoeducation on internet gaming disorder and mindfulness exercise most of the intervention content ha been adopted from a group therapy intervention to an online platform the 39 nbsp participant who participated over the course of the whole intervention rated the usability of the online intervention overall and across all measure a good or very good there wa no evidence for beneficial effect of gamification on motivation when compared with rating from a control condition area of improvement and study limitation are discussed due to an easy applicability and very good usability room2respawn show potential to develop into a low threshold treatment option which after rework need to be put to test on a sample showing clinical symptom of pathological internet gaming nbsp key word mindfulness internet gaming gamification internet gaming disorder usability applicability
Journal: International Journal of Psychology and Counselling

Title: M120. Negative Functional Outcomes of Diminished Emotional Expression in Schizophrenia: The Case of Smiling in Face-To-Face Interactions
Authors: Riehle, Marcel; Mehl, Stephanie; Lincoln, Tania Marie
Abstract: abstract background diminished facial expressiveness is a consistent finding in schizophrenia which appears to be most pronounced for positive facial expression ie smiling a an affiliative signal smiling ha the potential to be a behavioral marker of negative symptom and could be associated with functional outcome however most study investigated facial expression in people with schizophrenia in nonaffiliative context and rarely in face to face interaction furthermore only few study have looked at the social consequence of reduced facial expressiveness we hypothesized that people with schizophrenia in an affiliative face to face interaction 1 would display le smiling than control and that 2 low expressive patient compared to high expressive patient would exhibit more negative symptom lower social competence and receive more negative social evaluation method the sample consisted of 52 patient with a schizophrenia spectrum disorder and 39 healthy control all participant engaged in an affiliative role play with a study confederate independent set of raters then coded these interaction for the amount of smiling using the facial expression coding system face kring sloan 2007 social competence and desire for future interaction with the participant moreover in the patient sample we assessed psychotic symptom depressive symptom and social role functioning with structured interview we performed a median split within the patient sample distinguishing low and high expressive patient with respect to amount of smiling and tested for difference between the resulting group on all dependent measure we also tested for difference between the 2 patient group and control where measure were available result compared to control participant with a schizophrenia spectrum disorder exhibited significantly lower level of smiling d 0 56 significantly lower social competence d 0 68 and were evaluated a le desirable for future interaction d 0 58 however only participant in the low but not in the high expressive patient group differed from control on these 3 variable low expressive patient differed from high expressive patient with respect to negative symptom d 0 72 social functioning d 0 63 social competence d 0 66 and desire for future interaction d 0 80 no difference between the 2 patient group were found on other symptom dimension eg positive disorganized depression any sample characteristic and medication dose conclusion our finding corroborate emerging evidence suggesting that diminished smiling behavior in schizophrenia is a behavioral substrate of negative symptom in face to face interaction and indicative of negative functional outcome our result highlight the need for developing treatment that foster affiliative interaction skill in schizophrenia

Title: Time Course of Error-Potentiated Startle and its Relationship to Error-Related Brain Activity
Authors: Riesel, Anja; Weinberg, Anna; Moran, Tim; Hajcak, Greg
Abstract: error are aversive motivationally salient event which prime defensive action this is reflected in a potentiated startle reflex after the commission of an error the current study replicates and extends previous work examining the time course of error potentiated startle a a function of startle lag i e 300 m or 800 m following correct and error response in addition the relationship between error potentiated startle and error related brain activity in both the temporal error related negativity ern ne and spectral error related theta and delta power domain wa investigated event related potential erps were recorded from 32 healthy undergraduate while they performed an arrowhead version of a flanker task complex morlet wavelet were applied to compute oscillatory power in the delta and theta band range consistent with our previous report startle wa larger following error furthermore this effect wa evident at both early and late startle probe time increased delta and theta power after an error wa associated with larger error potentiated startle an association between ern amplitude and error potentiated startle wa only observed in a subgroup of individual with relatively large ern ne amplitude among these individual ern ne magnitude wa also related to multiple index of task performance this study further support the notion that error are aversive event that prime defensive motivation and that error potentiated startle is evident beyond the immediate commission of an error and can be predicted from error related brain activity

Title: Rejection sensitivity as a mediator of the relationship between experienced rejection and borderline characteristics
Authors: Rosenbach, Charlotte; Renneberg, Babette
Abstract: experienced rejection rejection sensitivity and borderline trait were examined rejection sensitivity mediated the relation between rejection and borderline trait social support wa identified a additional significant mediator we hypothesize rejection sensitivity to be a crucial factor in the etiology of bpd experience of rejection in childhood play an important role in the etiology of borderline personality disorder bpd additionally individual who report borderline symptom report high level of rejection sensitivity the current study aimed to disentangle the relationship between experience of rejection rejection sensitivity and borderline characteristic therefore we retrospectively assessed experience of parental and peer rejection collected data of self reported rejection sensitivity and social support and prospectively investigated borderline characteristic in a sample of 193 student result indicated that rejection sensitivity fully mediated the previously significant relationship between experience of parental rejection and borderline characteristic whereas peer rejection maintained a significant effect on borderline trait social support wa identified a a protective factor result indicated a crucial role of rejection sensitivity in borderline symptomatology

Title: Characterizing the dynamic stress response on neuroendocrine and neural network level
Authors: Sandner, Magdalena; Lois, Giannis; Wessa, Michèle
Abstract: this paper illustrates the investigation of higher scale interconnected wind turbine to realize it analytical design and simulation performance in term of reduced order model the present research is aimed to visualize the efficacy of the propounded harris hawk optimization hho approach for different reduced order transfer function with reference to model order reduction study compared to the higher scale model the applied methodology aim to obtain better result in term of steadiness and computational effort moreover to realize a higher dimensional power system the implementation of the hho may proffer more effectiveness and robustness a opposed to the state of the art optimization technique the applied methodology aim to obtain better result in term of stability and computational effort furthermore to realize a higher dimensional system implementation of the hho may offer more effectiveness and robustness a opposed to the state of the art optimization technique

Title: Stress immunization? Hair cortisol predicts blunted reactivity to an acute stressor
Authors: Sandner, Magdalena Eva; Lois, Giannis; Zeier, Peter; Wessa, Michèle
Abstract: 22q11 2 deletion syndrome 22q11ds is a genetic disorder associated with neurodevelopmental anxiety and mood disorder a well a an increased risk for developing psychosis cortisol level and stress reactivity reflect hypothalamic pituitary adrenal hpa axis activity and are believed to be altered in individual that often experience daily life stress depression and psychotic symptom however it is unknown whether individual with 22q11ds display an altered stress reactivity we included 27 adult with 22q11ds mean age 34 1 year 67 female and 24 age and sex matched healthy control hc mean age 39 9 year 71 female into an experience sampling study throughout 6 consecutive day we measured participant subjective stress related to current activity and at the same time collected salivary cortisol sample multilevel regression model were used to analyze cortisol reactivity to activity related stress diurnal cortisol level were significantly lower in the 22q11ds group compared to hcs b 1 03 p 0 001 22q11ds adult displayed significantly attenuated cortisol reactivity to activity related stress compared to hcs b 0 04 p 0 026 post hoc exploratory analysis revealed that these result were independent from 22q11ds psychiatric diagnosis or medication use these result indicate that adult with 22q11ds have lower cortisol level and attenuated cortisol response to daily stress possibly resulting from an increased sensitization of the hpa axis this suggests that alteration in hpa axis functioning previously reported in several psychiatric disorder including post traumatic stress disorder ptsd psychotic disorder and mood disorder also appear to be present in adult with 22q11ds

Title: Inhibitory Learning-Based Exposure Therapy for Patients With Pathological Health Anxiety: Results From a Single Case Series Study
Authors: Sauer, Karoline S.; Bailer, Josef; Jungmann, Stefanie M.; Witthöft, Michael
Abstract: exposure to illness related stimulus is a crucial component of cbt for pathological health anxiety modern exposure approach focus on forming inhibitory association and provide promising result an implementation in the treatment of pathological health anxiety is still missing the present single case series study investigated the applicability and effect of an inhibitory learning based exposure approach 12 session on health anxiety safety behavior and tolerance for aversive state in n 7 outpatient age m 35 14 sd 8 43 with a dsm 5 illness anxiety disorder or somatic symptom disorder with predominant health worry in multilevel model a high intervention satisfaction and little adverse effect were reported a significant ly steepened reduction of health anxiety b 0 10 pbaseline 001 ppre intervention 003 and body checking behavior b 0 14 pbaseline pre intervention 001 and a significant increase in distress tolerance b 0 07 pbaseline 02 ppre intervention 004 discomfort tolerance b 0 11 pbaseline pre intervention 001 and insecurity tolerance b 0 13 pbaseline pre intervention 001 were observed during the intervention in comparison to the baseline and pre intervention phase the present study provided first evidence that the principle of inhibitory learning can be effectively applied to the exposure based treatment of pathological health anxiety

Title: Inhibitory Learning versus Habituation in an Experimental Exposure Intervention for People With Heightened Health Anxiety: Increase of Distress Tolerance as a Joint Mechanism of Change?
Authors: Sauer, Karoline S.; Witthöft, Michael
Abstract: the inhibitory learning theory ilt craske et al 2008 changed the focus of exposure based treatment from erasing excitatory association and fear reduction habituation ha to reinforcing inhibitory association and fear toleration inhibitory learning il study which directly compare both approach il versus ha are scarce the present study aimed at implementing and comparing an il based n 26 age m 23 59 sd 4 38 with a ha based n 28 age m 25 46 sd 6 22 experimental exposure approach including in vivo interoceptive and in sensu exposure in a sample of people with heightened health anxiety a significant pre to post intervention reduction of state health anxiety p lt 001 which wa especially associated with an increase of distress tolerance dt pre to post exposure f 1 50 12 2 p lt 001 η p 2 20 wa observed a superiority of the il based over the ha based exposure intervention wa not detected in relation to major outcome e g state health anxiety a well a in relation to a change of dt the present study underline the importance of strengthening dt for heightened health anxiety during an exposure based intervention

Title: The executive functioning of Burundian refugee youth: Associations with individual, family and community factors
Authors: Scharpf, Florian; Mueller, Sven C.; Hecker, Tobias
Abstract: executive functioning ef may be important for refugee youth s long term adjustment the current study examined association between factor on different ecological level individual family community and inhibitory control ic working memory wm cognitive flexibility cf and selective attention sa among 226 burundian youth aged between 7 and 15 in three refugee camp multiple regression model revealed positive association between trauma exposure and cf and between posttraumatic stress symptom and sa and wm having more sibling father socioeconomic status and a better father child relationship were related to better ef including higher sa and wm higher level of maltreatment by mother were related to lower ic higher peer support wa related to higher wm being orphaned child s emotional and behavioral problem mother education community violence and the type of camp established v new were not significantly related to child s ef the finding underscore the importance of proximal social factor for child s ef father socioeconomic status and father child relationship quality were positively related to youth s executive skill having more sibling and supportive friend wa related to higher working memory maltreatment by mother wa associated with lower inhibitory control intervention promoting socioeconomic condition and father involvement may foster refugee youth s executive functioning

Title: The impact of social relationships on Ugandan children’s sharing decisions
Authors: Scharpf, Florian; Paulus, Markus; Wörle, Monika
Abstract: abstractrecent study provided evidence for an impact of social relation on preschool child s sharing behavior child have been shown to be more generous towards friend than nonfriends or stranger a evidence come largely from study with western child little is known about cross cultural difference and commonality in this pattern here we show that preschool and elementary school aged ugandan child show high level of generosity independent of the social relationship with the recipient this finding point to societal difference in early sharing the result are discussed in term of a formative impact of cultural tradition on the early development of sharing in the preschool year

Title: Nightmares and Associations with Sleep Quality and Self-Efficacy among University Students
Authors: Schlarb, Angelika A
Abstract: sleep problem are a common complaint among adult in university student international study showed prevalence rate between 4 7 and 36 2 for sleep difficulty and 2 3 of student report nightmare previous study show that nightmare are often associated with insomnia and mental strain but also with gender the goal of this study wa to outline nightmare association with sleep disturbance and mental strain a well a self efficacy among university student an amount of 2196 student 70 9 woman mean age 24 16 year participated in the study sleep characteristic nightmare mental strain and self efficacy were assessed by self report questionnaire analysis revealed that more than 24 3 of surveyed student suffered from nightmare 18 5 reported nightmare more often than once a week and 5 8 suffered from nightmare at least 3 time a week moreover nightmare were associated with symptom of insomnia and low self efficacy wa significantly associated with an increased rate of nightmare besides a total of 52 of student reported fitful sleep
Journal: Journal of Sleep Disorders and Management

Title: Telephone Support in an Internet-Based Treatment for Sleep Problems in Early Childhood
Authors: Schlarb, Angelika A; Brandhorst, Isabel; Peters, Elisabeth; Hautzinger, Martin
Abstract: study background mild to severe sleep problem are reported in 3 to 56 of young child behaviourbased treatment are highly effective in improving child s sleep the purpose of this work wa to examine the efficacy of an internet based intervention for young child s sleep disturbance mini kiss online and to a the effect of telephone support for parent method two intervention condition written information with or without additional weekly telephone support were compared to a waiting list control condition n 199 parent with their child aged 6 63 month were randomly assigned to one of the study condition the treatment consisted of six written information module based on a cognitive behavioural approach one of the treatment group had additional weekly telephone support data of sleep diary parental behaviour cbcl 1 5 5 pre post 3 month follow up and treatment evaluation were collected result acceptance of mini kiss online wa high child in both treatment condition showed significant increase in sleep efficacy and reduction in sleep onset latency duration of night waking or subjective global rating while there wa no or le change in the control condition parent of both treatment condition reduced their parental presence and physical contact to the child a benefit of personal assistance wa found for treatment evaluation and dropout rate conclusion mini kiss online is an effective and highly accepted internet based intervention to reduce sleep problem in young child personal telephone assistance counted for higher satisfaction and lower dropout but not for further improvement of the sleep behaviour of the child

Title: Infatuation and Lovesickness on Sleep Quality and Dreams in Adolescence
Authors: Schlarb, Angelika A.; Brock, Nathalie; Nussbeck, Fridtjof W.; Claßen, Merle
Abstract: background infatuation and lovesickness are widespread and significant experience in adolescence le is known about the connection between infatuation lovesickness and sleep the few study examining the link between infatuation and sleep quality show inconsistent result the link between lovesickness and sleep a well a the link between infatuation lovesickness and dream ha not been investigated yet the aim of this study wa to examine whether infatuation and lovesickness are linked to sleep quality and dream in adolescent method a self assessment online questionnaire wa constructed to a adolescent infatuation lovesickness sleep quality and dream in total data of 630 adolescent and young adult 150 male 480 female aged 16 21 were analyzed in this study result infatuation did not relate to overall sleep quality and dream sleep disturbance a a component of overall sleep quality were more frequent in infatuated adolescent adolescent currently suffering from lovesickness reported a significantly lower sleep quality more negative dream and nightmare furthermore nightmare influenced them more strongly the next day conclusion the association between infatuation lovesickness and sleep provide evidence for the far reaching effect of infatuation and lovesickness in adolescent life the fact that lovesickness lead to lower sleep quality and more negative dream should be integrated in new approach of insomnia treatment

Title: Did You Sleep Well, Darling?—Link between Sleep Quality and Relationship Quality
Authors: Schlarb, Angelika Anita; Claßen, Merle; Schuster, E.-S.; Neuner, Frank; Hautzinger, Martin
Abstract: background relationship quality and sleep quality influenced physiological and psychological health therefore the aim of the present study wa to determine a possible connection between relationship satisfaction and sleep quality and to test a theoretical model of sleep quality a related to relationship and psychological well being method fifty one heterosexual cohabitating couple between 24 and 70 year old participated the relationship quality wa measured by the german short version of relationship questionnaire to determine the sleep quality the pittsburgh sleep quality index and a two week sleep diary were implemented to gather information about psychological well being especially depression and anxiety the german symptom checklist wa used result sleep quality wa measured by the pittsburgh sleep quality index and relationship quality correlated significantly negative in addition the study found a positive correlation between sleep duration and relationship quality in a multiple regression model fighting and mental strain explained 38 of variance of sleep quality depression anxiety and relationship quality showed no further improvement of the model these finding suggested that relationship quality constructive partnership behavior and mental strain played an essential role in sleep quality

Title: Sleep Duration and Sleep Problems in a Representative Sample of German Children and Adolescents
Authors: Schlarb, Angelika A.; Gulewitsch, Marco D.; Weltzer, Victoria; Ellert, Ute; Enck, Paul
Abstract: objective the main purpose of the present study wa to evaluate sleep duration for nighttime sleep from early infancy to late adolescence in a german sample to illustrate the developmental course and age specific variability of these variable among subject method a total of 17 641 subject from the kiggs study were evaluated the questionnaire contained question about physical health living circumstance health behavior and risk health supply mental health health related quality of life and sleep kiggs assessed sleep by using parent questionnaire of child aged 0 to 10 year n 9944 and self report of adolescent n 7697 aged 11 to 17 year result total sleep duration decreased from 14 28 hour sd 2 33 at the age 0 0 5 to 9 50 hour sd 0 82 at the age of 10 5 11 above the age of 11 adolescent report a decrease of sleep at night from 9 41 hour sd 1 33 at the age of 11 11 5 to 7 42 sd 1 73 at the age of 17 5 18 year unspecified sleep problem were reported of 19 5 13 0 of the child had difficulty falling asleep difficulty sleeping through the night showed 8 8 of the child whereas 3 0 report both symptom difficulty falling asleep and difficulty sleeping through the night conclusion age specific variability of sleep duration is reported a well a sleep difficulty from infancy to adolescence this is important knowledge for the health care professional who deal with sleep problem in pediatric practice

Title: Can Gender Differences in Distress Due to Difficult Voices Be Explained by Differences in Relating?
Authors: Schlier, Björn; Sitara, Xenia; Strauss, Clara; Rammou, Aikaterini; Lincoln, Tania M.; Hayward, Mark
Abstract: abstract background research on gender difference ha found that woman relate to negative voice hearing experience with more negative emotion and report more distress due to voice which may be rooted in difference in relating to voice this study used a robust methodology and a large sample to explore gender difference in relating to voice and voice distress method matched sample of male n 124 and female n 124 voice hearer were drawn from a survey for secondary analysis voice severity e g frequency or loudness voice distress and different type of dysfunctional i e passive or aggressive and functional assertive relating were measured group comparison mediation model and network analysis were calculated result female voice hearer reported more severe voice more voice distress more passive and le assertive relating mediation and network analysis yielded evidence for pathway from gender to voice distress via relating and via difference in voice severity conclusion gender difference in the emotional impact of voice can be partially explained by relating behavior psychological intervention for voice hearing could be optimized by exploring the influence of gender in the emergence of distressing voice nevertheless gender difference need to be treated a one of several different possible mechanism when working with individual patient

Title: Why are you so slow? – Misattribution of transmission delay to attributes of the conversation partner at the far-end
Authors: Schoenenberg, Katrin; Raake, Alexander; Koeppe, Judith
Abstract: abstract this study address the question of how transmission delay affect user perception during speech communication over telephone system it aim to show that the occurrence of pure delay should not be neglected when planning a telephone or conferencing system even if no impact on the perceived quality of the call can be found it is for instance known that the communication surface structure change dramatically when transmission delay is inserted by the communication system furthermore study suggest a change in the perception of the interlocutor at the far end this paper describes two experiment that a the misattribution of the technical impairment delay to personality and behavior related attribute of the conversation partner the first experiment show that interlocutor are perceived a being le attentive when conversing in a three party setting with symmetrical and asymmetrical delay condition in the second experiment the misattribution is considered in more detail looking at ascribed personality attribute in two party interaction under transmission delay for both experiment comparing the conversation surface structure of delayed to non delayed call helped to understand the found outcome

Title: The Effect of Patient Progress Feedback on Psychotherapy Outcome
Authors: Schöttke, Henning; Unrath, Michael; Uhlmann, Christina
Abstract: lt b gt lt i gt background lt i gt lt b gt there is evidence that outpatient psychotherapy is effective in treating mental disorder however 5 10 of the patient get worse during treatment lt b gt lt i gt patient and method lt i gt lt b gt this randomised controlled trial investigates the effect of systematic feedback of patient progress to therapist on the outcome of psychotherapy a total of 230 adult patient were randomly assigned to three condition progress monitoring with feedback progress monitoring without feedback no progress monitoring subsequently they were treated with cognitive behavioral therapy in an outpatient clinic feedback wa based on three self report questionnaire questionnaire for the evaluation of psychotherapeutic change fep 2 outcome questionnaire oq 30 and assessment for signal case asc variance analysis with repeated measurement were conducted to verify whether feedback enhances treatment outcome lt b gt lt i gt result lt i gt lt b gt there were no statistical difference between the three condition with regard to sociodemographic and disease relevant variable patient impairment improved significantly in all three group but there were no significant difference between group moreover feedback had no differential effect on patient without initial improvement n 49 lt b gt lt i gt discussion and conclusion lt i gt lt b gt in our study collective patient progress feedback to therapist had neither a global nor a differential effect on treatment outcome in order to better demonstrate a potential feedback effect future study should aim for a higher frequency of feedback measure therapist attitude towards such feedback system and use clinical support tool

Title: Cognitive and emotional empathy in typically developing children: The influence of age, gender, and intelligence
Authors: Schwenck, Christina; Göhle, Bettina; Hauf, Juliane; Warnke, Andreas; Freitag, Christine M.; Schneider, Wolfgang
Abstract: in the current study the influence of age gender and iq on cognitive and emotional empathy in school aged child and adolescent wa examined adopting two behavioural paradigm participant were shown film clip with different scene of social interaction to which they were asked to respond thus 134 child aged seven to 17 year mean age 138 4 month sd 31 66 month were tested for emotion recognition perspective taking and emotional empathy age strongly influenced component of cognitive empathy and explained 33 5 to 39 1 of the variance gender and iq also were significant predictor yet only explained 3 to 5 respectively 8 to 9 of the variance in contrast neither age gender nor iq were related to emotional empathy result suggest developmental maturation of cognitive but not emotional empathy throughout childhood and adolescence to explain variability in emotional empathy additional biological and psychosocial factor need to be studied

Title: A new diagnostic tool for children with sleep disorders
Authors: Schwerdtle, B.; Kanis, J.; Kahl, L.; Kübler, A.; Schlarb, A.A.
Abstract: backgroundin addition to a parental evaluation the diagnosis of childhood sleep disorder should include a child s own assessment of sleep behavior in order to address the lack of self rating instrument for the assessment of sleep in young child a new self assessment tool wa developed the child s sleep comic here we present the first validation data

Title: How to Change Negative Outcome Expectations in Psychotherapy? The Role of the Therapist’s Warmth and Competence
Authors: Seewald, Anna; Rief, Winfried
Abstract: negative outcome expectation of psychological treatment predict unfavorable treatment outcome therefore therapist should approach negative outcome expectation and ideally transform them into more positive outcome expectation in this study we investigated the therapist s interpersonal behavior to optimize the modification of negative outcome expectation after inducing negative expectation in an online experiment we presented different video of therapist patient interaction to violate the induced negative outcome expectation we kept the expectation violating information constant and manipulated the therapist s warmth and competence result confirmed a significant influence of the therapist s warmth and competence on expectation violation which led to the most positive outcome expectation when the therapist wa both warm and competent in contrast to former correlational analysis our experimental study confirms the causal role of the therapist s interpersonal behavior and it impact on changing patient negative outcome expectation on the basis of these finding more powerful approach to optimize critical outcome expectation can be developed

Title: The interplay of interoceptive accuracy, facets of interoceptive sensibility, and trait anxiety: A network analysis
Authors: Slotta, Timo; Witthöft, Michael; Gerlach, Alexander L.; Pohl, Anna
Abstract: interoception is the sense of the body s physiological state both the ability to accurately perceive bodily signal and the self reported sensibility for the body were assumed to be reciprocally associated with negative affect up to now the specific interplay between dimension of interoception and negative affect remains largely unknown we investigated the interplay of cardioceptive accuracy assessed by a heartbeat tracking task facet of interoceptive sensibility a measured by the multidimensional assessment of interoceptive awareness and trait anxiety a measured by the trait version of the state trait anxiety inventory across two study n 243 using a network analytic approach the resulting network structure suggested a relationship between interoceptive sensibility and trait anxiety through the tendency to evaluate one s own body a trustworthy interoceptive accuracy showed no considerable association to other variable the finding question the relevance of cardiac interoceptive accuracy for trait anxiety in healthy population association of several interoceptive variable and trait anxiety ta were studied central and marginal facet of interoceptive sensibility is were identified is and ta were negatively linked over the appraisal of the own body a trustworthy cardioceptive accuracy showed no relevant association with facet of is or ta

Title: Stereotyping of Muslims in Germany: How the Presumed Influence of Media Stereotypes on Others Influences Attitudes and Behavioral Intentions Toward Muslims
Authors: Sommer, Katharina; Kühne, Rinaldo
Abstract: the study investigates the influence of medium stereotype on the degree of presumed medium influence on others and the resulting effect for people s own attitude toward a minority we examine how the presumption of negative effect of medium stereotype on others can lead to a correction of one s own attitude toward muslim in an online experiment we test the relationship among medium stereotyping presumed medium effect and attitudinal and behavioral consequence the result show that one s own attitude toward muslim is corrected when people presume a negative influence of medium stereotype about muslim on other people

Title: Metta-Based Therapy for Chronic Depression: a Wait List Control Trial
Authors: Stangier, Ulrich; Frick, Artjom; Thinnes, Isabel; Arens, Elisabeth A.; Hofmann, Stefan G.
Abstract: abstract objective current treatment for chronic depression have focused on reducing interpersonal problem and negative affect but paid little attention to promoting prosocial motivation and positive affect following this treatment focus the objective of the present study wa to examine whether the combination of metta loving kindness group meditation and subsequent tailored individual therapy focusing on kindness towards oneself and others metta based therapy mbt show greater improvement in depressive symptom than a wait list control group in patient with chronic depression method forty eight patient with dsm 5 persistent depressive disorder were randomly assigned to mbt or a wait list control condition outcome wa assessed after group meditation after subsequent individual therapy and at 6 month follow up the primary outcome measure wa an independent blind rating of depressive symptom at post test secondary outcome included change in self reported depression behavioral activation rumination social functioning mindfulness compassion and clinician rated emotion regulation result mixed design analysis showed significant difference between mbt and wlc in change from pre to post test in clinician rated and self rated depression behavioral activation rumination social functioning mindfulness and emotion regulation most of the change occurred during group meditation and were associated with large effect size improvement were maintained at 6 month follow up conclusion the result provide preliminary support for the effectiveness of mbt in treating chronic depression trial registration isrctn isrctn97264476

Title: Predictors for (Problematic) Use of Internet Sexually Explicit Material: Role of Trait Sexual Motivation and Implicit Approach Tendencies Towards Sexually Explicit Material
Authors: Stark, Rudolf; Kruse, Onno; Snagowski, Jan; Brand, Matthias; Walter, Bertram; Klucken, Tim; Wehrum-Osinsky, Sina
Abstract: abstractproblematic use of internet sexually explicit material sem is thought to be a possible precursor of a clinically relevant disorder labeled a hypersexuality sexual compulsion sexual impulse control disorder or sexual addiction knowledge about possible risk factor for developing a problematic internet sem use is scarce the present study investigated whether trait sexual motivation and implicit approach tendency towards sexual material are predictor of problematic sem use and of the daily time spent watching sem trait sexual motivation describes the general individual motivation to be sexually active in a long lasting trait like perspective and can be measured by the trait sexual motivation questionnaire in a behavioral experiment we used the approach avoidance task aat for measuring implicit approach tendency towards sexual material symptom of problematic internet sem use were assessed by the short internet addiction test modified for cybersex trait sexual motivation explaine

Title: Is a High Association Between Repetitive Negative Thinking and Negative Affect Predictive of Depressive Symptoms? A Clustering Approach for Experience-Sampling Data
Authors: Stefanovic, Mina; Rosenkranz, Tabea; Ehring, Thomas; Watkins, Edward R.; Takano, Keisuke
Abstract: a reciprocal relationship between repetitive negative thinking rnt and negative affect na ha been found in various type of psychopathology recent study have suggested that the magnitude of this association can vary across time and individual which may inform future psychopathology here we explored how these dynamic and interplay are manifested in student and general population using a statistical clustering algorithm across three experience sampling data set our clustering analysis consistently identified two group of individual one group had a higher bidirectional association between rnt and na and also higher inertia than the other group furthermore a prospective analysis revealed that the group with the higher bidirectional association is at risk of developing depressive symptom during the 3 month follow up period if they had experienced high level of na over the experience sampling phase these finding suggest that the dysfunctional affective and cognitive dynamic would be a promising target of preventive intervention

Title: Multidimensional perfectionism and the ICD-11 personality disorder model
Authors: Stricker, Johannes; Flett, Gordon L.; Hewitt, Paul L.; Pietrowsky, Reinhard
Abstract: the international classification of disease 11th revision icd 11 contains a dimensional model of personality disorder beyond general personality dysfunction this model accommodates six personality descriptor depicting maladaptive personality characteristic perfectionism is a well researched multidimensional personality disposition with strong link to psychological maladjustment yet it is unclear how multidimensional perfectionism is conceptually and empirically represented in the icd 11 in this questionnaire study we assessed relation between the icd 11 personality disorder model and perfectionism trait in two community sample n sample 1 293 n sample 2 308 all perfectionism trait except other oriented perfectionism substantially correlated with the six icd 11 personality descriptor and personality dysfunction additionally two perfectionism trait displayed small incremental utility for explaining personality dysfunction beyond the icd 11 personality descriptor this study show that perfectionism trait are related but not redundant to the icd 11 personality descriptor we discus implication for the measurement and potential gradual refinement of the icd 11 personality disorder model based on our finding and previous perfectionism research investigated relation of perfectionism and the icd 11 personality disorder model most perfectionism trait correlated with the six icd 11 personality descriptor most perfectionism trait correlated with personality dysfunction two perfectionism trait displayed small incremental utility beyond the icd 11 descriptor perfectionism research may inform measurement and refinement of the icd 11 model

Title: Other-oriented perfectionism in daily life situations: An experience sampling study
Authors: Stricker, Johannes; Kritzler, Sarah; Buecker, Susanne
Abstract: abstract how do person who expect perfection from others experience and behave in daily life situation to address this question we investigated the relation of other oriented perfectionism with the big five personality trait the big five personality state i e self reported short term behavior and perceived situation characteristic using experience sampling method esm on the first day of the study participant n 176 completed measure of other oriented perfectionism and the big five personality trait at random time point over the next 7 day participant completed real time situation report containing the big five personality state and the diamond situation characteristic other oriented perfectionism wa negatively related to state and trait agreeableness additionally other oriented perfectionism wa associated with the perception of daily life situation a low in duty positivity and sociality several relation of other oriented perfectionism with personality state were moderated by situation characteristic our study confirms disagreeable behavior a a core characteristic of other oriented perfectionism additionally other oriented perfectionist hold somewhat unfavorable view of their daily life situation the moderating effect of situation characteristic on the relation between other oriented perfectionism and personality state might explain why other oriented perfectionism display low and inconsistent relation with other trait level measure

Title: Global Self-Esteem Differentially Predicts Multidimensional Perfectionism in Early Adolescents Two Years Later
Authors: Stricker, Johannes; Preckel, Franzis
Abstract: perfectionism is a multidimensional personality trait whose facet differentially relate to indicator of psychological functioning such a global self esteem there ha been some theoretical disagreement whether perfectionism affect global self esteem or vice versa this question merit renewed attention due to increasing effort to prevent the development of maladaptive perfectionism facet in adolescent in addition recent research ha indicated a role of self esteem for predicting personality development this study aimed to clarify the longitudinal relation of multidimensional perfectionism and global self esteem a sample of 707 early adolescent participated in two measurement point two year apart global self esteem positively predicted personal standard negatively predicted doubt about action and did not predict concern over mistake beyond baseline perfectionism facet did not longitudinally predict global self esteem these finding provide the first evidence for a role of global self esteem in perfectionism development addressing early adolescent self esteem may aid in preventing the development of maladaptive perfectionism facet

Title: School satisfaction differentially predicts multidimensional perfectionism one year later
Authors: Stricker, Johannes; Schneider, Michael; Preckel, Franzis
Abstract: abstract perfectionism is a multidimensional personality disposition comprising different facet that relate differentially to various indicator of psychological and academic functioning the integrated model of the development of perfectionism posit that child parental and environmental variable influence perfectionism development so far environmental influence e g the school environment have gained only little attention in empirical research previous study showed that school satisfaction influence the development of achievement related individual difference thus raising the question how it affect multidimensional perfectionism the current study investigated school satisfaction a predictor of four facet of perfectionism 516 german high school student were assessed at two measurement point 1 year apart school satisfaction positively predicted personal standard β 0 13 95 ci 0 04 0 22 p 004 and organization β 0 11 95 ci 0 08 0 15 p

Title: The Mental Health of German Students During the COVID-19 Pandemic
Authors: Supke, Max; Schulz, Wolfgang
Abstract: abstract theoretical background the covid 19 pandemic ha changed the daily life of student completely study indicated that psychology student may be le stressed during the pandemic than other student this study compare psychology student and student from other discipline regarding their mental health alcohol consumption and partnership after the third wave of the covid 19 pandemic method the study sample consisted of n 127 psychology student and n 579 student from other discipline at the tu braunschweig in germany who participated in an online survey in june july of 2021 to analyze the difference between the psychology student and student from other discipline after the third wave we calculated t test chi² test and u test separately for female and male student result significantly fewer female psychology student were above the cut off value for clinically relevant depressive symptom 31 5 p lt 001 cramer s v 32 and anxiety symptom 22 2 p lt 001 cramer s v 27 than other female student depressive symptom 66 1 anxiety symptom 41 9 the small sample of male psychology student showed similar tendency while female psychology student rated their general health and life satisfaction higher than other female student male psychology student were le concerned about their professional future than their respective counterpart no difference were found concerning alcohol consumption and partnership conclusion we found indication that psychology student especially female student are le psychologically distressed after the third wave than student from other discipline better mental health knowledge could be an explanation for this
Journal: Zeitschrift für Klinische Psychologie und Psychotherapie

Title: Emotion Regulation and its Influence on Body-Related Distress in Overweight Women
Authors: Svaldi, Jennifer; Naumann, Eva; Trentowska, Monika; Lackner, Helmut K.; Tuschen-Caffier, Brunna
Abstract: overweight and obese individual are at greater risk for the development of a major depressive disorder a main factor contributing to negative affect in obese woman is body related worrying given the potential benefit of various emotion regulation er strategy in the modification of negative affect the aim of the present study wa to test whether experimentally induced body dissatisfaction can be modified by er strategy in obese woman body dissatisfaction wa experimentally induced in a group of 37 obese woman using model picture following this participant were randomly assigned to two different er strategy rumination on present emotion and thought or acceptance of whatever thought and feeling come up weight and appearance satisfaction distress about body feeling and mood were assessed both prior to immediately after and 4 min after the induction psychophysiological parameter were assessed continuously the main result reveal that after the use of er strategy weight and appearance satisfaction returned to baseline level however in the rumination condition distress about body feeling remained above and mood below baseline in the acceptance condition distress and mood returned to baseline level the result are discussed in term of the usefulness of er strategy with regard to reducing body related distress

Title: Posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms and suicidal ideation/behavior: The moderating effects of positive mental health and social support among Iranian and German students
Authors: Teismann, Tobias; Naghavi, Azam; Asgari, Zahra; Grundei, Lena; Brailovskaia, Julia
Abstract: abstract suicidal ideation and behavior are common in those suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder ptsd the present study investigated factor buffering the association between ptsd symptom and suicidal ideation behavior a total of 571 iranian student and 421 german student took part in the investigation social support and positive mental health pmh were considered a resilience factor moderating the association between ptsd symptom and suicide ideation behavior within both sample pmh moderated the impact of ptsd symptom on suicidal ideation behavior in iranian and german student social support moderated the impact of ptsd symptom on suicidal ideation behavior in iranian student only positive mental health and perceived social support seem to confer resilience and should be taken into account when assessing individual for suicide risk

Title: Tele.TAnDem Increases the Psychosocial Resource Utilization of                     Dementia Caregivers
Authors: Töpfer, Nils F.; Wilz, Gabriele
Abstract: abstract tele tandem is a telephone based cognitive behavioral therapy cbt intervention for dementia caregiver which incorporates resource activation a a superordinate heuristic we investigated whether tele tandem increased the utilization of psychosocial resource in dementia caregiver to this end 273 dementia caregiver were randomly assigned to receive the tele tandem intervention n 139 or usual care n 134 compared to the control group at posttest caregiver in the intervention group had utilized more resource related to well being and coping with daily hassle treatment effect on the utilization of resource related to social support were only marginally significantly greater at posttest for caregiver with higher baseline resource utilization treatment effect were not maintained at 6 month follow up result indicate that tele tandem can successfully activate the psychosocial resource of dementia caregiver

Title: Increases in utilization of psychosocial resources mediate effects of cognitive-behavioural intervention on dementia caregivers’ quality of life
Authors: Töpfer, Nils F.; Wilz, Gabriele
Abstract: in this study we advance dementia caregiver intervention research by drawing on the tenet of positive psychology we investigate the mediating mechanism of a cognitive behavioural intervention i

Title: Loving-Kindness Meditation Promotes Mental Health in University Students
Authors: Totzeck, Christina; Teismann, Tobias; Hofmann, Stefan G.; von Brachel, Ruth; Pflug, Verena; Wannemüller, Andre; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: abstract objective loving kindness meditation lkm ha been shown to improve wellbeing and positive emotion in clinical and non clinical population the main goal of the present study wa to examine whether lkm might be an effective intervention to promote positive mental health using the positive mental health scale pmh and to decrease depression anxiety and stress in university student method the sample n 110 consisted of university student in germany one half of them n 55 underwent lkm intervention they were compared with a matched control group n 55 which did not receive treatment all participant completed positive and negative mental health measure at baseline and 1 year follow up assessment lkm participant additionally completed the same measure before and after treatment multiple analysis of variance were conducted to test for short and long term effect of lkm on positive and negative mental health measure result a significant short term effect of lkm on anxiety and pmh wa found long term analysis revealed a significant decrease of depression anxiety and stress for lkm completers and a significant increase of depression anxiety and stress for the control group conclusion the result suggest that lkm enhances mental health in university student

Title: ACT in the workplace: A meta-analytic examination of randomized controlled trials
Authors: Unruh, Irina; Neubert, Marie; Wilhelm, Marcel; Euteneuer, Frank
Abstract: occupational stress is a crucial risk factor for the development of somatic and mental disorder and for the reduction of overall well being acceptance and commitment therapy act is an established treatment in clinical practice and it use a a non clinical workplace intervention proliferated in recent year this study provides an up to date meta analysis on how face to face act intervention affect occupational stress a well a psychological distress psychological flexibility and well being random effect meta analysis were conducted exploring act s efficacy concerning the four construct sub group analysis and meta regression were performed to investigate individual workplace related and treatment effect a total of 17 study including 860 participant allocated to act condition and 736 participant allocated to control condition were extracted act outperformed control condition passive and active control regarding psychological distress hedge g 0 38 95 ci 0 57 0 19 psychological flexibility g 0 33 95 ci 0 13 0 54 and well being g 0 24 95 ci 0 02 0 47 at post treatment and regarding stress g 0 22 95 ci 0 41 0 04 psychological flexibility g 0 31 95 ci 0 16 0 47 and well being g 0 26 95 ci 0 03 0 49 at follow up additional analysis revealed act to be most effective for office employee while showing little to no effect for health care worker finding demonstrate act to be an effective treatment to reduce psychological distress and stress and to increase psychological flexibility and general well being in a non clinical workplace setting an application for employee working in an office setting appears to be most promising

Title: The Power of the Present: Effects of Three Mindfulness Tasks on Women’s Sexual Response
Authors: Velten, Julia; Brotto, Lori A.; Chivers, Meredith L.; Hirschfeld, Gerrit; Margraf, Jürgen
Abstract: mindfulness based intervention are effective at improving sexual dysfunction in woman yet the mechanism of action are le clear our objective wa to investigate the impact of three mindfulness exercise on woman s sexual response forty nine woman participated in a laboratory session involving a series of 5 min exercise and erotic film they completed three mindfulness based exercise and a mental imagery task genital and subjective arousal were measured continuously during erotic film and genital arousal wa measured during the exercise a focus on the genitals led to greater genital arousal during the exercise a focus on sensation in the body and on the genitals wa associated with greater subjective sexual arousal during erotic film effect were small in size taken together the focus of attention during a mindfulness practice may differentially affect genital and subjective sexual arousal and ha implication for woman experiencing difficulty in different aspect of sexual response
