Title: Frozen with Fear? Attentional Mechanisms in Children with Selective Mutism
Authors: Vogel, Felix; Gensthaler, Angelika; Schwenck, Christina
Abstract: abstract background child with selective mutism sm are consistently unable to speak in certain social situation due to an overlap between sm and social anxiety disorder sad in child similar mechanism could apply to both disorder especially biased attentional processing of threat and fear induced reduced visual exploration referred to a attentive freezing appear promising in sm method a total of n 84 child 8 12 year sm n 28 sad n 28 typical development td n 28 participated in an eye tracking paradigm with video of a social counterpart expressing a question a social evaluation or a neutral statement we investigated gaze behavior towards the social counterpart s eye region and the extent of visual exploration length of scanpath across condition result there were no group difference regarding gaze behavior on the eye region neither gaze behavior with respect to the eye region nor visual exploration were dependent on the video condition compared to child with td child with sm generally showed le visual exploration however child with sad did not conclusion reduced visual exploration might be due to the mechanism of attentive freezing which could be part of an extensive fear response in sm that might also affect speech production intervention that counteract the state of freezing could be promising for the therapy of sm

Title: Contributions of impulsivity, obsessive-compulsive and body dysmorphic symptoms to different aspects of skin picking
Authors: Vöhringer, Julian; Martin, Alexandra; Schmidt, Jennifer
Abstract: risk of infection is elevated in patient with schizophrenia predicting their occurrence is essential a infection in this group of patient are associated with prolonged hospital admission and increased mortality the objective of the current investigation wa to identify the potential risk factor of major infection after diagnosis with schizophrenia this national prospective observational cohort study included 7788 people with schizophrenia born in denmark between 1975 and 1990 socio demographic psychiatric and health related data were obtained from danish national register the cox regression model wa used for data analysis crude and adjusted hazard ratio hr with 95 confidence interval 95 ci are presented the most significant risk factor associated with the development of major infection included young age female gender medical comorbidity and substance abuse a history of treatment with antipsychotic preceding the diagnosis wa negatively associated with such morbidity this study report several factor that might increase the risk of infection in individual with schizophrenia early intervention towards infection should be considered in the subpopulation of schizophrenia patient who are at increased risk of infection

Title: Associations between neonatal distress and effortful control in preterm born toddlers: does parenting stress act as a moderator?
Authors: Voigt, Babett; Brandl, Alexa; Pietz, Joachim; Pauen, Sabina; Kliegel, Matthias; Pöschl, Johannes; Reuner, Gitta
Abstract: abstractobjectives self regulation is a key factor in cognitive and behavioural development the present work explored the link between neonatal distress and effortful control skill of preterm born toddler a well a parenting stress a a moderator of this association method the sample comprised 119 preterm born child without major neurological complication periventricular leucomalacie grade 3 or 4 intraventricular hemorrhage seizure or sensory impairment assessment involved effortful control multitask behavioural battery parent report 24 month corrected age ca parenting stress parent report 12 24 month ca and the number of potentially distressful neonatal intensive care procedure a well a severity of illness during the neonatal period retrospective chart review result exposure to a higher number of distressful procedure wa related to lower effortful control behavioural measure only at the ca of 24 month when adjusting for gestational age severity of illness and soc

Title: Topics and techniques in clinical supervision in psychotherapy training
Authors: Weck, Florian; Kaufmann, Yvonne M.; Witthöft, Michael
Abstract: abstract clinical supervision is regarded a one of the most important component of psychotherapy training in clinical practice it ha been found that the implementation of clinical supervision varies substantially and often differs from the recommendation made in the literature the objective of the current study wa to investigate the frequency of topic e g ethical issue and technique e g role play in the clinical supervision of psychotherapy trainee in germany to this end we considered supervision in cognitive behavioural therapy cbt and psychodynamic therapy pt a total of 791 psychotherapy trainee 533 cbt and 242 pt were asked via the internet to provide information about their current supervision session we found that clinical supervision in psychotherapy training addressed topic that are central for the effective treatment of supervised patient i e therapeutic intervention therapeutic alliance maintaining factor and therapeutic goal however the most frequently used intervention in clinical supervision in psychotherapy training wa case discussion rarely were technique used that allowed the supervisor to give the supervisee feedback based on the supervisee s demonstrated competency for example 46 of the supervisor never used audiotape or videotape in the supervision difference between cbt and pt were rather small current practice regarding the technique used in clinical supervision for psychotherapy trainee contradicts recommendation for active and feedback oriented clinical supervision thus the potential of clinical supervision might not be fully used in clinical practice

Title: Context Effects in the Evaluation of Bodily Symptoms: Comparing Three Versions of the Health Norms Sorting Task
Authors: Weck, Florian; Witthöft, Michael
Abstract: the illness related evaluation of bodily symptom is considered to be an important maintaining factor in somatoform disorder however little is known about context variable that could influence this evaluation process in the current study participant completed three version of the health norm sorting task hnst and evaluated bodily symptom in different context i e different evaluation perspective and time frame of evaluation additionally the three hnst version were presented in different order bodily symptom were evaluated more often a a sign of illness when a specific time frame i e one week wa given however this context effect wa only large when participant had previously evaluated symptom existing without a concrete duration thus previously completed symptom evaluation appear to represent an important frame of reference in term of a cue that make specific context variable salient the result further suggested that these cueing effect might be le relevant for participant with elevated somatic symptom report

Title: Feasibility and effects of individualized recorded music for people with dementia: A pilot RCT study
Authors: Weise, Lisette; Töpfer, Nils F.; Deux, Juliane; Wilz, Gabriele
Abstract: abstractintroduction music intervention are thought to improve the behavioral and psychological symptom of dementia bpsd however result regarding the effectiveness of such intervention hav

Title: Reappraising fear: is up-regulation more efficient than down-regulation?
Authors: Wiemer, Julian; Rauner, Milena M.; Stegmann, Yannik; Pauli, Paul
Abstract: abstract catastrophizing thought may contribute to the development of anxiety but functional emotion regulation may help to improve treatment no study so far directly compared up and down regulation of fear by cognitive reappraisal here healthy individual took part in a cued fear experiment in which multiple picture of face were paired twice with an unpleasant scream or presented a safety stimulus participant n 47 were asked within subject to down regulate to up regulate and to maintain their natural emotional response valence and arousal rating indicated successful up and down regulation of the emotional experience while heart rate and pupil dilation increased during up regulation but showed no reduction in down regulation state and trait anxiety correlated with evaluation of safety but not threat stimulus which support the role of deficient safety learning in anxiety reappraisal did not modulate this effect in conclusion this study reveals evidence for up regulation effect in fear which might be even more efficient than down regulation on a physiological level and highlight the importance of catastrophizing thought for the maintenance of fear and anxiety

Title: Mental Defeat and Cumulative Trauma Experiences Predict Trauma-Related Psychopathology: Evidence From a Postconflict Population in Northern Uganda
Authors: Wilker, Sarah; Kleim, Birgit; Geiling, Angelika; Pfeiffer, Anett; Elbert, Thomas; Kolassa, Iris-Tatjana
Abstract: the peritraumatic cognitive process of mental defeat the complete loss of inner resistance ha been identified a a key predictor of ptsd yet most evidence on cognitive risk factor stem from industrialized country where survivor typically report few trauma research from postconflict setting indicates that individual difference decrease with accumulating traumatic experience a almost everybody develops ptsd at extreme level of trauma load would this leave le room for the impact of cognitive process in a sample of 227 ugandan rebel war survivor we investigated whether mental defeat influence trauma related psychopathology in regression model accounting for cumulative trauma exposure we found strong main effect of mental defeat on lifetime ptsd risk current ptsd severity and dissociative symptom but no mental defeat trauma load interaction effect our result indicate that peritraumatic mental defeat is central to understand individual difference in psychological reaction after single traumatic event a well a multiple traumatization

Title: CBT-BASED TELEPHONE INTERVENTION FOR FAMILY CAREGIVERS OF PEOPLE WITH DEMENTIA
Authors: Wilz, G.
Abstract: to prevent caregiver from the development of stress related health impairment effective intervention are still needed this presentation focused on the evaluation of a telephone intervention for family caregiver of people with dementia in germany the individual intervention 12 session in 6 month each 50 minute u cognitive behavioural therapy adapted to specific problem of the caregiver the intervention aim to improve well being quality of life and to reduce body complaint and depressive symptom a randomized controlled trial n 322 primary family caregiver wa conducted and the intervention wa implemented by cognitive behavioural therapist compared with caregiver in the control condition caregiver who received tele tandem demonstrated significantly greater improvement in well being depressive symptom ce d body complaint gbb 24 and quality of life who qol bref at post treatment measurement regarding the achievement of caregiver individual goal result showed that 77 achieved complete goal attainment finding support the acceptability and effectiveness of the tele tandem intervention

Title: Problematic smartphone use has detrimental effects on mental health and somatic symptoms in a heterogeneous sample of German adults
Authors: Winkler, Alexander; Jeromin, Franziska; Doering, Bettina K.; Barke, Antonia
Abstract: abstract although research examining the association between problematic smartphone use and mental health ha grown recently there is a lack of study investigating possible association with physical somatic symptom moreover many study are based on student sample from north america and china limiting their generalizability the current study aimed to examine problematic smartphone use in a broad sample of german adult an online survey comprising demographic question problematic smartphone use scale and somatic symptom inventory a well a depression anxiety stress and sleep quality scale wa completed by 930 participant problematic smartphone user reported longer usage per day more interruption to activity to check their smartphones and higher score for stress depression anxiety sleep disturbance and somatic symptom than did unproblematic user in comparison both group allocated similar proportion of time to various application the result showed small to moderate bivariate association between problematic smartphone use and indicator of mental health and somatic symptom while a multivariate analysis highlighted the importance of perceived stress since mental health and somatic symptom are associated with problematic smartphone use future study should investigate the causal direction of the association found

Title: Somatic Symptom Perception and Interoception
Authors: Witthöft, Michael; Bräscher, Anne-Kathrin; Jungmann, Stefanie M.; Köteles, Ferenc
Abstract: abstract model of chronic somatic symptom assume that abnormality in interoception are related to the development and maintenance of symptom distress different model however disagree on the exact nature of the assumed abnormality cognitive behavioral model stress a hypervigilant cognitive style predicting higher interoceptive accuracy whereas predictive processing model assume a le detailed sensory processing predicting lower interoceptive accuracy this study aimed at testing the relationship between interoception and symptom perception using structural equation modeling association between cardiac interoception and symptom perception were tested in a sample of student n 316 and a second heterogeneous sample n 340 including 63 patient with either pathological health anxiety or a somatoform disorder according to dsm iv stronger sensory symptom perception in the cardiorespiratory system were associated with lower interoceptive accuracy in sample 2 the finding are more in line with the predictive processing approach suggesting le detailed and more biased interoception being associated with chronic somatic symptom distress

Title: Cognitive Biases in Pathological Health Anxiety
Authors: Witthöft, Michael; Kerstner, Tobias; Ofer, Julia; Mier, Daniela; Rist, Fred; Diener, Carsten; Bailer, Josef
Abstract: pathological health anxiety refers to the medically unfounded fear of suffering from a severe illness difference in cognitive process related to attention memory and evaluation of health threat have been hypothesized to underlie pathological health anxiety in no study however have researcher systematically and simultaneously assessed different cognitive bias on the basis of the idea that multiple cognitive bias simultaneously contribute to psychopathology the combined cognitive bias hypothesis we compared 88 patient with pathological health anxiety 52 patient with depressive disorder and 52 healthy participant on their performance in several cognitive task involving health threatening content individual with pathological health anxiety showed a stronger attentional bias to health threat related information more negative explicit but not implicit evaluation of health threat and biased response behavior in light of health threat the result suggest that stronger binding between feeling of arousal and health threatening information in working memory might be crucial for the higher salience of health threatening content in pathological health anxiety

Title: An Analysis of the Pattern of Adaptive Emotion Regulation Associated with Low Paranoid Ideation in Healthy and Clinical Samples
Authors: Wittkamp, Martin F.; Krkovic, Katarina; Lincoln, Tania M.
Abstract: abstract background research on emotion regulation and paranoid ideation ha mostly focused on isolated regulation strategy and ha remained largely inconclusive according to the emotion regulation model by berking and whitley in affect regulation training springer new york 2014 successful modification or acceptance tolerance of emotion requires an adequate comprehension awareness clarity understanding of emotion and adequate self support method building on this model we investigated whether comprehension and self support strengthen the negative association between modification and acceptance tolerance and paranoid ideation in study 1 we examined the hypothesis cross sectionally based on questionnaire data from a combined sample n 125 consisting of people with a psychotic disorder people at risk of developing psychosis and healthy control in study 2 we examined the same hypothesis longitudinally by employing the experience sampling method in people with clinically relevant psychopathology below diagnostic threshold n 138 result in study 1 the association between modification and paranoid ideation wa not moderated by comprehension or self support however comprehension and self support moderated the association between acceptance tolerance and paranoid ideation in study 2 the interaction effect between comprehension and acceptance tolerance on paranoid ideation wa confirmed conclusion the result indicate that comprehending and accepting tolerating emotion could be protective against paranoid ideation

Title: Make the manikin move: Symbolic approach–avoidance responses affect implicit and explicit face evaluations
Authors: Woud, Marcella L.; Maas, Joyce; Becker, Eni S.; Rinck, Mike
Abstract: the present research aimed to replicate and extend finding of huijding muris lester field and joosse 2011 investigating whether symbolic approach avoidance response can induce implicit and explicit evaluation bias face with a neutral expression were shown on a computer screen and participant were instructed to repeatedly move a manikin towards some face approach and away from other face avoidance an affective priming task and a face rating task were used to a training compatible difference in implicit and explicit face evaluation respectively result showed that the manikin training wa successful the priming task revealed more positive implicit evaluation of approached than avoided face and approached face were rated more positively than avoided one in the face rating task these finding replicate those of huijding and colleague by demonstrating training effect on explicit evaluation and they extend them by demonstrating effect on implicit evaluation

Title: Alcohol Homograph Priming in Alcohol-Dependent Inpatients
Authors: Woud, Marcella L.; Salemink, Elske; Gladwin, Thomas E.; Wiers, Reinout W.; Becker, Eni S.; Lindenmeyer, Johannes; Rinck, Mike
Abstract: abstract aim alcohol dependency is characterized by alcohol related interpretation bias ibs individual with high level of alcohol consumption generate more alcohol related than alcohol unrelated interpretation in response to ambiguous alcohol related cue however a response bias could be an alternative account meaning that individual with high level of alcohol consumption generate more alcohol related ibs because of a greater baseline tendency to endorse alcohol related response method to test this alternative explanation the present study employed a homograph priming task reliability of which wa also examined the sample included 577 clinically diagnosed alcohol dependent inpatient and 61 control inpatient participant completed a homograph priming task prime homograph with and without an alcohol related meaning target word alcohol and soft drink before commencing their behavioral cognitive treatment at a rehabilitation clinic result contrary to our expectation we did not find an enhanced priming effect in alcohol dependent inpatient moreover there wa no correlation between the priming score and level of harmful drinking audit score conclusion the data provide limited support for the existence of alcohol related ibs possibly because of the low reliability of the priming task the feature of the task and the study s design

Title: Only on Invitation? How the Recruitment Strategy Determines Who Is Treated Online
Authors: Zagorscak, Pavle; Bohn, Johannes; Heinrich, Manuel; Kampisiou, Christina; Knaevelsrud, Christine
Abstract: lt b gt lt i gt background lt i gt lt b gt participant for efficacy study on internet based intervention ibi are recruited through self selected convenience sampling or targeted external invitation comparison are necessary to determine how recruitment strategy influence sample composition such comparison consequently yield potential for evaluating which condition are more probable to fulfill ibi s promise to be an effective treatment option for underserved population lt b gt lt i gt method lt i gt lt b gt a comparison of sociodemographic and clinical characteristic of differently recruited participant in an ibi for mild to moderate depression wa made 1 individual on sick leave due to an affective disorder who were informed about the ibi by their health insurance lt i gt n lt i gt 308 and 2 individual who self selected to participate e g after seeing information on the ibi in print medium lt i gt n lt i gt 699 lt b gt lt i gt result lt i gt lt b gt compared to the self selected group the externally selected group wa older le educated spent le time on the internet had a le positive attitude towards ibi and comprised more men group did not differ in initial symptom severity in treatment symptom change or previous psychotherapeutic experience lt b gt lt i gt conclusion lt i gt lt b gt the result indicate that larger share of underserved subpopulation e g le educated older male le internet savvy begin an ibi treatment when the insurer informs them about the ibi recruitment source doe not influence efficacy

Title: Thought Conditioning: Inducing and Reducing Thoughts About the Aversive Outcome in a Fear-Conditioning Procedure
Authors: Zenses, Ann-Kathrin; Baeyens, Frank; Beckers, Tom; Boddez, Yannick
Abstract: the human fear conditioning paradigm is a widely used procedure to study anxiety however merely thinking about the aversive outcome is typically not measured in this procedure this is surprising because thinking of an aversive event is of clinical relevance e g in the form of intrusion and theoretical interest we present two preregistered study that a included thinking of an aversive outcome a an additional dependent variable and b compared several intervention to reduce it we found that mere thinking of an aversive outcome could be successfully conditioned among the participant who showed successful acquisition extinction training wa le successful in reducing it than counterconditioning presenting new additional outcome also proved effective to reduce thought about the initial outcome when the new outcome were positive stimulus including thinking of the aversive outcome a an additional dependent variable may serve to enhance the understanding of anxiety related disorder and inform their treatment

Title: The perceived stress scale: Reliability and validity study in the Czech Republic
Authors: Figalová, Nikol; ; Charvát, Miroslav
Abstract: objective the aim of this study wa to create a czech translation of the perceived stress scale p to a it psychometric property on a representative sample of the czech general adult population and to compare the original 14 item version p 14 with the shortened 10 item p 10 and four item p 4 version sample and setting two pilot study were conducted to create the final czech translation of the scale n 365 and n 420 the final version of the czech p wa administered to a sample of the czech general adult population n 1725 of whom 981 were woman m 44 32 sd 12 8 the beck depression inventory bdi ii or the state trait anxiety inventory stai were administered alongside the p to a part of the sample a retest measurement after 14 day wa conducted n 159 statistical analysis using the confirmatory factor analysis the one factor two factor and bifactor model were compared the internal consistency stability in time and convergent validity of the scale a well a the known group difference were assessed the three version of the p were compared result the confirmatory factor analysis supported the bifactor model of the p 14 and p 10 and the two factor model of the p 4 all version of the scale showed good internal consistency and stability in time there wa a moderate to strong positive correlation between the p and the bdi ii and stai difference based on age sex education level and situational factor were found overall the p 10 showed the best psychometric property of all three version of the scale study limitation the sample consisted mostly of highly educated respondent
